column2: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Revision of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act at the next session of Congress is ruled out under terms of an understanding, reached late in the last session, that made it possible to pass the Administration bill providing a haven for 214,000 refugees in this country.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Three-fourths of the public believes that President Eisenhower is doing a good job, Sherman Adams, the assistant to the President, said today at a luncheon session that closed the forty-fourth annual convention of the Association of National Advertisers.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Sept. 23 -- Almost every concept of modern home planning has been incorporated into a prefabricated house shown here for the first time by the manufacturer, the National Homes Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Speaker of the Punjab Legislative Assembly in Pakistan reported here today that the United States gift of wheat last summer "very definitely" helped his country through its food crisis.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Budget cuts have forced the elimination of the shipping and inland transport policy staffs of the State Department, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- "You can't force free markets and the Treasury has no intention of doing so" in the distribution of its securities, bankers were assured today by W. Randolph Burgess, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury.

The Board of Education's prediction of an increase in enrollment for the new school year, which began last week, was borne out yesterday by registration figures. Enrollment for the first week of school, Sept. 14 to 18, showed a gain of 4,286 pupils over the number in the comparable period last year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Price guarantees for uranium ores of the Colorado plateau were extended today for an extra four years to March 31, 1962.

Although aides declared that the response to requests for signatures to a petition nominating Mayor Impellitteri as an independent candidate were so favorable as to approach "draft" proportions, the Mayor reiterated yesterday that he still was undecided on a race.

Stockholders of the Clorox Chemical Company at the annual meeting in Oakland, Calif., yesterday, approved the directors' proposal to increase authorized capital stock to 750,000 shares of $3.33 1/3 par value from 360,000 shares of the same par value.
Activity on the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange increased yesterday and price changes were somewhat irregular, closing 7 points off to 8 points up.

A familiar figure will be missing from the Long Island University scene next school year. Prof. Gregory Dexter Walcott, who has lectured before every undergraduate enrolled at the university since 1928, announced yesterday his intention to retire in June, when he will have completed a half-century of teaching.

The case for the development of the St. Lawrence River and Niagara hydroelectric potential by the New York State Power Authority has just been put with great persuasiveness by John E. Burton, who is chairman of the authority. In a speech at Massena, N. Y., a town which is close to the International Rapids Section of the St. Lawrence, Mr. Burton marshaled an array of arguments which, in our opinion, is conclusive.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 23 -- Yachts of the New World swept the first four places to become one up on their Old World rivals in the six-meter series being conducted by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today. The Western Hemisphere team now has two triumphs, Europe one.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Charles Ill of Arlington, Va., a Barnegat Bay E-Scow sailor out of Mantoloking, N. J., today took the lead in the eight-race North American sailing championship series for the Clifford D. Mallory Trophy.
GENEVA, Sept. 23 -- Japan asked formally today to be admitted provisionally to the group of countries whose commercial policies are linked through the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

Of the seven games scheduled for the fourteenth round of the world championship challengers' tournament in Zurich last night, the five that were finished were all drawn -- three in less than twenty moves -- according to a Swiss news report.
BONN, Germany, Sept. 23 -- Although Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West Germany's Chancellor, is on vacation, the political maneuvering to give him a two-thirds majority in Parliament still continues.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- "I'll tell you a little story," said the President of the United States this morning in an auditorium full of people intent on the problem of employment for the physically handicapped.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- The West gave another careful assurance to the Soviet Union today that it had no plans for undermining the security of the Communist part of the world.

Rocky Marciano and Roland LaStarza will fight for the heavyweight championship of the world tonight at the Polo Grounds. A crowd of 30,000 is expected to watch Marciano make the second defense of the championship that he won a year ago last night. The clash is scheduled for fifteen rounds and will start at 10:30 o'clock.

A quarterly dividend of 10 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Oct. 15, has been authorized by directors of Argus Cameras, Inc. The company previously paid 12 1/2 cents a share semi-annually.
It's now official. If you feel sleepy on the subway and doze off, the law is on your side.

Watching the Yankees polish off the Athletics for the last time this year at the Stadium yesterday by a score of 3 to 1, Casey Stengel felt he had good reason to regard his world series prospects with increasing optimism.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today ordered a comprehensive review of civil aviation in the United States. He asked Robert B. Murray, chairman of the Air Coordinating Committee, to make such a review so the public and the aviation industry could get "a clear and comprehensive statement of the aviation policies of this Administration."
Martin L. Scher has been appointed general manager of CBS-Distributors, Inc., factory distributing branch for CBS-Columbia, Inc., a subsidiary of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

The exchange of war prisoners in Korea, known as Operation Big Switch, was officially completed yesterday when the United Nations Command turned over to Indian custody the last of 22,600 Chinese and Koreans who repudiate communism and the Communists delivered to like custody more than 300 Allied soldiers, including twenty-three Americans, represented as unwilling to go home.
The collection of Egyptian antiquities at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, reputed to be one of the finest in the world, has been reinstalled and will be open to the public today.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 23 -- The recent demands of Christian Democratic trade unionists on the West German Trade Union Federation called on the federation to re-examine and revise "its over-all attitude toward state, society and economy."

ALBANY, Sept. 23 -- Governor Dewey ordered the State Insurance Department today to investigate the health and welfare funds of Local 33-E of the Building Service Employes International Union, A. F. L., which has become the storm center of an inquiry into labor racketeering at the Yonkers Raceway.

THE old query of "When is a duck not a duck?", and the response, "When it's a scoter," will bring only a knowing smile from those who will participate in the opening of the scoter, old squaw and eider season in New York and Connecticut one week from today.

Irene's fashion signature is a highly individual one. Hers are designs that have a well-groomed look, one that gives them the air of a sleek race horse. Her long-jacketed suits and slim skirts are carved in an outline that makes them seem particularly adapted to the tall, slim figures of American women.
WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Super Chief, owned by the Three H Farm of Las Vegas, Nev., scored a length and a half victory as the favorite in the Arizona Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 -- Dr. Barrows Dunham, author and suspended head of the Philosophy Department at Temple University, was dismissed today for defying the House Un-American Activites Committee.

Apparently referring to Governor Dewey's suspension of the license of the Yonkers Raceway, Rudolph Halley declared last night that his demand for a thorough investigation of the state's trotting track's had produced an explosion but that the explosion so far had created only a smokescreen and had not struck bedrock.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Jess W. Sweetser said today that the Glenn L. Martin Company, of which he is vice president, had had to do an almost complete engineering job when it began to put out its own version of the British Canberra jet planes, Mr. Sweetser urged common standards in airain and the United States.

The honesty of Joseph J. Burns, a 26-year-old taxicab driver, drew a $30 reward from two Venezuelan children to whom he returned the $280 they had lost in his cab. His deed also was worth a $100 award that the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau gave him yesterday at the Statler Hotel.
Two railroads announced yesterday that improved passenger service would become effective on Sunday morning, when standard time replaces daylight time.

Sales of the Colorado Fuel and Iron Corporation and its subsidiaries reached a new high record in the fiscal year ended on last June 30, and earnings rose 39 per cent over the preceding year, Charles Allen Jr., chairman, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.
Carrie Munn has her own way with fashion. Her designs are coquettish and saucy and never influenced by any trend but her own belief in youthful gayety and pretty frivolity.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 23 -- A significant turn against the Congress party Government and in favor of the Communists occurred in the important southwestern coastal state of Travancore-Cochin today, when the sixteen-month-old regime was defeated in a vote of confidence in the state Legislative Assembly.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 23 -- Germany has supplanted the United States as chief supplier of Argentina's import needs, according to Government statistics issued today covering the nation's foreign trade for the first four months of this year.

TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 24 -- Allied prisoners of the Korean war, including twenty-three Americans who had apparently been converted to communism or were reluctant for other reasons to return home, were delivered by the Communist captors into neutral nations' custody today.

NEWARK, Sept. 23 -- To circumvent political pressure and influence in selecting a man for the $10,000 job as construction engineer for the new $13,000,000 city hospital here the Citizens Hospital Advisory Committee has chosen an engineer from among applicants answering its newspaper advertisements.

ROME, Thursday, Sept. 24 -- For the first time since non-Communist workers broke away in 1948 from the Communist-dominated Italian General Confederation of Labor, all the country's labor unions except a tiny one affiliated with the neo-Fascist movement have joined together to organize a general strike of industrial workers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Four years and nine months ago the United States offered the world "a bold new program" to bring a better life to the people of underdeveloped areas by providing the technical know-how they lacked. Today, under the Eisenhower Administration, that program is being radically changed in concept and in scope.

A few months ago I visited my physician for a general check-up, and after a thorough examination I was pronounced to be in very good health. I was casually told to get a chest X-ray when in the neighborhood of the local Board of Health for safety's sake.

The Senate Internal Security subcommittee heard "new and important" evidence of subversive activities yesterday among discharged American employes of the United Nations, Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, reported.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 23 (UP) -- Troops from Dutch-held Western New Guinea have invaded the Indonesian islands of Morotai and Halmahera and burned homes and fired on the inhabitants, the Indonesian press agency Antara said today.

We assume that the Dewey administration will return to the fight for compulsory liability insurance for automobiles at the legislative session starting in January. This seems to be indicated by the strong, courageous speech made to insurance men here by Alfred J. Bohlinger, State Superintendent of Insurance.

The Democratic Judicial Convention for the First Judicial District, comprised of Manhattan and the Bronx, last night nominated City Court Justice Owen McGivern and Jacob Markowitz, chairman of the law committee of the New York County Democratic organization, for the Supreme Court.

BERLIN, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Mayor Ernst Reuter of West Berlin was turned back by Soviet zone border guards today at Lauenberg on his way to a meeting in Hamburg. The guards contended his travel papers were not in order.

ALBANY, Sept. 23 -- Representative Dean P. Taylor of Troy was elected unanimously today by the Republican State Committee to succeed William L. Pfeiffer of Loudonville as Republican State Chairman. He announced that he would devote most of his efforts before Election Day to advancing Republican chances of winning this year's municipal election in New York City.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Consumers' Price Index rose 0.3 per cent to new high ground today, with the New York transit fare increase, together with rises in rents and the price of food, contributing significantly to the advance. This was the sixth rise in a row reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

OTTAWA, Sept. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Sean Lemass, Ireland's deputy Prime Minister and trade chief, predicted today that the world will see neither dollar-sterling convertibility nor a drastic fall in wheat prices "in the immediate future."

PARIS, Sept. 23 -- A political development favorable to the European Defense Community Treaty, long shelved in France, was a statement made last night at the meeting of the Council of Europe in Strasbourg by Guy Mollet, Secretary General of the French Socialist party.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UP) -- The National Temperance and Prohibition Council voted today to ask President Eisenhower to reconsider a Defense Department order permitting liquor sales on Army and Air Force posts.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Following is the text of a message that the United State Government has asked Sweden to transmit to the Chinese Communists and North Koreans:

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Thursday, Sept. 24 -- When the twenty-three American prisoners of war, turned over to the Indian troops here as G. I.'s refusing repatriation, appeared in two Russian-built trucks at 12:28 P. M. today, they were singing an English version of the Communist "Internationale."

In dismissing the Government's anti-trust suit against seventeen investment banking firms Judge Harold R. Medina has terminated (barring the remote possibility of successful appeal) an action that belongs, for a number of reasons, among the most spectacular in the history of American jurisprudence.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Texts of Vice President Nixon's address at A. F. L. convention and of President Eisenhower's message follow:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- A book on Soviet psychiatry having wide circulation and use among universities, hospitals and practitioners was condemned as largely Communist propaganda in an analysis of the work released by the Senate Internal Security subcommittee today.

Word from Paris that Christian Dior has decided to show less skirt and more leg has garnered many a headline in recent weeks. Whether this will prove to be as revolutionary a change as his 1947 edict for the New Look remains to be seen.

LET'S look at it this way. Fifteen rounds add up to forty-five minutes and several hundred punches. It would seem almost an impossibility for a hitter of Rocky Marciano's explosiveness to strike out that often, and not hit one home run. Strong is the conviction of this ringsider that the Brockton Blockbuster must connect with the chin of Roland LaStarza sooner or later.

" Take a Giant Step," a first play by Louis Peterson, opens this evening at the Lyceum Theatre at 8 o'clock. Produced by Miss Lyn Austin and Thomas Noyes, "Take a Giant Step" features in the cast Frederick O'Neal, Louis Gossett and Jane White.

Commissioner Dominick F. Paduano of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity sent a letter yesterday to Louis Spinelli, an uncooperative witness in an investigation of a stuffed ballot box in the Democratic primary in Brooklyn on Sept. 15, ending his appointment as a corporation inspector.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 23 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru has invited Communist China to a conference on Tibet, he disclosed today in the upper house of Parliament. He said the Government of Mao Tse-tung had been asked to send representatives to a meeting in either New Delhi or Peiping.

HAVANA, Sept. 23 -- The police entered Havana University early this morning, detained twelve students and seized a quantity of arms and ammunition. Among the detained were Joaquin Pelaez, president of the University Student Federation, and Alvaro Barba Machado, former president of the federation.

Plans to consolidate the Timken-Detroit Axle Company and the Standard Steel Spring Company to form the Rockwell Spring and Axle Company, with twenty-four plants in nineteen cities, were announced yesterday by Walter F. Rockwell, president of Timken-Detroit Axle.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- A North Atlantic Treaty Organization fleet of 150 defensive vessels is being deployed to guard the Channel shipping approaches to Britain and the Continent during the crucial European phase of Exercise Mariner, Admiral Sir John Edelsten, commander of the Channel area, said today.

SEATTLE, Sept. 23 -- A bright picture of the future for the American mining industry was painted by three speakers at the final session of the annual convention of the American Mining Congress here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Emmet J. Hughes, who was in charge of writing President Eisenhower's speeches and reports, resigned today. He will be succeeded by Bryce N. Harlow of Oklahoma City.

Mayor Impellittert and high-ranking police officials began making plans yesterday to cope with a possible waterfront strike next Thursday and any violence along the docks that might erupt as a result of the expulsion by the American Federation of Labor on Tuesday of the crime-ridden International Longshoremen's Association.

Despite the fact that a considerable amount of new office space will become available for occupancy within the next twelve months in the midtown and Grand Central distinct, Ivor B. Clark, mortgage and realty expert, is confident that the market will absorb these additional commercial facilities without difficulty.

The Pennsylvania Railroad proposed yesterday to undertake a $30,000,000, six-year rehabilitation program of the Long Island Rail Road if the Interstate Commerce Commission would approve the Pennsylvania's previous plan to reorganize the Long Island, its bankrupt subsidiary.

William Zeckendorf, president of Webb Knapp, Inc., real estate development company, denied last night a report he had bought the Fifth Avenue department store of James McCreery Co. and resold it to George Farkas, president of Alexander's Department Stores of the Bronx.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept 23 (UP) -- University of Oklahoma Regents voted today to abide by a National Collegiate Athletic Association ruling that limits the television broadcast of the Oklahoma-Notre Dame football game to a single station.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 23 (UP) -- The Redlegs assured themselves of finishing no worse than sixth today when they pushed across a run in the ninth inning to defeat the Cubs, 4 -- 3.

Ira Wolfert, who received the Pulitzer Prize in 1943 for his news dispatches from Guadalcanal, has a new novel on Simon Schuster's list for publication Monday. "Married Men," described as a report on "the terrible war between men and money," is a story about a man of tremendous vitality and virility.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LONG BEACH, L. I., Sept. 23 -- The State Congress of Industrial Organizations, worried about state and national affairs, is planning to spend $100,000 in the next ten months to "educate" the general public.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 23 -- Throughout the years, since Sept. 16, 1918, there has been summer chamber music at South Mountain. Mrs. Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge founded the series, which is presented on an estate just outside of Pittsfield.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture predicted today that this year's 22,000,000-bushel potato surplus will push grower prices "far below" last year's levels. "Depressed prices for potatoes are likely to continue in 1954," it added.

A test of the legality and the operations of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations was initiated yesterday as the Wisconsin Republican announced he would ask the Senate to vote a contempt citation against Corliss Lamont.

Benjamin F. Fairless, board chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said some things that greatly needed saying in his talk before the Economic Club of Detroit, and said them in his customary vigorous and forthright manner.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 23 -- Jawaharlal Nehru, India's Prime Minister, assailed today the lack of permanent representation for Asia in the United Nations Security Council, except through the Chinese Nationalist Government on Formosa, which, he asserted, "does not represent any other part of Asia except the island of Formosa, and how much of that it represents I don't know."

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- After a study lasting more than four years, the Royal Commission on Capital Punishment recommended today that juries in murder trials be permitted to determine whether persons they have convicted should be sentenced to death or to lesser punishment such as life imprisonment.

The new Gourmet Corner in Wanamaker's fifth-floor house-wares department is designed to attract the cook who likes to work with tools that are handsome as well as functional. The shop also offers a complete line of herbs, spices, salad oils and vinegars.

An international diamond merchant arrived from San Francisco last night to try to identify $20,000 worth of uncut small diamonds allegedly stolen from him last Sunday and intercepted by postal inspectors here after turning up Tuesday in the mail of a Bronx housewife.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 23 -- United States athletes continued to dominate the track and field events at the Maccabiah Games today, but the score showed Israel ahead of the Americans by 254 points to 182.

Charles T. Douds, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, has dismissed the third set of charges of unfair labor practices brought against the Hearn Department Stores by representatives of 800 striking employes, the regional board announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 -- The ten-story Drexel Building, opposite Independence Square at Fifth and Chestnut Streets, has been sold to the Federal Government for $1,600,000. It was announced today that the sixty-four-year-old structure would be demolished to make way for the Independence Hall National Historical Park, a Federal project.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Peru will ask the United Nations General Assembly to set up a three-man committee to try to reach a negotiated settlement on the deadlock that has stalled the membership applications of twenty-one countries.
Richard Weininger, vice president of National Phoenix Industries, Inc., has been elected a director of the Consolidated Royalty Oil Company of Casper, Wyo.

The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York announced yesterday the opening of its thirty-sixth annual fund campaign. The organization will seek to raise $16,950,000, an increase of $2,450,000 over the amount contributed last year, to finance its 116 member hospitals and social welfare agencies, which now serve 575,000 men, women and children of all creeds and races annually.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- President Eisenhower, lending a hand to the United States Committee for United Nations Day today, called the United Nations a "sheer necessity" and said that despite its shortcomings "it still represents man's best organized hope to substitute the conference table for the battlefield."

THE two novels for today are adroit sketches of dynastic American family upheavals. One is Louis Auchincloss' "A Law for the Lion,"* the story of a legalistic New York clan shaken with divorce uproars stirred by a woman-who-dared type of heroine. The other is Wright Morris' "The Deep Sleep," a spirited inquest into the private lives of several rather bemused ladies and gentlemen who survived a defunct Philadelphia celebrity, also drawn from the legal world.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- The soybean market was active again yesterday, advancing for the sixth successive day and to the highest prices since late June. Commission and export houses were buyers. It was reported that Germany bought 240,000 bushels for shipment in November.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- One illustration of the crushing weight of responsibility on the President in this age of atomic armament is provided by the conflict among officials over the proposal that we should share with our North Atlantic Treaty Allies the production of new weapons.

ROME, Sept. 23 -- L'Osservatore Romano, the Vatican newspaper, branded as "an act of terrorism" the sentence of twelve years imprisonment imposed by the Polish court on Msgr. Czeslaw Kaczmarek, Bishop of Kielce. The Bishop was tried on charges of espionage and treason.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 23 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of the Cherry Valley Club scored 35, 40-75 to take a 2-stroke lead with 77, 75 -- 152 in the Women's Long Island Golf Association 54-hole medal play championship at the Meadow Brook Club today.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, Sept. 23 -- Two Westchester County professionals, Herman Barron of Fenway and Pete Cooper of Century, shared the lead at 139 at the end of thirty-six holes today in the Metropolitan Golf Association's open championship at the Rockville Country Club.
Burglars. took $30,000 worth of jewelry from the apartment of Mr. and Mrs. George Armour at 955 Fifth Avenue, near Seventy-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon, the police reported last night.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (UP) -- The Indians clinched second place in the American League race today, beating the White Sox by 8 -- 3 as Bob Lemon pitched his twenty-first victory of the season before 3,657 fans.

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- An unannounced bus slowdown on the lines of Rockland Coaches, Inc., and its four subsidiaries caused inconvenience today to bus travelers in Rockland County, N. Y., and northern Bergen County, N. J.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23 -- A pledge from President Eisenhower to recommend changes in the Taft-Hartley Act at the opening of the 1954 Congressional session and a conciliatory speech by Vice President Richard M. Nixon, got cold receptions today at the American Federation of Labor convention.

Amid charges of "dirty politics" and the frequent cheering, jeering and catcalls of spectators, the Board of Estimate rejected yesterday by a 13 to 3 vote a proposal of City Council President Rudolph Halley for the city to take over and operate the veterans' temporary housing colony at Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Sept. 23 -- Marshal Tito, President of Yugoslavia, unveiled his Army today, showing it in action during maneuvers for the first time. Correspondents had a chance to see the Yugoslav war games, anywhere they wanted, ask any questions they desired and get answers.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 23. -- The Lyric Theatre has refused a booking for Marian Anderson, Negro contralto, and also has refused to discuss its segregation policy with Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin's commission on interracial problems.

A group of shareholders organized as the R. Hoe Co., Inc., Stockholders Protective Committee announced yesterday that it had filed a proxy statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission seeking removal of four company directors and reinstatement of Joseph L. Auer as president.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 -- Richie Ashburn's 200th hit of the season, a single in the fifth, scored Willie Jones with the tie-breaking run and gave the Phillies a 2-1 triumph over the Giants tonight at Connie Mack Stadium. Robin Roberts went the route for his twenty-third victory.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 23 -- Humphrey Bogart and his wife, Lauren Bacall, will co-star next year in "Passport," to be directed and produced by Nicholas Ray for the actor's own company, Santana Productions. The picture will be filmed in its entirety in Italy.

A strong indication that President Eisenhower's Administration would turn over to private industry as soon as possible additional enterprises that have long been Government-operated was given last night by Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce.

MONTREAL, Sept. 23 -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent of Canada called upon the United States tonight to help remove the threat of communism and depression by reducing its trade barriers and by taking the lead to solve the world's dollar problem.

The branch plant of the Bellmore Dress Company at 1112-1126 North Avenue in Plainfield, N. J., has been purchased by Polskin, Inc., manufacturer of women's dresses and sportswear. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

BOSTON, Sept. 23 -- The products of thirty leading designers from world fashion capitals were displayed in Filene's French Shops' International Couture Fashion Show Tuesday night in the Sheraton Plaza ballroom.

Most Americans would probably express disbelief if told that something very close to censorship of incoming mail is practiced at our borders. Yet the fact is that for many months scholars, educational institutions, libraries and individuals with completely legitimate interest in books, magazines and other printed matter originating behind the Iron Curtain have found that delivery of such publications was slow, erratic or nonexistent.
The Seymour Fox collection of coats and suits was presented by Milgrim's yesterday at luncheon time at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The one-mile Jerome Handicap a race for 3-year-olds that dates back to 1866, was run for the eighty-fourth time yesterday at breezy Belmont Park, and first money of $18,800 went to E. P. Taylor of Toronto, whose Navy Page bobbed up with a half-length victory in the role of $23.50-for-$2 fifth choice.

The National Alcoholic Beverage Control Association, representing the officials of the sixteen states that handle liquor on a monopoly basis, ended their four-day session at the New Yorker Hotel yesterday with a demand that Attorney General Herbert Brownell tighten enforcement against illicit liquor and increase penalties for bootleg violations.

ROME, Sept. 23 -- The six-power conference called to elaborate a draft constitution for the proposed European federation of states, comprising France, Italy, West Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, made little progress today after it had heard a request from the French delegation that all of the most controversial problems be laid aside at least for the present.

EAST MORICHES, L. I., Sept. 23 -- Moriches Inlet, reopened after having been sealed by drifting sands in 1951, was being scoured, widened and deepened today as full moon tides of clear, tangy salt water flushed pollution from Moriches Bay into the Atlantic Ocean.

Debutantes headed by Miss Wendy Walker and including the Misses Catherine Streibert and Janet S. Norton are aiding in furthering the success of the dinner dance and entertainment, known as the Pippin Red Ball, for the benefit of the Travelers Aid Society, to be held tonight at the formal opening for this season of the Persian Room of the Plaza.

SUMMIT, N. J., Sept. 23 -- The first round of the state match play championship, being held under the auspices of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association, was completed today over the long and difficult south course of the Canoe Brook Country Club.

TRENTON, Sept. 23 -- With the deadline for the withdrawal of candidates from New Jersey's race for Governor and for the filing of nominating petitions by possible alternates less than twenty-four hours away, indications tonight were that one or both independent candidates might toss in the sponge.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- The stock market opened with a rally today in response to Wall Street's advance. But a sharp decline occurred in the War Loan and other undated British Government securities, which had depressing influence on other sections. Industrials were mostly lower. Among a few exceptions were dollar stocks, which made a general recovery ranging up to $2.

Clifford T. McAvoy, the American Labor party candidate for Mayor, ridiculed Governor Dewey's raceway investigation last night. He charged that "Tom Dewey's pal," J. Russel Sprague, Nassau County Republican leader, was "the head boodle boy."
The state-ordered three-day civil defense training exercise in this city began yesterday with a general meeting of Civil Defense officials from the local to the Federal level.

Pharmaceutical manufacturers and retail drug stores must increase their efforts to obtain the good will of the public to offset competition from other types of outlets, according to Willard A. Pleuthner, vice president of Batten, Barton, Durstein Osborn, Inc., advertising agency.

Issues of new public utility and industrial securities totaling more than $20,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The offerings consist of new first mortgage bonds of Duquesne Light Company and new common stock of the Carrier Corporation.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Malcolm Muggeridge, recently appointed editor of Punch, who is in the process of rejuvenating the 112-year-old weekly satiric magazine, advocated tonight a revolution in a newer British entertainment, television.

The Christmas bonus is not a part of a union employe's contractual compensation and a corporation has the right to rescind it without negotiation. Francis B. Delehanty Jr., arbitrator, ruled yesterday in a dispute between the National Distillers Products Corporation and the Distillery, Rectifying and Wine Workers' International Union of America, A. F. L.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 23 (UP) -- Del Crandall's sixth-inning single scored Andy Pafko with the winning run tonight as the Braves edged the Cardinals, 2 -- 1.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UP) -- The National Oil Marketers Association suggested today that the Administration review the special percentage depletion tax allowances granted oil and gas producers.

An increase last week of 253,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies on hand were 143,740,000 barrels, compared with 143,487,000 a week earlier and 113,315,000 a year before.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Saudi Arabia accused British authorities here today of committing new "acts of aggression" in the disputed area of the Buraimi Oasis, and warned once again that she might bring the lingering territorial quarrel to the United Nations.

An issue of $9,800,000 of 3 1/2 per cent revenue bonds of the Georgia State Office Building Authority maturing serially from 1954 to 1977 was put on the market yesterday by a banking syndicate managed by Robinson-Humphrey Co., Inc., and Blyth Co., Inc.

Supreme Court Justice Irving I. Levey ruled yesterday that radio station WOV of this city could broadcast a resume of each round of tonight's heavyweight title bout. The ruling followed an application of the International Boxing Club for a temporary injunction limiting the station's description of the progress of the bout to seventy-five words every three rounds.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept 23 -- Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, said today he hoped the proposed Korean peace conference would result in the unification of Korea, but declared that the sixteen United Nations members that sent forces to Korea did so "for no other purpose than to help repel aggression."

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 30 a headline read: "Frenchwoman Sets a Flying Mark, Breaks Sonic Barrier at 687 M. P. H." -- "Daughter-in-law of President Auriol Exceeds Speed Set by Jacqueline Cochran."

The statement of George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, to the Union Label Trades Department convention, as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 19, to the effect that "a strong union movement and high wage rates were the country's best insurance against depression," should bring a strong protest from those who have the best interests of labor at heart.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner, C. W. Griffin, recommended today that his agency approve railroad proposals to put the Port of New York, as well as Philadelphia and Boston, on an equal basis with Baltimore on railroad rates on imported iron ore to points in western Pennsylvania and Ohio.

Supreme Court Justice Irving I. Levey ruled yesterday that radio station WOV of this city could broadcast a resume of each round of tonight's heavyweight title bout. The ruling followed an application of the International Boxing Club for a temporary injunction limiting the station's description of the progress of the bout to seventy-five words every three rounds.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept 23 -- Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, said today he hoped the proposed Korean peace conference would result in the unification of Korea, but declared that the sixteen United Nations members that sent forces to Korea did so "for no other purpose than to help repel aggression."

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 30 a headline read: "Frenchwoman Sets a Flying Mark, Breaks Sonic Barrier at 687 M. P. H." -- "Daughter-in-law of President Auriol Exceeds Speed Set by Jacqueline Cochran."

The statement of George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, to the Union Label Trades Department convention, as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 19, to the effect that "a strong union movement and high wage rates were the country's best insurance against depression," should bring a strong protest from those who have the best interests of labor at heart.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner, C. W. Griffin, recommended today that his agency approve railroad proposals to put the Port of New York, as well as Philadelphia and Boston, on an equal basis with Baltimore on railroad rates on imported iron ore to points in western Pennsylvania and Ohio.

Despite the hot weather on Aug. 30, on the occasion of the "New in Shoes" seasonal opening for fall, many retailers have reported that sales returns were satisfactory and that they believe the long-range pull of the promotion would prove beneficial throughout the season.

Ever since the mythical Daedalus and his son Icarus made their celebrated flight men have been trying to conquer the air. Much of their success is attributed to how well they have studied and observed birds in flight and emulated the feathered minions in building airplanes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Americans for Democratic Action said today President Eisenhower had acted "as though Congress were the government and he its employe."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 16:

Mayor Impellitteri was asked yesterday by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., to appoint an arbitration panel to settle the dispute between the union and the New York City Transit Authority over the authority's proposed cuts in operating schedules of the municipal subway, bus and street car lines.

A new high in the number of voluntary insurance plans covering hospital, surgical and medical costs was reached in the United States last year, the Health Insurance Council reported yesterday in its annual survey of accident and health coverage.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Sept. 23 (AP) -- News York's police magistrates were told today they could expect more chemical test evidence in their courts as a result of the state's new drunken-driving law. James R. Barrett, chief of the Police Bureau of the State Division of Safety, said numerous local police agencies had embarked on chemical test programs since the law went into effect July 1.

The stock market lost a large part of its earlier gains in the late dealings yesterday and prices at the close were only slightly higher generally. Advances were confined mostly to fractions, with attention centered on the rails, motors and a few selective issues.

A strike of twelve maintenance employes at Sarah Lawrence College, Bronxville, N. Y., which began on Monday -- the first day of the new term -- was settled yesterday afternoon, Merlyn S. Pitzele, chairman of the State Board of Mediation, announced.

Volume continued light on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday with only rubber active in trading. Price changes were irregular, with wool, sugar, burlap, copper, lead and zinc higher; rubber, coffee and hides lower, and cottonseed oil, soybean oil, cocoa, potatoes and tin mixed.

R. C. Palmer has sold the four-story building containing two stores and eight apartments at 794 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, to an investing customer of M. C. O'Brien, Inc., broker in the transaction. The property, in the block between St. Johns Place and Lincoln Place, is assessed at $31,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UP) -- Fred M. Vinson, late Chief Justice of the United States, died almost "broke" despite a lifetime of Government service including some of the highest offices in the land, it was disclosed today.

Walter R. McDonald, a member of the Georgia Public Service Commission, urged yesterday that the Department of Defense stop the use of C-46 cargo planes by non-scheduled airlines in carrying American troops, to reduce the number of fatal air crashes.
COLUMBUS, Miss., Sept. 23 -- Southern farmers appeared today to have put their faith in Congress rather than in the Republican Administration's Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 23 -- Iranian Security forces thwarted last night an attempt by a group of air force officers and enlisted men identified as Communist sympathizers to destroy Teheran's military airport by fire.

In a move to expand its present facilities, the R. W. Shore Manufacturing Company of 33-17 Thirty-seventh Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, has purchased the adjoining plot 26 by 100 feet and containing a one-family dwelling at 33-11 Thirty-seventh Avenue.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Duntreath Farm's Van Crosby made his first appearance here a profitable venture when he scampered home a two-length victor in the $16,900 Ocean City Handicap today.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23 -- Units of the expelled International Longshoremen's Association began shopping around today for new homes in the American Federation of Labor.

Affidavits from 500 of the 1,200 employes of Yonkers Raceway were obtained yesterday as track officials moved swiftly to comply with the law in the hope of salvaging most of the forty-two nights of racing due to start Monday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Gustav Metzman, for many years chief executive of the New York Central Railroad and now chairman and president of The American Railway Car Institute, today asked railroads to order more cars from commercial car builders. Mr. Metzman termed the growing trend toward manufacture of cars by the railroads themselves a threat to the commercial car building industry and a factor in boosting car prices.

NORTH ANDOVER, Mass., Sept. 23 -- Brooks School has a new football coach. He is Paul Lanni, who, on first impression, looks as if he could play tackle on anyone's team. He is 6 feet 6 inches tall, weighs 248 pounds and has hands that virtually hide a football when he holds one.
New York's biggest civil defense exercise for the public will be held this morning, when it will be assumed that two fifty-kiloton atom bombs have hit Manhattan and Queens with devastating effect.

Special agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation rounded up yesterday four members of what they described as "the most notorious gang of automobile thieves in the country." All were arraigned in Brooklyn Federal Court after two indictments had been unsealed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, announced tonight that former prisoners of the Communists in Korea who appeared to have been indoctrinated with Communist ideology or were suspected of actions that caused their fellow prisoners added misery would be dealt with "sympathetically" on an individual basis.

CAIRO, Sept. 24 -- British-Egyptian negotiations on the future of the Suez Canal military base struck a serious snag at yesterday's session that checked what both sides had apparently regarded as swift progress toward an early agreement.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 24 -- Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of the Glen Oaks club matched par 35 on the back nine to win the Women's Long Island Golf association fifty- four-hole medal play championship by a four-stroke margin with 154, 73 -- 227 at the Meadow Brook Club today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -A new United States radio transmitter, one of the most powerful in the world, has started to beam Voice of America broadcasts into Russia and its satellite countries.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 24 -Three hours after all concerned were ashore tonight, the New World was established as the winner over the Old in the yachting series for the Sir Alfred Bossom Cup. Two protest hearings were held at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club after the race. It left the Western Hemisphere ahead by 72 points to 63 1/4.

" In Spite Of," the latest work by John Cowper Powys, will be issued here by Philosophical Library on Oct. 12. Subtitled "A Philosophy for Everyrnn," the book was writtgn in Mr. Powys' eightieth yeaF and it seeks to show how the individual, by accepting his lot in life, may enjoy living under any condi!tions "in spite of" all obstacles.

A house should not be "fashionable" but should reflect the prejudices, eccentricities and habits of its inhabitants, according to Mary Hamman, modern living editor of Life. Miss Hamman spoke at the first fall luncheon of the Home Fashions League, held yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel.
WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Ogden Hanover, 5-year-old son of Nibble Hanover created a new record for himself tonight at Roosevelt Raceway in capturing the $4,000 Missouri mile pace in 2:03 4/5.

GENEVA, Sept. 24 -- Organized migration from the overcrowded countries of Central and Southern Europe took a healthy spurt during the summer months of 1953, the Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration reported today.

NEW MILFORD, Conn., Sept. 24 -- Canterbury School's football team is a senior outfit that boasts a strong backfield, but the Blue's line is a big question mark. That's how Coach Roger Des Roches described his team as he put his twenty-nine-man squad through a full scrimmage today.

As in the previous week, sales finance companies and public utilities were major influences in the volume of loans to business by New York banks during the week ended on Wednesday. Repayments by these interests were reflected in a decline in business borrowings of $137,000,000, the largest drop since July 1, whereas a week earlier they had been among the strongest factors in an expansion of $175,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The State Department disclosed today that a member of the Polish diplomatic corps in New York had broken with his Government in June and taken up residence in Latin America.

Declaring that only the election of himself and his running mates would return good government to New York City, Harold Riegelman, Republican nominee for Mayor, gave reasons last night why in his opinion the voters of the city should not risk continuance of corruption, waste and incompetence in the city government by electing one of his opponents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The new Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government was told today that 72 per cent of the recommendations of the first such commission, which made its final report in 1949, had been put into effect.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Keystoner, brown colt owned by George H. Tipling of Cleveland and driven by Frank Ervin of Aiken, S. C., sped through the dusk today to win the eighth Little Brown Jug for 3-year-old pacers.

The New York State Board of Regents' decision yesterday that the Communist party was subversivewas the latest of a series of setbacks suffered by the Communist party in the United States. These began five years ago when the Justice Department began cracking down on it under the Smith Act, which prohibits conspiracy to teach or advocate the overthrow of the Government by force or violence.
DETROIT, Sept. 24 -- John Radulovich, father of an Air Force Reserve lieutenant who faces dismissal from the service as a doubtful security risk, denied today that he was a Communist.

PARIS, Sept. 24 -- Lord Ismay, secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, annonuced today that Atlantic pact countries would have 120 air bases, all equipped for jet operations, at the end of 1953. This is twice the number they had at the end of last year.

OTTAWA, Sept. 24 -- Canada has become "one of the strong bulwarks of the free world," Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president and publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said here today at a luncheon for national and civic leaders to announce enlarged plans for reporting Canadian news.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The stock markets were mostly poor today until a rally just before the close and in after-hours dealings losses were reduced. The recovery was most marked among British Government securities. The war loan which had suffered the sharpest loss ended with a fall of one-quarter per cent at 85 3/4 sterling.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- A compromise settlement of the developing effort of some Republican legislative committee chairmen to take over control of the party's general policy-making instrumentality will be proposed by Senator H. Alexander Smith of New Jersey.

Thanks to alumni whose pledges of support at the box office saved the game on Rose Hill, Fordham will put a football team on the intercollegiate field again this fall and it may prove to be the best eleven of Ed Danowski's eight-year tenure as head coach.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 24 -- A plan for giving country economic strength and so preserving it from decline was charted today by Thurman Sensing, executive vice president of the Southern States Industrial Council.

A difference of only one and onehalf cents an hour remained last night between the wage proposals of the New York Shipping Association and the International Longshoremen's Association in their efforts to reach a settlement and prevent a strike when the present two-year contract expires next Wednesday night.

IF Maurice Edelman is as able a Member of Parliament as he is a novelist, his country and his party should be grateful for his services, for Mr. Edelman is an expert novelist. The evidence lies before us this morning, a novel called "Who Goes Home,"* which s an adroit story about private lives and public reputations as they are molded by the peculiar codes and special circumstances which prevail in the Mother of Parliaments.
ALBANY, Sept. 24 -- The Board of Regents today listed the state and national Communist parties as subversive, thereby barring their members from any position in the state's public school system.

THE much-vaunted Hollywood "boycott" of television seems to be all over but the shouting. Maybe the producers will not release their pictures to the electronic upstart but the stars assuredly are making a rush to get their share of the video gold. The last week's crop of emigres to TV included no less than three Academy Award winners, Joan Crawford, Loretta Young and Ray Milland.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Departments of Defense and State today dropped plans to offer $50,000 inducements to Communist pilots to fly MIG-15 fighters to the United Nations side of the armistice line in Korea. At the same time they offered to return the MIG-15 already in United Nations hands to its "rightful owner."

The New York City Transit Authority stood firm yesterday in its dispute with the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., over economy revisions of transit operating schedules. The new timetables of train, bus and trolley runs were ordered posted starting Monday for the information of employes of the city-owned system.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 24--The thirty-fifth series of concerts at South Mountain, established by Mrs. Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge, continued here today with two events.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 25 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, United National commander, firmly demanded in a letter delivered to the Communists at Panmunjom, Korea, last night that they either immediately return or account for 3,421 Allied prisoners who have not been repatriated.

The six-story industrial building on a plot 175 by 200 feet at 611 West 131st Street has been sold by the Borden Company to the Broil-Quick Company which will occupy it for the manufacture of infra-red broilers and rotisseries. Nelson Co. were the brokers and the attorneys were Louis Drell for the buyer and Winsten Barrow for the seller.

Canada has obtruded herself in the best possible way since the war on the consciousness of the world. It is usually the fate of countries bursting into print to do so because something has gone wrong -- a political crisis, an assassination, a revolution, rioting, economic difficulties.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 24 -Service regulations for the professional soldiers in West Germany's proposed European army contingent have been drafted and are ready for enactment as soon as it appears that France will ratify the European Defense Community treaty, it was disclosed here today.

The East Side Airlines Terminal nearing completion on First Avenue between East Thirty-seventh and East Thirty-eighth Streets has been taken under a long lease by the East Side Airlines Terminal Corporation, from the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority. The contract, effective on Nov. 1, runs for twenty years with five-year renewal option.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy, Miami, Fla., and the Danish Davis Cup team of Kurt Nielsen and Torben Ulrich went down to defeat in quarter-final matches of the Pacific Coast tennis championships today.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company attained the second highest sales and earnings in its history for the first nine months of a fiscal year in the period ended on July 31, according to the report issued yesterday by Harvey S. Firestone Jr., chairman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The new Joint Chiefs of Staff have made a thorough review of the United States' military position and their estimates of the situation are not much different from the estimates of their predecessors.

GENEVA, Sept. 24 -- Trade unionists attending the Moral Rearmament Movement Assembly at Caux reacted sharply again today to published reports of condemnation of the movement by the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24 -- Former President Truman told the American Federation of Labor convention today that the organization's late president, William Green, had played a hitherto undisclosed part in Mr. Truman's nomination for the Vice Presidency in 1944.

JUST in case you never noticed it, the football season began last week-end. It had to battle for headlines with the national amateur golf the Marciano-LaStarza fight, the closing stages of baseball's pennant race, speculation over the world series and various other distractions. What is more, it will gather even more momentum tomorrow.
TORONTO, Sept. 24 -- The Port of New York Authority was attacked today as playing favorites and undermining New York's preeminent position as a handler of foreign trade.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- If the Korean peace conference is held the United States intends to give the Soviet Union and Communist China a choice between two basic courses of action: ...

SUMMIT, N. J., Sept. 24 -- Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr., the defending champion, was defeated in the second round of the twenty-eighth women's New Jersey State golf championship over the south course of the Canoe Brook Country Club today.

ONCE in a blue moon an artist who has been struggling along in this city of artistic hopes, dreams and heartbreaks, without recognition from his fellow countrymen, suddenly wins an international prize.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UP)--The Department of Agriculture reported today that the Government had suffered a $61,146,000 loss on its farm price support operations in the 1953 fiscal year that ended on June 30.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24 -- The union trustee in charge of reorganizing the local that was led by Thomas F. Lewis until his murder Aug. 28 reported today that a Lewis-controlled insurance agency had been drawing $63,000 a year in "service charges" from the local's employer-financed welfare fund.

After two days of climbing, the stock market yesterday grew tired, staggered through an inconclusive session and closed barely lower. Volume of only 1,020,000 shares was the smallest since Sept. 10. It compared with 1,240,000 shares on Wednesday.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 20 -Yugoslavia's fear of divulging her military situation to Italy, since the Trieste dispute reached its present intensity, has led Belgrade to curtail drastically military information furnished to Turkey and Greece, its Balkan pact partners who are allied with Italy in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

PARIS, Sept 24 -- It is the emphatic conviction of some of the most distinguished European and French experts in foreign policy and economics that France holds the key to the future of Western Europe in both these fields at a time when action is urgent to prevent setbacks that might wipe out much of the progress already made.

TRENTON, Sept. 24 -- Elmer H. Wene tossed in the sponge at 2 P. M. today and announced he would not attempt to split the ranks of the Democratic party in New Jersey by running as an independent candidate for Governor.

The two-story taxpayer building with eight stores and three offices at 2801-13 White Plains Road in the Bronx has been sold by Phillip P. Zipes, operator, to a client of Fred Weitzner, lawyer, for cash above mortgages of $130,500. It is assessed at $100,000. Emil Leepson was the seller's attorney.

ROME, Sept. 24 -- A twenty-four-hour general strike of industrial workers, reinforced by a twenty-four-hour strike of printers and a partial stoppage by urban transport workers went off today without violence or incidents worthy of particular notice.
All buses between Manhattan and the regional system of airports here will operate solely from the new East Side Airlines Terminal starting early in November.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- After nearly two years in office the Conservative party has suffered a sudden decline in popularity in the country and at the same time is facing serious internal difficulties over leadership and policy.

CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Sept. 24 (UP) -- Fred Eugene McManus, 19-year-old Valley Stream, L. I., youth who admitted having killed five persons in a wild series of hold-ups with his teen-aged sweetheart last spring, was convicted of first degree murder today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Point Four program to improve conditions in the underdeveloped lands has not been killed by amalgamation with the sprawling military and economic aid projects, but the result, as one official put it, has been to "cut back Point Four to Point Two and a Half."
Rockefeller Center went to the dogs yesterday -- but in a well-bred, decorous manner.
The modern plane has made obsolete in less than ten years many of the aircraft carriers that served the nation in World War II.

Carl Loeb, president of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City, declared yesterday that his group hoped to work with Roman Catholic agencies in planning for the whole city despite the recent withdrawal of fifty-three Catholic groups from the council.

Manufacturers of man-made fibers should organize a promotional campaign to restore rayon and acetate fabrics and blends to the favor they formerly held with consumers, speakers advised yesterday at the fifteenth annual meeting of the Textile Distributors Institute at the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Mrs. Agnes E. Meyer, long a crusader for establishment of the Cabinet post of Health, Education and Welfare today declared that bipartisan reactionaries on Capitol Hill were wrecking the new Department's Social Security and welfare programs.
Although I voted Republican last year, I must admit that I sometimes find Republican "statesmanship" quite baffling.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 24 -- The Government of Iran has struck at Hossein Fatemi, fugitive former Foreign Minister, in the ousted cabinet of Dr. Mohammet Mossadegh through his wife, his sister-in-law and members of his personal staff who were arrested last night and today on the charge they withheld knowledge of his hiding place.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Exercise Mariner, the re-enactment of the Battle of the Atlantic by the navies of nine North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries, has cost two lives, radio signals from British and United States ships disclosed today.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 24 (UP) -- Clarence Miles, a lawyer, said today that he and Bill Veeck, president of the St. Louis Browns, would occupy the top two positions in the club if and when it was moved to Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UP) -- A spokesman for the Department of Agriculture said today large Canadian rye imports may have "contributed" to a domestic price decline, but added that no recommendations for import quotas have been prepared.

Manhattan College welcomed twenty-six West German students yesterday morning. Edmund Tolk, head of the college's German Department, who is their faculty adviser, greeted the young men when they disembarked from the American Export Lines ship Independence.

John J. Murphy, who signed on as ordinary seaman aboard a Moore-McCormack freighter thirty years ago, will ship out as "pilot" of the line's passenger ship Argentina today although he still has not learned the finer points of navigation.

BERLIN, Sept. 24 -- Three months after the June riots that swept East Germany, the Communists there have again taken up the drive for increased production norms. They have thus picked up the hot potato they dropped at the outset of the riots.
VALDOSTA, Ga., Sept. 24 -- A fight over Federal farm price supports, one that may widen and make more permanent the cleavage between Northern and Southern farm leaders, appeared inevitable today.

There is a distinct air of uncertainty about the present moves toward European union in Rome and Strasbourg. In Italy, deputies of the Foreign Ministers of "Little Europe" -- the Schuman plan countries -- are meeting to work over a draft constitution for a supranational political community which will be submitted to the Foreign Ministers themselves at a conference in The Hague on Oct. 20.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The statement that penicillin was first discovered at the end of the Nineteenth Century by a French military doctor has been made in the reputable German medical journal Deutsche Medizinische Wochenschrift.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 24 -- J. Russel Sprague, Republican National Committeeman, was re-elected tonight as Republican leader of Nassau County, a post he has held since 1935.

For better or worse, this is a country where much credit attaches to personal wealth ethically gained. Not honor particularly, but the respect and admiration of a good many people. After all, what are most of us doing during a large part of our waking hours? Look about you on the street any Monday to Friday from 9 to 5.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- During the week ending Sept. 23, member bank reserves decreased $285,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 24 Paramount, after weighing critical and public reaction to Nicole Maurey's introduction as the wife of Bing Crosby in "Little Boy Lost," believes that it has a potential new star in the French actress.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 24 (UP) -- The Indonesian Government announced today that an uprising in Northern Sumatra had been brought under "complete control" with local forces killing thirty-four rebels and capturing eighty others.
LONDON, Sept. 24 -- What appears to be an organized campaign to popularize the idea of commercial broadcasting in Britain has begun.

KESAT, Vietnam, Sept. 24 (AP) -- French Union troops encircled more than 5,000 Vietminh soldiers amid flooded rice fields north of the Red River today. It was the biggest drive yet in a campaign to keep the Communist-led enemy from getting set for a fall offensive.

The formation of the Northeastern Life Insurance Company of New York, with a paid-in capital and surplus of $1,000,000, was announced yesterday by Lawrence L. Monnet Jr., president. The company, which will have offices at 110 William Street, will begin writing business on Oct. 1.

Former President Herbert Hoover will appear on a young people's television program on Oct. 18 to discuss the character of our Government and the opportunities that will be inherited by the coming generation.

A conflict of premieres looms for Nov. 3. "Sherlock Holmes," the Ouida Rathbone play in which the author's husband, Basil Rathbone, is starred, was announced yesterday to arrive that night at the Century. The same evening is scheduled to bring "The Trip to Bountiful," with Lillian Gish heading the cast of the Horton Foote play, to Henry Miller's.

Contracts for use of air rights over the vast expanse of the Pennsylvania Railroad tracks between Ninth and Tenth Avenues, Thirtyfirst and Thirty-third Streets, have been closed by Webb Knapp, Inc., as the initial step in a plan to develop the site with a great merchandise mart and "showcase for the products of America."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended September 19 totaled 23,884 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 113,330 cars or 15.9 per cent more than for the preceding week, 49,712 cars or 5.7 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 39,06 cars or 4.6 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two ears ago.

The atmosphere of Spain filled the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at noon yesterday when a colorful pageant arranged in honor of Jose Felix de Lequerica, the Ambassador of Spain, took place.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- If the Korean question is solved by establishing a neutral state under an international guarantee, the United Nations will be following the example set by the great powers of a century ago when they had to deal with the difficult questions of Switzerland and Belgium.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Colorful exhibits from the gardens, nurseries and countryside of Westchester County are on view at the County Center here, where the Town and County Flower Show opened at 2 P. M. today. The fourday show is being presented by the fifty-four garden clubs of the ninth district of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State.

Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke received a certificate of reasonable doubt yesterday from State Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Cox, opening the way to release in bail pending appeal from a three-to-six year sentence for compulsory prostitution.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active yesterday and closing prices were somewhat irregular, 9 points lower to 8 points higher.
LAS VEGAS. Nev. Sept. 24 (AP) -- Rita Hayworth and Dick Haymes were married here today in a three-minute ceremony.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UP) -J. Vivian Truman, brother of former President Truman, has quit voluntarily as Federal Housing Administration director for the Western half of Missouri. A Republican, Mayor Gerbert Studer of Sedalia, Mo., will succeed him, the agency said today. Base pay for the job ranges from $8,360 to $9,360 a year, depending on length of Federal service.
The Democratic State Committee, meeting yesterday in the Biltmore Hotel, nominated Judge Edmund H. Lewis of Syracuse to succeed himself as Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Dr. Marek Stanislaw Korowicz, the specialist in international law who deserted the Polish delegation to the United Nations last week to seek asylum in the United States, swore today that he took that step because it was only in this country that he could best serve his Communist-controlled homeland.
" I was stopped by the champion of the world and I don't hesitate to say that anybody who beats him will have to be 5,000 times tougher than I was tonight."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 24 -Eugene H. Walet 3d, 18-year-old Jesuit (New Orleans) High School senior, became the youngest skipper ever to win the North American sailing championship as the eight-race series ended off the Larchmont Y. C. today. He scored 48 1/2 points.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 24 -- Grant Golden of Northwestern University qualified for the final in the men's singles at the tennis tournament of the Maccabiah Games today. He will face a South African Davis Cup player, Syd Levy, for the title.

Good things come in pairs, according to the old saying, and also, if one is permitted a poor pun, in pears. That fine fruit, offering flavor, succulence and variety, is in best supply in New York stores this month and next. More than 500 carloads often come in during September, and receipts during October always reach that amount.

The international exchange of art and craft objects was extolled yesterday as a means of promoting understanding and appreciation among the peoples of many countries at a luncheon honoring Jose Felix de Lequerica, Spanish Ambassador to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. announced today an anti-trust consent judgment against Telescope Carts, Inc., Kansas City, Mo., and Folding Carrier Corporation, Oklahoma City, Okla.

DETROIT, Sept. 24 -- William J. Jameson, president of the American Bar Association, upheld today the constitutional right of all citizens to refuse testimony concerning Communist affiliations on the ground of self-incrimination in a criminal case.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of the Sadler's Wells Ballet on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over to raise funds for the Stepney Camp for underprivileged children at Botsford, Conn. Mrs. George A. Sloan is chairman and Mrs. A. Cuthbert Palmer, vice chairman, of the benefit committee.

Syndicate subscription books were closed yesterday on two of the week's major offerings of debt securities. Lehman Brothers, Blyth Co., Inc., and Phelps, Fenn Co., managers of the dealers' syndicate marketing $102,675,000 of the latest issue of public housing bonds, announced the closing of subscription books on five offering groups, which ranged in yield from 1.4 per cent to 3 per cent.

The current controversy regarding the proposed site for the much needed convention center in New York City serves to point up the seriousness of this problem. Within a month New York will be without an adequate, centrally located convention and exhibit hall.

CAIRO, Sept. 24 -- Ibrahim Abdel Hadi, former Premier and chief of the Royal Cabinet, was accused tonight of treason, corruption, terrorism, graft and complicity in murder in a seven-count indictment published by the Military Prosecutor.

An appeal to the United States Government not to raise the import duty on wool, because "Australia rides on the sheep's back," was made yesterday by Richard G. Casey, Australian Minister of External Affairs. Mr. Casey spoke at a luncheon of the American Australian Association at the University Club, 1 West Fifty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The presence in the capital of the members of the American Banker Association, after convening in other cities for nineteen years, was enveloped in an atmosphere of partnership with the Administration in sharp contrast with that of 1934.

PORTSMOUTH, N. H., Sept. 24 -- New England needs new industries, but its old industries should not be sacrificed in the interest of building foreign trade through the encouragement of imports, Seymour E. Harris, Professor of Economics at Harvard University, vigorously expressed this opinion here today at a meeting of the National Association of Cotton Manufacturers and the Northern Textile Association in the Wentworth-by-the-Sea Hotel.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 24 -- S. S. Holland of East Orange, vice president in charge of insurance for the Jersey City office of J. I. Kislak Company, was elected president of the New Jersey Association of Insurance Agents at the sixtieth annual convention today at Haddon Hall Hotel.

Shareholders of the National Bank of Detroit set a price of $45 a share yesterday on the issue of 313,200 new shares of the bank's capital stock to be offered to shareholders on the basis of one new share for each five shares held.

Rocky Marciano, the Brockton (Mass.) battler who holds the heavyweight championship of the world, made a successful defense of his crown against Roland LaStarza of the Bronx in a scheduled fifteen-round fight at the Polo Grounds last night.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 24 -- The Indians are getting the impression, apparently from skilled propaganda sources, that rioting anti-Communist prisoners in Korea are being incited by Chinese Nationalist provacateurs brought from Formosa surreptitiously by the United Nations Command and "planted" among legitimate captives in the neutral zone.

The usefulness of the United Nations as a forum for discussion of international problems is illustrated again in the present debate in the General Assembly. Apparent there is a rapid restoration of free world solidarity, recently impaired by the dispute over Indian participation in the Korean conference.

An industrial plot of 60,000 square feet occupying the entire blockfront on the west side of Thirty-sixth Street, between Forty- seventh and Forty-eighth Avenues, in Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by the Interboro Realty Company of Brooklyn, industrial developers. Thomas Harris was the seller.

The Mast, owned by Mrs. Esther duPont Weir, and Sundowner, flying the Yale-blue silks of James F. McHugh, had the race between them all the way in the thirty- ninth running of the Broad Hollow Steeplechase at Belmont Park yesterday, and The Mast was the winner after a head-and-head duel around the last turn and down the stretch.

A fur collection, created with the imagination and excellence always expected of Maximilian Furs, was seen yesterday in the West Fifty- seventh Street showrooms of that company. The wraps with the greatest news interest followed the trends recently reported in the dress market.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, expressed confidence today that a lasting world peace could be obtained, even though "Communist leaders who openly repudiate the restraints of moral law" might possess weapons capable of destroying civilization.

Commodity prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges with potatoes, cocoa, hides, zinc, rubber and lead higher; cottonseed oil, soybean oil and tin lower, and sugar, coffee, burlap, copper and wool mixed. Trading increased slightly in most markets and potatoes had the most active day since Aug. 11.

The world has grown so small that even printed matter -- which in earlier days took weeks to go even relatively short distances -- now is shuttled back and forth among nations at breath-taking speeds.

ROME, Sept. 24 -- Optimism soared today at the Rome sixpower conference when news was received of the speech that Guy Mollet, French Socialist leader, made in Strasbourg yesterday, promising the aid of Socialist votes for ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty by the French National Assembly.

When he finally fought his way back to his dressing room, which proved a much tougher fight than his scrap with Roland LaStarza, an unmarked Rocky Marciano attributed the successful defense of his heavyweight title to a change of style in the seventh round.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- Wheat developed a great deal of strength today and at one time was as much as 4 cents above the level of the previous close because of aggressive short covering. The upturn was rapid and it attracted sufficient selling to cause recessions from top levels. Other grains also showed firmness but the soybean market finally reversed its trend and closed lower.

The New York Clearing House Association, which was founded in a basement and now handles more than two million bank checks daily, will celebrate its 100th anniversary next month. The largest institution of its kind in the United States, it does more than 44 per cent of the nation's bank clearing business.

The new Hunter College graduate program, which for the first time in twenty years will grant a Master of Arts degree in liberal arts and science, has 205 registrants this term. The present program of English and comparative literature, the history, theory and composition of music, and the classics, soon will be expanded, Prof. Ruth G. Weintraub, chairman of the Hunter graduate committee, announced.
Election of Lyman C. Thunfors as president of the Rensselaer Valve Company, Troy, N. Y., was announced yesterday.
The blow-by-blow description of the Rocky Marciano-Roland LaStarza world heavyweight championship fight at the Polo Grounds last night follows:

A plumber whose eye for Old World beauty searched out a twelve-inch piece of ancient lead pipe in the ruins of Pompeii, witnessed yesterday the dedication of the Bronx Zoo's new Fountain of Youth containing the old, but still useful section of pipe.

Preliminary laboratory reports of the discovery of a new antibiotic that may take its place beside the five now in common use -- penicillin, streptomycin, chloramphenicol, aureomycin and terramycin -- were made yesterday in the current issue of The Journal of the American Chemical Society.

Wade McCargo, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, called yesterday on merchants all over the country to conduct an educational campaign to combat proposals for a national sales tax at either the manufacturing or retail level.

The gains that the Communists have made in southern India are not simply the automatic product of poverty and ignorance. The state of TravancoreCochin, where Prime Minister Nehru's Congress party has just suffered defeat, is near the top of the Indian list in literacy and compared with many other Indian areas is prosperous.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 24 -Dr. Nathan M. Pusey told Harvard's freshmen tonight, in his first talk to a student group as president of the university, that "our interest here is to read books, not to burn them."

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 23 -- Announcement that the Japanese Foreign Minister will arrive here Oct. 3 for a five-day visit has enhanced the prospects for conclusion of a Japanese-Indonesian peace treaty.
