Katsuo Okazaki is expected to discuss the treaty possibilities and review with local officials the whole range of Japanese- Indonesian problems.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Sept. 24 -- An American labor leader predicted here today that, barring a depression, the Republicans would increase their Congressional strength in next fall's election and win the Presidency again in I956.

In your editorial of Sept. 15 you state: "Moreover, Tito beclouds the issue by the false assertion that Mussolini forced 100,000 Yugoslavs out of the territory. Mussolini's policy of Italianizing the area was reprehensible and stupid, but there was no forced expatriation.

Yesterday's session of the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich was reserved for playing off adjourned games from the thirteenth and fourteenth rounds and resulted in victories for Dr. Max Euwe of the Netherlands and Ewfim Geller and Alexander Kotov, both of Russia, according to a Swiss news report.

Effort and expense directed toward sales promotion and advertising have not kept pace with increases in consumers' disposable income, it was said yesterday by J. K. Lasser, chairman of the Institute of Federal Taxation at New York University.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept 24 -- Following are excerpts from the address of Selwyn Lloyd, British Minister of State, before the United Nations General Assembly today:

Chicago announced yesterday plans for the sale of $12,500,000 of Board of Education bonds on Oct. 14. The obligations are to bear fixed interest of 3 per cent. Dated Sept. 15, 1953, they will come due Sept. 15 from 1956 to 1973.

Furniture collections derived from early nineteenth-century European styles, softened with neo-classical details and rich in the color of their woods, are on view with a pot-pourri of other home furnishings assembled to mark home fashions time at Wanamaker's and Abraham Straus.
Dr. C. J. Aackenzie, past president of the National Research Council, xvho recently retired as president of Atomic Energy of Canada. Ltd., has joined the Canadian Chemical and Cellulose Company, Ltd.

It was a butcher job. Rocky Marciano never even bothered to administer an anaesthetic. The heavy-fisted champion usually puts his foe to sleep. Defeat to said foe comes more painlessly that way. But at the Polo Grounds last night the Brockton Blockbuster chopped relentlessly away until brave, bold Roland LaStarza was so battered a hulk that Referee Ruby Goldstein had to intervene.

Plans for the installation in Mount Sinai Hospital of the city's first respirator center for polio patients with breathing difficulties were made public yesterday by the hospital and the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

A special counsel to direct a broad investigation of possible links between racketeers and harness track operators will be designated today when the State Harness Racing Commission opens public hearings on unsavory hiring practices at the Yonkers Raceway.

Directors of A. G. Spalding Bros., Inc., elected Walter B. Gerould as president and chief executive officer yesterday to succeed the late William T. Brown. George Dawson was elected vice president and a director. David G. Christensen was made secretary and controller. Charles F. Robbins continues as chairman of the board.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24 (UP) -- The Pacific Coast League today took over the San Francisco franchise as the Seals' owner, Paul Fagan, withdrew from baseball.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -Latin, already a dead language, is dying all over again in this country, according to Dr. John Latimer, assistant dean of the College of General Studies at George Washington University. He thinks he has a plan for reviving it as a study.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UP) -- The Army today refused to verify immediately the names of the twenty-three Americans listed by the Chinese Communist radio as refusing repatriation.

A strike that would force the closing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Cloisters was forecast yesterday by Wilbur Duberstein, counsel for the Museum Guardians Union of America, an independent organization representing the institutions' 170 day and night guards.

The opening of a new clinic for the study and treatment of eating and drinking problems with special attention to alcoholism and obesity was announced yesterday at Knickerbocker Hospital, 70 Convent Avenue.

ALBANY, Sept. 24 -- Following is the text of the opinion submitted by a special Regents Committee and approved unanimously by the full Board of Regents today in which the Communist party was officially listed as a subversive organization:
Before the first-class mail rate is upped to 5 cents an ounce something certainly ought to be done about restricting first-class mail to what it is supposed to be -- personal communications.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Dr. Gaylord P. Harnwell, president of the University of Pennsylvania, disclosed tonight that he had urged George Munger to remain as football coach at Penn, but Munger told reporters a short time later that he still desires to go ahead with his plan to retire.

Despite some danger spots in industrial areas where defense work has been concentrated, the job of converting industry in New York State to peacetime activity will be relatively small, the State Department of Commerce reported yesterday after a study of post- Korean economic conditions. Results of the analysis were published in the department's monthly economic digest, "Commerce Review."

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Power to fight the choking smoke-laden fogs that caused 4,000 deaths in four days last winter is to be asked of Parliament by the City of London, the mile square central district at the heart of this metropolis.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Sept. 24 -- Playing his last tournament in the district, Pete Cooper won the Metropolitan open championship at the Rockville Country Club today with a seventy-two hole aggregate of 284.

The United States Justice Department stepped into the controversy yesterday over restricted television of the Oklahoma-Notre Dame football game but the Associated Press said there were no indications the National Collegiate Athletic Association would back down in its stand.

There is an element of ironic justice in the latest purge in Soviet Georgia, the fourth such event merely in the past year and f half. Even by Soviet standards -- or the comparable standards of gangsters during, say, the Capone era of Chicago -- the now fallen Premier Bakradze deserved his downfall.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- A special committee of the British Medical Association reported today after a long study of general practioners that there had been some deterioration in the doctor-patient relationship since nationalized medicine was introduced in Britain in 1948.

Extension of the alternate-sideof-the-street parking program to a 145-square-block area of the upper East Side, Yorkville and East Harlem will go into effect on Monday. The ban will free 16.3 miles of curb space for three hours every day so that "New York will be a cleaner metropolis."

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Buses of Rockland Coaches, Inc., and its four subsidiaries were running behind schedule for the second day straight today, but their drivers denied it was a deliberate slowdown. Instead, they said it was a safety campaign in which they were following the rule book scrupulously.

The action of Corliss Lamont in defying the McCarthy committee on the ground that the latter is unconstitutionally violating the personal rights of private citizens raises again the interesting and important question of how far Congressional committees can properly go.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Britain told the United Nations today that any agreement for a reunited Korea would need to be backed by guarantees of the security of Korea and her neighbors.

The United States is "optimistic" that it can persuade the United Nations General Assembly to overrule decisions that had set aside dismissals of a dozen United States employee of the United Nations Secretariat who had been involved in Senate loyalty investigations, Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States representative to the United Nations, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- An electric brain designed to solve inventory checking problems for business was demonstrated yesterday by John Plain Co., Chicago merchandiser with headquarters at 444 West Washington Street.
Pork prices dropped slightly this week, but the advantages to the consumer are offset by increases in beef, eggs and veal.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24 -- A nationwide meat packing Btrike. with Swift Co. as the first target, was threatened today by the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen, A. F. L.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 24 -- Louis S. Rothschild, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board, told the shipping industry today that his agencies would assist in ship building and replacement, but would not engage in any large-scale Government building program to design and produce ships on a take-it-or- leave-it basis.

THE week-end fishing prospects, except for those surfcasters who are willing to travel, are no brighter than might be expected for this season, with the bluefish gradually fading from the scene and the bonito and albacore reports indicating only fair fishing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has abandoned a projected study of the most efficient size, type and location of public utility companies, Ralph H. Demmler, commission chairman, announced today.

Mayor Impellitteri was reported by close associates yesterday as having definitely decided to run for re-election as an independent candidate although the Mayor personally continued to insist that he had not made up his mind on the subject.
SEASIDE PARK, N. J., Sept. 24 -- A New Jersey National Guard fighter pilot was rescued six miles offshore today after bailing out of his disabled F-51 Mustang.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The nation's department store sales in the week ended on Saturday were 6 per cent above those in the corresponding week of last year.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, voiced today a plea to the country's parents, churches, schools and civic groups to attack the problem created by the "alarming rise" in juvenile delinquency. She urged emphasizing to children "the spiritual and moral teachings by precept and example."

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Beneath its calm surface Paris is worried lest the labor unrest which exploded in the unorganized strikes of last summer, planless compared to yesterday's orderly walkout in Italy, is smoldering in preparation for another eruption this fall. Aside from decreeing raises for the lowest- paid state employes, the harassed Government has done nothing to satisfy labor's grievances.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Foreign Office quarters confirmed today reports of difficulties in the negotiations in Cairo on the Suez Canal but they insisted the difficulties were not new ones but "the same old difficulties in pretty much the same form."

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 25 -- The New World, as represented by United States and Canadian yachtsmen, completed a successful series against the Old in international six-meter sailing today and became the first winner of the Sir Alfred Bossom Cup.
Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 1 to 13 points yesterday, closing steady.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- Prof. Joel H. Hildebrand of the University of California, received tonight the Willard Gibbs Medal at a dinner meeting of the Chicago section of the American Chemical Society. The award, founded in 1910 by William A. Converse, a former secretary of the Chicago section, is one of the highest in chemistry.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 25 -- The New Jersey Turnpike Authority has engaged weather experts to help its fight against accidents on the toll road, Maxwell Lester Jr. of Summit, a member of the authority, advised the Board of Public Works here today.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 25 -- Ibrahim Ali Did, 65-year-old joint head of the new Maldivian Government that seized power over the scattered group of islands in the Indian Ocean four weeks ago, arrived in Colombo yesterday as the new Government's first envoy to Ceylon.
After a delay of a year and a half, the Air Force is moving to acquire nearly 5,000 acres near Plattsburg, N. Y., for a jet bomber base.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The stockholders protective committee of Industrial Brownhoist Company said today holders of more than 40 per cent of the company's outstanding stock had given to it proxies to vote against a proposed merger with the Pennsylvania Coal and Coke Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Senate Permanent Subcommittee in Investigations headed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, postponed today the scheduled Monday appearance of Corliss Lamont, a left-wing author.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 25 -- There was feverish polishing of crystal balls in top echelon production circles today following the local opening last night of "The Robe" in the wide-screen CinemaScope photographic and projection system introduced by Twentieth Century-Fox.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, concluding negotiations here, signed a contract with the Bolivian Government today for the purchase of 10,000 tons of tin.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- For the first time since the new Administration took office the Treasury is reducing interest rates on an issue of Government securities.

Rocky Marciano received the biggest paycheck of his career yesterday. The heavyweight champion of the world, who repulsed Roland LaStarza's bid for the crown with an eleventh-round knockout the night before at the Polo Grounds, was enriched by $186,992. LaStarza's share, amounting to $76,997, also constituted his biggest purse.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- The world record for level flight was raised tentatively to 737.3 miles an hour today as the second of a brilliant new team of Royal Air Force jet fighters toppled the mark set earlier this month by the first.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Two world harness racing records toppled and two others were equalled today as the Grand Circuit concluded its annual stand at the Delaware County Fair.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon said today that she was accompanying her husband on his Far Eastern tour because she felt she had "a job to do" as an unofficial good will ambassador to America's allies in Asia."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Delegates to the United Nations General Assembly were urged today by Syria to give greater voice to Asia in the eleven-member Security Council.

PANAMA CITY, Fla., Saturday, Sept. 26 (UP) -- A Gulf of Mexico hurricane with 140 miles-an-hour winds roared early today toward a northwest Florida coastline studded with defense basis. It was expected to strike at dawn after shifting its course from due north to north-northeast late yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent to 110.7 in the week ended Sept. 22, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Lower prices for processed foods were nearly counterbalanced by higher prices for farm products, while the index for all commodities other than farm products and foods remained unchanged.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, and President Eisenhower discussed ways today of getting started "as soon as possible" on a multimillion-dollar program for selling surplus farm goods overseas. Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey and Harold E. Stassen, Foreign Operations Administrator, also attended the White House conference.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- France told the Soviet Union today that the West was willing to consider plans for guaranteeing Europe's present borders as an extra measure of guarding against the rebirth of militarism on the Continent.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The National Economic Conference for Israel opens here tomorrow to chart further intensive aid to Israel's economic development, chiefly through enlarged sale of bonds.

Directors of the New York City Omnibus Corporation yesterday passed the dividend on the common stock. It is the third time the board took no action on the quarterly dividend. The company operates bus lines, mostly in the Borough of Manhattan.

I was intrigued by your editorial in the Sept. 16 issue entitled "The News Survey -- Same Old Story," in which you emphasized the deplorable condition of municipal operation of the city's transportation system.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Stock exchange prices opened firmly today as a result of last night's late recovery in British funds and an increased interim dividend by Imperial Chemical Industries. However, week-end influences kept business down and prices did not hold their best levels.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 25 -- A complete procedure for determining how much atomic radiation a military unit or the civilian population has encountered in an atomic bomb attack was demonstrated today at an exhibition of German-made military equipment.

Many a modern mother craves a vital interest outside her home and family. This week at the First Annual Human Relations Conference at the New School for Social Research, a distinguished mother of four and grandmother of nine offered a few words of encouragement for women so inclined.

DETROIT, Sept 25 (AP) -- Car and truck production in the United States this week will total 129,494 units, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. The agency counted 106,819 cars and 22,675 trucks in the total.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -- The pennant-winning Dodgers won their 104th game tonight, tying the high mark of the 1942 Brooks, who did not win the flag because the Cardinals won two more games.

It was "Frederick Ashton Night" for the Sadler's Wells Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, not only because the program consisted of three ballets by the company's chief choreographer and associate director, but chiefly because the local premiere of his "Daphnis and Chloe" proved it to be an utterly ravishing creation.

A contract with a former radio sponsor, dated before 1949, has caused the cancellation of a television guest appearance by Fred Allen. Until yesterday he was listed to appear on the premiere of the Dave Garroway show next Friday from 8 to 8:30 P. M. over the N. B. C. network.

Volume was light on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday as trading positions here evened for the week-end. Only hides showed sizable activity, with the most sales since July 14. Prices closed generally lower, with hides, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, potatoes, tin, zinc, copper and rubber down; cocoa, sugar, burlap and lead mixed, and wool and coffee higher.

ROME, Sept. 25 -- The six-power conference here to draft a constitution for the proposed federation of European states registered substantial progress today. Its institutional and juridical committee reached unanimous agreement on two important points concerning the "chamber of nations," or lower house of the proposed European parliament.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Further proceedings to determine whether Doubleday Co., Inc., Garden City, N. Y., book publishers, may partially control the resale prices of independent book retailers were ordered by the Federal Trade Commission today. The agency set aside an initial decision dismissing a charge that Doubleday's resale price maintenance practices were unlawful and remanded the case to the hearing examiner "for completion of the taking of evidence."

Two United States citizens formerly employed by the United Nations refused to tell the Senate Internal Security subcommittee here yesterday whether they were or had been members of the Communist party.

SUMMIT, N. J., Sept. 25 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair and Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood reached the final of the twenty-eighth annual women's New Jersey State golf championship today at the Canoe Brook Country Club.

Your recent editorial on the psychological torture that the Reds inflicted on our G. I.'s in Korea reminds us that anti-Communist prisoners in our hands are about to suffer a similar ordeal. Over 22,000 Chinese and Koreans surrendered to us on promise of freedom and protection.

Two Roman Catholic Bishops will be consecrated at St. Patrick's Cathedral on Oct. 5 in the first double consecration ceremony there. They are the Most Rev. Edward V. Dargin, vicar general, and the Most Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg, chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, both of whom were elevated recently by Pope Pius XII to be auxiliary Bishops to Cardinal Spellman.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- A Republican and a Democratic Senator gave opposed views today on whether taxes could be cut without impairing America's defense against new weapons.

The estate of Irene S. Sheehan has sold the ten-room Norman-style dwelling at 48 Hampton Road in the Fox Meadow section of Scarsdale, N. Y., to Benjamin Miller. The Myron L. Blum Company and Carl W. Heye were the brokers in the sale.
Three group exhibitions, a one-man show and the opening of a new gallery are among this week's attractions.

A home - made Czechoslovak "Freedom Car" landed on American soil yesterday to await its owner, a mechanic, who designed it to carry himself, his wife and two children and four others through the Iron Curtain.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 -- Alvin Dark broke the National League record for homers by a shortstop in one season as the Giants downed the Pirates by 6 -- 2 tonight. Dark's twenty-third round-tripper surpassed the mark of twenty-two, set in 1930 by Glenn Wright, then with the Dodgers.

Daylight saving time will end tomorrow at 2 A. M. in New York and ten other states and in some communities in eleven other states. Most of the 60,000,000 Americans who lost an hour of sleep when summer time went into effect April 26 will set their clocks and watches back one hour tonight before going to bed and will enjoy the annual luxury of an extra hour's Sunday morning sleep.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 25 (AP) -- William M. Wickham's White Skies came within two-fifths of a second of his track record of 1:22 3/5 to win the first running of the $21,750 T. R. A. stakes before 10,981 fans today. The 4-year-old colt outran his four rivals to reach the end of the seven furlongs five lengths clear of Mrs. Samuel M. Pistorio's Tuscany.
Progress was reported yesterday by William Zeckendorf, head of Webb Knapp, Inc., on the company's plan for a helicopter center on the roof of the proposed twenty-story, merchandise mart here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today rejected a request by preferred stockholders of Wisconsin Central Railway Company for permission to inspect the ballots in a recent vote on a reorganization plan for the railroad.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Diplomatic authorities said today that a proposal for a joint international guarantee of a free but neutral Korea was one of the plans under consideration by the United States for presentation to the prospective Korean political conference.

BERLIN, Sept. 25 -- Although thousands of East Germans appear to have resigned from collective farms in the last three months the Communists are renewing their drive, in abeyance since last spring, to expand the collectivization program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Four straight singles off Marion Fricano with one out in the ninth inning gave the Senators a 1-0 victory over the Athletics tonight as Bob Porterfield posted his twenty-second victory and his ninth shutout.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Henry L. McCarthy, Commissioner of Welfare of New York, made a scathing attack here today on what he called "sob-story give-away programs" before welfare workers.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Israel went ahead today with plans to divert Jordan River waters for a hydroelectric project after rejecting a plea by a United Nations representative that it be called off.

Since deafness was once considered an indication of mental retardation and the deaf were regarded as uneducable, many even yet hesitate to admit that they are becoming deaf, it was suggested yesterday at the opening of the National Hearing Aid Show at the Commodore Hotel.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 25 -- Refugees streaming into Medan, capital of North Sumatra, told today of fanatical bands, including women and children, hurling themselves against police and army posts in what seemed to be a coordinated series of attacks.

Perhaps no suggestion by former President Truman received wider support than the one called Point Four, which Mr. Truman described in his Inaugural Address of Jan. 20, 1949, as "a bold new program for making the profits of our scientific advances and industrial progress available for the improvement and growth of the underdeveloped areas."

A 17-year-old youth was arrested last night shortly after he had returned with a rifle to a Bronx candy store from which he had been barred, and fired five bullets at the proprietor. The shop owner was not hurt.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 25 -- Arab radio reports said today that Syria had canceled all army leaves as a result of Israel's rejection of a United Nations request to stop work on a canal near the Syrian border.

The pending issue of New Jersey Turnpike Authority revenue bonds will consist of $150,000,000 of thirty-five-year term obligations, it was reported in under-writing circles yesterday. About $30,000,000 of the proceeds will be used to refund 1 7/8 per cent bonds due in 1958.

SAIGON, Vietman, Sept. 25 -- An attempt to encircle and destroy 5,000 Communist-led Vietminh troops in part of the delta area southeast of Hanoi has apparently failed as the French reported only light skirmishing today. The goal of the drive in the area appeared to have been met for the moment, however.

Again the time has come to give a financial helping hand to the organization that last year put forward a welcoming and helping hand to the greatest flood of travelers in its history. The Travelers Aid Society of New York, Inc., last year gave assistance to 210,000 persons, a number 70 per cent higher than in any previous peacetime year.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to homemakers:

With a starting line-up that includes only four men who played in the 1952 opener, Columbia begins its sixty-third football season today when it engages Lehigh at Baker Field. It will mark Columbia's twenty-fourth consecutive campaign under Coach Lou Little.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Three big airlines engaged in another extended word battle today before the Civil Aeronautics Board for lucrative routes in the Far East.

The sirens sounded yesterday and it seemed as though a cloud of death had descended upon the city and its environs. Automobiles drew up to the curb and their passengers moved quickly to cover. Trucks and buses halted their ceaseless din. The sidewalks were cleared of pedestrians.

Magistrate Paul Balsam in Lower Manhattan Court suspended sentence yesterday on eleven women found guilty there on Monday of disorderly conduct while picketing the United Nations headquarters Aug. 31.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The National Science Foundation announced today creation of a permanent advisory panel on minerals research to advise on development of a policy on basic research in minerals discovery and exploration.

College football's first Saturday of general participation presents a spicy menu today, the piece de resistance of which is the contest between Notre Dame and Oklahoma. This clash of titans at Norman has the Sooner state completely agog and commands the keen interest of a considerable portion of the gridiron-loving populace everywhere.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25 -- The American Federation of Labor's new dock union set up business today with 10,000 members in Great Lakes and Mississippi River ports.
For the best part of fifteen minutes yesterday morning, New York was as quiet as a prairie as the city went through its third and biggest civil defense training exercise against atom bombing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The immediate price of liquidating the Technical Cooperation Administration, which was the machinery for operating the Point Four program, has been a drastic drop in morale among the old personnel of the agency still remaining in service.

THERE are still a few weekends available for reconnaissance before the opening of the upland game season in New York, and those who have failed to locate "open" hunting areas within a few hours' drive are almost certain to be disappointed on opening day, for posting signs have increased in many near-by counties.

Carnegie Hall, which is papered some of the time, partly empty a good deal of the time, and filled to capacity only now and then, sold out last evening at a $6 top. What is more, the box-office until program time was besieged by latecomers pleading, some with tears in their eyes, for tickets.
TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 26 (AP) -- A typhoon left at least twenty-nine Japanese dead, 115 missing and 116 injured as it flooded and pounded a hundred towns and villages in southern Japan yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 25 -- Yugoslavia has handed the United States, Britain and France an exceedingly strong aide memoire on the subject of Trieste. She formally accused the three powers of unfairly favoring Italy in the dispute.

A legal battle for several million dollars left by the late Orlando Weber Jr., ornithologist, actor and son of the founder of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation, seemed likely yesterday as a petition to probate his will was filed in Surrogate's Court.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Following are excerpts from the translation of an address in French today by Maurice Schumann, French Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, to the United Nations General Assembly.

In a temperate, reasoned and perfectly logical opinion the New York Board of Regents, which governs our educational institutions, has reached the decision that the Communist parties of the United States and the State of New York are subversive in that "they advocate, teach and embrace the doctrine that the Government of the United States should be overthrown by force and violence."

GENEVA Sept. 25 -- Britain's effort to obtain agreement of other countries to the raising of certain tariff duties has run into such severe and largely unexpected opposition that further discussion of the problem by a committee of the contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has been postponed for several days.

The General Telephone Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday an increase in consolidated net income for the first eight months of this year to $8,585,000 from $5,340,000 for the corresponding period a year ago.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Sept. 25 -- David J. McDonald, president of the United Steelworkers, C. I. O., served notice on the American Federation of Labor today that it could not expect to swallow up C. I. O. unions in the process of unification.

There'll be a three-stake jamboree at Belmont Park today. Greentree Stable's Tom Fool, the champion handicapper, heads the line-up in the $50,000 added Sysonby. Mrs. George D. Widener's unbeaten 2-year-old filly, Evening Out, is among the entrants in the $25,000 added Matron, the "filly futurity." And Charfran Stable's Crafty Admiral, the top money-winner of last year, is one of the ten named for the $25,000 added New York Handicap.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- United States exports declined $30,000,000 in July to $1,346,300,000, the Bureau of the Census reported today. Imports also dropped during the month to $907,900,000.

Granted that our election laws accord any individual the right to seek public office, it seems too bad that Robert Granville Burke should have waited until this particular election to project his candidacy for the office of Borough President of Manhattan.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 25 -- Grant Golden of Wilmette, Ill., won the men's doubles championship in Partnership with Pablo Eisenberg of Princeton at the tennis tourney of the Maccabiah Games today and then teamed with Anita Kantor of San Francisco to win the final in the mixed doubles. Golden will try to make it a clean sweep tomorrow when he faces the South African Davis Cup player, Syd Levy, in the singles final.

Proposals for higher New York Stock Exchange commissions returned to the Wall Street spotlight yesterday, Keith Funston, president, notified the membership that a new schedule, providing for an over-all increase of 18 per cent, will be discussed at a policy meeting of the board of governors on Thursday, Oct. 15.

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 26 -- The Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission in Korea, holding the prisoners of war who refuse to return to their homelands, delayed today the beginning of the "explanation'' sessions during which United Nations and Communist representatives are to try to convince reluctant prisoners from their respective forces to change their minds.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -- On Franklin Field tomorrow, George Munger will unveil what is expected to be the last Pennsylvania football team he will coach, with Vanderbilt as the opening opponent on one of the most difficult schedules the Red and Blue has undertaken.

Mayor Impellitteri has taken a scrupulously correct position in response to Michael J. Quill's request that he appoint an arbitration panel to sit on the controversy over economizing schedules on subways and buses proposed by the New York City Transit Authority.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner heard testimony today for and against a proposal by the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad to use its stock holdings in the New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad to elect two directors in that company.

TANANARIVE, Madagascar, Sept. 25 (Reuters) -- Fishermen from the Comoro Islands caught a coelacanth, a prehistoric fish thought to be a "missing link" in man's evolution, off the East African coast yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Submarines and mine laying aircraft of the Orange, or "enemy," forces caused the theoretical closing to shipping of the Port of Milford Haven on the Western Atlantic approaches and the diversion of convoys as Exercise Mariner continued today.

WASHINGTON, Sept 25 (AP) -- A close friend of Fred M. Vinson said today the Chief Justice expressed deep concern just before his death because there was no pension protection for widows of Federal judges.

Always THE TIMES lives up to its motto: "All the News That's Fit to Print." Were it not for this policy I would never have known of an excellent proposal for striking right at the heart of inefficiency in the government of our city. I refer to an item tucked away on page 28 of your edition of Sept. 21, headlined "Burke Urges Review of City Job Seekers."

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 25 -- Communist saboteurs in the Iranian Air Force succeeded in disabling most of the planes assigned to carry out aerial surveillance of the potentially rebellious Ghashghai tribesmen of South Central Iran last Tuesday night, it was learned today.
The dramatic rescue of the crew of the freighter Greenville in eighty-five-mile an-hour winds and fifty-foot waves was told last night upon the arrival of the French liner Ile de France.

A thirty-hour marathon negotiating session ending at 9 o'clock last night produced a tentative agreement between the management of the Arma Corporation and the Engineers Association of Arma, thus clearing the path for the settlement of a nine-week violence - ridden strike affecting 5,000 workers at the company's two plants.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25 -- President Juan Peron announced today that he had instructed Minister of the Interior Angel Borlenghi to draw up an amnesty law to free all of Argentina's political prisoners and permit return of hundreds of Argentines living in exile.
LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Neutralization of Formosa, a delay in German rearmament and a review the British defense program a salient points in the British Labor party's foreign policy platform.

James J. Parker, 201 1/2 pounds, Paterson, gained an unpopular split decision over Jimmy Slade, 177, Bronx, in the ten-round feature bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night before a crowd of approximately 1,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Maxwell Rabb, White House race relations specialist, said today that a "complete and thorough analysis" of segregation of Negro and white patients in Veterans Administration hospitals was under way. The aim, he said, was to work out a technique by which to carry out President Eisenhower's order to eliminate segregation in the hospitals.

Modern furniture has now become a "period style" itself, David Brunn of the Drexel Furniture Company said this week at one of a series of breakfast meetings at the National Home Furnishings Show at Grand Central Palace. Trends in furniture and carpeting observed at the show were discussed by manufacturing officials, store executives and designers. Newspaper and magazine representatives attended the sessions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, told the North Carolina Democratic Club tonight that he strongly believed "we are on the way toward healing, once and for all, this old North-South cleavage that has plagued us for so long."

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, declared yesterday after witnessing the city's civil defense test that New York needed more shelters, hospitals -- particularly hospital annexes -- firefighting equipment and civilian defense volunteers.

When Prime Minister St. Laurent urged the United States "to maintain a strong bias toward freer trade in their commercial policies" in his address to the International Municipal Congress at Montreal he asked on behalf of Canada "no special favors" that would not be granted other free nations.

The Government's waterfront rackets investigation was accelerated sharply yesterday when a special Federal grand jury met in an unusual all-day session, questioned Joseph P. Ryan, head of the independent International Longshoremen's Association, and then handed up a sealed indictment against a "well-known waterfront racketeer."

MOSCOW, Saturday, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov's Government took another major step today to aid Soviet peasants. It announced big increases in prices for livestock products to step up lagging production and raise living standards.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- Reports of improvement in demand for flour had a stimulating effect on the wheat market here today. There was not much inclination to press the selling side of the market in view of the possibilities in the Government's surplus food program and in view of the fact that the Government owns so much wheat.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25 (UP) -- The Browns' stockholders voted today to change the club's charter to authorize its president, Bill Veeck, to move the franchise to another city.

Should Casey Stengel again direct the American League forces in next summer's all-star game, you can make a little wager right now that heading his choice of pitchers will be the name of Mel Parnell, written in large letters.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, announced yesterday that Senator Charles E. Potter of Michigan, his fellow-member on the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, has assumed chairmanship of a new Senate agency to investigate atrocities in Korea and the continued detention of prisoners of war.
BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 25 (UP) -- Two of the four top-seeded Americans fought their way into the semi-finals of the Pacific Coast tennis championships today.

Van Johnson, Hollywood luminary, is considering "Li'l Abner," the musical version of Al Capp's popular cartoon, as a vehicle for his return to the Broadway stage. The actor's interest in the musical is such that he has agreed to dye his blond hair black for the title role.

LONDON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- The Government of the Soviet Republic of Georgia has ousted three more ministers appointed by Lavrenti P. Beria, imprisoned former head of the Ministry of Internal Affairs, the Tiflis radio said today.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 -- Spokesmen for California farmers asserted today that the illegal influx of 100,000 or more Mexicans every month into the Southwest was only a "minor" phase of a problem lying chiefly in the lap of United States industry and commerce.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- The Department of Labor reported today that the average factory work week was unchanged between mid-July and mid-August at 40.5 hours. Normally a seasonal increase is registered. In most years since World War II the end of the vacation period and expansion of production for the fall buying season combined to lengthen the work week in August.

Aircrafts took over the stock market yesterday, pushing forward vigorously and accounting for a high proportion of the volume. Nine of the fifteen most active issues of the day were aircraft or aircraft parts makers and all nine were higher, gaining fractions to as much as a point, in the case of Boeing.

A new waterfront union, chartered yesterday by the American Federation of Labor to replace the ousted International Longshoremen's Association, immediately opened its fight for power on the docks controlled by the older, racket-infested union.

Four weeks of studying the American dairy industry ended yesterday for twenty cheese manufacturers, dairy technologists and scientists from Switzerland who were feted at breakfast in Altman's Charleston Gardens. The breakfast, designed to make the visitors feel at home, consisted of substantial native dishes to which the Swiss Consul General, Fred Gygaz, attributed his country's stability -- and copious waistlines.

There is no need to worry about the ability of advertising to meet present-day challenges so long as management provides backing and understanding, C. B. Larrabee, president and publisher of Printer's Ink, declared yesterday at a luncheon session of the 342d meeting of the National Industrial Conference Board in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ROME, Sept. 25 -- The three-day visit of Alexander Papagos, Greek Premier and Stephanos Stephanopoulos, Greek Foreign Minister to Italy, ended this evening with a cordial communique underlining among other things that the two countries were determined to continue strengthening western security through the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

PRINCETON, Sept. 25 -- Shooting for victory No. 31 in thirty- two starts, Princeton will rule a heavy favorite over Lafayette here tomorrow when the Tigers open their eighty-fifth season of intercollegiate football.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- The New Jersey Director of Motor Vehicles urged New York today to adopt a program of compulsory twice-a-year inspection of motor vehicles such as was in effect in his state. The system, he said, had slashed the New Jersey highway death toll.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- A mechanical substitute for the heart and lungs was patented this week by Abraham E. Chesler of Woodmere, L. I. The inventor intends it to supply blood circulation "for humans and other animals" during heart surgery or at other times when doctors want to halt heart action.

Prices of steel scrap dropped $3 to $6 a ton in the Pittsburgh area yesterday, to the lowest levels since shortly before the Korean war began. The new price cuts brought reductions in the last month to $10 to $12 a ton -- one of the most rapid scrap price declines in years.

As parents have probably suspected for some time, children have definite likes, even when it comes to colors used in their rooms. Parents who plan to redecorate their offspring's quarters this autumn might heed some advice given by a group of color and child development experts.

With Lloyd Mangrum as the captain, eight members of the United States Ryder Cup team of golf professionals left New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, late yesterday in a British Overseas Airways plane for England for a renewal of the series with the British.
If you found it too hot to work in those late August and early September days with the mercury between 90 and 100 degrees, you were not alone. So did the hens.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture, in a move to hold down Government spending and encourage lending by private agencies, today increased fees paid banks for handling farm price support loans. Banks now get 2 1/2 per cent of the 4 per cent interest rate charged farmers for price support loans on grains and other commodities.
ALBANY, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Divers searched today for the body of a crew member believed lost when a southbound oil barge rammed the end of a line of wheat barges in the Hudson River here.

TORONTO, Sept. 25--Canada's ports are free from the extortionist practices plaguing some United States waterfronts, Dominion Transport Minister Lionel Chervier told the American Association of Port Authorities here tonight.
TORONTO, Sept. 25 -- For operating a price-fixing combine, five leading Canadian rubber manufacturers were fined $10,000 each today.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 25 -- High Indian circles welcomed today a suggestion for unification and neutralization of Korea under international guarantees.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Sept. 25 -- Field Marshal Sir John Harding, chief of Britain's Imperial General Staff, said today Yugoslavia had the "makings of a powerful modern army." and Maj. Gen. Charles Palmer, Chief of Staff of the United States Army field forces, declared the Yugoslav Army was handling well the heavy American equipment of guns, trucks and tanks it was receiving in aid.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25 -- The American Federation of Labor ended its annual convention today by giving its unanimous support to Martin P. Durkin's charge that President Eisenhower had reneged on an agreement to send Congress a specific list of recommendations for changes in the Taft-Hartley Act.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 25 -- A program of a type normally associated with such imposingly avant-garde organizations as the Museum of Modern Art brought to a conclusion the three-day South Mountain Thirty-fifth Anniversary Festival. This afternoon's concert expanded from chamber music to chamber orchestral music, as Milton Katims led a small ensemble through Stravinsky's "Apollon Musagete," Hindemith's "Herodiade" and Respighi's "Trittico Botticelliano."

Dr. Marek Stanislaw Korowicz, the international law expert who deserted the Polish Delegation to the United Nations on Sept. 18 and requested political asylum in the United States, announced last night the receipt of an air-mail, registered letter from his former students in Communist Poland congratulating him on his escape.

To the practical minded progress no doubt is a good thing. The airplane is faster than the car, and that in turn can beat the horse. So can the tractor, on the farm. To the practical all of this is good, for speed is time and time is money, and there is indeed little enough of that commodity lying about free for the picking.
I have been traveling in Germany this summer, where I got a first-hand impression of the amazing recovery of that country.

Today's new film is a Russian import, "Vasili's Return," at the stanley. The Mosfilm Production star Sergel Lukyanov and was written by Galina Nikolovich and E. Gabrilovich from the novel, "Harvest," by Miss Nikolovich. "Vasili's Return" is the last directorial effort of the late Vsevolod Pudovkin.

A score of parents from Boulevard Houses, a city housing project in Brooklyn where one case of poliomyelitis occurred this week, prepared to spend last night at Health Department headquarters, 125 Worth Street, after the city and state Health Commissioners had turned down their demand for a special allotment of gamma globulin for their children.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, said today he would press the Department of Agriculture for a prompt report on what it plans to do about a big increase in Canadian rye grain imports.

The State Harness Racing Commission yesterday ordered the licensing of all employes at trotting tracks in the state as it held its first public session in the inquiry centering on hiring practices, payments to labor "trouble shooters," and stock ownership at Yonkers Raceway.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Next June's college crop will find jobs paying up to $375 a month, Philip H. Yost of the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company declares. He has just completed a study of the answers to questionnaires sent to 145 major companies by the Midwestern Placement Association.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- Pierre Voizard, who is scheduled to leave tomorrow for Tunisia to take up his duties as French Resident General, declared today that his first essential task would be to maintain order in the protectorate.
WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Ankaway captured the $5,000 Nevada Pace by a length over Bernard Hanover in 2:04 1/5 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Stanton Hal finished third.

The Avco Manufacturing Corporation increased its net sales to $312,728,859 in the nine months ended on Aug. 31 from the $219,939,742 volume of the same period last year, but earnings were reduced by strikes at company plants.

A new section is being opened this week-end by Marvin Glickman in his Tanglewood Park colony in Babylon, L. I., where the first section of twenty-eight dwellings has been sold. The houses, priced at $12,990, are offered through Gale-Oppenheimer.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 25 -- India's Untouchables, the depressed class that for ages has been beyond the pale of Hindu society, have apparently won one of their greatest victories over ancient prejudice as a result of last week's assault upon the revered Acharya Vinoba Bhave by a band of Brahmin temple priests.

A four-way contest for each of two Supreme Court vacancies in the First Judicial District, consisting of Manhattan and the Bronx, appeared assured last night when the Republican and Liberal parties named their judicial tickets. The Democratic and American Labor slates had been nominated earlier in the week.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Stockholders of General Motors Corporation at a special meeting today overwhelmingly approved a modification of the pension plan for hourly rated employes which provided for an increase in monthly payments from $1.50 to $1.75 for each year of service up to thirty.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (UP) -- Lefty Harvey Haddix pitched his twentieth victory of the season today as the Cardinals pounded out nineteen hits off four Cub hurlers for an 11-to-2 triumph.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Saturday, Sept. 26 -- Thousands of angry anti-Communist prisoners of the Korean war rioted and clashed with Indian custodial troops yesterday and captured an Indian major as hostage, it was revealed today. The riot was finally put down through the bravery of Maj. Gen. S. P. P. Thorat, commanding general of the Indian troops.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Al Rosen took the American League home-run lead tonight with Nos. 42 and 43 as the Indians drubbed the Tigers, 12 -- 3, with Rookie Dick Tomanek, a 23-year-old southpaw just up from Indianapolis, on the mound.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- British and American negotiators reached a provisional agreement today on a new one-year agreement for motion picture films.

Rudolph Halley, Liberal party candidate for Mayor, charged last night that Robert F. Wagner Jr., his Democratic opponent, "lied" in saying Mr. Halley had approached Democratic leaders and asked them for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 25 -- Ralph S. Damon, president of Trans World Airlines, declared tonight that the strength of this country "lies in the outstanding opportunities which are offered under a system of fair competition and free enterprise."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet delegate to the United Nations, said today that the Soviet Union's attitude to a unified Korea, with an international guarantee of its neutrality, would depend upon "concrete proposals."

BONN, Germany, Sept. 25 -- Opinion is being mobilized in West Germany to prevent the establishment of an information ministry, which its opponents fear might infringe the freedom of the press and provide the framework for a future propaganda apparatus of the Goebbels type.
A continuing jurisdictional conflict between the National Labor Relations Board and the State Labor Relations Board was reported yesterday to Governor Dewey by state board members.

Robert E. Sherwood, author of a long list of successful plays, three of which won Pulitzer prizes, was taken yesterday by his 5-year-old grandson, Joe Stillman, to see Joe's kind of show -- the Rodeo at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Federal Bar Association voted overwhelmingly today to oppose the proposed Bricker amendment to restrict the President's treaty-making powers.
Negotiations are under way for the sale of The Brooklyn Eagle to The New York Herald Tribune, it was disclosed yesterday by Frank D. Schroth Sr., publisher of The Eagle.

WEST POINT, Sept. 26 -- As far as Col. Earl (Red) Blaik is concerned the two-platoon system is still much in existence. The principal exponent of the platoons, Blaik employed the system as often as possible today as his Army outfit began its 1953 drive by beating Furman University, 41 -- 0, before a gathering of 8,450 at Michie Stadium.

TO the average small American there is something startling -- almost shocking, indeed -- in the first knowledge that such familiar things as ice-cream, firecrackers and baby carriages are not wholly American. Madeleine Gekiere's unusual picture book is designed partly as a quiz game and partly as a first step toward under
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Now that the war guns are silent in Korea, the trade guns -- directed against Britain -- are opening up in Japan.

In behalf of the New York City Hospital Visiting Committee, a member of the State Charities Aid Association, a luncheon and fashion Show will be held Oct. 21 in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre. Mrs. Eric Moederle and Mrs. Ralph F. Waltz are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -- The number of cases pending in the Federal courts has increased to the point that justice is sometimes denied to the litigants seeking it.

The receipt of two grants totaling $44,500 from the Fund for the Republic to advance Columbia University's bicentennial theme, "Man's Right to Knowledge and the Free Use Thereof," was announced yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of the university.

THESE are the American Years. During the past two and a half decades thinking people have been reading history again for the first time in half a century, consciously or unconsciously hoping thereby to find in our origins a clue to the understanding of contemporary difficulties and, from the thoughts and doings of famous men of former periods of turmoil and doubt, some comforts to buttress a sagging confidence in our own times.

" NO man but a blockhead," Dr. Johnson observed, "ever wrote except for money." And yet the members of Mystery Writers of America, Inc., as money-minded a group as exists (with the slogan of "Crime does not pay -- enough"), combine every year to produce an anthology out of which none of the contributors -- not even the harried editor -- makes a cent.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Ohio State's Buckeyes struck twice through the air and three times on the ground today to beat Indiana, 36 -- 12, in a Western Conference opener before a crowd of 75,898.

A trend toward the use of foreign-flag ships by American importers of dry cargo and petroleum products has accelerated and is one of the problems in the over-all study of the American merchant marine now being conducted by the Senate Subcommittee on Maritime Subsidies, according to Senator Charles E. Potter, Republican of Michigan.

ANY great enterprise which has to struggle to overcome its inherent difficulties as well as obstructions raised by opponents naturally undergoes moments of doubt and let-down. This is especially true when such an enterprise is a collective project, depending for success on half a dozen governments and a dozen legislative bodies, each subject to more or less frequent changes.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Sept. 26 Indiana University announced today that it would investigate nearly 400 cases in which American Indians were suing the United States for the difference between what their ancestors got for selling their land to the Government and the price they say they have received.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The White House still insists that President Eisenhower has not changed the practice of holding a news conference once a week, but the statistics of his first eight months in office show that he has held only fourteen thus far, or less than two a month.

PALO ALTO, Calif. AT Stanford one factor stands out in dress -- and that is casualness. Because fall here is a warm season, the white shirt with open collar, the cashmere sweater, blue jeans, denims or flannel slacks are standard garb for campus wear.

BACH: Little Organ Fugue in G Minor; MOZART: Marriage of Figaro Overture; BEETHOVEN: Contradanse No. 1; SIBELIUS: Valse Triste; etc., Concert Trio (Capri). The trio, two accordions and double-bass, is nexpectedly effective in the G 1Vfinor fugue, its reedy tones rather suggesting a baroque organ. When the' subject enters in the bass, however, one misses the weight of a 3Z-foot pedal bourdon. An odd, engaging piece of work.

The Right Rev. Wilburn Camrock Campbell, Bishop Coadjutor of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of West Virginia, charged yesterday that the Nationalist Government of South Africa had "silenced" an informal radio interview with him on the ground that the broadcast contained "propaganda of religious significance."

WITH its inciting title, its full-blooded writing, and its lurid heroine, Mr. Wellman's new jumbo historical can hardly fail to attract a wide following among those lovers of derring-do who give top priority to sensation.

IN this sequel to "Slipper Under Glass" Maggie Jones comes to New York to be a featured comedy dancer in moving picture. Every detail of dancing in the movies and on television programs is correct, but unfortunately the premise of the book -- that comedy dancing is just awkward clowning -- is preposterous.

SOME interesting developments in the design of men's clothes are likely to take place in the next few years, what with more and more designers of women's wear turning their talents to the sartorial problems of the male.

THE International Festival of Contemporary Music at Venice is over as far as the claims of its name go. What remains for the audiences, worn out by ten days of the unfamiliar, are the easy pleasures of Mozart and Brahms, Ravel and Debussy, conducted by von Karajan; Venetian church music in St. Mark's, and the New York City Ballet.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 26 (UP) -- Syracuse opened the defense of its Eastern football championship in impressive style before 18,000 fans in Archbold Stadium tonight, rolling over the Temple Owls, 42 -- 0. It was the tenth straight victory for the Orange over an Eastern foe.

EARLY this month Denmark honored her greatest composer, Carl Nielsen (1865-1931), by a week of festival performances. Despite slender advance publicity, the packed audiences contained a fair sprinkling of foreigners.
COLUMBIA, Mo., Sept. 26 (AP)-- Missouri's fired-up and desperately battling Tigers upset the Purdue Boilermakers, 14 -- 7, in impressive fashion before 20,000 today.
Hobart College's football team, scoring once in each of the first three periods, downed Brooklyn College, 20 -- 0, yesterday at the loser's field in the opening game for both teams.

DOCTORS are generally chary of the so-called "home medical adviser," giving imposing lists of symptoms with a tremendous allure for the hypochondriac and neurotic but not too much practical advice about what the patient himself can do to help the physician effect a cure.

IT all started with an idea for a radio program. As Thomas Scherman tells it, he began dreaming and thinking about the uses and advantages of a small orchestra when he was a student at the Mannes School. After the war he approached some of the executives at Station WQXR with a suggestion for a live series by a small orchestra.

OYSTER BAY, L. I. Sept. 26 -- Maybe VII, owned by William Horton of California and sailed by Herman (Swede) Whiton easily won the first of two races for the national small boat open championship today.

PHILADELPHIA this Saturday night gets the first chance to draw the bead on "The Ladies of the Corridor," the Dorothy Parker-Arnaud d'Usseau play which producer Walter Fried is aiming for an Oct. 21 opening at the reclaimed Longacre Theatre.

TO be known as the "Fiestas of the Fifth Sun," one of the most spectacular expositions in Mexico's history will be staged from Oct. 11 to 31. A series of colorful affairs will be presented in and around Mexico City depicting the country's customs, arts and history from the lost civilizations of long ago to the present time.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- Frustrated by ineptness at the plate in the clutch and by the pitching of Curt Simmons, the Dodgers were beaten by the Phils, 2 -- 1, in the tenth inning tonight, enabling the home team to tie the Cardinals for third place.

ON the West Coast fuchsias bloom unsparingly and are one of our most versatile performers. And although they are flowering now in the East, I hear that there the comparatively short season will end soon.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 26 -- The Government of Thailand is making arrangements to facilitate the removal of the first 200 members of the irregular Chinese Nationalist forces from northern Burma on Oct. 5, it was reported today by a high Thai official.

HAVANA, Sept. 23 -- Cuba is no longer a nerve center of Communist activity in this hemisphere, according to Col. Manuel Ugalde Carrillo, chief of the Military Intelligence Service of the Cuban armed forces. Since March 10, 1952, when General Fulgencio Batista seized power from President Carlos Prio Socarras, the Government's campaign against the Reds has reduced them to a condition almost of impotency, Colonel Ugalde said.

SOME twenty-odd years ago the Chicago White Sox had two catchers of approximately equal ability. One was Moe Berg, graduate of Princeton and the Sorbonne, a linguist of such formidable stature that he speaks or understands almost a dozen languages. The other was Buck Crouse who thought the English language was baffling enough.

SHADE trees become prey to many ills. Disease and insects shorten their lives and every year exact a terrific toll. Of all these menaces the arch foes are three internal fungus diseases: Dutch elm disease, oak wilt and maple wilt.

NILES, Mich., Sept. 26 (UP) -- A hold-up man was shot to death in a roadside gun battle today after an eight-hour spree of kidnapping and auto theft in which he captured two policemen and snapped their own handcuffs on their wrists.

THIS long, ambitious and intermittently exciting novel by Ira Wolfert is so confused, or at any rate so complicated, that it can best be summarized in terms of the more conventional novel that, for better or for worse, he didn't write.

SWEET WILL is with us again (though he has never really left us), this time in THE NONESUCH SHAKESPEARE (four volumes, $35), designed by Sir Francis Meynell and with an introduction by Ivor Brown, and distributed by Random House.

THERE was a "whooshing noise like the rushing of wind" and then in the pasture, still spinning, was the biggest top Johnny had ever seen -- as wide as the side of a barn, as high as a barn door and as blue as the twilight.

CAIRO, Sept. 26 -- Ibrahim Abdel Hadi, former Premier and chief of the Royal Cabinet in 1948-49, pleaded not guilty today to all charges in a six-count indictment accusing him of treason, corruption, terrorism, graft and complicity in murder as his trial opened before the newly constituted Revolution Tribunal.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 26 -- The Communist sponsorship of Indian membership in an enlarged political conference on Korea has resulted in another victory for the Communists and a setback for the United States on the propaganda front. Once again it has been made to appear that Russia and her satellites are more solicitous of Asian feelings than is the United States.

Southeast Asia, South Asia, Japan and the Philippines are to be given individual attention at the annual Far East conference of the Far East-American Council on Oct. 8 and 9 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Every once in a while a number of events coincide in such a way that it is possible to say that they have changed the trend, at least temporarily, of the world struggle. These past nine months have been such a time.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Congestion from visitors in the corridors at United Nations headquarters has reached the point at which the guided tour service now resorts to a "traffic cop" at peak intervals. The hub station is a midway point on the third-floor level, at which the clockwise and counter-clockwise routes that have been worked out reach a junction.

ANDREW CARNEGIE, the steelmaster, told Gladstone in 1887 that he would "consider it disgraceful to die a rich man." And, as Howard J. Savage puts it, "no man ever worked harder or more constantly than Andrew Carnegie" at the self-appointed task of giving.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Now it is official that the husband of a woman official takes his wife's rank, just as vice versa.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 26 -- Plans for establishing a West German information ministry, which its opponents feared might infringe freedom of the press and gradually develop into a propaganda apparatus of the Goebbels type, appeared today to have been quashed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The signing today of the United States-Spanish accords on military bases and aid came about after months of "exploration" and a year and a half of negotiation.

CHARLOTTEEVILLE, Va., Sept. 26 (UP) -- Jack Williams, 22-year-old junior from Lake Wales, Fla., stepped in as quarterback for Virginia Tech's injured star, Johnny Dean, today and led the Gobblers to their first victory over Virginia in eleven years, 20 -- 6.

DESPITE the seven million homes constructed in this country within the last seven years, the building industry has been unable to keep pace with record population growth. The result: More people per room in houses and apartments today than at any other time in the recent past and more different activities going on simultaneously within limited quarters.

During the Republicans' twenty-year travail in the political wilderness, one of their major burdens was the "anti-labor" brand stamped on the G. O. P. by the Democrats. General Eisenhower tried hard to cast off the stigma in the campaign last fall, and shortly after his election made a large gesture in labor's direction.

The West last week was embarked upon a new approach to the problem of how to deal with the Communists -- an approach that could cast the world struggle into a wholly different perspective. In the two most critical theatres of struggle -- the Far East and Europe -- it moved to seize the initiative for peace.

DES MOINES, Sept. 26 -- Secretary Benson has been receiving considerable criticism in Iowa in recent months and most of it seems to have been caused by what he has said, or neglected to say, rather than what he has done.

A DETAILED survey of the causes of all the fatal accidents reported on the roads of Pennsylvania in the space of one month offers overwhelming evidence that man, rather than the machine, is the factor that must be reckoned with in any effort to reduce the nation's traffic toll.

Mr. Sykes' review does not present relevant facts that are important. Almost a hundred years ago (in 1857) Gen. Ethan Allen Hitchcock's book "Remarks Upon Alchemy and the Alchemists" was published in Boston.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 -- Back in April, when the dizzy whirl began, the Giants would have snickered at anyone brash enough to predict a fifth-place finish for Leo Durocher's athletes. Today they were happy to attain it. For with a 5-3 victory over the Pirates at Forbes Field the New Yorkers clinched the top spot in the second division of the National League.

A television antenna manufacturing company that began doing business inconspicuously in a barn under the direction of two farmers, and in an area that does not have television, will mark its sixth year of operation this week by opening a new $1,500,000 manufacturing plant and a $500,000 aluminum extrusion mill.

MISS BAUM'S new novel will be considered, I suspect, one of the strangest books of the year. It may be also one of the most valuable. it is certainly one of the most gripping. Full of clinical character studies and shattering revelations, it is on one level a sort of neurological detective story concerning the adventures of an Italian faith-healer's attempts to cure a schizophrenic war veteran in Los Angeles.

A survey to determine the amount of narcotic addiction among pupils in the academic, vocational and junior high schools of the city was ordered yesterday by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools.

ESKIMOS living in the tiny villages scattered throughout the vast Arctic regions of Alaska are playing these days a little-known but vital role in the defense of the United States, a land which most of them have never even seen. They are serving as ears and eyes of the defense forces in this area where Asia and Europe reach closest to the North American continent over the short polar routes.

In a letter to THE TIMES of Sept. 20 one of your correspondents sounded a timely admonition that the country in its preoccupation with security and economic affairs should not neglect to take the long view toward conservation of its most important resource, the human being.

MADISON, Wis. ALTHOUGH men's styles in general will continue conservative on the University of Wisconsin campus this fall, male students will not dress as conservatively as their Eastern counterparts. The Wisconsin brand of student conservatism is born more of frugality than a desire to keep up with the national trend.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 26 -- Turkey's third largest political party, the Nation party, accused by the Government of being the principal champion of religious reaction in this secular republic, went on trial for its life today before the Ankara Court of Peace.

THIS is Mr. Auchincloss' fourth book and let it be said at once that it is not the major novel we have been waiting for. Yet parts of it are so impressive and the work as a whole so assured, that it further whets our appetite for the big book still to come.

WITH this third volume, in which he analyzes the international impact of the new Soviet regime, Edward Hallett Carr has completed a monumental and frequently brilliant history of the first six years of Soviet rule, the period of Lenin's dominant leadership. His first volume traced the evolution of the Bolshevik Revolution into the monolithic party-state and the reassembling under Soviet control of the principal fragments of the former empire.
PRINCETON, N. J. MEN'S fashions at Princeton are based on the maxim that dress should be distinctive and original within certain well-defined limits governed by an impeccably conservative good taste.

An English contract bridge team outscored an American team in a bidding contest, held simultaneously in London and New York, that ended, on the American side of the ocean, in the early hours on Friday. The Americans had started at 9 o'clock Thursday night.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 26 -- Richard C. Lee, Democratic candidate for Mayor, who lost the election by the slim margin of two votes two years ago, has entered the mayoralty race here again this year.

THE N. B. C. television network and the Mutual Broadcasting System will provide the TV and radio coverage of the world series baseball games between the Yankees and the Dodgers, starting Wednesday. Broadcast time will be 12:45 on weekdays. If a game is played on Sunday, air time will be 1:45. For video Mel Allen and Vince Scully will supply the commentary. On radio it will be Al Helfer and Gene Kelly.

MOST of the major Western railroads put into effect last week a family-fare plan for Pullman travel similar to that announced by the Union Pacific earlier this month. At the same time it was made known that on Oct. 19 the plan would be extended generally to coach travel in the West.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 26 -- Ore consumption by blast furnaces using Lake Superior ore dipped last month, and a further decline is anticipated for September because of curtailment of operations by a number of steel plants.

DALLAS, Tex. COMFORT is the keynote at Southern Methodist, with styles governed to a large extent by the easy-going spirit of the West. Ties are taboo in the classroom. And the most popular shoe is the loafer or moccasin.

WISHING trees, enchanted trees and trees where wood nymphs live are familiar conventions in our folk literature. But the stories in this book, gathered from many countries, are as diversified in their imagery as their sources.

Recent inventions have been running a broad gamut from machines whose action "closely resembles intelligence," to artificial mushrooms and a pocket-size fly-swatter. It seems to be time, therefore, for a short thesaurus of views on inventions -- and inventors.
TOKYO, Sunday, Sept. 27 -- Tempers boiled yesterday in both camps holding prisoners of the Korean war who are resisting repatriation to their native lands.

The reviews of "Me and Juliet" completely disarmed me. I went prepared to see a fair musical show and I left feeling I had seen one of the most authentic backstage musicals which has ever been presented in a Broadway theatre.

THE Students' Dance Recitals series will open on Saturday night with a performance by Federico Rey and Pilar Gomez, with Silvio Masciarelli as pianist. Of special interest on the program will be the first performance of a composition by Ana Ricarda to music of Granados.

Columbia began its 1953 gridiron operations yesterday by defeating Lehigh at Baker Field. While a crowd of 10,000 looked on the local athletes held off a surprisingly strong band of En gineers to carve out a triumph by the score of 14 to 7.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26 -- The American Federation of Labor called on the New York Shipping Association today to shun a "collusive" wage agreement with the gang-ruled International Longshoremen's Association, independent.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 26 -- A man-made "brain," called the best and fastest computer of its kind by its makers, will be rolling down to Oak Ridge soon. The Oracle, as it is called, is being carefully crated at Argonne National Laboratory in Lemont, Ill., for shipment by trailer truck.

ENDOWED with the cool but delighting eye of an amateur painter, Candace Thurber Stevenson is at her best in this first volume of poems when she gives us sharp impressions of Vermont landscapes, the look of barns and Autumn weather.

BY all odds Thorstein Bunde Veblen is the most interesting, the most provocative -- and the most provoking -- social analyst that America has produced to date. At once morbidly withdrawn and acidly defensive, his personality is irresistible to those whose interest lies in character analysis, while his ideas -- iconoclastic, perceptive, corruscating and maddeningly vague -- beckon just as strongly to those whose interest lies in an analysis of society.
MRS. BLAIN arrived in Japan after we had won the war, but she may have won, on the evidence of this entertaining book, some small part of the peace.

THE current reincarnation of Kipling's master-prose by Somerset Maugham recalls a rare session with the Master of Bateman's in the autumn of 1921, and time and death have quashed an "off-the-record" interdiction then imposed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -- A Senate agriculture subcommittee will hold hearings next month on imports of Canadian wheat classed as unfit for human consumption, it was announced today.

Many buyers were in the wholesale markets here last week shopping for new holiday lines replenishing stocks and checking on delivery schedules for holiday merchandise, according to resident buying offices.

In his address to the Assembly on Friday Deputy Foreign Minister Schumann ranged from Korea and Indo-China to the problem of the organization of Europe. Essentially, however, he was appealing to the common sense of Russia, assuming that such a quality exists in the czars who direct the destinies of the new Muscovite empire.

A PHOTOGRAPH can be an experience for the observer as well as the photographer. It may be, and frequently is, no more than a brief impression that is soon forgotten, or it may "stay with you" for a long time. Some pictures are "discovered,

Three parents who were arrested yesterday on disorderly conduct charges while picketing City Hall in an effort to obtain gamma globulin, the poliomyelitis preventive, for their children were found guilty in Night Court last night, and a City Councilman who had sought to intervene in their behalf was escorted from the courtroom at the order of the presiding judge, Magistrate Hyman Bushel.

Plans are going forward rapidly for the dinner dance and entertainment known as "Un Brin de Bonheur," to be held on the night of Oct. 22 in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York. The sponsor of the forthcoming fete is Parfums Caron.

THE Edward R. Murrow hour-long documentary on Berlin, with which "See It Now" returned to the C.B.S. television network last Tuesday evening, was a disappointing job and by no means in the same class as the program's study of Korea.

While Pennsylvania is encouraging widespread medical research with a view to ridding the roads of motorists afflicted with serious heart ailments, New York has turned a deaf ear to requests by medical organizations for a similar project in this state.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- The United States will face opposition from many of its friends and allies if it goes ahead with announced plans to try to overrule the United Nations tribunal that set aside the dismissal of twelve United States citizens involved in loyalty investigations.
" Who is lying?" seemed likely yesterday to become the leading issue in the Mayoralty campaign.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 26 -- The eighty-fourth annual Danbury Fair, hailed in Fairfield County as "a nonprofit traditional and historical institution," opens at the fair grounds here next Saturday for a nine-day run.

THESE wandering Irishmen have a way with them, and when art turns their faces toward France, Gaelic slips into Gallic gaily as an egg into a humming bird. There is great charm about the genus and talent too, to which happy combination Mr. Gibbings adds a mind well stored and a gift for evocation of all sorts of tales from the buried past and the lively present.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- Pennsylvania opened its football season, prospectively its last under Coach George Munger, with a 13-7 victory over Vanderbilt today in the first meeting between the two teams.

Elegant French eighteenth century furniture and French and other silver, rugs, tapestries and decorative paintings will be auctioned on Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
