WAYNE COLE has written a useful history of the America First Committee, tracing its hectic career as the "spearhead of isolationism," as Robert E. Sherwood has characterized it, from its birth in September, 1940, until it was shattered by the attack on Pearl Harbor.

Within the next ten days teams of Army engineers and scientists from the American Museum of Natural History will begin tapping, analyzing and probing the exterior of City Hall just below the first-floor level in quest of its "missing" cornerstone.

THE lay reader would be hard put to learn from Gerald Sykes' review of C. G. Jung's "Psychology and Alchemy" that Jung's psychological -- if they can be called that -- theories have been rejected by virtually every professional worker in the field other than Jung's (in Mr. Sykes' own words) "irresponsible devotees."

MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Tass indicated today that the Soviet Government would shun Big Four talks on Germany and other international problems because of conditions laid down in recent notes from the three Western Powers.

CAMILO JOSE CELA, the only considerable novelist to appear in Spain since the end of the civil war, fought in Franco's Army and was a member of the Falange party, and yet the censorship system forced the withdrawal of his first novel, published in 1942.

THE fall choral season is now under way, with dozens of vocal groups busy auditioning new members, planning repertory and rehearsing for concerts later in the season. So vast and diversified is the city's choral activity that whether one is interested in Bach cantatas, baroque and pre-baroque music, nineteenth-century romantics, or contemporary works, by dint of a little investigation one can find a group which specializes in one's favorite field of music.

BUFFALO, Sept. 26 -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of upstate New York, declared today that he opposed any Congressional inquiry into war atrocities in Korea because the subject had no "demonstrable relation to the law-making function."

The Aluminum Company of America has built in Pittsburgh, Pa., a skyscraper 410 feet tall which, except for its basic steel framework, is nearly all aluminum. It is the lightest building of its size in the world. The thirty floors of offices are warmed and cooled by aluminum panels in the ceilings, the lights get their energy from aluminum wires, water flows through aluminum pipes.

A medium-sized British freighter, long a familiar sight along the West African Coast from Dakar to Nigeria, recently changed hands and has been fitted out for a new assignment in a different part of the world.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 26 -- First Divisional Army headquarters at Kutaradja, chief town of the Atjeh district situated at the tip of North Sumatra, has announced the "situation is under control" in the region, although minor fighting and small acts of sabotage to communications continue.

DON'T look now, but people are beginning to talk. Nothing of any creative consequence has been done in New York so far this season except by two off-Broadway groups -- one at the Barbizon-Plaza, the other at Theatre de Lys.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Alabama became the first state today to ask the United States Supreme Court to consider the constitutionality of the Federal act giving ownership of offshore lands to the states.

Corporate dividends paid out of earnings or profits are taxable to the recipient stockholder as ordinary income. This is generally true even in a case where dividends are applied by the seller of stock toward the purchase price of the shares sold. This rule, however, is not without exception, according to a recent decision by the United States Tax Court.
WHAT does a Congressman do with his free time when Congress is not in session?

The responsibilities of higher education toward international aid and understanding will be considered at a conference arranged jointly by the United Nations, New York University and the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, which will convene at the United Nations headquarters on Oct. 6 and move to the university's Vanderbilt Hall Auditorium and the Carnegie Intercultural Center on the following day.

Bob Wetzel, a hard running left halfback, registered four touchdowns to pave the way for Brooklyn Tech's 32 -- 12 rout of a favored Abraham Lincoln High football team at Lincoln Field yesterday. Tech scored twice in the third quarter and once in each of the three remaining periods.
CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Sept. 26 (UP) -- Fred Eugene McManus was sentenced to life imprisonment today for the first of his five slayings in a week-end of crime last spring.

AN easy-to-read mixture of travelogue and analysis of the long-range effect of the occupation of Japan, "Journey by Junk" is the product of a return visit by the author, Willard Price, to his favorite hunting ground.

FRITZ HENLE'S show at the Village Camera Club, 65 Bank Street, which may be seen from 8 to 10 P. M. Tuesday, is a photographer's choice of pictures representing various places he has visited and photographed during a long career. As the pictures show, his interest has been exclusively in people and in the way they relate to their environment.

TRENTON, Sept. 26 -- The New Jersey State Fair, one of the oldest expositions of its type in the East, begins its annual eight-day run here tomorrow. Many new features have been added, and its promoters hope a new attendance record will be set before the fair closes next Sunday.

Plans are being advanced at frequent meetings for the Post-Debutante Tiara Ball, to be held on Dec. 29 in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service. Mrs. Franklin Marion Gentry heads the executive committee for the forthcoming fete, Mrs. Lila Tyng is honorary chairman and Mrs. Wickliffe Crider and Mrs. J. Courtney Ivey are co-chairmen of the program committee.

Seasonable weather and some large major promotions in New York and Brooklyn department stores brought a gain of about 10 per cent last week over year-ago sales. The retailers had cool weather this year, against a warm Indian summer weather a year ago, to boost their sales volume.

The Federal Government owns 3,653 inventions which are available to anybody royalty free but without an exclusive license. In cooperation with the Government Patents Board of which Dr. Archie M. Palmer is chairman, the Department of Commerce has published a book ("Government Owned Patents Available for License") in which these inventions are classified so that industrial companies, particularly the small ones, may survey them rapidly and decide which are worth further study.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: The sooner house plants are started indoors, the better. Lift the potted plants and move to porch, terrace or arbor while pots are cleaned, foliage syringed and any unruly growth trimmed back to make a shapely plant. After a few days, bring flowering and colored-leaved plants to a sunny window, green ones where it is light.

A thoughtless attack upon Acharya Vinoba Bhave, regarded by many Indians as almost as saintly as the revered Mathama Gandhi, has apparently done more for the cause of the Untouchables than could be accomplished by legislation. The doors of one of India's most restricted Brahmin temples have been thrown open as a result of the popular protest against the indignity suffered by Mr. Bhave when he attempted to lead an Untouchable group into the temple.

THE British Cameroons is a scrap of rain-forest covering some 34,000 square miles on the low-lying coast of West Africa. Its climate is oppressive; its people are poor and backward. Presumably it has social problems and political, too.
Six major league players who participated in the first world series in 1903 will attend the fiftieth anniversary series between the Yankees and Dodgers this week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Spain abandoned today her traditional policy of neutrality, which had kept her outside two world-wide conflicts in this century, by signing a defense agreement giving the United States the right to use a number of Spanish air and naval bases for the defense of Western Europe and the Mediterranean.

The president of Hearn Department Stores, Inc., demanded yesterday that members of District 65, Distributive, Processing and Office Workers Union of America, C.I.O., cease picketing the company's stores in Manhattan and the Bronx.

The New York City Technical Institute has announced plans for an expanded program of evening and Saturday courses for the fall semester. Under its new status as a community college, the institute will offer a number of courses for adults. In addition, the evening program will continue to offer certificate and degree courses in technical, business and sub-professional areas.

One of the nation's largest and best known privately owned public utilities, the Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago, oddly enough, had its genesis in the foresight of the late Samuel Insull -- a master at the art of pyramiding corporate utility structures.
The Red Cross Regional Blood Program received ninety-four pints of blood yesterday in payment of a "debt of gratitude."

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- A sharp Government attack on the Labor party and its leader, Clement Attlee, was delivered by the Home Secretary, Sir David Maxwell Fyfe, in a broadcast tonight virtually on the eve of next week's Labor party conference at Margate.

NEXT month Little, Brown brings out an Atlantic Monthly Press Book that is significant and -- as Jimmy Durante might add -- important too. The book is "Russian Assignment," and it is written by Admiral Leslie C. Stevens, who was our naval attache in Moscow for three years (1947-49).

SINGAPORE, Sept. 26 -- Chin Chee Tong, a Communist area committee member, who controlled terrorist activity on the outskirts of Kuala Lumpur, is among three Communists reported today to have been slain. Chin Chee Tong had his headquarters at Sungei Long, then miles from Kuala Lumpur, the capital of the Federation of Malaya.

There would have been 40,000 fewer parties last week with a consequent drop in the consumption of food and beverages as well as a lull in social relationships if it were not for a scheme evolved thirteen years ago by Stanley Home Products, Inc., Easthampton, Mass.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 26 -- An important change is coming over the policy of the Australian administration of the territory of Papua-New Guinea.

IOWA CITY, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Michigan State, the proud national champion of 1952, got a rugged test from Iowa today before the Spartans broke away for a 21-7 victory in their Western Conference football debut after an anxious four-year wait.

SLOWLY but surely nature is changing into fall costume. Here and there colorful fruits decorate shrubs and trees, which are also donning the bright yellow, bronze and red leaves of autumn. One of the first and most brilliant changes is found in the bright scarlet fruit clusters of native dogwood. The berries are particularly abundant this fall.

THERE recently appeared in your paper an item which said that the City Center was polling its clients in an effort to choose three out of eight plays all starring Jose Ferrer for its coming fall season.

SUMMIT, N. J., Sept. 26 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood overcame a deficit near the finish today to defeat Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair, 2 and 1, and win her third Women's New Jersey Golf Association match-play championship.

IF anybody thinks the high-fidelity surge of the last five years arises from some new, mid-century notion previously undetected in sturdy, responsible types of individuals, he or she can profit from a dip into phonographic history.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 -- A collection of more than 300 text and reference books from the Harvard School of Public Health will be the nucleus of a library for twenty South Korean doctors, who will compose the opening class of a new School of Public Health at Seoul National University, next Monday.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Sept. 26 -- Members of the Agriculture Committee of the House of Representatives indicated today that they had been prepared to order their own investigation of meat prices if Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, had not done so.

WITH felicitous assists from Jefferson, Hemingway, Shakespeare, Tolstoy, Voltaire, Stendhal, Goldsmith, Balzac, Proust, Kipling, Margaret of Navarre, Edward VII and a score of others, Mr. Brody has written a book to end all books about the Duke and Duchess of Windsor.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 26 -- State Commissioner of Labor John J. Egan said today that there could be no negotiation toward a settlement of the dispute here between the Hat Corporation of America and five locals of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union, A. F. L., until each side was prepared to give ground.

CAIRO, Sept. 26 -- The Syrian Ambassador to Egypt, Mustafa El Shahaby, discussed today with Foreign Minister Mahmoud Fawzi of a united Arab action against Israel if that state continued its canal-building project in the demilitarized zone along the Syrian border in the Lake Huleh sector of the Jordan Valley.

IN his last letter to his son, John, the Late George Apley sums up his foreboding about the future of Harvard University in these words: "There is actually some talk about a new president, about whom no one seems to have heard. Needless to say, this is only one of the wild rumors * * *.

THIS book will be of absorbing interest to two groups that do not always see eye to eye when watching birds, to wit: bird-lovers and ornithologists. Miss Len Howard of Sussex, England, has set down, in good print and plain language, not only her observations but her interpretations of bird behavior as she witnessed it at close hand in and around her Sussex cottage over a fair span of years.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- A belief of high government officials and leaders of both political parties in Britain that this is an opportune time to negotiate with the Soviet Union springs largely from knowledge of political and economic problems besetting the Russian state.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- In the last couple of weeks the biggest guns in the nation's political arsenals have been fired in what signalizes, for a certainty, the opening of the 1954 Congressional election campaign, and for a probability, the end of the protracted honeymoon between President Eisenhower and the bulk of the "loyal opposition" among the Democrats.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Senator Irving M. Ives of New York urged his fellow Republicans today to "toss politics out of the window" in considering proposed changes in the Taft-Hartley labor law.

PANAMA CITY, Sept. 26 (UP) -- Hurricane Florence blew itself out over northwest Florida today after battering the Florida coast, but its still heavy winds and rain moved on into Georgia after posing a flood threat to southeastern Alabama.

Despite the introduction of many "frill" subjects in recent years, the three R's -- reading, 'riting and 'rithmetic -- are still the basic courses taught in the nation's elementary schools. Yet complaints are frequently heard that the boys and girls of today do not read as well as their elders did, that the youth of this era do not spell correctly, do not know how to write a legible letter, or figure accurately.

Most advocates of fair trade continued to hurl invective at their adversaries and cheering words at their own circle last week. Emanuel Katz, president of Doeskin Products, Inc., a recognized champion of resale price maintenance, spoke little and prepared for action in the event that the United States Supreme Court cripples or eliminates fair trade in the next year.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Minnie Minoso and Jim Rivera each drove in two runs to support Connie Johnson's six-hit pitching in a 6-to-3 victory for the White Sox over the Browns tonight.

PARIS, Sept. 26 -- Premier Joseph Laniel pointed today to a resumption of business activity, lower prices, a stable franc and enough money in the Treasury to cover several months' expenses as the tangible results of his Government's activity during its three months of office.

After years of planning and preparation, construction has finally begun on New Zealand's biggest industrial enterprise -- the Murupara Project to harvest the lush man-made Kaingaroa State Forest southeast of Auckland on North Island.

THE weatherbeaten barn of a house sheltering the numerous Fripsey family needed paint. Seven Fripsey children (not counting Baby, of course) realized this fact. Since Papa's promotion hinged on the impression that his house and his family would make on the unknown head of his firm, sprucing up for "Terrible" Tibber became a summer project, with Marcy from next door helping.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Sept. 26 -- Champion Topflight Template of Twin Ponds, Welsh terrier owned by Mrs. Edward P. Alker of Great Neck and handled by John Goudie, was named best in the annual all-breed show of the Suffolk County Kennel Club at the Huntington Crescent Club today. Mrs. Madeleine E. Baiter judged the final.
FOR the Port of New York these autumn months have a strange and unreal quality that may be likened to the hour before dawn. The long night of mob domination is nearly over. At least on paper.

The State Harness Racing Commission will use a "fine tooth comb" in going over applications for re-employment at Yonkers Raceway before deciding whether to lift the suspension imposed on the track last Tuesday, it was said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- By a brief passage in his Boston speech, President Eisenhower has focused attention anew on one of the Administration's worst headaches. It is: How to balance the budget and cut taxes simultaneously without weakening our defenses against a Soviet Union that has now mastered the secret of the hydrogen bomb.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 26 -- Grant Golden of Wilmette, Ill., won his third tennis title at the Maccabiah games today by beating Sidney Levy of South Africa, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 0, in the men's singles. Golden won the men's and the mixed doubles titles yesterday in partnership with Pablo Eisenberg and Anita Kanter, respectively.

IT is appropriate and just that the first extended-exploration of Katherine Mansfield's life be undertaken by one of her compatriots. In "Katherine Mansfield: A Biography" Antony Alpers, a young New Zealander, has woven together an account sympathetic yet fair, scrupulous as to fact, precise in thorough detail and enriched by significant fresh material.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 26 (UP) -- Gus Bell and Jim Greengrass each hit a two-run double in the eighth inning today to snay a 6-6 tie and enable the Redlegs to score a 10-7 victory over the Braves.
Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, the commander of the Twenty-fourth Division in the early days of the Korean War, returned to America last week after three years in Communist prison camps.

BUDDY ADLER is one producer who is not singing any sad songs these days. With "From Here to Eternity" and "Salome" (a pair of decidedly different feathered birds) to his credit for the year, he is in the happy position of having his Columbia employers anticipating a combined gross income of close to $30,000,000 from his two films.

It was good to read Col. Benjamin Namm's letter referring to Lafayette. Every American should recall the debt owed his heroic action in behalf of the establishment of our country, his love and solicitude for its success. His friendship for Washington was an abiding source of strength to the "Father of His Country."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Post-season racing began at Larchmont Yacht Club today with 26 representatives of the three largest Long Island Sound fleets, in point of size of craft, reveling in a steady 14-mile southwesterly over an unusual nine-mile course.

THE casual player has a keen sense of failure if he does not make his bid. The expert expects to go down about once in three or four times; if he goes down less often than that he knows he is not bidding as much as he should.

YOU could hardly blame Dexter, ordinarily a well-behaved small dragon, for showing off when he suddenly found that he could blow smoke. The temptation was irresistible but, like many a human youngster who overworks a new trick to the envy and discomfort of his friends, Dexter quickly became insufferable.

FIFTY years ago today, "Old 97," the pride of the Southern Railway, came pounding fearsomely down the slope from White Oak Mountain, roaring and rocking and out of control, and plunged into eternity from the curving stillhouse trestle here.

ATHENS, Ga., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Georgia turned two Tulane fumbles into 10 points, Bob Clemens scored another touchdown and the Georgia Bulldogs beat the Green Wave, 16 -- 14, in a Southeastern Conference game today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -- Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of the Treasury, warned American Jews tonight not to meddle in political and economic policies of Israel by abusing the "power of the purse."

BUFFALO, Sept. 26 (UP) -- The president of the New York County Lawyers Association said today he hoped a proposed "fair trial free press" code would lead the bar and press along the path of complete understanding.
DETROIT, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Despite increasing development of automatic manufacturing processes, production costs in the auto industry are still rising.

Cocoa prices on the New York Cocoa Exchange advanced last week following release on Monday of a lover estimate for the Accra crop. Despite doubts concerning the accuracy of the first estimate of the main Gold Coast crop, the price of actuals also rose.

NEWARK, Sept. 26 -- A four-pronged drive by the newly organized United States Attorney's office in New Jersey, a campaign that is designed to reduce to a minimum syndicated gambling, narcotics traffic, bootlegging and tax frauds in this state, is expected to roll into high gear within the next few weeks.

A CAMERA store contest on a level considerably above the usual is being sponsored by the Camera Shop of Hanover, N. H. Called the Living Pictures Contest, the event is intended "to stimulate the interest of the amateur photographer to use his camera as a tool for recording excerpts from life * * *." Cameras and other merchandise prizes are offered in two classes: amateurs 16 years of age or over, and amateurs under 16.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 26 -- J. G. N. Strauss, leader of United party opposition, is fighting a losing battle to save the century-old common roll franchise of South Africa's 1,100,000 persons of mixed blood called Coloreds.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -- Clemson came from behind with a 75-yard touchdown march in the fourth period today to tie Boston College, 14 -- 14, in New England's first intersectional football game of the season.

Greentree Stable's great 4-year-old colt Tom Fool, in what was probably his last race over a New York track, made his 1953 record nine for nine, and won for the tenth straight time since last November, in the $54,500 Sysonby Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. David J. Seligson, associate rabbi of Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, and president of the New York Board of Rabbis, in his sermon yesterday morning at the synagogue declared that Judaism "has never made any distinction between the sacred and the secular."

In the last eighteen months the Fund for Adult Education of the Ford Foundation allocated $9,739,046 to adult education. In the second annual report of the fund, entitled "The Challenge of Lifetime Learning," issued yesterday, the importance of support for various aspects of adult learning is stressed.
LONG BEACH, L. I., Sept. 26 -- Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor of New York, said today that he considered Harold Riegelman, the Republican nominee, his principal opponent.

THE exhibition which will open at the Morgan Library on Oct. 2 is an important one. For the first time the library will put on view all of its Italian manuscripts, dating from the sixth to the sixteenth centuries, a group surpassed only in Italy.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 26 (UP) -- Michigan, scoring five touchdowns in a ten-minute flurry, overwhelmed the University of Washington, 50 -- 0, today in its season opener before 51,233 fans at Michigan Stadium.

WHAT is it like to live on a mountaintop in Idaho and watch for forest fires? Jeanne Kellar Beaty had undertaken to tell in this book, the greater part of which consists of a detailed account of the first summer she and her husband, bride and groom and tenderfeet to boot, spent as fire lookouts in the Salmon National Forest.

WEST ISLIP, L. I., Sept. 26 -- A fleet of 175 power yachts carried 600 Marine Corps Reservists today to two beachhead landings in the first phase of Exercise Volunteer, aimed at dislodging a mythical enemy at Willets Point.

EVANSTON, Ill., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Lloyd Israels, senior halfback who had spent the last two years on defense, blossomed into a brilliant runner and pass catcher today to lead Northwestern to a 35-0 triumph over Iowa State in the Wildcats' opener.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 (UP) -- The Mountaineers of West Virginia unleashed a powerful ground game today with Halfbacks Jack Stone and Joe Marconi leading the way to a 17-7 victory over Pittsburgh before a crowd of 43,446.

BRITISH settlement of Tasmania's capital city, Hobart, a century and a half ago is the theme of an Australian sesquicentenary series released last Wednesday. On two 3 1/2-pence claret stamps, paired throughout each sheet, are portraits of David Collins (1754-1810), founder of Hobart and Tasmania's first Lieutenant Governor, in 1804-10; and William Paterson (1755-1810), first Lieutenant Governor of New South Wales, in 1800-09.

In the winter schedule of the New York Public Library, which goes into effect on Thursday, several reference divisions in the Fifth Avenue building will remain open until 10 P. M. on Mondays and Thursdays and from 1 to 6 P. M. on Sundays.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 (UP) -- Southern California capitalized on its opportunities and line superiority to defeat Minnesota, 17 to 7, before 66,698 in Memorial Coliseum today.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 26 -- India's growing unemployment problem, which has necessitated abrupt changes in the general pattern of the national five-year plan, is being tackled first on the educational front. THE second novel by the author of "The Teahouse of the August Moon" is written in the grand tradition of oriental novels. "A Pail of Oysters" deals with Asians (in this instance Formosans and Chinese) high and low, among whom a sympathetic and upstanding American arrives.

Barnard College will begin its sixty-fifth academic year tomorrow as scheduled, although Milfloor building was slowed down by the two-month strike of the A. F. L. International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

Galbraith speaks with authority on the abandoned farm situation in New England -- "Abandoned Farms, Unabandoned Hopes" (Sept. 13) -- is that he is himself an abandoned farmer. OXFORD, Miss., Sept. 26 (UP) -- Sophomores Eagle Day and Bobby McCool steadied a shaky Mississippi offense, and a massive line stopped Steve (The Horse) Meilinger as the Rebels rolled to a 22-to-6 victory over Kentucky in a Southeastern Conference opener before 18,000 today.
BONN, Sept. 26 -- Reverberations of the post-election political struggle in Western Germany were heard far away this week in St. Louis, Mo.

A LITTLE book, "The Statesmanship of the Civil War," consists of three Page-Barbour lectures delivered at the University of Virginia in 1951. The lectures are based in part on materials from the author's larger work, "The Ordeal of the Union."
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Sept. 26 -- A 615-mile pipeline construction job in Northern Canada and Alaska has been placed up for bid by the Alaska District of the Army Corps of Engineers.

In behalf of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York a preview reception and tea will be given Thursday afternoon at the exhibition depicting the sixty-year old history of the organization. The exhibition will run through October at the Museum of the City of New York.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 26 -- W. G. Reynolds' Meadow Rice from Louisville, was driven by Jimmy Jordan to a new world record of 2.07 4-5 for the mile and one-sixteenth distance on a half-mile track pacing in the $10,000 Louisiana free-for-all closing feature at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UP) -- The Army has failed to meet its target date for installation of Nike -- anti-aircraft guided missile -- but hopes to have the weapon in operations soon, officials said today.

ROME, Sept. 26 -- Pope Pius XII addressed an encyclical letter to the Roman Catholic episcopacy throughout the world today proclaiming a Marian Year to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the definition of the dogma of the Immaculate Conception.

At a three-day meeting in the Statler Hotel last week the Quality Bakers of America Cooperative, Inc., demonstrated how the industry in general is surviving the attacks of the diet faddists and the girth-conscious.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Alan Ameche ran wild today as Wisconsin's Badgers rolled up yardage steadily to defeat Penn State by 20 -- 0 in an intersectional game before 49,000 fans at Camp Randall Stadium.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 26 -- Arnold Hanger's Chilean bred Iceberg II, ridden by Chile's champion jockey, Jorge Contreras, won the $50,000-added United Nations Handicap at the Atlantic City track today, covering the mile and three-sixteenths turf course in track record time of 1:55 4/5.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Further fuel was added to the fire building under the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act as a distinguished Latin-American educator, visiting professor of Spanish - American Literature at Columbia University for seven years, was detained overnight by Immigration authorities upon his return from a visit to France.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 26 -- The top sergeants of American industry -- the foremen, who represent the front line of management -- traded ideas on supervisory problems, cost saving, human relations and a variety of similar subjects at sessions that ended here today.

THE Yankees and the Dodgers, each loaded to the gunwales with traditions, will open the world series at the Stadium on Wednesday. The Yankee tradition is the one of Murderers' Row, of the explosive home-run bats of Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig and all the other distance sluggers who made the Bronx Bombers synonymous with unbridled power.

The need for an increase in air service by American-flag commercial carriers to the Far East was stressed last week by Trans World Airlines as a means of strengthening the nation's economic prestige in that vital area.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 26 -- Lafayette, victorious over Princeton only once in twenty-nine previous meetings, way back in 1901, came within three minutes of springing a momentous upset at Palmer Stadium today.

IN the winter of 1941 Fritz Hochwalder sat on a balcony overlooking Ascona, Switzerland, an old pencil and a few blank sheets of paper before him. In a few weeks he would have to report back to the labor camp for Hitler refugees in Tessin.

TO read Russell Criddle's autobiography is a provocative and challenging experience. At times it can also be a provoking one. "Love Is Not Blind" tells his story from the moment when he, the eldest son of a locomotive fireman in Susquehanna, Pa., suffers near blindness at age 12 from a snowball which scars the corneal tissue of his eyes, until, seventeen years later, his sight is restored by the surgical magic of a corneal graft.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Maryland's first string football team played only eighteen minutes today, just long enough to score once in each half. Between appearances of the varsity, the Terrapin reserves continued rolling in a 52-0 rout of Washington and Lee.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (UP) -- The Cubs rallied twice to beat the Cardinals, 4 to 3, on six-hit pitching by Warren Hacker today.

James C. Hagerty, the President's press secretary, the other day attributed a Shakespearean quote to the wrong play and got a scolding from the press-box scholars. How accurate is your own knowledge of Shakespeare?

NORMAN, Okla., Sept. 26 -- Notre Dame, with Ralph Guglielmi passing to two touchdowns and sprinting for another, defeated powerful Oklahoma, 28 to 21, before a crowd of 58,000 in 94degree weather today. Guglielmi passed to Joe Heap for scores in the first and third periods and ran 2 yards for another. Fullback Neil Worden accounted for the other Irish score with a 9-yard spurt on a pitch-out in the third period.

At the important meeting of physicists held last week at Tokyo, young Prof. Abraham Pais of the Institute of Advanced Study (Princeton, N. J.) rose to expound a theory which called for six dimensions to account for the many fundamental particles with which nuclear physicists must now deal.

Encouraging statements by Government leaders and industrialists on the state of the nation's economy had a beneficial effect on financial sentiment last week. As a result, rallying tendencies were evident in the stock market, but traders still acted cautiously and prices, on balance, rose moderately in quiet trading.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 26 -- A placement by Will McFarlane, after a Tommy Knight-Robin Turner scoring pass, gave Amherst an upset 7-6 victory over Brown in the opener for both football teams today.
LONDON, Sept. 26 (Reuters) -- The leading clubs in the first division of the English Soccer League won their matches today, leaving West Bromwich Albion in front in a tight race.

GENEVA, Sept. 26 -- Two small countries on opposite sides of Europe and about as different as can be in every material respect, are attracting an unusual amount of attention on the part of European and American economists for the astonishing vigor with which their economic systems have responded to basically similar, orthodox monetary and financial policies.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 26 -- With the Government facing huge losses in the form of subsidies to farmer as the result of depressed grain prices, President Juan Peron today told the nation's farmers that his regime hoped to hand over marketing of the country's cereal crops to agricultural cooperatives.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Sept. 26 (UP) -- Florida's fighting 'Gators, completely at home on a swampy field, fought Georgia Tech to a scoreless tie today to snap an eighteen-game Tech winning streak, but the Atlanta Engineers did manage to slog through their twenty-eighth game without a defeat.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- A partisan exchange over whether Republicans or Democrats could claim credit for tax reductions already scheduled for the coming year, developed here today.

TO THE EDITOR: I am both shocked and bewildered by Richard Rovere's use of the word "egghead" in his article on Adlai Stevenson. Before that article I thought Rovere a great reporter. Now I suspect he is a sly propagandist.

After nearly fourteen years of all but scandal-free operation, harness racing in the state now seems slated for its first major investigation by the State Harness Racing Commission -- an investigation which had its genesis in the slaying last Aug. 28 of Thomas F. Lewis, president of the union local that controls most of the 1,200 employee at Yonkers Raceway, now the banner track in the country.

DETROIT, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Bobby Layne's passing and the all-around brilliance of Doak Walker sparked the champion Detroit Lions to a 38-21 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers today in a National Football League opener before 44,587 fans.

TOKYO, Sept. 27 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida proposed today that the existence of Japanese military forces to defend their homeland against foreign aggression should be legally authorized. He announced at the same time that his Government would develop longrange plans for strengthening these forces.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- The final stage of debate in the eighth session of the General Assembly, starting tomorrow, will provide a busy week for the Soviet delegation.

A view of recent events, the New York Shipping Association will be building up trouble for itself, for its industry and for the Port of New York if it fails to consider carefully the consequences of writing an agreement with the racketeer-dominated union led by Joseph P. Ryan.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- M. Maurice Schumann's speech at the U. N. General Assembly intimating that the war in Indo-China might be settled by negotiations was received with loud cheers in France. The French people are more impatient to get their troops out of Vietnam than the Americans were to stop the fighting in Korea.

The Federal Government, which already has seized thirty-three alien - controlled tankers and freighters for alleged violation of the Ship Sales Act of 1946, is working on a considerable number of similar cases, and action is expected on them soon.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Cubs scored two runs in the eighth inning to defeat the Cardinals, 3 -- 2, before 13,378 fans today. The Cardinals thus finished the season in a third-place tie with Philadelphia, each team with a record of eighty-three victories and seventy-one losses.

Ferdinand, the Staten Island Zoo's king cobra, which used to feed exclusively on smaller snakes, partook yesterday of a mixed dish to the cheers of the zoo's herpetologist and assistant snakecatchers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 27 -- Olivia De Havilland will make her first appearance under the Columbia Studio banner as the star of the modernized version of Emile Zola's "The Human Beast." Two weeks ago, the studio had announced that Rita Hayworth would do the picture.

Hugh Rennie, 50 years old, a veteran actor in the legitimate theatre, ended his life by hanging in his apartment at 200 West Fifty-fourth Street at the corner of Seventh Avenue, the police said early today.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 27 -Alan Corey, .Henry Lewis, Phil Iglehart and Pete Bostwick teamed excellently today as Meadow Brook captured the national open polo championship by halting Chicago, 7 to 4, in the final of the thirtyseventh tournament on. International Field of the Meadow Brook Club.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Quarterback Y. A. Tittle threw three touchdown passes and Fullback Joe (Jet) Perry led the ground attack today as the San Francisco Forty-Niners upset the Philadelphia Eagles, 31 -- 21, in a game marked by a free-for-all fight in the fourth quarter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The eventual gift to the country of the approximately 3,000,000 personal papers of former President Truman -- documents now in safe storage at Kansas City, Mo., where he is writing his memoirs -- was announced today by the General Services Administration, which operates the National Archives.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 27 -- Champion Thenderin Brian Tristan, Irish setter owned by Mr. and Mrs. James Fraser of Olmstead Falls, Ohio, was named best in show at the thirty-first annual fixture of the Westbury Kennel Association today.

OYSTER BAY, L. I. Sept. 27 -- Raynham Hall, the pre-Revolutionary homestead, one of the few remaining on the North Shore, will benefit through a series of lectures on restoring and refurnishing American homes that will start on Oct. 19 under the sponsorship of Mrs. Antonio Ponvert of Cove Neck and a committee of Oyster Bay women.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- With crucial tests of Allied unity lying ahead in both Europe and Asia, diplomatic observers here have detected new symptoms of neutralism in Europe.

Prices of cotton futures turned firmer in the final trading session last week after a few days of drifting. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed Friday 7 points, or 35 cents a bale, lower to 16 points, or 80 cents, higher.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- The battle between the Vickers Supermarine Swift and the Hawker Hunter, the Royal Air Force's spectacular jet fighters, for the world record for{ level flight will continue and the scene may soon be switched to e southern California.

Dec. 21 has been selected as the local opening date for "Colombe," the Jean Anouilh comedy adapted by Louis Kronenberger. Julie Harris will star in the play, which is being sponsored by Robert L. Joseph and Jay Julien.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27 -- Alvin Dark, at home almost anywhere on a baseball field, where he has performed at short, third, second, in left and in right, today realized his great, secret ambition. Throughout his career, the captain of the Giants has wanted to pitch, and as the 1953 campaign came to a close, Dark was the starting hurler against the Pirates at Forbes Field.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 27 -Military authorities of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization gathered here for the forthcoming Exercise Weldfast believe these joint exercises and the October meeting of Greek, Turkish and Yugoslav general staff representatives will go far toward answering the question whether Southeastern Europe can be defended against Soviet attack.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- The excitement and exhilaration produced in the markets just over a week ago by the unexpected reduction in the bank rate have, in the past few days, evaporated almost as rapidly as they rose and part of advance that then occurred in security prices has been lost.

" Fire in the Ashes: Europe in Mid-Century," by Theodore H. White, will be published by William Sloane Associates on Oct. 28. Described as "the story of a new Europe rising from the ashes of despair through American vision and daring," the volume presents the developments within England, France and Germany, first in a general survey and then in "the human terms" of men "who truly represent their time and place."

The labeling of a confidential Army document as Communist propaganda seems to some of us crazy. If, nevertheless, that kind of insinuation is permitted to continue to permeate all ways of civic life, I, for one, question the wisdom of our complacence.
Events today: Jazz Concert forI the benefit of James P. Johnson,I Town I-T.]I, S p./; Quartetto Ita-] liano. Lexington Avenue Y. 3V[.-I Y. W. H. A_, 8:30.

Parents in Boulevard Houses, a city project in the East New York section of Brooklyn, voted yesterday to keep their children out of school for two weeks in their latest move to obtain gamma globulin for them. For the third consecutive night, the parents staged a sit-in demonstration in the offices of the city's Health Department at 125 Worth Street.
We are now faced with the necessity of swallowing a bitter pill -- the military agreement with Franco Spain. Let us all hope that the medicine will do more good than harm.

The features of the human face have been exalted to the limits of description in both prose and poetry. Eyes are usually limpid pools of fire; lips are bows of cherry red; ears are like dewdrops. But what about the nose?

" The church in America is under fire when it should be on fire," leading Americans to God, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared yesterday in a sermon at Christ Church (Methodist), Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street. The minister went on to suggest that "good" many come of the Congressional investigations of the loyalty of some clergymen, providing they renew our loyalties to God.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- President Eisenhower declared today that the national fund-raising efforts of the United Community Campaigns aid not only the sick, the troubled and the handicapped, but also "the cause of democracy itself."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- United States authorities said today that the question of consulting President Rhee on the reported plan for a unified, neutralized Korea had not arisen because the proposal was "only one among many" under study by the Eisenhower Government.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The American Veterans Committee accused the Eisenhower Administration today of "scuttling the Point Four idea" of technical assistance to underdeveloped countries.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 (AP) -Quarterback Norman Van Brocklin fired two touchdown passes to Tom Fears and Elroy Hirsch, both ends, and gave the Los Angeles Rams a 21-7 victory over the New York Giants in the National Football League opener today.
Major league attendance showed a decrease for the fifth straight year, with the 1953 gate almost a quarter-million under last season's total, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

TRENTON, Sept. 27 -- The New Jersey State Fair opened its sixtysixth season here today under a threatening sky. Despite the cloudy weather an estimated 75,000 persons were present, equaling last year's opening-day attendance figure.

RUMA, Yugoslavia, Sept. 27 -- President Tito condemned today the outbreaks of violence against priests of the Roman Catholic and Orthodox churches that occurred in the summer but appear to be dying down. Referring to the series of Communist-led mob attacks that injured several Bishops and forced some into hiding, Marshal Tito still insisted the church problem had become "acute" only because of church policies.
SPRING VALEY, N. Y., Sept 27 -- A sharp reduction of nonrush hour service by Rockland Coaches, Inc., which the company says touched off a slow-down by its drivers, will go into effect tomorrow.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 27 (AP) -Bert Rechichar's first field-goal attempt in professional football was good today for a National Football League record of 56 yards and was the winning margin in the Baltimore Colts' 13 -- 9 victory over the Chicago Bears.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 27 -- Upsala College here will celebrate this week the sixtieth anniversary of its founding in the basement of a Brooklyn church. The college, which started with sixteen students, now has 1,200.

As W. H. Lawrence wrote in this newspaper yesterday, some Washington reporters are concerned about the relative infrequency of President Eisenhower's press conferences. So far there have been fourteen. This is at the rate of about twenty a year, as contrasted with Mr. Truman's forty and Mr. Roosevelt's eighty.

Forty-one additional television stations in thirty-five cities have been linked this month to the Bell System's nation-wide video network facilities, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that during its first twenty years 1,391,000 depositors in 422 banks had been saved entirely or partly from losses due to bank failure.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 27 -- The troubles of Colombian newspapers that may cease publication under pressure of censorship are arousing wide interest in Latin America, where it is known the same thing could happen in almost any country in certain circumstances.

This city's program for protecting pedestrians from traffic hazards is far below the standard for major metropolitan centers, according to an objective analysis submitted to Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Marshal Kliment E. Voroshilov, chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union, is believed to be ill, diplomats said here today, citing reports received from Moscow. They noted evidence that the 72-year-old Marshall Voroshilov had been absent from important state functions in Moscow the last two weeks.

PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Sept. 27 -- Thirty-five thousand of the toughest fighters in Pakistan settled down to normal rural living today when Gadun tribesmen voluntarily became a part of the North-West Frontier Province of Pakistan. Thus they ended a sovereignty guarded for more than 2,000 years with rifle and dagger in Himalayan mountain passes as high as 10,000 feet.

In current discussions consequent upon the death of Chief Justice Vinson it is being assumed that President Eisenhower will select a successor from the surviving members of the United States Supreme Court or from the tried and true judges in the several federal judicial circuits.

BEDFORD, N. Y., Sept. 27 - Nancy Jane Imboden of Bronxville, with her chestnut gelding Dio, in the working hunter division, and Betsy O'Shea of Wilton Conn., in the horsemanship events, were the outstanding winners in the second annual Bedford Horse Show at the Shannon Stables' grounds today.

It is no slight to Turkey and no criticism of the American decision to support Turkey's bid for a seat on the Security Council to point out that the Philippines has also a good and an unusual case. Both Turkey and the Philippines are stanch friends of freedom.

THE Saturday night variety attractions on television, which for a good many viewers mean the Jackie Gleason program on C. B. S. followed by "Your Show of Shows" on N. B. C., are having their troubles this season.

A spokesman for the union representing strikers at Hearn's two department stores in Manhattan and the Bronx said yesterday that picketing would be called off if the company would reinstate 600 workers who have been on strike since May 14.
Pushing an old automobile into the East River got a Columbia University student into hot water yesterday. It caused some confusion, also, on Welfare Island and brought out two police boats.

MARGATE, England, Sept. 27 -Aneurin Bevan, leader of British Socialism's left wing, demanded tonight that the ailing Prime Minister, Sir Winston Churchill, resign "if he is unable to do his duty" and that Britain take the lead in opening negotiations for a settlement with the Soviet Union.

This week provides a wide variety of attractions in metropolitan art galleries. European and American painting and sculpture, past and present; artists of fame and promising beginners combine to step up the season.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 27 -- All Israeli and Maccabiah records were broken in Haifa today and yesterday in acquatic sports of the world Jewish Olympic Games.

Efforts of a group of parents in Westchester to settle on standards of social behavior for their youngsters were crystallized last week with the publication of an eightpage pamphlet on "out of school" behavior titled "Bronxville Families Agree."

Blouses to team with a skirt for cocktail and evening occasions or to wear under the jackets of dressy suits are shown here today. They constitute a valuable addition to a wardrobe, allowing for diverting costume combinations.

THE fierce urge of some men to own and drive automobiles completely different in appearance from anything else on the road, and faster and more powerful, keeps Perry B. Fina busy and prosperous. His firm, Perry Motors, at 145 West Fifty- fourth Street, specializes in stepping up car motors and redesigning their bodies.

The State Harness Racing Commission has decided to call off what would have been the second of its public hearings, scheduled tentatively for 10:30 A. M. today, into hiring practices and racketeering pay-offs at Yonkers Raceway, it was learned yesterday.

THE art of writing a good travel book has little to do with choice of material. Nearly any place will do, the unexplored interior of New Guinea being no more promising than the sidewalks of Paris. What counts is the traveler himself -- his personality, his curiosity, his ideas and his skill as a writer. If all of these are pleasing it doesn't matter whether his travels follow well-trodden paths.

Members of two unions on strike against the Arma Corporation at plants at Carle Place, L. I., and in Brooklyn will meet tomorrow at Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty- fourth Street, to vote on tentative agreements to end the walkout.
Nine new films, including importations from England and France, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

A series of thirteen half-hour radio broadcasts was opened yesterday afternoon at 1:30 by the Columbia Broadcasting System in cooperation with the American Composers Alliance. This program, featuring Leopold Stokowski and the C. B. S. Radio Orchestra, is named Twentieth Century Concert Hall and its programs will contain a mixture of contemporary and classic music.

Officers and men of the British cruiser Superb exchanged their navy uniforms for the tattered garb and bandannas of pirates yesterday afternoon to entertain 300 New York children aboard the ship, docked at West Fifty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- President Eisenhower intends to go on courting the friendship of labor, although he faces the risk that he not only may fail but also may sharpen dissension in his own party and political household.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Sept. 27 -- American farmers want reassurances. They want to know that no one is going to curtail the Federal farm programs they have won in the last twenty years, that Federal price supports and other subsidies -- along with Federal credit -- will be extended if hard times come.
Dullness prevailed in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Rates fluctuated narrowly and business transacted was reported to be only moderate.

Whether or not the quality of the football now being played under the new substitution rule is as good as it was when platoons were flooding the field every time the ball changed hands had best be left for the coaches to debate, and they promise to do so ad infinitum, without proving anything very much.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Government agencies now can buy only one type of bent wood chair instead of twenty-five varieties.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- The Government took two measures Friday on foreign trade and although their technical scope is limited they are considered important for the future of relations between France and the Organization for European Economic Cooperation on one hand and with the International Monetary Fund on the other.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -The Department of Defense has informed Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, it employs about 500,000 foreign nationals in jobs overseas.
SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 27 -- Although the shooting war is over in Korea, at least for the time being, wartime activities continue as usual on both sides of the two-anda-half-mile demilitarized zone.

Applicants for United States Air Force flight training who might later fail under the stress of combat flying can be spotted in advance and assigned to less exacting duties. This is the substance of a paper presented recently before the American Psychological Association meeting in Cleveland by Dr. John R. Barry of the Air Force School of Aviation Medicine, Randolph Field, Tex.

TRENTON, Sept. 27 -- The New Jersey Department of Institutions and Agencies has allocated $50,000,000 over the last four years for the expansion and improvement of facilities under its control, according to its first major progress report.

Answering the contention by Karl Marx that "religion is the opium of the people," the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken declared yesterday morning in Riverside Church that Christianity acted rather as "a stimulant" for mankind's finest enterprises.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- A project to plug the weepholes in the spandrels of the United Nations Secretariat building and make it watertight will be virtually completed this week after six months of labor and pioneering research.

It was a good summer for printing in the New York area. The New York Employing Printers Association, Inc., yesterday reported that sales for June, July and August were up 14.3 per cent over the same months of 1952. For the first eight months of the year they were up 9.35 over the similar period last year. August was 5.59 better than August, 1952.
In your edition of Sept. 13 you published a letter about the future of my country, proposing to neutralize and demilitarize Austria.

TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 28 -- The Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission is expected to make known today its arrangements enabling both sides in the Korean war to "explain" to prisoners why they should change their minds about rejecting repatriation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia, ranking Democrat on the Senate Armed Services Committee, said tonight he hoped Spain could be brought "completely and fully" into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -Dr. Leon Keyserling, chief economic adviser to the Truman Administration, warned today the nation soon could be in a "substantial recession or even depression" if Americans yielded to a "psychology of (economic) defeatism or fear."

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- A mardi gras parade of 2,600 residents, thirty-one floats and twenty bands opened this city's week-long celebration of its centennial this afternoon. The police estimated that 50,000 persons in a community of 74,000 population lined the streets or occupied three grandstands on the three-mile route from Grand Street and Gramatan Avenue to Hutchinsen Field on Sanford Boulevard.

Panama is celebrating its fiftieth anniversary this year and it is more than fitting that the United States Government should be the host to the friendly and popular President of Panama, Jose Antonio Remon. President Remon reaches Washington today, where he will spend three days.

The battle for batting honors in both of the major leagues went right down to the wire yesterday with Carl Furillo of the Dodgers winning the National prize by two percentage points and Mickey Vernon of the Senators capturing the American loop title by one, The Associated Press reported.
The addition of 300 full-time inspectors to the staff of the Department of Sanitation was urged yesterday by the City Club of New York as a major step in solving the city's street litter problem.

CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Australia issued a proclamation today clarifying the area of the continental shelf over which she is claiming jurisdiction. Where the shelf is common to Australia and other countries, Australia claims jurisdiction extending midway across the Arafura Sea to the Aru Islands which belong to Indonesia, and midway to Dutch New Guinea.

The establishment of the Robert Flaherty Foundation, Inc., with headquarters in the Museum of Modern Art, 21 West Fifty-third Street, was announced yesterday by Mrs. Robert Flaherty, widow of the pioneer documentary film maker.

KARAGANDA, U. S. S. R., Sept. 19 -- This city deep in the Soviet Union's Asiatic heartland is the fastest growing industrial center of these vast inner continental reaches and one that Americans will hear more of as years go by.
The insurance companies' complex new classification plan for automobile liability rates will go into effect today in Connecticut.

" To claim not to be surprised by anything is to admit an incapacity to learn from experience," writes Prof. Albert Gailord Hart in the preface to a second edition of "Money, Debt and Economic Activity,"* an excellent textbook.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Recessions in wheat prices early last week were checked by news from Washington that the Government was starting its surplus food export program, by which it was hoped that sufficient grain would be disposed of to make some impression on the large stocks in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The revised defense budget soon to be proposed by the Eisenhower Administration will be achieved by a new approach to its inherent problems. The method is to assure that whatever "balance of armed forces" is recommended by the Joint Chiefs of Staff there will be, as not before in Federal budget preparation, a balance of defense in relation to the rest of the national budget.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Washington Redskins parlayed two recovered fumbles and a rare 15-yard penalty against opposing Coach Joe Stydahar, to score 17 points in the last quarter today and defeat the Chicago Cardinals, 24 -- 13, in a National Football League opener.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Somebody ought to do something about George Washington's promotion.

Former Vice President Albert W. Barkley dedicated yesterday the new $2,000,000 Charles H. Silver Clinic at Beth Israel Hospital, Seventeenth Street near First Avenue, sharing the platform with a group of interdenominational speakers.

Gabriel M. Liegey of Far Rockaway, Queens, Professor of English at Fordham University for twenty-seven years and part-time professor at the College of Mount St. Vincent for twenty-five years, was an honored guest at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

An old-fashioned, golden-age controversy between a leading singer and an opera impresario developed yesterday when Helen Traubel, eminent Wagnerian soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, refused to sign a contract to sing there in the coming season.
IT was probably a decade or so ago that Charlie Keller first made the observation.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Sept 28 -- President Syngman Rhee of South Korea assailed today a proposal on the future of Korea that was reported to have been prepared by the United States for introduction at the Korean peace conference.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -The Athletics whipped the Senators, 9 -- 2, in the final game of the season today. Joe Coleman scattered ten hits while the A's pounded Bunky Stewart, the starter and loser, and Walt Masterson for thirteen blows. Mickey Vernon, the Senators' first baseman, got two of the Washington hits to clinch the league batting title.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27 -- The steel ingot rate for the country last week was 94 per cent of rated capacity, up 2 1/2 points from the revised rate in the week before. Most of this increase was due to the settlement of the wildcat strike at Lackawanna, N. Y.

Protestants, Roman Catholics and Jews paid tribute yesterday to the democratic precepts of this country and pledged anew their faith in the religious principles of brotherhood, understanding and goodwill.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, said tonight that his forces in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would give an excellent account of themselves, but were not strong enough to withstand all-out aggression.

The question of the truthfulness of Robert F. Wagner Jr., Manhattan Borough President, and Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council, candidates for Mayor on the Democratic and Liberal party tickets, respectively, continued yesterday to be an issue in the Mayoralty campaign.
Barely able to meet its normal maintenance requirements and facing a $75,000,000 backlog of work accumulated since before World War II, the Board of Education has called for professional assistance.

The opening of a new restaurant is a trial for owner, chef, waiters and, not the least concerned, the guests themselves. The management invariably feels the date was set too early, and that had it been a week later all those unfinished details concerning kitchen, decor and personnel would have been completed.

BERLIN, Sept. 27 (UP) -- All East German Government workers among the almost 5,000,000 persons who have picked up free United States food packages in West Berlin are to be discharged, the East German Communists said today.

The Yankees wound up their 1953 American League season on a rather dismal note at the Stadium yesterday as they dropped the opener of a scheduled double- header with Lou Boudreau's Red Sox, 2 to 1, then got nowhere at all in the so-called second game to the general disappointment of a crowd of 22,070.

What the Government does when it needs money is being tried by the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers Union, A. F. L., to keep itself from going bankrupt as a result of its eleven-week strike against the Hat Corporation of America at South Norwalk, Conn.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 27 -A thanksgiving service for "the beginning of peace in Korea" highlighted prayers this afternoon on Mount Zion in Jerusalem for the peace of the world. The service was a modern adaptation of the ancient temple service of the Feast of Tabernacles when seventy oxen were sacrificed as an offering for peace for all nations.

For more than sixty years Beth Israel Hospital, in lower Manhattan, has served its community well. To it have come men and women of all races, creeds and colors. The institu tion stands in the very heart of a community of two million persons representing twenty-four nationalities.

CAMP FRIEDLAND, Germany, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Repatriated German prisoners of war reported today three former servants of Adolf Hitler and fourteen former German Army generals were still in a Soviet camp in the Ural Mountains.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- Despite opposition from non-Communist union leaders, the Communist-led General Confederation of Labor pushed ahead today with its drive to create united action among French workers by organizing a "national conference on unity" among postal workers.
Ship brokers agreed last week that the charter market showed a bit more firmness and grounds for guarded optimism.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 27 - Arthur Knapp sailed William H. Stanley's Bumble Bee for the last time today. The 46-year-old Larchmont skipper guided the craft to a fifty-five second victory over Cornedius Shields' Aileen in the Larchmont regatta to end a dozen years of successful competition in the International class, the last decade at the helm of Bumble Bee.

Last Wednesday (September 23) Federal Judge Harold R. Medina dismissed the Government's suit against seventeen of the country's leading investment banking houses, a suit based on the charge -- to put it in its simplest terms -- that these firms had conspired to monopolize the nation's securities underwriting business.

Christian students have the duty to seek out truth in the universe instead of viewing education solely as a means of attaining a "job and money and what we call success," the Rev. Dr. John McGill Krumm, chaplain of Columbia University, declared yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 27 (AP) -Otto Graham hit on eighteen of twenty-four passes for 291 yards today, leading the Cleveland Browns to an easy 27-0 victory over the Green Bay Packers before 22,604 fans at Milwaukee County Stadium in the National Football League opener.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- There has been a big increase in trade recently between Western countries and Communist China, the Eisenhower Administration reported today, but it said it was resisting heavy pressure to force stricter embargoes by friendly nations.

The second half of the world chess championship challengers' tournament started last night with seven games of the sixteenth round in Zurich. According to a Swiss news report, decisions were recorded in four of the matches and the other three were adjourned.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -Britain will get some cheerful news tomorrow from the Ford Motor Company, which is bringing out a new "people's car" priced around $1,100 -- cheaper than any automobile now on the market here.

The haughty criticism of John Foster Dulles as "immature" is especially inappropriate for Mr. Nehru. It seems to be a far more naive immaturity to conceive of the world conflict as a fight between haughty statesmen which can be resolved by disdaining the merits of the various controversies and finding all solutions in the middle between the disputants.

NEW MARTINSVILLE, W. Va., Sept. 27 -- It wasn't the favored Slo-mo-shun V or even her closest rival in speedboating top layers, Such Crust III, which captured the honors and applause of 50,000 spectators on the Ohio River this afternoon.
The color and spirit of Spain are embodied in a collection of dolls and handicrafts from that country that will go on sale Oct. 5 at Franklin Simon.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 27 -- A young North Carolinian who "crashed" socially prominent New England and Long Island yachting sets was charged today with larceny, burglary and forgery while masquerading as a sports-loving son of a wealthy Connecticut family.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -All along the 12,270-mile air route from Britain to New Zealand technicians are preparing the groundwork for the world's greatest flying event, the LondonChristchurch air race starting Oct. 8.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 27 -- The Iranian Government has not yet decided on a date for the trial of Mohammed Mossadegh, ousted former Premier, and his top civilian and military collaborators on charges of rebellion.

Two separate alicles in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 21 seem to have a connection. On page 23 is an account of a eulogy of FioreUo H. La Guardia at his tomb. On page 28 is the pronouncement of Congressman Jacob K. Javits against a federal sales tax.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept 27 (AP) -- Tony Trabert of Cincinnati turned on the full power of his allcourt game today to overwhelm his Davis Cup partner, Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, for the Pacific Coast men's tennis championship.

Thirty-seven officers and men from the British cruiser Superb were among the 4,000 worshippers yesterday morning at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine) who heard the Rev. Dr. J. Stuart Wetmore declare that the church was "sick" and outline part of the diagnosis that should be made if a cure was to be effected.

Corliss Lamont cited yesterday half a hundred issues on which, he said, he disagreed or had disagreed with the Communists. These disagreements proved, he declared, that he had never been a member of the Communist party, as charged in a Congressional investigation last week.

The orphaned International Longshoremen's Association threatened last night to meet any attempt by the American Federation of Labor to raid its ranks with refusal to load or unload ships manned by A. F. L. seamen.
Former President Harry S. Truman arrived here last night by plane from Kansas City to receive the Four Freedoms award tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Senator Richard B. Russell, Democrat of Georgia, said today Administration cuts in Air Force funds were "wholly inexcusabl? and urged President Eisenhower to step up this country's pilot training program.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 27 -- The task of preparing a child for his first visit to a dentist is the joint responsibility of parents and dentists and calls for tact and honesty, a meeting of the American Society of Dentistry for Children was advised today.

HANOI, Vietnam, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The French High Command announced tonight it had been forced to send air support to Vietnamese battalions to ward off attacks by Vietminh rebel soldiers in a vital sector of the Red River Delta.

Later in the season, football and soccer players at Williston Academy, Easthampton, Mass., will turn out for the annual Mill Award kicking contest. The boys will just kick footballs. There will be no passing, no running, no blocking.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 -- The champion Dodgers today became the "winningest" Brooklyn club in history as they beat one of the "winningest" pitchers in baseball to set a record of 105 triumphs. The previous club high was 104 set by the Brooks of 1942.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 27 -The search for a new dean of the Harvard Divinity School will be the first step in the projected program for creating an important center of religious learning at the university, a university spokesman said today.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 27 -The Swedish international sixmeter yacht, Maybe VI, owned by Sven Salen and sailed by C. H. Norderskiold, came in second, as she did in yesterday's race, and it was good enough to capture the national small boat open championship today.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 27 -- Last week's reopening, after fourteen years, of the Rotterdam corn futures market, reflects the sharply improved Dutch monetary position. No obstacles are put in the way of Dutch and foreign traders to deal in this market.
In this, the first of two articles comparing the Yankees and Dodgers, we will take up the offense. And right off we strike a snag.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- The state aid to education formula is inadequate and ineqitable and must be revised if the schools are to weather their financial crisis and meet their responsibilities, Dr. James E. Allen Jr., Deputy State Commissioner of Education, declared here today.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Southpaw Warren Spahn won his twenty-third game of the season today as he hurled the Braves to an 8-to-2 victory over the Redlegs.

Exports of American cotton textiles in the first half of 1953 were 330,178,867 square yards, a drop of 14.3 per cent from those in the corresponding period of 1952, N. S. W. Vanderhoef, chairman of the board of the Textile Export Association of the United States, announced over the week-end. The decline from the 1951 level was 20.5 per cent.

The system of political commissars controlling Soviet agriculture has been abolished and replaced by a new organizational mechanism designed to tighten Communist party control over the admittedly backward collective farms of the Soviet Union.

After grappling for nearly ten hours with the problem of what to do with the moribund Browns, the American League club owners last night turned down the proposed shift of the St. Louis franchise to Baltimore. The secret ballot vote was 4 -- 4, with six affirmative votes needed to approve the transfer.
HAMILTON, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- Despite the setback at the hands of Cornell, Colgate is far from ready to write off its football team as a loss.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- V. K. Krishna Menon, the Indian representative, told the United Nations General Assembly today that he would like to have an explanation of a statement by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles that "the Republic of Korea has no ambitions which run beyond Korea."

To commemorate the 100th anniversary of the piano-making firm of Steinway Sons, Dimitri Mitropoulos and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, the First Piano Quartet and thirty solo pianists will play a special concert at Carnegie Hall on Monday, Oct. 19.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The charge that British authorities had besieged the village of Hamasa in the disputed Buraimi oasis and had threatened with death all seeking to enter the area was made tonight in a statement from the Saudi Arabian Embassy here.

Salvatore Tarto Sollazzo, imprisoned as the "master briber" of thirty-one college basketball players, lost by default yesterday a judgment involving $924,313 in back Federal income taxes and penalties.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Sept. 29 -- The United Nations Command disclosed today that it had filed a protest yesterday against a letter distributed to Korean war prisoners by the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission in which the latter guaranteed the captives their freedom to return to their homes.

Representatives of medical and drug advertisers, their specialized agencies and their publications gathered yesterday for the first meeting of its kind in a luncheon seminar at the Barclay Hotel sponsored by the Association of Medical Advertising Agencies.

Earnings of Universal Pictures Company, Inc., for the thirty-nine weeks to Aug. 1 were almost equal to the income reported for the entire year of 1952, according to the figures to be mailed to stockholders today.

Thousands of rush-hour and other passengers were delayed yesterday morning by a three-hour disruption on the East Side lines of the I. R. T. subway. The cause was the derailment at 8:28 A. M. of a truck on an empty train that was being shifted from the north-bound express track to the south-bound express track at Lexington Avenue and 129th Street to accommodate crowds caused by the taking out of service of a south-bound express.

Changes in bylaws designed to bar three supporters of Mayor Impellitteri in the recent primary from re-election as Tammany district leaders were approved last night as the New York County Democratic Committee met at St. Nicholas Arena, 69 West Sixty-sixth Street, to reorganize.

TOMMY HENRICH has been out of the Yankees organization for too long, but he still ranks as the perfect example of the perfect Yankee. He speaks of his old team-mates with the affectionate admiration of an Old Grad and he was talking about them at dinner the other night.

The bibelot, that useless if often charming decorative object so much a part of Victorian rooms, is returning to the contemporary scene in large numbers, to judge from recent model rooms. Bibelot, a French word, originally meant plaything: our word bauble comes from it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today the reported escape of Lavrenti P. Beria, deposed Soviet Minister of Internal Affairs, "begins to appear like a hoax."

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 28 -- A program calling for improvement in the fields of education, irrigation and public works in the Achin (Atjeh) district of northern Sumatra was announced today by First Vice Premier Wongsonegoro.

The Warren Petroleum Corporation and its subsidiaries increased net income for the fiscal year ended June 30 to $10,230,032, or $6.02 a common share, from $8,163,717, or $4.80 a share, for the preceding fiscal year.

Former President Harry S. Truman, paying a one-day visit to New York to receive the Four Freedoms award, took time out yesterday to voice his approval of Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan, the Democratic candidate for Mayor.

The prediction that Brazil would pay off its commercial backlog here by the end of the year and that early next year it would be the first Latin nation to complete repayment of its lend-lease debt to the United States was made here yesterday by Jose Maciel Filho, executive director of the Brazilian National Economic Development Bank and director of the Superintendency of Money and Credit.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 28 -- The first performance of "On Hemlock Brook," a two-act play by Arnold Sundgaard, which was commissioned by the Williamstown Bicentennial Committee, took place tonight. The play will be repeated every night this week through Saturday as part of the town's bicentennial celebration, which began Friday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The United States has asked Israel to accede to the United Nations request to stop work temporarily on its Jordan River canal project, near the Syrian border.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The Warsaw radio announced tonight that the Polish Government had suspended the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, from his duties. It said the Primate had been "allowed to retire to a monastery."

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 28 (Reuters) -- The International Cotton Committee's three-day meeting which ended here today voted against the establishment of a world cotton agreement proposed by the International Cotton Advisory Committee in Washington.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 28 -- Seven British explorers arrived here today from a remote part of Greenland, not knowing about such events as the Korean armistice and the fall of Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, former Premier of Iran.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, asserted today that he had not in any way changed his mind about the desirability of a conference of the heads of state of the leading nations and he bluntly denied that his advocacy of a meeting had caused conflict with his colleagues.

Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College, opened its sixty-fifth year at a special convocation yesterday in McMillin Theatre on the Columbia University campus. The convocation was held there because of the major reconstruction of Milbank Hall, Barnard's main classroom building.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 28 -- Burma has offered Ceylon 250,000 to 600,000 tons of rice annually on a five-year contract beginning next year at a sliding price that would be highest during the first year and lowest in the-last year of the contract.

The straightening of old highways and the building of new ones have brought about during recent years the appearance in increasing numbers of neatly lettered signs -- firmly attached to white posts and placed across what once were well-traveled thoroughfares -- reading "Road Closed."
