Notre Dame ran away with the honors yesterday in the first weekly Associated Press poll of 1953 to determine the ten best college football teams.

THE run of large snapper blues along the Connecticut shore of Long Island Sound is being described as remarkable, and the same term could be employed to designate the number of anglers perched on rocks, jetties, piers, docks and sandbars filling assorted containers with these fish.
Another will of Orlando F. Weber Jr., 33-year old ornithologist and actor, who died Sept. 13, leaving several million dollars, was filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- "An informal meeting" of the heads of government of the Big Four was suggested today by V. K. Krishna Menon, the Indian representative to the United Nations General Assembly. He told the Assembly that this might not produce a "magical" formula, but that it should at least "clear the air."

Coley Wallace, 204, New York, former Golden Gloves heavyweight champion, stopped Bill Gilliam, 211, East Orange, N. J., in 2:18 of the fourth round of a listed ten-rounder at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.

" You can't force a free market, and the Treasury has no intention of doing so." These are the words of W. Randolph Burgess, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, and they were spoken before the final session of the annual meeting of the American Bankers Association. It is the special function of Dr. Burgess to develop and shape Treasury policy in the field of debt management.

Stations WOR and WOR-TV and its 163 striking engineers and technicians agreed on a new twenty-one-month contract yesterday, ending a strike that began on Aug. 18. Ninety-six radio engineers will return to work this morning, exactly six weeks after the strike began, but the return of sixty-seven television workers will be delayed pending the resumption of programs over Channel 9.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The State Department said today that the thinking here on the future of Korea was in the "exploratory" stage, and there were no final decisions for President Rhee to take exception to.

The belated discovery that George Washington's promotion from lieutenant general to general never reached him serves at least to remind us that this nation had heroic beginnings and a real hero in this reserved gentleman from Virginia who had to content himself with three stars instead of a galaxy.

Your editorial of Sept. 22 "Communism and the Churches" severely criticizes the House of Representatives' Committee on Un-American Activities for releasing the testimony relating to Communist infiltration of the churches.

We publish today the second of a series of articles by our Moscow correspondent, now touring Central Asia, an area hitherto closed to Western visitors for many years. It is good that the Soviet Government has at least reduced some of the old senseless secrecy surrounding this vast region, though it is unfortunate that our correspondent's reports must continue to pass through Soviet censorship.

In comparing the Yankees and Dodgers on defense we move into that phase of play wherein the Bombers admittedly excel. In fact, their entire bid for a fifth straight world title rests pretty much on how well the Stengeleers' customarily smooth defense, emphasized by pitching, manages to fend off the superior batting power of the Brooks.
Wholesale salesmen want more time to show their lines to resident buyers and have requested standardization of buying office procedures to accomplish this objective.
Bags, gloves and jewelry are effective as well as necessary accents to a woman's costume. The general simplicity of this fall's dresses and suits provides a perfect background for accessories.

Donations to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program last Friday totaled 715 pints, of which 315 pints were contributed by employes of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company, 29 Ryerson Street, Brooklyn. Of the 347 pints of blood collected on Saturday, 253 were donated at the Flatbush offices of the Lincoln Savings Bank of Brooklyn.

After rising moderately in the last two weeks the steel industry's operating rate is scheduled to ease slightly this week to 94.9 per cent of theoretical capacity, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This would mean production of 2,139,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, and would compare with actual operations of 95.1 per cent last week and output of 2,144,000 tons.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- A two-year project to study and improve the administration of the public schools of the state was announced here today at the seventy-first annual meeting of the State Council of City and Village School Superintendents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The United States and Japan announced agreement today on jurisdiction over offenses involving members of the United States armed forces in Japan. Generally, it followed the lines of a provision in the North Atlantic Treaty coving American servicemen in Europe that went into effect Aug. 23.

While Samuel Reshevsky, United States, figured in an adjournment in his game postponed with Mark Taimonov, Russia, from the fifteenth round, Vassily Smyslov, Russia, increased his lead by drawing an unfinished game from the same round with Tigran Petrosian, Russia, after forty-eight moves, in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich, last night.

A portable lunch wagon and a parking lot on East Twenty-first Street, about 215 feet west of Bridge Plaza, in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by D. Alien Dillenberg through his Knickerbocker Main Street Corporation to the Arendas Realty Holding Corporation, of which Harry Roslin is president.

Playing strength among college football teams cannot be equalized by legislation, Lou Little of Columbia told the Football Writers Association at its weekly luncheon meeting at Toots Shor's yesterday.

The State Harness Racing Commission rejected yesterday as incompletely filled out the 1,000 "processed" applications for re-employment at Yonkers Raceway. It turned back the forms to the Yonkers Trotting Association, operator of the raceway, for reprocessing and made clear that the track would remain closed until a thorough check had been made on all the applications.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 28 -- The United States Supreme Court was asked today to rule on the constitutionality of the Connecticut law establishing a minimum price schedule on liquor sold in package and drug stores in the state.

DETROIT, Sept. 28 -- Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president and publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, told the Economic Club of Detroit today that skillful communication of democratic ideas, rather than sheer weight of armaments or economic power, was the ultimate safeguard of our free society.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 28 -- Although Hal Wallis, the producer, isn't ready to talk yet, the chances are exceedingly good that he will engage Robert Ryan to co-star with Shirley Booth in "About Mrs. Leslie." The assignment would represent a marked departure from the diamond - in - the- rough type casting of the actor.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Sept. 28 -- The high court in Jerusalem interrupted its summer recess today to grant an order nisi against the inspector general of police and the military commander of Jerusalem requiring them to show cause why they should not revoke an administrative order banishing four Arabs of Abu Ghosh clan from their village near Jerusalem to other parts of Israel.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 28 (UP) -- The 6-year-old son of a wealthy Kansas City business man was kidnapped from a Roman Catholic school here today by a woman who represented herself to be the boy's aunt.

Your editorial "Europe At a Crossroads" rightly suggests that the Strasbourg effort to create a European union by political means is getting nowhere. Has there in fact ever been a historical instance where political union was achieved except through economic association or through military conquest?

Women headed by Mrs. Herbert T. Mundin and including Mrs. Alfred Corning Clark are active in plans for the fourth annual entertainment known as the Fan Ball, which will be held Nov. 16 in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of Children's Memorial Cancer Fund, Inc.

BUFFALO, Sept. 28 -- Agreement that day-dreaming is the major factor in accidents on superhighways was voiced today by the country's leading traffic experts, but how to counter this situation drew sharp differences of opinion.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- In a message to the sponsors of Christian Education Week President Eisenhower said today that there was great need for daily devotion to God.

" THE Roosevelts would suffer grievously in a police state," Nicholas Roosevelt remarks in his reminiscences, "A Front Row Seat,"* "for freedom of expression is one of their most cherished privileges, including, specifically, freedom to criticize their relatives, whether asked to do so or not. The mere fact that one of them occupies the White House has never been a deterrent to cousinly candor."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Army today placed Lieut. Gen. William M. Hoge in command of the United States Army in Europe and named Lieut. Gen. Anthony C. McAuliffe, now Deputy Chief of Staff for Operations and Administration at Army headquarters here, to succeed him as commander of the Seventh Army in Germany.
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Prices in most groups advanced modestly on the stock markets here today, although large scale trading was inhibited by the approach of the end of the bookkeeping account.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today that he would not support a New Deal Democrat, Norris E. Dodd, for reelection as Director General of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Strong markets were the rule on the Board of Trade today. Selling in all pits was absorbed easily and buyers appeared to be encouraged by the action of the market. Wheat absorbed much long profit-taking pressure early, then established new highs for the day.
I agree with everything that One-Time Teacher says in your issue of Sept. 16. But the most pressing problem of today, the recruitment of new teachers, he does not mention.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 28 -- The Netherlands Government ordered a 5 per cent wage increase today, effective next Jan. 1. The Cabinet decision followed the recommendation of a committee of experts called in when representatives of employers and workers were unable to agree on the extent of a wage rise both agreed was necessary.

OKOLONA, Miss., Sept. 27 -- There is nothing quite like a Congressional bus tour. It is the long haul home with tired children after a vacation, the hilarity of a high school band en route to a football game, a week of breakfasts of ham and dinners and suppers of barbecue chicken, beef and pork, and the thought of a job well done, all wrapped up in one package.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The British European Airways said today in its annual report that it had suffered a net less of 1,459,131 ($4,085,566) during the fiscal year ended last March 31, 2.5 per cent more than in the previous year.

The Armed Services Textile and Apparel Procurement Agency will terminate its activities on Oct. 31, it was announced yesterday. Immediately thereafter textiles, apparel, footwear, equippage and related items formerly bought under a combined program by the agency will be purchased individually under a coordinated procurement program by the Army, Navy and Marine Corps.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Yugoslavia charged today that Bulgaria was pursuing a "policy of hostility" toward this country instead of cooperating for the return of "normal" diplomatic relations in Eastern Europe.

Al Lopez, who piloted the Indians to three straight second-place finishes in the American League, yesterday signed a new two-year contract to manage the team, General Manager Hank Greenberg disclosed.

" World Power in the Balance," a new work by Tibor Mende, a French political analyst, will be published by Noonday Press on Oct. 26. The work interprets the shifts of power in the last half-century and the roles the United States and Soviet Russia are playing in shaping the fate "of our grandchildren's world."

The major New York hotels were filled to capacity and the smaller ones were absorbing the overflow yesterday as close to a quarter million persons began converging on the city for the opening of the world series.

In an editorial on Sept. 23, you flatter the New Deal by stating that the recent proposals of Beardsley Ruml before the Ways and Means Committee represent ideas "first put forward by certain self-styled economists in the New Deal nearly twenty years ago.
Following is the text of the address by former President Harry S. Truman in accepting the annual award of the Four Freedoms Foundation, Inc., as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Five candidates for Mayor yesterday attended a Harlem luncheon of the Urban League of Greater New York in a bid for the support of Negro voters. They all promised to seek an end to discrimination in housing and in public and private employment.
The Board of Higher Education set up the machinery last night to begin a full-scale investigation of subversive activities in the city's four colleges.
A new issue of bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development will go on sale simultaneously today in six of the world's major financial centers.

The stock market followed the bond market into higher ground yesterday, touching the best level's since Sept. 10. Treasury bonds spurted in the over-the-counter market on the announcement of changed Treasury financing plans, some of the longer-term issues jumping 3/8 to 9/16.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, struck out yesterday against Rudolph Halley and Robert F. Wagner Jr. as "puppets" who would "surrender to sinister forces which have exploited and ruined our city administration."

The American League, after more than eleven hours of discussion over two days, still had not decided last night what to do with the Browns, although the owners were quite certain that the club would not operate in 1954 on the banks of the Mississippi.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Sept. 28 -- Jack Maher, in his twenty- fifth season as head coach of The Choate School's football squad, put on the usual doleful look today when questioned about his team's prospects. It was nothing new. Maher, who almost always comes up with a strong team, never is optimistic in pre-season prognostications.

Four newspaper men will be honored by Columbia University for their roles in the "advancement of international friendship in the Americas" when the 1953 Maria Moors Cabot gold medals are awarded to them at a special convocation in the rotunda of the university's Low Memorial Library at 3 P. M. on Friday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 28 tiP) ---At least twenty-two men lost] their lives today when a plane car-I tying soldiers from Camp Kilmer, N. J., crashed and burned at / Standiford Field here. All theI twenty other persons on board theI i twb-engine plane were injured.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- For the first time since taking office, President Eisenhower received a Chief of State in an official state visit today. The visitor was Jose Antonio Remon, President of Panama.

The Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation exhibited yesterday what it said was the first commercial compatible color television receiver styled for home use and designed for mass production. The set, which will retail for $700, was shown to members of the New York Society of Security Analysts at a meeting of the group in Schwartz' Restaurant, 54 Broad Street.
MONT JOLI, Que., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Two Quebec bush pilots have sold for "more than $1,000,000" their claims to iron ore deposits discovered while flying over rugged country in northwestern Quebec.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Despite the strong Administration pressures against passage of the Bricker Amendment, which is principally designed to prevent any treaties from being self- executing when they supervene domestic laws otherwise reserved to the states in the Constitution, the Congressional support of the amendment appears to have become more militant.

Two important races were presented at Belmont Park yesterday, with the result, in each instance, in complete disagreement with the general forecast. In the first of these offerings, the Anticipation Purse, the victory went to the Llangollen Farm's Porterhouse, with the favored Fisherman finishing fifth.
MARGATE, England, Sept. 28 -- The right-wing of the Labor party won a significant victory at today's opening of the party's national conference.

OTTAWA, Sept. 28 -- R. G. Casey, Australian Minister of External Affairs, who is here discussing common problems with Canadian Ministers, explained today why his country did not welcome any extension of the pact among Australia, New Zealand and the United States and could not relax import restrictions against dollar goods.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein has asked President Eisenhower's newly appointed Commission on Intergovernmental Relations to study the affairs of the Long Island Rail Road as an example of "wasteful and damaging conflict of authority" between the Federal and state Governments.

Walter C. Thompson has become executive vice president of the Torrington Company of Torrington, Conn. He succeeds Alfred W. Burg, who is retiring after thirty-seven years with the company. Ray B. Nichols succeeds Mr. Thompson as vice president in charge of sales.

Pier negotiations took a sudden turn for the worse yesterday when the International Longshoremen's Association increased its demands and gave employers until noon tomorrow to accept them on pain of a strike at 12:01 A. M. Thursday.

Robert G. Thompson, New York State Chairman of the Communist party, got a lawyer yesterday after reporting that he was having great difficulty in obtaining counsel in his contempt case, and Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman set Oct. 13 for trial.

A strong demand for "used" houses in Teaneck, N. J., is reported by the Hackensack branch office of J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker. The dwellings are offered in a wide variety of prices, the Kislak office said.
" What 14-year-old boy told his 15-year-old girl friend that he is 15 ?"

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The State Department received today the summary of a note from the Soviet Union that apparently suggested the possibility of a Big Five conference that would include Communist China, along with the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- A vaccine now being tested to combat a devastating cattle disease prevalent in New York State as septicemia, is known locally as well as in many other parts of the world has been developed by scientists, attached to the United Nations technical assistance program in Burma, it was announced here today by David Owen, executive chairman of the United Nations Technical Assistance Board.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UP) -- Aluminum scrap dealers told a Senate Small Business subcommittee today that the Air Force is losing money through unnecessary competition with private business.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- A total of 820,000 immigrants, more than half of Israel's population, has entered the new nation since 1948, David Horowitz, governor of the new Central Bank of Israel, reported today.

BERLIN, Sept. 28 -- The two most important figures in East Germany, who recently have been reported on the way out as a result of the June riots against Government decrees, are emerging stronger than ever.

An important development which should contribute to the security of the Pacific area has taken place in Japan, where Premier Yoshida has reached agreement with his conservative opposition on a bipartisan program of straightforward rearmament to defend the country against Communist aggression.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- Following are excerpts from the text of an address today by V. K. Krishna Menon, Indian delegate, at the United Nations General Assembly:

Today's recipes were devised principally for the busy woman who must rush home from the office to prepare dinner for her family. They are substantial main dishes for which most of the preparation can be accomplished in advance, thus leaving only a minimum of work to be done at the last minute.

Senator Wayne Morse served notice last night that if the 1954 elections resulted in an evenly divided Senate, he would switch his deciding vote to give the Democrats control of the legislative machinery.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Air Force announced today that it had given the signal for large-scale production of the huge eight-jet Boeing B-52 bomber, the ultimate successor to the "intercontinental'' B-36, and had ordered a supersonic fighter plane, the F-100, into quantity production ahead of schedule.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- It is confidently expected here tonight that Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. will recommend to President Eisenhower that he name Gov. Earl Warren of California to be Chief Justice of the United States and make the appointment so that the court will open next Monday with a full complement of nine members.

Funds contributed for education represent true enrichment. For this reason the entire New York community may well be pleased to learn that a new record in gifts, grants and bequests totaling $10,001,461 has been announced by New York University for the year ended June 30.

The American Red Cross will receive the entire net proceeds from the pari-mutuels, admissions and program and concession sales today at Belmont Park. This will be the first Red Cross benefit day to be held at a race track under the provisions of a special act of Congress last year permitting sports organizations to hold benefits exclusively for the relief organization.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 28 -- A German Red Cross official said today that most of the 1,117,000 German soldiers reported missing after having been taken prisoner by the Russians probably were dead and that only a few thousand prisoners could be expected to return home from the Soviet Union.

When Edouard Frederic-Dupont, "Mayor'' of Paris, visited City Hall yesterday to invest Mayor Impellitteri with the baldric of an honorary President of the Municipal Council of Paris, Mr. Impellitteri remarked that this honor would, in any event, "give me something to think about after the first of the year"

HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 28 -- A mud-encrusted wooden pier pile was lifted out of the Hudson River bed here shortly before noon today as construction began on this city's first new pier in twenty-five years.

A brilliant object that was seen by at least a dozen persons as it crossed the sky over this city from east to west at approximately 6:30 last evening was said by S. I. Gale, a guest lecturer at the Hayden Planetarium, to have been most probably a fireball.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Food chain operators were urged today by Franklin J. Lunding, chief executive officer of the Jewel Tea Company, to put their weight against any Government "boondoggling" expenditures that produce nothing for the general good.

A syndicate headed by First of Michigan Corporation is offering $1,200,000 of bonds of the Springfield, Mich., School District. The bonds, sold to the bankers by negotiation, incurred an interest cost of 3.59 per cent for the borrowing district. Maturing from 1955 to 1971, they were reoffered at yields ranging from 2 per cent to 3.35 per cent.
Carl Erskine and Allie Reynolds will be the starting pitchers for the Dodgers and Yankees, respectively, when the fiftieth world series opens at the Yankee Stadium at 1 o'clock tomorrow afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- At 10:17 o'clock this morning the way was cleared for Comdr. Herman MacGolrick Kennickell of the United States Navy to drop down to a mere lieutenant (j. g.). Anyhow, he wanted it that way.

Former President Harry S. Truman called last night for nonpartisan support of "a really strong defense" and a readiness -- "in firm agreement with our allies and from a position of united strength" -- to negotiate solution of differences with the Soviet bloc.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 28 -- The Vietminh rebel radio in Indo-China said today there was no possibility of peace negotiations with France. In a commentary monitored here it described any hope of an early peace as "Utopian."
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 -- The freighter Mankato Victory was seized by Federal customs agents in San Francisco Bay today soon after she had unloaded 286 American war dead.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Judge Evan Howell has resigned from the United States Court of Claims to become chairman of the Illinois Toll Roads Commission and to practice law in Springfield, Ill., Washington and Chicago.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 28 -- Yugoslavia formally rejected today a proposal by Italy for a plebiscite in the Free Territory of Trieste to decide whether the area should go to either country.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- Former President Harry S. Truman kept strictly to the role of a private citizen today when he arrived at United Nations headquarters to be the guest of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold at a small luncheon in the dining room of Mr. Hammarskjold's official suite.
MANCHESTER, England, Sept. 28 (Reuters) -- Vivian Leigh made a triumphant return to the footlights tonight when she played her first stage part since her nervous breakdown last March.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Northeast Airlines, the Atlas Corporation, Airfleets, Inc., and the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation (Convair) have been accused of violating the Civil Aeronautics Act in the sale of planes to the Italian airline, Alitalia Aeroline Italiane.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- The widespread use of transistors in electric products is not yet practical cost-wise, Robert W. Galvin, executive vice president of Motorola Inc., said today.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The text of a message to Chinese and North Korean prisoners of war from the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission follows:

Charles E. Bohlen, American Ambassador to the Soviet Union, was delayed forty minutes by airplane backfire problems as he started yesterday by American Airlines from La Guardia Airport for "brief consultations" with Secretary of State John Foster Dulles. He finally left at 2:55 P. M.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- The Arab states renewed their six-year-old attack on Israel in the United Nations today, accusing her of blocking the internationalization of Jerusalem and blaming her for the plight of Arab refugees displaced by the Palestine war.

WENTWORTH, England, Sept. 28 (UP) -- Eight members of the United States Ryder Cup golf team practiced today on the West course, with Sam Snead out-driving his countrymen in the Scotch foursomes workout.

ROME, Sept. 28 -- The six-power conference, in which France, Italy, West Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg are seeking to draft a constitution for a proposed European federation of states, ran into rough waters today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, put three witnesses on the stand today to support his charge that an Army study of life in Siberia, designed for the guidance of American occupation forces in the event of war with Russia, was loaded with Communist propaganda.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- The United Nations was warned today that its world-wide Technical Assistance Program, launched in 1950 to help underdeveloped lands combat poverty, ignorance and disease, was facing a period of stagnation and retrenchment.

TRENTON, Sept. 28 -- The Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court upset today the conviction and prison sentence of two to three years imposed on Michael Orecchio, former Bergen County chief of detectives, on charges of misconduct in office.
Lebanon Hospital built a doghouse yesterday around a blessed event that occurred on the lawn outside of its maternity division in the early hours of the morning.

The long delayed agreement with Spain granting the United States air and naval bases strengthens the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's Meditterranean flank, but at a cost that is as yet impossible to assess.

" The Strong Are Lonely," a drama about the Jesuits conversion of the Indians in Paraguay in the seventeenth century and the events leading up to the Indian revolt against the invading Spanish army, will open this evening at the Broadburst Theatre at 7:30 o'clock.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 -- President Eisenhower told the thirty-fifth National Recreation Congress tonight that proper use of the increased leisure time made possible by scientific development could contribute "richly" to the life of Americans and their communities.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Two railroad leaders charged here today that the government was letting truck lines drain the freight "cream" from the railroads through an outmoded transportation policy.
Fur skins of rare beauty, subtly handled for a custom retail collection, were shown to the press yesterday morning by Joseph Bernham in his penthouse studio at 16 East Fifty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Eric Johnston, chairman of the reconstituted International Development Advisory Board, asserted today that its members were "convinced" that the Point Four Program for aid to underdeveloped areas abroad would not be submerged in this country's over-all foreign assistance plan.

TASHKENT, U. S. S. R., Sept. 23 -- Airplanes coming in to land at the Tashkent airdrome circle a high wireless mast, over which the powerful beams of the Tashkent radio flash out over all Asia, and that seems to rear up hundreds of feet almost to flight level.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- The American Meat Institute today took issue with critics who have stated that the retail price of beef has risen while cattle prices declined.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 28 -- A 9-year-old boy who opens safes by touch told the police here today that he was the leader of a gang of juvenile thieves responsible for twenty-six burglaries since February.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady today, unchanged to 14 points net lower than on last Friday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Tuesday, Sept. 29 -- A field goal by Paul Groffsky of the University of Michigan a split second before the end of the game early this morning gave the United States a 25-to-23 victory over Israel and the basketball championship of the Fourth Maccabiah Games.

Building activity in New York City during the first eight months of 1953 showed a gain of 15 per cent over the corresponding period last year, according to preliminary figures compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor. The work started here this year was valued at $249,508,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UP) -- Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of the Navy, said today he had started a move to integrate the largely all-Negro stewards' branch of the Navy as part of a drive to eliminate all remaining forms of Navy segregation.

A group of forty-five, including sixteen handicapped persons, who will make a pilgrimage to religious shrines in Western Europe sailed on the Holland America liner Nieuw Amsterdam yesterday from Hoboken, N. J.

CAIRO, Sept. 28 -- The long-sought British - Egyptian agreement providing for the withdrawal of all British troops from the Suez Canal military base was virtually assured tonight after a two-and-one-half-hour meeting between the British and Egyptian negotiators.
As determined as shoppers in a supermarket crowds jammed the counters of S. Klein's Department Store on Union Square yesterday where more than 100,000 diamonds went on sale.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- The news of the agreements giving the United States bases in Spain was conspicuously published today on this side of the Pyrenees. The inevitable comment was that the accord strengthened the position of the United States on the periphery of Europe whether or not its interest in those marginal areas might increase if the European army planned for the center of Europe should fail to materialize.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Less than a third of the sum due to the United States under World War II lend-lease agreements has been paid, President Eisenhower said in a report to Congress. The report, covering the year ending last Dec. 31, was made public at the White House today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The largest Monday run of hogs since June 22 started this week's trading off to a 25 to 75 cents lower price set-up. Cattle were steady to 50 cents lower but vealer calves and sheep turned steady to $1 higher.

What Wall Street once thought was impossible will take place on Nov. 1 when the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria Corporation pays off the last $2,000,000 of nearly $11,000,000 of income 5 per cent debentures, due in 1954, which it issued in 1934 on emerging from reorganization.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Sept. 28 (UP) -- Jimmy Carter, lightweight champion, regained some lost prestige tonight when he scored a technical knockout over Ben Miloud of Casablanca in a non-title bout before 2,500 spectators.

Mayor Impellitteri yesterday entered the dispute between Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., and the New York City Transit Authority over new economy schedules for city-owned lines by creating a committee to settle the disagreement.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept 28 (UP) -- Large-scale expansion of industry and trade in the next twenty years in his country was forecast today by G. L. Mehta, Ambassador from India.

Long-term collective bargaining agreements have proved a disappointment, the American Management Association's national personnel conference at the Statler Hotel was told yesterday by Campbell W. Elliott, director of industrial relations of the Minneapolis-Moline Company, Minneapolis farm equipment manufacturer.

BOSTON, Sept. 28 -- The importance of plugging "little leaks" in Government spending was emphasized today by Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks as he told the Controllers Institute of America of the need for additional Federal economies.

A promise by Mayor Impellitteri "to make every honest effort in the preparation of my fiscal plans for 1954" to eliminate the highly controversial $5 and $10 automobile use tax that the city has collected for two years was made known yesterday.
The Dominican cruise vessel Nuevo Dominicano is being towed to Miami by the salvage vessel Rescue, the marine salvage department of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation reported yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 28 -- Sweeping revisions of the first two undergraduate years at Yale University, designed to place greater emphasis upon academic learning, were proposed today by a committee of distinguished Yale faculty members headed by Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, the university's president.

THERMAL, Calif., Sept. 28 (AP) -- A Navy combat veteran flew a batwing Douglas F4D Skyray 742.7 miles an hour over a measured course today, faster than any previous run, but through a quirk in international rules failed to set a record.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Sept. 28 -- The Dutch Government has begun an attempt to determine the extent of its sovereignty in waters adjoining western New Guinea.

MONTREAL, Sept. 28 (Canadian Press) -- Members of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., went on strike at noon today on Canadian deep-sea ships. No trouble was reported as crewmen walked off two ships in Montreal.

A New York diamond dealer and a Sabena Belgian Air Lines senior pilot were held in $50,000 bail each yesterday by United States Commissioner Edward McDonald on charges of smuggling $233,230 worth of diamonds into this country.

Rudolph Halley, Liberal party candidate for Mayor, condemned last night the practice of assigning hundreds of city policemen to professional sporting events when they could be used more effectively in fighting crime in the city.

Two new films open today at first-run theatres. At the Fifty- fifth Street Playhouse is a French import, "The Night Is My Kingdom," starring Jean Gabin and Simone Valere. The supporting cast of the drama is headed by Suzanne Dehelly and Gerard Oury. Marcel Rivet wrote the scenario and Georges Lacombe directed. Pierre Gerin produced the Arthur Davis Associates release.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., Sept 28 (AP) -- The 536-foot tanker Ticonderoga, blown almost in two by an explosion that left a hole in her hull big enough to run a train through, arrived in port today from Honolulu.

Even though action on their requests for changes in the pension plan was delayed, major league baseball players, represented by Allie Reynolds and Ralph Kiner, yesterday gained more concessions in five hours than they had in the past eight years.

Commodity prices were irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was light, with only the hides and the domestic sugar markets registering average activity. Wool, sugar, lead, copper and rubber closed mixed; hides, coffee, cocoa, burlap and potatoes lower, and cottonseed oil, soybean oil, zinc and tin higher.

The American Gas and Electric Company reported yesterday earnings of $30,598,141 for the twelve months ended Aug. 31, a gain of 21 per cent over the $25,283,501 net profit for the prior twelve months. Earnings per share were $2.53 for the latest twelve months against $2.21 for the comparable months a year ago.

Parents who worry about the wayward ways of the younger generation may well be worrying needlessly, if they accept their own generation's values. A study of atitudes of a representative group of freshmen and sophomores in a women's eastern university, reported in the current issue of Marriage and Family Living, disclosed that daughters interviewed tend to accept their parents' standards.

BERLIN, Sept. 28 -- An East German who spent nine years as a prisoner of war in the Soviet Union and traveled from one end of the country to the other estimated today that the Russians still were holding 40,000 to 60,000 German prisoners.
Robert W. Wilson in his letter published Sept. 13 wrote twaddle as far as the Navy is concerned when he referred to the armed services as a feudal structure and the enlisted men as peasants.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 28 -- Following yesterday's admonition against physical attacks upon clergymen, Marshal Tito, the President of Yugoslavia, called upon the women of the country today to engage in a reinvigorated effort against priests who were "against the people" and who, he asserted, were working against the Government.

Percy A. Miller Jr. was born in Carlisle, Pa., on June 7, 1899, and received his education in the Irvington, N. J., schools. He is in the insurance business and is a director of the Irvington Trust Company.

The average market price of bonds on the New York Stock Exchange was $95.58 on Aug. 31, the Exchange reported yesterday. A month earlier the figure had been $95.82. The new figure was the lowest since $95.30 on June 30 last.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28---The Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations General Assembly voted today to hearI oral petitions from four native ,groups in the French-administered trust territory of the Cameroons in the face of opposition led by the British and the French.

ROME, Sept. 28 -- The Foreign Ministry refused to comment officially on the Yugoslav note that was handed to the Italian Minister in Belgrade this morning rejecting the Italian proposal of a plebiscite to decide the future of the Trieste Free Territory.

A 16-year-old youth was arrested last night and charged with second-degree arson in connection with a fire that caused an estimated $500,000 damage to Hecht's department store warehouse, Fifteenth Street and the Avenue of the Americas, at the rush hour yesterday afternoon.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 29 -- The light airs of Long Island Sound today could not have been cut to better measure for Switzerland's representative in the opening race for the One-Ton Cup, a six-meter trophy that goes back to the last century.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The second unruly hearing in the Jersey City Commission's inquiry into municipal affairs wound up today with a move to cite Commissioner Frank H. Eggers for contempt.

NEWARK, Sept. 29 -- Retail gasoline prices dropped 2 to 7 cents a gallon today in the second day of a price war among station owners along Routes 1 and 27, between Perth Amboy and Newark Airport. There was also spotty evidence of the war in the Oranges and in Somerset County, where the first signs of a price cut were seen last week.

WASHINGTON Sept. 29 -- President Eisenhower's nomination to fill the present vacancy on the Supreme Court may have more influence on the future of civil liberties in this country than any other decision of his entire Administration.

When Mr. Truman is not confronted with the task of proving that Democrats are always right and Republicans are always wrong he can often make a top-notch speech. He did so on Monday evening at the Waldorf in accepting the annual award of the Four Freedoms Foundation.

MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich., Sept. 29 -- President Eisenhower's denunciation of "book burning" was quoted today in defense of Lieut. Milo J. Radulovich, 26 years old, an Air Force Reservist, as he appeared before an administrative board of three colonels at Sefridge Air Force Base, on charges of being a doubtful security risk.

ROME, Sept. 29 -- The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano called attention today to the "extreme gravity" of the recent events in Poland, where the Primate, Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, has been suspended from his duties and interned in a monastery.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Rated at the top in the East last year Syracuse appeared to be headed toward another big season on the gridiron when misfortune struck.

JOHARABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 17 -- One of the world's greatest land-reclamation projects, daring in its goal and almost overwhelming in its magnitude, is nearing completion on a 2,000,000-acre site that was part of an uninhabited desert waste of 22,000 square miles before 1950.

THE sputter of the beach buggy is loud along the Cape Cod beaches, from Monomoy to Race Point, for the big striped bass have arrived, and fat bluefish are providing all the variety any surfcaster could demand.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Sept. 29 -- Those optimistic individuals who have thought that "The Late Unpleasantness" between the states was cleared up at Appomattox are due for a change of thinking.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Albert M. Cole, administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, predicted today that "definite accomplishments in housing for all the people" would stem from the deliberations of President Eisenhower's Advisory Committee on Housing, which will start its closed-door meetings tomorrow.

A police raid on a midtown ticket agency yesterday resulted in the confiscation of 141 world series tickets and the taking into custody of three men on charges of scalping. Plainclothes police from Deputy Inspector James Nidds' Headquarters Squad made the arrests at the Embassy Theater Ticket Agency, 234 West Fiftieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Since Jan. 20, when the Eisenhower Administration took office, 578 alien criminals and subversives have been deported and "all progress" is being made toward the elimination of these "undesirables." William P. Rogers, Deputy Attorney General, said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Far Eastern Command has asked the Communists to account for nine more servicemen not exchanged under the Korean armistice and not otherwise accounted for.
Directors of the Hygrade Food Products Corporation declared a 100 per cent stock dividend on its common stock yesterday, payable on Oct. 29 to holders of record Oct. 15.

Witnessed by buyers and store executives from all parts of the country, the tiny dressy hat dominated the Millinery Stabilization Commission's showing of winter and holiday designs last night at the Astor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The White House announced that Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. had submitted in writing this afternoon an official but still secret recommendation to President Eisenhower for appointment of a new Chief Justice of the United States.

The women's division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York opened its annual campaign yesterday with a rally of 700 members at the Plaza Hotel. The federation's goal is $16,950,000, of which the women's division hopes to raise $2,450,000.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 29 -- Mrs. Robert Silver of Englewood led the New Jersey section of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association in the qualifying round for the Windle Trophy at Rock Spring today.

The house of Revillon, known for the elegance of its furs, gave the audience previewing its 1953-1954 collection yesterday an agreeable surprise. In addition to furs of superb quality and handling, Revillon showed many gay sports models.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 463 pints of blood on Monday, of which 166 pints were donated at the New York chapter of the Red Cross, Lexington Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street, and 114 by employes of the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company and the Biow Company, Inc., 640 Fifth Avenue.

Volume continued light yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges with only zinc, lead, rubber, burlap and the world sugar market showing slight improvement. The possibility of a dock strike curtailed activity. Zinc, however, had the most activity since Aug. 4.

The five-story building witht thre stores and eight three-I'oom1 apartments at /389 Third Avenue, I outheast corner of Seventy-ninth/ Street, has been sold by Patrick J'/ Delaney to the Elpetha Realty Cor-] poration, of which Vasilios Joanides/ is president. Hardy, Brauneis Taumann, Inc., was the broker.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The State Department tonight released the following unofficial English translation of the Soviet note received yesterday on proposals for big power conference:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Staff investigators for Senators looking for new curbs to place on alleged Communist-dominated labor unions have begun gathering information in Eastern industrial cities.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said today the United States does not propose to ask the free nations of Asia to cut off their trade with Communist China -- except for war goods.
LET'S start at the beginning and try to think this thing out to a reasonably logical conclusion. The beginning is usually recommended as the wisest starting point anyway.

HOUSTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The recent trend toward Government-guaranteed security is the "greatest internal danger" to the nation's economic growth, but there is hope for a change under the new Administration, Edward T. McCormick, president of the American Stock Exchange, declared today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 29 -- Marshal Tito's proposal for internationalization of the city of Trieste is not the final Yugoslav offer in the dispute with Italy, Edvard Kardelj, Vice President of the Federal Executive Council and the No. 2 man in the regime, disclosed today.

The Thomas Crimmins Contracting Company has purchased a vacant industrial plot on Forty-eighth and Forty-ninth Streets, north of Twentieth Avenue, in Long Island City, Queens, through the Cross Brown Company as broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

The fiftieth staging of baseball's major spectacle, the world series, will get off the mark at 1 o'clock today in the Stadium before a gathering expected to top 70,000. Regardless of the outcome in the best-of-seven-game struggle, something new is certain to be written into the records.

The bitter ten-week strike against the Arma Corporation, one of this country's largest manufacturers of electrical and electronic equipment for airplanes, ships and defense bases, was ended last night by the vote of two unions that had walked out in sympathy with a third union, which settled on a new contract yesterday afternoon.

ROME, Sept. 29 -- Giuseppe Pella, Italian Premier and Foreign Minister, has no intention of allowing the Trieste problem to sink back into oblivion after Marshal Tito's rejection of his proposal that the inhabitants of the Free Territory should themselves settle it by a plebiscite, it was stated in Foreign Ministry circles today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Johnny Saxton, fast-moving, swift-punching, clever New York welterweight, pounded out a unanimous ten-round decision over Middleweight Joey Giardello of Philadelphia tonight in the first indoor bout of the season at the Arena.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 29 -- More than 100,000 United States, British, Turkish, Greek and Italian troops will go into action early tomorrow from Sicily to Anatolia in the first large scale. Atlantic alliance maneuvers designed to test the plans for the defense of Thrace and the Turkish straits.

As Mayor Impellitteri proclaimed Fire Prevention Week beginning next Sunday, Fire Commissioner Jacob Grumet called together yesterday in his Municipal Building office leaders of business and industry to map fire prevention on a year-'round basis.

To get directly to the Yankee Stadium by subway, fans can take the Jerome-Woodlawn train of the Lexington Avenue line and get off at 161st Street. They may also take the Lenox Avenue or White Plains Road trains of the Seventh Avenue line to 149th Street and Grand Concourse and then change to the Lexington Avenue line.

DENVER, Sept. 29 -- President Eisenhower's Administration was accused of a "trillion-dollar giveaway of our natural resources" in a speech delivered today before the convention of the Oil Workers Union, C. I. O.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 -- Corporations should look more carefully into recreation as a opportunity for service, Raymond Firestone, vice president of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, said tonight at a general session of the thirty-fifth National Recreation Congress.

An event of some significance will take place at 8 o'clock this evening at the Barrymore, where Deborah Kerr, better known to filmgoers, will be introduced to the local stage as the star of "Tea and Sympathy."

Now that evenings are longer, dining by the soft glow of candlelight is back in favor. In anticipation of this, B. Altman Co. has collected a large group of new designs in silver candleholders that are now on view. Represented are designs from Denmark, France, Italy, Germany and this country.

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Buses of Rockland Coaches, Inc., and its four affiliates, which transport 50,000 passengers daily in Rockland County, N. Y., and northern Bergen County, N. J., ran behind schedule today for the seventh successive day because of the safety campaign the drivers started last Tuesday.

Stock prices for the first hour or two of trading yesterday responded to an accumulation of favorable overnight news developments. But the enthusiasm of traders petered out as the session wore on and bids were lowered sharply on small offerings.

The Board of Health will hold a special meeting tomorrow to consider whether stricter regulation is necessary for gas-flame refrigerators of a type that caused one death and two non-fatal cases of carbon monoxide poisoning on Saturday.

Retailers who have planned properly to meet consumer demand will have a record business in men's spring worsted suits during the first quarter of 1954, Michael Daroff, president of H. Daroff Sons, Inc., Philadelphia, predicted yesterday at the company's annual sales meeting.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Heavy profit-taking on early bulges weakened the grain market today. With the decline in demand, local professionals shifted to the selling side, helping along the reaction. Soybeans showed relative strength, and there apparently was some spreading going on in the way of buying of beans and selling of grains.

BUFFALO, Sept. 29 -- A majority of parking lot operators in the midtown and lower sections of Manhattan will increase hourly minimum rates for parking from 75c to $1, it was reported today at the annual meeting of the Institute of Traffic Engineers.

The New York City Housing Authority arranged yesterday for the borrowing of $48,658,000 for the temporary financing of two state-aided projects -- the Stephen Foster Houses in Harlem and the Governor Smith Houses on the lower East Side.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Negotiators for the United States and Chile said today that talks were continuing on Chile's request that this country buy 100,000 tons of surplus Chilean copper for the American stockpile. The negotiations have been going on here for the past two weeks.

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y., Sept. 29 (AP) -- A slight, brief recession was predicted today by the vice president and treasurer of a large New York department store. Kenneth C. Richmond of Abraham Straus said the decline in retail sales would be caused by a slackening of business activity following the Korean war.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 29 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies tonight urged the fullest possible interchange of atomic information between the British Commonwealth and the United States. Deploring excessive emphasis on the idea that the free nations were in competition, Mr. Menzies said the prospect of war between Britain and the United States was unthinkable.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A meager clue, and intimations the kidnappers of 6-year-old Bobby Greenlease were trying to make contact, brought a faint bit of hope today to his parents.
BERLIN, Sept. 29 -- Dr. Ernst Reuter, West Berlin's Mayor and one of the best friends of the United States in Europe, died here suddenly tonight of a heart attack. He was 64 years of age.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Ambassador Winthrop W. Aldrich attempted today in a speech at a luncheon meeting of the American Chamber of Commerce in London to dispel the fear, widespread in Britain and on the Continent; that a depression might soon occur in the United States.
TOKYO, Sept. 29 -- Japan's Foreign Minister, Katsuo Okazaki, departed for Southeast Asia today in a major move of the Japanese Government to regularize its relations with its Asian neighbors.

Governor Dewey's order directing the State Insurance Department to investigate the health and welfare funds of Local 32-E of the Building Service Employes Union, A. F. L., is a step in the right direction. The inquiry, however, should be extended to all union welfare funds in the state.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- The plight of Arab refugees displaced five years ago when fighting broke out in Palestine has reached urgent proportions and "the urgency increases every day," the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees reported here today.

Public Works Commissioner Zurmuhlen has given the city good news with his announcement that at long last the end of the Brooklyn Bridge reconstruction job is in sight. Tomorrow the newly completed north roadway and approaches will be opened and one-way traffic, which has been in effect since the rehabilitation work began, in March, 1950, will shift over from the south roadway.

ALBANY, Sept. 29 -- Frank C. Moore will resign tomorrow as lieutenant governor and his successor, Senator Arthur H. Wicks of Kingston, majority leader and president pro tempore of the State Senate, will be sworn in as acting lieutenant governor on Thursday.

CAIRO, Sept. 29 -- Israeli troops last night occupied an area near El Auja in the demilitarized zone along the Egyptian frontier, the Government announced today, adding that it regarded the action to be a "dangerous breach" of the Palestine armistice agreement.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- A recommendation by the National Employers Association that private industry pay its workers no less than 110 Francs (slightly more than thirty-one cents) an hour drew undeservedly hostile reactions from organized labor today.

YONKERS, Sept. 29 -- Mrs. Richard Nickelhoff of Fenway, who had the day's best medal score, a 79 for the par-74 Hudson River course, finished 4 up on par to lead the Westchester qualifiers for the Windle Trophy tourney today.

Marking the start of its fiftieth year, Spear Co., one of the city's oldest realty management concerns, has opened new air-conditioned quarters at 402 Fifth Avenue, southwest corner of Thirty-seventh Street, where it occupies the entire third floor.

THE merger of the American Broadcasting Company and United Paramount Theatres has led to the formation of a one-man subsidiary called Georgie Jessel. The comedian and toastmaster, with a couple of shows of his own and assorted guest appearances, turns up on Channel 7 with such frequency that he soon may be known as the poor man's Godfrey.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations declared today it would not have concurred in the nineteen-point White House document on Taft-Hartley Law revision because it was inadequate and would not even have met President Eisenhower's campaign pledge to seek a just and fair labor law.
Cosmologists and astrophysicists the world over will read with sorrow the news of the death of Dr. Edwin P. Hubble. Though only 63, he was an outstanding scientific figure twenty-five years ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- John A. Danaher, former Republican Senator from Connecticut, was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. The appointment requires Senate confirmation.
MARGATE, England, Sept. 29 -- The other Britain, a country and a people almost unknown to Americans, has gathered at this Victorian seaside resort for the annual conference of the Labor party.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 29 (AP) -- District Attorney Richard Bardwell reported today that he was investigating alleged attempts to force a Negro out of his new home and place of business in southern Wisconsin.

The Mueller Brass Company achieved a new high in sales in the nine months ended on Aug. 31, F. L. Riggin St., president, reported to stockholders yesterday, and net income rose to $2,559,916, equal to $4.78 each on 535,283 shares of common stock, from $2,050,244, or $3.86 a share, in the nine months to Aug. 31, 1952.
SIX stories above the garment center hubbub at 10 o'clock in the morning day before yesterday sixteen massive Metropolitan Opera Company bassos opened the 1953-54 opera rehearsal season.

Distress conveyances of Manhattan realty showed a decline in August, according to the monthly study of the Real Estate Board of New York. There were three foreclosures and two surrenders in lieu of foreclosures involving liens of $63,020.
The Mayor of Amsterdam paid an official visit to the Mayor of Nieuw Amsterdam yesterday but found that dignitary not in.
Three men were charged with felonious assault and two with grand larceny in Queens Felony Court yesterday morning in the aftermath of a gambling scheme that went awry.

Yonkers Raceway, which was suspended on Sept. 22 at the direction of Governor Dewey, began making arrangements yesterday to reopen tomorrow night. The raceway's plans are based on the belief that the ban will be lifted some time today by the State Harness Racing Commission.

State and city officials were charged yesterday by a Kings County grand jury with responsibility for inadequate enforcement of housing laws and for failing to take steps to remedy "worsening" conditions in substandard and slum areas.
Black was highlighted as the best city color for daytime in a collection of fashions designed by Patric for Miss America and presented yesterday by Arnold Constable at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Control of National Credit Card, Inc., the corporation which sponsors the all-purpose credit card, yesterday was vested in a du Pont-financed enterprise, Bulldog Publishing Company, Washington, D. C. by vote of the N. C. C. I. stockholders in Chicago, in a move to equip the company to continue its expansion.

Earl R. Michel has been appointed general sales manager of the air conditioning and refrigeration division of Worthington Corporation, Harrison, N. J., and Peter A. McLeod has been named product manager of the centrifugal refrigeration section.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- In a preliminary to twenty-eighth women's United States senior golf championship at the Westchester Country Club, one of the nation's most famous golfers, Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare of Merion, Pa., helped carry off the gross honors in a foursomes tourney today.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 29 -- The American Dental Association's campaign against the "increasingly exaggerated" claims in toothpaste and powder advertisements was renewed today when a panel of experts reported that no therapeutic dentifrice on the market was a definite safeguard against tooth decay or gum disorders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Treasury Department disclosed tonight that its new series "C" savings notes, to be put on sale on Thursday, would bear interest ranging from 1.56 per cent if held for six months to 2.21 per cent if held two years to maturity.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- A global postal tax to help prevent a cutback in the United Nations Technical Assistance Program was proposed today in the General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee as a way of raising at least $3,000,000 annually.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Soviet Union, in a new note to the Western countries, has proposed a five-power conference, including Communist China, to "lessen international tensions," and a four-power meeting on Germany.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- About 100 of the country's top industrialists, members of the Business Advisory Council of the Department of Commerce, will meet with Administration officials on Oct. 22-24 at Pebble Beach, Calif.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Lee J. Cobb, former Broadway star now appearing in films, has identified himself as a one-time member of the Communist party in testimony made public today by the House of Representatives Committee on Un-American Activities.

The Citizens Traffic Safety Board's survey as published in your Sept. 21 issue, showing that the traffic blights cost business and motoring public an estimate of $1,082,200,000 annually, should make every New Yorker shudder.

Mohawk Carpet Mills, Inc., one of the country's largest carpet producers, announced yesterday a 3 to 6 per cent increase in mill prices of its woven wool carpeting. The rise averages 5 per cent and will go into effect on Oct. 15.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UP) -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense and Admiral Arthur W. Radford, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, paid tribute today to the role of the free press of the United States in maintaining democracy.

In the same offhand way he might board a train for White Plains, Jack Simon, food buyer for Bloomingdale's, goes off to Europe. At the sound of the word truffle, he packs his bag, slips his passport into his pocket and is off on a several-thousand-mile hunt for delicacies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UP) -- The Petroleum Administration for Defense recommended today construction of an "emergency pipeline" from Texas and the Midwest to carry 940,000 barrels of crude oil daily to the East Coast.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Sept. 30 -- The rules established by the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission for governing the "explanation" sessions for prisoners of the Korean war who do not wish repatriation were made public this morning and a United Nations Command spokesman said of the new regulations: "The commission bought everything the Communists Wanted."

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Portland Unit of the American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., which has been on strike against the three Guy Gannett papers here since Sept. 13, said today that it soon would start publishing a morning tabloid.
The sole bid of $1,166,000 for the valuable old Post Office site in the heart of Newark was rejected here yesterday because of an inadvertent transposition of figures in the deposit check.
NEWTOWN, Conn., Sept. 29 -- A mental patient, sought by the police of nine states after, he escaped from Fairfield State Hospital two days ago, surrendered to hospital personnel this afternoon.
MOSCOW, Sept 29 (AP) -- Today's Soviet Government decree is apparently the second phase in the campaign to raise farm output and living standards.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 29 -- Prof. Hazairin, Minister of the Interior, said today that all Government services in strife-torn Northern Sumatra, scene of an Islamic revolt, had been restored to normal but he said it would take another month before order in the province was fully resolved.

The $75,000,000 issue of 3 per cent dollar bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development was oversubscribed heavily yesterday at the offering yield of 3.13 per cent. The supscription books were closed by the Morgan Stanley Co.-First Boston Corporation syndicate in mid-afternoon.

BERLIN, Sept. 29 -- The East German Supreme Court has sentenced seven leading mining officials to prison terms ranging from four and one-half to fifteen years on charges of sabotage and conspiracy with the West.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Democrat of Manhattan, tonight told Democratic leaders and candidates from nine Hudson Valley counties at a conference that the Republican party under President Eisenhower had changed the New Deal to the "Big Deal" and the Fair Deal of former President Truman to the "Raw Deal."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 29 -- The thereat of competition between American and Italian movie interests in filming the Helen of Troy legend ended today with the announcement by Warner Brothers that it had acquired from Ponti De Laurentis of Rome "all the rights" in the script and production of "Helen of Troy."

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Big Seven faculty took another step toward a pact with the Orange Bowl today by naming a special committee to meet with the officials of all other parties concerned in the proposed tie-up in the Jan. 1 Miami football classic.

GENEVA, Sept. 29 -- European steel output has been in the doldrums since the opening of the common market among the six members of the European Coal and Steel Community in May of this year, according to figures released today by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.
BOSTON, Sept. 29 -- The encroachment of "treaty law" is the greatest menace to constitutional government today, Dr. Clarence Manion declared tonight.
The condition of Carl Furillo's left hand still was the matter of paramount interest yesterday as the Dodgers staged their final workout before tangling with the Yankees at the Stadium today.

RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 29 -- Since the breakdown Sept. 17 of the four-nation talks at Bangkok on withdrawal of the Chinese Nationalist troops in Burma, the Burmese Air Force has been carrying out intensive attacks on the guerrillas' bases at Monghsat and Monghai and strategic spots on the main road from the Monghsat headquarters to the Thai border.

" A ROGUE WITH EASE."* by M. K. Argus, is a frisky set of variations on the theme of Cinderella. It is a tale of the lighthearted Nineteen Twenties, a fable about a rugged young individualist who decided one June morning to become a Russian prince. Up to that moment he had been only a Muscovite exile; after it, he had a dizzy career in Manhattan, Iowa and Hollywood's Coast of Glamour.

LEVITTOWN, Pa., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Levitt Sons, Inc., today offered to build -- at half the estimated cost -- two new schools in Bristol Township, but on the condition that the company have a free hand.
Following is the text of the statement issued at City Hall yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri announcing his candidacy for Mayor on the independent Experience party ticket:
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 29 (AP) -- The death toll from the crash of a chartered airliner climbed to twenty-three today when Dorothy Jean Bush, 32 years old, of San Antonio, the stewardess, died.

BOSTON, Sept. 29 -- Three of the country's leading centers for work on behalf of children have joined forces here for a cooperative attack on the emotional difficulties and behavior problems that plague an increasing number of the nation's youngsters.

The appointment of two men to direct the Washington activities of the American Merchant Marine Institute, which takes over today the functions in the capital of the now dissolved National Federation of American Shipping, was announced yesterday by Walter E. Maloney, president of the institute.

Frederick Ashton's "Sylvia," which the Sadler's Wells Ballet presented at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for its American premiere, is another of those productions with which this theatre-wise British company could settle down for a Broadway run if only it would consent to do so.
As a friend, partner and co-worker over a number of years of the late Chester A. McLain I would like to add a word to what has already been said of him in your columns.

Four draws and three adjournments were recorded in the seventeenth round of the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich last night, with the standing of the first two players, Vassily Smyslov of Russia and Samuel Reshevsky of the United States, remaining undisturbed, according to a Swiss news report.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Within a few minutes after being sworn into office, the new twelve-member Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government picked 79-year-old former President Hoover today to head the second study for over-hauling the Federal Government m a decade.
Fifty-one artists, opening a "center-of-the-road" exhibition last night, were delighted to cope with a traffic jam.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)--Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and Miss Jean Kerr, who once was on his office staff, were married today in St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Cathedral.

Mr. Fix-It, "who is forever condemned to put out little fires and to squirt the oil of human relations on organizational friction places," should have a bigger and a better place in a company's personnel set-up, the American Management Association's national personnel conference was told yesterday at the Statler Hotel.

Mayor Impellitteri announced formally yesterday his decision to run for re-election on the independent Experience party ticket so that "real" Democrats and "liberal" Republicans might have a candidate for whom they could vote.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- The second Soviet attempt at this session to expel the representatives of Nationalist China was rejected today by the United Nations General Assem bly. The Assembly approved a report of its Credentials Committee, which accepted the Nationalist credentials by a vote of 48 to 5.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Small Business Administration, in a new statement on its loan policy, announced tonight that direct loans it makes to small business will bear a flat interest rate of 6 per cent a year. The agency added that on loans where it participates with banks in advancing a percentage of a credit to a borrower it will charge a minimum rate of 5 per cent.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 29 -- The Iranian Government today gave the nation its first authoritative glimpse of the staggering cost of the thirty-month-long dispute with Britain over nationalization of the British-owned oil concession and conceded that economic development was impossible without a resumption of the flow of off revenues.

The United Nations Command in Korea seems well within its rights in protesting against a letter distributed by the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission to the prisoners of war -- the overwhelming majority Chinese and North Koreans -- who have refused to be repatriated.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 29 -- Bidding farewell to sportsmen from twenty - three countries of North and South America, Western Europe and the British Empire at the close of the Maccabiah Games in Ramat Gan today, Premier David Ben-Gurion told the athletes before him on the football field: "Come back to us for the next Maccabiah and bring along representatives of Rumania, Hungary and Russia."

Dean Rusk, former Secretary of State for Far Eastern Affairs, defended yesterday the "rigid" restriction by the United States of diplomatic conferences on Korea to the "fundamental" issue of Communist aggression there.

Protestant churches ministering to the Puerto Rican community here have increased threefold in the last six years, churchmen were told yesterday at the annual convocation of ministers of the Manhattan division of the Protestant Council of the City of New York.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- The slow pace of the United States' loyalty clearance program has brought to a virtual halt the hiring of United States experts by United Nations agencies that carry out the organization's world-wide Technical Assistance Program.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Sept. 29 -- Military negotiations between France and the Indo-Chinese state of Cambodia are again deadlocked after the Cambodians refused to make concessions the French felt were necessary in the interest of the common war against the Communist-led Vietminh.

Colors keyed to the tones of birthstones in the zodiac lent a novel angle yesterday to the showing of winter and holiday millinery designs by Eric Braagaard at Tailored Woman. Included in the gamut of colors shown were the deep, rich shades of garnet and ruby red as well as the paler and more delicate colorings of sapphire blue and tourmaline pastel pink.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The National Catholic Welfare Conference, on behalf of the cardinals, archbishops and bishops of the United States, denounced today Cardinal Wyszynski's internment by Poland.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks advised business men today to take a realistic view of current business adjustments and also of "the fundamental strength of our overall economy."

George (Birdie) Tebbetts late yesterday afternoon was signed by General Manager Gabe Paul to a two-year contract to manage the Redlegs, succeeding Rogers Hornsby. No terms were revealed when the announcement was made by Paul in his suite at the Hotel Biltmore, world series headquarters.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 29 -- The Government of Baden-Wuerttemberg, third largest state in West Germany will resign tomorrow to make way for a government to be headed by Dr. Gerhard Mueller, a leading member of Dr. Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union in a move to obtain for Dr. Adenauer a substantial majority in the Bundesrat (upper house of parliament).
LONDON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Kremlin ordered today its defense factories to switch over partly to manufacture of farm tractors to help increase the Soviet Union's potato and vegetable output.

The Soviet order that the armaments industry produce tractors for agriculture seems to confirm earlier indications that during the past three years the Soviet tractor industry has been in part converted to military production, perhaps for the needs of the Communist forces during the Korean war.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- A proposed merger of the Peoples National Bank and Trust Company of this city and the New Rochelle Trust Company, under discussion since July, was approved late today at special meetings of directors of both banks.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 29 -- The refusal today of County Clerk William H. Gilfert to accept substitute Democratic nominees on the Hudson County Republican ticket for the Nov. 3 election will be appealed to the courts tomorrow morning when the Republican leadership files suit to have the new candidates validated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Surgeon General's office of the Army reported today that the Medical Corps' examination of volunteers and draftees had been carried out so strictly that only sixty-six men had to be taken out of training in the last six months and returned to civilian life for physical reasons.

Everybody talked about the weather yesterday, and for a change nobody wanted to do anything about it. It was warm, the humidity was low, the breeze was continuous and caressing, and through the city's concrete caverns and stretching for miles beyond there was a special glow of gratitude for the weather man.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Publication of figures showing a further rise in Britain's industrial output in July and August stimulated the stock markets today. Prices although below the day's best at the close showed widespread improvement especially among the industrials which rose one shilling (fourteen cents) or more.

Edward Ridley Finch, a retired judge of the State Court of Appeals, was appointed by Mayor Impellitteri yesterday as the third member and chairman of a special transit committee set up to resolve the disagreement on new economy schedules between the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O.

The Fjell Line, pioneers in freight service between Scandinavian and other European countries and the Great Lakes, will open this week a regularly scheduled cargo service between European and United Kingdom ports, and Baltimore and Hampton Roads, Va., it was announced here yesterday by Great Lakes Overseas, Inc., local agents for the line.

MARGATE, England, Sept. 29 -- Aneurin Bevan and five other leaders of the left wing of the British Labor party have been reelected to National Executive Committee, it was announced today at the party's annual conference.

The economic outlook, at least through 1960, is good, Leon H. Keyserling, former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said yesterday at the sales convention of the Frank H. Lee Company in the Plaza Hotel. The company, producer of Lee and Disney hats, will close its three-day meetings today with a color television showing of its line.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- About 15,000 members of the United Packinghouse Workers, C. I. O., employed in twenty Chicago meat packing plants, walked off the job at noon today to attend a strike demonstration. A meeting of 5,000 in front of the offices of Swift Co. was addressed by local union leaders.

It's a free country and Mayor Impellitteri is proving it by making an independent race for re-election in spite of the ghastly showing he made in the Democratic primary. This time he is really free as a bird, as far as top-organization support is concerned, because the Democratic county chairmen have all fallen in line, at least ostensibly, behind the primary winner, Robert F. Wagner Jr., the original choice of the Tammany-Flynn organizations.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, moved yesterday to end rumors that Governor Dewey would not support him. He announced that the Governor would begin a series of television speeches next Tuesday in which he would ask the voters to support his fellow Republican.

The young men whose fancies turn in spring to thoughts of love will turn their eyes to the television set or their ears to the radio today to follow the progress of baseball's autumn classic, the world series.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 29 -- Dr. Richard B. Cattell, staff surgeon for the Lahey Clinic in Boston, said today that advances in pancreatic surgery held increasing hope for recovery of the patient after the removal of cancer of the pancreas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, forecast today that defense spending would drop $2,000,000,000 in the next fiscal year below the $42,000,000,000 that is expected to go out of the Treasury this year for the Army, Navy and Air Force.
