A substantial reorganization of the Tammany executive committee appeared to be in the making last night when county committees in the districts passed over a number of district leaders who had fought for the ouster of Carmine G. DeSapio in making recommendations for new district leaders.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A creditors' committee is going to exercise control of the finances of Dick Haymes, crooner who married Rita Hayworth last week.

SEIGNORY CLUB, Que., Sept. 29 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's national news-gathering cooperative, The Canadian Press, completed plans today for starting next Jan. 1 a new Canadian Press Company-Broadcast News Limited -- to supply world-wide news to the nation's privately owned radio and television stations.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 29 -- It was confidently predicted here today that with the growing support of "rebel" members of the United party, Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan soon would succeed in introducing a separate electoral register for South Africa's 47,000 voters of mixed blood in Cape Province.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 29 -- Despite the increased number of admissions to mental institutions and the tremendous cost of treating the mentally ill, the public schools of the state are failing to provide adequate programs for the promotion of mental health, the State Council of City and Village School Superintendents was told today at its seventy-first annual meeting.
Futures opened steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday but closed barely steady 3 to 11 points net off, with the near months showing the most weakness.

Hiram Walker, Inc., opened a "merchandising fair" yesterday on the top floor of the Statler Hotel. It covered everything from the first step in distilling to final sales in package store and bar and the use of spirits in cooking.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Thousands of letters are in the mail today asking the reactions of business men, economists, farmers, labor union leaders and trade association executives to the operations of the Export-Import Bank of Washington.
MONTREAL, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A strike of crew members on Canada's deep-sea ships today was described by shipowners as a threat to survival of Canada's merchant marine.

Shipping employers rejected last night contract demands submitted by the crime-infested International Longshoremen's Association and called on President Eisenhower to invoke the national emergency provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act to stop a coastwide dock strike at midnight tonight.

PORTSMOUTH; R. I., Sept. 29 -- When Portsmouth Priory School's football squad scrimmages a policeman blows the whistle to stop the plays, He is Arthur Allan, the former Boston College halfback, who once again is assisting Ralph Hewitt, head coach.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Carson, Pirie Scott Co., Chicago department store, today offered complete general insurance to the public as a new service. John T. Pirie Jr., president, said this is believed to be the first time all types of insurance have been made available to customers in a department store.

SAMARKAND, U. S. S. R., Sept. 25 -- The golden road to Samarkand today is an upholstered seat in a comfortable DC-3 plane with a trim Soviet airline hostess who passes out copies of Izvestia, Pravda and the satirical weekly Krokodil in the two-hour hop from Tashkent.

The turbulent waterfront situation became further complicated yesterday as deck officers aboard 150 American-flag oil tankers opearting out of the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts threatened to walk off their ships at 12:01 A. M. tomorrow.
LONDON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A fortunate Russian, after long efforts, may get a small plot of land on which to build a home.

It has been brought to my attention that the old Wyckoff homestead in Flatlands, Brooklyn, is about to be destroyed. As a descendant of the Wyckoff family and a member of the active Wyckoff Association, and also as a patriotic American, I am writing to protest this destruction.

TORONTO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Avro Canada, Ltd., maker of the CF-100 all-weather jet fighter, announced today that it has bought the Government-owned jet engine plant at near-by Malton in "a multi-million-dollar deal."

Mayor Impellitteri's qualified promise to seek repeal of the auto use tax if a substitute was found was termed "unsatisfactory" yesterday by William J. Gottlieb, president of the Automobile Club of New York.

Many little hands were stretched out yesterday in the play area of Bellevue Hospital, where rodeo performers staged their twenty-eighth annual show. The hands belonged to patients who clasped those of cowboys and cowgirls as they leaned off their horses.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 29 -- Mrs. Angeline Rause of 321 Center Street, celebrated her 105th birthday today, and her 72-year- old son and his wife observed their golden wedding anniversary.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., Sept. 29 -- Mrs. Edward Bishop of Glen Oaks, a 10-handicap player, fashioned a 41, 43 -- 84 and finished 3 up to lead the Long Island qualifiers for the Windle Trophy at the North Shore Country Club today.
The Council of American Master Mariners urged the Coast Guard yesterday to change one of its proposed rules, which the council said, "may lead to anarchy and mutiny."

Young women headed by Mrs. Thomas H. Barton, the Misses Kitty Lee Goode, Mary Jane Lansburgh and Barbara Cavanagh are serving on the junior committee for the International Children's Bazaar, to be held Nov. 23 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 29 -- A reduction in the price of rationed rice in Calcutta, in effect from today, is the latest in a series of events tending to show that the Indian "nonviolent" methods, used successfully against the British, work equally well and perhaps better when applied to India's own Government.

A pair of champions, Native Dancer, king of the 3-year-olds, and Tom Fool, the handicap star, met for the first time yesterday, but it was not on the race track. The occasion was the Red Cross benefit program that the Westchester Racing Association put on at Belmont Park.

Station WOR-TV, which has been off the air since Sept. 13, will resume limited telecasting in order to present the world series beginning today at 12:45 P. M. It will televise all games between the Dodgers and Yankees, but will not present any other programs for several weeks.

The major league baseball map, unchanged for fifty years, underwent its second revision in a little more than six months last night when the American League unanimously approved the transfer of the St. Louis Browns to Baltimore.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Two Democratic Senators from the farm belt brought back to the capital today accounts of acute distress and bitterness among the cattle farmers of their states.

If Chuck Dressen had any spies planted at the Stadium yesterday he will not be overjoyed by the report of his agents. The Brooklyn pilot had no apparent reason for assigning anyone to the Bronx ball park, for it had been announced that the Yankees would assemble there in the morning only for the purpose of holding a pre-series meeting.

Three new films open today at theatres in the metropolitan area. At Loew's State is Paramount's "Those Redheads from Seattle," starring Rhonda Fleming, Gene Barry and Agnes Moorehead. Teresa Brewer and Guy Mitchell head the supporting cast. The scenario was written by Lewis Foster, Geoffrey Homes and George Worthington Yates. Mr. Foster also directed and William H. Pine and William C. Thomas produced.

In one form or another, Fritz Hochwalder's "The Strong Are Lonely" has been played in many parts of Europe. It is easy to understand why from the adaptation by Eva Le Gallienne that opened at the Broadhurst last evening. Finding his theme in a godly utopia set up in Paraguay in the eighteenth century, Mr. Hochwalder has raised an absorbing religious speculation and written several very dramatic scenes.

New York State will receive "shortly" an additional allocation of 91,180 cubic centimeters of gamma globulin from the Federal pool, Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, announced in Albany yesterday. He explained, however, that the quantity would not be enough to change the policy of not supplying the serum for school contacts in poliomyelitis cases.

In taking steps to combat a recession, the Government should undertake a great national sales campaign as well as road-building and other projects, it was suggested yesterday by Josh Gollin, vice president of Schenley Distributors, Inc. He spoke at the weekly meeting of the Sales Executives Club in the Roosevelt Hotel, where he described the obstacles now existing in the advertising and selling of liquor.

The efficacy of port as a mid-morning pick-up, especially for hard - working housewives, was pointed out yesterday by a visiting Englishman, Fred Cockburn. He is senior partner and general manager of Cockburn, Smithes Co., Ltd., London, and Oporto, Portugal.

After an absence of five years, Muriel King, whose name as a designer is known throughout this country, has returned to Stein Blaine with a striking collection of fashions geared to after-five and evening hours. The collection is small and well planned.

MONTREAL, Sept. 30 (Canadian Press) -- Alben W. Barkley, former Vice President of the United States, said today the Republican Administration in Washington was suffering from "galloping paralysis" in handling big business and labor problems.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Budget Director Joseph M. Dodge figures that Government agencies spent $1,100,000 unnecessarily in June, so he is deducting the sum from current appropriations. He announced this today in a report on his efforts to stop "excessive buying" at the fiscal year's end.
BOKHARA, U.S.S.R., Sept. 27 -- The fabulous Minaret of Kalyan still towers against Bokhara's turquoise sky as beautiful and awesome as the day it was erected 845 years ago.

Aluminium, Ltd., is estimating its 1953 distribution of Canadian aluminum ingot at 489,700 tons, compared with 454,400 tons last year. Of the total 166,800 metric tons are allotted to the United Kingdom, 206,900 tons to the United States, 80,000 tons to Canada and 36,000 tons to other markets.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Johnny Bratton, No. 2 ranking welterweight from Chicago, for the second time could punch out no better than a split decision tonight against unrated Al (Sugar) Wilson of Englewood, N. J.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Consumer credit increased $217,000,000 in August, to $27,434,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Dwellings dominated the trading in Long Island areas in realty transactions reported yesterday.
An underwater scanning device, which uses a sharply focused beam of sound to measure the bearings and ranges of objects, was demonstrated in Buttermilk Channel here yesterday morning.

OTTAWA, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Canadian Government is prepared to sell millions of dollars worth of arms plants to private industry if the buyers agree to maintain the plants as part of Canada's defense potential, a Production Department official said today.

The first volume in "The Mainstream of America" series, a retelling of the story of America in narrative form, has been scheduled by Doubleday for publication next Thursday. It is Stuart Holbrook's "The Age of the Moguls," a story of the great leaders of business and industry from Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt to William Randolph Hearst.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- The Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations General Assembly rejected a request this morning by the Independence party of Puerto Rico for an oral hearing at which its president, Gilberto Concepcion de Gracia, had intended to attack the contention of the United States that the island was now a self-governing unit.
Arthur T. Safford Jr. has been appointed manager of sales of the Ecusta Paper Corporation, a subsidiary of Olin Industries, Inc.

Samuel Reshevsky of the United States suffered his first setback in sixteen games in the world chess championship challengers' tournament when he lost last night to David Bronstein, one of the nine competing Russians, according to a report from Zurich, Switzerland.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in September expanded slightly over the previous month and the corresponding month of last year, lifting the volume for the first nine months of 1953 to 266,279,846 shares.

" Les Six Francais" are known, at least by name, to all well-informed concertgoers; but the entire six -- Durey, Auric, Poulenc, Honegger, Milhaud and Tailleferre -- are not often represented on a single program, as they were in Gerald Tarack's violin recital at Town Hall last evening.

BUFFALO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Archbishop of Boston, said tonight that "certain religious leaders in America," had been victimized by what he called the infiltration tactics of communism.

The five-story apartment house at 62 East Eighty-third Street has been sold by Irving Enkels, real estate operator, to an investing client of William Alfred White, broker in the transaction. Richard Nussbaum was attorney for the buyer and Richard P. Carrigan acted for the seller.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 30 -- Religious objections to North American activities in helping develop Peru's jungle region appeared again today. The Consortium of Catholic Engineers charged that the plans of Robert T. Le Tourneau for helping develop the Peruvian hinterland would set up a "Protestant nucleus" in that region and "can have grave repercussions on the unity of the nation."

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The Foreign Office said today that a first study of the Soviet reply to the Western bid for a four-power meeting on German and Austrian issues showed that it added little to earlier notes on the same subject.

The Blum Folding Box Company, Inc., has leased the one-story building at 1028 Grand Street in Brooklyn from the State of Israel Supply Mission and will use it for the storage of folding boxes. The Kalmon Dolgin Company was the broker.
Roy Campanella may have a small fracture in the little finger knuckle of his right hand as a result of Allie Reynolds' hitting him in the second inning at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.

MARGATE, England, Sept. 30 -- Aneurin Bevan, leader of British Labor's radical wing, speaking before a cheering crowd of about a thousand of his followers tonight, accused the United States of recreating the kind of forces in Europe that led to World War II.

Steel consumers apparently have finished rebuilding their steel inventories and supplies in users' hands appear close to balance with demand, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.

The State Harness Racing Commission lifted its ban on Yonkers Raceway yesterday, but the cry of "the marshal calls for the trotters" won't bring out the horse-drawn sulkies in Westchester County until tomorrow night.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 30 (AP) The Main Chance Farm's Fascinator stole the play from her stablemate, Incidentally, to register a popular victory in the $18,550 Margate Handicap today. Incidentally was supposed to carry the hopes of Mrs. Elizabeth Graham's stable in the three-quarter mile dash but Fascinator took the lead shortly after the break and led William Goadby Loew's Case Goods home by two lengths.

The "neutralization" of Korea, under study by the United States as one means of settling the Korean problem, would have as its major advantage the "disengagement" of United States forces from the continent of Asia.

The report of Middle South Utilities, Inc., and its operating subsidiaries for the twelve months to Aug. 31, issued yesterday, showed a consolidated net income of $14,779,098, after all charges. This was equal to $2.17 a share on the company's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $12,845,982, or $2.04 a share, in the year to Aug. 31, 1952.
After fruitless weeks of negotiation, 2,000 deck officers on 200 tankers on the East and Gulf Coasts went on strike at midnight last night.

Carmine G. DeSapio nailed down his control as the leader of Tammany Hall last night when the Democratic County Committee met at Julia Richman High School, Sixty-seventh Street and Second Avenue, to ratify Tuesday night's election of Assembly District leaders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Like millions of his fellow Americans, Gov. Earl Warren of California made the mistake today of describing his new job as Chief Justice of the Supreme Court. So did another Californian, Vice President Richard M. Nixon, in expressing his pleasure at President Eisenhower's selection of his friend.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The United States and France announced new plans today to destroy the Communist threat in Indo-China and speedily end the eight-year-old war there.

The returns are in on the poll of City Center theatregoers to decide which of eight suggested plays are to be presented this fall at the civic playhouse. Bowing to the preference expressed by a majority of several thousand persons, the City Center will open its drama season on Wednesday evening, Nov. 11, with "Cyrano de Bergerac."
POMFRET, Conn., Sept. 30 -- This was the first "tough-stuff" day of the season at Pomfret School and members of the football squad were primed for a hearty workout. They were not disappointed.

Baseball was hot at the world series opener at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, but the spectators were generally cool, The crowd, more the typical series viewers than a baseball gathering, came late, left early and eschewed garish sports shirts and unruly noises. Mostly, the stands were filled with well-groomed men and women who behaved as though they had seen few baseball games during the season.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 30-- The second race for the One-Ton Cup was to the strong as well as the swift today. Belgium's Marletta was the winner over Norway's Lully III and Sweden's Maybe VI. The other five yachts in the six-meter series weren't around at the finish.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Former President Truman said today "the most important public relations man in the world is the President of the United States."

Some key jobs in the United States Information Agency, including that of deputy director, remain unfilled although the agency has been recruiting for nearly two months, Abbott M. Washburn, special assistant to Theodore C. Streibert, agency director, reported yesterday.

NEWARK, Sept. 30 -- A strong presentment filed today by a special Federal grand jury accused management, labor and the Government of "laxity and gross negligence" in waterfront operations in New Jersey.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 -- Despite the need for Federal economy, the Government must continue to foster and encourage opportunities for wholesome recreational facilities, Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, said here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- President Eisenhower sent "warm greetings" to the reporters, editors and publishers of the nation's newspapers today, praising them as "custodians of a majestic trust."
Chorus girls and dancers of ten night clubs on West Fifty-second Street, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, went on strike after their first shows last night.
As long as I can keep borrowing bats, I'll be in business.

Platan of the Hasty House Farms won the Lawrence Realization at Belmont Park yesterday. The colt, ridden by Conn McCreary, was rated cleverly through the mile and five furlongs to beat George Auerbach's Dictar by two lengths. In third place was the favored Level Lea, three-quarters of a length behind the runner-up.

SACRAMENTO, Sept. 30 -- Earl Warren, three times elected Governor of California, announced today that he had telegraphed President Eisenhower "humble acceptance" of his designation as Chief Justice of the United States.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Union Securities Corporation will place on the market today a new issue of $15,000,000 of first mortgage 3 5/8 per cent bonds of Indiana and Michigan Electric Company due in 1983 at a price of 102.31 to yield 3 1/2 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UP) -- The Army said today "mail call is a very special event" but it does not intend to let G. I. letters be used for subversive purposes.

LONDON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- A British women's quartet bettered the world record for the 880-yard relay by running the distance in 1 minute 39.9 seconds during a meet between England and the Netherlands at the White City Stadium.

The blueprint for New York City charter reform delivered to the public yesterday by a temporary state commission maps the fundamentals to make this a better managed city. The commission, headed by Devereux C. Josephs, president of the New York Life Insurance Company, saw the problem with a clear eye.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Soviet Union has been acquiring an arsenal of potent atomic weapons, and this country must assume there is no ceiling on the destruction that can be built into any atomic weapon stockpile, Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, asserted today.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 30 -- Gordon R. Clapp, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, charged today that private power interests were trying to vitiate the authority's "provocative example of low-cost electricity" with a country-wide campaign of "cunning and smear," which falsely pictured the regional resources agency as a "shameful Federal handout."

In your leading editorial on Sept. 28 you grudgingly accept the agreement with Spain as a fait accompli. At the same time you express "profound regret" that political and moral objections to the pact did not prevail over military strategy. You seem to feel that, in contracting with Franco, we now have betrayed the ideals for which we fought Hitler and Mussolini.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Following is a summary of the main points covered by President Eisenhower in his news conference today:

TRENTON, Sept, 30 -- Robert B. Meyner, Democratic candidate for Governor, charged today that the $50,000,000 building and expansion program of the State Department of Institutions and Agencies had been badly bungled and cited a number of "glaring examples" to bolster his accusation.

" THE SHORT NOVELS OF JOHN STEINBECK,"* with a foreword by Joseph Henry Jackson, is a wonderful, wayward, one-volume library that includes "Of Mice and Men," "Tortilla Flat," "The Red Pony," "The Moon Is Down," "The Pearl" and "Cannery Row." What more can you ask in the way of warmth and humor and humanity?
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Eisenhower said today that the fourteenth Chief Justice of the United States would be Gov. Earl Warren of California.

The people of New York City this year are extending their warm congratulations to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York on the occasion of that agency's sixtieth birthday. Since 1893 the Visiting Nurses, whose organization was founded by Lillian D. Wald, have carried devoted nursing care and health education to people wherever they lived in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens.

WENTWORTH, England, Sept. 30 (UP) -- Henry Cotton, Britain's non-playing Ryder Cup captain, expressed surprise tonight at the "casual" way the United States team was preparing for the international golf matches Friday and Saturday over the Wentworth course.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Eisenhower received a full report from Secretary of State John Foster Dulles today on yesterday's Soviet note about big-power meetings. The State Department, meanwhile, was in touch with the British and French foreign ministries about a "next move."
A state commission recommended yesterday that New York City, adopt a variation of the city manager plan called the mayor-manager plan.

Operations of the Long Island Rail Road for the first eight months of this year resulted in a net operating income of $273,840, it was announced yesterday. This compared with a net operating loss of $2,047,667 for the eight months ended on Aug. 31, 1952.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of rules covering interviews and "explanations" to prisoners of the Korean war who have refused repatriation, as announced today by the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission:

NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- Anti-white Mau Mau raiders, who had been reported starving and ready to surrender in their mountain and forest hideouts, have struck back with a new campaign of terror inside Nairobi, capital of British East Africa.

Congratulations go to Baltimore, along with an apprehensive look over the shoulder, for the first American League shift in fifty years has just turned the moribund St. Louis Browns into the menacing Baltimore Orioles. Menacing, that is, if they take after their prototype, the "Old Orioles" of 1894-96.

BONN, Germany, Sept. 30 -- Demands from members of the Christian Democratic Union, the majority party, for greater influence in the West German Trade Union Federation were emphatically rejected by the federation's leadership today. Those demands were presented after the Christian Democrats had won their victory in the general election on Sept. 6.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Eisenhower's news conference today, his first in ten weeks, yielded a mine of news, comments, and complaints ranging from the comical to the grave.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- That grin on Uncle Sam's face today was caused by the "first reversal of a trend."

More than 2,000,000 homes in the United States will be air-conditioned the year 'round with central units in the next five years, the American Institute of Management predicted yesterday.' The institute pointed out only 100,000 homes are in that category now.

ROME, Sept. 30 -- Prof. Auguste Piccard of Switzerland, who twenty-one years ago was the first man to rise high enough over the surface of the earth to enter the stratosphere, today became the man to have penetrated to the greatest depth under the surface of the sea.
The test of a telegram sent to Governor Dewey of New York and Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey yesterday by John V. Lyon, chairman of the New York Shipping Association, follows:
The American Labor party opened its city campaign last night as former Representative Vito Marcantonio, state chairman, assailed the Democratic, Republican and Liberal nominees for Mayor.

Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, declared yesterday that it had reached a decision on whether atomic energy should be patented and its uses released to free enterprise, or whether it should be a Government monopoly.

An item in the press again refers to the need for combating the cost of illness with some form of national health program. This need is based on a survey revealed by Representative J. K. Javits, Republican of New York, which showed that "one of five American families owes a medical bill, the average debt being $105 and the total exceeding a billion dollars.

French elegance and Irish individuality vie with Oriental daintiness in B. Altman's new fabric center that opened yesterday with a preview. Newly located on the fifth floor, the center catches the sunlight from the Fifth Avenue side, and daylight, as any fabric buyer knows, is important to ascertain true color.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- One of the nation's most celebrated woman golfers, Mrs. Edwin S. Vare, the former Glenna Collett, shared the lead in the initial round of the twenty-eighth women's United States senior championship today.

Baseball's golden anniversary world series opened at the Yankee Stadium yesterday and for more than three hours there followed some of the most violent cannonading a half century of inter-league warfare has seen.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Hans Hedtoft, the Danish Premier-designate, announced an all-Socialist cabinet tonight after the Liberal party turned down an invitation to join a Socialist-Liberal coalition.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Justice Holmes, awaiting President Taft's choice of a Chief Justice of the United States to succeed M. E. Fuller, wrote to Sir Frederick Pollock:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, urged the United States today to agree to stop collecting income tax on the salaries of United States citizens employed by the secretariat.

ALBANY, Sept. 30 -- After more than thirty years in government service, Frank C. Moore resigned today as Lieutenant Governor to head a privately financed, non-profit foundation that will study the problems of government administration on a country-wide basis.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Following is the joint communique on Indo-China issued today by the United States and France:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced today that it had been conducting a design study for a nuclear-powered aircraft. The Air Force, asked about the announcement, said the contract had been awarded twenty-eight months ago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Defense Department announced today the names of six additional Americans reported by the Communists to have died in Korean prison camps.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly decided today not to take up "the Korean question" until it had disposed of the six other items on its agenda.

The United States Steel Corporation announced last night the adoption of a new flexible pricing formula which will make possible lower costs to steel consumers under certain circumstances, without committing the steel company to a general reduction of mill prices.
The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, representing 80,000 engineers, yesterday became the fourth major operating union to make demands for wage adjustments from the country's railroads.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- In a split decision, the Federal Communications Commission authorized today a rate increase of 8 per cent for interstate long-distance telephone service of the Bell Telephone System, effective at midnight tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UP) -- The Army rejected today as "neither practical nor advisable" a plan to send to Korea the mothers of twenty-three United States soldiers resisting repatriation so they could plead with their sons to come home.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that prices of farm products had declined about three-fourths of 1 per cent between mid-August and mid-September.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Adlai E. Stevenson came to town today for the celebration of Democratic Women's Day, devoted to raising funds for the party, and for tomorrow's report to President Eisenhower on his world travels.

A collection of luxurious furs was presented yesterday by Bergdorf Goodman. Great variety in silhouette, texture and color, was noted. There were soft, bulky silhouettes, straight coats that were narrow but pliant, and curved but trim shapes that were often crisply tailored.
Public Enemy No. 1 of all women drivers who obey traffic rules is the male driver, according to two women who drove non-stop to San Francisco and then returned here.

Louis S. Rothschild, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board and Maritime Administrator, sailed aboard the United States liner United States yesterday for England, where he will attend a meeting of the North Atlantic Planning Board for Ocean Shipping.

United The States Lawn Tennis Association yesterday named the team that hopes to regain the Davis Cup in Australia next December. Tony Trabert of Cincinnati, the present national titleholder; Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, the Wimbledon champion and runner-up in the nationals, and Hamilton Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., and Bob Perry of Los Angeles, both 20-year-old stars, were chosen.

Water storage in the city's Catskill and Croton Reservoirs is down to 155,000,000,000 gallons, or 60 per cent of capacity, the lowest for any Oct. 1 since the water-shortage year of 1949. A year ago the reservoirs were at 83.9 per cent of capacity.
BUFFALO, Sept. 30 -- The nation's leading traffic engineers were told today to climb down from their ivory towers and find out what the public thought of their innovations to ease traffic congestion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Supreme Court, which ended its 1952-53 term in the tumult of the Rosenberg case, will reconvene next Monday for the 1953-54 term with a new Chief Justice and cases involving vital Constitutional issues on its docket.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- World series fever hit the United Nations today in varying degrees. A number of the delegates took it very seriously, some were mildly interested and others showed no interest at all at the exploits of the Yankees and Dodgers.

A narrowly - averted collision, presented with the realism of an actual highway mishap, was staged on Governors Island yesterday and was the top thrill in a series of hazard demonstrations in a special training course given by safety personnel at First Army Headquarters.

ALBANY, Sept. 30 (UP) -- The State Harness Racing Commission today suspended Wayne Smart and Carl Larsen, accused of "injecting a substance" into a horse entered in the Hambletonian trotting classic, Aug. 12.

Paul Van Zeeland, Belgium's Foreign Minister, placed a wreath yesterday on the Walloon monument in Battery Park, dedicated to the Walloons, the French-speaking Protestants who came to this country from what is now Belgium in 1624.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Defense Department has under active consideration a Canadian proposal to augment and improve substantially the radar network guarding Canada and the United States from possible Soviet bomber attack.
The city of Cleveland borrowed $6,000,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of water revenue bonds due semi-annually from 1958 to 1978 at an interest cost of 2.786 per cent.

AS the bell sounded for the start of the world championship fight at the Stadium yesterday, the Yankees bounded across the ring and fetched the Dodgers a clout on the whiskers even before the unprepared Brooks had a chance to get up their hands. This savage assault floored them for a count of four. They sparred cautiously for a while.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Newport Dream and Earl's Song extended long winning streaks as harness racing's Grand Circuit opened a ten-day stand today.

A strike of 50,000 longshoremen turned the sprawling waterfronts of New York and other North Atlantic cities into ghost ports at midnight last night, but there were strong indications that President Eisenhower would act, probably within twenty-four hours, to get the men back to work under an eighty-day Taft-Hartley injunction.
BOSTON Sept. 30 -- Direct investment of American private capital abroad has reached $15,000,000,000, William S. Swingle of New York president of the National Foreign Trade Council said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- President Eisenhower appointed Morris Wolf of Philadelphia today as general counsel of the Foreign Operations Administration.

ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- One of the most exciting football teams of George (Lefty) James' coaching regime at Cornell will undergo possibly its most trying ordeal of the season Saturday. Whether it will also prove to be one of his best elevens should be fairly well determined by its showing against Rice Institute of Texas.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- The Soviet Union called once again today for the admission to the United Nations of fourteen countries, five of them Communist states, in one package, and once again the reaction from the United States was: "No deals."

Baseball took cognizance of the world series' fiftieth anniversary yesterday by bringing on for the 1953 classic six players and an umpire who participated in the 1903 series between the Boston Red Sox and the Pittsburgh Pirates, which marked the first post-season clash between the champions of the American and National Leagues.

The last toasts were drunk at midnight last night and then the old Brevoort closed down "forever," as the hand-lettered sign outside read. The restaurant that had played host to Presidents, royalty and princes of epicure over the last century closed its career on a mournful note. None of the great was in evidence, only sad-faced Greenwich Villagers, and sadder-faced staff.

The death of Mayor Ernst Reuter of West Berlin was called shocking yesterday by John J. McCloy, former United States High Commissioner to Germany, before he sailed for a five-week European business trip aboard the Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth. Mr.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 1,256,000 barrels last week, according to the report issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were listed at 142,484,000 barrels, compared with 143,740,000 a week earlier and 120,276,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower told women reporters today that she would tackle the coming social season with her aide, Mrs. Mary Jane McCaffrey, serving as her social as well as her personal secretary.

Without fanfare or ceremonies a police patrol car rolled along the new three-lane roadway on the north side of Brooklyn Bridge from Manhattan to Brooklyn at noon yesterday to signalize the opening of the north roadway to traffic.

A special board of review composed of business men, educators and professional men released a report yesterday clearing the Council for Social Action of the Congregational Christian Churches of charges of "subversive, pro-Communist, disloyal or dishonest actions."

Today's new film is Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Mogambo," at the Radio City Music Hall Ava Gardner and Clark Gable are the stars of the Technicolor African adventure story with Grace Kelly, Donald Sinden and Philip Stainton in featured roles. John Lee Mahin wrote the screen play from a play by Wilson Collison.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., the Democratic candidate for Mayor, received last night the formal endorsement of the Greater New York C. I. O. Council, which says it speaks for 500,000 members of trade unions living in New York City.

An indication that some objects for the home are unaffected by changing styles and tastes may be seen in a huge collection of porcelain and stoneware produced by the Royal Copenhagen factory of Denmark and now included in an exhibition at Georg Jensen, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-third Street. Examples designed over a period of 178 years are included.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30 -- Goodwin Jess Knight -- familiarly known as "Goodie" -- who will succeed Governor Warren, has served seven years as Lieutenant Governor. He has often indicated an intention to run against Governor Warren, with whose policies and politics he has frequently been in conflict.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 30 -- Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, Harvard University's new president, said in an address today that there was "a very widespread religious illiteracy," and asked schools of religion to help restore vigorous and creative faith.

In his Boston speech President Eisenhower said: "In the American design -- as we perceive it -- each group in our nation has special problems. None has special rights. Each has peculiar needs. None has peculiar privileges," and again -- "The supreme belief of our society is in the dignity and freedom of the individual.

MANYAS, Turkey, Sept. 30 -- Intensive air and sea action marked the opening day of exercise Weldfast, the five-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization maneuver in which more than 100,000 troops will test the effectiveness of the West's plans for the defense of Southeastern Europe and the Turkish straits.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of today's White House news conference, with most of President Eisenhower's comments in the third person in accordance with conference rules:

IN view of the tremendous increase in the number of hunters during the past few years, it is not surprising that a certain percentage is made up of individuals who confuse liberty with license, consider that the possession of a hunting license gives them the right of trespass, and expect others to provide them with good hunting at no expenditure of time and effort on their part.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Northwest Airlines asserted today that it should be allowed to drop its service to Miles City, Mont.

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- The terms of the communique on United States aid for Indo-China published today were rather too warlike to suit some Frenchmen who like to hope for a negotiated peace, especially if there is one for Korea.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development completed its seventh year of successful operation and moved smoothly into its eighth on June 25 last. It might be said, however, that it didn't take official cognizance of its birthday until early last month at its annual meeting in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Eisenhower said today that the fact of Soviet possession of the hydrogen bomb was of the utmost significance and made it more important than ever to find out whether the Soviet Union and its satellites were interested in honestly attempting to reach some kind of a negotiated settlement in which the free world could have confidence.
PARIS, Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- Car makers put their new models on the line tomorrow at the opening of Paris' fortieth motor show, first of the season's big automobile previews.
Gov. Earl Warren of California, describing himself as a "progressive Republican," has commended the middle way in political philosophy. Warning his party against extremes, he once declared:

MADRID, Sept. 30 (UP) -- Generalissimo Francisco France sent the Spanish - American bases - for - aid agreement to Parliament today for approval with a message praising the United States as a firm nation of strong leaders and brave men.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported that industrial production "declined slightly" in September after a "substantial" increase in August.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 23.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Eisenhower ruled out a national sales tax at the retail level today as a possible means of producing revenue needed by the Federal Government. He left the door open, however, for a general sales tax to be levied on manufacturers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- A plea for lower rates and greater competition in the field of automobile insurance was made before the National Association of Insurance Agents today.

Rudolf G. Sonneborn, national chairman of the United Israel Appeal, reported yesterday that expenditures of the Appeal's agencies for immigrant and rehabilitation programs in Israel were almost one-third, or about $22,000,000, behind the budgetary needs for the first eight months of this year.

Yesterday was no time for the uninformed in the ways of finance to visit the gallery of the Stock Exchange. From that point one might have got the impression that the bulls were in command and the ticker was running late. At least there was enough cheering noise coming from the floor to give that impression.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Exercise Mariner, the current re-enactment of the Battle of the Atlantic by the navies of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, has pointed the way for minor modifications in the design of some United States naval vessels, radio dispatches from Vice Admiral Thomas S. Combs, commander of the NATO striking fleet now maneuvering off Iceland, indicated today.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday and active months closed unchanged to 13 points up.

The Labor party is surprising no one during this week's annual conference at Margate by accomplishing little and failing even to settle its own quarrels. The party is more obviously divided than ever before and unable either to come up with new ideas or agree on the old ones.

Since Robert Anderson is a sensitive writer, it is fortunate that some sensitive actors are playing his drama. He calls it "Tea and Sympathy." Deborah Kerr and John Kerr (not related despite the same name) helped to give it an infinitely sensitive performance at the Ethel Barrymore last evening.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Eisenhower declared emphatically today that he never had knowingly broken an agreement with any associate.
BERLIN, Sept. 30 -- West Berlin mourned today the death of its Mayor, Ernst Reuter, and began what promises to be a long and critical debate as to his successor.

Directors of the Atlas Plywood Corporation voted to resume the payment of common dividends with the declaration yesterday of 15 cents a share for payment on Oct. 28. The last previous payment was 37 1/2 cents in May, last year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- A 27 per cent cut in funds supplied by the United Nations Technical Assistance Program to the World Health Organization is being carried out on thirty-seven projects in twenty-four countries.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- The Women's Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York held its first golf tournament today at the Century Country Club, with 112 women competing against Roslyn (Cookie) Swift of Glen Oaks.

Behind the strike of waterfront workers is this clear-cut issue: The American Federation of Labor is determined to end racketeering on the piers. To achieve this goal it was compelled to revoke the charter held by Joseph P. Ryan and his associates and to grant it to another group.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- In a renewed effort to obtain certification for an all-cargo trans-Atlantic service, Seaboard Western Airlines, Inc., today told Herbert K. Bryan, an examiner of the Civil Aeronautics Board, that foreign airlines were "capturing the lion's share of the expanding air-freight business."

Bonds called for redemption in September before maturity increased slightly over the August figure but were the smallest for the month since 1949. They amounted to $17,966,000, compared with $15,984,000 in August and with $40,313,000 in September, 1952.

The International Longshoremen's Association, chief target of the waterfront clean-up laws adopted three months ago by New York and New Jersey, began yesterday its court fight to have the laws declared unconstitutional.
A new development in textile weaving which eliminates the hot humid atmosphere of the cotton weave shed was demonstrated yesterday in the basement of the Iselin-Jefferson Building at 90 Worth Street.

Elegance and mastery of design mark the fashions by Ben Reig and his designer, Omar Kiam, shown yesterday by Bonwit Teller at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Their chic and unmistakable look of quality were eloquently apparent in sleek town suits, costume suits, a group of "little black dresses" and handsome evening designs.

Sales and earnings of Argus Cameras, Inc., in the fiscal year ended on July 31 were the largest in its history, according to the annual report of Robert E. Lewis, president, mailed to stockholders yesterday.

Plans have been advanced at recent meetings at the Ambassador for the evening performance Nov. 18 at the Belasco of "The Solid Gold Cadillac," a new comedy with Josephine Hull and Loring Smith, for the benefit of the Washington Square Home for Friendless Girls.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 30 -- Republic Pictures under a new policy of financing independent picture production, has concluded its first deal with Virginia Van Upp to write and produce "The Big Whisper." Miss Van Upp is in Germany, where she has gathered first-hand material for the suspense drama.

GENEVA, Sept. 30 -- Three small but troublesome impediments to international trade have been removed as a result of the use by injured parties of machinery provided by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Bebop is bebop in four of the official languages of the United Nations, but in the fifth, Chinese, it is just "vulgar music."

The Yankees won the ball game, but they may have lost Allie Reynolds for the balance of the series. From Reynolds himself it was learned in the victorious team's dressing room a few minutes after yesterday's opener had been concluded that the right-hander had reinjured his back and his availability for the balance of the series was "doubtful."

Frederick Ashton's new version of Delibes' "Sylvia," which the Sadler's Wells Ballet presented for the second time at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, is just as beautiful and engrossing a work as it seemed to be the night before. Indeed, it is so full of riches -- visual, choreographic and musical -- that it will, in all likelihood, continue to be beautiful and engrossing for many more re-seeings.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 1 -- Both the United Nations Command and the Communists in Korea have decided not to begin today their efforts to convince their former personnel, prisoners of war now in neutral custody, that they should change their minds about returning to their homelands.

Five hundred lawyers, jurists and civic officials attended the annual Red Mass of the Roman Catholic Church yesterday morning to ask Divine guidance for the administration of justice during the fall court terms. The service was held at St. Andrew's Church, Duane Street and Cardinal Hayes Place, near Foley Square.
NIAGARA FALLS, Sept. 30 (AP) -- An agricultural economist predicted today that farm prices and incomes next year would be about the same as this year.

Interest in the world series cut stock market interest yesterday, with the result that the turnover for the day was but 940,000 shares. Prices receded slightly. The only excitement of the session was produced by Heyden Chemical, which had a pleasant run-up on word that it had developed a new antibiotic.
Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, predicted his election yesterday in an interview after the formal opening of headquarters of Citizens for Riegelman at the Roosevelt Hotel.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Work was begun on the Clyde today on a 22,500-ton transatlantic passenger liner for the Canadian Pacific Railway Company.
Bruce Wormald, a 20-year-old Columbia University student, found out in Mid-Manhattan Court yesterday that there are cheaper ways of getting rid of an old car than dumping it in the East River.
Your editorial on the status of Secretary Benson was most appropriate.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- Indications pointing to a longshoremen's strike that would tie up Atlantic shipping was an unsettling factor in the grain markets today. In addition, the coarse grains were affected by the fine weather which makes an early movement of the new crop corn almost a certainty. At all events, demand for grains was narrow and made it rather easy to depress prices.

New securities offered publicly here in September rose sharply to the second 1953 monthly total of more than $1,000,000,000 and to the highest level since May. The flotations were also the largest for any September in more than twenty-seven years.

Representatives of labor organizations in the retail field opposed the recent recommendations of the wage board appointed by Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, at a final hearing yesterday in the Bar Association building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- Drastic cuts in staff of the European headquarters of the Mutual Security Program here are expected to reduce expenditures about 50 per cent in the current as compared to the last fiscal year, ending June 30, 1953, when they amounted to about $10,000,000.

The National Better Business Bureau, Inc., reported yesterday that it was "pleased" over the new ruling of the Federal Trade Commission which permits non-deceptive use of conditional "free" offers. The ruling referred to was that made by the F. T. C. on Sept. 11 in dismissing a complaint against Walter J. Black, Inc., publisher.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 -- Governor Warren's designation, although rumored for days, still came as something of a surprise to many Californians.

Jim (Junior) Gilliam, who made the first Dodger hit, the first Dodger put-out and hit a home run in his first world series, was the least affected by defeat and the calmest fellow in the Brooklyn dressing room yesterday.
HAMILTON, Mass., Sept. 30 -- Mrs. George S. Patton Jr., widow of a celebrated soldier, was killed today when thrown from her horse during an early morning drag hunt. She was 67 years old.

Passenger and cargo ships, led by the superliners United States and the Queen Elizabeth, churned out of New York harbor yesterday in numbers reminiscent of a wartime convoy as steamship operators sought to beat the longshore strike deadline of 12:01 A. M. today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The pioneering First Lady of Panama, Senora Cecilia de Remon, today showed social workers at the Department of Health, Education and Welfare three spectacular color films of her penetrations into her country's innermost jungles and outermost islands to promote health, education and welfare.

Dr. John F. Mahoney, the city's Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday that he would ask the Board of Health at its meeting today to adopt the revised plan of gamma globulin distribution announced on Tuesday by Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Commissioner of Health.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Stock market prices advanced today in fairly active dealings. British Government securities rose in advance of the announcement of the Government's refunding operation.

Volume on the New York commodity exchanges was extremely light yesterday. Only hides, soybean oil and wool had fair activity in one of the dullest days of the year. Cocoa, sugar, coffee and metal importers concentrated on clearing deliveries in port before the longshoremen's contract expired at midnight.

Castro Convertibles, maker of [sofa beds, has ieased .the store and I showroom space comprising the ground floor in the Publicity Building at 1572-76 Brodway, which also fronts on West Forty-seventh. The floor was occupied during World War II by a U S. O. servicemen's canteen and was used until recently by the Pepsi-Cola Company for the same purpose.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 1 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan submitted to a joint session of both Houses of Parliament today a bill revalidating the original voters act. By so doing he widened the split in the opposition United party, which is torn between those who refuse to tamper with the century-old common roll franchise and those who favor Prime Minister Malan's plan.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- The French battalion that has fought in Korea will be transferred to Indo-China in the next few weeks. The move is part of the reinforcement of the French expeditionary force provided for in the new military plan of Gen. Henri-Eugene Navarre, French Commander in Chief in Indo-China, upon which was based the grant of $385,000,000 of additional United States aid.
Charges of unfair labor practices will be filed against the Cafe Owners Association of New York today by the American Guild of Variety Artists, A. F. L.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The imminent departure of Hugh S. Cumming Jr., newly appointed Ambassador to Indonesia, to his post at Jakarta has focused attention here on official Washington's reaction to political changes reflecting an increase of Communist influence in the new republic and the recent revolt in northern Sumatra.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today the resignation of Marion W. Boyer as its general manager and the appointment of Maj. Gen. Kenneth D. Nichols as his successor. The change will take place Nov. 1.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Friday, Oct. 2 -- Anti-Communist prisoners in the Korean neutral zone today staged their second mass break-out attempt in two days and two were killed and five wounded by Indian guards. It brought the total casualties in the rioting to three prisoners of war dead and ten wounded.

The recent fun-page advertisement in your splendid paper announcing a meeting in celebration of the 3000th anniversary of the founding of Jerusalem calls attention anew to the status of that historic city with the United Nations -- and indeed with all the nations of the world.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 1 -- While in a prisoner-of-war camp in North Korea last winter Bernard Berman, then a private first class in the Army, made an unusual request in a letter to his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Morris Berman of 504 Monmouth Avenue, Lakewood.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 1 (UP) -- Authoritative sources said today that restrictions on the freedom of the press would be lifted by the Colombian Government either before or during the forthcoming general assembly of the Inter-American Press Association, scheduled to meet in Mexico City next week.
Akron, Ohio, announced yesterday that it would offer to bidders on Oct. 13 an issue of $3,000,000 of waterworks general obligation bonds dated Nov. 1, 1953 and maturing on Nov. 1, 1955 to 1974.

THE town's most fortunate cab driver these days is Carmelo Longobardi, who works out of the National Transportation Company garage at Twelfth Avenue and Forty-ninth Street. His assignment puts him in a reserved seat at all the world series games and his cab clock keeps paying off in a parking lot all through game time.

VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Oct. 1 -- An original musical comedy in three acts, composed by two of Valley Stream Central High School's 1953 graduates, will be presented at the school's auditorium tomorrow night and Saturday night.

Fieldcrest Mills, Inc., newly organized company which recently took over the textile properties of Marshall Field Co., announced yesterday that Frederick C. Dumaine Jr., president of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, has been elected a director.

Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council and Liberal party candidate for Mayor, clashed publicy yesterday with Harold Riegeman, his Republican adversary, over the question of Mr. Halley's political independence.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 1 (UP) -- The fourteen members of the Radical minority of the Chamber of Deputies called upon the Executive today to report why Dr. Manuel V. Ordonez, attorney, had been detained without charges for several week.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Oct. 1 -- Switzerland's red-hulled Ylliam VIII slipped over the line first to get the upper hand in the six-meter sailing for the One-Ton Cup today. The victory was her second in three races. One more and the cup goes to Lake Geneva.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program collected 11,209 pints of blood last month, as compared with 9,966 pints in August. T. Morgan Williams, program chairman, announced October's goal as 15,000 pints, representing 10,000 for local use and 5,000 for defense needs.
I threw everything at Brooklyn except the resin bag.
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- The stock markets here were active again today and widespread gains were made, some of them substantial, among industrial shares and foreign bonds.

Princeton, which divided its line talent and alternated two eleven-man units in its precarious 20-14 opening-game victory over Lafayette, apparently will take no such chances against a respected Columbia foe at Palmer Stadium tomorrow.

The American Heritage Foundation, which has taken over the Crusade for Freedom, the group that supports Radio Free Europe and its broadcasts to people living behind the Iron Curtain, has scheduled a two-day meeting in Washington Oct. 20 and 21 to enlist prominent groups and organizations in its campaign.

The first office skyscraper to be erected in Manhattan's downtown financial district in more than two decades will go up on the site of the old New York Produce Exchange Building on Broadway at Bowling Green.

Two new films open today at first-run theatres. At the Criterion is an R. K. O. Technicolor melodrama, "Devil's Canyon," starring Virginia Mayo, Dale Robertson, Stephen McNally and Arthur Hunnicutt. Robert Keith and Jay C. Flippen head the supporting cast.

Esther Dorothy is the ideal furrier for those looking for news. Her collection of new fall designs, shown yesterday at 60 East Fifty-sixth Street, was no disappointment. The designer regaled her audience with topaz mink, broadtail and mink on lace and a new sleeve cut on the curve to conform to the contour of the arm, which, she says, seldom hangs straight.

Four newspaper men who will receive Maria Moors Cabot medals from Columbia University today for their roles in "advancement of international friendship in the Americas," were honored yesterday by the Overseas Press Club.

MONTREAL, Oct. 1 -- The Shipping Federation of Canada said today that cargoes for North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries of Europe had been transferred from strike-bound Canadian ships to foreign vessels.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- President Eisenhower agreed today that the Principle of equality of opportunity and treatment must be given full effect in regard to the citizens of Panama and of the United States employed in the Canal Zone.

Behind the facade of "Comedy in Music" lurks Victor Borge, a skillful pianist whose one-man show will be introduced at 8 o'clock this evening at the Golden. Dubbed the "pixie Paderewski," the keyboard comedian, who obeys his whims in varying the program with each performance, has been visiting legitimate theatres on the road since Jan. 26.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Eligible to compete for the first time this year, Mrs. Henri Prunaret of Natick, Mass., won the women's United States senior golf title with a record-breaking score of 162 for thirty-six holes at the south course of the Westchester Country Club today.

In reference to Harold Weiner's letter published in your Sept. 29 issue I would like to point out that, having myself been in France for a long time, I know of the deep hatred of the French people for the German invaders.
The performance of "Sylvia" by the Sadler's Wells Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House last night had Nadia Nerina in the title role for the first time, and a delightful Sylvia she proved to be.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 1 -- The Alexandria Gazette went to press today with a special issue reporting the world in great turmoil.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Cordell Hull will celebrate his eighty-second birthday quietly tomorrow, gratified that the main principles for which he stood in his long public career have been carried forward by the United States Government to this day.
Following is the text of an address by Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor made yesterday at a luncheon of the New York State Chamber of Commerce at 65 Liberty Street:

Ebbets Field is easily accessible by automobile or subway from mid-Manhattan. It can be reached by rapid transit by the Brighton line of the BMT, the Independent Subway and the Lexington and Seventh Avenue lines of the IRT.
THE TIMES of Sept. 24 carries a news item headed "Vinson Left $7,163 But He Owed $6,000."

Two East Side sites have been purchased by .builders for improvement with apartment houses. One is at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and- Eighty-first Street and the other is on' the [south side of Seventieth Street between Second and Third Avenues.

A sharp reduction in seamen's training operations is being sought by the Maritime Administration for its fiscal 1955 budget, and the shipping industry has been canvassed by the agency as to what extent it would be willing to participate financially in continued training.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Moving sharply on the turn into the stretch, Joe Gavegnano's Coastal Light pounded home an easy winner in the Exchange Club Purse, before 9,752 racegoers today. Backed down to 7-10 favoritism, Coastal Light scored by 3 1/2 lengths.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Oct. 1 (UP) -- A wave of upsets hit the California State amateur golf tournament today and knocked out all the remaining favorites with the exception of the national amateur champion, Gene Littler.

Lives there a man with soul so dead who never has found himself spiritually merging with the landscape, rehashing the talk at last week's cocktail party, projecting endless Walter Mitty dialogues -- all while driving his newly tuned-up auto along one of the country's super-smooth, super-fast super -highways?

The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service completed its fourth year of service yesterday and added up its record of hauling military cargoes and passengers to different parts of the world on American Government-owned and privately owned ships.

Career fashions modeled by career girls were presented yesterday at Milgrim's. Clothes under $100 from the fourth-floor shops were shown with imaginative, inexpensive accessories and a special group of hats from the Young Flair Millinery collection.
Biographical sketches of the members of President Eisenhower's board of inquiry in the pier strike follow:

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- Continuing its policy of agitation, the Communist-led General Confederation of Labor ordered railwaymen on lines running out of Lyon Station in Paris to the southeast to halt work at 6 o'clock tonight for twenty-four hours.

WESTBROOK, Conn., Oct. 1 -- A bright sun and a light wind provided a comfortable but not too productive opening day for the few shooters who turned out for the opening of the scoter, old squaw and eider duck season today.

ROME, Oct. 1 -- The Pope excommunicated today all those persons, whether Polish or of any other nationality, who were in any way concerned with the suspension of Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, Primate of Poland, from his ecclesiastical duties and his internment in a monastery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican on Wisconsin, says the nation's security would be "infinitely more endangered" today if Congressional investigators had not persistently sought out subversion and espionage.

CRESTWOOD, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Mrs. Jan Berlage of Siwanoy carded 37, 38 -- 75 today to capture gross honors in the women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association play at Leewood. Matching women's par of 36, 39 -- 75 for the 6,253-yard layout, Mrs. Berlage scored in a field of fifty for her second such triumph of the season.
A dinner in honor of the fortieth anniversary of the founding of the New York State Commission for the Blind was held last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Less than a dozen tankers in the New York area were affected yesterday by the day-old strike of deck officers, which coincided with the longshoremen's walkout, and it appeared that the full impact of the strike would not be felt for another week or ten days.

BERLIN, Oct. 1 -- West Berlin, normally ablaze with flashing neon lights, became a city of flickering candles and torches tonight as its people began a final two-day tribute to their dead mayor, Dr. Ernst Reuter.

Those incredible Yankees were down almost on one knee at the Stadium yesterday in their spectacular dash toward a fifth straight world series triumph, but that, perhaps, is as close as they will come to being stopped.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 1 -- Douglas Abbott, Finance Minister of Canada, today urged United States tariff adjustments to increase trade without placing new barriers against Canadian production.

Troubled relations between the New York City Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., reached a new level of tension yesterday. The Authority refused to recognize a special committee set up at the union's request by Mayor Impellitteri to settle a disagreement over transit operating schedules.

To Rodman Gilder whose death -- sudden and unexpected to the wide circle of his friends -- was recorded yesterday, nothing that concerned the city of his birth was alien. The history of New York had been his life-long study and the changing scene always invited from him eager curiosity and fascinating side trips into the past.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Under Secretary of Commerce Walter Williams said today that in these days of high employment business men must solve their financial problems "without running to Uncle Sam."

LEAD, S. D., Oct. 1 -- Less than seventy-five years ago, when this section of the West was still wild and free, a persevering young man could take a pick, shovel and an old washpan and scoop up enough gold to make himself rich. Anyone interested in duplicating that feat today should first consider the operations of the Homestake Mining Company, the nation's largest gold producer.

Sales finance companies were a dominant factor in the net volume of loans to business by New York City banks during the week ended on Wednesday -- their sixth successive week of such prominence. The companies led the list of new borrowers in an expansion of $113,000,000 last week.

The best religious education for children might well be more and better religious education for their parents, religious leaders and specialists in child development indicated yesterday at a conference at Riverside Church. The parley -- the annual city - wide conference for Christian education leaders -- was conducted under the sponsorship of the Protestant Council of the City of New York as a feature of Religious Education Week.

Adlai E. Stevenson, former candidate for President and titular head of the Democratic party, said yesterday that he might endorse Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic nominee for Mayor, "but I will do it at the proper time."

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Oct. 1 -- Ceylon has offered asylum to Amin Didi, former President of the Maldive Islands who was deposed in the recent coup and is now under arrest and in exile on one of the Maldive's many atolls.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Indianapolis local of the International Typographical Union said today it had been informed that the members have rejected another union proposal to raise a $1,000,000 defense fund.

The dry weather in August has caused more than a month's delay in the completion of Columbia University's beautification program for its bicentennial celebration next year, Frederick Miller, consulting engineer in charge of the project, disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- President Eisenhower's ailment in his right elbow has been diagnosed as bursitis.

The New York State Employment Service of the State Labor Department, in its September Labor Market Letter released yesterday, reported that 3,500 executives, with a work force of 180,000, predicted in answers to questionnaires that there would be a 4.5 per cent rise in jobs by December.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Strange as it seems to anyone who listened to yesterday's debate here, the international conference that is to bring about "a peaceful settlement of the Korean question" is supposed to meet less than four weeks from now.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Adlai E. Stevenson reported today that President Eisenhower was giving careful consideration to his proposal that the free world seek to regain the peace initiative by proposing a durable system of mutual non-aggression guarantees covering the Soviet Union as well as the countries of Western Europe.

AUCKLAND, N. Z., Oct. 1 -- After visiting five continents and traveling 45,000 miles to investigate American technical aid, Senator Allen J. Ellender, Democrat of Louisiana, said here today he was convinced that the United States program was being abused.

IT was a day for the junkmen, Eddie Lopat and Preacher Roe. They sell the batters nothing valuable, or even good, with their specious spiels. It is tawdry merchandise that they offer -- soft stuff, slow curves, sliders, change-ups, screwballs and teasers. In the baseball players' jargon it's called "junk." It looks easy to hit but, as Yogi Berra once said in an admirable summation, "It ain't."

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, yesterday pledged himself and his administration, if elected, to undertake "early and aggressive" action to correct conditions that he said were causing New York to lose shipping business to other American ports.

CAIRO, Oct. 1 -- Former Premier Ibrahim Abdel Hadi and an obscure electrician named Mohammed Ahmed Awad were condemned today to death by hanging after they had been found guilty of treason by the ruling army junta's Revolution Tribunal.

PARAMUS, N. J., Oct. 1 -- Maureen Orcutt of Ridgewood triumphed in a one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association with a three-over-par 40, 37 -- 77 over the Ridgewood Country Club course today.

MAHANOY CITY, Pa., Oct. 1 -- The Anthracite Board of Concilation, oldest industry-wide arbitration machinery in the industrial history of this country, commemorated its fiftieth anniversary tonight with a dinner attended by 1,500 persons, including prominent union and industry leaders.

MARGATE, England, Oct. 1 -- A foreign policy resolution of the National Executive Committee of the British Labor party, calling for the neutralization of Korea and Formosa, the seating of Communist China in the United Nations and delay in the rearmament of Germany, was approved decisively by the delegates to the party's annual conference today.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 1 -- India's break-up into linguistic units began today with the inauguration of the strongly Communist Andhra State on the Southeast coast by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru. A Government commission is soon to begin investigations looking toward formation of other linguistic states, compartmentizing major population groups having their own languages and cultures.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Saturday were 819,709 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Oct. 1 -- The Netherlands ship Sibajak arrived here today after having paused to pay a call and give presents to the lonely eleven-man crew of the Coast Guard light ship stationed off the Massachusetts coast near Nantucket.

BOKHARA, U.S.S.R., Sept. 27 -- The fabulous bazaars and market places of old Bokhara are no more and in their place there is a collective farmers' municipal market and a small department store selling the same kind of goods one would buy in Moscow.

A complaint of secondary boycotting against Local 333, United Marine Division, of the International Longshoremen's Association was lodged with the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board yesterday by the Marine Towing and Transportation Employers Association.

President Eisenhower's prompt invocation of the Taft-Hartley Act in the longshoremen's strike opens the way for a temporary eighty-day injunction. There is no doubt that the President was correct in holding that the strike, if permitted to continue, would "imperil the national health or safety."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 --A business and Defense Services Administration was created in the Department of Commerce today as a medium of cooperation between Government and business in promoting the nation's economic stability and growth.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Two world harness-racing, records were equaled, four under two-minute miles were registered, and three of four feature races went extra heats at today's Grand Circuit session at the Lexington track.

Increased power and engine performance and styling improvements are the outstanding advances in the 1954 line of cars announced yesterday by the Hudson Motor Car Company. There is a reduction of $50 on three models of the Wasp series, but the others remain at the 1953 level.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower said today that the Red Cross "personifies the great and nobler virtues of man that are the richest heritage of the Almighty." He spoke informally at the dedication of a new building for the District of Columbia Red Cross Chapter.

TORONTO, Oct. 1 -- A closely guarded corner of the A. V. Roe $50,000,000 aircraft plant at nearby Malton houses Canada's hottest aviation secret -- Project Y. There an expanding team of researchers is developing what they hope will be the West's first flying saucer.

I was shocked to learn of the manner in which the Board of Education has been employing substitutes for unfilled teacher positions. The failure of 200 duly qualified and properly tested teachers to accept assignment to our city schools caused a serious shortage.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower told state civil defense directors today not to get discouraged.

Abraham Blumenkrantz, chairman of the General Instrument Corporation, took issue yesterday with Benjamin Abrams, president of the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation, on future pricing of color television receivers.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 -- The American Dental Association closed its annual convention here today with an attack on misleading advertising of dentifrices.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 1 -- West Germany's Trade Union Federation, having rejected a set of demands from Christian Democratic labor leaders yesterday turned around today and said it was willing to negotiate. And thereby hangs a tale.

KALISPELL, Mont., Oct. 1 (UP) -- One member of the 1903 Pirates, who lost the world series to Boston, five games to three, didn't receive his invitation to attend the 1953 series as an honored guest of organized basball.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Ralph J. Cordiner, president of General Electric Company, said today that electric utilities will be forced to double their capacity for generating power within ten years. Instead of planning for a recession which need not come, the industry should be getting ready for its most active and prosperous decade in history, he asserted.

LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- I was out for a walk in Moscow one autumn night a few years ago. My meditations were interrupted by a roar and a crash. Across the street a cloud of dust and plaster arose. People ran from all directions.

If he can get some fast horses to ride, Earl Sande, who is nearing his 55th birthday, intends to go back to work as a jockey. That was the No. 1 item of racing news yesterday at Belmont Park, where Sande, and 17,885 others, saw Mrs. Esther duPont Weir's The Mast, the 5-to-2 favorite, win the $17,800 Brook Steeplechase.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 1 -- Brig. Gen. Hossein Azmoudeh, chief prosecutor of the Iranian Army, revealed today that he would ask a court martial to sentence former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh to death for his rebellious attempt to retain power against the orders of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi in August.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- During the week ended Sept. 30, member bank reserves decreased $177,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The Marine Midland Corporation announced yesterday that it had offered to acquire the Potsdam Bank arid Trust Company of Potsdam, N. Y., through an exchange of stock. The basis of the offer is two shares of Marine Midland stock for each share of the stock of the Potsdam bank.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- The fortieth French Automobile Show opened here today with keen competition evident among French, British, German and Italian manufacturers for European and other export markets. Fourteen countries with 105 automobile, truck and bus manufacturers are represented.

William Woodward, turf leader and former head of the Hanover Bank and a director of the Federal Reserve, who died last Saturday at the age of 77, left his estate in trust for the benefit of his widow and family, it was learned yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Despite gales and violent thunderstorms planes of the Royal Air Force Bomber Command flew 1,000 miles from their base in Lincolnshire today to "attack" a naval striking force as it headed toward Scotland in Exercise Mariner.
