The Grand Union Company, which operates a chain of about 300 retail food stores, had an increase of 50 per cent in earnings in the quarter ended on Aug. 29, while retail sales were 10.8 per cent larger than the corresponding three months of last year.

Again there are signs that the inadequate structure of our water supply is creaking under the burdens placed upon it. This is not to say that we are necessarily in for another water shortage similar to that of 1949-50, but there are some similarities between the water storage situation now and the one that existed four years ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said today, upon signing the mutual defense treaty between the Republic of Korea and the United States, that it represented "another link in the collective security of the free nations of the Pacific."

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- The wheat market registered a quick recovery following announcement that President Eisenhower had acted to halt the longshoremen's strike by invoking the provision of the Taft-Hartley law providing for a cooling-off period.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- High United Nations officials are planning to ask the General Assembly to set up new regulations strictly limiting the political activity allowed employes of the organization.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Speculation regarding possible changes in the British Cabinet was intensified here today as political observers watched closely the activities of Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister, and Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 2 -- Indian Army guards killed one North Korean prisoner and wounded five other captives yesterday at a Korean neutral-zone camp in quelling a demonstration and attempted mass break-out by aroused anti-Red prisoners.
Two of the most dejected fellows in the visitors' clubhouse at the Stadium yesterday after the Dodgers had lost their second world series game to the Yankees were Preacher Roe and Roy Campanella.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The United Mine Workers Journal said today that organized labor might as well realize the only way it would get the Taft-Hartley Law changed was to elect a sympathetic Congress in 1954.

A number of employes in Wall Street did not have to work overtime last night after all. It had been expected by some of the larger brokerage firms that the railroad unions might disclose their demands for new wage contracts during the day.

AUGUSTA, Me., Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Portland Daily Examiner Company filed its certificate of incorporation with the Secretary of State today. The corporation was formed by striking members of the Portland Newspaper Guild who plan to publish a morning tabloid in composition with The Portland Press Herald.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Representative James P. Richards, Democrat of South Carolina, pushed a handcart stacked with bundles of United Nations documents into the conference room of the General Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee today to dramatize a United States request for a slash in documentation as a means of saving United Nations money.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- A number of the countries that sent troops to fight for the United Nations forces in Korea have expressed surprise at the extent of the bills sent them by the United States for equipment and logistic support.

Led by newspapers, a $2,000,000 ad campaign will be placed through Hilton Riggio, Inc., by the B. B. Pen Company beginning Oct. 12. Copy will promote the company's new B. B. Rol-Rex pen, with an engraved cap and metal sleeve retractor button, topped with the company's "Red Head" ruby crown.

National Airlines, Inc., agreed yesterday in a stipulation filed in Federal Court to pay $169,398 in damages to a woman who was severely injured in a crash of one of the line's planes in Elizabeth, N. J., in February, 1952. The settlement was believed to be the largest ever received by a woman in a personal accident case.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Among the items in Earl Warren's public record that especially commended him to the President and the Attorney General as they weighed his qualifications for Chief Justice of the United States was the part he took in the controversy over the special loyalty oath prescribed by the regents of the University of California for the faculty.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Abba S. Eban, Israel's delegate to the United Nations, denounced today as "completely untrue" charges by Egypt that Israel forces had occupied an area at El Auja, in the demilitarized zone separating the two countries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Department store sales in the week ended Sept. 26 were 3 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board which listed the following changes from like periods of 1952:

PARIS, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- Representatives of twenty-one American, European and Asian steamship companies today decided to maintain present fares, despite rising costs, to compete with cheap tourist fares recently introduced by airlines.

VIRGINIA WATER, England, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Eight Americans tee off for the Ryder Cup series tomorrow with their eyes on the ball, but their thoughts on an old adversary -- Henry Cotton, Britain's golf tactician whose masterminding has everyone groggy.

Sales in September for twelve major New York City department stores registered an aggregate loss of 4 per cent compared with September of 1952, according to a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Three-under-par best-ball scores of 67 carried teams representing Fenway, Vernon Hills and Mount Kisko into a tie for the Westchester professional-president championship at the Quaker Ridge golf club today.

Resources of the Manufacturers Trust Company at the end of last month were $2,806,785,378, against $2,700,243,933 on June 30, according to the bank's quarterly statement of condition, issued for publication today. Deposits rose to $2,573,862,235 from $2,474,464,789.

Volume was low, especially in the afternoon, when the stock market tried to compete with the world series, but the tone on the New York Stock Exchange showed an improvement yesterday. Despite a mildly softer Treasury bond market, aircrafts, chemicals, televisions and some of the oils pushed ahead and THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average of fifty stocks closed 1.16 points higher at 171.01.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- President Eisenhower's use of the Taft-Hartley Law's emergency section raised some fine legal and policy points for the first time today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Counsel for the Civil Aeronautics Board recommended today that Seaboard and Western Airlines be authorized to operate an all-cargo route to Europe. Five other cargo airlines are seeking the same grant.

President Eisenhower invoked the national emergency provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act yesterday to halt the coast-wide dock striker, and leaders of the crime-spattered International Longshoremen's Association promised that they would send the 50,000 strikers back to work as soon as a formal no-strike order was issued next Monday or Tuesday.

There is now formal announcement in Washington and Paris of the agreed plan for a victory drive against the Communists in Indo-China. The United States has confirmed that it will give additional financial assistance to be used primarily in the equipping of more Indo-Chinese troops to take the field.

DETROIT, Oct. 1 -- Senator Frank Carlson, Republican of Kansas, indicated today that he would oppose further increases in postal rates until the Post Office Department could show proof of increased efficiency and reduced operating costs.

For the second consecutive year directors of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., have declared common stock dividends in excess of earnings of the company, one of the largest producers and distributors of gas in the country. A final dividend of 30 cents a common share was declared yesterday, bringing to 90 cents a share the payments for 1953.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Middle West, for many years the center of authority and the home of the most powerful leaders of the Republican party, is steadily losing ground to the rising generation of the East and Far West.
Around - the - clock fashions designed by Elfreda-Fox were shown by Jay Thorpe yesterday at luncheon in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel.

An expected 25,000 persons will pour $1,000,000 tonight into the betting machines at Yonkers Raceway, where the fall meeting of trotting and pacing races has been delayed for four days as a result of an investigation set off by a murder.

After rising to an altitude of 53,000 feet in a balloon, which was a record a quarter of a century ago, Prof. Auguste Piccard, at the age of 69, goes down into the Tyrrhenian Sea to the record depth of 10,330 feet. We have been hearing of Piccard and his deep-sea plans ever since 1947. At last he has succeeded in making his dream come true.

Three directors of the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad will meet with common and preferred stockholder groups on Oct. 14 in New York City to "attempt to agree upon the basic principles of a plan of recapitalization," it was announced yesterday.

Mayor Impellitteri said yesterday that he would not reject the support of Joseph Pizzo, his Bronx campaign manager, who was called as a witness in the investigation after the murder of Thomas F. Lewis, Bronx labor leader.

HERBERT A. PHILBRICK'S "I Led Three Lives," the story of the nine years in which he worked within the Communist party to aid the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has been made into a series of films (10:30 P. M. Sundays over WNBT).

In a lucid and persuasive analysis of the international situation former Secretary Acheson advances the conclusion that the free world has succeeded in stopping the Communist bloc from attaining world domination and that we now are entering upon a new phase in which negotiations become possible.
The Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company has purchased for $1,500,000 a coal mine that cost between $8,000,000 and $10,000,000 to develop and equip only four years ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Counsel for Owen Lattimore asked the Federal Court of Appeals today to reject a Justice Department plea for the restoration of four counts of a seven-count indictment for perjury that were dismissed on May 2 by Federal Judge Luther W. Youngdahl.

The city's medal of honor for distinguished service was presented yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri to Col. Jose Antonio Remon, President of the Republic of Panama, at a traditional City Hall reception for visiting dignitaries.

The business at hand is important, of course, but there is more to baseball than the world series. In the front office work goes on as usual and yesterday was no exception. Just before the second series game got under way at the Stadium came the announcement that the Yankees had signed Frank Leja, a 17-year-old first baseman from Holyoke, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Immigration and Naturalization Service today assured members of the American Committee for Cultural Freedom and the American Civil Liberties Union that it would seek ways of avoiding unnecessary detainment of resident aliens of the United States when they re-enter the country after visits abroad.

Pan American-Grace Airways (Panagra), which is celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of its first operations between North and South America, is inviting five young men from each of the countries it serves in Latin America to visit the United States as "junior ambassadors."

ARMONK VILLAGE, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Plans for a multimillion-dollar colony of up to twenty executive office buildings on the 400 acres of Cornelius R. Agnew's Wenga Farm in the heart of this northern Westchester County hamlet became known today by a petition filed at the office of the North Castle Town Clerk, Joseph T. Miller.

The sixth and final volume of Sir Winston Churchill's "History of the Second World War" will be published by Houghton Mifflin on Nov. 30. The period covered in "Triumph and Tragedy" is that between D-Day in 1944 and the collapse and surrender of Germany and Japan.
Many a countryman, with open fields or woods at his back door, must have been impressed, or perhaps amused, by Raymond R. Camp's account of his woodchuck-hunting expedition the other day.

Terminating an ownership of about two years, Jack Brause, real estate investor and deeloper, sold the blockfront taxpayer on Astoria Boulevard, between Eighty-fourth and l.lghty-f/fth Streets, in Jackson EIeights, Queens, to Julius 2JJntz, who resold the property to a client of Benjamin Pul/er, attorney.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 1 -- After a long and bitter dispute the Mexican Government has come to terms with a foreign-owned power company in an agreement which it hopes will be taken as proof positive that the Administration here wants foreign capital and is prepared to treat it fairly.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Fires that have been smoldering underground for a month broke out into the open today in Harriman State Park and the United States Military Academy near Fort Montgomery.

On Monday, Alice Witt had the happiest day, so far, of her 18 years -- she went with her fiance to buy the engagement ring. But then, along with the thrills of appearing in news pictures and on television, her troubles began.

The New York Drama Critics Circle re-elected its entire staff of officers at its meeting at the Algonquin yesterday afternoon. The officers are: Joseph Shipley of The New Leader, president; Walter Kerr of The Herald-Tribune, vice president; George Freedley, curator of the Public Library Theatre Collection, secretary; Tom Wenning of Newsweek, treasurer.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, Oct. 1 -- The entry of John Ford, four-time winner of the Academy Award for direction, into the field of Cinerama as director of "Seven Wonders of the World," to be produced by Merian C. Cooper, is expected to be made official soon.

MANYAS, Turkey, Oct. 1 -- The newly competed radar network guarding the strategic Turkish Straits successfully passed its first test in large-scale maneuvers today when it enabled Turkish jet fighters to intercept "enemy" aircraft carrying simulated atomic bombs.

Metropolitan art galleries usually make it a rule to open the season with group shows, and two of these, devoted to non-representational and near-abstract work, are to be found in Greenwich Village, the traditional home of the advance guard.
BUFFALO, Oct. 1 -- A school traffic safety program tested in New York City for the last two years was adopted today by the Institute of Traffic Engineers as the basis of a country-wide standard.

Dr. John F. Mahoney, the city's Commissioner of Health, called a special meeting of the Board of Health yesterday to discuss a move to prohibit the use of water- cooled gas flame refrigerators after Jan. 1. The board scheduled a public hearing for Oct. 14 on the proposed amendment to the Sanitary Code outlawing these potential killers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The United State Information Agency reported today that Government aid in financing book sales abroad had increased the circulation of American books and periodicals in six European countries, Israel and Formosa during the last twelve months.

As a result of the record-breaking abundance of beef, beef liver is in excellent supply at a city-wide price of about 69 cents a pound. This is a reasonable figure, especially in relation to the neglible waste in this meat cut and the amount of nutrients it yields. Liver has been called a "storehouse of nutrition."
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 1 -- The difficulties being encountered by Indian custodial forces in Korea were ascribed by an Indian news agency correspondent in Korea today to the United Nations Command.

ALBANY, Oct. 1 -- Senator Arthur H. Wicks of Kingston, Majority Leader and President pro tempore of the State Senate, was sworn in today as Acting Lieutenant Governor. He succeeded Frank C. Moore, who resigned yesterday to head a governmental research foundation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UP) -- Dr. Edward J. McCormick, president of the American Medical Association, said today he was a "little inclined to believe" that cancer, heart disease and polio would be conquered within ten years.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 -- Rehabilitation programs around the world for severely disabled persons are "more than a service -- they are a language which cements international goodwill and good feeling," Dr. Henry H. Kessler, director of the Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation, West Orange, N. J., said here today.
On Sept. 23 you reported the cooperative effort of seven citizen groups to secure statements from the candidates on municipal issues.
Four straight ?

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Butter manufacturers from the United States and foreign countries today studied a plan to dispose of surplus butter through Government purchase and resale at 10 to 12 cents a pound under current market prices.

Pork, which has been high in price for some time, apparently is being offered as a "loss leader" in many chain stores this week-end. Although the wholesale prices on pork have remained stable, many of the "specials" in pork loin roasts are retailing at below the wholesale level, the City Department of Markets reports.

KENT, Conn., Oct. 1 -- Kent School's coach, Jim Draper, is optimistic about the Blue and Gray eleven. It's unusual when you run into an optimistic coach these days, but the affable Draper believes Kent "has the strength to have a good year."

In a speech here last night former Secretary of State Dean Acheson criticized the Eisenhower Administration for cutting military and foreign-aid budgets. He also attacked his old enemy, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, for "insults" to allies and for "totalitarian" anti-Communist methods.

Split-second timing and expert seamanship by the masters of two trans-Atlantic luxury liners brought 2,183 passengers and 81,339 gross tons of shipping safely into North River berths without the aid of strikebound tugs yesterday as a gray dawn was beginning to break over Manhattan.

CAIRO, Oct. 1 -- Egyptian troops moved up to the Sinai Peninsula frontier today. Israeli forces were said here to have remained behind barbed wire entrenchments near El Auja in the demilitarized zone area that Egyptian reports said they occupied Monday night.
The futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 1 point up to 7 points off.
The United States Steel Corporation's new policy of matching competitors' steel prices by absorbing freight costs in some markets met a mixed reaction from other producers yesterday.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 1 -- The United States program for emergency financial aid to Iran is limping badly, hobbled at the very outset by Iran's archaic monetary and credit structure.

Trading on the New York commodity exchanges continued dull yesterday with only cocoa, the world sugar market and burlap showing slight improvement over Wednesday's inactivity. No sales of copper, lead, tin and zinc were reported. Continued interest in baseball kept volume down.

The French homemade pastries that Mme. Colette Hebert offers in her little bakery at 1031 Third Avenue, near Sixty-first Street, include the delectable quiches Lorraine, flaky-crusted pie with a rich custard filling topped with bits of crisp bacon, salt pork and ham.
AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Seiberling Tire and Rubber Company today followed two other rubber concerns in boosting passenger car tire prices about 2 1/2 per cent and truck tires about 5 per cent.
American-flag ships headed for scrap piles in foreign waters have been placed under the export control of the Office of International Trade, the Department of Commerce announced yesterday.

The "jerry-built" structure of the old International Longshoremen's Association, which has perpetuated gangster control of New York's waterfront, is sure to fall if the decent, hard-working dockmen get the opportunity to choose between it and the new American Federation of Labor longshore union, the Rev. John M. Corridan, famed waterfront priest, asserted yesterday.

TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 3 -- An exchange of letters yesterday between the United Nations Command and the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission reflected the tension in the camps in the neutral zone in Korea in which prisoners of war refusing repatriation are confined.

While the Communists continue to delay the appointment of their representatives to the Korean conference and even threaten to wreck the whole conference project, in violation of the armistice terms, the United States and South Korea have formally signed a mutual defense treaty which introduces a new element into the situation.

Alterations are planned for the four-story dwelling at 115 East Ninety-fifth Street which Fred H. Hill, as president of the Melfra Realty Corporation, has contracted to purchase from Frank Surez. William A. White Co. were the brokers. The buyer plans to convert the structure to seven apartments of one and one-half and two and one-half rooms.
I am writing you in regard to your recent news article relative to cases in Long Island Magistrate's Court.
Adlai E. Stevenson, seated on a green sofa yesterday morning alongside Robert F. Wagner Jr., endorsed Mr. Wagner's candidacy for Mayor of New York.
I wasn't shooting at any record; all I was aiming to do was get our backs away from the wall.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Senate Commerce subcommittee, which once charged New York City with having the "toughest and foulest" waterfront in the country, was ordered today to wind up its affairs and submit its final report.

MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 2 -- John Canty, 28 years old, a bookkeeper employed by the Westchester Racing Association now conducting a meet at Belmont, was held this afternoon on a forgery charge after he allegedly had tried to cash a forged pari-mutuel betting ticket.

College is decidedly not the place for a girl to learn how to buy a vacuum cleaner, Dr. Mirra Komarovsky said in an inteview this week. As thousands of girls returned to college campuses, she reaffirmed the value of a liberal education to the homemaker and career woman alike.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Howard Ehmke almost ruined the battery in his car today listening to the radio description as Carl Erskine broke Ehmke's 24-year-old strike-out record in the third game of the world series.

Supporters of Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor, obtained yesterday an order from Supreme Court Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan directing the Board of Elections to remain open fifteen hours a day, including Sunday, to permit inspection of records.

Vince Martinez, Paterson, scored a technical knockout over Vinnie D'Andrea, East Side boxer, in the feature scheduled for ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The New Jersey scrapper, the rookie of the year in 1952, punished his foe so severely that Referee Petey Scalzo halted proceedings after 1:58 of the fifth.

A dozen colts and a pair of fillies are entered in the sixty-fourth running of the futurity at Belmont Park today -- and it's difficult to pick the favorite in this race that usually points out the champion among the 2-year-olds.

LOS ANGELES, Oct 2 (AP) -- Indiana held Southern California to a 7-7 half-time score tonight, but wilted before breaks and superior manpower as the Trojans scored a 27-14 victory before 49,578 in Memorial Coliseum.

President Eisenhower's three-man board of inquiry into the Atlantic Coast dock strike will begin today the job of fact-finding that is expected to result early next week in an anti-strike injunction and the return to work of 50,000 longshoremen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- President Eisenhower today named Thomas Sovereign Gates Jr., an investment banker of Philadelphia, to be Under Secretary of the Navy. The nomination is subject to Senate approval. Mr. Gates succeeds Charles S. Thomas, who left the Navy post in August to become an Assistant Secretary of Defense, and expects to begin his duties next week.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- The four-day advance in security prices here was temporarily halted today by week-end profit taking, but the setback proved light and the markets closed on a confident note. British Government securities lost ground slightly in quiet business.

Although he didn't get his man, Donald Juers, an 18-year-old messenger who reads a lot of mysteries, behaved like a swash-buckling whodunit hero yesterday when a would-be robber attempted to relieve him of a $4,260 payroll on a busy midtown street.

YONKERS, Oct. 2 -- Holding off a terrific stretch drive by Ralph H. Kroening's bay gelding, Lord Steward, the Arden Homestead Stable's Florican, the fastest trotter in competition, won the $10,000 Brewster free-for-all mile trot as the fall harness meeting opened tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 2 -- The Israeli - Egypt Mixed Armistice Commission meeting in Auja El Hafir today condemned Israel for attacks on Bedouins in the demilitarized zone adjoining the Sinai Peninsula and called upon Israel to withdraw her armed police from the zone.

Was that a ray of brilliant sunshine that beamed down on Ebbets Field yesterday afternoon, lighting up the countenances of Brooklyn fans? Did the cloud that had been hanging over them for two days begin to break up and drift away? Yes, joy gave a little poke with its finger and nudged the gloom back whence it came.

Four of the exhibitions of paintings on view this week -- by an Italian, by a Swiss-born artist who made his name at the Bauhaus, by an Austrian, and by an American -- give the New York art front a decidedly international look.

MANCHESTER, England, Oct. 2 (Reuters) -- The Manchester Guardian said editorially today that when Englishmen look at Uncle Sam they tend to see his bristling whiskers without seeing the generosity of the features behind them.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 2 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was assured today that if a constitutional amendment was needed for West Germany to enter the proposed European army he would get the necessary two-thirds majority in the Bundestag, the lower house of the Bonn Parliament.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Oct. 2 -- Judge Henry J. Bendheim stepped down from the bench in his own court tonight to prosecute a speeder whom he himself had apprehended after giving chase for two miles at seventy miles an hour.

YONKERS, Oct. 2 -- William F. Bleakley, attorney for the Yonkers Trotting Association, said today that his visit to Fay in Sing Sing took place in 1948 and was made on behalf of a client, the president of a heavy construction corporation, who was anxious to learn what the chances were that Fay would be paroled.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 -- Mr. Gates, a son of the late Thomas S. Gates, a president of the University of Pennsylvania and himself a trustee of the university, said he was "very complimented by the appointment."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 2 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's plans for its Sigmund Romberg biography, now known as "Deep In My Heart," has undergone a series of changes. Jose Ferrer was signed this morning to portray the composer and Roger Edens was appointed as the producer.

ALBANY, Oct. 2 -- Following is the list of persons who have visited Joseph Fay, convicted extortionist, in Sing Sing Prison since his imprisonment there in February, 1948, as made public today by the State Correction Department:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- The Soviet Union said today that its proposals for admitting five Communist countries and nine non-Communist states to the United Nations at one time were the only way to settle the long membership controversy.

DETROIT, Oct. 2 -- The United States stands ready to negotiate with the Soviet Union toward ending the "cold war" and easing the acute tensions throughout the world, Under Secretary of State Walter Bedell Smith declared here today.
ST. PAUL, MINN., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Corporation gifts to worthwhile non-profit organizations received the endorsement of President Eisenhower today.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 2 -- Elimination of Social Security's $37,000,000,000 in reserve funds might be financially and economically possible, but the question was whether it would be psychologically possible, Ewan Clague, Commissioner of Labor Statistics in the Department of Labor, said here tonight.
Ample space for family living is agreeably achieved by an architect's plan and enhanced by a decorator's skill in a ranch-type model house now open for public inspection.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 2 -- A request for investigation of the fatal shooting yesterday of a North Korean anti-Communist prisoner and the wounding of five other North Koreans by Indian guards at a neutral-zone compound, was introduced in the Korean National Assembly this evening.

Appointment of Walter T. Shirley, one of the Mayor's principal] backers when he was elected in 1950, as chairman of the Independent Citizens Committee for the Mayor's Re-election was announced yesterday at the Impellitteri campaign headquarters in the Shelton Hotel, Lexington Avenue and Forty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- President Eisenhower has a sore right elbow as a result of a household accident two months ago. the White House said today. He is having heat treatments and is progressing satisfactorily.

" Sunnyside," the sylvan Tarrytown, N. Y., retreat of Washington Irving in the Eighteen Hundreds, will observe its sixth anniversary on Monday as a restoration project. And, as a birthday present, the old-time Hudson River home of the famous author will display a new item of Irvingiana that has been presented by John D. Rockefeller Jr., who financed the restoration.

Praise for Carl Erskine came from every corner of the losing team's dressing room yesterday at Ebbets Field. All the Yankees agreed that the Flatbush right-hander had "terrific stuff." Manager Casey Stengel handed all the credit to Erskine.

Having been fabulously successful in other forms of show business, Victor Borge has moved into the theatre, hoping no doubt to become notorious. Whatever he wants, even though it may only be money, he deserves to get. For at the moment he seems to be the funniest entertainer in the world, with or without piano; and he should be urged to keep open house on Broadway for a long time.

The Army's Transportation Corps is constantly seeking further improvement in rail, highway, water and air equipment to do a better job in beach and port operations and in its tactical role within a combat zone, Brig. Gen. Paul F. Yount asserted last night.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- Attempts by the Vatican to discourage and possibly end an experiment being conducted by the Roman Catholic Church in France in sending priests to work in factories and share the life of the workers are meeting strong resistance from the Catholic clergy here.
RUBE WALKER, the forgotten man who serves as Roy Campanella's substitute, laced into the first pitch in batting practice at Ebbets Field yesterday and sent the ball screaming over the fence.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Kimberly Kid established himself as the one to beat in next week's $70,000 Kentucky Futurity by winning a final tune-up trot for the race today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- Senator Milton R. Young, Republican of North Dakota, said today that his inquiries in North Dakota and in many Midwestern and Mountain States since adjournment of Congress has disclosed that "farmers and ranchers, as well as many business men, bankers and others are greatly worried" over the farmers' economic outlook.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Post Office officials said today they were setting up a system of written examinations to fill the basic supervisory jobs in the postal service.

DETROIT, Oct. 2 -- Roger Franz and Vin Drake, Fordham's alternating quarterbacks, put on a brilliant exhibition of passing tonight as the Rams launched their sixty-second season of football with a 21-7 victory over the University of Detroit before 14,900 spectators at the university stadium.
ALBANY, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Appellate Divsion today unanimously rejected a plea by James A. Leary, Saratoga republican leader, for dismissal of the conspiracy indictment against him.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 2 -- Figures thus far available for mine production of tin in concentrates in August all show a decrease, the International Tin Study Group reported here today.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation had a net income of $1,100,000, equal to 40 cents each on 2,769,486 shares, in the thirty-nine weeks ended Sept. 26, according to preliminary estimates yesterday. In the corresponding period last year the net was $1,277,000, or 46 cents a share.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Simple but dignified ceremonies will mark the official swearing in on Monday of Gov. Earl Warren of California as the fourteenth Chief Justice of the United States, according to plans announced today by Supreme Court officials.

Col. Jose Antonio Remon, President of the Republic of Panama, told members of the Pan American Society of the United States last night that unity in this hemisphere depended largely on an equality of economic opportunity for its peoples.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Department of Justice disclosed today that an investigation had been ordered to determine whether the major liquor distillers had violated the anti-trust laws. The investigation will be conducted by the Anti-Trust Division, of which Stanley N. Barnes, assistant attorney general, is the head.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today that manufacturers' sales, seasonally adjusted, fell off a $1,000,000,000 in August, new orders were off $1,500,000,000, and inventories climbed $400,000,000 higher than in July.

OSLO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Vladimir Kuts, a 26-year old Russian runner, tonight broke the Bislet Olympic Stadium record for 5,000 meters by running the distance in 14 minutes, 5.2 seconds. The old mark, set in 1946 by Britain's Sidney Wooderson, was 14:08.6.

Plans were advanced at a tea given yesterday at the Pierre by Mrs. Richard A. Johnson for the dinner dance in behalf of the Hemophilia Foundation to be held on Oct. 23 in the ballroom of the hotel. Mrs. Johnson heads the benefit committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Defense Department said today it "is considering an Army proposal" to level off the intake of volunteers and draftees, a move that probably would stabilize monthly draft calls at about 34,0O0 men.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 2 -- Sir Percy Spender, Australian Ambassador to the United States, called here tonight for a united Anglo-American policy toward China as one means of strengthening the free world's effort to reach a basis of co-existence with Communist nations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A 28-year-old Pole who fled communism to seek freedom in the United States, said today there was only one way to liberate the Soviet-dominated countries of Europe -- by war.

A commanding officer faces many problems. But holy to handle children who swarm over the base is not included in the Articles of War. Some 35 per cent of the men in our Armed Forces today are married.

ALBANY, Oct. 2 -- The temporary State Commission on Highway Financing indicated strongly tonight that it would recommend to Governor Dewey an increase in the state gasoline tax, with the proceeds to be earmarked for a multi-million dollar highway program.

New York City would be free of its present financial difficulties if something were done to rehabilitate its run-down tenements, according to Emanuel M. Spiegel, president of the National Association of Home Builders. He was one of the speakers at a luncheon meeting yesterday of the New York State Home Builders Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

NEWARK, Oct. 2 -- Paul L. Troast, the Republican candidate for Governor of New Jersey, tonight defended an appeal he had made by letter to Governor Dewey of New York in 1951 to commute the prison sentence of Joseph S. (Joey) Fay, the New Jersey labor leader who is serving a prison sentence in Sing Sing for extortion.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- Chicago national and state banks reported today that their total deposits, loans and discounts, cash resources and holdings of Government bonds were higher on Sept. 30 than on June 30. Savings deposits showed a small shrinkage to $2,051,179,000 from $2,058,844,000.
Francis H. Atkins has been appointed general credit manager of the industrial products division of B. F. Goodrich, Akron, Ohio.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Moissey Brysman of New York has studied the hazards of window-washing, particularly on skyscrapers, and has invented a machine that cleans the outside while the operator sits comfortably indoors. He received Patent No. 2,653,333 on it this week.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- A Communist-organized twenty-four-hour strike on the Southeastern Railway lines that ended this evening failed to tie up traffic, although some delay in suburban and long lines service was caused. Despite the Communist strength on the railroads, few workers responded to the strike call, which was opposed by the' non-Communist unions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2--Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday to 110.6 (1947-49-- 100) according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Generally lower prices for meat were largely responsible for the decrease in the processed foods index, which in turn caused the decrease in the all commodities index.

Since the Sadler's Wells Ballet was last in New York three years ago it has restudied, remounted and restaged its production of "Giselle." The new version was shown for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, with Margot Fonteyn in the title role, Michael Somes as Albrecht and Rosemary Lindsay as Myrtha.

VIRGINIA WATER, England, Oct. 2 -- Fred Daly, an easy-going Irishman with nerves of steel, ran home a twelve-foot uphill putt before a breathless crowd of nearly 10,000 that flanked the thirty-sixth green at the Wentworth Country Club course today.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Boston University's stubborn Terriers, holding Syracuse scoreless in the first half and staving off a last-period drive by the 1952 Eastern champions, surprised tonight by holding the Orange to a 14-14 tie before 18,000 fans in Archbold Stadium.

HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Remnants of a Vietminh brigade that once numbered 5,000 men maneuvered frantically in the Red River delta tonight to avoid extinction by French Union forces. A ten-day-old French drive appeared to be paying off.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, listed yesterday some of the savings he said could be achieved by improving the management and efficiency of the city government. He estimated their total at $70,000,000 a year.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program collected 801 pints of blood on Thursday. Of this amount, 406 pints resulted from the first of a two-day blood-mobile visit at the plant of the International Business Machines Corporation at Poughkeepsie.
Edgar W. Couper, president of iCouper- Ackerman- Sampson, Inc., ,general insurance agency in Binghamtoh, N. Y., has been elected a director of the New York Statet Electric and Gas Corporation.

A university should use every resource to protect the "honest scholar" whose ideas do not coincide with those dominating public opinion at the moment, Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The early development of a cure for cancer, perhaps within ten years, was predicted today by one of the country's leading authorities on the subject, Dr. Cornelius P. Rhoads, scientific director of the Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases in New York.
Your editorial of Sept. 23 "How Much Civil Service?" is an important contribution to the analysis of the personnel management problems facing the Administration.

The California Toll Bridge Authority announced yesterday that it would offer on Oct. 15 an issue of $3,000,000 of San Francisco and Oakland Bay Bridge refunding and improvement revenue bonds dated Sept. 1, 1953 and maturing on Sept. 1, 1962.

HE saw Manhattan as a windowed sierra and the Grand Canyon of the Colorado River as a vertical walk beneath the sun through ancient lands and seas, tropics, glacial periods, deserts -- a picture book of man's layered lives on earth. He had the sense of wonder that makes discoverers and the sense of style that dramatizes discoveries for others to see and understand.

Donald L. Milham, vice president of the General Electric Company and general manager of its lamp department, said yesterday it was not known whether General Electric would appeal Judge Phillip Forman's ruling. He both attacked and praised the decision.

The hall where Henry Ward Beecher lectured when he was minister of Plymouth Congregational Church, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, is being renovated. It will be dedicated at 8 P. M. on Thursday, Oct. 15, as a memorial to Newell Dwight Hillis, second successor to Mr. Beecher.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 2 -- Mrs. Mary Norton, former Representative from New Jersey, announced tonight she had resigned as a member of the National Democratic Committee.

TRENTON, Oct. 2 -- Clifford R. Moore, a Negro member of the State Civil Rights Commission, demanded today the resignation from the commission of Joseph Bicking of Camden, who had charged that the appointment of a white man as director of the State Division Against Discrimination was an act of racial bias.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- The military headquarters and political directorate of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization -- SHAPE and the Atlantic Council -- have become as regular features of the life of Paris as if they had always existed. They illustrate how soon new and revolutionary institutions are taken for granted.

MANILA, Oct. 2 -- Evidence of mass disfranchisement of Filipino electors in one heavily populated area of Central Luzon marked the second and final twelve-hour period of registration for new voters today for the national elections next month.
The third game of the world series yesterday coincided with the smallest stock market turnover since Sept. 9. Its 890,000 shares followed 940,000-share days on Wednesday and Thursday.

BERLIN, Oct. 2 (Reuters) -- The East German Parliament will pick a new president for the Soviet-sponsored Republic next Wednesday at the expiration of the term of Wilhelm Pieck, 77 years old, A. D. N., official East German news agency said tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- India has started a search for support for her suggestion that the United Nations call on the Big Four to meet to discuss the world's major problems.

Mao Tse-tung reviewed some 400,000 of his Red Chinese soldiers in Peiping on Thursday in celebration of the fourth anniversary of his proclamation of the "people's republic." Young Communists released hundreds of doves over the "Gate of Heavenly Peace." At the same time, in a more accurate bit of symbolic trimming, formations of Soviet-supplied jet planes circled over the city.

Alternate-side parking will be introduced on Monday in an eighty-block strip extending from 130th Street north to the Harlem River and to the Polo Grounds at 155th Street. The rule will apply from Fifth Avenue on the east to Eighth Avenue on the west as far north as 145th Street, above which the line will move another block west to include Bradhurst Avenue.

GENEVA, Oct. 2 -- The United States had a comparatively easy time of it today when its import rectrictions came up for criticism in the meeting of the contracting parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Contrary to general belief, those Dodgers, it suddenly develops, "isn't dead."

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Oct. 2 -- Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Baltusrol and J. Bud Geoghegan of Crestmont, playing alternate shots, today won the qualifying medal in the seventh pro-woman golf championship for the Frank J. Cloran trophy. They turned in a record score of 3-under-par 34, 34 -- 68 at Forest Hill Field Club.

Department stores can improve their selling efforts, and their competitive position in relation to chains, by changing their basic concept of item presentation on floors carrying heavy traffic, according to Bernard G. Cohn, president of the Independent Retailers Syndicate, Inc., a New York resident buying office.

Lumber production in the week ended Sept. 26 was 4.7 per cent below the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by regional associations. Shipments were down 6.1 per cent and orders 8.5 per cent. Following are the weekly statistics in thousands of board feet.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- Conflicting price trends appeared in the futures trading on the Board of Trade today. In wheat the December was weak while July registered further gains. A sharp downward revision in cash corn premiums, together with reports that corn was drying out rapidly, caused declines in the yellow cereal and this weakness affected oats.

LONDON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A jewelry store on Moscow's Petrovka Street recently displayed an emerald of several carats, priced at 35,000 rubles. That is about as much as an average Russian would earn in four and one-half years. It is nominally $8,750.
ROME, Oct. 2 (UP) -- A Communist woman Deputy took part in a fight today among Neo-Fascists and Communists in the new Italian Parliament.

Four volumes in the Pleasures of Life Series are scheduled for publication by Horizon Press in the next two months. On Oct. 19, volumes titled "Clothes," by James Laver, and "Women," by C. Willett Cunnington, will be issued. Then on Nov. 2 two books by Andre Simon, "Drink" and "Food," will be released.

ROME, Oct. 2 -- The international conference of foreign ministers deputies which has been meeting in Rome for the last ten days to draft a constitution for the proposed European political community, or federation of European states, made some progress today.

ALBANY, Oct. 2 -- A spark kindled by the labor racketeering raceway scandals today touched off a major political explosion that brought in the names of two leading members of the State Legislature, a former Republican candidate for Governor and a long list of figures prominent in labor and politics.

There was happiness in the Dodger dressing room yesterday for the first time in this world series, but no hilarity. Carl Erskine, already breathless from the tension of the extraordinary game he had just pitched, was mobbed by writers and photographers as soon as the clubhouse door was opened.

District Attorney Frank A. Gulotta of Nassau County announced yesterday that he was widening his inquiry into the activities of William C. De Koning Sr., long the union hiring power at Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury, L. I., to include his relations with contractors in Nassau generally.
Following are sketches of some of the persons listed as having visited Joseph Fay, convicted union extortionist, in Sing Sing Prison. Individual comments, where available, are included.
ALEXANDRIA Va., Oct. 2 -- The "Rebels" put the pressure on the "Damn Yankees" today to get back that fire engine New York forces trundled out of this city in 1861.

OTTAWA, Oct. 2 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's exports to the United States rose by $20,000,000 during August, but shipments to the United Kingdom dropped by almost $6,000,000. This shift toward increasing emphasis on the American market showed today in the Bureau of Statistics' August trade report, which estimated Canada's total exports at $342,600,000, down $3,900,000 from $346,500,000 last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission has accepted a consent settlement with Lagomarcino-Grupe Company, Burlington, Iowa, and Davenport Brokerage Company, Davenport, Iowa, and the companies have agreed to stop brokerage practices which the commission says violate the law.

Jack S. Harris, former political affairs officer at the United Nations, refused yesterday to tell the Senate Internal Security subcommittee what circumstances had led Dr. Ralph J. Bunche to recommend him for positions with the United Nations and the State Department.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 2 -- A house-to-house check-up of the Malayan Federal Capital, Kuala Lumpur, was ordered today. It will involve 300,000 men, women and children. Its object is to prevent Red terrorists sneaking into town to collect money, food and medical treatment when wounded in battle and then returning to the jungle war.

World Series Starts Today! That was the startling information, printed on 10-by-12 score sheets, that greeted many of the record crowd of 35,270 as they wended their way through the peanut and popcorn wagons and the souvenir venders into Ebbets Field yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill announced today that Anthony Eden would resume his duties as Foreign Secretary next Monday.
The current studies of traffic and parking problems and solutions pay all too little attention to the great mass of car owners who are in the lower money brackets.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 2 -- Mrs. Jerome Kandell of Elmwood Country Club, White Plains, N. Y., won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Windle Trophy match play-against-par tournament at the Fresh Meadow Country Club today with a score of 2 up.
A spokesman for the New York City Anti-Crime Committee charged yesterday that "business men and politicians contact Fay to get their labor problems straightened out."

Increased construction and labor costs were cited as factors justifying the increased consumers' rate sought by the Long Island Water Corporation at a hearing yesterday before the Public Service Commission at 233 Broadway.

UNITED NATION, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Henry Ford 2d, a member of the United States delegation here, pledged today his country's continued financial and moral support of the United Nations technical assistance program. He hailed the program as "one of the most effective means of helping peoples overcome conditions which breed unrest, tyranny and war."

MONTREAL, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Ed Roebuck pitched a seven-hit shutout tonight as the Montreal Royals of the International League defeated the Kansas City Blues of the American Association, 10 -- 0, in the first game of the little world series.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Oct. 2 -- A group of business executives from all sections of North Carolina and neighboring states enrolled at the University of North Carolina this week-end for the start of a six-month executive development program planned for persons already carrying major executive responsibilities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Labor management and the Federal Government have laid the groundwork for an agreement on mine safety problems in the soft coal industry, including the retention of John J. Forbes as director of the United States Bureau of Mines.

Activity on the New York commodity exchanges continued dull yesterday despite the fact that the docks are expected to be in normal operation by the end of next week. Interest in baseball continued to compete with trading on the exchanges. Volume on hides and zinc improved slightly and soybean oil had the most active day since May 7.

The First National Bank of the City of New York reported as of Sept. 30, 1953, total deposits of $565,860,410 and total assets of $715,693,032, compared, respectively, with $543,311,200 and $692,366,359 on June 30. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $139,072,930 against $150,005,203; holdings of United States Government securities to $191,916,307 against $154,647,107; and loans and discounts to $253,556,900 against $255,346,384.

While covering the recent German elections I never heard the Social Democratic party referred to as "Pink Communists," nor has anyone in Germany ever charged, as does Hans Thenen in his letter printed on Sept. 23, that Social Democrats "have a slight trend toward totalitarianism."
SEOUL, Korea, Oct 2 -- A new effort to achieve understanding and cooperation between South Korea and Japan will be made early next week when representatives of the two countries meet in Tokyo.

MIAMI Oct. 2 (AP)--Baylor, the country's tenth ranking football team, ran into surprisingly stern opposition tonight before defeating the Miami Hurricanes, 21--13, before a rain-drenched crowd of 28,042 in the Orange Bowl.
Hen tracks appeared yesterday on a blackboard at Columbia University like those of fourteen years ago that presaged the making of the first atomic bomb. This time they concerned cancer.

With 11,000,000 married women working outside the home, homemaking should be thought of as a "husband-wife" role, not as a "wife-only" role, Dr. Clark E. Vincent suggests in the October issue of The Journal of Home Economics. Dr. Vincent, whose article is entitled "Role Clarification for the Contemporary College - Educated Woman," is instructor in family sociology at the University of California, Berkeley.

TRENTON, Oct. 2 -- The longstanding monopoly of the General Electric Company in the incandescent lamp field was broken here today in a drastic and unexpected decision handed down by Judge Phillip Forman in United States District Court.

Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., obtained an order in Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday directing the New York City Transit Authority to show cause Monday why it should not be restrained from going ahead with new transit operating schedules to which the union objects.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- John Foster Dulees, Secretary of State, told William N. Oatis, Associated Press correspondent, that his release from a Czechoslovak Communist prison was a source of deep personal satisfaction to President Eisenhower.
BUFFALO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A Harvard economist called on business and Government today to "act at once" to prevent a business recession.
FRUNZE, U.S.S.R., Sept. 22 -- It is not quite 750 years since the events that are still known in central Asia as the catastrophe at Otrar took place with historic consequences whose end is not yet.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein moved yesterday to strike Mr. and Mrs. Charles Spinelli from the voting rolls, charging that they did not live in an apartment at 1526 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, in May when they gave that address in registering for the Mayoralty election.

The slow and tortuous progress toward a solution of the Suez Canal dispute between Egypt and Britain would be a worrisome affair to watch except for the fact that one can at last see a happy ending shaping up. It is probably still some distance off, but when one considers the importance of the issue and the strength of feelings on both sides there is nothing unnatural about the delay.
MOSCOW, Oct. 2 -- Three college editors from the United States prepared today to leave the Soviet Union, convinced that "we have made some impression on the people'' in a ten-day stay.

A proposed Japanese Government news agency would not infringe on press freedom, Hitoshi Ashida, former Premier of Japan, said yesterday when he arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, on a British Overseas Airways plane from London for a month's visit to this country.

Rudolph Halley, President of the City Council and Liberal candidate for Mayor, charged last night that Tammany Hall and the Republican party had conspired to defeat good government since 1945, when a grand jury investigation of former Mayor William O'Dwyer's Administration as District Attorney of Kings County was "allowed to die."
Intersectional games in all sections of the country are prominent on today's intercollegiate football program, which finds Harvard and Rutgers among the late starters opening their season.

Among the memoranda filed with the Randall Committee on Foreign Economic Policy, according to Washington news dispatches, is a special study prepared by the American Tariff League. The substance of this study, it is reported, is that the United States has reduced its tariffs to a lower average level than that prevailing in most of the principal trading countries of the world.

DUBLIN, Oct. 2 -- The nationalistic Gaelic Athletic Association explained today that its ban on "foreign games" did not apply to American football. By that ruling it had consented to the playing of a football game between two United States Army Air Force teams in its arena in Croke Park here.
A recording machine that was allegedly stolen last month identified its owner in Bronx Magistrates Court yesterday.

Howard Solomon's criticism of Nehru reflects America's persistence in believing that every nation in the world must choose sides in our battle against communism. ATHENS, Oct. 2--Earl Mountbatten, commander of Allied forces in the Mediterranean under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said today that the relationship between his and the command of Admiral William M. Fechteler, commander in chief of Allied forces in southern Europe, was "extremely happy."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, a member of President Eisenhower's Commission on Federal-State Relations, said today that there was a strong possibility it could not agree unanimously on its recommendations.
Tugboat crewmen supported the longshoremen's strike yesterday by refusing to dock and undock passenger and dry cargo ships, but their action had little effect on arrivals and departures.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 2 -- India launched a national farm extension project today that is expected to be a potent force in raising the living standards of one-fourth of the country's rural inhabitants, or about 75,000,000 persons, in the next three years.
EL PASO, Oct. 2 -- Six Army buses from near-by Fort Bliss were pressed into service today to carry illegally entered Mexican farm workers 300 miles down the Rio Grande for deportation.

Prominent women headed by Mrs. Edward F. Hutton and including Mrs. Leopold Stokowski will act as manikins in the fashion revue to be presented at the eightieth anniversary celebration dinner dance and fashion show under the auspices of the National Federation of Textiles on Tuesday night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Residential sales in Scarsdale N. Y., were reported by the Robert E. Farley Organization, brokers. A fourteen-room house at 12 Cooper Road was sold by Dr. F. A. Lowenstein to Robert Krasner; Alexander A. Landesco Jr. bought a ten-room house at 17 Cotswold Way from Laura A. Kelly, and Christine Smith sold her home at 167 Lyons Road to Ralph Imperato.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 2 -- Columbia and Princeton, each of whom won close games from "Middle Three opponents last Saturday, clash here tomorrow at 2 P. M. in the first of their 1953 Ivy League games.

For the second time in as many weeks, "Porgy and Bess" has been granted a reprieve. Encouraged by a healthy spurt in business at the Ziegfeld Theatre, Blevins Davis and Robert Breen, producers of the musical, reported yesterday that its run had been extended through Saturday evening, Nov. 28.

Lasting success in the mail-order business will come only to those who use honest words, who deliver what they promise and who really want to satisfy their customers, it was emphasized yesterday by Fred R. Michaels, mail-order merchandise manager of Sear, Roebuck Co. He spoke at the thirty-sixth annual convention of the Direct Mail Advertising Association at the Statler Hotel, Detroit.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 2 -- France and Turkey were understood tonight to be considering making a new commercial accord providing for enlarged trade, the sending of French technicians to Turkey and a settlement of Turkey's long-standing debt to France.

Quick - frozen precooked fish sticks, introduced yesterday by the Birds Eye division of the General Foods Corporation, may give a much-needed lift to the fishing industry by raising the consumption of fish in this country, according to Herbert N. Stevens, Birds Eye product manager of seafoods.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange drifted into new low ground for the season yesterday, and closed barely steady, 6 to 15 points lower than on Thursday.

DETROIT, Oct. 2 -- A board of three Air Force colonels at Self-ridge Air Force base held under advisement today the case of Lieut. Milo J. Radulovich, 28-year-old Reserve officer accused of being a "poor security risk" because of suspected associations by his father and sister with Communists.

Michaels, mail-order merchandise manager of Sear, Roebuck Co. He spoke at the thirty-sixth annual convention of the Direct Mail Advertising Association at the Statler Hotel, Detroit.

WITH a somewhat "hedging" assurance of balmy Indian Summer weather, the week-end anglers should enjoy fairly good sport if they are willing to fish the surf or troll for striped bass, and the bottom boats can provide plenty of cod and a scattering of pollock.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 3 (UP) -- Scatback Leroy Bolden scampered for three touchdowns for Michigan State today to rout Minnesota, 21 -- 0, and push the Spartans into first place in the Big Ten title race.

In contrast to the reports of new discoveries that usually emanate from scientific meetings, the biggest news at the ninety-fourth annual meeting of the American Dental Association held here last week was the charge that manufacturers of dentifrices were undermining the nation's dental health by misleading advertising.

CAPTAIN VIDEO and other space rangers notwithstanding, the old-fashioned cowboy still has a loyal following, especially among the very young. For this group there is a new cowboy-and-bandits picture book, traditional in plot but very modern in appearance.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 -- Gov. Earl Warren's appointment to be the Chief Justice of the United States this week set in motion a train of political events extending in prospect as far as 1958 and holding the potentiality of significantly affecting the national political picture.

Two shipowner groups warned last week that their members might remove all radiotelephones from their vessels unless they were exempted from a rule that required them to maintain a watch with this auxiliary equipment.

THE presence of the 28-year-old British play-opera-screen-television director virtuoso, Peter Brook, in a Washington hotel rather than in New York or Boston, where his main activities of the moment were centered, suggested that he had some theatrical plot on the capital.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- The logic of weights and measures in the English-speaking world was established more than 800 years ago when King Henry the First decided that a yard was the distance from the tip of his nose to the tip of his thumb with his arm outstretched -- presumably at room temperature and above sea level.

About thirty-five years ago a young man named Joseph Fay from Troy, N. Y., arrived in Newark, N. J., and joined Local 825 of the A. F. L. Hoisting Engineers. BOULDER, Colo., Oct. 3 (UP) -- Missouri's split-T offense and sharp secondary completed and intercepted enough passes today to defeat Colorado, 27 -- 16, and end a twelve-game home winning streak for the Big Seven's youngest member before 24,000.

Despite the general emphasis on the need for volume distribution, some products are still sold on an allocation basis, as so many were during World War II. One such rationed line is the original Hummel dolls, bisque figurines of children, produced by a company known as W. Goebel in a factory near Coburg in West Germany.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- A mother and four of her children died of suffocation here this evening when they were trapped on the second floor of their burning home. The dead were: Mrs. Elizabeth Brown, 40 years old; two daughters, Patricia 6, and Deborah, 1; and two sons, Edward, 7, and Charles, 3.

Along the Atlantic coast all summer long a tense struggle combining murky underworld politics and bitter inter-union strife has been shaping up. Last week the struggle was brought out into the open by a union-management dispute that figured only incidentally in the general waterfront picture.

New York continues to be a New Deal-Fair Deal city, with a majority its voters supporting the policies of Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman. Even in the 1952 sweep for President Eisenhower, Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic candidate for President, carried the city by a plurality of 359,439, with the Liberal party contributing 336,948 votes to his total.

IT used to be said that American history was all cluttered up with Adamses, and now Irving Brant has discovered that the history of the United States during the Administration of Thomas Jefferson has been cluttered up by an Adams when the family was out of office.

ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 3 (AP) -- A proposal to merge with the Air Force Association was placed before the Air Reserve Association today. The Reservists scheduled a vote on the issue for the final session of their annual convention here.

CANADIAN television is now a year old, having started at Montreal and Toronto early in September of last year. Many lessons have been learned in the year. both production-wise and in programming. Production is smoother now, and there is an increase in the number of live studio and sport shows.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 3 -- The recovery of mental patients depends to a significant extent on the social organization of their hospital regardless of how expert the individual psychiatric treatment may be, a study conducted here at one of the country's leading institutions for research into psychoneuroses has shown.

The retirement of G. Darlington Richards as organist and choirmaster at St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, will take place today. He will end forty years of service in the parish and fifty-four as an organist.

Did Casey Stengel order Vic Raschi to "stick it in his ear" when Roy Campanella came to bat in the eighth inning of Friday's game? And if Casey said it, who heard him say it? These were the questions that made the rounds before yesterday's game at Ebbets Field.

Newspaper advertisements for cooperative apartments offering estimated tax savings of $7 to $18 a month are "inaccurate and misleading," according to State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein. If such deceptions continue, he warned, he will take legal action to eliminate them.

The New York Shipping Association told a Presidential board of inquiry yesterday that until a clear-cut decision was reached on who represented striking Atlantic Coast dock workers, employers might be reluctant to sign a new agreement with the International Longshoremen's Association.

Along with the millions of children and teenagers who have started to school during the past month are many mature men and women who are returning to colleges and universities for their "second chance" at the higher education that they had missed in their youth.

SEPTEMBER and October are busy months for gardeners who take pride in a lawn. This is an ideal time for making a new one or repairing an old one. But the lawn seed mixture sown by the gardener is a carefully balanced blend of several grasses, each one as true to type and free of impurities as it is possible for the seedsmen to make it.

There was some cash-collecting at the rate of more than $1,200 a second in Belmont Park's Widener Chute yesterday. Llangollen Farm's Porterhouse, a son of the Argentine-bred stal lion, Endeavour II, raced six and a half furlongs in 1 minute 16 seconds, won the sixty-fourth Futurity by three and a quarter lengths and added $92,875 to his earnings.

Resuming play after two days of rest in the world chess championship challengers tournament in Zurich last night, fourteen of the competitors, paired for seven games of the eighteenth round, reached only two-definite decisions.

CANADENSIS, Pa. -- The Poconos will flame with their brightest colors between Oct. 11 and 14, according to the regional goosebone prophets and weather seers whose predictions hereabouts have stood up pretty well down the years.

TRENTON, Oct. 3 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court will hear arguments on Monday in a test case challenging the constitutionality of the distribution of the King James version of the New Testament in the public schools by the Gideon Society.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The General Accounting Office has reported to Congress that "disregard for the financial interests of the United States" has resulted in the unnecessary and costly duplication of various Government facilities in the Panama Canal Zone.

What is more, these amateurs are responsible for originating many new varieties.
