Earl Sande, who once was America's greatest jockey, but who hasn't worn silks since 1932, has agreed to ride the 3-year-old gelding Honest Bread in tomorrow's third race at Belmont Park and thus begin, at the age of 54, what he hopes will be a comeback campaign as a rider.

THE emergence of China as a Communist power and a Soviet ally has been -- as is no longer news -- a diplomatic disaster of cardinal proportion to the United States. Because of the resulting political storm, a calm and careful history of the American effort and policy in China has been greatly needed.

BAGOTVILLE, Que., Oct. 3 (UP) -- Seven half-starved men who survived six weeks in the wilderness after their plane made a forced landing were flown to safety here today only a few hours after they had been sighted from the air.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 3 -- Town elections will be held in thirteen communities of Fairfield County Monday, with local issues predominating in all contests. It is generally assured that the Republican incumbents in every town save one will be re-elected for two-year terms.

NEWPORT, R. I. -- Analysis of Government policies that both hinder and help preservation work was the principal theme running through the annual forum of the National Trust for Historic Preservation here today.
Scholarships totaling $19,000 have been awarded to fifteen young American artists in the Louis Comfort Tiffany Foundation's 1953 competition.

MANILA, Oct. 3 -- The polite and diplomatically correct four-day visit to the Philippines of Japanese Foreign Minister Katsuo Okazaki, which ended today, left a heavy residue of disappointment here. Not one solid commitment was forthcoming about reparations payments.
SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Notice of a strike vote Monday by 250 bus drivers of Rockland Coaches, Inc., and its four affiliated lines was posted here today at the company terminal.

The College English Association, with 150 academic and business leaders in attendance, will hold its fourth Institute at the Corning Glass Center, Corning, N. Y., on Oct. 15-17. The theme of the institute will be "Business and the Liberal Arts: An Exchange."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct 3 -- Capitalizing on a fourth-quarter break to notch its-second touchdown and then fighting off a desperate bid by their arch rivals in the waning minutes of the game, Pennsylvania's football team racked up its second triumph today by halting Penn State, 13 to 7, in the forty-second clash between the schools at Franklin Field.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 3 -- In the western sections of the Missouri River basin, where the farmer, rancher and miner once threatened to push the herds of big game into extinction, the number of deer, elk and antelope has reached a record high this year. In some regions these animals appeared to be eating themselves and the white man out of a home.

Marine traffic management in the Port of New York no longer is strictly a man's job. Since the end of World War II a number of women have guided successfully many phases of the city's vast overseas commerce.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Medical experts on the application of atomic energy in cancer research and treatment voiced doubt today that a single cure for cancer would ever be discovered.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 3 -- Japanese Foreign Minister Katsuo Okazaki arrived here today for top-level reparations talks with Indonesian leaders in an effort to pave the way to formalization of peace between the two countries and restoration of formal diplomatic relations.

WHEN the French diplomat at the house party said, "Here in England a financial scandal in public matters means political death," Michael Erskine retorted, "And quite right, too." The most brilliant Minister in Britain's Tory Government and slated to be the next Chancellor of the Exchequer, he could hardly have said otherwise.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UP) -- A privately financed scientific study of the political "pressures" and procedures of nominating candidates for President was started today by the Brookings Institution. It is being directed by Paul T. David, the institution's senior staff member, who has labeled present methods of selecting delegates to nominating conventions "intolerably confused."

THE qualities that seem to characterize top-notch inventors are faith in the idea, the ability to coordinate into a single unit many techniques and principles and, above all, a disinclination to be bound by orthodox restrictions or boundaries.

Prof. Auguste Piccard has long been known to newspaper readers as the man who went up into the stratosphere to a height of 53,000 feet, which was a record twenty years ago. Last week he made the front page of every newspaper by going down 10,330 feet, almost two miles, into the Tyrrhenian Trench, which is in the Mediterranean Sea a little southwest of Naples and a little northwest of Sicily.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 3 -- An American identified by the United States Embassy here as Dr. Ralph B. Swain, a member of the Point Four program staff in Nicaragua, was shot and killed today by bandits on the Puebla-Oaxaca Highway, one of Mexico's major and best traveled roads.

FERGANA, U. S. S. R., Sept. 29 -- Wherever you travel in Central Asia, whether it be to modern Alma Ata with its atmosphere somewhat reminiscent of the Western United States or to ancient Bukhara redolent of the age of Scheherazade, you hear of the Fergana Valley.

A new application of the principle called by the ugly word "automation" was presented before the National Electronics Conference at Chicago by H. Ziebolz and H. M. Paynter of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. They use electronic computers to simulate the operation of a manufacturing plant or to control actual manufacturing processes within a plant.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- The United States had enjoyed independence from Britain for more than a century before the victory over Spain in 1898 established us as a great military power. India, barely six years after attaining independence from Britain, has now come to the fore with equal suddenness, not as a military power, but as the spokesman here of the hundreds of millions of Asian peoples -- half the world's population.
Rear Admiral Daniel V. Gallery, Chief of Naval Air Reserve Training, declared here yesterday that a surprisingly high percentage of veterans from Korea had returned to the Reserves.
The Dodgers evened the world series at two games apiece yesterday by defeating the Yankees, 7 -- 3, before a new record Ebbets Field crowd of 36,775.

FROM now until heavy freezing weather, the gardener may safely dig, divide and replant his peonies. However, if the plants are growing nicely and are in a satisfactory location, they are best left undisturbed.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Atlanta Crackers, in the Class AA Southern Assciation where no Negro has ever played, have two Negro players on their roster.

In a determined effort to rid the city school system of "cultural inbreeding" brought about by New Yorkers who apparently have the inside track on appointments, the Municipal Civil Service Commission has made a bid for talented "outsiders" to infiltrate the ranks and bring with them new ideas and perspectives.
Six recent college graduates have been appointed teaching internes at Columbia College for the 1953-54 academic year. The college is the university's liberal arts school for men.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3 -- Public and voluntary welfare and health services are expensive and social agencies too often do not get their money's worth because of lack of coordination, Ralph W. Whelan, executive director of the New York City Youth Board, said here today.

EVEN in the black nineteenth century, no Vermonter was forced to undergo the spirit-crushing anxiety of a coal-miner or steel-worker. with a wife and children in danger of being evicted from a company-owned tenement.

It was the firm conviction of Henry Ford that he could play every position on the team. But his grandson, Henry Ford 2d, never has made any similar claim for himself. He was only too happy after the war, when his company was losing money at an estimated rate of $68,000,000 a year, to snatch an "idea" pitcher from one of the farm clubs of his chief rival in the automobile league.

GENTLENESS is not considered a characteristic of the pioneer, but the phrase "gentle pioneers," occurring in the first sentence of "Memories of Myrtle Bank," is the aptest description of the two brothers who are the heroes of this study of three decades of family life in North-East Tasmania.

FOREIGN diplomats characteristically began by underrating him, owing to his small person and quiet manner -- and progressed to the discovery that he was not only outthinking them but was too tough as well as too agile to handle.

ROANOKE, Va. -- For motorists accustomed to the easy grades and straightaways of turnpikes and super-roads, the Federal highways which traverse the highland country of southwestern Virginia and adjacent West Virginia, Kentucky and Tennessee offer some of the most challenging and exciting driving in the East.

THE debate over American policy toward the Soviet Union and whether it should limit itself to containing Moscow's dynamic imperialist tendencies or whether it should seek to roll back the Communist empire from Eastern Europe by a process of liberation has been argued vigorously and often in the United States and abroad.

MILAN, Italy, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Aldo Icardi's defense attorney said today that he would contend that Italy had no right to try the former United States Army lieutenant -- even in absentia -- for the wartime death of Maj. William Holohan.

DIFFERENCES of opinion between leading singers and opera managers? They have been popping up as long as there have been leading singers and opera managers, and you may be sure that they will continue to erupt just as hurricanes do at this time of the year.

PRUDENCIO DE PEREDA is an Hispano-American writing in English -- and one associates his name with a slick fiction because of an earlier success, "All the Girls We Loved." This new novel, however, is authentic Spain.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Ohio State's Buckeyes scored four touchdowns with a display of power in the second half to rout the California Bears, 33 -- 19, today in their nationally televised intersectional football clash.

BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Tommy Davis, Louisiana State University's fleet second-string fullback, scored two touchdowns and kicked three extra points to lead his mates to a 42-6 victory over outweighed and outclassed Boston College tonight.

HAMILTON, N. Y., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Holy Cross rolled to a 19-6 victory over Colgate before 6,000 fans this afternoon. The big Crusader eleven played through a scoreless first half before pounding its way through an obviously tired Colgate line.
Mr. Feder has designed the lighting for many Broadway productions and was lighting consultant to the United Nations.

SEASIDE PARK, N. J., Oct. 3 (AP) -- New Jersey shore municipalities estimate it will cost $2,421,000 to combat beach erosion during the current fiscal year and have asked the state to pay half of the bill.

LIMA, Peru, Oct. 3 -- Two well-known Peruvian surgeons have performed a successful and virtually bloodless brain operation using only instruments of the Inca period, 2,000 years ago, according to report published here.

The interesting picture story, "The Rise and Rise of the Skyscraper" ( Sept. 20) by Winston Weisman, omits a forerunner of the skyscraper that antedated by fifteen years the Equitable Life Assurance Society building. Three days before your article appeared, the American Institute of Steel Construction honored the Cooper Union building here with a memorial plaque on the centennial of Peter Cooper's pioneering efforts in introducing roiled structural beams.
ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- A set of the four Shakespeare folios -- that is, a copy of each of the first four editions of William Shakespeare's plays, has been presented to Cornell University.

OMAHA, Oct. 3 (AP) -- "D Day of World War III" is past and the United States is losing the war at a "fantastic rate," Dr. A. T. Bouscaren, an associate professor at the University of San Francisco, said here today.

IN this new pavilion especially designed by Frank Lloyd Wright on the parking lot adjacent to the present Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum at Eighty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue, a large retrospective exhibition -- "Sixty Years of Living Architecture" -- will shortly open.

THE columnist Bob Ruark, who has described himself as being "cute, angry, loud, puckish or perverse every day in print," spent six weeks of 1952 on an East African safari. His purpose was to heed the horn of the hunter he had listened to since childhood, and to collect hides and heads of animals for his trophy room.
BERLIN, Oct. 3 -- One in three West Berliners turned out today to pay their final respects to Mayor Ernst Reuter, the man they credit with having saved them from communism.

GLENN MILLER appears well on his way to becoming the first leader of a popular dance band to achieve the status of a legend. It is almost nine years since he disappeared and was presumed killed on a flight from London to Paris.

MOST people do not form personal attitudes about drinking: they absorb the accepted attitudes of their class and circle. In this respect, drinking is not different from other topics of opinion and patterns of conduct, but it is well to be reminded of the fact because most talk -- Wet and Dry -- about drinking is in terms of biology, immorality and rational individual choice.

Re Prof. J. K. Galbraith's "Abandoned Farms, Unabandoned Hopes" (Sept. 13), only the civility of urban life restrains the city man from assault and battery on luncheon companions who prate endlessly on rural joys.
The Citizens Union called yesterday for "some drastic revision of the Election Law," which it termed a quagmire of traps and technicalities."

WHITING, Ind., Oct. 3 (AP) -- A truck driver, delayed at a dock, was credited with saving fourteen persons from a fire early today, including the family of Steve Kraly, rookie pitcher for the New York Yankees.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- "National Employ the Physically Handicapped Week" opens tomorrow under a proclamation issued by President Eisenhower Aug. 12, but it received preliminary impetus today with an array of official statements and a "kick-off" dinner.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Some of the offenses attacked by Pope Pius today already have been listed as crimes against the world community, but experts here said that while there was "plenty of law," there was no international machinery for punishment.
Referring to Winston Weisman's article which has been widely esteemed by architects, "The Rise and Rise of the Skyscraper" (Sept. 20), may I question its accuracy on one detail?
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 -- Pittsburgh and Oklahoma fought to a 7-7 tie today in a bruising defensive contest watched by 33,928 spectators at Pitt Stadium.

BROCKTON, Mass., Oct. 3 -- The new $18,000,000 Veterans Administration Hospital here, which is near completion, will accept its first seventy-five patients on Tuesday, it was announced today by Dr. Peter A. Peffer, manager of the hospital.

ATHENS, Oct. 3 -- The United States Sixth Fleet, including the aircraft carriers Franklin D. Roosevelt and Coral Sea, was reported today to have passed the Strait of Messina on its way to the "relief" of Greece in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization maneuver called Exercise Weldfast.

MARGATE, England, Oct. 3 -- The British, who invented party politics, are entering a period of intensified activity by two great parties, Conservative and Labor, which today dominate political life in a stronger, more confident Britain.

STUART HUGHES, associate professor of history at Stanford University, starts from a sound basis: "The American tends to take Italy for granted and to assume that he knows more about it than he actually does." He will know a great deal about Italy if he will take the trouble to read this excellent study which will now assume an honored place in the series of The American Foreign Policy Library which Sumner Welles edits.

Fire losses in the United States are at a record dollar level for the third consecutive year and for the first time in history are expected to approach -- and possibly exceed -- the billion dollar mark by the end of the calendar year.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 3 -- Twenty-three seconds stood between Columbia and one of its typical stunning football triumphs today when a fourth-down desperation pass enabled Princeton to snatch the victory by 20 -- 19, as it did in the last three minutes against Lafayette a week ago.

Plans are under way for the annual luncheon of the Friends of the Philharmonic, to be held Nov. 5 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Philip L. B. Iglehart, a member of the auxiliary board, is chairman of the luncheon committee, and Mrs. James J. Lee is vice chairman.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 3 -- Pass interceptions by Muhlenberg in the final period staved off two Bucknell touchdown drives, the visitors gaining an 18-to-13 victory in an upset at Bucknell Memorial Stadium.
NEWARK, Del., Oct. 3 -- Delaware's Blue Hens stopped Lehigh's passing attack today and displayed one of their own to topple the Engineers, 26 -- 13.

ATHENS, Oct. 3 -- Foreign Minister Stephan Stephanopoulos said on his return to Athens today from ten-day visit to Italy with Premier Marshal Alexander Papagos, that he was "very satisfied" with their talks with Italian Government officials.

Descriptions of Spain usually begin with a reference to the fact that it is isolated from the rest of Europe by the high wall of the Pyrenees. This fact must have been a prime consideration for the American negotiators in the recently announced arrangement for American air bases in Spain.

DALLAS, Oct. 3 -- Record and near-record employment levels and high personal incomes should continue to hold department store sales to a high level this fall, the Eleventh District Federal Reserve Bank reported this week in its monthly business review.
State governments are borrowing money at a record pace and the rising cost of their bond issues is getting to be something for planners of big capital outlay to reckon with.

IT has long been the theory of Washington correspondents that no man with all his buttons would want to be press secretary to the President of the United States, regardless of the $18,000 salary, a Government-chauffeured limousine or all the other honors and perquisites that go with the job.
Disturbed by the apparent lack of public interest in the New York City election, candidates and leaders of all political parties joined yesterday in appeals to potential voters to register ...
Rudolph Halley, Liberal party candidate for Mayor, made a three-hour tour of the Bronx yesterday in an open car and greeted thousands of persons attracted by announcements from a sound truck.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, must be credited with giving two useful assists this week to his chief, Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense. Mr. Talbott announced the start of quantity production of the Boeing B-52 jet bomber and the North American F-100 supersonic jet day fighter.
At his news conference last Wednesday President Eisenhower said with great earnestness:

FREDERIC WAKEMAN, who helped dismember the advertising business in "The Hucksters," is still hell-bent on taking things apart, although it isn't altogether clear this time just what he is taking apart.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Finland has approached the British Government with a suggestion for a triangular trade agreement between Britain, Finland and the Soviet Union, a spokesman for the Board of Trade said today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 3 -- Col. Simbolon, commander of the First North Sumatran Division, who arrived here Friday to report to the Cabinet on the revolt of Islamic leaders in that part of the country, declared tonight that the situation in northern Sumatra was "very serious" and contended that "it is impossible to resolve it solely by force of arms."

The Union Settlement will be the beneficiary of a performance of "Sherlock Holmes," with Basil Rathbone in the leading role, on the night of Nov. 4 at the Century Theatre. Mrs. Samuel Stelle Smith is chairman of the settlement's women's auxiliary, under whose auspices the benefit has been arranged. Her aides include Mrs. Alfred F. Loomis, Mrs. William H. Savage and Mrs. Herbert Lloyd.

The tragedy of fanatic, regimented and desperate men who have become the pawns of great power politics was written again in blood last week as Chinese and North Korean prisoners of war rioted against their Indian guards.

MEXICO CITY -- Plans have recently been completed for the creation of a new tour route around the Gulf of Mexico a combination of sea and land connections, which will open up new tropical backgrounds to motor tourists and provide, for the first time a circular itinerary that will involve no backtracking.

ONLY Dior may think the raised hemline is the new fashion: television knows better. This season the new rage obviously is to be fatherhood. With Peggy Wood and Lucille Ball staking out early claims to motherhood as a TV way of life, the brain trusters of video decided to capitalize on what was left.

Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College, announced last week that sixteen new members had been appointed to the faculty and teaching staff. Included in the new appointments are two visiting professors.

RICHMOND, Oct. 3 -- Sales in the Fifth District department stores for the first three quarters are about 1 per cent behind the same period last year. September volume, however, was off an estimated 3 per cent. With the exception of real estate loans, all other loan categories in the district last week declined, but the total for the year is still 6 per cent above that of a year ago.

AT the recent Town and County Flower Show in White Plains, N. Y., house plants lined up on several tables vied for attention with terrace gardens and flower arrangements. A steady flow of visitors flocked around the house plant section, perhaps because of the variety of plants.

SUMMER is the time to enjoy a pool, autumn with its balmy yet energetic days the time to construct one. And garden pools are fun to make. If the backyard engineer starts now, there is sufficient time to complete the job before it is too cold to work outdoors or before the ground freezes.

" SHE was learning to love moments. To love moments for themselves." And this tale of Maud Martha Brown's youth, marriage and motherhood is made up of the moments she loved. With a few exceptions when straightforward narrative takes over, it is presented in flashes, almost gasps, of sensitive lightness -- distillations of the significance of each incident -- and reminds of Imagist poems or clusters of ideograms from which one recreates connected experience.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Trailblazing methods in adult education to speed the "melting-pot" process in Israel are being shared with teachers of this country by Miss Shulamith Katznelson, here on an exchange fellowship.

Last week the towboat Eugene Moran, with invited observers on board, went to Buttermilk Channel, New York harbor, to demonstrate an echo-sounder which promises to make commercial fishing much easier than it ever was. In the bottom of the towboat was mounted a "transducer," which swept back and forth like a searchlight, except that the sweeping was automatic.

Historically it is an established fact that if the capital gains tax were to be imposed upon an equitable basis, permitting capital losses as a deduction from ordinary income, the revenues would fare badly. This result was actually experienced in the early Nineteen Thirties.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Complete tickets for town offices were filed with the Election Commissioners in the Rockland County Court House this week by both Republican and Democratic township committees, and an all-out partisan fight is indicated for control of the county government at the general election on Nov. 3.

Borough President John Cashmore announced yesterday that he would seek to save from demolition the historic Wyckoff House at Ditmas Avenue and East Fifty-ninth Street in the Flatlands district of Brooklyn. The one-and-one-half- story frame structure is reported to be the oldest dwelling in the United States.

LOVER Carmichael had too many deadlines to meet. Besides inheriting Northfield's weekly newspaper he was also the driving force behind a campaign for a workshop for the handicapped and captain of the junior high's football team.

TOKYO, Sunday, Oct. 4 -- The Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission adopted yesterday disciplinary rules that would permit the Indian Custodial Force to court-martial and punish prisoners of the Korean war in the custody of the commission.

JOHANNESBURG. South Africa, Oct. 3 -- Southern Rhodesia, the dominant partner in the new British Central African Federation, is falling into line with Kenya, the Union of South Africa and Nyasaland in enacting stringent laws to curb native African unrest.

IN the midst of the most hectic period of excitement and technological turmoil that motion pictures have seen in a generation, a group of unexcited people will be looking for more revolutions and taking the whole thing in stride.

The dilemma facing the producers of "The Joe Louis Story" -- where to find a man who could look like Joe, slug like Joe, and act like Joe -- was solved happily with the discovery of 24-year-old Coley Wallace. Wallace, himself a ranking fighter, turned actor to portray the Brown Bomber from his teen-age days in Detroit, through his triumphs and his defeat in 1951 by Rocky Marciano.

As the aviation industry approaches the fiftieth anniversary of the Wrights' flight at Kitty-hawk, N.C., on Dec. 17, its airline sector, both domestic and international, is entering a critical stage of its vast development.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Senator William F. Knowland, the Senate Republican leader, returned to Washington today from a five-week tour of eleven countries and warned the free world "to stand firm."

A troubled world may be sorely beset by vexing problems but Ebbets Field became an Elysian field of joy unrestrained yesterday as Chuck Dressen's magnificent Dodgers toppled the seemingly invincible Yankees for the second successive afternoon to square the 1953 world series at two games apiece.

Greater flexibility in pension plans is being discussed as a means toward more practical administration of benefits under such plans. The discussion centers especially on the question of the retirement age for employes.
EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 3 -- Dick Thomas and his high school teammate, Joe Collier, were the stars today in a powerful Northwestern attack that defeated a weak Army team, 33 to 20.

IN ten short stories of mice, rabbits, sylphs, elves and humans Rosalie Fry borrows and embroiders motifs from classic tales. A mouse listens to a godmother reading Cinderella's adventures; a pauper shepherdess and a princess exchange places briefly; a lonesome stork plays guardian to a baby who grows up into a facsimile of Hans Christian Andersen.
Recently the idea of "neutralizing" Korea in a pattern similar to Belgium and Switzerland has been advanced by certain diplomats and officials.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, Oct. 3 -- Antioch College will celebrate its 100th birthday tomorrow on the campus where 3,000 guests gathered a century ago to see Horace Mann inaugurated as its first president.

THE last full week of September obviously was set up primarily to provide the one-two punch on behalf of Vern Sneider. On Wednesday of that week the John Patrick adaptation of the first Sneider novel -- "The Teahouse of the August Moon" -- opened in New Haven on its way to Broadway.

HAVANA, Oct. 3 -- Dr. Armando Hernandez, prominent adherent of former President Carlos Prio Socarras, who disappeared mysteriously three weeks ago, was found by the police early this morning lying on Real Street in Marianao bound hand and foot.

THIS fond report by Dorothy Canfield Fisher upon her state and its people, past and present, is close to the final word. "Vermont Tradition" is a summation of all that is best in the tonnage that has been printed concerning the Green Mountain country -- and something more.

THE publication of an explanatory rendering into English of the Koran, the Sacred Book of 350,000,000 Mohammedans, in an edition selling for fifty cents is an event of great religious as well as literary importance.
EXCELLENT, and extremely natural, techniques for fighting off sharks were adopted, according to experts, by two Air Force men recently during twenty-two hours of harrowing submersion in the Atlantic.

BERLIN, Oct. 3 -- For two years Western officials have feared that West Berlin's coalition government would founder on the rocks of political ambition. This week storm signals were hoisted for the city's ship of state when the man who had held the coalition together suddenly died.

MADRID, Oct. 3 -- The negotiation of aid-for-bases agreements between the United States and Spain has in fact established an alliance between the two countries even though diplomatic language makes vague assurances to the contrary. The controlled press of this authoritarian state is realistic enough to refer specifically to the new "alianza."

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 3 -- With the Belgian Chamber of Deputies reconvening next Tuesday after its summer recess, the stage is set for Parliament's debate on the ratification of the projected European Defense Community treaty and its corollary, the surrender of part of Belgium's sovereignty.

ALL over South Africa the ever-patient vultures are hovering every year, every month a little closer to the parched veld, to the people in the cities, to the complacent rich and the petrified poor. There is poverty in every city in the world, and in most of them there is that thing known as charity.

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Rice Institute, considered a power in the Southwest Conference, invaded the Ivy League today as it tangled with Cornell at Schoellkopf Field but for three periods the Big Red refused to be impressed. The Ithacans put up a mighty battle before succumbing, 28 -- 7, as the Texans clinched matters with a last quarter two-touchdown outburst.

DEVON, Pa., Oct. 3 -- A wirehaired foxterrier, imported from and a champion of England, became best today in the 653-dog event of the Devon Dog Show Association. He was the hound-marked 2 1/2-year-old, Ch. Travella Superman of Harham.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 -- The Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters will open its national convention here tomorrow with an address by George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, of which the union is an affiliate.

LOS ANGELES -- Out-of-state sight-seers, who in the past have found themselves caught up in the confusion of Los Angeles downtown traffic while trying to drive across town, can now return to these parts with a somewhat easier mind.
DETROIT, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Competition in the automobile industry will get rougher next year. It will be particularly rough on the so-called "independents."

DURING the first half of this century a few men accurately envisioned the enormous complexity of the nation's conservation problems. Aldo Leopold was one of this group. After his varied and rich experiences in forestry and wildlife management, the University of Wisconsin, in 1933, created a Chair of Game Management for Mr. Leopold -- a position he held until he met his tragic death five years ago while fighting a forest fire.
CLEMSON, S. C., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Three lightning scoring plays gave Maryland a 20-0 victory over Clemson today in the first Atlantic Coast conference football game for each team.

The power of music -- and musicians -- to surmount obstacles was dramatically demonstrated in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., recently, when Harry Trebilcox, young Wilkes-Barre pianist, played a recital for left hand alone.

SAIDU, Pakistan, Sept. 22 -- While the West ponders the threat of technological unemployment, the 500,000 tribesmen in Swat State keep such problems at a minimum by working only three hours a day, from 8 until 11 A. M., and virtually ignoring anything more mechanical than their treasured rifles.

ONCE upon a time the American colonies fought against heavy odds to be independent of Europe. In those days the intervening ocean was wide and isolating. The defiant little states strung along the western shore of the Atlantic were weak and poor compared to the imperial powers of the mother continent.

SINCE it provided an "original evening in the theatre" when it opened here in 1947 and continued to do so for more than 700 performances, the fact that "Finian's Rainbow" is being sought by three groups of movie makers should come under the heading of good news.

After twenty-nine years as a retailer and wholesaler of men's hats, Adam Hat Stores, Inc., has decided to start manufacturing its own line. Formerly the company had its hats produced on a contracting basis, but each contracting factory did almost all its business with Adam.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 3 (AP) -- John Pappas, Boston University football star and student leader, died today of injuries suffered in the Boston-Syracuse game last night. His death was the first fatality of the collegiate gridiron season in a game, although another youth was injured fatally in practice on Sept. 15.

THE current concern about the United States aviation industry, a concern created by the widely publicized cutbacks in orders for military aircraft, is offset by the findings of a survey, published last week, which indicate that as a whole the industry is in top-flight condition.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Harold E. Stassen, Director of the Foreign Operations Administration, appeared today to be facing a Senatorial investigation into the procedures he has followed in carrying out Congressional demands for a sharp reduction in the personnel of his far-flung organization.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 3 (AP) -- "Hams" -- amateur radio enthusiasts -- conducted their annual exercise today to show how it was possible to cope with disaster when normal communications facilities like telephone, telegraph and commercial radio were out of commission.

Joseph S. (Joey) Fay, building trades labor leader and convicted extortioner, was transferred yesterday from Sing Sing to Clinton Prison at Dannemora, known in the underworld as "Siberia." The transfer was ordered by Governor Dewey. He also called for weekly reports on Fay's visitors.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The White House announced today that President and Mrs. Eisenhower would attend the induction Monday of Earl Warren as Chief Justice of the United States.
WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., Oct. 3 (UP) -- Joe White, a second-string quarterback, helped by an interference ruling, led Wake Forest to an 18-to-12 victory over Villanova today before 10,000 fans.

DISAPPOINTED in love, afraid of getting into a rut, Jinny Craig leaves her comfortable Missouri town for a teaching job in a remote corner of New Mexico. Once arrived she unexpectedly acquires a ramshackle adobe house, a forlorn old lady as house-mate and, inexplicably, the hostility of the rancher who had hired her.

WRITING simply of Swedish farmers who came to the United States in the late nineteenth century, Lillian Budd combines in her story the realism, folk quality and mysticism that characterizes Swedish literature at its best.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Most of the customary autumn planting might better be postponed until after a good rain. Dry soil makes transplanting difficult. Water is essential to the success of moving plants. Soil should be moist beforehand and be kept moist until the plant is growing in its new location. Soil around all evergreens should be well soaked once a week.

POOLS are not to be forgotten when it comes to winter protection. And a few safety measures taken before heavy frost arrives will stave off costly repairs next spring. At any rate, care of the pool is even less tedious in winter than summer.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Pa., Oct. 3 -- The link between two heavily traveled traffic arteries, U. S. Route 611 in Pennsylvania and U. S. Route 46 in New Jersey, over the Delaware River here, is nearing completion. The last of the steel girders that will carry the roadway of the new bridge across the Delaware between Delaware Water Gap and the New Jersey side has been put into place.

YONKERS, Oct. 3 -- Rushing between horses in the final sixteenth, Casanova from Lemoore, Calif., with George Phalen in the sulky, scored a length victory in 2:04 2/5 in the $5,000 Irvington pacing feature before 23,278 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

IN an interview printed on this page a fortnight ago, Louis Peterson, author of "Take a Giant Step," recalled some of the pleasure and pain of his boyhood in Hartford. No doubt it would be misleading to regard his play as literal autobiography.

PARIS, Oct. 3 -- Reports from London that Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill soon would again press for a meeting of the heads of the Western Governments with Premier Georgi M. Malenkov of the Soviet Union, received large headlines in the Paris press today and were read with keen interest here. The Prime Minister's proposal, made last May, was strongly supported by public opinion here.

MR. FLOOD began to write "Love Is a Bridge" while he was still an undergraduate at Harvard, and he finished it between a brief enrollment in law school and a brief enrollment in the Army; he is now 23.

In two different spheres, some of the tensions between Japan and her Pacific neighbors appear to be easing. From Manila comes the word that full agreement has been reached on Japanese reparations for the Philippines. From Seoul is the announcement that talks between Korea and Japan will be resumed in Tokyo this week. Dr. Yang, Korea's able Ambassador to the United States, will take an important part in these discussions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Defense Department let it be known today that it was studying the touchy problem of how to reduce the number of armed forces personnel and dependents deployed overseas.

Rabbi Zev Zahavy in a sermon yesterday morning at the synagogue of Congregation Zichron Ephraim, 163 East Sixty-seventh Street, called for counter-moves against hatemongers who, he declared, were busy in many of our large cities.

The appointment of Alexander Purdon, until recently secretary treasurer of the dissolved National Federation of American Shipping, as executive secretary of the Committee of American Shipping Lines Serving Essential Foreign Trade Routes, was announced yesterday by R. S. Hecht, chairman.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 3 -- A leading West German conservative newspaper, the Frankfurter Allgemeine, suggested today that if the four-power negotiations were to be long delayed, the West German and French Governments should jointly talk to the Soviet Union.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- British sources here said that there had been no conversations between Selwyn Lloyd of Britain and Andrei Y. Vishinsky of the Soviet Union and that as far as they knew none was planned.

CAIRO, Oct. 3 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, President and Premier, attended today for the first time a conference of the Egyptian team conducting secret informal negotiations with the British on the future status of the Suez Canal military base. The meeting, which lasted an hour, was held at the Foreign Ministry.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 1 -- The peasants of Yugoslavia have become an important factor in the election campaign that Marshal Tito, the President, started last Sunday.

OF course, I will never forget the sensations when the Winslow House was built in 1893 in Oak Park, Ill., the year I left Adler Sullivan and started my own practice. All Oak Park and River Forest began prowling around the place:

AS this column has observed before, it's largely a matter of chance which British mystery novels are published in America, and vice versa. Each country receives a good deal of the other's shoddiest produce -- and what's perhaps more regrettable, regularly misses some of the best trans-Atlantic items.

Lafayette High, the Public Schools Athletic League champion last year, opened its football season with a 7-6 victory over Brooklyn Tech at Lincoln Field, Brooklyn, yesterday. It was the Frenchies seventeenth straight success in a three-year period.

CANTON, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- St. Lawrence University scored two fourth-period touchdowns to defeat Hofstra of Hempstead, L. I., 18 -- 7, today to highlight Homecoming Day. Bill Rose, 200-pound fullback from Rochester, registered all the Larries' touchdowns for their second victory in two times out.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Two hundred British business leaders gathered in London Thursday and demanded that all United Nations strictures against trade with Communist China be abolished. To State Department officials, as well as to industrialists and foreign traders here the London meeting carried omens of increasingly strident demands for the United States to relax its stand against the trade in strategic materials which China and her ally, the Soviet Union, now are courting.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 3 (UP) -- Halfback Tony Branoff, a sophomore, ripped off two touchdowns and kicked a pair of extra points today to lead Michigan to a 26 to 7 victory over Tulane before a crowd of 52,914.

THE operas of Richard Wagner have been slow in making their way into the repertory of LP recorded music. While seventeen of Verdi's thirty-three operas are available in one or more recordings each, the only Wagnerian operas thus far recorded complete are "The Flying Dutchman," "Lohengrin," "Die Meistersinger," "Parsifal," "Tannhaeuser" and "Tristan und Isolde."

Billy Martin, second baseman for the New York Yankees, turned his hand last week to a field with which he is completely unfamiliar -- therapeutic medicine. And if the happiness on the face of 8-year-old Johnny Durkin is the test, the experiment was a complete success.

' FLORIDA has played a strange part in this war," observes a character in Dr. Slaughter's latest novel. "Her ports were occupied, or blockaded, almost from the beginning. Yet the Confederacy would have perished long ago without her help.
THE arguments over the Anglo-American bidding match, reported in last. Sunday's TIMES, demonstrate anew how hard it is to say what is right and what is wrong in contract bridge.

Hamilton College's football team, scoring with only fifteen seconds remaining in the first half, edged a determined Brooklyn College squad, 7--0, at the losers' field yesterday. The game was Hamilton's opener and the Kingsmen's second straight loss.

FORT DEFIANCE, Ariz., Oct. 3 (UP) -- A team of four men is digging on the Navajo Indian Reservation north of this community with "high hopes" of finding the legendary diamond field that the Spanish explorer, Francisco Coronado, sought almost 400 years ago.

Modern economic troubles have overwhelmed one of the first rail lines to cross the Continental Divide -- the colorful old narrow-gauge division of the Denver and Rio Grande Western that winds through two-mile-high Marshall Pass in the Colorado Rockies.

MORE than one hundred persons turned out for last week's organizational meeting of the new photo group at the Village Art Center, 42-44 West Eleventh Street, to explore the possibilities of meeting regularly for the simple purpose of showing their pictures to one another and promoting discussion about these and photography generally.

HONGKONG, Oct. 3 -- Premier Chou En-lai gave a reception in Peiping Thursday in honor of experts sent by the Soviet Union to aid in communist China's reconstruction, Hsinhua (New China) News Agency reports.

The appointment of Miss Grace A. Reeder, director of the New York State Bureau of Child Welfare since 1937, as assistant executive director of the Child Welfare League of America was announced yesterday by Marshall Field, president of the league.
EVERETT, Mass., Oct. 3 (AP) -- The wet concrete roof of a nearly completed oil storage tank collapsed today "with a rumble like an earthquake" and killed one worker and injured nineteen others.

THERMAL, Calif., Oct. 3 (AP) -- A Navy combat hero piloted the Flying Wing Douglas jet F4D Skyray an average of 753.4 miles an hour today to win back the world measured course speed record for the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- President Eisenhower appointed today Judge Carroll C. Hincks, senior jurist of the Federal District Court for Connecticut, as Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second District. Judge Hincks fills the vacancy left by the resignation in July of Thomas W. Swan, Chief Judge of the three-judge court.

Harold Riegelman, the Republican candidate for Mayor, showed up at a dinner at the Roosevelt Hotel last night, the text of a scorching critique of mismanagement and inefficiency in the city administration snugly tucked in his pocket. And there, it developed, it was to remain.

THREE new cameras in the top-to-middle and inexpensive price brackets were introduced here last week by Eastman Kodak Company. The $215 Kodak Chevron, which takes twelve 2 1/4 x 2 1/4 pictures on 620 film and is equipped with a split-field rangefinder and Kodak Ektar 78mm f/3.5, has the Kodak Synchro-Rapid 800 Shutter and built-in contacts for all types of flash lamps and electronic flash.

In his Boston speech President Eisenhower claimed that his Administration had cut $6.5 billions off the January, 1953, budget of the Truman Administration for 1953-54. How much validity is there to this claim?

HOW quickly the lawbreakers of yesterday become the grand old men of today, and how rapidly can a solitary experiment turn into a gilt-edge security. Such are some thoughts prompted by the glittering assemblage of twentieth century painting that celebrates the fifth anniversary at the Sidney Janis Gallery.

Engineers of the University of Michigan have developed a new, simple means for obtaining high-altitude data. A four-foot, fifty-pound nylon sphere is dropped through the atmosphere and its rate of fall measured by means of an internal radio transmitter. The sphere is carried in an Aerobee rocket to a height of seventy-five miles, "kicked out," then inflated before beginning its long fall. Stations track the radar signals.

PORT ISABEL, Tex. -- On Padre Island, a pencil-thin island stretching 110 miles along the coast of southern Texas, a new vacationland is being born astride one of the principal routes to Mexico. Cameron County fathers are proclaiming that Padre Island is "the South's greatest new pleasure frontier."

THE current revival of interest in Edward Gibbon and his massive "History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire" -- a work so impressive that it was never very far submerged -- should receive another lift from this sound and unpretentious biography by Michael Joyce, a competent British critic and essayist.

Examining the record of the Republican party at Albany and Washington, Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor, declared yesterday that it added up to a political philosophy based on the theme, "Never give the citizens an even break."

THE harvest season outdoors finds garden organizations appropriately taking account of their year's activities and discussing plans for the future. Today the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc., welcomes its members to a three-day conference at the Rip Van Dam Hotel, Saratoga Springs, N. Y.

The effects of the late summer drought were clearly to be seen on the hills two weeks ago, particularly where the trees were shallow-rooted along the ledges and stood in sere, sad tan. Now that look of drought-blight begins to recede, not because it has lessened but because the fall color has begun to come to so many other trees, more happily situated in deeper soil.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 30 -- Yale did the expected in its football game with Brown today. Assayed at two touchdowns better than their rivals from Providence, the local athletes proved to be just that as they registered a 13-to-0 victory in the fifty-eighth meeting between the schools since 1880.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 3 -- Four retired Iranian brigadier generals and eleven other persons accused of complicity in the April political assassination of Brig. Gen. Mahmoud Afshartous, national police chief under ousted Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, went on trial today with the signs pointing clearly toward acquittal of most of the defendants.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 3 (UP) -- Halfbacks Lloyd Caudle and James (Red) Smith, smartly handled by Jerry Barger, a reserve quarterback, powered Duke today to three touchdowns in the second period and a 21-to-7 victory over Tennessee before a crowd of 30,000.

United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, Inc., will be the beneficiary of the entertainment, known as the Velvet Ball, to be held on Oct. 23 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Samuel P. Peabody heads the committee for the fete and the co-chairman is Mrs. Paul S. Ames.

EVEN if this novel were not based on the Tristram legend of Malory's "Morte d'Arthur" it would hold its own as a romance of medieval chivalry. But Dorothy James Roberts has not only named her book after the philter that was drunk between sea and black sky on the storied passage to Cornwall, she has novelized the lovers' defiance of a knightly world.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 3 -- India's yearly summer monsoon rains, which are annually both a blessing and a curse, have passed on once more, leaving the usual trail of vast destruction along with smiling fields promising a bumper harvest.

THE kitchen is moving to the center of the house. Very often it is the core of family activities. Planned kitchens recently on view at professional and trade snows and in model homes have contained areas for sewing, space for laundering a place for dining (as opposed to just eating), equipment for entertainment (a TV set) and often, of late, the kitchen has actually been the living room.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 3 -- Court action has been started here to determine the legal ownership of valuable unpublished notes of the Lewis and Clark Expedition discovered in the attic of a pioneer St. Paul family. The tattered and yellowed manuscripts, dated from 1803 to 1805, are in the handwriting of Capt. William Clark, according to experts.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UP) -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said tonight that the threat of germ warfare was "a major concern" to Government defense planners.

NOT only have the Dodgers come back from the dead but they are off the critical list also. They did far more than sit up and take nourishment in the fourth game of the world series at Ebbets Field yesterday. They thumbed their noses at the doctors and the coroners. They even looked healthier than the Yankees as they drew even with their tormentors at two victories apiece.

In connection with Jesse Merritt's letter recalling Lafayette's visit, and for the purpose of keeping the record correct, may I point out that three companies of infantry of the Eleventh Regiment Artillery, N. Y. S., were entertaining the plan of forming a separate organization of select membership.

ON Stage 5 at Hal Roach studios a yard-long rocket ship recently careened across the heavens emitting clouds of green and red smoke. As cameras ground for "Riders to the Stars," the craft flew directly into the path of a man-made meteor shower.

THE ordinary book on faith and science, whether written by scientist or theologian and whether it seeks to illumine the contradictions or the compatibilities between science and religion, tends to be boring -- probably because it threshes old straw.

A PSEUDO-BIOGRAPHICAL novel, this is the melodramatic life story of an egoistic, imaginary, supposedly world-renowned artist, one Alexander Dram. Dram is a ladies' man with a vengeance. He takes his women where he finds them and usually leaves them in tears.

FROM the heights above Jerusalem and Hebron, and from a hundred Palestinian heights in between, you look down, when the sun stands fiercely overhead, across the wilderness of Judea to the Dead Sea, and the Dead Sea glares back in a deep blue ageless stare.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Joe O'Brien drove Scotch Victor to a split-heat victory in the fifty-fifth trotting of the Walnut Cup at the Lexington trots today.

ATLANTA, Oct. 3 (UP) -- Georgia Tech got one touchdown on the breaks, dug in on the goal line and finally gave up two safeties to beat Southern Methodist, 6 to 4, today and barely stretch football's longest unbeaten string through twenty-nine games.

SIXTY years ago this fall, two Viennese physicians published a modest paper describing their success in treating several cases of hysterical paralysis by uncovering painful emotional experiences of many years before, seemingly forgotten but actually buried in an unconscious part of the mind.

The presence in Washington last week of our Ambassador to Moscow, Charles E. Bohlen, gave this country's chief foreign - policy strategists a chance to take another look at the total picture of post-Stalin Soviet foreign policy. Washington's estimate of the Kremlin's tactics and objectives determine not only our countermoves in the international arena but also key decisions on the domestic scene, not least those dealing with the budget and defense preparations.

A dinner will be held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Oct. 12 for the alumni and staffs of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center and guests of the center's twenty-fifth anniversary celebration, which will take place on Oct. 12 and 13.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Alan Ameche went 24 yards around left end through a rainstorm today for a third-period touchdown that gave Wisconsin's Badgers a 13-11 victory over Marquette.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- An old United Nations, just like an old automobile, is a highly salable commodity, a fact that has been proved week in and week out since the opening in 1950 of the permanent $68,000,000 United Nations Headquarters.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 3 -- One of the most bitterly contested legal battles in Turkish history ended today when the Canakkale criminal court found Capt. Oscar Lorerntzon responsible for the collision of his ship, the Swedish freighter Naboland, with a Turkish submarine on April 4, resulting in the lost of eighty-one lives.

When he was rounding third and tearing for home on Mickey Mantle's ninth inning single yesterday, Billy Martin was aware that he would be delivering an insignificant run. However, the second-sacker of the Yankees refused to go along with those who insisted that he had been guilty of a "rock."
Jacques Thibaud, one of the world's greatest violinists, the pride of French music lovers, the most inspiring, noblest, deeply moving artist -- Jacques Thibaud is no more.

TOTAL cash awards have been increased from $4,000 to $4,500 for winning entries in the Ninth Annual National High School Photographic Awards, which opens Oct. 15 and closes March 15, 1954, according to announcement last week by the National Scholastic Press Association, sponsor of the annual event with the cooperation of the Eastman Kodak Company.

IT MIGHT not be fair, precisely, to say that Alex Guinness casts himself to type, he being perhaps the most skillful and clever actor making comedies these days, as well as the most audacious in the choosing of the sort of things he plays.

Madrigals by the Elizabethan musician, Thomas Morley, will be sung at a concert today at 5 P. M. by the New York Pro Musica Antiqua at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

The recent letter of John Wesley Coulter, "Knowing Other Lands," recalls my many moments of wonderment at the lack of knowledge of the world's geography, or for that matter of the geography of our own country, in people of all ages and degrees of education.

FOR its final week at the Metropolitan Opera House, the Sadler's Wells Ballet will present all but two of its American repertoire of ten ballets, the two missing ones being "Giselle" and "The Shadow."

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Oct. 3 -- A $1,151,750 welfare home will open next month to initiate a new era of comfort for Morris County's indigent and aged who are now crowded into a fifty-five-year-old brick building.

These are not classical times. Your critic wrote on Sept. 13: "The conflict * * * has long since escaped from the control of individual men." Which is true and which eliminates the possibility of classics. The Peloponnesian War was colossal, the biggest war Thucydides ever saw or heard of, but it was not so large that a commander could not address his whole army and inspire it by his own words and actions.

FOR many months the people of he country have been told of the steadily crowing threat of Russian military and air power. Then came the news a few weeks ago that the Soviet has apparently achieved the hydrogen bomb.

Despite an increase in net public and private debt in this country since the end of 1946, the national debt burden has actually fallen. At the end of 1952 it stood at 190 per cent of national income, against 187 per cent at the end of 1951, 221 per cent at the end of 1946, 184 per cent in 1943 and 425 per cent in 1933.
TOKYO, Oct. 3 -- The light of hope for an early, just and reasonably lasting settlement of pending problems on the war-shattered Korean Peninsula dimmed measurably during the past week.

VIRGINIA WATER, England, Oct. 3 -- Two three-foot putts -- the kind a 20-handicap golfer knocks carelessly into the hole -- cost Great Britain what had threatened until those last tense moments today to be one of the biggest upsets in the twenty-six-year-old history of the Ryder Cup matches.

Members of the Women's Association of the Brick Presbyterian Church have arranged a fashion show and tea in behalf of their charitable enterprises to be held on Oct. 20 in the Recreation Hall of the church at Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street.
Formation of Knapp Mills de Mexico, S. A., with headquarters in Mexico City, was announced yesterday by Knapp Mills, Inc., New York, a producer of lead-clad steel and lead-clad copper.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 3 -- Leaders of Yugoslavia, which once was a strong member of the Soviet-operated Cominform, are scrutinizing developments in West European integration, particularly the European Coal and Steel Community but including the political council of Europe.

WITH customary catholicity the local art galleries are providing attractions which range from backward glances at work by eighteenth and nineteenth century masters' to "space paintings" purporting to give us glimpses into the life on other planets.

RETAILERS breathed in relief last week when President Eisenhower turned thumbs down on the proposed retail sales tax. But they're not yet out of the woods. Many plans are under consideration to make up revenue that will be lost when the excess profits and personal income tax increases expire on Dec. 31, but the Administration appears to be favoring the controversial manufacturers excise tax.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- Thirty-three thousand employes of Swift Co. were notified today that a 5-cent general hourly wage increase and a health insurance program was agreed on last night by the packing company and three unions.

Announcement last week by a large segment of the steel industry that it had adopted, or was contemplating, a system of pricing that would involve limited absorption of freight charges, heralded a rather significant decline in the cost of steel for many consumers.

Dr. John H. Keating, president of the New York Heart Association, announced yesterday that Dr. Norman Plummer, medical director of the New York Telephone Company, had been appointed chairman of an association conference, called "Heart in Industry," to be held on Nov. 20 in the Statler Hotel.

THE other day, driving up to Missoula, my car was halted by a great flock of sheep, blanketing the highway for a couple of hundred yards ahead. You get through, slowly, by sounding your horn. The sheep bleat and scatter to the sides with every honk; then their ranks close again. Little by little you cautiously edge through.

Pittsburgh business and labor groups have joined to cooperate with Duquesne University in a program of weekly half-hour television shows aimed at explaining how the Communists are working to overthrow the United States Government and the Governments of other free nations.

Mayor Impellitteri defended yesterday the financial condition of the city and declared that those persons who contended the city's finances were not in a healthy state were guilty of "pure, unmitigated bunk."

A small department store opened its doors for the first time twenty-five years ago next Tuesday at 152d Street and Third Avenue. The establishment was called Alexander's. Its original capital was $7,500.

LONDON, Oct. 3 (Reuters) -- West Bromwich Albion maintained its two-point lead over Huddersfield in the first division of English soccer with a 2-1 victory over Middlesbrough today. Huddersfield downed Aston Villa by 4 -- 0. The third-place Wolverhampton Wanderers were held to a 3-3 draw by Sheffield United.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct 3 -- Emil (Bus) Mosbacher Jr., Yacht Racing Association champion of the International Class, scored his first triumph in the post-season seven-race series for the De Coppet and Philip Haebler trophies off the Larchmont Yacht Club today.

The little muleteer of the Gowanus Canal, meaning Manager Chuck Dressen of the Dodgers, was himself again yesterday after his club had made the world series an even thing by beating the proud Yankees for the second straight time at Ebbets Field.

SOME people scale mountains for fun. Others poke into caves. For more than a quarter century it has been Helen Worden Erskine's semi-professional hobby to track down hermits and recluses and the motives for their eccentricities.

Since the end of World War II institutions of higher learning in this country have undergone an extensive self-valuation of their goals, aims and objectives. The war itself, followed by the influx of veterans to the nation's campuses and the demands of changing world conditions since the war, caused many colleges and universities to reconsider their academic programs and map out new plans for the future.

Conductor Billy Hodgkiss and Train 254 from Philadelphia pulled in at their customary time, 8:35 A. M., at Pennsylvania Station Friday. What happened immediately afterward, however, was not on the timetable.

John Adams of Queens, Morris of the Bronx and Andrew Jackson of Queens were the team victors yesterday in three group cross-country runs sponsored by the Public Schools Athletic League over the two and one-quarter mile course at Van Cortlandt Park.

PSYCHOLOGICAL surveys of motorists' behavior, conducted by the American Automobile Association, have led to the creation of a composite personality type which the A. A. A. considers one of the major hazards on the highway. This is the "showoff"

CINCINNATI, Oct. 3 -- "Clerical opportunism has taken advantage of vital state needs [in Israel] to build itself a citadel of power which cannot endure." Dr. Nelson Glueck, president of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, declared this morning at the opening of the Reform Jewish seminary's seventy-ninth academic year.

VIENNA, Oct. 3 -- The Soviet satellites in Eastern Europe, with the single exception of East Germany, find themselves this autumn with the best harvest in years. But they are having so much trouble getting it in that it seems likely the Communist phenomenon of poverty in the midst of plenty will be repeated during the coming winter and spring.

ANY stick is good enough to beat a dog with when familiarity has bred contempt: and the critics have, of course, used the visit of the Bavarian State Opera to Covent Garden in order to point a moral to our own resident company.

IN 1951 W. W. Norton Co. issued a book named "Masterpieces of Music Before 1750," -- an anthology of fifty musical examples, most of them far off the beaten track, from Gregorian chant to J. S. Bach. These were compiled, edited and transcribed for modern notation by Carl Parrish and John F. Ohl. The book soon was adopted as a text by several colleges.

Ernest Raynaud's article, "Another Problem for France -- Alcoholism" (Sept. 20), is of particular interest when considered in the light of that nation's unhappy financial state. We are told that "France is short of sugar and has to buy it abroad; even so, a large part of the [sugar] beet crop is converted into crude spirit, which is sold to the Government, which destroys it."

MANHATTAN, Kan., Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Kansas State Wildcats scored their greatest football victory in a decade today by downing the highly favored Nebraska Cornhuskers, 27 -- 0, in a Big Seven Conference game.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Oct. 3--i%[iss Cornelia Wales, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Chauncey Wales, and John Merrick Reeder, son of Mr. and Mrs. David K. Reger, were married here this afte'oon in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Ralph T. Haas. A reception was held at the Wales home.

Persons interested in the work of the Play Schools Association have taken over two performances of "The Tea House of the August Moon," on Oct. 21 and Oct. 29, at the Martin Beck Theatre to raise funds for the organization. Mrs. George W. Naumburg and Mrs. Ruth R. Goddard are co-chairmen of the committee in charge.
IOWA CITY, Iowa, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Iowa splurged to one of its wildest scoring binges today in running up a 54-12 victory over Washington State in an intersectional football contest.
