SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Golden Gate Baptist Theological Seminary -- a $10,000,000 project -- will be buit on a 125-acre site on Strawberry Point, school officials announced this week. Strawberry Point lies about five miles north of the Golden Gate Bridge on the east shore of Richardson Bay, an arm of San Francisco Bay.

FALL finds motorists converging on the Midsouth as lively programs of events get under way at Southern Pines, Pinehurst, Tryon and other resorts. High favorite with the golfing crowd, Pinehurst, N. C., opened its fifty-ninth season last week.

Substantial numbers of buyers remained in the wholesale markets here last week, resident buying offices reported. Ordering was somewhat more conservative than in former years and, since manufacturers did not build large inventories, deliveries have slowed. Retail business was good during September and stores are planning for a good fall season despite the slow starts.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sunday, Oct. 4 (Reuters) -- Prince Oscar Bernadotte died here early today after an illness of several weeks. He was 93 years old. His physician. Dr. Hjalmar Casserman, said he had been suffering from a "general debility" for several weeks, and his condition became critical last night.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Charfran Stable's Crafty Admiral, last year's handicap champion, gained his fifth major triumph of 1953 when he accounted for the eighth running of the $28,000 Olympic Handicap before 19,365 fans here today.

HOW does Hollywood, feel about CinemaScope now that it has had the opportunity to witness a full-dress display of the wide-screen process heralded by Twentieth Century-Fox as being a development destined to change the future course of the screen?

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 3 -- The fourth dimension -- defense -- was no problem for Harvard's triple threat, Captain Dick Clasby today. The Natick, Mass., senior intercepted two passes to set up a touchdown and field goal and passed for two tallies, as Harvard sputtered to a 16-0 victory over Ohio University of Athens, Ohio, in the Crimson's opener.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 3 -- Any existing notion that Navy was lacking in early season firepower proved entirely unfounded today. Before a gathering of 15,000 fans at Thompson Stadium, the midshipmen sailed through Dartmouth's defenses to score a 55-7 triumph.

ROME, Oct. 3 -- Speaking to the participants in the sixth International Congress on Penal Law, Pope Pius XII urged all civilized nations today to elaborate a code of international law that would punish persons responsible for unleashing an unjust war or for waging it with excesses in cruelty.

ANYONE who visited the home of Walter and Louise Arensberg in California will carry forever the memory of a house literally teeming with works of art. Paintings by Duchamp, Klee, Picasso, Braque, de_Chirico, Dali nudged each other over every inch of wall.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 3 -- Notre Dame's speedy football team scored a 37-7 victory over Purdue today. The Irish tallied as they pleased, with Fullback Neil Worden's power, Halfback Johnny Lattner's speed and Quarterback Ralph Guglielmi's lateral passes overwhelming the Boilermakers.

THIS might be designated National Downbeat Week, since the Philharmonic-Symphony, Philadelphia Orchestra, Boston Symphony Orchestra, Cleveland Orchestra, Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra and others are launching their 1953-54 seasons between now and next Sunday.

English and American eighteenth century furniture, fine porcelains, oriental rugs, bronzes and other art property will be auctioned on Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UP) -- Herbert Hoover Jr., the State Department's new petroleum affairs trouble-shooter, is working hard to push the British-Iranian oil dispute toward a quick settlement but "sees no immediate solution."
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 3 -- A strong and determined Rutgers football team erased a 13-0 deficit and went on to defeat heavily favored Virginia Tech, 20 -- 13, today.

For the next six months, more than 500,000 members of the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, along with allied welfare and neighborhood groups, will celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Jewish Community Center movement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The United States pressed ahead today in its effort to elicit from the Soviet Union a clear-cut "yes" or "no" to the Western Big Three proposal for a four-power foreign ministers meeting on German and Austrian problems.

MOST scientists, show reverent respect for the boundaries of their specialties. Physicists feel like apple-stealing kids if caught on the premises of chemistry. Paleontologists keep as quiet as brachiopods whenever the conversation veers toward physics.

Commenting on endorsements of Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor, by former President Harry S. Truman and Adlai E. Stevenson, former Democratic candidate for President, Edward C. Maguire, campaign manager for Mayor Impellitteri, said yesterday that those in "the Wagner camp must be panicky if they have to reach out to the prairies of Illinois and Missouri to bolster their bid for New York City votes."

At the "unrepatriates" camp at Panmunjom, 22,600 Chinese and North Koreans, and 359 former U. N. soldiers are being guarded by Indian troops of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission. A correspondent of The New York Times last week cabled this description of the camp:

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 -- Unable to build up sufficient momentum on attack to take the pressure off their embattled defense, the New York Football Giants bowed to the Pittsburgh Steelers, 24 -- 14, before a near-capacity crowd of 31,500 spectators at Forbes Field tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The most important piece of land for American farmers is three and a half acres on Capitol Hill. For there, in the Senate and the House, farm legislation is produced, and there, in 1954, will come the sum total of what members of Congress found while mending fences on home grounds between sessions.
HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Vietminh rebels penned under French attack north of the Red River were milling tonight and a French Army spokesman said their discipline had cracked.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Oct. 3 -- Lou Barbaro and Mrs. Joseph Goldsmith of Hollywood eliminated Fred Baker and Mrs. Theron U. Lyman of Maplewood, the defenders, 2 and 1, in the quarter-final round of the Frank Cloran pro-woman tournament at the Forest Hill Field Club today.

Bernard M. Baruch, one of the most distinguished graduates of City College, will be honored with a convocation on Thursday to rename its business school in his honor. The ceremony will take place at 10:30 A.M. in the auditorium of the school, at Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

Most statistical studies are centered about mean values and so-called normal distribution. But engineers must consider extreme values. Thus a forecast of floods is necessary for the construction of channels, bridges, reservoirs, dams and hydroelectric plants, and a study of droughts in treating problems arising from stream pollution, sewage disposal and water supply.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Elry Falkenstein, a second-string quarterback, and J. C. Caroline, a sophomore halfback, sparked Illinois to a 33-21 victory over Stanford today.

TO read Ivy Compton-Burnett so belatedly for the first time is, surprisingly, a surprise. It is easy enough to take a reputed excellence and wit for granted; it is quite something else to be astonished by it face to face.
HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 3 -- Teachers in the Texas public school system are trying to find markets for larger amounts of the state's oil.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Oct. 3 -- Dr. Noval Neil Luxon, assistant to the president and Professor of Journalism at Ohio State University where he has just rounded out twenty-five years of service, today was named dean of the School of Journalism at the University of North Carolina, effective Dec. 1.

THIS week marks what amounts to the final phase of the parade of new and returning shows on television. There will be a few others as the season progresses but these premieres round out the winter schedule substantially as it will be for the season:

CINCINNATI, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The University of Cincinnati's Bearcats scored three times in the first ten minutes tonight and never turned off the pressure as they romped to a 57-7 victory over William and Mary. In its two previous gaines, W. and M. had beaten Wake Forest and tied Navy.

A NEW approach in slide-projector design was introduced here over last weekend by Revers Camera Company of Chicago, who demonstrated the Revere 444 Slide Projector as their first entry in the 35mm still-picture field.

A major segment of the $8,000,000,000 natural gas industry breathed a little easier last week. For the first time since the advent of the Eisenhower Administration, the head of a powerful governmental agency made it clear that the supplier of essential utility service, such as natural gas, will receive fair treatment in matters of rate regulation consistent with a policy of financial soundness and good public service.

TO a gruesome degree success or failure in the New York theatre hangs on a single cast of the dice -- the opening-night performance. For author, players, director, the producer and his staff, it climaxes pressures and anxieties that have been mounting through months of writing and rewriting, casting and recasting, fund raising, rehearsing, tryouts in cultural centers beyond the jurisdiction of Vincent Impellitteri.

TO the tourist the French "supplement," the inevitable extra charge for carrying luggage in taxis or for special service at hotels and restaurants, is a constant annoyance. To the French it is an accustomed part of living, an emolument that returns as frequently as it is given.

FORT ANN, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- Reconstruction of the last of several colonial and Revolutionary War period forts whence the community of "Fort Anne" derives its name, and the conversion of the Laura I. Martindale home in Charles Street to a historical museum are the main objectives of a newly organized corporation to be known as Fort Anne Restoration, Inc.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 3 -- The Iranian Government took drastic action today to end the shortage of local currency that had all but stalled the United States $45,000,000 emergency aid program.

LAWNS where drought, weeds, insects and diseases have made inroads this year can be renovated to look like new. Damage is common to lawns that were seeded on poorly prepared combinations of topsoil and subsoil.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 3 -- Seven degrees of Doctor of Philosophy and two of Doctor of Education were among the baccalaureate and advanced degrees conferred on a class of 103 graduates of eleven divisions of Rutger's University at fall graduation exercises this morning.

Trees have malignant tumors just as animals do. Dr. Philip R. White, research associate, and Dr. William F. Millington, laboratory fellow, at the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory, believe the tumors will throw some light on the nature of malignant growth in animals.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Britain will continue to sponsor a proposal for talks with the Soviet Union on the highest level. This became known today despite what is regarded here as the failure thus far of the Soviet Government to give the slightest hint that it might be prepared to accept such a proposal.
HARTFORD, Oct. 5 -- Republican party leaders in Connecticut are getting concerned about party warfare that has split the party since Gov. John Davis Lodge took office in January, 1951.

TOKYO, Oct. 3 -- During the difficult negotiating sessions in Panmunjom, when the general principles for handling the prisoners of war who did not wish to be repatriated were being worked out, Maj. Gen. Choi Duk Shin, South Korean representative who had walked out of the talks in protest, said:

General Clark is, of course, completely right in promptly and emphatically rejecting the Indian request that the time for the "persuasion" of anti-Communist prisoners in Korea be extended beyond the ninety days stipulated in the armistice agreement. There is certainly no justification whatever for breaking faith with the prisoners after they have been told that Dec. 23 is the last day of their ordeal.
For the second time since the end of fighting in Korea, members of the crew of a United States aircraft carrier will contribute blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Clarence W. Miles, Baltimore attorney heading the syndicate that bought the St. Louis Browns franchise, plans to go to Chicago tomorrow to talk over his problems with Charles Comiskey and other officials of the White Sox.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Sen. John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, said today "unscrupulous manufacturers" apparently were "deliberately confusing" the Army engineers in order to sell them spare equipment parts the Army did not need.

ALTHOUGH a short book, "Johnswood" is composed of so many elements, emotional and factual, that it is difficult to convey a sense of its qualities. Johnswood itself was the house built in the mountains of Arkansas by John Gould Fletcher, the poet, and his wife.

THE new ruling of the American Actors' Equity Association under which no more than 40 per cent of a cast can be foreigners, in a New York stage presentation, appears to be, on the face of it, outrageously immature.

WHEN the Sadler's Wells Ballet comes among us, especially after an absence of several seasons, there are so many things to be about it one scarcely knows where to begin. Perhaps the best place is with a general conclusion, working backward from there.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The White House social whirl, complete with gold braid and tiaras, which everybody thought had gone with the Trumans, is on again full blast.

TODAY'S recipes emphasize the fact that the cranberry has more culinary possibilities than the classic cranberry sauce and cranberry jelly. That home cooks will want to explore such possibilities seems likely in view of the huge harvest of cranberries now starting to market and the attractively low prices attendant on large supplies.

Negro teachers should be distributed more evenly through the city's schools, rather than concentrated in predominantly Negro areas, it was agreed yesterday by members of a forum on racial discrimination in the schools arranged by the Flushing branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
Nathan Habib has been appointed editor and research director of Maritime Research, Inc., publishers of The North Atlantic Exchange a weekly statistical guide to the ocean freight charter market.

Kiyoko Otani, young Japanese soprano, gave her first New York recital Saturday night at Town Hall. The comely, petite vocalist has made many appearances in opera in her own country, and also has been heard there on the concert stage. Her program provided her with the opportunity to display her abilities in both of these fields.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 4 -- With French and Vietminh forces still in the stage of active preparations for the fall campaign in Indo-China, French strategy is hampered by two main difficulties: the defense of Cambodia and inexperience of the Vietnamese armies. French action, despite Cambodian opposition, may be expected soon.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (UP) -- Lou (The Toe) Groza's string of consecutive points after touchdown ended at 121 today, but the Cleveland Browns survived the lapse without trouble to whip the Chicago Cardinals, 27 to 7, before 24,374 fans.

The different ways in which the Lord's Supper is celebrated are "a major symbol" of "the separation and disunity" of the Christian Church, the Rev. Ira W. Langston said yesterday morning at the Park Avenue Christian Church (Disciples of Christ), Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 4 -- The Great Danbury Fair opened its eighty-fourth annual agricultural exposition yesterday in a setting of autumn tints with a record attendance of 19,048 men, women and children. Last year's opening day attendance was about 3,000 less.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 4 (UP) -- Clement Hirsch, vice president of the Las Vegas Jockey Club race track, said today the track will have only two days of racing this week.

The economic significance of the aid Communist China is to receive from the Soviet Union during 1953-57, China's First Five-Year Plan period, has been revealed by Pravda, the Soviet Communist newspaper, in an article that gives the first clues on the 1957 production objectives sought by the Peiping regime.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 4 -- A sharp increase in circulation of anti- Semitic pamphlets in many of Mexico's major cities during the last three months is causing concern to Jews here.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Admiral Lynde D. McCormick of the United States, Supreme Commander of the forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in the Atlantic, said today that the NATO powers were in a better maritime position now than the Allies were at the beginning of World War I or World War II.

With registration for the New York City election beginning today and continuing all this week, leaders of all political parties prepared yesterday for an intensive drive to get as many citizens as possible to qualify themselves for voting in the election on Nov. 3.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- The major cigarette companies were challenged today to conduct research projects to prove or disprove recent medical suggestions that cigarette smoking leads to lung cancer. The challenge was made as 11,000 surgeons gathered for the thirty-ninth annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons, a week-long meeting that begins tomorrow.

VIENNA, Oct. 4 -- An American singer protested on the open stage tonight on behalf of his Viennese colleagues against the suspension by the Austrian Minister of Education and Culture of Dr. Egon Hilbert, head of the Austrian State Opera and Theatres.
It was John H. Williams who said: "The instability of the economy is equaled only by the instability of economists."
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 4 -- Labor unions, like social workers, are striving "to maintain and develop in man his God-given self-respect," Martin P. Durkin said here tonight.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- The unusually dry and hot weather last week had a bullish effect on wheat, specially the July, while at the same time it was bearish on corn which showed substantial declines.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Oct, 4 (UP) -- Gene Littler, 23-year-old national amateur golf champion, won the California amateur title with a 5 and 4 victory over Dr. F. M. Taylor, Pomona dentist, in a scheduled 36-hole final today.

While the top ten of intercollegiate football were rolling along about as expected with the exception of Oklahoma and Georgia Tech, New York's own Fordham and Columbia were distinguishing themselves over the week-end.

The Sadler's Wells Ballet devoted its week-end at the Metropolitan Opera House chiefly to "Sylvia." The single exception was Saturday evening's presentation of "Giselle," in which Violetta Elvin made her first New York appearance in the title role, with Alexis Rassine as the Albrecht.

MANILA, Monday, Oct. 5 -- President Elpidio Quirino, campaigning for re-election in the southern Philippines, lashed out yesterday at foreign "meddling" in local political affairs. He gave notice that he intended to make this issue a major one in the Nov. 10 elections.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy proposed tonight that the nation spend $10,000,000,000 more a year to increase its defenses against hydrogen bomb attack, while the head of the Office of Defense Mobilization declared in a separate statement that Russia had such weapons and the ability to use them "suddenly and without warning."

In an article on "Full Employment and Stable Prices" in its October monthly review, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York pointed out that "more Americans were at work this summer than ever before in the nation's history."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Army's plans to show off its first fifty-ton tank -- the T-43 -- at Aberdeen, Md., next Thursday have been canceled by Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, on the ground that the demonstration would be contrary to high policy on experimental weapons.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 4 -- Boris Goldovsky's "Opera Theatre," a lively feature of the New England musical scene since 1946, last night began its first cross-country tour with a performance at the Lyric Theatre here of Mozart's youthful opera, "La Finta Giardiniera," translated into English and rechristened "Merry Masquerado."

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- A reactionary tendency in the stock markets here followed an upward rush as the bank rate was cut, but a fresh advance on a broad front occurred last week. The markets are taking the bit between their teeth and developing upon decidedly bullish lines.
There was a small change for the better in the ship charter market last week and reasonably heartening optimism continued to prevail among the brokers.

The police engaged in a game of charades early yesterday morning with three alleged extortionists and won easily. Two of the suspects tried to enact the roles of narcotics squad detectives, the police said, but their poses were discovered. A half-dozen plainclothes policemen then assumed the guises of cab drivers and street sweeps and made a perfect score.

Any cool day which follows a heat wave is, of course, a very fine thing indeed. It uplifts the spirit and makes the average humble man feel himself to be ten feet high and with the strength to move vast mountains. He all but dances as he goes about the everyday occupations which but a few days before had seemed unbearable and endless.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4 -- For the immediate future and for most of the fourth quarter it is a good bet that the steel production rate will hold pretty close to 90 per cent of rated capacity. Backlogs and the slight hitch in supplies due to a strike at Buffalo will assure such a condition.

Paul Hoffman, former administrator of the Economic Cooperation Administration, voiced criticism yesterday of those -- "often good people" -- who, in combating communism, used the term "un-American." The loose use of that term, Mr. Hoffman held, has resulted in the spreading of confusion as to what the word "American'' really means.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Herbert Morrison, deputy leader of the British Labor party, outlined today the "essentials" for a Labor victory in Britain's next general election, which, he said, "may not be long delayed."

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 4 -- The Government of Pakistan has cleared the way for early adoption of a Constitution with complete agreement among provinces and states on representation in the House of the People, the lower House of Parliament.

Rudolph Halley named three racketeers yesterday whom he said he would seek to drive from the city if he were elected Mayor. In three campaign speeches he stressed the importance of making New York free of crime and corruption.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, today opened the twenty-eighth international convention of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, A.F.L., with an address in which he said that the most important thing in the lives of the American people was world peace.

Stoyan Pribichevich, a noted author, recently criticized THE NEW YORK TIMES on figures involving the number of Yugoslavs deported from Italy by Mussolini. THE TIMES claims there were only "voluntary" repatriations, while Mr. Pribichevich quotas a figure of 122,430, supplied by Marshal Tito, for "forced" deportations.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, acknowledged today that he had made two visits to Sing Sing Prison, in 1949 and 1950, to confer with Joseph S. (Joey) Fay, convicted union extortionist. Fay was transferred yesterday to Clinton Prison at Dannemora, the "Siberia" of New York prisons.

MONHEGAN ISLAND, Me., Oct. 4 (UP) -- The police hunted two men today for questioning in the death of a New York woman, whose body was found at sea three weeks after she had disappeared from an island cottage.

YONKERS, Oct. 4 -- Dr. Charles Robbins, a 33-year-old Philadelphian, regained the National Amateur Athletic Union 20-kilometer run title by setting a fast pace over the twelve-and-a-half mile course today. Robbins' last previous victory in the grind was in 1946.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- A rare Sunday meeting of Britain's Privy Council at Balmoral Castle in Scotland, where Queen Elizabeth II is vacationing, gave rise to the belief here, that the Government intended to revoke the constitution of British Guiana.
Paul Kennedy's dispatches on Point Four, admirable in many respects, seem to have been written to reflect certain Washington viewpoints arid without the benefit of personal observation in the field.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Mr. Warren left his resignation as Governor on his Sacramento desk as he departed for Washington. One of his last acts as Governor was to pardon a man whose murder conviction in 1937 won him wide public notice.
BILOXI, Miss., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Six outboard motorboat drivers from four states won titles today in the American Power Boat Association national championship.

CAIRO, Monday, Oct. 5 -- Egypt's ruling Revolution Council, the twelve-man Army junta that seized power fourteen months ago, announced early this morning that two more of its members had been added to the Cabinet, making a ratio of six officers to eleven civilians.
PARIS, Oct. 4 -- The French retail price index fell in September to the lowest level in the last two years.

Instead of viewing the Statue of Liberty and the famous New York skyline, which usually greet travelers sailing into the harbor from Europe, tired passengers arriving from a voyage on the Cunard liner Britannic yesterday looked upon the domed windows of Grand Central Terminal and the huge American flag over the waiting room.

ZURICH, Oct. 4 -- The problems of business of all European countries grappling with rehabilitation were discussed exhaustively at the fortieth annual meeting of the Swiss Bankers Association held recently in Baden.

State Supreme Court Justice Edgar J. Nathan Jr., president of Congregation Shearith Israel, Central Park West and Seventieth Street, accepted last night a kiddush cup, or ceremonial goblet, from Alfred E. Mingle, of Salem Lutheran Church, Aaronsburg, Pa. A. kiddush cup is used among Jews to bless wine for ceremonial purposes.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $80,532,207,046. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 5 -- Efforts by United Nations and Communist representatives in Korea to persuade prisoners formerly held by the Allies to return home will be postponed another week, and possibly more.

UTICA, N. Y., Oct. 4 (AP) -- The State Chairman of the Democratic party called tonight for the resignation of Republican State Senator Arthur H. Wicks, the acting Lieutenant Governor, and demanded an "impartial investigation" of the influence that Fay apparently had wielded from his Sing Sing prison cell.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 4 (AP) -- George Blanda threw a 16-yard pass to Jim Dooley in the corner of the end zone with three minutes to play today to give the Chicago Bears a 17-13 victory over Green Bay in a National Football League game before 24,835 fans at the City Stadium.

The fate of "Kismet," the lavish musical written by Charles Lederer, Luther Davis, Robert Wright and George Forrest, now rests with Mr. Lederer instead of the original sponsor, Edwin Lester. The change, which will formally take place today, was confirmed yesterday by Mr. Lederer in San Francisco, where the show concludes a four-week stand on Saturday night with a cast headed by Alfred Drake and Doretta Morrow.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 4 -- One thousand workmen have been swarming over Roosevelt Raceway for the last week, converting it from a trotting track into the home of the Long Island Agridustrial Exposition. Scheduled to start Saturday, the fair hopes to entertain a million people in its nine-day run.

The Harv-Low Realty Corporation has purchased from a client of Bernard Friedman, lawyer, the five-story apartment building for forty-seven families at 1758 Eastburn Avenue, in the Bronx, for cash above mortgages amounting to $121,994.

High school athletics should be treated as "an integral and effective" part of the scholastic program rather than as an extracurricular activity, twenty-five high school principals urged in a report issued yesterday by Teachers College, Columbia University.
Despite an article in her Constitution that seems to renounce the maintenance of armed forces, Japan retains the right to arm in self-defense, according to former Premier Hitoshi Ashida.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Abba Eban, Ambassador of Israel, urged tonight that the Israeli Government and the Arab states be allowed to work out their own settlement of the many disputes that divide them.

EDGEWATER, N. J., Monday, Oct. 5 -- Fire that exploded fish-oil storage tanks sent flames a half mile high and raged out of control for more than an hour late last night, threatening to spread through this congested industrial area fringing the Hudson River.

ALL day and through the night men and women volunteers on a high midtown roof-top follow aircraft flight over Manhattan's towers. They quietly call the point of approach, altitude and point of progress into a telephone connected with the White Plains filter center.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 4 -- Breaking the game wide open with a four-goal at attack in the fifth chukker, Milwaukee swept to an 8-7 victory over Meadow Brook in the Monty Waterbury final for the national handicap polo title on Bostwick Field today.

THERMAL, Calif., Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Navy's F4D jet Skyray, which set a world's speed record of 753.4 miles an hour over a measured course, is being prepared for some sea duty aboard an aircraft carrier.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4 (UP) -- Gordon Soltau kicked a field goal from the 13-yard line with six seconds to go today to give the San Francisco Forty Niners a 31 -- 30 victory over the Los Angeles Rams at Kezar Stadium before 43,922 fans.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Neutral observers came to the defense today of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission in Korea, which has been under heavy attack here for alleged pro-Communist rulings.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 4 -- The South has taken the lead in the production of three industrial minerals, stands foremost in the supplying of pulpwood and the capacity to manufacture paper and pulp, and in ten years is expected to lead in chemical production, the fastest growing industry in the country, according to a report of the Southern Association of Science and Industry.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Oct. 4 -- The men who make sailing competition on Long Island Sound possible by serving on race committees banded together at the Knickerbocker Yacht Club today to distribute some weird and wondrous trophies to each other for distinguished service in "the unrelenting war of extermination against the hereditary enemy -- the racing yachtsmen."
LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Telephones and radios in every room -- and television in the suites -- threaten to disturb the peace that visitors have found for years in London hotels.

High fashion for the home knitter's product this fall will be provided by yarns that give finished garments a woven fabric appearance. She will find added inducement to knit in metallic-sparked and synthetic yarns.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Earl Warren, leaving his post as Governor of California, arrived in the capital tonight to become the fourteenth Chief Justice of the United States tomorrow.

The young American pianist, Larry Walz, selected for himself a demanding program on the occasion of his Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon. Ravel's "Gaspard de la Nuit" is one of the keyboard's real finger-twisters, but as if that were not enough, Mr. Walz also included two of Liszt's Transcendental Etudes ("Chasse-Neige" and the delightful "Feux Follets"), Chopin's B flat minor Sonata, three Scarlatti Sonatas and Beethoven's Sonata in D, Op. 28.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Two hundred fifty legislators from thirty nations, banded together in the Inter-Parliamentary Union, will meet this week and debate the worth of international programs of technical and financial assistance.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 4 -- Clients of this capital's barbershops are becoming worried about the increasing taciturnity of their barbers, according to a columnist in the newspaper Clarin.

The casual acceptance of victory, which the Yankees displayed following their first two series victories, vanished yesterday. For the first time in the 1953 series the Bombers' dressing room presented a jubilant scene, as the players, led by Ed Lopat, whooped it up.

Total resources of the National City Bank of New York amounted to $5,897,819,619 at the end of last month, according to the bank's quarterly condition statement, issued for publication today. They compare with $5,762,668,401 on June 30 and with $5,888,906,767 at the end of September, 1952.

The hitherto solid ranks of twenty-five tanker operators in their contract dispute with the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A. F. L., were reported bent, if not broken, over the week-end. The union has been on strike since midnight last Wednesday when a two-year agreement expired.

An all-inclusive questionnaire will be sent out tonight or tomorrow morning to each of the eight licensees of trotting tracks in the state by the special counsel for the State Harness Racing Commission, it was learned yesterday.

Louis C. Sirkus sold to Samuel Krasilovsky and others the commercial buildings at 247-51 Green Street, in Brooklyn, on a plot 100 by 200 feet, subject to a purchase-money mortgage of $19,000. H. Preston Haselwood was attorney for the seller and City Title Insurance Company insured title.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 4 -- A man with a head full of secrets, Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of West Germany, returned to Bonn last night after a post-election vacation at Buhler Hohe in the Black Forest.

Whatever happens to individuals, the Supreme Court of the United States goes on. It recessed last spring, held a subsequent brief session to consider the Rosenberg case and today will resume its sessions. One Chief Justice, the late Fred M. Vinson, has left this earthly scene; another, Earl Warren of California, will take the oath and occupy the otherwise empty chair today.
No major local art events are scheduled this week, but many exhibitions will open in various museums and galleries.

Dublin Bay prawns, shellfish unusual both for their sweetness and tenderness, are being served for the first time in a few well-known restaurants about town, including Luchow's. Fortunately for home cooks, a buying agency for Luchow's, the 1882 Corporation, 103 East Thirteenth Street, is selling the prawns at retail, the only agency to do so. They cost $1.50 a pound.

Julian Karolyi, Hungarian pianist, who made his local debut two years ago at Town Hall, was heard in his second recital here late yesterday afternoon in the same auditorium. He had prepared an elaborate schedule, including the twenty-four Preludes, Op. 28, of Chopin; Schumann's "Kreisleriana" and items by Liszt, Debussy and Kodaly.

JIM McDONALD'S career as a Yankee has been a rather checkered one and even when he pitched well he could have been justified in slapping a lawsuit on his team-mates for nonsupport. Rarely, if ever, did they get him any runs. But he couldn't complain at Ebbets Field yesterday. They got him plenty. What's more, he needed them.

You are to be commended on the three articles by Paul P. Kennedy on the new status of Point Four. It is with dismay that we who have seen it in actual operation learn that it will be absorbed along with Mutual Security Administration into Foreign Operations Administration.
Speedy Presidential action was expected today to end for eighty days the economy-strangling Atlantic Coast pier strike.

The Rev. L. Doward McBain challenged last night this country's "would-be defenders" and critics of the Protestant clergy to "face up to some of our basic inconsistencies" of foreign policy and cited the recent alignment with Spain as one example.
I would have given anything in the world to finish yesterday's game but I simply ran out of gas.

One interesting problem of schoolboy coaches is the student from foreign climes who turns out for football. Converting soccer and rugby players offers a challenge and most coaches accept it with relish.

WASHINGTON, Oct 4 -- In a maneuver underlining the new importance placed by strategic defense planners upon the northeast air approaches from the Soviet Union to the continental United States, a mass flight of B-36 "intercontinental" bombers soon will "try out for size" the huge Thule Air Force Base in northern Greenland.

A display of this season's textiles is now on view at the Fashion Institute of Technology, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street. Arranged by the Textile Advisory Committee of the Educatonal Foundation for the Apparel Industry, the exhibition will be open to the public and the industry on Mondays and Wednesdays from 2 to 4 P. M. through October.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 4 -- President Itzhak Ben-Zvi invited representatives of 190,000 immigrants to his office in Jerusalem today and heard about the hardships of life in huts of wood, tin or canvas in work villages in remote parts of Israel.

Women headed by Mrs. Lewis T. Preston and Mrs. Harold L. Suttle, co-chairmen, have been holding meetings at the Ambassador recently to formulate plans for an annual series of dinner dances to be held early next year under the auspices of the Volunteer Committee and the Board of Trustees of Roosevelt Hospital.

At a meeting of the eastern regional group of the United Cerebral Palsy organization in the New Yorker Hotel yesterday, Lionel O. Grossman, president of the New York State branch, said he hoped to have a clinic in every one of the state's forty-four counties within two years.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- Analyzing what he described as France's outdated economic system, Finance Minister Edgar Faure declared today that economic expansion was the key to solving the difficulties of low French wages and of French agriculture.

" This is one of my new designs for the resort and spring season; how do you like it?" The speaker was Kasper of Penart; the scene, his designing room in one of the tall buildings of the garment center.

Because big corporations still are regarded by far too many as recipients of huge profits and nothing else, E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., has come up with some interesting information to show that it gives as well as takes in the economic grab bag.
" When you throw your best pitch and a guy hits it like that Mantle did, then there's just nothing you can do about it."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 4 -- Yugoslavia offered today to hold bilateral talks with Italy on the Trieste dispute. Vice President Edvard Kardelj said it was "not too late" for such talks.

The Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center will reach the high point of its two-day twenty-fifth anniversary celebration on Oct. 13, when it presents Distinguished Service Awards to twenty-four men and one woman with long records of service to medical science.

In line with Congressional legislation and the President's proclamation, especial emphasis is being given this week to the desirability of helping the physically handicapped Individuals and companies are being asked to give more thought to the possibility and the wisdom of giving employment to those who have some physical disability.

If there's one town in the world that every G. I. wants to see, it's New York City -- and that goes double for the boys who call at home Service men on pass pour into New York every day from neighboring Army camps, Navy installations and ships.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 4 -- Victor Reuther, assistant to his brother, Walter Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, gave a warning today against any attempt to limit the independence and freedom of the West German trade union movement.

The leaders in the world chess championship challengers tournament in Zurich continued with their drawing tactics last night, when four of the seven games scheduled for the nineteenth round were decided in that manner, according to a Swiss news report.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, criticized today the use of dollar-a-year men in the Department of Commerce's new Business and Defense Services Administration.
The sun still shone brilliantly for the fifth game of the 1953 world series at Ebbets Field yesterday. But for Brooklyn everything went black in mid-afternoon.
A lively lady of show business won one of her greatest ovations at a testimonial dinner here last night marking her golden jubilee as an entertainer.

Government shipping statistics, while adequate, are compiled in such a way that it is difficult for observers to find exactly what they are looking for, the Association of American Ship Owners said yesterday.
After a short ownership, Harry Klein, operator, has resold the forty-family apartment house at 431-437 West Fifty-sixth Street, on a plot 100 by 100 feet, to a client of Robert S. Ratner, lawyer.

VALLEJO, Calif., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Fire swept the Mare Island Navy Yard waterfront today, destroying a Navy tug and barge, several warehouses and a pier. One firefighter drowned and twelve were injured or overcome by smoke.

WARSAW, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Polish press today printed a letter from East German Premier Otto Grotewohl to Premier Boleslaw Bierut expressing thanks for the "great help" being given by the Polish Government and nation to East Germany.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York's deposits, loans and total resources, as of Sept. 30, show gains over those of three and twelve months ago, according to the bank's quarterly statement of condition, issued for publication today.

The next Mayor faces a bitter situation in meeting the bills for what the city needs and wants. With annual costs now running at $1,529,000,000, or $188 for every inhabitant, the three Mayoralty candidates already serving on the Board of Estimate fear the budget must rise to some degree. Only the outside challenger contends it can be slowly squeezed down.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- The atmosphere of London is not only more cheerful than that of Paris; it is more confident than at any time since the war. The contrast between France's self-doubt and fear of the future and England's sturdy faith in British destiny is immediately apparent. Both attitudes are exaggerated; France has a vitality her political action belies and Britain still faces an uphill economic struggle.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Cornelius Shields' Aileen was first at every mark today to defeat Susan, Emil Mosbacher's International Class champion, in the fourth race of the fall series being conducted on the Long Island Sound by the Larchmont Yacht Club.

EVERGLADES, Fla., Oct. 4 -- In one of the largest Florida land transfers of modern times Barron G. Collier Jr. and Miles Collier have sold about one-third of their extensive holdings in Collier County to the Gerry famiy of New York for about $4,000,000.

PUEBLO, Col., Oct. 4 -- A new $30,000,000 seamless tube mill will be opened officially here tomorrow by the Colorado Fuel Iron Corporation. The first west of the Misssissippi, the new mill will be an important supplier of seamless tubing and casing to the oil and gas industries of the western United States and Canada, according to Charles Allen Jr., chairman of the board of directors of the corporation.

The investment banking firm of Smith, Barney Co. announced over the week-end that a nationwide syndicate of about 350 investment houses was being formed to bid on Oct. 14 for a new issue of $150,000,000 of revenue bonds of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.

Africa and the East must be built up economically and educationally so the people will be better equipped to live democratically and counter the Soviet challenge to civilization, the Right Rev. Bravid W. Harris, Missionary Bishop of Liberia, said in a sermon yesterday at St. Martin's Protestant Episcopal Church, 230 Lenox Avenue.

An easier tone that developed for the British pound sterling and Canadian dollar as the week-end approached was the feature of the foreign exchange market during the past week. Business was reported as moderately active.

City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs announced yesterday formation of a citizens' committee for his re-election on the Republican and Liberal party tickets. Mrs. Wendell L. Willkie and Mrs. Fiorello H. La Guardia are among the vice chairmen of the committee.

Recent news stories and letters to the editor on inefficiency in the government of our city focus attention on the qualifications of those who have been appointed to various administrative and executive posts in many municipal agencies. One reader suggested that "any Mayor, City Council President or Borough President" could adopt, on his own volition, the custom of having every non-Civil Service appointee pass the scrutiny of panels of professional men.

OSSINING, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Warden Wilfred L. Denno explained here today how it might have been possible for Senator Condon and Mr. Meany to visit Fay in Sing Sing, without Mr. Meany's name showing on the record of visitors.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 4 -- The Commodore Whitmore Trophy, chief prize in a series of races held on four days for cruising yachts at Indian Harbor Y. C., was won today by Paul Campbell's 42-foot cutter Julie.
Seven new films, including importations from England, Italy and the U.S.S.R., are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

A series of imports from Japan that have a truly Far Eastern flavor rather than the pseudo-Oriental look that is so rampant these days has arrived at the Penthouse Gallery, 15 West Fifty-fifth Street.

LOW - PRESSURE television, the kind that does not seek to overwhelm the helpless viewer with synthetic urgency and false bombast, may be coming back into style. At least there is an encouraging step in that direction with a long overdue return of Dave Garroway's show (8 P. M. Fridays over N. B. C.).

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic nominee for Mayor, called yesterday on the State Legislature to adopt a resolution for an amendment to the State Constitution to permit New York City to borrow $500,000,000 for school construction to be financed out of taxes now imposed by the state to retire veterans' bonus bonds.
International affairs and local politics were commingled here yesterday in the largest and most colorful Pulaski Day parade up Fifth Avenue since the celebration was started seventeen years ago.

BOSTON, Oct. 4 (UP) -- former major league baseball park may be named as a memorial to a Boston University football player who died of injuries suffered in Friday night's game against Syracuse University.

On September 23, last, Federal Judge Harold R. Medina threw out of court the long and costly "conspiracy'' suit of the Government against seventeen of the nation's leading investment banking firms. Although it had spent nearly three years trying to do so, Judge Medina found, the Justice Department had not even succeeded in establishing a prima facie case against the defendants.

SEATTLE, Oct. 4 (AP) -- A new contract granting a $4.50 weekly wage increase was accepted today by Seattle Typographical Union 202, A. F. L., lifting another barrier to resumption of publication by The Seattle Times. The newspaper has been closed two and a half months by a strike.

Several times during yesterday's game at Ebbets Field, activities were halted while the umpires, managers and various players wondered what to do about a blinding glare from centerfield that was bothering both Yankee and Dodger batters. Finally a small tarpaulin was placed under the railing in the centerfield section, directly in line with the batter's box, and this seemed to help.

THE legendary heroes of the past have a curious fascination for several modern novelists. Perhaps it is because their own world is so complex and amorphous and men of today are so afflicted with mixed motives, self-doubts and unbeliefs that they turn with relief to stories of a simpler age when heroes were heroic, heroines were beautiful and wars were tests of in dividual courage rather than of scientific ingenuity and mass production.
The Husky Oil Company increased consolidated net sales and operating revenues to $9,057,004 in the fiscal year ended last June 30 from $6,975,335 in the previous year, but earnings declined.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 4 -- A Cabinet crisis existed in the border province of Corrientes today as a result of the poor reception President Juan D. Peron received in the state's capital last Thursday. Four Cabinet ministers and more than a dozen other high officials of the provincial government suddenly announced their resignations last night for undisclosed reasons.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 4 -- The life of Gen. George S. Patton, colorful commander of the Third Army in World War II, will be brought to the screen by Warner Brothers. The studio's plans were kept a secret until the announcement today that Jack L. Warner had "received from the Department of Defense the priority on the filming" of the general's adventuresome career in two world wars.

STALINABAD, U. S. S. R., Sept. 29 -- This bright, modern and progressive-appearing city tucked into a lush irrigated valley under the shoulder of the Tien Shan Mountains can be regarded as a monument to the practical application of Soviet multinational policy.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Oct. 4 -- England's red-hulled Marylette, owned and skippered by Lieut. Col. J. E. Harrison, scored her first victory in the international six-meter sailing competition for the One-Ton Cup today. This was the fourth race in the series.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 4 -- Iran's military prosecutor made public today a twenty-page indictment of 72-year-old former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh for rebellion against the Shah and the Constitution, with a demand that the court-martial impose the death sentence.

The cotton futures market turned softer last week in comparatively light trading. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange at the close of trading on Friday were off 20 to 36 points, or from $1 to $1.80 a bale.
Senator W. Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, reiterated yesterday his criticism of the policy of being "budget-minded" rather than "survival-minded."

The trend toward increasing use of heavy electrical appliances in homes is causing inequities in residential electricity rates that can be removed only by new rate schedules, the Long Island Lighting Company argued yesterday before the Public Service Commission.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Government restrictions on the civilian use of nickel for items ranging from can openers to railroad cars will be lifted on Nov. 1.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday all the near months establishing new lows for the season, and closing prices were unchanged to 25 points net lower than on last Friday.

Claude Monteux, son of Pierre Monteux, the conductor, and in his own right a gifted flutist, gave an excellent account of himself in Carnegie Recital Hall last evening. For his program Mr. Monteux had the assistance of Isidore Cohen, violinist, and Hubert Doris, pianist.

Caution against uncritical confidence and a sense of security in such new motion-picture devices as stereoscopic projection and stereophonic sound was voiced yesterday by speakers at the opening session of the seventy-fourth annual convention of the Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers at the Statler Hotel.

In a whirlwind, breath-taking finish that doubtless will be remembered as long as baseball is played, Casey Stengel's Yankees yesterday became the first club in history to win five world series championships in a row.

The restraining order issued last night after the President had decided to seek a Taft-Hartley injunction, and which will temporarily halt the coast-wide strike of longshoremen, was fully justified by the facts. The causes and circumstances of the dispute were ascertained by a capable and distinguished Board of Inquiry which reported to President Eisenhower yesterday.
The United Press board of coaches named Notre Dame the nation's top college football team for the second week in a row yesterday, but Michigan State gained ground on the Irish.
Vassily Smyslov of Russia led Samuel Reshevsky of the United States by a point after eighteen rounds were completed in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich last night.

Linen Closet Week, sponsored by the Allied Linens and Domestics Association, Inc., officially opened yesterday. Participating are the personnel of 2,500 department stores, 500 specialty shops, 230 manufacturers and 110 member groups of the Linen Trade Association.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- H. H. Corey, chairman of the American Meat Institute, warned today that meat packers have been shaving their profit margin too close. He addressed the institute's annual meeting.

Chase National Bank's deposits, loan and total resources on Sept. 30 were higher than at the close of the previous quarter and at the end of September a year ago, according to the bank's quarterly condition statement issued for publication today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- The American people are "eating their way out of the beef problem," Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture, told the forty-eighth annual meeting of the American Meat Institute tonight.
RIO DE. JANEIRO, Oct. 5 -President Getulio Vargas signed today a bill creating the Brazilian Petroleum Corporation, known as Petrobraz.

Mayor Impellitteri formally opened his independent Experience party campaign headquarters in the Shelton Hotel, Lexington Avenue and Forty-ninth Street, yesterday afternoon by firing a few potshots at his principal rivals and pledging himself to make an all-out" fight for re-election.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- The Soviet Union appears to be contemplating a new kind of popular front in West Germany as a means of threatening to unleash illegal and presumably violent action to block remilitarization of the Federal Republic through either the projected European Defense Community or a national army.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Thousands of South Koreans jammed the downtown streets of this Republic capital today in a demonstration against Indian custody of anti-Communist war prisoners.

Yale and Columbia in the Bowl at New Haven and Pennsylvania and California at Franklin Field, Philadelphia, are two of the most attractive pairings on the week's intercollegiate football program in the East.
One can well understand the frustrations of our military leaders in trying to deal with subversion, but their recent efforts in this direction call for serious scrutiny.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, sent a representative to London today to begin discussions with the British and French on a reply to the Soviet Government's note of last week on big power talks.

Detectives of the West Forty-seventh Street station house were searching last night for a woman, who identified herself earlier in the day to Welfare Department officials as Mrs. Josephine Santiago of 257 West Sixty-ninth Street and her husband for questioning in connection with the apparent abandonment of six children.
A low-cost, compact radar set, designed for tugboats, yachts, fishing and other small craft, was demonstrated yesterday by the Raytheon Manufacturing Company.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- Herman Barron, carding a three-under-par 68 on his own ball, carried three Fenway club members to a sweep of the best-ball honors in the weekly Westchester Professional Golfers' Association pro-amateur tournament today at Ryewood Country Club.

The tumult in the clubhouse of the champions had subsided to a degree that permitted Casey Stengel to express himself in a tone slightly under a shout. For a half-hour or so, following his Yankees' wrap-up of their fifth straight world series yesterday at the Stadium, the dressing room scene was the familiar picture of happy confusion, boisterous backslapping and vigorous handshaking.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 5 -- President Juan D. Peron said today he believed in hemispheric solidarity and praised President Eisenhower as one of the most powerful leaders of the Western World. He prophesied that the day would come when "all Americans, from the North Pole to the South, will be fellow-citizens and there will be greater happiness in the entire continent."

JERUSALEM, Oct. 5 -- The Israeli Government has informed the United States, Britain and France that an agreement for the evacuation of British troops from the Suez Canal military bases would be a threat to the balance of power between the Arab states and Israel.

The eighth National Hardware Show opened with one big sale yesterday in Grand Central Palace and the 71st Regiment Armory. A few hours after the doors were thrown open, B. F. Goodrich Company placed an order for $600,000 worth of power lawn mowers.

Rudolph Halley, Liberal party candidate for Mayor, challenged Governor Dewey last night to tell the public what he intended to do about Lieut. Gov. Arthur H. Wicks and J. Russel Sprague, Republican national committeeman.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- The United States, the major financial backer of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, joined other countries today in warmly supporting the continuance of the seven-year-old agency on a permanent basis.

Diplomacy in our times has changed its nature. Indeed, it is no longer diplomatic. It is blunt, menacing, crude. Still the things it talks about are the things old-fashioned diplomats talked about: disputed territories and spheres of influence; grievances and modes of redressing them; finally -- and even though in these modern days the threat of attack is never made -- war.

VIENNA, Oct; 5 (UP) -- Three secretaries employed in the United States Embassy in Vienna were seized by Russian soldiers near the Austro-Hungarian border on Saturday and detained for an hour and a half.
PARIS, Oct. 5 -- The National Assembly will reconvene tomorrow after its summer recess. The Government, it is predicted, will have to clear some lofty hurdles in the next few weeks.

Five Latin Americans will study in the United States this year under the auspices of a scholarship program established in honor of former Secretary of State Cordell Hull. The announcement was made yesterday by Frank Houston, head of the Cordell Hull Foundation and Kenneth Holland, president of the Institute of International Education.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 5 -- Protestant churchwomen were urged here tonight to "make it their business" to defend Christian principles of democracy and brotherhood wherever and whenever they were placed in "jeopardy."

Paul Muni, last seen on Broadway as Tony, the tempestuous Italian winegrower, in the 1949 revival of Sidney Howard's romantic drama, "They Knew What They Wanted," will return to the local stage this season as an English bank clerk.

A collection of Frank Lloyd Wright's statements on architecture within the last twenty-five years will be published Oct. 19 by Horizon Press entitled "The Future of Architecture." The volume contains "Conversation," an explanation of Mr. Wright's aims and contributions in architecture, and his lectures given at Princeton in 1930, Chicago Art Institute, 1931, and in London in 1939. The book is illustrated with photographs of the architect's "epoch-making" buildings.

It is not supposed to happen. Recitals this early in the season are supposed to be the effort of hopeful, well-intentioned and at best promising performers. But Norman Carol, who played the violin last night at Town Hall, seems not to have heard of these concert-hall proprieties.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Oct. 5 -- It was the United States' turn to collar top honors in the international six-meter sailing competition today. Checking a challenge by the Swiss sloop, Andre Firmenich's Ylliam VIII, Magnus Konow's Lllanoria recorded her first victory by taking the fifth race in the series.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Motor carriers operating in New York State told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that they planned, by Jan. 1, to substitute a surcharge of 50 cents a shipment for the present surcharges levied to meet the cost of the state's weight - distance tax on motor vehicles.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct 5 -As the country commemorated its eighth Armed Forces Day today, President Sukarno warned that foreign and domestic elements continued to plot the overthrow of the Indonesian Republic. He called upon the army to maintain constant vigilance and alertness against dissident groups.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 5 (UP) -Editors and newspaper men from twenty-five American countries and territories gathered here tonight to discuss freedom of the press and other problems in the ninth general assembly of the Inter-American Press Association.

United Nations, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, has sent to the Chinese Communists a message confirming receipt of their proposal that the Korean peace conference be a round-table affair. Some delegations here hope that this will be a step toward clearing the air and will result in the Chinese Communist making known their position on the unsettled issues regarding the conference.

ROME, Oct. 5 -- Italian official circles saw no possible basis of an Italian-Yugoslav understanding on Trieste in the speech delivered yesterday by Dr. Edward Kardelj, Yugoslav Vice President. The speech was regarded here more as an effort to confuse the Trieste issue than as an honest effort to negotiate.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- United States business had investments abroad of about 15 billion dollars in June this year, the Department of Commerce has reported.

A construction company controlled by Lawrence E. Gerosa, Democratic candidate for Controller, is suing New York City for $490,000 in connection with excavation work, Vito Marcantonio, state chairman of the American Labor party, noted yesterday at an interview in his office at 11 Park Place.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, was reported to have talked over with President Eisenhower today the feasibility of a bipartisan approach to amending the Taft-Hartley Law.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- The danger of overeating, especially for older persons, was emphasized here today at the tenth annual Newspaper Food Editors' Conference, at a session conducted by the Kretschmer Corporation, manufacturer of wheat germ.
Five hundred copies of today's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES will be flown this morning from New York to Chicago on the first air delivery of regular mail between the two cities.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 5 (Reuters)-- A top Mau Mau leader and fourteen other wanted anti-white terrorists were seized today as British troops and city police carried out two surprise raids in Nairobi's native quarter.

OTTAWA, Oct. 5 (AP) -- A 5 per cent reduction in western Canada's basic freight rates to be counter-balanced by a 10 per cent increase for Ontario and Quebec will be ordered shortly by the Board of Transport Commissioners. Effective dates are Nov. 15. Chief Commissioner J. D. Kearney said today, in announcing that the board will order the changes soon, that they are designed as a partial measure of rate equalization.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- The United Nations General Assembly today elected Turkey, the United States candidate, to the Eastern European seat on the Security Council, now held by Greece. Eight ballots were required before Turkey obtained forty votes, the exact two-thirds majority required, over Poland, the candidate of the Soviet bloc.

BOSTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The president of Group Securities, Inc., called tonight for a "new look" at Federal laws and "administrative attitudes" governing mutual funds.

Before the recent war who but the physician talked of plasma? Now the word has passed into the vernacular. Almost the same has happened to "fibrinogen," "fibrin," "thrombin," "serum albumin." "Gamma globulin" is now a familiar term, largely because the blood fraction for which it stands did its part in checking last summer's polio epidemic.

NEWARK, Oct. 5 -- The New Jersey State Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations came out today in opposition to the appointment of Dr. John P. Milligan, Superintendent of Schools in Atlantic City, as director of the State Division Against Discrimination.

The Rev. Dr. Paul A. Wolfe, Moderator of the New York Presbytery of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A., coupled yesterday an endorsement of the proposed merger of that church with two smaller Presbyterian groups in this country with a plea in the latter's behalf that their strength be "protected and preserved."

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- The first known successful transplanting of animal material to human patients, in operations to correct malformation of the major artery leading from the heart, was reported here today at the opening of the clinical congress of the thirty- ninth annual meeting of the American College of Surgeons.
MONTREAL, Oct. 5 (UP) -- The Montreal Royals took a 3-0 lead in the little world series tonight by downing the Kansas City Blues, 5 -- 3, behind the eight-hit pitching of left-hander Tommy LaSorda.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that producer prices of 1953 crop tobacco yet to be marketed will be supported at the minimum rates announced before the planting season.

Earl Sande made his comeback as a jockey at Belmont Park yesterday, and the riding star of Sport's Golden Era showed that he is still a better than fair hand with a thoroughbred. Indeed, for a man who rode his first winner while Woodrow Wilson was President, and whose last ride in competition occurred during Herbert Hoover's term, Sande's return to the saddle was an unqualified success, though he failed to win his race.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, had a word for the Yankees' fifth straight world series victory tonight: Monopoly.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 5 -- Refugees from behind the Iron Curtain are "a potent force" working for the establishment of a united Europe, an official of the West German Federal Republic told the National Conference of Catholic Charities today.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- A Westchester County water agency was created by unanimous vote of the Board of Supervisors today to draft plans for future watersheds and water distribution systems. Long under discussion, the board will be the first central agency of its kind in this county of 448 square miles.

With a pair of silver scissors presented to him by Gordon K. Greenfield, president of Franklin Simon, Ramon de la Presilla, Consul General of Spain, cut a ribbon at the entrance of the store's Plazita Espana yesterday and formally opened this specialty section housing Spanish goods.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 5 -- Activity has been increased in the Indo-China war in the last twenty-four hours. It is not yet, however, an offensive involving regular Vietminh divisions and the French expeditionary corps.

TRENTON, Oct. 5 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court was asked today to decide whether the distribution of pocket-size copies of the King James version of the New Testament and parts of the Old Testament in the public schools of this state was constitutional and whether a local board of education might legally give material assistance to the distributor.

Women, including Mrs. Walter S. Gubelmann and Mrs. Thomas W. Dewart, are active in furthering the success of the series of entertainments known as the Five Enchanted Evenings, arranged for the benefit of Hospitalized Veterans Music Service.

An exhibition of glass "paintings" by Ruth Kilby is on view now through Oct. 17 at the Ward Eggleston Galleries, 161 West Fifty-seventh Street. Bits of colored glass fused onto a glass sheet make translucent and unusual pictures.

What President Quirino had to say about American noninterference in the Philippine election is considerably less important than the occasion on which he said it. He was speaking at the inauguration of the big hydroelectric power project at Maria Cristina Falls in northern Mindanao. It is certainly true that no American should "meddle" in the intricacies of Philippine domestic politics.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Robert R. Mullen, executive director of the National Citizens' Committee for Educational Television, in a report today on its first year's progress, declared that educational TV had advanced from a "grim picture" to an "encouraging situation."

IT was bleak and dismal at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. But it was far more bleak and infinitely more dismal in Brooklyn. The greatest of all Dodger teams -- or so it was labeled -- couldn't do a doggone bit better than slews of lesser teams. The Yankees, as is their habit, won the world series.

TASHKENT, U. S. S. R., Sept. 30 -- Soviet Central Asia has made very substantial strides forward industrially and agriculturally in the last nine years, but with the exception of Kazakhstan perhaps has not developed at quite so stormy a pace as the enthusiasts of 1944 envisaged.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday in a letter to the United Parents Associations that the school system would make a "thorough study" of the recent failure of 200 teachers to report to duty and the rush of would-be teachers to fill the vacancies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Val Peterson, the Civil Defense Administrator, warned tonight that the nation might be forced to move its key factories underground or "see all of our production facilities blown up some afternoon by a surprise Russian attack.

Sixteen new singers will join the roster of the Metropolitan Opera Company this season, while twenty of those heard last season will not return, it was announced yesterday by Rudolf Bing, general manager.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UP) -- The Government has announced that more than 101,000,000 pounds of primary aluminum will be made available to independent fabricators during the fourth quarter of 1953.

ST, PAUL, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, today accused the Eisenhower Administration of "packing" the National Labor Relations Board with members antagonistic toward unions.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 5 -- Scalping parties of Democrats successfully took to the warpath today in Fairfield County, long considered a safe Republican preserve.

WHEN Nadine Gordimer's collection of short stories, "The Soft Voice of the Serpent," was published last year several critics greeted it with an extravagant enthusiasm that was almost unfair to so young a writer. No author could be expected to live up to such notices. Today Miss Gordimer's first novel, "The Lying Days," is published. And, inevitably, it is a disappointment.

Unusual color accents for bedrooms and baths are presented in a series of model rooms now on view on the first floor at McCutcheon's. The three bedrooms and single bathroom arranged by Mary L. Brandt contain, in each case, all the linens necessary for both rooms, and two alternate color schemes are presented in swatch form.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- President Eisenhower told a White House visitor today, his best golf score since he returned from Europe sixteen months ago was a 78 for eighteen holes.

Vito Marcantonio, former Representative in Congress and now state chairman of the American Labor party, and The Daily Worker, spokesman for the Communist party in New York, appeared yesterday to have reached the parting of the ways.

Called "New York Couture," the creations of five famous American designers -- Adele Simpson, Mollie Parnis, Harvey Berin, Larry Aldrich and Herbert Sondheim -- were presented by Bonwit Teller yesterday morning in its sixth-floor salon.
Two New York-born priests became Roman Catholic bishops yesterday in the first plural consecration in the history of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, it turns out, was one of the three original incorporators of what became the White House Spanish class before her predecessor as First Lady, Mrs. Harry S. Truman, eyen joined up.

ALBANY, Oct. 5 -- Senator Arthur H. Wicks, Acting Lieutenant Governor, today vigorously rejected demands that he resign because of his visits to Joseph S. (Joey) Fay, a convicted labor extortionist, at Sing Sing.

Plans for the rehabilitation of New York Harbor and the adjacent waters after an enemy attack were discussed yesterday at a two- hour meeting at the New York City Office of Civil Defense, 425 Avenue of the Americas.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- Arrangements for financing $15,000,000 capital improvements from Westchester tax returns by 1958 were outlined this afternoon by James D. Hopkins of North Castle, chairman of the County Board of Supervisors and Republican candidate for county executive.

Two more Washington officials added confusion instead of light to the current discussions about continental defense this week and the menace of Soviet atomic and hydrogen weapons to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Senator William F. Knowland of California, Republican leader of the Senate, ruled out today negotiation of a non-aggression pact with the Soviet Union unless the Kremlin first agreed to the holding of free elections in Soviet satellite countries.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Earl Warren, a smiling, broad-shouldered Californian, was sworn in today as the fourteenth Chief Justice of the United States. He succeeded Fred M. Vinson, who died on Sept. 8.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont and chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, accused Democrats today of conducting an organized campaign to spread rumors in big farm states that the Eisenhower Administration was out to "ruin" farmers.

LONDON, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden conferred today with Richard G. Casey, the Australian Minister of Internal Affairs, in discussions observers believed were called to ease British-American tension over the Pacific defense pact among the United States, Australia and New Zealand.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that grower prices of this year's corn crop will be supported at a national average of $1.60 a bushel, the same as last year.
LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Despite profit-taking sales that caused some of the leading industrials to close below their best prices today, the undertone of the securities markets here remained firm.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The National Farmers Union today urged the Federal Power Commission to reject the Idaho Power Company's proposal to build three dams in the Snake River "as a wasteful and incomplete utilization of the people's resources."

The textile industry is entering a highly competitive era and conditions may force some producers out of business, Leon Lowenstein, chairman of the board of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., asserted yesterday. He held, however, that there is not likely to be a "deep recession" for the textile or any other industries in the immediate future.

CAIRO, Oct. 5 -- The British-Egyptian dispute over the status of the Suez Canal military bases, which responsible Egyptian quarters asserted a week ago was on the verge of settlement, now is apparently on the verge of a new deadlock.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Communist workers demonstrated today around the Parliament building in Georgetown, capital of the colony of British Guiana, as a British cruiser rushed troops to reinforce colonial police and militia.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 6 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark urged the Neutral Nations Commission today to seek the views of anti-Communist prisoners concerning repatriation to dispel the commission's apparent "assumption" that the Chinese and North Korean captives actually desired to return to communism.

A conveyor belt for pedestrians will be installed next spring in the Erie station in Jersey City, to carry 21,000 passengers daily through the passageway connecting the Erie Railroad and the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad tubes, it was announced yesterday.
During this year and next the Atlantic City Electric Company expects to spend nearly as much on new construction as it did in the four decades from 1907 to 1947.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 5 -- Yugoslav reports called attention today to continued frontier tension between this country and the bordering Soviet satellite states. The latest report said Yugoslav border guards were forced to fire yesterday "in self defense" on Rumanian civilians who were said to have opened fire first and on six Hungarian officers alleged to have done the same.

During 1953 some 400,000 residents of this country, it is estimated, will have traveled to Europe and spent $320,000,000 exclusive of fares. This sum would have been greater if our Government didn't levy a duty on all purchases in excess of $500 per tourist. (The duty-free limit is $200 on tourists who have been out of the country less than twelve days.)

Earl Browder, former head of the Communist party of the United States, declared yesterday he believed the Soviet Union was just as eager to prevent the admission of Communist China to the United Nations as was the United States.

Volume on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday showed improvement over last week's levels but remained light. Uncertainty concerning the dock strike and continued interest in baseball limited trading. Prices closed irregular with sugar, soybean oil, copper, zinc and wool mixed; rubber, coffee, cottonseed oil and cocoa lower, and hides, potatoes, burlap, lead and tin higher.

Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois took second place in public favor again yesterday just before 4 P. M. when he entered an American Airlines waiting room at La Guardia Airport and found a baseball player named Carl Furillo the hero of the moment.

WASHINGTON, Oct 5 (AP) -- A Congressional study group today reported deeper economy cuts in the Federal payroll, but hinted at surprises in store when the number of foreigners hired by the United States overseas was disclosed.

Phil Rizzuto had a visitor at the Stadium yesterday. Before the game, a man approached the Scooter and introduced himself as Dr. Marcellus Johnson of Roanoke, Va. At first Li'l Phil did not recollect having met the gentleman before, but when the stranger mentioned "Basset, 1937" he no longer was a stranger.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Maureen Connolly coasted through the second day of the Pan American tennis tournament today.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5 -- Lieut. Gov. Goodwin J. Knight was sworn in today as California's executive head, succeeding Gov. Earl Warren, new Chief Justice of the United States.

The Nassau County Board of Supervisors yesterday failed to reappoint Irving T. Bergman as special counsel for the county in labor matters following the disclosure that he owned 8,000 shares of stock in the Nassau Trotting Association.
