When the late E. M. Statler opened his first permanent hotel, in Buffalo in 1907, he provided one facility not then available in "any other hotel in the world at that time." The quotation is from Rufus Jarman's biography of Mr. Statler, "A Bed for the Night." Mr. Statler attached a bath to every room -- not just some rooms, not just one room on a floor, but to every room in his hotel.

Believers in free enterprise economy "must really enterprise," Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey reminded bankers attending the 100th anniversary dinner of the New York Clearing House Association last night.
BILOXI, Miss., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Doug Creech of Charlotte, N. C., established a competitive world record for Class C hydroplanes today as he won the John Ward Memorial Trophy.

Stocks ignored almost everything but the world series finale yesterday and settled lower in lackadaisical trading. Some chemicals, aircrafts, rubbers and rails were soft but steels and motors held up well to the mild selling pressure.

The status of the Holy City of Jerusalem is of grave concern to the entire civilized world. Therefore, Michael Francis Doyle raises important points in his letter of Sept. 24, printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Oct. 2, in which he attacks the Government of Israel for attempting to develop Jerusalem as the seat of its government.

UNITED NATIONS, AT. Y., Oct. 5 -- Former Secretary of State James F. Byrnes asserted today that Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania had disregarded and violated important provisions of treaties they had signed at the close of World War II and hence did not qualify for membership in the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -Following is the text of President Eisenhower's letter directing Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. to seek a court injunction to help eng the East Coast dock strike:

An 18-year-old Russian youth who said he had deserted from the Soviet Army in East Germany and stowed away on a ship to reach this country surrendered voluntarily to immigration authorities here yesterday and asked for asylum.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 5 -- One hundred and twenty-nine of the state's 169 communities held elections today and, in most instances, the Republicans retained control.

Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks and Foreign Operation Director Harold E. Stassen will be among speakers at the fortieth National Foreign Trade Convention scheduled Nov. 16 to 18 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. In announcing the program yesterday the National Foreign Trade Council, sponsoring organization, said the meeting would cover major problems of United States foreign economic policy.

Ireland is prepared to invite greater foreign capital investment directed at new economic expansion, Sean F. Lemass, Deputy Prime Minister of Ireland and Minister for Industry and Commerce, said yesterday.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 5 (AP) -- The secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of Labor accused the press today of a "great cover-up" for what he called the "Republican mess in Washington."

France and Italy as well as this country contributed designs for the luxurious fur collection shown yesterday by Gunther Jaeckel at the Plaza Hotel. The French and Italian models, which will be copied, included designs from Heim, Griffe. Manguin, Balenciaga, Dior and Viscardi.

The New York City Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., agreed yesterday at the behest of Justice Walter R. Hart in Supreme Court, Brooklyn, to try to settle their differences over new transit operating schedules out of court within a week.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Grain futures worked irregularly lower today, although sales of wheat were not specially heavy. The general demand was indifferent however, and the markets at no time showed disposition to rally. Corn is in process of adjustment to the new crop basis, with ideal weather conditions working in favor of sellers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UP) -- Medical authorities told Congress today that 70 per cent of the nation's 10,000,000 arthritis sufferers could be restored to useful, self- supporting lives with proper medical care.

Even without the aid of an almanac, even without the browning leaf, the flight of birds, it would be uncomfortably evident that autumn is here. The other day there was a slight tingling in the nose, and a mild degree of stuffiness in the head.

DEERFIELD, Mass., Oct. 5 -- Bob Marr, the one-time Williams backfield star who came to Deerfield Academy last season to lighten some of Headmaster Frank Boyden's coaching chores, is a busy man these days. The Big Green opens against Vermont Academy next Saturday and Marr is still uncertain about his starters.
WASHINGTON, Oct 5 (AP) -- The text of a report to President Eisenhower by a Special Board of Inquiry appointed to look into the East Coast longshoremen's strike follows:
The market for United States Government and other top grade securities had another day of strength yesterday, with several of the Treasury issues scoring new high prices for the year.
YONKERS, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Sandy Fingo won the $4,500 Somers Pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway in 2:06 for the mile.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 5 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, held the first of a series of talks with the Allied High Commissioners in Bonn today on ways and means of inducing the Soviet Union to negotiate on the future of Germany and related questions.

Registration in the city was extremely light yesterday, the first day to enroll for the election on Nov. 3. Only 259,630 men and women qualified, 10 per cent fewer than in the last comparable year of 1949 when the previous citywide election took place. First day registration in 1949 was 288,166.

The development of a new large-size color television picture tube, said to be adaptable to mass-production methods, was announced yesterday by C. B. S.-Hytron, the electronic tube-manufacturing division of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.

Stockholders of the Atlantic Gulf and West Indies Steamship Lines will meet Oct. 14 to consider the dissolution of the company, which, since 1908, has directed a large part of the passenger and cargo trade from this country to the Caribbean area.
Olive drab and navy blue were dominant colors upon the American scene in World War II when service men on leave crowded our railroad stations, theatres and street corners.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Ray M. Gidney, Controller of the Currency, reported today that national banks in the first six months of this year had record net profits of $293,588,000 before dividends but after taxes.

Your editorial of Sept. 22 entitled "Communism and the Churches" has just come to my attention. Evidently you were referring in part to my testimony before the House Committee on Un-American Activities, given on July 7, and only recently made public. You remarked "* * * that a charge of so great a nature might have better been turned over to church authorities for internal action. * * *"

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Treasury announced tonight that tenders for $1,500,000,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury bills to be dated Oct. 8 and to mature on Jan. 7 were opened at the Federal Reserve banks today. Of the $2,541,451,000 applied for $1,500,620,000 was accepted, including $226,710,000 entered on a noncompetitive basis and accepted in full at the average price of 99.647, representing a discount rate of about 1.397 per cent per annum.

Columbia's 20-19 setback in a thriller at Princeton last Saturday was attributed to offside penalties by Lou Little, the Lions' coach, yesterday. He spoke at the weekly football writers' luncheon at Toots Shor's Restaurant.

Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres today. At the Normandie, the attraction is "Little Fugitive," an independently made comedy-drama, starring Richie Andrusco, a child actor. The offering, photographed on Coney Island by Morris Engel and written and directed by Mr. Engel, Ruth Orkin and Ray Ashley, is being distributed by Joseph Burstyn, Inc.

A group of hand-tailored coats made in Holland was presented yesterday at Oppenheim Collins. In subtle colors frequently woven with black were coats made expressly for American women. Fabrics from Holland, the British Isles and Italy were shown in silhouettes that varied from semi-fitted styles to flared or tapered shapes.

October, usually a good steel production month, is running true to form this year, with mills thus far operating around 95 per cent of capacity. The industry operated at 95.3 per cent and turned out 2,149,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings last week and is scheduled to run at 94.6 per cent and make 2,132,000 tons of metal this week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 834 pints of blood on Friday. Of this total 385 pints were collected on the second of a two-day donation at the International Business Machines Corporation plant in Poughkeepsie. N. Y., which gave 406 pints on Thursday.

Your editorial of Sept. 22 entitled "Communism and the Churches" has just come to my attention. Evidently you were referring in part to my testimony before the House Committee on Un-American Activities, given on July 7, and only recently made public. You remarked "* * * that a charge of so great a nature might have better been turned over to church authorities for internal action. * * *"

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Treasury announced tonight that tenders for $1,500,000,000 of ninety-one-day Treasury bills to be dated Oct. 8 and to mature on Jan. 7 were opened at the Federal Reserve banks today. Of the $2,541,451,000 applied for $1,500,620,000 was accepted, including $226,710,000 entered on a noncompetitive basis and accepted in full at the average price of 99.647, representing a discount rate of about 1.397 per cent per annum.

A group of hand-tailored coats made in Holland was presented yesterday at Oppenheim Collins. In subtle colors frequently woven with black were coats made expressly for American women. Fabrics from Holland, the British Isles and Italy were shown in silhouettes that varied from semi-fitted styles to flared or tapered shapes.

Net sales and net profit of Eagle-Picher Company and consolidated subsidiaries for the nine months ended on Aug. 31 were 18 per cent and 5 per cent, respectively, above the levels achieved in the preceding nine-month period, according to the report released yesterday.

THE opening of small portions of waterfowl refuges to controlled shooting, similar to that permitted on Lake Mattamuskeet in North Carolina and at Horicon, Wis., undoubtedly would make it much easier to obtain additional refuges throughout the country.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Oct. 5 -- The Cold Spring team of Jack Sirlin and Jack Mallon won the Long Island Professional Golfers Association weekly amateur-pro tournament today. They carded a best-ball seven-under-par 33, 30 -- 63 at the Huntington Country Club.

GENEVA, Oct. 5 -- In the view of the United States Government, at least part of the recent improvement in the capacity of the rest of the world to earn dollars at a tolerable rate reflects fundamental adjustments in the pattern of world trade that give promise of being permanent.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 5 -Roy M. Brewer, who resigned recently as international representative in Hollywood for the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, has accepted an offer to join Allied Artists as an executive assistant to Steve Broidy, president of the producing company.

The Job of the government can be successful today only if everyone assumes his share of responsibility, "and at the top of the list of responsibilities is the continuous support of private, nonprofit institutions and organizations," C. D. Jackson, special assistant to President Eisenhower, declared last night.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, was told yesterday by representatives of the five Republican county organizations that "quiet samplings" of voter sentiments had shown him to be running "neck and neck" with Robert F. Wagner Jr., the Democratic nominee, and ahead of Rudolph Halley, the Liberal party choice.

Government is the business of all the people, and no level of government is closer to the people than local government. On Nov. 3 a municipal election will be held to install a new team to administer your city government: a Mayor, a President of the City Council, a Controller to watch over finances, a Board of Estimate, a City Council.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 5 -- The Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association closed its regular season with the annual Harriet Bassler Memorial Trophy tournament at the Westchester Country Club today. Mrs. Hugo Boeddinghaus of Greenwich C. C. won by three strokes, with 82 -- 15 -- 67.

DES MOINES, Oct. 5 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today she believed that a non-aggression pact with the Soviet Union was possible if the United States had the patience and perseverance "to live in uncertainty" until such an agreement was completed.

Bowing to an injunction issued under the national emergency provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act, the International Longshoremen's Association last night ordered 50,000 striking longshoremen to return to their jobs tonight or tomorrow morning in ports from Newport News, Va., to Portland, Me.

BABYLON, L. I., Oct. 5 -- The last steel girder for the two-mile Captree Causeway Bridge spanning Great South Bay to Captree Island at the eastern end of Jones Beach arrived today and is to be fitted into place at noon tomorrow.
Twenty-three world series marks were broken and seventeen were tied during the six-game 1953 classic between the Yankees and Dodgers that ended yesterday, The Associated Press reported.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Office of International Trade announced today that it had denied to Charles Y. Rofe of Flushing, N. Y., all validated export license privileges for at least one year.

Jimmy Herring, Ozone Park, L.I. middleweight, upset Marvin Edelman of Philadelphia in the ten-round feature bout at Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. Herring, 161 3/4, scored consistently with sharp left jabs and hooks to win the decision unanimously. Edelman weighed 161 1/4.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 5 (AP) -Brazilian coffee exports in the first eight months of 1953 ran considerably under 1952 exports for the same period, according to the Brazilian Coffee Institute.

Three or four minutes after Billy Martin's bat had killed for the seventh time the Dodgers' hopes of winning a world series, the mourners' procession came marching, heavy-footed, into the Brooklyn dressing room yesterday at Yankee Stadium.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- The United Nations turned a simply furnished, book-lined room looking out toward the East River today into a memorial for Abraham H. Feller, the first legal counsel of the organization and for six years one of its policymakers.

Earl Sande, the riding star of the Nineteen Twenties who is attempting a comeback at Belmont Park, had a fourth-place finish to show for his lone effort yesterday in the seventh race. On Monday he had signalized his return to action by taking the show spot with Honest Bread in the third race.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 5 -- United States Embassy officials and Pakistani Government leaders joined today in a vigorous condemnation of allegations published in the United States Oct. 1 that the 1,000,000-ton wheat grant to Pakistan was being mishandled.
MIAMI, Oct. 6 -- Two thousand of the nation's "baby doctors" were warned today against putting complete confidence in any of the current standard tests of mental growth used with young children.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange, after an easier opening, turned stronger yesterday and closed steady, up 6 to 12 points net on the active months than on Monday.

The Bankers Trust Company ofi New York reported as of Spt. 30,I 1953, total deposits of $1,875,502,-1 811 and total assets of $2,099,821,-I 597, compared, respectively, with] $1,775,610,681 and $1,999,329,808/ on June 30. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $667,871,138 against $560,911,275; holdings of United States Government securities to $343,555,517 against $373,850.379. and .IQans and discounts o $977,003,580 against $959,079,948.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 6 -- President Eisenhower asserted today that the United States and its allies were forced to continue stockpiling atom and hydrogen bombs to defend themselves against Communist Russia's plans for world domination.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Wheat futures eased after a fair midday rally, outside buying being of small volume while there was further scattered long liquidation, but firmed again in the late trade. The unfavorable weather appeared to have lost its influence, and not much attention was being paid to the strong cash prices.

Their record - shattering fifth straight world championship safely tucked away the Yankees were back at the Stadium again yesterday packing their gear and, in most instances, completing plans for another busy fall and winter season.

HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 6 -- The Conservative, Liberal and Agrarian parties have retained majority support in Finland according to almost complete results of Sunday's and Monday's municipal elections.
Appointment of two deputy commissioners for city departments was announced yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri.

LONDON, Oct. 6--British dependence on the United States for supplies of high-octane aviation fuel since the refining facilities at Abadan, Iran, were lost will be reduced next year when three large "platformers," or super-fuel "re-formers," will be in operation here for the Anglo-Iranian and the Shell Oil Companies.

HICKSVILLE, L. I., Oct. 6 -- An aroused group of home-rule advocates here vowed today they would appeal the decision of Supervisor Charles E. Ransom of Oyster Bay Township denying Hicksville voters an opportunity to ballot for incorporation.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- The first successful use of the skin from a donor after death to save the life of a severely burned child was reported today at the thirty-ninth annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 6 -- President Eisenhower sent his greetings today to the annual meeting of the Inter-American Press Association and expressed the hope in his brief message that the conference would "further the cause of a free exchange of information among all peoples."

The aged father-in-law of a Brooklyn landlord who had admitted fleecing his tenants offered yesterday in Kings County Court to make amends for his son-in-law's wrongdoing by giving $10,000 a year to any charity named by the judge.
Thirteen aircraft experts representing almost half of Great Britain's foremost jet and rocket engine designers visited New York yesterday after completing a trans-Atlantic journey -- by ship.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 -- Two bank merger plans extending across the Philadelphia County line were announced today.
MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Ontario and Western Railway Company announced today it has made a deal to save its thirty-one diesel locomotives from Government seizure.

A battery of new English knitting machines is being set up in this country by Allen Knitting Mills, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Harry F. Goldman, president, Producing cotton knitted fabrics of finer yarns, the machines will increase the output of interlock jersey that can be made shrink-resistant under the "Redmanized" process.

MIAMI, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Orange Bowl committee today decided to consider matching the champions of the new Atlantic Coast and Big Seven collegiate conferences in the Orange Bowl game next New Year's Day.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- A crisp, cookie-like pastry done with eggs and sugar as well as the usual flour and shortening was introduced today by Lever Brothers at the Newspaper Food Editors Conference convening here this week. An adaptation of the pate used in France for napoleons and other typically French pastries, this version was devised in the firm's test kitchens.

The bipartisan approach to revision of the Taft-Hartley Act which Senator Irving M. Ives of New York is reported to have talked over with President Eisenhower has much to commend it. The idea envisages a joint Senate committee equally divided between Republicans and Democrats.

In a talk with a group of labor leaders yesterday, Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, declared that "responsible labor organizations are the most important single factor in our economy."
Directors of the Dow Chemical Company approved a 2 1/2 per cent stock dividend yesterday, payable on Nov. 20, to holders of record of Oct. 20. A similar stock dividend was distributed last December.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6-- Representative Daniel A. Reed has been quietly lining up support among key members of the House of Representatives for a $5,000,000,000 tax reduction program, according to trustworthy sources.
CONCORD, N. H., Oct. 6 -- "Break Up the Delphians."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- That deep-throated resonant honking that floated over the Rocky Mountains this summer may well have come from trumpeter swans as they heralded another increase in their population.
The Girl Scout Council of Greater New York began yesterday its annual fund drive for $650,000, of which $145,000 will be raised through cookies sales by the 48,000 Girl Scouts in this city.

Heavy rain and general political apathy combined to eut registration sharply yesterday. The result was one of the smallest second-day turnouts in years, with only 138,371 persons qualifying, 32 per cent fewer than on the second day in 1949, the last comparable period when a city-wide election was held.

SCHENECTADY, Oct. 6 -- (AP) Demand by labor unions for a guaranteed annual wage is "possible only under a dictatorship," said Ralph J. Cordiner, president of the General Electric Company, speaking at a Chamber of Commerce dinner here tonight to celebrate the 75th anniversary of the electrical industry.

MOSCOW, Oct. 6 -- United States newspapermen in Moscow henceforth will be subject to Soviet income tax laws and will pay at the rate of 10 to 13 per cent on all earnings above basic monthly exemption of 600 rubles (about $150).

Many parties were given at the dinner dance and fashion show held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the National Federation of Textiles. The fete marked the eightieth anniversary of the federation.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the performance of the Sadler's Wells Ballet tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the SpenceChapin Adoption Service. Mrs. Robert W. Dowling, president of the beneficiary, heads the committee in charge of plans for the event.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 7 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark relinquished his Far East Command and left for the United States today "with the hope and prayer that the armistice which we have signed will bring peace to this part of the world."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower entertained Chief Justice and Mrs. Earl Warren for tea today. The choir of St. Paul's Cathedral, London, sang "I Was Glad," the anthem they performed at the coronation of Elizabeth II, and other selections.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The United States champion, Tony Trabert of Cincinnati, and all the other seeded players, except Sweden's Sven Davidson, reached the quarter-final round of the Pan American tennis tournament today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Life insurance men from all parts of the country turned their attention at the opening of the American Life Convention's annual meeting today to the problem of the agent -- how to keep him in the business and encourage him to sell more insurance.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 6 -Week-end maneuvers to test the Swedish Army's ability to cope with enemy paratroop landings far inland have given fairly satisfactory results, Maj. Gen. B. Colliander said today in reviewing this aspect of the Swedish war games, which have embraced the whole country during the last week.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Harold E. Stassen, director of the Foreign Operations Administration, said here tonight that the United States Government intended to expand its bilateral technical assistance programs with economically underdeveloped countries by using "to an increased degree" the resources of colleges and universities in this country.
Back in the days of the horse-car, a young woman made a visit to patients in a hospital. That night she could not sleep and the next morning she vowed she would never go back.

Some idea of the impression that American culture will make in foreign countires can be gleaned from an exhibition that opens today at the Museum of Modern Art called "Architecture for the State Department.'' It consists of models and enlarged photographs of nine of the buildings that have been built for sites from Tokyo to Rio de Janeiro under the State Department's Foreign Buildings Operations Program.

The State Harness Racing Commission told Governor Dewey yesterday that it was no longer able to cope with the labor, criminal and financial problems engendered by the growth of trotting track gambling in the state.

The lives of five deer and two giraffes were saved today thanks to President Eisenhower's action halting the strike that affected the ship bringing the animals to port. They would have been shot had the strike not been stopped.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- In a discussion of the atomic threat to the free nations, Lord Tedder, marshal of the Royal Air Force, said today that the policy of "passive air defense" reported to be under consideration by the United States, would be "a fatal mistake."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Sector Milton R. Young, Republican of North Dakota and a farm bloc leader in Congress, proposed today a three-point program that he said could halt a farm depression "overnight". He ran headlong into Department of Agriculture decisions on some Federal price supports.

The Appellate Division ruled yesterday that Mayor Impellitteri must make public a report he has kept secret since May of last year on an investigation of charges maladministration of the city's penal institutions.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Greyhound Corporation announced today the purchase of railroad-held stock interests in its Pacific and Pennsylvania subsidiaries and the purchase of the Tennessee Coach Company's entire operation.

The three-story building containing a store and five apartments at 45-07 Laurel Hill Boulevard in Woodside, Queens, has been sold by Matthew J. Lyons to Antonio Barone. Ernest T. Bower, Inc., was the broker.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 6 -- Carl G. Cooper, fifth vice president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, now holds the two top Hollywood labor positions left vacant by the resignation of Roy M. Brewer as the union's international representative here.

Carl (Bobo) Olson, American middleweight titleholder, yesterday arrived at La Guardia Airport aboard a United Airliner from San Francisco to finish training for the world championship bout with Randy Turpin of England, the European ruler, at Madison Square Garden, Oct. 21.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon and his wife, Patricia, arrived today to embark on a seventy-day goodwill tour of sixteen countries in the Orient.
The National Maritime Union, C. I. O., has issued a sharp reminder to its steward department members that the customer is always right.
LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Activity slackened in the stock markets here today and prices were less steady than of late. Nevertheless, the undertone was still described as firm in nearly all markets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- A conscientious American trying to meet his responsibilities to his family and his country would have a hard time this week figuring out what his Government was saying to him about the dangers of a Soviet hydrogen bomb.
OTTAWA, Oct. 6 -- The Supreme Court of Canada in a 5-to-4 decision today knocked out a number of city ordinances that many lawyers felt were a threat to freedom of the press.

A service at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow will constitute the formal Jewish dedication of the Pauline A. Hartford Memorial Chapel at Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. The Protestant and Roman Catholic dedicatory rites at the interfaith house of worship already have been held.

WEST ISLIP, L. I., Oct. 6 -- The sudden appearance of a large number of poisonous black widow spiders in new housing developments here has caused increasing hysteria among housewives in the last two days and led members of the Islip Town Board to declare a "state of emergency" today until something was done to control the pests.

Striking dock workers in New York and eleven other Atlantic Coast ports flocked back to their jobs yesterday in response to a no-strike order issued under the national emergency provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- A flurry of political activity stirs the bright October air as Britain's two major parties debate their programs and estimate their prospects. This week the Conservative conference follows last week's Labor meeting at Margate. The Government is at midterm, the Prime Minister is presiding, Mr. Eden is back on the job, there are special Cabinet meetings at which colonial problems in Africa, Malaya and now in British Guiana press for attention.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Charles E. Wilson, the Secretary of Defense, said today that the Soviet Union was at least three years behind the United States in the development of atomic and hydrogen bombs and he expressed the belief that Russia could not win a war against the free world now or ever.
Architectural plans for the first four buildings of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, the first new medical school to be established in this city since 1898, were made public yesterday.

Charlotte, N. C., sold issues of bonds totaling $9,225,000 yesterday to a syndicate headed by National City Bank of New York at an interest cost of 2.6901 per cent. The bid was 100.0034 for 6s, 2 1/2s, 2 3/4s and 1s for obligations maturing from 1955 to 1988. Reoffering of bonds due from 1955 to 1985 was made at yields ranging from 1.5 per cent to 2.95 per cent.

Elizabeth Yates, who in private life is Mrs. William McGreal of Peterborough, N. H., has been named recipient of the first annual William Allen White Children's Book Award for her novel "Amos Fortune: Free Man." The novel was chosen by a vote of Kansas school children in the fourth through the ninth grades.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Oct. 6 -- Ceylon has decided to increase her contribution to the United States Tea Council by $25,000 this year, thereby bringing the amount for next year to $375,000.

The importance of the salesman in an era of competitive selling was stressed yesterday by speakers at the weekly luncheon of the Sales Executives Club in the Roosevelt Hotel. Companies which do not recognize the key role of such men, it was said, will soon find themselves lagging behind the competition.

LABOR Day may be the official end of summer for most people. But in the "Books of The Times" office it means the beginning of pandemonium. Then the fall freshet of new books starts rolling in, sometimes as many as fifty in one day. On nearly any day in September and October a half dozen books that seem eminently reviewable are published.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 7 -- The United Nations Command announced that it would begin the construction today of facilities where Communist agents will be able to meet with their former personnel to try to get them to return to their homelands. The United Nations action paved the way for beginning the controversial "explanation" sessions within a week.

Even President Eisenhower's five-point program for a free world did not dispel recessionary sentiment on Wall Street yesterday. Stock prices sagged in early dealings to new lows for the month. Although the list for a while during the afternoon showed some rallying tendencies, the movement did not gain any real momentum, with the result that the market closed irregularly lower.

The action of Mayor Impellitteri in appointing a committee to review the city's pension systems and to inquire into the desirability of reducing the employe's share of contributions to one-quarter of the service pension cost is, I believe, in the long-range interest of the city as an employer.

The Citizens Union, announcing its usual appraisal of the various candidates for Mayor, reported yesterday that Harold Riegelman, Republican; Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democrat, and Rudolph Halley, Liberal, were all qualified. Mayor Impellitteri was described as "totally inadequate" and his defeat was said to be imperative.
Bobby Watkins, the Ohio State halfback who scored four touchdowns against California in full view of a nationwide television audience, yesterday was named The Associated Press back of the week.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (AP) -- For the first time since March, 1952, Sears, Roebuck Co. reported today its sales last month were lower than the comparable month one year before. Sales for the fiscal year through Sept. 30 held to a new record high for a comparable eight months, the company added, however.

Former Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore severely criticized the fiscal policies of New York City yesterday, charging that a saving of $80,000,000 in interest charges would have occurred in 1951 if the city followed the same borrowing practices as upstate communities.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6--The present price decline does not spell disaster for American agriculture, and it is not of such severity that this country must act as if it were headed into a depression, an agricultural economist asserted today.

IF names make news, people make television programs. Fresh proof of the adage is afforded by Edward R. Murrow's new program, "Person to Person," which is being presented at 10:30 P. M. Fridays over C. B. S. By the simple process of taking the cameras into the homes of different personages, the presentation offers interesting TV.

The Isbrandtsen Company, challenger of the legality of a dual system proposed by the Japan-Atlantic and Gulf Freight Conference, failed yesterday to prevent the introduction, as evidence, of its own and lower rate schedules at a FederalMaritime Board hearing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today the united States was not entirely happy over the handling of prisoner repatriation by the Neutral Nations Commission. However, he declined to comment specifically on an attack on India by Senator William F. Knowland.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Edward L. Williams, retired New York lawyer, took the oath of office today as Director of the United States Operations Mission in Spain. He will establish headquarters in Madrid to supervise the economic and technical assistance phases of the recent agreement signed with the Spanish Government.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UP) -- The Army announced tonight that "several employes" at its Signal Corps laboratories at Fort Monmouth, N. J., had been suspended recently "for security reasons."

Wall Street, probably more than any other market, has its fashions and at the moment the one group of securities which is "old hat" is the rails. The arguments are the usual ones -- the rails are faced with some heavy wage demands that could well eat up net; if business goes down the rails are sure to suffer volume-wise and a regulated industry finds it difficult to cut costs.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh announced yesterday the creation of a special bail court to clear all applications for bail and thus "ferret out the gangster elements who are behind the bail bond business." The new court will be at 100 Centre St.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Public and private medical authorities told a Congressional committee today that the use of gamma globulin to fight poliomyelitis would be continued but that perfection of a vaccine was needed to prevent the disease. Gamma globulin, it was explained, prevents paralysis resulting from the disease in most cases, but does not prevent the disease itself.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Florida Supreme Court ruled today that falsely calling a man a Communist in public was slanderous because it charged him "with having a loathsome state of mind."
A five-day conference to study means of improving utilization of the country's professional and scientific manpower will open today under the sponsorship of the National Manpower Council.

The work of Margot Kempe, the ceramist, whose terra cotta sculpture, lamps and bowls might be to harmonize or contrast with textured surfaces in contemporary rooms, is on view in the showrooms of Ernst Schwadron, 757 Madison Avenue.

In public utility financing transactions yesterday new issues of common stock priced at $7,960,000 were cleared for offering to investors, and new issues of mortgage bonds totaling $12,000,000 were purchased by banking syndicates at public bidding for reoffering later in the week.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 6 -- The French today announced that the raid on Laokay had ended with a partial success. It is not yet known how the troops who parachuted on the Vietminh supply base will get back to their own lines, but they are being aided by groups of underground partisans of the proFrench mountaineers who infiltrated the region of Laokay and it is believed the retreat will be successful.
Prague, Czechoslovakia, appears to have become a major center for training Communist agents to spread subversion in the colonial and underdeveloped countries of Asia, Africa and South America.

Early New York furniture, long a perplexing subject to the student of local artifacts because of the lack of documentary evidence, will go on exhibition tomorrow at the Museum of the City of New York.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- A Norwegian delegate -- male -- reminded a United Nations Committee, including a number of zealous suffragettes, today that sometimes it's the women's vote that keeps the man in political office.

WAITE HOYT had been a brilliant pitcher for the Yankees in his youth and he was just playing out his string as a National Leaguer some two decades ago. The exact time is not important except that it was not too long after the Yanks had won the 1932 world series in four games from the Chicago Cubs.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Democratic State Chairman, Richard H. Balch, said tonight Governor Dewey should set up a special grand jury, if necessary, to investigate the power that the extortionist. Joseph Fay, wielded from a prison cell.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- State Department officials rejected today a report from aborad that the United States, Britian and France had decided on partitioning the Trieste Territory. They said there had been no decision on any settlement proposal.

GENEVA, Oct. 6 -- Economic cooperation in Europe received a setback here during the last few days when the opposition of railroad administrations successfully defeated efforts to expand regular international bus services for tourists.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 6 -- Following is the recorded text of President Eisenhower's address today before the sixth national assembly of the United Church Women:

The Netherlands will throw its foreign trade doors wide open to imports from the United States, provided this country erects no new tariff barriers against Dutch exports, Dr. A. B. Speekenbrink declared yesterday. He is Dutch Minister Plenipoteniary and Envoy Extraordinary, as well as head of the Netherlands Embassy in Washington.

To commemorate the fortieth anniversary of the first passenger flight from Albany to New York, the pilot who made the trip in 1913 will retrace that route today. He will take off from Albany at 1:5 P. M.

Nine hundred persons, nearly all in good humor, left Grand Central Terminal last night aboard three special "boat trains" headed for Halifax. There they will board the Queen Mary tomorrow afternoon for Europe. The ship was diverted to Halifax because of the longshoremen's walkout here.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor, charged last night that New York City had been consistently "short-changed" hundreds of millions of dollars because of the city-state financial relationship.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 6 -- The Hudson County Republican organization acted illegally when it named four Democrats as substitute candidates for state offices in the November general election, Superior Court Judge John B. McGeehan ruled here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- In a spirit of harmony rare at United Nations meetings, the General Assembly voted unanimously today to continue the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund on a permanent basis.

HAVANA, Oct. 6--The Urgency Court of Santiago today condemned twenty-nine revolutionists who participated in the abortive revolt of July 26 to prison sentences ranging from seven months, to thirteen years. Seventy-two who had been provisionally released yesterday were acquitted.

Hornblower Weeks, national brokerage and investment banking firm founded in 1888, announced yesterday that virtually the whole personnel of the Detroit brokerage firm of Bennett, Smith Co. will become associated with Hornblower Weeks' Detroit office on Nov. 2.
Rudolph Halley, Liberal party nominee for Mayor, said last night that New York City needed its own Fair Employment Practices Commission "with teeth in it."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- President Eisenhower announced today the selection of two of the three members of the Rubber Producing Facilities Disposal Commission, which will dispose of Government- owned synthetic rubber plants.

It is not common knowledge, in spite of the statement made by George Howorth in his recent letter, that workers never recoup their losses sustained in a prolonged strike. The higher rates gained by strikes are in general paid year after year, and on top of them are piled further wage adjustments granted voluntarily by management in later negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said today the urgency of the world situation commanded that consideration be given to every means of reducing friction, including some form of non-aggression pact with the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The president of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad today denied that, in the eleven years of his association with that railroad, there had been any attempt by the New York Central to influence its policies on operations.

ROME, Oct. 6 -- The Chamber of Deputies, after having listened to a two-hour speech by Giuseppe Pella, the Premier and Foreign Minister, approved the Government's foreign policy tonight by 293 votes to 200, with nineteen abstentions.

CAIRO, Oct. 6 -- Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, Deputy Premier and strong man in Egypt's ruling Revolution Council, has given British negotiators an ultimatum requesting a time limit on the talks on the Suez Canal military bases and asking them to state how far they are willing to go to meet certain Egyptian demands, an informed source said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation staged a round-up today of alleged Communists accused of conspiracy to teach and advocate the over-throw of the Government by force and violence and took seven persons into custody.

MONTREAL, Oct. 6 -- The first jet plane service linking North America and Europe may be opened within eighteen months with non-stop flights between Montreal and London, Sir Miles Thomas, chairman of British Overseas Airways, said here tonight.

BOSTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- George A. Nicholson Jr. of Watling, Lerchen Co. of Detroit said today "we in the investment business must produce the capital necessary to raise out national standard of living even to higher levels."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- With Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield officiating, the first bag of regular mail containing 3-cent letters and 2-cent postcards from this city was flown to Chicago today aboard an American Airlines plane.
A first mortgage was arranged by the Walter L. Rothschild Co., broker, for the Hy-Grade Land Corp on the sixty-five-family apartment house at 760 E 10th St in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Val Peterson, head of the Civil Defense Administration, asserted today that he believed this country would get "the whole book" in modern weapons in the event of war with the Soviet Union.

Samuel Reshevsky of New York, defeating Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam a second time last night, gained half a point on Vassily Smyslov of Moscow in the twentieth round of the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich.

ELEUTHERIA, Greece, Oct. 6--High-ranking officers of the Atlantic alliance early today watched the culminating phase of the week-old Operation Weldfast, designed to test the defenses of Southern Europe. The action took place on a beach near this pond.

The shirt has come into its own as the single most important trend in the blouse field for fall. Not content with merely adapting men's shirts, several designers have actually copied them line for line, adding but few modifications.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- A declaration stressing the defensive character of the projected European Defense Community, signed by its six members plus the United States and Britain, is one means of allaying Russian fears over German rearmament that has been discussed by three major Western powers, it was learned authoritatively today.

Minot F. (Mickey) Jelke, noticeably thinner than when he began an eight-month sentence on Rikers Island for illegal possession of two pistols, was freed from City Prison under $50,000. bond yesterday, pending appeal of his conviction of compulsory prostitution.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Department of Justice announced an anti-trust consent judgment today prohibiting General Electric Company and International General Electric Company, Inc., from joining any restrictive cartels in the world-wide sale of electric equipment.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Following is the text of the response of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles to questions at his news conference today relating to reports that the United States had under consideration some form of nonaggression pact with the Soviet Union:

Donation on Monday of 535 pints of blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program was reported yesterday. This included 184 pints from the Quaker Maid Company, 80 Thirty-ninth Street, Brooklyn. Yesterday another 243 pints were donated aboard the aircraft carrier Hornet at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, on the first of a four-day drive there.
Fairbanks, shrouded in the ice of Alaska, and Barstow, shimmering in the heat of the Mojave Desert, have little in common except American G.I.'s and United Service Or ganization Clubs.

A testimonial dinner for Dr. Buell G. Gallagher on the first anniversary of his assuming the presidency of City College was held in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night. Some 300 alumni and friends of the college heard tributes to the president and pledged $120,000 toward a goal of $200,000 to furnish, staff and maintain a new student center to be opened next September.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 6 -- Bickering and jockeying for position among rival factions of Iran's dismembered Parliament broke into the open today, threatening to hamper the efforts of Premier Gen. Fazlollah Zahedi to solve the country's crowded agenda of political, economic and social problems.

In a dispatch from Tokyo published yesterday in THE NEW YORK TIMES the United Nations Command in Korea was quoted as having called the attention of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission to a photograph that appeared in THE TIMES of Sept. 27.

For the first time, a team of scientists, headed by Dr. Vincent du Vigneaud, Professor of Biochemistry at the Cornell University Medical College here, has succeeded in synthesizing a hormone of the body's master gland, the pituitary.

The problems arising from the increased use of magnetic sound tracks to provide stereophonic or directional sound for motion-picture films will be the subject of an open forum at today's session of the seventy-fourth annual convention of the Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers at the Statler Hotel.
PARIS, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The American Ryder Cup team, which narrowly took the measure of the British last week, invaded the Continent today and gave a golf lesson to the best of her professionals.

Notre Dame again was the first choice of the sports writers and broadcasters yesterday in the second weekly Associated Press poll of the 1953 football season, just as it had been in the pre-season poll.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Oct. 6 -- Showing the way at every mark, Sweden's Maybe VI, owned by Sven Salen and skippered by Maj. C. H. Nordenskiold, registered her first triumph in the international Six-Meter sailing tests in Long Island Sound today.

" Blowing Wild," which arrives at the Paramount, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Gary Cooper, Barbara Stanwyck, Anthony Quinn and Ruth Roman head the cast of the action drama, which was produced by United States Pictures and is presented by Warner Brothers. Hugo Fregonese directed and Milton Sperling produced from a script by Philip Yordan.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Oct. 6 (AP) -- A special campus policeman today accosted a Baltimore Evening Sun reporter working on a story about University of Maryland authorities' confiscation of copies of the student newspaper.
LONDON, Oct. 6 -- British troops are being rushed to the colony of British Guiana to forestall a suspected attempt "to set up a Communist dominated state," it was officially announced tonight.
DETROIT, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Rumors of merger talks involving two of the smaller auto companies are being heard again in industry circles.
The twenty-family apartment house at 4537 Vireo Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by Phillip P. Zipes, operator, to a client of Sidney Freedberg, lawyer. It is assessed at $91,000.
A "business decline" but not a "depression" is in the cards, continuing into the first half of 1954, it was asserted yesterday by Arthur Babson, vice president of Babson's Reports, Wellesley, Mass.

Some things funny to one man are irritating to another, but cartoon humor has shown that now and then something turns up which is funny to practically all of us. Last week Britain's delegate to the United Nations widened the audience for U. N. debates by introducing a humorous quip employing the idiom of bebop.

The five judges of the Appellate Division granted unanimously yesterday a temporary injunction prohibiting picketing at the two Hearn department stores by members of the Distributive, Processing and Office Workers, C. I. O., who have been on strike since May 14.

During a state visit to Paraguay President Peron of Argentina has made a number of speeches and statements which are represented as heralds of a new orientation in his foreign policy. He has repudiated any ambition to set up and lead a regional bloc against the United States and any attempt to influence other Latin-American countries against us.

MEREDITH WOOD, Book of the Month Club president, and Ralph Thompson, one of the club's editors, got into friendly controversy the other day over pronunciation of Greenwich Village's Houston Street. Mr. Wood's Uncle Houston has always called it
An increase in pupils exceeding the expectations of school officials has forced the Board of Education to hold classes in a building that has been replaced with a new structure.

Governor Dewey entered the New York Mayoral campaign last night to plead the cause of Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate, and to accuse Mr. Riegelman's three chief rivals of trying to use the harness racing and Joseph S. Fay disclosures for a "smoke screen" to avoid discussing city issues.

The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service took action yesterday in the six-day strike of deck officers of East and Gulf Coast tankers, and a joint meeting of the disputants will be held this afternoon at the Commodore Hotel. Commissioner Henry Winning of the agency's regional office here has been assigned to the case.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Government today faced the prospect of moving within a half billion dollars of the national debt limit late this month or early in November.

Open-market trading in Manhattan real estate during the first eight months of this year lagged behind that for the corresponding period last year, according to the monthly survey of the Real Estate Board of New York.

Governor Dewey said in a statement last Friday: "I have just seen the list of Joseph Fay's visitors at Sing Sing, which includes elected officials. * * * I thoroughly disapprove of any public officer calling upon a convicted extortionist, except in the course of his official duties.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 6 -- A repetition of last year's exciting see-saw game, in which Yale never led until it scored the winning touchdown with eight seconds to go, is looked for here Saturday when Columbia comes into the Bowl for one of the top Ivy football scraps of the season.

MADRID, Oct. 6 (Reuters) -- Rabbi David A. J. Cardozo of New York predicted today "a new development of Jewish life and perhaps later of Jewish culture in Spain" if the present activities of the Jewish community in Madrid continued.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Preliminary Senate investigation developed today that the United States Army already had case histories of about 1,800 instances of alleged enemy atrocities against United States servicemen in Korea, but that many of the accused were war prisoners already free under the truce terms.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 6 (AP) -- The president of the Texas Mid-continent Oil and Gas Association said today the industry now has oil "running out of our ears" but should increase its drilling rate by from 8,000 to 10,000 additional wells a year. R. F. Windfohr of Fort Worth said future demand for United States crude oil cannot possibly be fulfilled at today's rate of drilling and discovery without dipping into national reserves.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The top spokesman for the new Baltimore Orioles said today he was shopping for "the best general manager possible," but had not found him yet.

Congratulations on your editorial "Point Two and a Half" and to Paul Kennedy for his excellent series of articles on what has happened to the Point Four Program. I hope every reader has become cognizant of the Eisenhower-Dulles regime's undermining of this program by an administrative reorganization and a changed philosophy.

Through the medium of your newspaper I should like to thank and compliment all members of the Air Warden Service residing within Queens and participating in any way in the state-ordered Civil Defense drills of Sept. 23, 24 and 25 respectively.

Allison Nelson, a pianist from Australia, came to this country a little less than ten years ago, met Harry Neal, American pianist, and eventually went into partnership with him -- marital as well as musical. As a two-piano team they have played in this country and rather extensively in Australia, and last night at Town Hall they made their New York debut.

Prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges with no item ending lower in all positions. Potatoes, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, hides, zinc, tin, coffee and cocoa closed higher. Sugar, rubber, burlap, lead, copper and wool ended mixed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Following are excerpts from the official transcript of the press conference today of the Secretary of Defense, Charles E. Wilson:

An investing client of the Cross Brown Company has purchased the five-story loft building on lot 20 by 100 feet at 40 West Thirty-eighth Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues from David S. Meister. Assessed at $80,000, the property rents for about $20,000 a year. Walzer Walzer were the attorneys for the seller.

Sir Percy Spender, Australian Ambassador to the United States, offered a plan last night to break the deadlock on atomic control. He proposed an agreement that on a stipulated date "the use of atomic and hydrogen bombs and weapons shall be prohibited provided that in the meantime effective systems of control and inspection are able not only to be agreed to but also put into effect."

The Rangers yesterday got a lift for their National Hockey League opener in Detroit tomorrow with the acquisition of Ike Hildebrand 26-year-old right wing from the Cleveland Barons. In return, the New Yorkers sent Jack Stoddard, a wingman, on loan to the Barons of the American League.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Point Four program through which the United States gives technical assistance to underdeveloped countries is "going to bog down" in that it is being converted to an economic and military assistance program, Senator Allen J. Ellender Sr., Democrat of Louisiana, said today upon completing an official 45,000-mile inspection tour through equatorial Africa and the Far East.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- Speaker Edouard Herriot told the French National Assembly, called in special session today as a result of the August wave of public service strikes, that many of the letters from Deputies asking for the Assembly's convocation were considered to have been forged.

In the judgment of this newspaper Harold Riegelman is the candidate best qualified and, in fact, the only candidate qualified to be the next Mayor of New York. We endorse him without hesitation, convinced that his election would offer the best promise since the days of La Guardia to restore good government to this misgoverned city.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- A night's accumulation of 16,000 pounds of first class mail was flown out of Chicago's Midway Airport on four airliners about 9 A. M. today.
Billy Martin, who captured most of the 1953 world series honors, also led both teams in the slugging averages computed by the Associated Press yesterday.

THE average individual would not consider buying a suit, no matter how much it had been "marked down," that was tailored for a man eight inches taller and fifty pounds heavier but a number of novice shooters seems to diseragrd "fit" when they buy their first shotgun.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6--Delegates to the United Nations General Assembly were shown Defense Department films today in which five United States fliers explained how mental and physical torture had been used by their Communist captors in Korea to extort "confessions" that they had engaged in germ warfare.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Arthur E. Summerfield, Postmaster General, called on the publishers of newspapers and other periodicals today to perform "a good, thorough job of soul-searching" as a step toward accepting proposed increases in postal rates on second-class mail.

Little did Ralph Farnworth, 31-year old chorus boy in "Guys and Dolls," realize that he would be able to win one of the Alice M. Ditson Scholarships at Columbia University's Opera Workshop after undergoing what is considered in medical circles a rare operation for the removal of calcium deposits in the back of his throat.
TENAFLY, N. J., Oct. 6 -- William Mangin and Dr. Edward Rosenthal of Aldecress won the New Jersey State best-ball tournament at the Knickerbocker Country Club today with 5-under-par 34, 33 -- 67.

Alf M. Landon, defeated Republican nominee for President in 1936, said yesterday that he had written Republican Congressional leaders that it was imperative that they reach an understanding with President Eisenhower on a legislative program before the next session of Congress if they expected to win control of both Houses in next year's Congressional elections.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 6 -- Dedicating itself to the reunification of divided Germany, West Germany's second post-war Bundestag (lower house of Parliament) assembled for the first time today and elected its officers.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Oct. 6 -- Lieut. Gen. K. S. Thimayya, chairman of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission, told correspondents here at his first press conference today that the Indian troops on hand could prevent a mass outbreak of prisoners if ordered to do so, but that such an order never would be given.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- Four Long Island Sound International class skippers, playing hosts to Bermudian counterparts, treated their guests unkindly today by winning the first team race for the Amorita Cup.
BEL AIR, Md., Oct. 6 (A/P) -- Three bettors hit a $6,626.40 daily double at Bel Air race track today, the seventh largest pay-off ever recorded in United States. racing and Maryland's second largest.

ROME, Oct. 6 -- A joint United States-British-French step in both Rome and Belgrade, which it is hoped may furnish the basis for a solution of the Trieste problem, is expected almost hourly, it was learned today from an unimpeachable Italian source.

Is the recently demonstrated improvement on the part of the rest of the world to earn dollars purely adventitious and transitory or does it contain elements that can be expected to be more or less permanent?

The New York Clearing House Association, at its 100th annual meeting, elected N. Baxter Jackson president yesterday. Mr. Jackson, chairman of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, succeeds Alexander C. Nagle, president of the First National Bank.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Prices on live hogs plunged 50 cents to $1.25 a hundred pounds today. Receipts so far this week have run the largest since the first week in March. At their new levels prices were the lowest since mid-April. Cattle were steady to 50 cents lower except for the extreme top on steers, which was 25 cents higher. Vealers were strong to $1 higher and sheep mostly about steady.
The State Bridge Building Authority of Georgia announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Oct. 29 on $9,750,000 of bonds dated July 1, 1953, and due on July 1, 1954 to 1969.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Civil Service Commission sent word today to heads of Government agencies that payroll economies must continue, but that the rights of career employes to their jobs must, at the same time, be protected.

The Lehman Corporation, one of the country's largest closed-end investment trusts, reported yesterday that its net realized profits on investments in the first quarter of its fiscal year, ended on Sept. 30, had been $2,180,698, compared with $1,621,006 in the corresponding quarter a year ago. The corporation's ordinary net income was $1,058,801 for the three months, against $1,049,395 in the same period of 1952.
Samuel Reshevsky of New York, tied for the lead in the twenty-first round of the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich, last night, according to a Swiss news report.

ALBANY, Oct. 7 -- Counsel for Scheideler, Beck Werner, Inc., a New York advertising agency, and for eight former officers or employes of a second agency, the Duane Jones Co., today asked the Court of Appeals to reverse a $300,167 judgment against them in a business "pirating" action.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 7 -- Six European airlines have joined in a project to study the possibility of integration. A report commissioned by the airlines and currently being studied by them takes a clear stand in favor of more coordination but against any new supernational European aviation authority or any decisive integration.

OTTAWA, Oct. 7 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent announced today that the Federal Government's subsidy to Canada's gold mines would be continued for another year "in substantially its present form."
Governor Dewey said yesterday that he was not satisfied with Acting Lieut. Gov. Arthur H. Wicks' explanation of his visits to Joseph S. Fay, convicted labor extortionist, in Sing Sing Prison.

The money for the first national newspaper campaign of Stephen F. Whitman Son, Inc., Philadelphia candy maker, will come from its former budget for TV and part of its window displays, it was said yesterday by Julian Barksdale, sales manager.

La Corredora, owned by Mrs. Marian W. O'Connor and ridden by Ira Hanford, proved distance was quite to her liking at Belmont Park yesterday. Competing in the $59,000 Ladies Handicap over the route of a mile and a half, the 4-year-old daughter of Little Beans took the $40,900 first money by a margin of five lengths.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- The United States did an about-face today and withdrew its own $100,000 economy resolution in the General Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee after receiving assurances that every effort would be made to cut the 1954 administrative costs of the Technical Assistance Administration of the United Nations.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- Over the wind-blown Knollwood Country Club course, Jack Patroni, Apawamis instructor, set the pace for the qualifiers in the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship with a 2-under-par 69 today.

The pride, esprit, morale and effectiveness of the Marine Corps are still high despite the corp's expansion in size and current problems that have affected all the services, Gen. Lemuel C. Shepherd Jr., commandant, declared in a letter recently received.

Registration continued to lag yesterday and only 356,535 persons qualified to vote in the Nov. 3 election, compared with 380,058 enrolled on the third day of 1949, the last comparable period when a city-wide election was held.

The slump in the nation's zinc industry became more pronounced last month, according to figures reported yesterday by the American Zinc Institute. Shipments of domestic zinc dropped for the fifth month in a row, and metal stocks continued to pile up at smelters. Stocks as of a week ago were at the highest level in more than six years.

Rudolph Halley, Liberal party candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday that organized gamblers of the "Costello Mob" again were accepting bets on the city's streets. This, he declared, is a result of Tammany's victory in nominating Robert F. Wagner Jr. for Mayor.

Three players whose contracts belonged to the Minneapolis club in the American Association were purchased yesterday by the Giants. Harry Gentry, an outfielder, Gall Harris, a first baseman, and Bill Gardener, a shortstop, all of whom played at Nashville last season, will report for training at Phoenix, Ariz., next spring.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 -- With its contract dispute with Local 77 of the American Federation of Musicians settled, the Shubert Theatre Corporation was completing arrangements today for rescheduling diverted musicals in the organization's four "legitimate" theatres here.

Consumers of coal in the city are to have a guarantee of sorts in this heating season, it was learned yesterday. Coal delivered on and after next Thursday is to bear a delivery ticket saying whether it is "standard" or "substandard." In addition, all advertising of any type that mentions prices must include these descriptive terms.

Some adjustment in the economy is due as a result of heavy inventories, according to Paul Mazur, partner in the banking firm of Lehman Brothers. A substantial recession or the threat of it, however, can be forestalled by the Government, which by its spending power, wields a powerful influence on the economy, he said.

GROTON, Mass., Oct. 7 -- This was one of those rare autumn afternoons on which a prep school football team took part in a mid-week varsity game. The principals were Groton School and English High of Boston and the teams waged a close struggle before Groton succumbed, 13 -- 0, after a scoreless first half.

Net sales and net profit of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., and subsidiaries for the year ended on June 30 increased 13 per cent and 33 per cent, respectively, from results attained in the previous fiscal year.

Nathan Wilson, operator, who recently purchased the vacant three-story industrial building at 420 Austin Place, at East 144th Street, in the Bronx, has resold it to the 420 Austin Place Realty Corporation, represented by Samuel Feldman, lawyer.

I refer to your editorial of Oct. 5 entitled "Mr. Halley 'Explains'," and relating to Mr. Halley's vote against the Dewey transit plan in the Board of Estimate and my comment on it over the Tex and Jinx program.

After moving hardly at all on unimportant volume most of the day, stocks gathered strength near the close yesterday, packed 290,000 shares of turnover into the final thirty minutes and closed with the best gains since Sept. 22.

The Young Women's Christian Association, now celebrating its centennial, was the recipient yesterday of a quaint portrait of its early days -- a painting that hang in one of the parlors of the association's national board headquarters, 600 Lexington Avenue.

Twenty-seven medical, charitable and social organizations share in the $2,000,000 estate of Dr. Max Einhorn's, retired gastroenterologist and inventor of surgical instruments, it was learned yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Bob Ferris and Mel Wright combined their pitching talents to allow Montreal only two hits tonight as Kansas City won the fourth game of the little world series, 4 -- 3. Montreal now holds a 3-1 lead in the series.

YONKERS, Oct. 7 -- In the first serious crackup of the 1953 season in the metropolitan area, AL Clark, a driver from Westbury, L. I., suffered a fractured jaw, a possible fractured skull and multiple lacerations of the head in a three-horse collision in the fourth race at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 7 (AP) -- A Harvard University study of Russia says interviews with Soviet refugees indicate "the atmosphere of fear which pervades Soviet society envelops the Communist party itself."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 30, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:
Warren Spahn of the Braves and Ed Lopat of the Yankees, both left handers, topped the Major Leagues in earned-run effectiveness for 1953.

ROME, Oct. 7 -- Ambassador Clare Booth Luce today informed Giuseppe Pella, the Italian Premier and Foreign Minister, that he shortly might receive a proposal that the United States Government hoped would help to bring about a solution of the Trieste problem.

Elmer A. Carter, Republican candidate for Manhattan Borough President, suggested yesterday that Rudolph Halley, Liberal party candidate for Mayor, hire a lawyer to assist him in preparing campaign statements. Mr. Carter said Mr. Halley, in urging passage of a law that would prevent the city from doing business with a contractor practicing discrimination, apparently did not know that there was such a law on the statute books of both city and state.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- President Eisenhower today named Maj. Gen. Emerson L. Cummings to become Chief of Army Ordnance, succeeding Maj. Gen. Elbert L. Ford, who will retire at the end of this month. General Cummings has been Assistant Chief of Ordnance. That department procures tanks, vehicles and weapons for the Army.

Department stores with annual sales over $1,000,000 showed net profit from merchandising operations of 1.3 per cent of net sales during the first half of 1958, it was reported yesterday by the Controllers' Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The Long Island Rail Road put the first of its two new electc commuter coaches into fulltime service on the Pennsylvania Station to Babylon, L. I., run yesterday at 5:25 P. M. The road has twenty of the cars on order, at a cost of $125,000 each.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 7 (UP) -- The trial of Jack Cowart, a former official in the Department of Agriculture, was recessed today because of the sudden illness of former Gov. Dan Moody of Texas, a defence lawyer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Moves by the New York City Board of Higher Education for its own investigation into subversive activities within its college system are being watched hopefully by the Senate Internal Security subcommittee, its chairman, Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, said today.

Rubber prices continued to fall to new yearly lows on the New York Commodity Exchange. Prices dropped 90 to 95 points on Monday, were easier in the active months on Tuesday and tumbled 65 to 80 points yesterday on 1,010 tons, the highest volume since Sept. 23. The spot price of rubber also reached a new low for the year; 21 cents a pound, down 5/8 cent.
Cabbage is a homely vegetable, almost always plentiful and cheap. Its close cousins have a higher standing in our meals. We are thinking of cauliflower, Brussels sprouts and broccoli.

Important fall silhouettes in luxurious fabrics were presented by Rosette Pennington at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. The slimmest sheaths, the empire and princess styles, the curved cupola shape, the wide, billowing silhouette were included.

Gasoline stocks increased 738,000 barrels last week, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were listed at 143,222,000 barrels, or 19.6 per cent above the 119,793,000-barrel supply reported a year earlier. On Sept. 26 gas supplies amounted to 142,484,000 barrels.

Additional support for your excellent editorial of Sept. 30 denouncing the pro-Communist bias of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission may be found in President Eisenhower's statement of May 26.

ALBANY, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Democrat of Manhattan, said today he was not a candidate for Governor of New York but would accept the 1954 Democratic nomination if it was offered.

Michael L. Radoslovich, architect for the Board of Education, has filed plans for a new junior high school building to be erected at 222 East Seventy-sixth Street at an estimated construction cost of $2,500,000. The cost, with equipment, was put at $3,275,000. The school will house 1,725 pupils and is expected to get under way next fall, with classes scheduled for opening in September, 1955.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 8 -- Angry charges and countercharges were hurled back and forth yesterday among the United Nations Command, the Communists and the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission as a result of the turbulent situation that has arisen in the handling of prisoners of the Korean war who have said they did not wish repatriation.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The Reynolds Mining Corporation has announced that it is proceeding with development of its Haitian aluminum ore reserves. The concern is a subsidiary of the Reynolds Metals Company, Richmond, Va.

Since the revision of the General Agreement of Tariffs and Trade at the Torquay, England, conference two years ago, American textile exports to Cuba have declined substantially, it was asserted yesterday by the Textile Export Association of the United States.

MIAMI, Oct. 7 -- Members of the School Health Committee of the American Academy of Pediatrics issued a statement on school health policies today strongly urging closer cooperation among the schools, community health officials, parents and private physicians.

In contrast to negative reactions of past years, exporters are showing a more positive interest in proposed insurance coverage for foreign credit and exchange transfer risks, according to first returns in a nation-wide survey, it was reported yesterday at a meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau in the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The problem of housing, long a matter of legislative concern on Capitol Hill, appeared to be heading toward the personal level for a number of the country's top lawmakers here, to say nothing of assorted diplomas, public servants and workaday citizens.

The Tablet, the Brooklyn diocesan Roman Catholic weekly, was criticized last night by Rabbi Israel Goldstein for its attack on the late Rabbi Stephen S. Wise. The newspaper recently had upheld charges by Benjamin Gitlow, ousted in 1929 as general secretary of the Communist party, before the House Committee on Un-American Activities that Dr. Wise once had collaborated with Communists.
KANSAS CITY, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Twice in th e week of negotiation with the kidnappers of Bobby Greenlease the mother went to the phone to plead for assurances her boy was alive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Hiring by the nation's factories in August dropped 25 per cent below the average for the month since World War II but the employment situation is still "highly favorable," the Bureau of Labor Statisties reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Later this month the Commodity Credit Corporation will offer to city banks approximately $350,000,000 of "certificates'' on crop loans. They will bear 2 1/2 per cent interest.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 7 -- Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, proposed here tonight that religion and education join forces in a "stand-up fight" against irresponsible attacks on their loyalty and integrity.

Wider support of voluntary hospitals as the best means of continuing a high standard of medical service was urged by Governor Dewey yesterday at the opening of the campaign in Brooklyn of the United Hospital Fund and Visiting Nurse Association. He addressed 1,000 persons at luncheon in the St. George Hotel.

If "The Little Hut" had not been so fabulously successful for three seasons in London, it might not seem so ordinary when it is produced here now. Extraordinary success abroad arouses extraordinary expectations here. In the production that opened at the Coronet last evening, the Andre Roussin comedy about fashionable sin on a desert island has its moments of impudent amusement.

An improved design for spherical roller bearings has been announced by SKF Industries, Inc., of Philadelphia; which said the product had an increased anti-friction bearing capacity of 25 to 50 per cent and a service life two to three and a half times greater than formerly was possible.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- The production of gas turbines for the propulsion of ships is now economically feasible, according to British marine engineers, who say they have weighed the production and running costs against the competition of steam turbines and Diesel engines.

New York State continues to remain in the van of those states reporting progress in labor legislation and labor law administration in the past decade. We are indebted to the State Labor Department Division of Research and Education for a simple, factual account of the highlights in this field.
The Morris and Essex Kennel Club dog show, matched only by Westminster in national prestige, will not be held next year.

Robert F. Shuping has been appointed sales promotion manager of Julius Kayser Co., hosiery. Richard S. Sheetz has been named manager of Sterilamp-Odorout sales of lamp division of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in Bloomfield, N. J.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Chief Justice Earl Warren, after a tussle with the cord on a "borrowed" judicial robe, administered the oath of office today to John E. Peurifoy, new United States Ambassador to Guatemala.

Plans for erecting a factory Building in Brooklyn were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of a vacant parcel of land at the southwest corner of Quincy Street and Classon Avenue by Edward T. Kelly, in whose family the property had been held for more than sixty years.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- Britain has taken soundings here on whether she should ask the United States to clarify its recent suggestion that the question of inviting India and other Asian countries to the proposed Korean peace conference be decided at the conference itself.
