Efforts to settle out of court the controversy between the New York City Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., over new transit schedules were described yesterday as hopeless. Meanwhile, the union met to vote on demands for $40,000,000 in pay rises, vacations and pension funds for workers on the city-owned lines.

The views of three of the four major mayoral candidates on school issues were reported yesterday by the United Parents Associations, in announcing the replies to questionnaires recently sent the candidates.

BUFFALO, Oct. 7 -- The New York State Congress of Parents and Teachers, at its convention here, adopted today a legislative program seeking teacher training scholarships and additional state aid for education this year and next.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 7 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer revealed today a number of major casting assignments involving the program of eighteen to twenty pictures that the company plans to complete by the end of its fiscal year next August.

Everyday life in the United States is this nation's best advertisement. Unfortunately, most of the world's population never has an opportunity to catch even a glimpse of it. Their knowledge of us sometimes is distorted, either deliberately or as a result of misinformation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Corporations in the United States had $88,200,000,000 more assets than liabilities at the end of June, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 6 -- A new era for Israeli education began yesterday when 230,000 children passed through the portals of the unified Government-administered elementary schools. With the opening of the new school term, four school networks with different ideological trends were amalgamated and brought under the direct control of the Ministry of Education.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- President Eisenhower has decided to put a stop to loose official talk about the Soviet Union's possible hydrogen bomb and related subjects.

The C. B. S. television network will present a special color program from 1 to 1:30 P. M. today that can be received on home sets as black-and-white pictures. Entitled "Eye Opener," it will feature Carmen Miranda, Gwen Verdon, Nanci Crompton, Polly Bergen and Kajar, the magician. A pick-up from Central Park will feature Gene Autry, Jack Mahoney and Dick West.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- The increasing use of many drugs to manage a medical affliction and the use of multiple agents to induce anesthesia appear to have caused an increase in the number of patients who die from heart failure on the operating table or in diagnostic examining rooms, it was reported here today at the Clinical Congress of the American College of Surgeons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- India delivered to the State Department today a message expressing her concern over "recent developments" in Korea and appealing for United States aid in curbing threats against the prisoner repatriation program by the Government of Dr. Syngman Rhee, South Korean President.

Completion of the steel superstructure of the Captree Bridge on the 10,800-foot crossing of Great South Bay near Babylon, in Suffolk County, is a milestone in the construction of the Long Island arterial parkway system conceived more than twenty-five years ago.

PARIS, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The American Ryder cup golf team had little trouble defeating a collection of European all-star professionals today despite a hole-in-one by a Dutchman, Gerard De Wit, and some surprisingly good play by his teammates.

ANDROS ISLAND, the Bahamas, Oct. 7 -- This must be a magic island, for according to reliable reports no visiting sportsman has ever been greeted with the all-too-familiar phrase, "You should have been here last Week," and according to those who have been fishing and shooting during the past few days, we couldn't have arrived at a better time.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 7 -- Leftist Prime Minister Cheddi Jagan charged in the House of Assembly today that the Governor of this British colony had called for troop-laden warships as a show of force here without consulting his elected ministers.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- The French Cabinet decided today to urge a five-power conference such as the Soviet Union proposed in its note of Sept. 29. The conference, which the French would confine to Far Eastern questions, would include representatives of Communist China, the Soviet Union, the United States, Britain and France.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Secretary Oveta Culp Hobby revealed today how her Department of Health, Education and Welfare got its long name. The account adds one more item to the legend of the late Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Plans for the transformation of three blocks on the western fringe of Chicago's Loop business district into one of the city's greatest construction projects, involving expenditure of $75,000,000 to $100,000,000, were announced today by Walter S. Franklin, president of the Chicago Union Station Company and of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 7 (UP) -- Arthur B. Eisenhower said tonight it took eighty persons working overtime to assemble the $600,000 in small bills paid to the kidnappers of Bobby Greenlease.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 7 -- President Rajendra Prasad inaugurated today the new capital of the north Indian state of East Punjab at Chandigarh (cross on map), about 150 miles from New Delhi, in the presence of a large and distinguished gathering.

" If we can win this one it will make our season." So pronounced Coach Ed Danowski yesterday as he sent a hale-and-hearty Fordham squad of thirty - four players through their final hard practice session for Saturday's game with Syracuse in that school's Archbold Stadium.

Being a Dodger fan has its compensations and heartbreaks. It is sometimes questionable whether the advantages outweigh the latter. Perhaps it is too soon after the series to make any equitable comparisons. It will suffice to say that there have been many painful disappointments. One of the main sources of discomfort over the years has been John Mize, whose retirement was announced yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 7 -- Rumanian Jews here submitted two memoranda to the Bucharest Government today requesting the release of Jewish leaders imprisoned for Zionist activities and the removal of a ban on Jewish emigration to Israel.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 7 -- Mohammed Ali, Prime Minister, moved cautiously today as he hinted at early adoption of a Constitution patterned after the laws of "progressive federal countries."

THE new Mainstream of America Series edited by Lewis Gannett gets off to a lively start with Stewart Holbrook's rowdy and readable. "The Age of the Moguls."* This is a czar-spangled chronicle of the industrial, commercial and financial tycoons -- including Theodore Roosevelt's "malefactors of great wealth" -- whose marches to power in America made America powerful in the world.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The highly regarded Danish men's doubles team was beaten in the third round of the Pan American tennis tournament today by the United States-Chilean team of Hugh Stewart and Luis Ayala.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Sir Winston Churchill, the British Prime Minister, rejects any unilateral approach to the Soviet Union about high level talks that might endanger the "special relationship" between Britain and the United States, an authoritative source said tonight.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 7 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's new cabinet began to take shape today and it appeared that the list of ministers would be enlarged to accommodate a broader coalition, assuring the Chancellor of a two-third majority in the Bundestag, the lower house of parliament.

The hold-over Nassau County grand jury investigating charges of labor racketeering and irregular ownership of stock at the Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I., handed up a number of indictments shortly before midnight yesterday at Mineola.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower talked taxes, farm problems and civil defense with a series of callers today. In addition he got a report on Brazil from Mrs. Fleur Cowles, writer and editor, who visited the South American country last summer.

GENEVA, Oct. 7 -- All but three of the thirty-four Governments adhering to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade have now agreed to an extension of the present tariff truce beyond the end of 1953.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 7 -- Unaware that the Garden State Bus Lines, Inc., had suspended operations on three routes at 2 A. M. today, more than 1,000 commuters waited in vain this morning for their usual means of transportation between their homes in Bergen, Passaic and Hudson Counties and this city.

It is not surprising that at its recent annual convention the British Labor party should have renewed its agitation for the admission of Red China to the United Nations. For it was while it was in power that the British Government, in January, 1950, extended formal recognition to the Peiping regime, albeit, it is only fair to remember, under tremendous pressure from the large (capitalist) interests in the Far East.

WASHINGTON, Oct, 7 -- Another loan of $10,000,000 to assist the development of southern Italy was announced today by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. The borrower is the Cassa per il Mezzogiorno, a Government agency in charge of the program for the economic and social development of the area.

Arrangements for the interchange of designs, fabrics, patents and trade names between sportswear producers in the United States, Italy, Sweden, Holland, Austria and Switzerland were made known yesterday by Harry Doniger, president of David D. Doniger Company, manufacturer of McGregor sportswear.

Establishment of a new laboratory for the Department of Air Pollution Control was announced yesterday by Commissioner Leonard Greenburg. The laboratory will take over all work on measurement of sootfall formerly performed by the chemical laboratory of the Health Department.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- President Eisenhower allocated $10,000,000 from his disaster emergency fun today to help farmers in thirteen drought-stricken states to get hay supplies for winter feeding of livestock.

PHILLIPSBURG, N. J., Oct. 7 -- Robert B. Meyner, Democratic candidate for Governor, asserted tonight that the state was facing a serious and chronic water shortage as a result of a "growing population and expanding industrial output."
HOUSTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The chairman of the board of the Texas Company warned oil men today that another attempt in Congress would be made next year to repeal the industry's depletion tax allowance.

ROME, Oct. 7 -- A European government with powers in the fields of defense, economy and foreign politics became a tangible possibility today when the French delegation to the six-power conference in Rome accepted the "supranational" principle as a basis on which such an executive body could operate.

ATHENS, Oct. 7 -- Stephan Ste-phanopoulos, Greek Foreign Minister, said today the Greek Government had been advised through the United Nations of Bulgaria's willingness to enter into "direct" negotiations with Greece on subjects concerning the two countries. The Foreign Minister added that the capital of some neutral nation, in which both Greece and Bulgaria were represented, would be selected within the near future for the parleys.

HONOLULU, Oct. 7 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon arrived here today on the first leg of a 38,000-mile world tour. After predicting statehood for Hawaii during the next session of Congress he embarked on a busy three-day schedule of official and social functions.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Oct. 7 -- A plea to the International Labor Organization to help the people of the Maldive Islands, who are facing starvation, was made by Dr. M. C. M. Kaleel, Ceylonese Minister of Labor, when he opened the Asian maritime conference of the United Nations body yesterday in Nuwara Eliya, Ceylon.

Mayor Impellitteri submitted yesterday to a closed meeting of the Board of Estimate a proposal by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley that the function of establishing off-street public parking lots be assigned to the Department of Traffic, with authority to install parking meters in such lots.

Robert W. Dill, newly-appointed Collector of Customs for the Port of New York, was welcomed officially yesterday by 800 of the steamship operators, importers, customs brokers, forwarders and other members of the shipping industry with whom he will be closely associated in his post.

Chase Mellen Jr. and Eugene R. Canudo, Rudolph Halley's Liberal party running mates for Controller and City Council President, respectively, were rated above their Democratic and Republican rivals in an appraisal of candidates for these offices made public yesterday by the Citizens Union, a nonpartisan organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Arthur E. Summerfield, the Chevrolet dealer turned Postmaster General, hastily shifted designs for a new three-cent stamp today, perhaps to keep from giving an edge to an old competitor in the truck manufacuring business.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- A monograph on Britain's greatest liquid asset in international trade has been published by the Scotch Whisky Association and launched at a reception, with appropriate refreshments, attended by a corps of experts on the subject.
BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- Wilhelm Pieck, chairman of East Germany's Socialist Unity Communist party, was re-elected today president of the East German government for another four-year term.

A syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. will place on the market today a new issue of $8,000,000 of first mortgage bonds of Mountain States Power Company. The obligations, due in 1983, bear 4 per cent interest and are priced at 101.58 to yield about 3.91 per cent if held to maturity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- A conservative attitude by business with regard to inventories is disclosed in the latest report by the Department of Commerce's Office of Business Economics, covering August inventories. According to the figures compiled by the agency, business inventories at the close of August had an estimated value of $77,800,000,000, an increase of $450,000,000 from the July 31 level, after allowance for seasonal variations and other adjustments.

BOSTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- In his first speech as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission Ralph H. Demmler said today "our job and your job and the job of a lot of other people is to make the American system of free enterprise work."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The Bureau of Agricultural Economics said today it looks as though the present dairy surplus problem -- involving a Government investment of $360,000,000 in stocks of dairy products -- will continue next year.

DETROIT, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Gil Turner, 156 pounds, of Philadelphia, gave Italo Scortichini, 155 1/2, Italy, a sound thrashing tonight as he pounded out a unanimous ten-round decision before 3,053 fans at Olympia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Whatever may be the considerations that have caused the President to delay giving to the people a clearer concept than they possess of the enemy's atomic threat and our ability to deal with it, surely an overriding reason why he should do this soon has now been supplied.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 7 -- A group of Rutgers University students was credited today with the revival of the 117-year-old "cannon war" between Rutgers and Princeton. Invading the Tigers' campus before dawn, the visitors applied bright scarlet paint to the historic war-piece in front of Cannon Club, one of Princeton's seventeen upperclass eating clubs.
Saturday night . . . a small Midwestern town near an Army base . . . the U. S. O. Center is filled with soldiers lounging, at the snack bar, writing letters, playing pool.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- New York State has substantially lowered -- possibly by "several millions" -- its estimate of share of the cost of the huge St. Lawrence River power project.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Spanish Republican Parliament-in exile has not been invited to attend the Washington conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union, opening Friday.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman and Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. promised last night to campaign actively for the election of Robert F. Wagner Jr., the Democratic candidate for Mayor. Mr. Lehman and Mr. Roosevelt spoke at the opening of headquarters for Volunteers for Wagner in the Belmont-Plaza Hotel, Forty-ninth Street and Lexington Avenue.

The prospect of larger returns for New York's savings bank depositors was in view yesterday, when the state's Banking Board considered the desirability of lifting the present 2 1/2 per cent maximum ceiling. No information could be obtained last night regarding the board's decision, although the fact that it had considered the matter was confirmed.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Wheat futures gained strength today as a result of disquieting weather and crop reports from the winter wheat areas, especially in the hard winter wheat sections. The crop is said to be deteriorating where it had germinated and was above ground. Many growers are still waiting for rains before seeding.
CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The Comiskey clan tonight debated whether to grant a requested release of Frank Lane as general manager of the White Sox to take an important post with the Baltimore Orioles.

Two public loaders received $100 for every 200 tons of newsprint unloaded from barges onto East River piers and trucks, while a stevedoring company netted only $1.50 for the same load, according to testimony heard yesterday in General Sessions.

Astronomers will be extremely grateful to you for your wholly deserving editorial on Dr. Edwin P. Hubble. But I was slightly surprised by your reference to Dr. Hubble's well-known Silliman Lectures, published under the title "The Realm of the Nebulae," as "The Realm of the Universe."

In the opening hours of the Health Department's drive against defective water-cooled gas flame refrigerators, the 200 health inspectors began getting results that could mean the saving of endangered lives.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- A crack bat talion of British troops will sail for British Guiana aboard the aircraft carrier Implacable in three days, the War Office announced today. The first battalion of the Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders has been placed under orders and 700 camp cots have been taken aboard the ship at Devonport, it was announced.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Lothair Teetor, chairman of the board of the Perfect Circle Corporation of Hagerstown, Ind., is expected to be named Assistant Secretary of Commerce in charge of Domestic Affairs. Mr. Teetor would succeed Craig R. Sheaffer, fountain-pen manufacturer who resigned last month.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 7 -- The Indian, Swedish and Swiss observers at the "explanations" to the prisoners of the Korean war refusing repatriation will be quick to halt any attempt at coercion or "brain-washing" of anti-Communist captives by the North Korean and Chinese Communists, high Indian sources have indicated.
One of the city's oldest department stores, James McCreery Co., will close after Christmas.

Thirty-five "jovenes embajadores" (junior ambassadors) from seven South-American countries arrived in New York yesterday on the fourth day of a two-week air four of eleven major cities in the United States.
Union rivalry threatened yesterday to paralyze Atlantic Coast ports.

With all the building going on around town and all the holes in the ground in the making or in prospect, the conscientious sidewalk superintendent has all he can do if he confines his perambulations to mid-Manhattan.

Wool apparel cloth sales in the first seven months of 1953 increased 7 per cent, it was announced yesterday by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers. In the January-July period sales of men's wear cloths by seventy-five reporting companies showed a gain to 25 per cent, while women's wear was up 33 per cent.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 844 pints of blood Tuesday, including 223 pints from a community donation at Great Neck, L. I., and 147 from the New York Port of Embarkation, Brooklyn.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- A classless Conservative party was established as a goal for the party's regional workers by Viscount Woolton, their leader, in a speech before the Conference on Local Government Questions at Margate today.

A high school student who thought he had killed his father during an argument late yesterday and fled into the Sterling Street station of the I. R. T. subway on Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, ran to his death under the wheels of a train, the police reported. The accident resulted in a delay of more than an hour during the peak of the rush period on the Flatbush Avenue branch of the Seventh Avenue line.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Randolph Churchill, son of Britain's Prime Minister renewed today his charge that a section of the British press dealt chiefly in pornography. He also accused British newspaper owners with few exceptions of not publishing criticism of their own or other papers.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 7 -- The Iranian Government issued a double-barreled warning today that it would tolerate no attempt by the Tudeh (Communist) party to exploit the two traditional breeding grounds of political disorder in the capital -- the university and the bazaar.
WASHINGTON, Oct 7 -- Mrs. India Edwards, vice chairman and director of women's activities of the Democratic National Committee, resigned today as woman's director. She retained her vice chairmanship.

The obliging Jose Ferrer, who recently bowed to the preference expressed by several thousand City Center theatregoers in a poll on which plays they desired most to see him in this fall at the civic playhouse, also has acquiesced to their demands that he extend his drama season there for an additional two weeks.
New low rates on bulk shipments across the Atlantic were filed yesterday with the Civil Aeronautics Board by Pan American World Airways.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 7 -- Mrs. Francis J. Klaess of Rockville was the only player to break 90 today as the first round of the thirty-six-hole women's New York State senior championship tournament started at Cherry Valley.

Young women headed by Miss Barbara G. Lord and including Miss Elizabeth R. Johnson are serving on the junior committee for the dinner dance in behalf of the Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue, Inc., to be held tonight in the Terrace Room of the Plaza.

The mushroom cloud that rises above every new atomic explosion begins to haunt all peace-loving nations and drives them to ever greater efforts to banish the specter of annihilation by establishing a firm, just and enduring peace. These efforts have been pursued by the Western World, and in particular by the United States, both during and since the last World War.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Bill Veeck, still struggling to move the Browns to Baltimore, today told a Circuit Court heading that the shift would be jeopardized and the club would become bankrupt unless injunction and receivership suits against the Browns were dismissed.

Philip P. Zipes, operator, has purchased the thirteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 176 West Eighty-seventh Street, at the northeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue, through Curtis So-love, broker.

A new super de luxe Royal V-8 and Meadowbrook V-8 series are included in the 1954 line announced yesterday by the Dodge division of Chrysler Corporation. Several safety features have been added to all models while body lengths have been increased an average of four inches.

TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 7 -- An Arizona rancher and farm labor contractor of Yuma County was indicted today for having concealed illegal alien workers and operated a short-wave radio system between his home and fields by which aliens were warned to hide from immigration investigators.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 7 -- The United States Government is giving serious consideration to ending the present methods of employing Mexican farm laborers, "braceros," when the agreement between the two countries expires at the end of this year.

With the opening of the 1953 financial campaign of the United Hospital Fund of New York more than 5,000 men and women volunteer workers will seek contributions to this worthy cause. They will not receive any payment for their efforts, yet upon them and upon the generosity of donors to the drive will depend the size of contributions to the fund.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 7 -- Pakistan urged France today to call a round-table conference, at which "all political elements in Morocco," together with all French political parties, would be represented, to discuss the future of the French protectorate.
The fall season of the New York City Opera Company will open tonight at the City Center of Music and Drama at 8:15 P. M. with a performance of Rossini's "La Cenerentola."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UP) -- Community Chest officials met with Thruston B. Morton, Assistant Secretary of State, today to discuss reports that State Department employes were being coerced into contributing to the annual charity drive.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 7 -- Paul L. Troast, Republican candidate for Governor, outlined here today a five-point program designed to improve the New Jersey school system and protect its teaching personnel.
Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, charged last night that his three rivals were "all responsible and equally responsible'' for "all the city's troubles growing out of mismanagement.''

GENEVA, Oct. 7 -- Seven countries have agreed to give asylum to 227 "difficult" cases from among the group of nearly 15,000 European refugees in Shanghai, the United Nations High Commission for Refugees said today. These are mostly invalids or persons who for various reasons require permanent institutional care.

Following is a summary of the first three days of the New York City registration, by Assembly Districts, as compared with 1952, a Presidential year; 1950, when a Governor, Senator and a Mayor were elected, an 1949, the last city-wide election:

The Jay Broiler Company, manufacturer of electrically controlled rotisseries, has purchased the building at 34-08 Northern Boulevard, in Long Island City, Queens, in a deal involving more than $500,000. The structure has a frontage of 185 feet on the boulevard and is served by a spur of the Long Island Rail Road.

WHEN the Dodgers meet the Yankees in the 1954 world series next October, the Brooks are quite likely to be better fortified in pitching strength than they were last week. What's that? Heavens, no! This pairing isn't at all guaranteed. Since a short-range prediction in sports is risky, a long-range one is ridiculous.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- Premier Joseph Laniel, Finance Minister Edgar Faure and other members of the Cabinet made a vigorous defense today before the Finance Committee of the National Assembly of the economic program put in operation by decree by the Government this summer.

GUATEMALA, Oct. 7 -- Guatemala's rail system was at a stand-still today as a result of a strike called last night by 6,000 workers of the International Railways of Central America. The workers are asking higher pay and other conditions that the company, owned by United States interests, says it cannot meet.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- The combined influence of yesterday's decline on Wall Street and the possibility of labor trouble here following the employers' rejection of an engineering wages claim halted the rise of stock market prices and sent prices drifting downward.

Two design treatments of the "motif from the past" are exhibited in two new collections of decorative materials. One group, which has a fresh, contemporary look, is made of drapery prints and textured upholstery materials, and is available through decorators at Decorative Fabrics, 13 East Fifty-third Street.
Prices of active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, up 4 to 9 points.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- West Berlin's senate, the executive branch of the western sector government, said today it would continue in office until a new mayor was elected by the city legislature to replace Dr. Ernst Reuter, who died suddenly last week. Nevertheless, the senate urged that a successor be named as soon as possible.
A brilliant showing that illustrated the versatility of American fashion took place at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday noon when the Coty American Fashion Critics' awards for 1953 were presented.
Following is the text of Mayor Impellitteri's keynote telecast in his campaign for re-election on the Experience party's ticket, delivered over WNBT, Channel 4, last night:

A proposal that the Board of Education extend its facilities to 13,000 mentally retarded children who are now in the so-called uneducable category was put forward yesterday by Arthur Levitt, Brooklyn member of the board.

From his background as a motion-picture executive and a former Broadway actor and writer, Dore Schary, production chief at Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer, informed an audience of 600 aspiring performers yesterday how to get to Hollywood as quickly as possible.

There was glory enough for all, just for getting into the world series. Now comes the matter of cash, and Commissioner Ford Frick yesterday disclosed that each winning share, before taxes, amounted to $8,280.68, while each losing share was worth $6,178.42.

The auto stocks are acting strangely down in Wall Street. Both Nash and Hudson have been strong in recent sessions on merger rumors. But while this strength presumably stems from investors' belief that a consolidation would help both Nash and Hudson shareholders in that a stronger company would be created, it would seem that General Motors and Chrysler shares should weaken in fear of new competition from a possible "Big Fourth" of the auto industry.

Representative Daniel A. Reed, according to reports from the Washington Bureau of this newspaper, "has been quietly lining up support" in the House for a program which will slash revenues next year by approximately $5 billions.
The Philharmonic-Symphony will open its 112th season tonight at 8:45 with a Carnegie Hall concert under the direction of Dimitri Mitropoulos, musical director of the orchestra.

THERAPIA, Turkey, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Dauntless Florence Chadwick swam the swift waters of the Bosporus from Europe to Asia and back today, and tomorrow she will attempt to conquer the Dardanelles to complete her grand tour of four of Europe's great waterways within a year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- A college classmate of Morton Sobell, convicted spy, identified himself today as one of the radar specialists suspended by the army on security grounds.

James Bove, convicted in 1945 of extortion with Joseph S. (Joey) Fay, petitioned yesterday for his release from the city penitentiary on Rikers Island. His petition, charging illegal imprisonment, will be heard in Bronx Supreme Court today.

Mayor Impellitteri, making what was described as the keynote speech of his campaign for re-election on the independent Experience party's ticket, told voters over television last night that he had cleaned up "messes" in the Police and Fire Departments that confronted him when he took office three years ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Representative Thaddeus M. Machrowicz, Democrat of Michigan, said today he had obtained delay in a move by the Air Force for dismissal of a veteran master sergeant on security grounds related to Communist associations when the sergeant was only 12 years old. He explained that Sgt. Victor Havris, formerly of Detroit, now on duty in France and is slated for discharge Oct. 20, needed time to prepare a defense.

A demand that the Polish Government cease its harassment of the Roman Catholic Church and deal with it according to the provisions of the Polish Constitution was made last May by the Catholic bishops of Poland, according to information received here yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 7 -- Six-year-old Bobby Greenlease was found dead today in a lime-sprayed grave behind a honeysuckle hedge in St. Joseph, Mo. A record ransom of $600,000 had been paid three days ago for the kidnapped boy.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- The trend toward more and more Government activity in the field of insurance has been temporarily halted by the Eisenhower Administration, Robert L. Hogg, executive vice president of the American Life convention, said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- An order that Dictograph Products, Inc., Jamaica, N. Y., stop "coercing" dealers to sell its hearing aids exclusively was issued today by the Federal Trade Commission.

GUATEMALA, Oct. 8 -- The Guatemala Government took over the International Railways of Central America today. President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman appointed Afonso Bauer Paiz, former Minister of Economy and Labor, as the receiver. Senor Bauer Paiz assumed temporary control of the company's $63,000,000 properties this morning.

Fresh meat prices have declined as a result of the heaviest arrivals of meat last week since January. The Consumers' Service Bureau of the City Department of Markets reported that 39,500,000 pounds were received during the week ended Oct. 3.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 8 -- India denied today that Lieut. Gen. K. S. Thimayya, Indian chairman of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission in Korea, had said at a press conference that Indian custodial troops would not resist a mass break-out by anti-Communist captives in the demilitarized zone.

In a move to end discrimination in fraternities and sororities at state-operated colleges, the State University of New York yesterday ordered all student social organizatiors to sever their national fraternal affiliations and to eliminate any "artificial criteria" in the selection of members.

TRIESTE, Oct. 8 (Reuters) -- United States and British troops and their families in Trieste were ordered to keep off the streets today by Army authorities fearing outbreaks of violence over the two-power decision to pull out of the territory.

Our readers show a continuing interest in special homemade breads, particularly those thick-crusted loaves made from whole grain flours. Absent during the summer because of their poor keeping quality, such flours are now back on grocers' shelves.

A dual rate system, which the Transpacific Frieght Conference of Japan proposed to institute Sunday for cargoes from Japan, Korea and Okinawa to the United States West Coast, was ordered held in abeyance yesterday by the Federal Maritime Board.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Representative W. Sterling Cole, chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, tonight applauded President Eisenhower's frankness in telling the American people that the Soviet Union has the capability of attacking the United States with the hydrogen bomb.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 8 -- Mrs. Van Devanter Crisp of The Creek won the New York State women's first senior thirty-six-hole golf championship today at Cherry Valley.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- The team of Long Island Sound International Class skippers and that of Bermuda divided today's two races for the Amorita Cup, which left the United States side one up in the series.

A well-groomed man, about 45 years old, selected the Fifth Avenue branch of the National City Bank at Fifty-first Street yesterday afternoon "to surrender" to the police -- but after seven minutes of conversation with the vice president of the branch, he changed his mind and walked out.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- President Eisenhower ordered his colleagues to stop making off-the-cuff statements about the Soviet Union's super-weapons today and issued a carefully prepared fact sheet on the atomic arms race.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of a United States note calling on the Chinese and North Korean Communists to make known whether and when they would be ready for a political conference on Korea:

In line with today's interest in decorating every nook and cranny of the home, the merchandise in a new shop is devotee to those areas usually, concealed behind closed doors. The closet and its various aspects and accessories are the primary interest of Sherle Wagner, 123 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Commodity prices closed irregular in average volume on the New York exchanges yesterday. Coffee, potatoes, lead, zinc, cocoa and cottonseed oil were lower; rubber, burlap, wool and wool tops closed higher, while sugar, hides and soybean oil closed mixed.

Rudolph Halley, the Liberal party's candidate for Mayor, was assailed at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate by Bronx Borough President James J. Lyons as "a radio gangbuster, TV expert and publicity-hunter who is more interested in catching headlines than in catching criminals."

Belmont Park didn't have a stakes contest on its program yesterday, but the Mate Handicap for 3-year-olds, the feature, was a $10,000 added race. Ted Atkinson, who has the proper regard for money, had 654 reasons for wanting to win it with Greentree Stable's Lotus Eater.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 8 -- In a series of surprise raids, twenty-one persons, including some prominent Moslem leaders, have been arrested by authorities in South Sumatra during the last several days.

A thirteen-state alarm had gone out Wednesday night for a little brown bag containing about $75,000 worth of jewelry but the gems were found intact yesterday in a Bronx garage where they had remained overnight since the return of the taxicab in which they were left by their owner.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- The American College of Surgeons served notice here today on the rest of the medical profession that it was intensifying its year-old campaign to eradicate surgical practices that the college considered unethical.

The eighth National Hardware Show entered its closing stages yesterday in Grand Central Palace with business about 10 per cent above that in the first four days of last year's event. The show, open to the trade only, closes today at 5 P. M.
Cotton futures closed barely steady yesterday, off 4 to 17 points, after light trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today that Britain's economic position had improved greatly in the last two years and that she was rapidly regaining her independence of outside economic help.
Duke Snider, 27-year-old outfielder of the Dodgers, won the National League slugging title for 1953 by a fraction of a percentage point over Milwaukee's Eddie Mathews.
INDIAN VILLAGE, Korea, Oct. 8 (UP) -- Twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week, 22,500 North Korean and Chinese war prisoners show their hate of communism.

Round - the - clock negotiations ended early yesterday afternoon the eight-day strike of East and Gulf Coast desk officers employed aboard 200 tankers. The National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, A. F. L., won during the session what was described as the "best tanker agreement in the history of the industry."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- President Eisenhower told the thirty-sixth annual meeting of the American Council on Education today that he thought interchange programs so important to international understanding that he wanted them in all fields.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue service gave out the figures -- but no other facts --today on a woman who might be America's richest -- she had more than $2,000,000 of 1950 income left after paying $4,309,000 taxes on a total of $6,413,000.

It will be many a moon before Columbia gets over the disappointment of its last-minute 20-19 defeat by Princeton. However, the Lions are not letting their chagrin over that heart-breaking setback dampen their spirited approach to tomorrow's battle with Yale, a team that Lou Little rates as superior to the Tigers.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- The enormous popularity in London of the modern American musicals, in particular those written by the Rodgers and Hammerstein partnership, was never more clearly shown than at the Drury Lane Theatre tonight. A packed and distinguished audience gave the first performance here of "The King and I" an ovation both warm and prolonged.

Leonard Buder's excellent report of Sept. 30 concerning the increased interest of educators in the promotion of preventive mental health measures in the public schools of the state is extremely encouraging. Together with the home and church the school presents an important factor in the reduction of the enormous cost of mental illness.

ALBANY, Oct. 8 -- Governor Dewey and Senator Arthur H. Wicks will meet in the Capitol here Monday afternoon to thrash out the politically explosive issue of Mr. Wicks' visits to Joseph S. (Joey) Fay, a convicted labor extortionist, in Sing Sing Prison.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- President Eisenhower confirmed today that the United States Government had under study a proposed system of nonaggression pacts designed to quiet alleged Soviet fears. At the same time he shied away again from any questions dealing with his early participation in a Big Four conference.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- A major new program of exchange fellowships, bearing President Eisenhower's name and involving eventually 100 grants a year worth $770,000, was announced here today, prior to its being "given" to the President at a celebration of his sixty-third birthday at Hershey, Pa., next Tuesday.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 8 -- In spite of the existing gap between India's available internal resources and the capital outlay of the five-year plan, the Central Government has decided to spend the equivalent of $350,000,000 more during the next two and one-half years of the plan.

Florida Power Corporation is issuing to holders of its common stock rights to subscribe for 211,416 new shares of stock at $24 a share until Oct. 8. Secondary subscriptions, subject to allotment, will be permitted only to round out fractional subscription privileges.

The Health Department announced yesterday that its inspectors already had closed and sealed sixty-eight defective water-cooled gas-flame refrigerators in the drive against these potential killers that began on Wednesday.

COLOGNE, Germany, Oct. 8 -- West Germany's breakfast, luncheon and dinner tables have been set with the foods of the world in this country's second International Post-War and Luxuries Exhibition, called "All You Can Eat and Drink," being held here this week.

The City Planning Commission proposed yesterday as the basis for public hearings next Friday and Oct. 19 a 1954 capital outlay budget of $531,209,579, the largest such proposal in the city's history. The total proposed by the commission represented a substantial cutting of the $785,193,536 requested by city departments and agencies seeking 1954 funds for public works to be financed from the proceeds of city bonds.

The New York City Opera Company led from strength when it opened its fall season at the City Center last night. The opera was Rossini's "La Cenerentola," and the production was the imaginative one that charmed the town when it was unveiled last spring.

There was something of a debut in the Sadler's Wells Ballet performance at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, when Svetlana Beriosova danced the title role in "Sylvia" for the first time. This is the most important assignment the young dancer has had thus far, and she has every reason to be pleased with herself this morning.

MANILA, Oct. 8 -- President Quirino has filed suit for criminal libel against the Manila Chronicle, a consistently anti-Administration newspaper, for publishing a cartoon depicting him as a modern day Moses carrying a stone tablet graven with political paraphrasing of the Ten Commandments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff, the senior military advisers of the nation, have proposed keeping the Army and Navy at about their present size and have recommended the continued build-up of a modern Air Force.

A VARIETY program in color, including a studio number by Carmen Miranda and a pick-up of Gene Autry, the singing cowboy, riding horseback in Central Park, was staged yesterday afternoon by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The show and color were about on a par: not very good.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia, who today denounced the United States and British decision to turn over the administration of Zone A of Trieste to Italy, is understood to have privately agreed with Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden of Britain last spring on a similar solution.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Earl Blaik has stood among the strongest advocates of two-platoon football and, with two games behind his Army team, he is more convinced than ever that it was a mistake to do away with the free-substitution rule.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Close cooperation between Canada and the United States to meet defense and other problems on a continental basis was endorsed here today at a conference of Canadian and United States defense production officials.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The assistant collector of customs in Minneapolis testified today that he had changed the identification of frost-damaged Canadian grain marked "unfit for human consumption" without consulting his superiors here or in Washington.

Food distributors were warned yesterday by Ralph W. Burger, president of The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, to move cautiously before adding non-food lines. Many food stores in the last year or two have added items other than food.
Four thousand students and faculty members of Fordham University assembled in the university gymnasium yesterday morning to open the academic year with the Mass of the Holy Ghost.

PARIS, Oct. 8 (AP) -- France is allowing only 7,500 Americans enter Morocco to man the huge United States Air Force bases there, and American officers said today that that number soon would not be enough to do the job.

The consolidated net income of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., and subsidiaries for the fifty-two weeks ended on Aug. 1, increased 74.5 per cent above the volume recorded in fifty-three weeks ended on Aug. 2, 1952, according to the annual report issued yesterday to stockholders by Jack I. Straus, president.
Rudolph Halley presented motion pictures yesterday of men he said were bookmakers exchanging money on Broadway sidewalks.

A one-story taxpayer building with seven stores at 28-40 Westchester Avenue in White Plains, N. Y., opposite B. Altman's new branch store has been purchased by Nathan Wilson, operator, from the Don-Rae Holding Corporation, Clarence G. Feltner was the broker.
David Bronstein of Moscow yesterday defeated Laszlo Szabo of Hungary in the world chess championship challengers' tournament at Zurich

James P. Mitchell, Assistant Secretary of the Army, who will be sworn in today as Secretary of Labor, is eminently fitted for the post to which he has been named by President Eisenhower. As successor to Martin P. Durkin he will have the respect and confidence of management and labor, whose spokesmen are familiar with his abilities in a difficult field.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 8 -- Postmaster General Hubert L. Anthony expressed thanks to the United States Navy in the House of Representatives today for the promptitude with which it had flown a parcel of cortisone from Pearl Harbor to Fanning Island, 1,500 miles away, to save the life of M. F. Giles of Sydney, an officer of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission's station on the island, who was critically ill.

It may be chronicled that the 112th season of the New York Philharmonic - Symphony Society opened last night under the direction of Dimitri Mitropoulos in Carnegie Hall, before an audience that packed the auditorium and hearkened attentively to every offering of the orchestra and its distinguished leader.

James Paul Mitchell, who was named today by President Eisenhower to be Secretary of Labor, is on leave of absence as vice president in charge of personnel and labor relations at Bloomingdale Brothers, Inc., here. He has had a long background of Army and civilian personnel service.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The United States, acting for the United Nations members whose forces fought in Korea, asked the Communists once again today whether they would attend a Korean political conference proposed for Oct. 15.

NOT one passerby in the Times Square night tide looked a second time at Annette Kellerman at the Astor Hotel curb the other night, but this same slender lady would have jammed pedestrian traffic at that spot if she had paused for even a minute forty-three years ago.

The family of a Brooklyn soldier disclosed yesterday that he had died of bulbar polio at Camp Gordon, Ga., last Monday, two days after he had been refused admission to the post hospital and marked fit for duty. The story was verified by military authorities, who are investigating.
The New York State Banking Board removed yesterday its ceiling on the interest rates savings banks may pay to depositors.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The United States and Britain announced jointly today that they would withdraw their occupation forces and return Zone A of Trieste to Italy.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct 8 (AP) -- Kimberly Kid, the strong favorite, swept to straight-heat victories to capture the rich Kentucky Futurity for 3-years-old trotters on a Grand Circuit program today.
Aviation history repeated itself yesterday when a single-engined seaplane landed on the East River and taxied to a mooring at Twenty-third Street.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- Defending the policy of his Cabinet during the August public service strikes, .Premier Joseph Laniel asked the National Assembly today for full approval of his economic action. He also asked rejection of any vote of censure in a motion at the close of the debate.

In an appraisal of candidates for Borough President in the five boroughs, the Citizens Union, a non-partisan organization, gave its top rating to James A. Lundy, Republican seeking re-election in Queens, and the Rev. James H. Robinson, Liberal candidate in Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- President Eisenhower today named James Paul Mitchell of Spring Lake, N. J., to be Secretary of Labor.
Federal officials conferred last night on an order requiring Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia, union boss of the Brooklyn docks, to show cause why he should not be cited for contempt of court.

My sincere and great admiration for your newspaper impels me to send you the following remarks with the hope that they will be taken in the spirit in which they are written. I am referring to your editorial "'World Bonds,' 'world Sale'" which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 1.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 8 -- The pulling and hauling that usually takes place in the forming of a Government continued today in West Germany.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Eight nations now administering dependent territories, including the United States, found themselves this afternoon on the losing end of twenty-six separate ballots in the Trusteeship Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

OMAHA, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Defense Transport Administrator James K. Knudson said today he would not hesitate to recommend that the Interstate Commerce Commission order certain railroads to increase their supply of freight cars if the railroads neglect to meet Government goals voluntarily.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of this afternoon's White House news conference, with President Eisenhower's remarks in the third person as required by conference rules:
OTTAWA, Oct. 8 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Government today terminated its two-year control over the sale of primary nickel in Canada.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Oct. 3 amounted to 812,554 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 7,155 cars or 0.9 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 39,366 cars or 4.6 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 46,203 cars or 5.4 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Bernard M. Baruch, who set out to make a name for himself after graduation from City College sixty-four years ago, returned yesterday to see his name lettered in bronze on a plaque affixed to the college's School of Business and Public Administration.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 8 -- Henry Bettman, chairman, and Wallace Collett, a member of the City Planning Commission, said today that they had not decided whether to yield to the City Council's demand for their resignations.

Three justices of the Court of Special Sessions, Brooklyn, reserved decision yesterday on Harry Gross' third application this year to obtain a reduction in his twelve-year sentence for bookmaking and conspiracy.

MIAMI, Oct 8 -- It is as much the responsibility of a pediatrician to help prepare a child emotionally for an operation or hospital stay as it is to make arrangements for his physical care, Dr. Sydney S. Gellis, Assistant Professor of Pediatrics at Harvard Medical School, said today.
The statement by Governor Dewey on an investigation of harness racing in the state follows:

The United States and Britain have launched a plan to recognize the existing partition of the Free Territory of Trieste as a de facto and temporary solution for this explosive area. The time is ripe for a solution -- perhaps even overripe -- for the quarrel between Italy and Yugoslavia has reached dangerous proportions.

The Corps of Engineers, North Atlantic Division, yesterday submitted a proposal to the Governors of Delaware, New Jersey and Pennsylvania for a $91,000,000 Delaware River channel-deepening project between Philadelphia and Trenton.

A BREATHTAKING discovery has been made. It's a game called football. It bears a vague resemblance to the bewildering hodgepodge we've been looking at for the past dozen years, but the faceless robots of the two-platoon system have yielded to real football players. A fellow finally can watch a game with the satisfaction of knowing who's doing what.

Dr. Bernardo Alberto Houssay, Nobel Prize winner in physiology and medicine in 1947, reported last night that experiments performed by him and his colleagues in Argentina suggested a direction for research aimed at finding a preventive for diabetes.

Several weeks ago THE NEW YORK TIMES reported a statement by the American Committee for Liberation From Bolshevism to the effect that it was forced to discontinue its assistance to political groups of the Russian and non-Russian emigres from the Soviet Union in view of their failure to achieve a "united front" against the Communist dictatorship.

Most of us lead sheltered lives, in the sense at least that among the people we know and even meet casually there operates a relatively high moral conscience. Whom do we know that would torture an animal, kill a child? Thus when a crime of almost incredible inhumanity comes before us, like the kidnapping and murder of 6-year-old Bobby Greenlease, we are struck dumb.
Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther warned last night against succumbing to the lure of Soviet "peace" offensives, or faltering in the defense of Western Europe for any reason.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Department store sales in the United States were 3 per cent lower in the week ended on Saturday than in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. It listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Air Chief Marshal Sir John Slessor, who was chief of the British Air Staff from 1950 until his retirement at the end of last year, said tonight that atomic weapons constituted the strongest deterrent to war that the world had ever known and that a third world war was, therefore, unlikely.

Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer reserved decision yesterday in the Bronx Supreme Court on a petition submitted by James Bove for his release from the city penitentiary on Rikers Island. Bove was convicted in 1945 of extortion with Joseph S. (Joey) Fay, who was transferred last week from Sing Sing to Dannemora when it was disclosed that he had received numerous visits in his cell from politicians, labor leaders and raceway officials.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of an announcement by the United States and Britain that they will turn over their occupation zone in the Trieste area to Italy for administration:

ROME, Oct. 8 -- Ambassadors of the United States and Britain informed Premier Giuseppe Pella today of the decision taken by their Governments to withdraw their troops from Trieste and return the city and its surrounding zone to Italian administration.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 8 -- Crowds of demonstrators smashed windows at the United States and British Embassies and the Italian Legation tonight following a statement by Marshal Tito, Yugoslav President, that the nation could not accept Italian acquisition of Trieste.

Theatregoers are advised that Clifford Odets has a new play in the offing. Having emerged from a period of drought three years ago with the successful "The Country Girl," Mr. Odets is now ready to proceed with his latest script, "The Flowering Peach," which he also will direct.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Free Territory of Trieste, sometimes called "Europe's perpetual dynamite keg," has an almost unbroken history of being shuttled back and forth between nations who want its natural port.

MANILA, Oct. 8 -- President Elpidio Quirino renewed tonight his denunciation of "foreign intervention" in the Philippines election campaign. He spoke at his home town of Vigan in the Province of Ilocos Sur.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- A petition with hundreds of signatures of Glasgow University students was airmailed tonight to Adlai E. Stevenson, the 1952 Democratic Presidential candidate in the United States, asking him to stand for election as the university's rector.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- During the week ended Oct. 7, member bank reserves decreased $6,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

More than 17,000 of the 24,000-odd signatures on Mayor Impellitteri's independent Experience party nominating petitions are technically defective, according to specifications filed yesterday with the Board of Elections in support of Democratic objections to the validity of the nomination.

Governor Dewey has taken the resolute and broad-gauged action required by the circumstances in establishing a commission under the Moreland Act to make an immediate and complete investigation into the harness racing business in this state. He has chosen three able lawyers to make the inquiry, Bruce Bromley as chairman, John F. Brosnan and George Trosk.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Eight planes took off today to race half way around the world to Christchurch, New Zealand, for prize money totaling 29,000 ($81,200). The winner is expected to arrive there tomorrow when it will be Saturday by New Zealand time.

The gasoline and service station recently completed at the northwest corner of Wantagh and Jerusalem Avenues in Wantagh, L. I., has been sold by Berger-Tilles Projects to Westover Mills, Inc., of Providence, R. I. The sale was subject to a net lease to the Meenan Oil Company, which operates the property as a Tydol gasoline station.
YONKERS, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Stanley Dancer drove his Volo Chief, an 8-year-old bay horse, to victory in the Flushing Pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Weakness in December wheat, which was under steady selling pressure, tended to unsettle all the grain markets today. Heaviness in the December option, however, was in contrast to the July future, which showed independent strength based on unfavorable weather.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, and City Council President Rudolph Halley, his Liberal party opponent, appealed separately yesterday to Albert M. Cole, Administrator of the Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency, for enough Federal funds to start 135,000 public housing dwelling units a year for the next six years.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 8 -- The United Church Women, representing an estimated ten million Protestant churchgoers in this country, overwhelmingly recorded today its opposition to racial segregation in public schools.

International influences on interior design were discussed and demonstrated yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Fashion. Group at the Astor Hotel. The speakers were two American interior designers: Paul McCobb, who commented on a recent visit to Italy, and William Pahlmann, who described his recent trip around the world.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Oct. 8 -- Switzerland gained the One-Ton Cup, symbol of international supremacy in six-meter yacht racing, after scoring a third triumph in the series off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Y. C. today. The Swiss craft Ylliam VIII, won the first, third and seventh races.

All the office space in the twenty-five-story building just completed on the site of the old Ritz-Carlton Hotel at 380 Madison Avenue has been rented. The last vacant floor was leased by Associated Transport, Inc., trucking concern, according to the Cross Brown Company, agents.

EASTCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Joseph J. Martin, 28 years old, a New York lawyer who was Democratic candidate for Town Clerk of Eastchester i nthe November election, died early today in a fire that swept the attic bedroom he occupied in his parents' two-and-a-half-story frame house at 8 Bronson Avenue in the Green Knolls section.

Plans for altering the four-story dwelling on lot twenty by one hundred feet at 58 East Ninety-second Street into apartments were announced yesterday by Fred H. Hill, who has signed a contract to buy the property from Sigmund Sternberg Jr., and Frank Veith, executors of the Sigmund Sternberg Estate.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Sir Gladwyn Jebb of Britain today asked Asian and African delegates, who are attacking the French administration of Morocco, why they did not ask for a debate on the treatment of Moslems in Soviet Central Asia.

Sales finance companies continued to exert a major influence on the volume of New York bank loans to business last week. Affecting the situation for the seventh successive weekly reporting period, the companies' repayments cut the advance in business borrowings to $6,000,000.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- The stock markets were in hesitant mood today. The recovery on Wall Street yesterday encouraged a modest rise in selected shares but the improvement was short lived and prices soon began to drift lower nearly all markets except British Government securities.
From the Forty-second Street quarters of the Giants yesterday came word of the first step toward the reorganization of Leo Durocher's pitching staff.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Mario Llamas, a young railroad clerk, carried the United States champion, Tony Trabert, to five sets today before losing, 4 -- 6, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 10 -- 8, 6 -- 0, in the quarterfinals of the Pan American tennis tournament.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 8 -- The second International Congress at The Hague, sponsored by the integration-minded European Movement, opened here today under the discouraging auspices of news that the Foreign Ministers' conference scheduled to be held here Oct. 20 had been postponed.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8 -- Mexican border-jumpers, diverted from the Texas area by crop failures and a United States Immigration Service campaign, are crossing the California - Arizona international boundary at a record rate.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- A Yugoslav spokesman denounced here yesterday the decision of the United States and Britain to turn over their zone in the Free Territory of Trieste to Italy.

" West window superintendents" among the 147,000 commuters of the New York Central and New Haven Railroads reported yesterday that the Central's $18,000,000 twin-lift bridge over the Harlem River at 132d Street and Park Avenue was 40 per cent completed.

Although stocks sold off in the last hour or so of a dull market, many small gains remained at the close yesterday and THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average registered a small rise. Du Pont, Norfolk and Western, and Goodrich were among the better performers of the day. Electric equipments made early gains but could not hold them and closed mixed.

However uncertain the outcome of the Korean truce, conditions in Asia call for renewed concentration on economic progress in which the United States can play a key role, it was concluded yesterday at the opening of the annual Far East Conference.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- President Eisenhower said today that a balanced budget still was one of the Administration's firm, basic goals, but he declined to predict when it might be achieved.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 9 -- The United Nations Command said today it would be able to reduce the time required for construction of "explanation" facilities for use by the Communists in Korea from seven days to five. A message to the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission said the Allies, by working around the clock and accepting assistance from the Indian troops could complete temporary arrangements by Sunday.

The cause of Western solidarity has received fresh impetus as a result of two new European developments. One is the return of Secretary Eden to the direction of British foreign policy, signalized by a speech in which he emphasized that the unity and strength of the North Atlantic Alliance are the first condition of Western survival.

PARIS, Oct. 8 (UP) -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther's headquarters today announced plans for the establishment of an Allied tactical air force at Izmir, Turkey, within easy striking distance of the Soviet Union's Caucasus oil fields centered around Baku.

MONTREAL, Oct. 8 (UP) -- Maurice Richard, the greatest goal-getter in the history of hockey, scored twice tonight as the Montreal Canadiens opened the defense of their Stanley Cup laurels with a 3-0 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks before 14,390.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- The lives of school children may be shortened by trying to make them grow faster with school meals and school milk, according to Prof. R. A. McCance of Cambridge, who discusses the problem of overnutrition in the current issue of the British medical journal, the Lancet.

Voters of ninety-five municipalities in twenty-six states and Alaska approved the issuance of $44,579,545 in new issues of bonds during September, compared with $44,205,540 for the same month last year, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The total for August, 1953, was $29,758,600.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 8 -- The Screen Extras Guild, A. F. L., submitted today to producers of motion picture and television films proposals calling for wage increases ranging from 10 to 15 per cent and establishment by the employers of an old-age pension program and a health and welfare fund to include dependents of performers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Government estimated this year's cotton crop today at 15,596,000 bales -- a level that will require a vote by growers on whether they want production controls on next year's crop. Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson is expected to proclaim marketing quotas on the 1954 crop either tomorrow or early next week.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- The Bureau of Child Health of the New York City Department of Health and the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company were among twenty-two organizations named today by the National Safety Council as recipients of its annual merit awards for exceptional public service in home accident prevention.

FRESH CREEK, Andros Island, Bahamas, Oct. 8 -- The light tackle angler should find this brackish creek a happy fishing ground, for the horse-eye jacks, yellowtail snappers and assorted large and small members of the snapper family respond enthusiastically to almost every small underwater lure that is cast more than twenty feet from the bank.

HONG KONG, Oct. 8 -- Communist China declared today that unless it participated in the United Nations the settlement of many major international questions, above all the questions of Asia, would be impossible.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield announced today that the three-cent stamp being issued to commemorate the 300th anniversary of New York City, would be, in over-all design, an artist's conception of New Amsterdam, with a Dutch ship anchored in the harbor.

Registration picked up slightly yesterday -- the fourth day -- but gains in Queens, Richmond and the Bronx failed to match huge slumps in enrollment in Manhattan and Brooklyn. The total registration for four days was 233,992 fewer than in 1949, the last comparable period when a city-wide election was held.

DETROIT, Oct. 8 (UP) -- Earl Reibel, rookie Detroit center, assisted on all four goals tonight as the Red Wings opened their bid for a sixth straight National Hockey League championship with a 4-1 victory over the New York Rangers before 10,493 at Olympia.

EL PASO, Tex., Oct. 8 -- Employment of Mexican farm workers under a "crossing card" system will be started soon, according to Harry Moore, executive secretary of the El Paso Valley Cotton Association, who has just returned from conferences in Washington with Immigration Service officials.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican of Massachusetts, and Speaker of the House of Representatives, declared today, in predicting Republican gains in next year's Congressional election, that every Republican he saw was "tickled to death with conditions."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- The new United States note to Communist China and North Korea received a cool reception here today.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 8 -- Former President Truman called tonight for a joining of all "liberal and progressive" forces in an effort to break the hold of "stand-still" thinking, which he said now gripped many of this nation's leaders.
What do our boys overseas want for Christmas? "Something to remind them of home." That is the unanimous opinion of directors of the United Service Organizations from Guam to Istanb ul.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Delegates attending the forty-eighth annual meeting of the American Life Convention heard today a discussion of the reversal of trends toward "bigger and more powerful government in Washington" and toward "the concentration of emergency powers in the Executive Branch."

The sum spent on advertising by department stores for the November-December period will average about the same as last year although in some instances linage may be down. This was predicted yesterday by Howard. P. Abrahams, manager of the sales promotion division and visual merchandising group of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 8 -- Iran's Communists and their extreme nationalist allies succeeded today in closing Teheran's bazaar and in proclaiming a strike of university students in support of the ousted Premier, Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh.

Demands of a minority group of stockholders for representation on the board of the Minneapolis St. Louis Railway have been rejected by the road's directors. In a letter to Ben W. Heineman of Chicago, head of the minority group, which was made public yesterday, L. C. Sprague, president of the Minneapolis St. Louis, said the demands had been considered by the board at a meeting on Sept. 24.

Columbia Pictures Columbia Pictures Corporation declared a dividend of 25 cents on its common stock and voting trust certificates for common stock, payable on Nov. 5. In addition, directors at their meeting in Hollywood, Calif., declared a 2 1/2 per cent stock dividend on the stock and certificates payable in common stock on Dec. 7. Cash will be paid in lieu of fractional shares.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Federal Judge J. Sam Perry today acquitted the defunct Commercial Home Equipment Corporation and three of its former officers of mail fraud charges.
The New York City Transit Authority reported yesterday that the 15-cent fare on city-owned lines failed in September to yield as much additional revenue for the month as had been expected.
The following book, published recently, may be of interest to homemakers who are considering planning a new kitchen or modernizing an old one:

OTTAWA, Oct. 8 -- A delegation followed Mayor Charlotte Whitton up Parliament Hill today and heard her try to persuade Prime Minister Louis S. Laurent and members of his Cabinet to reconsider a plan approved by Parliament to move the National Film Board from this capital to Montreal.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 8 -- Authorities uncovered new evidence today pointing to Carl Austin Hall as the killer of 6-year-old Bobby Greenlease and prepared to prosecute the kidnapper and his accomplice under state laws for kidnapping and murder.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 8 -- The United States Government was criticized today by John S. Knight of Detroit, president of the Inter-American Press Association, for its response to gestures by President Juan D. Peron of Argentina for rapprochement between the two countries.

American Water Works Company, Inc., a holding company controlling sixty-three waterworks enterprises in nineteen states, announced yesterday that it had placed in registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed public offering of 225,000 shares of $25 par value cumulative preferred stock.

It may come as a surprise to some persons to realize that Pakistan has functioned successfully as an independent state since 1947 without having adopted its own basic constitutional law. This must be attributed in part to the earnest determination of all Pakistanis to make their new Government a success.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- The Foreign Ministry issued a statement tonight denying that the Cabinet had decided yesterday to "propose a five-power conference." The statement said the Ministers had exchanged views on the Soviet reply to the Western note and that "peace in Indo-China remains a constant preoccupation of the Government," but that no decision linking the two problems -- the reply to the Soviet Union and Indo-China -- had been taken."

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Frank Lane, the high-pressure baseball salesman whose deals raised the once lowly White Sox into pennant contention, today failed to swing his hottest trade yet -- himself to the Baltimore Orioles.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- President Eisenhower asserted today that he had never said that the whole Tennessee Valley Authority was an example of socialism, but that certain features conflicted with his political philosophy. The President did not identify those features.

For many years Paris has been considered the world's most difficult city in which to drive an automobile. A street pattern complicated by circles and a lack of stop lights endanger both pedestrians and motorists, who drive with little thought of any speed limit.

MARGATE, England, Oct. 8 -- A policy in which the unity and strength of the Western Alliance form the basis for perserverance in seeking conferences with the Soviet Union, was announced for Britain by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden at the opening of the Conservative party's annual conference today.
Governor Dewey appointed a three-man Moreland Act Commission yesterday to conduct a special inquiry into every phase of harness racing operations in the state.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The president of the National Association of Manufacturers called today for a long-term foreign trade program which should consider "gradual reduction of tariff barriers of all kinds."

Trygve Lie, since his retirement last spring from the United Nations, has been at his mountain lodge in Norway writing a book of memoirs covering his seven years as Secretary-General. Macmillan hopes to publish the book next year.

The names of Mayor Impellitteri, Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen and others will not be enshrined in bronze with the Roebling family as among those who contributed to the history and greatness of the Brooklyn Bridge, the Board of Estimate decided yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Montreal Royals won the little world series tonight as Hamp Coleman blanked the Kansas City Blues for eight innings and coasted to a 7-2 victory in the fifth game of the set.

Six civilian employes at the Army's Fort Monmouth, N. J., radar research laboratories were questioned yesterday at a preliminary hearing in the United States Courthouse by counsel for the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations. The subcommittee, headed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, is investigating Possible Communist infiltration in the armed forces.
Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "Regina," City Center, 8:15; "Rigoletto," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today refused to consider two proposed color telecasting plans on the ground that at this stage they were "merely paper systems."

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 8 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Cheddi Jagan told the House of Assembly tonight that his Leftist Cabinet had decided to send a delegation to London to protest against the landing of troops here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission turned down today a request of motor carriers operating in New York State to permit them to substitute a 50-cent charge for each truck shipment handled in lieu of the surcharge they have been adding since May, 1952, to meet the cost of the state's weight-distance tax.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it would support grower prices of the 1954 wheat crop at a national average of not less than $2.20 a bushel -- or one cent less than the average rate for this year's crop.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Oct. 8 -- The Lawrenceville School's football team, unbeaten last year and with one victory safely tucked away this campaign, has a relatively experienced first eleven but not too much depth.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 8 -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Montclair set a course record today as her team, representing the Women's New Jersey Golf Association, registered a 30-15 victory over a Westchester-Fairfield group at the Montclair Club.
Chicago, Ill., announced yesterday that it would offer on Oct. 27 an issue of $6,000,000 of 1 1/2 per cent highway bonds dated Jan. 1, 1947 and due Jan. 1, 1955 to 1966.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Two favorites were among those eliminated during the two rounds of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship at the Knollwood Country Club today when Claude Harmon of Winged Foot and Jack Patroni of Apawamis, the medalist, went down to defeat.

Plans have been made at recent meetings for the tea, fashion show and cocktail party for the benefit of the American Library in Paris, to be held on Oct. 20 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. A large group of women, including Countess Jean de Lagarde, wife of the French Consul General at New York, and Mrs. Howeth T. Ford, are aiding in the arrangements for the event.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Former President Herbert Hoover and six other prominent Americans announced today that they were circulating a petition, to be presented to President Eisenhower, opposing the admission of the "so-called Chinese People's Republic" to the United Nations.

While the United States is not unknown to John Cavanagh, youngest of the London Big Ten Couture Group, he was professionally a stranger to New York until yesterday morning when he presented a collection of fourteen dresses, suits and coats. The showing took place in the apartment of Princess Helena Gourielli at 625 Park Avenue.
