Plans have been made at recent meetings for the tea, fashion show and cocktail party for the benefit of the American Library in Paris, to be held on Oct. 20 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. A large group of women, including Countess Jean de Lagarde, wife of the French Consul General at New York, and Mrs. Howeth T. Ford, are aiding in the arrangements for the event.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 (UP) -- John Hager, a taxicab driver separated from his wife through lack of money for a home, was disclosed tonight as the man whose tip led to the solution of the kidnapping case.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- The practice of performing brain surgery to relieve epilepsy, which has been fairly common for twenty-five years, was criticized today at the final sessions of the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.

"At Home With Ethel Waters," the one-woman revue in which Miss Waters appears and sings in twenty-two numbers, will be withdrawn from the Forty-eighth Street Theatre after tonight's performance, the twenty-third. Although the revue managed to complete only three of the six weeks planned for it in New York, the notices from the drama reviewers were rather favorable.

It has become the fashion to derogate modern men of the sea. Those who lament the days of the "blue-nose" skippers and bucko mates may well pause and consider the skill with which present-day shipmasters and their crews have plied their profession in recent weeks.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.5 per cent in the week ended Oct. 6 to 110.2, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8 -- Not all the drama of the United Nations is confined to the stage of the General Assembly or to its political stars. Some of it is enacted Tuesdays at 6 P. M. when the United Nations Drama Group, composed of the stagestruck among the Secretariat's 4,000 members, meets in the staff lounge for play-reading in languages and accents reflecting many corners of the world.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Colgate's injury-riddled Red Raiders, previously overwhelmed by Cornell and Holy Cross, appear due for another football setback tomorrow when they engage Harvard in the Stadium.

MIAMI, Oct. 9 -- Progress in the development of an experimental anti-poliomyelitis vaccine is now advanced enough to justify mass testing on children within the next few months. Dr. Jonas E. Salk, research professor of bacteriology at the School of Medicine of the University of Pittsburgh, announced this development in reporting today on research conducted since the original announcement of a vaccine last spring.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Strict Federal controls of the 1954 cotton crop were proclaimed today by Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson, who said the action "will mean very severe adjustments, with a heavy impact on the economy of the Cotton Belt."

Events today: "Carmen," City Center, 2:30 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert, Wilfrid Pelletier conducting, Town Hall, 3; "Die Fledermaus," City Center, 8:15; Martha Schlammel, folk singer, Town Hall, 8:30; Leonard Rose, 'cellist, Washington Irving High School, 8:15.

Riverdale Country School's football team yesterday recorded its fifteenth straight victory over a three-year span when it defeated a neighborhood rival, Horace Mann, 15 -- 0, on the winner's field. This was the opening contest in the Ivy Prep School League, in which Riverdale is the defending titleholder.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- A brief that renews the request for permission for an interchange of aircraft between Eastern Air Lines, Pan American World Airways and Panagra was filed today with the Civil Aeronautics Board.

General Sessions Judge Francis L. Valente ruled inadmissable as evidence yesterday testimony given before the State Crime Commission in July, 1952, by a waterfront public loader now on trial with a long-shoreman on charges of extortion.
Construction begins this month on a United Seamen's Service Center in Pusan, Korea. Pusan will be the fourteenth overseas port with a club for American seamen today.

Mrs. Marie La Guardia urged last night the election of Council President Rudolph Halley as Mayor because, she said, he would give the city the same "clean, honest government" her late husband, Fiorello H. La Guardia, had given the city.
The three Moreland Act Commissioners appointed by Governor Dewey to clean up the state's harness racing tracks said yesterday that their inquiry would not be a "whitewash."

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 9 -- A warning against an "ominous trend to legislate freedom of expression out of existence" was sounded today to the Inter-American Press Association by the chairman of its Freedom of the Press Committee.

With a long week-end ahead, Wall Street slowed down yesterday. Volume was only 900,000 shares, the smallest since the previous Friday, and price changes for the list as a whole were negligible. There were, however, a few exceptions.

Willie Troy, Washington middle-weight, scored a technical knockout over Terry Moore of Baltimore in 2:49 of the seventh round of a scheduled ten-round feature last night at St. Nicholas Arena. The winner outclassed his foe from the start before Referee Al Berl called an end to the one-sided contest.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- The stock markets remained dull here today with prices moving narrowly and irregularly' and tending to drift lower. British Government securities weakened. Price movements in most sections of the industrial market were too mixed to indicate any definite trend.

Motion picture films of alleged bookmakers making "lay-offs" of bets near Broadway and West Fifty-first Street, used by Rudolph Halley, the Liberal party's candidate for Mayor in his television program Thursday night, were received yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and Police Commissioner George P. Monaghan.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, declared today that, although an all-out war with Russia was neither inevitable nor even likely in the near future, this Government should tell the public more about the destructive power of the hydrogen bomb "and the crisis we face."

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 9 -One of the closest contests in the nation's oldest football rivalry is forecast for tomorrow in Palmer Stadium, when Princeton and Rutgers meet for the fifty-fourth time in a series dating to 1869.
Six of this week's exhibitions of paintings are, divided between artists taking a wholly abstract approach and those who stop at their own halfway mark.

Early introduction of more cigarette brands to join at least ten new and fast-growing brands and sizes was predicted yesterday by Lewis Gruber, vice president and director of sales of the P. Lorillard Company. He emphasized, however, that the growing and changing cigarette market shows "no sign of anything like saturation" and is big enough to absorb any meritorious new brand "without violent injury" to established brands.

TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 10 -- The United Nations Command gave the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission, handling the prisoners of war in Korea, assurances today that the Allies would protect the commission against attack by the South Korean Army.

The sixteen district superintendents of the New York area of the Methodist Church met yesterday with the resident Bishop, the Rev. Dr. Frederick B. Newell, at Methodist headquarters, 150 Fifth Avenue, and completed final arrangements for revival services to be held in 1,300 churches in the area.

NEWPORT, R. I. Oct. 9 -- Frederick H. Prince, financier and railroad magnate of this city who died Feb. 2 at Biarritz, France, at the age of 93, left personal property of $13,254,310, exclusive of real estate, according to an inventory filed by his executor, F. B. Kenney, in Probate Court her today.
Good Thief Sunday will be commemorated tomorrow for the first time by Roman Catholics in prisons, reformatories and other correctional institutions in the United States.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Senator Prescott Bush, Republican of Connecticut, today told a luncheon session of the American Life Convention that President Eisenhower is using the economy scalpel to slice away the fat from the military establishment but is not touching the muscle.

The landing of British troops in British Guiana, for the announced purpose of heading off a threatened Communist-fomented uprising, was denounced yesterday by the National Committee of the Communist party, U. S. A., 268 Seventh Avenue. The statement was signed by William Z. Foster, chairman, Elizabeth Gurley Flynn and Pettis Perry.
A woman's desire to live in an apartment instead of a town house led to a $52,000,000 deal yesterday whereby the Chrysler Building and two near-by skyscrapers changed hands.

If all good resolutions and all the many appeals to good citizenship have thus far failed to move you, you still have this one day to get out and register for the November election. The whole day is available, with the registration places open from 7 A. M. to 10:30 P. M.
GEORGETOWN British Guiana, Oct, 9 (AP) -- The British action today in suspending the Jagan Government's leaders was withheld until the troops could land.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- United States diplomatic authorities predicted today that the European Defense Community would be in effect within a few months.

The Philadelphia Orchestra, conducted by Eugene Ormandy, will be heard in a weekly series of one-hour radio concerts over the C. B. S. network beginning early next year. The starting date and time of broadcast have not been set, but C. B. S. said it was considering a Saturday evening hour for the 110-member group. The orchestra has not been Heard on radio regularly for the last four years.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Navy will play Cornell tomorrow in a test that can clearly stamp either team as a major eastern football threat.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 9 -- The 2,002 whites in Nylstroom, a rural center in the Transvaal Province, want to move the 198 inhabitants of Indian descent into the veldt one mile out of town. The Indians own fourteen businesses compared with thirteen held by whites.

The United States Military Academy at West Point, N. Y., has joined the many well-wishers congratulating the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L. I., now observing the tenth anniversary of its founding on Sept. 30, 1943, with a special ten-day celebration.

SWEDESBORO, N. J., Oct. 9 -- The mysterious fatal shooting last night of 3-year-old Lawrence Monahon was solved today, the police said, when the boy's brother and sister admitted he had been shot dead by a 20-gauge shotgun the youngsters had wanted to use in a cowboys and Indians game.

Nicholas Lana of 752 Clawson Street, Oakwood Heights, Staten Island, will be back at his $3,600-a-year job as a laborer in the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity next Tuesday. He was thrown out of work last spring on a technicality.

BOSTON, Oct. 8 -- John Moors Cabot, Assistant Secretary of State for Latin-American Affairs, asserted today that equitable trade was the only door through Which the United States could hope to maintain friendly relations with Latin America.

MARGATE, England, Oct. 9 -The hotel lobbies were full of men and women in evening dress and gay with decorations for service in war and peace tonight as the Conservative party celebrated the climax of its annual conference. Most of the celebrants will be doing the dishes forty-eight hours from now.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The United States stood firmly at the side of Britain today in her suppression of what was termed a threat to this hemisphere by the "international Communist conspiracy'' in British Guiana.

Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Cox made some thoughtful comments in upholding the validity but not the wisdom of a 1951 law mandating retirement of New York City policemen at the age of 63. He said the law was "unwise in its results, in that it deprived the Police Department of a number of its most skilled police officers."

Promises of an invasion of the Red China mainland from Formosa "when the time comes," and appeals to the United States Government not to recognize the Peiping regime were heard by 800 members and friends of the New York Chinese community at a dinner in the Waldorf Astoria Hotel last night on the eve of the anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 9 -- Katsuo Okazaki, Japanese Foreign Minister, said in a formal statement before his departure for Rangoon today that Japan had agreed to by-pass the San Francisco treaty and sign a bilateral peace pact with Indonesia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- James P. Mitchell became the Secretary of Labor today at a brief White House ceremony witnessed by President Eisenhower, the new Secretary's wife and his mother, Mrs. Peter J. Mitchell.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 9 (AP) -- A tropical storm crossed Florida from the Gulf of Mexico to the Atlantic with winds of sixty miles an hour and driving rain today, flooding highways and farmlands.

A 17-year-old youth, awaiting disposition of a simple assault charge against him, raced out of a startled courtroom in Special Sessions yesterday and was recaptured at revolver point in the corridor by three court attendants.
LONDON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Colonial Office statement suspending the Constitution of British Guiana:

Efforts to invalidate the independent nominating petitions for Mayor Impellitteri were assailed yesterday as attempts to "thwart the wishes of many thousands" of voters. Edward C. Maguire, campaign manager for the Mayor, so described the moves made Thursday by supporters of Robert F. Wagner Jr., the Democratic nominee.
"A House on Grand Street," an entertaining Yiddish drama of American Jewish life, was presented last evening at the President Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The International Harvester Company received a patent this week on an invention that automatically feeds each cow in a dairy barn in accordance with its individual requirements. The farmer pre-sets the mechanism and at feeding time merely starts the motor.
YONKERS, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Ferman Hanover, 6-year-old gelding owned by Cleo A. Young of Timmonsville, S. C., won the $6,000 junior free-for-all pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway in 2:04 2-5.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 9 -The Columbia football team, eager to get back on the winning trail after last Saturday's loss to Princeton, travels to the Yale Bowl today to renew one of the nation's oldest football rivalries.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The text of a Yugoslav note to Great Britain and the United States today concerning Trieste follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- President Eisenhower told legislators from thirty-two nations today that the conference table must supplant the battleground as a means of settling disputes if civilization was to progress in the future.

The appointment of Vice Admiral Richard L. Conolly as president of Long Island University, Brooklyn, was announced yesterday by William Zeckendorf, president of the institution's board of trustees. The admiral is expected to assume the position early next month.

Adoption of the nonpartisan recommendations of the temporary state commission appointed to study this city's governmental structure was urged yesterday by Devereux C. Josephs, president of the New York Life Insurance Company and chairman of the commission.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- The Trusteeship Committee of the General Assembly adopted today a resolution that would give the Assembly the power to decide when a dependent area could be considered to have reached selfgovernment.
The following is a round-up of household hints that may be of interest to the homemaker.

The legal fight by five expelled members of the New York local of the National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots of America, A. F. L., to be reinstated in the union is scheduled to be pressed in Supreme Court, Queens, on Tuesday.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 9 (UP) -- The police disclosed today that a factory worker believed to be the Pennsylvania Turnpike murderer who killed two truck drivers had confessed to the murders in Uniontown, Pa., two months ago but had been released.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, told a delegation from the High School Teachers Association yesterday that he did not propose as Mayor to assume the responsibilities of the Board of Education.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -West Germany formally notified the United States today it had paid $17,520,835.99 on its big external debt, which approximates $1,600,000,000.

The six-story factory building at 33-28 to 34-08 Northern Boulevard in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by Seymour A. Berger and another to the Tribune Realty Corporation. Allan Haymes and Hollander Associates were the brokers.

Michael McConnell, a homeless 48-year-old porter and window cleaner who was discharged recently from his job in St. Francis Hospital in the Bronx, was arrainged yesterday in Bronx Magistrate's Court on charges of having stolen $11,000 in cash and checks from the hospital's convent at 525 East l42d Street, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Navy and the Atomic Energy Commission maintained today their set policy of silence on reports that some Navy aircraft carriers in European waters had atomic bombs aboard.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- If every American drank three glasses of milk a day -- the quota established as essential for robust health -- dairymen would not have milk enough to produce a single pound of butter for the Government or anyone else to buy.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 9 -- Age will save Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, Iran's ousted Premier, from hanging even if the court martial scheduled to try him on charges of rebellion should impose the death penalty. The maximum punishment faced by the 72-year-old nationalist leader is two to ten years of solitary confinement.

CAIRO, Oct. 9 -- Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, Deputy Premier, warned Britain tonight that "This Government has never believed for a moment that talks constitute the only means whereby the Fatherland's objectives may be achieved."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Paul M. Herbert, Columbus attorney and former Lieutenant Governor, today asked an Ohio Supreme Court order for Gov. Frank J. Lausche to appoint "forthwith" a successor to the late Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio.

NEWARK, Oct. 9 -- Much of the past attitude toward the handicapped "is a throwback to the days of the Spartans, when the disabled were linked with 'evil spirits,'" Dr. Henry H. Kessler, director of the Institute for Rehabilitation, said today at the sixth annual meeting of the New Jersey Society for Crippled Children and Adults.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Oct. 9 (UP) -- Following are the texts of the letter from Brig. Gen. A. L. Hamblen, United Nations repatriation chief, to Lieut. Gen. K. S. Thimayya, chairman of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission, and accompanying letter addressed to the anti-Communist Chinese and North Korean prisoners of war:

The arcana of maritime law are best left to the learned members of the admiralty bar. However, in recent years dramatic and well-publicized salvage cases like the Greenville, the Flying Enterprise and the American Farmer have aroused the curiosity of the general public in the branch of maritime law dealing with salvage.
The Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., agreed yesterday to submit their dispute over curtailment in transit services to extralegal study by a State Supreme Court Justice.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- The United States has urged South Korea not to make trouble in the Korean zone where 5,000 Indian troops have custody of war prisoners who have refused to go home.

With only eighteen days left to arrange for the political conference on Korea within the time limit fixed by the armistice agreement, the United States, as designated spokesman for the United Nations, has sent another note to the Communists, asking pointblank whether they have any intention of carrying out the armistice agreement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Department of Defense moved today to start work on the construction and improvement of air and naval facilities in Spain. The base agreement with Madrid was signed Sept. 26 after protracted negotiations between the United States and the Franco Government.

Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain received yesterday a public service award from the New York County Council of the Veterans of Foreign Wars. The award, in the form of a plaque, cited Mr. Mulrain's introduction of the alternate-side parking plan, the increased mechanization of street cleaning and refuse collection and the more extensive use of street litter baskets.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 -- Philadelphia's Museum of Art came alive tonight with fashion and pulchritude sweeping through its majestic great hall and down the vast stairway leading to it. The scene was like something from the Renaissance.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 9 -The University of Virginia, an athletic orphan for nearly two decades, joined the Atlantic Coast Conference today. That brought the newly organized league's membership to eight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration today reported another sharp increase in G.I. home-loan applications in September but said that appraisal requests for proposed new dwelling units had dropped during the month.
The Citizens Union endorsed yesterday four candidates for District Attorney in the three counties that will elect prosecutors this year, making a double endorsement for Bronx County.

The futures market held quietly steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and closing prices were 1 point up to 8 points off. Hedge selling was light. There were 15 October notices issued, most of which were stopped by a leading spot concern.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- President Eisenhower will attend the cornerstone laying ceremony for a new library at Defiance College in Ohio next Thursday.

In the past nine years the membership of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, 133 East Sixty-second Street, New York 21, has grown from 28,000 to the present 47,729, making New York's unit the largest single council in the world. The steadily increasing interest in the movement among the girls is understandable, for Scouting concerns itself with teaching all girls of every race, religion and national background -- without preaching to them.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- The Foreign Ministry's denial that the cabinet decided Wednesday to seek a five power conference, including Communist China, was received today with much surprise in political circles, where it was not taken literally.

OMAHA, Oct. 9 -- America's railroads were praised yesterday for the vast improvement in their services by John N. Lind of Pittsburgh, new president of the National Association of Shippers Advisory Boards.
Your editorial of Oct. 3 entitled "City Pension Politics" violates the spirit of judiciousness, impartiality and fact-gathering usually associated with your paper.

The pace of registration moved upward yesterday -- the fifth day -- but the gain of 37,882 over the figure for the fifth day of 1949, the last comparable year when a city-wide election was held, still was not sufficient to overcome voters' apathy earlier in the week.

Brookmeade Stable's His Boots, who won Belmont Park's Grand National Steeplechase when he was a 4-year-old in 1949, did it again yesterday in the role of $6.50-for-$2 favorite in the fifty-third running of the year's top over-the-jumps contest.

In the recorded history of collecting, probably no chapter can equal the spectacular, recently written tale of that little item of the glassmaker's art -- the paperweight. Not even the rise of the Currier Ives star in the last few decades can compare with the cometlike advance of the ingeniously contrived glass spheres.

The Transit Authority opened yesterday, three bids received for supply 200 new cars for the municipal subway lines. The American Car and Foundry Company quoted $121,190 a car plus 2 1/2 per cent for escalation to meet rises in manufacturing costs.

ROME, Oct. 9 -- Amidst shouts of "Viva Trieste!" the Chamber of Deputies made it clear this afternoon that it welcomed the United States-British offer to return Zone A of the free territory of Trieste to Italian administration

Mayor Impellitteri urged the United States Housing and Home Finance Agency yesterday to support a request by the city for an additional Federal grant of $50,000,000 to pave the way for $250,000,000 of slum clearance housing and redevelopment work.

David D. Doniger Co. will use what is described as the greatest retail promotion in the sportswear industry for the McGregor Drizzler Jacket, it was announced by Harry Doniger, president. The campaign will be conducted by 5,000 public and private golf courses, 15,000 driving ranges and 7,000 McGregor retailers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- A preliminary program under which educational institutions would do their own house-cleaning of subversives was tossed today into the complicated policy-making machinery of the American Council on Education.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- Thirteen Asian and African countries presented a resolution tonight calling on the United Nations General Assembly to recommend that Morocco become completely independent within five years.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Roy Campanella's All-Stars, aided by a two-run homer by Junior Gilliam of Brooklyn, unloaded a twelve-hit attack tonight to beat the Birmingham Black Barons, 7 -- 3, in an exhibition baseball game, the second of the day between the two teams.
CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (AP) -- A TV repairman estimated today that Americans will pay $250,000,000 this year to get rid of double images, fuzziness and other faults in their television pictures.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Halfback Paul Cameron scored one touchdown, engineered another and led the University of California at Los Angeles to a 13-0 victory over Wisconsin tonight. A crowd of 69,161 saw the Pacific Coast Conference eleven score its second straight triumph over the Big Ten Badgers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- A total of $938,400 for the 1954 expenses of the United Nations Department of Trusteeship and Information from Non-Self-Governing Territories was approved today by the General Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- The Amorita Cup, for which United States and Bermuda International Class yachtsmen have been sailing since 1939, came back to Long Island Sound today when a four-boat team of local sailors won two of the three concluding races conducted by the American Yacht Club.

A civil anti-trust suit was filed yesterday by the Government in Federal Court against the American Smelting and Refining Company and the St. Joseph Lead Company, two of the largest lead producers in the United States.
Columbia and Fordham find themselves in the spotlight today in two of the numerous attractive offerings on the intercollegiate football program in the East.
TRIESTE, Oct. 9 -- Demonstrations against Italy have been taking place in the frontier towns of the Yugoslav-occupied Zone B of the Free Territory of Trieste.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 9 (UP) -- The kidnap-slayers of 6-year-old Bobby Greenlease will be put in solitary confinement in Kansas City's "Penthouse" jail to protect them from fellow prisoners and mob violence, authorities announced today.

BONN, Germany, Oct 9 -- Two of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's supposed supporters apparently voted against him today when he was re-elected chief of the West German Federal Government. Fourteen others abstained.
ALBANY, Oct. 9 -- The State Banking Department today authorized savings banks to invest in $300,000,000 worth of interest-bearing obligations issued by the General Motors Acceptance Corporation.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Grains developed a strong tone yesterday on broader buying of wheat because of forecasts that the dry spell would continue another five days. Buying in wheat was especially active in July as the drought now is a threat to the 1954 winter wheat crop.

Cardinal Spellman protested yesterday against the alleged refusal by the neutral nations custodial forces in Korea to let Korean and Chinese-speaking Roman Catholic chaplains visit Catholic prisoners of war.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 -- Pennsylvania will seek its third straight football victory this season, and its first over California in the game scheduled at Franklin Field tomorrow. The Quakers have met the Golden Bears five times since 1924, losing by 14 -- 0 that year, by 27 -- 13 in 1927 and by 12 -- 7 in 1929.
A flock of stars from the Lone Star State dominate this week's listing of individual football offense honors for small colleges.
DETROIT, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The nation's auto retailers are selling a lot of new cars right now but it's taking all their ingenuity -- and a lot of price slashing.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- Clarence Doser of Scarsdale eliminated Al Brosch of Cherry Valley, the defending champion, in the semi-final round of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship at the Knollwood Country Club today.

The sleek, seventy-seven-foot yacht Kyma, which once figured prominently in a World War II "phantom convoy" anti-submarine experiment, left yesterday morning as deck cargo aboard the Hamburg-American Line freight vessel Heidelberg.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Budge Patty upset Gardnar Mulloy in the quarter-finals of the Pan American tennis tournament today and the last Mexican player was dropped from the singles competition.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Government reported today that crop production this year will be the third largest of record, exceeded only in 1948 and 1952.

To have parlayed a casual conversation about a new apartment into the biggest real estate deal in New York's history is exactly the sort of flamboyant operation people have come to expect from William Zeckendorf.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today was asked to move quickly to set up rules and regulations to govern pay-as-you-see television.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art will be closed today if a strike of 170 members of the Museum Guardians Union of America, independent, is called at 8 A. M. as threatened.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- The special session of the National Assembly called as a result of the social uproar during the public service strikes in August ended today with rejection of the motions of censure presented by the Socialist and Communist opposition.
LONDON, Oct. 9 -- The British Government announced today that it would ask suspension of the Constitution of British Guiana and a study of a new one.
NEWARK, Oct. 9 -- Thirteen automobiles piled up tonight on a "smog stretch" of the New Jersey Turnpike near here, injuring sixteen persons.
A Federal grand jury took over yesterday the investigation of a work stoppage on Brooklyn piers.
MIAMI, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Miami defeated Clemson with a six-touchdown attack in the second half tonight for a 39-7 victory over the Tigers -- bitter rivals of the Hurricanes in two bowl games.
NEW HOPE, Pa., Oct. 9 -- Gay barge parties, one-time rival of the hay ride, may be restored to the Delaware Canal now that water again flows through the historic waterway.

In a cash deal involving about $1,300,000, Charles F. Noyes has purchased for investment the twelve-story building at 56 to 60 Madison Avenue, southwest corner of Twenty-seventh Street, and a five-story structure forming an "L" at 21 to 25 West Twenty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UP) -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower will drive to Hershey. Pa., next Tuesday for s celebration of the President's sixty-third birthday anniversary.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 9 -Henrik Ibsen's "Tne Lady from the Sea" will be brought to the screen as the result of an unusual collaboration between a New York shipping firm, the Bernuth Lembcke Company, and Allan Dowling Productions.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- The New Rochelle Yacht Club drew an entry of nineteen cruising craft for its annual overnight race to Stratford Shoal, which started tonight from Hick's Ledge off Echo Bay.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Authoritative statements on foreign policy were made at the Conservative party conference yesterday by Anthony Eden, resuming direction of the Foreign Office, and by the Marquess of Salisbury, who has been substituting for Mr. Eden during the latter's illness.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 9 -- Yugoslavia asked the United States and Britain today not to turn Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste over to Italy.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 9 -- Three persons were killed when Orthodox Hindus in Mysore rioted yesterday as athletes belonging to the Untouchable community attempted to participate in wrestling bouts being held at the palace of the Maharajah of Mysore.

"The Builder," a novel by Norbert and Bessie Bergquist, is the only book published today. Issued by Pageant Press at $3, it deals with the life of a man who dreams of establishing newer and finer paper mills. Through the protagonist's experiences the authors portray the growth of the paper mill industry in this country.

A dangerous blind spot in United States foreign policy was evidenced when Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, nudged by Adlai Stevenson, proposed a nonaggression pact for Russia in order to allay the latter's fears of a rearmed Germany.

CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand, Oct. 9 (Reuters) -- Flight Lieut. Roland Burton, British bomber pilot, today won the grueling 12,000-mile England-to-New Zealand air race, flying halfway around the world in 23 hours 51 minutes 7.2 seconds.
MONTREAL, Oct. 9 -- There would be no objections to having a Russian air service join the International Air Transport Association provided it met requirements of the association.
LONDON, Oct. 9 (Reuters) -- There will be no cut in British movie production, J. Arthur Rank announced today at the annual meeting of Odeon Theatres and other companies within his organization.
Although today's households are smaller, the housewife's duties may be heavier than in the past, according to the Office of Information of the Department of Agriculture.

It is much more important for parents to hold to their principles and what they believe to be right or wrong than "abdicate" this responsibility when arguments with teen-age youngsters over behavior problems arise, Dr. Milton R. Sapirstein said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today invited comments from interested parties on a proposal to alter its proxy rules.
CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (AP) -- A Treasury official said today "it will take several years to bring" the nation's financial affairs "into sound order."

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Three persons were missing and believed dead and two were known to be injured in a fire and series of explosions following the collision of a loaded explosives truck and a passenger car just west of Omaha tonight.

Lafayette High School of Brooklyn bids for its eighteenth straight football victory today when it meets New Dorp High at Wagner College Field, Staten Island. The Frenchies, who lost twenty letter men from last fall's team, passed a stern test by beating Brooklyn Tech, 7 -- 6, last week and are likely to continue unbeaten if they turn back New Deep.

The free Asiatic nations received assurances yesterday of United States readiness to help them solve economic and mutual security problems within the limits of its own resources, on the condition that Asians themselves take the initiative.

There used to be a theory that the stronger the libretto the weaker the opera. Much ink has been wasted, pro and con, without anybody really answering the problem. But certainly "Regina," the opera by Marc Blitzstein that returned last night to the stage of the City Center, has a powerful libretto; and the libretto manages to dwarf the music.

FRESH CREEK, Andros, the Bahamas, Oct. 9 -- There may be some Elysian flats where the fabled bonefish are more abundant than they are on the shallow bars of Fresh Creek, but the average angler will have to make the great change before he finds them.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Racing was resumed today at Garden State Park, the pioneer plant in New Jersey, before a crowd of 15,399.

A 27-year-old truck driver, on his way home to escort his pregnant wife to the hospital, took time out yesterday to rescue a woman from the Harlem River and then shrugged off his heroism as something that "happens every day."

CLEVELAND, Oct. 9 -- The United Jewish Appeal reported here today that in the first nine months of this year its constituent bodies had spent $44,356,814 to aid 520,000 distressed persons, including 385,000 in Israel, in eighteen countries on four continents.

GEORGETTWN, Oct. 9 (Reuters) -- The People's Progressive party is expected to make a protest to the United Nations over the British intervention. A party statement said: "We emphasize that there was no threat to life and liberty."

J. Frederic Benedict, owner of a small metal-fabricating plant in Morris, N. Y., near Oneonta in Otsego County, was sworn in yesterday as New York regional director of the Small Business Administration. His area covers this state, New Jersey and Fairfield County, Conn.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 -- Although all girls, whether they go on to college, a career or marriage, or all three, would benefit from a training in home economics, only 25 per cent of high school girls receive such instruction today, Mrs. Julia Kiene, director of the Home Economics Institute of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, told a meeting of home economics teachers here last night.

ROME, Oct. 9 -- The international conference that has been trying to draft a constitution for a European political community, or federation of European states, broke up today after having made more progress than had been thought possible.

HAWORTH, N. J., Oct. 9 -- Mrs. A. J. Bryant of Upper Montclair won low gross honors in the next-to-last one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association today. Playing over the White Beeches course, Mrs. Bryant led home a field of forty-six contestants with a 3-over-par 41, 36 -- 77.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UP) -- The public wasn't supposed to know this yet, but the Army has developed a new "mechanical mule" that is about as ornery as the old oat-eating variety. The four-wheeled secret kicked over its security traces at a weapons demonstration at the Aberdeen, Md., proving grounds.

There is the fellow -- call him the meteorological reactionary -- who never seems to believe it when the weather changes. You remember him from the first hanging-hot days of June, the chap in the heavy tweed suit and the watertight stormproof shoes, bounding out of his house in the morning as if it were a nippy March evening.

Ancient political ground rules have been revised here this year to cope with Mayor Impellitteri's personality, as paradoxical in politics as his election in 1950. Mudslinging is restrained and the trade-mark of this campaign's attacks on the Mayor is the preface: "The Mayor is a very nice man personally, but -- "

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Calvin Griffith, vice president of the Senators, said today the Washington club would not stand in the way if the post of general manager of the newly formed Baltimore Orioles should be offered to Bucky Harris.
HONOLULU, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Vice President and Mrs. Richard M. Nixon were literally up to their waists in well wishers today -- shouting, running elementary school students who almost mobbed them.
New issues of public school bonds totaling $40,000,000 were posted for sale yesterday by the State of South Carolina and the city of Philadelphia.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 9 -- A drastic reform of exchange policy is now being discussed by Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, Minister of Finance, embracing a new program to issue exchange for coverage of imports through the free market.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, interrupted his British West Indies wedding trip today to fly back to this country to participate in an investigation of alleged security leaks at Fort Monmouth, N. J.

The personnel of the United States aircraft carrier Hornet gave 647 pints of blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Program in a four-day collection that ended yesterday. Each day two bloodmobiles were in operation aboard the carrier at the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn.

JAMESBURG, N. J., Oct. 9 -- Despite an 8 on the par-5 thirteenth hole today, Milton (Babe) Lichardus of Baltusrol clung to a four-stroke lead at the midway point of the New Jersey's P. G. A. 72-hole championship over the Forsgate Country Club course.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 9 -Army and Dartmouth, both smarting from setbacks suffered a week ago, will meet for the fifth time since 1895 before an estimated crowd of 20,000 at Michie Stadium tomorrow.
ANDERSON, Ind., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Carl Erskine, who is accustomed to public appearances but lets his right arm do most of his talking, was named Mayor-for-the-day in his home town today.

SEATTLE, Oct. 9 -- Dr. Dennis Jackson, Professor Emeritus of Pharmacology at the University of Cincinnati, was honored by the American Society of Anesthesiologists for his service to their profession by being elected to honorary membership. Dr. Jackson in 1915 developed in experiments with animals the basic techniques now used in anesthesia on humans (employment of an alkali to absorb carbon dioxide).
Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor, declared yesterday that Rudolph Halley was "a faker, a liar, a phony, a hypocrite and an opportunist."

Arnold Galiffa, an All-America quarterback at West Point in 1949, signed a contract yesterday to play for the New York Football Giants. The former cadet was acquired from Green Bay in a deal that had sent Val Joe Walker, a defensive halfback from Southern Methodist, to the Packers earlier this season.

Coffee prices continued to tumble yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange on persistent rumors of a change in Brazil's export policy that would increase the percentage of the coffee cost that could be negotiated on the free cruzeiro market.

As many of the Chinese as are still free will observe today the annual Double Ten anniversary, so called because it falls on the tenth day of the tenth month. It commemorates the proclamation, forty-two years ago, of a new and free China by Dr. Sun Yat-sen.

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- Commissioner Frank Mascola of the New York office of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service will preside over a meeting between the management of Rockland Coaches, Inc., and its 253 bus drivers to be held in Bergenfield, N. J., Monday morning, when an attempt will be made to end the differences between the company and its drivers.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 10 (UP) -- Virginia celebrated its admission to the Atlantic Coast Conference today with a 24-20 upset victory over George Washington.

The National Agricultural Institute, sparked by the passing and running of its freshman quarterback, Will Thompson, sent Brooklyn College to its third straight loss of the season by 27 to 14 at Brooklyn College Field yesterday.

Under the American principle of national origin -- "If a cat has kittens in an oven they are biscuits," Mark Twain put it -- Peter T. Lamont is a Netherlander. For Mr. Lamont, coordinator of marketing for the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) was born in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, in 1900.

Rudolph Halley, Liberal party candidate for Mayor, outlined yesterday a comprehensive program for attacking the city's traffic problem. He stressed rigid enforcement of parking regulations and the creation of additional off-street parking facilities.

The facts are most impressive: Scheduled airline flying and certain other forms of civil flying are now reasonably safe and are becoming safer all the time.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- The favorite project of United States foreign policy is o help create an integrated European Defense Community. The supranational army established by such a body within the framework of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would include German divisions. Thus West Germany would be rearmed, helping to restore the Continent's military balance and, at the same time, a long step would be taken toward the eventual goal of a United Europe.
EASTON, Pa., Oct. 10 -- Muhlenberg College. held to a 7-7 tie in the first half, scored on marches of 71 and 38 yards to upset Lafayette, 20 -- 7, at Fisher Field today.

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 10 -- Texas Republicans will make another bid for support in the next Congressional elections when the party's national chairman, Leonard W. Hall, arrives for visits tomorrow, Monday and Tuesday in major Texas cities.

FRESH CREEK, Andros, Bahamas, Oct. 10 -- This broad creek, which has not attained river status despite its mile-wide spread at several points, is one of the greatest concentration areas for bonefish we have ever seen, and we have never heard of flats where more of these torpedo-shaped scrappers could be taken in such large numbers in such brief periods.

In the absence of directions in a last will and testament that the estate taxes shall be paid out of specific funds or properties of the estate, as, for example, out of the residuary estate, they are required under New York State law to be equitably apportioned among the persons interested in the gross estate.
OXFORD, Miss., Oct. 10 (AP) -Mississippi, sparked by the running of Earl Blair and the defensive line play of Crawford Mims, rolled to a decisive 28-6 victory over Vanderbilt today.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- Syracuse's football team dug way down into its bag of tricks and brought out a play youngsters might use in a sandlot game to clinch a 20-to-13 victory over Fordham at Archbold Stadium today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 -- On the basis of coal production, employe hours in manufacturing and industrial power sales, the index of industrial activity in Pennsylvania reached a new high for August. The index stood at 230 points, a gain of 14 points or 6 per cent over the level reported for August, 1952, according to statistics compiled by the Bureau of Business Research at the Pennsylvania State College.

BERLIN, Oct. 10 -- West Berlin's United States-supported food-give-away program ended today. A total of 5,500,000 rations were distributed to residents of East Germany and the Soviet sector of Berlin in the eleven weeks of operation.

THANKS in large part to the resourcefulness of the Broadway theatre, "Tea and Sympathy" is the first big popular success of the season. Not that the play is a mediocre one. It is an uncommonly discerning study of character.

MADRID, Oct. 10 (Reuters) -- Hard on the heels of Spain's signing of the defense-and-aid agreement with the United States has come the announcement that Spain's only political party, the Falange, will hold its first National Congress since the Civil War ended in 1939.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 10 (AP) -Pronto Boy, 2-year-old trotting gelding from the Hayes Fair Acres stable of Duquoin, Ill., equaled his world record today in winning the $11,400 Lexington Stake at the final session of a Grand Circuit meeting.

SEATTLE, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Five admitted Pacific Northwest Communist leaders were convicted by a Federal court jury today of conspiring against the Government, but the sixth defendant in the twenty-five-week trial, Karly Larsen, was acquitted.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10 -- Once again victory beckoned to Columbia's football team today and then eluded it as the Lions lost to Yale by 13 -- 7 in the Bowl.

MAUCKPORT, Ind., Oct. 10 -Hoosier history teachers, students and other citizens interested in Indiana lore, gathered here today to study their "history on wheels." The two-day trio, part of the Hoosier Historical Hours, is retracing the cross-country raid of Brig. Gen John Hunt Morgan, who cut a wide swath across southern Indiana with his Confederate cohorts during the Civil War.

THERE is a delightful excitement in the discovery, on picking up a book by an unfamiliar author, on a subject all too familiar, that the book has added something fine and valuable. That was this writer's experience on reading The Inward Journey."

LOOKING through The London Times Literary Supplement the other day we were struck by a letter in the letters column that called for the formation of a society whose sole aim was the promotion of friendship and cultural relations between England and Texas.

LINVILLE, N. C. -- North Carolina's Grandfather Mountain, just off the Blue Ridge Parkway and long popular with tourists for its panoramic views, its spring blossoms and fall foliage spectacle, now has a new facility for sight-seeing.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- This business community is studying a report by planning experts who forecast what their report calls an "exodus of city population and business" unless something is done to stop the flow of families and commerce to the suburban regions of this industrial area.

AVIATION'S crystal ball is so transparent that it reaches out to infinity, making the dream prophecies of Jules Verne come true on a basis of scientific probability. To get a practical prophecy of the future THE NEW YORK TIMES asked responsible leaders in various aspects of aviation -- airlines, aircraft manufacturers, experimenters, pilots, etc. -- to give their imaginations free rein in answering this question: Where do you think aviation will be in 2003?

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 10 (UP) -Paul Giel and Bob McNamara sparked Minnesota to a 30-to-13 upset of Northwestern in a Big Ten Conference game today. The Gophers cracked the Wildcats open with punt returns, line smashes and passes.
Yale beat Columbia and Syracuse defeated Fordham yesterday. Scores of leading games:

TODAY some of the best aerial training in the world is being given our commercial and military pilots without taking them a foot off the ground. The "flying" has been done since 1947 by means of complex devices known as simulators which, although they are expensive to build, are saving the airlines and the military forces plenty of money.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Agriculture Committee of the House of Representatives called on the Secretary of Agriculture today to extend price supports to cattle immediately lest "economic disaster" overcome producers.

MANILA, Sunday, Oct. 11 (UP) -- The American correspondents. Richard Applegate and Donald Dixon, were reported in jail in the Red China port city of Whampoa, near Canton, as recently as mid-August, it was learned today. The information came from a traveler, who received it from a Communist police official in Whampoa.

DETROIT, Oct. 10 -- Two vote-getting Democratic Governors, Frank J. Lausche of Ohio and G. Mennen Williams of Michigan, hold the key to Republican strategy in both states for the election next year. Because their plans for 1954 are not yet certain the Governors have become models of reticence that keeps the Republicans and their own Democratic partisans guessing.

WALTER TERRY will open his annual series of demonstration-interviews at the Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street, next Sunday afternoon at 2:40, with Frederick Ashton as the artist of the day.

WASHINGTON -- At least fifty of the world's air pioneers will assemble here this week to observe the fiftieth anniversary of powered flight. Many of them were in the air almost from the beginning. One phase of the observance will be a pilgrimage this Tuesday to Kitty Hawk.
LONDON, Oct. 10 -- For the second time in three days, a huge London audience acclaimed the opening performance of an American musical.

AIRPLANES make noise. The bigger airplanes get and the more of them there are flying, the more noise they make. This displeases people living near airports where planes take off and land all day and night. The people complain, and that worries the airlines and the airplane manufacturers.

TO date, all efforts to mate science fiction with the murder mystery have failed in varying degrees and for various reasons. In this latest try at such crossbreeding the usually adept Sam Merwin is no luckier than his predecessors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)--The Postmaster General, Arthur E. Summerfield, said today he and his wife would not contest further a claim costing them more than $100,000, filed by the Internal Revenue Service.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 10 (UP) -The Inter-American Press Association appealed today to five Latin-American Presidents to put an end to onerous restrictions on newspapers and newspaper men in their countries.

PERSONIFIED boats and trains are familiar and popular figures in stories for small children. This is, however, the first time I have come an animated mailbox. This mailbox hasn't as much personality as "Little Toot" or "The Little Red Engine," but he has his pride.

WACO, Tex., Oct. 10 (UP) -- Francis (Cotton) Davidson fired a touchdown pass to Wayne Hopkins with less than three minutes left to play today and gave Baylor a 14-7 victory over Arkansas before 25,000 fans.

TRENTON, Oct. 10 -- Naturalized citizens often take greater pride in their new allegiance than do native Americans, Judge Phillip H. Forman of the United States District Court here told the first session of the New Jersey State Conference on Citizenship today at the Trenton State Teachers College.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP) -Movie censorship, "fair trade" and self-incrimination are among the constitutional issues docketed for the Supreme Court's first business session on Monday.

A GREATLY traveled British author, Ann Bridge, specializes in the production of novels set in all those thrilling places she's seen. Her last book, "The Dark Moment," was about exciting, modern Turkey. Yet it can surely give no offense to the Turks to suggest that "A Place to Stand," which is about wartime Hungary, may offer even greater interest to the reader.
Another area of upper Manhattan will be brought under the alternate-side-of-the-street parking ban on Tuesday, the Departments of Traffic and Sanitation announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 -- The ambitious schedule that Pennsylvania's departed administration wished on a reluctant George Munger caught up to the Red and Blue with a vengeance today. California, twice beaten in faster company, swamped the previously undefeated Quakers, 40 -- 0, before 52,000 at Franklin Field.

DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 10 (UP) -Jerry Barger, an understudy quarterback, guided Duke 66 yards to a winning touchdown in the last 39 seconds today as the Blue Devils downed Purdue, 20 to 14, before 30,000 fans to stay unbeaten and untied.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 10 -- Fighting back in the last quarter when it scored twice to Brown's once, the University of Rhode Island football team today defeated the Bruins, 19 to 13, for the second consecutive time.

LIGONIER, Pa., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Favored Uncle Joe, a 6-year-old brown gelding owned by Mrs. T. A. Randolph of Upperville, Va., won the sixteenth running of the International Gold Cup race in record time before 16,000 today at the Rolling Rock Hunt Association's meeting.
LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Rumblings of protest were heard from the British Labor party today against the Conservative Government's action suspending the Left-Wing elected Government of British Guiana.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- It was only a few days ago that Army's coach, Col. Earl (Red) Blaik, said that lack of endurance was a contributing factor in the Cadets' defeat at the hands of Northwestern last week.

The new Swedish American liner Kungsholm sailed Friday from the Dutch shipyard in Flushing, where she had been completed, for her home port of Goeteborg. The 22,000-ton liner is scheduled to arrive today in the Swedish port, where she will receive a warm welcome from Government and shipping officials.

WHEN John Caldwell told "The Korea Story" he wrote a bitter and angry book. His new book. "China Coast Family" is entirely different. It is gentle, tender and warm, often nostalgic, and it is deeply moving.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- The week of talk in Washington about the Russians and the hydrogen bomb -- they have, they haven't; they can, they can't -- found the United Nations too numbed by seven years of atomic chatter and atomic deadlock to react at all.

This is the time of year when a vegetable garden needs a frost. The gardener himself secretly wishes for a frost, though it isn't quite cricket to come right out and say so. Openly he is expected to brag about the tomatoes he still has ripening. Actually, he has ripened just about enough tomatoes for this year.

Women interested in the work of the George Junior Republic are active in the arrangements for the third annual dinner in behalf of the organization to be held on Wednesday night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. J. Truman Bidwell is chairman of the organization's Women's Executive Committee, and serving with her as co-chairmen are Mrs. Robert H. Ellinger, Mrs. Donald Perkins, Mrs. Frank E. Adair and Mrs. C. C. Jolliffe.

SORRY, but this is not going to be written on a birch hark scroll with a wild goose quill dipped in berry juice. Those days are gone, we hope, forever. Whether the Outdoor Man is one of the world's most civilized individuals or not is a matter of opinion, but he is no savage.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Oct. 10 -Ceylonese rubber interests are strongly opposed to a recommendation of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development that no more land in Ceylon should be brought under rubber cultivation.

ANY list of the world's greatest fictional detectives must perforce include Georges Simenon's patient, shrewd, stolid yet sensitive Commissaire Jules Maigret (who is regularly demoted in English to inspector, a lowly rank in the French police force).

Deep in the ocean is a scattering layer which derives its name from the fact that concentrations of marine organisms reflect sounds that strike them. The layer appears on ships' depth traders during the day as a false bottom, rises to the surface or disappears at night.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 10 -- Long-rumored rifts in the Indonesian Communist party broke into the open yesterday following a three-day plenary session of the party's Central Committee.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 10 -The first primary in Greenwich's history will be conducted on Tuesday when three candidates will seek the Republican nomination for first selectman and two Democrats will vie for that party's top position. Contests will also be held for the second selectman nomination in each party.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP) -- The board of directors of the American Society of Newspaper Editors elected sixteen new members today. They are:
BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 10 (AP) -- An inspired Kentucky football team refused to crumble before Louisiana State University's hard-charging line and fought favored L. S. U. to a 6-6 deadlock tonight.

MR. MURFIT'S pet shop was very small; Hector was very large. As genial a dog as ever lived, Hector worked havoc among the goldfish and white mice every time he wagged his tail -- which was often. Try as hard as he could, Mr. Murfit, a kindly man and a worried one, couldn't find a proper home for Hector; customers preferred dear little Chihuahuas.
THE meaning of every bid in bridge is limited by what the same player did before. A bid may sound strong but be weak, if the player has shown unmistakably by a previous bid that he has a weak hand.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 10 -- Yugoslavia has moved armed reinforcements into Zone B of the Free Territory of Trieste.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 10 -- An attempt by Iranian naval personnel to sabotage the patrol ship Babr in Khorramshahr harbor eight days ago has resulted in the relief of the admiral, a relative of ousted Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, commanding Zone 1 of the Persian Gulf Commana and the arrest of forty-four sailors, according to reports today from general staff sources.

LIST Walt Disney and his colleagues as long-range planners. Although the producer already has something like a dozen live-action and cartoon features lined up for release through 1955, his company is quietly preparing another three numbers worthy of comment.

Four hours after he had slipped an engagement ring on his fiancee's finger, Eugene O'Neill, 21 years old, of 50-21 Forty-third Street, Woodside, Queens, was killed yesterday at 2 A. M. when his automobile went out of control on the Meeker Avenue Bridge between Brooklyn and Queens.

HIGH speeds in the air are accepted so casually today that we tend to forget another big advantage of flying: covering long distances with ease and comfort and reaching inaccessible places. But it is because the airplane can shake itself free of the ground and sail over mountains and deserts that it is used extensively for all kinds of exploration and surveillance.
OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., Oct. 10 -- The man who pioneered the belt conveyor in 1891 has a host of ideas on how things and people are going to move in the future.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 10 -- One of the highlights of this city's observance of the sesquicentennial of the Louisiana Purchase will be the opening Friday at the historic Cabildo of a $50,000 Purchase exhibition of rare French art and documents.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- United States prestige among its traditional friends abroad has suffered serious decline while at the same time liberties are being threatened at home because of the rise of demagogues and a disturbance of balance in the functions of constitutional government, Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, declared tonight.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- Toplight Template of Twin Ponds, owned by Mrs. Edward P. Alker and handled by John Goudie, was named best of breed at the annual fall specialty show of the Welsh Terrier Club of America at Strathglass Farm, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh J. Chisholm, today.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- Ben Hogan, the American and British Open and Masters champion, up from Fort Worth to help honor Winged Foot Golf Club's golfers at the annual "Night of Champions" banquet this evening, teamed with Doug Ford of Harrison, N. Y., in a best-ball exhibition today.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 10 (UP) -- Quarterback Duncan McDonald stepped off the bench today to throw a touchdown pass in the fourth period that enabled Michigan to gain a 14-13 victory over Iowa in its Big Ten opener.
The beleaguered International Longshoremen's Association, already under attack in the Port of New York, fought yesterday to hang on to its Southern locals.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 10 -More than 15,000 men, representing Roman Catholic parishes in Union County, are expected to march here tomorrow, in the annual parade of the Union County Federation of Holy Name Societies.

A city survey of the ferry service between St. George, S. I., and Sixty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, indicated yesterday that future operation by the city probably would mean a 20 per cent increase in vehicular fares to avoid yearly deficits.

TWO fairs were held last summer in Madrid -- one an agricultural fair under the umbrella pines of the Casa del Camo and the other a book fair in the Paseo de Recoletos. The first was by American standards a small town show, in which the best exhibits were those of peasant costumes and of that delightful but useless animal, the Arab horse.

MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 10 -- With factories and ranch houses rapidly springing up on the farmland of Nassau County, the Mineola Fair found it impossible to mount an old-fashioned county agricultural exposition here today.

SIR ARTHUR CONAN DOYLE'S hound, that one wearing the Baskerville silks, better pull over to the side of the track. This Maine beast is too fast for him, in fact for any literary hound that ever slavered over a quarry or bayed the moon.

ONE of the central questions of our time is the future shape and nature of Soviet power. That great divide which was the death of Joseph Stalin raised this question with the greatest urgency. If, as Isaac Deutscher has argued, the Stalinist dictatorship was an anachronism already when its founder died and the future likelihood is for Russia's "democratic regeneration," then the problems before us have one hue.

SEATTLE, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Stunned by the Huskies of Washington, the Southern California Trojans needed two long runs by Aramis Dandoy and Lindon Crow to salvage a 13-13 tie today in their Pacific Coast Conference football game.

HARTFORD, Oct. 10 -- Top political leaders in both major parties in this state are trying to read some meaning into the results of elections this week in 129 of the state's 169 communities, but they are having a difficult time doing so.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The next three months are a seedtime for the Eisenhower Administration -- a Period of making ready for what may be its most crucial year.

An audience of 1,300, consisting mostly of children from 4 to 8 years old, attended the first of the season's young people's concerts presented by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony. Being one of three concerts in the Introductory Series, the event was at Town Hall.

PEOPLE sometimes ask if the comedy, "The Teahouse of the August Moon," is not, in reality, a serious piece of work. Then I hasten to point out that they should make the "Teahouse" what they wish, for it was meant to be that way.

In his article, "The 'Outsider' Who Is Harvard's President," (Sept. 27) Gilbert Bailey says Nathan Pusey "to be near New York * * * got a job teaching at the private Riverside School" some twenty-five years ago.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 10 (AP) -- The initial Saturday of the Garden State Park fall meeting attracted a crowd of 28,627 today. The feature was the $25,000-added Quaker City Handicap, first of seven stakes on the agenda of the twenty-five-day session.

ALBANY, Calif., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Aided by a disqualification in the $25,000-added Golden Gate Mile Handicap, Willie Shoemaker pushed home six more winners at Golden Gate Fields today to run his season victory total to 385 -- only five short of the record.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 10 -- Trygve Lie, former Secretary General of the United Nations, emphasized here tonight the need for the free world to speed up the economic development of underprivileged areas.

Bank operations in the quarter ended Sept. 30 gave no indication of an adverse change in business conditions. On the contrary, leading New York City institutions reported higher earnings for the period than a year ago, more loans and an increase in other earning assets.

New chairmen have been chosen for the division on the welfare of the aged and for the division of child welfare of the Welfare and Health Council of New York, it was announced yesterday by J. Donald Kingsley, executive director of that organization with headquarters at 44 East Twenty-third Street.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 10--Plans have been completed by IMiss Frances Delaffele, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dominic DeRaffele, for her marriage to Joseph DeClerk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. DeClerk of Woodhaven !L.I.

FOR a number of years after the first flights of the Wright Brothers it was possible for any talented individual to learn and know all there was to be known about aeronautics and aircraft design. In the years since there has been a profound change; today it is impossible to discover the individual designer of one of our modern airplanes because there is no such person.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP) -- The State Department said tonight it was "very seriously concerned" over Red China's "unjustified" imprisonment of thirty-three Americans, including two correspondents who disappeared after having been seized March 21 near Hong Kong.

Teachers of physics from twenty-five colleges in central Pennsylvania have been invited to Bucknell University for a two-day conference, Oct. 23-24, at which they will discuss teaching techniques and hear addresses by several prominent physicists. The conference has been called by the Central Pennsylvania section of the American Association of Physics Teachers.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Oct. 10 -- A Homecoming Day crowd of 4,200 saw the United States Merchant Marine Academy defeat Rensselaer Poly of Troy, 24 -- 6, today for the fifth time in five meetings between the schools at Tomb Memorial Field.

WITH "The Caine Mutiny," more than two years after its appearance as a book, finally committed to film and the film draped in graceful loops around a Columbia studio cutting-room, some of the principals in the project could take time out last week to elucidate on the sizable fabric of legendry that has grown up around it.

AUSTRALIA, like this country, has been having an offshore resources argument. But it is not over oil, nor is it a states-rights dispute. It is a running controversy with Japan over offshore pearl fishing grounds, which Australia prizes so much that she recently asserted her right to control them to the limits of her continental shelf, up to 200 miles from shore.

LATE Professor of Geology at the University of Bonn, Hans Cloos was one of the German scientists who did not sympathize with the aims of the Nazi Government. During World War II -- as a valve and a means of salvation from the confinement, brute force and untruth of the times -- he began writing about great upheavals of the past and other problems that interested him.

AS a coin collector, I am very curious about the significance of the facsimile of the United States 1853 gold dollar in the upper right-hand corner of your Sept. 6 cover photograph. It would seem odd to go back a hundred years to a coin now obsolete, and certainly most unfamiliar to the people of Germany, for a symbol of significance to the present election.
TAIPEI, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Nationalist China celebrated its "Double Tenth" Independence Day today with a flag-starred show of its reviving military power.

The rebirth of the Seattle Gas Company, once crumbling under the pressure of public electric power's tax-exempt competition, is a saga of the Pacific Northwest. It symbolizes, along with other gas companies in the region, the determination of industrial and utility executives in the territory to bring an adequate supply of natural gas at the cheapest cost to the only major area in the United States without this all-important fuel.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- Mining and manufacturing production throughout the world, excluding the Soviet Union, reached a record height in April, May and June of this year.
