STORRS, Conn., Oct. 10 -- The University of Connecticut opened its new half-million dollar Memorial Stadium today by beating the previously undefeated St. Lawrence football team, 26 -- 6.

ONCE again T. S. Eliot's "The Confidential Clerk" is the play of the month and now that its short season at the Edinburgh Festival is over and it has opened in London for a run which gives every promise of great success, I make no apology for bringing it up once more.

Albert M. Cole, administrator of the United States Housing and Home Finance Agency, returned to Washington yesterday after touring housing projects with City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses, Chairman Philip J. Cruise of the New York City Housing Authority and aides.

Rabbi Israel Goldstein, president of the American Jewish Congress, in a sermon yesterday morning at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street, suggested a group of twelve Christian and Jewish philosophers and religious leaders meet in "a small neutral country" and arrive at a solution of today's international problems.

THE Wright brothers transformed gliding into powered flight with the combination of two wooden propellers and a small gasoline engine that would not run the ordinary automobile of today -- a four-cylinder piston machine of twelve horsepower.

RENEWED interest in surface decoration on all furnishings for the home is reflected in the new patterns on fabrics, wall coverings and rugs, a sampling of which is pictured here. Unlike examples of last year and the year before, they are primarily illustrative. Distinctive designs, often large in scale and almost always picturing recognizable objects, have replaced the over-all pattern effect of last year, when printed patterns often imitated woven textures.

THE cool tang in the October air feels good on many a retailer's fevered brow. "Seasonable" weather will insure movement of soft lines such as coats and suits and children's cold-weather apparel. There has been no serious doubt about the salability of these goods, but the extra push provided by the cool breezes will dispel the need for premature mark-downs.

BOSTON, Oct. 10 -- The four New England states that share the Connecticut River Valley have agreed to work together in cooperation with the Federal Government in plans for a system to control floods in the stream.

PULLMAN, Wash., Oct. 10 (UP) -- Washington State College, led by Halfback Wayne Berry and Fullback Vaughn Hitchcock, a sophomore, scored a second period touchdown today and then held off a last ditch aerial attack to gain a 7-0 victory over favored Oregon in a Pacific Coast Conference football game before 15,000 Homecoming fans.

An official reception at City Hall, following a parade from the Battery, will be extended to King Paul and Queen Frederika of Greece upon their arrival here Nov. 2, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's Reception Committee.
The largest chain of home furnishings stores in the country reviewed its first six months of operation last week. It gave itself good marks for better than satisfactory performance.

A three-day holiday week-end celebrating the 461st anniversary of the discovery of America by Christopher Columbus began yesterday with a heavy outflow of New Yorkers to the country to enjoy the beautiful fall weather.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, declared yesterday that the submission of the dispute between the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., to an "impartial adviser" had cleared the way for a reduction in transit fares at the earliest possible date.

WAKE FOREST, N. C., Oct. 10 (UP) -- Connie Gravitte, a halfback who was better known as a baseball star before today, made some sensational catches of a football to lead North Carolina's Tar Heels to a last-quarter, 18 to 13 victory over Wake Forest.

BRUSSELS -- At 7:15 on a September morning, a United States-built Sikorsky S-55 helicopter lifted from the heliport almost in the center of Brussels and set course for Antwerp and Rotterdam. This helicopter, owned and operated by Sabena, the Belgian national airline. was inaugurating the world's first international passenger helicopter service.

FORTY years ago, Dr. Bela Schick, a young Hungarian scientist at the University of Vienna, devised a test which was to contribute greatly to repressing diphtheria, then a widespread scourge especially virulent among children. In diphtheria, certain bacilli cause the formation of false membranes in air passages, especially the throat.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 10 -Emboldened by the unparalleled voting support for the Republican party in the South under President Eisenhower's leadership in last year's election, Birmingham Republicans on Monday will make their first bid in the city's history to capture control of the municipal administration.

UNQUESTIONABLY a good many readers will be lifted to honest heights of emotion by Paul Gallico's inspirational little story about an anxious and thoughtful snowflake. Born in the heart of a cold, gray cloud, Snowflake falls to the earth, where her adventures begin.

BELGRADE, Oct. 10 -- Things do not change, said Thoreau; we -- that is, people -- change. And this is confirmed once again in the reaction both here and in Rome to the American-British decision to turn Trieste over to Italy.

TOKYO, Oct. 10 -- The Chinese Communists announced tonight that they and the North Koreans had accepted the United States' proposal for a meeting to arrange the time and place of a political conference on Korea.

VIENNA, Oct. 10 (Reuters) -The Communist-backed World Federation of Trade Unions today called on its members to woo non-Communist unions away from their present affiliations by joining their strikes or getting them to join W. F. T. U. strikes.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- A Casablanca newspaper, La Vigie Marocaine, declared today that the French Government had documents showing that Sidi Mohammed Ben Youssef, deposed Sultan of Morocco, had made overtures to Hitler's Germany through her Consul General in Tangiers during the last war.

One of the important hormones secreted by the pituitary gland, which lies at the base of the brain, is oxytocin, which plays its part in childbirth and the flow of milk. From Cornell University Medical College comes the news that Dr. Vincent du Vigneaud and his associates, Drs. Charlotte Ressler, John M. Swan, Carleton W. Roberts, Panayotis G. Katsoyannis and Samuel Gordon, have synthesized oxytocin.
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 16 (AP) -- An Alabama team that had trouble getting started, finally awoke today to rout Tulsa 41 to 13.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 10 (UP) -Georgia Tech found its long-sought scoring punch in Quarterback Bill Brigman and Glenn Turner today to blast a crippled Tulane eleven, 27 to 13, and stretch college football's longest unbeaten streak to thirty games.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UP) C. C. Shah, Indian delegate to the Interparliamentary Union, told the assembly today that "no international organization is effective unless we bring all nations to the conference table."

NOTRE DAME, Ind., Oct. 10 -An exhibition of modern paintings, believed to be the finest ever assembled in the Midwest, will be a feature of the festival of the arts opening Monday at the University of Notre Dame.

With five men among the first seven finishers, Georgetown University defeated St. John's University and Fordham over the five-mile varsity cross-country course at Van Cortlandt park yesterday. Georgetown compiled the low total of 25 points to 41 for St. John's and 73 for Fordham.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 10 (AP) -- The University of Rochester defeated Union College, 21 -- 7, today in a game marked by long runs and an injury to Linesman Lawrence T. O'Neil.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- Mobility, Inc., a Westchester County philanthropic organization dedicated to the care of physically handicapped persons, will embark on a new phase of its work Tuesday by opening a workshop here in an old brick building at 13 North Central Avenue.

NINE years ago Deborah Kerr (it rhymes with star) left England (she was born in Scotland) to come to America. Nine is a favorite mystical number, and it has favored Miss Kerr. In her ninth working year here, she has demonstrated beyond a shadow of a doubt to both believers and doubters that her talents, if quiet and finite, are none the less brilliant and subtle.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 10 -Plagued by political dissension, spreading regional rebellion and economic hardship, Indonesia is undergoing a severe testing of her capacity to exist as a stable, united nation. The revolt that flared several weeks ago in the remote, fanatically Moslem province of Atjeh at the northern tip of Sumatra is symptomatic of the disintegration that threatens this sprawling young republic of 80,000,000 inhabitants.

KITTY HAWK, N. C. -- Nearby Kill Devil Hill will capture considerably more attention during the fiftieth anniversary of powered flight this December than it and the Wright brothers did in 1903. A four-day program has been planned for what, in 1903, was a barren, isolated spot.

Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute has reorganized its academic administration operation and procedures to develop educational programs for producing graduates who can cope with the increased responsibilities of the twentieth century.

Dollar volume in the nation's department stores for the week ended Oct. 3 was 3 per cent below the corresponding week of 1952 according to data prepared by the Federal Reserve Board and listed in the table below the chart. Only two districts showed advances in the week: San Francisco, 4 per cent, and Boston, 1 per cent.
DETROIT, Oct. 10 -- Harold D. (Muddy) Ruel, director of the Detroit Tiger minor league farm system, today was named general manager of the Tigers, succeeding Charlie Gehringer.

BEANIE was not going to do farm chores on his birthday -- no, sir! -- nor share his gifts with his brothers and sisters. So he took his new puppy and new make-believe gun and ran off to hunt bears, along a dark forest trail in the Great Smoky Mountains.

WILLA CATHER strongly believed in the artist's right to a private life. She defended herself successfully against demands made on her by an era of strenuous "public relations," and when she died in 1947 her will disclosed she had sought to obtain privacy for her posthumous life as well.

HERE is a way to write a book: Start a journey at a certain date and place. Traveling thence, set down in order and detail each event, conversation, emotion and spectacle encountered. End the book with the end of the journey.

Level Lea, John S. Phipps' 3-year-old Bull Lea colt, with Willie Boland riding, won the $75,000-added Jockey Club Gold Cup over two miles at Belmont Park yesterday. This was the thirtyfourth running of this stamina-and-speed stake and marked the seventh year in a row that a 3-year-old had come home in front.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- In an age of bebop, the current exchanges of notes between the Western Powers and the Soviet Union regarding a conference on Germany suggests the stately and intricate steps of the minuet.

ALPINE, Tex., Oct 10 -- Officials of Mexico and Texas will meet here Oct. 24 to make further plans for establishment of the Big Bend International Park on both sides of the United States-Mexican border.

MANILA, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Firing from machine guns and other automatic weapons broke up a Nationalist party rally north of Manila last night in the first eruption of political terrorism of the Philippines Presidential campaign.

BOAT trains, the special province of Southampton and Cherbourg and Le Havre, ran out of Grand Central Terminal last week to the amazement of New Yorkers and Europe-bound travelers. The occasion was the International Longshoremen's Association strike which had tied up.

THE Rolleicord IV, the latest in a succession of models of this medium-priced reflex camera, which originated in 1933, appeared in the stores last week. Once but a "poor relation" of the more impressive Rolleiflex, justifying its existence only as a commercial measure to satisfy the demand for a less costly version, the Rolleicord has been steadily improving its status over the years.

IN fifty years the airplane pilot has made a complete circle, from the serious-minded, and cautious Wright Brothers, through the days of the stunt fliers and the wing-walkers and back again to the era of safe and sane and highly scientific flying.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- Paul Hoffman's Cayuga, an 8-meter sloop out of City Island Y. C., won the New Rochelle Yacht Club's Stratford Shoal overnight race which finished inside Huntington Bay today. Cayuga placed first after handicaps were allocated. The race is an annual prelude to the fall rendezvous of the Cruising Club of America.

With a well-earned victory under time pressure, Samuel Reshevsky of New York gained the undisputed lead last night in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich, according to a Swiss news report.

BONN, Germany Oct. 10 -- Although the French and West German Governments have agreed to resume negotiations for a settlement of their dispute over the Saar coal and steel area, no quick and easy solution seems to be in sight.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Oct. 10 (AP) -- The United States Merchant Marine Academy, celebrating its tenth anniversary, won praise today from President Eisenhower for its job in training officers for the merchant fleet.

B. C. Summer Symphony, under the direction of Peter Herman Adler.

Changes in the law that has been interfering with the receipt of Soviet bloc publications here -- and thus hampering vital research into activities behind the Iron Curtain -- have been recommended by the Bureau of Customs and the Post Office Department, it was learned yesterday.

CAIRO, Oct. 10 -- The Anglo-Egyptian negotiations on the future status of the Suez Canal military base appeared today to have survived the jarring effect felt by Egyptians from Thursday's speech by the Marquess of Salisbury, former British Acting Foreign Secretary.

Padrutt of Chippewa Falls, Wis., to the Eighty-fourth Congress.

Several young women, including the Misses Leslie Martin, Elsie Alden Lee and Carol Kraham, are serving on the debutante committee for the annual dinner dance known as the White Wing Ball to be given Wednesday night in the Trianon Rom of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Oct. 10 -- Some brisk political maneuvering, winding up in a display of unity among long-contentious Republican factions, took place in California this week as Earl Warren relinquished the Governorship to become Chief Justice of the United States.

Six high school students and a psychiatrist explored last evening in a televised panel discussion the question of "What Causes Hostilities in Children." They found many answers, most of them traced to the home, the school and society in general.

A UNIQUE book, "War, Communism and World Religions" is important to all who would understand the present world scene. Moreover, it contains material not elsewhere available in one place. TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 10 -Harmony has been the keynote of the administration of acting Gov. Charley E. Johns since he succeeded Gov. Dan McCarty, who died Sept. 28 at the age of 41.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 10 -The Great Smoky Mountains, along the Tennessee-North Carolina line for seventy-one miles, are near the season's peak of autumn coloring. WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct, 10 -- Clarence Doser, 45-year-old professional at the Scarsdale Club, defeated Mike Homa of the Westchester Country Club, 1 up, at the thirty-seventh hole, to win the twenty-seventh Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association match-play championship over the Knollwood C. C. course today.

BEETHOVEN: Eroica Variations; Claudio Arrau, pianist (Decca, ten-inch). This originally appeared as the last side of the two-disk sat of the "Diabelli" Variations and is now issued separately. A clean, energetic performance.

ROME, Oct. 10 -- Premier Giuseppe Pella told the United States and British Ambassadors tonight that the Italian Government gratefully accepted the plan to turn over the administration of Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste to Italy.

This apparently made the 1952 race the most costly in history.

CONFRONTED with the Homeric problem of how to avoid Scylla without falling into Charybdis, David B. Steinman proposes to bridge the dilemma. ALONG about 1800, when the arteries of commerce were stretching farther and farther into the West, a Tennessee tavern-keeper, John Crockett, hired out his son Davy to drovers and wagoners. The Steinway Centenary Concert, which will bring to the stage of Carnegie Hall more than thirty famous pianists, will take place on Monday evening, Oct. 19, not on Nov. 19, as is erroneously stated in the top caption on Page 7 of today's Section 2.

At the luncheon session today at the annual meeting of the National Jewish Welfare Board at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, the organization's Frank L. Weil Awards for 1953 will be presented to Dr. Oscar I. Janowsky of New York, Mrs. Walter E. Heller of Chicago and Charles W. Morris of Louisville.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (UP) -- The American Hospital Association reported today that rates in general hospitals increased about 6 per cent during the year. It was the smallest annual increase in rates since 1949, the association said.

Divided opinion as to the future course of business gives an overall picture of financial markets toned with uncertainty. Traders in the stock market are cautiously appraising day-to-day developments and as a result price movements such as occurred last week have seldom been more indecisive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, said today the people were entitled to know if the joint Chiefs of Staff believed America's larger cities could not be defended against atomic attack.
An autumn color -- orange -- enlivens some handsome new room settings, while a winterlike one -- gray -- gives a delicate look to a new furniture group on view at B. Altman Co.
Likening the importance of the school system to that of national defense, Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor, promised last night never to stint on appropriations for education.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 11 -- American Jewish communal leaders, representing scores of cities, today presented $14,973,000 to the Unite Jewish Appeal at its national report conference here.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- The assertion by Sir Winston Churchill, British Prime Minister, that German forces might be introduced into the Western defense through the Atlantic pact if France did not speed ratification of the European Army treaty was received here today with reservations.

ALBANY, Oct. 11 (AP) -- With personal registration completed in the state, it appeared today that voters were taking comparatively little interest in the local contests to be settled in the Nov. 3 election.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- United States diplomats gave close study today to President Tito's threat to send Yugoslav troops into Zone A of Trieste should Italy try to occupy it.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- In the absence of officials qualified to comment authoritatively, an optimistic attitude was perceptible here today about an acceptance by the United States of a Communist proposal for talks at Panmunjom on arrangements for a Korean peace conference.

TRENTON, Oct. 11 -- Republican leaders in New Jersey, for the first time since the start of the present campaign, are assuming a noticeably pessimistic attitude in respect to their chances of retaining the Governorship at the Nov. 3 election.

Cotton futures prices in the domestic market moved irregularly last week, but closed generally in lower ground on reports of higher crop prospects. On the New York Cotton Exchange futures contracts at the close of trading on Friday were 20 points lower to 3 points higher, or down $1 a bale to up 15 cents.

To a capacity audience that had lived vicariously the turbulent matrimonial difficulties of Rite Wiener on radio for two years, Saturday night's opening of "Second Marriage" at the Second Avenue Theatre at Second Street was first-rate entertainment.
A Navy veteran of twenty-eight years' service in all types of warships and in shoreside posts will take over command of the Military Sea Transportation Service Atlantic area operations on Friday.

Of the leaders in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich, Paul Keres of Estonia made the only gain in the twenty-third round, last night. Samuel Reshevsky of the United States adjourned his game and Vassily Smyslov of Russia took his turn for a bye.
MONTAUK, L. I., Oct. 11 -- A forty-five-foot fishing cruiser, the Frieda M., was lost in high seas a mile south-southwest of Montauk Light today, with the probable drowning of one of five men aboard.

Lack of adequate school space in New York City is owing to confusion, inefficiency and political pressure, Rudolph Halley, Liberal and Independent party candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday in an analysis of the city school building program.
The tragic kidnapping and murder of Bobby Greenlease has shocked us all. It is good to know that his murderers have been caught, but this is poor solace for his parents.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11, (UP) -- Pan American World Airways asked the Civil Aeronautics Board today to approve the interchanging of airplanes .among Eastern Air Lines, Panagra and Pan American.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Robert D. Murphy, a career diplomat now Assistant Secretary of State for United Nations Affairs, is expected to be named Deputy Under Secretary soon.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 11 -- President Tito said today that Yugoslav troops would enter Zone A of Trieste the moment an Italian soldier set foot in it.

Plans for a housing development in Glen Cove, L. I., have been announced by Morwand Homes, Inc., builders, who have purchased for the purpose a large tract of land on Landing Road, north of Morgan's Memorial Beach. The sale was negotiated by Richard L. Elrod of the Elrod Realty Company, brokers, of Williston Park, L. I.
When, on Sept. 23, Federal Judge Medina threw out of court the long and costly anti-trust suit against seventeen of the nation's leading investment banking firms, he said:

BONN, Germany, Oct. 11 -- Proposals for further liberalization of trade with the Western world and restoration of Germany's "traditional trade relations with countries beyond the Iron Curtain" have been presented to the Bonn Government.

RAY BOLGER, the gentleman who radiates infectious impishness, has brought his varied comedy wares to television in a new situation item that may be seen at 8:30 Thursday evenings over the A. B. C. network. The show's script is on the uneven side but Mr. Bolger is in fine fettle, which is what counts.

Since March 6, when Nikita Khrushchev became the No. 1 man in the Secretariat of the Central Committee of the Communist party of the Soviet Union, and until his recent appointment to the post of first secretary of the Central Committee, in the American press, and particularly in your paper, it is stated too often that Mr. Khrushchev is a Ukrainian.
ROME, Oct. 11 -- Italian official circles took a serious view today of the situation that is being created in Trieste by the threatening speeches made by Marshal Tito.

DETROIT, Oct. 11 (UP) -- Dave Gatherum, a rookie goalie playing his first National Hockey League game, scored a shut-out tonight as the Detroit Red Wings beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 to 0, before 11,923 fans at Olympia.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 -- Villanova's football team, soundly beaten by three Southern opponents, posted its first victory of the season by defeating Boston College, 15 -- 7, at Fenway Park today. The loss was Boston College's second after a tie in the opener.
ALBANY, Oct. 11 -- Senator Arthur H. Wicks will confer here tomorrow with Governor Dewey on the issue of his political future.
NEW HAVEN, Conn. Oct. 11 (AP) -- After two defeats, Benrus Watch Company of Waterbury has decided to pull out of its legal battle with the Hamilton Watch Company of Lancaster, Pa.

ZURICH, Oct. 11 -- Attacks on Switzerland and threats of reprisals made by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers of New York, because of the tripling of the Swiss customs duty on American nylon stockings on Sept. 1 moved Swiss authorities to present their side of the situation.

General domestic support of the policies of the Eisenhower Administration was urged last night by Harold E. Stassen, director of the Foreign Operations Administration, as essential to the steady strengthening of "the great partnership of the world's free nations."

Native foods of the Western hemisphere are a likely topic for discussion on the anniversary of the discovery of America. In finding the New World, Christopher Columbus opened up treasures of many sorts. Not the least of them related to those ever necessary activities, eating and drinking.

ASBURY PARK, Oct. 11 -- An unqualified prediction that the United States "will have no depression" was made here last night by Dr. William A. Irwin, economist for the American Bankers Association. Declaring "there are no ifs, ands and no buts" Dr. Irwin, who was principal speaker at the annual chamber of commerce dinner said he was "placing no time limits on this statement."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Presidential birthday celebrations somewhat reminiscent of those held for Franklin D. Roosevelt may be in prospect again in the next four years, if this year is any indication of things to come.
HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 11 (UP) -- French war planes bombed Communist Vietminh rebel troop concentrations and supply depots today as ground forces probed enemy lines across the Red River delta.

ALBANY, Oct. 11 -- The Special Regents Commission appointed more than twenty months ago to search through textbooks in the state's public school system for subversive material never has held a meeting.

Your issue of Sept. 21 carried a letter from professor, one-time Ambassador, Carlton Hayes, aiming at a refutation of my own letter to you on the Spanish agreements, published Sept. 16. Professor Hayes writes that I have lived outside Spain for over twenty-five years. That is not so. He writes that I have been "severely critical in turn of every regime which Spain has had in the last twenty-five years."

That school-agers like to earn their own spending money was reaffirmed by recently released results of a survey made this summer by teachers participating in a Family Financial Security workshop program at the University of Pennsylvania.

The task of ascertaining whether waterfront workers wish to be represented by the racketeer - dominated union headed by Joseph P. Ryan or by the American Federation of Labor is an operation of considerable magnitude and may take several months.

Archbishop Gerald T. Bergan of Omaha and two New York prelates participated yesterday in a solemn service at St. Patrick's Cathedral marking the forty-third anniversary of the consecration of the church.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- A team of British engineers and business leaders who visited the United States in February, 1952, to make a study of engineering and allied industries reported today that British companies could learn many lessons from American experience.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- A critical shortage in men and women to do the simultaneous interpretation during United Nations proceedings has arisen. The organization is finding it difficult to obtain properly trained persons for the job.

The New York State Banking Board has decided to eliminate the existing ceilings on the interest rates paid by savings banks and loan associations under its jurisdiction. The ceiling on savings banks depositor interest dividends has been 2 1/2 per cent; that on various types of saving and loan shares has ranged in recent years from 3 to 5 per cent.

The separation of church and state is "a great help to the cause of religion" and a hindrance to the cause of communism, the Rev. Hugh McCandless asserted in a sermon yesterday at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, York Avenue at Seventy-fourth Street.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- A 3 1/2- year-old Kerry blue terrier, bred in the United States and owned in Canada, crossed the border to carry off the main laurels in one of America's foremost dog shows today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- President Eisenhower's economic advisers today depicted the national economy as slowing down slightly from last spring's record-breaking drive to something like a strong, steady pace.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- The drought became worse over the major part of the winter wheat sections last week. Heavy rains were confined to comparatively small areas, while precipitation in general was extremely light. The situation in the Southwest is more serious than lsewhere, but moisture deficiencies exist in most of the Winter Wheat Belt.
OSLO, Norway, Oct. 11 -- The Norwegians elect their new Storting (Parliament) tomorrow for the next four-year period.
Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, offered yesterday what he described as a "wholly new approach" to the problem of city-personnel relations.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Seventy-five experts, nominated by the National Manpower Council to look into the utilization of scientific and professional manpower, wound up a four-day conference today with general agreement that there would be a continuing shortage of trained persons for the medical, teaching and engineering professions through the next decade.

BEDFORD, Ind., Oct. 11 (UP) -- Senator William E. Jenner, chairman of the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee, charged today that former President Truman was "trying to protect cronies and pals even if they might be Communists."
LONDON, Oct. 11 -- As was to be expected, the recent pace of the advance in the stock markets was bound to slacken soon, and this has occurred in the last week:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The average American family's income increased by $16.35 a week between 1944 and 1950, the Government reported today.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 11 -- A Government spokesman said today that Iran was ready to "arrange" return of Iranian oil to the world markets.

Virtually every scientific, political, sociological or economic movement "which has been labeled progress" is based on "man's greatest discovery," the concept of the unity of God, the Rev. Dr. Robert D. Hershey, pastor of the Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central Park West at Sixty-fifth Street, declared yesterday morning in his sermon.
Three subway trains of the Independent division were delayed for eight minutes in lower Manhattan last night because of what inspectors called a "drunken vandal" who tampered with a power alarm box.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Quarterback Jimmy Finks' passing and Tackle Nick Bolkovac's 28-yard field goal late in the final quarter enabled the Pittsburgh Steelers to gain a 31-28 victory over the Chicago Cardinals today in a national football league game before 25,935.
Cardinal Spellman took off by helicopter yesterday from a cinder-covered Harlem River parking lot on the first leg of a trip to Rome.
LONDON, Oct. 11 -- The British Government counts on time and diplomacy to cool off Yugoslav threats as well as Italian ambitions in the current Trieste crisis.

Rabbi Irving Miller, president of the Zionist Organization of America, yesterday voiced apprehension over the first that the State Department "seems to be seizing every opportunity to chastize Israel publicly." A regrettable deterioration of American-Israeli relations may result, he declared.

It is ability, not disability, that counts, the Rev. John Urich, blind pastor of Grace and St. Paul's Lutheran Church, 123 West Seventy-first Street, said yesterday morning in a special service for Employ the Physically Handicapped Week.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Sir Winston Churchill has made many speeches that went echoing around the world. His address at Margate win also reverberate far beyond the confines of these crowded islands. But the big news yesterday was not the speech, wise and sometimes witty as it was. The event was the reappearance of a star performer on the national and international stage.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 (UP) -- Doug (Diesel) Mohns, rookie Boston wing, scored his first National Hockey League goal tonight as the Bruins opened their 1953-54 season by defeating previously unbeaten Montreal Canadiens, 4 -- 1, beforea sell-out crowd of 13,909 at the Boston Garden.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 11 -- A Public Service Company bus rammed broadside into an automobile making a U-turn on the White Horse Pike thin afternoon, demolishing the car and injuring twenty-two persons.

The shipowners who have been holding out for higher charter rates gained a little last week over their customers who were waiting to see if the market would wilt a bit more.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams rode full throttle over the Green Bay Packers today, scoring five touchdowns and adding the rest of their points on Ben Agajanian's kicking to win a National Football League game, 138 -- 20, before a crowd of 23,352 at the Milwaukee County Stadium.
The Moreland Act Commission intends to make early and wide use of the powers of subpoena conferred on it by Governor Dewey in its efforts to uncover hidden raceway ownerships.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 11 -- Steel demand and backlog were heavy enough last week to support a rate of 95 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the week before. As conditions assume a more normal pattern and with October usually a good steel-producing month the rate will stay close to 95 per-cent of capacity for the rest of this month.

Six youths, two of then armed with revolvers, were taken into police custody yesterday, when patrolmen broke up a burgeoning gang fight among fifty teen-agers in East 102d Street between Third and Lexington Avenues.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The American Red Cross has changed its recommendations for the first-aid care of frostbite and the use of the tourniquet for the control of severe bleeding.

BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 11 (UP) -- Red-faced Kentucky coach Paul (Bear) Bryant apologized to his football players here last night for a vigorous "bawling out" he gave them after the game with Louisiana State.
WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 11 -- A Roman Catholic priest, who is also an author, attacked the Kinsey report today on the ground that "you can't put love and spirituality on an I. B. M. card."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The United States reply to the Communist suggestion of Panmunjom as the site for preliminary talks on the Korean political conference will be written at a top-level State Department meeting tomorrow morning.
The city appears to be in for a major overhaul of the methods by which it is run.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP) -- The Independent Petroleum Association of America said today the domestic oil industry is facing disturbing uncertainty because of prospects of re-entrance of Iranian oil into world markets, and over-expansion of European refining capacity.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 11 (UP) -- Tony Trabert, United States champion, and Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., defending Pan American titleholder, today won the men's doubles crown in the twelfth annual Pan American tennis tournament, defeating Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., and Sven Davidson Swedish champion, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, C -- 4, in the final.

SECAUCUS, N. J., Oct. 11 -- No fleet of speedboat daredevils, men, women and teen-agers, has a more difficult or longer regatta season than the New Jersey Outboard Association, headed perennially by Commodore Emile Jacoby of North Bergen.

Capt. Stephen Booth McKinney, retired wartime Chief of Staff of the Third Naval District, plunged to his death yesterday from the bedroom window of his third-floor apartment at 1049 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Democratic Digest charged today that the Eisenhower Administration, for the first time in American history, "is making a practice of adopting at least two policies on many of the basic issues facing the nation."
The Rev. Dr. Ralph V. Sockman declared yesterday that justice was the foundation of all other virtues, but he related it to the jurisdiction of God and not to a court of law.
NEWARK, Oct. 11 -- Methods to curb an increase in rowdyism at high school football games and other events are being explored by the New Jersey Interscholastic Coaches Association.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 11 -- Patsy Ann Smith of Cross River, N. Y., won the hunter seat horsemanship championship after scoring in the open event as the twenty-fourth annual two-day Montclair horse show closed at the West Orange Armory today.

Although the Morality Play, "Everyman," was written more than five centuries ago, it has been revived with fresh appeal by a talented group of players representing the organization called Everyman's Theatre. The first of four performances was given last evening at Jan Hus House, 351 East Seventy-fourth Street.

This week, designated as National Business Women's Week, takes note of the fact that one out of every three workers in this country today is a woman. The number of women gainfully employed is increasing steadily and is now close to 20,000,000. More than half of these women are married and of these 24 per cent have children under 18.

DETROIT, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The champion Detroit Lions bottled up San Francisco's feared 1-2 running punch of Hugh McElhenny and Joe Perry and defeated the Forty-niners, 24 -- 21, to take over first place in the Western Division of the National Football League today.

Touchdowns by Bernard McGee, Richard Roman and Genaro Novelli enabled the Cardinal Hayes eleven, to turn back St. John's Prep, 20 to 0, at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday. The victory was the first in two games for the Bronx school and St. John's now has a 1-2 record.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 11 -- Following the announcement of partial liberalization of dollar imports in early September, a list of goods has been published whose import from the dollar area after Oct. 15 will no longer be subject to quantitative restrictions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The office of the Secretary of Labor is marked for new stature.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee made public today texts of testimony and exhibits from its hearings last May to emphasize its recommendations for stronger security regulations within the Government.

The United Nations Command, in three separate communications, has been urging upon the Chinese and Korean Communists the necessity of getting on with the political conference provided for in the armistice terms. It suggested a preliminary meeting in Geneva, Honolulu or San Francisco to set a time and place
The New York Americans gained their third victory yesterday in American Professional Soccer League play at Sterling Oval, when they defeated the Brookhattan-Galicia eleven, 3 to 1.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 11 -- Cheddi Jagan, ousted Prime Minister, flung back the charge of conspiracy at the British today. He accused London of inventing a Communist plot as a "smoke screen to cover up Britain's attempt to scrap even our limited Constitution."

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 11 -- The first step toward the conversion of Chancellor Green Library into an undergraduate campus center at Princeton University was taken today as a wrecking crew began to remove the old heating system.
INDIAN VILLAGE, Korea, Oct. 10 -- Perhaps the busiest and hardest working member of the custodial force guarding prisoners of war here is the head marl himself.

DARIEN, Conn., Oct. 11 -- The "horseless carriage" age returned here in costume and vehicle today, with 1,000 persons viewing the second annual fall meet of the Horseless Carriage Club. There were 109 vehicles in the day-long competition at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club, a record for Connecticut horseless carriage meets and one of the biggest entry lists in New England.

A woman in Queens complained to the police yesterday morning that a bomb seemed to have dropped into her back yard. The police checked quickly and came up with the consoling news that the sky was only raining radio transmitters.

Gen. Mark W. Clark, who recently returned to America after relinquishing the Far East Command, is reported by Harper to be at work on a new book. It will cover his experiences since those described in "Calculated Risk," which was an account of the war in Africa and Europe as he saw it.
LONDON, Monday, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Soviet Union's top newspaper today described suggestions the North Atlantic Treaty powers might offer Russia security guarantees as "mendacious propaganda."

The three basic titles in the rural American's library are the Bible, a Shakespeare and the mail order catalogue. The size and contents of the first two volumes largely remain the same. But the last is an ever-changing mirror of Americans and the way they live.

The biggest bubble-burst of the season, next to Alabama's deflation by Mississippi Southern, took place before 81,745 pop-eyed witnesses in the Ohio State Stadium on Saturday and the pall of tragedy hangs over Columbus.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP) T. Coleman Andrews, Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, said today he hoped soon to inaugurate a new income tax return that would make tax-paying simpler if not less painful.

The New York Businessmen's and Industrial Division of the National Committee for Labor Israel, yesterday opened its drive for $500,000 at a meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The national quota is $5,000,000.

Registration for the New York City election on Nov. 3, which closed Saturday night, reached a disappointingly low total of only 2,399,548. It reflects the apathy made evident by the vote in the recent Democratic primary.

This week's outstanding art event is the Whitney Museum's annual exhibition of Contemporary American Painting, opening on Thursday. Another annual, opening today at the Riverside Museum, is the twenty-ninth by the New York Society of Women Artists.

Strength in the pound sterling and a weak active market in the Canadian dollar featured trading in the foreign exchange market last week. The pound sterling closed on a firm note as a good undertone permeated the market, whereas transactions in the Canadian dollar followed a steady downward pattern.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Sparked by Fred Enke, who pitched two touchdowns, and George Taliaferro, a demon ground-gainer, the Baltimore Colts defeated the Chicago Bears today for the second time in the National Football League season, 16-14.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- The midseason was inaugurated by Jean Desses with smart, short party frocks fifteen inches off the floor, all monotone in dark or subtle hues. Their most distinguished feature was a very gracious neckline twisted and draped to emphasize the bust and shoulders.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Susan, Emil Mosbacher's International Class champion, added the Robert de Coppet Memorial Trophy to her list of prizes today. She won the final of the six-race post-season sailing series off the Larchmont Yacht Club. Competing in four races, Susan gained three first places and one second for a percentage of .981, as compared with .881 for Cornelius Shields' Aileen.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- Experts of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation and the European Payments Union consider that the building up of protective tariffs, to which France has recently turned, has become one of the major problems for the future of Europe in the fields of currencies and trade.
Your editorial captioned "Warning on Water" is indeed most timely, as is your admonition to water users to "go easy" lest some drastic steps become necessary to conserve our dwindling water supply.

CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 11 -- Commerce Minister John McEwen said tonight there had never been any intention by the Australian Government to exclude Japanese pearlers from the waters north of Australia. He was commenting on a report that Japan proposed the pearling dispute be submitted to the International Court of Justice.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Nothing seasons politics like a dash of speculation and the latest tidbit, spiced by the delay in an appointment to the Ohio Senate seat is that another Presidential candidacy is budding in Ohio.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 11 -- While Sir Winston Churchill, Britain's Prime Minister, and other Western statesmen keep angling for a meeting with the Soviet Union, diplomats in Bonn are inclined to doubt that Soviet authorities are yet ready to talk, at least about Germany.

CAIRO, Oct. 11 -- Egypt's President, Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, assailed British Conservative party leaders tonight for what he called their "political maneuvers" designed to influence next month's Sudanese elections.

A homicidal maniac was being sought by the police last night in the murder of a woman whose stabbed and dismembered body was found earlier packed in a leather suitcase in front of 182 Claremont Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Bullet Bill Dudley, whose week-end activities on the gridiron have been reduced to kicking placements for the Washington Redskins, booted two 16-yarders today at Griffith Stadium and these helped beat the Giants, 13 -- 9. This was the third straight setback for the New Yorkers, and it appears now that they and their followers are in for a long, hard and futile season in the National Football League.

BERLIN, Oct. 11 -- West Berlin's coalition Government moved closer to possible dissolution today. The coalition has presented a united front against Communist pressures since the city split in 1948. This week-end both right-wing parties demanded that someone from their ranks be named Mayor to succeed Ernst Reuter, who died Sept. 29.

Marshal Tito's indignant reaction to the decision of the United States and Britain to turn the administration of Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste over to Italy sounds like a throwback to the late nineteenth century. He talks as though we were not living in a world in which one carelessly thrown match might cause a continental explosion.

The Ehven Holding Corporation, a syndicate formed by Moses H. Hoenig, attorney, has purchased the apartment house for sixteen families on lot 42 by 123 feet at 369 St. John's Place, Brooklyn, in the first change of ownership of the property in about twenty years.
With the social season getting under way, it's time to plan for that important new dress that wall make you feel -glamorous when you go a-partying.

ROSLYN, L. I., Oct. 11 -- A preview of the Roslyn Museum of Natural History, a public school project described by American Museum of Natural History officials as equal in quantity and quality to the finest small museums in the country, was held here today at the new East Hills Elementary School.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, preaching yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, declared that communism's ultimate defeat or victory would be determined by "a vast struggle between communism and Christianity" for the minds and souls of men.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 11 -- The Israeli bench, from Supreme Court justices to magistrates, took pledges of office today. President Itzhak Ben-Zvi presided at a ceremony marking the introduction of reforms designed to increase the independence of the judiciary from the executive arm of the Government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP) -- Dr. Raymond F. McCoy, president of the Catholic Association for International Peace, said today that United States and Russian possession of the hydrogen devices appears to pose a choice of United Nations control or "boundless destruction."

CHICAGO, Oct 11 -- The Republican Administration will preserve the American tradition of equal justice, Maxwell M. Rabb, assistant to Sherman Adams, today told the eleventh plenary session of the National Community Relations Advisory Council here. Mr. Adams is assistant to President Eisenhower.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 12 -- The United Nations charged today that the Communists had brought warplanes into Korea in violation of the armistice agreement. The Allies asked the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission to investigate.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- The need for a strong military establishment under present conditions cannot be overemphasized although our Government does not put its faith primarily in material things, John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, asserted here tonight.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- Aroused by the gravity of the unrest in the rural districts of France, the Government has made strenuous efforts in the last few days to give satisfaction to the farmers. The Government also sought to prevent any widespread disturbances in the peasants strike scheduled to take place tomorrow.
CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (UP) -- The New York Rangers scored three goals in the final period tonight to beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 5 to 3, for the Rangers' first victory this season.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 11 -- The ancient Toltec pageant of the Fifth Sun was enacted today before about 30,000 persons in the Olympic Stadium of Mexico's new University City.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- The Rev. George F. Kempsell Jr. was installed here today as the twelfth rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. James the Less by Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan of the New York Diocese.

In a sense Sir Winston Churchill has been away for some months, and there have been fears among his friends -- who include many of his political opponents -- that he would not be back. The New York City Opera's production at the City Center yesterday showed that the company is not devoting all its care and attention to its new productions. "Boheme" in the afternoon was the company's seventy-third performance of the work and the evening's "Don Giovanni" was the fortieth.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (UP) -- Fire swept a hotel and mission in Chicago's Near West Side district today, killing four persons and injuring six. One of the dead was a 24-year-old girl who had been visiting friends in the Boston Hotel, on West Madison Street.

A syndicate of investors has purchased 101 to 107 Delancey Street, southeast corner of Ludlow Street, from Ralph Abrams. The building occupies a plot fronting eighty-eight feet on Delancey Street and has as its main tenant the French Roumanian Restaurant, one of the leading eating places on the lower East Side.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art and its branch in Fort Tryon, Park, the Cloisters, remained closed yesterday because of a strike by 170 guards.

The women's division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies will honor Mrs. Edgar Mayer of Tarrytown, N. Y., for her contribution to community progress at a luncheon tomorrow at the 21 Club. Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger and Mrs. Maurice Wertheim are co-chairmen of the event.

A concert of original compositions by Bozidar Kunc, Yugoslav composer-pianist, was presented last night in Town Hall. Mr. Kunc, an able pianist, played his Sonata in A flat, a Nocturne and a Capriccio.

The two top executives of the $450,000,000 Radio Corporation of America, David Sarnoff, chairman, and Frank M. Folsom, president, have sold the major portion of their stock holdings in the giant communications and manufacturing concern.
The following letter is reprinted from the Aug. 24 issue of Life magazine:
ROME, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Lazio of Rome, Italy's top baseball team, has asked President Eisenhower to keep their American coach in Italy.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 11 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said tonight that many Americans who voted for General Eisenhower last fall "on the assumption that the more enlightened and responsible elements in the Republican party were in the driver's seat" had had "a whole series of rude awakenings" since inauguration day.

Three Negro candidates for Manhattan Borough President -- Elmer A. Carter, Republican, the Rev. James H. Robinson, Liberal, and Andronicus Jacobs, American Labor party -- spoke yesterday on the "Between the Lines" television program, broadcast from station WNBT.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- The 64-year-old Duke of Bedford, one of Britain's richest men, was found dead this afternoon in a thicket on his Devon estate after a three-day search. The Duke had several gunshot wounds, apparently accidentally inflicted by his own shotgun, which lay beside him.

Edwina Divers, New York soprano, made her local debut late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. With Merwin Snyder at the piano she sang a rather mixed program, which included Mozart's Allelujah, Charpentier's "Depuis le jour," spirituals and religious songs.

Distance isn't regarded as a barrier by Leland Hayward when it comes to getting an urgently needed actor. Requiring a distinguished performer to lend verisimilitude to the characterization of a British Ambassador to the United Nations in "The Prescott Proposals," arriving Dec. 16 at the Broadhurst, Mr. Hayward flew to London last Monday and is returning today.
The Isthmian Line freighter Steel Vendor, a floating battleground in the war between rival pier unions, got its crew back yesterday, but made no progress toward unloading its cargo.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UP) -- American Farm Bureau Federation spokesmen plan to press Congress for expansion of a program under which United States foreign aid grants are made in surplus farm commodities instead of cash.

Money has become more "expensive" in recent months, reflecting the results of the Administration's anti-inflationary, "sound" currency policies, but borrowers are no less eager, even at the higher interest rates.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Hugh Gaitskell, Laborite member of the House of Commons and former Chancellor of the Exchequer, warned today that West Germany might be driven toward the Soviet Union if it was kept out of the European Defense Community or the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

Irrigation, conservation and land reclamation policies Of the United States have borne little relationship to the needs of the nation, declares Roy E. Huffman of Montana State College., At our best we have been opportunistic; at our worst, foolhardy and short-sighted.

Jon Robertson, 10-year-old pianist, made his local debut yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The program contained Schubert's seldom heard Sonata in E major, better known as "Fuenf Klavierstuecke," and the "Variations on a Theme by Huettenbrenner."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 1 -- Jerry Wald, executive producer for Columbia and one of Hollywood's nine Polders of the Irving Thalberg Memorial Award, said in an interview today that there was too much loose talk among the makers of movies about "big" pictures being the answer to all of the industry's economic problems.

MRS. CAROL GINIGER, wife of K. S. Giniger, vice president and general manager of Hawthorn Books, stopped in McCutcheon's the other day to pick up a few skeins of yarn right after she'd been at her attorney's in Fifth Avenue to sign her will.

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 11 -- "The Ethel Merman Show," a revue starring the singer-actress in what is essentially her first off-Broadway appearance, except for films since she achieved stardom in 1930 through "Girl Crazy," opened a sixteen-day rum in Dallas yesterday at the State Fair Auditorium.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Carl Austin Hall, a sullen drug addict, and his unkempt woman friend confessed today they had prepared to kill Bobby Greenlease before they kidnapped the 6-year-old child.

President Eisenhower rightfully said in his address to the Church Women of America that "peace will not come by threats and slogans, but peace will be born only by courage, knowledge, patience and leadership." If that is so, then boastful and belligerent statements by officials of our Government should be avoided at all times.

BERLIN, Oct. 12--Dr. Otto Suhr, chairman of West Berlin's Chamber of Deputies, was tonight nominated by the Social Democratic party as its candidate to succeed the late Ernst Reuter as Mayor of West Berlin. Dr. Reuter was a Social Democrat.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Ever since President Monroe, in December, 1823, proclaimed the Doctrine that bears his name, in the name of the United States alone instead of jointly with Great Britain (as had been suggested by British Foreign Secretary Canning, its basic originator), the United States has been pledged to resist every threat of force made by a Power of the Eastern Hemisphere against an established local regime in the Americas.
Although the price of money, the interest rate, is at its highest in twenty years, experts in the money market now see indications that the peak has been passed.

The packaging industry must continue to assist the nation in maintaining the industrial preparedness which is essential to defense, Walter Williams, Under Secretary of Commerce, said yesterday at the opening of the three day forum of the Packaging Institute at the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The State Department announced today the signing of an agreement with Greece giving the United States joint use of several air and naval bases. The United States also received the right to station and house military personnel in Greece.
The idea of naming the Secretary of Labor as the President's staff officer on all labor matters, as reported from Washington yesterday by Joseph A. Loftus, makes sense.
LONDON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Soviet note to the United States on Trieste, as broadcast from Moscow:

ALBANY, Oct. 12 -- Governor Dewey called on Senator Arthur H. Wicks today to resign immediately as majority leader of the Legislature's upper house and thus remove himself from the line of succession to the Governorship, but Mr. Wicks refused.

DETROIT, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The football hopes of the San Francisco 49ers were jolted today with the announcement that passing star Y. A. Tittle would miss two or three games because of a fractured cheekbone.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 12 -- Plittersdorf, the housing project for United States Government employes near Bonn, once described as "Westchester on the Rhine," soon will cease to be an all-American community.
Sleeping on the subway, which three weeks ago seemed well on the way toward being established as an inalienable human right, was yanked back into the realm of the misdemeanor yesterday.

Twenty-five years ago this month, canned tomato juice was introduced to consumers. It appeared after four years of processing research by the Kemp Brothers Packing Company of Frankfort, Ind., which had in mind the development of a new baby food
Teen-agers from the city high schools and parochial schools predominated yesterday in the fourhour Columbus Day Parade up Fifth Avenue from Forty-fourth to Eighty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Following is the text of a United States note that the Government of Sweden has been asked to transmit to the Chinese and North Korean Communists, as made public by the State Department:

French cottons for women's apparel are becoming increasing popular among American dress manufacturers, according to Eric A. Sorter, president of Soptra Fabrics, Inc. More than 500,000 yards of printed cotton fabric, he said yesterday, will be imported this year for use in both dresses and suits.
Winter squash will be abundant from now through December in many pretty colors and shapes.
New York department stores, which ordinarily lose volume at this season when good weather attracts potential customers into the open instead of to the buying counters, did rather well yesterday.

A Florida-type model containing twenty-four large units will be built in Montauk, L. I., by Morey Amsterdam, radio and TV entertainer, it was announced yesterday by Alan A. Stevenson, vice president in charge of real estate sales of the Montauk Beach Company.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- Miss Jeanette G. Douglas of San Francisco, arriving at United Nations headquarters this morning for what she expected to be a quiet tour of the buildings, found herself the center of a flurry of attention as the 500,000th visitor to be clocked through by the guided-tour unit since it began operation last October.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Six officials of the National Association of Soil Conservation Districts promised today to fight the closing of seven regional conservation offices under the Agriculture Department's reorganization plan.
TORONTO, Oct. 12 -- The notion that former service men are responsible for recent increases in crime was disputed here today by James V. Bennett, director of the United States Bureau of Prisons.

White Skies paid a visit to the Jamaica race track yesterday and turned the trip into one of considerable profit. Competing in the $23,500 Interborough Handicap, the 4-year-old colt who has done most of his campaigning in New Jersey captured the six-furlong event and in so doing earned $16,250 for his owner, William M. Wickham.

One-third of the funds raised through the March of Dimes next January will be used to finance polio prevention projects, it was anonunced yesterday by Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

A 34-year-old Chinese counterman who gave his name as James Lew confessed to the police last night that he had killed and dismembered Kay Gibson in a jealous rage early Saturday when she told him she planned to marry another man the next day.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- The Soviet Union, which has long sponsored a "package" proposal for the simultaneous admission to the United Nations of fourteen would-be members, tied up today a new and smaller package for the entry of five applicants.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 12 -- Japan has decided to withhold application for admittance to the Colombo Plan for the cooperative economic development of South and Southeast Asia. The decision was made apparently because of opposition by some of the member countries.
Some folks save string. Some save tinfoil. Some even save money. But college football fans are saving 6 minutes 18 seconds each Saturday.

LONDON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The International Rubber Conference opened here today in an atmosphere of deepening gloom as the price of natural rubber nosed down to its lowest level in more than three years.

Rudolph Halley, Liberal party candidate for Mayor, proposed yesterday that the Hack Bureau in the Police Department be stripped of its power to hear charges against taxi drivers. He recommended that the powers be vested either in a civilian board or in a magistrate or other judge.

Business must determine the cost of performing individual functions to reduce overhead, J. McCall Hughes, vice president and controller of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, said yesterday at the opening of the three-day office management conference of the American Management Association at the Astor Hotel.
Gilda Muehlbauer, violinist and this year's winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation Award, was presented in recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, Oct 12 (AP) -- A high official of Jamaica's Government said today that United States and Canadian manufacturers were planning branch industrial projects in Caribbean territories.

Aside from cuts suffered by John Cannady, the Giants emerged from Sunday's losing game at Washington in good physical condition. Cannady, with lacerations under both eyes, will be able to play when the Giants make their home debut against the Chicago Cardinals at the Polo Grounds Sunday.
Brooks Brothers, Inc., retail clothier, reported yesterday an 11 per cent gain in net sales and sharply increased earnings for the fiscal year ended July 31.

Three new flims arrive today at first run theatres. At the Astor is "Main Street to Broadway," a tale of theatrical life, with a large roster of stars, including, Tom Morton, Mary Murphy, Agnes Moorehead, Tallulah Bankhead. Lionel Barrymore, Shirley Booth and Leo Durocher.
GRASSY POINT, N. Y., Oct. 12 -A war-born engineering technique came into play today when the first of eight huge caissons for the $500,000,000 New York-Buffalo Thruway was floated down the Hudson.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 12 -The optimism with which the movie business was viewing a golden three - dimensional future earlier in the year now appears to have turned to pessimism.
LONDON, Oct. 12 -- British exports last month amounted to 201,800,000 ($565,040,000) or about 14,000,000 ($39,200,000) less than the average for July and August, the Board of Trade said today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 12 --Gov. Frank J. Lausche of Ohio, a Democrat, today named his hometown friend, Mayor Thomas A. Burke of Cleveland, to the vacant seat of Robert A. Taft, late Republican leader in the United States Senate.
LONDON, Oct. 12 -- The international situation, particularly in Trieste, British Guiana and Egypt, cast a shadow over stock market trading here today and prices declined in nearly all sections.

Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College, has sent to the faculty and staff of the college a confidential memorandum outlining a proposed procedure to be followed if any member is called before an investigating committee of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Two powerful new radio transmitters have started to beam broadcasts of the Voice of America deep into Communist-ruled Eastern Asia and Siberia for the first time, it was disclosed today.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 12 (AP) -- William Goadby Loew's fleet filly, Case Goods, delighted the majority of the 22,180 fans at Garden State Park today by winning the $10,000 added New Jersey Breeders Stakes by three lengths. The daughter of Case Ace defeated a son of Case Ace, Greentree Stable's Card Trick, with Jockey Dave Gorman merely flicking the whip during the final seventy yards to keep the miss about her business.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Oct. 12 -Prime Minister Dudley Senanayake resigned today and Sir John Kotelawala, Ceylon's Transport Minister, was asked by GovernorGeneral Lord Soulbury to form a new Government. Sir John, a violent anti-Communist, will announce his Cabinet Wednesday.

The violent Yugoslav reaction to the American and British decision to turn over the administration of Zone A of the Trieste Territory to Italy has precipitated a situation which harms the Western position and might have graver consequences. One may discount the danger of war as too stark a madness to contemplate.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -The National Boxing Association made it official today: there isn't a heavyweight fighter in Rocky Marciano's class.
The Moreland Act Commission investigating raceways decided yesterday to supplement the old subpoena method of interrogating live witnesses with the new written questionnaire technique.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Supreme Court, in orders issued today, agreed to hear forty-two cases involving constitutional issues and important questions of Federal law. At the same time, it denied nearly 200 applications for hearings, rehearings or other forms of relief from actions in the lower courts.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- The British Government received with unconcealed coolness today the proopsal by the Yugoslav Government for a four-power conference to discuss the United States-British decision to hand Zone A in Trieste to Italy.

The outermost reaches of space, beyond the familiar universe, are no place for customers. That is (perhaps) the reason the honest-to-goodness space ship that is the latest advertising premium for a contest winner does everything but fly.

The nation's steelmakers produced a record amount of ingots and steel for castings in the first nine months of this year. Output in September, however, declined from both the August level and that of September, 1952.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Oct. 12 (AP) -- A man accused in two slayings on the Pennsylvania Turnpike maintained his innocence today and implicated a mysterious "other man."

In your issue of Oct. 6 Joseph Z. Kornfeder of Detroit takes issue with your editorial of Sept. 22 entitled, "Communism and the Churches." His letter contains this sentence: "Perhaps you are unaware that a group of prominent Methodist laymen known as Circuit Riders has for over two years tried with scant success to induce their church to take internal action concerning what you call 'alleged Communist penetration'."
Reports from Belgrade indicate that the Yugoslav leaders are preparing a capital decision on their future relations with the United States Government.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Oct. 12 -The Republican party pinned its hopes for a victory in tomorrow's election of a member of the House of Representatives from the Ninth Congressional District here on fair weather. a heavy vote, and patience with the Eisenhower Administration on the part of Wisconsin farmers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Following are the texts of Yugoslavia's notes to the United States and Britain and to the United Nations on the American-British decision to turn over Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste to Italy.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- The situation in British Guiana became an important domestic political issue today when Labor party leaders demanded that the Conservative Government account for its actions in the colony.

YONKERS, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Bill Hylan drove Spruce Up to an easy three-length victory in the feature $4,500 Jersey Pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway. The 7-year-old bay horse owned by George Norris of Dundalk, Md., covered the mile in 2:05 4/5.
Whether it's for "Sunday-goto-meetin'" or playing in the park, a little girl's coat this season can be just as fashionable as her mother's.

The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations has unearthed a trail of "extremely dangerous espionage" at the Army's Fort Monmouth, N. J., radar laboratories, "and if it develops it will envelop the whole Signal Corps," Senator Joseph R. McCarthy Republican of Wisconsin, said yesterday.

The high cost of graduate study for social work was one of the reasons given yesterday for the shortage of trained personnel in the field. Low salaries for social workers and failure to make the profession attractive to students were other reasons also discussed at a conference called by the Bureau of Personnel and Training of the National Jewish Welfare Board at the Harmonie Club, 4 East Sixtieth Street.
William C. Jordan has been appointed vice president and general manager of the Hughes Aircraft Company, Culver City, Calif.

Women's preferences provided guidance for styling of the three series of cars in the 1954 line announced yesterday by the Plymouth division of the Chrysler Corporation. Color combinations and fabrics utilized in interiors were based upon studies of home furnishings.

HYDERABAD, Pakistan, Oct. 12 -Standing in the shadow of camels, tractors and giant cranes, hundreds of bronzed workmen took their midday rest today and gazed across a mirage come true: broad canals of water from the Indus River that eventually will convert millions of acres of wasteland into rich harvest fields.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 12 -- One hundred and sixty-eight alleged leaders of the Turkish Communist party will go on trial in Istanbul Thursday charged with conspiring with the Soviet Union to divide the Turks by fomenting religious reaction.

BOSTON, Oct. 12 -- Admiral Robert B. Carney, Chief of Naval Operations, said today that "numerically, at least," Russia had become the world's second naval power. He added that it was obvious the Soviet Union was determined to emerge from its landlocked position and assume a place in the maritime world.
ROME, Oct. 12 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, arrived at 7 o'clock this evening to attend the inauguration of a new seminary of the pontifical North American College Wednesday.

NEWARK, Oct. 12 -- Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City was accused here tonight of writing to Governor Dewey as early as January, 1951, requesting executive clemency for Joseph S. Fay, convicted extortioner and labor leader.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 12--Dr. Nathan Marsh Pusey will be installed tomorrow as the twenty-fourth president of Harvard University in a simple ceremony that will preserve one tradition and break another.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the validity of a Texas tax on natural gas transported by pipeline companies to consumers in thirty-eight other states.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 12 -- The pro-British Ulster Unionist party, entrenched in power since 1921, is in sight of another general election victory. Nominations today gave it a walkover for twenty-one of the fiftytwo seats in the House of Commons. Four Nationalists also were unopposed, leaving sixty candidates to fight for the twenty-seven seats in the Oct. 22 balloting.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- Gene Loveless and Gino Maturo of the New York A. C. withstood a strong finish by Jim Lyden and Charles Peterson to win the halfmile senior doubles shell event by two seconds in a Columbus Day open regatta today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UP) -The last all-Negro units will be gone from the Army eight months from now as the armed forces bring their nonsegregation program toward completion, the Assistant Defense Secretary, Dr. John A. Hannah, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury reindicted Hugh Bryson of San Francisco, president of the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards, today on charges that he had filed a false non-Communist affidavit with the National Labor Relations Board.

Pete Modica, a 30-year-old righthander whose baseball career has been solely in the minors, yesterday was purchased by the Giants from the Nashville club in the Southern Association. The Vols used Modica principally as a relief pitcher.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- Delegates at the United Nations welcomed today any indication in the Yugoslav note that Belgrade would take no action in the dispute over Trieste pending direct negotiations with the United States, Britain and Italy.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 13 -The Communists in Korea seemed today to be ready to begin soon their efforts to convince 22,500 former Chinese and North Korean soldiers that they should return to communism.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday that his Liberal rival, City Council President Rudolph Halley, owed his political start to endorsements from "powerful organization Democrats."

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Fulfilling a promise to Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture, to examine cattle and beef prices, the American Meat Institute reported today that it had completed such a study based on published market quotations of the Department of Agriculture.

BAHRING POINT, Andros, Bahamas, Oct. 12 -- Doves streaking downwind, teal flashing around a point of reeds, snipe zig-zagging across a wide meadow -- all these provide plenty of challenge for the wingshooter, but none can compare with the wild pigeon of Andros.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 12 -- Yugoslavia proposed today a conference with the United States, Britain and Italy on the Trieste issue and notified the United Nations of her determination to repel any Italian attempt to send troops to Zone A of the Free Territory.

Harvard University today installs a new president, the twenty-fourth since Henry Dunster, who died just short of three centuries ago. Life in America has changed considerably during that interval and it is unlikely that Nathan Pusey, during his forthcoming term in office, will find students coming to Cambridge with quantities of wheat, rye, barley, turnips, apples; beef on the hoof; butter, cheese or flour.
Upsets took a severe toll of the nation's ranking college football teams last week-end. Mighty Notre Dame, which had an open date, remained on top of the list yesterday.

The New York State commission with least work to do is the one appointed twenty months ago by the Regents to investigate charges that textbooks used in the public schools contain subversive material. According to a news story that we published yesterday, the commission has never held a meeting.

Mayer Refrigerating Engineers, Inc., have sold their building at 110 Carlton Avenue in Carlton Hill, N. J., to the Malcolm Barber Supply Company of Passaic, and in turn have purchased the building of the Drum Equipment Corporation in Lincoln Park, N. J. Both transactions were negotiated by the David T. Houston Company as broker.
Lieut. Gen. Elwood R. Quesada, Army Air Forces commander in World War II, now retired, said yesterday that when the United States became weak it would be destroyed.
ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 12 -Though an adult might never guess it from teen-agers' blue jeans and drape sweaters, clothing plays a big part in the life of a highschool girl.

SALEM, N. H., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Tony DeSpirito, 17-year-old riding star from nearby Lawrence, Mass., booted home five winners today and a new betting record for a single day in New England was established at Rockingham Park's annual Columbus Day doubleheader racing program.
St. Louis, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Five of even minority stockholders withdrew as plaintiffs today in a suit seeking to keep the Browns from moving to Baltimore.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- The tension between Yugoslavia and Italy over Trieste prompted the United Nations security guards today to begin a restudy of the available photographs of the Yugoslav delegation here.

The United Nations Command in Korea has charged that the Communists have violated that part of the truce terms which provides that reinforcing combat weapons, combat aircraft, armored vehicles and ammunition are not to be brought into Korea by either side.
" HOW do you feel?" asked Steve Owen, shaking hands with Harvey Harman. "A little low," said the Rutgers coach. "Me, too," said Lou Little, shaking hands with both of them.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Maritime Administration lifted today some restrictions on the construction of foreign merchant ships in United States shipyards in a move to permit these yards to compete more favorably with foreign shipbuilders.

Customs collections here last month followed the traditional September pattern, rising sharply as importers brought in large quantities of goods in anticipation of the port's annual difficulty with its longshoremen. The rush was so great that collections rose approximately 12 per cent over September, 1952.

VIENNA, Oct. 12 -- Thirteen out of sixteen alleged spies said to have been dropped in Rumania from camouflaged United States planes were sentenced to death today in Bucharest, according to the Bucharest radio. The remaining three received sentences of twentyfive, twenty and three years imprisonment respectively, the radio added.

The Standard Brands Building at 800 Grand Concourse in the Bronx has been sold by the Standard Brands Company to the 800 Grand Concourse Corporation, headed by Julius Perlbinder, which will demolish the building and erect an apartment house.

The two-family house at 7112 Fourteenth Avenue in the Lefferts Park section of Brooklyn has been sold by Roma Boggiano and Margaret Clust to Mario Udovich. The Cantalupo Realty Company was the broker.
Marcella DeCray, harpist of the Philadelphia Orchestra, made a solo appearance last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

The problem of Trieste is again very much to the fore. It is disturbing to see how little statesmanship is being displayed in the commentaries of our press or in the leadership, or lack of leadership, of responsible politicians on such a question.
