DETROIT, Oct. 12 -- Drastic measures to erase slums and end traffic strangulation was prescribed for the cities of America today as a long necessary course of treatment that now had become a matter of simple survival against atomic attack.

Ch. Free Chase Pumpkin Coach, a 3 1/2-year-old English cocker spaniel belonging to the Free Chase Kennels of Lawrence, Mass., became best in show yesterday in the thirty-second event of the Bronx County Kennel Club in the Kingsbridge Armory.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 12 -- Dr. George Schwarzkopf, an eye specialist, reported today that a safe in his home at 2901 Pacific Avenue had been broken into and $33,950 in cash stolen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UP) -Representative Daniel A. Reed, Republican of New York, said today that the United States was now in a "disastrous" position largely because of foreign policy blunders by the Roosevelt and Truman Administrations.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -The Supreme Court today declined to review a 1949 settlement of a stockholders' suit against automobile manufacturer Henry J. Kaiser and several associates.

The Museum Guardians Union of America, independent, whose members have been on strike against the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park since last Saturday, charged yesterday that New York policemen were being used as, "scabs and strike-breakers."
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 12 (AP) -The House Agriculture Committee found strong sentiment in this dairy-grain-livestock area today for broader use of farm price supports.

William Dale, pianist from Miami, Fla., made his New York debut last night in a relatively brief program at Town Hall that included Mozart's Sonata in C major (K. 330), Brahms' Variations on a Theme by Handel, and a new Sonata by William Rice of Houston, Tex., who like the pianist, is a former student of Paul Hindemith at Yale University.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations charged today that the State Department's personnel files, particularly those concerned with the Foreign Service, had been maintained for years with a disregard for national security.
The National Retail Dry Goods Association, which represents 7,000 department and specialty stores throughout the country, is planning a concerted attack on the principle of the sales tax.
The explosive problem of Trieste was imperiling yesterday the unnatural alliance between Yugoslavia and the West.

Congratulations to THE NEW YORK TIMES on Walter Sullivan's admirable article on Mayor Ernst Reuter in connection with the latter's sudden death on Sept. 29. The great qualities and contributions of Berlin's beloved Mayor to the free world -- next to Adenauer perhaps the greatest leader in postwar Germany -- were appropriately extolled.

Elaborate and simple, fine and homespun, the objects assembled at the New York Antiques Fair, which opened yesterday at the Seventyfirst Regiment Armory. Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, present an impressive spectacle of the past.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Michael Patrick O'Brien, the modern-day man without a country, got permission today to live in the Dominican Republic.

Anything less than the registration of every qualified and available citizen is a disappointment. Anything less than the realization of every registration in November is a disappointment. These two disappointments have been with us every year since the popular vote became the way of government in this country.

TRIESTE, Oct. 12 -- Politicians in several capitals were concerned today with control of this lovely city, but most of its 250,000 inhabitants were mainly preoccupied with their suddenly dimmed economic future.

DETROIT, Oct. 12 -- Joseph M. Dodge, director of the Federal Bureau of the Budget, said today that economies the Eisenhower Administration hoped to achieve during its first year in office would be offset, and perhaps exceeded, by the loss of revenue from taxes that were slated to expire in 1954.
PARIS, Oct. 12 -- Farmers in about twelve departments of Central France protested today against falling agricultural prices by blocking highways for several hours.

The formation of a committee of Democrats to support the candidacy of the Rev. James H. Robinson, Liberal and Independent party nominee for Manhattan Borough President, was announced yesterday afternoon by Lloyd K. Garrison, a member of the Democratic State Committee from the Ninth Assembly District.
Harvard, Yale and Princeton, be it noted, have come up to this fourth week of the football season with perfect records.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- President Eisenhower still is bothered a little by an upset stomach but the trouble is not serious. The President is going ahead with his plans to attend a party in his honor at Hershey, Pa., tomorrow on the eve of his sixty-third birthday.

OSLO, Norway, Tuesday, Oct. 13 -- No definite trend had yet emerged from the Norwegian parliamentary election early today when 17 per cent of the vote cast yesterday had been counted. Almost all of the early returns were from rural districts.

Samuel Reshevsky of New York and Vassily Smyslov of Moscow changed places again at the top in the world chess championship challengers tournament in Zurich last night, according to a Swiss new report. Reshevsky, who had the edge in his twenty-third-round game with Alexander Kotov of Russia, reached a difficult knight ending.

TOMS RIVER, N. J., Oct. 12 -The possibility of assuming legal guardianship of the two sons of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the atom spies who were put to death in June, was being considered today by Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Bach, with whom the boys have been living here.

Theodore Roosevelt Medals for Distinguished Service will be awarded to Van Wyck Brooks and Dr. William Beebe at a dinner at Theodore Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street, on Oct. 27, the former President's birthday.
CAIRO, Oct. 12 -- British and Egyptian negotiations on the future status of the Suez Canal military base, which nearly collapsed over the weekend, are to continue at least until the end of this week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower heard assurances today that American women "still look upon President Eisenhower as the greatest guy they know and they are all for him."

JOHN M. SMITH Jr. was attending the twenty-fifth reunion of his college class. The evening had been merry and now he was asleep in the same dormitory where he had been a student. He was having a nightmare. In his dream he seemed to be lost in the ruins of his formal education and a ghostly inquisitor was asking the most embarrassing questions.

" Russian Assignment," a portrait of Russia and of daily Russian life, by Vice Admiral Leslie C. Stevens, U. S. N. (retired), will be published on Oct. 22 by Atlantic-Little, Brown. Admiral Stevens, who served as a naval attache in Moscow from 1947 to 1949, has based his book on his observations, both official and unofficial.

The Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, one of the nation's greatest scientific and humanitarian institutions and one of Manhattan's most notable landmarks, began yesterday a twoday celebration of its twentyfifth anniversary.

The turn of the week brought more than its quota of news bearing on one phase or another of the economic and financial situation. To begin with, the Congressional Joint Committee on the Economic Report released the monthly statistics furnished it by the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 12 -- The chairman of the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee said today he felt confident there would be no war with the Soviet Union so long as the United States maintained an adequate defense.

The entire block bounded by Second and Third Avenues and Sixty-eigth and Sixty-ninth Streets has been purchased by the Chanin Organization for improvement with a nineteen-story apartment house to contain 1,100 suites. The cost is estimated at $25,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Federal executive agencies started off the 1953-54 fiscal year on July 1 with $164,500,000,000 at their command. That was almost $14,000,0000,000 less than at the start of the 1952-53 fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The United States and its United Nations Allies in Korea agreed today to go along with Communist proposals for a preliminary meeting at Panmunjom on the peace conference. However, the matters to be discussed were specifically limited.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12--Dr. Farid Zeineddine of Syria accused France today in the United Nations of seeking to "break the unity" of the Moroccan people by pitting Arab against non-Arab. He also said France fostered cultural and religious discord to make French "domination" easier.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The United States had under advisement tonight the protests of both Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union against the decision by the United States and Britain to turn over Zone A of the Trieste Territory to Italian control.

VAN HORNESVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- If the churches will get busy and work as fast as the scientists have been doing, if the oldsters will retire and let younger men run things and if the United States will continue to lead by example, we need not worry about the future, Owen D. Young believes.

Working in close cooperation with the French police, Federal agents here uncovered an alleged international narcotics ring yesterday. They seized eleven pounds of pure heroin, valued at $500,000 on the illegal market, in two fire extinguishers aboard the French luxury liner Flandre.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The widow of a Washington attorney who defended the Garsson brothers in a 1947 war contracts fraud trial today filed suit for $2,500,000 damages from the Garssons and four Illinois firms.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Soluble coffee has come to Brazil -- but with some misgivings among coffee trade sources.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 12 (AP) -Tony Trabert, United States champion, won the Pan American tennis title today by defeating Kurt Nielsen, the Danish Davis Cup ace, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1.
HERSHEY, Pa., Oct. 12 -- "Happy Birthday, Mr. President!"
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UP) -Medical experts said today that poliomyelitis was still a menace and the paralyzing variety was increasing.
New accessories that might lead a decorative as well as useful life in the home are on view at the Willow, 182 West Fourth Street.
The Brooklyn Eagle notified its employes yesterday that a deal for sale of the daily newspaper to The New York Herald Tribune had fallen through.
MOSCOW, Oct. 12 -- Russia accused the United States and Britain today of having transformed Trieste into an illegal military base and of having violated the Italian peace treaty.

Military duty today shapes the future attitudes of more young Americans than almost any other single force. Last year, our armed forces "graduated" more than a million service men back into civilian life, while only 350,000 graduates left the nation's colleges.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Jockey Bobby Stevenson and Trainer Bowes Bond took both divisions of the Pimlico Breeders' Stakes today before an opening-day crowd of 13,071.
BAGUIO, The Philippines, Oct. 12 -- In the mid-northern provinces of Luzon Island, President Elpidio Quirino is a strong candidate to succeed himself.
HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Oct. 12--This was defense day for Peddie School's varsity football squad.
" Late Love," Rosemary Casey's comedy, co-starring Arlene Francis, Lucile Watson and Neil Hamilton, will open at 8. P. M. tonight at the National Theatre under the sponsorship of Michael Abbott.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 12 -- Clarence Manion of South Bend, Ind., chairman of the Commission on Inter-Governmental Relations, said here tonight that "the concentration of Government powers is a prelude to the success of the Communist conspiracy to take over America today from the inside."
HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 12 -- The experiment of manning posts only with Vietnamese troops in North Vietnam (Tonkin) has had mixed results.

In an article published Oct. 5 in THE NEW YORK TIMES entitled "Anti-Semitic Drive Expands in Mexico," it is stated, among other things, that "while there is no official bar to the entry of Jews into Mexico, Jewish leaders believe there is an effective procedure within Mexican consulates abroad to keep them out.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 12 -- About 6,000 of British Guiana's 30,000 sugar workers went on strike today. They walked out in response to an appeal issued yesterday in the name of the People's Progressive party to strike in protest against the Governor's dismissal of that party's ministers from the State Council.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., making his first frankly political television appearance since he won the Democratic nomination for Mayor, emphasized last night that he was a "family man." It is because he believes he can help other families improve their situations that he is running, he said.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Oct. 12 (UP) -- Coffee prices shot up nearly 10 per cent today as a new system of foreign exchange control went into effect.
The Philadelphia Orchestra, under the direction of Eugene Ormandy, will give the first of ten Tuesday evening concerts at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8:30 o'clock.
It was a wise and timely decision on your part to publish, in your issue of Sept. 24, the letter on the need for chest X-ray.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 12 -- The Economic and Financial Committee of the United Nations General Assembly voted unanimously today to get behind the technical assistance program and push it out of its financial crisis.

Two hundred followers of Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia, union boss of the Brooklyn docks, fought three pitched battles with the police yesterday as a rival union ran longshoremen through an Anastasia-imposed blockade to unload a strikebound freighter.

LONDON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- A columnist for The Daily Mirror, Britain's most widely-read daily newspaper, declared today Dwight D. Eisenhower "may yet rank with Harding and Coolidge as one of the most disastrous Presidents of the United States."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Robert C. Sprague, Massachusetts electronic manufacturer, said today his investigation of the Nation's defenses against atomic or hydrogen bomb attacks would include inspection of Arctic areas but that much of his work would be done at home in Williamstown, Mass.

Capt. Franck Garrigue will bring his last French Line command, the liner Ile de France, into the pier at West Forty-Eighth Street today and prepare for a round of farewells before sailing home into retirement.

On Oct. 5 THE NEW YORK TIMES published a special dispatch from its Saigon correspondent indicating the possibility of an attack upon Cambodia by five Vietminh battalions reportedly massed at the northern and eastern frontiers of the kingdom. Your Saigon correspondent adds:
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 (UP) -- An attorney proved today that two automobiles could be parked for the price of one.

TOKYO, Oct. 13 (Reuters) -- Aircraft with the insignia of the Rising Sun on their wings are appearing in increasing numbers over Japanese cities. They are mostly foreign - made, but industrialists here are taking the first steps to re-establish the Japanese aircraft industry, which was once capable of producing 10,000 planes a year.

Economists and others who have been watching the steel industry's operations for a slump that might tip off a general recession in industrial activity have not detected any such signals yet. For the last three weeks the steel industry has been turning out metal at a fast pace as its furnaces produced at better than 95 per cent of theoretical capacity.

New York is a "monster" that needs "almost an atomic bomb" to eliminate its defects, Jacques Greber, 70-year-old French architect and town planner, asserted yesterday. M. Greber arrived here aboard the French liner Ile de France with 1,067 other passengers from Le Havre and Southampton.

A Nassau County judge acknowledged late yesterday that he was the target of a projected inquiry to determine whether an unidentified jurist had shared with William C. De Koning Sr., indicted labor boss, in profits from the sale of programs at Roosevelt Raceway.

Individual incentive is the key to sales success, it was emphasized yesterday by four men under 39 years of age who are presidents of their own companies. They spoke at a luncheon of the Sales Executives Club of New York in the Roosevelt Hotel, where officers and members of the Young Presidents' Organization were honored on the occasion of its third anniversary.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Despite sharp differences of opinion here regarding the meaning of the new United States note to Communist China and North Korea, there is general agreement on two things:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The State Department went ahead today with plans to send a United States representative to Panmunjom for the Korean peace conference preliminaries.

The purchasing power of the American dollar reached the lowest point in its 168-year history in August, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday. This sent the nation's cost-of-living to a new record high.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- An on-the-spot inquiry, conducted by investigators of the House of Representatives, failed to turn up evidence that influence had been used to obtain contracts for the construction of military bases in Germany and France.

BAHRING POINT, Andros, Bahamas, Oct. 13 -- Well before, the sun brought first light, a dory bumped the side of the cruiser Wilmar, a gabble of native voices heralded the arrival of our pigeon guides, and a roar from Captain Geoffrey Brown indicated that he did not take kindly to losing large patches of paint from this contact.

Notre Dame was ranked the nation's top college football team yesterday for the third straight week by The United Press board of coaches. Although the Irish were idle last Saturday, twenty-seven of the thirty-five coaches who make up The United Press board voted them No. 1.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Henry Ford 2d, an industrialist with strong ideas on international cooperation, took his proposal for a lower tariff a step forward today by suggesting the program be sold to the people of the nation.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 13-- President Eisenhower and President Ruiz Cortines will meet next Monday on the United States-Mexican border, but according to present plans they will skirt a discussion of problems that have arisen in the past year to strain relations between the two countries.
Two waterfront racketeers interrupted their trial yesterday in General Sessions to plead guilty to charges of extorting $100 a shipload of newsprint unloaded at East River piers.

Businesses were not paying their bills quite as promptly in August as they had been a year earlier, according to a survey just completed by the Credit Research Foundation of the National Association of Credit Men.

Initial successes in a "two-way" racial integration project in Southern colleges and universities were noted yesterday in the fifth annual report by Dr. Harry J. Carman, chairman of the board of the National Scholarship Service and Fund for Negro Students, Inc., 31 West 110th Street.

Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee and an avowed champion of pure amateurism, indicated yesteray he was disturbed by the trend toward "state amateurism" that he had observed during a two-month tour of Europe.
Mayor Impellitteri told a television audience last night that he was the only candidate for Mayor this year whom the Communists hated and feared.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The recent success of a concern of British soft drink manufacturers "in persuading Americans to drink gin and tonic" was cited by the British Treasury today as evidence that even personal tastes in the United States could be changed by determined efforts.
Zone A of the disputed Free Territory of Trieste is garrisoned by the "Blue Devils" of the United States Army's 351st Infantry Regiment.
STRATFORD, Conn., Oct. 13 -- The American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy campaign moved into this community in force tonight and met with a warming welcome from the new Town Council.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Syria's side of the argument was set out once again today in a new communication sent to the United Nations Security Council. This reiterated the Damascus Government's complaint that the Jordan project, involving an area in the demilitarized zone, was a violation of the 1949 Syrian-Israeli Armistice Agreement.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 (Up) -- President Franklin D. Roosevelt thought it was "criminal" of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur to "raise false hopes" among his men in the Philippines, besieged soon after Pearl Harbor, a former Presidential secretary, William D. Hassett, said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- James M. Mead, member of the Federal Trade Commission, today denounced a new F. T. C. rule governing the use of the word "free" in advertising.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- In a quiet trading session the stock markets here today generally finished on a rising note although small net losses far outnumbered gains.

Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra gave their first New York concert of the season last night in Carnegie Hall. The audience rejoiced in the beauty, warmth and luminousness of the orchestral tone, in the finish of detail, the admirable balance of parts and skillful tone-coloring of the performances.

Mixing the living and the dead on stage for comedy purposes is an extremely tricky assignment and the new television version of "Topper," based on the late Thorne Smith novels, was not up to the task on its premiere (8:30 P. M. Thursdays on C. B. S.). The show fell disconsolately between "I Married Joan" and "Outward Bound."

Norfolk, Va., sold $5,000,000 of general bonds maturing from 1954 to 1978 at public auction yesterday at a net interest cost of 2.57 per cent. The Chase National Bank and associates submitted the winning bid of 100.14 for a combination of 5s, 3 1/2s and 2.6s.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 13 -- Great concern is being felt by Malayan producers at the recent sharp decline in rubber prices. No. 1 grade rubber sold in the Singapore market today at 56 3/4 Malayan cents a pound, the lowest price since early 1950 and a drop of 5 1/4 Malayan cents in eight days.

Seventeen parking lot operators in the midtown and lower sections of Manhattan posted higher rates yesterday, with other operators slated to follow suit later this week. Rates can be changed only after sixty days' notice to the Department of Licenses.

For each of the last eighteen years we have eaten more pork than beef. Since Jan. 1, however, we not only consumed practically all of the record amount of beef produced but we had to resort to withdrawals of surplus beef from storage to satisfy our appetite for our favorite meat.
The city will begin a scientific attack today on the problem of air contaminants with the opening of the laboratory for the Department of Air Pollution Control at 130 East 101st Street.
The use of portable gas processing plants, already being employed successfully in the Southwestern states, is about to spread to western Canada.

In recent years many Americans have become familiar with the firm-textured, slightly sweet rye honey cake that is as much a staple in Holland as brown bread in Boston. Now for the first time they can taste the version prepared by Jb. Bussink, a Dutch concern that has been baking cakes in Deventer since 1593.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- Reversing the program of its officials who had set the start for Friday, the French National Assembly decided to open tonight a long debate on agricultural policy provoked by general discontent of the peasantry.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 13 -- The Norwegian Labor party has kept its absolute majority in the Storting (Parliament), complete returns from Monday's general election indicated. Labor captured 20,000 more votes than it did in its runaway victory four years ago when it won eighty-five mandates out of a total of 105.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Liquid savings of individuals in the second quarter of this year amounted to $3,700,000,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Emanuel H. Bloch, guardian of the two children of the executed atom spies, Ethel and Julius Rosenberg, charged yesterday that their imminent exclusion from the public school in Toms River, N. J., was "some kind of a political plot."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The foreign secretaries of the United States, Britain and France will meet in London Friday and Saturday. The theory of the meeting is that the Western powers cannot make progress with the Communists unless they first make peace with each other.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges closed generally higher yesterday. Volume in most markets was good with the domestic sugar contract registering the largest number of sales since Aug. 19. Cottonseed oil, soybean oil, hides, potatoes, cocoa, copper, zinc, tin, lead, wool and burlap were higher, rubber and coffee ended lower and sugar was mixed.

The pilot who has flown faster at sea level than any other man believes that for at least ten years the aviation industry will have to be satisfied with speeds of less than 800 miles an hour in conventional aircraft. Rockets and the military services' pilotless assortment of aircraft, however, will be flying beyond the sound barrier and attaining greater speeds.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Oct. 13 -- The new Prime Minister, Sir John Kotelawala, formed his Cabinet today consisting of fourteen ministers.

The Christopher Awards for the third quarter of 1953 will be presented to Spyros Skouras, Charles A. Lindbergh, David Lawrence and others for accomplishment that "reflects the God-given talent that can be exerted for good by one individual in the communication fields."

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 13 -- Raymond A. Rich, vice president of the Philco Corporation, Philadelphia, said here today that a high level of consumer spending with a relative level of consumer, dealer and distributor credit is essential to the economic health of the nation.

BONN, Oct. 13 -- A disagreement on the size of the Cabinet appeared today to be delaying the formation of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's new coalition Government. One capital newspaper, the General-Anzeiger, said this morning that a "tug of war for ministerial chairs" had developed.

Iran today is made up of substantially the same population that it had during the twenty-eight months of former Premier Mossadegh's regime, but it faces the world with a new and different look. This week a spokesman for Premier Zahedi said that his country is now ready to try again for a settlement of the dispute with the British over the Iranian oil fields.
The nation's banks will be enabled to provide increased financing and servicing of Commodity Credit Corporation price support loans under a new arrangement announced yesterday.
Gen. James A. Van Fleet, retired Commander of the United States Eighth Army in Korea, indicated last night that he would run for Governor of Florida "if I can be of any real service."

Two new films open today at first run theatres. At the Criterion is "The Big Heat," a Columbia melodrama, starring Glenn Ford, Gloria Grahame and Jocelyn Brando. Alexander Scourby and Lee Marvin head the supporting cast. Sydney Boehm wrote the screen play from a story by William P. McGivern. Fritz Lang directed and Robert Arthur produced.
..A. fire .in.a six,story vacant loft buildingat !58 Sands.S/reet, Brookl lyn,[.t0ok the life 'of.one fireman la//t eyening and necessitated five alarms, -'

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13-- The Supreme Court was asked today to set aside a decision that has stood for more than thirty years and declare organized baseball a business, not a sport, and therefore subject to the anti-trust laws.
V. K. Forsyth, vice president of the Solvay-American Corporation of New York, has been elected a director of Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company, succeeding F. E. Notebaert, who has retired.

With some fanfare, including congratulations by Mayor Impellitteri, 74-year-old Nicholas Lana returned yesterday to his $3,600-a- year laborer's job in the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity. But for technical reasons, he must resume city work under his fictitious name of Joe Porgie.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 13 -- The Dutch First Chamber, or upper house of Parliament, will begin consideration of the European Defense Community Treaty Oct. 27, Dr. Jan A. Jonkman, chairman of the First Chamber, announced today.

IT isn't ordinarily recommended by football coaches as a method for keeping limber the throwing arms of T-formation quarterbacks, but Arnold Galiffa practiced pin-point passing by throwing hand grenades in Korea. What is more he threw them with astonishing accuracy a distance of 75 yards and that's twice as far as the book says a grenade can be tossed.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 13 -- The Communists have notified the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission that they will begin tomorrow morning their long-delayed explanations to the 22,500 North Koreans and Chinese who do not desire repatriation, a Communist source said today.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 13 -- In his campaign, Mr. Johnson urged the voters to pass "a protest" vote against failing farm income, high interest rates and high prices. He pledged himself to continue the "progressive tradition" of Mr. Hull, who was considered "a maverick" by the Wisconsin Republican organization because of his votes for Democratic domestic policies.

Impasse, a well-campaigned 3-year-old owned by the Valley Farm, won the $10,000 race that highlighted the card at Jamaica yesterday. A crowd of 17,150 saw the chestnut gelding, favored at $7.10 for $2, capture the mile-and-a-sixteenth test by three lengths.

The Mathieson Chemical Corporation had a net income, of $14,379,903 in the first nine months this year $13,014,846 for taxes, Thomas S. Nichols, president, reported in the statement to be mailed to stockholders today. This compares with $11,489,208 after $8,400,000 taxes for the corresponding period last year.
The stock market got off to a fast start yesterday and then quickly faded.

Roger Franz was benched yesterday and George Murphy, a senior, will start at quarterback for Fordham in Friday night's home opener against Boston College at the Polo Grounds. Coach Ed Danowski, sorely disappointed with his team's loss against Syracuse Saturday, also revealed four other changes involving Halfback Mal Stafford and three line men.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Asserting there still are remnants of the "too old at forty" feeling, a Government committee urged today that capacity and not age be the deciding factor in hiring.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 13 -- Dr. Nathan Marsh Pusey "gratefully and prayerfully" accepted today the position of twenty-fourth president of Harvard University.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Establishment of direct contacts between Western leaders and Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov is one of the key objectives for which the British delegation will press when the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France meet here late this week.

Supreme Court Justice S. Samuel Di Falco reserved decision on a motion by Louis Schiff and Jacob Sacks owners of 200 shares of the 4,000,000 outstanding shares of common stock of R. K. O., who seek a receivership for the parent company and its subsidiary Radio Pictures, Inc.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Oct. 13 -- Lester Johnson, a small-town district attorney, became tonight the first Democrat ever elected to Congress from the Ninth Wisconsin Congressional District. The election was viewed with national interest as a possible reflection of a Midwestern farmer vote on President Eisenhower's farm policies as outlined by Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson.

The report that 72 per cent of the Hoover Commission's proposals on governmental reorganization have been wholly or partially put into effect is cause for encouragement but not complacency. It is a great tribute to the remarkable work done by the bipartisan group of which former President Hoover was chairman and Dean Acheson vice chairman that so many of its recommendations have already taken form through legislative or administrative action.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor, promised yesterday that, if elected, he would maintain an open-door policy at City Hall. The pledge was made to a group of business men who visited him at his Biltmore Hotel campaign headquarters to offer their support.

One does not challenge Elgin Grose-close without some trepidation and qualms about disputing so well-known an authority. But his remarks of Sept. 26 about antagonism to the Point Four program strike me as being based more on personal ill feeling than they seem to be founded in the facts.

The regional Red Cross blood program collected 524 pints of blood on Friday, including 182 at the Western Electric Company, 395 Hudson Street. On Monday, Columbus Day, with the centers closed and only two bloodmobiles out, the total was 172.

James P. Warburg, author of "Germany -- Bridge or Battleground," among his many other books on foreign affairs, has a follow-up on that volume scheduled by Harvard University Press for Oct. 26 publication. In "Germany: Key to Peace," Mr. Warburg condemns our post-war policy in Germany and predicts the end of European unity if we persist in our policy to include German troops in the European Army.

A former Army officer told the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations yesterday that "a sizable amount" of "top secret" documents of the Army Signal Corps were missing, according to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- President Eisenhower and the National Security Council got their first look today at what the Administration-appointed Joint Chiefs of Staff consider the minimum military forces needed for national security.

Many tickets have been purchased for the performance tomorrow night of "Late Love," a new comedy, with Arlene Francis, Lucile Watson and Neil Hamilton, at the National Theatre, for the benefit of the Manhattan School of Music Scholarship Fund.

TRIESTE, Oct. 13 -- Among the many groups in Trieste whose future has suddenly turned dark as a result of the United States-British decision to evacuate the city and turn its administration over to the Italians, the most helpless are the 4,458 displaced persons now receiving allied care.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 13 -- "The Caine Mutiny Court Martial," Herman Wouk's dramatization of his best-seller, enjoyed a successful preview last night at the Granada Theatre. Tonight at San Diego the all-male company will present an official premiere before top Navy officials and West Coast critics.
Two of the most important persons in the home equipment and furnishings fields, the consumer and the manufacturer, spoke up for themselves at two meetings here last night.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- The United States carefully chose a middle line today in the dispute on French rule in Morocco and carefully walked down it.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A major reorganization of the Department of Agriculture, the first since 1942, was outlined today by Secretary Ezra Taft Benson and his top officials.

Objects with a fluid, molded appearance are included in the new collection of Steuben crystal, along with other designs that have the handsome, carved look typical of pieces made in the past by that concern. Seven of the new designs are available in the Steuben glass shop at 718 Fifth Avenue, while twelve other new pieces may be found in the Steuben Glass Room at Lord Taylor.

It is regrettable that Senator Wicks has refused to resign immediately his leadership posts that place him first in line to fill any vacancy in the office of Governor. The President pro tem of the Senate has plainly misappraised the extent of the public's loss of confidence in his judgment after disclosure of his repeated visits to Sing Sing Prison to see the convicted labor extortionist Joseph S. Fay.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The highly competitive soap industry faces even keener competition in the year ahead, R. R. Deupree, chairman of the Procter Gamble Company, told stockholders at the annual meeting here today. But, he said, "we look ahead with real confidence to the future."

Carl F. Kauffeld, curator of reptiles at the Staten Island Zoo at 614 Broadway, West New Brighton, was bitten on the right hand yesterday by a five-foot Indian king cobra while helping the snake shed its skin in its cage. A police radio car rushed Mr. Kauffeld to St. Vincent's Hospital in West New Brighton, where Dr. Thomas Dunn, who has treated many persons bitten by reptiles, injected anti-venom.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 13 -- Police, backed by strong parties of British troops, raided the homes and offices of the leaders of the People's Progressive party at dawn today and seized truckloads of documents in a search for evidence of subversive activity.

Gifts totaling $475,000 from 100 women were announced yesterday at an advance gifts luncheon of the women's division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies in the 21 Club, 21 West Fifty-second Street.
CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- All signs point to the Athletic Department of Notre Dame mustering strength in urging university officials to accept a Sugar Bowl invitation.

John Biagini, 35 years old, a Brooklyn waterfront habitue, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz in Kings County Court to an indeterminate term of up to three years in the city penitentiary on his plea of guilty to usury and conspiracy.

Three alien Communist leaders asked the Federal court yesterday to prevent the Immigration Service from forbidding their political activities and from restricting their personal life so closely as to violate their "human rights."

Wool flannels and jerseys in pastel tones of pink, white and blue provided an attractive showing of Jerry Gilden designs yesterday at Russeks. Styled with simplicity and good taste, the dresses looked worth more than their modest price tags of $14.95 to $22.95.

Rikuparo Katsumori, a Japanese trader, testified at a Federal Maritime Board hearing yesterday that the proposed institution of a contract non-contract dual rate system by the Japan-Atlantic and Gulf Freight conference was most favorable for stability.

Free competition in the oil industry offers the best hope for the conservation of the nation's petroleum resources, B. Brewster Jennings, president of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., told an audience of 1,300 oil executives and their guests at an Oil Progress Week luncheon yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Arnold Galiffa's first real workout with the New York Football Giants yesterday at the Polo Grounds was an impressive one. The former West Pointer, recently signed by the Giants, alternated with Chuck Conerly in a passing drill and, in the words of Steve Owen, "looked good."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Hungary's officials in Washington may travel freely within a forty-mile radius of the White House under liberalized travel restrictions announced today by the State Department.

CAIRO, Oct. 13 -- Maj. Salah Salem, Minister of National Guidance, told foreign correspondents tonight that the next meeting of the British-Egyptian negotiators in the dispute over the future status of the Suez Canal military base would be decisive. "I think we have a full change of agreement." On Saturday, he had said that "I firmly believe that to reach an agreement with the British side is quite impossible."
KITTY HAWK, N. C., Oct. 13 (AP) -- The world pioneers of aviation retraced the steps of the Wright Brothers by helicopter today.

ALBANY, Calif., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Wee Willie Shoemaker made three trips to the winner's circle at Golden Gate Fields today, bringing him within one victory of matching Tony DeSpirito's national record of 390 set last year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The United States stood firm today on the decision of last week to give Italy control of Zone A of the disputed Trieste territory.

GLASGOW, Scotland, Oct. 13 (Reuters) -- Harry S. Truman and Adlai E. Stevenson, former President and candidate - for - President of the United States, respectively, today declined nominations for the illustrious office of Rector of Glasgow University.
There are no signs of recession in the packaging industry.

Three five-story apartment buildings occupying a plot 120 by 100 feet at 926 to 940 East 180th Street, in the Bronx, have been sold by Dr. George Mullen to the Echo Realty Corporation for investment. There are six stores and fifty-six apartments in the buildings, which were sold in a deal arranged by M. S. Gaumont and Louis Abrams, brokers.

The Federal Republic of Germany is publishing the formal terms of an official bond exchange offer under which defaulted prewar German bonds of the Young, Dawes and certain other dollar loans can be surrendered for new bonds.
DETROIT, Oct. 13 -- An administrative board of three colonels recommended today that Lieut. Milo J. Radulovich be discharged from the Air Force Reserve as a doubtful security risk.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Oct. 13 -- An artmobile was formally opened here today. The chief speaker, Thomas M. Beggs of the Smithsonian Institution, called it an "inspiration for the nation." A crowd of 700, mostly women, attended.

A pre-election drive within the city government to repeal the $5 and $10 automobile use tax opened yesterday with the introduction before the City Council of a bill calling for expiration of the levy before June 1. The measure, which had four Democratic Councilmen as its sponsors, was referred to the Finance Committee.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Dwight David Eisenhower 2d, grandson of the President, stole the show today as his family was interviewed under the eyes of Secret Service men, present at the President's request.
Cotton futures closed steady yesterday, three to nine points net higher on the active months than on Monday.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 13 -- The Future Farmers of America began celebrating their twenty-fifth anniversary here today.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 13 -- Sir Winston Churchill, maker and writer of modern history, will receive the $35,000 Nobel prize for literature this year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The minimum objectives of the Administration tax program, which will be submitted to Congress next January, have now been set. They are:

NORWICH, Conn., Oct. 13 -- One of the biggest mergers in the history of eastern Connecticut, involving textile plants at Norwich and Jewett City, received approval here this afternoon. It involves acquisition of the Aspinook Corporation of Jewett City by the U. S. Finishing Company on the basis of sixteen shares of the U. S. Finishing for each share of Aspinook.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- The Soviet Union called today for a meeting of the United Nations Security Council to elect a governor for Trieste and to put the Free Territory on a permanent basis within three months.
A small bird, tentatively identified as an orange weaver, a native of West Africa, was found Monday in Central Park in critical condition, apparently a victim of exposure and malnutrition.

The West Side Savings Bank, which occupies its own building at 422 Avenue of the Americas, at West Ninth Street, has leased space for a branch office on the ground floor of the fifteen-story Dodge-Olcott Building at 180-2 Varick Street.

Anthony (Tough Tony) Anastasia, boss of the Brooklyn waterfront, and the high command of the International Longshoremen's Association were cited last night for criminal and civil contempt of a Federal no-strike injunction.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, called on President Eisenhower today to press for revision of the McCarren-Walter Immigration Act, as the President said he would during the 1952 election campaign.

ALBANY, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The pilot of an American Airlines plane that crashed here Sept. 16 apparently was unable to lower his wing flaps because of a mechanical failure, witnesses at a Civil Aeronautics Board hearing testified today.

WATERTOWN, S. D., Oct. 13 (AP) -- The House of Representatives Agriculture Committee today found South Dakota farm organizations almost solidly united for high level price supports for most products except beef cattle. It also ran into considerable criticism of Federal farm programs advocated by Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson.

The trend toward an earlier start of winter vacations has proved a boon to manufacturers of women's resort and cruise wear. Members of the Sportswear Guild who specialize in this type of apparel said yesterday that wholesale buying of new lines for the winter resort season was more active than at any time in the last four or five years.
Shoe styles for every occasion were shown yesterday morning by Bonwit Teller in the Hampshire House Cottage.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that "peaceful world trade with our Allies must increase, not decline," and added that the Eisenhower Administration was formulating policies to carry out this program.

HERSHEY, Pa., Oct. 13 -- President Eisenhower, at a huge and colorful party honoring his sixty-third birthday, uttered a fervent plea tonight for international understanding. "Knowledge," he said, "is not enough; what we need is understanding.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The president of Republic Steel Corporation said today he sees no danger of a deep recession, despite a decline recently in steel production.
POTTSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 13 -- "Strange things are happening" at The Hill School this season. A new spirit that insists on victory seems to have invaded the campus and the feeling has spread.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, promised yesterday to strengthen and improve the city's child health and welfare services if he is elected. In a statement he said he would name the best men he could find to head the Health, Hospital and Welfare Departments and would keep them free of political appointees.
The Board of Elections refused yesterday to invalidate the Experience party petitions for the independent nomination of Mayor Impellitteri for re-election.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Foreign Operations Administration announced a plan today under which it hoped to work the disposal of some $175,000,000 worth of surplus United States agricultural commodities into the Mutual Security Program.

The three-story building on lot 23 by 78 feet at 579 Avenue of the Americas, adjoining the corner of Sixteenth Street, has been resold by Edward Schwartz, operator, to Elizabeth Sacalis. It is leased to Lampland, Inc., lamps and novelty furniture.
TORONTO, Oct. 13 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared here today that educational institutions in the United States were failing to give young people a realistic understanding of world problems.

While Samuel Reshevsky of the United States was engaged in a struggle with Ewfim Geller of Russia which was adjourned after forty-one moves, Vassily Smyslov of Moscow vanquished Paul Keres of Estonia in twenty-eight moves last night in the twenty-fourth round of the world chess championship challengers' tournament at Zurich.

The currently popular Oriental look has been used to provide backgrounds for a new collection of furniture that will be presented today in room settings at Bloomingdale's and W. J. Sloane. The furniture, called "The New World Group," is made by the Baker Company and is representative of trends popular in contemporary furniture design today.
MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Oct. 13 (AP)--A 14-year-old boy told a conscience-stricken story today of putting his younger brother in a cedar chest, causing his death, the State Police reported.

The development of specialization among research scientists has made it increasingly difficult for researchers to communicate with each other, Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, warned here yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The meeting of the Big Three to be held here over the week-end was planned before the storm blew up over Trieste, so it was not called to discuss the tumult that followed the decision to turn over Zone A to Italian administration. That issue will certainly be on the agenda of the Foreign Ministers, especially now that Russia has intervened and the problem has been referred to the United Nations.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Members of the National Association of Retail Druggists in convention here today were given Democratic and Republican views on Governmental treatment of business. The speakers were Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, Senate Democratic leader, and Senator Andrew F. Schoeppel, Republican of Kansas, member of the Senate Committee on small business and chairman of its Subcommittee on Monopoly.

TRENTON, Oct. 13 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll was called upon today to repudiate Paul L. Troast, Republican candidate for Governor, because of the letter Mr. Troast wrote to Governor Dewey of New York requesting executive clemency for Joseph S. Fay, convicted extortioner and labor leader.

FOREST HILLS High School's entire faculty is intrigued by the parking-summons resistance of a faded blue sedan that has squatted a foot from the curb outside the school's northern boundary since February.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- The view of officials here today was that at their meeting in London Friday the Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain and France would discuss many topics including the pending Big Four conference, the Far East and Trieste.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A new primary unit, the Bureau of Foreign Commerce, was established in the United States Department of Commerce today.

The Inter-American Press Association has ended its ninth annual session in Mexico City in the paradoxical situation of being stronger than ever while freedom of the press is facing a series of setbacks in the hemisphere. However, the very fact that IAPA is by now a more powerful and authoritative champion of the free press in Latin America gives promise that the tide is going to flow forward again before very long.
Awkwardly at first and then with increasing confidence and grace, the soldier danced with the United Service Organizations hostess. Other G. I.'s and hostesses watched him.

ROME, Oct. 13 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York was received in private audience by Pope Pius at Castel Gandolfo this morning and remained in conversation with him for about forty-five minutes.

MONTREAL, Oct. 13 (UP) -- Gordie Howe, Detroit's star right-winger, is making a fast start in defense of his National Hockey League scoring title, but shares first place with a rookie teammate, Earl (Dutch) Reibel.

ALBANY, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Senator John H. Hughes of Syracuse, who is considered a possible successor to Mr. Wicks, commented that the "burden" was on the Majority Leader "to present facts which will dispel all suspicion and remove all doubt of wrongdoing" in his visits to Fay.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the Columbia University-Presbyterian Hospital Medical Center has been observed with fitting ceremonies. The distinguished clinicians and scientists in attendance testified to the importance of the Center not only in our community life but in the advance of medicine as a whole.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- The United States and Britain today turned down the Soviet Union's new, small-model package proposal for breaking the deadlock that has kept twenty-one governments outside the doors of the United Nations.

BOSTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted a Boston wool broker and his assistant today on sixteen charges of using the mails to defraud, and conspiring to defraud the First National Bank of Boston and Commercial Factors of New York out of $947,000.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Diplomats, looking back over the seven months of Premier Georgi M. Malenkov's regime in the Soviet Union, are impressed not only by the efficiency with which it has weathered internal crisis but by the shift in ideological emphasis and actual working methods.

The strike by 170 guards and watchmen, which has closed the Metropolitan Museum of Art and its Fort Tryon Park branch, the Cloisters, continued yesterday with no apparent indication of an early settlement.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 13 -- Self-help among Asian countries was emphasized today by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India and Foreign Minister Richard G. Casey of Australia in opening the annual meeting of the consultative committee of the British Commonwealth's Colombo Plan for economic cooperation in South and Southeast Asia.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- Having to face Ohio State after absorbing a 40-0 beating from California is hardly a cheerful prospect, but Pennsylvania has no thought of throwing in the towel in this football season yet. As a matter of fact, the Red and Blue still is ahead of the game for 1953, having scored victories over Vanderbilt and Penn State before running afoul of the Golden Bears.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- President Eisenhower, in a recess appointment today, named Donald A. Fraser to be United States marshal for Connecticut.

Vic Power and Elston Howard, the first Negroes to be brought up by the Yankees, were among eight minor league players whose contracts were purchased by the world champions yesterday. Power and Howard were with Kansas City last season and the former, with a mark of .349, was the batting champion of the American Association.

YONKERS, Oct. 13 -- Pronto Don, leading money-winning trotter with $265,085, today drew the No. 3 post position in a field of ten named for the $25,000 Gotham Trot of one mile and a half on Thursday's Grand Circuit program at Yonkers Raceway. A probable 6-5 favorite, Pronto Don will be driven by Benny Schue.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- An early decision on easing the regulations against the export of iron and steel scrap was promised to scrap dealers today by the Government.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13-- Attacks against the oil industry in Washington last summer represented the acme of "demagogic unfairness," Frank M. Porter, president of the American Petroleum Institute, said here tonight.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 13 -- C. Carleton Gisborne, incumbent First Selectman, and his complete slate of running mates put down a Republican insurrection in this community today by sweeping all eleven election districts in a primary vote for candidates for town office.

FORT WORTH, Oct. 13 (UP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias, the defending champion from Tampa, Fla., and Polly Riley, Fort Worth amateur, shared the medal today in the qualifying round of the annual women's Texas open golf tournament with 2-under-par 73's.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 13 -- The multi-million dollar Iskenderun naval base and training center built with United States funds and designed to serve as the eastern anchor for Allied Mediterranean fleets, will be activated next Tuesday, the United States Military Mission here announced today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- A five-year extension of the United Nations program for aid to refugees now carried on by the Office of the High Commissioner for Refugees was proposed jointly here today by six countries.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 13 -- The Yugoslav Government is seeking a United States-British guarantee against further Italian expansion in the direction of Yugoslavia.
Youngsters from many parts of the metropolitan area streamed into Madison Square Garden yesterday for their annual matinee at the World's Championship Rodeo there.
Martha Rountree, moderator of "Meet the Press" and "The Big Issue," will discontinue her appearance on both programs in about a month. Her successor has not been named.

ALBANY, Oct. 13 -- Governor Dewey today set Nov. 17 as the date on which Senator Arthur H. Wicks is scheduled to stand or fall as Majority Leader and President pro tem of the Legislature's upper house and as the state's second highest officer.

Rudolph Halley, the Liberal party candidate for Mayor, last night characterized Robert F. Wagner Jr., his Democratic opponent, as a "front" for Tammany Hall and accused him of failure to speak out against crime and corruption in the city.
If an individual can profit by increasing his own production, he will see the importance of increasing national productivity.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 13 -- R. H. Coleman of Bridgeport, Conn., was elected president of the American Hardware Manufacturers Association at the 105th semi-annual convention here today at the Marlborough-Blenheim Hotel. He succeeds Herbert B. Megran, of Harvard, Ill. Vice presidents named were Franz T. Stone of Tonawanda, N. Y.; Mark L. Lacey of Southington, Conn., and B. B. Wood of Piqua, Ohio.

The musical variation of Edna Ferber's successful novel, "Saratoga Trunk," is gradually getting under way. Yesterday it was learned that Moss Hart, recalled as the author of such notable musicals as "As Thousands Cheer" and "Lady in the Dark," already is collaborating with Miss Ferber on the song and dance version and would also be involved as director.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- A strong market developed in wheat futures today, and there was also a sharp upturn in soybeans. But coarse grains were inclined to heaviness at times and rye was again handicapped by the reported shipment of 389,000 bushels of Canadian rye to this market.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 13 -- Israel's offer of a temporary suspension of work in the demilitarized zone near the Syrian border to enable to United Nations Truce Supervision Organization to clarify the disputed points related to Israel's Jordan River hydroelectric project was made official today in a letter from Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett to Maj. Gen. Vagn Bennike, United Nations Chief of Staff in Jerusalem.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 13 -- Jack Patroni and Frank Donahue of Apawamis won the Westchester County Golf Association's pro-amateur best-ball tournament today over the Siwanoy course. They carded a 7-under-par 33, 31 -- 64, to triumph by a stroke.

CAIRO, Oct. 13 -- Mahmoud Sabry Ali, a former employe of the British forces in the Suez Canal base, was hanged at 9 A. M. today, less than forty-eight hours after he had been condemned by the ruling army junta's Revolution Tribunal on charges of spying for an unnamed foreign power and seizing and torturing Egyptian nationalists.

MELBOURNE, Oct. 13 -- Lieut. Gen. William Bridgeford, chief executive officer of the 1956 Oympics, said today his committee was taking an active interest in the provision of sufficient accommodations for visitors to the games, though this was not its responsibility.

While negotiators have been warily seeking to expand the fragments of accord that have barely been able to silence the Korean battlefield, the other great Asian tinderbox has been smoldering under the relentless rain of the southwest monsoon.

Governor Dewey assailed the city administration last night, laying some of its policies to "stupidity." He charged the Impellitteri regime with "government by abdication" in that it wished to raise expenses but lacked the courage to raise the necessary funds.

Everyone at the National last evening seemed to find Rosemary Casey's "Late Love" adorable. This will have to be a minority report from one theatregoer who found it cute. Miss Casey is the author of "The Velvet Glove," in which a demure Mother Superior turned out to be a devious politician.

Taking advantage of the conflict within the Western defense system over Trieste, the Soviet Government has promptly intervened with a protest and a demand. In its eyes this protest and demand must have the double merit that they have a semblance of legality and at the same time hit all parties concerned.
A 1940 Plymouth sedan was sold for $13 yesterday although it was a far-down-at-the-heels cousin of the much publicized ramblin' wreck from Georgia Tech.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 14 -- Four farm youths were honored tonight for outstanding achievement in agricultural work by the Future Farmers of America as that organization completed its second day of convention business here.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Oct. 14 (UP) -- The Government announced today that only wheat and newsprint imports will continue to be paid for with foreign exchange at the official preferential rate of 18.82 cruzeiros per dollar.
LOUISVILLE, Oct. 14 (UP) -- Pee Wee Reese, the team captain and shortstop, indicated today that he might be receptive to an offer to succeed Charlie Dressen as manager of the Dodgers.

VENICE, Italy, Oct. 14 -- The United States Administration will ask Congress to support a three-to-five-year cooperative international effort to break the back of Europe's worst overpopulation problems.

The trouble with those little Public Notices and Commercial Notices tucked away at the foot of the inside back page is that they are a form of one-way communication. Did the couple traveling to Miami find the couple they sought to help drive "in exchange transp.?" Did someone ever get in touch with a "responsible person" wanted to drive an empty car to Phoenix, Ariz.? One never finds out.

CHARLIE DRESSEN did not do too well managing in 1951, when the Dodgers blew the pennant. So the Brooks renewed his contract without hesitation. He did only a fair job in 1952, rallying his forces in the homestretch when they seemed ready to blow it again. Once more, though, his contract was renewed.

HOLYOKE, Mass., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Whiting Co., Inc., one of the country's largest makers of high grade papers, has been sold to two members of the concern and a local business man, it was announced today by Edward C. Whiting, president and treasurer.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- In its best shape to date, the Army football team will move into the Polo Grounds Saturday to play Duke, one of the top-ranking elevens of the country.
Charlie Dressen, who guided Brooklyn to two consecutive National League pennants after having narrowly missed one in his first season in charge, will not manage the Dodgers next year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- President Eisenhower announced today a four-point assistance program for Bolivia providing $5,000,000 worth of agricultural products and $4,000,000 in funds for other essential commodities and services.

Mayor Impellitteri, in an ardent preface to a prepared speech, defended yesterday the Department of Air Pollution Control against what he called a "shocking" attack by one of his opponents in the mayoral race. The Mayor did not name the department's attacker, but it was criticized last week by Harold Riegelman, the Republican candidate, as politically tainted.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14 -- The Federal Administration was sharply criticized today for "poor foresight" on the needs of the United States merchant marine and this country's private shipbuilding industry. John J. Grogan, national president of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., made the criticism.

One hundred paintings and drawings inspired by the stories of Hans Christian Andersen went on display yesterday at Georg Jensen's Christmas shop, 683 Fifth Avenue. They are representative of 4,000 submitted in an international competition by boys and girls from forty-five countries.

Amateur chefs who like to make oysters Rockefeller may well be interested in a new gadget that simplifies the preparation of this New Orleans specialty. It is the Searak, a set consisting of a green, pie-shaped pan, a bag of rock salt and a wire rack so shaped that it holds the shellfish securely in place both for baking and serving.

A 424-page opinion was filed yesterday by Federal Judge Harold R. Medina in connection with his recent dismissal of the Government's anti-trust action against seventeen of the country's leading investment banking houses. The case was initiated almost six years ago, and the trial itself lasted for almost three years.

MERCERSBURG, Pa., Oct. 14 -- Things were looking up at Mercersburg Academy this afternoon. Its football team, beaten in both of its games, seemed to show more spark and enthusiasm than it had since the season's start. The result was that Herbert (Fido) Kempton, the Royal Blue and White's grizzled coach, was happier.

Nassau County Judge Norman F. Lent, who received the indictment last Wednesday night in which William C. De Koning Sr. was accused of extorting money from workers at Roosevelt Raceway, acknowledged yesterday that he had been associated with the indicted union leader in a concern that had the printing and distributing concession for the track's racing programs.

The Children's Court of this city has failed to achieve the aim of the juvenile court movement to protect and help children in trouble, rather than punish and embitter them, it was asserted yesterday in a report on the tribunal.

GREENWICH, CONN., Oct. 14 -- The Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, reported tonight on his 23,000-mile trip to the Far East before the quarterly meeting of the National Council of the Episcopal Church at Seabury House here.

The New Jersey Turnpike Authority yesterday raised funds to finance extension of the expressway from the Newark Airport interchange to the Holland Tunnel Plaza through the sale of an issue of $150,000,000 of long-term toll revenue bonds at an interest cost of slightly less than 3 1/2 per cent.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Oct. 14 (UP) -- A Belgian airliner plunged nose first into a pine woods from a height of 200 feet and exploded today shortly after taking off from Rhein - Main airport, killing all forty-four persons aboard, eleven of them Americans.

The fifteen-story office building at 250 Church Street occupying the blockfront from Leonard to Franklin Streets has been purchased by a client of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company for investment in a deal arranged by the Charles F. Noyes Company, broker.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- New York will join here with delegations from member nations in a "salute to the United Nations" at a mid-day observance of United Nations Day, Oct. 24. The program, which will be open to the public, will be held outdoors if the weather permits, with the two ramps on the west side of the General Assembly building as the stage.

OTTAWA, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Canadian Government has decided to float a new bond issue of $700,000,000 to provide funds to pay off two maturities next month and convert parts of the second Victory Loan maturing next March, the Finance Department announced today.

Betty Hutton has returned to the Palace, where she performed last evening, and modified raptures will be suitably inscribed in this place. The raptures are for Betty, who is as blonde, exuberant and crinkly nosed as ever. The modifications apply to her material.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, predicted "limitless blessings for mankind in the coming age of super-flight." He spoke at a dinner celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of powered flight.

FRESH CREEK, Andros, the Bahamas, Oct. 14 -- After a week of unparalleled bonefishing, exceptional reef fishing, unusual pigeon shooting, and some over-eating induced by the culinary arts of Whyam Surrender, chef of the Andros Yacht Club, we are not looking forward to the arrival of the Nassau amphibian that will separate us from this happy island.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- A reactionary trend developed in wheat prices on the Board of Trade today, while corn and oats showed a rather steady undertone despite the increasing movement of new-crop corn. Selling of wheat was not aggressive but the slow demand made the local pressure effective.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Arguments were completed in the Supreme Court today in three cases involving the status of organized baseball with reference to the anti-trust laws and the court took the issue under advisement. In the normal course of court procedures a decision would be unlikely for several weeks.
Stockholders of the Electric Bond and Share Company were informed at their annual meeting yesterday that earnings of the company are at the best levels in twenty-three years.

It is not hard to see that summer is gone and another autumn has come. In lives that rely on clocks and calendars there are other sure signs. The pin oaks have developed their tinge of red and chrysanthemums blossom on coats. The decision to buy more charcoal for the outdoor barbecue pit has been put off until spring.
Rudolph Halley, the Liberal party candidate for Mayor, promised last night to institute an intensive program to aid many of the 600,000 men and women in the city over 65 years old.

The vacant brownstone dwelling at 230 East Sixty-first Street will be modernized as a result of its purchase by Dr. Emanuel Josephson for cash over a mortgage of $25,000 in a deal negotiated by the M. Morgenthau-Seixas Company, brokers.

Fashions designed to flatter and create an illusion of height for women five feet five or shorter in height were shown yesterday at the Pierre Hotel in B. Altman's presentation of Varden Petite designs. Slim crepe and wool dresses with satin binding and piping trim and sheer wool costume suits styled with quiet good taste were offered for day wear.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- President Eisenhower today made the refusal of Federal employes to testify before Congressional committees on the ground of possible self-incrimination a basis for their dismissal from their Government jobs.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 -- Capt. Arnold R. Kline, commanding officer of the United States Naval supply depot at Los Angeles harbor, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on six felony counts of converting Government property to his own use.

The city's proposed $28,900,000 slum-clearance and 2,184-apartment development plan for Washington Square Southeast was bitterly assailed yesterday. Greenwich Village tenants, property owners and civic workers presented arguments against the plan at a public hearing before the City Planning Commission at City Hall.

Several years ago Maurice Evans took a long-term option on Vern Sneider's novel, "The Teahouse of the August Moon." Its stage version opens tonight at the Martin Beck Theatre at 8 o'clock. The novel adapted into play form by John Patrick, is being presented by Mr. Evans in association with George Schaefer.

The American Civil Liberties Union advocated yesterday an interpretation of the Foreign Agents Registration Act of 1938 that would legalize the importation of Soviet literature for scholars and all other persons if it bore "the name and address of the responsible publisher."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, left by air for London tonight to make a new effort to draw the Allies closer in their search for "the basis of a lasting peace."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- A committee of the House of Representatives received assurance today that the nation's life insurance companies could provide satisfactory health insurance to virtually all persons.

In terms of trial time and volume of court record, the investment banking trial just ended ranks near the top of six major anti-trust cases adjudicated in recent years. In trial time the banking case was exceeded only by the civil action brought in 1947 against the United Shoe Machinery Corporation. Here is how the major anti-trust trials compare in trial time, pages of transcript of courtroom proceedings, and exhibits figuring in the litigation:

Mrs. William T. Gossett of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and Mrs. William P. White of 13 Summit Avenue, Baldwin, L. I., were installed as alumnae trustees of Barnard College last evening at the fall board of trustees meeting. Mrs. Gossett and Mrs. White were elected to the board by members of the Barnard Alumnae Association. Four alumnae trustees serve on the twenty-six-member board.

A second Japanese business man testified at a Federal Maritime Board hearing here yesterday on the proposed establishment of a dual rate contract system by the Japan-Atlantic and Gulf Freight Conference.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 14 -- A memorandum presenting the Bonn Government's views on all aspects of the question of reuniting Eastern and Western Germany has been submitted to the United States, Britain and France, the news service of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's political party, the Christian Democratic Union, stated today.

September shipments of rayon and acetate yarn and staple totaled 87,100,000 pounds, a decline of 11 per cent compared with August and 20 per cent below September, 1952, it was announced yesterday by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc., reporting agency for the industry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The American Federation of Labor appropriated $200,000 today as a starter to organize a new union of longshoremen and said it expected cooperation, not injunctions, from Federal authorities.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- There were several factors contributing to yesterday's Democratic upset victory in the Congressional election.
AMSTERDAM, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- Richard H. Balch, Democratic State Chairman, called tonight for the special session of the Legislature Nov. 17 to include an investigation of the state prison system.
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 14 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley won first low gross today in the final one-day tournament of the women's Long Island Golf Association.
Concern over the present shortage of scientific manpower was expressed yesterday at a conference at Teachers College, Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- High-level Pentagon planning on the size and composition of future military forces struck a vacuum today as the Joint Chiefs of Staff took back to their closed door council room a set of plans that apparently got a cool reception yesterday at a meeting of the National Security Council.
BERLIN, Oct. 14 -- The East German Government has announced the arrest or trial of fifty-two persons charged with espionage for the West in the last three weeks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- John Moors Cabot, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, today accused Guatemala of "openly playing the Communist game" and said that no regime so doing could expect "positive cooperation" from this country.

A broader and "tougher" law enforcement program to eliminate three violations that are causing 90 per cent of fatal highway accidents was announced yesterday by Commissioner James R. Macduff of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau. The offenses he cited were speeding, driving on the wrong side of the road and driving while not having the right of way.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday its endorsement of General Sessions Judges Jonah J. Goldstein and John A. Mullen and City Court Justice Francis E. Rivers, candidates for re-election on the Republican, Democratic, Liberal and Independent party tickets.

The Tishman Realty Construction Company of New York announced here yesterday that it had purchased the French Lick Springs Hotel in French Lick, Indiana, from the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company in a deal negotiated by Irving Wolper, New York realty broker.

An exhibit of five evening gowns flown to this country from Paris, Rome, London, Barcelona and Ireland was presented yesterday by Pan American World Airways, 600 Fifth Avenue, to announce a fashion travel counseling service, available to the fashion industry.

Stockholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company authorized the giant communications concern yesterday to issue more than $600,000,000 in convertible debentures for new construction and expansion purposes.
Two hundred alumni of Columbia College opened its third annual scholarship fund drive yesterday at an organizational dinner in the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street.

Members of the Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York have arranged their annual card party for the afternoon of Nov. 9 in the ballroom of the Colony Club.

Commodity prices closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was normal, but zinc had the heaviest sales since Sept. 21 and cottonseed oil since Sept. 16. Burlap and copper closed mixed; sugar, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, potatoes and wool were lower, and hides, zinc, coffee, cocoa, lead, tin and rubber ended higher.
The importance of the tailored suit and the draped coat were stressed at a fashion show given yesterday in the new Peacock Alley of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Arnold Constable.
Factory shipments of several large electrical household appliances rose sharply in the first eight months of the year.

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 14 (UP) -- Chantry, a $110 bargain horse, today became the first favorite in nineteen years to win the Cesarewitch Stakes, and it was believed he won a sizable fortune for his owner-trainer, Stafford Ingham.

On many occasions we have taken the opportunity to say that the city administration has made far too inadequate provision for the fight on smoke. A Bureau of Smoke Control, inadequately financed, limped along for three years or so without making any significant contribution to solving the problem.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Wisconsin, whose voters chilled the Presidential prospects of Robert A. Taft in the Republican primaries of 1940 and froze out the renomination campaign of Wendell L. Willkie in 1944, blew an icy breath in the direction of President Eisenhower and his Administration Tuesday when, in the Ninth Congressional District, it elected the first Democrat ever to be sent to the Capitol from that area.

YONKERS, Oct. 14 -- Pronto Don, world record-holder at one mile and a quarter and two miles, is a probable 6-5 favorite in a field of ten to regain the silver Gotham Bowl in the fourth annual $25,000 trot over the mile-and-a-half distance tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

Coach Ed Danowski pointed yesterday to evidence on films to support his contention that the sleeper pass play that led to Fordham's 20-13 defeat against Syracuse last Saturday was illegal. Motion pictures of the game played upstate showed "three infractions of the rules on the play, which resulted in a 70-yard gain for the Orange and a subsequent deciding touchdown."

The 7,114-gross ton Bull Lines passenger vessel Puerto Rico, last of a long line of American liners active before and after World War II in trade to the North Caribbean, has been sold to Swiss interests, it was learned yesterday.

With steels and aircrafts in the lead, the stock market made an irregular advance yesterday in the most active trading of the month. THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average rose 0.90 point and closed at 171.35.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Cutbacks in Federal employment from July 31, 1952, to the end of July, 1953, more than offset increased hiring by state and local governments, the Bureau of the Census reported today. The drop for Federal, state and local governments was the first in six years, the agency said.

Acknowledging that, at times, he might be considered "in the advertising business," Ben Hogan, golf star, received the bronze plaque of achievement from the Advertising Club of New York at a luncheon yesterday.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 851 pints of blood Tuesday, including 257 from military and civilian personnel at Mitchel Air Force Base, Garden City, L. I., and 193 from a community donation at the Flushing (Queens) Young Men's Christian Association.
Infants' and children's wear imported from many European countries was shown yesterday in Gimbels' new "Young Boutique" on the store's second floor.
