AT THE WOOMERA RANGE, Thursday, Oct. 15 -- To an observer in a plane about 3,000 feet above the atomic-bomb firing area within an hour after the explosion, the blast zone appeared as a blackened circle about a quarter mile in diameter.

In a deal reported to have involved $15,000,000, the well-known Plaza Hotel in the blockfront between Fifty-eighth and Fifty-ninth Street facing the Plaza and Fifth Avenue, has passed into ownership of a hotel group healed by A. M. Sonnabend of Boston.

" The American Legion Reader," a selection of the "most interesting" material published in the magazine in the last thirty years, will be issued on Armistice Day, Nov. 11, by Hawthorne Books. The fiction, articles, humor and cartoons to be included in the book were selected by Victor Lasky, co-author of "Seeds of Treason."

The beleaguered International Longshoremen's Association decided yesterday to call a special convention, at which Joseph P. Ryan, the union's indicted president, would quit his $20,000-a-year lifetime job.
The rushing of British troops to British Guiana and the overthrow of the duly elected Prime Minister, Cheddi Jagan, and his ministers is outrageous and deplorable.

Tenants of many faiths who live in the Apthorp Apartments, Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street, will go this morning to Calvary Cemetery to bury the Irish-American woman who took her brother's place during World War I as elevator operator and stayed on the job for thirty-five years without a complaint.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- The United States would be willing to open the Korean peace conference to neutral participation if the talks produced solid progress toward a settlement of Korea's future.

Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, said last night that the United Nations had accomplished more than was generally recognized. Its specialized agencies, he added, are engaged in "practical international cooperation on a scale without precedent in history."

MANILA, Oct. 14 -- Mounting reports of terrorism and attempts to deprive voters of their franchise through fraud are reaching the Commission on Elections here and finding their way into the metropolitan press.

ROME, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Pope Pius XII dedicated and blessed the new $3,500,000 Pontifical North American Ecclesiastical College here today. He said its completion "lights a stronger flame of hope for the church in the United States of America and in the world."
Excerpts from the decision of Judge Harold R. Medina, throwing the Government's anti-trust suit against seventeen investment banking houses out of court, follow:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson said tonight he was asking livestock and meat industry leaders for advice before he decided whether to place choice cattle under a direct price support program.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 14 -- Herman Melville's South Seas story, "Typee," is engaging the attention of rival independent producers. Oscar Dancigers and Henry Ehrlich scheduled the story today for production in February coincident with the announcement that United Artists had acquired world-wide distribution rights to their production of "Robinson Crusoe," starring Dan O'Herlihy, and filmed in Mexico both in English and Spanish language versions.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- A confident feeling radiated throughout the stock market today and was reflected in widespread gains. Investment demand, which was stimulated in late trading yesterday, was fairly persistent. Bargain hunters were interested in several recently depressed store groups. They were among the best performers today, along with textiles motor and other engineering issues.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- Decrees of the Ministries of Finance and Economic Affairs, announced today, sought to encourage trade between France and countries within the Soviet orbit by granting immunity from some taxes to goods destined for export beyond the Iron Curtain.

Advertising is fighting a losing battle against public distrust. The Advertising Federation of America gave this warning yesterday in announcing details of its new 1953-54 consumer campaign. Purpose of the drive (the fifth in eight years) is to educate the public concerning the values and services of advertising.

ROME, Oct. 14 -- The new Pontifical North American Ecclesiastical College have almost double the capacity of the old seminary. Aside from the faculty, it will house 307 students, but can readily be expanded to accommodate 359.

A court fight by Democrats to invalidate the petitions re-nominating Mayor Impellitteri as the candidate of the Experience party was put over yesterday until 10 A. M. tomorrow. State Supreme Court Justice Thomas A. Aurelio adjourned a hearing on a motion by supporters of Robert F. Wagner Jr., the Democratic nominee, after a conference in chambers.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- Britain called on the United Nations today to take a cue from her Government and take in a little advertising -- the dignified kind, of course.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UP) -- Fifteen universities have refused to sign contracts with the armed forces for service correspondence courses on the ground that a security clause would let the military establishment dictate the dismissal of professors, the Defense Department said today.
Los Angeles sold $20,000,000 of electric plant bonds at public bidding yesterday at a net interest cost of 2.6026 per cent.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 14 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury tossed a bombshell into Virginia's gubernatorial campaign today by indicting the state Democratic campaign manager. Sidney S. Kellam, on a charge of evading income taxes.

Mayor Impellitteri, seeking re-election as the candidate of the independent Experience party, made a shirt-sleeve appearance on television last night. He said New York's school system was the largest and finest in the world and that the problem of overcrowding in some buildings was well on the way to solution.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- More parents should learn to "cherish the differences in children" and accept the challenge to perfect special traits rather than stifle them, Miss Helen Ross, administrative director of the Institute for Psychoanalysis at Chicago, told 200 persons in the Scarsdale High School auditorium last night.

ALBANY, Oct. 14 (AP) -- An American Airlines pilot testified today that crowded skyways over Albany Airport caused him to give up trying to land here the day a sister ship crashed, killing all twenty-eight persons aboard.

The colorful diction with which Judge Medina seasoned his off-hand contributions to courtroom colloquies during the years of the investment banking trial was not lacking in his final voluminous opinion.

On Oct. 17, 1952, President Eisenhower in a speech in Newark, N. J., criticized the Democratic Administration for want of "leadership" in not enacting a "better law than this McCarran Act." He reminded the country that failure to expunge the national origins quota system from our statutes contravened fundamental American belief.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety- four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 7:

Officers of City College's senior class replaced nineteen college administrators yesterday as part of the annual Senior Day activities. Harry Pollak, president of the class, substituted for Dr. Buell G. Gallagher as president of the college.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines today issued a new Federal safety code for anthracite mines. The bureau said the code, which replaces safety standards formulated five years ago, was "designed to modernize the safety rules and practices in the anthracite industry.

ABSECON, N. J., Oct. 14 -- Mrs. Cuyler S. Patton of the Scarsdale (N. Y.) Club won the first half of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association post-season tournament today by scoring 50, 42 -- 92 at Seaview Country Club.

Vassily Smyslov, Russia, and Samuel Reshevsky, United States, met last night in the pivotal game of the world chess championship challengers' tournament at Zurich, contested forty-one moves of an English opening adopted by Smyslov and adjourned after a five-hour session in a position favorable to Smyslov.
Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, city Commissioner of Hospitals since 1949, has resigned his post to become dean of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

ALBANY, Calif., Oct. 14 (UP) -- Little Willie Shoemaker failed to score with his six mounts at Golden Gate Fields today to the bitter disappointment of 7,815 fans present who had hoped to see him break the world riding record.

The Estate Securities Company has contracted to purchase the six-story forty-eight-family apartment house at 144-03 Barclay Avenue in Flushing, Queens, from the Investors Funding Corporation. Sidney M. Seigel was the broker and the attorneys were Jacobs, Leibowitz Kahn for the buyer and Sam Heller for the seller.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 14 -- With startling suddenness the anti-Western protest demonstrations against the United States-British decision to turn Trieste over to Italy seemed to end this afternoon.
The Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York opened its annual drive yesterday for $285,000 to support its twelve residence and activity centers in Manhattan and the Bronx.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- On the ground that the United States would not consider now a five-power conference including Communist China, the French Cabinet agreed today to accept the priority allotted to the proposal for a four-power conference while hoping that a five-power meeting might follow a Korean peace conference.

A decline last week of 594,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 142,517,000 barrels, compared with 143,111,000 a week earlier and 120,910,000 a year ago.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- In a speech that seemed to presage increased denominational controversy in this country, the Most Rev. Geoffrey F. Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury and Anglican Primate of All England, charged the Roman Catholic Church today with intolerance and oppression.

Before the present week is out Secretary of Agriculture Benson will probably proclaim a referendum on the question of controlling cotton products next year. The law provides for such a referendum if total cotton supply is above "normal." In this case there is no possible room for discretion. The indicated "normal" supply for the coming year is about 16.4 million bales; the supply in prospect is well over 20 million bales.
A member of the Transit Authority offered yesterday the hope of a fare reduction from 15 cents to 12 within a year, but he attached a big "if."
The duo-pianists Vera Appleton and Michael Field played a recital at Town Hall last evening to celebrate the tenth anniversary of their debut in that hall as a two-piano team.
Efficiency may not be so efficient after all, a group of men who hire efficiency experts was told yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Dr. Samuel M. Brownell, brother of Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr., was named today Commissioner of Education in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 President Eisenhower signed an executive order today assigning to permanent Government agencies the remaining functions of agencies that dealt with price, wage and salary controls.

Sunlight streaming through the fifteenth-floor windows on two sides of the new studio just opened by Dorothy Liebes at 305 East Sixty-third Street catches the glint of metallic yarn in the half-finished fabrics on the hand looms.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Brazilian cruzeiro skidded 12 points today as the Government moved to put the nation on a pay-as-you-go basis.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 14 -- The kind, quantity and use made of outside assistance to needy countries of south and southeast Asia came in for critical discussion today by the Consultative Committee of the Colombo Plan.

Only drivers can fully appreciate the value of soon-to-be-installed "yield" signs that will replace twenty of this city's yellow, octagon-shaped "stop" markers on a trial basis. Motorists who have come upon a deserted intersection in early hours of the morning and coasted through the "stop" sign only to be summarily haled over to the curb for a violation will give full approval.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Dr. Gilbert H. Grosvenor, president of the National Geographic Society, received today from Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of the Navy, the Navy's highest civilian citation, the Distinguished Public Service Award.
TORONTO, Oct. 14 -- A United States criminological psychiatrist said here today that traditional prison punishment was a futile means of dealing with the increase of crime in the United States.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 14 -- Leaders of red-tinged People's Progressive party here have been rebuffed in their efforts to lay their case before the British Government in London. The whole situation here is thus forced into a period of waiting.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 14 -- Delayed messages from North Sumatra reported today that Moslem dissidents there had launched a strong attack in the Meureudoe area of Atjeh, sixty-two miles southeast of Kutaradja. After thirteen hours of heavy fighting, during which the rebel forces employed mortars and Bren guns, the Government units withdrew to the coast, the reports said.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, announced yesterday that he would ask for the resignations of all present members of the Board of Education, if he is elected, because the board is "riddled with politics" and because "the majority of the Board of Education doesn't know what it's all about."

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor, sent a telegram yesterday to David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., and a vice chairman of the Liberal party, calling for "repudiation" of Rudolph Halley, his Liberal party opponent.

David L. Cole, attorney from Paterson, N. J., and former director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, has been selected to arbitrate the dispute between the building material supply dealers in the metropolitan area and Local 282, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., the union announced yesterday.

Sales of leading chain stores and mail order companies showed an aggregate loss of 0.5 per cent in September compared with the corresponding month in 1952, according to a compilation of forty-five companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday and closed 1 point lower to 9 higher on the active months.

HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 14 -- The arrival here today of Gen. Henri-Eugene Navarre, French Commander in Indo-China, and Vietnam military chiefs was seen as marking an end of the calm in the fighting and the resumption of large-scale activities.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 14 -- James M. Roche, who was ousted as United States Marshal here today by order of President Eisenhower, described the move as "clearly a breach of contract." He received the order this afternoon following an announcement in Washington that Donald Fraser, a Republican, had been named to succeed him.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A George Washington University researcher said here today that manufacturers of penicillin for eight years had been pouring down the drain a by-product effective against cancer in the test tube.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 15 -- Despite a threat that force was about to be used against them, the bulk of 1,000 Chinese prisoners of the Korean war who do not wish repatriation refused today to move into an area where the long-delayed "explanation" talks by Communist lectures were to have begun.
Five more of the civilian employes at the Army's Fort Monmouth, N. J., radar laboratories interviewed recently by Senate investigators have been suspended by the Army for "Communist activities."
BALTIMORE, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Pin Oak Farm's Make a Play won the $10,000 added Marguerite Stakes at Pimlico today, driving to a three-quarter-length decision over Phil Godfrey's O'Alison.
The new A. P. Moller Company cargo ship Johannes Maersk will make her New York debut this morning fresh from Denmark where she was built.
EVERETT, Mass., Oct. 14 -- New England's first catalytic cracking plant, a 24,000-barrel unit, was dedicated by Governor Christian A. Herter today at the Esso Standard Oil Company refinery.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Peter Thorneycroft, President of the Board of Trade, said today that he believed there would be substantial trade between the East and the West if the "cold war" ended and the ban on the shipment of strategic materials to countries in the Soviet bloc were lifted.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- The United States, emphasizing that its "unavoidable" $50,000,000,000 arms budget was being forced by the Communist menace, made it clear today it could not contribute to any new international funds for economic development of less fortunate countries until there was a general disarmament.

The James Weldon Johnson Community Center will be the beneficiary of a preview of "The Man Between," starring James Mason, on the night of Nov. 3 in the auditorium of the Museum of Modern Art. The occasion will mark the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the center.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14 -- A group of patients suffering from muscular dystrophy, traditionally looked on as an inherited, crippling, hopeless disease, in which the muscles progressively waste away, was reported today to be responding satisfactorily to a new treatment at the School of Medicine of the University of California.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- A guarantee of peace in Europe by the United States, Britain and Canada is one of the proposals now under discussion here for assuaging Russian fears over the European Defense Community Treaty and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

On net sales of $65,507,099, which were 14.5 per cent above those of a year ago, the Diamond Alkali Company had a net income of $4,703,476 in the first nine months of this year. This was equal to $1.90 each on 2,263,803 common shares and compared with $3,795,362, or $1.50 a share, for the 1952 period, when sales were $57,169,091.

NEWARK, Oct. 14 -- The Rev. Dr. Lester H. Clee, president of the New Jersey Civil Service Commission, spent fifteen minutes on television this evening defending the action of Paul L. Troast, Republican nominee for Governor, in writing to Governor Dewey of New York on behalf of Joseph S. Fay, convicted extortioner and labor leader.

In his recent speech in Detroit Gen. Bedell Smith was reported to have said that the new budget put forward by the Malenkov regime shows an actual increase -- not decrease -- in all military expenditures over last year.

The Braz,ban o,,-el-nnltul]} Tl'adP' Bureau in New York reporlod rp-i eeipt of a statement in which Fi-, nance Minister Oswaldo AranhaI said that five import groups set[ up under the new exchange lawl Will be subject to constant changesI in line wih developments."

It is a wholesome fact that no boy or girl can be "sent" or "sentenced" to the George Junior Republic at Freeville, N. Y. Each must agree to enroll voluntarily. They arrive through parents, guardians, social-work agencies and probation officers, prepared to assume the full obligation of citizenship in the Republic.

A 63-year-old widow charged with obtaining $100,000 by stock fraud from more than fifty victims, including the pastor of her church, was enjoined yesterday from the further sale of securities in this state.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- There ought to be one day in the year when everybody has a word of understanding for the President of United States, and his birthday is as good a day as any.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- After a long delay the Austrian Academy has published a full account of the remains of an 80,000-year-old tribe of Ice Age mammoth hunters, or Aurignacian men, unearthed at Langmannersdorf near Sankt Poelten about thirty miles west of Vienna.

Ruggiero Ricci last night won the race to be the first violinist to perform Prokofieff's unaccompanied D major sonata in New York. By playing it as the fourth number of his Carnegie Hall recital, he nosed out his two major rivals, Szymon Goldberg and Joseph Szigeti.

ALBANY, Oct. 14 -- The State Civil Service Commission today threw a roadblock in the path of any person seeking appointment to any state job or promotion in the state service who has ever been a member of any of the thirty-five organizations listed as subversive by the United States Attorney General.

TRIESTE, Oct. 14 (AP) -- A band of 200 pro-Italian youths raided offices of the Yugoslav economic delegation here tonight, smashed windows and hurled out the furniture. They had been inflamed by Slovene rioting in behalf of President Tito of Yugoslavia.

Official circles in Florida are giving active consideration to the building of a toll expressway to run 103 miles between Hollywood and Fort Pierce, instead of the 313-mile road proposed to link Jacksonville and Miami and a ninety-five-mile connection between Stuart and Miami.

ATHENS, Oct. 14 -- Rumania has proposed restoration of "normal diplomatic relations" as well as a further development of commerce with Greece, the Greek Foreign Ministry announced today. Rumania and Greece have not been on diplomatic speaking terms since before World War II.

The 1953 Audio Fair opened yesterday morning at the New Yorker Hotel, concurrently with the fifth annual convention of the Audio Engineering Society, founders and original sponsors of the Audio Fair. The fair is devoted to the exhibition of sound reproducing equipment.
Federal Judge Harold R. Medina is convinced that the prevailing practice of marketing securities at a fixed public offering price does not violate the anti-trust laws.

There was an ovation at the Jamaica race track yesterday that turned back the calendar. When Tom White's Miss Weesie won the seventh race, an ordinary six-furlong event, by a half-length from the favored Will Be There, the crowd of 18,184 let out a roar that was most moving in its genuineness.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Gen. Carlos Ibanez del Campo, President of Chile, swore in today a new Cabinet that contained none of the Popular Socialists who had held posts in the old Government.
TORONTO, Oct. 14 -- Ontario's 15,000 pulp and paper workers will take a strike vote Sunday and the eleven unions involved are gloomy over prospects for avoiding a walkout.

Any attempt to re-establish currency convertibility on a limited basis that would not permit free transfer of capital and dividends is foredoomed to failure, according to Belgian banker Fernand Collin.

YONKERS, Oct. 14 -- A bottleneck caused by reconstruction of the Cross County Parkway at Fleetwood in East Yonkers will be eliminated in a month, but two more bottlenecks in the same general area will develop to hinder traffic on the parkway for many months, George S. Haight, superintendent of the Westchester County Parkway System, said this evening after an inspection tour.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- A Senate Armed Services subcommittee reported to President Eisenhower today that the "imbalance in world power" created by the demobilization of Germany and Japan was "being corrected."

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Secretary of the Air Force Harold E. Talbott warned last night that additional cutbacks in American air power would "invite disaster." He said that at present, though the United States appeared to be "vulnerable" to Soviet air attack, such an assault would be "suicidal."

Mass X-ray surveys are inadequate as a solution to the tuberculosis problem, a pathologist told the annual meeting of the Association of Life Insurance Medical Directors yesterday at the Statler Hotel.

The office of the American Association for the United Nations has numerous requests for information as to whether or not the letter of Michael Francis Doyle of Philadelphia on the question of the internationalization of Jerusalem represented the views of the association.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 14 -- The film "The Moon Is Blue" was seized here today by the police and the manager of the theatre that had placed the picture on exhibition was arrested on charges of violating city and state ordinances banning possession of obscene films.

" Hansel and Gretel"? Is the City Center serious? Indeed, it was last night when it put on its new production of this little masterpiece. It was serious without being stuffy. It provided a fairy-tale conception of the fairy-tale opera, and the grownups who made up the bulk of the audience seemed to be thoroughly disarmed.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- The General Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee approved today the largest single item of its 1954 budget -- $9,399,700 for conference and general services. Approval came after a number of delegations had raised questions concerning the present travel arrangements of the United Nations.

All major candidates for Mayor, except Mayor Impellitteri, agreed yesterday in replies to a questionnaire from seven civic groups that city personnel policies were in need of improvement but disagreed, in some respects, as to the remedy.
Two new issues of public utility bonds totaling $18,000,000 were bought by banking syndicates at public bidding yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- The General Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee approved today the largest single item of its 1954 budget -- $9,399,700 for conference and general services. Approval came after a number of delegations had raised questions concerning the present travel arrangements of the United Nations.

All major candidates for Mayor, except Mayor Impellitteri, agreed yesterday in replies to a questionnaire from seven civic groups that city personnel policies were in need of improvement but disagreed, in some respects, as to the remedy.
Two new issues of public utility bonds totaling $18,000,000 were bought by banking syndicates at public bidding yesterday.

Leg of lamb is selling at the lowest price since February, 1950, the Consumers' Service Bureau of the City Department of Markets reported yesterday. The most general price for this cut is 65 cents a pound, 4 cents lower than last week and 14 cents below the price at this time last year.

An increase of 17.2 per cent in sales to a record $190,708,540 for the first nine months of this year enabled the National Cash Register Company to better its earnings over the same 1952 period by 13.6 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- A spokesman for the Social Democratic party in West Germany said today the creation of the European Defense Community would bar the unification of his country.
Motorists have been advised to watch for a huge ship propeller that will be navigating the highways between Staten Island and Qnincy, Mass, next week.

The emphasis is on designs of the past in Bergdorf-Goodman's new and large collection of furnishings, which is composed of antique furniture and objects d'art together with a group of contemporary accessories in which the influences of past styles also are evident.
TRENTON, Oct. 15 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll mildly rebuked Paul L. Troast here today for writing to Governor Dewey of New York on behalf of Joseph S. Fay, convicted extortionist and labor leader.
The seventy-fifth anniversary of the General Electric Company turned into a howling success yesterday as the company prepared to add at least ninety-four newborn stockholders to its rolls.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Dr. Joseph S. Davis, director emeritus of the Food Research Institute of Stanford University, was named today economic adviser to the Commission on Foreign Economic Policy.

Making the most of the advantage gained in the first session of the twenty-fifth round of the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich, Vassily Smyslov of Russia defeated Samuel Reshevsky, United States, in fifty-six moves last night, according to a Swiss news report.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 15 -- Princeton will have a new look when it takes the field against Navy in Palmer Stadium Saturday. The Christian Dior influence has nothing to do with it. It is a matter not of raising hemlines but the elevation of replacements to a starting job on the varsity.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday and the close for active months was 13 points up to 1 point off.

John Patrick has turned some portentous ideas into a delightful comedy in "The Teahouse of the August Moon," which opened at the Martin Beck last evening. This is the story of the American occupation in Okinawa that was told originally in a novel by Vern Sneider.

A ruling of the Florida State Supreme Court has cleared the way for the sale next month of $15,000,000 of bonds by the State Board of Education in behalf of needy counties. The proposed issue is the first of a total of $100,000,000 authorized by a 1952 constitutional amendment to be sold over ten years for school construction.
Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat of Iowa, has endorsed the country-wide fight of the National Retail Dry Goods Association against a national sales tax.
That century old ideas handled with a fresh approach can make news was apparent in two shows this week devoted to period furnishings for the home.

NOW that we have ended another session of entreating, cajoling, begging, exhorting and urging citizens of New York City to register so that they may vote, something new -- outright threatening -- is added to the perennial civic comedy. Says THE TIMES of Oct. 12: "Mayor Impellitteri said yesterday it was unfortunate that nothing in the law provided penalties for those who fail to vote."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday amounted to 804,070 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 8,484 cars or 1 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 38,727 cars or 4.6 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 64,613 cars or 7.4 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Sir Winston Churchill, who won the 1953 Nobel prize for literature yesterday, has long been recognized as a master of oratory and literary style as well as a great statesman. He has had a brilliant career as an author since 1898, when his first book was published.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, yesterday accused Robert F. Wagner Jr., his Democratic rival, of "gross negligence and inaction" in the enforcement of housing laws when Mr. Wagner was city Housing Commissioner.

FORT WORTH, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias ousted Betty Dodd from the second round of the women's Texas open golf championship today, 3 and 2, then played the final two holes "just for practice."

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- The American Farm Bureau Federation asserted today that direct Government price supports on cattle would prove impractical and unworkable if adopted. Such controls would be subject to the same "dismal failure" that marked the application of direct price controls to hogs in World War II, the organization said.

The conservation record of the Roosevelt-Truman Administration was, contrary to general opinion, one of the worst in the recent history of our country. Despite much lip service, they actually subsidized soil erosion. The price supports of wheat and other crops induced farmers to plant millions of acres that should be in grass or forest.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky told the United Nations Security Council today that the Soviet Union would never countenance a settlement of the Trieste question reached without Soviet participation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UP) -- A "risk" insurance program for American farm crops stored overseas may get under way "within two or three weeks," the Department of Agriculture reported today.

The Transit Authority agreed unanimously yesterday on a fifth member to succeed Eugene F. Moran, who has submitted his resignation, but the agency refused to identify him until the appointment is accepted.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Senator George W. Malone, Republican of Nevada, said today that 77 per cent of the value of all Government stockpile materials now in this country was purchased abroad.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 15 -- There are two important aspects to the present mood of the Yugoslavs who have demonstrated against the United States-British decision to turn Trieste over to Italy.

Judicial candidates of the Republican, Democratic and Liberal parties for vacancies in the First District, consisting of Manhattan and the Bronx, and for vacancies in Manhattan alone, were rated as qualified, without exception, in a report of the New York County Lawyers Association yesterday.

Tri-Continental Corporation continued as one of the country's largest closed-end investment companies with gross assets of $170,455,884 on Sept. 30, according to the company's third-quarter report released yesterday. This compares with gross assets of $171,423,105 three months ago and $177,029,786 following its merger with the Capital Administration Company, Ltd., on April 8 of this year.

The Moscow Government, in its protest note to the United States and Great Britain on the Trieste matter, said that the status of the Territory of Trieste "guarantees democratic rights and basic freedoms of the populations."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The top organization of the Navy, the policy-making superstructure that has remained unaltered in any major respect since the beginning of World War II, was headed today for overhaul in the administrative shipyard.

INDIAN VILLAGE, Korea, Oct. 15 -- Many of the 490 Chinese prisoners who refused to be swayed by the Communists on the first day of the persuasion process showed hate and contempt for their former leaders. They made their hate plain in both words and actions when they went into the explanation tents today.
THERE have been periodic pieces through the years about the last of New York's Troubadours, urban version of the wandering minstrel. All these have been premature.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15 -- The Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., that covers deck crews for almost all Pacific Coast shipping, adopted a resolution today calling for "a policy of mutual cooperation between all bona fide non-Communist A. F. L. and C. I. O. unions in the seamen's field."

The Police Department is to be commended on its success in averting a repetition of last Monday's violence on the Brooklyn waterfront when followers of Anthony Anastasia (a Joseph P. Ryan supporter) fought to prevent rival A. F. L. longshoremen from working a pier.
Governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to submit to the members a plan for an 18 per cent increase in commissions. If adopted, the plan will take effect on Nov. 9.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 15 -- In the darkened Stanley Theatre, which has 4,200 seats, eighteen persons gathered tonight to watch a private and unscheduled showing of the photoplay "The Moon Is Blue," banned yesterday as "indecent and obscene" by Bernard J. Berry, municipal public safety director.

A gift to the Greater New York Fund is a recognition of the individual citizen's responsibility to his fellowmen. Sixteen years ago the Fund was organized to serve as a practical means for most business men to do their share toward meeting the hospital, health and welfare needs of the city.

The performance of "The Teahouse of the August Moon" on the night of Oct. 27 at the Martin Beck Theatre has been taken over to raise funds for the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y. Mrs. Henry C. Flower Jr. and Mrs. Lucius D. Clay are co-chairmen of the women's committee aiding in the sale of tickets.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan, the ousted Prime Minister of British Guiana, said today that he had sent a cablegram to India's Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, appealing for help in his fight with the British.

Following are the text of an address by President Eisenhower last night at Kansas City at the convention of the Future Farmers of America as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES and excerpts from an earlier address at Defiance College in Ohio as reported by The Associated Press:
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Oct. 15 -- A determination to stamp out communism in Ceylon was announced tonight by Sir John Kotelawala, new Ceylonese Prime Minister, in his first broadcast to the nation. He said:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- During the week ended Oct. 14, member bank reserves increased $254,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

YONKERS, Oct. 15 -- Pronto Don, the big 8-year-old chestnut gelding from the Hayes Fair Acres Stable of DuQuoin, Ill., driven by Bernard Schue, led a ten-horse parade to the wire tonight in the fourth annual mile-and-a-half $25,000 Gotham Trot.

Although somewhat illogical, the present system whereby the advertising agency is paid by the media seller rather than the client is still the most practicable. This is the belief of a majority of sales executives recently polled by Sales Management magazine on advantages of the current system over new plans being offered.
Dr. William E. Shoupp has been appointed assistant division manager in charge of development of the atomic power division of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Pittsburgh.

RICHLAND, Wash., Oct. 15 (AP) -- First steps toward building a "gigantic" atomic reactor to run the Government's plutonium plant at the near-by Hanford works and still have power to spare were announced today by the General Electric Company.

It is with mixed feelings that we view the decision of Dr. Marcus D. Kogel to resign as Commissioner of Hospitals and to accept the deanship of the new Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 15 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies said today that he favored an early meeting of world leaders to see whether they could reach mutual understanding on atomic controls.
A Federal judge ordered yesterday that a three-man statutory court be convened Oct. 27 to rule on the constitutionality of a key section of the New York-New Jersey waterfront reform laws.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- The securities markets were in a restrained mood here today. While most prices moved up, the demand was lighter than yesterday's and increases were almost all limited to a few pence. The best spots were textile, shipping and electrical equipment issues.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Department store sales in the week ended Oct. 10 were 5 per cent below sales in the corresponding week last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

CLEVELAND, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Shipments of iron ore, coal and grain in Great Lakes vessels in September were the second highest on record, making the season's tonnage 10 per cent above the previous record.

An encouraging subscription has been reported for the performance of "Sherlock Holmes" on the night of Nov. 5 at the Century Theatre, which has been taken over to raise funds for St. Barnabas House. Mrs. Henry W. de Forest heads the benefit committee.
BERLIN, Oct. 15 -- The ranks of East Germany's two most important organizations are being "purified" in a parallel screening of their several million members.
TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 16 -- Only ten of the first 500 Chinese prisoners of the Korean war who met with Communist "persuaders" yesterday decided to return to Red China.

Gold ingots valued at $50,000 were stolen from a warehouse at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, between 2 and 6:35 A. M. yesterday. The thieves disdained taking a number of silver bars, which they scattered about the warehouse floor in their search for the gold.

Contemporary designs give a new look to some of the Ottavia embroidered curtains which, with a group of poles, tie-backs and other hardware for hanging them, are on view at Lord Taylor. Such embroidered fabrics, often combined with needle-work, have been a traditionally popular type of window dressing.
BERLIN, Oct. 15 -- West Berlin's Chamber of Deputies has set next Thursday as the date for its election of a successor to Mayor Ernst Reuter, who died Sept. 29.
Stock trading yesterday broke out of a lethargy that had lasted three weeks.

NO modern novelist pays less heed to current fashions in fiction or to current shibboleths in criticism than Sholem Asch. With massive dignity, with stubborn independence and with noble dedication to spiritual themes Mr. Asch goes his own way, industriously turning out pedestrianly written novels. But, although stiff and ponderous in their writing, his novels always are enriched by a transparent sincerity and a genuine vitality that command respect.
To a leisurely stroller in Central Park on the first really fine Sunday of the fall -- and at the same time the first of Indian Summer -- it seemed that the horse and buggy days had come back.

The explosive problem of Trieste is again before the Security Council of the United Nations, where Soviet Russia seeks to exploit it in favor of the Communist cause over the tacit objection of every other nation concerned, including Communist Yugoslavia. The Soviet Government accuses the United States and Britain of violating the Italian peace treaty and of maintaining a military and naval base -- from which, actually, they are anxious to withdraw.

The sixty-two-family apartment house at 2015 University Avenue in the Bronx, recently bought by Walter L. Rothschild, has been sold to an investing client of M. Wertheimer, lawyer, for cash above mortgages of $200,000. Robert E. Hill, Inc., were the brokers in the sale.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- A British rubber man said today that the proposed withdrawal of the United States Government from the synthetic rubber industry should not impair the competitive position of the natural commodity.

The Citizens Union gave strong endorsements yesterday to City Councilmen Stanley M. Isaacs and Earl Brown, Republican - Liberal and Democratic-Republican candidates, respectively, for re-election in the Twentieth and Twenty-first Manhattan Districts.

ABSECON, N. J., Oct. 15 -- Mrs. Cuyler S. Patton of the Scarsdale (N. Y.) Club, first-day leader with 92, duplicated the score at Seaview Country Club today to win the 36-hole low gross prize in the annual post-season tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association.

Negotiations for a new working agreement opened yesterday between Local 996, Lighter Captains Union of the International Longshoremen's Association, and the lighterage division of the Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York. The union's present contract expires the end of this month.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Form players at Garden State Park had to wait today until the seventh and feature event before their confidence was rewarded. W. H. Foales' consistent Just Sidney scored a front-running victory in the six-furlong race in 1:12 1/5 to return $4.40 for $2.

In another season it is pleasant to contemplate the day when windows can be thrown open once again to the soft, warm air of a new spring. In this season we now are in, after those windows -- air conditioned homes excepted -- have been open many weeks, it is no less pleasant to contemplate a time when the windows will be banged shut against autumn's chill and winter's cold.

MANILA, Oct. 15 -- President Elpidio Quirino, repeating charges his Nationalist political opponents were seeking American intervention in the Philippines elections called this "a treasonable act" tonight.

Success in "switch," or triangular, foreign trade deals depends primarily on having a "wanted" commodity not available in a country short of dollars or other currency essential to buying it in the usual way.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- President Eisenhower has sent Eric A. Johnston as his personal representative to the Arab states and Israel on a mission to relieve tensions and promote stability in the Middle East.
A four-alarm fire destroyed a block-long manufacturing plant at Arverne, Queens, in the Rockaways last night and damaged at least six near-by houses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UP) -- The Federal Government is spending $41,600 to remove that "log cabin" look from the East Wing lobby of the White House. No longer will guests arriving for social functions be obliged to scuff their black patents across a raw cement floor. Nor will their eyes be offended by hot-water pipes and electric ducts draped down the walls and across the ceiling.

It is peculiarly fitting that Winston Churchill's Nobel Prize should be an award, in the language of the citation. "For his historical and biographical presentations and for the scintillating oratory in which he has stood forth as a defender of eternal human value." Mr. Churchill might have preferred a Peace Prize, or he might not.
Consolidated net income of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its operating subsidiaries was $452,146,107 in the twelve months ended on Aug. 31, the company reported yesterday.

Shepard Traube, Broadway producer-director, cast a Long Island Rail Road conductor yesterday in a role only slightly less villainous than that of Jack Manningham, the murderous husband of "Angel Street," a play Mr. Traube produced on Broadway ten years ago.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 15 -- Navy Minister Renato Guillobel has declared a maritime strike called for today "outside the law" to disrupt public order. Their demands are for higher pay.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Yugoslavia's ruling Federal Executive Council unanimously approved today the stern measures President Tito has set in motion to block Italian rule over Zone A of Trieste.
Having lost successively to Princeton and Yale, Columbia hopes to atone for those football setbacks against the final of its Big Three rivals, Harvard, at Baker Field tomorrow.
VENICE, Italy, Oct. 15 -- A plan for moving 117,600 Europeans to new homes in the Western Hemisphere and Australia was approved today at the International Migration Conference here.

It will require one and a half to two and a half years of study for the American Cancer Society to answer conclusively the question of whether smoking does or does not have a role in the recent startling increase in deaths from lung cancer, it was reported here yesterday.

The New York Botanical Garden issued an invitation yesterday for visitors to see a sweet-scented, white-blossomed hawthorn tree whose legendary associations reach intimately into the story of Christ's death and resurrection.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The National Bureau of Standards is recognized and respected throughout the world, and its services are vital to the strength of the country, a committee of scientists said today.

The hall where Henry Ward Beecher gave lectures when he was minister of Plymouth Church, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, was dedicated last night in memory of Newell Dwight Hillis, second successor to Beecher.

The American Foundation for the Blind presented Migel medals yesterday to George L. Raverat, "for splendid services for the blind throughout the world," and to Harold T. Clark, "for pioneer work for the blind for fifty years."

Rudolph Halley, Liberal party candidate for Mayor, charged last night that the Department of Housing and Buildings was "honeycombed with laxity and corruption'' while his Democratic Mayoral opponent, Robert F. Wagner Jr., was its commissioner in the first administration of former Mayor William O'Dwyer.

ROME, Oct. 15 -- Premier Giuseppe Pella told the United States, Britain and France today that grave consequences in Italy's politics and her attitude toward international problems would follow any departure from the policy on Trieste announced Thursday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 15 -- Columbia Pictures has received permission to portray President Eisenhower on the screen in "The Long Gray Line," based on the autobiography of Sgt. Marty Maher, retired athletic director at West Point, as told in the book "Bringing Up the Brass."
ALBANY, Calif., Oct. 15 (UP) -- Wee Willie Shoemaker equaled a world riding record today when he booted home Haltafire in the feature at Golden Gate Fields for his 390th victory of the year.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct 15 (AP) -- Gil Turner, rapid-punching Philadelphia welterweight, gained his second victory in a week with a fifth-round technical knockout tonight over his outclassed fellow townsman, Johnny Bernardo. Turner weighed 152 1/2 pounds and Bernardo 155 for a scheduled ten-rounder at the Arena.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy indicated yesterday that Julius Rosenberg, executed spy, had set up a wartime espionage ring at the Army's Fort Monmouth, N. J., radar laboratories and he said that the spy ring "may still be in operation."
STOCKHOLM, Oct. 15 -- The award of the Nobel Prize to Sir Winston Churchill was announced today by the Swedish Academy.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 15 -- Britain has offered to lend a Royal Navy cruiser to Turkey provided the Turks agree to pay refitting and operating expenses for the vessel. It is understood the loan would be made on a long-term basis with an option for renewal if both countries wished.

A tract of forty-three acres in Eddystone, Pa., has been purchased by the Philadelphia Electric Company as the site for a generating plant. The Baldwin-Lima-Hamilton Corporation was the seller and Albert M. Greenfield Co. were the brokers. The parcel was sold for $575,000.
I was keenly interested in the comment by Fred C. White regarding the defeat of former President Hoover's recommendation early in 1932 for an excise tax on the end products of manufacture.
A showing combining the talents of seven of America's top fashion designers and one of France's great couturiers was presented by De Pinna yesterday at the Plaza Hotel.

An advance gifts luncheon attended by more than 300 leaders of industry was given yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by the Greater New York March of Dimes to herald the opening next month of the campaign in this city for $4,000,000 to support the program of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UP) -- United States companies and individual Americans controlled about 7,500 foreign business enterprises in 1950, worth $22,200,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 15 -President Eisenhower promised the nation's farmers tonight a solidly based agricultural program in the interest of the whole country.

In a move to meet the teacher shortage, the Board of Education yesterday raised the age limit for teacher candidates in the 1A-6B category from 35 years to 40. The new maximum will hold until June 30, 1955.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) - A Democrat and a Republican, each experienced in running Senate investigations, disagreed sharply today over the Eisenhower Administration's new plan to force balky witnesses to testify.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Morris Wolf of Philadelphia, former Deputy Attorney General of Pennsylvania, was sworn in today as general counsel of the Foreign Operations Administration. He was named to the post on Sept. 30. Air. Wolf is a member of the Republican Finance Committee in Pennsylvania.

The commercial introduction of color television within three or four months was foreseen yesterday after members of the Federal Communications Commission had witnessed color programs on thirteen different makes of sets at a demonstration in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BOSTON. Oct. 15 (UP) -- Toronto's hard-checking Maple Leafs, aided by some defensive blunders, beat the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 1, tonight to jump into a second-place tie with Detroit in the National Hockey League standing.
The Moreland Commission appointed by Governor Dewey began its investigation of the state's trotting tracks yesterday.

If the raisin may be said to have its day, then this is it. Consumption of the ancient food that nourished the "hungry and weary" in Biblical times rises from now to Thanksgiving and stays high until after Christmas. The fruit we now know to be a concentrated energy source is necessary to the raisin breads, pies, cakes and puddings of fall.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- In Amman, the Jordanian capital, where the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees has its regional headquarters, the names of 100 Palestinian Arabs have been stricken at their own request from the agency's ration lists. This is the first time an entire group has asked such action.
The worst fall drought since 1949, year of the great water shortage, has dried up wells and half emptied reservoirs in suburbs and rural areas around New York.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Sir Winston Churchill formally acknowledged today the award to him of the Nobel Prize for literature. The Prime Minister became the sixth Briton to receive the award for literature. Official announcement of the award was made today in Stockholm, but news of it had leaked out Tuesday.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Oct. 15 -- The Haverford School's unbeaten eleven has developed "tremendously" despite a late start in pre- season practice. Before putting his squad through a light drill today in preparation for tomorrow's traditional game with Penn Charter here, Coach Fred R. (Doc) Wallace said, "We have one of the best running games we've had at Haverford for a long while."

American shipbuilding yards cannot hope to compete with European yards, where costs still average 40 to 45 per cent less than in this country, Senator John M. Butler, acting chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on Maritime Subsidies, said yesterday.

That Charlie Dressen, who on Wednesday turned down a one-year renewal of his contract to manage the Dodgers, is irrevocably through as pilot of the Brooklyn club he guided to two straight National League pennants seemed definite yesterday.

THE upland game hunter will have plenty of opportunity during the week-end, for the pheasant season opens today in New York's northern zone and will open in Connecticut tomorrow, with conditions and prospects excellent.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 15 -- Dr. Norman Salit, president of the Synagogue Council of America, said in Bonn today that his discussions with Dr. Hermann Ehlers, President of the Bundestag, and with senior officials of the Adenauer Government had conveyed to him "the impression that the West German Government is thoroughly ashamed of the Nazi and anti-Semitic excesses of the past."
Junior high school students in New York State are to get more work in American history. And it will be taught in a different and, it is hoped by educators, a more exciting manner.

ROME, Oct. 15 -- For Mission Sunday, this week-end, Pope Pius XII addressed a message to missionaries throughout the world whom he described as "untiring workmen of the Gospel's progress and sometimes too, alas, sorrowful witnesses or glorious victims of most tragic trials."

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Sir Winston Churchill, British Prime Minister, outlined to John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, tonight his views on the possibility of achieving a conference with Georgi M. Malenkov, Soviet Premier.
In an apparent bid for the votes of city employes, Mayor Impellitteri moved yesterday to freeze into permanence $73,000,000 of cost-of-living bonuses granted to 110,000 of them since 1951.
KANSAS CITY, Oct. 15 -- An effort to provide an agricultural program far superior to that now in existence was promised the nation's farmers today by Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- A proposal for the creation of an international organization to finance the construction of low-cost housing on a world-wide scale was advanced today by Leon Jouhaux, a member of the French delegation here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Mrs. Oscar A. Ahlgren, president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, today announced a new home - school - community - church campaign aimed at the abatement of juvenile delinquency.

Again II, an Argentine-bred owned by John S. Kroese and ridden by Henry Moreno, was the winner of the Knight Errant, the classified handicap of a mile and a sixteenth that served as the feature attraction at the Jamaica racetrack yesterday.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 15 (Reuters) -- President Eisenhower believes the United States has "no better allies in the world" than the British Commonwealth, Vice President Richard M. Nixon declared here tonight.

Activity increased yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Potatoes registered the highest volume since May 21, cottonseed oil the greatest since Sept. 16 and cocoa the largest since Sept. 26. Prices closed generally higher, reflecting strength on the stock market.

The Daily News announced in this morning's issue its support of Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor; of his running mates, Paul A. Fino, candidate for Controller, and Henry J. Latham, candidate for Council President, and of most of the Republican candidates for other city offices.

Lulu Perez, 20-year-old Brooklyn featherweight, will go after his twenty-third straight victory tonight at St. Nicholas Arena when he squares off with 23-year-old Joey Cam of Boston in the feature bout of ten rounds. The New Englander, also taking a winning streak into the ring, will seek his eighth in a row and twenty-first triumph in twenty-six outings.

Apparently the days of "Guys and Dolls," the phenomenal musical at the Forty-sixth Street, are numbered. A notice has been posted on the theatre's backstage bulletin board, designating Nov. 28 for the departure. The principals of this troupe will be blended with the touring facsimile on Nov. 30 in Baltimore.

The program of the Philharmonic-Symphony's concert last night in Carnegie Hall was one of many sorts, curiously compounded. The program did not amalgamate; neither did the qualities of the performance. It is, however, a pleasure to relate that the orchestra was in first-class form and intonation, and that the orchestral performance made by far the best and most interesting part of the concert.
Loans to business by New York banks rose $14,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, advancing for the third successive weekly reporting period.
A FRENCH AIR BASE, Vietnam, Oct. 15 -- The French today launched their most powerful offensive in two years against the Communist-led Vietminh.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Political news took the center of the stage in grain pit operations here today. Reports that high-level Government price supports would likely be continued beyond 1954 stirred up the most bullish sentiment in a long time.

RABAT, French Morocco, Oct. 15 -- French authorities here accelerated the progress of their reform program this week with the cooperation of Sultan Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa and of the Maghzen (Central Moroccan Government).

The Commissioners of the Port of New York Authority have drawn up a special resolution in tribute to Inspector Cornelius F. Cahalane, who is retiring tomorrow as the authority's police consultant at the age of 78.

THE TIMES for Oct. 7, on page 31, has an article entitled "'Replaced' School Is Drafted by City." The article refers to the construction of new Public School 6, which was to replace old Public School 6 (and it was old when I was a first-grader nearly forty years ago).

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 15 -- Forty-two Jordanians were killed and sixteen injured last night while scores of buildings were blown up by a force of Israel's regular army that attacked three villages near the armistice lines with shells, grenades, automatic weapons, torpedoes and dynamite, according to findings of the Israel-Jordan Mixed Armistice Commission in Jerusalem today.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor, offered last night a plan that, he said, would provide housing at less than $45 a month for a three-and-a-half-room apartment and about $65 a month for four and a half rooms. He asserted that there was a shortage of housing for "middle income families" at rents they could afford.

MONTREAL, Oct. 15 (UP) -- Bernard (Boom Boom) Geoffrion and Jean Beliveau each scored twice tonight as the Montreal Canadiens gained undisputed possession of first place in the National Hockey League with a 6-1 victory over the New York Rangers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Until Congress at its next session takes up for disposal the plan sponsored by Senator Bricker to amend the treaty-making clause in the Constitution the conflict over his proposal will continue to be limited to publications by lawyers and by those few laymen who venture into intrude on the learned dispute.

ALBANY, Oct. 15 -- Senator Arthur H. Wicks will carry the issue of his fitness for the post of Majority Leader of the Legislature's upper house to the people on Sunday in a state-wide radio and television broadcast.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 15 (UP) -- Sydney S. Kellam, a Leader in Senator Harry F. Byrd's Virginia Democratic organization, resigned tonight as Democratic campaign director for the state. He said his indictment by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiracy and income tax evasion had been a political move.
Somewhere in the United States is an 18-month-old black and tan terrier that may become the object of a nation-wide dog hunt unless it hies home to Indiana.

Fordham's football team returns to the Polo Grounds tonight after a two-year absence. The Rams will oppose Boston College in what shapes up as a close and interesting battle between these long-time rivals. Kick-off time is 8:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- A Senate subcommittee charged today that Communists and their sympathizers, in addition to infiltrating the executive agencies, had held key posts on the staffs of Congressional investigating panels.

The Colombian subsidiaries of the South American Gold and Platinum Company are now permitted by that country to sell their gold production in the free markets of the world at the best prices that can be obtained, N. C. Marshall, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Three loans, totaling $40,200,000, were authorized today by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development for the expansion of privately owned electric power facilities in Japan.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- A plea for wider recognition of the rights of retarded children was made today by Ray Graham, assistant superintendent of public instruction for Illinois, and director of education of exceptional children.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- Lal Shah Bokhari of Pakistan suggested today that member nations of the United Nations turn over some of the Secretariat jobs allotted to them to representatives from the non-self-governing territories.

An increase in the net income of the Gillette Company to $13,700,171 in the first nine months of this year from $10,627,315 in the 1952 period enabled directors to declare an extra dividend of 75 cents yesterday.
Unidentified cars used by the New York State Police in patrolling highways were described by experts yesterday as a menace to motorists.
VANCOUVER, Oct. 15 (AP) -- A simple plaque, marked "Burnaby Terminal," was unveiled today on completion of the $93,000,000 Trans Mountain Oil pipe line from Edmonton to Vancouver.

TORONTO, Oct. 15 -- Juvenile courts in most parts of the United States are still detaining delinquent children in jails and police lock-ups a few hours to several months, according to a report submitted today at the eighty-third annual Congress of Correction.

NOW is the time for all good men to come to the aid of their party. That sentence normally is a typewriter exercise to make fingers more agile. But it has particular pertinence on the gridiron for the next twenty-four hours or so, especially at the Polo Grounds.

VIENNA, Oct. 15 -- Fear of Germany and criticism of the United States seemed today to be themes of the congress of the Communist- controlled World Federation of Trade Unions, which has been meeting in Vienna this week.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- Delegates of Pakistan and Lebanon urged Western policy makers today to recognize North African independence movements as a political reality.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 15 -- The largest mass sedition trial in the history of the Turkish Republic opened in Istanbul military tribunal today when 167 alleged Communist party members were formally charged with having conspired with the Soviet Union against the legitimate Government of this country.
For the first time since 1948, Soviet bloc delegates showed up last night at a Yugoslav reception for United Nations diplomats.
New issues of public utility mortgage bonds totaling $18,000,000 will be placed on the market today. The offerings are as follows:
The Port of New York Authority will offer for sale on Oct. 27 $20,000,000 of second series bonds due in 1984.

We regret deeply the injection of the issue of alleged American meddling into the hotly contested Philippine political campaign. In so far as this is susceptible of being distorted into any form of anti-Americanism it can betray the real feelings of the candidates and the people to whom they appeal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The appointment of a Republican woman to succeed Miss Frieda Miller, for nine years director of the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor, is regarded here as nearing final announcement.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 16 (AP) Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, said today "communism has established a strong beachhead in Guatemala" and has taken root to a "considerable extent" elsewhere in Latin America.

The four-story apartment house accommodating thirty-nine families at 640-650 East Second Street in Brooklyn has been sold by Alice Listernick to Meyer Lauber. The Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company insured title to the property, which is assessed at $127,000. It occupies a plot 100 by 125 feet and was sold for cash above mortgages of $97,689.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 16 -- A reply to the suggestions that Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, made yesterday for amendments in the proposed Allied note to Moscow was believed tonight to be on its way here from London where the Western Big Three foreign ministers have been in session.

An off-duty detective captured a masked gunman yesterday after a pistol duel that had caused panic among seventeen employes of a Brooklyn loan office and startled crowds in the downtown section of Brooklyn. The gunman, who was shot in the left forearm, was captured in a subway station.

Two undefeated school football teams, Evander and Stuyvesant, clash at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, today. Each has two victories, but Evander's triumphs, over Mount St. Michael and Taft, were more impressive.

An "important" employe at the Army's Fort Monmouth, N. J., radar laboratories, a close friend of Julius Rosenberg, executed atom spy, broke down yesterday and agreed to tell all he knew about espionage rings.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 16 -- Subtle differences rather than superficial similarities are significant in six modern houses that will be open for public inspection here Sunday. The occasion, the third of its kind in this community, is a modern house tour conducted for the benefit of the New Canaan Community Nursery School.

The recess appointment of Gov. Earl Warren as Chief Justice and his immediate assumption of the duties of the office raise some question as to the advisability and desirability of recess appointment to such high judicial posts.

TRENTON, Oct. 16 -- The Senate subcommittee set up to study the problems and expense of juvenile delinquency in the United States will not be able to achieve its goal with its present appropriation of $44,000, its chairman, Robert C. Hendrickson. senior Senator from New Jersey, declared here today.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 16 -- Denying an application for an injunction sought by operators of the Stanley Theatre, here, to prevent police officials from interfering with the showing of the motion picture, "The Moon Is Blue," Superior Court Judge Thomas J. Stanton ruled today that the police had acted within their rights in seizing the film.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday that Robert F. Wagner Jr., his Democratic rival, had an anti-labor record as a member of the State Assembly. He asserted also that Mr. Wagner had voted against bills aimed at curbing racial discrimination and Communist activities.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Export controls on all grades of iron and steel scrap were relaxed today by the Bureau of Foreign Commerce of the Department of Commerce.

The Virginia State Ports Authority has under study a comprehensive report by a top consulting engineering concern designed to attract a more equitable share of world trade and industry for Old Dominion ports.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday to 110.1 (1947-49=100), according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The Plain View Methodist Church, situated on Old Country Road, near Hicksville, L. I., which was closed eighteen years ago, will reopen tomorrow. The closing came about because of population shifts and the reopening has been made possible for the same reason.

Baked Alaska is the traditional dessert for the annual dinner of the trustees of Finch College. They dined last night. Each year, at the request of the trustees, the dish is prepared by the school's pastry chef, Karl Majer. He learned to make it even before he joined the staff of Finch twenty-eight years ago.
Interunion rivalry prevented the unloading of a freighter in Brooklyn yesterday and forced her removal to Port Newark last night.

Boston College spoiled Fordham's return to the Polo Grounds by scoring a touchdown in each of the first three periods, then holding fast against the Rams' last-quarter rally to gain a 20-13 victory last night.
ALBANY, Calif., Oct. 16 (UP) -Wee Willie Shoemaker rode two winners at Golden Gate Fields today to set a world record of 392 victories in a season.

TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 17 -- The Communists, seeking to convince their former personnel that they should go home, were obliged to meet today with more Chinese prisoners of the Korean war. The development followed refusal of North Korean captives yesterday to appear before the Red "persuaders."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 16 -- Yale University observed today the 250th anniversary of the birth of one of her sons, Jonathan Edwards. The program ended with a dinner in Jonathan Edwards College, one of the ten undergraduate residential colleges at Yale, which was named after the noted colonial minister who was graduated from Yale at the age of 17 with the class of 1720.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- What appeared to be a rejection of the French union by the Vietnamese caused disquiet here today, but this was lessened when it was learned that they had made their demands much less categorical.

Charlie (Chuck) Dressen, with no malice or bitterness toward anyone in Brooklyn," agreed yesterday to manage the Oakland club of the Pacific Coast League for an indeterminate period and at an undisclosed salary. The erstwhile pilot of the Dodgers also will purchase stock in the minor league organization. "It's a real deal," Dressen said. "I'll make more money at Oakland than I did with the Dodgers."
Futures were slightly easier on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and closing prices on the active months were unchanged to 8 points off.
The fifteen-round middleweight championship boxing bout between Randy Turpin and Bobo Olson, in Madison Square Garden, will be broadcast over C. B. S. radio on Wednesday at 10 P. M.

WITH increased numbers of black ducks, mallards and teal reported on many upstate marshes and waterways, the opening of the New York waterfowl season beginning at noon today (Long Island excepted) should provide plenty of activity for wildfowlers.

Untold numbers of homeless and destitute Koreans will be able to face the coming winter's cold because of the generosity of thousands of Americans Recently the 8,500,000th pound of relief cloth ing donated this year to American Relief for Korea was sent to the war-torn peninsula.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 16 -- Slum clearance programs with Federal aid were endorsed here today by Albert M. Cole, the Eisenhower Administration's top housing official.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 16 -- South Africa intends to abolish discrimination against the import of goods from the dollar area at the beginning of next year so that importers can buy goods from whichever market is cheapest.

As far back as the Democratic nominee for Mayor can remember, he wanted to go into politics and emulate the career of his distinguished father, Robert F. Wagner Sr., who served in the United States Senate for twenty-two years, from 1927 to 1949.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 16 -- Hudson County Republicans rewrote tonight their ticket for the Nov. 3 elections after the New Jersey Supreme Court had barred them from placing dissident Democrats on the slate.

Among the recently operated art exhibitions there is one, at the Arthur Newton Gallery, that is quite out of the ordinary. In it is a group of tapestries made by the Edinburgh Tapestry Company, the only-one of its kind in the British Isles, which is reviving an old art that already has been taken up in France.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 16 -- First-place prizes for general excellence among New Jersey daily newspapers with a circulation of more than 40,000 were awarded today to The Newark Evening News and The Newark Sunday News at the thirty-second annual Better Newspaper Institute held by the New Jersey Press Association at Rutgers University.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Saturday, Oct. 17 -- Anti-Red Chinese prisoners of war angrily screamed and yelled obscene oaths at Communist explainers today when the Reds, after a six-hour delay, began attempts to coax the P. O. W.'s back to Communist domination.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (UP) -- The world welterweight champion, Kid Gavilan of Cuba, will defend his title against Chicago's Johnny Bratton in the Chicago Stadium on Nov. 13, James D. Norris, International Boxing Club president, said today.

A banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., is offering to investors $8,000,000 of 4 per cent first mortgage bonds of Mountain States Power Company due in 1983 at 101.58 to yield 3.91 per cent.
CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- The President's speech on the farm situation at Kansas City last night was not explicit enough to stimulate buying of grain futures, and prices sagged.

Duke, undefeated and seldom scored on, engages a rejuvenated Army team in New York City's only major intersectional college game of the football season at the Polo Grounds today. The contest will get under way at 2 P. M.

It appears as if the town has a bright, new hit in "The Teahouse of the August Moon," the John Patrick adaptation of Vern Sneider's novel that opened at the Martin Beck Theatre on Thursday night. For the first time this season all of the local drama appraisers (there are eight) were of the same mind in heaping praise after praise on the newcomer.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 (AP) -Detroit University's line blunted Villanova's offensive and let its backfield run wild tonight as the Titans routed the Wildcats, 27 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Representatives of power producing companies urged the Federal Power Commission today to reject a proposed accounting revision which they said would conflict with procedures of twenty-one states.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (UP) -- A confidence man with sixty-seven aliases and a six-page police record admitted today he had sent expensive gifts to President and Mrs. Eisenhower and other Washington figures as a device for cashing phony checks.
AUSTIN, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Texas Railroad Commission today ordered a cut of 140,531 barrels a day in the allowable output of oil for November.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption in September averaged 36,022 bales for each working day. This compared with an average of 36,292 for August and 37,798 bales for the corresponding period a year ago. The daily average consumption of linters was 4,547 bales, compared with 4,437 for August and 3,444 a year ago.
The West Point corps of 2,400 cadets passes in review at the Polo Ground today and two battalions of midshipmen parade in Princeton's Palmer Stadium in two of football's big games of the day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The highest-ranking British and United States officials dealing with atomic energy concluded today a series of exploratory conferences concerning the extent to which each Government might like to resume the wartime partnership in atomic development if the American law were liberalized.

President Eisenhower in his Kansas City speech displayed a sympathetic understanding of the farmer's problems, but in discussing his Administration's program deliberately refrained from setting it forth in concrete terms.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 12 -- Argentine sheep ranchers on Tierra del Fuego are preparing to fight a mass invasion that threatens their livelihood. According to spokesmen for the ranchers on the "Land of Fire," the most southerly major inhabited island in the world, millions of rabbits are eating their way from the Chilean sector to greener ranges in the Argentine territory, leaving a wake of denuded pastureland.
The following are new products that may be of interest to homemakers:
Anybody seen a stray gondola? A full-size, seaworthy, genuine Venetian craft has been lost somewhere on the roads between Brooklyn and Cincinnati, sometime since Oct. 7.

A prediction that the basic hourly wage for workers on the city-owned transit lines would rise at the end of the year from $1.86 to $2 was made yesterday by Justice Walter R. Hart of the Brooklyn Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- A doorbell for dogs is one of the 768 inventions patented this week. The inventor, Fred M. Adams of Shreveport, La., who calls it an "animal alarm scratching device," has combined a board on which the dog can sharpen its claws with a bell to alert the household.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The threat of an allegedly Communist-inspired maritime strike faded in Brazil today after the arrest of six strike leaders and last-minute conciliatory moves by President Getulio Vargas.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- India reopened today her campaign to stop alleged persecution of the Indian-Pakistani minority in the Union of South Africa. South Africa immediately made it clear that she still was of the opinion the question was a domestic one and none of the United Nations' business.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Thomas A. Burke, the Ohio Democrat appointed Monday to the Senate seat made vacant by the death of Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, paid a visit to Washington today. He came primarily as the Mayor of Cleveland, to seek Government assistance in the financing of a new transit system for his city.

BERLIN, Oct. 16 -- The East German Government completed today its seizure of farms. Western observers estimated that almost 5 per cent of the arable land in that region had been taken over in this new action.
