Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday that one of the men who tried to get Joseph S. Fay out of Sing Sing was one of Governor Dewey's "closest political associates on the national scene." He called upon the Governor to deny it.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16 -The creation of a code of fair practices to encourage private investments in underdeveloped countries is being considered by several delegates here. It is thought of as an effective means of helping to raise standards of living.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Glenn McCarthy, Inc., Houston, Tex., has notified the Securities and Exchange Commission it proposes to sell 10,000,000 shares of stock at $2 each.
DUBLIN, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Irish Turf Club stewards are expected to meet tomorrow to discuss the banning from English tracks of horses trained by Paddy Prendergast.

THE best of all reasons for preserving the stately homes of England is to give Ivy Compton-Burnett's characters a place to live and speak the champagne-dry dialogue she writes for them. They need nothing particularly lavish. A seedily patrician drawing room that was once part of an abbey will do for the lord of the manor, his wife (or wives) and a posse of loquacious relatives.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, said today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had committed no election law fraud in handling his campaign finances.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 16 -- City Commissioner Donald Spence, director of the city's Department of Revenue and Finance and president of the Hudson County Park Commission, was named today in two conspiracy indictments that were handed up by the September term of the Hudson County Grand Jury.

Varied views on the best solution of the city's financial problems have been expressed by mayoral candidates in reply to a questionnaire sent to them by seven cooperating civic groups. All of the candidates except Mayor Impellitteri submitted answers to the questions.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- Pennsylvania and Ohio State, two teams who hope to rebound from stunning defeats last week, clash tomorrow at Franklin Field in their first meeting in twenty years.

A filly-and-mare race for a purse of $10,000 was the top event at the Jamaica track yesterday, and first money of $6,500 was won by Mrs. John W. Hanes' Devilkin, trained by Max Hirsch and ridden by Bill Boland. The 4-year-old filly was the 16-to-5 third choice in a six-horse line-up.

SYDNEY, Australia, Saturday, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Two Australian labor leaders spearheading a fight to drive Communists from trade unions told Vice President Richard M. Nixon yesterday the United States must not appease Russia. Mr. Nixon flew here Thursday from New Zealand.

TRENTON, Oct. 16 -- The campaign for Governor continued in high gear today. Paul L. Troast, the Republican nominee, toured Bergen County, and Robert B. Meyner, the Democratic candidate, swung through Morris.

The concert of Canadian music conducted by Leopold Stokowski and a picked orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, sponsored by Broadcast Music, Inc., of this city and its Canadian affiliate, might have appeared as an event of special political and diplomatic significance, so far as externals were concerned.
Objection to the borrowing of money outside the city's debt limit to pay for transit improvements other than the proposed Second Avenue subway were heard yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
The American Tobacco Company, which makes Lucky Strike and Pall Mall cigarettes, is planning a merger with its subsidiary, the American Cigarette and Cigar Company, which markets Pall Malls.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 16 -- The decision to announce de facto partition of the Free Territory of Trieste by granting Italy control of Zone A was bound to touch off some protests. But a good many diplomats apparently thought there would be more protests from Rome than from Belgrade.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- Delegates who have been taking an active role in the Morocco debate at the United Nations will attempt over the week-end to work out a resolution that might command a two-thirds majority.
LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Prices tended to improve in nearly all parts of the stock markets here today.

GREENSBURG, Pa., Oct. 16 (AP) -- A few hours after the police said he had written a statement implicating himself in the slaying of two sleeping truck drivers on the Pennsylvania Turnpike, John Wesley Wable pleaded innocent tonight to murder charges.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France agreed tonight to put the Israel-Jordan border incident before the Security Council of the United Nations, it was learned authoritatively.
Discovery of an error affecting the $1 denomination in the current series of United States stamps with portraits of Presidents was announced yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Porterhouse can achieve a racing championship that his immigrant father, Endeavourer II, never approached by winning the Pimlico Futurity tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- A Federal grand jury will be asked to determine whether Warren L. Stephenson, former Republican official, perjured himself when he told a House of Representatives subcommittee about his "four percenter" activities.
VENICE, Italy, Oct. 16 -- Brazil and Paraguay have offered substantially increased possibilities for the resettlement of European families from overcrowded parts of this continent.

If American industry will give its export market as much attention in periods of good domestic trade as it does when home trade falls off, it will go a long way in restoring the confidence of foreign buyers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Harvey O'Connor, who has written biographies of United States millionaires, was indicted on a contempt of Congress charge today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The United States was reminded today that its own post-war occupation policies in Japan were in part responsible for the obstacles to Japanese rearmament.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 16 -- Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan, recently dismissed Prime Minister of British Guiana, accused the United States today of an "imperialist" maneuver to keep him from going to London to present the case for his allegedly Communist-dominated People's Progressive party before British officials.

President Eisenhower's announcement of Eric A. Johnston's mission to the Near East comes at a moment when relations between the Israeli and their Arab neighbors are rapidly deteriorating. Dr. George J. Candreva, who has headed the Urdu service of the Voice of America since shortly after it was established in May, 1951, deplored yesterday "certain Congressional inquiries which made a political football of the 'Voice' and the United States Information program."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UP) -Dan A. Kimball, former Secretary of the Navy, was asked to leave a confidential State Department meeting on rubber matters two weeks ago.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 16 (AP) -- All seeded players advanced without the loss of a set today in the first round of the annual fall festival tennis tournament at the Greenbrier Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The question of whether Congress in passing the Federal Water Power Act of 1920 took away from the states the right to control the navigable streams for power development was argued in the Supreme Court today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- A balanced Federal budget in the 1956 fiscal year, beginning July 1, 1955, even if all $8,000,000,000 of scheduled tax cuts should take effect, was forecast today by Gerhard Colm, chief economist of the National Planning Association.

Supreme Court Justice William H. Munson, an upstate Republican, was designated yesterday, to begin hearings here on Monday morning on a motion to invalidate the petitions nominating Mayor Impellitteri as the Experience party candidate for Mayor.
Benjamin Horowitz and Samuel Wishnow, formerly with Allan S. Feldman Co. have organized the Wishnow Horowitz Real Estate Company and have opened offices at 9 West Burnside Avenue in the Bronx.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 16 -- The Swedish Academy of Literature's choice of Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill for this year's Nobel prize in literature has had a mixed reception among Sweden's literary reviewers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- An up-to-date immunization map of the inhabited world, believed to be the only one of its kind, has been drawn up here to expedite the inoculation of persons traveling overseas on United Nations business.

NOVARA, Italy, Oct. 16 (Reuters) -- The strange case of Maj. William V Holohan of the United States Office of Strategic Services, who was murdered in a behind-the-lines operation in Italy in World War II, will be aired in court here next Monday.
The city's water reserve is only twelve days better off, at the present consumption rate, than the supply of Oct. 16, 1949, the shortage year.

Dr. Alfred J. Kahn's report on the city's Children's Court is deserving of careful attention from everybody interested in child welfare and the future of New York. The growing political and economic strength of the non-Communist world is creating an opportunity for greater attention to the long-rage problems of improving international trade, Harold E. Stassen declared yesterday. The director of the Foreign Operations Administration spoke before 300 men at a Public Affairs Committee luncheon of the Union League Club, 38 East Thirty-seventh Street.
The Neptune Ball, a gala dinner dance, will be given on Nov. 3 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the United States Merchant Marine Memorial Fund.
Some people who plan to buy furniture after Dec. 1 may be able to get it at slightly lower prices.
Mayor Impellitteri, denounced as bunk last night the claims of his campaign rivals that crime had increased during his administration until now streets and parks were unsafe.

ALBANY, Oct. 16 -- Senator Arthur H. Wicks has appealed to all Republican county chairmen in the state to give their attention to the radio and television speech he will make from New York on Sunday in an effort to prove his continued fitness for legislative leadership.
VIENNA, Oct. 16 -- The Bucharest radio announced today a fourth Cabinet change in what is obviously a step-by-step reorganization of the Rumanian Government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (UP) -- Robert A. Hogg, an Idaho Power Company engineer, said today that both the Government and private individuals would continue to spend money on irrigation development in Idaho no matter who developed the Snake River.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 16 -- While the Yugoslavs continued to send reinforcements into Zone B of Trieste, commanders in the Zagreb military district were reported tonight to be preparing for additional movements if necessary.
MONTREAL, Oct. 16 (Canadian Press) -Representatives of owners of Canada's strikebound deep-sea ships said today they "see no immediate assistance coming in any form" from the Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Representative Charles J. Kersten, Republican of Wisconsin, said in a prepared statement today that after hearing representations of a Roman Catholic priest and a labor delegation he had interested himself in a parole hearing for Joseph S. Fay, labor leader who is serving a New York prison term for extortion.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Two Senators objected today to plans by the Air Force to build the last two of five bases in French Morocco.

A ring of jewel thieves that looted East Side apartments of more than $1,000,000 in jewels and furs this year -- gaining entrance merely by opening unlocked doors -- was believed smashed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Sales of Series E and H United States Savings Bonds slightly exceeded redemptions in the first nine months of this year, the Treasury announced today, even though substantial numbers of the bonds have reached maturity.

One of the stellar exhibits at the New York Antiques Fair, which appeared at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, on Thursday, was discovered only the night before, "hidden" away in a leading Fifth Avenue art gallery.

Smarting from defeats at the hands of Princeton and Yale, Columbia's football team returns to Baker Field today to engage Harvard's undefeated eleven. It will be Columbia's annual Alumni Homecoming Day. Entertainment and ceremonies will precede the kick-off at 2 P. M.

Average daily shipments of copper to domestic fabricators increased slightly last month and production of both primary and secondary crude copper edged higher. Producers' stocks of refined metal were off moderately.
HAVANA, Oct. 16 -- Cuban censorship will be lifted soon and there will be general elections for a President and Congress Nov. 1, 1954, President Fulgencio Batista said today.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Dr. Vincent Nardiello, New York State Athletic Commission physician, found Bobo Olson "more at ease" than Randy Turpin when he examined the American middleweight champion today prior to his fifteen-round world title fight with Turpin at Madison Square Garden next Wednesday night.

ABILENE, Kan., Oct. 16 -- The man from Abilene came back today, and Abilene did just what you'd expect a town to do for a local boy having his first home-coming as President of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Massachusetts Business Development Corporation of Boston applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to market 150,000 shares of $1 par value common stock.

A list of commodities which may now be imported into the Netherlands without an official license has been compiled by the Netherlands Chamber of Commerce in the United States. Numerous raw materials and a variety of manufacturing equipment and machinery are included.

For the first two hours of yesterday's session on the New York Stock Exchange prices and volume moved strongly upward, with steels, rails, motors, chemicals and oils showing outstanding strength.

Commutation fares would have to be raised 23 per cent and single fares 21 per cent to meet the wage increases sought by unions representing employes of the Long Island Rail Road, William Wyer, trustee of the bankrupt carrier, declared yesterday.

The twenty-fifth round in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich was completed yesterday when two adjourned games were played off, according to a Swiss news report.

Lumber production for the week ended Oct. 10 was 6.4 per cent below the like week last year according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were down 7.1 per cent and orders 8.1 per cent.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., Oct. 16 -- Mrs. Sally Francis of Apawamis posted a 42, 37 -- 79 at Vernon Hills today and Mrs. Donald O'Brien of Winged Foot scored a 38, 41 -- 79 to lead a field of forty-five in the Women's Tri-County Golf Association final one-day tournament of the season. Wolfe, associate Professor of English at Brooklyn College, under the supervision of a board of scholars from nine universities in three countries.

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct 17 -- Yale remained among the unbeaten teams today after a gallant squad of Cornellians held the Elis to a scoreless tie before a gathering of 25,000.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 17 -- Alabama drove once to the 13-yard line and again to the 6, but couldn't shake off an old jinx or a superb Tennessee defense today as the arch rivals of Dixie battled to a 0-0 draw before 40,000 fans and millions on television.
A would-be hold-up man was in the hands of the police last night because his intended victim happened to have been a wrestler in is youth.

Construction contract awards in the thirty-seven states east of the Rockies totaled $1,741,673,000 for September, according to figures compiled by the F. W. Dodge Corporation. This figure was 23 per cent above the previous month but 15 per cent below September, 1952.

Market letters from Wall Street firms continue to comment on the failure of stocks to respond to the pronounced Dow Theory "sell signal" of Aug. 31 and Sept. 14. Two or three have even remarked that, for several years, a market operator could have done pretty well by waiting a week or so after each signal, then doing the opposite.

GRAPES in general are a good fruit in home gardens, for they are quite productive when pruned and sprayed properly. Two factors, however, have limited the period of enjoyment of this fruit in the Northeast: (1) An early September frost may ruin the entire crop, and (2) grapes taste best when they ripen on the vine, but old varieties have not stored well.

Soon after it was first introduced on a small scale for clinical use, penicillin was given to patients indiscriminately, whether their afflictions were infectious or not. Ralph A. Tudor, Under Secretary of the Interior, is scheduled to address the American Society of Civil Engineers, which will begin a five-day convention tomorrow in the Statler Hotel. Mr. Tudor will speak at a luncheon on Wednesday.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct, 17 -- Williams College remained unbeaten by downing Bowdoin 20 -- 14, today on Weston Field. This made it three victories and one tie for the Ephmen.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 17 -- Llangollen Farm's Porterhouse ran one of the most disappointing races of 1953 today by finishing fifth and last while Joe Gavegnano's Errard King romped to victory in the $72,820 Pimlico Futurity.

Claudio Arrau gave the first of a series of seven recitals devoted to the piano sonatas of Beethoven yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 17 -- Finance Minister Alfredo Hernandez reported "very satisfactory" results today at the second conference of the Committee of Economic Cooperation of the Central American Isthmus at the close of its week's meeting.

The Venetian gondola that went astray on its overland voyage from Brooklyn to Cincinnati was located yesterday, still on the way. Where it had been for a week remained, temporarily, a mystery.

He needs the machine in preparing his Ph.D. thesis. When it is not working for him it is doing odd jobs for psychologists and anthropologists at the university.

Davenport, president of the library's board of trustees.

Members of the National Lawyers Guild were urged yesterday "to repulse the threat to its existence" contained in the declaration of Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. last August that the guild was subversive and would be required to show cause why it should not be put on the list of subversive organizations.

LOS ANGELES -- A combination slide and stereo table projector was introduced by the Three Dimension Company at last week's Western States Convention and Photographic Trade Show here. The unit is the Project-or-View dual-purpose projector, which employs the same set of controls for operating slides for viewing or projection, has an eight-by-ten-inch viewing screen of special black glass, matched three-inch f/2.8 lenses, twin 300-watt projection lamps, and a manual changer.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Southern California beat Oregon State in a Pacific Coast Conference game today, 37 -- 0, handing the Beavers their fifth straight shutout of the season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Representative John Taber, Republican of New York, today cited a $137,000 home for an Embassy secretary as an example of "extravagance" that must be halted if the United States is to have balanced budget next year.

SPECIES tulips are a delight to all who know them. The variation in size, color and season makes them adaptable to many places and most of them increase as readily as scilla, grape hyacinth or snowdrop. With but few exceptions, species tulips produce small flowers on short stems, ranging from six inches to twelve or fourteen.

COOL nights have helped to retard the opening of hardy chrysanthemum blooms as much as ten days. Plantings in and around New York City, therefore, will be at their best toward the end of the week.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Transplant seed of hardy biennials and perennials to the places where they are to bloom. First, turn over the soil incorporate fertilizer and rake fine. Water once a week this fall and mulch after the ground freezes. Keep in the cold frame until spring, tender seedlings or those too small to transplant to the open ground.

Robbins of New York City, president of the National Housing Conference, predicted here today. He addressed the National Association of Housing Officials as they closed their annual convention.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Gene Smith of Washington and Bill Bossio of Pittsburgh fought to a draw tonight in a bruising ten-rounder that was televised nationally. Each weighed 127 1/2 pounds.
CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Senator Frank Carlson, Republican of Kansas, said today that Congress should oppose any further "kidnapping" of rate-making power by the Post Office Department.

COMPLETION of steel work recently on the Captree Causeway Bridge means that by next summer New Yorkers will have a new Long Island parkway leading to a new recreation area on the ocean, Captree State Park.

BOSTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Boston University's Sam Pino and Joe Terrasi each scored two third-period touchdowns today as the favored Terriers rallied in the second half to beat Brandeis University, 40 -- 14, before 8,500 fans at Braves Field.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- This town is still full of echoes from the days of America's isolation. It has changed, in policy and personnel, more than any other world capital in the last generation. No nation has taken on so much or moved so far in such a hurry. Yet the habits of the past, like the bent figures of homeless former Senators, still haunt the capital.
UDINE, Italy, Sunday, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Three Italian divisions facing the Yugoslav frontier north of Trieste were ordered on a state of emergency late last night.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- With the resumption of the French Parliamentary session, the Cabinet of Premier Joseph Laniel has entered an uneasy period in which anything more than superficial treatment of the fundamental problems could break the party truce and cause a Government crisis.
There is a new trend in the men's clothing field. Instead of expanding plant facilities to produce new lines, companies are purchasing concerns specializing in one type of apparel.

With the four leaders paired in the twenty-sixth round of the world chess championship challengers' tournament last night in Zurich, and both of their games being drawn, there was no change in the standing, according to a Swiss news report.

Three Brooklyn business establishments lost their day's receipts to hold-up men last evening. A Safeway Store at 2892 Ocean Avenue in the Sheepshead Bay section, the Barton's Bonbonniere at 20 DeKalb Avenue in downtown Brooklyn and a liquor store at 8520 Seventh Avenue in the Bay Ridge section were robbed by gunmen between 7 and 9 P. M., and in all cases they escaped.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- James Griffiths, a Labor member of Parliament and a former Cabinet minister, led 30,000 Welsh miners in a protest march through Cardiff today as a demonstration against a change in the unemployment insurance law.

ROME, Oct. 17 -- Premier Giuseppe Pella's strong stand on the Trieste question, which culminated in the Anglo-American proposal to put Italy in effective possession of Zone A, has strengthened his political position so greatly that he seems set to remain in power almost indefinitely.

DALLAS, Oct. 17 (AP) -- A majority vote instead of three-fourths, called necessary by its sponsors if the minor leagues are to have a hand in making the rules of baseball, was proposed at a meeting of twenty-two minor league presidents and representatives of six major league clubs today.

THE four articles that Life magazine excerpted from "The Secret History of Stalin's Crimes" last April did an injustice to their author by making him appear a sensationalist and a shadowy figure. Actually the volume under review is a serious study of the three big Moscow trials in 1936, 1937 and 1938, staged by Stalin against leading oppositionists and others.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 17 -- The one thing Los Angeles would like most to have is major league baseball. The one thing it would like most to get rid of is smog. In the forefront of efforts aimed at both these goals is a black-haired girl of 23 named Rosalind Wiener, the first woman elected to Los Angeles City Council in thirty-eight years.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 17 -- Herbert Hoover Jr., State Department oil consultant, arrived here today on what was officially described as a fact-finding mission concerning the dispute over Iran's nationalization of the British oil concession.

A CLIFF dweller recently removed to Westchester County found himself involved in an occupation (gardening) about which he knew less than nothing. Right now his big dilemma is bulbs. What are they? How do you plant them?
WACO, Tex., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Baylor staged four first-half touchdown drives today, then permitted capable substitutes to complete the job of routing Vanderbilt, 47 -- 6.

Governor Dewey's future as a figure of national importance appears to be deeply involved in the state investigation of harness racing scandals and the effort to depose Senator Arthur H. Wicks of Kingston as temporary president of the State Senate because of Wicks' prison visits to Joseph S. Fray convicted labor extortionist.

TO THE EDITOR: MAY I reply to the letters attacking my review of C. G. Jung's "Psychology and Alchemy;" The most serious complaints are that I have not done justice to charges of pro-nazism and anti-Semitism against Jung.

AS usual, the annual of contemporary American painting at the Whitney Museum covers all phases of work being done today, from ultra-realism to violent expressionism and complete abstraction. But to this reviewer it seems that this year there are more pictures over-large for the statements they make, more examples of enforced novelty than usual and a considerably higher percentage than usual of artists who were represented in the preceding annual.

CAIRO, Oct. 17 -- Three more men were hanged here this morning after having been convicted of treason in a secret trial Tuesday before the ruling army junta's extraordinary revolution 'tribunal, composed of three officers. The week's total of executions is four.

Only one American steamship company, Pacific Far East Line, Inc., of San Francisco, has taken advantage of a Government offer to charter nine speedy Mariner-type freighters for commercial operation under a bareboat charter agreement.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 17 -- The Israeli Army General Staff took precautionary measures today along the armistice lines with Jordan in the light of reports that the Amman Government moved units of the Arab Legion to areas bordering Israel.
The United States, world leader in the development of atomic energy, is turning its sights on the utilization of this destructive force for peaceful purposes.
BALDWIN, L. I., Oct. 17 -- An acute building shortage and a serious lack of qualified teachers were cited here today as the two most pressing problems facing the public schools of Long Island.

TRENTON, Oct. 17 -- Republican and Democratic campaigners prepared today for a bitter finale to the New Jersey gubernatorial contest as the conviction spread among political observers that the balloting would be very close.

Higher standards for accreditation of engineering programs in colleges and universities were recommended last week by the American Society for Engineering Education and the Engineers Council for Professional Development. The proposal called for division of engineering education into "professional-scientific" and "professional-general" education.

YELLOWSTONE PARK, Wyo., Oct. 17 -- The number of visitors to Yellowstone National Park, largest of the nation's playgrounds, has fallen off 1.7 per cent from Jan. 1 to Sept. 30, park officials announced.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 17 (UP) -- Michigan State crushed Indiana, 47 to 18, for its twenty-eighth straight victory today. The triumph kept Coach Clarence (Biggie) Munn's Spartans unchallenged atop the Western Conference standings with three triumphs. It was Indiana's second Big Ten loss.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 17 (AP) -- A second world speed record is claimed today for the Navy's new F4D Skyray jet interceptor with an average speed of 728.110 m.p.h. over a 100 kilometer closed course.

Alfred R. Loos, chairman of the State Parole Board, yesterday challenged Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor, to make public the name of "the high national figure" he said had tried to get Joseph S. Fay, convicted labor leader, out of Sing Sing Prison.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Find and George Auerbach's Dictar, who made a one-three finish in the Ohio Derby on the previous Saturday, did a one, two job in the $62,800 Grey Lag Handicap at the Jamaica track yesterday. The pair of 3-year-olds finished four lengths apart after Find had led all the way in the nine-furlong run.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 16 -- Politically on the farm front today, Republicans are like the little boy who knocked the bee hive out of the tree. All the lad could think of was to run.
AMES, Iowa, Oct. 17 (UP) -- Iowa State College stunned Missouri, 13 to 6, today in a Big Seven conference football game with a second-half drive.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 17 (AP) -- The largest crowd of the season at Garden State Park, 35,298 fans, saw a record field of fourteen 3-year-olds go postward in the $25,000 added Benjamin Franklin Handicap today. The overnight list of seventeen was reduced when Buck 'n Gee, Count Cavour and Thaxter were scratched.

A collection of water-colors painted by a Swiss artist in the Missouri Valley in the frontier days of the early Eighteen Thirties arrived here yesterday after lying idle in a German castle on the Rhine for more than 100 years.

A YEAR ago airlines belonging to the International Air Transport Association stopped paying for their passengers' trips from European airports into the cities they serve. Many airline passengers and some of the carriers dislike the new system, which requires passengers to arrange and pay for their own limousine or bus trips between downtown terminals and the fields, just as they do in the United States.

ALTHOUGH producer Kermit Bloomgarden doesn't live in Brooklyn, he, too, may have to wait until next year. True, as of the moment, he still is dickering for Carl Zuckmayer's "The Devil's General," which opened recently to a genarally favorable London press.

MIAMI BEACH -- Encouraged by the state's $1,000,000 appropriation for adtising and a prediction of an 8 per cent increase in tourist travel to Florida, transportation lines, communities and hotels in the state will make a greater bid than ever this year for new tourist dollars and for former visitors who have been attracted to other American and Caribbean resorts.

THOUGH precisionists may question the use of the term "novel" for this somewhat loosely connected series of episodes, "Shim" nevertheless succeeds admirably in its purpose. It presents sharply, vividly, often with moving eloquence, a vanished Southern world of nature as seen through the eyes of an uncomplex boy of 14 at the end of the last century.

THIS year New York City is having its most unusual mayoral campaign in twenty years. Not since Fiorello H. La Guardia won his first term at City Hall in 1933 in a three-sided contest with John P. O'Brien and Joseph V. McKee has there been so much uncertainty about the outcome of an election.

LOS ANGELES -- Although not remarkable for the volume of new items shown, the biennial Western States Convention and Photographic Trade Show held at the Statler Hotel here last week by the Master Photo Dealers' and Finishers' Association gave ample indication of the industry's ability to develop original ideas in design.

By one precious inch Army stopped Duke short of its goal line in the final minute of play at the Polo Grounds yesterday to save its superbly won 14-13 victory over one of the nation's top-ranking football teams.

The United States, we read, is giving Turkey a handsome, modern naval base at Iskenderun, at the head of the gulf of that name in the extreme northeast corner of the Mediterranean Sea. It is said to be a fine, modern base, well equipped, and completely built and furnished through United States funds.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 17 -- The decision of the National Vietnam Congress rejecting the French Union has caused indignation among officers and soldiers of the French expeditionary force engaged for several days in battle for the defense of Tonkin.

RECORDED here are the numerous conversations which Gustav Janouch held with Franz Kafka, beginning in 1920, when the former was 17, and continuing throughout four years of a fairly close relationship. Max Brod declares in his introduction that Janouch's reminiscences made him feel "as if my friend had come to life again * * * and entered my room."

IN "Beyond Anxiety," James A. Pike focuses upon what he has found in his personal and pastoral experience to be the principal types of human anxiety. He lists these as fear, guilt, inhibition, frustration, indecision, loneliness and despair.
For the long pull, there are more people already in houses than people who want houses.

NEW DELHI, India. Oct. 17 -- A mixed impression of progress made by economically ailing countries of South and Southeast Asia emerged today as the Colombo Plan Consultative Committee ended its annual meeting here.

Four persons, three men and the wife of one of them, were being questioned last night by local police, Post Office inspectors and Secret Service men who suspected they were members of a ring that had robbed six local post offices in the last nine months and a department store in Washington on Thursday night.

ONE of the landmarks on St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands, Bluebeard's Castle Hotel, has been put up for sale by the United States Government. The hotel, erected in the Thirties by the Government as an incentive to the local tourist trade, was for years operated under lease by private interests.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 17 -- A Continental transport plan approaching in size and organization that of the interstate traffic system of the United States was set up here today. Seventeen European ministers of transport or representatives of equivalent rank unanimously approved a protocol establishing a permament organization with executive powers to deal with road, rail and inland waterway transport.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 -- Dr. Courtney Craig Smith was inaugurated today as the ninth president of Swarthmore College.
Winter is here for the great numbers of salesmen who have joined the ranks in recent years in the blissful warmth of the seller's market.
The steady rise of the African rock lobster trade is truly a reflection of the old adage about mighty oaks and little acorns.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- Senator Arthur H. Wicks recorded yesterday in a New York television studio the speech with which he will seek to establish tomorrow that there is no reason for him to yield legislative leadership.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- It is very possible that the tone of the conference of Foreign Ministers here this week was set by a non participant well before Messrs. Eden, Dulles and Bidault had met and exchanged the preliminary remarks about their joint purposes.
SHARYLAND, Tex., Oct. 17 (AP) -- An estimated 200,000 Texans lined a parade route today for President Eisenhower, who came here for a week-end of relaxation after a visit to New Orleans.

Prospect Avenue, between Fourth and Sixth Avenues in Brooklyn, will be closed to traffic, beginning tomorrow at 10 A. M., to permit construction of the first section of the Prospect Expressway, Borough President John Cashmore announced yesterday.

The law began taking over last week on the lawless frontier known as the Port of New York. That was the real significance of the hectic developments in the death struggle between the International Longshoremen's Association and the new union the American Federation of Labor set up to drive it from the docks.
Extending of life insurance protection to retired workers by formalizing group insurance plans for that purpose is being given greater thought by many companies.

IN 1924 Congress passed the so-called "Rogers Act" and provided for a permanent group of "foreign service officers" from which the President would make appointments to diplomatic and consular posts. Thereafter, Secretary of State John Hay's definition of a "quiet legation" was no longer accurate: "A stuffed mattress which the political acrobat wants always to see ready under him in case of a slip."

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 17 -- While expressing concern over British Guiana, the Indian Government was undecided today about taking up the case for the deposed Government of the colony pending a report from the Indian Commissioner to the British West Indies.

Of the various big businesses in this country that are experiencing difficulty in obtaining qualified workers, there is none in which the situation is more acute than in hospitals. Traditionally, the demand for hospital services has exceeded their availability.
CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Sub Fleet, a 4-year-old bay colt, accounted for the biggest purse of his career today as he won the $106,200 Hawthorne Gold Cup and set a new track record in the bargain.

The forthcoming invasion of the Canada-United Kingdom steamship trade by Saguenay Terminals, Ltd., wherein the company will attempt to "free" cargo rates, is being watched by shipping men with considerable interest.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 17 -- Gettysburg College notched its third straight today with a 22-7 triumph over Lehigh in a football series that began in 1915.

Florence Chadwick, aquatic conqueror of the English Channel and the Straits of Gibraltar, Bosporus and Dardanelles, said here yesterday upon her arrival from Europe that she had given up long-distance swimming and would devote her efforts in the future to beating par on the golf links.
The National Labor Relations Board accused the old International Longshoremen's Association and the Anastasia brothers of Brooklyn yesterday of threats, coercion and violence on the piers.
The extended discussion of the Point Four program prompts me to offer the following comments:

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Bill Veeck, appointed today as special adviser to the Chicago Cubs president, P. K. Wrigley, and Don Stewart, head of the Cubs' Los Angeles club, will "spearhead the campaign to bring major league baseball to Los Angeles?"
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The United Nations was praised today as "an instrument of peace" by Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

THE "rule" is, with nine cards of a suit in the two hands, don't finesse for a queen -- unless you have special information. They have even made a rhyme about it, "With eight ever, with nine never," thus using the two worst words in the bridge lexicon, ever and never, to make one bad rule.

TORONTO, Oct. 17 (UP) -- George Armstrong, a rangy right wing, scored a third-period goal against the New York Rangers tonight to give the Toronto Maple Leafs a 1-1 deadlock in a National Hockey League encounter before 13,010 fans.

Robert DiCamillo, 17-year-old senior from Mount Pleasant High School, Schenectady, and Arthur Dunn, a 16-year-old sophomore from Sewanhaka High School, Floral Park, L. I., were the individual victors yesterday in the seventeenth New York University interscholastic cross-country meet at Van Cortlandt Park.

A courageous taxicab driver delivered a murder suspect to the police early yesterday morning by halting his cab in front of the Transverse Police Station in Central Park and shouting for help in the station entrance.

SINCE the end of the war Umbria has each fall dedicated a week to music -- the Sagra Musicale Umbra. Most of the music is sacred, and the celebration traditionally ends on Oct. 4, the day of Umbria's own and favorite saint, Francis of Assisi.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- A new success story is being related here by United Nations officials back from the Jordan River Valley, where a campaign against malaria has been waged and won.

THERE is a triple-language (English - French - German) publication making the rounds of Europe by the name of International Book Advertiser, and it has us puzzled. Perhaps triple-threat would be more like it. The other month this Zurich periodical reported to its readership on American book promotion methods and cited the following as typical.

A VASTLY encouraging indication of what clever filmmakers can do without much money but with talent, perseverance and artistic integrity is to be had in the pleasant little picture now showing on the Normandie's screen -- the much-publicized and celebrated "Little Fugitive," which Joseph Burstyn has released.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 17 (UP) -- Sandy Lederman, sophomore back, and Bob McNamee led a resurgent University of Washington eleven to a 14-6 Pacific Coast Conference victory over Oregon on a slippery, rain-soaked field today in the forty-seventh renewal of their rivalry.

Columbia extended what has become a tradition with Lion football teams in defeating Harvard yesterday by 6 to 0. The tradition lay not in the conquest of Harvard, particularly, but in the manner in which the victory was scored.

AWARDED the Carnegie Medal in England as the outstanding children's book of 1952, Mary Norton's "The Borrowers" is a fantasy that brings to mind such impressive titles as "The water Babies," "The Wind in the Willows" and even "Alice in Wonderland."
LORD CHESTERFIELD, said Dr. Samuel Johnson acidly, taught his illegitimate son the manners of a dancing master and the morals of a slut.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 17 -- The Board of Visitors of William and Mary College has voted to change the name of its Department of Jurisprudence, said to be one of the oldest in the world, to the Marshall-Wythe School of Law.
In London today the Foreign Ministers of the Western Big Three are to wind up what John Foster Dulles considers the most important conference he has attended since he became Secretary of State.
Testimony on the theft of secret radar and electronic data from the Signal Corps' laboratory at Fort Monmouth, N. J., points to "many more important disclosures" of espionage there during...

REGINALD and Gladys Laubin have taken a company of nine Crow Indians to Europe for a tour, scheduled to open in Oslo on Oct. 2. This is said to be the first time that an authentic Indian dance program has ever been presented to Europe, and since Mr. and Mrs. Laubin know more about the subject than the great majority of Indians, it should be an event of international importance.

THE novice hunter seldom lacks for advice on the equipment and methods designed to provide pleasant, productive days afield, although some of the advice may be conflicting as well as confusing. Most beginners, however, seem less informed on the "don'ts" that play an equally important part in successful hunting.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 17 (UP) -- Ossie Pickworth of Australia holed out a ninety-foot approach shot for an eagle 3 on the long ninth hole today and went on to win the Ampol golf tournament for the sixth time in eight years.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Illinois' J. C. Caroline and Mickey Bates paced the unbeaten Illini to a 27-7 Big Ten football victory over Minnesota's Gophers today.

Although cotton growers are disappointed over the drastic curtailment of acreage on their 1954 crop imposed recently by the Department of Agriculture, there is little doubt that the controls will be approved in the referendum on Dec. 15. To become effective at least two-thirds of the growers voting must approve the controls.

George Washington's best uniform -- the one he wore when he resigned his commission at Annapolis in 1783 -- has gone to the cleaner, presumably for the first time in 170 years. The buff-and-blue coat, breeches and vest are in excellent condition. Washington probably wore them only on a few state occasions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- "Operation Cleaning" is over and the mission has been accomplished.
An inadvertent motion by a young immigrant attending an auction seventy-five years ago started a ribbon business that has grown to be one of the largest of its kind in the country.

AT last New York has a long overdue showing of the paintings of one of the greatest individualists among the creative artists of our time -- one of the soundest painters of our period, yet one of the slowest to win recognition -- a man who is neither a moralist nor a philosopher, but who in his fullest work paints directly out of himself and paints himself onto his canvas: Fernand Leger.

NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 17 (UP) -- Oklahoma opened its drive for an eighth consecutive Big Seven Conference championship today with a display of power that humbled Kansas, 45 to 0, before a crowd of 42,500.

JOINING the fall season of shows and festivals, the New York Horticultural Society will hold the first of its monthly meetings and exhibits on Wednesday at the Essex House, 157 West Fifty-eighth Street. The show to be seen in the Colonnades Ballroom from 1 to 4 P. M., has classes for chrysanthemums and other seasonal garden material, as well as flower arrangements.
MANHATTAN, Kan., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Kansas State's Wildcats struck with four long-distance touchdown plays today to defeat Colorado, 28 -- 14, for their third Big Seven conference victory.
Elaborate divertissements have been planned for the Fan Ball to be held on Nov. 16 in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Children's Memorial Cancer Fund, Inc.

OCCASIONALLY, the reader comes across an unostentatious novel, likely to be lost in the shuffle of competing best sellers, whose tale and its telling is an unexpectedly thoughtful and moving delight. Such is James Wellard's novel of North Africa
As delegates to Lord Russell's conference on the horror of atomic war, I would suggest such delegates as these:

A rising stock market usually generates optimism. Last week's was no exception. Although there was little change in the prevailing uncertainty regarding the business outlook, some views expressed were noticeably less pessimistic than before.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Jim Garrity picked up a blocked punt in the final minute of play and raced 24 yards for a touchdown today as Penn State dropped favored Syracuse from the unbeaten ranks by downing the Orange, 20 -- 14.

AFTER a certain age, a day of great happiness (under the sign of love, that is) promises a sadder morrow than a day of gloom. On the gloomy day, one says to one's self, "How well Nature takes care of things!
CLEVELAND, Oct. 17 -- The appointment of Mayor Burke sends Cleveland's "Mr. Democrat" to Washington to take the seat of the nation's "Mr. Republican."

A recorded concert observing the seventieth anniversary of the opening of the Metropolitan Opera House will open the season on Wednesday at 8:15 P. M. of the monthly musical programs at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. Giovanni Martinelli, Metropolitan Opera tenor from 1913 to 1942, will be the guest of honor.

INTRODUCING Mario Soldati to American readers, "Dinner With the Commendatore" is a distinguished and highly enjoyable addition to the sizable list of fine books that have come to us from post-war Italy. Mr. Soldati, well known in his own country as an author and a leading film director, possesses a gift that is in short supply nowadays, at least where serious writing is concerned: he is a master of the art of telling a story.

The blood serum of some mental patients is more poisonous to developing tadpoles than blood from normal persons, Dr. Roland Fischer of the Department of Public Health and General Hospital, Regina, Sask., reports in Science. Moreover, blood serum from normal men is more poisonous to tadpoles than that from normal women.

The local professional football season gets under way officially today, with the New York Giants entertaining the Chicago Cardinals at the Polo Grounds. The game will start at 2:05 P. M. The Giants played at home earlier in an exhibition.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Army Signal Corps, which likes to call itself the "nerves" of the Army, had some raw nerves this week.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Oct. 17 -- Dr. George Fisher, National Boy Scout Commissioner, who has attended all thirty-four Boy Scout pilgrimages to the grave of Theodore Roosevelt in Youngs Memorial Cemetery, placed a wreath this afternoon at the iron gates enclosing the tomb as 1,000 Scouts from many eastern troops stood by.

THERE are more than 6,000 members of Actors Equity. Of these, only about 2,400 see the working side of a theatre curtain each season, and of the 2,400 only about one-tenth are fortunate enough to make it to Broadway. These discouraging statistics point up the achievement of 33-year-old Walter Matthau, who in the past five seasons has appeared in eight Broadway productions.

THE all-important first step toward space travel is the construction of a wheel-shaped space station, an artificial satellite floating more than a thousand miles above the surface of the earth. The station, which would have military as well as purely scientific uses, could be completed by 1967 at a cost of five to six billion dollars.

THE airline passenger who would like to fly from New York to Los Angeles at the speed of sound is going to have to wait. For some years he will have to stooge along across the country at 300 to 500 miles an hour.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 17 -- Halfback Charley Finger led Adelphi College to its first victory of the season by scoring two touchdowns and kicking a field goal as the Panthers scored a 30-0 victory over Brooklyn College at Adelphi Field today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Farm belt residents hoisted an urgent warning this week to President Eisenhower and his Administration that continued Republican control of both houses of Congress was genuinely in jeopardy in the 1954 Congressional elections.

Plans are being formulated at frequent meetings for the performance of "II Trovatore" on the night of Dec. 2 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc., of which Mrs. William Randolph Hearst is founder and president.

FALCON HEIGHTS, Tex., Oct. 17 -- The $55,000,000 Falcon Dam on the Rio Grande, the international project that President Eisenhower and President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines of Mexico will dedicate Monday, already has become a boon to the agriculture-rich lower Rio Grande Valley.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Resources For The Future, Inc., a nonprofit corporation fostering research-and education in the natural resources, has completed a major phase of preparations for its nation-wide citizens' forum meeting opening here Dec. 2.

The 3,000th anniversary of the establishment of Jerusalem as the first capital of Israel by King David will be marked with ceremonies Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden. The occasion, under the sponsorship of the Israel Bond Organization, is expected to attract 20,000 persons. Admission will be by the purchase of an Israel bond.

AGAIN Marchette Chute has entered the lists, and if she has fared less well in her tilt with Jonson than with her earlier subjects it is for no want of endurance and gallantry. She has read with determined approval everything that Jonson wrote (eleven resistant volumes in the Herford and Simpson edition), and has read up on everything that concerned him.
LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Britain dedicated two memorials to airmen of World War II today, one to the Commonwealth air forces' dead, the other to men of the United States Air Force.

The new West German Federal Republic is moving forward in its effort to make good on bonds sold to help tide the pre-Hitler Government over the World War I reparation crises. About $300,000,000 are held by Americans.
LONDON, Oct. 17 -- The United States, Britain and France moved closer today to a conference with Yugoslavia and Italy on the future of Trieste and farther from high-level talks with the Soviet Union.

WITH all due allowance for the substantial costs involved, commercial standards in television are getting sloppy and annoying. In many different ways the sponsors and networks are taxing the viewers good nature beyond reasonable bounds.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 17 -- Prominent guests from abroad will be among the speakers at the thirty-second biennial convention of the Girl Scouts of the United States of America here, beginning tomorrow and ending Wednesday.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N. J., Oct. 17 (AP) -- The oldest and youngest civilian defense plane spotters in the nation work at the same ground observer corps post at this shore community. They are Calvin W. Miller, 86-year-old retired carpenter, and Ronnie Barker, 7, a second-grade pupil.

WITH "Ben Jonson of Westminster" Marchette Chute finished a series of three biographies of English poets, and for the moment at least has ceased the ramblings about London which began with "Geoffrey Chaucer of England" and continued by way of "Shakespeare of London."

The largest group of American students to go to any foreign country under the Government's exchange program recently for Europe. They were the 224 American students who received United States scholarships for graduate study in French universities as Fulbright students.

TOKYO, Sunday, Oct. 18 -- Shouting, cursing Chinese prisoners of war appeared before "explainers" from their homeland yesterday in the demilitarized zone of Korea and, of 430 captives involved, only nine indicated that they wanted to go home.

THE slumber of weary travelers resting at the La Guardia Hotel, now rising across Grand Central Parkway from La Guardia Airport for occupancy next March, will not be disturbed by the noise of airplane engines, not even jets.

ROME, Oct. 17 -- Premier Giuseppe Pella said today the Italian Government would resign if the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France, now meeting in London, reached any decision indicating that they had yielded to Yugoslav threats and gone back on the United States and British intention of returning Zone A of Trieste to Italian administration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UP) -- Senator George A. Smathers, Democrat of Florida said today the time had come when Congress should vote Federal funds to the states for education, "with no strings attached."

WE speak of forcemeat and most cooks know we mean a finely ground meat mixture. But if we refer to "forcefish," the term is not so easily recognized. Fish that has been mashed, pounded or ground to a paste is common in foreign cuisines but less familiar in American cooking.

NEWARK, Oct. 17 -- Since last Tuesday, without interruption during daylight hours. high-pressure automatic equipment has been used to pour 1,000 gallons of water a minute on a dump fire near the Elizabeth waterfront, the smoke from which has been linked with many multiple-car accidents on the adjacent New Jersey Turnpike in the last two months.
DETROIT, Oct. 17 (UP) -- Earl Reibel and Johnny Wilson rapped home goals as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 2 to 1, tonight before 10,183 fans at Olympia.

At the back of most record catalogues there is a section devoted to recordings that compilers find hard to classify. "Spoken and Miscellaneous" is the way they are headed in one catalogue. "The Theatre, Films and Speech" is the heading in another.

THERE is material for an original and perceptive book in the story of crime and political corruption in New York City, but Ed Reid has not written it. By now most newspaper readers are familiar with the official scandals uncovered here in the past few years.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 17 -- City Commissioner Donald Spence charged today that the two conspiracy indictments handed up against him yesterday by the September term of the Hudson County grand jury were the result of a plot to sacrifice him in return for "renegade Democratic votes" for Republican candidates in the Nov. 3 election.

These fine October days are full of skittering leaves and mellow sunlight -- and questions. Why do the squirrels take all the hickory nuts? What do the crows complain about in weather like this? How many seeds are in a milkweed pod? Did anybody ever count them?

JERUSALEM, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Jordan asked today her sister Arab states ringing Israel for military aid to ward off possible "fresh Israeli aggression" on her borders. Jordanian soldiers were given orders to shoot on sight any Israeli troops crossing the border.

PERSIAN walnuts, black walnuts, heartnuts, Chinese chestnuts, dwarf Asiatic chestnuts, filberts -- all these and many other beautiful nut-producing trees can be grown in the northern states. In fact nut-tree growing in this area has aroused the interests of bankers and laborers, lawyers and housewives and other widely diverse groups.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 17 (UP) -- Bobby Garrett, with a brilliant passing performance today, brought Stanford from a two-touchdown deficit to a 21-20 victory over U. C. L. A. and knocked the Bruins out of the nation's undefeated ranks. The game was played in Stanford Stadium before a crowd of 45,000.
THERE is no more ardent advocate of two-platoon football than Steve Owen, and he snorts in disdain at the shoddiness of one-platoon play.

The attempts to set into motion the process of persuading reluctant anti-Communist prisoners in Korea to be repatriated are bringing out some facts that may be useful in an appraisal of the entire truce process. In the first place, only a tiny fraction of those who have been "persuaded" have agreed to return, and reports indicate that most of these may have made up their minds previously to do so.
THE threat of the Soviet H-bomb is casting a long shadow across Washington.
LONDON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The British Lawn Tennis Association disclosed today an investigation into the amateur status of Jaroslav Drobny, tennis star, has been completed.

IT is a matter for argument that there has ever been a cultural renaissance in Chicago, but there is no danger at all that the city will be buried under the silt of neglect that finally overwhelmed Nineveh. What threatens Chicago is a volcanic eruption of books about Chicago.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 17 (UP) -- Sophomore Quarterback Jim Miller, calling the signals for the first time, today led Wisconsin to a 28-to-19 Big Ten triumph over Purdue before 36,500 homecoming fans.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- The Camp Fire Girls of Greater New York presented a ten-foot- high pin-oak tree today to the United Nations as a symbol of friendship for children throughout the world. The tree had been bought through individual contributions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UP) -- The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations will reopen a search on Monday for the identity of officials who let Russia use United States printing plates to issue $250,000,000 worth of German currency which this country redeemed.

Current popular songs and motion pictures having religious themes are an indication that "there is a deep-seated yearning for religion among people," Rabbi William F. Rosenblum said in a sermon yesterday morning at Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street.

Many buyers were in the wholesale markets here last week, placing reorders for holiday and fall merchandise. Deliveries were slow on many items because of late ordering, and with the arrival of cooler weather, delivery delays are expected to increase, resident buying offices reported.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 17 -- Hudson County Clerk William H. Gilfert today refused to accept the names of four substitute candidates offered by the Republican County Committee to fill vacancies in three state offices and one county office on the party's slate in the Nov. 3 election.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 17 -- Business gains in Cleveland for the first nine months of this year ranged from "very strong" to moderate with nonresidential construction, steelmaking and new automobile sales leading, it was reported by the Federal Reserve Bank.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- Next Saturday, the eighth anniversary of the coming into force of the United Nations Charter, will find the U. N. in a paradoxical position: its standing among Americans has declined, but at the same time it is regaining its earlier stature as the principal forum for discussion of the world's problems.

" The plight of academic freedom" has become the genuine concern of many an intellectually honest educator in America today. There is no doubt that such a phrase as "character assassination" is taking on a sinister realism. It is further obvious that a climate of suspicion and coercion is hardly conducive to right thinking and that a spirit of free inquiry needs to be maintained at the core of our institutions of learning.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Oct. 17 -- New Zealand has been watching the dock troubles in the United States with sympathy and a little local pride. Not long ago the situation in New Zealand had many parallels with that prevailing in the United States, but the waterfront control authority has just reported that the last year was one of the most peaceful in history.

PEOPLE of the theatre, those in front of the footlights as well as behind, were accustomed to refer to Rodgers Hart as the American Gilbert Sullivan. People of the theatre now are accustomed to refer to the succeeding firm of Rodgers Hammerstein as just that -- Rodgers Hammerstein.

IN "Land Birds of America" amateur ornithologists have the popular bird book that they have long been waiting for. Two eminent ornithologists of the American Museum of Natural History have produced an informative, satisfying text that gracefully complements numerous large and remarkably accurate photographs.

The convention on genocide -- the new name for the old crime of destroying groups of human beings -- has the not unexpected distinction of being the most ratified document sponsored by the United Nations. Last week Lebanon and Uruguay announced that their Governments will soon deposit their ratifications with the U. N., bringing the total number of countries so supporting this treaty to forty-three.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The United States is beginning to develop a new campaign against communism in Latin America, but it seams to be a campaign without any decisive weapon.

WINTER does two things to automobiles. It makes them more liable to break down and it makes them more dangerous. Careful check-ups at this time of year can cut down on both operating costs and the death list.

THAT well-known columnist, Mr. Earl Wilson, recently took a trip around the world in thirty days. There is little question that he was busier than Phileas Fogg, but he never left Broadway. This species of travel book is a vast compendium of one-line jokes of a familiarity so grating that it may be said on absolutely unimpeachable authority that none of them is in use any more at the comic's table in Lindy's.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 17 -- Notre Dame used powerful line play to score 16 points in the second half today and down Pittsburgh, 23 -- 14, before 57,998 fans.
The Queens Big Brother Movement, 12 Clinton Terrace, Jamaica, is carrying on a recruiting campaign for qualified men between 21 and 45 years old to serve as volunteer Big Brothers.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 -- Five chances at a touchdown from inside Ohio State's 20-yard line brought only one tally to Pennsylvania today. These repeated failures from the 7,7, 11 and 17 cost the Red and Blue a major upset triumph on sun-drenched Franklin Field as the visiting Buckeyes rallied for a 12-6 victory.

YONKERS, Oct. 17 -- My Volo, an 8-year-old bay gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. Louis M. Kehoe of Detroit and driven by Ed Morgan, captured the $5,000 Pacoy Memorial mile pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Aneurin Bevan, leader of the British Labor party's Left Wing, assailed tonight the policies of Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill's Government on Trieste and British Guiana. These two points are expected to furnish ammunition for Labor when Parliament opens next week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The United States is beginning to develop a new campaign against communism in Latin America, but it seams to be a campaign without any decisive weapon.

CONSIDERATION of that old but ever popular shrub, lilac, for fall planting might profitably follow along the lines of lengthening their period of bloom or of finding a place for some of the pink flowering kinds. As a matter of fact by planting only certain of the pink lilacs, bloom can be spread from late April through June 1.

IOWA CITY, Oct. 17 (UP) -- Half-back Dusty Rice, peppery 175-pound senior, returned to his old form for the first time in two years and led Iowa to a 21-to-7 victory over previously unbeaten Wyoming in an intersectional football game before 29,000 fans today.
PARIS, Oct. 17 -- Almost complete agreement on Cambodia's military sovereignty was reached today after laborious negotiations in Pnompenh, capital of Cambodia.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- A 287-mile railroad journey that has been spread over seven weeks will end tomorrow morning when one of the heaviest loads ever carried by rail reaches its destination at Little-brook power station in Kent.

Dick Osterhout of Syracuse ran away from the field at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday as he led his team to a cross-country victory over Navy and St. John's. With five harriers among the first nine, Syracuse compiled 29 points to 49 for Navy and 54 for St. John's.

One Egyptian policeman and ten from Brazil have begun a six-week course in crime detection at New York City's Police Academy and New York University's Graduate School of Public Administration and Social Service under scholarships from the United States Bureau of the Budget.

TOKYO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The New York Giants toyed with their Tokyo namesakes today, opening a fourteen-game exhibition baseball tour with a convincing 11-1 triumph before 42,000 fans at Korakuen Stadium in Tokyo.
PARIS, Oct. 17 -- Almost complete agreement on Cambodia's military sovereignty was reached today after laborious negotiations in Pnompenh, capital of Cambodia.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- A 287-mile railroad journey that has been spread over seven weeks will end tomorrow morning when one of the heaviest loads ever carried by rail reaches its destination at Little-brook power station in Kent.

One Egyptian policeman and ten from Brazil have begun a six-week course in crime detection at New York City's Police Academy and New York University's Graduate School of Public Administration and Social Service under scholarships from the United States Bureau of the Budget.

TOKYO, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The New York Giants toyed with their Tokyo namesakes today, opening a fourteen-game exhibition baseball tour with a convincing 11-1 triumph before 42,000 fans at Korakuen Stadium in Tokyo.

BUDD SCHULBERG'S brilliant portrait of a Hollywood producer, "What Makes Sammy Run?" and Norman Mailer's powerful study of World War II GI's, "The Naked and the Dead," novels once headed toward the screen but detoured en route, again are being considered as movie possibilities.
MOSCOW, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Soviet foreign policy magazine New Times tossed a new splash of cold water today on the idea that security guarantees from the West might help ease world tensions.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 17 -- A 1954 Democratic state ticket of Lausche for Governor and Burke for Senator was viewed today as likely. The prediction by political observers had its basis in Gov. Frank J. Lausche's appointment this week of Mayor Thomas A. Burke of Cleveland to succeed the late Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican.

For many months there have been reports of farmer unrest in the thirteen states of the Midwest which went solidly Republican in 1952 for the first time since 1928. The rumblings in the Farm Belt have been Chiefly caused by the continuing price-cost squeeze.

The New York Green Cross safety parade marched down Fifth Avenue for an hour and twenty minutes yesterday afternoon to remind us to avoid accidents.

Prominent women headed by Mrs. Madison H. Lewis, chairman, and Mrs. George S. Piroumoff, co-chairman, and including Mrs. Charles S. Whitman Jr., are working for the success of the pre-opening performance of "Escapade," a new comedy, on the night of Nov. 10 at the Forty-eight Street Theatre for the benefit of the Sheltering Arms Children's Service.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Oct. 17 (UP) -- Maryland's Terrapins stormed almost the distance of the field four times for touchdowns today to knock North Carolina out of the undefeated ranks by 26 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Three hundred and forty-five years ago the first five Poles to come to this country arrived at Jamestown on board the English vessel Mary and Margaret and settled there as glassmakers. Tomorrow at the first permanent English colony in America Polish-American organizations will commemmorate the occasion.

THE best memoirs partake of fictional truth as well as of the "really true." They are generalized, that is, beyond the merely personal and the merely dramatic. Not just a record of events and emotions, but an appreciation of the significance of the record is what we ask.

PAUL FROMM came to this country in 1938, seeking a refuge from Hitlerism. He settled in Chicago, started a wine importing business and prospered. But he is not the kind of man for whom making money for its own sake is a sensible purpose of life, and in recent years he began casting about for a way to spend the money that would be both creative and reflective of his gratitude to this country.

MANILA, Oct. 17 -- Ramon Magsaysay, Nationalist - Democratic candidate for President of the Philippines, charged President Elpidio Quirino and his Liberal party today with "screaming and kicking like spoiled children" because they had failed to gain United States endorsement of their administration.

CARAVAN HALL is a huge third-floor rehearsal room on East Fifty-ninth Street frequented by wandering herds of television players. A rehearsal of unusual circumstances was in progress there last week -- preparation for the first production of Shakespeare's "King Lear" to go on television, at least in this country.

Randy Turpin and Carl (Bobo) Olson will fight for the middleweight championship of the world on Wednesday night. The pair will clash in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden, and the winner will be generally recognized as the king of the 160-pound division.

In the neutral zone in Korea, just off the road from Munsan to Panmunjom, there lies a five-square-mile rectangular area, fenced off and heavily guarded. To the south of the rectangle is a city of compounds and enclosures fenced off by double lines of barbed wire.
Three patrolmen and two young men were hospitalized for exposure last night after they jumped into the East River in a futile attempt to save the life of an elderly Bowery resident.

TROY, N. Y., Oct. 17 -- Union College pushed over four touchdowns in the first half and then coasted to a 32-6 victory over Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute today in up-state Hew York's oldest football rivalry.
Public hearings to iron out any flaws in a broad program of modernization of the state's rules of the road will be held here next month by the Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicles problem.
It was to my great sorrow that I read that the Imperial's current offering, "Wish You Were Here," will be calling it a run in the very near future.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 17 -- Prof. Walter Hallstein, Secretary of State in the West German Foreign Ministry, left Bonn to fly to London today, presumably to make inquiries there about the results of the Allied foreign ministers meeting.

A tour of four of New York's distinguished private art collections has been arranged for this Tuesday afternoon and the afternoon of Nov. 17 to aid the Scholarship Fund of Greenwich House Music School. Mrs. George W. Naumburg is chairman of the music school committee in charge of the tour.

Twister, a Herreshoff S Class boat owned by Warner M. Willcox, was the chief winner in the season-long competition for Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound championship points, according to the final standings just issued.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 17 -- Anti - Western displays in Yugoslavia and the suspicions persisting in the West that President Tito is a Cominformist at heart have tended to obscure the basic foreign policy of Marshal Tito's Government.
A new combination bauxite and oil carrier will be launched next Friday at Burntisland, Scotland, for the Aluminum Company of Canada.
