KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 17 -- Mohammed Ali, Prime Minister of Pakistan was elected today president of the Pakistani Moslem League by an overwhelming majority. His succession to the leadership of the major political party, of which the Orthodox Moslems in the Government are the guiding members, was interpreted as the most significant assurance that his reform policies would have the endorsement of the nation.

Varied divertissements by professional entertainers will be presented at the dinner-dance, known as "Un Brin de Bonheur," which will be held on Thursday night in the main ballroom of the Plaza Hotel for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York.

Expeditions of the American Museum of Natural History last summer returned with 45,353 insect and spider specimens from the Western United States and Central Mexico, it was reported here yesterday by Dr. Mont A. Cazier, chairman of the museum's Department of Insects and Spiders.

HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 17 (AP) -- French Navy commandos blew up two bridges on the coastal highway south of Thanhhoa today to help isolate Vietminh forces menaced by a French offensive between Cap Ron and the Red River delta.
Rudolph Halley, Liberal party candidate for Mayor, declared yesterday that the burden of his opponents' campaigns was to convince the people that good government could not be had in this city.

THE Buffalo Philharmonic and the American Symphony Orchestra League have worked out a scheme whereby the Buffalo orchestra will devote eight of its twenty Saturday night "pop" concerts to the publicizing of orchestras of other cities.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 -- While the money market in this district continues "tight," improvement is expected soon. A check of representative concerns has convinced the Federal Reserve Bank here that "there are no noteworthy instances of builders or mortgage companies holding excessive amounts of completed loans which cannot be disposed of in a secondary market."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 17 -- Government sources disclosed tonight that all Army reservists in the Zagreb military district who are 26, 27 or 28 years old had been called to duty in view of the crisis over Trieste.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 17 (UP) -- Duncan McDonald, Michigan's talented reserve quarterback, tossed three touchdown passes today as Michigan defeated Northwestern, 20 -- 12, before 65,490 fans at Michigan Stadium.

AFTER the Moscow Art Theatre had produced "The Cherry Orchard" in January, 1904, Chekhov wrote to his wife: "One thing I can say: Stanislavsky has ruined my play for me." This acid remark is quoted by David Margarshack in his current "Chekhov: A Life" (Grove Press).

ANY reader who likes modern, fast-paced adventure ought to enjoy this story of three Connecticut boys who drive to New Mexico to prospect for uranium. Complications start as soon as Steven, Barney and Whipper arrive in Albuquerque to meet Porter, the fourth member of the expedition.

INTERPRETATION of the meaning, scope and contribution of higher education as illustrated by the work of New York's four municipal colleges -- City, Hunter, Queens and Brooklyn -- will be the object of "Panorama," a series of twenty-six television programs to be shown over WABD in cooperation with the Board of Higher Education of New York City.
The group that has made it possible for repair parts to be stockpiled, ready for instant use, will celebrate its thirty-fifth anniversary tomorrow.

The Yale Edition of James Boswell's autobiographical works is a project that, when it is complete, will be one of the most impressive and interesting monuments of its kind in the whole of English literature. This third volume of the hero's adventures opens on June 18, 1764.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 17 -- The question of governmental economy is overshadowing farm policies in the third of this fall's trio of contests to fill vacancies in the House of Representatives which were held by Republicans.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address at New Orleans yesterday commemorating the sesquicentennial of the Louisiana Purchase, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 17 -- President Eisenhower helped today to celebrate the 150th anniversary of the Louisiana Purchase.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 17 -- A handful of native politicians here have given a practical demonstration of political tactics here in the last few weeks that alarmed the leaders of the British Commonwealth, won the attention of the world public, and might easily have produced a Communist or near-Communist state in this northeast corner of South America.
ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 17 (UP) -- Using two backfields with equal devastation to Georgia's line, Louisiana State also checked Zeke Bratkowski's passes today to score a 14-to-6 victory before 21,000 fans.
BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Oct. 17 -- Across the Midwest's rolling prairie, two harvests are in progress: farmers are reaping another golden crop of corn, and Republicans are reaping a political whirlwind.

MARGIE BENTON sat down to polish an old brass elephant and wished it were clean. Instantly it shone like gold. No genie appeared, but a voice sounding like an English butler announced that here was Mr. Askew, and at Margie's service.

THE question often arises as to whether it is possible or even wise to cut back to a reasonable size the overgrown trees and shrubs in a foundation planting. For it is not unusual in the suburbs to see evergreen trees towering to the roof or above it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- The Army said today it still had no evidence that microfilm copies of secret data from its Fort Monmouth, N. J., Signal Corps laboratory had fallen into the hands of Communists in Germany.

The Colombo Plan conference just ended in New Delhi has received and issued an encouraging progress report. Gains in food production, as the result of Colombo Plan investment, have been noted in India, Burma, Indonesia, Pakistan and Vietnam. Public works projects such as irrigation and power developments are recorded as advancing rapidly in several countries and more slowly in others.

ATLANTA, Oct. 18 (AP) -- G. Bromley Oxnam, presiding Bishop of the Methodist church, declared today that no Protestant nation had been seriously infiltrated by communism because "Protestants stand for the free mind in the free society." He added that this "emphasis on individualism * * * has created an atmosphere in which the Communist virus cannot live."
PARIS, Oct. 18 -- French reaction to the London conference and note to the Soviet Union today was unenthusiastic.
Former President Herbert C. Hoover delivered yesterday a lecture on civics to the youth of America in which he ranged from discussion of Government problems to the reason a President goes fishing.

Thirteen-year-old William J. O'Connell looked badly shaken when he appeared yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court as complainant against one of two teenage assailants. When his story had been unfolded, everybody in the courtroom could understand why.
ALBANY, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A prominent Republican State Senator and a Republican county chairman insisted tonight that Mr. Wicks should quit as majority leader and President Pro Tem of the Senate.

Representatives of dry cargo shipping, tanker operations, the Navy and the Coast Guard will be among a score of speakers who will discuss maritime safety this week at the National Safety Council's forty-first National Annual Safety Congress and Exposition in Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UP) -- Top military reserve officials said today that a "disappointingly low" number of draftees were joining organized reserve units after completing their active service.

BROADDUS ANDREW JACKSON sits under the whispering Norway maples in Red Hook housing project in Brooklyn, an imposing fellow in a huge purple sweater. His broad chest is a miniature old-fashioned garden of bright-colored campaign ribbons.

The Long Island Rail Road called on the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen yesterday to agree to the elimination of "arbitrary and burdensome" work rules that have increased the line's operating costs. The program was put forward in reply to demands by the union for rule changes that would add an estimated $6,000,000 to the railroad's annual payroll.

Henry Laskau of the 92d Street Y. M. H. A. captured the national Amateur Athletic Union's 15,000-meter walking championship in the Ridgewood section of Brooklyn yesterday. Laskau toured the 9 miles 564 1/6 yards in 1:15:09 to finish nearly 500 yards ahead of John Deni of Pittsburgh.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 18 -- The first group of Jewish businessmen and communal leaders from the United States who had been invited by Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion for an economic planning conference here arrived today.

The joint communique issued in London yesterday at the end of the Big Three Foreign Ministers' Conference, together with the substantially identical notes sent to Moscow by the representatives of the three Governments, indicated the expected Western agreement on essentials.

Reduction in size of New York City's taxicabs, being considered by the City Council, has been opposed by the shipping industry on the grounds that it would result in increased waterfront congestion and higher costs in the handling of steamship passengers.
Rudolph Halley, the Liberal party's nominee for Mayor, centered his fire yesterday on "the machine bosses" of both major political parties.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- More than half of the 55,000,000 individual income taxpayers in the United States can definitely look forward to the Ides of March as just another day.

A sense of "ultimate security" is necessary for every individual, and this desire for security is "even nearer home" than fear for the survival of civilization, the Rev. Dr. Albert J. Penner said yesterday in a sermon at the Broadway Tabernacle Church (Congregational), at Fifty-sixth Street.

BAYONNE, N. J., Oct. 18 -- Surplus and obsolete Navy equipment, ranging from tiny aluminum rivets to three fifty-ton-capacity railroad hopper cars and a $100,000 electric generator, will be sold here Nov. 4. The sale, to be held by the United States Navy Supply Depot's disposal division, will be the largest public auction ever held by the Navy.

Reconstruction has been completed on two bridges on Bruckner Boulevard in the Bronx, both vital links in the city's arterial highway program, Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Zurmuhlen announced yesterday.

SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- A bus strike that threatened to strand 50,000 riders in Rockland County, N. Y., and Bergen County, N. J., was postponed for twenty-four hours today to give state and Federal mediators a chance to work out a peaceful settlement.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- Representatives of thirty countries will meet informally tomorrow to plan how to keep alive the proposal for the creation now of a new international fund for the development of less fortunate lands.

On Wednesday of last week Federal Judge Harold R. Medina filed his opinion in the case of the Government's conspiracy suit against seventeen of the country's leading investment banking firms, thus formalizing his statement of two weeks earlier when he announced he was dismissing the case.

The weather year is full of oddities, those unexpected changes and reverses, misplaced days all out of tone with their season. So much so, one wonders why the strange lazy, sunny phase that follows the first chill of autumn but falls before winter has settled down, why it ever got a name all its own.
A local advertising agency maintains strongly that 48,000,000 Americans are being undersold on wearing apparel.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 18 -- A musical pageant entitled "A Dream and a Promise" opened the thirty-second national convention of the Girl Scouts of the United States of America this afternoon.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- After a survey of the world meat trade, the Commonwealth Economic Committee reported today that British consumption of meat last year averaged eighty-four pounds a person. This was eleven pounds higher than in 1951, but still thirty-five pounds under the pre-war average.
PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Important details have just been issued about the nature and amount of commercial exchanges provided in the accord between France and the Soviet Union for the July, 1953-54, period.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The St. Louis Board of Police Commissioners tonight ordered an investigation of alleged discrepancies in the police reports on the arrest of the Greenlease kidnappers, with special emphasis on the recovery of half of the ransom money.
Three important museum shows are featured in the heaviest week of art exhibitions so far this season.

The ninth national convention of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O. -- its second consecutive "peace and harmony" gathering -- opens this morning in the Manhattan Center in a period of great internal strength.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 18 -- Clarence (Buddy) Combs drove home a goal after 45 seconds of the overtime period to give Long Island a 5-4 victory over Bostwick Field today. It was the final game of the Long Island polo season.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 18 -- Radioactive dust clouds were recorded over Canberra until noon today by instruments installed at the Australian National University. The clouds were estimated to have traveled at forty miles an hour from the atomic testing site west of Woomera where an atomic explosion took place last Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- United States officials took a long look today at the results of the Western Big Three foreign ministers' conference in London and were not highly pleased with what they saw in the import of these results.

MONTREAL, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The International League and the new Baltimore Orioles of the American League reached an agreement today under which the Orioles will pay the triple A circuit $48,749.61 for relinquishing the Baltimore territory.

The problems of two generations getting along together when an elderly mother comes to live with her married daughter were unfolded last week at the first performance of a new play on family living by American Theatre Wing Community Plays.
AMSTERDAM, Oct. 18 -- On Dec. 1 the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company will redeem the balance of the 3 1/2 per cent convertible bond loan at 101 per cent.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 18 -- Two Plainfield lawyers, a 44-year-old Republican and a 33-year-old Democrat, are the relatively unknown contestants in the Sixth Congressional District race here that suddenly has drawn national attention.

The refusal of Chinese and North Korean prisoners of war to return to Soviet domination indicates that communism would be overthrown in the satellite countries "if a free election were allowed," the Rev. Michael J. Deacy declared yesterday.
Henry D. Clark has been appointed sales training manager of the television-radio division of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

With three more rounds to be played in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich, Vassily Smyslov of Russia reached a score of 16 1/2 -- 8 1/2 last night for a two-point lead, according to a Swiss news report. He drew with Svetozar Gligoric of Yugoslavia after twenty-one moves in the twenty-seventh round.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Pillsbury Mills, Inc., launched here this week-end with great fanfare and expense a European recipe service calculated to bring an exotic flavor to United States cooking and baking by introducing into it some of the elements that have made a solid gastronomical reputation for the Old World countries.

BERLIN, Oct. 18 -- Erich Ollenhauer, head of West Germany's Social Democratic party, said today the world was threatened not only by Soviet Communism on the left but also by American "McCarthyism" on the right. He said in a speech written for a meeting of the International Socialist Journalists that democracy would be destroyed if totalitarian methods of fighting communism became dominant.

Shigeru Kaneko, Japanese pianist, was heard in her first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Against a background consisting of a Japanese screen and flower arrangement, the young musician made a charming picture in her colorful kimono and obi.

A double vocation that ties Christian faith to on-the-job situations was urged yesterday morning by Lee H. Bristol Jr., advertising man and vice president of the Laymen's Movement for a Christian World.

A strong steady undertone in the British pound sterling and a late recovery for the Canadian dollar marked the foreign exchange trading during the past week. Business transacted was reported as fairly active.

Recent books and articles show what is beginning to look like a trend. Authors are re-reading history or remembering it after years of forgetfulness. Some of the most criticized offspring of the New Deal are being recognized by the strawberry marks on their left shoulders and claimed as scions of respectable Republicans.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- Ambassador Abba Eban of Israel prepared tonight to submit to the Security Council a counter-claim against Jordan. The Council meets tomorrow to consider the tensions that have arisen between Israel and her Arab neighbors.
BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Oct 18 -- Organized labor lined up with the farmer again last week.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 18 -- Turkey is prepared to provide a site and facilities for a major Allied military base designed to compensate at least in part for a loss of Britain's Suez Canal zone installations.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The stock markets have been much under the influence of conflicting and at times disquieting developments in the last week. An initial setback followed the increase of tension over the situation in Trieste, British Guiana and Egypt and the uneasy peace that is being maintained in Korea.
Concerning some American wild-fruit jams newly arrived at the Maison Glass, 15, East Forty-seventh Street, Alex Manson, the proprietor of that delicacy shop, says:

American life is being stifled by a relatively new "orthodoxy," which asserts that "the individual exists as a servant of the group," William H. Whyte Jr., associate managing editor of Fortune Magazine, declared yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, York Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18 -- There is no longer doubt that steel output this year will set a new high -- and the record is likely to be one that will stand for several years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UP) -- Representative W. Sterling Cole, Chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, said today that any idea that atomic weapons would not be used in the next war probably was "wishful thinking."

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The Rev. Joseph Christie, noted Jesuit polemicist, replied vigorously today to charges of intolerance and oppression made against the Roman Catholic Church last week by the Most Rev. Dr. Geoffrey F. Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury.

The cleavage between medicine and religion that began in the late Middle Ages and reached a climax in the nineteenth century is rapidly being dispelled with the growth of understanding in both fields, the Rev. Dr. Otis Radcliffe Rice, religious director of St. Luke's Hospital, declared yesterday in a sermon at the afternoon service in the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine.)

DETROIT, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Norm Van Brocklin lobbed two touchdown passes and set up another score with his aerial magic to lead the Los Angeles Rams to a 31-19 upset over the champion Detroit Lions today in a National Football League game before 55,772 fans.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 18 -- The first semblance of an organized opposition to the Pakistani Moslem League, which controls the Government, was disclosed today.
Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, declared yesterday that Senator Wicks could "render the greatest service to the public by withdrawing now from his post as Majority Leader."

An explanation for "blighted and decaying areas" in almost all large American cities and suggestions for removing "roadblocks" to replacement of worn-out structures are offered by Miles A. Colean, housing and city planning authority, in a report Twentieth Century Fund is publishing today.
TOKYO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The New York Giants came from behind today for a 5-3 victory over an All-Star team from Japan's Central Professional Baseball League.
TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 19 -- The Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission rejected today new Communist demands that it produce North Korean captives for talks with Red "explainers."

Future prices of cotton in the domestic market moved higher last week. Despite a mild reaction on Friday, all deliveries finished the trading period with net gains. Active options on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 2 to 22 points, or 10 cents to $1.10 a bale. Current crop deliveries made the best showing.
MISSION, Tex., Oct. 18 (AP) -- John Moranz, Dallas artist, said today that President Eisenhower was as good an artist as Sir Winston Churchill "and Churchill is a good artist."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The United States is about to throw open its doors to more than 200,000 distressed and desperate people seeking refuge and a new life on these shores.

The Welfare and Health Council is trying to induce settlement houses in the city to help teenagers discharged from institutions after being treated as narcotics users. At present a few settlement houses are working on the problem but other community centers are disinclined to participate.

Roger Cortesi of Auchincloss, Parker Redpath, New York; Walter Maynard of Shearson, Hammill Co., New York, and Sewell S. Watts Jr. of Baker, Watts Co., Baltimore, are the only incumbents nominated by the Association of Stock Exchange Firms to stand for re-election to its board.

The key contract in the construction of the $90,000,000 third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel -- driving of the bore under the Hudson River -- has been awarded jointly to three companies, low bidders at $17,260,370.

Three candidates for Borough President of Manhattan outlined their plans for handling the borough's problems at a breakfast meeting yesterday of the Men's Club of the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street.

The National Labor Relations Board gave the go-ahead signal yesterday for court action to prohibit the old International Longshoremen's Association from interfering with the organizing activities of its American Federation of Labor rival.
Lured by the pastel autumn foliage and the cool dry air, thousands of New Yorkers took to the highways yesterday in a mass escape from the city where they will soon be locked in winter hibernation.

The Paris, a twenty-five-story residential hotel on plot 100 by 100 feet at the southeast corner of West End Avenue and Ninety-seventh Street, has been purchased by Nathan Wilson from Ivor B. Clark and the Knott Hotels Corporation in a deal negotiated by Cornelius F. Sullivan of the Charles F. Noyes Company.

CEBU, Philippines, Oct. 18 -- The issue of United States intervention in the Philippine election campaign was expanded and partly clarified by President Elpidio Quirino in a speech last night. The President received polite applause from a crowd of several thousand persons in the town plaza.

EVER since the bottom fell out of Army football a couple of years ago, cadet well-wishers looked toward the Navy game with feelings of trepidation. They were sure that the West Pointers would be badly outmanned and outclassed. They need feel that way no longer. Red Blaik has achieved a modern coaching miracle. The sandy-haired genius of the Plains is operating far, far ahead of schedule.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UP) -- The Cleveland Browns, rallying behind the clutch passing of Otto Graham, exploded for 17 points in the fourth quarter today and walloped the Washington Redskins 30 -- 14, before a crowd of 33,963.
Useful objects for the kitchen, together with a variety of decorative pieces for the home, are on view in new ceramic exhibits.
BOSTON, Oct. 18 -- Daniel Bloomfield is a quiet man. His name rarely appears in the newspapers.

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The United States, Britain and France urged Russia today to attend a foreign ministers' conference that Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said "might" lead to a meeting of the heads of the four Governments. A conference of these heads of government had been sought by Sir Winston Churchill, the Prime Minister.

Plans for improving within the next year the entire undeveloped portion of the 1,258-acre Flushing Meadow Park in Queens have been disclosed by the Park Department. Only a part of the tract is now in use as a park.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 18 -- President Marshal Tito stressed today that the Yugoslav Army would not fire on United States and British soldiers in the Trieste area. But he remained firm behind his statement of last week that if Italian troops entered Zone A of Trieste, Yugoslav troops would do so too.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 18 -- Two brothers, one the Attorney General of the United States and the other the United States Commissioner of Education, agreed today to go into partnership. But it is to be an unusual type of arrangement.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- The possibility that new farm legislation to replace the present law, which expires at the end of 1954, will provide for continued high support levels inspired a lot of buying on the grain markets last week. The Administration's program is still a matter of conjecture, which was not cleared up by the President's speech at Kansas City on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Foreign assistance by the United States, expanded through increased military aid, totaled $7,030,000,000 for the 1953 fiscal year ended June 30. This was the highest amount of foreign assistance since World War II.

" CAN I help it if I find mankind take an affection for me at once?" The young man who wrote those words of frank self-approval was only repeating a thought that occurred to him frequently. Nearly every day he wrote down in his journal some similar tribute to his own merits. No more vain, snobbish and smugly boastful man ever lived.

As your readers may or may not be aware, the proposed Washington Square Southeast development plan has been sharply criticized in its present form by most of the informed citizens and civic organizations of the Greenwich Village area. It would appear, then, that as a consequence the plan as drawn may well be tabled by either the City Planning Commission or the Board of Estimate.
ORSON WELLES withstood last night the demanding rigors of television infinitely better than his vehicle, "King Lear."

Nine leaders in various fields have accepted the invitation of Robert Saudek, director of the Ford Foundation's TV-Radio Workshop, to serve on an advisory board and help chart the course of the workshop. They are:

A parade along Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon, followed by a religious service in honor of the American flag, constituted the thirty-second annual "Massing of the Colors" under the auspices of the New York chapter of the Military Order of the World Wars.
PENN YAN, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- College students at the second annual Family Life Conference at Keuka College agreed that higher education should put more stress on guidance for married life.

Rabbi Irving Block of the Village Temple, which is housed in the Village Presbyterian Church in Thirteenth Street near Seventh Avenue, preached for the Presbyterian congregation yesterday morning a sermon he used Friday night for his own Reform congregation.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 18 -- Israel instructed her United Nations delegation today to request the United Nations Security Council to consider a complaint that Arab states, particularly Jordan, had committed a series of breaches of armistice agreements by violence and murder in border regions.

When Presidents meet it is a historic occasion and in the nature of things a friendly one. The hands that are being stretched across the Rio Grande today when the Falcon Dam is dedicated by Presidents Eisenhower and Ruiz Cortines are symbolic of the good relations that now exist between the United States and Mexico.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Some Democratic Senators are preparing to question President Eisenhower's appointment of Robert E. Lee as a member of the Federal communications commission.
State Senator Arthur H. Wicks defended yesterday his visits to Joseph S. Fay, labor extortionist, in Sing Sing Prison.
Russia has become one of Italy's best textile customers.

The New York Americans defeated the Philadelphia Americans, 4 to 1, at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, yesterday and, strengthened their hold on first place in the American Soccer League standing. They held a 3-1 lead at half-time. The highlight of the game was a hat trick by Harry Quigley, New York's outside left.

" The Marriage of Figaro" has always been one of the New York City Opera's best productions, and last night, when the company presented the Mozart masterpiece for the first time this fall, its well-devised English version was as fresh and adorable as ever.

Scoring twice in the first half, Iona Prep of New Rochelle, defeated Cardinal Hayes of the Bronx, 13 -- 7, at Randall's Island, yesterday before 3,000 spectators. Iona has now won twice and tied once, while Hayes has lost two of three starts.
LONDON, Oct. 18 (UP) -- The test of a statement today by the United States, British and French foreign ministers at the close of a conference here:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A slowdown in defense plant expansion was reflected today in government approval of only 54 programs for federal tax benefits.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 18 -- Scientific advancement in the production of textiles from synthetic fibers and engineered fabrics has resulted in the expansion of technological education. Such education provides employes who can handle new machinery, adapt improvements to individual mills and translate research developments into production volume.

The friendly surroundings of the Polo Grounds apparently made a difference as the New York Football Giants, who had known only defeat on the road, made their first start at home yesterday and whipped the Chicago Cardinals, 21 -- 7. It was not an overly impressive victory, but a 1-3 record looks lots better than 0-4 and Steve Owen's men had reached the win-or-else stage in the National Football League.

Saturday evening's "La Traviata" had two singers in leading roles for the first time. Jean Fenn sang Violetta and Riccardo Manning was heard as Alfredo. Other singers, previously heard in this opera, were Cornell MacNeil, Mary Le-Sawyer, Mary Kreste, Luigi Vellucci, Donald Gramm, Emile Renan and Leon Lishner.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Oct. 18 -- The mix-up in the telecast of Senator Arthur H. Wicks' speech today heavily overshadowed here the reaction to what he said. This city, Mr. Wicks' home, is the seat of his power.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- The Western Big Three Foreign Ministers were still trying, at their adjournment today, to get the Italian and Yugoslav Governments into a five-power conference on Trieste.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 18 (AP) -- The champions of the Big Seven and Atlantic Coast conferences -- probably Oklahoma and Maryland -- will meet in the Orange Bowl football game here next New Year's Day.
Fifty-seven college football teams throughout the nation boasted unbeaten and untied records today following a week-end that erased twenty-four teams from the list.

A four-engined Eastern Air Lines plane with twenty-seven persons aboard crashed and was destroyed by flames as it was taking off in a fog early today at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, killing at least three persons and injuring eighteen.

Edward C. Maguire, campaign director for Mayor Impellitteri, candidate of the Experience party, declared yesterday that supporters of Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic Mayoralty candidate, were using "Communist and Nazi tactics" in trying to invalidate the Mayor's independent nominating petitions.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (UP) -- Joe Perry, the National Football League's leading ground gainer, scored three touchdowns today as the San Francisco 49ers overcame a 21-point deficit to beat the Chicago Bears, 35 -- 28, before 40,740 fans.

Followers of football at Phillips Exeter will have to look far back in the academy's history to uncover a squad that has made as imposing a start as the present Red and Gray eleven. Three successive one-sided victories already have been posted by Exeter's seventy-third team.

ALBANY, Oct. 18 -- Governor Dewey's counsel took sharp issue tonight with a statement by Senator Arthur H. Wicks that a bill he had sponsored in 1944 would have barred "the criminal element" from the state's race tracks if Mr. Dewey had not vetoed it.

DALLAS, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A majority of the minor leagues voted today for better representation in making the rules of baseball, favored an unrestricted draft and asked for a return to control of major league broadcasts and telecasts in minor league territory.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, has been fighting communism in a "consistently sensible fashion" and in "strict accord with American tradition," the Rev. Florence D. Cohalan, Professor of History at Cathedral College, declared yesterday.

In 1804 Thomas Jefferson commissioned Meriwether Lewis and William Clark to explore the newly purchased Louisiana Territory. They kept journals of their voyage up the Missouri, across the Rockies and down to the Pacific Coast at the mouth of the Columbia River.

TIMMINS, Ont., Oct. 18 -- This forest-ringed community, center of the great Porcupine gold-mining region, with 40,000 inhabitants, faces an uncertain future in a country whose growth and prosperity have been unequaled in the post-war world.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The State Department said tonight that "the United States Government has been increasingly concerned at the mounting tension along the frontier between Israel and the neighboring Arab states."

BOSTON, Oct. 18 (UP) -- Defenseman Bob Armstrong, scoring his first goal in sixty-one regular season National Hockey League games, sparked the Boston Bruins to a 3 -- 2 victory tonight over the New York Rangers. The Bruins moved into a fourth-place tie in the league.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 18 (UP) -- The Green Bay Packers snapped a three-game losing streak today as they rolled over the Baltimore Colts, 37 -- 14.

Dr. Joseph B. Cavallaro, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, urged yesterday that the teaching of American history be required in all tax-supported city schools and colleges, and that there be a return to the teaching of religious values on a-non-dogmatic basis.

WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Mrs. Arden Young Bardwell, 43 years old, of Weston, a former New York actress, was killed early today when a car driven by her husband crashed head on into a tree on North Main Street. Her husband, Charles Moore Bardwell, is in Norwalk Hospital with a fractured skull, broken ribs and internal injuries.

" The Girl in Pink Tights" now has a home. It will be the Hellinger, where the musical is scheduled to be examined by first-nighters on Feb. 25. Starred in the Joseph Fields-Jerome Chodorov-Sigmund Romberg-Leo Robin show will be Jeanmaire and Charles Goldner.

In honor of the splendid public service furnished by the Brooklyn Public Library, Borough President Cashmore has proclaimed the week of Oct. 19 to 24 as Brooklyn Public Library Week. During that week the Library will put on display at its main building and in its fifty branches the activities which have made the Brooklyn Public Library a leader in its field.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Federal Housing Administrator Albert M. Cole tonight took issue with a criticism that President Eisenhower's advisory committee on housing is "heavily weighted" with opponents of low-rent dwellings.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 18 -- Eliashev Ben-Horin, attache of the Israeli Embassy, asserted here tonight that "all too often" excuses had Been found for unprovoked Arab aggression against Israel, but that now the nation was being "promptly hauled before an international tribunal" for the razing of a village in Jordan by Israeli troops or vigilantes.

World diplomats, addressing the opening session of the twenty-second annual New York Herald Tribune Forum in the General Assembly Hall of the United Nations, pleaded last night for greater public support for the world organization.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 18 -- Once-beaten St. Peter's Prep dropped Demarest High of Hoboken from New Jersey's undefeated schoolboy football ranks today when it posted a 14-0 victory at Roosevelt Stadium. It was Demarest's first setback in four starts.
Westchester and Nassau County prosecutors will question witnesses today in an effort to obtain information on alleged shakedown of employes at Yonkers and Roosevelt raceways.

ABOARD THE S. S. NIEUW AMSTERDAM, en route to Cuba, Oct. 18 -- The development of savings banking in New York State requires authority to expand into "new, fast-growing areas," but the bankers have an obligation to make full use of those public service powers already granted by the Legislature.

DETROIT, Oct. 18 (UP) -- Goalie Terry Sawchuk returned to the Detroit line-up tonight and shut out the Montreal Canadiens, 4 to 0, as the Red Wings moved into first place in the National Hockey League.

ROME, Oct. 18 -- Secrecy was maintained today as to the nature of the proposals for a solution of the Trieste problem made to Italy and Yugoslavia by the foreign ministres of the United States, Britain and France.

ZURICH, Oct. 18 -- Dr. F. A. Lutz, professor of economics at the University of Zurich, up to a few months ago associated with Princeton University, addressed an assembly of bankers, business men and economists Wednesday on "the convertibility of European currencies."
Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

When one's firm convictions on the subject of world peace differ so radically from the frequently expressed equally firm views of most informed Americans, duty requires a public statement of the problem.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $80,288,979,010. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 18 -- Martin Melcher, husband of Doris Day, has formed an independent producing company and will make a number of films for release by Warner Brothers, Jack L. Warner, studio head, announced today.
An imported hound-marked wirehaired foxterrier, Ch. Travella Superman of Harham, became best in show yesterday in the event of the Queensboro Kennel Club in Jamaica.
FALCON HEIGHTS, Tex., Oct. 18 -- The Falcon Dam is planned as the first phase of a multi-million-dollar international conservation, irrigation and power project to transform the Rio Grande Valley.

A bleak outlook on housing and a costly future in schools loom ahead for the next city administration, a survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES showed yesterday. With dissatisfaction in both fields helping to push 75,000 New Yorkers a year to the suburbs, the political campaign is bringing out varying ideas on how to make the city a better place in which to live.

HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 18 -- Gen. Rene Cogny, commander of French Union forces in northern Indo-China, said today his plan in starting an offensive into enemy territory in Vietnam was to force the Vietminh to fight or, at least, to destroy supply depots.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Monday, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Offshore procurement contracts awarded European nations during the fiscal 1953, ended last June 30, totaled $1,596,000,000, the United States Army's European Headquarters here announced today.

The Citizens Union made public yesterday a letter to Mayor Impellitteri offering to him a final opportunity to appear on its "Searchlight" program, which is broadcast Sunday afternoons over WNBC. Mr. Impellitteri is the only candidate for Mayor who has not appeared or been scheduled to appear since the primary election.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- New Yorkers rated well down the list in the number of times they were present and voting on roll calls during the first session of the Eighty-third Congress.

Since her debut in 1940, good taste has marked the work of Doris Trotman, and that virtue was much in evidence late yesterday afternoon when she returned to Town Hall to give her first recital there in four years. There was taste in the selection of her material, in her manner of singing and in her sensitive interpretations.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 18 (AP) -- New Orleans' recent gift to Notre Dame, Halfback John Petitbon, scored twice today as the Quantico Marines' more mature football team knocked Holy Cross out of the undefeated ranks with a 17-0 victory.

A large tract in the estate section of Glen Cove, L. I., has been sold by the Elsinore Realty Corporation to Morwand Homes, Inc., for improvement with seventy-six dwellings in split-level design. The property, known as Shorecrest on the Sound, is on Landing Road, just north of Morgan's Memorial Beach.

" America's Hope: Youth With Faith" is an inspiring theme for National Catholic Youth Organization Week, which will be observed here in New York City and in the rest of the country from Oct. 18 to 25. Some 200,000 city boys, girls, young men and young women will be part of the 6,000,000 throughout the nation who will participate in the event.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor, declined last night to name the "high political figure" he said had tried to get Joseph S. Fay, labor leader convicted of extortion, out of Sing Sing Prison. He repeated his demand that Governor Dewey order the State Parole Board to make public the names of those who interceded in Fay's behalf.

The autumn has come now, and in every household in the world there are the first preliminary stirrings of the general unrest known as Fall Cleaning. Nothing will prevent this running its full course from A to Z, that being from cellar to attic, for the cleaning is as much a traditional part of the autumn as are the turning leaves.

Recent bargaining sessions involving the C. I. O.'s giant auto and steel workers' unions make it clear that general adoption of a guaranteed annual wage stands high on the list of pressing labor goals. According to union leaders, all they are asking is that employers promise workers some minimum level of income each year to pay their grocery bills, doctors' bills, rent and of her necessary expenses.

Harold Riegelman, the Republican candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday that Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., was supporting Robert F. Wagner Jr., the Democratic candidate, in the hope of getting "a green light from the city to make the police a local of the Transport Workers Union."

Home Properties, Inc., operators, sold the four-story house for eight families at 866 Kelly Street in the Bronx to a client of Benjamin Liebov, attorney. Jacob S. Lampert was the attorney for the seller of the parcel, which is assessed at $25,000.

Dedication of the recently completed Carnegie Endowment International Center on First Avenue at Forty-sixth Street will take place at 1:30 P. M. today on the esplanade at United Nations Plaza and Forty-seventh Street. Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, Sir Cedric Hardwicke and Dorothy Maynor will be among the participants.

After a month of steady, though slight improvement in the ship chartering field -- both in rates and in the number of vessels -- the gloom that has enveloped ship brokers for months was dissipated last week.

There is usually an oversupply of amendments to the State constitution to be voted on at the November elections and this year is no exception. We recommend a yes vote on all the nine amendments that will be on the voting machine Nov. 3. These propositions have, as required, been approved by two separate Legislatures.

Moving uptown from its previous location in the Circle-in-the Square, the Collegium Musicum, under the direction of Fritz Rikko, presented the first of three concerts late yesterday afternoon at the Carl Fischer Hall.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Oct. 19 -- The Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission is critically close to disbanding and leaving to an uncertain fate the remaining prisoners of the Korean war.

Business management should begin now to prepare uniform standards of health, safety, manufacture and operation to fit the coming electrone and atomic energy revolution in industry, according to Roger E. Gay, president of the American Standards Association.

John Casella, a Columbia tackle, and Cliff Coughlin, a Hofstra end, were among the ten players nominated yesterday as the "unsung heroes" in last week-end's games by the Eastern Intercollegiate Football Association. Also cited were Pennsylvania's Jack Shanafelt, a tackle, and George Welsh, a substitute quarterback at Navy.

FALCON DAM, Tex., Oct. 19 -- More than twenty persons, including some of Mexico's top newspaper reporters and entertainers, were believed killed in an airplane crash today while en route to the meeting of United States President Eisenhower and Mexican President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines.
