BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 19 -- The Yugoslav Government was represented today as not being adamant on its past proposals for settlement of the Trieste dispute. These include an offer by President Tito to accept Italian sovereignty over the city of Trieste if Yugoslavia obtained the rest of the Free Territory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Diplomatic officials believe the latest note from Peiping represents an acceptance of United States proposals for preliminary talks at Panmunjom on a Korean peace conference. Accordingly, plans to have United States representatives there next Monday went forward.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, said today the United States, with superiority in atomic weapons, could assault the Soviet Union from its ring of bases around the Russian empire.

Proposals of the City Planning Commission to cut the 1954 capital expenditures for new school construction from $101,560,000 to $70,158,274, reducing the number of new schools in the year from twenty-nine to nineteen, came under the heavy fire of the Board of Education yesterday.

The Arabian American Oil Company (Aramco) declared yesterday that about 13,000 of its 15,000 Saudi Arabian employes had been on a general strike since Saturday in protest over the arrest of a group that had been attempting to organize a union in violation of Saudi Arabian law.
A questionnaire checking on all aspects of trotting track operations in the state was made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- There seems to be something special about the representatives of the people from Wisconsin -- a cantankerous quality, a weakness for the political hot-foot, a gift for creating trouble among the leaders of the Republican party.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- A special unit of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations set out today to determine whether espionage through Communist infiltration in this Government had been responsible for the currency engraving mystery.

Investigations began yesterday into the plane crash shortly after midnight at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, in which two persons were killed. More than a dozen were injured, at least five of them seriously, in the accident.
The last trade show to be held in Grand Central Palace got under way yesterday at 1 P. M.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Oct. 19 -- Disunity in the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission and confusion over the prisoners of the Korean war have overshadowed the problem of 359 Allied captives who have refused repatriation.

IF any one play of the past week-end created conversation among the football fraternity, it was the left-handed forward pass by Pete Vann of Army against Duke. Hemmed in on the right side by surging Duke tacklers, Vann switched the ball to his left hand and hit Fred Attaya with a pass that went for a 17-yard gain.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UP) -- People begin to grow old at about the age of 30, but they are living longer all the time, an expert on old age said today.
BOSTON, Oct. 19 -- A number of leaders in the country's business and industrial life put the national economy under a microscope today and came up with these reports:
Ewfim Geller, 28-year-old player from Odessa, won both of his adjourned games yesterday, in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich, according to a Swiss news report.
ABOARD THE S. S. NIEUW AMSTERDAM, Oct. 19 -- New York's savings bankers were warned officially today against competing for deposits by increasing interest dividend rates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Supreme Court refused today to review an appeal by the International Workers Order, Inc., a fraternal insurance organization, from a New York State order requiring its liquidation on the ground that it was a creature of the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Ambassador Abba Eban of Israel called at the State Department twice today to urge the United States to hear the "full story" of the Israeli-Arab situation before taking a stand one way or the other.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- The United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee adopted today a resolution that duplicated one adopted last year in urging a reduction in tension in French Morocco.
A system that will provide psychologically oriented social service to every new case in Manhattan's Children's Court will be initiated tomorrow.
Handy Harman, refiner and fabricator of precious metals, paid tribute last night to its vice president and treasurer, Howard W. Boynton, on the occasion of his fiftieth anniversary with the company.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 19 -- West Germany's foreign policy remains postulated on the hope that a European Defense Community will be established soon. But if the treaty providing for such a supranational military and political organization is not ratified by France or the other proposed members, the Bonn Government would like to see the swift enactment of a direct alliance between the United States and West Germany.
New York's water cargo tonnage in 1952 was 11,000,000 tons less than the year before, but at least half of the loss was attributed to completion of the New Jersey Turnpike.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Department of Justice has asked the Supreme Court to review a Court of Appeals ruling that overturned anti-monopoly proceedings by the Federal Reserve Board against Transamerica Corporation, a California banking and investment company.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- Representatives of seventeen smaller nations agreed today to push the proposal for a new international economic development fund.
Holders of Class "A" stock of R. Hoe Co., Inc., have requested a special meeting, their "protective committee" announced yesterday.

The speech of Gen. Otto L. Nelson Jr. at the meeting of the American Society of Planning Officials is reported in THE TIMES of Oct. 13 as emphasizing the need for drastic measures to erase slums and end traffic strangulations as a matter of simple survival against atomic attack.

SANDS POINT, L. I., Oct. 19 -- After being runner-up for the title six times, Jack Mallon of the Cold Spring Country Club won the Long Island Professional Golfers Association championship today at the Sands Point G. C.

The parent-counseling service of the Child Study Association of America, 132 East Seventy-fourth Street, is now ready to expand its activity by arranging appointments directly with parents, the organization announced yesterday.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 19 (AP) -- A flood of foreign oil into the United States is robbing the producers of Texas of $983,400 daily in revenue, a Texan said today.

Bert Bell, the commissioner of the National Football League, which has been accused of being "a conspiracy" because of its television policy, reiterated yesterday his belief that the Government's charge would not be upheld. The case is in the hands of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia.
Advocates of fair trade were jubilant over the Supreme Court decision. Business elements that have fought for free retail pricing were silent.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- Several hours after Bao Dai had hailed the identity of views between himself and the National Congress in Saigon, Prince Buu Loc, his envoy in Saigon, returned here with a motion of the principal leaders of the Congress expressing refusal to dissolve and demanding that the Congress be turned into a constituent assembly.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Britain's Parliament will reconvene tomorrow, after an eleven-week recess, with the Government facing questions and Opposition criticism on two major issues.

White Skies gave another demonstration of class yesterday. The 4-year-old colt, owned by William Wickham, competed against nine others in the New Rochelle Handicap at the Jamaica Race Track, and had no trouble winning, by almost three lengths, in a six-furlong sprint.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Publicly reported dividend payments by corporations were 6 per cent higher last month than in the same month of last year.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 19 -- Dr. Mordechai Nurock, member of Israel's Knesset (Parliament), said here tonight that Israel was "on the offensive, not the defensive" in the current dispute over border violations between the Jewish state and Jordan now being considered by the United Nations Security Council.

A bill to permit permanent personal registration will be presented at the next regular session of the State Legislature, Assemblyman J. Eugene Goddard, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee to Study the Election Law and Related Matters, said yesterday.

NUEVO GUERRERO, Mexico, Oct. 19 -- President Eisenhower left the United States today for the first time since he took office and for an hour he enjoyed himself in a setting that blended old and modern Mexico at its best.
Among economical choices in fruit is canned pineapple, which is ever the cook's faithful friend because it comes in so many styles adapted to so many different serving methods.

A shortage of properly trained salesmen as well as of top-flight sales executives is facing the chemical industry, which at the same time badly needs "creative" selling. This was the gist of talks by speakers yesterday at the second chemical sales clinic arranged by the Salesmen's Association of the American Chemical Industry at the Commodore Hotel.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 19 -- Superior Court Judge John B. McGeehan ruled today that the names of four Republican candidates may be listed on the voting machines for the Nov. 3 general election, though they were selected seven days after the lapse of a deadline he himself imposed.

Rudolph Halley, Liberal party candidate for Mayor, proposed yesterday a nine-point program he said would keep city employes from leaving their jobs in record numbers and improve morale and working conditions.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, promised last night a program of 45,000 new or reconstructed homes each year for five years if he became Mayor. For the next five years after that, he said, he wouldl step up or relax the building program depending upon the needs.

Capitalizing on his speed, Floyd Patterson, unbeaten Brooklyn fighter, gained a unanimous decision over Wes Bascom, light-heavy-weight from East St. Louis, Ill., in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- The United Nations Security Council decided today to summon back Maj. Gen. Vagn Bennike, truce supervision chief in Palestine, for a first-hand account of the rising tensions between Israel and her Arab neighbors.

On Oct. 1 I appeared as a member of a panel discussion sponsored by the Protestant Council of the City of New York at the Riverside Church on the subject "The Place of Religion in the Total Education of the Child." I was one of four members of the panel. My theme was "The Place of Religion in the Community."

Reporting on United States Prisons Director James V. Bennett's speech before the American Prison Association in Toronto Oct. 12, Murray Illson, NEW YORK TIMES correspondent, wrote: "Mr. Bennett took issue with 'armchair criminologists' who have contended that wartime battle experiences predispose veterans to commit violent criminal acts."

Great Britain's equestrian team, the winner of the 1952 Olympic Games competition, arrived yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, to praticipate in the sixty-fifth National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden, Nov. 3 to 10.

ALBANY, Oct. 19 -- The state's Democratic leadership has decided to follow a "hands off" policy on the issue of Senator Arthur H. Wicks' fitness for legislative leadership if the matter should come to a floor vote in the Senate when the lawmakers convene for a special session here on Nov. 17.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art, closed since Oct. 10 by a labor dispute, ordered 170 striking guards yesterday to return to work by Friday morning or forfeit their jobs.

Operating revenues of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation exceeded $202,000,000 and net income reached $25,472,606 in the twelve months to Sept. 30, Earle J. Machold, president, announced today. This was equal to $2 a share on an average 11,306,036 shares of common stock.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority has drafted a $121,000,000 program under which water of the Jordan River system would be used to provide irrigation and electric power for Jordan, Syria and Israel.

The President must now face the very tough problem of amendments to the Taft-Hartley Act, an issue clouded with controversy stemming from former Secretary Durkin's resignation. I want to propose what seems to me a constructive method of approaching this problem.

X-ray examinations of Bill Albright's knee and Emlen Tunnell's chest revealed no fractures yesterday and the Giants expect both to be available for Sunday's meeting with the undefeated Cleveland Browns at the Polo Grounds.
Beware of instituting profit-sharing plans unless you are reasonably sure there will always be profits to share, an economist warned yesterday.

John J. (Gene) Sampson, long a leader of insurgent forces in the old International Longshoremen's Association, swung over last night to the new dock union chartered by the American Federation of Labor.
The Queens sewer case caved in yesterday.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- Jack Lyons, titleholder at Sands Point, toured the Westchester Country Club's par-72 championship West course in 32, 34 -- 66 today to gain a lead of 6 strokes at the half-way point in The New York Herald-Tribune's second annual golf tournament of champions.

ST. LOUIS Oct. 19 (AP) -- The policeman whose work led to the solution of the Greenlease kidnapping case today became the central figure himself in an inquiry into reports the Federal Bureau of Investigation had discovered discrepancies in police accounts of the case.

ROME, Oct. 19 -- Official sources said today that Premier Giuseppe Pella had decided to resign because of the attitude toward the Trieste problem assumed by the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France in their London meeting. However, he has deferred his resignation.
TOKYO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The text of a message today from Communist China and North Korea to the United States and the United Nations on proposed discussions for the Korean peace conference:

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19 -- Establishment of an International Council of Free Asia to pool the economic resources of the free countries of the Far East and thus combat communism was called for today by Senator William F. Knowland of California.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UP) -- Kevin McCann, president of Defiance College at Defiance Ohio, arrived at the White House today to join President Eisenhower's staff, possibly as a speechwriting consultant.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 19 -- Henry L. Hopkinson, British Minister of State for Colonial Affairs, arrived here today to investigate the political crisis that led to dismissal of six elected ministers on charges they planned a Communist regime here.

Among the nine amendments to be voted on Nov. 3 the one most seriously affecting New York City is No. 8, which would permit the city, with the Legislature's approval, to tax real estate 2 1/2 per cent of the five-year average of full value of taxable property, instead of the present 2 per cent.
A despondent husband, grieving over the wife who had abandoned him and his two young daughters, shot himself at 9 P. M. last night in the midst of crowded Times Square.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 19 -- Iran today received $4,700,000, the second installment of United States emergency financial aid, amid signs that the monetary difficulties that threatened to stall the economic program had been temporarily surmounted.

TRENTON, Oct. 19 -- Augustus C. Studer, counsel to the legislative committee that investigated the summary dismissal last January of Deputy Attorney General Nelson F. Stamler, will tender his resignation at the next meeting of the group, it was learned here tonight.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- The Dunwoodie team of Andy Macko, the professional, and Nick Washenko carded a best-ball 32, 32 -- 64 for the par 70 route at Quaker Ridge today to win the final pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association season by a stroke.

The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago eventually may give gas properties of its Public Service Division to its own stockholders. The division supplies both electricity and gas in a large suburban area of northern Illinois, outside Chicago.
As it enters its final two weeks, this year's mayoral campaign is noteworthy for its departures from the traditions and practices of past elections.

Father Thomas F. Carey and Father Robert A. Morris, who control the destinies of the Blackfriars Guild, have reason to offer a special prayer of thanksgiving this morning. For, to start their thirteenth season, the Blackfriars have come up with an enjoyable script and a child actress who contributes a beguiling performance.

The early days of the Russian revolution are the subject of a book by I. N. Steinberg entitled "In the Workshop of the Revolution." With the death of Stalin, Mr. Steinberg became the last survivor of Lenin's first and only coalition cabinet, in which the writer served as the first Soviet Commissar of Justice.
Michigan State, seeking its second straight national college football championship, moved closer to Notre Dame in The United Press ratings released yesterday.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 19 -- A centralized recruiting system for all the armed services to eliminate waste and inequities in military service was urged here today by Brig. Gen. Lewis H. Renfrow, deputy director of the Selective Service System.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Bill Veeck, sporting a smile as wide as the open collar of his sports shirt, today gave thanks to P. K. Wrigley, owner of the Chicago Cubs and Los Angeles Angels, for getting him back into baseball.
YONKERS, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Berty York, a 5-year-old mare, overtook Noble Dean in the last 5 yards at Yonkers Raceway tonight to win the featured Bronx Pace.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Supreme Court refused today to hear an appeal from lower court decisions holding the Louisiana Fair Trade Law and the McGuire Act, a Federal statute, constitutional.

CHESHIRE, Conn., Oct. 19 -- "They're out to get us." That was the opening statement by Coach George James today in a brief talk to his Cheshire Academy football squad before sending it through a 100-minute drill. "I hear the Uconns have their best freshman team in years," he continued, "and are going to let us have it if they can."
Three of the candidates for Mayor agreed here yesterday that the Times Square sector needed to be improved. They differed somewhat, however, in their approaches to the subject.

James Wright Brown came to this city a good many years ago, as it now seems, with a record of successful newspaper experience behind him, beginning as a newspaper delivery boy in Detroit and proceeding through the ranks until he was able to buy a controlling interest in a publication now known as Editor Publisher.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- The National Safety Council received a Federal charter today.

Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., criticized President Eisenhower yesterday on merchant marine problems. He also declared his opposition to a "government hiring hall controlled by politicians" for New York waterfront workers.

A miscellany of new food products, procedures and events is considered in today's column. Subjects range from an innovation in packaging for baked apples to a series of foreign cookery demonstrations to be given this week at Bloomingdale's.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Margaret Harshaw, soprano from the Metropolitan Opera Company in New York, made her local debut tonight as Bruennhilde in Wagner's "Die Walkuere." The full-length opera in German opened the season at the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden.

Relationships between American industry and art, and the influence of mechanization on cultural values in the United States were considered yesterday by speakers at the twenty-second annual New York Herald Tribune Forum, held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The opinion that the Republic of Korea will not resume the fight against the Communist armies was expressed yesterday by Gen. Mark W. Clark in a brief interview at Governors Island. The former head of the United Nations Far East Command received military honors, including a guard of honor and a seventeen-gun salute, when he called on Lieut. Gen. Withers A. Burress, First Army commander.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- The Wicks case looms large in the background of the Mayoralty campaign here, where in three consecutive elections Oscar V. Newkirk, a Republican, has won the City Hall post by 244, 240 and 756 votes.

CARLISLE, Pa., Oct. 19 (AP) -- James P. Warburg, retired New York banker and author of books on economics and world affairs, called today for a "policy of liberation" in foreign affairs aimed at "helping the so-called free world to make itself truly free."

CINCINNATI, Oct. 19 -- Though we live in the atomic age, "in our science of human relations we have not learned how to put two and two together to make four," Dr. Ethel J. Alphenfels, Professor of Education at New York university, said today at the thirty-second national convention of the Girl Scouts of the U. S. A.
Dedicatory ceremonies were held yesterday afternoon for the new $5,000,000 center erected by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace on First Avenue.

George Shapiro, Governor Dewey's counsel, demanded yesterday that Robert F. Wagner Jr., the Democratic candidate for Mayor, produce "forthwith" the name of the important national Republican figure alleged to have interceded for the parole of Joseph S. Fay, convicted labor extortionist, or publicly retract the accusation.

Mayor Impellitteri boasted in a televised political speech last night that his administration had added greatly to the city's hospital facilities and had developed new weapons to combat disease and illness while taking all necessary measures to preserve the public health.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Paced by an upturn in soybeans, all grain futures on the Board of Trade made gains today. In some deliveries high prices for the crop season were registered for soybeans, with further commission accumulation indicated.

The 23,000-ton Greek luxury liner Olympia is to sail today from Southampton, England, on her maiden voyage to this country. The 612-foot vessel is expected to cross the Atlantic at a speed of twenty-one knots, bringing her here on Oct. 29.

KINGSVILLE, Tex., Oct. 19 -- The country's largest cattle empire, the King Ranch, began celebrating its 100th birthday today with a series of discussions on a subject to which its owners have devoted most of their interest for many years.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 19 -- One of the little known phases of the pull and tug over farm problems involves soil conservation.
FALCON DAM, Tex., Oct. 19 -- The President of the United States and the President of Mexico dedicated Falcon Dam on the Rio Grande today as a new bond of goodwill between their nations.
Sales and earnings of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. in the nine months ended with last September continued to climb.

BOSTON, Oct. 19 -- The United States could build a continental early air raid warning screen for less than $370,000,000, it was disclosed over the week-end. The annual operating cost was placed at about $100,000,000.
CORTLAND, N. Y., Oct. 19 -More Pakistan talk was heard, and more Pakistan flags flew, in this town today than any place this side of Karachi, half a world away.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The United Nations Administrative Tribunal in session here has awarded compensation totaling $48,230 to four members of the United Nations Secretariat dismissed by former Secretary General Trygve Lie after they had refused to answer questions about alleged Communist connections.

OTTAWA, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Canadian Government sold a $700,000,000 bond issue in thirty minutes today. Finance Minister Douglas C. Abbott reported that the loan, offered to investors through dealers and banks, had been "heavily oversubscribed."

The Tropic Shop and the Grand Central Wicker Shop have formed a merger and have leased the former Ovington store at 437-439 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Thirty-ninth Street, which will be used for the retail sale of rattan furniture and house furnishings.

DETROIT, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Kaiser Motors Corporation today reported a net loss of $10,796,574 for the six months ended June 30. Kaiser said the figure, only one announced, includes an undisclosed profit by its newly acquired subsidiary, Willys Motors, Inc.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Vietnam's National Congress demanded today that Bao Dai, Chief of State, make it a constitutional assembly that would draw up a charter limiting his powers.

Nathaniel Benchley's new comedy, "The Frogs of Spring," will open this evening at 8 o'clock at the Broadhurst Theatre. Leading roles in the play will be acted by Anthony Ross, Hiram Sherman, Haila Stoddard and Barbara Baxley.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 20 -- The Chinese and North Korean Communists have accepted a United States proposal to meet at Panmunjom, Korea, next Monday to arrange for a Korean peace conference.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 19 -- Cornel Wilde, who recently returned from England after starring in "Star of India" for Raymond Stross Productions, will be going back to London in the early spring to head the cast of another independent production -- a biography of Lord Byron, to be written by Robert Buckner, the Hollywood writer-producer, and made jointly by Mr. Buckner and John Bryan, British producer.
Stock prices tested most of yesterday the levels attained in last week's advance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee reported today that it had documentary evidence to prove that for a long time there had been a close and effective relationship between Moscow and American Communists in matters before the United Nations.
Thousands of persons were late for work yesterday morning when a Manhattan-bound B. M. T. Sea Beach express train was derailed as it neared the Canal Street station at 8:25 A. M.

A single rate for all residential users of electricity produced by the Long Island Lighting Company would impose a disproportionate burden on consumers now enjoying lower rates in more heavily populated areas, the company told a Public Service Commission hearing yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The cost-price "squeeze" the farmers are in this year -- with costs of things they buy still high but the prices of farm goods they sell still down -- will probably continue in 1954, the Agriculture Department said today.

DESPITE the bluebird weather, the wildflowers on the Hudson River and on Lake Champlain reported unusually productive duck shooting over the week-end. Even the half-day on Saturday provided fair bags of teal, mallards and black ducks.

Turkish plans for the development of a really substantial NATO military base in southeastern Turkey have much to recommend them. They have not yet been officially broached, but that they are under consideration is not doubted. The adoption of the plan by NATO and its fulfillment would have important strategic consequences and advantages.

Senator Wicks has amplified but not improved his explanation of why he went to Sing Sing Prison repeatedly to see the convicted labor extortionist Joseph S. Fay. His "only purpose in going was to keep labor peace and avoid jurisdictional strikes in my Senatorial district."

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 983 pints of blood on Friday, including 344 at Fort Monmouth, N. J., the second of a two-day donation that totaled 516. Included in Friday's total were 196 pints from Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc., Murray Hill, N. J.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The failure of the foreign ministers conference here even to gesture toward the plan of Sir Winston Churchill for a talk with Georgi M. Malenkov, Soviet Premier, has provided fresh ammunition for the Prime Minister's foes in coming political battles.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 19 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon today visited Melbourne Cricket Grounds where the main Stadium for the 1956 Olympics will be built. He declared it a fine site and said he could not understand the criticism that has been levelled at preparations for the Olympics.

When Secretary Dulles reports to President Eisenhower today on the London conference of the Big Three he will presumably tell him what he has already told the public -- namely, that he is "very happy" about it, that he found it "extremely satisfactory," and that he is confident that its results will help to achieve world peace and security.

The first hundred years of Steinway Sons, as manufacturer of pianos and servant of music in the United States, were fittingly memorialized last night with a gala concert at Carnegie Hall. Naturally, the piano and pianists played a large part in this centenary concert, but the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, which antedates Steinway by eleven years, also was on hand.

The two five-story remodeled apartment houses at 120-122 East Thirty-seventh Street have been sold by Henry Payson, real estate operator, to an investing customer of Culver, Hollydey Co., brokers in the transaction. The property is assessed at $94,000.

Twenty table settings from as many different countries -- all members of the United Nations -- are on view at Altman's. The arrangements, many of which signify a special festivity associated with the country, were designed with the cooperation of representatives of the participating nations.
GROSSINGER, N. Y., Oct. 19 (UP) -- Randy Turpin did approximately seven miles of roadwork before breakfast today and then relaxed the rest of the day.
FALCON DAM, Tex., Oct. 19 (AP) -- Following are the texts of prepared addresses by President Eisenhower and by President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines of Mexico at the dedication of Falcon Dam here today:

Democratic forces opposed to Mayor Impellitteri moved in Supreme Court yesterday to strike his name from the voting machines in November by attacking the validity of three-fourths of the signatures on his nominating petitions in the Experience party.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor; indicated today that he had lost hope of getting any acceptable changes in the Taft-Hartley labor law from the present Congress.
Cotton futures declined 1 to 6 points yesterday in moderate trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 19 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion said categorically tonight that Wednesday night's raid against the Jordanian village of Kibya had been carried out by inhabitants of frontier settlements who had been armed and trained by the Government to defend their homes.

The Little Orchestra Society, which has been enlivening the local musical scene since 1947, last night began its seventh New York season. Thomas Scherman, its founder, again was at the helm, and the work he selected to give his new series of eight concerts a light-hearted start was Stravinsky's "Mavra," a witty opera buffa dating from 1922.
NOVARA, Italy, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Two Italians testified today that two Americans flipped a coin to see which would shoot their World War II comander, Maj. William Holohan of New York.

Most commodities prices advanced yesterday on the New York exchanges. Only potatoes were lower in all positions. Cocoa, soybean oil, rubber, burlap, hides, copper, lead, tin and zinc were stronger and coffee, sugar, cottonseed oil and wool closed mixed. Volume was unusually light.

SAMUEL SHELLABARGER'S fourth historical novel, "Lord Vanity,"* is an expert and entertaining mixture of accurate historical background and violent melodrama. Mr. Shellabarger has his thumb as firmly on the pulse of popular taste as any novelist now at work. He can describe a duel, a seduction or a torture as graphically as the most cynical purveyor of blood and thunder.

It is hard to see why, with approximately fifty-eight million females 14 years of age or over in the United States, the Post Office Department should be confronted with a deficit. For if every female in that group were to write only two letters per week, affixing a three-cent stamp to each, in the course of a year the stamp sales therefrom would amount to $180,960,000.

The "short-sighted" disclosure of technical facts about new weapons that has taken place since World War II will cost us dearly in the race for security, Dr. Vannevar Bush, president of the Carnegie Foundation of Washington, warned here last night.
Hugh W. Robertson, vice president of the Westchester County Newspapers, yesterday was elected president of the New York State Association of The Associated Press.
The Middle West and the East furnish most of the heavy action in intercollegiate football this week, with Notre Dame and Georgia Tech squaring off in one of the season's blue ribbon games.

The General Electric Company in the first nine months this year had sales of $2,341,048,000, highest in its history, and increased earnings 23 per cent to $116,386,000 from the $94,750,000 earned in the 1952 period.

The thirty-ninth annual meeting of the Audit Bureau of Circulations will be held Thursday and Friday in the Drake Hotel, Chicago. The meeting will open with the annual report of William A. Hart, president and chairman of the board of the A. B. C.
DUBLIN, Oct. 19 -- The election campaign in northern Ireland is receiving less attention in the Republic of Ireland than any held since this island was partitioned in 1920.

PARIS, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Eric Johnston, President Eisenhower's special. envoy en route to the Middle East to examine tensions in that area, said today he would undertake "extremely delicate and sensitive negotiations" but that they would not involve the current border dispute between Israel and Jordan.
LONDON, Oct. 19 -- With the exception of selected industrial issues and most of the gold mining issues, prices declined on the stock market here today.

LAS VEGAS, Nev. Oct 19 (UP) -- The nation's newest race track at this desert resort area suspended operations today for an indefinite period because of a lack of interest by the public at the pari-mutuel machines. The suspensoin was announced by general manager Al Luke.
TOKYO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The New York Giants today beat a picked team of Japanese professional baseball players, 4 -- 1, before 41,000 fans.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, State Rent Administrator, announced yesterday that the rent office for southern Manhattan would send notices at once directing landlords to replace water-cooled gas refrigerators condemned by Health Department inspectors, or suffer a penalty of a $3 reduction in the rent they may collect.

BOSTON, Oct. 19 -- Exploding hydraulic fluid was blamed today for the blast that took a toll of thirty-six lives and caused injuries to forty other persons aboard the Navy's aircraft carrier Leyte at a dock here last Friday.

The moderate recession in steel operations that many industrial observers had predicted for the fourth quarter has not appeared yet. The industry's productive pace thus far in October is slightly faster than it has been in any month since June.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Orange Bowl's two-year pact with the Big Seven and Atlantic Coast Conferences was praised by coaches and college officials today as a step toward taking some of the taint of commercialism off post-season football.

The six-story building containing four stores and twenty-nine apartments at 3500 Tryon Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Vickers Realty Corporation to the Hochman Realty Corporation in a transaction negotiated by Allan S. Feldman Co. as brokers. The property occupies a plot 25 by 109 feet and is assessed at $115,000.

A somber, heavily jowled man wearing a black homburg was accused yesterday of having fleeced an international power equipment concern in Jaipur, India, of $230,273 and of having sought to conceal his thefts by forging two sentences of a typewritten letter he had received from a dead man.

Education seems to have passed the period of stressing vocational specialization, Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, told the Board of Higher Education in his biennial report last night. "For the college as a whole four principal professional concern has been with the vitality of our basic liberal arts program," he said.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States delegate to the United Nations, turned in a four-word reaction today to the Administrative Tribunal's decision fixing indemnities in the cases of the four United States citizens involved in loyalty investigations.

The city's drive to coordinate the care of tuberculosis patients in and out of hospitals will come into full force on Nov. 1, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Aaron D. Chaves of the Health Department's tuberculosis bureau.

The Manhattan College basketball team has scheduled twenty-two games for the coming season, it was announced yesterday by Kenny Norton, director of athletics and basketball coach. The campaign will get under way Dec. 2 when the Jaspers meet American University at home.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 19 -- South Africa insisted again today that the question of the treatment of persons of Indian origin within her borders was a domestic affair and did not fall under the jurisdiction of the United Nations.

NEWARK, Oct. 19 -- Edmund Stevenson, Republican chairman of Hudson County, asserted today that Mr. Meyner was "owned body and soul" by Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City, whose administration he described as one that "matches, in viciousness alone, anything in the country."
HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 19 -- Two violent Vietminh attacks were repulsed last night by the French forces advancing in the rebel-held province of Thanhhoa in Central Vietnam.

I can understand the Administration's dilemma about taxes, a situation brought about by making promises before studying the facts. I don't understand the reasoning which leads to the conclusion that a sales tax, either a retailer or manufacturer level, is preferable to continuing the income tax at its present rate.
New high records in sales and earnings were achieved in the first nine months this year by the Continental Can Company.

Those of us who anticipated and then enjoyed the New York World's Fair back in 1939 and 1940 will recall that one of the attractions of the project was the idea that after the fair closed the site would become a 1,258-acre park, one of the city's finest. We recall that Park Commissioner Moses supported the World's Fair for that area largely because of the promise that it would pave the way for the park.

In the next ten days, persons hurrying through Grand Central Terminal will have an opportunity to check their punctuality, or that of trains, against ninety - five clocks instead of that station's usual sixty-three.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, predicted today that introduction of new weapons might lessen the need for the United States to send troops overseas.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- The United Nations Security Council acceded today to Arab demands that it discuss the Palestine question with special mention of last week's attack by an Israeli force on the Jordanian border village of Kibya.

Rudolph Halley charged yesterday that a Democratic candidate for high city office, whom he did not name, had figured in an official investigation of bribery of public officials and falsification of records.

RANDY TURPIN of England will meet Bobo Olson, the Swedish-American-PortugeseHawaiian, for the middleweight championship of the world in Madison Square Garden tonight and the experts are even more baffled than usual. And when you get an expert unsure of himself, confusion is doubly compounded.

Prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges in light trading. Vegetable oils, soybean oil, hides and potatoes were higher, with rubber, cocoa, coffee and burlap lower. Sugar, copper, zinc, tin and wool ended mixed.

Harold Riegelman, Republican nominee for Mayor, yesterday made public a letter that he said showed that union labor was being intimidated into voting for Robert F. Wagner Jr., the Democratic candidate.

A net income of $78,897,595 was earned by the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation in the first nine months this year. Equal to $2.72 a share on 28,952,794 capital shares, the profit compared with $70,739,620, or $2.45 a share, on 28,806,344 shares cleared in the corresponding period last year.

A recent headline in this newspaper said: "Republican Urges Benson to Resign." The event that evoked this advice from a fellow party member to the Secretary of Agriculture was the election of a Democrat in Wisconsin's traditionally Republican Ninth Congressional District.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 (UP) -Paul Penson, a right-handed Air Force pitcher sought by half a dozen major league clubs, signed with the Phillies today for a price below the $5,000 bonus limit. The 22-year-old Penson won fifty games and lost seven for the Eglin, Fla., Air Force Base during his three-year enlistment.

Randy Turpin, the Leamington (England) boxer who once held the middleweight championship of the world, will oppose Carl (Bobo) Olson of Honolulu in a fifteenround bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. Although neither fighter is a world titleholder now, the winner will gain general recognition as champion of the 160pound division.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles endorsed today the idea of a five-power meeting on Trieste.
KINGSVILLE, Tex., Oct. 20 -This nation's oversupplies of agricultural products could be changed from a burden to a blessing, Robert J. Kleberg Jr., president of the King Ranch, declared tonight..
The celebration of Jerusalem's 3,000th birthday at Madison Square Garden last night was used as an occasion to make a sharp attack on recent United States policy toward Israel.
Major custom smelters advanced the price of copper 1/2-cent a pound yesterday to 29 1/2 cents because of improved demand.

THROUGHOUT history, in times of crisis and disaster, men have looked to the future, if not with confidence, at least with hope. It would be better than the unhappy present. There would be plenty to eat. The enemy would be defeated. The Messiah would come. The heathen would be converted. Education, universal suffrage, scientific discoveries would usher in a brave new world.

ABOARD THE S. S. NIEUW AMSTERDAM, Oct. 20 -- Appointment of depositors to the boards of trustees of mutual savings banks was proposed today by members of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York attending their annual convention on cruise to Havana.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- A United Nations committee voted today to continue the office of the High Commissioner for Refugees for five years from Jan. 1, 1954, with Dr. G. J. van Heuven Goedhart as high commissioner.

DETROIT, Oct. 20 UP) -- The Detroit Times said today that it had learned from reliable sources in Washington that the General Motors Corporation had made an offer to the Kaiser Motors Corporation for the purchase of its Willow Run plant.

RYE, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- Jack Lyons, the Sands Point champion, today added a par 72 to his opening round of 65 to win the second annual New York Herald Tribune golf tournament of champions with a 36-hole score of 138 for Westchester Country Club's West course. The tourney was limited to 1953 club champions of the metropolitan area.
INDIO, Calif., Oct. 20 (UP) -Eddie Meyer, one of the nation's oldest speed boat pilots, escaped serious injury when his hydroplane turned over while traveling more than 100 milies per hour.

The problem of service morale and service incentives was still under study in the Pentagon this week as defense officials prepared a "Magna Carta" for the armed forces for presentation to the next session of Congress.

The current imbroglio over Trieste is another example of the urgency of solving the problem of federating Europe. There are lots of New Yorkers who have moved to Bridgeport, Conn. In fact, all of Fairfield County has been infiltrated by New Yorkers, many of whom still work in New York.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Icardi declined to make any statement about his present status. He said that "any answer -- either yes or no -- would be prejudicial to the United States of America."
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 20 -- The only certainty in the great Midwestern farm belt today is the uncertainty of farmers over the future.

MONTERREY, Mex., Oct. 20 (UP) -- Darkness halted efforts of rescue parties tonight to recover bodies from the wreckage of a Mexican Government plane, taking newspaper men and other public figures to the dedication of Falcon Dam.
The last and perhaps most controversial of the proposed constitutional amendments on the ballot for Election Day is No. 9, relating to the New York State Forest Preserve.
Sales by jewelry stores this year will be about 6 per cent above those in 1952, according to William Wagner, executive secretary of the National Jewelers Association.
Joseph Szigeti, as is his wont, arranged a program of violin music for his recital last night in Carnegie Hall that gave no consideration whatever to box-office or gallery appeal.

TUGUEGARAO, the Philippines, Oct. 20 -- Ramon Magsaysay, the Nationalist-Democratic candidate for President, completed a two-day electioneering sweep through Northern Luzon here this afternoon. He appeared before cheering crowds in this city of 50,000 in the heart of the fertile Cagayan Valley.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- The laity of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Chicago today elected Suffragan Bishop Gerald Francis Burrill, 47 years old, of Dallas, as successor to Bishop Wallace E. Conkling, who resigned July 1 after eleven years as head of the local diocese.

A home colony is planned for a fourteen-acre tract on the west side of Albany Avenue, between Pennsylvania and Delaware Avenues, in Amityville, L. I., which has been sold by Dr. Michael M. Schultz to the Arrow Land Corporation, of which Abraham G. Cohen is president.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Oct. 20 -- World mine production of tin in concentrates in August slumped to 13,700 long tons from 16,100 in July, the International Tin Study Group reported here today.

Although a start of the political conference on Korea within the time limit set by the armistice agreement has now become impossible, the Communists and the United States as spokesman for the United Nations have at least agreed on a preliminary meeting to make final arrangements for it.

ROME, Oct. 20 -- Doctors should refuse to take any part in atomic, bacteriological or chemical warfare when "this type of war represents an injustice," said Pope Pius today in addressing a group of military doctors from nine countries who met in Rome during the last few days.

Vassily Smyslov of Russia strengthened his hold on the lead in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich last night when he drew with Mark Taimanov of Russia in a Catalan opening lasting forty-two moves. They were on ever terms in a four knights ending, which held no prospects for either of them, according to a Swiss news report.

Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens condemned yesterday as "in danger of immediate collapse" a third of a mile of the main trunk of the $18,000,000 Corridor Sewer System, one of the largest in the borough.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The guessing game over the general manager of the new Baltimore Orioles will end by next week at the latest, Clarence Miles, the club president promised today.

Election of Arthur B. Foye of this city as president of the American Institute of Accountants took place yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Professional Society of Certified Public Accountants at the Palmer House in Chicago.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- The West persuaded the United Nations Security Council today to drop the Trieste case for two weeks to provide time for a new try at direct negotiations.

New York gave Gen. Mark W. Clark a four-star welcome yesterday. He was greeted in a traditional paper snowstorm and parade up the canyon of lower Broadway echoing with the cheers of 300,000 spectators.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Radar is promoting speed and economy for inland waterway traffic by reducing bad weather delays, M. C. Dupree, transportation manager of the Ashland Oil and Refining Company of Ashland, Ky., said today. He reviewed waterway radar use at a meeting of the Radio Technical Commission for Marine Services.

Subpoenas for 172 persons suspected of illegal registration for the mayoralty election are returnable today in the election frauds bureau of State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein's office at 80 Center Street. Several thousand registrants are to be called in for explanation.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The British Government still believes in "friendly, informal and personal talks" between the heads of the Western Governments and Soviet Premier Malenkov as a means of reducing world tension, Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today.

What to do when a child refuses his meals, what foods to serve to please a husband, how to inspire the appetites of oldsters -- these are some of the topics to which the attention of housewives is constantly being called.

TRENTON, Oct. 20 -- The legislative committee that investigated the summary dismissal last January of Deputy Attorney General Nelson F. Stamler announced here tonight, after an all-day closed session, that it would issue both a majority and a minority report on its long inquiry.

NEWARK, Oct. 20 -- George Armstrong of Oradel, N. J., former prohibition agent, whose indictment yesterday under the Kefauver Special Occupational Gambling Tax Act is believed to be the first handed down in any Federal court, faces total maximum penalties of twenty-six years in prison and fines of $265,000 in the event he is convicted, Federal officials said today.

Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. announced here last night that the Justice Department would support legislation at the next session of Congress for a new system of public defenders to be appointed by the United States District Courts.
There were more "bears" in Wall Street last week than there had been in twenty months, according to statistics released yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

BELMAR, N. J., Oct. 20 -- More than a dozen civilian specialists in the high secret Evans Signal Laboratory of the Army have been suspended as questionable security risks, Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 20 -Bryan Foy, now finishing his independent production of "The Mad Magician," a three-dimensional horror show, starring Vincent Price, expects to turn his attention next to a topical comedy-drama concerning American soldiers taken prisoner in Korea who profess to be interested in communism to ease their lot in captivity.

DETROIT, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Roy Fruehauf, president of the Fruehauf Trailer Company, said today that he and several associates had obtained 65,200 shares -- about a 15 per cent interest -of the Detroit and Cleveland Navigation Company.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- Convicts in Sing Sing Prison at Ossining learned today with chagrin and some surprise that they had a thief in their midst -- a practicing thief, that is. To make matters worse, until last night, he was the only culprit free to come and go.

ALBANY, Oct. 20 -- More than 350 Republican leaders and legislators gathered here tonight for a testimonial dinner for William L. Pfeiffer, who resigned as Republican state chairman on Sept. 23 after more than four years in the post.

Eric Johnston's Presidential mission to "Ease Middle East Tension," to quote your headlines, is bound to fail as miserably as Nevile Henderson's mission to pre-war Germany. This writer has just returned from a four-month study tour of the Arab states and Israel and can state unequivocally that there is not the remotest possibility of bringing the two sides together in economic projects with a view of reducing the disturbing frictions.

At 8 o'clock tonight the legitimate stage will reclaim the Longacre, utilized for radio purposes by WOR since 1944. The distinction of bringing back the house to the fold goes to "The Ladies of the Corridor," starring Edna Best and Betty Field. Featured members of the supporting cast are Walter Matthau, Frances Starr, Shepperd Strudwick, June Walker, Margaret Barker, Vera Allen and Lonny Chapman.

DETROIT, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Great Lakes Steel Corporation announced today price reductions averaging $5.96 a ton on a "small number of special steel items" but added there had been no change in the prices of any of the standard products that make up the large tonnage.

PARIS, Oct. 20 -- The French National Assembly today overrode the objections of Premier Joseph Laniel and by a large majority decided on a debate on the situation in Indo-China resulting from the rejection by the Vietnam nationalists of the French Union in its present form.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles confirmed today that the United States was holding back further economic aid to Israel.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 20 -- The task for today's adults is to prepare children for a world of permanent freedom from fear and want, Mrs. Oswald B. Lord, United States representative on the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, told the thirty-second national convention of the Girl Scouts of the U. S. A. here tonight.
YONKERS, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Sharon Rose, driven by Stanley Tweedie, came up with a rush through the stretch to win the $5,000 Concourse Pace at Yonkers Grand Circuit meeting tonight in 2:04 4/5.

Mayor Impellitteri, continuing his television campaign to win reelection as the candidate of the independent Experience party, reported last night that tremendous progress had been made in improving housing in New York.

MANAGING editors have grown considerably more mannerly since Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur wrote "The Front Page," but Station WORTV, in its current revival of the minor epic on the Fourth Estate, has carried the process of refinement a shade too far.

BERLIN, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Two "Fascist terrorists" are under arrest and others are being sought for killing four Communist police officers in gun fights in the Soviet zone, East German authorities said tonight.
The United States Lines Company took no action on the common stock dividend due at this time, as a result of the unsettled dock labor problems and a $2,844,700 reduction in nine months' earnings.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- President Eisenhower's plea of last April that savings achieved by disarmament be earmarked for world aid and reconstruction was incorporated today in a resolution submitted by the United States for approval by the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Americans for Democratic Action petitioned President Eisenhower today to remove Dr. Clarence E. Manion as chairman of the newly appointed Commission on Inter-Governmental Relationships and to reconstitute its membership.
LONDON, Oct. 20 (UP) -- West Germany replaced the United States as the world's second ranking shipbuilding nation during the third quarter of 1953, Lloyd's Register of Shipping disclosed today.

Operations of the Texas Company and its subsidiaries in the first nine months of this year resulted in a record net profit of $133,352,687 after all deductions. This compared with the previous peak of $130,289,802 established in the 1952 period.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- The grain markets lacked the aggressive buying support today that had been in evidence yesterday, and the tone was heavy during most of the session. However, there was a fair recovery late in the day on rather free short covering.

The regional Red Cross blood program's Bronx center at St. Barnabas Hospital, 183d Street and Third Avenue, which is open only on Wednesdays, has changed its hours for today to 3 P. M. to 8:30 P. M., instead of the usual 2 P. M. to 7 P. M.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 20 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, embarking on his second term as West German Chancellor, clearly reaffirmed today the principles of foreign policy with which he had so overwhelming a success in the September general election.

The Jarka Corporation, 47 Whitehall Street, one of the world's largest stevedoring enterprises, and its president, Frank W. Nolan, were accused yesterday of having paid out $119,859 in commercial bribes.

A syndicate of eighty-nine investment houses headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Drexel Co., and Glore, Forgan Co., will place on the market today a new issue of common stock of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company having a market value of $20,600,000.

The theory among pro football teams used to be: "Stop Otto Graham and you have a chance to stop the Browns." Many have tried, few have succeeded, but the Giants will give it another whirl Sunday at the Polo Grounds. Steve Owen's outfit will concentrate on trying to minimize Graham's aerial artistry, but no longer is the Cleveland "pitcher" the only defensive problem.
A white-haired, 84-year-old architect moved quietly around his living room yesterday, helping to arrange large bronze chrysanthemums and greenery in flower holders.

ROME, Oct. 20 -- Three divisions representing the flower of the Italian Army are now ranged along the Italian-Yugoslav frontiers near Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste. This is the area the United States and Britain promised Oct. 8 to return to Italy and which Marshal Tito, the Yugoslav President, threatens to invade as soon as the first Italian soldier sets foot inside it.

The record should be straightened out with regard to the sweeping generalization by William Vogt in his Oct. 14 letter to THE TIMES. He is justly worried over the tons of topsoil which wash into our rivers and streams daily. But just why this situation, an age-old one, makes "the conservation record of the Roosevelt-Truman Administration * * * one of the worst in the recent history of our country" is hard to see.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Fifteen railroad unions representing about a million "non-operating" employes announced today that they had asked the Government to intervene in their dispute with the carriers and also had authorized a strike vote.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 20 (UP) -River Jordan, a hot-and-cold running son of Bimelech, turned on the steam at Pimlico today as he sped to a five-length victory in the featured $4,500 purse and Jockey Ira Hanford scored a riding triple before 10,721 fans.

Three four-story buildings containing six stores and thirty-three apartments at 599-611 Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn have been Sold by Solomon Goldwyn to the Kruro Realty Corporation, represented by Dryer Traub, attorneys.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 20 -Considering that Yale has yielded only one touchdown in four games and that the unbeaten Bulldogs failed to score in their tie with Cornell last Saturday, the natural supposition would be that Coach Jordan Olivar would be bearing down hard on offense in preparing his team for Saturday's contest with Colgate in the Bowl.
The harness racing inquiry veered yesterday into developments involving the State Thruway Authority and the State Liquor Authority.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Wednesday, Oct. 21 -- Polish and Czechoslovak members ended their strike against the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission today in order to question an American war prisoner who had changed his mind without coaxing and had decided to return to Allied territory.
Three mayoralty candidates agreed last night that the traffic problem was the city's most difficult.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20 -This country's security was viewed tonight by George M. Humphrey, secretary of the Treasury, as dependent on economic strength, guarded and directed to sustain a defense program whose worth can be measured not by its cost but by its wisdom."

Guilt by relationship -- through a kind of blood taint -- is one of the less attractive among the many unattractive features of totalitarian "justice." Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican Liberal of New York, declared last night that when Congress convenes in January he intended to introduce a resolution providing for the appointment of a commission on revision of the United Nations' Charter.

The report entitled "A Court for Children," written by Dr. Alfred J. Kahn after a study conducted under the auspices of the Citizens Committee on Children of New York City, which was reviewed in THE TIMES of Oct. 15, is excellent. Nevertheless, it is likely to produce misconceptions on the part of the uninformed reader.

DUBLIN, Oct. 20 -- The chief domestic problems facing the Republic of Ireland today are the necessity for expanding its industrial and agricultural production and for stemming the flour of its young men and women to other lands.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, assured Senate investigators today that he intends to put the mining industry in this country on a "going concern" basis.
BOSTON, Oct. 20 -- Advances in industrial packaging so novel that many of them outshine the product packaged were put on display today.

BOSTON, Oct. 20 -- Navy and civilian experts were building up air pressure in the port, or left side, catapult when the fatal explosion ripped the Navy aircraft carrier Leyte last Friday afternoon. This was disclosed today as a Navy court of inquiry focused attention on the catapult safety valve.

The New Jersey Highway Authority has decided to receive bids on Nov. 18 on an issue of $135,000,000 of state-guaranteed bonds to finance the remaining major construction work on the Garden State Parkway.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson announced today the Government will support the price of oats, barley, rye and grain sorghums produced in 1954 at 85 per cent of parity -- the same percentage as this year.
MILAN, Mich., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Frank Costello will be released from Milan Federal Penitentiary Oct. 28 after serving twelve months of an eighteen-month sentence for contempt of Congress.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 20 -- The compilation of social data and economic statistics recited this afternoon to a sober group of Bundestag deputies by their grave impassive Chancellor, Dr. Konrad Adenauer, in effect explained the political miracle accomplished by West Germany within the last five years.

Further strides in effectiveness of industrial advertising depend on a better understanding by the sales manager of the significance of the advertising manager's responsibility and function. This warning was issued yesterday by Fred Adams, president of the G. M. Basford Company. He spoke at a meeting of the Salesmen's Association of the American Chemical Industry, Inc., in the Commodore Hotel.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 20 -- Israeli Government finances will be seriously dislocated, but the man in the street will not immediately feel any impact from State Department action withholding grant-in-aid funds from Israel, business circles here felt.

Advisers of Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor, were considering seriously yesterday a court action to compel the State Board of Parole to disclose the names of persons who interceded for Joseph S. Fay, convicted labor extortionist.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 (UP) -- President Franklin D. Roosevelt considered British Prime Minister Winston Churchill a "tying" house guest who often disrupted Presidential households at Washington and Hyde Park, N, Y., a former White House secretary said today.

Three of the major mayoral candidates, Harold Riegelman, Republican, Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democrat, and Rudolph Halley, Liberal, sat side by side as guests of honor yesterday at the weekly luncheon of the Sales Executive Club in the Roosevelt Hotel.

The hearings on the right of Mayor Impellitteri to run for reelection on Nov. 3 on the ticket of his independent Experience party were recessed in State Supreme Court early today after a hurried midnight conference between the Mayor and his counsel, John T. McGrath.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UP) -The Bonneville Power Administration gave twenty-year contracts today to four private power companies. The contracts equal in length to those held by the Federal agency's public and industrial customers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- A number of Arab members of the United Nations gave a somewhat dubious first appraisal today to new proposals that a sort of small-size Tennessee Valley Authority be set up in the Middle East for the mutual benefit of Syria, Jordan and Israel.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The British Government published evidence today of a Communist-inspired political conspiracy that threatened the colony of British Guiana and forced the Government here "reluctantly" to suspend its sixmonth-old Constitution.

Fordham shifted its attention to defensive tactics yesterday in an hour and a half intrasquad scrimmage at Fordham Field. The varsity drilled intensively against the reserves, using the simulated plays of Rutgers University, next Saturday's opponent at New Brunswick, N. J.
The cotton futures market here continued to fluctuate within a narrow range yesterday and closing prices on active months were steady, 1 to 3 points up on the day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, assured Lester B. Pearson, Canada's Minister for External Affairs, today that if litigation was started to block construction of the St. Lawrence River power project, attempts would be made to dispose of it promptly.
Stanford's Bob Garrett, whose passing attack knocked U. C. L. A. out of the undefeated ranks last Saturday, yesterday was named the Associated Press' back of the week for his 21-point scoring feat.

Prices of stocks, in the first fifteen minutes of trading yesterday, had much of the vigor in evidence during the last hour and a half of Monday's session. However, the list labored most of the day. A large part of the 0.49 gain in THE NEW YORK TIMES composite average was accounted for by a few issues.

BERLIN, Oct. 20 -- After three weeks of behind-the-scenes wrangling it appears probable that the uneasy coalition held together by West Berlin's late Mayor, Dr. Ernst Reuter, will continue in one form or another regardless of the outcome of Thursday's mayoralty elections.

Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said here last night that his talks in London last week-end with British and French leaders were designed to set up a world society of "consent" as opposed to one of "coercion," which he termed the Soviet method.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- New York designers captured the three top awards in an American fashions competition here tonight by vote of an audience of Washington notables attending a fashion festival.

THERE'S one public school in New York where no pupil is ever tardy. It's an institution with only four classrooms built under an apartment house on West Second Street between Avenue Z and Belt Parkway in the Brighton Beach district in Brooklyn.
HORSE CAVE, Ky., Oct. 20 (UP) -- This little town sought today to dispose of 45,000 gallons of a deadly chemical that might make the community unlivable should rains break a prolonged dry spell.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Obligations to the ultimate consumer of home furnishings are being neglected by manufacturers, sales people, decorators and editors, Mrs. Jan Streate Cox said here today.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Uncertainties of the international political situation helped to restrict business on the stock markets here today. Prices continued to sag during the morning but rallied in the afternoon and closed mostly with little net change.

Robert Morris, Republican candidate for Justice of the Municipal Court in the Ninth District of Manhattan, was found "qualified" for the position last night after an hour's debate over his qualifications by members of the Association of the Bar of New York City.
CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Reduction of quitting time traffic jams and accidents in industrial areas was urged today at the annual congress of the National Safety Council.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today that the three big Western powers were trying to find terms for a conference on the Trieste problem that would satisfy both Yugoslavia and Italy and that he personally thought that "if the situation is handled quietly now we may yet achieve a peaceful solution."

Formation of a "Golden Rule Medical Aid Committee" of physicians to carry out the charitable aspects of a doctor's practice was formally proposed last night by Dr. Alfred P. Ingegno to the Kings County Medical Society.
Washington's Bob Porterfield, a hard-luck hurler most of his big league career, and a rookie, Harvey Haddix, in his first full season with the Cardinals, were the 1953 shutout kings of the majors.
Brooklyn's National League champions and St. Louis' thirdplace Cardinals dominated the 1953 Associated Press major league All-Star team, capturing half of the ten positions.

NOVARA, Italy, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A Communist Member of Parliament who was a wartime partisan leader testified today that the Communist party believed that a former United States Army officer on trial in absentia here for murder "is still a member of the United States intelligence service."
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20 (AP) -The Air Force today gave the first public demonstration of its swifter-than-sound F-100 Super Sabre fighter.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- The figure of 2.19 per cent -the recommended over-all increase in the contributions of three Soviet states toward the 1954 budget of the United Nations -- dominated today's meeting of the General Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee.

BOSTON, Oct. 20 -- New England college administrators have become so concerned wth scholarship competition for outstanding students that an informal committee of three has been appointed to study the situation, according to one college official.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 20 -- Two German-born biochemists most probably will be the recipients of this year's Nobel Prize for medicine for their outstanding work in biochemistry, it is reliably reported here.

WATERTOWN, Conn., Oct. 20 -- Taft School's locker room was strangely quiet before football practice today. The English department had chosen this day to spring an examination on the seniors and upper middlers and virtually every member of the squad appeared with a book, hoping to do some "boning."

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society's 1952-53 season ended with a deficit of $107,135.78, it was reported yesterday by David M. Keiser, vice president and treasurer, at the annual meeting in Steinway Hall.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 20 -The Army is formulating a new program to meet the perplexing problem of maintaining an adequate flow of manpower into its organized Reserves and the National Guard.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The nation's business activity continued at a "high rate" at the end of summer. But some of the basic economic indicators have either stabilized or eased from their highest levels.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Disagreement between United States military and Treasury key men over giving to Russia engraving plates on which currency for expenses in occupied Germany were printed at will from 1944 to 1946 was aired at the Capitol today.
DENVER, Oct. 20 -- The 180member executive committee of the American National Cattlemen's Association opposed today any legislated beef cattle price supports or controls.

THE opening Monday of the grouse, woodcock, squirrel and rabbit season in the southern zone of New York State attracted few hunters and, according to reports from those who tramped the woods and fields, the results were far from satisfactory.

ALBANY, Oct. 20 -- The State Building Commission urged today that New York City undertake a scientific study of its needs for new school construction.

On the average, a share of Big Board stock was worth $38.20 at the end of September. That was 14 cents less than at the end of August -- and the lowest average for any month-end since October of 1950. A tabulation issued by the New York Stock Exchange showed that the 1,527 issues of stocks on the Big Board Sept. 30 had a market value of $110,478,753,424.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 20 -The thirty-first synod of the Second Province of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States opened today a two-day meeting here in the Cathedral of the Incarnation. The province represents. Six dioceses in New York State, the Diocese of Newark, the Diocese of New Jersey and five missionary districts.
A bet that seemed to be a "sure thing," made on a favorite to show, or come in third, resulted last night, the police said, in the arrest of Michael Masko, 28 years old, on a grand larceny charge.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Oct. 20 -- When parents, teachers and students work together to develop an acceptable code of youthful behavior, Dr. M. Robert Gomberg said last night, the process by which the agreement is arrived at is even more important than the standards themselves.

BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Dr. Frederick Resseguie, president of the Saratoga National Bank, testified today he never had met Herbert C. Stone of Gloversville, identified as the bank's largest stockholder.

The loft building with a frontage of 166 feet at 516 to 528 West Forty-third Street, between Tenth and Eleventh Avenue, has been sold by the General Kitchen Equipment Company of Weehawken, N. J., which had held the property for investment.

The National Maritime Union, C. I. O., offered its hand in friendship yesterday to its counterpart within the American Federation of Labor, the Seafarers International Union, in a resolution calling for a "no-raiding" pact, but at the same time it shook a warning finger.

Navy's 65 -- 7 rout of Princeton Saturday advanced the midshipmen to first place among the nation's major college football teams in scoring average, to second in total offense and third in rushing, the National Collegiate Athletic Association Service Bureau revealed yesterday.

The Dalis Realty Corporation, investors, who recently bought 630 to 638 Third Avenue, southwest corner of Forty-first Street, added to their holdings yesterday by purchasing two four-story buildings with a frontage of forty feet at 568-70 Third Avenue, between Thirty-seventh and Thirty-eighth Street, from the Wood-Man Realty Corporation, Maurice Epstein, president. Sanford M. Salke was the broker, and title was insured by the Title Guarantee Trust Company.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 20 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon, speaking at a parliamentary luncheon in Canberra today, said the Australians need never suppose the Administration or other leaders in the United States would revert to isolationism.

Aviation's foreseeable future is the subject of a book by Holmes Alexander that Rinehart will issue Nov. 9 under the title "Tomorrow's Air Age." Mr. Alexander wrote the book with the cooperation of the Air Force research laboratries. He examines the future of air medicine, new construction materials and aircraft power plants, as well as many other problems that are expected to arise in the progress of aviation.
The waterfront dispute moved yesterday from the piers to Federal Court, with the following results:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said today the United States would go along with the Communist acceptance of allied proposals to confer on a Korea peace conference, and that the United States representative would leave for Panmunjom tomorrow.

MOSCOW, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Soviet press today carried a bitter attack on Prime Minister Churchill for what it called his attempt to deliver an ultimatum to France on ratification of the European Defense Community treaty.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, who was captured in Korea early in the war during the furious fighting around Taejon, received a hero's honors here today.
PARIS, Oct. 20 -- The debate that is to take place in the National Assembly Friday doubtless will reveal much confusion and dissatisfaction about the war in IndoChina.

Commissioner of Investigation James H. Sheils, in a long inquiry into the contracts under which the $18,000,000 Corridor Sewer System was built in North Queens, discovered "serious omissions" in the contract covering the third of mile section condemned by Borough President James A. Lundy.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Admiral Lord Nelson's famous signal, "England expects every man to do his duty," flew in Trafalgar Square today as officers and men of the Royal Navy gathered to honor the memory of those who fought the battle for which the square is named.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The administrative group that was set up recently to coordinate execution of the defense policies formulated by the National Security Council is reported to be working smoothly. It has proved to be a sound piece of machinery, able to accomplish its important function.

A student celebration stemming from "Rush Week" activities of Columbia College fraternities got out of hand for a brief period last night when young men crowded the streets and blocked traffic near girls' dormitories. One man was arrested on a disorderly conduct charge.

James J. Shallow has been appointed general manager of the accessory division of the Philco Corporation, Philadelphia, and David Brody will replace Mr. Shallow as general sales manager of Philco Distributors, Inc.
ROME, Oct. 21 -- The parliamentary machinery of the dominant Christian Democratic party swung behind Premier Giuseppe Pella today and pledged its support for the Government's policy on Trieste.

The use of apartment house incinerators in the city will be curbed drastically after Jan. 1, 1955, in the campaign to reduce smoke, Dr. Leonard Greenburg, Commissioner of Air Pollution Control, announced yesterday.
The city finished plugging a sizable leak in its water supply plumbing yesterday, 233 feet under Central Park just inside the West Ninety-third Street gate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- President Eisenhower today deplored the fact that the country's citizen army was being asked to fight and resist communism with only a meager education in the responsibilities of citizenship.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- President Eisenhower made a recess appointment today of George Wadsworth of Buffalo, N. Y., to be Ambassador to Saudi Arabia and Minister to Yemen in place of Raymond A. Hare, recently named Ambassador to Lebanon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Miss Elizabeth T. Bentley, an admitted former Communist spy ring courier, swore today that she had obtained samples of United States military currency for counterfeiting by an ally, Russia, in 1943.
DETROIT, Oct. 21 (AP) -- General Motors has resumed production of Hydra-Matic transmissions, halted in August by destruction by fire of its transmission plant in Livonia, Mich.
The body of Michael Brogan, a supporter of the new American Federation of Labor union on the strife-tossed waterfront, was pulled out of the Hudson River yesterday morning.

The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company announced yesterday that it will appeal to the Federal courts for a clarification of conflicting rulings by two government bureaus concerning a $2,723,882 item in its bookkeeping.
