ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 21 -- Robert B. Meyner, Democratic candidate for Governor, declared here tonight that the Republicans were "panicky" and "on the run" and that even Republican leaders admitted they were "behind the eight-ball."

Declaring that the morale of 15,000 postal clerks in the New York Post Office had hit "rock-bottom," Ephraim Handman, president of Local 10, National Federation of Post Office Clerks, A. F. L., announced yesterday that a "grievance rally" would be held Sunday at 2 P. M. at Central Commercial High School, 214 East Forty-second Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- The six Arab members of the United Nations asked the Security Council tonight to take up a new joint complaint of "aggression by the armed forces of Israel" committed last week against three border villages of Jordan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that near-record supplies of livestock feed will be "more than adequate" this fall and winter, although some drought areas may suffer shortages.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- President Eisenhower said today he thought it was more important to stress that the cost-of-living figures were flattening out than to point out the new high levels reached by the price index in recent months.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 21 -- A Presbyterian minister landed his four-place Piper Clipper at Princeton Airport here today, hitched a four-mile ride to town, and promptly called to order his eleven-man seminary class in the original Greek text of the New Testament.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- The Philippines today bluntly attacked the opposition of "highly developed" countries to the creation now of a special economic development fund for underdeveloped lands.

BONN, Oct. 21 -- The United States High Commissioner's office in Germany and the headquarters of the Commander in Chief, United States Army in Europe, jointly announced today the appointment of an interim mixed parole and clemency board for persons convicted by war crimes tribunals.

AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 21 -- Anti-Israeli demonstrations were held in cities throughout Jordan today in protest against the attack by Israelis on the Jordanian village of Kibya. Businesses were closed for three hours from 11 A. M. as employes responded to the call made yesterday by a group of political leaders in Nablus for a strike.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 21 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon arrived here today on his Far Eastern tour. In a statement on Kemajoran airfield where a racial military guard of honor was arrayed, Mr. Nixon said he hoped to discuss with President Sukarno and other Indonesian leaders "matters of mutual interest."

Samuel Reshevsky, United States, defeated Svetozar Gligoric, Yugoslavia, last night, in the twenty-ninth and semi-final round of the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich after forty-one moves of a Catalan opening.

The role of Roxane, the romantic, gentle lady in "Cyrano de Bergerac," which is to serve as the first of the City Center productions this season, opening Nov. 11, will be undertaken by one of Hollywood's attractive actresses, Arlene Dahl.

Six tapestries by Jan Joors, in strong colors and bold designs, are on view at the Hugo Gallery, 26 East Fifty-fifth Street. The exhibition is the first to be held in this country by the artist, who once worked with his father in Belgium on designs for stained glass windows. The tapestry display will continue through Nov. 7.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 21 (AP) -- A new treatment for bronchial asthma -- described as "apparently the easiest, safest, least expensive and highest producer of satisfactory results" -- was announced today by a Washington doctor.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21 -- West Coast steamship spokesmen declared today that Government competition with private industry in ocean transportation was endangering the United States merchant marine.

More than twice as many bacteria are usually found in the air of the streets as in the air of the subways, a subway engineer told members of the American Society of Civil Engineers yesterday. The society is holding its convention this week at the Statler Hotel.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 21 -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, chairman of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, arrived here by special plane today at the head of a group on a study tour of fourteen Latin-American countries. Senator John

Casey Stengel, the only manager ever to pilot a team to five consecutive world championships, yesterday was named manager of the year for the second straight time and the fourth time in the last five years.
TRIESTE, Oct. 21 -- An economic depression already has begun to show itself in Trieste.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 21 -- The United Nations is a failure, a cancer eating at the peace and tranquility of the world and unless it is radically reformed it should disappear from the face of the earth, Dr. Daniel F. Malan, South African Prime Minister, said today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- The National Safety Council's forty-first annual convention heard testimony today that many motorists who blasted their horns to bully their way through residential neighborhoods, the drivers who wanted to race in the getaway from traffic lights and others who defied traffic regulations might be mentally unbalanced.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 21 -- Reliable non-Yugoslav sources estimated today that the Yugoslav Army had assumed positions from which it easily could seize the port city of Trieste.
HARTFORD, Oct. 21 -- The Most Rev. Henry J. O'Brien was consecrated today as the first Archbishop of the new Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hartford.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Government cannot promise a balanced budget next year, W. Randolph Burgess, special deputy to the Secretary of the Treasury, asserted today.
Rudolph Halley, Robert F. Wagner Jr. and Harold Riegelman became involved yesterday in an exchange of accusations, statements and replies dealing with the Joseph S. Fay parole case.
WEST MILTON, N. Y., Oct. 21 (AP) -- The last steel plates have been welded into a huge sphere that will become a bathtub laboratory for an atomic submarine power plant.

Unseated and thrown two years ago in a collision with the Supreme Court, retail price maintenance seemed yesterday to have got back into its saddle. That was the interpretation placed by friends of Fair Trade legislation on the refusal of the Supreme Court to review the decision of the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals upholding the constitutionality of the Louisiana Fair Trade Act and the federal McGuire Act.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Western Big Three powers have formally proposed a five-power conference on Trieste and Yugoslavia has conditionally accepted, Yugoslav officials reported today.

SAN DIEGO, Oct. 21 -- A thoroughgoing, possibly "drastic" cleanout of the nation's military reserve forces to rid them of unfit and unreliable personnel was called for today by Dr. John A. Hannah, Assistant Secretary of Defense in charge of manpower and personnel.
Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor, criticized Secretary of State John Foster Dulles yesterday for withholding aid to Israel because of "alleged border violations."

The first voter in this year's Mayoralty election to be disqualified by court order on charges of illegal registration is a former city inspector who's name figured in a case of ballot-box stuffing in the Democratic primary last month.

Cortland, N. Y., is a small city and, as cities in the United States go, an old one. Settled in 1791, it is a county seat in a rich agricultural region of central New York State. The bulk of its 18,000 inhabitants would normally not be expected to display a very deep interest in foreign affairs.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 21 -- One of the quietest campaigns ever waged for the election of a Northern Ireland House of Commons ended tonight with the Unionist party apparently sure of retaining its firm grip on the Government.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Persons and places got a bit scrambled by President Eisenhower today in the give-and-take at his press conference.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- Khalil Takieddine, the Lebanese representative, suggested today that the United Nations General Assembly recommend that France establish "democratic constitutional institutions" in Tunisia and hold legislative elections on the basis of universal suffrage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Israeli representatives rejected today United States charges that Israel was "defying" either the United States or the United Nations in the Jordan River development controversy.
A fresh attempt to uncover the mysteries behind emotional disorders in children, and how to treat them, begins today with the opening of the Henry Ittleson Center for Child Research.
Delegates representing 1,200,000 steel workers demanded yesterday an increase in employer-financed pension payments.
With a busy social season unfolding, Russeks keyed its showing of gala cocktail and evening fashions yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to the theme "White and Black Tie Evenings."

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 21 -- The Argentine-led inter-American labor organization, Association of Latin- American Syndicalist Workers [La Agrupacion de Trabajadores Latino-Americanos Sindicalistas] issued its first direct blast today against the Communist-dominated World Federation of Trade Unions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 21 -- Jules Schermer, associated with Fox until recently, has been signed by Columbia as a staff producer and has been handed a new property titled "The Killer Wore a Badge" as his first assignment.

The Johns-Manville Corporation, the nation's largest manufacturer of building products, transacted a record volume of sales in the first nine months this year. Its consolidated net earnings, however, fell to $15,850,435 from $18,122,613 in the comparable period of 1952.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- It was a clear case of two other fellows, former Ambassador Joseph C. Grew explained at a dinner given by the Crusade for Freedom here tonight. He was telling some of the lighter operations of Radio Free Europe, in which he is a leading spirit.

The "brain-washing" operation which the Communists are attempting on the war prisoners in Korea is still in its initial stages, but it is already producing two results which, barring a most unlikely reversal of the trend, provide full vindication of the United Nations fight for these prisoners and can only redound to the benefit of freedom everywhere.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 22 -- Lieut. Gen. K. S. Thimayya announced just before the neutral nations commission went into session in Korea this forenoon that he was going to suggest that the commission abandon meetings pending an all-around agreement on the conduct of the "explanation" sittings.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 21 -- The meeting of the Presidents of the United States and Mexico Monday probably smoothed official friendship between the two countries for some time to come, but it left the Mexican newspaper and radio corps that covered the story much ruffled.

Night television broadcasts were cited yesterday by Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Casey, chairman of the New York City Transit Authority, as factors in the continuing decline of passenger traffic on the municipal subway, bus and street car lines.

Arthur Godfrey confirmed yesterday that he had "fired" Julius La Rosa and Archie Bleyer from his radio and television shows because of their outside business activities, although he "loved" them both. He also referred to a growing morale problem among his cast members and said that he had warned them three weeks ago, "Do better or I'll drop you."
A ground-breaking ceremony for the $10,000,000 Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University will be held Sunday afternoon at Morris Park Avenue and Eastchester Road, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Representative Thomas J. Lane, Democrat of Massachusetts, complained today that the Defense Department's recent ruling on progress payments to contractors is a blow at small business.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 14:
OSLO, Norway, Oct. 21 (UP) -- Former President Truman was reported today to be a leading candidate for this year's Nobel Peace Prize.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- India and Pakistan announced here today that they had no differences over a possible conference with South Africa regarding the treatment of persons of Indian origin in the Union. In effect they publicly opened the door, if but slightly, to holding such talks.
Worcester, Mass., announced yesterday that it will offer on Oct. 28 an issue of $2,410,000 of bonds dated Oct. 1, 1953, and maturing from Oct. 1, 1954 to 1973.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 21 -- In its second auction of foreign currency credits today under the Aranha Import Plan, $636,000,000 in American dollars exchange was offered for auction. These credits cover five categories of imports, varying from essential to luxury items.

Grandma Moses doesn't keep track of time. The phenomenally successful 93-year-old "primitive" painter, in New York for the last few days on one of her rare trips, couldn't quite remember when she had been here last; but that was an unimportant detail in an active, busy life.

The new 23,000-ton passenger liner Olympia, now on her maiden voyage to New York for the Greek Line, has been registered under the flag of Liberia, giving this trans-Atlantic passenger operator the most distinctive international complexion of any company in the trade.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Charles S. Thomas, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Supply, has ruled that the Buy-American provision of the Armed Services Procurement Regulations do not apply to aluminum in any form.

Mayor Impellitteri is off the ballot as a candidate for re-election on the independent Experience ticket and, barring an unlikely write-in appeal, he is out of the campaign. It is premature to assess the complete range of effect of this event. The Democratic primary results had seemed convincing enough testimony, to almost everybody but the Mayor himself, that he was not destined for a second term.
The blow-by-blow account of the championship fight between Randy Turpin and Carl (Bobo) Olson at Madison Square Garden last night follows:

In a letter mailed yesterday to stockholders of R. Hoe Co., Inc., manufacturer of printing presses, eight executives of the company urged shareholders to resist a move to force the reinstatement of the company's former president Joseph L. Auer and the retirement of four directors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The annual struggle, a wearing war of attrition, to frame the administration's defense budget for the next fiscal year (starting July 1, 1954) is now in full swing in Washington.

Twelve days ago Mister Gus suddenly became the most-talked-about 2-year-old on the turf. A blazing 1:08 2-5 for six furlongs down the Widener chute at Belmont Park on Oct. 10 by the first-time starter intrigued nearly every one in racing circles.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Bernard M. Baruch, adviser to Presidents, was among a group of business men who gave their views today to the Commission on Foreign Economic Policy.
YONKERS, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Bill Haughton won his second straight race of the Yonkers Raceway Grand Circuit program when he drove Ethel Lady to victory in the Jerome Pace in 2:06 4/5 tonight.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 21 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan today set a time limit of five years on his demand that Britain transfer three British-protected African territories to the South African Union.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 -- Eleven Americans and a Swiss scientist were honored tonight at the Franklin Institute's annual Medal Day ceremony in the institute's lecture hall. The award ceremony followed a reception and dinner attended by several hundred scientists in varied fields.

ALBANY, Oct. 21 -- Recent changes in the New York State Welfare Law and other changes soon to take effect, as well as state and local studies, have laid the groundwork for multi-million dollar savings in welfare administration and relief costs, the Citizens Public Expenditure Survey said today.

Greenwich Village is one of the world's most famous communities. Certain people now propose to begin wiping out the Village, as we know it, and to replace it with a series of apartment house projects.

Joseph Curran of the National Maritime Union seems to stand alone when he says that longshoremen can clean their own house if given the opportunity. Presidents George Meany of the American Federation of Labor and Dave Beck of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters insist that the grip which racketeers have fastened on the waterfront in the last twenty-five years cannot be broken by the rank and file alone.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 21 -- With eight foreign exhibitors represented, the Thirty-fifth National Metal Exposition and Congress here today is showing a marked international flavor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Bishop Raymond A. Lane, superior general of the American Foreign Mission Society at Maryknoll, N. Y., has been awarded the 1953 peace award of the Catholic Association for International Peace, it was announced today.
ATHENS, Oct. 21 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther warned today that the coming three years would be "most critical" for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

A "liquid saccharin" that is easier to use in cooking than tablet saccharin is being introduced in drug stores, including the Whelan chain, under the name of Sweeta. Squibb is making it for those on special diets seeking a sweetening with no calories.

QUEBEC, Oct. 21 -- A small Italian freighter, a German cargo ship, and a trans-Atlantic liner were involved in marine accidents, off Quebec today, but no loss of life occurred, even though damage was heavy to the Italian freighter.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Thursday, Oct. 22 -- The Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission rejected today an Indian proposal for indefinite adjournment. It decided to try to "find some way" out of the current deadlock over the "explanations" to prisoners of war who reject repatriation.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 21 (UP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said today the time had come for a new "face-to-face" attempt to reach an understanding with Russia.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 21 -- Mrs. Roy F. Layton of Chevy Chase, Md., was re-elected national president of the Girl Scouts, it was announced here today at the close of a four-day session.
LONDON, Oct. 21 -- The first British motor show since World War II at which the customer is boss was opened today at Earl's Court by the Duke of Edinburgh.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The White House said today 454 drought-stricken counties in thirteen states were now receiving Federal aid.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 21 -- Mrs. Joshua L. Lewis of Brooklyn, N. Y., was re-elected unanimously to her third one-year term as president of Mizrachi at the closing session of the women Zionist group's twenty-eight national convention here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UP) -- The average American youth completed a full high school education in the last ten years, while a generation ago the average boy and girl had gone only through the eighth grade, the Census Bureau reported today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- President Eisenhower stoutly defended Ezra Taft Benson, his Secretary of Agriculture, today against demands for his removal. He said he leaned to the view that the farmers were taking their economic distress in better stride than the politicians.

Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, called last night for leadership among diplomats in the ever-changing world so that an educated public opinion would become as accustomed to the need for give-and-take and compromise in international politics as it has long been on questions of local concern.

HAVANA, Oct. 20 -- President Fulgencio Batista is approaching a crisis in his remarkable career. In the next few weeks he must make up his mind whether he is going to set Cuba back on the road to liberty and free elections or hold the dictatorial reins tighter and tighter in the face of an always more restive people.

" What Price Israel," by Alfred Lilienthal, an exploration of the problems posed by the establishment of Israel on the theory of Jewish nationality, will be published by Regnery on Monday. Mr. Lilienthal, who was consultant to the American delegation at the San Francisco conference of the United Nations, is the author of the article "Israel's Flag Is Not Mine," which appeared in Reader's Digest.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Evening Star reported here tonight that top-level Pentagon policy makers had evolved a "revolutionary change" in United States retaliatory strategic bombing techniques against the Soviet Union in the event of war.

The luxurious Center Theatre at Forty-ninth Street and Avenue of the Americas -- one of the original units in the Rockefeller Center building program -- will come down to make way for a tall air-conditioned office building.

The camp committee of the Parents Association for Children of Retarded Mental Development is seeeking now to obtain placement for mentally handicapped youngters in residential camps next summer. One of the group's primary concerns will be to interest organizations conducting nonprofit children's camps in making their facilities available even for limited periods in the camping season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Under Secretary of State, estimated tonight that the Soviet Union would not start an offensive war against Western Europe unless its lines of communication through the satellite Countries were more secure than they now were.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of today's White House news conference, with President Eisenhower's remarks in indirect discourse, as required by conference rules:

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, charged "rabble rousers and demagogues" today with attempting to create panic among the nation's farmers. He said the farmers were "less panicky than some politicians."

THE prospects for the opening of the deer season in the Adirondacks Sunday are not too bright because of the extremely dry conditions in many areas. Although there may be a heavy rainfall before the week-end, the foliage will be rather thick for good hunting.

The vitality of contemporary craft production in this country is evident in an exhibition opening at the Brooklyn Museum today. Arranged by the museum and the American Craftsmen's Educational Council, it is called "Designer-Craftsman -- USA" and includes 243 pieces by 203 craftsmen.

Four Staten Island bookmakers were sentenced yesterday in Special Sessions to one to three years in prison for criminal contempt of the Richmond County grand jury, which is investigating crime and corruption in the borough.

The excellence of Pauline Trigere's designing was in evidence yesterday when her complete line of fall and winter fashions was presented by De Pinna. The showing took place in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre Hotel.

A radioactive fried egg was pictured shortly after breakfast yesterday morning at a scientific panel discussion here. It was at the twenty-sixth annual graduate fortnight held at the New York Academy of Medicine Building, 2 East 103rd Street.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- The British Labor party announced tonight that it would ask the House of Commons to declare that the Conservative Government had shown no justification for suspending British Guiana's Constitution two weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Representative Richard Simpson, Republican of Pennsylvania, promised today to continue to fight for restrictions on imports of foreign residual oil.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 21 (UP) -- Tom Fool, handicap king of the 1953 racing season, arrived today for Saturday's $50,000 Pimlico Special and his last bid for more turf glory.

The New York Rangers are ready for their home opening of the National Hockey League season tonight. The Broadway Blues will skate against the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden, and a crowd of 10,000 fans is expected to turn out for the contest.

In "The Ladies of the Corridor," which was acted at the Longacre last evening, Dorothy Parker and Arnaud d'Usseau insist on pointing out that unattached ladies of venerable years are pathetic and lonely creatures. Unfortunately, nearly everybody knows that without having to go to the theatre.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- John G. Pew Jr., vice president of the Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, was elected today to lead a slate of sixty new officers of the Marine Section of the National Safety Council.

TODAY'S books are outstanding explorers' tales. The first is E. M. Forster's "The Hill of Devi,"*. a superb memoir of fantastic experiences in the princely India of far away and long ago, a volume that might well have been called "The Maharajah and I." The second is Vice Admiral Leslie Stevens' "Russian Assignment," a remarkably full account of the life a questing stranger may lead between the Soviet dictators and their sadly oppressed proletariat.
Families are purchasing larger quantities of frozen food than ever before.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Bureau of Mines experts testified today the United States was dependent on sources outside the Western Hemisphere for at least part of its needs in twenty-one key minerals.

Bumper-to-bumper driving is a major cause of accidents and traffic tie-ups in New York, Col. William S. Chapin, consulting engineer of the Triborough Bridge Authority, said yesterday. He outlined some of the city's traffic shortcomings at the closing session of the annual meeting of the American Bridge, Tunnel and Turnpike Association at the Park Sheraton Hotel.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, asserted last night that the public record of Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic nominee, was replete with inconsistencies and was based on political expediency.
British interests have bought the Australian subsidiary of Julius Kayser Co., hosiery manufacturer, for $2,000,000.
Directors of Electric Bond and Share Company elected as vice presidents yesterday C. C. Colt and A. A. Talmage, in connection with the holding company's activities in making new investments.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- President Eisenhower, who once said he liked bass singing, heard some of the best tonight.

Public misunderstanding of the nature and scope of anti-social behavior may cause society to slip back as much as fifty years in dealing with crime and delinquency, a conference of probation officers was told here yesterday.

Joshua Logan, producer-director of "Kind Sir," co-starring Mary Martin and Charles Boyer, has entered a Louisiana sanitarium outside of New Orleans for "several weeks of complete rest," according to a spokesman.

When your nose hurts and you have a black eye and your lips are swollen it's difficult to talk. But you can smile, after a fashion, when you have just won the middleweight boxing championship of the world.
LAKEVILLE, Conn., Oct. 21 -- Tom Stearns, former Washington and Lee back, who is assisting the head coach, Delaney Kiphuth, in football at Hotchkiss School, was an arm-weary person today.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased 279,000 barrels last week. The American Petroleum Institute reported that supplies at the weekend amounted to 142,796,000 barrels, compared with 142,517,000 a week earlier and 122,002,000 a year ago.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- The weekly Catholic Herald will reply tomorrow to charges of intolerance and increasingly "exclusive propaganda" made against the Roman Catholic Church last week by the Most Rev. Dr. Geoffrey F. Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury, and by a group of Anglican priests in a new booklet "Infallible Fallacies."

Changes in commodity prices were irregular yesterday. Volume on the New York exchanges was about average. Trading in the domestic sugar contract was the most active since Aug. 14. Cocoa, cottonseed oil, rubber and lead advanced; sugar, coffee, potatoes, soybean oil, hides, burlap and copper lost ground, and tin, zinc and wool ended mixed.

TORONTO, Oct. 21 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs moved into a tie for second place in the National Hockey League tonight as Erie Nesterenko scored a third-period goal that gave the Leafs a 1-1 tie with the first-place Detroit Red Wings.

FLORAL PARK, L. I., Oct. 21 -- An anonymous telephone report this morning that a bomb had been planted in Sewanhaka Central High School resulted in a holiday for 2,000 students and a possible loss to local taxpayers of $2,000 in state aid.
NEWARK, Oct. 21 -- Frank Hague Eggers' bolting the Democratic party to support Paul L. Troast, Republican candidate for Governor, came as little surprise today to leaders of both parties.
The program of the recital given last night in Carnegie Hall by Robert Goldsand was one that covered a wide field of classic, romantic and modern music.

Richard Schuckman's letter on British Guiana implies an interesting question -- should we allow democracy to be overthrown by communism when it acts in the guise of democracy? No one disputes that Jagan and the five other Ministers in Executive Council were elected popularly, nor that his party program was put before the public openly.

When President Eisenhower -- the local boy who made good -- stopped off at the old homestead in Abilene the other day he took with him possibly a far greater crowd than he knew. That crowd was not physically present, of course -- as were the thousands who cheered Mr. Eisenhower on his first homecoming as President, or as were the sixteen bands that tootled away -- but they were there in spirit.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The chairman of the Federal Power Commission said today he would talk over with staff members the propriety of their attending dinners given by persons interested in pending cases.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 21 -- John J. McCloy, United States High Commissioner in Germany for three years, returned here today for the first time since he relinquished the post in July, 1952.
NOVARA, Italy, Oct. 21 (AP) -- An Italian woman who said she spied for the Allies in World War II testified today that a former American lieutenant on trial in absentia ordered that she be murdered.
CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Bulls in grains renewed their activities today, following yesterday's lull.

Business ties between an upstate harness racing track and one of the leading Republican State Senators became known yesterday. The recently appointed state inquiry commission indicated it would look into this relationship in its investigation of racing scandals.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- President Eisenhower said today he could not comment on the action of a member of Congress in writing to President Syngman Rhee of the Republic of Korea urging that he liberate Chinese and North Korean prisoners who do not want to go home.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 21 -- City Commissioner Frank Hague Eggers, a nephew of Frank Hague, former state Democratic leader, announced today his support of Paul L. Troast, Republican candidate for Governor.

Those who employ slogans in criticizing Administration policy would be well advised, it would appear, to make sure that these devices, however uproarious or however devastating they may sound to their authors, are constructed in such a way that they won't go off in one's face.

Nothing has greater bearing on the prosperity of a nation than its foreign commerce, and this country's dependence on foreign trade is one of the critical phases of our national life, Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs for the Port of New York, asserted last night.

It has been a busy six months for Ward M. Canaday, president and chairman of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc. Between April 24, when he sold his company's automobile assets to the Kaiser interests, and last Tuesday, Mr. Canaday has tied up many loose ends.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Food and Drug Administration said today that seizure actions were in process in the courts against fifty shipments of the drug Tryptacin.
PARIS, Oct. 21 -- In her mid-season collection, Schiaparelli presented four wardrobes at "budget" prices for a couturiere's clothing.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 21 -- Herbert Hoover Jr., oil consultant to the United States State Department, began talks today with Iranian Premier Gen. Fazlollah Zahedi.
The cotton futures market closed steady yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, with final prices 2 to 15 points net higher than on Tuesday.
ABOARD THE S. S. NIEUW AMSTERDAM, Oct. 21 -- Mutual savings banks have failed to hold their place in the competition to attract the public's savings.

NEWARK, Oct. 21 -- Paul L. Troast, Republican candidate for Governor, defended again tonight his action in writing to Governor Dewey of New York in an effort to obtain executive clemency for Joseph S. Fay, labor leader and convicted extortioner.

The annual dinner dance in behalf of the Yorkville Community Association win be held on Jan. 22 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Plans were discussed for the forthcoming fete at a luncheon given yesterday by Mrs. Eliot Lee Ward in her home at 580 Park Avenue for members of the benefit committee.

APARRI, The Philippines, Oct. 21 -- The physical strain of five months of intensive electioneering is beginning to show on Ramon Magsaysay and he has been forced to slow the pace of his intensive campaigning through the Philippine countryside.
Smoke overcame eighteen firemen yesterday while they were fighting a blaze in a garment center loft building at 118 West Twenty-seventh Street.
Once again yesterday the stock market attempted to pause in its upward climb, but once again strength developed as trading progressed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Food and Drug Administration said today that seizure actions were in process in the courts against fifty shipments of the drug Tryptacin.
Mayor Impellitteri lost yesterday his chance to run for re-election as the candidate of the independent Experience party.

One of your correspondents, Rose Dobbs, in a plea for permanent personal registration asks what arguments exist against it. She asserts that failure to register can be laid to other causes than non-interest and cites absence from the city and illness as reasons.

Food manufacturers and other advertisers are changing their methods of packaging as a result of the growth of self-service, Harold Jaeger, vice president and general manager of Geyer Advertising, Inc., said yesterday.

LEONARDO, N. J., Oct. 21 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy tonight called for whole-hearted cooperation by both Democrats and Republicans in defeating the Communist menace in the nation and in the world. He spoke before an audience of about 1,000 persons in the Leonardo grade school.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 957 pints of blood Tuesday.

Trans-World Airlines began yesterday eastbound non-stop service between Los Angeles and New York. The initial flight, made in a Super Constellation with fifty-eight passengers and a crew of five, arrived at the New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 6:26 A. M., 8 hours 17 minutes after taking off from the West Coast.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 21 -- The debate in the Constituent Assembly on the form of Constitution to be adopted by Pakistan bogged down today in a series of controversial interpretations of Islamic law.

Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, raised a question yesterday of whether "we have not now reached the point of diminishing returns in production of fissionable materials for military use."
Plans for the record $600,000,000 new financing program of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company were completed yesterday:

CAIRO, Oct. 21 -- Hopes for an early settlement of the British-Egyptian dispute over the Suez Canal base dimmed but did not die today. The negotiating teams of the two sides put their demands in writing for the first time and found that they could not be reconciled.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- The stock markets here closed on a firm note today after a day characterized by slackness of business and a dull start. The principal exception to an afternoon rally were South African gold minings, and weakness here was ascribed to the tone of the speech of Prime Minister Malan of South Africa to a congress of his Nationalist party.

Carl (Bobo) Olson of Honolulu became the middleweight champion of the world by defeating Randy Turpin, Leamington (England) fighter, in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night. Moving along inexorably after spotting his rival the first five rounds, Olson scored two knockdowns in gaining the unanimous decision.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Oct. 21 -- Corp. Edward S. Dickenson of Big Stone Gap, Va., one-time farmer, carpenter and "laborer" came back to the United Nations side today.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- The French Cabinet decided today to insist that Bao Dai, Chief of State of Vietnam, and his Government make it clear whether they intend to negotiate for further independence on the assumption that Vietnam will stay in the French Union or leave it.
LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Aneurin Bevan, leader of the radical wing of the British Labor movement, agreed today to oppose Herbert Morrison in the election of deputy parliamentary leader of the party.

The direction of the business affairs of the city of New York is lodged in the Board of Estimate, whose function is primarily executive rather than legislative. The board is composed of the three city officials who are elected citywide -- the Mayor, the Controller and the President of the City Council -- and the five Borough Presidents.
FRANK BOUCHER was thumbing through the National Hockey League rule book in his office at Madison Square Garden yesterday. Suddenly he stopped, stared quizzically at one item and started to laugh.
Directors of the Douglas Aircraft Company have voted an extra dividend of $1.50 in addition to the regular quarterly of $1 on the capital stock.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 21 -- A Baltimore grand jury presentment today named two city officials, eight other individuals and five corporations in a bribery inquiry.

VIENNA, Oct. 21 -- A speech two days ago by Udo Illig, Austrian Trade Minister, in which he seemed to complain that the United States was forcing Austria to accept goods instead of direct financial aid and was hurting her chances of trading with other countries, has caused considerable comment in diplomatic circles here.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 21 -- With the possible exception of one man, Army will be at full strength for the game with Columbia Saturday at Michie Stadium here.

If Miss Claire McCormick is the victim of any more thefts, they won't occur on Manhattan's upper West Side. She has moved from there to West New York, N. J., where she hopes for a quieter time. She made her move two weeks ago -- without benefit of her $3,800 coupe.

The Reynolds Metals Company, a leading producer of aluminum, not only established new records for sales and earnings in the first nine months of this year but the net for the three quarters almost matched the highest annual income in the company's history.
Production of newsprint in North America last month totaled 553,397 tons, just 412 tons less than was manufactured in September, 1952, according to the Newsprint Service Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Labor Department regime of Martin P. Durkin left the new Secretary, James P. Mitchell, and the Administration a "hot potato." It is a recommendation that the President ask Congress to raise the minimum wage from the present 75 cents an hour to $1.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Ascribing Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson's unpopularity in the country's farm community to a case of "pocketbook nerves" appears today as an over-simplification of his plight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- A $6,000 Cadillac automobile, complete with Texas license plates, was presented today to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, and his bride as a wedding gift.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 21 -- Henry L. Hopkinson, British Minister of State for Colonial Affairs, said today he was "entirely satisfied" that the Governor of British Guiana, Sir Alfred Savage, was justified in dismissing six elected local Ministers Oct. 9 and calling in British troops to guarantee order.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- President Eisenhower said today that the Tennessee Valley Authority was a historical fact and he did not know whether it could be sold to private industry without wrecking the whole system.

At Saratoga in August of '52 Mr. and Mrs. Michael F. Drinkhouse of Bedford, N. Y., bought a yearling for $300. They named him Marola. Yesterday at Jamaica, flying Mrs. Drinkhouse's silks, he won for the first time. His owner bet $2 across the board on him.

Sleek silhouettes in luxurious furs were presented yesterday at a luncheon at the Plaza Hotel by the House of Aronowicz. The furs were treated like fabrics in their cut and fit. An added asset was the natural depth and luster of the pelts.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- The General Assembly's Administrative and Budgetary Committee approved today an assessment scale for the 1954 United Nations budget. The United States' percentage of the bill is the smallest since the world organization began in 1945.

GENEVA, Oct. 22 -- Leaders of the governing body of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade were working desperately tonight to prevent a serious split between Britain and her Continental neighbors on commercial policy.

Dominick F. Paduano, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, issued an appeal to New Yorkers yesterday not to waste water. The city's Catskill and Croton water reserves were down to 133,989,000,000 gallons, or 52.9 per cent of capacity.

An American edition of a psychological study by Dr. Elie A. Cohen of concentration camp prisoners and jailers will be published Nov. 19 by Norton. The book, entitled "Human Behavior in the Concentration Camp," describes life in a camp and explains the behavior of prisoners and jailers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- The United States has decided to pull out the Coast Guard cutters it has contributed to the international network providing weather information to commercial planes flying the North Atlantic.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- Maj. Gen. Vagn Bennike, chief of the United Nations truce supervision organization in Palestine, declared today he did not think the present conditions in the Middle East would lead to a "major conflict between Israel and the Arab states."

Two fund raisers were acquitted by a Federal Court jury yesterday of using the mails fraudulently to collect money for alleged cancer victims. Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan, however, disagreed with the verdict and told the jury: "I think they are guilty."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UP) -- John Slezak, Assistant Secretary of the Army, said today the ammunition program, recently a subject of grave Congressional concern, was "in better shape" than ever before in the nation's history.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Maj. Gen. William F. Dean said today that he would take a lenient attitude toward United States soldiers who temporarily succumbed to Communist prisoner-of-war indoctrination.
HANOI, Oct. 22 -- French infantry backed by tanks seized today the important Vietminh base of Phunhoquan in the Day Mountains of Central Vietnam, south of the Tonkin delta.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 22 -- State food ministers are studying a Government analysis of rural economic reform in Communist China with a possible view to adapting to the Indian scene any suitable aspects.

Dealers in the metropolitan area were notified yesterday that beginning Nov. 1 they would have to pay approximately one-half cent more for a quart of milk to the 50,000 producers in the New York milkshed. It was not immediately clear when the increase would be passed on to the consumer.

MOSCOW, Friday, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A decree today ordered a 72 per cent increase in domestic consumer goods distribution by the end of 1954 in an effort to improve the living standards of the Soviet people.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, charged last night that the law firm of which Robert F. Wagner Jr. is a member had represented "underworld clients." These clients he named as Frank Costello, James J. Moran, who was found guilty of extortion, and Leonard Erickson, brother of Frank Erickson, the gambler.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Two Republican members of Congress from New York called upon the State Department today for an immediate explanation of its suspension of economic aid to Israel.
VIENNA, Oct. 22 -- The Austrian Government came to grips with Soviet occupation authorities tonight over the question of which of them is to control the actions of the Austrian police.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Robert F. Wagner Jr., who may become Mayor of New York City, was conforming to a familiar pattern in which American city politicians have great faith when he denounced as "cruel and intemperate" this Administration's action in withholding grants in aid from the State of Israel.

NEWARK, Oct. 22 -- Paul L. Troast, Republican candidate for Governor, asserted tonight that his Democratic opponent, Robert B. Meyner, had "demonstrated his unfitness for the high office of Governor" by criticizing the rule-making procedure of the New Jersey Supreme Court.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Two German-born biochemists, one an American and the other a Briton, were awarded the 1953 Nobel Prize for Medicine and Physiology jointly today. The prize was for their discovery concerning the basic life processes carried on within human cells.

TRENTON, Oct. 22 -- Carrying a briefcase and, in the words of a guard, looking "more like a lawyer than a criminal," Frank Erickson, once the reputed head of a nationwide gambling empire, was released from New Jersey State Prison here today after serving ten months and nineteen days.
A preview of fabrics and colors for next spring and summer was given yesterday at a luncheon of the fabrics division of the Fashion Group at the Astor Hotel. More than 350 new fabrics were displayed.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Despite a $10,000,000 increase in revenues, the Tennessee Valley Authority's net power income tumbled more than $6,000,000 during the 1953 fiscal year, compared with the previous year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Government acted today to insure that supplies of scrap iron and steel will not be siphoned off the domestic market for the benefit of foreign steel makers.

The leader of 1,200,000 unionized steel workers declared yesterday that the guaranteed annual wage would be a major demand in steel contract negotiations next year. But he indicated that no strike would be called to force its acceptance.
All the guards who went on strike fourteen days ago at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and its medieval uptown branch, the Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park, voted last night to return to work immediately.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Coast Guard representatives said today that they expected no difficulty in putting into effect next Jan. 1 the first major revision of the International Maritime Rules of the Road since 1897, when they were first set up.

Interest ran high yesterday at the opening of the Frank Lloyd Wright exhibition -- a fully furnished house and a pavilion displaying much of the architect's work on land adjoining the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, Fifth Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street.

GEORGE SCHOOL, Pa., Oct. 22 -- About this time last year things looked mighty dark for George School's young head football coach, Bob Geissinger. The former Springfield College quarterback, who took over the duties here in 1952, greeted a squad at that time that included only two letter men.

The conduct of the Italians when they invaded the Dalmatian coast in 1941 makes one apprehensive for what they may do to the port of Trieste should it be abandoned by the American and British troops without any previous guarantees as to the rights of its minority inhabitants or its future use as an international port.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission said today six manufacturers of commercial blotting paper have signed a consent agreement that they will not seek to fix prices.
The Atomic Energy Commission's decision to build a multi-million-dollar nuclear reactor for the large-scale generation of electric power is the opening of an important era in the story of power.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 22 -- Warner Brothers surprised the film industry today by adopting the CinemaScope widescreen system sponsored by Twentieth Century-Fox and discontinuing its efforts to further WarnerScope, a competitive process of photography and projection.

Vice Admiral Francis C. Denebrink disclosed yesterday that the Military Sea Transportation Service, which he commands, had reduced its fleet by 105 ships since August, when it controlled the operations of 602 vessels.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 22 -- A Federal court decision favoring the Greenwich Water Company's efforts to obtain rights to the Mianus River and rejecting the protests of twenty-two property owners was received here today.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Lord Cherwell, who, as Paymaster General, has been one of Prime Minister Churchill's most intimate advisers in the Cabinet for many years, is to resign from the Government almost immediately and resume his academic duties at Oxford University.

The great story ends in triumph and tragedy, victory in war and defeat in peace, and such is the way of humanity. We begin today the last of six volumes of memoirs written by the greatest protagonist in one of the greatest dramas of history.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- A natural sciences group tonight called upon scientists everywhere "to strengthen the spirit of free inquiry by clear and courageous public expression." Scientists were urged to lose their fear of being "labeled" for saying things they believed.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- If you ask George Munger, you can't beat the Pennsylvania football team for spirit and high morale -- not, after the comeback it made against Ohio tSate, following California's stampede on Franklin Field.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- During the week ended Oct. 21, member bank reserves increased $10,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

YONKERS, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Alan Myer of Bridgeville, Del., drove Ernest Duke to a handy victory in the Flatbush Face on the Grand Circuit program at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The 5-1 shot took the lead at the half after trailing Florita, driven by Bill Haughton, and never was headed thereafter.

IT was a wonderful fight. At the end Bobo Olson's chin trembled and his eyes welled with tears. He was crying. Randy Turpin laughed happily, beaming at friend and foe alike. But the disconsolate, emotionally wrought Olson was the winner and the jubilant Turpin was the loser. Yet it was that kind of fight, strange and unpredictable to the finish, brimful of action and surprise.
The Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday to make permanent $73,000,000 in cost-of-living bonuses for 110,000 city employes, effective Jan. 1.
In the welter of this campaign too little attention is being given to the constitutional amendments which will be set forth before the voters on Nov. 3.

Paul Hindemith's symphony, "Die Harmonie der Welt," which had its first New York performance at Carnegie Hall last night, is an impressive work, both in aim and in reach. It is not music designed for charm or easy appeal, and it may not win friends readily.

PARIS, Friday, Oct. 23 -- An agreement was reached early today among the majority parties of the National Assembly that insured the approval of a French farm reform program. The action averted a Cabinet crisis.

Although for a time it appeared that a tie would mar the proceedings, the New York Rangers' first game of the National Hockey League season on their home ice, was a success. While a crowd of 8,859 looked on in Madison Square Garden last night, the Broadway Blues defeated the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 3, in a tense contest.
The State Department was criticized here yesterday by a number of organizations for withholding economic aid to Israel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- President Eisenhower's commission on foreign economic policy will extend its inquiries to Europe next month.

Ilya Lopert, president of the Lopert Films Distributing Corporation, announced yesterday that he was withdrawing from the distribution field, turning over five current properties, "Gilbert and Sullivan," "The Captain's Paradise,'' "Fan Fan the Tulip," "The Man Between" and "Night Beauties," to United Artists to be handled as Lopert-United Artists releases.
MEN and women who work in New York skyscrapers by day never meet the men and women cleaners who take over at night. They form independent tides that never rip or cross.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 22 -- Marshal Tito, Yugoslav President, broadened today his original threat to send troops into Zone A of the Free Territory of Trieste.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 22 -- Mrs. Janet Jagan scoffed today at charges made by the British Government that she and other members of the People's Progressive party had plotted arson or other terrorist measures here.

HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 22 -- The atmosphere in Indo-China has improved and it appears that the French may have been mistaken in believing that Vietnam's nationalists wanted a complete break with France and the end of the Bao Dai regime.

A carefully prepared and extremely capable performance of Gottfried von Einem's opera, "The Trial" ("Der Prozess"), heard for the first time in America, was given last night, in English, by the New York City Opera Company at the City Center.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- The House of Commons decided by a vote of 294 to 256 tonight that the Government had acted wisely and justly in suspending the six-month-old Constitution of British Guiana because an allegedly Communist-dominated party had gained control of the Colonial legislature.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- American companies had investments of nearly $4,500,000,000 in petroleum enterprises abroad at the end of 1952, the Department of Commerce estimated today.

NOVARA, Italy, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Far behind the enemy lines in war-time, former Lieut. Aldo Icardi of Pittsburgh, Pa., turned into a playboy, wining and dining Italian signorinas after the mysterious murder of his commander, a witness testified today.

Interest in international adoptions has grown at such a rate since World War II that a large-scale study of the procedures and practices involved is urgently required, according to the American branch of the International Social Service. This is an agency of thirty years' standing, with branches, representatives and cooperating units in many countries.

All organizations purveying public transportation on land, by sea and airborne are required by governmental regulations to carry passengers and goods with the utmost regard for their safe arrival at destinations. It is axiomatic in law that a common carrier is an insurer of the persons and freight being transported.

YONKERS, Oct. 22 -- Mickey Homa of the Westchester Country Club and Harry Montevideo of Apawamis teamed for a six-under-par 134 to win the Metropolitan Professional Golf Association's pro-pro, best-ball championship over the Hudson River C. C. course today.

Most stocks showed little tendency to move in any direction yesterday and several leading groups were sluggish. But enough issues showed good gains to send THE NEW YORK TIMES industrial average to its best levels since Aug. 14 and the combined average to the highest point since Aug. 18.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 22 -- Representative Thomas B. Curtis, Republican of Missouri, suggested here today that it might be a good idea for "private concerns" to handle the nation's Social Security program.

The one-story building at 2310 Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn has been leased by Palmer Plastics, Inc., from Louis Richman. The Kalmon Dolgin Company was the broker. The building will be used by the lessee for the storage, shipping and distribution of plastic novelties.
TOKYO, Oct. 22 (UP) -- It was "take me out to the ball game" -- Japanese style -- for Ed Lopat's touring major league all-stars today and they all declared they never had seen anything like it.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 22 -- A busload of Western livestock men, the spearhead of a caravan, left here today for Washington, D. C., where they will protest low cattle prices and drought conditions at a meeting with Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 22 -- The National Metal Exposition and Congress stepped aside tonight to permit its sponsoring American Society for Metals to present awards to three of the nation's foremost metallurgical experts.

BOSTON, Oct. 22 -- The death toll in the blast and fire aboard the carrier Leyte last Friday rose to thirty-seven today when a Boston Naval Shipyard worker died at the Chelsea Naval Hospital. He was Charles J. Murphy, 51 years old, the fifth civilian to die of burns.

Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, accused the city's administration yesterday of a "callous attitude" toward unsafe and unsanitary housing of Puerto Rican and other families here. He declared "a lazy course of inaction" had been adopted to meet the problem.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 22 -- More than a dozen atomic cannon are being shipped to United States forces in Europe, top Army officials reported today.

Plans for the first stage of the new $6,500,000 aquarium at Coney Island were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. For the initial phase the board appropriated $450,000, which is to be matched by an equal amount from the New York Zoological Society.

PARIS, Oct. 22 -- A plea that European countries import more from each other and even from the dollar zone is made in a new report by the managing board of the European Payments Union, soon to be published.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- The United States has begun a program for the construction of its first full-scale atomic energy plant for peaceful use.
Volume was light yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Only soybean oil was active, with trading the heaviest since Oct. 2.
Electric bulbs of new design to serve as lamps, and lamps that can be used without electric cords, have been suggested as solutions to the problem of inadequate portable lamp designs.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Friday, Oct. 23 -- The pro-British Unionist party, which has been in power in Northern Ireland since the Government was established in 1921, won control of the House of Commons for the eighth successive time in the general election held yesterday.

Early commuters in downtown New York found the water curb-deep in a few spots off South and West Streets yesterday morning. A high perigee tide, possibly aided by the winds, had pushed sea water up into lower Manhattan storm sewers and out into the streets.

There is a deep hunger among the Russian people for American jazz, love songs and other popular music, according to Mrs. Thomas Whitney, wife of the former Associated Press correspondent in Moscow. Despite the vigilant efforts of Soviet officials to eradicate such music, she said, it is bootlegged and hummed and sung throughout the country.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Secretary of the Treasury, George M. Humphrey, today declared that the Administration "can make no promises of any tax reductions at all". next year except the corporation excess profits and individual income taxes.

TRENTON, Oct. 22 -- The long-awaited majority and minority reports of the legislative committee that last spring investigated the dismissal of Nelson F. Stamler were released here tonight. The action followed a stormy session of the committee at which an oral battle between members of the group lasted for nearly two hours.

A net income of $81,480,515 was made by the Shell Oil Company in the nine months ended with September, a substantial gain over the $62,656,651 net in the 1952 period, when earnings were adversely affected by a strike that shut down the company's Houston refinery and chemical plant for seventy-five days.
Business loans made by New York City banks declined $43,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, marking a shift in the local credit pattern that is at odds with seasonal experience.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- More than 200 prominent Americans signed a petition, delivered to President Eisenhower today, opposing the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens came from behind twice tonight to tie the Chicago Black Hawks and then went on to win, 3 to 2. Ken Mosdell scored the winning marker with less than two minutes to play to put Montreal in a tie with Detroit for first place in the National Hockey League standing.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 22 (AP) -- The University of South Carolina, bolstered by lightning-like passes and opposition fumbles, rolled to a 14-7 State Fair football triumph over Clemson College today.

The naming of Edward Allen Pierce as national campaign chairman of the 1953-54 appeal of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation for $5,000,000, beginning on Nov. 15, was announced yesterday. Mr. Pierce is a partner in the investment firm of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee was told today the Government's mineral and stockpiling policy "is absolutely in accord with the best desires of the Kremlin."

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 22 (AP) -- President Soekarno said in effect tonight that Vice President Richard M. Nixon's visit here from the United States would not change Indonesia's policy of trying to steer a middle course between Communism and the West.

Despite the hemming and hawing, "The Caine Mutiny Court Martial" is being routed into the Plymouth after all. Look for the Paul Gregory offering to arrive Jan. 18 with an all-male company headed by John Hodiak, Lloyd Nolan and Henry Fonda. The staging is credited to Dick Powell and the supervision to Charles Laughton.
LAOAG, the Philippines, Oct. 22 -- Ramon Magsaysay predicted today he would win the Presidency by 2,000,000 votes "if there is a clean election."

Two motorships will resume the carrying of truck trailers between New York and Albany on Nov. 9, as a result of a Federal ruling that truckers may charge shippers lower rates in using the water route.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Saturday's Pimlico Special shaped up late today as a two-horse race. Track officials said that only Tom Fool, the Greentree Stable champion that has won all nine starts this year, and E. P. Taylor's Navy Page were on hand to become entries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (UP) -- The nation's 14,000,000 factory production workers earned an average of $70.49 a week in mid-September. This was a decline of $1.20 from the previous month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 1,078 pints of blood on Wednesday, the largest day's total so far this month. Toward this amount New York Typographical Union 6, A. F. L., 853 Broadway, gave 318 pints; personnel at Camp Kilmer, New Brunswick, N. J., 304 pints; employes of the Guaranty Trust Company, 35 Nassau Street, 138 pints, and employes of the National City Bank, 20 Exchange Place, 136 pints.
Aurora Mauro-Cottone, in her seventh Town Hall recital since her debut in 1939, played a program of unusual interest last evening.
ROME, Oct. 22 -- Premier Giuseppe Pella had a half-hour's conversation with Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, United States Ambassador, today.
Construction plans for five new elementary schools and two junior high schools, estimated to cost $13,000,000, were approved yesterday by the Board of Education. They will accommodate 7,341 pupils.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 23 -- The neutral nations commissioners met for two hours today in an effort to find a formula for convincing the North Korean war prisoners to listen to the Communist "explainers." The prisoners have refused so far to hear the Reds, who want to try to win them back.

Meat prices dropped this week. The Consumers Service Bureau of the City Department of Markets attributes this to a disappointingly slow demand for this season of the years" caused in large measure by the unusually mild weather. Beef, lamb and veal today show substantial price changes at retail.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Further rain in the West and Southwest has brought substantial benefit to the winter wheat crop and changed the picture in that section radically.
SALISBURY, Southern, Rhodesia, Friday, Oct 23 (Reuters) -- The Central African Federation came into being today when the new Constitution took full effect.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 22 -- Israel asked the United Nations truce supervision organization tonight to investigate reports the Jordanian Government had concentrated Arab Legion forces near the Old City of Jerusalem and to order their withdrawal.

The first one of the United Nations prisoners who had at first been reluctant to return to the free world has changed his mind and has decided to come home. His parents have already said that they are happy to have him back. His local newspaper has spoken for the community in saying that he is no different from other returning soldiers and that they will be delighted to see him again.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Following are excerpts from today's address by Thomas E. Murray of the Atomic Energy Commission:

Dave Beck, chief strategist of the American Federation of Labor drive on the waterfront, was asked yesterday to testify before a Brooklyn grand jury next week on whether his organization planned to use strong-arm tactics in its recruiting drive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Admiral Robert B. Carney, Navy member of President Eisenhower's new Joint Chiefs of Staff, struck back today at critics who have described the Navy as outmoded in the era of atomic warfare.
Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., and Benson Hedges, two leading tobacco-processing companies, may soon merge.

Sibnath Banerjee, president of the Hind Mazdoor Sabha, the Indian Socialist Trade Union Federation, issued a statement yesterday defending Dr. Frank Buchman's Moral Rearmament Movement against criticism made in Brussels last Friday by the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.

ALBANY, Oct. 22 -- The Court of Appeals refused today to hear a case challenging the right of the New York City Board of Education to question teachers about Communist party affiliations and dismiss those who refuse to answer.

Fourteen candidates of the American Labor party joined yesterday in urging party members and trade unionists to disregard the editorial in yesterday's issue of The Daily Worker, Communist newspaper. In their opinion the editorial advised its readers to vote for Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor, but for A. L. P. candidates for other city offices.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A farmer will have to comply with all acreage allotments on basic crops next year to qualify for price support on any of them.

A syndicate of investors headed by Louis A. Fixell has purchased the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building for seventy-nine families on plot 128 by 104 feet at 245 West 104th Street, northwest corner of Broadway. There are eight stores in the property, which is assessed at $740,000 and which was sold subject to a mortgage of $605,000 held by the Equitable Life Assurance Society. Arthur S. Bernard was the broker.

When it was done last winter in the upper Forties, George Tabori's "The Emperor's Clothes" was not considered a strong drama by a majority of the Broadway savants. In its reincarnation last night on West Thirteenth Street -- to be exact, on the crowded stage of the Greenwich Mews Theatre -- the play about Budapest in 1930 still appeared to be rambling of character and wordy of disposition.

The four-story store and apartment building at 4530-4536 Park Avenue in Weehawken, N. J., has been sold by Seven Thirty Park Avenue, Inc., to Supplies and Repairs, Inc. J. L Kislak, Inc., was the broker and the attorneys were Thomas R. Armstrong for the seller and Hirschberg, Nashel, Zorn Cronson for the buyer.

In line with their London agreement to persevere in their joint efforts to bring about a lasting solution of the explosive Trieste problem the United States, Britain and France have now formally proposed a Five-Power conference with Italy and Yugoslavia to discuss the situation. The three Powers are in the happy position of being able to act in this matter in a wholly impartial and disinterested manner because they seek nothing for themselves.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- A Midwestern farmer stressed before the House of Representatives Committee on Agriculture a major problem that is faced by farmers and by the Administration in the matter of international relations through more imports of farm products.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Most of the exhibitors were, appropriately enough, installing their own displays on the Navy Pier here today in preparation for Chicago's first "Do-It-Yourself Show."
Carl Furillo, who raised his average almost 100 points to capture the batting title, was named yesterday as the player having made the greatest comeback of the 1953 National League baseball season.

A WITLESS and tasteless charade, put on in the distinctive style of a road company Minsky, marked the return of Bob Hope to his video chores on Tuesday evening over N. B. C. television. The program was the season's low.
Supporters of Robert F. Wagner Jr. went to court yesterday to compel the State Parole Board to make public the names of all those who had tried to get a parole for Joseph S. Fay, labor extortionist.

A prominent member of the United States Senate is fond of saying, as he did to a New Jersey audience a couple of nights ago, "You don't go skunk-hunting in striped trousers and a tall hat while waving a lace handkerchief." This picturesquely and typically irrelevant remark may or may not satisfy his listeners, but it may also raise some questions in their minds about other things you don't -- or shouldn't -- do.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- Sheikh Ahmed Abdul Jabbar of Saudi Arabia called today on the conscience of the western nations, and particularly France, to alter their stand on the complaint against French rule in the Protectorate of Tunisia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, issued a statement of welcome today to Nasrollah Entezam, Iran's Ambassador-designate, who will present his credentials later to President Eisenhower. Mr. Dulles said he hoped Iran would flourish with the end of Communist-abetted disorders.

In certain well - run homes there are two desks One, a dainty thing like its owner, is used for keeping in splendid disorder the household's petty finances, and for conducting occasional social correspondence. Beyond an infrequent surprise inspection of the books, after plaintive notes have been received from the stores, this desk remains untouched save by its rightful proprietor.

Madison Square Garden will be the scene of boxing for the second time in three days when Pierre Langlois of France faces Garth Panter, a 23-year-old Salt Lake City scrapper, in the main bout of ten rounds tonight. The 27-year-old Frenchman ranked tenth among the middleweights, is favored to win and thereby move a step closer to a bout with the new champion, Carl (Bobo) Olson.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Few Republicans in Congress seemed happy today with President Eisenhower's strong defense of Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, at a time when the President announced he was shunning any active role in next year's Congressional election campaign.
OTTAWA, Oct. 22 -- Dr. Charlotte Whitton, Mayor of Ottawa, declared open warfare today on the Canadian Government's ambitious construction plan for the Federal capital.

The American Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that the "Motorola TV Hour," a dramatic series, would make its debut on Dec. 1, alternating with the "United States Steel Theatre" on Tuesdays from 9:30 to 10:30 P. M. The new series, to be sponsored by Motorola, Inc., will be produced by Herb Brodkin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on last Saturday, Oct. 17, aggregated 822,539 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 18,469 cars, or 2.3 per cent more than for the preceding week, 15,869 cars, or 1.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 64,109 cars, or 7.2 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

A Supreme Court jury yesterday awarded William Burdick, 55-year-old carpenter, of 219 East Twenty-third Street, $56,150 damages for injuries suffered on Jan. 23, 1952, when a policeman mistook him for a hold-up man shot him in the left leg.

The nation's business seems to be heading toward a decline likely to cause a fall in the Federal Reserve Index of industrial production from the September level of 234 to about 200, the level of 1950.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, unchanged to 9 points down. The market opened 3 to 7 points off and held within a narrow range all day. There was some hedge selling, and December liquidation increased.
Whenever Columbia defeated Army's football team, the victory provided a full share of thrills for Lion fans. This has happened four times during a span of sixteen games since 1899.
Some sound advice for salesmen is contained in the latest issue of "Lost Sales -- Their Causes and Remedies," published by the National Sales Executives.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 22 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, having led West Germany a long way on the road back to independence and freedom since 1949, hopes to take another big step forward within the next few months.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Lothair Teetor, Indiana industrialist, was appointed Assistant Secretary of Commerce today by President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the Methodist Church denounced tonight those who had barred him from making an address next month in the Philharmonic Auditorium in Los Angeles as "a few misguided little men."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- Only an efficient ground observation corps could provide adequate warning against hostile aircraft, Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, said in a letter delivered here today. The letter was designed to stimulate volunteer staffing of Westchester observation posts and the thirty-two-county air raid filter center.

As Halloween approaches, pumpkin, one of New England's oldest vegetables, comes into its own. As spicy fragrant pie it holds an esteemed place in American tradition through Thanksgiving, Christmas and the entire holiday season. The pumpkin jack-o'-lantern of Halloween recalls the ancient superstition that evil spirits bent on destroying fall crops roamed the fields. The lighted candle within remains as a symbol of great fires built in pagan days to protect the harvest.
Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens served notice yesterday that he would attempt to shift the cost of repairing the condemned Queens sewer to the entire city.
CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- American business must increase its efforts to raise consumption in the coming decade, Paul Mazur, senior partner of Lehman Brothers of New York, said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Department store sales in the week ended on Oct. 17 were 5 per cent below those in the corresponding week of last year. This was the third consecutive week in which sales showed a decline from 1952, the Federal Reserve Board reported. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1952:

TRENTON, Oct. 22 -- Robert B. Meyner, Democratic candidate for Governor, declared here tonight that both the majority and minority reports of the legislative committee that investigated the discharge of Deputy Attorney General Nelson F. Stamler failed to disclose why the links between the underworld and the political "higher ups" had not been exposed.
PARIS, Oct. 22 -- A treaty declaring Laos to be "fully independent and sovereign" but within the French Union was signed today.
The secrecy that has surrounded the ill-fated $49,000,000 synthetic gasoline plant of Carthage Hydrocol, Inc., of Brownsville, Tex., has been lifted partly.

VIENNA, Oct. 22 -- Although United States strategic planners months ago abandoned the concept of a "critical year," advocates of the European army are using a similar line of thought to urge its swift implementation.
LONDON, Oct. 22 -- The supply of gasoline in London and its suburbs was rapidly drying up today as the strike by drivers ran into its third day.

Vassily Smyslov, 32-year-old Soviet grandmaster, won the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich and the right to play Mikhail Botvinnik of Moscow for the title next year, according to a Swiss news report last night.
SENDAI, Japan, Oct. 22 (UP) -- The New York Giants unleashed a fifteen-hit attack today to defeat a combined team of the Tokyo Giants and Kokutetsu Swallows, 10 -- 4.

Only four months ago Rear Admiral Hyman G. Rickover, named yesterday to head the first full-scale atomic energy plant for peacetime use, was nearly forced into retirement from the Navy. This was despite the fact he was in charge of construction of the first atomic-powered submarine.
BOSTON, Oct. 22 -- Excessive overhead costs were described tonight by Clifford F. Hood, president of the United States Steel Corporation, as the biggest challenge facing the economy.
Arthur O. Dietz, president of the C. I. T. Financial Corporation, informed stockholders yesterday that the credit picture in its retail automobile financing operations is satisfactory.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 22 -- Prime Minister Churchill has discussed with intimate advisers the possibility of attending the current session of the United Nations General Assembly. If he should attend, it is understood, he would use this dramatic means to urge a settlement of critical issues between the Soviet Union and the Western powers.
MANILA, Oct. 2 -- The disposition of the armed forces has attracted much attention in connection with the election campaign.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Business remained quiet and prices continued to move narrowly and irregularly on the stock markets today. However, the rises outnumbered the falls in nearly all markets except those for the mining and oil shares.

DETROIT, Oct. 22 -- Dave Beck, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., today disciplined five of six local union officers charged with mulcting contractors and soliciting bribes.

KINGSPORT, Tenn., Oct. 22 (UP) -- Thruston B. Morton, Assistant Secretary of State, said today passage of the controversial Bricker amendment to limit the President's treaty-making powers would be a blow to national security.
PADUCAH, Tex., Oct. 22 (UP) -- Senator Robert S. Kerr, Democrat of Oklahoma, said tonight President Eisenhower knew "too little" about farm problems.

A stock dividend of 10 per cent was proposed yesterday by directors of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, subject to approval of shareholders at a special meeting on Nov. 12. It would be the bank's first stock-dividend since 1945.
BOSTON, Oct. 22 -- You just follow your nose to find the path to a Nobel Prize.
The International Business Machines Corporation cleared $24,092,078 in the first nine months of this year, $2,840,845 more than in the 1952 period.
