Rudolph Halley has issued a challenge to Robert F. Wagner Jr. and Harold Riegelman, two of his rival candidates for Mayor, to debate the campaign issues by radio land television.
LONDON, Oct. 22 -- A famous British physiologist said tonight: "Dr. Krebs taught us how the body manages to convert foods such as sugar, fats and amino acids into energy.
The Governor's special commission investigating trotting racetracks in New York State will hold its first public hearing next Wednesday in the State Supreme Court Building on Foley Square.
Department stores were urged yesterday to adopt the methods used by manufacturers to determine costs and profits.
A grant of $329,000 has been made to Columbia University by the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation for the establishment of a center for the study of air flight structures.
BERLIN, Oct. 22 -- Dr. Walther Schreiber, a Christian Democrat, was elected Mayor of West Berlin today to succeed the late Dr. Ernst Reuter, a Social Democrat.
Russia has boasted of plans to use atomic energy for peacetime pursuits since Sept. 23, 1949, when President Truman announced that an atomic explosion had taken place in the Soviet Union.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22 -- Harry Bridges, West Coast long-shore leader, expressed reserved sympathy today for steamship operators with their reduced profits. However, he scoffed at statements that "waterfront labor difficulties" had caused a sharp post-war decline in coast wise and intercoastal shipping.
WHITEVILLE, N. C., Oct. 22 (UP) -- The imprisoned Imperial Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan renounced the organization today and urged that it be disbanded.

The Peron-controlled Latin-American Federation of Labor (A. T. L. A. S.) has issued its first direct attack on the Communist-dominated World Federation of Trade Unions and the pro-Communist Latin-American Labor Federation (C. T. A. L.) led by Vicente Lombardo Toledano of Mexico. These blasts are obviously part of the Argentine President's campaign to woo favor in the United States.

THE ill wind, a warm one, which is making things difficult for the upland game and waterfowl shooters, is providing pleasant fishing weather for the salt-water enthusiasts. The big bluefish are still lurking in the vicinity of Shrewsbury Rocks.

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Oct. 22 -- A German scientist has given testimony indicating that the Russians had access to secret radar information from the Evans Signal Laboratory of the Army at Belmar, N. J.
ABOARD THE S. S. NIEUW AMSTERDAM, Oct. 22 -- Representative Jesse P. Wolcott, Republican of Michigan, said yesterday there probably would be no necessity of increasing the Government debt limit.

Determined to bring the cost of maintaining city bus service down to a reasonable level, the Transit Authority plans to put experts in automotive maintenance in key positions on its bus operating staff.

Carl (Bobo) Olson couldn't wait to get back to the wife and kids. The sturdy Hawaiian who moved into the middleweight championship of the world by outpointing Randy Turpin in fifteen rounds at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night left by plane for his home in San Francisco at 8 o'clock yesterday morning.

The New York Football Giants, anxious to bring all possible offensive pressure to bear on the Cleveland Browns, may start their three best running backs in the same backfield in Sunday's game with the undefeated Eastern Conference leaders at the Polo Grounds.

Mayor Impellitteri, ruled off the ballot on Wednesday, announced last night that he would not participate in a write-in campaign, despite the urging of supporters. He asked also that they refrain from carrying on any such campaign.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 23 (UP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, charged tonight there was "political significance" behind an indictment against Sidney S. Kellam, former state Democratic campaign manager.

Your editorial comment of Oct. 13 entitled "No Textbooks on Trial," following the story of the previous day from Albany about the fact that no charges regarding textbooks had been filed in twenty months with the special commission appointed to hear such charges if any, rejoices too soon, and on the wrong point.

BOSTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Fullback Lou Petroka raced 77 yards for a touchdown 70 seconds after the opening kick-off tonight to start Boston University's hard-running football forces rolling for a 52-12 victory over Lehigh. While scoring eight touchdowns and four conversions, the Terriers equaled their single game scoring record.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- The Trustee Committee of the United Nations General Assembly adopted today a resolution urging the Secretary General to employ persons from non-self-governing territories for positions on the secretariat.

The controversy between the Kings County Medical Society and the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York flared again yesterday when Dr. George Baehr, president of the plan, canceled a proposed meeting at which the two groups were to have discussed their differences.

Among this week's art exhibitions there is one made up of imaginary paintings of American scenes by twenty leading young Italian artists. These pictures are being shown, for the benefit of the Hospitalized Veterans Music Fund, at the apartment of Helena Rubinstein (Princess Gourielli), 625 Park Avenue.
LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Troops moved into the London area tonight ready to man gasoline tank trucks and to cope with the threat of a complete stoppage of motor driven traffic in the city.
The New York Regional Red Cross Program received 935 pints of blood on Thursday from donors at collection centers and at Blood-mobile units.

PANMUNJOM, Oct. 23 -- The neutral nations commission will toss its problem back to the two opposing sides in the Korean conflict. It is the commission's idea that, if the United Nations Command and the Communists cannot come up with a solution to the problem themselves, at least they will fully understand the commission's difficulty.

MOSCOW, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The announcement of measures to increase internal trade indicates that some of the best brains in the Soviet Union have received the task of making good on the Government's promise to raise living standards.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 23 (UP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway warned of the "implacable hostility" of communism to education today at ceremonies dedicating the Patton Memorial Library at Lafayette College. The library, donated by Mrs. Marcellus Dodge, was named for the late Gen. George S. Patton.
OTTAWA, Oct. 23 (Canadian Press) -- A seamen's strike threatening to paralyze Canada's ocean merchant fleet ended today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Army Chief of Staff, will leave Sunday for the Far East on a "routine inspection trip," the Army announced today.

OTTAWA, Oct. 23 -- One of the matters preoccupying the minds of Louis St. Laurient, the Prime Minister, and other government leaders is the tune with which to greet President Eisenhower on his visit here.

TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 24 -- Arthur H. Dean, special United States envoy, flew to Korea today for a meeting with Communist representatives at Panmunjom to work out plans for the Korean political conference.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Speaking to members of Parliament from his party, the Independent Republicans, Premier Joseph Laniel said today that France must "hold firm" in Indo-China if she wanted to prevent a capitulation that would lead to "a massacre." He

LEYLAND, England, Oct. 23 -- A Centurion tank, standard armored weapon of Britain and many of the Continental members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, rumbled off the production lines here this afternoon, the first product of Europe's most modern tank factory.
At 40, Rudolph Halley is the youngest of the candidates for Mayor and the only one with a national reputation.

AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 23 (Reuters) -- Arab nations have rejected a plan presented here by President Eisenhower's special envoy for a joint irrigation and power project with Israel, Abdullah Yafi, Premier of Lebanon, said tonight.
DETROIT, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A Packard Motor Company spokesman said that the Chrysler purchase of Briggs would have no immediate effect on Packard.

BOSTON, Oct. 23 -- A Tewksbury, Mass., man, 51 years old, who had been confined to the state farm as a mental delinquent since he was 10, was among fourteen men enjoying freedom today by order of the Massachusetts Superior Court.
The New York commodity exchanges yesterday were quiet, as is usual as the week end nears.
No action was taken yesterday on the dividend of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company usually declared at this time.

Theatregoers attending last night's performance of "The Frogs of Spring" at the Broadhurst were treated to the unusual spectacle of witnessing Anthony Ross in the role of a Manhattan dweller in the first act and Burgess Meredith, director of the comedy, in the same part for the second and third acts.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 23 -- The Indian custodial forces are considering the segregation of anti-Communist leaders in the prisoner-of-war camps in Korea, who are blamed for fomenting recalcitrance of their fellow inmates.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- A crowd of 27,000 is expected to be on hand at Michie Stadium tomorrow to see the seventeenth football game between Army and Columbia.
ALBANY, Oct. 23 -- Dr. William S. Dix, librarian of Princeton University, called tonight for a research program directed at uncovering "the psychological and sociological causes of book burning."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- Dr. H. E. Moussa al-Shabandar, Iraqi Ambassador to the United States, said at the fall meeting of American Friends of the Middle East today that relations between the United States and the Arab world were being "poisoned."
LONDON, Oct. 23 -- The first recorded cases of impregnation of women with stored frozen semen have been reported by United States researchers.

TOKYO, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Gen. John E. Hull told the Japanese today the United States could not and did not want to keep armed forces here indefinitely and that Japan must take over her own security as soon as possible.

A consolidated net profit of $14,245,795 was reported yesterday by the Procter Gamble Company for the three months ended on Sept. 30, last. This is equal to $1.48 a share of common stock and one of the best showings for the period on record. It compares with $12,637,208 or $1.31 a common share made in the similar quarter a year ago.

Brooklyn opened its 168th playground yesterday. The three-acre site adjacent to Public School 269 at Foster and Nostrand Avenues also was identified as the 591st built in New York by the Department of Parks.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 -- Gordon Dean, former chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today that we should serve notice on the Russians of our readiness to use the atomic bomb if necessary.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 --- "Deliberate sabotage" of the United States merchant marine, "inspired by the Communist party on the Pacific Coast," was charged today by Harry Lundeberg, secretary-treasurer of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L.

" LEAVING HOME,"* our first book this morning, is a galvanic three-part chronicle of Brooklyn destinies in the Nineteen Thirties by Elizabeth Janeway. This is the story of two sisters and a brother -- Nina, Marion and Kermit Bishop -- their manners, morals, marriages and misalliances. One gets to Scarsdale, one gets to Vassar, one gets to Washington. But none of the three ever really leaves Bay Ridge.

Britain's House of Commons has acted wisely, we believe, in sustaining the Government's prompt and vigorous action to scotch a Communist assault upon the potential liberties of British Guiana. The predicted outcries of iron-handed "imperialism" have, of course, materialized.

BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., Oct. 23 (AP) -- An official of the Saratoga National Bank testified today that he never had discussed bank affairs with Herbert C. Stone, missing Gloversville man, although Mr. Stone was listed as the bank's principal stockholder.

The American thesis on the Indo-Chinese problem, upheld with so much conviction in THE NEW YORK TIMES, seems justified according to the norms of global anti-Communist strategy. The eventual fall of this key position into Communist hands will ring the knell of Southeastern Asia.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor, has promised to drive racketeers from the waterfront if he is elected. He added, however, that this would be only a part of his program to correct conditions that are driving shipping business from the Port of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- Powerful Navy, unbeaten and tied once in four games, will meet the University of Pennsylvania on Franklin Field tomorrow in a football game that is expected to attract 50,000 fans.

Mayor Impellitteri condemned yesterday the "almost criminal public apathy in New York" and the election law that kept him off the ballot. He said that, were it not for these things, he would have been re-elected Mayor.
The cotton futures market closed barely steady yesterday, unchanged to 4 points off, with trading on the New York Cotton Exchange light.

The end of hostilities in Korea and a slackening in Government aid cargoes have increased the National Defense Reserve Fleet in the Hudson River off Jones Point, N. Y., opposite Peekskill, N. Y., to 154 ships, the largest concentration of vessels ever assembled in a single anchorage in the river.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Oct. 9 -- The opening of remote and desolate reaches of the Sahara through industrialization, a dream long cherished by a handful of visionaries, has lately reached the stage of actual planning.

Samuel Reshevsky of New York, representing the United States in the world chess championship challengers' tournament in Zurich, yesterday completed his schedule by drawing with Mark Taimanov of Russia, in a thirteenth-round match, according to a Swiss news report.

William Raisch, who was consulting engineer for Queens when that borough's $18,000,000 Corridor Sewer System was built, termed as "ridiculous" yesterday Borough President James A. Lundy's charge that a section a third of a mile long was "in danger of immediate collapse."

The general elections in Northern Ireland reaffirmed a long-existing state of affairs. The "Six Counties" are strongly Protestant and profoundly, attached to Britain and the Commonwealth. It therefore stood to reason that the conservative, pro-partitionist Unionist party was going to win the election as easily as it in fact did.

ALBANY, Oct. 23 -- The Court of Appeals cleared the way today for the construction of the New York Coliseum, the $20,000,000 convention and exhibition hall that the city plans to build in the Columbus Circle area.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Italy's Ambassador said today that he had been reassured by the State Department that the United States and Britain would honor their decision to turn over Zone A of Trieste to Italy.
GENEVA, Oct. 23 -- Japan was admitted to the trade councils of the free world today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- United States District Court Judge F. Dickinson Letts ruled today Representative Ernest K. Bramblett, Republican of California, must stand trial on all eighteen counts of an indictment accusing him of payroll padding. The trial is scheduled to begin Dec. 2
The Chrysler Corporation plans to buy the plants, machinery and equipment of its principal body builder, the Briggs Manufacturing Company, for $35,000,000.
ALBANY, Calif., Oct. 23 (UP) -- Wee Willie Shoemaker rode three winners at Golden Gate Fields today to reach and pass the dream goal of 400 victories in a season.

YONKERS, Oct. 23 -- Trustful Hanover, owned by C. N. Myers and L. B. Sheppard of Hanover, Pa., and driven by Hugh Bell, set a world record of 2:02 for 3-year-old pacing fillies on a half-mile track by winning the Dobbs Ferry, a junior free-for-all mile event at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

Since plays by Shakespeare's contemporaries are not often performed in this community, the production of Beaumont's "The Knight of the Burning Pestle" has some sight-seeing value at the Theatre de Lys, where it opened last evening. It was first produced about 1607, when Shakespeare was writing such plays as "Troilus and Cressida" and "Antony and Cleopatra" and when Ben Jonson was writing court masques for the new king and queen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower watched Julius La Rosa, who was dismissed by Arthur Godfrey, star today in a dress rehearsal of a musical for a Navy benefit and told him afterward he had put on a "wonderful" show.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 23 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, declared today that doubtful security risk cases involving military personnel should be resolved in favor of the nation, not the individual.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Government halted sales tonight of its Series C Treasury savings notes to clear the way for the marketing of $1,500,000,000 to $2,000,000,000 of longer-term issues next week.

The possibility that Marshal Bulganin may be shifted from Defense Minister to a new post as head of Soviet consumer goods production and distribution seems suggested by the news that he, as well as Deputy Premier Mikoyan, participated in the Moscow conference.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- Two factions of underdeveloped nations introduced separate resolutions here today in an effort to unhinge the proposed special fund for economic development from the requirement that the world disarm.

NOVARA, Italy, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A dark-haired former partisan agent testified today she was sure that if former Lieut. Aldo Icardi ordered the slaying of Maj. William Holohan he had done it on superior instructions.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- The American Joint Distribution Committee, the largest welfare organization aiding needy Jews abroad, announced today that it planned a budget of $27,372,000 for next year to aid 200,000 persons in Israel, North Africa, the Near East and Europe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- A review of our foreign aid budgeting is under way with the probability that military assistance funds in the program will be appropriated directly to the Department of Defense rather than to the Foreign Operations Administration as heretofore.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett expressed the belief last night that United States-Israeli friendship would remain constant and stable despite present "misunderstandings."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- J. Howard McGrath, former Attorney General, is taking a post as executive vice president of Edward Lamb Enterprises, Inc., of Toledo, which controls various broadcasting and manufacturing companies. Mr. Lamb, who announced the appointment, said that Mr. McGrath would "spend considerable time at each of our operations."

" Russian Influence on Early America," a new work by Clarence A. Manning of the Slavic History Department of Columbia University, will be issued by Library Publishers on Dec. 3. The author gives a history of Russian expansion in nineteenth-century America and offers an interpretation of Russia's past philosophy of expansion and a comparison with the U.S.S.R.'s present foreign policy, casting light on current problems between East and West.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 23 -- Fordham's air-minded football team will be a one-touchdown favorite when it invades Rutgers stadium tomorrow afternoon.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 23 -- The University of Michigan observed the centennial of its Engineering College today. Having awarded 21,500 graduate and undergradute degrees in its 100 years, the college paused to mark its past and -- with the help of a critical layman -- to survey the future.
LONDON, Oct. 23 -- The volume of business dwindled further in the stock markets here today. Prices again moved indecisively, with a slight tendency to drift lower.

Samuel Palley and Louis Kraft, builders, are expanding their Utopia Ranch Homes colony at Sixty-seventh Avenue and Utopia Parkway in the Fresh Meadow section of Queens, where an exhibit model is on display. They have just completed forty houses and now plan to construct twenty more.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 23 -- The United Nations Israel-Jordan Mixed Armistice Commission today condemned "armed Jordanians" for mining an Israeli train yesterday morning, and derailing a locomotive and a number of fuel cars. No one was injured.

MIAMI, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Mighty Maryland slashed to a three-touchdown lead over Miami's Hurricanes in a thirteen-minute demonstration of running and passing power tonight, then coasted to a 30-0 victory in the Orange Bowl.

Borough President Cashmore of Brooklyn has given assurance that the march of progress will not mean the destruction of the historic Wyckoff House at Ditmas Avenue and East Fifty-ninth Street in the Brooklyn Flat-lands area. Reputedly the oldest dwelling in the United States -- built in 1637 -- the Wyckoff House had been threatened by street and sewer plans with the razing of its right wing.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 23 -- The Yale University cross-country team swept the first three places to score a startling upset victory over Manhattan and Fordham today.
The Metropolitan Mixed Pair championship went last night to the contract bridge pair of Mrs. Blanche Reeves and Lester Gluckman of New York.
Notre Dame and Georgia Tech, playing before a capacity crowd of 57,000 in the red brick stadium at South Bend, Ind., command top billing on today's intercollegiate football program.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Opponents of the allegedly Communist dominated People's Progressive party of British Guiana appealed today for capital investment and propaganda by Britain to counter Communist influence in the colony.
Despite a higher volume of sales, consolidated net income of the Studebaker Corporation dropped to $4,171,498 in the first nine months this year from $9,299,511 a year ago.

VIGAN, the Philippines, Oct. 23 -- Ilocos Sur has been frequently mentioned by the Nationalists as the province in which President Elipidio Quirino's administration Liberals were resorting to intimidation and other irregular means to insure victory in the forthcoming Philippines Presidential elections.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau took a good look at the drought today and pronounced it -- in places -- the worst in history. But there are indications that the severe dry spell may be breaking up soon, with rains already coming to parts of the parched Southwest and Midwest.
ALBANY, Oct. 23 -- Governor Dewey today closed to campers and sportsmen all forests in the state except those in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
HAVANA, Oct. 21 -- The political situation in Cuba is baffling, unsatisfactory and even dangerous but there are hopeful elements in it.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- The custom of a young man's "asking father" for permission to marry the girl of his choice may have faded out of use, but parents still wield a powerful influence over their youngsters' choice of a spouse, according to Dr. Marvin Sussman, Professor of Sociology at Union College here.

Twelve shoppers on a crowded Brooklyn thoroughfare were injured yesterday, none seriously, when a 65-year-old woman lost control of her car, mounted the curb and ran for forty feet among pedestrians on the sidewalk.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 23 -- A Bronx contractor was electrocuted here today while working with his men on a million-dollar sewer construction project.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 23 -- An authoritative Government official said today that Yugoslavia was prepared for a compromise on the territorial boundary of Zone A of Trieste that would still leave the port city of Trieste to Italian sovereignty.

The New York Chapter of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation will start its 1953 fundraising campaign with a thirteen-hour telethon over WPIX and, in part, over all other New York TV stations on Saturday, Oct. 31 at 11 P. M.
For the second day, a perigee spring tide caused tidal waters to overflow some city streets and low acres in the suburbs.

Gabriel Banat gave a violin recital in Town Hall last night. There were some admirable qualities about his playing. In matters pertaining directly to the fiddle Mr. Banat has solved a good many of the problems that have brought gray hair to his elders.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Cambodian Government announced today that King Norodom Sihanouk would end a self-imposed exile from his capital early next month.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 23 -- A secret indictment returned against Anthony Valentino, former union official, on Oct. 22, 1952, during his trial here on charges of filing a false non-Communist affidavit under the Taft-Hartley Law, was released today from the United States District Court.
Meeting here yesterday and Thursday were fifty representatives of a little-known type of social service. They were delegates to the annual conference of the National Committee on Homemaker Service.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 23 -- The election results announced today gave the Unionist party four more seats in Northern Ireland's House of Commons to bring its total to thirty-five in the fifty-two-member House.

Sales of quality merchandise are far in advance of lower priced goods in almost every ready-to-wear classification. This was the report of Felix Lilienthal Co., resident buying office in its monthly market digest, issued yesterday.

In an unprovoked attack, a Yugoslav seaman scheduled to be deported yesterday afternoon slugged and seriously injured Robert G. Thompson, a Communist party leader, with a lead pipe. The attack came while both men were in line awaiting lunch in the Federal House of Detention, 427 West Street.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 23 -- British colonial authorities are "actively considering" criminal proceedings against some of the leaders of the British Guiana People's Progressive party.

The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company has leased the tenth floor for New York sales offices in the fifteen-story and penthouse building being built by the Rovi Corporation at 579 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of East Fortyseventh Street. A similar building

THE long-studied assault on England by unmanned missiles now began; the target was Greater London. For more than a year we had argued among ourselves about the character and scale of the attack, and every preparation which our wits could devise and our resources permit had been made in good time.

Sales of two new homes in the Colonial Heights section of Yonkers, N. Y., were reported by Nathan Rikelman, broker. Lawrence Jossen bought the dwelling at 41 St. George Parkway from Puzio Pacifico, builders; Joseph Russack bought one of the Minerva Ranch Homes being built by the Louis Construction Corporation on Helena Avenue.

AXTELL, Neb., Oct. 23 (UP) -- An ammunition truck exploded on a highway today with a force that blew the vehicle to bits and rocked buildings twenty miles away. It was the fourth such occurrence in six weeks and followed a similar mishap at Lovelock, Nev., only yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 23 -- A flash fire swept the experimental fishing trawler Delaware amidships just before noon today but was halted before it damaged any of the scientific equipment aboard. The cause and the extent of damage were not officially disclosed.
Magazines are stepping up their circulation promotions in connection with holiday season issues.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, made a new demand to Robert F. Wagner Jr. last night for an explanation by the Democratic nominee of his law firm representing Frank J. Costello, underworld overlord; James J. Moran, convicted extortionist, and Leonard Erickson, brother of Frank Erickson, the boss bookmaker.

Upward momentum for the stock market began to peter out about noon yesterday. Prices moved down under the leadership of the chemicals, with the result that the list closed with a small net loss, the first in eight sessions.
In a recent editorial you commented on the Citizens Committee's report on the Children's Court and the necessity for full discussion of the suggestions included in the report.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said yesterday that the number of suspensions of civilian specialists in radar-electronics work at Fort Monmouth, N. J., had risen to a minimum of twenty and might exceed that amount substantially.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- Lieut. Gen. John B. Coulter, Agent General for the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency, declared today that a smoothly coordinated program had been worked out between the agency and the more extensive United States bi-lateral aid program.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- The General Assembly re-elected Dr. G. J. van Heuven Goedhart of the Netherlands today to serve five more years as United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The White House announced today that 1,456 employes had been forced off the Federal payroll in four months of the Eisenhower Administration's security program.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- The American Association for the United Nations completed preparations today for tomorrow's outdoor public celebration of United Nations Day, at noon at the United Nations Plaza and Forty- fifth Street.
Corporations and local governments planning to borrow in the public market next week stand to benefit from the strength of the bond market.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent to 110 per cent of the 1947-49 average in the week ended on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said after a White House conference today that the Administration would propose some "improvements" in the present farm program early next year. Nothing "revolutionary," however, was contemplated, the Secretary added.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- An "encouraging decrease" in bias in schools throughout the country is indicated in a report that will be read tomorrow at a meeting of the American Jewish Committee's executive committee.

Mrs. Agnes E. Meyer renewed her attacks yesterday on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. She said he was a handicap the Republican party "can no longer afford," and urged that Congress control investigations that were "conducted in total disregard of established American principles of justice and fair play."

Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians has given the Metropolitan Opera an ultimatum that if no new contract has been agreed on by Nov. 2, when the orchestra is scheduled to start rehearsing, the instrumentalists will not appear for work.

Events today: "Hansel and Gretel," City Center, 2:30; Claudio Arrau, pianist, Town Hall, 3; "La Boheme," City Center, 8:15; Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Whittemore and Lowe, duo-pianists, Carnegie Hall, 8: 45.

Queen Elizabeth has personally invested Dr. Frank Aydelotte with the insignia of a Knight of the British Empire. No one who knows Dr. Aydelotte's magnificent service to the whole institution of the Rhodes Scholarships could quarrel with this bestowal of a richly deserved honor.

Families of returning Korean prisoners are advised to encourage their participation in normal community life as soon as possible. The more quickly they can enjoy the pleasures of everyday hometown living as individuals, the sooner they will be able to put out of their minds the horrible experiences they have gone through, say spokesmen for the National Recreation Association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 23 -- "The Way West," the 1950 Pulitzer Prize novel by A. B. Guthrie Jr., has been purchased for filming by Hecht-Lancaster Productions. The author is working for the independent company, preparing the screen play of "The Gabriel Horn," a novel by Felix Holt dealing with pioneer days in western Kentucky.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 23 -- Debates on the Palestine question were scheduled today for Tuesday morning and afternoon by the United Nations Security Council.

Paul Douglas, who has not appeared on Broadway since 1946, when he gained wide attention for his portrayal of the obtuse junk man in "Born Yesterday," is returning to Broadway as guest star of the successful comedy hit, "The Seven Year Itch," at the Fulton Theatre.
Japanese officials disclosed plans yesterday for a trade promotion center in the old I. J. Fox Building, 393 Fifth Avenue, near Thirty sixth Street.
OXFORD, Ohio, Oct. 23 -- Dr. John D. Millett was inaugurated today as the sixteenth president of Miami University.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 23 -- Notre Dame was braced tonight to defend its ranking as the nation's No. 1 football power against the challenge of a Georgia Tech eleven that had not experienced defeat in a thirty-one game string dating back to 1950.

The Community Service Society has taken a close look at its program and has come up with a few far-reaching decisions. Most important is the move to integrate its health work with its social services -- a move which the society is convinced will result in a more rounded service to the thousands of New York families that seek its help each year.
Negotiations to avert a milk strike this afternoon in New York, northern New Jersey and southwestern Connecticut were in progress early today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- A French automobile designer received a patent this week on a sedan body without doors. The car opens up somewhat like a clam shell to admit and discharge passengers.
An annual World Order Day message from the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. will be read tomorrow at services of many of the congregations affiliated with the council.
BERLIN, Oct. 23 -- Frida Hockauf, a motherly looking weaver, is being built up by the Communist press in East Germany much after the manner of a Hollywood movie queen.

REPORTS from several New York and Connecticut areas indicate an improvement in the woodcock shooting during the past few days, so far as the number of birds are concerned, but the dry covers make hunting extremely difficult.

In a world still smoldering from the ruins of war but already brightened by the rays of peace, the representatives of "the peoples of the United Nations" met and drafted a Charter, which became effective just eight years ago today. It was and it still is a Charter of our hopes, the basic instrument on which a structure of international understanding and collaboration can yet be built.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 (UP) -- A $1,000,000 damage suit was filed in Superior Court today against Bing Crosby by three persons injured when their automobile and a car driven by the singer collided.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The production of jet warplanes at two big North American Aviation Company plants was halted today by a strike that a union official termed the beginning of an industry - wide struggle between unions and the aircraft industry.
The following is a round-up of new products which may be of interest to homemakers:

GROTON, Conn., Oct. 23 -- The atomic-powered submarine Nautilus, which will be launched here on Jan. 21, is not only the first means of transportation powered by nuclear energy, she is also the first submarine for which an interior decorator was consulted on the inside color schemes.

Lumber production in the week ended on Oct. 17 was 2.4 per cent below that of the like week of last year, according to reports wired yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES by regional associations. Shipments were down 5.1 per cent and orders were up 2.9 per cent. Following are the weekly statistics in thousands of board feet:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- As the House Agriculture Committee wound up its fact-finding tour of Mid-Western states this week, a member facetiously remarked:

The New York City Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild announced yesterday that it had unanimously adopted the report of its judiciary committee, declaring all candidates for judicial office in New York City, with one exception, to be qualified, including the candidates of the American Labor party.

PARIS, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Ernie Durando, a solid slugger from Bayonne, N. J., knocked out highly ranked Charles Humez of France tonight in 2:30 of the sixth round, with the Frenchmen on his knees listening to the referee count ten.

Lafayette rallied in the last four minutes of play yesterday to turn back previously unbeaten Boys High, 14 -- 13, on the loser's field in Brooklyn. Lafayette, tied once in four games this season, has played twenty contests without a defeat.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Saturday, Oct. 24 -- The Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission today put off until Monday an announcement that may indefinitely delay the stalled Communist "explanations" to defiant anti-Red prisoners of war.
Today's column deals with reader letters that cover cooking problems ranging from roasting a goose to freezing hard-cooked eggs.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 23 -- Cornell, seeking its first victory over Princeton since 1949, will be favored by a touchdown tomorrow, when the teams clash here at 2 P. M. in the Ivy League's "game of the day."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 23 -- Undefeated Yale, the country's second ranking defensive football team, plays host to Colgate's Red Raiders in the Bowl today.

Rudolph Halley, Liberal party candidate for Mayor, declared last night that Harold Riegelman had turned down an invitation to debate the "real issues" of the campaign because the Republican candidate was afraid of being challenged on his own record. Mr. Riegelman is also counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission, a private agency.

Work planned for Piers 32 and 49 on the North River now can proceed as a result of the Board of Estimate's approval of an aggregate expenditure of $380,383, Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, said yesterday.

The New York Knickerbockers will shoot for their second consecutive triumph in a two-year-old rivalry when they meet the College All-Stars at Madison Square Garden tonight in the second game of a basketball double-header for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund.

TOKYO, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Ed Lopat's major league all-stars, who swaggered through Tokyo on a red carpet of welcome, suddenly found themselves on a path of thorns today when the second-division Mainichi Orions of the Pacific League defeated them, 5 -- 4.

The remodeled conservatory of the New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park, was the scene for the first time yesterday of the opening of the National Chrysanthemum Society's three-day annual exhibition. In past years the show has been held in the garden's Museum Building.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Top men of industry today forecast that, despite a "readjustment" already in progress, business in 1954 will hold up to within 5 per cent of this year's high level.

Acting Lieut. Gov. Arthur H. Wicks has been told by a top Republican leader that it is likely the State Senate will not let him retain his post of Majority Leader. This statement was made yesterday by Dean P. Taylor, the Republican State Chairman, who had so advised the Senator.

Rugged Garth Panter, Salt Lake City middleweight, gained a split decision over Pierre Langlois of France in the main attraction of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. Panter weighed 159 pounds and Langlois 157 3/4.

ABOARD THE S. S. NIEUW AMSTERDAM, Oct. 23 -- Prudent savings hank management has both a responsibility to avoid destructive competition within the industry and an obligation to pay the highest possible return to depositors, the president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks declared today.

There appears to be no valid reason why the Moreland Act Commissioners inquiring into unsavory harness racing practices should investigate the route of the New York-Buffalo Thruway in lower Yonkers. It is understandable that opponents would like to see it altered to save their own properties, but the fact that the Thruway passes close to Yonkers Raceway seems far removed from the purpose of harness track investigation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today an export payment program to encourage export of fresh and processed oranges and grapefruit.
Prices of bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange advanced $1.16 for each $100 of par value in September, the Exchange announced yesterday.

GENEVA, Oct. 23 -- A legal opinion that could greatly strengthen the resistance by United Nations employes to security investigations by United States Congressional and administrative agencies was published here today by the Federation of International Civil Servants Associations.
CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Sharply higher prices were registered for wheat and soybeans today, while the coarse grains were inclined to lag.

FORT DIX, N. J., Oct. 23 -- Age, or the lack of it, appeared as a factor in the rigors of military flying today, when the country's oldest and youngest Ground Observer Corps volunteers received rides in an Air Force helicopter.

The original Bricker resolution during the past year has undergone so much legal surgery, not only as to language but as to central objective, as to be hardly recognizable. But Senator Bricker's enthusiasm remains strong for whatever text is at hand.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 23 (UP) -- Champion Tom Fool leads a three- horse field to the post tomorrow in the seventeenth running of the $50,000 pimlico Special.

The building containing thirty-six apartments and five stores at 1459-61 Boston Road in the Bronx has been sold by the Katesair Realty Corporation, client of Julius Brandes, lawyer, to the Len-Saul Realty Corporation for cash above mortgages of $77,000. It is assessed at $120,000. Allan S. Feldman Co. were the brokers.

Dr. Marcus D. Kogel, retiring Commissioner of Hospitals, will remember July 14, 1953, as a quiet Bastille Day in his department's fight against tuberculosis. For the first time after years of over-crowding and delayed admissions, the census of tuberculosis patients in the city's hospitals dropped below the complement TB beds.
PARIS, Oct. 23 -- By a vote of 320 to 252 Premier Joseph Laniel won the National Assembly's support for farm reforms early today.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The United States High Commissioner's Office announced today that Georgii Vladimirovici Khorumzhii, alias Georg Mueller, was being held in special security custody in an espionage investigation.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 23 -- New records of attendance, sales and space purchased by exhibitors were set at the thirty-fifth National Metal Exposition and Congress, which concluded its five-day meeting here.
The husband-wife relationship, rather than individual disturbances, should be the basis for treating marital discords, Dr. Nathan Ackerman said in a lecture this week.

The season's first school football double-header at Randalls Island will be overshadowed today by clashes between undefeated elevens. In the Bronx, Poly Prep of Brooklyn faces Riverdale, while in New Jersey, Montclair High is matched against East Orange.

A Yorkville property passed to the control of a syndicate of investors when a group headed by Benjamin J. Frost bought 1482 to 1488 Third Avenue, southwest corner of Eighty-fourth Street, from Walter Marshak.

Four income tax agents, including the former head of the Internal Revenue Bureau's office in Troy, N. Y., were convicted last night of conspiracy to defraud the Government by extorting money from taxpayers. A fifth was acquitted.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 23 (AP) -- C. V. Whitney's Fisherman, No. 1 juvenile of America, and The Pie King, 2-year-old, champion of England, arrived at Garden State Park today from New York.
Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld broadened yesterday his order prohibiting a waterfront strike until Christmas Day to include the new American Federation of Labor dock union.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee continued today its evaluation of testimony on alleged "interlocking subversion" in Government departments.

William M. Wickham, a Kentuckian who is in the tobacco business near Lexington, won his fourth New York race track purse in five recent tries when his 4-year-old filly Winning Stride hustled up in the stretch for an on-the-wire decision in the $7,500-added sprint that headed the Empire City-at-Jamaica program yesterday.
The head of a civic group that had been campaigning against "unsavory characters" at Yonkers Raceway said yesterday he had been threatened with death if he did not "lay off."
BERLIN, Oct. 23 -- A twofold program to aid West Berlin's needy was announced today.

The popularity of stainless steel accoutrements for the table may be attributed in part to the handsome, contemporary objects introduced in the last five years. New designs this autumn repeat for the most part the simplicity and good looks that distinguished the earlier ones.
" Don Giovanni" was performed at the City Center last evening with a new soprano, Catherine Bunn, making her debut with the New York City Opera Company as Donna Elvira.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Representative W. Sterling Cole, Republican of upstate New York, has declared he plans to introduce legislation to halt the Defense Department's relaxation of drinking rules at military posts. Mr. Cole, a member of the House Armed Services Committee, has taken the position that it is "wrong and unnecessary for the Government to be in the business of trafficking in bottled liquor."
Forest fires have burned several thousand acres of woodlands in New Jersey and New York State in the last three weeks.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct 23. (UP) -- Gen. Mark W. Clark, former Supreme United Nations Commander in the Far East, accepted the presidency of The Citadel, a military college, at Charleston, S. C., today, according to an announcement by Gov. James F. Byrnes.

HAVANA, Oct. 21 -- As everybody knows, Sir Winston Churchill is fond of Havana cigars. Somebody here coined a phrase on his behalf: "Cuba is always on my lips." However, a man who sent him thousands of the finest Havanas during the war ruefully confessed today that Sir Winston did not and could not smoke a single one of them.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Representative William A. Dawson, Republican of Utah, told a Senate subcommittee today American Government policies "are making us increasingly dependent on the whims of foreign government for our strategic metals."

TWICE as many new varieties are being introduced by leading rose growers this fall as were a year ago. This is contrary to past procedure when most firms held back the majority of their novelties for the spring trade.

WHEN lessons are given in the play of the cards, they are almost wholly devoted to declarer's play. Books on the play of the cards devote at least 75 per cent of their space to declarer's play. Yet most expert players consider defensive play a more important phase of the game.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24 -- Probably no post in American education, public or private, has greater potential influence or prestige than that which will be assumed on Nov. 15 by Dr. Samuel Miller Brownell. As the thirteenth United States Commissioner of Education, Dr. Brownell will be concerned with the whole framework of the nation's schools and colleges, in which a record number of 36,000,000 pupils are enrolled.
Not so many years ago locomotive engineers had to jump down from their cabs and squirt oil into engine parts just about every time the trains stopped.

ANOTHER year steals over us. Another Thurber book rides the tide. Again comes the time to put Thurber and Thurberism in a retort, light a Bunsen burner underneath and try to analyze the distillate. Once again the product defies identification with other compounds of humor.

WHAT makes a law-abiding pedestrian, who looks and acts normally, become a ruthless traffic violator when he gets behind the wheel of a motor vehicle? According to Thomas W. Ryan, director of the Division of Safety, State of New York, such a person may be a skillful driver, sound in body and mind, experienced and even with a pleasant disposition.

In spite of all doubts and fears, all antagonisms, all skepticism all the way around the world, where many see riding in the loom of bloody sunsets the four horsemen of the Apocalypse -- in spite of all this, United Nations Day was celebrated yesterday in New York City and in many other places with hope, faith and fervor.

THE felicitous working relationship between Director Elia Kazan and Playwright Tennessee Williams, as epitomized by such dramatic offerings as "A Streetcar Named Desire" and "Camino Real," will be continued with "27 Wagonloads of Cotton," Kazan divulged last week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The State Department was denounced sharply today for its withdrawal of economic assistance to Israel.

ALBANY, Calif., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Fleet Bird, dark bay son of Bull Lea, today established a new world record for a mile and three-six-teenths in winning the $50,000 added Golden Gate Handicap with a time of 1:52 3/5. High Scuo was second and Goose Khal third.

Opposition to the admission of Red China to the United Nations was voted unanimously yesterday by sixteen members of the executive council of the All-American Conference to Combat Communism at a meeting in the New Yorker Hotel.

JOHN LODWICK is an important writer, with a really interesting animus, who knows enough of this world not to have to wrap his stories up in the mists of eternity. Though at 37 he has published a dozen novels, he has no reputation in this country and apparently no very high or coherent reputation in his native England.

Novel divertissements have been planned for the bazaar to be held on Tuesday and Wednesday in the Parish House of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest to celebrate the eighty-fifth anniversary of the church. Proceeds from the event will be donated to the missionary work of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.

EVERY flower has its special day, and today is set aside by Rutgers University, New Brunswick, N. J. for their annual Chrysanthemum Field Day. The display may be seen at the University's Horticultural Farm No. 1 from 10 A. M. to 5 P. M.

Leaders of the $12,500,000,000 gas industry, along with the heads of Federal and state regulatory commissions, will meet this week at the thirty-fifth annual convention of the American Gas Association in St. Louis.

THE following observations are prompted by Somerset Maugham's recent selection from the stories of Kipling. It is impossible to read anything that Kipling wrote without being aware of the remarkable quality of his observation: his ability to make you see what he has seen.
BONN, Oct. 24 -- Western Germany this week was like a small boy who, pleading for a rifle, fervently promises that he will be very careful and not shoot anybody.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 -- Several recommendations pertaining to American shipping are expected to grow out of a three-day hearing here this week by a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce.

THE marriage took place in 1831 at Arlington House, one of the show places of Virginia. The bride was the great-granddaughter of Martha Washington. The bridegroom was the obscure second son of one of the more colorful generals of the American Revolution.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Jim (Popcorn) Brandt, a halfback making his first start of the season, and Fullback Fran Rogel led the Pittsburgh Steelers to a 31-14 victory over the Green Bay Packers tonight in a nationally televised National Football League game.

NEITHER distance nor political unrest should deter travelers from visiting the Orient these days. Even time is no obstacle, for it is possible to pack an amazing amount of sight-seeing into the space of two weeks. Not that four weeks -- or possibly months -- would not be preferable to two, for Asia is another world, several other worlds, in fact, and all with fascinating differences that deserve more than a hasty glance.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -- Despite the effects of diminishing defense production, employment in the Philadelphia labor market area edged upward to a new high in September. Preliminary estimates indicated that employment, aided by seasonal factors, reached 1,647,300 at the middle of the month, a gain of 2,800 over July.

The Yugoslav seaman who battered the skull of Robert G. Thompson, convicted Communist party leader, on Friday in the Federal House of Detention faces a possible ten-year prison term in this country. The seaman, Who had been scheduled to be deported, was held yesterday in $25,000 bail on a first-degree assault charge brought by Federal authorities.
Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate, seems to have the lead at present in what is now a three-cornered contest for election as Mayor of New York City on November 3.

MOSCOW, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Soviet publications continued today their sharp jabs at Britain's Prime Minister, Sir Winston Churchill. Journals here charged that Sir Winston's policy as expressed Oct. 10 to the Conservative party conference in Margate, England, could lead to catastrophe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, will leave Washington tomorrow for a three-week tour of United States' defense installations in Europe. He has been told on the eve of departure to brace himself for one probing question from European statesmen and journalists that might be phrased as follows:

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- Columbia had neither the personnel nor the ingenuity to cope with Army and Earl Blaik's cadets romped to a 40-7 victory at Michie Stadium today. This was the largest score recorded against Lou Little's Lions since 1949, and it could have been larger.
THURMONT, Md., Oct. 24 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower arrived here this afternoon for a week-end at Camp David, the Presidential retreat in the Catoctin Mountains near here.
Harold H. (Pee Wee) Reese is almost certain to be the Dodgers' next manager and the appointment is expected to be made about the middle of next month.
The present-day strength in the bond market is an invitation to the Eisenhower Administration to make another effort to lengthen out the maturity schedule of the public debt.

" AND now comes in the sweet o the year!" Jack Falstaff would say if he were with us and had been rightly instructed in American foods and drinks. Of course he would not have in mind the armies of the goldenrod, the "frosty asters like a smoke upon the hills," the smoldering crumble of hues in the maple tree, or the bonfires burning gold and crimson on the verge of twilight.

THIS is a perceptive and absorbing personal record of more than two crowded years in Russia. Everyone interested in Russian-American relations should read it, as well as all who like good travel books. Admiral Stevens' account of the experiences a non-Communist foreigner can have in Soviet Russia is the best I know of in any language.

Responsible Yugoslav officials in the United States believe the door could be opened to a compromise on Trieste if a conference on the problem were held without any prior commitment required of the Belgrade Government to accept the award of Zone A to Italy.

RED BANK, N. J., Oct. 24 -- Land's Corner, owned by Mrs. William J. Strawbridge of Paoli, Pa., and ridden by E. H. Bennett, won the twenty-third running of the Monmouth County Hunt Cup today, defeating Done Sleeping, George T. Weymouth's timber champion of the year, by four lengths.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 24 -Trinity College began a drive this week to raise $8,200,000 in what is described as the first phase of a program "to solidify its position as one of the leading liberal arts colleges in the country."

MADISON, N. J., Oct. 24 -- Twenty municipalities, in Morris, Essex and Union Counties are trying to reach agreement on an alignment for a $60,000,000 limited-access highway to replace Route 24. State Highway Department engineers have plans for such an artery on the drawing boards.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 (UP) -- The top offensive guns, of the University of California at Los Angeles, Paul Cameron and Primo Vallanueva, alternated today to overwhelm Washington State, 44 to 7, before 27,608 fans in Memorial Coliseum.

TOKYO, Oct. 24 (UP) -- With Hank Sauer hitting three home runs to lead the way, the Ed Lopat Major League all-stars redeemed, themselves today as they defeated the Pacific League All-Stars, 13 to 7, before a crowd of 40,000.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 24 -- After months of research, Dr. Richard P. McCormick, Professor of History at Rutgers University and president of the New Jersey Historical Society, has completed an analysis of New Jersey's election systems from 1664 to the present.

WHERE do authors get the ideas for their plays? There are almost as many answers as there are plays. Shakespeare ransacked Plutarch and Holinshed's Chronicles. The playwrights who have mined the Cinderella lode with profit, if laid end to end, would reach from the Battery to Van Cortland Park.

The Riverdale eleven rolled to its third straight victory this season and the seventeenth in a row over three campaigns by stopping previously undefeated Poly Prep of Brooklyn, 21 -- 6, yesterday on the winner's gridiron in the Bronx.
HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 24 -- Trinity College swept to its fourth straight victory of the season today, outclassing Middlebury by 33 -- 7.
American women don't know how to use perfume or how to get the most out of it. This is the contention of the Fragrance Foundation.

CHANDLER BROSSARD'S novel "The Bold Saboteurs" is unconventional in the extreme and will have admirers as well as unsympathetic readers, but few intelligent readers would deny that it is an unusual performance and worthy of a far more thoughtful review than Herbert Mitgang gave it.

Kathleen Ferrier ranked with the immortals of song, with the greatest singers of this or any other age. If other contraltos' voices can be compared to the 'cello, hers could be compared to the organ, with all its glorious sonority, heavenly sweetness, infinite variety and shading.

New York University's Center for Safety Education and the Traffic Institute of Northwestern University are opening a four-course training program for policemen and traffic personnel in November, Dr. Herbert J. Stack, director of the N. Y. U. center, announced yesterday. Classes will meet at the university's Washington Square Center.

A photograph of a portrait of a young man, which was brought here recently from England, was put forward last week as a link in a chain of evidence pointing to Christopher Marlowe, the great English dramatist and poet, as the author of Shakespeare's writings.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Perhaps the most important question raised by the Allied note dispatched to the Russian Government last Sunday night was that of the form of the Soviet Union's future contacts with the Western World.
A panel discussion on art and adult education will open a series Tuesday at 6:15 P.M. at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- There is widespread sentiment in this area that it is about time the Republican party got more solidly behind President Eisenhower. At the same time, there is strong feeling that the General has had time enough in which to "feel his way" and should start moving on positive programs.

THE reviewers of Franz von Papen's "Memoirs" found him to be the spirit behind Hitler, the villain of the piece, and the victim of his own personal bad judgment. And, in general, they looked at his book as a confession of a devilish or a blindly ambitious German. But this is a superficial way of looking at von Papen's story.

BOOKS about the Arctic, in recounting hardships and how they were overcome, often omit the small, revealing details of life in the north. This is the first book on the Arctic I have seen that does not sacrifice the ordinary for the dramatic.
COLDER weather puts many of us in good appetite for the hearty dishes of Germany. To those home cooks in touch with current market conditions, German sauerbraten immediately comes to mind.

Warm weather last week made its impact felt in New York and Brooklyn department stores whose sales were about 10 per cent lower than a year ago. The disparity in volume was heightened by the fact that in the 1952 week, temperatures were 5 degrees below normal, while this year they were 5 degrees above normal.

DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 23 -- Duke University today dedicated its $750,000 William B. Bell Research Building for medicine. More than 400 medical and nursing alumni holding their fourth triennial reunion here, as well as faculty members and officials of the university, attended the ceremony.

Trustees of the Pan American Medical Association flew to Caracas, Venezuela, yesterday for the installation of Dr. Pedro A. Gutierrez Alfaro, the Venezuelan Minister of Public Health and Welfare, as president of the association.

The refusal of the Supreme Court of the United States to review the decision of the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals, holding the Louisiana Fair-Trade Law constitutional, removed the opportunity for a final determination of an unusually controversial issue during the current term of the court.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 24 -- East Orange ended Montclair High's sixteen - game winning streak with a 27-14 victory at Martens Stadium before 12,000 fans today. Junie Walker passed for two touchdowns and raced ninety-eight yards for a third to pace the attack.

THE sassafras is one of those rare trees whose attributes can be appreciated during the four seasons of the year. What is more, it is a small to mediumsized tree that grows wild in this area and in great abundance. This month sassafras passes through its most spectacular stage -- one of "burning" fall colors.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 24 -- George J. Fitzpatrick, Hudson County Freeholder, announced today that he would file a statement Monday with District Attorney Frank Hogan in New York asking an investigation into statements made by Jersey City Mayor John V. Kenny regarding the Mayor's association with labor leader and convicted extortionist, Joseph Fay.

HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A Vietminh regiment attacked a column of French Union armored and infantry troops from ambush ten miles south of Phunhoquan today, but was beaten back into the hills after five hours of hand-to-hand fighting.

MANHASSET, L. I., Oct. 24 -Members of the committee in charge of plans for the Thanksgiving Ball on Nov. 27 for the benefit of the North Shore Hospital at O'Hara Hall of the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, have been meeting in the playhouse at Greentree, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. John Hay Whitney, to address more than 1,500 invitations that are to be sent out next week.

Panmunjom, the tiny hamlet on Parallel 38 in Korea, is a geographical symbol of the tortuous pace that has marked negotiations for a Korean settlement. There, for two years, U. N. and Communist delegates moved from deadlock to impasse in pursuit of a truce.

TOKYO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The United States Air Force said today that orders from Washington to cut flying time to save money had forced suspension of "rest and recuperation" flights to Japan for soldiers in Korea.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 24 (UP) -- Gen Matthew B. Ridgeway, Army Chief of Staff, said today the nation could not gamble with its safety by rushing a substitution of "new and untested weapons" for its foot soldiers.

Miss Samuels' principal is to be congratulated for trying to oust from the school the notion that the children from Puerto Rico are any different from others, and for her efforts to dispel the prejudices against them. But I fear that the devil is being expelled from the window only to reappear through the door.

NO human activity has ever been so fully chronicled in advance of the event as has the conquest of space. The literature of astronautics now forms a small library, even if one confines one's self to the serious, factual works and ignores the avalanche of fiction.

THESE letters to "Papa and Mama" from a Vassar girl spending her junior year studying in England are refreshing, gay and, in a delightfully silly way, bursting with warmth, exuberance and the uncertainty typical of youth.

STIMMUNG (something the wine houses advertise and meaning roughly "this joint is jumping") has partly returned to the local literary scene. Austrian letters were shell-shocked for quite a while after the holocaust but they have regained consciousness with a stout vitality and a calculated lack of delicateness that differs from the pre-World War II period of Werfel, Kafka and Zweig.

More than 90 per cent of the 12,000,000,000 yards of natural and synthetic textiles produced in the United States are sold and distributed through New York's wholesale textile markets. Nevertheless, the city offers no formal college course for training those who sell the goods.

IN the clear, warm days of Indian summer the problems besetting the farmers are ripening into the nation's biggest political issue. The farmers are worrying over surpluses in some areas, drought damage in others -- and about the spread generally between the prices they get for their produce and those they pay for the things they buy.

One hundred million Americans' knowledge of what happened on that day in Wall Street comes from reading and conversation. Of the other 56,000,000, those alive today who were 16 years or older then, many have vivid recollections -- of how their investments were wiped out.

REBECCA CAUDILL sets her story in the Kentucky hills, some forty years ago, just far enough back to escape the modern conveniences that today's 10-year-olds know. Two Tuttle families, each with three children, live within four miles of each other.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 2 -Georgia Tech's string of football games without defeat was snapped at thirty-one today by Notre Dame. With an eye-catching display of power that did much to justify their ranking as the nation's No. 1 team, the unbeaten Irish downed the Southeastern Conference champions, 27 -- 14, before an overflow crowd of 58,254 at Notre Dame Stadium.
WARSAK, Pakistan, Oct. 19 -- Competitive provincialism, an Asian characteristic, is dissipating itself in Pakistan through a series of community projects.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- Newburgh's city manager, Robert P. Aex, is looking for a new job and there is evidence that the "reform" movement that put him in office almost two years ago is on the decline.

IF you board a northbound trolley at Independence Square, fifteen minutes of swaying and jerking and a few more minutes walk will bring you to the corner of Eighth Street and Fairmount Avenue. There is not much there to charm a tourist. It is as drab as a hundred corners in Southwest Chicago, South Boston or the eastern bulge of Manhattan Island.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- The United Nations celebrated its eighth birthday today -- out-of-doors in First Avenue and in a school in Costa Rica, a town hall in Tasmania, a street in Liberia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -Many industrialists who have scoffed at Government pleas to build new plants outside potential target cities for atomic bombs are beginning to accept the Office of Defense Mobilization view that when it comes to building new factories it is good business to disperse them.
Coat and outerwear business was slow in the wholesale markets here last week because of the unusually warm weather.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 24 (UP) -- Quarterback Leroy Fenstemaker threw a 31-yard touchdown pass to End Dan Hart with 55 seconds left in the game today to give Rice an 18-to-13 victory over Texas before 48,000 fans in Memorial Stadium.

The liner United States has the greatest "power of survival" against sinking or burning of any merchant ship or Navy auxiliary afloat, William Francis Gibbs, designer of the record-breaking ship, said last week.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 -- California's Republicans are worried about their chances of winning the special Congressional election Nov. 10 in the Twenty-fourth District in suburban Los Angeles.

A business man explained the other day why he was trying to minimize his market and how he was going about it.

RENO, Nev. -- For vacationists, autumn in western Nevada and northeastern California is probably the best season of the year. From October to Thanksgiving the eastern slope of the Sierra Nevada mountains basks in a prolonged Indian summer.

THE hardest thing for a reviewer to write, believably and persuasively, is an all-out, no - reservations rave; and that's the problem that faces me this week as the result, of all things, of the first novel of a 23-year-old writer.
KIKI who has played, danced and skated her way into popularity with very young children now has a new experience to delight any youngster who has ever been or wanted to go to summer camp.

PROVING -- if proof is necessary -- that sponsors and their advertising agencies know a good thing when they see one, the number of situation comedies in television jumped from six to twenty-one, compared with totals last year at this time, according to Radio-TV FACTuary, prepared by Executives Radio-TV Service. In radio, totals in the same category rose from five last year to eleven this year.

THANKS to persistent Cossack invasion, many Americans have become familiar with a number of Russian religious choral works. Being in Russian, however, those works have seemed to be mostly compounds of thrilling effects made by very high and very low voices that combine to give a feeling of reverence.
Sol Rubinow of New York City, former intercollegiate chess champion, paired with his brother, Morton Rubinow of Boston, last night won the 1953 Metropolitan Contract Bridge Open Pair Championship.

THERE is something unique and refreshing about "From Down Under to Nippon." in that the author, Gen. Walter Krueger, has chosen to write about the men he commanded rather than to present this thick volume as a personal memoir.

MUSIC in recent years has taken an increasingly important place as one of the humanities taught and cultivated in the colleges and universities of the country. But compared with other studies it is a late-comer to the academic faculty in many institutions.

THE camera lens and color film have replaced the painter's brush and palette as more exact and frequently as beautiful a medium for recording bird life. An extensive display of what the Audubons of the camera have achieved in their field is attractively presented in a new book, "Land Birds of America" (New York: McGraw Hill. $12.50).
The manufacture of pipe from plastics is expanding rapidly into a rather important industry.
THERE is no reason for one neighbor to look longingly at another's outdoor fireplace. It is fairly easy to build and the gardener now has ample leisure time in which to construct one of his own.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Hasty Road became the richest 2-year-old in racing history today by defeating Revolt in the Breeders' Futurity at Keeneland.
DENVER, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission confirmed today what "looks like an important new discovery" of uranium-bearing ores in central Wyoming.

FEW battles in American history have been debated more hotly than Little Big Horn, where, on June 25, 1876, Lieut. Col. George A. Custer, Brevet Major General, led five troops of the Seventh Cavalry into a Sioux-Cheyenne ambush from which no man escaped.
GENEVA, Oct. 24 -- Carefully circumscribed permission to raise tariff duties on certain imports from Continental Europe was granted to Britain today.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 -- Dr. William David Coolidge, the New England scientist who developed the use of the X-ray into an exact science, describes himself as "an onlooker now, pretty much of a playboy."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The executive board of the United Gas, Coke and Chemical workers, C.I.O., has proposed a legislative program for restoration of the natural beauties of Niagara Falls, financed by fees from public power development on the United States side of the falls.

Seven leaders in the Boy Scout movement in New York and New Jersey were honored yesterday for outstanding service to boyhood at the thirty-third annual meeting of Region Two of the Boy Scouts of America at the Astor Hotel.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 24 -- When the Governments of Egypt, Lebanon, Jordan and Syria signed armistice agreements with Israel in 1949, their backs were against the wall. During brief flare-ups in the period of the truce ordered by the Security Council, Israeli forces drove the Egyptian Army deep into the Sinai Peninsula and left it with only a beachhead of sixty square miles in southern Palestine.

DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 24 (UP) -- A quarterback, who came out for football reluctantly because he thought he could never rise above third string, dashed 75 yards for one score and led a 70-yard march for another today as Duke larruped North Carolina State, 31 to 0, before 15,000 fans.

BERLIN -- This city, split from within and sealed off from her neighbors outside, is nevertheless becoming increasingly popular with tourists. The upward trend began in 1950. Last year there were 1,200,000 visitors and it is estimated that the total will run well above that figure this year.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 24 -- Auto dealers in this area have stepped up promotional efforts to reduce the large number of used cars on their lots before cold weather. Similar efforts are being made to move stocks of new cars. While the recent prolonged warm weather has had a dampening effect on big stores' sales during early October, several special events for sale of soft goods were reported to have met gratifying response.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Oct. 24 (UP) -- James Ray Smith, a 225-pound tackle, saved Baylor's unbeaten record with two unerring conversions and magnificent defensive play today as the nation's sixth ranked team squeezed by Texas A. M. 14 to 13.
ROME, Oct. 24 -- Italy told the United States, Britain and France yesterday that she was ready to resume a normal military situation at the Yugoslav frontier if Yugoslavia would do the same.

Some of the standards by which the tax exemption of disability benefits paid to employes in compliance with self-insured plans under New York State law will be determined are dealt with in new Internal Revenue Service rulings on two specific cases.

Disabled veterans of the Korean campaign, as well as their widows and dependents, may be entitled to more than fifteen major benefits after being discharged, Abraham Janko, national service officer of the Disabled American Veterans, said yesterday.

Drs. C. M. Agress, H. I. Jacobs, W. G. Clark, M. J. Binder and M. Lederer of the Veterans Administration Center and the University of California School of Medicine at Los Angeles, Calif., have succeeded in dissolving clots in the heart arteries of dogs. The solvent is the digestive enzyme trypsin.
