Variety and abundance characterize the New York auction sales this week. Four sales at the Parke- Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, that lead off with books, include early paintings, eighteenth- century French and other furniture, bibelots and decorations and precious-stone jewelry.

THIS is such a slight memoir that the reader puts it down with a feeling of exasperation. William H. Forbes, the son of one of America's great industrial builders, had many natural endowments. He had cultivated tastes: He was a sportsman, he traveled, he had fine friends.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 24 -- Maj. Shale L. Tulin of the Air Force, director of information services for the Civil Air Patrol in Washington, urged here today that the nation's high schools introduce aviation education courses.

Women active in furthering the work of the Rudolf Steiner School have taken over a pre-opening performance of "Escapade," a new comedy, with Roger Livesey and Ursula Jeans, on the night of Nov. 11, at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre, to augment the school's scholarship fund. Mrs. Antoinette Johnson heads the benefit committee.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 24 (UP) -- Stan Wallace, fullback, broke loose for two long touchdown runs today to lead Illinois to a 20-13 victory over Syracuse.
The marine engineers who are building the atom-powered plants of tomorrow's ships are in the process of learning their way around the old-fashioned steam and diesel plants of today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The National Labor Relations Board announced today a new policy on unions of which officers are under indictment for allegedly giving false information in non-Communist affidavits.

The dispute between the Metropolitan Opera and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians remained unsettled yesterday. The union rejected yesterday morning a "final" offer from the Metropolitan and notified the opera company by telegram.

It is common knowledge that the easy-to-dig iron ore deposits of the Mesabi Range in northern Minnesota will be nearing exhaustion in another generation. Since 1884 more than two billion tons of Mesabi ore have been shipped through the natural waterways of the Great Lakes to the steel mills of the East.

THE volumes of the series published annually under auspices of the Council on Foreign Relations aim at a dispassionate analysis of American world policy. The author, Richard P. Stebbins, modestly disclaims any pretense at definitive world history.

HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 24 -- A survey of Nationalist opinion in Vietnam showed today a split between the moderate elements that do not desire to cut ties with France and the extremists who seek complete independence outside the French orbit.
Rudolph Halley called yesterday for a showdown on his assertion that Lawrence E. Gerosa, Democratic candidate for Controller, had been involved in a state insurance bribery investigation.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 24 -- Yale University will conduct an on-the-spot study of teaching in the public schools of the Town of Fairfield, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Representative Harold H. Velde reported today that he was seeking the "advice and counsel" of religious leaders in directing the work of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

The cow has an extra stomach, called the rumen, in which cellulose is broken down by bacterial action and turned into sugar-like nourishment. This process is still much of a mystery. To clarify it, Drs. Warren D. Kitts and Leland A. Underkofler have devised an artificial cow's stomach or rumen. Into this they feed cellulose in the hope of finding out how a cow can digest woody material.

Back in the hills some of the farmers are putting winter bustles on their houses. The process, which is a venerable one, uses the good weather at this time of year and the materials at hand. A low fence, often of mesh wire, is put up two feet or so from the walls all around the house with a gap only for the doorway.

BEGINNERS who are bitten with the rock gardening bug would do well to construct their garden this fall. This will allow the soil and rocks to settle before the major planting is done next spring. However, there are a few plants, namely the species crocus, tulips and bulbous iris that should be set out this year.
LONDON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Arsenal Gunners, playing without three of their stars, romped to a 5-1 victory over neighboring Charlton Athletic in English League soccer today.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 24 -- The City Charter Committee, a fusion of Democrats and independent Republicans, and the regular Republican organization are in the homestretch of a bitter City Council race. The election is Nov. 3.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The United States is understood to have informed the Indian chairman of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission in Korea that this Government will not permit the use of force to make prisoners of war listen to Communist "explanations" as to why they should return to the Communist homelands.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24 -The fiftieth anniversary of the dedication of Harvard Stadium was celebrated today and the Crimson's football performers furnished the proper finishing touch to the occasion.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 24 (AP) -- The University of Missouri Tigers found themselves in the last half of their Big Seven Conference football game with the Nebraska Cornhuskers today and rolled to a 23-7 victory. A crowd of 26,000 saw the game.

The John Hay Whitney Foundation is accepting applications from qualified teachers in the public high schools of seven states for the 1954-55 John Hay Fellowship Program. A total of twenty fellowships will be awarded to teachers from public high schools in Alabama, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Maine and Washington for study in the humanities.

VIENNA, Oct. 24 -- Seven Austrian prisoners, who were released by the Hungarian Government yesterday, have reported here that four fellow prisoners were killed and thirty wounded by camp guards at Tiszaloek on Oct. 4.

THE heroic Pole who fought both Nazi and Soviet invaders in 1939 and later commanded the gallant Polish II Corps in Italy, Lieut. Gen. Wladyslaw Anders has sought in this book to explain why, as he sees it, Germany lost the war against Russia.

A FORMER New York City Water Commissioner once was quoted as admitting that there was one nice thing about a water shortage: people at least thought about water waste during it -- and they never did any other time. While upstate reserviors supplying New York are reflecting the long dry spell, the city is not suffering -- yet -- from an honest-to-goodness water shortage.
TOKYO, Sunday, Oct. 25 -- The Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission prepared today to admit it cannot solve the dispute over Communist efforts to persuade Korean war prisoners to return home.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Pa., Oct. 24 -- The first of the three new bridges being built by the Delaware River Joint Toll Bridge Commission in this area will be opened some time next month, according to Alexander R. Miller of Easton chairman of the commission.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -- The Missionary Sisters of the Sacred Heart have entered into an agreement to purchase Woodcrest, the 138-acre Dorrance estate in suburban Radnor, for use as a retreat house and orphanage.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 24 -Dan Pobojewski, who couldn't make the grade at Michigan State, and sophomore Quarterback Froncie Gutman led Purdue to a stirring 6-to-0 triumph over Michigan State today, ending the Spartans' 28-game winning streak in one of the season's biggest upsets.

Racing silks of outstanding stables will provide a brilliant decor for the dinner dance known as the Belmont Futurity Ball to be held on Thursday night in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club. The ballroom will be decorated to resemble Belmont Park and the annual Belmont Futurity for the occasion.
BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 24 (UP) -- The Southern California Trojans put on a brilliant punting show today in defeating California, 32 -- 20.
DURHAM, N. H., Oct. 24 (AP) -- In one of New England's biggest collegiate football upsets of the season the New Hampshire Wildcats rolled to a 34-0 triumph today over St. Lawrence.

Opinions may differ on the outlook for business next year. But few will disagreee as to the immediate effect on investment sentiment of the long list of favorable earnings and dividend reports issued last week. They helped lift the stock market to its best level since August.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The new Secretary of Labor, James P. Mitchell, has taken over what probably has been the most demoralized department of the Government.

LUFKIN, Tex., Oct. 24 -- A privately financed water project designed to insure the future industrial and agricultural development of the Lufkin-Nacogdoches area of east Texas has been proposed by the Nacogdoches-Lufkin Water Association.

THE previous volume by Mrs. Henrey, "The Little Madeleine," delighted readers and critics alike with its spirited writing and its lack of affection or concern for literary vogues. It related with humor and pathos the hardships and joys of a very poor French family and ended with Madeleine leaving for London with her widowed mother.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 24 -- The new Student Union and Freshman Center at Williams College was used for the first time today as more than 300 guests, representing families of 150 of the 277 students enrolled in the freshman class, attended the first annual Parents' Day.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 24 (AP) -Circuit Judge Michael T. Sullivan has declared null and void all testimony in a pre-trial divorce hearing from which the press was excluded.

A NEW information center was opened last Friday by the State of Vermont Development Commission at 1268 Avenue of the Americas, next door to Radio City Music Hall. With the object of publicizing the state, the bureau will maintain, among other things, a tourist information service, answering prospective visitors' questions about Vermont's recreational possibilities, lodgings, etc.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Cardinal Spellman rebuked European critics of "McCarthyism" today and said that Americans would not be dissuaded from their determination to root out Communist subversion.

THERE is almost certainly no other white man alive who could have written this book, since no other white man has lived so unique a life. Sasha Siemel is the original "wild Russian" who strode through the pages of Julian Duguid's "Green Hell" some twenty years ago.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: It is not too late to sow a lawn. Little or no germination may be expected before March, unless the mixture has a high percentage of rye grass. September-sown seed has germinated more slowly than usual because of dry weather. Keep seeded areas free of leaves. Watering is not essential if dew or hoar frost is prevalent these fall mornings.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Manilal Gandhi, 61-year-old son of the late Mohandas K. Gandhi, was released from Pretoria prison today after having served thirty-eight days of a fifty-day sentence imposed for violation of racial regulations at the Germiston African settlement on Dec. 8.

Richard DiCamillo, slender harrier from Mont Pleasant High School, Schenectady, scored his second major victory in two weeks yesterday when he triumphed in one of the two varsity races in the third annual St. John's University interscholastic cross-country run at Van Cortlandt Park.

MODERN interior design, according to Edgar Kaufmann Jr. of the Museum of Modern Art, began a century ago "when creative, perceptive people reacted to vast problems posed by technological change, especially by mass production." The contemporary approach involves planning, and making rooms suited to our way of life, our abilities and ideas.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 24 -All of Connecticut's larger cities will be holding municipal elections a week from Tuesday. Political analysts are wondering whether a Democratic trend that developed in the small-town elections two weeks ago will continue.
Seventeen persons were injured in Brooklyn last night when a bus collided with an auto and then plowed through four large plate glass windows into an automobile showroom.
Shipping and stevedoring companies in the Port of New York were cautioned yesterday to file license applications soon or face not being able to operate after Nov. 30.

THESE days rarest and tallest of all North American birds, the Whooping Cranes, go south in the annual migration from northwest Canada to their winter refuge on the Gulf Coast of Texas, where they are guarded by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.

MISTY - EYED old - timers could almost hear hoofbeats receding into the twilight when the cavalry vanished in 1942 as an arm of the United States military service. The cavalry went out fighting. For it was the Twenty-sixth Cavalry, the last regiment of regulars mounted in combat, which covered the withdrawal to the Bataan Peninsula of the late Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright's corps of four Philippine Army divisions.
A hitch developed yesterday in the suit by Robert F. Wagner Jr. to compel the State Parole Board to make public the names of those who had tried to get a parole for Joseph S. Fay, labor extortionist.

KING PAUL and Queen Frederika of the Hellenes are scheduled to arrive in the United States Wednesday, at the invitation of President Eisenhower, to visit Washington and tour the country. They come as emissaries of their people as well as monarchs.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24 -- Hopkins Grammar upset Iona Prep of New Rochelle, N. Y., toppling the visiting football team to its first defeat, 25 to 6, on Pratt Field today.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Dick Glock scored three touchdowns, passed for another and booted a pair of extra points today to lead Ursinus to a 38-21 upset victory over previously unbeaten Swarthmore.

NEXT Saturday from 5:30 to 6:30 P. M., the N. B. C. Television Opera Theatre will present "Carmen" in color -- compatible-type color that can be viewed on ordinary receivers in black and white. Peter Herman Adler, the music and artistic director, is a little concerned about the outcome.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -- Investigators for the House Un-American Activities Committee today completed the serving of subpoenas on thirty-four persons in their inquiry into possible communism in the public school system.

Adult education will become an increasingly important factor in the application of geriatrics (care of the aged) because of the increase of elderly persons in the population, W. Ballentine Henley, president of the College of Osteopathic Physicians and Surgeons in Los Angeles, declared yesterday.

THE annual "miracle" on Fifty-fifth Street once again unfolds. The intrepid, not to mention indefatigable, Jose Ferrer, as you may already have read, is preparing to offer patrons of the City Center's drama series the following playbill: Nov. 11-22, "Cyrano de Bergerac"; Nov. 25-Dec. 6, "The Shrike"; Dec. 9-20, "Richard III" and Dec. 23-Jan. 3, "Charley's Aunt."
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Vanderbilt combined its best passing and running offense of the season today to defeat Virginia, 28 -- 13.

CAIRO, Oct. 24 -- The Arabs do not know what the United Nations Security Council can or will do about the Israeli attack on Jordanian villages last week. They doubt that anything more than talk will come of it.

NEWARK, Oct. 24 -- Nelson F. Stamler said today that he might "answer" in a television and radio broadcast the majority and minority reports of the Hannold Legislative Committee, which investigated his dismissal as a deputy attorney general last January.

Determination to help others, when expressed in individual acts of kindness and charity, can do more than diplomacy to improve world conditions, declared Rabbi Louis C. Gerstein in a United Nations Day sermon yesterday morning at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue (Orthodox), Central Park West and Seventieth Street.

EDWARD R. MURROW'S presentation of the case of Lieut. Milo Radulovich, who is threatened with dismissal from the Air Force because of anonymous charges of pro-Communist sympathies against his father and sister, was not just a superb and fighting documentary (10:30 P. M. Tuesday over C. B. S.). It was a long step forward in television journalism.

PLASTIC surgery is both the oldest and the youngest of the surgical specialties. Hindu surgeons were replacing ears and noses several thousand years ago, often with much the same techniques used today. This intimate autobiography by one of the Western hemisphere's busiest plastic surgeons, Dr. Maxwell Maltz of New York, is as smoothly written as a slick magazine story, and as exciting as a picaresque novel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The State Department would like at least three or four weeks to seek harmony with South Korea and other Allied participants in the Korean political conference.

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 24 (UP) -Southwest farmers said today two days of rain had saved millions of acres of crops but the nation's drought -- one of the worst in history -- tightened its grip on the northeast section of the country.

PRINCE WAN WAITHAYAKON, Thailand's Foreign Minister and permanent delegate to the United Nations -- he was runner-up to Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit of India for the Presidency of the General Assembly -- feels inextricably involved in the Broadway musical, "The King and I."
UPPER SANDUSKY, Ohio, Oct. 24 (UP) -- A college student who wanted to become a minister pleaded guilty today to second-degree murder rather than face trial for his life on a first-degree charge.

IN a recent exhibition of children's paintings a little boy who had been born and lived all his life in the asphalt jungle had to paint a picture of the countryside. He lined his street with trees and with five-story buildings -- which obviously seemed to him so low that they were proper "country" rather than "city" edifices.

C.V. Whitney, who doesn't really need the money, won his second big purse of the week at Jamaica yesterday when his 4-year-old colt Cold Command collected first money of $38,150 in the $56,200 Westchester Handicap. Whitney's Fisherman won $60,100 in the East View Stakes last Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- President Eisenhower said today he was convinced the Administration would produce a program that would help farmers obtain "their fair share of the national income and work for the good of all."
The minor parties, except for the Socialist party, which decided against running a city ticket this year, will be back on the ballot in full force again on Nov. 3.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -- The Negro Labor Committee, U. S. A., was told here today that the American Federation of Labor was behind the committee's efforts to purge American labor of Negro Communists.

WAUSAU, Wis., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Knut Einar Heikkenen, 63 years old, who was called a key Communist by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in 1950 and ordered deported two years later, is now a man without a country.

TO a great degree next year's harvests depend upon an evaluation of the successes and failures in the summer just past. Nowhere perhaps is a candid over-all survey more important than in the vegetable plot.

TROY, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- The third industrial council at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute next Friday and Saturday will be devoted to the electrical and electronics field. Executives and scientific leaders of the industry will attend. Previous conferences were on the petroleum and chemical industries.

THERE is a small but choice exhibition of early oils and water - colors by Winslow Homer at Maynard Walker's that no lover of painting should want to miss. For it covers the most radiant period of his career, before he began to paint the famous marines whose blustery power seems a total and willful denial of his early delicacy.

HAVANA, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Censorship was lifted in Cuba today, and some personal rights were restored. But the citizens were not sure where they stood because the tough "law of public order" was still on the books.
City officials will break ground on Wednesday for a health center and a library, and lay the cornerstone for another library, all in Brooklyn.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- Debutantes from the New York area attended the sixty-fifth annual Autumn Ball tonight in the Tuxedo Club, where thirteen debutantes, the largest number since before World War I, were introduced to society.
New York will give one of its traditional ticker-tape welcomes tomorrow to Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, hero of Taejon and for three years a prisoner of war of the Chinese Communists.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 24 -- The police of this city today started a quiet campaign to eliminate the two-year-old best-seller, "From Here to Eternity," from the shelves and display windows of book and stationery stores. Last week the police here banned the motion picture, "The Moon Is Blue," from the Stanley Theatre and arrested its manager on a charge of possessing "indecent and obscene" pictures.

AN informal little history of great figures and events in American technology, "Machines That Built America" aims to show the importance of mass production in the growth of the United States. The author's idea is that without an ample supply of Collins axes to clear the forest, of McCormick reapers to harvest the grain, and of Colt six-shooters to subdue Indians, westward pioneering would have slowed to a walk.

THE author of "As I Remember" is one of the most distinguished New Testament scholars of our day. Edgar J. Goodspeed was also one of a brilliant group of young Baptists who were instrumental in founding the University of Chicago, or who were at least involved in the beginnings.

It amazes me how a flimflam like "The Moon Is Blue" can create such a furor when "Invasion U. S. A." is running around loose. The picture is precisely what its title purports: a sneak invasion of the United States by an "unidentified" enemy.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 24 -- Arthur H. Dean, United Nations representative at the preliminary talks to arrange a political conference, said today he was optimistic as to the outcome of the talks.

TO commemorate the tenth anniversary of Abraham Neuman's appointment to the presidency of Dropsie College for Hebrew and Cognate Learning, the board of governors and faculty of the college published a collection of his essays and addresses.

THOSE who read this important book will come away with a better understanding of Father Divine and of his sect than any other account could afford them. They will also have flashes of illuminating insight into the American society that produced the man and the movement.

The Chief of Chaplains of the United States Air Force, Maj. Gen. Charles I. Carpenter, has said: "We of the Chaplains Corps have as our prime responsibility the spiritual wel fare of the men of the Air Force during their hours of duty aloft and on the base.

REVERSING the popular superstition, Eunice Lackey spins an engaging tale of a black cat who brought prosperity, happiness and good luck to a village. Lucky Blacky is neither a spook nor a Machiavellian Puss in Boots.

WHEN the Bard family decides to bolster its income by taking paying guests, 15-year-old Andrea has her own scheme for publicizing the California ranch. She trains Blue Smoke, a quarter-horse informally bequeathed to her by the ranch's first visitor, to be a topnotch cutting horse -- a champion at carving out cattle from the herd.

I have followed with special interest The New York Times Magazine articles on Germany. I enjoyed very much the one by M. S. Handler, "German With the European Idea" (September 13). I regret I cannot say as much for Drew Middleton's "The Great Challenge of Germany" in the issue of the previous week.
IT IS good to find among the many books on self analysis and inner fears a volume which simply refreshes the human spirit. Margaret Henrichsen's "Seven Steeples" is that rarity.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 24 -- In the state political campaign the Republicans are seeking Democratic votes by urging a refusal to follow traditional party allegiances.

MANILA, Oct. 24 -- A young Tondo district gangster, Florentino (Scarface) Suarez, who has been accused of slaying the principal witness against Oscar Castelo, Acting Defense Secretary, in a disbarment case growing out of bribery charges was stabbed to death tonight by two men in a jeepney (an Army jeep converted locally into a small bus).
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- In a move indicating a likely trend in Senate Democratic policy, Senator Walter F. George, Democrat of Georgia, today called for an end of economic aid for Europe.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 (UP) -- George Kanter, manager of Pierre Langlois, said today a language misunderstanding apparently was the cause of a dispute over the fighter's condition in a bout last night in New York City.

The world chess championship challengers' tournament, begun in Neuhausen, Switzerland, on Aug. 30, ended yesterday, when the two games adjourned from the thirtieth and final round were played off at the Kongresshaus in Zurich.
Supporters of a manufacturer's right to fix minimum store prices on his products laid plans last week to make their principle as foolproof as possible.
Many parties will be given at the fifty-sixth annual dinner of the Society of Colonial Wars in the State of New York to be held Wednesday night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

GUESSING about birthday presents is a tantalizing pleasure at any age. When a boy is going to be "big enough and grown-up enough" for a special combination birthday present, the suspense is especially hard to bear.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 -- New construction and repair jobs are taxing the capacity of Great Lakes shipyards and necessitating a rush of early vessel lay-ups. Marine men said that if all freighters scheduled for repair sailed until the usual late November or early December closing date, it would be impossible for shipyards to complete repairs in time for the opening of the 1954 shipping season.

THE weekly television program of Bishop Fulton J. Sheen made that veteran and popular writer and speaker known to an even wider audience. The program also won over not a few die-hards who had been churlishly asking, "Can any good thing come out of video?"

An exhaustive, world-wide search in the first few years after World War II for a major new source of iron ore will soon provide the United States Steel Corporation with the first installment on what promises to be a long-term dividend.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -With a 35-yard field goal in the last minute of a ferociously fought and tremendously exciting football game, Pennsylvania toppled Navy on Franklin Field today, 9 -- 6.

YONKERS, Oct. 24 -- Ferman Hanover, a 6-year-old brown gelding, won the Greenville free-for-all pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight as 26,147 spectators watched the first public choice of the night score in the feature event.

ROCKY'S ambition was to make the basketball team. His closest friends in the seventh grade were sports enthusiasts, but so too was Brian, the one boy with whom he always disagreed. Brian's talent for stirring provocations found a new outlet when the class launched a school paper.

AN amazing figure, Mr. Nathan. As editor, as critic, he has been sitting in the theatre's aisle seats for a period in time that would seem incomprehensible to mere man. All critics are fond of pointing out, when each theatrical year ends in June, that to have sat through the season required the utmost in stamina.

SOME years of experience as part of a team hammering out agreements with delegates from other countries convince me of the very practical importance of international good manners. This involves national attitudes and conduct even more than the finesse that is demanded of professional diplomats.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 24 (UP) -- Southern Methodist cashed its breaks today in a 14-6 intersectional victory over game but fumbling Kansas.

IN Italy, it seems, everybody except Alberto Moravia believes in the family, and like nowhere else on earth. Take this Italian family: father and mother, youngish middle-aged, two small children, boy and girl, and of course the cat (in the end, just as much his own feline personality as the humans are theirs) -- and what can a writer do with them?

SINCE the publication a quarter century ago of Victor Nelson's "Prison Days and Nights," no other convict has written more sensitively of the torments of penal purgatory than Double-Lifer Runyon. A Western bank robber, deficient in Willie Sutton's technique, the author was a bungler.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Government got assurances today that industry would go along with continued high taxes if that was necessary to achieve President Eisenhower's "sound money" goal.
The needs of the country as a whole and of youth in particular dictate a lowering of the voting age to 18, in the opinion of former Gov. Ellis G. Arnall of Georgia.
ALBANY, Oct. 24 -- When the state's voters go to the polls on Nov. 3 they will elect not only for county and town officers but also pass on nine amendments to the State Constitution.

SINCE children are natural conformists it's not surprising that a witch's little daughter might prefer going to school -- like the other children -- to riding around in the dark and the cold. When Minikin Snickasnee secretly defies her mother and sets out in pursuit of the good life she innocently creates a fine furor in the village.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 24 (UP) -- Ohio State ground out two last period touchdowns to beat Wisconsin, 20 to 19, today. A Badger field goal attempt failed in the final seconds.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Except for the Democratic victory last week in the Ninth Congressional District of Wisconsin, the Republican Administration has experienced no tests of strength in this area since last November's Presidential elections.

The joint declaration of 1948 by the United States, Great Britain and France in regard to the future of the Free Territory of Trieste was made with an eye to the Italian elections of that year. Whatever its effect on the election, it was an instance of the unwise policy of making commitments with long-term implications for the sake of immediate results.

The phenomenal growth of attendance and wagering at harness horse races in New York State is shown in the following table, which gives also comparative figures for flat, or thoroughbred, racing. The table starts with 1940, the year that pari-mutuel betting became legal in this state.

ONE reason why the war novels still come is that some of the old theatres of action have been reactivated. Chin Kee Onn's "Silent Army" is about the Japanese invasion of Malaya -- and the newspapers say that peninsula again is the scene of fighting.
Ten fire companies from Brooklyn and Manhattan were ferried last night to Staten Island to help fight a spectacular blaze that destroyed five acres of parched woodland.

CHOREOGRAPHICALLY speaking, it was very much a Frederick Ashton season that the Sadler's Wells Ballet gave us this year. Of the ten works they presented, five were by him; and of the five new works in the repertoire four were his.

AT this moment when Allied policy toward Russia is being re-examined, eyes focus on Eisenhower and Churchill -- two old friends, old arguers, old collaborators -- who are exchanging views directly and through their subordinates. Both men recently set out the goals they seek.

WHITE PLAINS -- A small but devoted number of city dwellers is finding the week - end activities of the Westchester Trails Association a pleasant way to combine the traditional Sunday drive to the country with a more intimate view of the autumn landscape.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Every so often an idea begins to stir in this city which in due course affects all our lives and even the direction of our civilization.
BACH: 'Cello Suites Nos. 1 in G and 3 in C; Antonio Janigro (Westminster). Fine, musicianly playing of these arduous unaccompanied works. Janigro has heart as well as technique and tone.

SUNNY autumn week - ends bring with them the temptation to postpone the annual task of tidying up the garden. It is undoubtedly more fun to work on a lawn that is slowly reviving after the summer's parching, or to set out new shrubs and bulbs, than it is to concentrate on fading flower beds and old vegetable patches.

Stuyvesant High's eleven remained unbeaten and unscored upon in five starts, one of which was a tie, by crushing Taft, 33 -- 0, while DeWitt Clinton defeated Blessed Sacrament, 19 -- 8, in the schoolboy doubleheader at Randalls Island yesterday.

A GOOD many readers will remember with pleasure affection the novel "Little Mule," which chronicled the very early years of its title-character, a boy disposed by irrepressible temperament to kicking, stubbornness, charm and precocious deeds of valor.

THE battle of the "scopes" ended suddenly and dramatically last Thursday morning in a one-round victory for Twentieth Century-Fox and CinemaScope when Warner Brothers gave up efforts to develop WarnerScope as a rival method of panoramic-type photography and entered into an alliance to use CinemaScope.

Plans are under way for the Versailles Ball, which will be held on the night of Nov. 6 at the Wal, dorf-Astoria, to raise funds for the restoration of the royal chateau in Versailles, France. Mrs. William T. C. Gaynor is chairman of the women's committee ai'ding in the plans for the fete.

THE Bishop of Worcester, Dr. Richard Hurd, was an astute man. Reflecting upon a royal charge, for he was tutor to George Augustus Frederick, George III's heir, he remarked of the 15-year-old, "He will probably be the most polished gentleman or the most accomplished blackguard in Europe."

CHATTANOOGA, Oct. 24 -- Republican popularity, nearing its crest in this area a year ago, is definitely on the wane because of two important issues -- the Tennessee Valley Authority policy of the Eisenhower Administration and falling farm income that has not been accompanied by receding consumer prices.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- The eighth anniversary of the adoption of the United Nations Charter was marked today with the announcement by the American Jewish Committee that a nationwide poll, under its auspices, had disclosed that 84 per cent of the people of the United States wanted it to continue its membership in the United Nations.

Plans are being advanced at frequent meetings at the Ambassador by members of the women's committee for the varied social events to be held in connection with the sixty-fifth National Horse Show, which will open on Nov. 3 at Madison Square Garden and will continue through Nov. 10.

Roosevelt Raceway has been trying to buy back a "gangster-tainted" block of 6,400 shares of stock, worth about $179,000, in the Old Country Trotting Association. The Old Country is one of two companies that operate the raceway.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 24 (AP) -Dr. Grayson L. Kirk, the president of Columbia University, here to receive an "Ohioana" award, said today that mass education was not adequate for training potential leaders.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- The use of radar by the police here in the last several months "has not substantially implemented the work done by traffic control cars" in the opinion of Chief Judge George D. Ogden of City Court.

THERE isn't enough enthusiasm for acting -- just good old acting -- these days. The enthusiasm is mostly for entertainers, and most of that is for the ones on TV. As a consequence, many fine performances by actors of substance and skill are being passed up by those who used to go to movies or are being taken as a matter of course by those who do.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 24 -- St. John's College has completed a sweeping inventory of modern education with a special three-day stock-taking in which "too many" schools were found to be fearridden and failing to teach students to think.

Impetus to establishment of a comparatively new type of pension plan, whose benefits depend to a large extent upon the fluctuation in market value of the assets in the fund, is expected from the recent Internal Revenue Service ruling on their eligibility for tax consideration.

An orchestra composed for the most part of automobile workers who are members of the Congress of Industrial Organization unions will give a concert at Carnegie Hall tonight, but American Federation of Labor unions in that field are not worried about the incursion.

PORTLAND, Ore. -- Civic movements are underway throughout the Pacific Northwest to change the names of many communities which often are confused with similarly named cities and towns elsewhere in the nation. The effort centers here in Portland, which is not to be confused with Portland in Maine on the other side of the continent.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Pat Smythe, riding for the first time in international competition as a member of the British equestrian team, won the opening jumping event at Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight by the margin of one and one-fifth seconds.
IOWA CITY, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Iowa broke out of a 13-13 tie with a 24-yard touchdown pass late in the fourth period today for a 19-13 victory over Indiana, to stir a homecoming crowd of 50,129.
September purchases of life insurance of $2,758,000,000 brought the aggregate for the first nine months of the year to $26,665,000,000, some 18 per cent more than a year ago.
HEMPSTIEAD, L. I., Oct. 24 -- A favored Rhode Island football team, with a victory over Brown to its credit, received a stunning 27-12 setback tonight from Hofstra

CAMDEN, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Today's running of the $20,000 added Princeton Handicap had all the storybook elements. There was a dead-heat finish between Belair Stud's Hyphasis and R. C. Hanna's Candlewood. Darby Dan Farm's Skipper Bill was third, while W. M. Wickham's White Skies, odds-on favorite, wound up fourth.
BERLIN, Oct. 20 -- Hamburg police are searching for a strong-armed lunatic who steals only statues and announces his intentions beforehand.

Enrollment this fall in the basic course of the University of Chicago's downtown University College will bring to more than 500 the number of adults who have taken this unusual course on "how to think" since it was organized in 1946. The fundamental purpose is to provide training in clear thinking, effective reading and the ability to express thoughts well, both on paper and aloud.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 24 -- An inspired Brown University football team made its own breaks here this afternoon and turned in the biggest upset in New England football this season by defeating Holy Cross, 6 -- 0, before a crowd of 13,000.

AMMAN, Oct. 24 (UP) -- The Arab League announced today that its member nations would quadruple appropriations for defense against "Jewish aggression," while Syrian President Adib Shishekly renewed demands for the "liberation of Palestine.

WHEN Barnaby Conrad talks about bull-fighting, he talks as a bull-fighter. He has been one. During the war, while serving as a United States Consul in Spain, he studied the art under the toreros Sidney Franklin and Juan Belmonte, the idol of Spain, and later fought in thirty amateur corridas.

IT is an event of intellectual significance for Reinhold Niebuhr to write a book, even a small book. If Niebuhr published a book in his sleep (he might do it -- who knows? ) it would still inform the waking hours of thoughtful men. This is not because he is a cleric, though he dignifies that role above other living men.

The New York Knickerbockers shackled a highly regarded All-Star team in the second half last night to launch the professional basketball season in Madison Square Garden with a victory. The score was 89 to 71. The game was watched by 13,521, whose presence contributed to the Free Milk Fund for Babies.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 24 (UP) -- Quarterback Tony Rados' accurate passing and Halfback Lenny Moore's elusive running carried Penn State to a 27-21 victory over a game Texas Christian team today before a homecoming crowd of 30,000 fans.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Underdog Mississippi State battled Alabama to a 7-7 tie today. State's Jackie Parker led his mates to a second period touchdown and Alabama's Bart Starr passed brilliantly to get the tying touchdown in the third.
From fisticuffs to fashion is a strange transition, but Joseph Halpert, one of New York's leading manufacturers of dresses, made it some years before he was old enough to vote.

NEWEST of the labels on the market is Epic. This is the result of the split between American and British Columbia. Now that the domestic company no longer has access to the British masters, it has affiliated with Philips of Holland, and is releasing Philips disks under the Epic label to sell at $5.95 each.

" STANTON is the most unmitigated scoundrel, the most depraved hypocrite and villain," Gen. George B. McClellan concluded. Sharp - tongued Gideon Welles agreed: "He is rude, arrogant and domineering toward those in subordinate positions if they will submit to his rudeness, but is a sycophant and dissembler in deportment and language with those whom he fears.

Joe Fay always believed in doing things his own way. He was born in Port Washington, L. I., on Feb. 2, 1892, the son of the superintendent of a sand and gravel pit. His father was sober, hard-working and a devout Roman Catholic. He encouraged his children to study.

REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A dozen villages, wrecked by floods in the mountains above Reggio Calabria, lay dark and half-empty tonight while rescuers struggled to bring help to the victims.

The speech that Thomas E. Murray delivered in Chicago Friday on the Atomic Energy Commission's decision to build a full-scale nuclear power plant will have its repercussions, and especially in Soviet Russia. If we succeed in generating electric energy with a uranium reactor at a reasonable cost we shall go far toward implementing our Point Four program; for without power the program loses much of its industrial appeal.

THE Cleveland Browns had the ball on the fourteen-yard line of the Philadelphia Eagles a fortnight ago and Otto Graham promptly called for a favorite Cleveland play, the beartrap. A beartrap is bigger than a mousetrap, and opens a wider hole in the enemy line, but the fundamental principle is the same.
Harness racing is the fastest-growing spectator sport in the United States. Its scandals, with their roots in New York, are bursting into ugly bloom in widely scattered parts of the country.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- A French official went to Cannes today to confer with Vietnam's Chief of State, Bao Dai, before the latter goes to Saigon to clear up the uncertainties concerning the Indo-Chinese state's attitude toward the French Union.

The New York Rangers will skate against the Canadiens of Montreal in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. With the Broadway Blues already in possession of two victories, the chances are strong that a crowd of 13,000 fans will be out to see them match body checks with the Flying Frenchmen.

BERLIN, Oct. 24 -- In the competition for the loyalty of the Berliners and East Germans, the East German Government announced today extensive price reductions and a private United States organization began giving away 1,000,000 pounds of butter in West Berlin.

THERE is charm and nostalgia for old and faded things in this novel about the emergence of the new South. There is also a great deal of fury and hate and burning and the spilling of blood. And these too maybe are to be expected in these latter days.

MANILA, Oct. 24 -- Senator Jose C. Zulueta announced his resigna tion from the Nationalist party today in a quarrel with party leaders over election prerogatives in his province, Iloilo, on Panay Island, in the Central Philippines. He did not resign as Senator and is not up for re-election, his six-year term having begun in 1951.

In "Unpartisan Chief Justice of the U. S." (Oct 11) the author, James Bassett, an apparently reputable California political writer, in the sixth paragraph says this: "In his (Warren's) unprecedented three terms as Governor of America's third largest state. . . ."

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oat. 24 -- The probability that Pakistan would become a secular state receded today with the majority in the constituent assembly in agreement that the law of Islam would be the guiding principle of the Government.

THE following unique experience occurred to the undersigned California motorist while passing through Buzzard's Bay, Mass., the other day. Out-of-town motorists who have been less fortunate in their encounters with local traffic police might take heart from it.

VIENNA, Oct. 24 -- Perhaps the most genuine concern over the Trieste crisis, founded upon intellectual reality rather than emotion, is that being expressed these days in Austria. Unlike Rome and Belgrade, Vienna stakes no claim to the famous and beautiful Adriatic city which, until the end of World War I, was part of its imperial domain. But the lifeblood of Austrian economic health is pumped through Trieste's port.

The City of Brighton on the south coast of England has commemorated this Coronation year by building a garden designed for the special enjoyment of the blind. Led by Curtis Willson, who has been totally blind since World War I, many organizations and individuals have helped to make this garden of perfumes. The guide rail bordering the paths was given by the Soroptomist Club; teak tables and chairs by the Rotary Club.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 24 -- Fordham exhibited a well-rounded game in submerging the Rutgers football team today. The Rams moved along pretty much as they pleased to chalk up a 40-to-13 triumph over the lumbering Scarlet eleven before a crowd of 9,000.
MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- The voters approved today a proposal to merge the seven school districts in northern Westchester County. The ballot was 2,360 to 333.
LONDON, Oct. 24 -- A city whose circulation had nearly been halted received an emergency infusion of gasoline and Diesel oil today from Army and Air Force troops driving strike-bound trucks.

Wagner College's Seahawks scored their first gridiron shutout since 1950 when they blanked Brooklyn College, 38 to 0, at Grymes Hill, Staten Island, yesterday. The Seahawks held Brooklyn College to a minus-one-yard rushing as they scored in the first three periods to hand the Kings-men their fifth loss in five games this season.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 24 -A happy band of Cornell football players marched across the Palmer Stadium turf this afternoon after beating Princeton, 26 to 19, and on their shoulders they carried Dick Jackson of Athens, Pa.

Two gunmen robbed a hardware store manager last night of $1,200 in cash and an undetermined amount in checks after seizing him in his car and driving him for several blocks in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn. The victim was Henry Rosen of 8738 Twenty-third Avenue, Brooklyn.
In employing physically handicapped persons, some forward-looking hospital administrators are finding a solution to the critical shortage of hospital personnel discussed in this column last Sunday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 15 -- British Central Africa was federated into a new state primarily to attract American capital for the development of its rich natural resources, but it is already being jarred by race politics similar to those that divide the neighboring white South Africans.

TRENTON, Oct. 24 -- The New Jersey governorship campaign is about to enter its final week. Crime, corruption and personalities appear on the surface to be the dominant issues. Temporarily lost in the shuffle has been the question of legalizing bingo and other minor games of chance, one of the two main issues at the outset of the race.

The election for Mayor of New York is nine days off. Last week the Mayoralty candidates and their strategists, searching for clues to the outcome, devoted a good deal of attention to these developments:

SEATTLE, Wash., Oct. 24 (UP) -- Stanford poured it on in the first half and then staved off a Washington surge to down the Huskies, 13 -- 7, and remain unbeaten in Pacific Coast Conference football competition. The result kept Stanford a solid contender for the Rose Bowl.

STANDING on a balcony in Skoplje, capital of Macedonia, and addressing 250,000 followers who pressed into Marshal Tito Square until the Square could hold no more, Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia was well aware of the allegation that he is a dictator, that the storms of protest throughout the country on the question of Trieste were manipulated by him.

WHEN most New Yorkers think about Central Park (if, indeed, they think about it at all), they consider the vast tract (840 acres) a survival of primeval days when dinosaurs were dinosaurs and not fossils confined to the fourth floor of the Museum of Natural History.

JOSE LIMON and his company will make their first local appearance of the season on Saturday night in the Students Dance Recitals series at the Central High School of Needle Trades, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Joe Ujobai of Phoenixville, Pa., kicked two extra points today, and that enabled the Gettysburg Bullets to defeat Muhlenberg, 20 to 19.

APPLICATIONS are being accepted in the competition for the fifth annual City College Robert J. Flaherty Film Award. Prof. Hans Richter, director of the City College of New York Institute of Film Techniques, which sponsors these awards for outstanding creative achievement in the production of factual films, says that entries must be in by Dec. 11.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 24 -- Lieut. Louis Shoulders, the veteran St. Louis police officer credited with breaking the Greenlease kidnapping case, turned in his immediate resignation today.

THREE volumes of Yiddish verse were published by Yuri Suhl before he turned to writing novels in English. It is not suprising, then, that he has the ability to create and evoke characters that are distinct individuals, endowed with meaning and relevance beyond their time and place.

ACCORDING to Jim Corbett jungle lore cannot be learned; it can only be absorbed, a little at a time. During his seventy-eight years this distinguished veteran has absorbed a tremendous amount, and with rare skill he leads his readers on exciting trips along the Indian jungle trails he knows so intimately.

THE scramble for the non-stop regularly scheduled transcontinental traffic between Los Angeles and New York got under way last week with Trans World Airlines getting off the ground first. American Airlines has been announcing non-stop scheduled service both ways across the country to start Nov. 29 with its new DC-7, scheduling 7 hours 15 minutes eastbound and 7 hours 50 minutes westbound.
When the new law simplifying the processing of imports for duty purposes went into effect on Sept. 8, Customs Service officials took special measures to make the changeover as painless as possible.

The men's clothing industry is tackling one of its basic problems -- production information. Market research and statistical information has been available to the manufacturers and the picture is now being completed with the addition of output data.
The Cleveland Browns will be on display today at the Polo Grounds, where the New York Giants will see what they can do about stopping the all-winning record Otto Graham Co. have compiled this year.

WHEN Angel Records hits the market, in a few weeks, it will institute a merchandising experiment that the industry will watch with close attention. Angel, which is the American label for British Columbia, will bring out classical disks packaged two ways -- one in a sealed plastic envelope housed in a sturdy album, with art work and program notes, selling at $5.95.
THANKS for your article on "Little Fugitive." You are so right.

OCTOBER and November are ideal months for a visit to Mexico. The rainy season has passed, leaving the fields bright with flowers, the temperature hovering between 70 and 80, and the skies a steadfast, sunny blue. Moreover, the visitor misses the swarm of American turistas that descend on the land in summer and winter.

NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 24 (UP) -- Merrill Green, an Oklahoma substitute, broke away for a 51-yard scoring run with thirty-six seconds left to play today to give the Sooners a 27-20 Big Seven Conference victory over Colorado. A homecoming crowd of 34,000 watched.

OF the sixteen operas written by Eugene Francis Charles d'Albert in the intervals between his concert tours, Tiefland (1903) appears to have demonstrated the greatest vitality. It has been staged hereabouts within the memory of men now living, and in the opera houses of Central Europe is said to be one of the most popular works in the repertory.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24 -Missing three grand opportunities in the last quarter after yielding the tying touchdown in the third session. Yale's football team was held to a 7-7 tie by Colgate's Red Raiders before 25,000 in the Bowl today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24 -Missing three grand opportunities in the last quarter after yielding the tying touchdown in the third session. Yale's football team was held to a 7-7 tie by Colgate's Red Raiders before 25,000 in the Bowl today.

UP in the bow of this section today is a review of "Russian Assignment," by Vice Adm. Leslie C. Stevens (Retired). Now everyone who has given the matter some thought, or is accustomed to Gilbert Sullivan, would know at once how a vice admiral (retired) should appear.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24 -- The fight for water, which in our West once led to bloody feuds between the cattlemen and the homesteaders, has now achieved official recognition in the United Nations. In fact, Syria's recent complaint that Israel is trying to divert water from the River Jordan contains the specific charge that this constitutes "a threat to the peace."

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 24 -- The Right Rev. James P. DeWolfe, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, installed the Rev. Canon James Green as dean of the Cathedral of the Incarnation at a special service here today.

Women interested actively in the New York Botanical Garden have taken over the performance of "The Solid Gold Cadillac," with Josephine Hull, on the night of Nov. 10 at the Belasco Theatre to raise funds for the Garden. Mrs. Richard S. Meredith and Mrs. Charles G. Stradella are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.

ONE of the world's foremost collections of Confederate States stamps and used covers was broken up here last week at a public auction and dispersed among albums of collectors residing in all parts of the country. These philatelic holdings had been assembled across many years by Van Dyk MacBride, a Newark dealer in investment securities. A resident .of Nutley, N. J., he is Ipresident of the Confederate Stam!@ Alliance.
GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 24 (Reuters) -- Five leaders of the allegedly pro-Communist People's Progressive party were held tonight for questioning by police.
WE had fun, didn't we?"
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Steve Meilinger fired a dormant Kentucky attack with two last-period aerial plays as Kentucky downed Villanova, 19 -- 0, tonight.

SUMMIT, N. J., Oct. 24 -- Two historic paintings depicting sea engagements of the frigate Constitution with British men-of-war became the property of the Navy today. Capt. Hugh C. Haynsworth Jr., commander of the Naval Supply Depot at Bayonne, accepted them here on behalf of Rear Admiral John Heffernan,-Navy Department curator.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Steve Meilinger fired a dormant Kentucky attack with two last-period aerial plays as Kentucky downed Villanova, 19 -- 0, tonight.

SUMMIT, N. J., Oct. 24 -- Two historic paintings depicting sea engagements of the frigate Constitution with British men-of-war became the property of the Navy today. Capt. Hugh C. Haynsworth Jr., commander of the Naval Supply Depot at Bayonne, accepted them here on behalf of Rear Admiral John Heffernan,-Navy Department curator.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 24 (AP) -- All-America Paul Giel propelled Minnesota to a 22-to-0 victory over previously unbeaten Michigan today.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 24 (UP) -- Quarterback Charlie Sumner put his team ahead and then saved the day with an end zone interception in the final seconds today as William Mary, using only eighteen players, defeated George Washington, 12 to 7, in a Southern Conference game.
The St. John's cross-country team gained its first victory of the season yesterday by defeating New York University, 26 -- 29, over the Van Cortlandt Park course.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Oct. 24 (UP) Quarterback Harry Speers connected on a desperation pass late in the final period today to help Florida gain a 21-to-21 tie with Louisiana State before 40,000 fans.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Oct. 24 -- Whether the state shall continue to grant more than $5,000,000 a year to its public schools, some of it for children who do not even attend them, has overshadowed the other issues in Kentucky's election Nov. 3.

Old people often are surprisingly healthy, both physically and mentally, but they are greatly preoccupied with the fear of being socially isolated, a cooperative study by the Cornell University Medical College and several other agencies indicates.

THE $3,000 second annual Osborne Color Transparency Contest for camera club members is announced by Fred Seeley, vice president of the Osborne Company, Clifton, N. J., publisher of commercial art calendars.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 24 -- A plan to bring forty-five outstanding educators to the faculty of the University of Notre Dame by offering salaries sufficient to attract them was outlined today by the Rev. John J. Cavanaugh, C. S. C., director of the Notre Dame Foundation.

BAGUIO, the Philippines, Oct. 24 -- Ramon Magsaysay, the Nationalist candidate for President, has been dealing primarily with domestic issues in his campaign talks in northern Luzon. Many of his speeches have been delivered before relatively unsophisticated audiences made up of farmers and residents of small towns and he has keyed his remarks accordingly.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 24 (UP) -- Dick Thomas, bottled up by Pittsburgh most of the day, found the range in the last minutes of the fourth quarter and passed Northwestern to a 27-21 victory over the Panthers today.

A NATION'S stature in the theatre is measured by its creative achievements in the world's best plays, of the past and of the present. Almost every European country encourages the development of this kind of theatre in the manner best suited to the tastes and talents of its own culture, without importing foreign talent to show them how it should be done.

SHERIDAN, Wyo., Oct. 24 (UP) -- National Guard emergency crews brought the first marooned hunters out of the snow-clogged Big Horn Mountains today as rescuers hurried to free hundreds of others before another blizzard cut them off.

AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 24 (Reuters) -- A Jordanian Government spokesman said today the Arab Legion had fought a twenty-minute skirmish with an Israeli patrol that crossed the demarcation line north of Tulkarm.

TELEVISION, once considered the virus that might finish off the long-ailing legitimate theatre, has assumed qualities of an antibiotic that is pouring more vigor into Broadway than anything since Richard Rodgers began working with Oscar Hammerstein 2d.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 24 -- A fourth-down 22-yard scoring pass from Quarterback Rick Francis to Frank Sutkowski with seven minutes to play, and a conversion by John Binswanger, enabled Wesleyan to gain a 20-20 tie today with unbeaten Amherst in the opening Little Three encounter.

RATOONS are the young shoots that sprout in the sugar cane plantations of Natal's South Coast. Hemmed in between the green hills and the sea, these plantations lie like a bright bandana on the face of the province. Trapped, too, in a hothouse of churning emotions are the whites, Indians and Zulus who work these sugar fields --Or so Miss Rooks would have us believe in her new book.

AN orchestral event of uncommon interest should be Mr. Mitropoulos' performance at the Philharmonic-Symphony Society's concerts of this week of Arnold Schoenberg's symphonic poem, "Pelleas und Melisande." This will be only the second appearance of the work on the Philharmonic-Symphony's programs, although the society gave the score its first American hearings at its concerts of Nov. 18 and 19, in 1915.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 24 -- An 85-yard first-period touchdown run by converted halfback Bryan Satterlee of Troy, N. Y., and a place kick by Frank Mattison held up through Bucknell threats today as Lafayette College won, 7--6, before a Founders' Day crowd of 8,000.

Many tickets have been sold for the performance of "A Girl Can Tell," a new comedy with Janet Blair in the leading role, on the night of Nov. 12 at the Royale Theatre for the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys Club.

A country housewife dressed in a gay plastic apron cooking supper on a gas stove may not realize it but both the source of heat and the garment once splashed about as liquids in the cargo space of a ship moving north along the Eastern Seaboard.

Now something new has been added to the movies -- the "Panoramic" screen. They have taken from the height of the screen to add to its width so that we can see more people at once. So now we are treated to the sight of headless and footless torsos march-marching about. I never saw a dream walking but I have seen any number of torsos talking. And it ain't good.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24 -- Democratic spokesmen in this region are confident that the stock of the Republican party has slipped since Inauguration Day last January; Republicans are far from sure that it hasn't. Many of the hundreds of thousands of rank- and-file Democrats who cast their votes in 1952 for General Eisenhower, along with the man-in-the- street Republican, seem to be adopting a "wait-and-see" attitude.

THE formative years of one of the world's most remarkable women provide the material for this historical novel. The author traces, with careful attention to documentary data, the colorful life of Catherine the Great from her summons to the Russian Court while still a girl in her teens until that triumphal moment when she is to be crowned Empress of Russia.

American companies had invested nearly $4,500,000,000 in petroleum enterprises abroad at the end of 1952, according to figures just released by the Department of Commerce. Foreign oil investment grew by approximately $1,000,000,000 between 1950 and 1952, and at the end of last year accounted for 30 per cent of all such investments.

SINCE George Meredith's death in 1909 he has had few biographers; until now there had been only two in the past quarter-century. Full-length literary studies have been almost as sparse. Meredith has lain entombed in tortuous, if glittering, obscurity with no breath of revival like those of Melville, James and Dickens.
In the capricious field of metals, which is noted for sharp changes in prices and supply-demand trends, vanadium has attained a rare market stability.
SANTA FE, N. M., Oct. 24 -- Intoxicating liquors may now be legally sold to Indians in New Mexico, but Indian officials are resisting all attempts to set up liquor stores on the reservations.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 24 -- Greentree Stable's Tom Fool, the handicap king of 1953, led all the way in the three-horse field today to win the seventeenth running of the Pimlico Special by eight lengths in track-record time.

IT probably came as a surprise that Winston Churchill, statesman, author, artist, bricklayer, aphorist and putterer, took literature's highest award, the Nobel Prize. He follows hard on such literary esoterics as Hesse, Gide, Eliot, Faulkner, Lagerkvist and Mauriac, and one philosopher, Bertrand Russell, a composite that is hardly Mr. Churchill's cup of tea.

RICHARD STRAUSS' final opera, "Capriccio," will be presented, in the spring by the Juilliard School of Music. It will be given four or five showings, which will be the opera's first performances in this country. One reason the school authorities picked this work from among six or seven Strauss operas still unproduced here was because they were especially charmed by the libretto written for it by the conductor, Clemens Krauss.
BUFFALO, Oct. 24 -- Reversal of a speeding conviction obtained through radar evidence is expected to bring a change of procedure in similar City Court cases here.

SINGAPORE, Oct. 24 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon received a welcome in half a dozen languages when he and his wife arrived in Singapore today from Indonesia on a world tour. He was almost pulled off his feet as Chinese, Malays and Indians among the big welcoming crowd tried to shake hands. Mr. Nixon said:

TORONTO, Oct. 24 (Canadian Press) -- Trygvie Lie, former Secretary General of the United Nations, said today that the world organization had no magic formula for peace, but was a workshop to achieve that purpose and deserved a chance to grow strong.

ANDREW WYETH is unique among modern artists. His meticulous tempera paintings and his expert water-colors have enough apparent versimilitude to endear him to the most esthetically conservative of art lovers, yet advocates of avant-garde art are also champions of his work. because they see that what appears to be literal transcription is instead a highly selective means toward an intense, subjective and wholly twentieth-century expression.

ON these bright October days when migrating birds make headline news, seeds are quietly undertaking their own excursions in their own ingenious ways. Seeking fresh fields to conquer, they will avail themselves of any means of transportation offered by wind, animals, birds and man.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 (UP) -- A strike that halted production of the nation's newest jet fighter, the F-100, spread today to a plant working on F-86 Sabre jets.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Oct. 24 -- School officials here turned today from the pressing problem of too many students to deal with a new and more light-hearted surplus -- hundreds of dogwood trees growing wild on school property.

For a long time I have wondered why, in commenting favorably on a Negro play -- either written by or for Negroes -- the New York drama critics unfailingly fall back on the cliches: "an honest play, a play written with dignity, a moving play."
MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Auburn's Tigers came back from their humiliating defeat by Georgia Tech with a furious ground attack that overwhelmed the Tulane Green Wave today, 34 -- 7.
HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 24 -- Dartmouth College has increased its assets to more than $42,000,000, John F. Meck, treasurer and vice president of the institution, said today.

NO one has any difficulty in falling in love with "The Teahouse of the August Moon." A comedy about the meeting of the Occidental and the Oriental minds in Okinawa during the war, it deals with some implacable realities in a spirit of round-eyed wonder.

The first airplane flights of Wilbur and Orville Wright will be marked here the week beginning Nov. 2 by the New York City Committee for Celebrating the Fiftieth Anniversary of Powered Flight. With Edward V. Rickenbacker as chairman, the committee will work in conjunction with the national program headed by Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle.

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Rugged John Carson caught every football in reach today and helped Zeke Bratkowski get Georgia's air carnival back on the victory circuit today with a 27-14 triumph over North Carolina.

PANMUNJOM, Oct. 24 -- A week ago Friday Maj. Gen. S. P. Patil Thorat, commander of Indian custodian forces, stood on a mound overlooking the P. O. W. compounds, studiously practicing golf swings with his chrome and leather-trimmed shooting stick.

The threatened milk strike in the metropolitan area was postponed yesterday until 4 P. M. today. Meanwhile, negotiators representing 200 milk distributors and 13,000 delivery men and plant workers continued their efforts to avert a strike that would cut off deliveries for 12,000,000 persons.

Your critic wrote in your section recently that: "Although the times are big, the plays are small." After referring to: ". . . the global conflicts between Communism and democracy today," he expresses regret at the failure of dramatist to say something great, or to produce a play of classical proportions that would express the terrible conflict of this time.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 24 (AP) -- Worcester Tech sprang a 9-0 football surprise on Coast Guard Academy today. The Engineers took command in the second half with a touchdown, conversion and safety after the Cadets threatened three times in the first half.

Tokyo is a city of about six million persons, and all six millions seem to have their hands on auto horns. A budding automobile driver shopping for a new vehicle looks first and last for a loud, yes, even louder, horn. There is no dearth of decibels there.

The American Chemical Society, 60 East Forty-second Street, has announced that Prof. Alfred Burger of the University of Virginia has been elected chairman for 1954 of its Division of Medicinal Chemistry.

ROEBLING, N. J., Oct. 25 -Robert B. Meyner, Democratic candidate for Governor, said today that the recent report of the legislative investigating committee made Attorney General Theodore Parsons the whipping boy for the breakdown in law enforcement in the state.

Joseph T. Sharkey of Brooklyn, vice chairman of 'the City Council, charged yesterday that slum conditions in that borough and the city at large were being perpetuated by unscrupulous real estate speculators.

WITH the New York political pot at high boil, workers caught in it are jumpy as noodles ready for the table. There's astonishing activity, for example, on the fourth floor at the Roosevelt Hotel, where women of the Citizens Committee for Riegelman twitter about, stuffing literature into envelopes, filling baskets with booklets, working telephones.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Three of the nation's top military leaders left by air today for first-hand inspections of the United States' defensive position abroad.
Because an overzealous rookie guard went offside at a critical moment, the Giants lost to the Browns, 7 -- 0, in the rain and the mud at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- King Paul and Queen Frederika of Greece will land at the National Airport here Wednesday afternoon to begin their visit of state in response to President Eisenhower's invitation. They will fly here from New York after arriving there aboard the liner United States.

The executive board of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, at a national conference last night, adopted a resolution calling on the United States Government and the United Nations Security Council to sift all facts of the Israeli-Arab controversy before passing judgment or levying penalties.

St. John's Prep defeated Xavier of Manhattan, 13 -- 0, at Boys High Field in Brooklyn yesterday and ended the latter's three-game winning streak. The triumph was the fourth for the Little Redmen in five football contests this season.

Governor Dewey deserves high praise for his forthright stand on the question of Senator Wicks' resignation. While there is a seeming conflict of executive and legislative powers involved, the Governor has promptly posed the issue of removal to the State Senate to be convened.

Cotton futures prices in the domestic market last week held to a narrow trading range in comparatively light dealings. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were 8 points higher to 9 points lower, or up 40 cents a bale to off 45 cents. The near-by deliveries gained ground, while the more distant contracts drifted lower.
Widespread mobilization by police and health authorities began almost immediately late yesterday afternoon in the metropolitan area to minimize distress from the milk strike.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 25 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion told 150 Jewish business and financial leaders from seven countries here tonight that "there are world forces which cannot be reconciled with Jewish independence and with national equality for the Jewish people."

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 25 -One birthday used to be enough for Mrs. Sarah Frances Rockwell when she was a young Southern belle back in the days of the Civil War. But today, as she turned 109, she happily observed her second party within a week in recognition of the occasion.

A tract of land just south of Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx has been purchased by a corporation formed by the Van Cortlandt Chapter of the American Veterans Committee in cooperation with the United Housing Foundation for improvement with cooperative apartments that will represent an investment of about $3,000,000.

OAKENGATES, England, Oct. 25 -- Both the beer and the opinions run strong in the busy Midlands and its striving farmlands, and strongest of the opinions is that someone, somewhere, had better get busy and patch up a peace between the West and Russia.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25 -- Unless another setback develops in the business picture the steel market is expected to assume a more normal nature. Hectic bidding for supplies has come to an end for the first time in several years.

With only 46 seconds left to play, the Canadiens of Montreal last night transformed a bright New York Ranger prospect into one of gloom. The Broadway Blues had outskated their speedy foes through most of the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden and seemed certain to salvage at least a tie.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- A back-towork movement among striking drivers of London's gasoline and oil trucks became stronger tonight. It promised an early end of a walkout that has slowed metropolitan traffic since the middle of last week.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- A six-year program to resettle Arab refugees and develop the natural resources of the Middle East was proposed to the United Nations today by thirty-three prominent religious, educational and civic leaders.

Anatole and Roberto Kitain, who have both given recitals here separately, joined forces yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall and presented their first joint recital in the United States. The sonatas that the brothers played together were Brahms' Sonata for Violin and Piano, Op. 108; the Debussy Violin Sonata and Beethoven's "Kreutzer."

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 25 -- The seventh annual cotton mechanization conference will be held in Gadsden, Ala., next Thursday and Friday. Six hundred representatives from various segments of the industry in fifteen states will attend, the National Cotton Council announced today.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Indian officer was enjoying the night-time calm of his garden when he spotted the glistening eyes of a panther.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower returned to the White House at 10:45 P. M. today after an overnight stay at Camp David, the President's week-end resort in the Catoctin Mountains near Thurmont, Md.
BERLIN, Oct. 25 -- East Germany's Communists have opened a new drive to enlist the population in their fight against sabotage and other anti-Communist activities.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- The grain market was generally firm last week. Its strength was attributed to the prevailing belief that high support prices for farm commodities will be retained by Congress.

Two artists made their debut with the New York City Opera Company in the performance of Verdi's "La Traviata" yesterday afternoon at the City Center. They were Maria Di Gerlando, the Violetta of the cast, and Claudio Frigerio, who was heard as the elder Germont.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The new United States Information Administration, which took over the Voice of America and other propaganda functions from the State Department, is about ready to operate on its own.

Our export wheat market depends to a distressing extent upon United States overseas aid -- non-military aid. The more we cut it down, the less we are going to sell and the larger the surpluses with which the Government must deal at home.

The new regulations announced by the Department of Air Pollution Control as an intensification of the city's attack on smoke are far-reaching. Only actual application of these rules can prove their effectiveness. The brunt of the new attack is to be borne by incinerators, which Dr. Greenburg, the Air Pollution Control Commissioner, finds "responsible for a large amount of the soot-fall in our city" and brands as "the villains which begrime nice white shirts."

Ever since it became evident that unions in mass-production industries were determined to win the guaranteed annual wage in up-coming negotiations there has been a deluge of economic theorizing on the subject, practically all of which is beside the point.

There is a tendency to put adolescents "on ice" or to leave them unprepared for the responsibilities and the maturity needed to meet today's accelerated and complicated way of living. Mrs. Jean Schick Grossman told a group of parents last week at the third in a special program series on adolescence at the New York Society for Ethical Culture.

The confused and embittered situation between the Arab states and Israel prompts us to share with the readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES a factual review of this explosive problem in the hope that a more constructive attitude will prevail among all men of goodwill and that a more helpful program of action will be fashioned by our Government.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Ease and width over the bosom and shoulders of a sleek princess silhouette, sometimes with a swinging gore in the center back of the skirt, was the line that Nina Ricci offered this midseason.
Paul Mayer has hung up his diploma from the former Cordon Bleu Cooking School in New York and opened his office-kitchen at 252 East Sixtieth Street (PLaza 1-0969).

GEORGETOWN, Guiana, Oct. 25 -- With two arrests added today to five yesterday, the police have shown the teeth of emergency powers conferred in the crisis over local leftists' efforts to get control of the colony.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- The primary task of education is to train youngsters to judge between right and wrong, and not merely try to teach all sorts of seemingly useful facts, which probably will be forgotten.

SHERIDAN, Wyo., Oct. 25 (AP) -- While scores of snowbound hunters poured out of northern Wyoming mountains behind bulldozers, rescue operations were begun today in western Colorado for ninety more hunters also caught by storms.

Roll Persinger's viola recital at Town Hall last night combined two things. It displayed his considerable gifts and it provided an evening of fine music-making. For both the violist and his excellent accompanist, Brooks Smith, approached their selections with the attitude that serious musicians bring to chamber music.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 25 -- Yale students are going to have their own television programs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The American Home Economics Association urged Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, today to maintain the identity and functions of the Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A 52-yard field goal by Bert Rechichar helped the Baltimore Colts beat the Washington Redskins, 27 -- 17, in a National Football League game today.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 25 -Hussan von Haus Kilmark, U.D.T., one of the most successful dogs in obedience competition, achieved his seventh perfect score of the year in the trials of the German Shepherd Dog Club of Long Island today.
