SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 (UP) -- The Detroit Lions got two scoring opportunities today and cashed in on both of them to whip the San Francisco Forty Niners, 14 -- 10, before 54,862 fans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The economy of the United States can sustain a defense program costing up to $70,000,000,000 or $75,000,000,000 a year without undue strain, according to a report issued today by the National Planning Association.
Three more investigative experts, who helped dig out waterfront racketeering for the State Crime Commission, have been added to the staff that is studying the harness racing scandals.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 25 -- The campaign personalities of Thomas B. Stanley, Democratic nominee for Governor of Virginia, and his Republican opponent, Theodore Roosevelt Dalton, epitomize divergencies in governmental philosophy that are at stake in the Nov. 3 election.

A plan to provide complete weather coverage for trans-Atlantic commercial planes has been devised by the International Airlines Navigators Council to fill the gap to be left when the United States withdraws Coast Guard cutters now dispensing that information from mid-ocean.

The memories of yesterday are vivid, but of last year they are vague, and of ten and twenty years ago they often are but wisps of unreality. How difficult it becomes, then, for the mind to grasp fully the fact that any trace of civilization existed on this earth thousands of years ago.

To celebrate the publication of "Varied Harvest: A Miscellany of Writing by Barnard College Women" by G. P. Putnam's, a reception for the contributors will be held on Wednesday at the home of Mrs. Alvan Barach, 35 East Eightyfourth Street.

New Yorkers have been enjoying an average income 38 per cent higher than that of the average American -- $2,264 here last year. But as the city prepares to entrust its future to a new Mayor on Jan. 1, its jobs and its business activity are running into increasing competition from other areas.
The Rev. Dr. Phillips Packer Elliott declared yesterday that the church must give to the state and to the world the distinctive gifts that it possesses.

Records were set by the Radio Corporation of America in the first nine months this year. According to David Sarnoff, corporation chairman, sales of products and services by the company and its subsidiaries reached $609,428,166 through the end of September.

The International Longshoremen's Association will rally its forces in Madison Square Garden tonight. The gathering will be both a show of strength for the old pier union and a gesture of defiance to the rival union chartered last month by the American Federation of Labor.
Three bright shovels with handles of blue, white and orange -- the city's colors -- turned the first earth yesterday for the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University.
Sentry Duty is the loneliest task of a soldier. And today every member of our armed forces is a sentry guarding the frontiers of freedom.

The State Attorney General paved the way yesterday for an immediate hearing of Robert F. Wagner's court action in the Fay case. Nathaniel L. Goldstein said his office was ready for the hearing, designed to compel the State Parole Board to make public the names of those who tried to get a parole for Joseph S. Fay, labor extortionist, as soon as the proceedings were started "in the proper way."

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 26 -- The Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission postponed until this afternoon a meeting at which it was expected to approve a statement making public its sharp internal differences over the handling of "explanations" to Korean war prisoners who do not want to go home.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 25 -- Yugoslavia denounced today Italy's proposal for the withdrawal of both countries' troops on the frontier near Trieste. She termed it "obvious hypocrisy."

Five theologians will be publicly installed as professors on the faculty of Union Theological Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street, at 4:30 P. M., Wednesday, Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen, president, announced yesterday.

Dasher, Dancer, Prancer and their teammates are being groomed for their Yuletide visit to children eagerly anticipating their company. Already talk of Christmas gifts and cards is in the air. This should remind mothers -- as we are doing here -- that the time has come to make party dresses for their little daughters.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Acts of violence on both sides of the IsraeliJordan frontier were condemned today by the National Executive Committee of the American Jewish Committee.

TAXILA, Pakistan, Oct. 15 -- A 2,300-year-old link in man's heritage from the Persian, Greek and Hindu cultures has been excavated in three successive cities on adjoining sites here. They were partly destroyed by barbarian Ephthalites, or White Huns, in the sixth century.
Although a fair amount of business was transacted in the ship charter market last week, rates for the most part leveled off and in some cases went down slightly, local brokers reported.
PARIS, Oct. 25 -- Signs of French industrial recovery were reflected in an announcement here last week that steel and iron exports were back to the level of 1929, a record year for the industry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The "high brass" workers at the Pentagon, including Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Army Chief of Staff, who objects to the word "brass" as having a derogatory ring, are about to have brass handles to pull as they enter the nation's military headquarters.

As an organization founded to oppose all forms of totalitarianism in Latin America and to defend civil and political liberties in the hemisphere, we are shocked by the recent address of Assistant Secretary of State Cabot, speaking of improved relations with Juan Peron on the part of our Government.

Americans are in special danger of trying to make God fit into "our plans, our patriotism, our way of life," the congregation of St. Martin's Protestant Episcopal Church, Lenox Avenue and 122d Street, was warned at yesterday morning's service. The speaker was the Rev. Dr. William Lloyd Imes, field service director of the New York State Council of Churches.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 25 -- Maj. Gen. Lucas V. Beau of the Air Force, national commander of the Civil Air Patrol, declared here today that the patrol was the only properly trained organization in the nation that could be activated in a minute's notice in an emergency.

HANOI, Vietnam, Oct. 25 (AP) -French-Vietnamese armored and infantry columns continued today their attempts to draw the Communistled Vietminh forces into battle outside the southern fringes of the Red River delta.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 25 -India has abolished or reduced various levies on textile goods, including export duties on some fabrics, and has announced measures for the relief of unemployment in the industry.

A new novel by Esther Forbes, her first book since "The Running of the Tide" was published in 1948, is planned for January publication by Houghton Mifflin, entitled "Rainbow on the Road." Set in New England during the early nineteenth century, it deals with an itinerant painter and a highwayman whom he strangely resembled.

A "live" color program and films will be transmitted Nov. 3 from New York to Hollywood to give the West Coast its first view of the R. C. A. system in action, Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff, chairman of the boards of the Radio Corporation of America and the National Broadcasting Company, announced yesterday.

The city's Democratic and Republican party leaders were accused yesterday of careless conduct of municipal affairs and waste of public funds resulting from an evasion of the spirit of the civil service provisions of the state constitution.
AMSTERDAM, Oct. 25 -- Authorities have decided to abolish the export bonus dollar plan.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- The happiest people in Britain this week-end were the pedestrians, the almost undisputed masters of the streets because a strike of gasoline truck drivers had immobilized motorists.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Wall Street and Throgmorton Street seem to have exchanged roles these past few days. While the New York market has become less bearish and is showing signs of steady recovery, the London market has been acting less bullish and showing downward trends.

NEWARK, Oct. 25 -- Paul L. Troast, Republican candidate for Governor, recalled today that on Sept. 22 he had criticized New York authorities for not having cooperated with New Jersey in the development of a rapid transit system.

Now hear this, soldiers and former soldiers: the old-fashioned canvas bunk on troopships (that oblong piece of rough fabric lashed securely to tubular steel frames arranged in tiers) may be on its way out.

A continuing decline in the number of persons receiving public relief in this city was reported yesterday to Major Impellitteri by Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy. Mr. McCarthy announced that the public assistance caseload in September was 249,258, compared with 249,366 in August, a drop of 108.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Sentiment for direct price supports on cattle was high tonight in the cattle men's caravan. The group moved into Washington to make recommendations to the Administration on how to stop plummeting livestock prices.

The first rain in thirteen days fell over the New York area yesterday, and the Weather Bureau cautiously viewed it as the beginning of a wet spell that could break the grip of the worst drought since 1949.
Knitting and crocheting with ribbons is a handicraft that has grown in popularity in spite of its difficulty for beginners.

Powerful anti-Israel forces have long been at work in this country to impair relations between Israel and the United States, Dr. Emanuel Neumann, a member of the Jewish Agency Executive, declared here yesterday.
The American premiere of "Outward Bound With Columbus," an opera composed expressly for radio by Riccardo Nielsen, was presented in an hour-long recording over WNYC yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -The Federal Reserve Board said today the time is approaching when other free world nations may be able to get along without United States financial aid.

BOSTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- An Amer-I ican Airlines plane carrying seven-] teen passengers and a crew ofI three skidded twenty-five feet off] a runway into soft mud after mak-I ing an instrument landing at Logan International Airport today. No one was injured. The front leftI wheel of the twin-engined Convair out of Buffalo became mired in mud, but the craft remained upright.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 25 (AP) -- A leaky Xavier pass defense and Boston College's superior speed gave Boston a 31-14 football victory over the Musketeers before about 10,000 fans today.

Travis Childs' Childs Chico Negro, a smooth-coated chihuahua that made its debut last May, became best in show yesterday in the Progressive Dog Club's twenty-first annual event for toy breed dogs at The Livingston in Brooklyn.
It is almost a commonplace to say that most debates on the tariff are notable chiefly for the fact that they are almost spectacularly devoid of realism.

Victoria Kingsley, British soprano who made her local debut last season at Carl Fischer Hall, gave her second New York recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Following her custom, she accompanied herself on the guitar and devoted herself chiefly to the folk repertory.
Thirteen thousand milk drivers and plant workers struck yesterday, halting the flow of milk and milk products to 12,000,000 persons in the metropolitan area.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 -- Pan American World Airways announced today it would begin its second winter schedule of nonstop Tokyo-to-Honolulu flights next Sunday night, taking advantage of the Pacific jet stream, a "built-in tailwind" averaging 80 to 100 miles an hour.

Girl Scouts and Brownies marched into three houses of worship on Fifth Avenue yesterday to attend special services in observance of Girl Scout Sunday. The day opened the annual national celebration of Girl Scout Week.

Whether grapefruit appears on the breakfast table or not, the chances are better than even that it will turn up in large space in the breakfast newspaper. What is described as the biggest citrus campaign in the forty-five years the Florida Citrus Exchange has been promoting the fruit is scheduled to run in every major market center in the country.

If the Italian Government had hoped to soothe Marshal Tito by its proposal of last Saturday to "normalize" the military situation along the border that runs from Trieste to the Alps it was quickly disappointed. The Yugoslav reply is that Italy began to reinforce her border guards as far back as last August, that the Yugoslav army did not move until after Oct. 8 and, finally, that the Italian offer is "hypocritical."
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 25 (AP) -John B. Kelly Jr., United States single sculls champion, helped lower the Mexican senior doubles sculls mark in the Mexican national rowing championships today.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate, promised yesterday to be a "fighting Mayor" who would go to Washington and Albany to protect the interests of the working people of the city. He spoke at a convention of Local 1,102, Retail Dry Goods and Chain Stores Union, C. I. O., at the Park Sheraton Hotel, Seventh Avenue and West Fifty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Senator Alexander H. Wiley, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, predicted tonight that the "clouds that hover" over United States relations with Israel would pass.

The Peru (Neb.) State Teachers headed a list of forty-six undefeated and untied college football teams around the country, The Associated Press reported yesterday. It was the only team with seven triumphs.

ARTHUR GODFREY'S humility may be a shade tattered and worn but otherwise the fuss over his dismissal of Julius La Rosa, the singer, mercifully is showing signs of subsiding. The worst of the crisis apparently is over and most viewers probably will recover after a few days of peace and quiet.
The 1953 Team of Four Metropolitan Championship went last night to the contract bridge team of Alexander Weiss, Charles Sanders, A. Lewis Gotthelf, Jack Cushing, Sims Gaynor, all of New York.

Now that the Court of Appeals has cleared the way for the vitally needed New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle it is to be hoped the project can be carried without further obstructionist tactics from drawing board to completion. As it is, the city will be without a major mid-Manhattan convention and exhibition hall for at least three years and large gatherings that should be accommodated here are of necessity shifting to other cities.

ZURICH, Oct. 25 -- When the ministerial council of the Organization of European Economic Cooperation reassembles in Paris next Thursday the most urgent topic will be that submitted by the French Government for the regulation of imports from the European Payments Union countries. The regulation would cover the six-month period, Oct. 1, 1953, to March 31, 1954.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 25 (UP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation saint today it would charge a woman with giving false information on the Greenlease kidnappingmurder case.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 26 (UP) -The first American soldier to break with the Communists after refusing repatriation said today he had remained behind to get information to use against the Reds in "exposing their lies to the world."
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 25 -- The Shah, on the eve of his thirtyfourth birthday, distributed titles to sixteen-acre farms today to 1,600 cheering former tenants of crown lands.

Postal clerks and carriers shouted yesterday their condemnation of "inhuman working conditions," "speed-ups" and "sweatshops" in the New York Post Office. At a mass grievance meeting 1,200 voted to send telegrams of protest to President Eisenhower and Arthur S. Summerfield, Postmaster General.

DETROIT, Oct. 25 (UP) -- Terry Sawchuk, Detroit goalie, turned in his second shutout of the season tonight as the Red Wings blanked the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 -- 0, for their fifth straight victory on home ice.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 25 -The United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association approved an extensive list of sanctioned meets and tournaments and elected officers at the closing session of its annual convention today.
Four new films, including importations from England, Italy and the U. S. S. R., are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
PARIS, Oct. 25 (AP) -- United States military leaders stationed here are putting pressure on Washington and Paris to back Prime Minister Churchill's proposal for highest-level talks with Moscow.

ALBANY, Ga., Oct. 25 (UP) -- Bill Spear took his Italian Ferrari into the lead in the closing minutes of the 250-mile feature event of the international sports car races at Turner Air Force Base today to win the Strategic Air Power Trophy and break up a Cunningham sweep.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- An imposing work of art begun seventy-six years ago, no less, has finally been completed in the great rotunda of the Capitol and will be formally dedicated early next year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Recent disclosures by United States soldiers who had been taken prisoner in the Korean war prompted the Senate Internal Security subcommittee to make public today the text of testimony before it in May.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Although the production of beef is expected to taper after breaking records this month, housewives will hold an exceptionally strong position against any attempt to increase prices this fall and most of the winter.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 25 -- Demand for natural gas for home heating eventually is expected to supplant a major part of the competitive market in the oil and coal industries. This view was expressed here today by leading executives at the annual convention of the American Gas Association, fact-finding and service organization of the $12,500,000,000 industry.

Harold Riegelman charged last night that his chief rivals for the mayoralty were trying to divert public attention from "the real issues" by injecting "fictitious Mr. X's and Mr. Zeros" into the campaign.

Get out the rule books! This is the day Westmount High School of Montreal plays host to Proctor Academy of Andover, N. H., in the fifth annual football game between the schools. It is a day on which not one, but two rule books are necessary.
A fairly large amount of business was transacted in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Prices were mostly steady and fluctuated within a narrow range.
PARIS, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Francis Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, launched a building fund campaign today to provide United States Roman Catholics in Paris with a church of their own.

A five-story business building at 153 West Sixty-fourth Street has been purchased by an investing client of Walter Scott Co., brokers. The seller was the 153 West Sixty-fourth Street Realty Corporation, represented by Ellis F. Van Ryser, president.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public, which will mature within twelve months, amount to $80,288,908,010. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Preliminary conversations designed to lead to the projected political conference on Korea are being initiated precisely at the time of a major conflict and probable showdown on the issue of prisoner interrogation. While the two conflicts in the presentation of opposing points of view are not organically connected, they are part of the same general problem, and pose corresponding tests of any Communist intention to make a peace.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Ben Hogan, putting poorly and playing what he termed "miserable golf," shot a 72 today in his round against the linksmen of Great Britain.
BERLIN, Oct. 25 -- The Supreme Restitution Court for Berlin, tribunal of final appeal for those seeking restoration of property lost through Nazi persecution, will officially begin work Wednesday.
October 24, 1953, will go down in the book as one football's unforgettable days.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 (AP) -The Los Angeles Rams fired a spectacular, long range, 21-point salute in the second quarter at the Chicago Bears today but had to break a deadlock in the final period to win the game, 38 to 24.

Two world premieres were played by the two-piano team of Arthur Whittemore and Jack Lowe at Saturday evening's PhilharmonicSymphony concert in Carnegie Hall. With Dimitri Mitropoulos on the podium, the Concerto for Two Pianos by Ernst Krenek and the Dance Variations by Morton Gould were unveiled.

One-man shows of work by both Europeans and Americans are featured in this busy week of exhibitions. Paintings and drawings by Morgan Russell, the American modernist, are being shown today at the Rose Fried Gallery. Knoedler's will show tomorrow temperas and water-colors by Andrew Wyeth, while Curt Valentin will exhibit bronzes, oils, drawings and lithographs by Marino Marini, the contemporary Italian.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 25 (UP) -- Coach Frank Leahy of Notre Dame, who collapsed between the halves of the Georgia Tech football game yesterday, was reported improving rapidly today. The university also said he might be able to assist in coaching the Irish against Navy next week-end.

This Christmas will be particularly merry for the toy industry, with cash registers jingling more cheerily than ever before. A record is in the making and it is likely that last year's mark will be passed by about 10 per cent.

A recent letter on this page called again for restrictive legislation regarding the unnecessary blowing of horns on city streets. This is a problem, like so many concerned with the traffic situation, that is ever with us, but a problem that can be reduced by the application of a little common sense.

" High Named Today," a play by David Zelog Goodman, has been scheduled for production on Broadway during the week of Feb. 22. Marjorie Symons and Gilbert Perlman will sponsor the presentation, a modern drama in three acts and seven scenes with a cast of nineteen players.

A husky, 17-year-old youth was held yesterday in $13,500 bail in Brooklyn Felony Court after Magistrate Charles Solomon had heard testimony of how the defendant and four others had been on a knife-wielding rampage Saturday night.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 25 -Spencer Tracy is being mentioned in connection with "The Bridges at Toko-ri," which the producing unit headed by William Perlberg and George Seaton will make for Paramount, but whether MetroGoldwyn-Mayer will be willing to lend the star for the assignment is a matter of conjecture.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles, gaining 366 yards passing, ran up the highest score ever registered against the Chicago Cardinals today to win, 56 to 17, before 22,064. It was the fifth straight league defeat for the Cards.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 25 -Five championships were awarded at the annual Saddle Tree Farms horse show today, and four junior riders qualified for finals at the national fixture in Madison Square Garden.
Representatives of forty-one United Nations delegations attended pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

Production of men's clothing is running well above the 1952 level. During the first eight months of the year factories were operated at 82 per cent of capacity compared with 67 per cent last year. All segments of the industry showed increases in output compared with the preceding year, according to the Clothing Manufacturers Association.

For forty-five minutes yesterday a 12-year-old boy threatened to jump from a perch atop a skylight on the roof of a five-story building in the Bronx. He was finally persuaded to come down by the Rev. John Steltz of St. Athanasius Roman Catholic Church.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 25 -Vice President Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan has chided the United States for lack of understanding of Indian policies in the "cold war." These policies have brought forth American accusations against this country ranging from neutralism to pro-communism.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 26 -- United Nations and Communist representatives met today at Panmunjom, Korea, to prepare for a high level political conference on Korean problems. The Communists promptly insisted that neutral representation at the peace conference should be made the first order of business of the Panmunjom talks.

The Concert Society of New York presented Elisabeth Schwarzkopf as the artist for its inaugural concert yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. This is the organization that is replacing the defunct New Friends of Music on the local scene, with a series of sixteen concerts at the familiar late afternoon hour.

The Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers observed yesterday that "modern Christians are trying to apply Christianity to the world's problems." He preached the sermon at the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street.

Voters in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn will be electing District Attorneys on Nov. 3. The importance of the office goes without saying. The zeal, the fairness, the fearlessness with which wrongdoing in either public or private life is pursued by the District Attorney greatly influence the character of the community.
The City Club of New York, in an analysis of the nine proposed amendments to the State Constitution, recommended to its members yesterday that they vote affirmatively on all but No. 9 on Nov. 3.

Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York declared yesterday that Acting Lieut. Gov. Arthur H. Wicks' explanation of his prison visits to Joseph S. Fay was a "brazen effrontery."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The Federal Civil Defense Administration, which has had a hard time getting funds out of Congress, will try harder than ever at the next session.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 25 -Vice President Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan has chided the United States for lack of understanding of Indian policies in the "cold war." These policies have brought forth American accusations against this country ranging from neutralism to pro-communism.

The Concert Society of New York presented Elisabeth Schwarzkopf as the artist for its inaugural concert yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. This is the organization that is replacing the defunct New Friends of Music on the local scene, with a series of sixteen concerts at the familiar late afternoon hour.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 26 -- United Nations and Communist representatives met today at Panmunjom, Korea, to prepare for a high level political conference on Korean problems. The Communists promptly insisted that neutral representation at the peace conference should be made the first order of business of the Panmunjom talks.
LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Striking drivers of London's gasoline and oil trucks voted at several meetings today to return to work tomorrow morning.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UP) -- The Army passed the buck today on the responsibility for promoting George Washington.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26 -- James A. Farley, former Democratic National Chairman, said today that he believed the Republicans probably would lose control of Congress next year.

Operations in the nation's steel plants fell off slightly last week after reaching the best level since mid-June, and were scheduled to ease a bit more this week. The industry operated at 95 per cent of theoretical capacity last week and turned out 2,142,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Republican leaders in New York are as bad as the Democratic bosses, Rudolph Halley charged last night in assailing the contention that the slate headed by Harold Riegelman is a "good government" ticket.
GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 26 -- Seventy teams participated in the last regularly scheduled tournament of the Long Island Professional Golf Association at the Fresh Meadow Country Club today.
TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 26 -- Iran has broken up the three Tudeh (Communist) party committees directing the party's finances, propaganda and training activities.

Rufus E. McGahen, a member of the Board of Water Supply since Aug. 16, 1936, has asked for retirement on Dec. 1. This paves the way for Mayor Impellitteri to fill the vacancy in the $15,000-a-year lifetime job before his own term expires on Dec. 31.

NEWARK, Oct. 26 -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, has charged Republican state and county officials with laxity in following up with prosecutions the disclosures of racketeering by the Senate Crime Investgating Committee he headed.
PRICHARD, Ala., Oct. 26 (AP) -- "Come out here quick and get this elephant out of my front yard," an excited voice shouted over the phone to the police early today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee heard testimony today that the American public poured almost $1,000,000,000 a year into juke boxes.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The policeman who solved the Greenlease kidnapping case and then resigned under inquiry fire, changed his mind tonight about appearing before a Federal grand jury investigating the case and said he would testify. His resignation has not yet been accepted.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Chuck Dressen hinted today that Oakland may be the site for a major league baseball club.

MOSCOW, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Soviet Union delivered a sharp note to Greece tonight protesting against the granting of military bases to United States armed forces. The note accused Greece of granting territory "for preparations for a new war."
A $4,350,000 issue of Seaboard Air Line Railroad's equipment trust certificates will be offered to the public today by a syndicate headed by Salomon Bros. Hutzler.

The Illinois Central Railroad last night received the Gold Oscar of Industry awarded by the magazine Financial World for the best annual report issued for 1952. It was presented to Wayne A. Johnston, president of the railroad, before 1,400 business leaders at the annual award dinner given by the magazine in the grand ballroom of the Statler Hotel here.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 26 -- Preliminary discussions of the Saar dispute were opened in Bonn today by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Andre Francois-Poncet, French High Commissioner.
Notre Dame's victory over Georgia Tech gained new support for the Fighting Irish, who tightened their grip on the No. 1 spot in the Associated Press' weekly football poll yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 - -A. Elwood North, under sentence of death in Florida for murder, won a Supreme Court hearing today because among other things the jury twice had received in secret "divine guidance" from a Baptist minister.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- Britain cautioned the United Nations today of a possible walkout by its delegation from its committee debate on the formation of the Central African Federation if an Indian move to debate it proved successful.

Fordham engages the University of Miami at the Polo Grounds Saturday and it is the hope of the Floridians that this game will lunch a football rivalry that will grow rich with tradition through the years. Jack Harding, the director of athletics at Miami, told the Football Writers Association weekly luncheon-meeting at Toots Shor's Restaurant yesterday that the aim was to build the series to the national prominence once enjoyed by Fordham and St. Mary's.

Plans have been advanced at recent tea and luncheon meetings for the annual tea dance and fashion show to be held for the benefit of the Judson Health Center on Nov. 18 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Paul H. Raymer heads the benefit committee, and among her aides is Mrs. George H. Pride.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- President Eisenhower entertained tonight at another in a series of dinners at the White House. The guest list:

BERLIN, Oct. 26 -- Friedrich von Paulus, former German Field Marshal General, who with the remnants of his Sixth Army surrendered at Stalingrad, has been released by the Soviet Union, according to an official report.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 (UP) -- Bing Crosby showed no sign of being drunk when his car crashed into another automobile, injuring three persons, the State Highway Patrol said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Supreme Court refused today to hear a suit brought by a common stockholders' protective committee to prevent the Arkansas Natural Gas Corporation from paying claims of class A stockholders on a basis alleged to discriminate against the holders of common stock.

By returning Zone A of Trieste to Italy, the Allies have bolstered their solemn pledge made in 1948, performing thus an act of international justice which will undoubtedly strengthen the unity of the Atlantic organization and preserve peace in that part of Europe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Val Peterson, Civil Defense Administrator, said today that his agency would need about $650,000,000 to carry out its mission over the next several years, but that its budget for the fiscal year 1955 "will not be out of line" with what was requested for this fiscal year.

George Kanter, who seconded Pierre Langlois, French middle-weight, in his fight with Garth Panter at Madison Square Garden last Friday night, was suspended indefinitely by the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday. The handler was penalized for remarks he made after Langlois had dropped a ten-round decision to Panter.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, attended his first rally of this year's municipal campaign last night. He called for the defeat of Representative Henry J. Latham, Republican candidate for President of the City Council, as a rebuke for his vote in the House to override former President Harry S. Truman's veto of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act.

PARIS, Oct. 26 -- The United States Legion of Merit was awarded today to a Frenchwoman, Capt. Valerie Andre, an army doctor and pilot, for her valiant services in Indo-China. The presentation was made by Harold E. Talbott, United States Secretary of the Air Force, at a ceremony at the French Air Ministry.

From Cleveland yesterday came a report that Coach Paul Brown of the undefeated Browns had charged the New York football Giants with deliberate negligence for not covering the Polo Grounds gridiron before Sunday's game. The Browns won the National League contest, 7 -- 0, in the rain and mud.

It's Westward Ho this week for the big show in intercollegiate football. Thither Pennsylvania and Navy are hieing, after working each other over for sixty minutes of as rugged play as the season has produced. Meanwhile Army betakes itself to New Orleans for a joust with Tulane on Saturday.
I have spent thirty years in the Near East and I have yet to read a more realistic appraisal of the Arab-Israel problem than that contained in Alfred M. Lilienthal's letter to you, published Oct. 21.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -James C. Hagerty, White House press secretary, said today there was "a good chance" that some form of Presidential news conference would go on television before the end of the year.

YONKERS, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Noble Dean, winner in only one of his twenty-six previous starts, won the $4,000 Mount Vernon Class A pace on the Grand Circuit tonight at Yonkers Raceway in 2:06 for the mile.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- Britain's national debt amounted to 26,051,213,252 ($72,943,397,105) last March 31, a rise of 160,762,379 during the fiscal year that ended on that date, the Government said in a White Paper today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 26 -- Yugoslav official sources called today for a conference on the Trieste dispute to be arranged with the utmost speed.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Tenedos scored a three-length victory over Indolence in the $4,000 Old Rosebud Purse, feature event as Churchill Downs opened its fall racing season today before a crowd of 8,000 Yardmaster was third.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Maurice Goldblatt, chairman of the board of the University of Chicago Cancer Research Foundation, today announced plans that would add $100,000 a year to contributions to the foundation's funds for cancer research.

Recently both Harold Riegelman and Rudolph Halley have been guilty of gross misstatements in regard to the operation of the Department of Housing and Buildings and of Mr. Wagner's activities as Commissioner of Housing and Buildings.

Geometric patterns, distinguished with clear sun-washed colorings, have been used by Earline and John Brice in a collection of designs for Cabin Craft rugs. The carpets are on view at Simon Manges Son, 575 Madison Avenue, where they may be ordered through decorators. After Jan. 1 they will be available in stores.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 26 -- While most of the other big studios are cutting down filling operations, Universal-International plans to continue pushing ahead at top speed during its new fiscal year, which starts next week.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 26 -- Copies of a seven-year plan designed to reduce Israel's foreign-currency deficit for consumer goods were circulated today by the Government.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Notre Dame is getting tremendous results from a new, mobile defensive alignment that was developed two weeks ago by accident.

TOKYO, Oct. 26 (Reuters) -- One of the biggest financial sensations since the war rocked Japan today when an investment association with 150,000 members announced it was suspending business because of a $1,500,000 deficit.

SENDAI, Japan, Oct. 26 (UP) -- Curt Simmons of the Phils pitched a five-hit shut-out as Ed Lopat's major league All-Stars defeated the Pacific League professional all stars by 3 -- 0 today before 30,000 fans.

DETROIT, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Mrs. Helen Winter, one of six Communists indicted under Smith Act charges of conspiring to advocate the violent overthrow of the Government, was denied a separate trial today. The trial of the six Communists begins tomorrow before Federal Judge Frank A. Picard.

LONDON, Oct. 26 (Reuters) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden today defended the sixteen-nation declaration of last August that said that if the Korean armistice were breached it would be impossible to confine hostilities to Korea.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Senator Mike Mansfield, Democrat of Montana, asserted today that the Communist-led Vietminh in Indo-China could be turned back if United States military aid was continued and appropriate recognition given to the national aspirations of the Indo-Chinese states.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Some 350 cattle men told Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture, today that they wanted "a raise in pay."

Counsel for Robert F. Wagner Jr. will go to Albany today to ask a Supreme Court Justice to hear his suit to force the State Parole Board to make public its record of those who interceded for Joseph S. Fay, imprisoned labor extortionist.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Protests against so-called attempts to "intimidate the pulpit" came today as Christians of various faiths gathered to examine America's moral position in a troubled world.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- Pakistan, acknowledging a "debt of gratitude" for past economic aid, appealed to the United States today to continue to play its role in this "noble activity."

The Republican party is faced with the choice of continuing the "easy money" policy or committing political suicide, Raymond Rogers, Professor of Banking, Graduate School of Business Administration, New York University, asserted yesterday.
The Suez Canal Company, operator of a 100-retie maritime "turnpike" in the Near East, is finding that more and more of its business is coming from America.
The General Foods Corporation achieved a new high in sales in the six months through September, and bettered its earnings.

MONTREAL, Oct. 26 (Canadian Press) -- The International Civil Aviation Organization will meet in emergency session tomorrow to discuss the United States' decision to withdraw June 30 from a weather report and air-sea rescue program in the North Atlantic.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- Dr. Charles W. Mayo said today that the Communist technique of producing "confessions" was intended to bring American prisoners "down to that animal level of response where resistance was associated with death, where yielding was associated with survival, and where survival on any terms seemed more important than the moral principles that distinguish men from beasts."
" HOW ya doin, kid?" said Steve Owen in greeting his pal, Lou Little. "Not as well as you are," said Lou with an answering grin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission and the Secretary of Defense said today that their agencies were releasing all the information they could without giving "aid and comfort" to the enemy.
The petticoat craze is reaching a new peak. In spite of the popularity of the sheath silhouette, bouffant petticoats are in great demand, while sheath styles are part of a basic lingerie wardrobe.
Elmer Davis, veteran commentator, announced last night that he had discontinued his news broadcasts over the American Broadcasting Company's radio network because of poor health.

When Theodore Roosevelt died in 1919 the sudden silence that fell upon the country made it seem to a learned professor at Yale as if a military band had stopped playing. It is a little difficult today to appreciate in retrospect the effect upon the country and the world of his "strenuous life" in and out of politics.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Oct. 26 -- The commission in charge of procedures on repatriation of prisoners of the Korean war failed to agree on how to disagree after more than two hour of wrangling today.

MONTREAL, Oct. 26 --Proctor Academy of Andover, N. H., today gained an 18-17 decision over Westmount High School of Montreal. The victors scored all of their points in the first half, which was played under American high school football rules.
The orphaned International Longshoremen's Association took over Madison Square Garden last night to show its muscles in public. Expelled a month ago by the American Federation...
Sunday's rain had a negligible effect on the city's water supply problems, but it did bring about the reopening of New Jersey's woodlands to hunters and campers.
The Twenty-four Preludes of Chopin's Op. 28 are not often heard as Jan Smeterlin played them at his Town Hall recital last evening.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Hasty House Farms' Pomace won the $15,000 added Laurel Sprint Handicap today, leading from the start of the six-furlong event.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Air Force held in abeyance today a planned statement regarding the case of Lieut. Milo J. Radulovich, a Reserve officer who has been judged a security risk because of the alleged Communist associations of his father and sister.

Last summer Brenda Lewis, Metropolitan Opera soprano, confessed to a chronicler of theatrical events that "Broadway is what I really bide my time for -- I love acting just as much as I do singing.'' A person of conviction, the singer recently called Shephard Traube to ask for a comedy part in his forthcoming musical comedy, "The Girl in Pink Tights."
The city's traditional welcome for Maj. Gen. William F. Dean yesterday turned into a tribute to the G. I.'s and junior officers who had served with him in Korea and in World War II.
Secretary of the Navy Robert B. Anderson argued last night for a defense strategy prepared for the employment of both traditional and atomic weapons.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Community Arts Cooperative of suburban Washington, which offers an unusual cultural opportunity for grade school children, has started its seventh year this month.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Arthur Ehlers, who was a 6-year-old boy playing in Baltimore streets when major league baseball left here, was hired today to be general manager of the Orioles, who will play in the American League next season.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Purdue students were still whooping it up today because their football team broke off Michigan State's victory string at twenty-eight with an upset 6-0 victory on Saturday.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 26 -- An overwhelming victory was claimed today by the Party of Revolutionary Institutions in state elections in Lower California North. On the basis of preliminary returns, it seemed likely that the party would be credited with no less than 80 per cent of the vote.

Moloney, Regan Schmitt, Inc., newspaper representatives, have leased the ninth floor in the twenty-eight-story office building under construction at 261 Madison Avenue, between East Thirty-eighth and Thirty-ninth Streets. The lease involves an aggregate rental of almost $1,000,000, according to the Hudhattan Corporation, broker in the transaction.
PARIS, Oct. 26 -- United States officials are busy allaying apprehensions caused in Europe by Washington reports of plans to reduce the number of United States troops stationed in Europe.

The shortage of fluid milk as the result of the strike by drivers and plant workers brings up the question of milk substitutes. These must be chosen for their high protein, calcium and riboflavin content. It is these properties that make fluid milk so essential in diets at all ages.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- The United States charged today that Soviet personnel supervised the North Korean center where Communist torture induced United States fliers to confess they had engaged in germ warfare.

The American National Theatre and Academy will be the beneficiary of a dinner dance and entertainment, known as the Gilbert and Sullivan Ball, in the main ballroom of the Plaza tonight. A feature of the entertainment will be the presentation of "Fantasia '53," based on a Gilbert and Sullivan theme, by a group of stage and screen stars.

It's been many a day since raincoats were strictly utilitarian. Today a raincoat must be fashionable and as right for wear on sunny days as gray ones. It has developed into that extra coat that every woman wants in her wardrobe.
The Kingdom of Denmark has set aside $10,500,000 more to be applied to the retirement and cancellation of bonds.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 27 --United Nations and Communist representatives met for the second time at Panmunjom, Korea, today in an effort to work out plans for a Korean peace con ference. The discussion today centered on whether the preliminary talks should consider what nations would take part in the peace meeting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Supreme Court dismissed today, on stipulation of the parties concerned, an application by the Chase National Bank of New York for a review of a lower court decision that held the bank liable under the Bankruptcy Act for sums repaid to it by the Associated Gas and Electric Company more than twenty years ago.

Children in summer camp exposed to polio should be kept there for treatment rather than be rushed back home, a noted polio authority told a large gathering of New York State physicians yesterday. The warning was given by Dr. Philip M. Stimson, Professor of Clinical Pediatrics at Cornell University Medical College, at the annual scientific assembly of the New York State Academy of General Practice at the Hotel Statler.
PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Judd Brumley of Greenville, Tenn., the defending champion, tied for the medal in today's qualifying for the North and South seniors golf championship.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- James C. Hagerty, White House Press Secretary, said tonight that the Government's new information order, which will be issued within two weeks, would be a "great step" toward a freer flow of news.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 26 (AP) -- The English team came through with three perfect rides tonight to clinch its second straight international jumping victory at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UP) -- Federal authorities are puzzled and concerned by a steady increase in the number of bank robberies in recent years, officials said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Treasury announced a heavy over-subscription for its offering of $1,500,000,000 of 91-day bills due on Jan. 28, 1954.
ST. LOUIS, Oct: 26 -- The strong regulatory arm of the Federal Government gave assurance today that the investing and consuming public would receive fair treatment in utility rate proceedings.

The third and final volume in Bruce Catton's history of the Army of the Potomac will be published Nov. 24 by Doubleday under the title "A Stillness at Appomattox." Following his "Mr. Lincoln's Army" and "Glory Road," Mr. Catton presents an account of the Civil War from the winter of 1864 to the truce at Appomattox.

Henry Ford 2d, calling for a liberalized foreign-trade policy, urged last night a direct Government subsidy to the "small group" of domestic producers who would be hardest hit by substantial tariff reductions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- The United Nations Security Council will take up two aspects of the Palestine question tomorrow. There were strong indications that the Western powers intended to take Israel to task on both counts for the new flare-up in Arab-Israeli relations.

Events today: Hector Zeoli, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, noon; Vera Lowy Ernst, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30 P. M.; "Madama Butterfly," City Center, 8:15; Herta Glaz, mezzo-soprano, Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., 8:40.
DETROIT, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The General Motors Corporation employed an average of 557,261 workers throughout the world during the first nine months of 1953. Payrolls were $2,009,000,000 for the period.

Quincy, Mass., awarded $1,555,000 of various purpose bonds due from 1954 to 1978 to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates at a bid of 100.109 for 2.2's. Reoffering was at yields ranging from 1.35 per cent to 2.4 per cent.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 26 -- A temporary state commission to study the problems of financing education was recommended here today by Frank C. Moore, former Lieutenant Governor of the state.

Age apparently hasn't much to do with making buildings obsolete in New York. Not if we can judge from the fate of the Center Theatre, which a mere twenty-one years after its construction as one of the city's more luxurious places of entertainment is about to be torn down to make way for something new.

The always individualistic British pedestrian has been more so during the past few days because a strike diminished the flow of motor vehicles. So reports this newspaper's correspondent Thomas F. Brady. This happened on the eve of a move by Transport Minister A. T. Lennox-Boyd for the stricter regulation of persons going about their lawful business on foot.

Joey Giardello of Philadelphia, a top-ranking middleweight, scored a unanimous decision over Walter Cartier of Greenwich Village in the ten-round feature bout at Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night.
GENEVA, Oct. 26 -- Expansion in East-West trade, which seemed to be in the cards for 1953, has so far failed to develop.

Four candidates for the Borough Presidency of Manhattan spoke yesterday at a luncheon of the Urban League in the Theresa Hotel, 125th Street and Seventh Avenue. They were Hulan E. Jack, Democratic nominee; Elmer A. Carter, Republican; the Rev. Dr. James H. Robinson, Liberal-Independent, and Andronicus Jacobs, American Labor party.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced allotment to the United States of a 209,558,085-bushel quota of wheat to export this year under the International Wheat Agreement.
MADRID, Oct. 26 -- A concordat between the Vatican and Spain was ratified today by the Spanish Parliament (Cortes).

In serving our service men, the United Service Organizations also makes a direct contribution to our nation. Witness: the American Consul General in Greece, John B. Holt. Testi mony: a letter to U. S. O.: "Again I should like to commend the excellent and important achievement of the U. S. O. in Salonika.

Sales of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company in the first nine months this year improved over those of a year ago, but earnings declined about 15 per cent as a result of increased labor and material costs, W. A. Roberts, president, explained in the report issued yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Treasury is going to borrow $2,000,000,000 more this week to meet current Federal expenses.
Today's new film is a British import, "Gilbert and Sullivan," which will open at 8:30 P. M. at the Bijou. Starting tomorrow, performances will be given on a two-a-day, reserved-seat basis.

The trials of two teachers, who are among fifteen members of the school system accused of insubordination for failure to answer questions concerning possible Communist party affiliation, were opened yesterday by the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- A regional public health authority in the Middle East could save "thousands of Israeli and Arab lives annually," Dr. Kalman J. Mann, director-general of the Hadassah Medical Organization, declared today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- The United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee recommended today that all necessary steps be taken to lead to full sovereignty and independence for the French protectorate of Tunisia.

Home town newspapers are one of the best vehicles for reaching the public with facts about the advantages of the American free enterprise system, says Everett D. Reese, president of the American Bankers Association.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 26 -- A seminary cannot afford a monastic existence, but must be a part of life, the Rev. Dr. M. Stephen James said today as he was installed as the fifth president of the New Brunswick Theological Seminary. The ceremony took place in a formal service in Kirkpatrick Chapel on the Rutgers University campus.
The mounting controversy between physicians and the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York was joined by another voice her last night.

The one-story taxpayer building at the northwest corner of 210th Street and Ninety-first Avenue, in Hollis, Queens, has been purchased by Joseph B. Rosenblatt and Rennold Wacht in a transaction negotiated by Hillyer Bell, Inc., as brokers.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, said last night that transit fares in the city would rise to 20 cents, and probably 25, if Robert F. Wagner Jr., his Democratic opponent, was elected Mayor.

The circumstances which have halted the flow of milk and milk products to twelve million persons in the metropolitan area are disquieting. A month ago five teamsters' locals and two hundred milk dealers began negotiating a new contract. There were ninety-eight union demands and some thirty employers' demands.
Differences in the housekeeping problems of the wage-earning woman and the full-time homemaker are greatly exaggerated, Charlotte Adams believes.
LONDON, Oct. 26 -- The demand for good equities helped to keep prices fairly firm on the stock market here today. But trading remained quiet.

In a broadcast on United Nations Day Dr. Radhakrishnan, the philosopher who is Vice President of India, has given a lucid exposition of the point of view on which his Government bases its policies in the conflict between the free world and communism. Dr. Radhakrishnan makes it plain that India stands firmly in the camp of democracy and has no taste for Communist regimentation and oppression.
Ways in which New Yorkers could weather the milk strike without risking impairment of their health were suggested yesterday by Dr. John F. Mahoney, Health Commissioner.

The greatest service and challenge of educational television is in the field of adult education, David D. Henry, vice chancellor of New York University, told 100 delegates yesterday in the New Yorker Hotel at the opening session of the third annual conference of the Adult Education Association of the United States.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Export-Import Bank announced today a credit of $60,000,000 to finance the purchase by Japan of United States cotton.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Supreme Court will review New York State's ban on the French motion picture, "La Ronde."

Twenty-one judicial posts are to be filled by the voters on Nov. 3, but in many cases there is no contest because of common party endorsement of judges seeking re-election after satisfactory service on the bench. As usual, we commend to our readers the advice of the various bar associations as the best guide to voting.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 22 -- The new Government of the Indian-occupied portion of Jammu and Kashmir State apparently has turned thumbs down on Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz as United Nations administrator of a plebiscite on the future of the state.

A so-called "caravan" of cattlemen, numbering approximately 350, converged upon Washington yesterday to demand an audience with the Secretary of Agriculture and present him with what amounts to a thinly veiled ultimatum for a policy of high, rigid price supports for cattle. Spokesmen for the group protest that "there are no politics involved" and Secretary Benson has taken them at their word.

Stewart P. Coleman, director of Standard Oil Company (N. J.), has been elected a trustee of the National Industrial Conference Board. He fills the vacancy created by the resignation of James S. Kemper, chairman of Lumbermen's Mutual Casualty Company, now United States Ambassador to Brazil.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 26 -- The fear of war continued to run high in this tense, divided city tonight.
There will be no upset victory in the contest for election as Manhattan Borough President, in the opinion of candidates for the office.

From the riches of material that have come down from the many-sided life of Theodore Roosevelt, the American Museum of Natural History has assembled an exhibit that tells a lively story of the family man, author, naturalist and political figure.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 26 -- Dr. Ward Darley, president of the Association of American Medical Colleges, said here today that developments in medical education and research since World War II were resulting in a renewed interest in preventive medicine. Out of this, he added, "is emerging the concept of the promotion and management of health."

The annual United Hospitals' drive for funds is under way, and volunteers are appealing for a total of $3,500,000 to help meet the expenses of eighty-one hospitals in the five boroughs of New York City. Last year these hospitals aided nearly 1,000,000 patients who could afford none or only part of the cost of medical care.
A Westchester grand jury investigation will be started today into the 1952 murder of John Acropolis, county labor leader, whose death has been linked to the struggle for Yonkers Raceway spoils.

VIENNA, Oct. 26 -- Occupied Austria's economic vitality is surprising -- possibly even to the Austrians themselves. Dire predictions had been made ever since the Habsburg Empire was broken up that the little Austrian rump state never could survive.

Members of the Episcopal Actors Guild have taken over the performance of "The Teahouse of the August Moon" on the night of Nov. 10 at the Martin Beck Theatre to raise funds for the organization. Mrs. Charles Manton Richter heads the benefit committee.

Joseph L. Ennis Co., real estate operators, have purchased the seven-story ten-family apartment house at 23 East Seventy-third Street from the F. G. Holding Corporation, of which D. R. J. Arnold is treasurer. Harold B. Silverman was the broker.

A total of 897 pints of blood was donated on Friday to the regional Red Cross program. Bloodmobiles collected 188 pints at St. John's University in Brooklyn; 144 at Public School 148, Thirty-second Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street, East Elmhurst, Queens, in a community donation, and 137 at Time, Inc., 9 Rockefeller Plaza.
The Cunard Line has ordered a third new passenger liner for its Canadian service, according to word received here yesterday from the line's home office in Liverpool, England.

An investigation of autopsies performed by the Queens assistant medical examiner, Dr. Jacob Werne, was ordered yesterday by the City Department of Investigation and the Queens District Attorney's office.

More than twenty-seven years of using a camera to document mayhem and murder for five New York County District Attorneys have convinced Charley Blue that commuting between his home at 319 Avenue C and Stamford Conn., should be a snap.

Most prices advanced yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Trading was light and sugar had its quietest day of the year. Wool, cocoa, coffee, sugar, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, copper, zinc, lead, tin and burlap were stronger.
WINNEPEG, Man., Oct. 26 -- Uncertainty as to future United States economic policy is causing anxiety and irritation in Canada.

HAMBURG, Germany, Oct. 26 -- Max Brauer, the enterprising and popular burgomaster of the Free and Hanseatic City of Hamburg, who was once a United States citizen, seems to be in danger of losing his job in next Sunday's city elections.

OTTAWA, Oct. 26 (Canadian Press) -- The exchange of goods and services between Canada and other countries totaled more than $60,000,000,000 in the seven years from 1946 to 1952, the Bureau of Statistics reported today. Canada recorded a surplus of $340,000,000.

SOUTHBOROUGH, Mass., Oct. 26 -- There is a bit of a switch taking place at St. Mark's School these days. Benny Howarth, the varsity football coach, is ill in the school's infirmary. The gridiron squad, on the other hand, is in fine shape and emerged from last Saturday's Middlesex game without mishap.

LOON BAY, N. B., Oct. 26 -- A welcome rain is driving against the windows of this snug cabin, an occasional spatter hissing on the birch logs in the fireplace. But none of the assembled hunters has voiced any protest over the weather, for the rain promises to quiet down the woods and improve all of the many forms of shooting available here.

LINCOLN, R. I., Oct. 26 (AP) -- Tony DeSpirito made a personal triumph out of Lincoln Downs' opening program of the fall meeting today, riding five consecutive winners and finishing third in another race.

WALDEN, N. Y., Oct. 26 -- Maurice F. O'Brien, 56 years old, former chief of the Internal Revenue Bureau office in Troy, N. Y., who was convicted last Friday of conspiring to cheat the Government in income tax fraud cases, shot and killed himself here today, the police said.
The Inland Steel Company produced and shipped more steel and achieved larger dollar sales in the first nine months this year than in any previous comparable period.

On Oct. 5 THE TIMES carried a news item captioned "Twenty-Five Educators Seek Athletics as Studies." It was the report of a work conference held at Teachers College, Columbia University, by a group of twenty-five school principals last summer. The gist of the story was that this group, from the loftiest motives, urged that high school athletics be treated as an integral and effective part of the scholastic program rather than as an extracurricular activity.

CAIRO, Oct. 26 -- Eric A. Johnston said today that he saw "a significant source of encouragement in the fact that so far the door has been kept open" for discussion of the Jordan River development proposal.
The uneasy border between Israel and the Arab slates will again be the subject of debate before the United Nations today.
The city set a deadline of 4 P. M. today for settlement of the strike that has cut off milk deliveries to 12,000,000 persons in the metropolitan area.

Harry and Frieda Mohlberger have resold the four-story store and apartment building at 126 East Fifty-third Street, Brooklyn, to Isidore Kominsky Associates. The building, on a plot 120 by 100 feet at the corner of Clarkson Avenue, contains six stores and thirty-five apartments.
Although its tax bill was $14,282,442 for the first nine months this year, the Republic Aviation Corporation turned in a net profit of $6,105,199.
Americans drink more beer than any other beverage except milk -- not counting the present milk strike here.

The last concrete for the new ramp from the George Washington Bridge to the south lanes of the Henry Hudson Parkway will be poured today. Barring complications, the $1,300,000 project will be in service by mid-November.

Gen Mark W. Clark agrees with Sir Winston Churchill's conclusion in today's installment of his memoirs that the transfer of Allied forces from Italy to Southern France in World War II cost the free world a great opportunity to reach Vienna ahead of the Russians.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 26 -- Chief of Police James L. McNamara said today he had initiated police action to keep "From Here to Eternity," by James Jones, from the shelves and display windows of book and stationery stores.

A pair of occurences that followed one upon the other caused the 22,948 fans at Jamaica race track yesterday to buzz with wonderment and wishful thinking-out-loud all afternoon. The situations came about early, and placed in eclipse all the subsequent happenings on the program.

Staff members of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations questioned an important civilian section head in the Evans Signal Laboratory yesterday on his connections with a figure named as a member of the Alger Hiss spy ring.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- A clause banning racial discrimination will be put into contracts made by the nation's capital city starting Nov. 16.

Merger plans and extra or stock dividend announcements sent the stock market off to a good star yesterday. There were strong gains. By mid-afternoon, however, the move had lost momentum, A gradual but well-controlled retreat set in and THE NEW YORK TIMES combined average closed the day with a net loss of 0.70 point as 176.19.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, with actual months 9 points up to 3 points off.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Paced by soybeans and corn, grain futures moved up today, profit-taking sales being readily absorbed. Corn was bought on smaller-than-expected receipts and by a less bearish showing than indicated by stocks in all positions on Oct. 1.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- President Eisenhower set up a Cabinet committee today to seek means to preserve minerals mining facilities and to make sure that raw materials will be available for any contingency.

A neatly dressed, homburg-hatted man in his sixties was caught cheating an I. R. T. turnstile in Brooklyn yesterday morning. In his pockets a policeman found $1,197 and change, plus three bank books showing deposits in his name of $10,028.

A statement of policy, outlining Barnard's position on Congressional investigating committees and communism among the teaching or administrative staff, has been made public by Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of the college.

PENNSAUKEN, N. J., Oct. 26 -- Paul L. Troast, Republican candidate for Governor, declared here tonight that his Democratic opponent, Robert B. Meyner, had "long been particularly antagonistic" toward South Jersey, and that if he were elected the area would "truly become a forgotten land."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- Harold H. Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor of New York, said he was "assured" by the State Department today that full economic aid to Israel -- about $60,000,000 this year -- would be resumed as soon as the dispute over Jordan River waters was settled.

ATLANTA, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Development of the first simple method for detecting stomach cancer -- the use of a rotating brush inserted through the mouth to collect tissue cells from the stomach wall -- was reported today.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 27 -Directors of the Industrial Trust Company and the ProvidenceUnion National Bank approved a merger today. If voted by the stockholders, the consolidated institution would become the second largest bank in New England.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- The extension of the United Nations program for aid to Arab refugees until June 30, 1955, and expansion of its budget to cover continued care for 872,000 refugees were recommended today to the General Assembly.

The metropolitan area will have no milk today, but hope grew last night that the strike of 13,000 milk drivers and plant workers would end in time for normal deliveries tomorrow. A price increase of 1 1/2 cents a quart was expected to follow the wage agreement.

A proposal that championship regattas begin at noon instead of at 2 P. M. was brought before the delegates of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound last night at the organization's annual meeting in the New York Yacht Club.
GROTON, Conn., Oct. 27 -- The Tiburon, first of two attack-type submarines ordered by the Peruvian Government was launched here today.

The Greentree Stable's Tom Fool, handicap champion of the year, yesterday was retired from racing by his owners, John Hay Whitney and Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson. The son of Menow-Gaga closed a spectacular season by winning the Pimlico Special in record time last Saturday.

The Temporary State Commission on the Courts was urged yesterday to recommend a new courthouse for Brooklyn as part of the commission's program for reorganizing the state's century-old judicial system.
Governor Dewey, making his second campaign television appearance for Harold Riegelman, described Robert F. Wagner Jr. last night as a fraud.

The American returning from a round of Western Europe brings back a bagful of contradictory impressions. The free capitals of the Old World contain a very articulate population, never so argumentative as now. Not only are they talking more than usual, but they are talking at Americans, chiefly with the idea of having their own point of view taken into account.

PARIS, Wednesday, Oct. 28 -After a debate that dragged dully throughout the night the National Assembly adopted at 6:15 o'clock this morning a resolution asking the Government to "define and apply" in Indo-China approximately the policy it has defined and applied for the last six months.
The Department of Agriculture has a new pamphlet for householders, "Poultry: Buying Guide for Consumers," that gives a helpful basis of comparison between the cost of dressed and eviscerated birds.
Record sales were rung up by two leading television and radio manufacturers in the first nine months this year, and were reflected in substantially improved earnings.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 27 -Israel's blueprint for harnessing her resources was made public today as Eric Johnston, President Eisenhower's special representative, arrived here to confer with government leaders on a regional Jordan Valley development program drafted by the Tennessee Valley Authority.

YUKON 5-9940, a one-number telephone exchange, will be set up for one day this week to handle calls during the twenty-four-hour, six-station TV appeal for funds for the New York Chapter of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation, scheduled to begin before noon on Saturday.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- The British Government, like the Eisenhower Administration, is having trouble with the farmers.

Robert F. Wagner Jr. accused the Republican party last night of being "without a heart and without a conscience," because, he said, it had failed to set up a worthwhile program for the sick and needy.

TOKYO, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Faced with the loss of his world flyweight championship after eleven dull, clinch-ridden rounds, Yoshi Shirai of Japan rallied in the final four rounds tonight to win a unanimous decision over Terry Allen of England.

Directors of the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday halved the year-end stock dividend paid each year since 1935. Instead of ordering the usual 5 per cent stock distribution, the board declared a 2 1/2 per cent dividend payable on Jan. 28, to holders of record of Jan. 4.

HAMBURG, Germany, Oct. 27 -Max Brauer, the Socialist Mayor of Hamburg, was an angry man this morning. Already at 9:15 o'clock he was in a fighting mood, although he was in his party clothes, all dressed up in striped pants to receive a visiting French general.
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday unchanged to 10 points up, with the near months showing relatively more strength than the distant.

Jacob Blaustein, president of the American Jewish Committee, said yesterday in a statement on tensions in the Middle East that his organization was gratified "that the United Nations has at last undertaken to deal with the entire Middle East situation."

Herta Glaz, mezzo-soprano, sang a recital last night at the Theresa L. Kaufmann Auditorium of the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A. The event was the first of three song programs at the Kaufmann Auditorium in which Miss Glaz will take part.

Continuing our discussion of candidates for judicial office, with bar association recommendations submitted as the best guidance to voters on Nov. 3, we deal today with the Municipal Courts. In each of the following districts there is one place to be filled.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 27 -- The preliminary training of doctors soon will undergo change and innovation. This was forecast today when the Association of American Medical Colleges, at its sixty-fourth annual meeting here, approved the findings reached in a two-and-one-half-year study of premedical education in 115 of the country's colleges and universities.

Events tonight: Puccini's "Madame Butterfly," members of the Fujiwara Opera an the New York City Opera, City Center, 8:15 o'clock; Czechoslovak benefit concert, members of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, Rafael Kubelik, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Wanda Krasoff, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30.

DETROIT, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Five of six officials of the American Federation of Labor Teamsters Union charged with extortion and conspiracy were bound over for trial by Recorders Judge Martha W. Griffiths today. Charges against Anthony J. Liuzzo, a union business agent, were dismissed on recommendation of the assistant prosecutor.

A marked improvement in service on the Times Square I. R. T. shuttle during rush hours has been achieved by the Transit Authority, which found that train crews had been skipping some of their scheduled runs.
Prices of stocks lost ground again yesterday. But most of the selling occurred early in the session.
OSWEGO, Ill., Oct. 27 (AP) -- The King and Queen will pay a visit to a northern Illinois farm couple and they are "honored and delighted." It cannot interfere with their busy work schedule, however.
Proponents of Fair Trade were urged yesterday to undertake a more intensive program of public education on its value as a basic economic and social function.

MONTICELLO, N. Y. Oct. 27 -Supporters of Robert F. Wagner Jr., went into Supreme Court here today in an effort to force the State Parole Board to make public a list of the names of persons who recommended parole for Joseph S. Fay, labor extortionist.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 27 -- A former Internal Revenue Bureau employe won his plea today to have a grand jury's reprimand deleted from the record of Federal District Court here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of California, said today he expected Republican Congressional leaders to sit in with President Eisenhower and Cabinet members for final decisions on the Administration's new legislative program.
CARSON CITY, Nev., Oct. 27 -- The Federal Bureau of Indian Affairs has "no intention of simply walking out on the Indians of any particular area and dumping our problems in the laps of the states."

EASTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 27 -- Dale Lash, coach of Williston Academy's football squad, is the envy of rival tutors this season. Apart from the fact that his team is still unbeaten, he has two top flight quarterbacks, a situation rare in prep school circles.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Harold E. Stassen flew to Paris today prepared to reassure Europe that the economy of the United States is sound and that the Eisenhower Administration is willing to enter long-range planning for Western Europe's economic future.

Trading on the New York commodity exchanges was moderate yesterday. But wool volume was the best in some time and rubber had the highest turnover since Oct. 7. Changes in prices were irregular, with wool, coffee, sugar, lead and tin higher; rubber, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, zinc, burlap and hides lower, and cocoa, potatoes and copper mixed.

The Appellate Division dismissed by a three-to-two vote yesterday an action by twenty members of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, who challenged the legality of by-laws adopted by the society in 1900 and 1907.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Charles Luckman, former soap company executive who served briefly as Food Conservation Administrator under President Truman, will help design the United States' new air bases in Spain, it was disclosed today.

The Brandon Residence for Business Women was dedicated yesterday by the Volunteers of America as its first boarding establishment for women in New York. The nine-story residence is at 340 West Eighty-fifth Street.

YONKERS, Oct. 27 (AP) -- April First and Ernest Duke finished in a dead heart for first place in the $4,000 Westport Pace tonight on the Grand Circuit card at Yonkers Raceway with a 2:05 3-5 clocking.

" The Head and Heart of Thomas Jefferson," a new work by John Dos Passos, scheduled originally for Nov. 20 publication, has been postponed by Doubleday to Jan. 21. The book traces Jefferson's intellectual and personality developments and presents portraits of the men who most influenced those traits -- his father, the Scotch intellectual, Dr. Small, and John Adams.
Whoever is elected Mayor next Tuesday is likely to find that redemption of campaign promises of the last few months will involve financial and political wizardry of the highest order.

TRENTON, Oct. 27 -- The ranks of the Democratic party in New Jersey were breached today for the second time in a week when Elmer H. Wene, who lost to Robert B. Meyner in the primary, announced that he would not support Mr. Meyner for Governor.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 28 -The Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission handling the problem of the Korean war prisoners reported today that it had evidence of three murders, possibly four, of North Korean and Chinese prisoners inside the neutral stockades.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 27 (AP) -The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the world's fourth largest steel producer, re, ported today a net income of $25,170,000 for the first nine months of 1953, equal to $3.88 a share. The. company earned $5,411,000, or 70 cents a share, in the first nine months last year.
The Health Department ordered a Brooklyn market yesterday to stop giving away milk its owners had brought into the city to help children during the milk strike.

Seven leading oil companies issued yesterday their reports for the first nine months of this year and all except one showed an improvement over the similar period last year. Some of the companies had earnings at a peak level for that period.

A reconstructed Bronx bridge, designed to eliminate a "bottleneck," eliminated $2,167,000 from the city treasury but not the "bottleneck" as city officials yesterday opened the Eastern Boulevard Bridge that carries Bruckner Boulevard over the Bronx River.

THEODORE H. WHITE, a foreign correspondent still on the sunny side of 40, has performed an extraordinary feat in his new book, "Fire in the Ashes."* He has written a book of topical journalism about the political and economic plight of modern Europe that is not entirely pessimistic. Mr. White believes that the world crisis may not be as critical as it looks.

Four three-story buildings containing a store and twenty apartments at 39 and 41 Bank Street and 303 and 305 West Fourth Street, the northeast corner, have been sold by the Tranquility Gate Corporation of Ridgefield, Conn., to Thomas M. Graham for investment.
