It was written at the bottom of a grocery list and was discarded near the telephone. Just below the routine "doz eggs" and "loaf brd," it said, "I want a day of my own. One day with no children yelling, no bill collectors, no broken windows, no problems.

The commissioners of the State Insurance Fund dealing with workmen's compensation refused yesterday to disclose the business records of Lawrence E. Gerosa, Democratic candidate for Controller, unless he gave his unqualified consent.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- Maj. Gen. Vagn Bennike, the United Nations' chief truce supervisor in Palestine, told the Security Council today that tension between Israel and Jordan had increased to the "breaking point."

King Paul and Queen Frederika of Greece, due to arrive here this morning aboard the liner United States, will be welcomed for what they are: friendly persons delegated to speak for the Greek people. The throne in Greece exists by virtue of a popular vote, cast when the only choice lay between communism and a monarchy.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 27 (AP) -Striking Arab workers at the giant Arabian American Oil Company installations at Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, have ignored a week-old decree by that country's Premier and Crown Prince to return to work or be dismissed, reliable sources said here today.

The Boeing Airplane Company lifted earnings in the nine months this year to $13,576,164 from $10,167,366 a year ago. Shareholders will benefit with a $2.50 dividend declared yesterday for payment Nov. 28.

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Wilwyn, Britain's crack 5- year-old thoroughbred, won the mile-and-a-quarter Limekiln Handicap Stakes today -- his last race in England before being flown to the United States on Sunday.

The New York City Opera repeated last night the experiment it tried last fall. It presented Puccini's "Madame Butterfly" with members of the Fujiwara Opera Company singing the leading Japanese roles. Again the foreign visitors brought their own costumes and properties and their own crisp, formal, fluttery manner of performing.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 27 -- Mayor John V. Kenny charged today that Eugene Mori of Vineland, N. J., acted as agent for former state Democratic boss Frank Hague of this city when Mr. Mori sold sixty-five acres of Secaucus meadow land to the New Jersey Turnpike Authority last year for $375,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 27 -- Box-office receipts and public response to the Cinema Scope process introduced by "The Robe" provide real proof of reawakened interest in motion picture entertainment, Charles P. Skouras, president of National Theatres, Inc., declared today in urging the industry to give fun support to the making of more high quality films in the new process.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The plans of Representative Harold H. Velde, Republican of Illinois, involve marriage and not a race for the United States Senate.
SINGAPORE, Oct. 27 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon listened to a Red guerrilla today a few hours after the latter had surrendered.
HAVANA, Oct. 23 -- The good Havana cigar won't be quite so good this year.

James Leo Herlihy's "Moon in Capricorn" is an odd and interesting drama well suited to the Theatre de Lys, where it opened last evening. Since some little atrocities have trod the boards in the show asylum of Christopher Street, that may seem like fainter praise than this department intends to give it.
Although taxes far exceeded earnings of the Commercial Credit Company in the first nine months this year, consolidated net income rose to $17,529,853 from $14,462,573 in the 1952 period.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Riding side by side, Ireland's Capt. Colin O'Shea and Capt. Michael Tubridy tonight turned in the best performance in a paired jumping event to crack England's string of three straight international victories at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

MADRID, Oct. 27 -- The Falange party adopted today resolutions to reconcile its ultra-nationalist and totalitarian program inspired by Fascist doctrine with Generalissimo Francisco Franco's policy of international collaboration with the democratic parties.

LOON BAY, N. B., Oct. 27 -A pall of mystery, as dark as the clouds that decanted rain on the hunters in this area today, hovers over Loon Bay Lodge tonight. Although at least a dozen shots echoed from these hills, no deer hang from the racks, and not a hunter admits touching a trigger.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 27 -- An urgent plea for improved state regulation of public utility services was made today by the head of the National Association of Railroad and Utilities Commissioners.

VIENNA, Oct. 27 (UP) -- Frank Rohrbacher Jr., 27 years old, a New Yorker freed from eight years' captivity behind the Iron Curtain, has applied for permission to join his parents in Stamford, Conn., it was reported today.

If you get hurt in an accident here in New York City you will have to wait longer to get your case tried than anywhere else in the country. This is the unpleasant finding of the Institute of Judicial Administration. Its nationwide study shows that the greatest delay in jury trials is in the New York Supreme Court.

If there has been some confusion in a number of different statements about Japan's progress toward accepting a rearmament program it may well reflect some of the confusion in Japanese thinking for which there is good reason. We have made, in some eight years, a complete reversal of our own attitude and policy and have asked the Japanese to make a similar change.
The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations decided yesterday to seek to bring William Perl and David Greenglass here from their Federal penitentiary cells for questioning.

A dispute over what constitutes a "magic" recital may prevent the opening of Himberama" at Town Hall Saturday night. "Magic" is the designation that Richard Himber has given to the attraction, which he is producing and in which he is scheduled to appear with Henny Youngman.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, declined today to discuss when United States economic aid to Israel might be resumed.

MONTREAL, Oct. 27 -- The International Civil Aviation Organization's executive council met today in an emergency session to discuss the United States decision to withdraw from the weather and air-sea rescue program in the North Atlantic and then decided to defer the discussion.

Many sportsmen of New York State are unwittingly being persuaded by false propaganda that the proposed Amendment No. 9 to the State Constitution, to be voted upon in November, would be of benefit to them. I have long been active in conservation work, having served as president of the Jefferson County Fish and Game Protective Association in 1951 and 1952.

I have noted with interest your editorial of Oct. 23 entitled "The City Council." Your kudos for Stanley Isaacs is well deserved; however, I feel that there is one other area deserving of THE TIMES' notice.

Net earnings of the United States Steel Corporation for the three months ended Sept. 30 were the second highest of any third quarter in its history, topped only, in 1916. And the company's steel shipments for the first nine months this year set a new record.

The United States and its allies must raise their "economic ceilings" so that the free world will be able to have both more guns and more butter, Senator Alexander Wiley, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, declared last night.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- A new daily paper, The Recorder, the first addition to Britain's "national press" in twenty-three years, made its appearance here this morning. The first issue consisted of ten standard pages and sold at 2d (2 1/2 cents).

President Batista of Cuba has fulfilled his promise to lift the censorship and restore the major constitutional guarantees that he suspended for ninety days on July 26. On that day there was a sanguinary uprising in Santiago, at the eastern end of the island.

BECAUSE Native Dancer is the Glamor Boy of the American turf, the world's richest horse race will be held at Garden State Park, near Camden, on Saturday. Admittedly, that's circuitous reasoning, but it happens to be factually correct.

An appeal for the "greatest educational campaign of all time" to assure world peace was made yesterday by Hugh L. Keenleyside, director general of the United Nations Technical Assistance Administration.

TRENTON, Oct. 27 -- Robert B. Meyner, Democratic candidate for Governor pledged tonight that, if elected, his administration would dedicate itself to solving the 1951 murder of Willie Moretti, syndicate gambler, and to finding out "who got the money?"
The Estate Securities Company, operators, bought the four-story apartment house at 1015 Avenue N in Brooklyn from the Elgart estate through Sidney M. Seigel, broker.

DETROIT, Oct. 27 -- The trial of six Michigan Communists, charged with conspiracy to teach and advocate the overthrow of the Government by force and violence, opened here today before Federal Judge Frank A. Picard.

WHITE PLANS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -A Westchester grand jury voted today to end its one-day special inquiry into the death of John Acropolis, Westchester labor leader who was killed fourteen months ago when he tried to organize Yonkers Raceway employes.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 27 -- Yugoslav sources have made clear their idea of an agenda for the proposed conference on Trieste.

There was good news for Fordham's football team yesterday. Dr. Harold X. Connolly, team physician of the Rams, gave the green light for Coach Ed Danowski to use Vinnie Drake in Saturday's game against the University of Miami at the Polo Grounds.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Price movements on the stock markets here today were small and irregular. Some recent speculative favorites declined on neglect and several blue chip industrial issues were slightly lower. However, there were about as many small gains as losses and the undertone remained firm.

A house designed primarily for recreation is the contribution of the Long Island Home Builders Institute to the hospital expansion drive of the Long Island Industry Fund. Materials, equipment, services, furnishings, land and labor were all contributed free to make possible the construction of this model house, which will be open to the public tomorrow noon at Syosset, L. I. The enhance fee of 50 cents a person will go to the charity.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- It looks as if free checking service for carrying luggage of passengers on the nation's railroads is on the way out.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Sir Winston Churchill stressed today his desire and his availability for private conversations on the general international situation with President Eisenhower.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 27 -Rural life in this country needs more religion and more material security, the national convocation on the church in town and country heard at its opening session here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Cattle men from thirty states started back to their farms and ranches today after having failed to budge Ezra Taft Benson from his basic agricultural policy.
MANILA, Oct. 27 -- Prospects that the Nov. 10 Philippines Presidential election will not be characterized by frauds and violence have improved.

To the tale of death marches, massacres and wanton murder inflicted by the Communists on their helpless prisoners in Korea has been added another shocking account of human degradation. This is the report of Dr. Mayo to the United Nations on the torture of more than one hundred American fliers to extort "confessions" drafted according to prior specifications to back up the Communist hoax about American "germ warfare."
BOSTON, Oct. 27 -- Gov. Hugh Gregg of New Hampshire is preparing to announce his retirement from politics at the end of his present two-year term. He was elected in 1952.

Nathan Karp is the Mayoralty candidate of the Industrial Government party, which is the ballot designation of the Socialist Labor party. He is himself a clothing cutter and, in this campaign, in several appearances on radio and television, he has shown how a "mere workingman" can uphold with dignity, firmness and intelligence the political principles for which he stands.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (UP) -Harold E. Fellows, president of the National Association of Radio and Television Broadcasters, said today that dangerous new restraints had been placed on radio TV news coverage.

MME. WANDA LANDOWSKA, the harpsichordist, was the subject on Sunday afternoon of one of the N. B. C. network's televised conversations with elder leaders in various walks of life. The half-hour program afforded a rewarding insight into the career, philosophy and artistry of one of the more remarkable women of our times.
ROME, Oct. 27 -- Official circles here withheld comment on Mr. Dulles' statement on Trieste pending receipt of the text of what he said.
Managers of the Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways defended their harness track operations yesterday and said that they were cleansed of labor racketeering and free of all other scandals.

Introducing its newly decorated and enlarged bridal salon, Bergdorf Goodman presented a collection of ready-to-wear and custom-made bridal gowns yesterday. Designed by Miss Alice Kelly, the store's bridal consultant, the gowns more than lived up to the charm and fine taste employed in the new setting.

UNITED NATION, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- Following is the text of a report by Maj. Gen. Vagn Bennike of Denmark, Chief of Staff of the Truce Supervision Organization in Palestine, to the United Nations Security Council today:

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Count Cavour drove to victory in today's feature race at Garden State Park under hard urging by Jimmy Stout. The 19-5 shot was a half length in front of Maryland Line at the end of the mile and a sixteenth raced in 1:46 3/5 and it was another length back to Red Jeep.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 27 -- A prominent Protestant church leader called upon his fellow Christians today to resist "by every means" the expansion of Soviet totalitarianism.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Norman Thomas said today that President Eisenhower had assured him that it was not the policy of the Administration to exclude Socialists from the Civil Service.

On the record of spot promotions, the one-quart beer package is the way to greater volume and profits all along the manufacturing and distribution line. This was the opinion voiced by Walter C. Plummer, merchandising manager of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company, at the second session of the National Beer Wholesalers' Association at the Commodore Hotel yesterday.
Ted Kluszewski, first baseman of the Redlegs, and Gene Woodling, New York Yankees' outfielder, defensive standouts for the past few seasons, were up to their old tricks again in 1953.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- An international maritime conference is to be held in London to discuss methods of preventing the pollution of the sea and beaches with waste oil discharged from ships and the consequent death of countless numbers of sea birds and other forms of maritime life, including inshore fish.

" Gently Does It," a London importation seen over there as "Murder Mistaken," arrives at 8 o'clock this evening at the Playhouse. Written by Janet Green, a former actress, who will be making her Broadway bow as a playwright, the thriller will be presented by Edward Choate and George Ross, in association with Wauna Paul.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Oct. 27 -- Solomon Lasky, 40 years old, a World War II infantry veteran twice cited for bravery and now a civilian employe at Fort Monmouth, has been suspended in the security investigation at the military installation.

Notre Dame, which battered aside one of its season's toughest rivals while other leading powers faltered in a week-end of upsets, emerged the overwhelming favorite of the United Press board of coaches yesterday as the No. 1 college football team.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- South Africa's policy of apartheid (racial segregation) constitutes a grave danger to the peace of that continent, according to a report issued here today.
The armed forces' budget for the next fiscal year, starting July 1, 1954, will contain few surprises if present thinking in the Pentagon and the National Security Council continues
VIENNA, Oct. 27 -- Hungary has announced that her bread-grain problem has not been solved.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Hadassah condemned today methods by Congressional committees that "limit freedom of speech and expression, attempt to control thought and interfere with free exchange of opinion."

The Musicians Union rejected yesterday what the Metropolitan Opera Company described as its final offer. This led to the belief that the deadlocked negotiations between the orchestra and the management might cause the theatre to be without opera this season for the first time in fifty-five years.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 27 -Dr. O. Meredith Wilson, secretary of the Ford Fund for the Advancement of Education, was elected the ninth president of the University of Oregon today by the Oregon Board of Higher Education. The foundation has headquarters in New York.
John L. Bogert, naval architect, embarked enthusiastically on his ninety-sixth year yesterday by offering a plan to protect America's large cities from air attack.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky accused the United States today of working secretly for the breakdown of the task of examining prisoners of the Korean war who have refused repatriation.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 27 -- Under Secretary of Commerce Walter Williams said here today he could not "conceive how sound money can be a threat to continued prosperity."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 --President Eisenhower exhorted seven heroes of the Korean war today to lead in peace, too, so there would be no more medals of honor.

BERLIN, Oct. 27 -- None of the books "purged" earlier this year from the United States Information Service libraries in Germany has been restored to the shelves despite State Department assurances that certain removals were a mistake and had been annuled.
The Port of New York Authority borrowed $20,000,000 in the public market yesterday on the security of the new consolidated bond series introduced last December.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 27 -- The New York State School Boards Association was warned today against school "overbuilding" in trying to meet anticipated enrollments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- King Paul and Queen Frederika of Greece will arrive in New York tomorrow from Europe. They will start on what is described as the longest and most varied tour any royal couple ever has made in the United States.
" Maybe we're not going to win the title, but we're going to have a lot to say about which team will win it," Steve Owen, the coach of the New York Football Giants, said yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 27 -- The Westchester County Golf Association rang down the curtain today on its 1953 tournament season. Eighty teams took part in the closing professional-amateur event at the Metropolis Country Club despite the inclement weather.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood program received on Monday 772 pints of blood, including 258 at the Masonic Temple, 71 West Twenty-third Street.

ALBANY, Oct. 27 -- For the first time this year, the State Youth Commission is conducting a statewide campaign to divert into nondestructive channels the burst of youthful energy that annually emerges with the coming of Halloween.

Two new issues of public utility mortgage bonds and natural-gas company debentures totaling $55,000,000 will be placed on the market today, following their sale to investment banking syndicates at public sealed bidding. The offerings are as follows:
A crowd of 15,851 paid $51,265.50 to watch the first of five nontelevised wrestling programs at Madison Square Garden last night.
ROME, Oct. 27 -- After six months of negotiation, Italy and the Soviet Union signed a protocol in Rome today renewing the agreement that has regulated trade between the two countries since 1948.

All the treasures of Golconda could not have outdazzled the multitude of diamonds presented yesterday by thirteen of the nation's leading jewelers in a show called "Diamonds, U. S. A." at the Plaza Hotel.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 27 -- Here in the heart of the Democratic stronghold of Hudson County, Paul L. Troast, Republican candidate for Governor, defended tonight his acceptance of the support of City Commissioner Frank Hague Eggers.

Members of Auxiliary Number 5 of Stony Wold Sanatorium have arranged the annual entertainment known as the Tip Top Ball, to be held for the benefit of the institution Nov. 6 in the St. Regis Roof. Mrs. Robert Fisher is chairman and Mrs. Adrian Lambert vice chairman of the executive committee of the auxiliary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The United States Government has promised Britain that it will review the whole question of its attitude toward a Western Big Three meeting with Georgi M. Malenkov, Soviet Premier, but not before ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty has been disposed of.
Many children in the New York area fortunate enough to have the fast-disappearing fluid yesterday were told by their mothers: "Drink your milk now; I had to wait on line two hours to get it."

To help meet the ever-growing demand for paper, a $6,000,000 mill will be built in the east-central area of Brazil. This mill will make its pulp from eucalyptus wood, the first in that country to do so. There are only two other paper mills in Brazil, each of which makes its pulp primarily from pine.

OTTAWA, Oct. 27 -- Western Canadian farmers are intensely worried that the huge surpluses of wheat and other grains will knock the bottom out of prices when free trading begins on the British exchanges next December.
The Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation has attained the highest sales and earnings for any third quarter in its history.

We trust that reports of "tangible progress" in the milk strike negotiations are correct. With milk supplies virtually exhausted and the possibility of 400,000 quarts being dumped in the next twenty-four hours the controversy has reached a point where a settlement is mandatory.
PRINEVILLE, Ore., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Members of the Oregon Cattle Men's Association oppose the livestock price aids asked by the group in Washington, their secretary reported today.

Ignorance or prejudice concerning intricate foreign currency dealings by which a majority of countries transact trade will mean continued loss of business for American foreign traders, the Export Managers Club heard yesterday.
Van Wyck Brooks and Dr. William Beebe received last night The odore Roosevelt Medals for Distinguished Service at a dinner celebrating the ninety-fifth anniversary of the late President's birth.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Wednesday, Oct. 28 -- A heated discussion of the Soviet Union's neutrality in the Korean war and its possible participation in the Korean peace conference engaged the United States and Communist delegates today trying to arrange a full-dress political parley on Korean problems.

A letter to this newspaper which we published Saturday raises a legitimate protest against the irritating and unnecessary noise from buses in New York City. Every time a bus picks up speed after halting in traffic or at a bus stop there issues from the motor a loud screeching and whirring that in our opinion is one of the principal causes of New York's nerve-racking bedlam.

Your editorial on Oct. 19 correctly pointed out how desirable it was to pay our Governor an adequate compensation. However, Amendments 5 and 6, which purport to raise the salaries of the Governor and Lieutenant Governor, actually contain a serious flaw.

Two shops at which accessories for the home are available opened yesterday within a block of each other. Design Previews, 224 East Fifty-seventh Street, exhibits furniture, accessories and fabrics, while Gallery Urban, 234 East Fifty-eighth Street, displays paintings and reproductions of works of art.
In another sector of Greenwich Village, at the Provincetown Playhouse on Macdougal Street, a group called No Angels, Inc., presented "What's Up!" a musical, in its first performance last night.

These are the weeks when many suburbanites like to burn brush in their back yards, and the open hunting season and crisp autumn air lure more people into the woods.

There were indications yesterday that Red Barber may not return next year as the chief play-by-play radio and television announcer for the Brooklyn Dodgers, a job he has held since 1939. Piece goods prices are generally lower than they were a year ago, mills reported yesterday. Corduroy and cottons are quoted slightly below 1952 levels and rayon is off sharply, as much as 10 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today he thought there might be a five-power conference on Trieste before the United States-British decision to withdraw occupation troops was carried out.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and its subsidiaries made more money for their owners in the twelve months to Sept. 30 than in any twelvemonth period since 1933.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The Secretaries of State and Defense at separate news conferences denied today that there were any plans to reduce the number of United States combat troops assigned to Western European defense.
Brooklyn resident will vote in local contests next Tuesday for a Borough President, District Attorney, five judges, nine City Councilmen and an Assemblyman.

A. L. Burbank Co., Ltd., steamship owner, operator, agent and broker, celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary yesterday. An illustrated booklet outlined the history of the concern. A. L. Burbank is chairman.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, spoke with Koca Popovic, Yugoslav Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, for a half hour this morning as French officials continued their search for a formula that would allow holding an international conference on the subject of the disputed Free Territory of Trieste.

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 27 (UP) -Charlie Dressen found security in the game of baseball today as he signed a three-year contract as general manager and field manager of the Oakland Acorns of the Pacific Coast League with the added stipulation that he could stay as long as he wanted.

A three-judge statutory court reserved decision yesterday on the constitutionality of the provisions of the new waterfront reform law requiring longshoremen to register with the Bi-State Waterfront Commission.

The Grandma II, a twenty-six-foot houseboat captained by Robert Tabler of Brownsville, Tex., tied up yesterday morning at Twenty-third Street and the East River. She thus completed a 3,600-mile voyage from the Mexican border that began on June 1 and is said to be the longest outboard engine voyage on record.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, Oct. 27 -- Five prominent leftists arrested over the week-end were brought to Georgetown before daylight today. The action followed an indefinite detention order last night by Governor Sir Alfred Savage. Under emergency powers granted the Governor, he may suspend all ordinary court procedure.
The New York Rangers will be out to smash a long-standing jinx tonight when they engage the victory-hungry Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

If the new chief of the Appraisers Stores at 201 Varick Street takes his job as seriously as 74-year-old John H. Flynn, who will retire Friday as United States Appraiser of Merchandise in this district, he will have to be a hiker of outstanding ability.

RABAT, French Morocco, Oct. 27 -- The efforts of Pierre Voizard, new French Resident General in Tunisia, to resolve the tensions that baffled his predecessor, Jean de Hauteclocque, are being followed anxiously here and throughout French North Africa.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- Irregular price currents featured grain futures trading today. Corn was relatively strong, with December advancing to a new high for the movement, going through the previous resistance point of $1.50 with little opposition.
Rudolph Halley declared last night that Robert F. Wagner Jr., his Democratic opponent, was the hand-picked selection of Frank Costello, the gambler.
The Algam Corporation, which collects 60 per cent of the net profits at Yonkers Raceway -- but actually runs no races there -- made public its listed stockholders yesterday.

Revival of the New York City Parking Authority to provide more parking facilities was proposed last night by Robert F. Wagner Jr. as a way to reduce traffic congestion.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- A sixty-member United Nations committee adopted today a resolution calling on the Union of South Africa to set aside its racial segregation policy.

A four-week campaign to call public attention to the needs of the city's aging population and to recruit support for special programs for older persons was opened yesterday by the Community Service Society.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Herbert Brownell Jr. said today that a forthcoming Presidential order would provide for adequate safeguards for defense secrets without depriving the public of any essential information about the Government.
A new 235-horsepower V-8 engine is one of the chief mechanical advances in the 1954 line announced yesterday by the Chrysler division of the Chrysler Corporation.

The American Labor party cannot survive for very long if its candidate for Mayor receives less than 100,000 votes in the forthcoming election, Vito Marcantonio, the party's state committee chairman, said last night.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 28 -Leonard W. Hall, chairman of the Republican National Committee, called upon the party workers in New Jersey tonight to get out the "stay at home" vote next Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -Senator William Knowland, Republican of California, said he would oppose any "lump sum" appropriation for foreign aid in the next session of Congress.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The United States decided today to resume economic aid to Israel promptly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- A labor union official said today Gov. Arthur B. Langlie of Washington "is not representing the majority of the people of the state" in opposing the proposed Federal Hell's Canyon dam.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Thursday, Oct. 29 -- A neutral nations inspection team returned last night from fourteen days behind the Communist lines in North Korea. A reliable source said the inspectors found evidence the Communists were building up their military machine.
We here conclude our discussion of the candidates for judicial office on the Nov. 3 ballot, offering the bar associations' recommendations as the best guide for voting.

Members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union of New York City and Vicinity voted last night to authorize a strike against nine metropolitan newspapers if a new contract embodying their wage and other demands was not signed by Saturday.
HONG KONG, Oct. 28 (AP) -- One hundred and one Americans are still inside Communist China. Thirty-two of them are in prison.

The Olympic Games always have been international in character, so that disputes attached to them have echoed around the world. Perhaps that is why so much attention now is focused on the problems that face the program planned for 1956 in Melbourne, Australia.

BANGKOK, Thailand; Oct. 28 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon got an earful of troubles in Southeast Asia today as tempers flared between Thailand and Burma over air violations along the touchy frontier.

ELMIRA, N. Y., Oct. 28 (AP) -The New York State Grange passed a resolution today commending what it called the "fair principles in behalf of a new farm program" of the Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Eisenhower said today that unless there was a worsening of the drought, he saw no need to call a special session of Congress on farm problems.
BOSTON, Oct. 28 (UP) -- A bewildered "man without a country" has been detained eight months aboard a United States ship plying mostly along the Atlantic Coast.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, criticized John J. McCloy, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, today in a speech attacking the "bleeding hearts" who opposed his investigative methods.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Thursday, Oct. 29 -- The United States envoy, Arthur H. Dean, meeting with his Communist counterparts to arrange a Korean peace conference, promised today to exchange views on the question of what nations should attend the full-dress meetings if the Reds would agree first to a time and place for the major parley.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Manager Marty Marion, his baseball future uncertain, is awaiting an important phone call from a man he has not met, General Manager Arthur Ehlers of the Baltimore Orioles.

A new material made of vinyl, especially designed for outerwear use, was put on the market yesterday. It was described by its manufacturer as waterproof, strong and pliable and comfortable at low temperatures.
The Skelly Oil Company reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $22,600,100, or $3.93 each on the 5,746,117 common shares outstanding, for the first nine months of 1953.
Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were steady yesterday, advancing 5 to 10 points.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Interior Department announced today a reorganization of the Reclamation Bureau designed to shift responsibility for basic technical work to Denver and make it the bureau's main working center.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Oct. 28 -Iceland, smallest and poorest member of the Atlantic alliance, has two big problems: fish and Americans.
HAMBURG, Germany, Oct. 28 -Among German cities Hamburg is a sight to be seen.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission was asked today to rule that, in rate making, a natural gas trans-
Net earnings of the National Steel Corporation for the quarter ended Sept. 30 showed little change from the previous three months but were up sharply from the strike-affected third quarter last year.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Oct. 28 -- The Communist problem exists in other British Caribbean colonies as well as British Guiana, and Trinidad is showing some anxiety over the crisis in the neighboring colony.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- A manufacturing conference was told today that work sampling and other applications of mathematical laws can be used to take the gamble out of production, engineering and other management problems.
Improvement in the final hour sent the stock market list higher yesterday. But the late gains were not broad enough to enable the averages to show a net rise on the day.

Red Barber has resigned as chief radio and television commentator for the Brooklyn Dodgers to do a clubhouse telecast for the New York Yankees. He will be heard over WPIX before and after each game at Yankee Stadium next summer under the sponsorship of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.
Rudolph Halley charged last night that Robert F. Wagner Jr., his Democratic rival for Mayor, had accepted $15,000 in contributions from the Queens and Kings Democratic organizations.

LOON BAY, N. B., Oct. 28 -There is far more to hunting than the pulling of a trigger, for although we walked the woods from daybreak until dusk without raising the rifle, we count these hours to be among the most pleasant ever spent in the woods.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden called today for a solution of the Trieste problem within the next few months to pave the way for effective security arrangements for the West in southeastern Europe.
The Transport Workers Union charged yesterday that the schedules calling for a train every two minutes during rush hours on the Times Square shuttle were impossible to follow.
King Paul and Queen Frederika arrived here on the liner United States yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The House Un-American Activities Committee will move into Philadelphia in mid-November to investigate charges that Communists have infiltrated the teaching ranks of that city's public school system.

Alexander M. Turner, Pacific Coast division vice president and general factories manager, has been elected a vice president of Owens-Illinois Glass Company, Toledo, Ohio. Mr. Turner will be director of personnel administration, succeeding R. H. Mulford.

Thomas Jefferson Miley, executive vice president of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., has joined the Order of Irritated Recipients of Letters from City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses.

Those who take time to view the vivid maritime panorama that unfolds itself in our port every day will welcome a bright new addition to the scene that will cross the harbor bar this morning on her maiden voyage. The newcomer is the 23,000-ton Olympia, the first large passenger vessel built for Greek operators since the year 1915.

All boxes have been taken for the sixty-fifth National Horse Show, which will open on Tuesday at Madison Square Garden and will continue there through Nov. 10. Brig. Gen. Alfred G. Tuckerman is president of the National Horse Show Association.

Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, called yesterday for a continuation of Federal slum clearance and public housing funds. He asserted that the state's $735,000,000 fund for these purposes was not enough "to do the full job."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by conference rules:

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 28 (UP) -- Jupiter, with a well-paced ride by Sir Gordon Richards, came from behind in the stretch at Newmarket today to win the Cambridgeshire Stakes by three-quarters of a length.

AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 28 -- Jordan said today she was rapidly strengthening her armed forces because she was convinced another Israeli incursion of the type that occurred Oct. 14 against the Village of Kibya would inevitably lead to a full-scale conflict.

The letter of Bernice P. Rogers, a former Assistant Corporation Counsel of the City of New York under Tammany Hall auspices, which appeared in your issue of Oct. 27, in answer to Harold Riegelman's factual statement of Robert F. Wagner's conduct as Commissioner of the city's Department of Housing and Buildings, contains such inaccuracies as to require correction.
Amendment No. 9 is necessary to close up a clever and menacing breach achieved by the power interests in the defensive wall around the people's great Forest Preserve in the Adirondocks and Catskills.

Harold Riegelman declared yesterday that increased state aid for schools was not necessary and that if elected he would take the responsibility for finding the necessary money to develop an adequate school system.
A Supreme Court show-cause order calling upon the State Insurance Fund to make public its file on Lawrence E. Gerosa, Democratic candidate for Controller, was obtained yesterday by Rudolph Halley.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 28 -- "Green Mansions," the W. H. Hudson novel, is finally going to reach the screen under the auspices of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. The studio, which has owned for eight years the fantasy centering on Rima, the bird-girl who flies through the tree tops of the Venezuela jungles, plans to start filming in the spring.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 28 -- The Iranian Government is moving cautiously toward a resumption of diplomatic relations with Britain, but wants first to see progress toward a settlement of the dispute over nationalization of the British-owned oil concession.
The City of Philadelphia, Pa., borrowed $10,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance construction of public school buildings.
Elegant headgear, custom-designed by Laddie Northridge for holiday time, was presented yesterday at a luncheon in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre Hotel.

All four leading candidates for Mayor have informed the Citizens Union that they favor permanent personal registration and will try to get it for the city if elected. The next Legislature is expected to pass a bill, recommended by Governor Dewey, making permanent personal registration optional for New York and other cities in the state.

Election returns in the Bronx next week will mean much more than which candidate wins a local office. The vote may set in motion forces that can affect one of the most powerful Democratic organizations in the country and greatly influence the choice of Governor next year.

The heaviest rainfall in two months -- 1.93 inches here in twenty-three hours ending at 9 A. M. yesterday -- ended the long drought throughout the state. Governor Dewey as a result reopened the state's forest and open lands to hunters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Arthur Lourie, assistant director general of the Israeli Ministry for Foreign Affairs, stressed tonight that the United States Government's decision to resume aid to Israel still did not resolve such problems as permanent peace between his country and the Arab states and the economic future of Israel.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- Abba S. Eban, Israeli representative to the United Nations, today accused the four Arab neighbors of Israel of carrying on a concerted campaign "not to make peace with Israel, and not to let Israel live in peace."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The executive committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations has been thrown into turmoil by a subcommittee's published report dealing with the Packinghouse Workers Union, C. I. O.

Operating revenues of Middle South Utilities, Inc., and its subsidiaries, which form one of the nation's largest electric systems, reached $124,002,215 in the twelve months to Sept. 30. This was a gain of $7,925,450 over the previous twelve months when gross amounted to $116,076,765.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The King and Queen of Greece stepped off the Presidential plane, the Columbine, at 3:59 P. M. today after a flight from New York and a new pattern of official welcome to Washington was set. Cutting away from the past, in which Presidents and First Ladies
Industry and union negotiators told Mayor Impellitteri last night they were sure they could settle the four-day-old milk strike without city help, but they did not say when.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Helped by the publication of a number of good dividend and profit statements, the tone of the stock markets was cheerful today. Prices advanced modestly in nearly all sections.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 28 -- Four hundred and fifty Protestant leaders began work here today on a "message to the churches."
MADRID, Oct. 28 -- The Falange party made a strong bid today for wider powers and more direct participation in the Government of Spain.

One of Denmark's favorite sausages is now coming to the United States to lend its well-seasoned meatiness to cold-weather menus. Medister, as it is called, was introduced to food writers this week at a luncheon given at the Copenhagen Restaurant by A. Hempel Trading, Inc.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 28 -- The Tennessee Production Company announced here today that it has purchased the oil and gas properties of the recently-liquidated Reno Oil Company, a 45-year-old West Virginia oil producer with major holdings in North and West Texas.

The Federal Maritime Board inquiry into the proposed dual rate system of the Japan-Atlantic and Gulf Freight Conferences, now in its fourth week, continued yesterday before board examiner Robert C. Furness. The hearing is being held in the board's offices at 45 Broadway.
BUNNELL, Fla., Oct. 28 (AP) -- A New York oil executive died today when a small private plane crashed and burned in woods four miles west of here.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 28 (AP) -The Navy coach Eddie Erdelatz, whose spotter said one of Penn's two No. 20's substituted illegally last Saturday, argued today that football's new replacement rule should be enforced by the officials.

Commodity prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume eased from the previous day's level as most markets were inactive. Coffee, cocoa, hides and rubber were lower, cottonseed oil, copper, potatoes and burlay ended higher and sugar, soybean oil, zinc, lead, tin and wool closed mixed.
Harry Gross' twelve-year book-making and conspiracy sentence was reduced yesterday to eight years.

A decline of 130,000 barrels occurred last week in the nation's gasoline stocks. The American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday that supplies of gasoline last Saturday amounted to 142,666,000 barrels, compared with 142,796,000 a week earlier and 120,767,000 a year ago.

Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, declared last night that the Republican state administration has taken the position that New York city either must shift for itself or submit to absolute dictation from Albany. The only thing the voters of the city can do about it, he said, is to elect as Mayor the Democratic candidate, Robert F. Wagner Jr.

Members of the "caravan" of 350 cattlemen which converged from thirty states on Washington were on their way back home yesterday, their individual moods ranging, one gathers, from disappointment to bitterness. They had moved on the capital to demand of Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson that the Government put price supports of 90 per cent of parity under cattle on the hoof.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- The refusal of most Asian and African countries to join in public denunciation of the Communist germ-warfare charges against the United States has kept Washington from introducing a resolution branding the accusations as lies.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 28 (UP) -- The Sands Hotel said today it had canceled its engagement of Larry Adler, the harmonica player, because of "public opinion" and a telegram sent to the American Legion post here by the chairman of the Legion's Anti-Subversive Commission in Illinois.

Is the New York Stock Exchange going "to get tough" with all companies whose stocks are listed on the Big Board when they don't fully comply with its listing regulations? That question was going the rounds in Wall Street yesterday as a result of the action of International Business Machines in halving its usual 5 per cent year-end stock dividend.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics Consumer Price Index for this city for September, released yesterday, shows a slight rise again for the fifth consecutive month.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28 -Yale's hopes of having Ed Molloy ready for Saturday's football game with Dartmouth in the Bowl have been abandoned and its top quarterback and passer has been virtually written off for the season.

Fordham was concerned with Miami's passing threat yesterday as Coach Ed Danowski sent his squad through a second straight day of contact work. The Rams will meet the Hurricanes Saturday afternoon in the Polo Grounds.

HARTFORD, Oct. 28 -- The Governors of Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island agreed today to support plans for a 260-mile expressway to link the New York metropolitan area with Provincetown, Cape Cod, in Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Eisenhower outlined today the tone and substance of what the United States proposed to tell the rest of the world about its progress and how it felt about things generally.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Eisenhower is beginning to retrace the steps of the 1952 campaign. He tried then to put policy above politics, but the political pressures forced him off his course, and it's happening again.
YONKERS, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Freddy Hawk, 7-year-old gelding pacer came up fast through the mud in the stretch to win the $4,500 Kitchawan Pace at the Grand Circuit meeting tonight at Yonkers Raceway.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns, only undefeated team in the National Football League, today lost their No. 1 standing as the pro loop's best offensive combination.

Forty-seven years ago young William H. Lee stood his first watch as quartermaster on the coastwise steamer Persia. Last night, as Capt. William H. Lee, assistant general manager of the United States Lines in charge of labor relations, he was honored by company officials at a surprise dinner marking his retirement.

Saturday night's scheduled presentation of Richard Himber's sleight-of-hand show "Himberama" at Town Hall has been canceled. Arrangements were quickly made yesterday by Mr. Himber to put on the attraction at Carnegie Hall Nov. 13.

The French National Assembly showed little enthusiasm in Tuesday's debate on Indo-China, but it did show plenty of common sense. The policy of hanging on, fighting it out and meanwhile training the Indo-Chinese to take over militarily and politically was reaffirmed.

Wanda Krasoff, a young pianist from San Francisco, played a recital last night in Town Hall. Her interpretations commanded respect for their general musicianship and efficiency. Miss Krasoff did not assemble a program that was allembracing; she evidently confined herself largely to certain pieces that she knows she can handle, and she did handle nearly all of them very well.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Oct. 28 -A new era of high-hat, swallowtail-coat diplomacy has come to this dismal, mud-filled town.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The detention of five Leftist political leaders in British Guiana without formal arrest was described as a regrettable necessity today in Parliament by Colonial Secretary Oliver Lyttelton.
Outlays for export advertising this year, including those made by foreign branches and subsidiaries of domestic concerns, will range up to $247,000,000.

Color "takes the floor" in a new collection of rugs by the Waite Carpet Company. Except for one pattern, the additions to the line are in fresh and unusual colors. They were selected by John Gerald and Miss Katharine Kinnane, decorators, who also design the patterns for this company.

HOLYOKE, Mass., Oct. 28 -- Opposition to United States diplomatic relations with the Vatican was expressed in a resolution adopted this afternoon by 450 delegates attending the 151st annual convention of the Massachusetts Baptist convention in the Second Baptist Church.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Eisenhower said today that, apart from his sore arm, recent medical tests were cheering to a man of his age.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Oct. 28 -- Earthmoving machinery and dredges in the Jordan River diversion canal near the Syrian border were halted this afternoon. The move was in compliance with Israel's undertaking yesterday to suspend work in the controversial hydroelectric project pending examination of the question by the United Nations Security Council.

Mayor Impellitteri's thwarted campaign for re-election resulted in a deficit of more than $8,000. This was shown yesterday in a listing by the Board of Elections of expenditures so far reported in the city campaign, but the figures are incomplete since candidates have until twenty days after the election to file complete reports.

Plans were furthered for the sixth annual Bachelor's Ball at a meeting of the committee held last night in the home of Miss Justine Montgomery at 140 East Sixtyfifth Street. The ball will be held on the night of Dec. 12 in the Terrace Room of the Plaza.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 28 -- Federal regulation of the natural gas industry was described today as having reached the point where new legislation was required to protect the fuel producer.

Public interest during the campaign here has centered on the nominees for Mayor, but the election of candidates for Controller and President of the City Council is almost of as much importance. The holder of each office has three votes on the Board of Estimate, the same as the Mayor.
Coal is extremely unlikely as a worth-while source of germanium, the rare metal that is used, a tiny speck at a time, to make transistors and electronic components come alive.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 (AP) -Jerry Ford, director of athletics at the University of Pennsylvania, said today Ivy League schools were considering setting up their own "formal" football league.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Army announced tonight that at least 6,113 United States servicemen had been murdered, tortured, starved or subjected to other forms of bestial treatment...

A veteran subway motorman was killed and another injured last night when a passenger train with only its crew aboard ran into the rear end of a work train. The accident occurred on the elevated tracks of the West End B. M. T. line on New Utrecht Avenue, Brooklyn.

Investment banking syndicates competed aggressively again yesterday for a major new issue of AA-rated public utility debt securities. They were encouraged by continuing firmness in the bond market and by the paucity of pending major offerings of high-grade corporate bonds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by President Eisenhower today outlining policy for United States overseas information activities, and of a letter from Theodore C. Streibert, United States Information Agency Director, on the organization and aims of the agency:
The City Planning Commission approved yesterday changes in the route of the Queens-Midtown Expressway estimated to effect a saving of $769,000.

At his press conference yesterday President Eisenhower expressed the opinion that a Big Four meeting of the heads of government would not advance the cause of peace until the Soviets show good faith and honesty of purpose, and do so in deeds, not words.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Buying support broadened on early setbacks in the grain list today, resulting in good recovery from the low spots. There was commission accumulation of both wheat and corn on the dips, and in soybeans profit-taking sales were absorbed on moderate declines.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 28 -- Robert B. Meyner, Democratic candidate for Governor, made a whirlwind tour of Hudson County today and promised, if elected, to see that the "remaining vestiges of the Hague dynasty crumble into dust."

The New York Shipping Association told the old International Longshoremen's Association yesterday that no new labor contract could be reached until an election had determined what union represented the waterfront workers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -Following is the text of a statement by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles or economic aid to Israel:

Forty-two young women, debutantes of this season, will be presented at the fifth annual Debutante Ball of the New York Junior League, to be held Nov. 25 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Frank Richards Ford is chairman of the executive committee for the fete.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 28 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's supposed plan for a "European" settlement of the Saar dispute was emphatically rejected today by the second and third largest parties in the West German Bundestag. One of these is a member of the Chancellor's government coalition.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct. 28 -- Immediately after his return by air to Saigon, Bao Dai, Vietnam's Chief of State, issued a message today urging the Vietnamese people to show moderation.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 28 -- Outmoded admission policies and the high cost of medical education are keeping many qualified students out of medical schools, the Association of American Medical Colleges was told here today.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 28 -- Rural churches of different denominations were urged today to learn to work together for the benefit of their communities.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- StewartWarner Corporation increased the quarterly dividend on its capital stock today and reported improved financial results for the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30 compared with a year ago.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation this year had the highest sales and earnings in its history for a nine-month period.
Milk dealers attempted again yesterday to bring the now precious fluid into the dried-up metropolitan area, but their efforts -- a drop in the bucket at best -- came to naught in many cases.

A conservationist's views on the over-consumption of natural resources will be published Nov. 17 by Ronald Press entitled "Resources and the American Dream." The author, Samuel H. Ordway, discusses the causes of over-consumption, its dangers and "what we can and should do" to correct the drain on our resources and avert "very real cultural and economic dangers."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 28 -- For the first time since the Trieste crisis was precipitated by the United States-British decision of Oct. 8, Government sources appeared optimistic that a Trieste solution would be achieved. This was reflected particularly in press and radio reports.
An ordinary-looking pair of doorknobs that had been in constant use for thirty years was "retired" yesterday to a museum as one of the milestones of American industry.
Harold Riegelman summarized last night six key pledges he had made in the campaign and promised that they would not be forgotten if he was elected.

Wait long enough in "Gently Does It," acted at The Playhouse last evening, and the hideous criminal is unmasked and sent to his doom. This is the thriller by Janet Green that was known in London as "Murder Mistaken" but has now come to New York to scare Americans.

DURING Clyde Lovellette's senior year at the University of Kansas, professional basketball coaches drooled with envy at the sight of him. He was quite a sight, too. At 6-foot-9 and 245 pounds he filled the eye -- along with a considerable segment of the court. Despite his size, however, he had the delicate, feathery touch in his shot-making of a seamstress threading a needle.

Individuals and groups here expressed appreciation yesterday of the United States Government's action in resuming economic aid to Israel following that country's offer to suspend work on the Jordan River hydroelectric project.

Emil Schwarzhaupt, retired distillery executive, left a net estate of $6,987,569, including $2,376,718 in charitable bequests, at his death here on March 30, 1950, according to an estate tax appraisal yesterday at the State Office Building.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -The Post Office Department said today it had let out 166 employes under President Eisenhower's security program, set up four months ago. In addition, ten other employes are under suspension pending further investigation for security.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28 -Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, told the national convention of postmasters today that the Eisenhower Administration's claim of a $1,000,000-aday cut in the Post Office's deficit could not be substantiated.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Consumer Price Index has risen slightly for the seventh straight month.

PANMUNJOM, Thursday, Oct. 29 -- Lieut. Gen. K. S. Thimayya of the Indian Army, chairman of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission said today he would make a "surprising" announcement tomorrow regarding the prisoner-ofwar situation.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 28 (AP) -- A 13-year-old girl stole the show from male amateur golfers today as Joani Bruni of Laredo, Tex., won the medal in the twenty-eighth national amateur championships.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Rocky Castellani smashed out a unanimous decision tonight over Mickey Laurent of France. Castellani weighed 158 pounds and Laurent 158 1/2.
In three separate ceremonies in Brooklyn yesterday ground was broken for a library and a health center and the cornerstone for a second library was unveiled.
A prediction made earlier this season by Manager-Coach Frank Boucher concerning his New York Rangers came true last night at Madison Square Garden.

VIENNA, Oct. 28 -- A young American who was forced to serve in the German Army and was imprisoned in Russia for five years and in Hungary for three because he had been born of ethnic German parents and educated in Hungary, told a strange story at a news conference here today.

A modified assembly-line technique, a quality-control system, and I. B. M. (International Business Machines Corporation) recordkeeping have enabled Peter Pan Foundations to produce more than 5,000,000 brassieres this year in its Newark factory.

Three companies took no action yesterday on common dividend payments normally ordered at this time. The omitters were the Georgia-Pacific Plywood Company, the Union Asbestos and Rubber Company and Alexander Smith, Inc.
NOVARA, Italy, Oct. 28 (AP) -The prosecution demanded today life imprisonment sentences for two Americans accused of murdering their commanding officer, Maj. William Holohan, in 1944.
Furniture stores all over the country are betting against any economic depression in the near future.
MOSCOW, Oct. 28 (Reuters) -Wilbur and Orville Wright were slow starters in the field of aviation, a Russian publication said today.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 28 -A decline in the efforts of "professional disparagers and enemies of the public school system" was reported today by Dr. Richard Barnes Kennan, executive secretary of the defense commission of the National Education Association.

Nassau County Judge Norman F. Lent denied yesterday under oath that he had been aware that William De Koning Sr., alleged labor racketeer, was one of eight partners with him in a business that made big profits on the fringe of harness racing.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The War Office announced today a reorganization of Britain's air defenses that is regarded as a preliminary step in long-range plans for integrating guided missiles into the country's anti-aircraft system.

BERLIN, Oct. 28 -- United States officials in Bonn and Berlin denied tonight having received instructions from Washington to restore to the shelves any of the books of forty-six authors that had twice been banned from American information service libraries in Germany.

DETROIT, Oct. 28 -- Recorders Judge Martha W. Griffiths today ordered seven men bound over for trial in the second reecnt court action here involving extortion and conspiracy charges against local officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L.

The Mayoralty campaign is now drawing to a close and in a few days the voters of New York will decide which of the candidates will be entrusted with the leadership of this city for the next four years. There are three principal aspirants to the office, and the welfare of New York as the world's greatest municipality depends to a large degree on the man chosen to fill this position of utmost responsibility.

An eminent pianist who had not appeared before the public for seven years suddenly found himself on the concert platform yesterday afternoon, and a music critic who had planned to spend a quiet afternoon at his desk found himself lecturing on Chopin.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 28 -- When Motsamai Mpho, a native African welfare worker, bought a copy of a booklet, "When Malan Goes," in a bookshop here, the police thought they saw a Red.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Government aid to communities in economic distress as a consequence of competitive imports was urged here today.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 28 -- The Argentine Government in another move designed to demonstrate its friendship for the United States is planning to lift its ban against American magazines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The President today at his press conference said that the decision of this Government to resume economic aid (grants) to the State of Israel, which for one month were suspended, resulted from Israel's acceptance of the approval by the Security Council of the United Nations of the findings of its supervisor of the truce in that area, Maj. Gen. Vagn Bennike of Denmark.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Eisenhower asserted today that no plan existed for a reduction of any United States combat forces anywhere.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson announced today that corn would not come under strict Federal controls in 1954. The grain is the raw material which is converted into meat, poultry and dairy products in the form of livestock feed.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 28 -- When Motsamai Mpho, a native African welfare worker, bought a copy of a booklet, "When Malan Goes," in a bookshop here, the police thought they saw a Red.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Government aid to communities in economic distress as a consequence of competitive imports was urged here today.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 28 -- The Argentine Government in another move designed to demonstrate its friendship for the United States is planning to lift its ban against American magazines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Earl O. Shreve of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was sworn in today as national director of the United States Savings Bonds Division of the Treasury Department. The oath of office was administered by Chief Justice of the United States Earl Warren.
A one-woman show was held yesterday in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 28 -The importance of bringing more knowledge of the working world to young people living in suburban communities was emphasized here last night during a special panel discussion by vocational guidance specialists. The panel pointed out that opportunities often were limited in suburban areas for first-hand observation of industries and businesses in actual operation.
Five packages containing $14,000 and a $100 Government bond tumbled onto a kitchen stove yesterday when a Consolidated Edison Company employe started to replace an old gas meter in a Bronx apartment.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -The Foreign Operations Administration today authorized a $20,000,000 purchase of flue-cured American tobacco by Great Britain.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 28 (UP) -The Pie King, Irish bred 2-year-old champion of the English turf, had an abbreviated spin from the starting gate today in preparation for his test at Garden State Park here Saturday in the Garden State Stakes, the world's richest race.
The General Motors Corporation, world's largest industrial enterprise, rolled up dollar sales in the first nine months of this year that surpassed the record for any full year in its history.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- The Trades Union Congress, the central organization of the British labor unions, told the Government today it was opposed to the removal of subsidies and price controls on meat.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 28 (AP) -- England's Pat Smythe on Prince Hal outrode Canada's Shirley Thomas on White Sable tonight in a special jump-off to capture the top individual international jumping trophy of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.
The Association for the Help of Retarded Children is seeking $1,000,000 to provide additional assistance to children of low mentality.

The Czech conductor Rafael Kubelik, who was heard here last March conducting the Chicago Symphony, made his second New York appearance last night at Carnegie Hall. The occasion was a concert presented by the Czechoslovak National Council of America to mark the thirty-fifth anniversary of T. G. Masaryk's founding of the Republic of Czechoslovakia.
OTTAWA, Oct. 28 (Canadian Press) -- Maritime Central Airways, one of the oldest aviation companies in Canada, criticized United States Air Force cargocarrying operations in Canada today.

The Czech conductor Rafael Kubelik, who was heard here last March conducting the Chicago Symphony, made his second New York appearance last night at Carnegie Hall. The occasion was a concert presented by the Czechoslovak National Council of America to mark the thirty-fifth anniversary of T. G. Masaryk's founding of the Republic of Czechoslovakia.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UP) -Life magazine has lent former President Truman one-eighth of the amount it will pay him for his private memoirs -- reported to be about $600,000.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Critics of the United States were told today that the Civil Aeronautics Administration in Washington was not blocking the purchase by United States air operators of Britain's Comet III jet airliner, which is now under construction.

SHAFTSBURY, Vt., Oct. 28 -An official history of Vermont, prepared under special commission from the State Board of Education, has been removed from the schools of this small farming community of 1,700 because it has been described as "subversive."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- President Eisenhower declared today he was seeking legislative agreement on a dynamic, forward-looking program that would give Republican candidates for Congress a great big bulge on their opponents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -President Eisenhower had high praise today for Governor Dewey of New York but said he had no personal knowledge of whether the Governor planned to seek a fourth term or might be available for a Federal position.

The North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations are making "satisfactory" progress in planning for coordinated use of NATO merchant fleets in the event of an international emergency, according to Federal shipping authorities who returned from London yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- The resolution voted by the National Assembly today by 315 to 251, according to a corrected count, showed there was no majority for upsetting the Government's policy in Indo-China, although there was almost universal criticism of it.

When Broadmeade Stable sold its yearlings at Belmont Park in May of 1952, Philip Godfrey paid $4,300 for a Rosemont-Swing Time filly. Godfrey named her O'Alison. Yesterday, at Jamaica, O'Alison hit a jackpot. She won $50,775 in the Demoiselle Stakes.
PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Dewitt Balch, Cincinnati, toppled a champion today in the North and South seniors' golf tournament.
Forty out-of-town music critics and orchestra managers gathered at the Lotos Club yesterday afternoon for the opening of the Music Critics Workshop Program.

Blazoning the virtues of shows for other producers has kept Bill Doll, a member of long standing in the ballyhoo fraternity, on his toes. The principles gained through close association with theatrical baubles doubtlessly are being utilized by him to the best advantage in behalf of "Sherlock Holmes," which is Mr. Doll's first independent effort in the managerial field. It starts at 8 o'clock tonight at the Century.

GREENVILLE, S. C., Oct. 29 (UP) -- Secretary of the Army Robert T. Stevens said tonight that recent disclosures of possible Communist espionage in the Army were "shocking" and promised no let-up in a campaign to uncover disloyal personnel.

It is always good for us to be reminded that the inhabitants of small countries are commonly as intelligent as those of big countries. This is true of the people of Iceland, although there are only about 150,000 of them, or somewhat fewer than the population of Yonkers; and although their land, six-sevenths of it too sterile for cultivation, is only about the size of the State of Virginia.

On first thought one wonders why more librarians do not follow the example of the Hertford, England, public library which has assembled, and put under glass like a prize exhibit, a collection of books tattered, torn, burned and stained.

The four-story apartment house on plot 25 by 145 feet at Remsen Street, Brooklyn, has been purchased by A. J. Schechter, real estate operator. The seller was represented by Irving L. Levitt, attorney.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 29 (UP) -- An investigator for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today that David Greenglass, convicted atom spy, "has some extremely important information on espionage in the radar field" and is willing to disclose it to the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

LONDON, Friday, Oct. 30 (UP) -- The United States alone has developed atomic power for submarines and naval launching of guided missiles, but ranks far behind the Soviet Union in over-all undersea strength, Jane's Fighting Ships reported today.

The North Star Woolen Mill Company has leased the eleventh floor in 417 Fifth Avenue for larger offices and showrooms. It now is at 100 Park Avenue and will move about Dec. 1. The lease is for five years and was negotiated by Cushman Wakefield, Inc.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) --- Producers continued to unload hogs at the fastest rate since January today, but buyers showed better ability to absorb numbers than in most recent sessions. Trading was active and 25 to 50 cents a hundred pounds higher. Cattle were uneven, ranging from as much as 50 cents higher on heifers to 25 lower on cows. Sheep were steady to 25 cents better.

NOVARA, Italy, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A defense lawyer said today that Aldo Icardi of Pittsburgh, on trial in absentia on a charge of engineering the wartime murder of his commanding officer, was "both a devil and a saint -- like every good spy."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- President Eisenhower let it be known today that he favored the election of every Republican over every Democrat for every office any place.

Merwin Hodel, a 205-pound fullback from Colorado, was added to the roster of the New York Football Giants yesterday. He will accompany the team to Chicago for its National League game with the Cardinals on Sunday. The Giants will leave for the contest from Grand Central Station at 5:30 P. M. today.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 29 -- Leading United States Jewish business men agreed here today to attempt to mobilize $75,000,000 in loans from American Jews for the consolidation of Israel's short term indebtedness.
An effort will be made soon by the National Association of Shirt, Pajama and Sportswear Manufacturers to increase the sale of men's pajamas.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Ben Hogan's fellow professionals voted by a landslide to name him the 1953 "professional golfer of the year," it was announced tonight.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Frank Leahy will entrust his unbeaten Notre Dame football team to a "3-D" coaching platoon against once-defeated Navy Saturday.
New York Stock Exchange commissions will rise an average of 18 per cent on Nov. 9. It will be the first change since November, 1947.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- A full investigation of Communist infiltration of the Navy Department during World War II was projected today by the Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives.

Rudolph Halley, Liberal-Independent candidate for Mayor, questioned last night the sincerity of Robert F. Wagner Jr. in campaigning for good government. The Democratic candidate is a friend of William J. McCormack, "commonly referred to as 'Mr. Big' on the waterfront," Mr. Halley said.
Although roasting is the usual way to cook a turkey, braising has many advantages with small turkeys.

George Araujo of Providence and Teddy (Red Top) Davis of Hartford will box ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The New England lightweight championship, held by Davis, will be at stake in the nationally televised contest.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Oct. 29 -- The Governor of Trinidad said today that the action of the British Government in suspending the Constitution of British Guiana had been an effective step toward blocking organized Communist penetration of the Caribbean colonies.

SHAFTSBURY, Vt., Oct. 29 -- Two members of the Shaftsbury School Board resigned today as this small Vermont community rebelled against the removal of an official history of Vermont because it was described as "possibly subversive."
CLEVELAND, Oct. 29 -- Something more than a "thumping" Sunday sermon is needed to arouse Protestant churchgoers to an awareness of pressing international problems.
Complete approval of the program of the Welfare and Health Council of New York City was expressed yesterday by nearly 800 delegates of the 355-member agencies of the council.

A new method of distributing lumber at wholesale under which Western mill owners may store their products temporarily until a satisfactory sales contract with Eastern markets is arranged has been worked out in Detroit.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The chief Congressional spokesman of the protective tariff forces predicted today that Congress would reject "any proposal which will admit a flood of imports."

A $10,000,000 expansion program was announced yesterday for Reichhold Chemicals, Inc. Henry H. Reichhold, chairman of the board, told of the plans for improving and enlarging production facilities in all twelve Reichhold plants in this country following the first directors' meeting in the company's new executive offices at White Plains, N. Y.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Britain and France today asked Maj. Gen. Vagn Bennike, Chief of the Truce Supervision Organization in Palestine, how the work of United Nations observers under him was organized and whether more should be provided.
DETROIT, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Frank Costello, the gambler, came out of prison today only to face the prospect of more Federal prosecution.

Despite increases in its defensive power, there are still no grounds for complacency about the strength of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the naval leader of the fourteen-nation alliance declared last night.

BERLIN, Oct. 29 -- The official East German radio said tonight that under a secret agreement between President Eisenhower and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, the building of a West German army would begin this winter whether or not France and Italy ratified the European Defense Community Treaty.
Because ships cannot hope to compete with aircraft on the basis of speed, the new luxury passenger liner now being planned by the French Line will not be built for "blue ribbon" ocean crossings.

Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens, the Board of Estimate's only Republican, is having a hard fight for re-election. At the same time, the Democrats face trouble in keeping at least two of their four Council seats in the borough -- the city's second largest in terms of registered voters and the most independent of all in voting habits.

" Iowa," one G. I. said. "has one thing you can't find anywhere else in the world -- my house.' ' "When I get back to Brooklyn," another said, "I'm never going any farther away than the end of the B. M. T. Line.
Israel's determined efforts to win economic independence was reaffirmed yesterday before a meeting of a new trade organization.
PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Foreign Minister Georges Bidault defended the European Defense Community Treaty today in a speech before the Council of the Republic, France's advisory second house.

Inclusion for the first time of the new Commodity Credit Corporation certificates in the loan totals was a major factor in raising business borrowings from banks here $52,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday.

Dark skies and a stiff northwest breeze failed to dampen New York Harbor's welcome to the sleek, white 23,000-ton passenger liner Olympia on her maiden appearance here yesterday as the flagship of the Greek Line.

Prof. William H. Kilpatrick, educator, and Prof. Selman A. Waksman, Nobel prize winner and discoverer of streptomycin, received the Justice Louis D. Brandeis gold medals of the Jewish Forum last night. The presentation was made at the McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, as part of the Jewish Forum Foundation's thirty-fifth anniversary observance.

HAVANA, Oct. 29 -- Terms of the contract under which the Cuban Government will pay $13,000,000 in cash to stockholders of United Railways of Havana as a purchase place for that property were made public here today. The final documents will be signed in mid-November, according to the Government commission in charge of purchase and reorganization of railways.

Stockholders of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) will receive an extra dividend of 75 cents a share along with the regular quarterly dividend of 75 cents on Dec. 11. Last year the extra dividend was only 50 cents a share. The current declarations will bring the year's dividend disbursements to $4.50 a share, or 25 cents more than was received by shareholders in 1952.
