Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan of New York Protestant Episcopal Diocese conducted a memorial service yesterday morning at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine) for Dr. James Miles Farrow, retired cathedral organist and choirmaster, who died last August in Baltimore.
A former United Nations employe pleaded possible self-incrimination yesterday in refusing to tell whether he had introduced an American to a Russian official for espionage purposes.
A vigorous defense of scholars who are nonconformists or entertain unorthodox views was made yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 7 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was the fourth week sales have been "minus."
Two thousand employes at sixty cafeterias in Manhattan and the Bronx went on strike yesterday for higher pay and other contract improvements.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 29 -- Churches should actively encourage young families in rural districts to buy farms instead of renting them, a commission on farm life recommended today at closing sessions of the National Convocation of the Church in Town and Country.

Many parties were given at the Belmont Futurity Ball dinner dance and entertainment last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club. The ballroom was transformed into a miniature of Belmont Park for the occasion. Racing silks of outstanding stables provided a colorful decor.
Rudolph Halley, Liberal party candidate for Mayor, had the stump pulled right out from under him yesterday, presumably through an oversight of eager campaign workers.
Fordham's football hopes rose, yesterday when Center Jim O'Brien reported for duty. He was pronounced fit for action against Miami tomorrow at the Polo Grounds.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, issued a "warning" yesterday that New York could become the crime capital of the world if either of his two principal adversaries should win next Tuesday's election.
Share earnings of the Southern California Edison Company this year will be the smallest for any year since 1948, according to W. C. Mullendore, president.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 29 -Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Speaker of the United States House of Representatives, delivered a few words of advice and encouragement today to the West German Bundestag.

The second Isaac Ray Award has been given to Dr. Gregory Zilboorg for his book "The Psychology of the Criminal Act and Punishment." Harcourt, Brace will publish it next spring. The award was established last year by the American Psychiatric Association.

A full-scale effort to curb drunken drivers here will be started by the police by Nov. 15. The chief weapon in the campaign will be the new state law that compels motorists to submit to chemical tests for intoxication or forfeit their legal right to drive.

MONTREAL, Oct. 29 (UP) -- Tom Johnson, a 25-year-old defenseman from Baldur, Man., played a dual role tonight and scored two goals as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 1, to gain a 4-point lead in the National Hockey League over the second-place Detroit Red Wings who were idle.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Prices of grain futures receded sharply from early tops today, profit-taking sales being too heavy for the reduced demand.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- It seemed probable tonight that Western Europe would take a new step toward freer trade. The British and French gave the lead by announcing decisions for some reduction of import quotas when the Council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation met here at the ministerial level.

The State Superintendent of Insurance publicly accused Thomas I. Parkinson of "nepotism" yesterday and said Mr. Parkinson soon would resign as chairman of the board of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

The United States Rubber Company's net sales reached a new record of $657,393,028 in the nine months ended with September, and earnings were expanded to the second highest for any such period in its history.
PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 29 (AP) -- The tournament "giant-killer" was eliminated from the North and South seniors golf championship today.
A new minimum wage order for the retail trade, giving more pay to 42,000 employes in stores throughout the state, was announced yesterday.

In your issue of Oct. 9 Alexander Kerensky undertook the difficult task of explaining to the American public the complex dispute which is taking place at present between a number of the Russian political emigres and the American Committee for Liberation from Bolshevism.

SOMERVILLE, N. J, Oct. 29 -- Paul L. Troast, Republican candidate for Governor, proposed tonight the creation of a revolving state fund to aid in the construction and modernization of schools. Without being specific as to the amount, he pledged a "substantial" increase in the amount of state aid to schools.

THE cycle now is complete. Twenty years ago the effervescent Chick Meehan, a little man with big ideas, was coaching football at Manhattan College. By nature, by disposition and by desire Chick was strictly big league. Being as ingenious as he was imaginative, Meehan was forever shooting for newspaper headlines. If the news wasn't there, he made it.
Joint announcements have been made by three Philadelphia investment houses regarding the dissolution of Biddle, Whelen Co. of that city at the end of this year.
Two new issues of public utility preferred and common stock priced at more than $9,200,000 will be offered to investors today. The offerings are:

Football attendance at major college games fell off a bit during the first half of the 1953 season, but the Ivy League, the Border Conference and two of the South's three major leagues showed increases.

The election of Dr. Wilson George Smillie as president of the New York Heart Association and the re-election of Carl Whitmore as chairman of its board of directors were announced yesterday. Mr. Whitmore is a former president of the New York Telephone Company and Dr. Smillie is Professor of Public Health and Preventive Medicine of Cornell University Medical College.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Hans E. Inslerman, brother of a man who testified before the Federal grand jury that indicted Alger Hiss in 1948, said today he had been suspended as a section chief at the Evans Radar Laboratory at near-by Fort Monmouth.

The straightforward statements of policy released by President Eisenhower on the Government's overseas information program will, we think, be generally approved. They set a sensible framework within which this important function is to be carried out by the reorganized United States Information Agency under the direction of its new chief, Theodore C. Streibert.

ANNIE APPLESEED, distaff counterpart of old Johnny Appleseed, operates from a quiet suite high in the Chrysler Tower. Chrysanthemum seed, from her supply go out all over the world -- to veterans' hospitals, to universities, city parks, garden clubs, housing projects and even to prisons when inmates ask for them.

MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 29--Lawrence W. McKeown, Nassan County Democratic chairman admitted today he had accepted a $1,000 campaign contribution from the indicted raceway labor leader, William C. DeKoning.
South Carolina borrowed $30,000,000 here yesterday on bonds secured by the unconditional taxing power of the state at a net interest cost of 2.04 per cent.
The first of a series of events celebrating the Wright Brothers' first halting flight in powered aircraft on Dec. 17, 1903, was held last night.
Fly-Lo, C. T. Chenery's bay gelding, won the outstanding race on the Empire-at-Jamaica card yesterday, an allowance event for 3-year-olds at six furlongs.

The Standard Oil Company of California had a record net profit of $140,217,394 in the first nine months this year. It is equal to $4.89 a share and compares with $130,364,015, or $4.55 a share, made in the 1952 period.

Disorderly conduct charges were dismissed yesterday against Shepard Traube, Broadway theatrical producer, who had been accused July 30 by a conductor for the Long Island Rail Road. Mr. Traube's attorney said his client would sue the railroad for false arrest.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Defense officials appear unable to decide what stand to take toward former United States prisoners of war who falsely confessed "war guilt" to their captors or succumbed to Communist indoctrination while in Korean prison camps.

Robert F. Wagner Jr. is the Tammany candidate for Mayor, a designation which he "gratefully" accepted. But he is also the candidate of Michael J. Quill, a labor leader so reckless that the Wagner-Quill connection and Mr. Wagner's labor promises seem to us to demand exploration in the public interest before Election Day.

Although the Near York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange will be closed on next Tuesday, which is Election Day, the Midwest Stock Exchange in Chicago will remain open. Ordinarily, when odd-lot orders are placed for stocks that have markets both in New York and Chicago, they are executed in Chicago at the prices shown on the New York ticker tapes.
Four days of slow retreat for stock market prices ended yesterday with an advance on a broad front.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation broke all its previous records for profits, production and steel shipments in the first nine months this year. And its September quarter earnings were at a new high peak for any third quarter.
The Columbia football squad leaves this morning by plane for its game tomorrow at Ithaca against a Cornell team that is in its best physical shape of the season.

LANSING, Mich., Oct. 29 -- A mobile kitchen concentrating in a thirty-three-foot van-type trailer seven perfectly equipped "work centers" was demonstrated yesterday to home economists and press representatives. It will be opened to the public today.

BOSTON, Oct. 29 -- The Right Rev. Norman B. Nash, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Massachusetts, asserted today that Senator William E. Jenner was "inconsistent" in his views on the attitude of Congressional investigating committees with respect to clergymen.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 29 -Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has raised its 1954 production program from eighteen to twenty features with the addition of "Digby," a novel by David Walker, and "The Gallery God," to be developed at the studio as an original screen play.

WALNUT RIDGE, Ark., Oct. 29 (AP) -- One of the New York Yankees' ace hurlers, Johnny Sain, today announced his retirement from baseball after eleven years in the majors. Sain, a winning hurler for the Yankees during the 1953 world series, said he would devote all his time to managing an automobile agency here.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 28 -- Rain caused a last-minute change in the plans of Army's football team today. After a curtailed drill, the squad of thirty-eight players left by bus for La Guardia Airport to board a New Orleans-bound plane.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- France, as a friend of all parties to the Trieste dispute is advising everyone to calm down, stop making speeches and cease trying to find a swift and final solution until tempers are cooled.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- France said today that the Soviet Union could prove its desire for peace by renouncing Communist germ - warfare charges against the United States.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Supreme Court Justice Isadore Bookstein ruled tonight that the State Parole Board could not be forced to make public a list of the persons who had recom mended parole for Joseph S. Fay, labor extortionist.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Paul G. Hoffman, board chairman of the Studebaker Corporation, said today there was no truth in rumors that Studebaker was planning a merger with any other automobile company. He acknowledged, however, that the corporation had been approached "many times" by advocates of such a merger of independents in the automobile industry.

Five scientists and two organizations distinguished for medical research and public health achievement were named yesterday as the 1953 winners of the annual Albert Lasker Awards of the American Public Health Association.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday numbered 804,413 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- During the week ended Oct. 28, member bank reserves decreased $233,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Negotiations for an end to the five-day-old milk strike collapsed at 2:05 A. M. today.

Loin lamb chops are selling at their lowest price since January, 1950, the Consumers Service Bureau of the City Department of Markets reported yesterday. The general price is 99 cents a pound, which is 11 cents less than last week and represents a cumulative reduction of 20 cents a pound within the last two weeks.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 29 (UP) -- Nick Shuk, one of Maryland's most popular jockeys, rewarded his backers with four winners on today's eight-race program at Laurel.

AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 29 -- Responsible officials here are openly urging the expulsion of the United States Point Four mission to Jordan following the resumption of United States aid to Israel and continued American support for Arab-Israeli cooperation in the development of the Jordan Valley.

Prior to the time your fine editorial "Milk and the Public" appeared there were disturbing questions in my mind on the retail price of milk, as related to the method of distribution in the New York area, to which I attempted to apply my experience in labor negotiating.
MADRID, Oct. 29 -- Generalissimo Francisco France announced today that the Falange party would continue to be the main organized political force of the Spanish regime.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, said today the Senate Judiciary Committee had received several protests against President Eisenhower's selection of Earl Warren to be Chief Justice of the United States.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- The Government's attempts to prosecute French Communist leaders for subversion received a severe setback today when the National Assembly Committee on Parliamentary Immunity rejected an official request to strip five Communist Deputies of their immunity.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- The United States decided tonight to put before the United Nations the full story of Communist atrocities in Korea.

Can the basic idea of a futures market -- the hedging of risks related to the buying and selling of commodity delivery contracts -- be used to broaden the market for United States Government securities?

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 30 -- The North Korean war prisoners in neutral custody have agreed to listen to the arguments of the Communist "persuaders" who will try to get the captives to return to their Communist homeland.
American women are turning to foreign-made sewing machines to achieve artistry in their embroidery, according to a distributor of the machines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The State Department said today it was possible that India, and perhaps others on the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission, might be asked to attend the Korean peace conference to answer

GENEVA, Oct. 29 -- European governments will continue a reorganized weather reporting service over the North Atlantic, Gustav Swoboda, Secretary General of the World Meteorological Organization, said today. The decision followed the withdrawal of the United States contribution to the chain of fixed ships now acting as weather stations in that ocean.

MANILA, Friday, Oct. 30 -President Elpidio Quirino reiterated his attacks on Opposition Nationalist-Democratic political leaders yesterday for allegedly wanting United States intervention in the Nov. 10 Philippines elections.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 29 (AP) -- England's Pat Smythe, last rider of the evening, came up with the only perfect performance tonight to win her fourth personal international jumping victory at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- King Paul of Greece thanked the American people today for their spiritual leadership against Communistic materialism.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Department of Agriculture appeared today to be ready to put into effect its reorganization plan for the Soil Conservation Service despite growing protests from farm leaders in various states and from members of Congress.

A VICTIM of the television industry's own peculiar concept of enlightened economics, "Author Meets the Critics" unexpectedly left the air Wednesday evening. If there are programs that deserve to be saved, this is one.

The nature of the forces unleashed in this twentieth century against our civilization has been shown again by the White Paper issued by the Army regarding Communist atrocities in Korea. This report of grisly horror and calculated bestiality, of savage torture and cold-blooded massacre, which the United States Government intends to put before the United Nations, comes with sickening impact. Of the 29,815 victims, there are at least 6,113 Americans.
The chairman of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy suggested yesterday the possibility of development by private industry of mobile atomic power plants.

The board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association announced yesterday afternoon that the Metropolitan would grant no salary increase for the coming season to members of its orchestra if the increase raises the musician's base pay more than 2 per cent.

Mickey Mantle, 21-year-old center fielder of the world champion New York Yankees, will undergo an operation on Monday for the removal of loose cartilage from his right knee. The operation will be performed by Dr. Daniel Yancey in Burge Hospital, Springfield, Mo.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 29 -- An eighteenth-century bakery, where bread and cakes will be mixed according to recipes of 200 years ago and baked in wood-fired brick ovens, will be opened to the public tomorrow at the Raleigh Tavern in this restored Colonial city.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 30 -- The Communists rejected today a United Nations proposal that the meeting on arrangements for a Korean peace conference discuss its time and place before taking up its composition. Ki Sok Bok, North-Korean delegate, said in the session at Panmunjom, Korea, that the suggestion put forth yesterday by Arthur H. Dean, the Allied delegate, was a "trick."
Shipowners on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts have informed seamen's unions that, effective tomorrow, they will stop paying war bonuses for voyages in many parts of the world.

The Radio Corporation of America reported yesterday that it had demonstrated at Camden, N. J., three methods for transmitting film on color television. The test was made for engineering consultants of stations and networks.

YONKERS, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Black Prince, driven by Jimmy Jordan, held off the stretch bid of Rebel Land, piloted by Dr. V. C. Fobian, to win a photo decision in the $4,000 Cloister feature pace on the Grand Circuit program tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

If there was any doubt that the drought was truly over it should have been washed clean away by the oceanic downpour that pelted New Yorkers around midday yesterday. Was it our imagination, or weren't there an inordinate number of improvident souls scurrying along our streets without umbrella or slicker or rubbers yesterday?

GENEVA, Oct. 29 -- Communist China's Red Cross organization is trying to get the Executive Committee of the League of Red Cross Societies to approve, or at least debate, a resolution condemning the United Nations forces in Korea and their Governments for allegedly mishandling the prisoner repatriation issue.
Intermittent rain continued to fall in the New York area yesterday on the fourth day of a wet spell that broke the grip of the worst fall drought since 1949.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The story of Communist atrocities in the Korean war is being sent by short-wave radio to all parts of the world. Pamphlets bearing atrocity pictures are in production for quick distribution.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Retail food prices for 1954 are expected to average close to this year's level with the farmer's share in the consumer's dollar remaining about the same, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

Last August, when Premier Malenkov set down his Government's new economic policy, he promised the Soviet people a "sharp upsurge" in the production of consumer goods within the next two or three years. Some of the key details of this program have now been revealed by Deputy Premier Mikoyan, and these details shed interesting light both on the current situation of the Soviet consumer and on that consumer's future prospects.

LOON BAY, N. B., Oct. 29 -- One day of rain was badly needed in these parts, but there can be too much of a good thing. The driving rain that sluiced through the woods today kept the hunters lodge-bound until late this afternoon.

Having declared that the idea of "A Girl Can Tell" came from his own family, F. Hugh Herbert ought to be cautious about going home. He at least should toss his hat in the door before he enters. For the characters of his new comedy, which was acted at the Royale last evening, are monumentally uninteresting and the central idea gets pretty tedious before he brings down the curtain and lets the folks go home.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The geo-politics of military air power figures prominently in the continuing discussions here of next year's military budget.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- When Senator Duff of Pennsylvania was asked this morning to comment on the President's revised outline yesterday of the limits he intends to set on his partisan activities, the big red-haired veteran of political wars in the Keystone State and the 1952 Republican National Convention made a prediction that was quickly sustained by the event in what must be record time.
All four candidates for Mayor believe that the caliber of city service can and should be improved but they differ in some respects as to the means of achieving this end.

A robust and stimulating production of "Othello" arrived last night in a section of our community not normally associated with the drama. The presentation was the first in a repertory season by the Shakespeare Guild Festival Company at Jan Hus House in Yorkville. It was, indeed, a noteworthy beginning for the group.
OCEAN war against Japan now reached its climax [in 1944]. From the Bay of Bengal to the Central Pacific Allied maritime power was in the ascendant.

After having been owned for 110 years by Cornelius V. S. Roosevelt and his heirs, title to the property at 815 Broadway has developed into 3,600th interests as the result of various deaths during the Roosevelt family ownership that started in 1843.
The investment banking business of Harris, Hall Co., of Chicago and that of Dean Witter Co. of San Francisco are to be merged about Dec. 1 under the name of Dean Witter Co.
The Transit Authority hired yesterday Leo Casey, a former newspaper man and publicist of the New York World's Fair, as its public relations director at $12,000 a year.

Arrangements have been concluded for the second production in the Cinerama process, Louis de Rochemont's "The Thrill of Your Life," it was announced yesterday by Simon H. Fabian, president of Stanley Warner Cinerama Corporation.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Oct. 29 -- The North Shore Horticultural Society of Long Island will open its five-day flower show tomorrow afternoon in the former home of Mrs. Joseph E. Davies, now the College of Arts and Sciences of Long Island University, on Route 25A.
BONN, Germany, Oct. 29 -Moderation and restraint marked the two-day debate on West German Government policy concluded today in the bundestag, lower house of parliament.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Britain endorsed today the United States stand tying the creation of an international economic development fund to world disarmament.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Chief of the South Korean Air Force said today the Communists had repaired all thirty of their air fields in North Korea and had moved about 400 fighter planes south of their Yalu River sanctuary.

Volume continued light on the New York commodity exchanges yesterday. Price changes were irregular, with potatoes, cocoa, zinc, lead, tin and rubber up; while coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, hides and wool were lower and sugar, copper and burlap were mixed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Simon E. Sobeloff, Chief Judge of the Maryland Court of Appeals, will be appointed Solicitor General of the United States, qualified sources said today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission decided today to permit the State of Washington to intervene in the Hell's Canyon case.

Schoenberg's once controversial symphonic poem after the same drama that inspired Debussy's opera, "Pelleas and Melisande," was played last night for only the second time in this city by the Philharmonic - Symphony Society eighteen years after its New York premiere by the same body in 1935.

New Yorkers gave the Red Cross 325,000 pints of blood for the Armed Forces in the three years of the Korean war. They supplemented this offering with $16,080,000 in gifts and, last year alone, with 332,592 hours of volunteer work.
Rudolph Halley lost another round yesterday in his fight to compel the State Insurance Fund to make public its file on Lawrence E. Gerosa, the Democratic candidate for Controller.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 29 (AP) -Frank Stranahan of Toledo, Ohio, defeated Bus Mueller of Houston, 7 and 6, today, in the men's tournament of the Mexican amateur golf championships. The Ohioan posted five birdies.

On Sept. 15 Postmaster General Summerfield published an order (No. 55355) in the Postal Bulletin raising international surface mail rates, in several cases by over 100 per cent, effective Nov. 1. By order No. 55410, published on Oct. 27, the Postmaster General postponed the effective date of these increases with respect to second-class mail to Dec. 1.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican of New York, long regarded as a friend of organized labor, was appointed today acting chairman of a Senate Labor and Public Welfare subcommittee to study amendment of the Taft-Hartley Law.
EAST MEADOW, L. I., Oct. 29 -- Democrats of Hempstead Township accused two Nassau County Republican officials last night of padding registration roles with 952 "phantom" voters.

TRENTON, Oct. 29 -- Nelson F. Stamler, former racket-busting Republican prosecutor, whose dismissal last January as Deputy Attorney General resulted in a legislative inquiry, announced today his support of Robert B. Meyner, Democratic candidate for Governor of New Jersey.

The Moreland Act Commission investigating harness racing refused to pass judgment yesterday on the part played by Nassau County Judge Norman F. Lent in a venture in which William De Koning Sr., alleged labor racketeer, was one of nine partners.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29 -- A British Commonwealth Pacific Airlines plane crashed near here today, killing the nineteen persons on board.

George Killoran, a suspended city detective who was known as "the morphine bandit," was acquitted yesterday of charges of stealing morphine from drug stores. The jury held that he had been temporarily insane at the time of the hold-ups.
Robert F. Wagner Jr. served notice last night on Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, that he had no deals or commitments with anybody, including Mr. Quill.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Pie King, British 2-year-old champion, came down with a hoof ailment today and appeared a doubtful starter in the world's richest horse race -- the $266,395 Garden State Stakes Saturday.

KEARNY, N. J., Oct. 29 -- A collision here of a gasoline truck and a truck loaded with hot-dog and hamburger rolls at 7:15 A. M. today set off a chain of events affecting thousands of persons and hundreds of industries.
William Kapell was born here on Sept. 20, 1922, and showed musical talent at an early age. At 10, he began to study piano with Dorothea Anderson LaFollette at the Yorkville Settlement School.
The American Foundation for Allergic Diseases has been formed to stimulate and coordinate study and treatment of allergy diseases.
LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Domestic industrials continued to attract most of the investor's attention here today and the demand broadened.

A business plot 100 by 80' feet on the west side of Thirty-first Street, 140 feet west of Thirty-fourth Avenue, in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the Hugh Green estate to a client of Harry Newman, attorney. The buyer plans to improve the parcel with an industrial building.
Two of the three metal companies that announced yesterday their earnings for the nine months this year showed sharp declines from a year ago.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular yesterday, and closed 2 points higher to 7 points lower than on Wednesday.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Two of Britain's most powerful unions pressed today for wage increases totaling millions of pounds as many of their members showed increasing impatience with the delay in granting their demands.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A ruling that opened certain courses at the Louisiana State University to qualified Negroes was headed back to Federal District Court today for action after reversal by the United States Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals.

A new talent in the world of fashion was introduced to the public yesterday during luncheon in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel, Mort Mogel, trained abroad in the best tradition, presented a fall and winter collection of custom originals that stressed great style in silhouette, detail and fabric.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- President Eisenhower said today "the interest of this Administration is to create a balanced but advancing economy and prosperity in this country."

A child's safety habits, which "should start in the cradle," are the responsibility of a number of adults, it was agreed yesterday at the Fourth Safety Institute of Parents and Teachers at the Statler Hotel.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Nationalist China assured Thailand and the United States today that it would disavow all guerrilla forces remaining in Burma following the evacuation of troops willing to move to Formosa.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Prospects for a top-level four-power conference with the Soviet Union appear in British Government circles to be receding rapidly. It is feared the chances of ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty have suffered almost as much.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- A generally weak tone was shown yesterday by the grain list in the early trade, with the sharpest decline in corn. However, recovery set in later on commission house buying, although corn continued under pressure.
Fewer new securities were offered publicly here in October than in the preceding month but more than a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization today approved Federal tax benefits to assist in the erection of a steel plant in New England.

Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens was ordered yesterday by the State Supreme Court to deliver to the builder of the condemned section of the North Queens Corridor Sewer the public records on the basis of which he had pronounced the drain "in danger of immediate collapse."

RAMSEY, N. J., Oct. 30 -- Paul L. Troast, the Republican candidate for Governor, returned today to Bergen County, once the stronghold of syndicated crime, in the hope of cutting his party's losses to a minimum.

An interpretation of the life and work of twenty-two major figures in 300 years of English literature is the substance of a work by Annette T. Rubinstein. It is titled "The Great Tradition in English Literature: From Shakespeare to Shaw."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Average primary market prices registered no change over the week ended on Tuesday, and remained at 110, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher average prices for processed foods were counterbalanced by lower average prices for farm products.

Directors of the Teaxs Gulf Producing Company announced yesterday a 10 per cent stock dividend, an extra dividend of 15 cents a share and a quarterly dividend of 35 cents a share on the common stock. The cash dividends will be paid on Dec. 5, while the stock disbursement will be made on Dec. 16. Record date will be Nov. 18 for the three dividends.

YONKERS, Oct. 30 -- David Caudle, 4-year-old brown gelding owned by William C. Harris of New York and driven by Bill Haughton, scored a length-and- one-half victory in the Yorktown, a one-mile Class A pace, on the Grand Circuit card at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

There will be two defections tonight from the ranks of current Broadway attractions, but November promises to bring in seven new bills. The departing productions are "The Little Hut" and "The Frogs of Springs."
Contributions of 715 pints of blood were made Thursday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. A mass donation of 187 pints in Garden City, L. I. was the largest group gift of the day.

LONDON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- The Anglo-Iranian Oil Company is planning a new venture into the Persian Gulf oil industry, authoritative sources said today. Informants said that Anglo - Iranian, with French help, plans oil exploration off the coast of Abu Dhabi, one of the independent sheikdoms along the Persian Gulf.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 30 -- In a reassessment of policy comparable to that which precipitated the break with the Cominform, Yugoslavia's leaders were represented today as being prepared to readopt neutrality as a basic tenet.
Names famous for three centuries are magnified in a handsome and informative exhibition of silver at the Newark Museum.
Bullish and bearish forces fought to a stand-off in the stock market yesterday.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor, made public yesterday a letter he had sent to the heads of all organizations in the Police Department informing them he intended to deal with them on labor relations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The United States Information Agency announced today that three works by Vera Micheles Dean and one by Walter Duranty had been removed from the United States libraries in Germany because the contents were no longer of value to the agency's program there.

NEWARK, Oct. 30 -- The official weekly publication of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark is "strongly urging" its readers "to cast affirmative votes for the legalization of bingo in next Tuesday's election."

The European Army acquired a new lease on life Thursday night when a debate on it was held in the French Council of the Republic (the upper house, or Senate). It is true that the Council has only an advisory function, but Foreign Minister Bidault came out strongly and surprisingly for the European Defense Community on behalf of the Laniel Government.
Your farm policy editorial of Oct. 27 was an excellent presentation of half the case.

The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $25,000,000 of first mortgage pipeline bonds due in 1973. The bonds are to be sold at competitive bidding.

A five-year contract containing "no strike" and "no lockout" clauses has been signed by a Congress of Industrial Organizations union and Associated Food Shops, Inc., representing 100 restaurants in the metropolitan area.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor, has reversed his position on the creation of a parking authority for the construction of off-street parking facilities. Once opposed to the idea, he is now for it.

Richard Lewine has been appointed an executive producer by C. B. S. television with his first assignment to be the preparation of a color program series. Jerry Danzig, formerly supervisor of color programs, has been assigned to prepare a one-hour dramatic program to be televised in black-and-white.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- A solution soon to the conflict over the stalemated proposal for a special economic development fund was indicated here today. The proposed $250,000,000 project has been the subject of intensive debate between underdeveloped and developed countries during the last three weeks.
Election Day is next Tuesday, and this is the last time we shall argue the question of who would make the best Mayor of New York.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 30 -- A dispute is developing between Afrikaner Nationalists in the South African Union and the all-British Government of the Central Africa Federation.

In a move apparently aimed at tightening the Iron Curtain, the Soviet Government has decided to prohibit next year the export of all major newspapers and magazines published in the non-Russian areas of the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Sherman Adams, Assistant to President Eisenhower, said tonight that "it is not possible to change the political complexion of a National Administration as quickly and thoroughly as people might wish."
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 30 -- The cooperative nursery school movement is "growing like Topsy," the biennial convention of the National Association for Nursery Education was told today.

Lawrence Marks, who built the Colonial home on half-acre plot in the Fox Meadow section of Scarsdale, Westchester County, has sold it to Joseph C. Lasser in a deal negotiated by the Myron L. Blum Company, Hartsdale brokers.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 30 -- Wild tribesmen near the Tibetan border attacked a goodwill mission of twenty-five Indian officials and Army personnel last week and are believed to have killed at least ten.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., the world's largest chemical enterprise, cleared $172,829,089 in the first nine months of this year, its second highest on record for the period.
Detectives guarded the corridor approach to the grand jury room in the Mineola Courthouse yesterday as twenty builders of small homes in Nassau County appeared before the hold-over panel.

LEICESTER HEMINGWAY, the younger brother of Ernest Hemingway, has jammed the material for a book of war memoirs and a dozen short stories into his first novel, "The Sound of the Trumpet."* When you have read this book you know how it was with several hundreds of thousands of Americans who traveled abroad between. D-Day in France and the following springtime in the rancid rubble of Germany.

Bruce Wormald finally disposed of his 1936 automobile yesterday at a cost of $49.25. The 20-year-old Columbia University student had pushed the car into the East River on Sept. 27, after it had lain on Welfare Island for more than a year, and he was unable to move it in response to Police Department orders.

LAWRENCE, L. I., Oct. 30 -- The news here tonight was not so much that the Babylon Symphony Orchestra conducted by Christos Vrionides presented a concert in the local auditorium. Rather it was that some twenty-five music critics and symphony orchestra representatives from all over the country converged en masse from New York, where they are participating in a music critics workshop, to see and hear how smaller organizations in this metropolitan area operate.
LONDON, Oct. 30--Prices appreciated in nearly all sections of the stock markets here today under the lead of domestic industrial issues.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- Burma circulated today a series of letters that she said backed her charges in the United Nations that Nationalist China planned to let thousands of Chinese guerrillas stay on Burmese soil.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- More than 80 per cent of the personnel in the Air Force's Strategic Air Command, upon which rests much of the burden of United States security, are Reserve, not regular, personnel.

Teddy (Red Top) Davis of Hartford, Conn., won the New England lightweight championship last night by gaining the unanimous decision over George Araujo of Providence, R. I., in the feature clash of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -- A Republican-controlled House submittee asked Secretary Benson today to hold up his controversial reorganization plan for the Soil Conservation Service.

VIENNA, Oct. 30 (AP) -- In defiance of the Vatican, Communist Poland announced today she had appointed a Roman Catholic Bishop to the Diocese of Breslau (Wroclaw). In the Roman Catholic Church only the Pope has the power to appoint Bishops.

Passengers who arrived Thursday on the new Greek liner Olympia said yesterday they had found the last part of the trip the roughest. That was the part in which they were on dry land waiting up to six hours for their luggage.
Former Chief City Magistrate Edgar Bromberger has presented to the Police Athletic League the five-story family house at 125 West Seventy-ninth Street for use as a youth center.

GENERAL EISENHOWER, in accordance with previous and agreed arrangements, assumed direct command of the land forces in Northern France on September 1 [1944]. These comprised the British Twenty-first Army Group, under Field-Marshal Montgomery, and the American Twelfth Army Group, under General Omar Bradley, whose operations Montgomery had hitherto controlled. Eisenhower disposed of five armies in all.

The Treasury incurred an average discount cost of 1.306 per cent a year in its latest weekly sale of $1,500,000,000 of ninety-one-day bills, for which bids were opened yesterday. This compares with 1.22 per cent at the preceding sale.

VIENNA, Oct. 30 -- A special session of Parliament, black borders in the newspapers and a five-minute pause from work marked Austria's protest today against the fact that on the tenth anniversary of the Moscow declaration promising her freedom she still was not free.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Outsiders dominated the finish of the $5,000 Chevy Chase Purse today with Thorncliff Farm's Rock Cottage, an 18-to-1 shot, beating C. E. Baker's Slam Thru by a nose.

The National Labor Relations Board is making definite progress in attacking the thorny problem of communism among union leaders. It has tightened its procedure in certain types of representation cases -- namely, those involving unions which have officers under indictment for filing false non-Communist affidavits.
BROOKVILLE, L. I., Oct. 30 -- Mr. and Mrs. W. R. Coe of Planting Fields, Oyster Bay, won fourteen blue ribbons today at the opening of the North Shore Horticultural Society's five-day flower show.

Staten Island is the site of a continuing investigation into the relationship between crime and politics. But since the disclosures by Special Prosecutor William B. Herlands have cut across party lines -- and the end is not yet -- corruption is not an overt issue in the Richmond borough elections.

SUFERN, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- If the New York State Thruway Authority has its way west of here, it will move the Ramapo River about 200 yards and cover up three reserve wells of the village water supply. Long nettled by negotiations with the authority, the village is now fighting mad and is sending its attorney to Albany on Monday to seek an injunction against the authority.

TROY, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- Fifty million television sets will be in operation within five years, Dr. Allen B. Du Mont predicted to the third annual Industrial Council tonight at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -President and Mrs. Eisenhower already have cast their absentee ballots in New York City's mayoralty election.

Joao Carlos Muniz, the Brazilian Ambassador, called upon Pan-American business leaders yesterday to help maintain the high rate of trade between Brazil and the United States and to increase the flow of American private investment to his country.

OSAKA, Japan, Oct. 30 (UP) -- Southpaw Ed Lopat's major league All-Stars put on their most explosive hitting demonstration since arriving in Japan, pounding out eighteen safe blows in a 15 -- 1 victory today over the Nankai Hawks, champions of the Pacific Professional League.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in October was below that of September and was the smallest for a corresponding month since 1948.
TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 31 -- The negotiator meeting at Panmunjom to arrange a Korean political conference adjourned their sixth session today, rounding out the first week of discussions.

It was a pleasure to read your editorial of Oct. 21 on Amendment 9, because it contained none of the bitter, false accusations which our opponents have been using against us. It stated concisely the issues as you see them There are a few errors of fact, in my opinion, and a false conclusion to which I direct a few remarks.

The New York City Opera Company last night presented "Rigoletto" after a two-year absence from the repertory, with Julius Rudel conducting the work for the first time and with eight singers making their first appearance in roles large and small.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- The new Westchester Bank and Trust Company, financed in part by the five sons of John D. Rockefeller Jr., will begin operating on Monday with eight offices in White Plains, New Rochelle and Valhalla.

The city of Hartford, Conn., announced yesterday plans for the sale of $3,685,000 of bonds of various issue on Nov. 9. The bonds will be dated June 1 and Dec. 1, 1953, and will come due serially, from 1954 to 1963.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Harlan H. Hutchinson of Lone Rock, Iowa, patented this week a chair that is attached to the person so that the user can sit down whenever he likes. The inventor regards his device as especially suited for milkers, automobile mechanics and others who are required to move around a lot.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- President Eisenhower accepted today the resignation of William D. Mitchell, Small Business Administrator, without the customary tender of thanks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Canadian Government will permit television cameras in Parliament for the first time when President Eisenhower makes a major address to a joint session Nov. 14 in Ottawa. The speech also will be broadcast.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- The United States will confer with its allies before it asks the United Nations to take specific action to deal with the reports of Communist atrocities in Korea.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Gen. Mark W. Clark stood and saluted a formation of parading infantrymen today, taking the last parade and review of his thirty-six-year military career.

In choosing its Lasker Award winners for distinguished achievement the American Public Health Association has again selected a man who, subsequent to that selection, has been named a Nobel Prize winner. Among the 1953 Lasker Award winners announced yesterday is Dr. Hans Adolph Krebs, Professor of Biochemistry at Sheffield University in England.

The New York Knickerbockers will open their home schedule of the 1953-54 National Basketball Association campaign when they oppose the Minneapolis Lakers, the defending champions, in the second game of a league doubleheader at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Mrs. Rita Caruso, in a purchase for investment, has acquired the eight-family building at 200 Prospect Park West in Brooklyn from Mrs. J. Bertles. The property is assessed at $39,000 and was sold through the Charles Partridge Real Estate Company as broker.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 30 -- Dartmouth, in the throes of the worst season in its seventy-two-year gridiron history, will try to remove Yale from the undefeated ranks tomorrow in the bowl.
Thomas I. Parkinson defied yesterday efforts of the State Superintendent of Insurance to force his retirement.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Manufacturers' sales rose in September, but the rise was less than usual, the Department of Commerce said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Senator Wiley said in his introduction that perhaps the most basic impression given by the report was that the world Communist movement had grown very rapidly in the last thirty-five years.

The new International Longshoremen's Association of the American Federation of Labor held its first meeting with the New York Shipping Association yesterday. However, the union found the employer group unwilling to consider contract proposals at this time.
OSLO, Norway, Oct. 30 -- The Nobel Peace Prize for 1953 was awarded tonight to General of the Army George C. Marshall, United States soldier-statesman who gave his name to the Marshall Plan.

Willard F. Rockwell Jr. and Wiliam Zeckendorf have been elected directors of Allegheny Airlines, Inc. Mr. Rockwell is president and a director of the Rockwell Manufacturing Company and Mr. Zeckendorf is president and a director of Webb and Knapp, Inc.

Any week-end afternoon, and everywhere about the suburbs; wan agriculturists can be found these days engaged in planting bulbs. Lying dormant now, the bulbs will regain new life during the winter, and in the early spring will send up their gaily colored flowers as a salute to a new season.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 30 -- Eric Johnston, President Eisenhower's special envoy, told United States officials here today he believed skillful diplomacy could win Syrian and Jordanian approval for a United States-backed plan for co-operation with Israel in developing the Jordan Valley river system.
BERLIN, Oct. 30 -- A soldier who allegedly spent seventeen months in East Germany will face a general court-martial tomorrow in an unusual application of the Smith Act.
LONDON, Saturday, Oct. 31 (AP) -- High building costs and inadequate tax relief threaten to cripple Britain's merchant shipping industry, a maritime finance company asserted today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Bergen and Rockland County commuters have asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to require four bus lines to restore schedules of runs between New York and Nyack and between New York and Spring Valley to the number operated before Oct. 1.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Peter F. McCauley, 13-year-old schoolboy who saved one youngster from drowning and gave his life in an attempt to save another, was among thirty-five heroes awarded Carnegie bronze medals today.
At the request of military and community leaders, the American Social Hygiene Association is working to eliminate vice conditions in areas visited by military personnel.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- It must be an old Southern custom to celebrate Hallowe'en early, a few officials here decided today, when checks from Maryland communities began pouring into the offices of the United Nations Children's Fund.

Who says New York City has no heart? That pernicious rumor should be laid to rest by the recent report of John S. Sinclair, chairman of the New York Chapter of the Red Cross, in which it is revealed that New Yorkers gave 325,000 pints of blood to our armed forces during the Korean war, $16,080,000 in gifts to the Red Cross, and last year alone contributed 332,592 hours of voluntary work.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 30 -- Turner Catledge, the managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said tonight that vigilant protection of freedom and knowledge in education, the press and other American institutions was essential to preserve democracy.

BOSTON, Oct. 30 (UP)--A successful conversion by Halfback Don Molenda after a 41-yard breakaway touchdown run by Halfback Bob Girman enabled Marquette University to score a 7-6 victory over Boston University tonight before 19,730 fans at Braves Field.
The following is a round-up of new product that may be of interest to homemakers:
I want to thank you for the splendid editorial entitled "Poor Advice for Mr. Benson" which appeared in THE TIMES of Oct. 21.

Two years ago at the age of 70 General of the Army George C. Marshall resigned the last of four significant roles he had played in his country's recent history and returned to the comparative ease of his country home in Leesburg, Va.

Fordham's football team, which reached a 1953 peak of efficiency with a 40-13 conquest of Rutgers last Saturday, will oppose a powerful University of Miami eleven at the Polo Grounds today. With no competing gridiron attraction in New York, Fordham authorities hope for a crowd of at least 20,000. Kick-off time is 2 P. M.

If Harold Riegelman were less self-reliant and determined, he might at times wish for a bit of blarney, a dash of sheer irrelevant glamour. Being the logical-minded lawyer he is, however, the Republican candidate for Mayor wastes no time on such vain yearnings, but moves vigorously around the town, delivering carefully considered speeches.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- The Council of the Republic adopted a motion today expressing reservations about the European Defense Community. This was taken in political circles as an indication of the unwillingness of the French Parliament to ratify the treaty until further safeguards and guarantees could be obtained.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- A national manufacturing conference was told today that a buyers market will benefit consumers in more ways than one.
GADSDEN, Ala., Oct. 30 (AP) -Machines that all but replace hoes, mules and hand-picking in cotton fields were demonstrated today.
EL PASO, Tex., Oct. 30 -- Mexican Government officials are preparing to issue multiple-visit tourist cards to United States tourists early next week in Laredo, Tex.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Oct. 30 -- Moscow has expanded its propaganda organization in Iceland, and the move has yielded dividends.

Volume improved yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges, the usual week-end lull being absent in most markets. Hides had the heaviest trading since April 6, burlap since Sept. 29, and zinc since Sept. 21. Prices were generally higher.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The United States and Japan ended four weeks of hard bargaining with agreement today that Japanese "self-defense forces" must be strengthened.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- Voters here blocked today a proposed bond issue that would have brought a new combined high school to serve the twin villages of Tarrytown and North Tarrytown. The vote was 1,719 against and 1,701 in favor.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 30 -- Robert B. Meyner, Democratic candidate for Governor, made a barnstorming tour of Camden County today in a final effort to gain votes in this highly industrialized area. He visited half a dozen factories and delivered addresses at seven rallies.

Rudolph Halley demanded yesterday that state Democratic leaders repudiate their support of Lawrence E. Gerosa if the Democratic candidate for City Controller failed to make public his dealings with the State Insurance Fund.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- The United States explained here today that the people of Puerto Rico were overwhelmingly in favor of their present relationship with the United States and that the "last vestiges of colonialism" had disappeared in that territory.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- The Federal debt limit will have to be raised above its present $275,000,000,000 statutory limit, Budget Director Joseph M. Dodge said today. He made the assertion in answer to questions from the floor following an address to the Executives Club of Chicago at a luncheon meeting.

Proposed Amendment No. 3 to the State Constitution, to be voted on by the people next Tuesday, deserves more discussion than has so far been devoted to it in the local press. This is the amendment which would require the election of the Governor and the Lieutenant Governor jointly, by the casting by each voter of a single vote applicable to both offices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Arthur Toll, counsel for a House Government operations subcommittee, said today that the Veterans Administration was investigating home loan guaranty activities in the V. A.'s seventy regional offices.

Bonds called for redemption in October before maturity dropped to the lowest for any month since September, 1949, and to the lowest for any October since 1932. The month's total of $13,506,000, compared with $17,966,000 in the preceding month and $62,166,000 in October, 1952.

PRINCETON, H. J., Oct. 30 -- Princeton will seek to get back on the victory trail tomorrow when lit clashes with resurgent Brown in Palmer Stadium. crowd ofI 15,000 is expected for the 2 P. M. kick-off.
TOKYO, Saturday, Oct. 31--North Korean war prisoners marched defiantly this morning to interviews at Panmunjom by their Communist countrymen who would try to win them back.

ROME, Oct. 30 -- The twenty-third annual convention and world travel congress of the American Association of Travel Agents which drew 1,500 delegates to Rome, ended tonight after a message from Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, United States Ambassador.
After the discordant crash of a week ago, when the roof fell in for four of them, the members of football's hit parade can step out with a little more confidence today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The United States Government announced today it was about ready to close one of its most financially successful deals in history. It is about to sell -- for $3,500 -- a 1904 Cadillac automobile it bought 20 years ago for $100.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UP) -The Department of Agriculture announced today that producers of Maryland tobacco and Pennsylvania filler Type 41 tobacco voted against marketing quotas on their 1954 crops in a referendum yesterday.
Libelous and highly prejudical letters sent to several members of a Federal Court jury caused a mistrial yesterday in James Rutkin's $22,500,000 recovery suit against a former bootlegger-partner.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Employment held steady between September and October despite the return of additional young summer workers to school.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 30 -- Gov. Goodwin S. Knight today dismissed James G. Bryant as State Director of Employment. He appointed as Mr. Bryant's successor William A. Burkett, a former Treasury agent who charged in a speech early this year that more than $20,000,000 in fraudulent or improper payments had come out of the state unemployment insurance funds during 1952.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Senator Walter F. George said today that Congress should void the billion-dollar increase in the social security tax that becomes effective Jan. 1.

HARRISBURG, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The United States today won its first championship of the 1953 Pennsylvania National Horse Show and with it the top team award, but England's Pat Smythe gained her fifth personal victory in tonight's international jumping.
Harry Gold, convicted atomic spy, has linked Alexander Svenchansky, a Russian-born radio broadcaster, to a Soviet spy ring.

With the passing of the years since Theodore Roosevelt's death, in 1919, the twenty-sixth President of the United States has emerged from the cloud of political controversy in which many of his immediate contemporaries saw him into the brilliant sunlight of present-day popular appreciation.

A proposed 1954 capital budget of $531,745,343, the largest in the city's history, was adopted yesterday by the City Planning Commission. It was $106,179,612 larger than the proposed 1953 budget adopted by the commission last year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- The delegates of the United States and the Soviet Union had a few words to say today about movies. There were no rave reviews.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Fleet Admiral William D. Leahy said today he feared the United States had lost the war in the Pacific in one phase of the Battle of Leyte Gulf in October, 1944.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange opened 4 to 8 points off yesterday, and the close was irregular, 9 points lower to 3 points higher than on Thursday.

One of the buildings used for the publication of the former Jersey Observer at 80 Washington Street in Hoboken, N. J., has been leased by the Martin Furniture Company from The Evening Journal Association. The four-story structure, which contains 10,000 square feet of space, will be used by the lessee for the retail sale of furniture.

More and more business executives are beginning to realize that a gruff manner and knowing all the answers will not guarantee their success. An extensive survey of 250 top executives has brought this realization out.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 30 -- Twenty 2-year-old colts, including most of the best that are still in training, but not including The Pie King, the one that won top ranking in England last summer, have been entered in tomorrow's Garden States Stakes, which will be the richest horse race ever run.

The Falange party has taken the spotlight in Spain for the first time in many years. This may be of considerable significance, but it will be necessary to wait and see whether Generalissimo Franco gives the Falangists a larger share of important Government posts and more authority.

MADRID, Oct. 30 -- United States architects and engineers have begun drafting plans for the construction of four major air bases in Spain to be used jointly by the United States and Spanish Air Forces.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 30--The National Study Conference on the Churches and World Order overwhelmingly voiced its opposition to the controversial Bricker amendment today.

Among this week's art exhibitions is one devoted to a single picture -- Jack Levine's "Gangster Funeral," which is shown at the Alan Gallery, along with a selection of paintings and drawings related to it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- A pessimistic report on present Republican prospects in the Congressional elections next year is being prepared for President Eisenhower by one of the party's chief campaign strategists.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Former State Representative James J. Adduci of Chicago was acquitted today of unlawfully receiving a commission on a state contract while he was a state legislator.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Maj. Gen. William F. Dean disclosed today that he was within minutes of suicide during his captivity in Korea lest, under pressure, he might disclose secrets to the enemy.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The trustee of the bankrupt Tucker Corporation said today the company's wholly owned subsidiary in Syracuse, N. Y., had an increase of $214,316 in net earnings in 1952.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of a joint statement by the United States and Japan issued upon the conclusion today of talks dealing with Japanese defense and other problems:

The election frauds bureau is staying open over the week-end to complete its check of the voting qualifications of 952 county hospital employes whose names were registered wholesale in Hempstead Township, L. I., by Nassau County Republican leaders,

Victor and Gemma Fontaine, an elderly couple who have spent much of their lives backstage in restaurants here End abroad, have opened a new eating place, La Lune D'Argent at 985 Second Avenue (Fifty-second Street). The cooking is Italo-French.

The Charfran Stable's Crafty Admiral and the Hampton Stable's Alerted are rated at the top for the $75,000 added Gold Cup, which will have its seventh running in the Empire-at-Jamaica meeting today. Alerted will start as an entry with the 3-year-old filly La Perouse.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Billy Maxwell, 1951 United States champion, and Frank Stranahan, former British titleholder, moved through two rounds of the Mexican amateur golf championship with ease today, but Dale Morey of Martinsville, Ind., was eliminated.

TORONTO, Oct. 30 (Canadian Press) -- A "bonus" sale of shares to a company official and transaction by which majority control of the company passed to George Weston, Ltd., were attacked and defended today in a stormy annual meeting of Loblaw Groceterias Company, Ltd.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The United States and Britain have agreed on most of the technical details for withdrawing their troops from Zone A of Trieste and turning the area over to Italy.

More significance than meets the eye attaches to the speech of Foreign Minister Georges Bidault to the French Senate on Thursday. For the first time since the debate on the European Army split the Laniel Cabinet into opposing groups, he came out flatly in favor of the project.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Numbers are not a good gauge of Communist influence, the special Internal Security subcommittee of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee warned today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP)--The Agriculture Department said today that the level of farm prices had declined 2.34 per cent between mid-September and mid-October.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 30 (AP) -- New York State produces two and one-half times more canned goods a year than all of Russia, the vice president of the American Can Company said today. T. E. Alwyn said the figures "clearly indicated" the difference "in energy and know-how between the Soviet Union and the State of New York."

Sales of complete aircraft and propellers were reported yesterday by the Aircraft Industries Association at $4,200,000,000 for the first half of 1953. This compared with $2,900,000,000 for the same 1952 period.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board estimated today that industrial production had fallen about 1.3 per cent from August to September but had held steady in October.

Postage rates for international mail will increase tomorrow. Acting Postmaster John H. Sheehan of New York advised yesterday. Under the new rates, letters for all overseas countries will require 8 cents postage for the first ounce and 4 cents for each additional ounce or fraction.

The potential usefulness of the services of the aged in community activities was emphasized yesterday afternoon in a talk at the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church, at Fifty-sixth Street. Miss Gertrude Landau, headworker at the William Hodson Community Center, 4190 Third Avenue, was the speaker.

Opponents of the proposed plan to redevelop the area surrounding Washington Square, and put a highway and pedestrian overpass through the park were assured yesterday that no decision on the plan would be made until after the election.
A two-alarm fire caused $50,000 damage to a milk company's garage in the Bronx yesterday, five minutes before the company had planned to start selling 50,000 quarts of milk.

Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, said last night that the milk strike was the "crowning proof" of the impotence of the present city administration, of which his two principal rivals are a part.
A record high level in shirt production is expected this year. Output during the first six months was 24 per cent ahead of the 1952 period.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Queen of Greece just threw up her hands today when asked how many members of the United States Congress had visited her and her husband in Athens.

Before criticising salesmen's selling methods, advertising managers and agencies would do well to study their own techniques for flaws. This advice is given in "Profits and Proofs," house organ of the Philadelphia ad agency Hening Co.

LOON BAY, N. B., Oct. 30 -- Today's report might have been concerned primarily with the back-breaking effort of toting a large buck over some five miles of extremely rough terrain, a situation which undoubtedly would have left us more exhausted but less embarrassed than we are at this moment.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 30 -- Dore Schary, an Academy Award-winning writer (for "Boys Town") before he became chief of studio operations at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, used his vacation time last summer to create an original movie scene.
NOVARA, Italy, Oct. 30 (AP) -- An Italian defense attorney today described former Lieut. Aldo Icardi, accused in the murder of his World War II commander, as "a miserable pig."
Members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union of New York City and Vicinity approved last night the terms of a new agreement with the Publishers Association of New York City.

Charles S. Munson, chairman of the Air Reduction Company, received the Chemical Industry Medal last night. In his acceptance speech he called for more basic research and more chemists to help the chemical industry meet the needs of both national defense and the civilian economy.
ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 30 ---Cornell and Columbia will meet in their forty-first football game at Schoellkopf Field Saturday, with the Big Red a slight favorite.
The Federal Maritime Board has refused to approve the sale of the Bull Lines' passenger vessel Puerto Rico to Swiss interests, it became known yesterday.

The Religious Education Association of the United States and Canada, composed of 2,500 leaders in education, religion and child welfare, will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary at a convention on Nov. 8-10 at the University of Pittsburgh.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- Europe's Marshall Plan Council singled out France today as being particularly responsible for holding up the movement toward freer trade in Western Europe. It ascribed this to the retention of most of her import quotas.

Lafayette, favored to down Madison, and Brooklyn Tech, the choice over Tilden, share top billing on today's local school football schedule. Only five games are listed in the city as several teams have taken the week-end off and others are preparing for election day contests.
The milk strike went into its sixth day today with an indication that a settlement might be approaching.

Today's new film is "Battle for China," a feature-length documentary in Magicolor, photographed by sixty-three cameramen over a twenty-one-year period and produced by Peking Studios of the Chinese Peoples Republic and Central Documentary Film Studios of Moscow, at the Stanley Theatre.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30--Israel's representative charged today that Syria's attempt to block Israel's diversion of water from the Jordan River was part of "its avowed political and economic warfare" against Israel.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- President Eisenhower said again today that it was difficult to believe that Communist governments intended to honor agreements that would aid the cause of peace.

Critics have been warned by the Baker Street Irregulars to speak no ill of Sherlock Holmes in anything they may choose to say about Ouida Rathbone's play, "Sherlock Holmes," which was performed at the New Century last evening.
GENEVA, Oct. 30 -- Monetary policy in the principal European countries has ceased to be a deflationary factor.

A collection of fashions fit for a queen was shown yesterday morning on the Greek Line flagship Olympia. The superb gowns were by Norman Hartnell, dressmaker to Queen Elizabeth II. All told there were twenty-six models, each equally handsome in fabric and workmanship. The Olympia was docked at West Fifty-seveth Street.

QUINCY, Mass., Oct. 30 -- The 29,300-deadweight-ton tanker George Livanos, fifth vessel in the eighty-year-old shipping history of the Livanos family to bear that name, was launched here today in the Bethlehem Steel Company's yard. It was constructed for the Atlantic Oil Carriers, Ltd., a subsidiary of the Livanos shipping interests.

Robert F. Wagner Jr. declared last night that he and his running mates would be elected next Tuesday because the people of the city were convinced that the program of the Democratic party was their program.

Events today: Young People's Concert, Little Orchestra Society, Hunter College, 11 A. M.; "Madama Butterfly," New York City Opera, City Center, 2:30; Claudio Arrau, pianist, Town Hall, 3; Dutchess County Philharmonic Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 5:30; Philharmonic-Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; "The Marriage of Figaro," New York City Opera, City Center, 8:15.

OTTAWA, Oct. 30 -- Objections by the United States Civil Aeronautics Bureau forced Trans-Canada Air Lines today to announce the abandonment of plans for a weekly flight from Montreal to Mexico by way of Tampa. The first regular flight was to have started tomorrow.

TOKYO, Oct. 31 (UP) -- Saburo Hirai's eighth-inning home run gave the Tokyo Giants a 2-to-1 victory over the New York Giants today, with Frank (Lefty) O'Doul, former major league star, sharing credit in the triumph.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 31 -- Yugoslavia seemingly ruled out today any chance that Italy might regain through negotiation the Italian population centers in Zone B of the Free Territory of Trieste.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 -- A six-year improvement program to gear the Port of Philadelphia to the mushrooming business and industrial growth of the Delaware Valley will be instituted next year.

In 1937 Prof. B. J. Luyet, director of the St. Louis University's Institute of Biophysics, and his colleague, Dr. Pierre M. Genenio, developed rapid freezing and thawing methods which made it possible to suspend life in vinegar worms, young chick embryos, muscle fiber and other living tissues.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 31 -- Tulane, cashing in on penalties and fumbles, battled Army to a scoreless tie in the Sugar Bowl Stadium today before 38,000 homecoming fans.

Floods of printer's ink have been pouring over Panther Mountain Dam in the southwestern Adirondack Mountains for many months. As the flood crest rolls by Tuesday, the voters of the state, by their action on State Constitutional Amendment 9, will decide whether the dam is to be converted from blueprint paper into stone or the smoke of hopeless dreams.

NO matter how many plants there are about the house, it is always a thrill when one of them flowers indoors. Except for a dark apartment with no chance of any sun, a little careful planning ahead makes it possible to have a few flowers all winter long.

THOSE who have wistfully wondered why it is that no more than one film has been made from a Gilbert and Sullivan operetta in the twenty-five years since sound -- that one was "The Mikado," made in England, with Kenny Baker, before the war -- may be surprised to discover that the answer is as simple as this: the D'Oyly Carte company, which owns the properties, was loathe to release them for the screen.

JOSEPH WOOD KRUTCH has whittled himself a thoroughly delightful, thoughtful and humorous book of personal essays. Mr. Krutch is a first-class naturalist because he is a thinker -- which praise can be given few nature writers today.

A DEFT portrait of a first-class heel, "The Kingpin" tells the story of a mill-worker's son in a small North Carolina town who has spent his growing years in a desperate attempt to cross the railroad tracks. The effort ends in Bill Tucker's intrigues in behalf of a shady political opportunist named Harvey Pollock, who is determined to unseat United States Senator Ralph Anson.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 31 -- The trend to foreign-language programs in elementary schools was emphasized here today by the Kentucky Association of Colleges, Secondary and Elementary Schools.

HAVANA, Oct. 31 -- The Government at daybreak today outlawed communism on the ground that Moscow's system and aims are international in character and involve conspiracy against Cuba's national sovereignty.

Cotton from this year's crop is being pledged for Federal loans at a record rate. With the price in the open market slightly below the amount that can be borrowed from the Government, many farmers are taking advantage of the price support thus afforded and through Oct. 23 pledged 1,840,000 bales of the staple.

A RECENT issue of Publishers Weekly -- the Sporting News of the book business -- was devoted entirely to the "international flow of books," and the role that books play as our country's ambassadors. Leafing through this efficient periodical reminded us of the first time we walked through the avenues of Bombay and noticed the American books on the stalls and shelves.

The recent reversal by the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit of the Tax Court decision in a stock dividend situation (C. P. Chamberlin et al. v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, 18 T. C. 164) was not unexpected.

PANAMA CITY, Panama -- The fiftieth anniversary of Panama's birth as an independent republic will be the occasion of a typical Latin-American fiesta period this week. There will be folk dancing in the streets, bull fights, fireworks and parades of beautiful girls, with the high point a nationwide birthday party on Tuesday.

THE best way to understand and enjoy a foreign country is to work in it; a visitor is apt to see only the set pieces, but when you are working you can also observe "backstage." That is one reason why I was delighted at the call to go to Italy, where I had never been, to make "The Great Love."
May I be so forward as to correct some errors in Bernard Stengren's "Then and Now" (Oct. 11)?

THE centerpiece of this entertaining autobiography is Peter Freuchen's famous peg-leg. It stumps through palaces and lecture halls, around his not very profitable Danish farm and across Arctic Siberia. It provides an ingenious hiding place for smuggled documents and its confiscation by the Gestapo almost ends his vagabond life.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The resignation of William D. Mitchell as Small Business Administrator was hailed as a victory for small business men today by George J. Burger, vice president of the National Federation of Independent Business.
Recommendations on what should go into the making of a new foreign economic policy for the United States increased sharply last week.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 31 -- Paced by the accurate passing of Quarterback Tom Knight, Amherst remained among the ranks of the unbeaten with a 13-6 victory over Tufts today. The Jeffs' record is five triumphs and a tie.

LOON BAY, N. B., Oct. 31 -- The best of the northern deer hunting is to come. For with extremely dry weather throughout most of New Brunswick during October, the kill was very light, but rain the past week eliminated the dry condition and the arrival of overdue snow will provide almost perfect conditions.

FOR thousands of motorists who make the annual winter migration southward, the trip down is like visiting an old friend. Despite a wide choice of good routes, many drivers continue to follow the same roads each year with a tenacity of purpose that is admirable, if lacking in imagination.

BROADWAY'S joyfully heralded victory last spring in getting a revision of the city's building code to permit the sale of liquor in legitimate playhouses is suddenly beginning to sound as hollow as stage thunder.

Ninety-five candidates are in the running for the twenty-five City Council seats that will be at stake in next Tuesday's election. Each has the nomination of at least one of the four legally recognized parties.

TOKYO, Oct. 31 (Reuters) -- The statement issued in Washington yesterday at the conclusion of talks between United States and Japanese representatives drew a mixed reaction from political parties here today.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 31 -- Suffolk County voters will go to the polls Tuesday to elect a county clerk, sheriff and coroner. In the ten townships, they also will choose 132 town officers. Republicans now hold a vast majority of the offices to be filled.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 31 -- A color telecast of Bizet's opera, "Carmen," which was staged at the Colonial Theatre in New York, was watched here this afternoon on one of the first color sets to be released for home use.

RADIO and television will provide complete and comprehensive election returns on Tuesday. All radio stations will break into regularly scheduled programs for preliminary reports and most will devote their entire time to election news later in the evening, with reporters stationed at the various headquarters.

LANCASTER, Pa., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Lafayette scored a pair of touchdowns in the first three minutes and added 20 points in the final half to drop Franklin and Marshall College from the unbeaten ranks with a resounding 34-13 victory today.
