AUBURN, Ala., Oct. 31 (UP) -- The Auburn Plainsmen made Florida their fourth victim, 16 to 7, today with a pair of bruising backs, Charley Hataway and Bobby Freeman, supplying the power.
Former President Harry S. Truman will deliver a major Armistice Day eve address on civil rights at the seventy-third annual dinner of the City College Alumni Association on Tuesday night, Nov. 10.

THE last of the shows is a fitting finale to the waning outdoor season. Chrysanthemums, of course, will be spotlighted at all four exhibits, but other flowers and fruits of the harvest season will share the honors.

ROME, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- Voters will elect nine members of the City Council Tuesday in the climax to a two-and-a-half year political battle that has raged over adoption of city charter revisions providing for a city manager form of government.

DISCUSSIONS about confusion among women on the "feminine role in a changing society" have been cropping up regularly the last few years. Several months ago we reported on a psychological study of three hundred adolescent girls which indicated -- according to the specialists who conducted the research -- that these youngsters to a startling degree showed "little desire to mature as feminine personalities."

Fewer buyers were in the wholesale markets here last week, according to resident buying offices. Attention centered on completing delivery of holiday goods. However, many buyers are expected during the first half of November to shop lines and place initial spring orders. The continued warm weather limited reorders of fall merchandise.

Occupational horizons for women are definitely widening, according to indications from last June's graduating class at Wilson College. A report from the placement director shows that 62 per cent of the class members are working at thirteen different types of jobs and 18 per cent are pursuing advanced study.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- The United States said today that pro-Nationalist Chinese troops who refused to leave their jungle camps in Burma would be regarded as outlaws.

President Frank J. Shaughnessy of the International League has a plan he believes will enable major league baseball to solve its vexing problems of territorial expansion. Shaughnessy some twenty years ago founded the "Shaughnessy play-offs," which sparked new life into the minor leagues during the depression era.

Many dinner parties will be given in honor of the performance of "The Solid Gold Cadillac" on the night of Nov. 11 at the Belasco Theatre for the benefit of the Masters Nursery. Mrs. John J. Lenhart, who heads the benefit committee, will entertain with a buffet supper after the performance.

EVER alert to the needs of pet owners, Herbert Zim here gives advice on the care, feeding, training and breeding of the popular shell parrakeet, or, if you wish to sound really knowledgeable, the budgerigar. "It is a lot of fun to raise and train parrakeets, but even more fun to breed them and have young," he says encouragingly.

A FOUR-YEAR course for photographers leading to a bachelor of fine arts degree has been established at the California School of Fine Arts in San Francisco. The course began this fall and will consist of historical and general background, development of the creative personality and training for a professional career in photography.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 31 -- Two hotly-debated local issues -- "big government" and "traffic strangulation" -- will come to tests in voting Tuesday.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A former Army private who duped doctors and hospitals in eight states with his pose an an experienced physician will serve the next three years in jail.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- With the emergence this week of working plans for an independent agency to inform other peoples about United States ideas and aims a new development in Washington's role in world leadership appears to have crystalized.
The Port of New York Authority has urged the Interstate Commerce Commission to equalize rail rates on import iron ore moving from North Atlantic ports to steel mills in the Youngstown, Ohio, area.

AMID the hue and cry of "one platoon," "horse - and - buggy football," "two platoons" and "free substitution," King Football is well-embarked on another autumnal reign. Coaches everywhere are going through their "ninety-day headache" period. They lie awake nights designing new offensive maneuvers that will confound the opposition.

SUFFERN, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- Charges that Supervisor Charles E. Lack, local lawyer, was not a property owner in Rockland County when he was sworn into office on Nov. 24, 1952, caused a furore in Rockland County political circles today.
New York's thrifty are certain to benefit as a result of the State Banking Board's recent action terminating the twenty-year old ceiling on interest dividend payments by savings banks.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Paced by the flawless ride of Arthur McCashin of Pluckemin, N. J., the United States equestrian team won the International Challenge Trophy jump at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight.
ALBANY, Oct. 31 -- Nearly thirty years of Democratic domination of Albany's local government is being challenged in Tuesday's election.

FRANCE is undecided about the role she will try to play in Europe and the reforms she will make internally to fit her to play a role. She is pushed one way by old habits of thought, memories, fears and distrust of her own capacities, and pushed another way by French visions of a possible future for France and Europe that sometimes seem to have awakened more enthusiasm abroad than in France.

After reading Hanson Baldwin's "Is There a Defense Against the Atomic Bomb?" (Oct. 18). I felt constrained to write you on this matter. As an Englishman who was bombed out of his home and works in the last war and witnessed the effects of the flying bombs or V-1 and the Rockets or V-2.

WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Raymond E. Snyder, Republican, who ended the Democrats' reign of twenty-six years over Waterbury in 1947, seeks his fourth term as Mayor Tuesday. He is opposed by William St. John, Democrat, a former Army officer seeking his first political post, and Anthony R. Martino, Socialist, who is making his third bid.

In the six and a half years since Great Britain dropped on the U. N.'s lap an item called "the Palestine question," that item has never been off the world organization's agenda. Much has happened since then -- partition, the establishment of Israel, the invasion of the Holy Land by Arab armies, their defeat and the uneasy truce -- but the essential positions of the parties involved has not altered.

SEVERAL chilly nights ago on the broad expanses of the back lot at Twentieth Century-Fox's Beverly Hills studios, Henry Hathaway, the director, called for action on the "Prince Valiant" set. At his command bright orange and white flames burst forth from dozens of strategically placed jets illuminating a burning stone castle of fifth-century Scandia.

TORONTO, Oct. 31 (UP) -- Sid Smith scored two goals tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs snapped a three-game losing streak at the expense of the New York Rangers, 4 -- 1, before a crowd of 12,650 at the Maple Leaf Gardens.
JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 31 (UP) -- Texas Tech's Red Raiders upset Mississippi State, 27 to 20, today before 16,000.

THAT celebrated Celt, in-again-out-again Finnegan, had nothing on an Englishman named Anthony Quayle, who, by the way, also happens to be the managing director of England's Shakespeare Memorial Theatre (Stratford-on-Avon).

PARIS, Oct. 31 -- A revolt in the National Assembly against the war in Indo-China petered out this week and ended in a grudging endorsement of the Government's policy. At the same time what appeared to be a revolt in Indo-China against the French Union likewise petered out, with Bao Dai, head of the Vietnam State, and his Premier joining the French Premier in minimizing the move of Vietnam Nationalists against the Union.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- Rockland County voters will choose a District Attorney and township officials next Tuesday in an election that will determine the political patronage in the county for several years.

CARL BAKAL'S "Filter Manual" (San Francisco: Camera Craft Publishing Company. $3), which is packed with useful data and contains as its principal feature a "filter dictionary" listing filter recommendations for more than 200 subjects alphabetically arranged, was published last week.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Oct. 31 -- Iceland's economy is in such straits that the alternative to devaluation is a sharp budget reduction, in the opinion of responsible circles here. The Government is loath to resort to either measure.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 31 -- Widespread ignorance and public indifference are handicapping the fight against the mental illnesses that are afflicting a growing proportion of our people, Richard Weil Jr., president of the National Association for Mental Health, said here tonight.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 31 (UP) -- George Shaw led Oregon to one of the season's big football upsets today as the underdog Webfoots knocked Southern California from the nation's unbeaten list, with a 13-7 Pacific Coast Conference victory.

As the hard-fought municipal political campaign entered its final phase yesterday each of the three major candidates for Mayor offered the traditional forecast of victory for himself and his entire ticket on Tuesday.

THE amateur photographer in Italy appears to be discovering the camera all over again. In that country amateur photography since World War II has been devoted almost entirely to a fresh and lively responsiveness to familiar aspects of day-to-day living. Although a similar approach is making rapid headway in the United States and other countries, Italian amateurs have adopted it almost as a national attitude.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 31 -- Iran's Foreign Minister expressed hope today for a resumption of diplomatic relations with Britain once certain "preliminaries" related to the dispute over oil had been ironed out.

IN what I wrote two weeks ago about our contemporary antagonism in the arts toward beauty (exemplified particularly in painting and sculpture, music and literature) I confessed my inability to find a satisfying rational basis for an attitude so prevalent.

NASSAU, Bahamas -- This fast-growing vacation spot is placing the biggest array of resort attractions in its history at the disposal of American visitors this fall and winter. Accommodations in every price range, activities for every age group, excellent transportation from any part of the United States and shopping savings are some of Nassau's advantages.

NOWSHERA, Pakistan, Oct. 4 -- Americans from at least twenty states would feel at home in sections of the North-West Frontier Province. This smallest of the country's five provinces typifies the growth of a nation that six years ago used packing cases for desks of men new to the ways of government administration.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Dartmouth cut loose with a dazzling passing attack today to effect one of the most startling upsets of the college football season in the East.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 31 -- The following is the chart showing how the Garden State Stakes was run at Garden State today:

DETROIT, Oct. 31 (UP) -- Dave Creighton and Cal Gardner pounded home third-period goals tonight to give the Boston Bruins a 3-to-1 victory over the defending National Hockey League champions, the Detroit Red Wings, before 10,075 fans at Olympia.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Settlement of the $17,000,000 Garrett snuff fortune has been completed after twenty-three years of litigation, it was announced today.

Korea's greatest needs and methods of meeting them were discussed for nearly an hour last night by a panel of teen-aged students on the New York Times Youth Forum. For the second half of the program questions were asked by students in the audience.
NEARLY nine months ago Robert M. Weitman switched from managing director of the Paramount Theatre to vice president in charge of program and talent development for the American Broadcasting Company.
Art as a paying career will be the subject of a lecture, the second in a free series, on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

The paintings collection of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Rosenberg, containing nearly 100 examples predominantly of the modern French school, will be shown for the first time in its entirety in an exhibition for the benefit of the New York Association for the Blind, opening on the evening of Nov. 18.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Four men and two women who have had graduate training in political science will go to work for Congress Monday as "internes."

BERMUDA'S six-pence stamp with "Royal Visit 1953" inscribed -- for the expected arrival of Elizabeth II on Nov. 24 -- has as its design the famous Bermudan "longtail bird" from a photograph by Bernard Brown, an American who is the Associated Press correspondent in Hamilton and sports editor of the Hamilton Royal Gazette.

The forty-sixth annual autumn exhibition, entitled "Winter's First Flower Show," of the Horticultural Society of New York will be held on Thursday, Friday and Saturday in the Colonnades Ballroom of the Essex House for the benefit of the Goodwill Industries of New York.
OSWEGO, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- The mayoralty campaign in this upstate community of 22,000 persons sounds like the national election of a year ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- A two-year survey in eighty-four countries and territories has yielded a mass of facts and figures that came off the presses this week in the form of the first World Directory of Medical Schools.
Mayor Impellitteri climaxed the issuance of three proclamations last week with recognition of the coming fiftieth anniversary of the Flushing Historical Society.
HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 31 -- Warren D. Lamport, former managing director of the port of Seattle, has been named director of the port of Houston.

Unbeaten Lafayette High School moved another step closer to its third straight football season without a defeat by conquering James Madison, 14 -- 6, at Lincoln Field yesterday. It was the fourth success for the Frenchies, who were tied once. Madison suffered its second defeat against a victory and a tie.

GOOD American children, brought up on the romantic story of Pocahontas saving the life of Capt. John Smith, are saddened if they subsequently read any history by the doubts cast upon their hero's character and veracity.

The sixty-fifth National Horse Show will begin in Madison Square Garden on Tuesday. It will continue day and night through Nov. 10. WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- Westchester voters will decide Tuesday whether to continue the forty-five years of Republican rule or accept Democratic claims that the entrenched party's ties with raceways, Thruways and extortionists warrant a change.
MANILA, Oct. 31 -- Since withdrawing his candidacy for President, Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo has stirred the national imagination by defying open terrorism from a speaking platform.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 31 -- A man who only four years ago suffered a crippling attack of bulbar poliomyelitis has been named administrator of the Middlesex County Rehabilitation and Polio Hospital in near-by North Brunswick Township.

The Dutchess County Philharmonic Orchestra presented a program of music of Norway yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, with Ole Windingstad conducting and with Percy Grainger as soloist in the Grieg Piano Concerto.

BERLIN, Oct. 31 -- An American who fled to East Germany pleaded guilty today to charges that he returned twice to the United States zone with Soviet agents and took them on a guided tour of United States military installations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers charged today that most of the commissions set up by President Eisenhower to study national problems were merely devices "to stall and avoid decisions."

YONKERS, Oct. 31 -- Pat Tuccio's Katie Key, 7-5 favorite from Riverhead, L. I., winner of the $50,000 Roosevelt Trot in August, scored a one-length victory over Lord Steward in the $7,500 Pleasantdale free-for-all trot on the Grand Circuit program before 24,808 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

BONN, Germany, Oct. 31 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of West Germany, expressed his confidence today that France would render a favorable verdict on the European army treaty in January or February.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Two big unions are waging a campaign that may shut down most of the aircraft industry.

ONE of the higher high spots in the brief history of television occurred on the evening of June 15, 1953, when, in the course of the Ford fiftieth anniversary show, the two reigning queens of the musical theatre, Ethel Merman and Mary Martin, set out on a joint recapitulation of some of the more memorable popular songs of the past half century.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 30 (AP) -- West Virginia, the nation's fifth ranking team and No. 1 on offense, bogged down on the ground and needed a blocked punt recovered in the end zone to defeat Penn State, 20 -- 19, today. The victory extended college football's longest major winning streak to twelve.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Oct 31 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon urged the Vietnamese today to make greater efforts in the war for the defense of Southeast Asia and to attain their own independence.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 31 -- A record goal of $1,000,000 has been set by Princeton University alumni for their fourteenth annual giving campaign, which will open tomorrow and continue through Feb. 15.

The handkerchief industry will see a resumption of shipments from Hong Kong late next spring, according to Arthur M. Klurfeld, director of the Handkerchief Industry Association. Hong Kong goods available for the coming holiday season, he said, will be from stocks that were received earlier this year before shipments to the United States were suspended.
BONN, Oct. 31 -- A man whose fate it was to be a hinge on which history turned reappeared on the world stage this week after an absence of several years.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 -- While hours of production workers in Pennsylvania factories have averaged slightly below 40 a week for several months, hourly earnings have continued to rise. They reached a new peak in September of $1.83 and carried weekly earnings to a record high of $72.16, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported.
BILLINGS, Mont, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Tom Yellowtail, George Takes-the-Gun and Frank He-Does-It fingered their rifles. They joked and laughed, a little nervous. It was almost time for the chase.

Lilienthal, who has traveled extensively in the Middle East and served as consultant to the American delegation at the San Francisco conference of the United Nations.
GENEVA, Oct. 31 -- Construction of Europe's first cyclotron and synchrotron for nuclear research is planned to begin next spring.

NEWARK, Oct. 31 -- Both proponents and opponents remained confident today of victory in the municipal referendum here next Tuesday on the question of replacing the City Commission form of government with a Mayor and nine Councilmen.

IT is rare that a point in law should make newspaper headlines and provoke national debate. But as an ever-growing number of witnesses refuse to answer seemingly pertinent questions on the ground that their truthful answers would tend to incriminate them, discussion mounts over the rights and wrongs of the Constitutional Amendment invoked in justification of their refusal.

THE publication of a new volume by Frank Lloyd Wright is a measure of the respect, almost the reverence, in which he is held. This nearly universal admiration is a well-earned tribute not only to the author's complete devotion to his ideals through storm and calm, attack and adulation, but also and perhaps even more to his creative imagination and his sense of the poetry of existence.

The Little Orchestra Society opened its sixth season of young people's concerts at Hunter College yesterday morning. Because of the illness of Max Leavitt, the customary narrator, Thomas Scherman, the conductor, took over as narrator as well as leader of the orchestra.

LOS ANGELES -- The first days of November raise the curtain in the Southwest on a regional attraction which has no rivals this side of Africa. It is the desert. Although in an age of automobiles and air-conditioning the vast expanses of sand and sagebrush, dunes and cactus are navigable and even enjoyable the whole year around, their prime season is November to May, when maximum temperatures drop from 100-and-up into the arid, balmy 80's.

ISKENDERUN, Turkey, Oct. 24 -- This 3,000-year-old Mediterranean port city has evicted the encroaching sea and the malarial mosquito. Now it is trying to overcome centuries of neglect and meet goals set by North Atlantic Treaty Organization planners and the Turks themselves.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., Oct. 31 -- Dr. Luther Hilton Foster will be inaugurated tomorrow as the fourth president of Tuskegee Institute.

STARTING across the border from Brownsville, Tex., Mexico's Gulf Coast extends southward in a gigantic curve. At the Bay of Campeche the curve swings north and east, forming the coast of Yucatan. In all these hundreds of miles of shoreline there are excellent beaches and interesting towns, cities and villages where one can vacation, fish, bathe and loaf in the sun.

IF you like to sit in front of a cozy fire and listen to stories by the hour, this new book of Jesse Stuart's is just the thing for you. "The Good Spirit of Laurel Ridge" is a story of the Kentucky hill country that Mr. Stuart loves so much and tells about so well.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 31 -- Jordan said today that the Arab Legion had been justified in firing on Israeli officers Thursday because the Israeli representatives had crossed the frontier No Man's Land without previously having notified the Jordanian authorities.

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- Cornell put the brakes on Columbia's strong opening assault and took charge after trailing by 6 -- 0 early in the second period for a 27-13 victory today. The Big Red went to the head of the Ivy League class as Yale suffered its first defeat against Dartmouth.
Harold Riegelman, Republican candidate for Mayor, renewed last night his attack on Robert F. Wagner Jr. for accepting campaign support from Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union.

DALLAS, Oct. 31 -- The fall upswing in business is not as great as last year, the Eleventh Federal Reserve Bank indicated in its monthly business summary. Although department store sales in September reflected the usual fall upswing with a 3 per cent increase over August, they were 7 per cent below September a year ago.

In accordance with arrangements made by the International Civilian Aviation Organization, an agency of the United Nations, the ships of fifteen seaboard nations ring the North Atlantic. Some millions of American citizens will go to the polls next Tuesday to express their decisions as to various candidates and issues. GENEVA, Oct. 31 -- The Executive Committee of the League of Red Cross Societies decided today to expand the services provided by the League Secretariat to national societies in the field of disaster relief. NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 31 -- Rutgers extended a record today. In seventy-five consecutive games its football team now has scored at least one touchdown. But for the fourth time this season it failed to score enough. Colgate beat the Scarlet, 33 -- 13.

ESTERO, Fla. -- This unincorporated community of 300 persons lies between Fort Myers and Naples on the Tamiami Trail, U. S. 41. Except to stop for gas or a drink of orange juice, there is little reason for the average tourist to pause.

BOSTON, Oct. 31 -- Municipal elections will be held in all but two of Massachusetts' thirty-nine cities next Tuesday, with light voting generally forecast. Lawrence will have its election in December and Beverly will wait until 1954.
DALLAS, Oct. 31 (UP) -- Fullback Doug Cameron's power running and Charley Brewer's passes today sparked Texas to a 16-to-7 upset of Southern Methodist before 51,000 fans.

TRENTON, Oct. 31 -- With the New Jersey political campaign all out over, eleventh-hour television appeals are planned by the two major candidates for Governor, Paul L. Troast, Republican, and Robert B. Meyner, Democrat.

MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 31 -- The investigations of Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceway, have put the Nassau County Republican party on the defensive for Tuesday's election for the first time in thirty-six years.

Troubles of Trieste The troubles of Rome in the Istrian peninsula, which have recently become acute, began some time ago. In 177 B. C. a Roman Consul led an army to Istria to suppress an Illyrian race living there which was much given to piracy. The peninsula was incorporated in Italy by the Emperor Augustus.

PARK CITY, Utah, Oct. 31 -- At the junction of two transcontinental highways, U. S. 30 and U. S. 40, a shabby, peeling sign points the way to Park City, lead-zinc mining center of the nation -- a community typically rich in history, statistics and heartbreak.

TALLHASSEE, Fla. -- It now appears reasonably certain that a bob-tailed toll turnpike will be built along the lower east coast of Florida, with the work starting some time next spring and being completed by 1956. The foreign diplomat or journalist trying to answer that key question must perforce turn to the Soviet press, the best available barometer though hardly an infallible measuring instrument. VIENNA, Oct. 30 -- Economic conditions in Hungary were described in Linz today by Mrs. Erzebet Marothy, who escaped last Sunday with her husband to Austria. But both, according to her statement, were glad to pay this price to be freed from what she said was slavery.

BERLIN, Oct. 31 -- The East German Interior Ministry reported today that it had broken up a nationwide network of "spy groups" said to have been working for United States and West German agencies.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 31 -- Virginia's electorate, which last year reversed its Democratic tradition and supported Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, will vote Tuesday on the acceptability of Republican leadership at the state level.

JACKSONVILLE -- A spot check of fall and winter tourist prospects along Florida's east coast from Jacksonville Beach to Miami reveals no lack of optimism that the new season will be equal to, if it does not exceed, that of last fall, winter and spring.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 31 -- Tennessee will vote Tuesday on night proposed amendments to the state Constitution, and those approved -- if any -- will be the first ever added to what is described the oldest unamended governmental constitution in the world.

HIGHER speeds, more flights and commuter-type service are the things the commercial airlines will be featuring for this winter's vacation traveler. The speed will be evident principally on the non-stop trans-continental service between New York and Los Angeles.

JOSEPHINE HULL, a tiny, spirited, twenty - four - carat actress who, among her other feats in a career that began back in 1902, kept a decade rolling in the aisles, is the recipient these days of all kinds of verbal medications, prescribed singly or in a batch, every time the curtain drops on "The Solid Gold Cadillac," her newest play.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 -- Repsentatives of the television and broadcasting industry in Los Angeles here have expressed concern to police and city officials about a proposed ordinance that would require police permits for broadcasting activities on public thoroughfares.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31 -- Republicans and Democrats agree the city election here Tuesday will be close, but not quite as close as two years ago, when a Superior Court judge ruled the incumbent Republican Mayor, William C. Celentano, the winner by the margin of two votes.

STANFORD, Calif., Oct. 31 (UP) -- The amazing Stanford Indians rolled to their fifth consecutive Pacific Coast Conference victory today as they routed the Washington State Cougars 48 -- 19, before a crowd of 19,000.

ST. CROIX, V. I. -- The rains are coming to their seasonal end and the American Virgin Islands are busy getting ready for a new tourist season. The three lovely islands -- primitive St. John, elegant St. Croix and sophisticated St. Thomas -- are all at work planning and renovating.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 31 -- Controversy is raging in the Union of South Africa on the Malan Government's intentions toward the trade unions. Ivan L. Walker, former Secretary for Labor and a Conservative in politics, has reiterated his charge that the Nationalist Government plans to destroy the free trade unions. This charge has been denied by government spokesmen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General of the United States, said unqualifiedly today that he was not the mysterious "Mr. X" of Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate for Mayor of New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Raymond T. Schaeffer, director of disaster services for the American Red Cross, said tonight that the decisions at Geneva today "would not affect" the organization's activities.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Oct. 31 -- Twenty-one out of 459 former North Korean soldiers chose today to return home after having listened to the pleas and entreaties of North Korean officers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Washington social season opens officially Tuesday with the Cabinet dinner at the White House.

CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 31 -- There was a 14-to-1 winner today at the Garden State Park in the $269,395 Garden State Stakes for 2-year-olds -- the richest horse race ever run. Cain Hoy Stable's Irish-bred Turn-To did the job.
The cornerstone for the new Robert P. Patterson Army Reserve building on New York University's Bronx campus will be laid on Wednesday morning with a military ceremony.

MANHATTAN, Kan., Oct. 31 (UP) -- Sheer split-T power smashed Kansas State's dream of a long-sought Big Seven football championship today as Oklahoma's perennial titleholders romped to a 34-0 victory before a crowd of 21,500.
OTTAWA, Oct. 31 -- Considerable importance is attached here to President Eisenhower's visit Nov. 13 and 14 when he is to adress a joint session of Parliament.

WITH space diagrams for Florida-bound trains already open to Dec. 31, the tempo of travel to the southland is picking up daily and rail officials are expecting a good season. Full winter service will become effective on Dec. 17 from New York.

ANY D. E. Stevenson novel flows along like a country air in a boogie-woogie session. Its pleasant people go their quiet ways filled with a sense of life's goodness. Theirs may not be the best of all possible worlds, but it has bluer skies and fleecier clouds than ours.

After an eight-day deadlock, negotiators for the Metropolitan Opera Association and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians reached an agreement late yesterday afternoon. Members of the Metropolitan Orchestra will be on hand for rehearsal tomorrow.

ABOUT six months ago the Louisville Philharmonic Society received a grant of $400,000 from the Rockefeller Foundation for an ambitious four-year program devoted to commissioning, performing and recording contemporary music.

PROBABLY anyone who has ever attempted to place a posy or two artistically in a vase or bowl knows that a certain amount of thought must go behind it. Often the container is not right, or else the flower will not stand up by itself.

The algae, especially the Chlorella species, have been receiving a good deal of attention in the last few years because they may aid in solving the problem of feeding a world population that is rapidly outgrowing its food supply. Theoretically 55,000 pounds of protein can be harvested from a single acre of Chlorella -- more than sixty times the annual output of an acre of soybeans.

THE decision of the United States, announced a few days ago, to withdraw from participation in "weather ship" service in the North Atlantic apparently heralds the end of one of the most colorful aspects of sea duty in which man has ever served.
November is by tradition the chill, raw, dark end of autumn and the wet, slushy forerunner of winter, a long span of long nights and abbreviated daylight. For once we will welcome such a month.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 31 -- Voters of Little Rock will decide Tuesday whether the city's first Republican Mayor since carpetbag days will serve a second term.
ASK any boy or girl in Australia if they have heard of the Rayner sisters and their eyes will light up and they'll say, "Oh, you mean Joan and Betty."

BOSTON, Oct. 31 -- Carroll Lowenstein, Harvard's former captain, came up with a masterly demonstration of passing today in the Stadium, throwing five touchdown passes and running for another as the Crimson crushed Davidson, 12 -- 6.

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 31 (UP) -- Corky Tharp, who broke away for gallops of 88 and 63 yards, and Bart Starr, who fired three touchdown passes, lit the delayed fuse on Alabama's offensive powder keg today to roll up a 33-to-12 victory over Georgia before 36,000 fans.

ST. PETERSBURG -- The people of Florida's west coast communities anticipate fine things from the coming winter season despite financial page notes about a declining stock market, tighter money and falling retail sales. In fact, they anticipate a booming season and the only question in their minds is how much money the tourists will spend once they get here.
For the cups that cheer but do not inebriate, Robert B. Smallwood is your man.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 31 (UP) -- Howard (Hopalong) Cassady, a red-haired sophomore halfback who likes the wide-open spaces on a football field, played a key role in four touchdowns to keep Ohio State in the Big Ten race with a 27-13 victory over Northwestern.

RALEIGH, N. C., Oct. 31 (UP) -- L. Q. Hines got in the line-up for only one play but won another football game for William and Mary today by booting the extra point that beat North Carolina State, 7 -- 6.

HISTORICALLY speaking, the memorial exhibition, at the Rose Fried Gallery, of work by Morgan Russell, who can fairly be identified as America's first totally abstract painter, is of considerable interest. For obvious reasons he called his pictures "synchromies" and they are best described in his own words of 1913: "I have labored uniquely with color -- its rhythms, its contrasts, and certain directions motivated by color masses."

THIS beautifully made book tells of a youngish married couple's voyage on a thirty-two-foot schooner among the Society Islands, most famous of which is the incomparable Tahiti. The author, an experienced magazine editor and yachtsman, knows how to write informatively and pleasingly, and his photographic log, accounting for more than a third of the pages, is truly magnificent.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- The Soviet Union charged today that the United States decision to spread the story of Communist atrocities in Korea before the United Nations was part of a campaign to keep international tensions high.

Twenty-seven noncommercial television stations are expected to be on the air by the end of 1954, the National Citizens Committee for Educational Television estimated in a recent report. Two are already telecasting, KUHT-Houston, and KUSC-Los Angeles. In twenty-five other communities, plans, backed with cash and equipment, are so well advanced that operating stations will become realities in the near future.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- President Eisenhower was elected a year ago this coming week, but he still seems to be searching for a clear vision of his job.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 31 -- A veteran Fairfield County politician, commenting on the seven city and town elections next Tuesday said: "Sure, lots of new people are moving out here from New York but what kind of people are they, Democrats or Republicans?"
NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 31 (UP) -- Duke reached its peak of offensive power today to smash Virginia, 48 to 6, before 20,000 fans in this seaport's annual Oyster Bowl.
The upward trend of stock prices met with some resistance during the week, as the market faced one of the most important tests it has had on the up side since the September collapse.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Oct. 31 (UP) -- Tennessee's waiting game paid off in a 20-6 victory over North Carolina today as a recovered fumble opened the gates for a burst of third-period touchdowns. The Vols scored their first triumph over a major foe this year.

THE Dance Center of the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A. has taken a drastic, courageous and forward-looking step this season in the curtailment of its customary schedule of performances. For a number of years the "Y," under the careful eye of its educational director, Dr. William Kolodney, has provided a home for the recitalists -- especially the young moderns -- and they will undoubtedly be hard put without it.

THE "Wild Place" is Wildflecken, in northern Bavaria, once a Nazi training center. The people in it were for the most part Poles deported to work in Hitler's war industries, and Kathryn Hulme, of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, was there to help tide them over until they could get back home.

THIS is Fairfield Osborn's second book on the dwindling supply of, and soaring demand for, the essentials of life. Five years ago, when "Our Plundered Planet" was published, eminent demographers, who do not take kindly to present reassertions of the prophecies of Malthus, still were predicting a downturn in the birth rate, especially in industrialized countries such as ours. They were wrong.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct 31 (AP) -- Georgia Tech overcame a shaky start to rout Vanderbilt, 43 -- 0, today in a versatile display of power, speed and passing.

Crafty Admiral picked up $53,550 with apparent ease at the Jamaica Race Track yesterday. Competing in the $80,400 Empire City Gold Cup, the 5-year-old horse from the Charfran Stable captured the mile and five-furlong test by ten lengths in the near-record time of 2:43 3-5.
Oscar Zeitz, assistant treasurer of Hoffman-La Roche, Inc., has been appointed controller. He has been with Hoffman-La Roche since 1929.

MANILA, Oct. 31 -- Roughly 5,000,000 Filipinos are scheduled to go to the polls Nov. 10 to vote their preferences in the most contentious Presidential election in Philippine history. The candidates are now engaged in final campaign tours, and the rivalries have reached a maximum stage of intensity.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 31 -- Washington officials said Gerard B. Lambert, Princeton millionaire, was "crazy" fifteen years ago when he proposed to put low-cost housing on a sound business footing.

HAVANA -- The Island of Cuba, which Columbus 461 years ago called "the fairest land that human eyes have ever seen," is making the greatest bid in its history to attract the eyes of tourists from the United States during the coming winter season.

HOMER is said to have died of vexation at not being able to solve a riddle. We don't take them so seriously today, but swapping riddles is still one of the most popular -- and merriest -- pastimes among children and young people.
SINGAPORE, Oct. 31 -- Richard G. Casey, Australian Minister of External Affairs, said in Singapore today he believed that the Communists in Malaya and Indo-China were directed from Peiping.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti -- Haiti is inviting American tourists to come down here this winter to help celebrate the 150th anniversary of her dramatic birth as an independent republic, the second in the Western Hemisphere. In preparation, Haiti has spent $7,000,000 to provide its most historic city, Cap Haitien, with modern touches without sacrificing its picturesque French colonial charm.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 31 -- A prized collection of thirty-six Italian and Spanish Renaissance paintings donated by the Samuel H. Kress collection has been placed on exhibit by the Museum of Fine Arts here.

THE accolade of a full-dress biography is not too rare a distinction these days for actors, since that badge of achievement has been accorded in recent seasons to Charlie Chaplin and Douglas Fairbanks Sr., among others. "The Oliviers" is, nevertheless, a well-deserved tribute to a remarkably talented couple -- and, incidentally, to the author's research, scholarship and knowledge of his subjects.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 31 -- A key to the way the changing Moslem world may go politically in the next few decades is being forged in the Constituent Assembly of Pakistan, largest of the Islamic nations.

LONDON, Oct. 31 (UP) -- West Bromwich Albion, which had the only all-victorious road record, lost at Blackpool by 4 -- 1 today as muddy fields caused a number of upsets in English League soccer. West Bromwich's first division lead was reduced to two points as Wolverhampton won.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Billy Maxwell of Odessa, Tex., and Frank Stranahan of Toledo fought their way through the quarter-finals and semi-finals today and will meet tomorrow for the Mexican amateur golf championship.

Outplayed during the first quarter, Far Rockaway High School's unbeaten eleven went on a scoring rampage to crush Jefferson, 53 -- 6, yesterday on the winner's gridiron. Dave Intrabartolo led the Sea Horses to their fourth victory in five outings, one of which was a tie.

The Korean war ended formally for Pan American World Airways yesterday, when the line made the last Pacific airlift flight.
Onondaga Lake at Syracuse will be the scene again of the intercollegiate rowing regatta in 1954. The date is June 19.

The appointment of Dr. Courtney Craig Smith, president of Swarthmore College, as a director of the John and Mary R. Markle Foundation of New York was announced yesterday. The foundation supports charitable and medical research projects.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Congressional and Treasury staff experts were reported near agreement today on a plan to give taxpayers bigger deductions for medical expenses.

MIAMI BEACH -- Hotel and apartment house operators here are wagering $10,000,000 on the 1953-54 winter vacationist. This is the approximate total of improvements, new facilities and buildings put up since last winter and being readied for the coming season.

THE rolling plains of Oklahoma give way to the richly wooded Ozarks. The little asphalt tongue of a single landing strip comes suddenly into view. And you are in Fayetteville, Ark., a town of 12,000 population and seat of the State University.

ONE thoroughly contemporary reader would like to take exception to John W. Aldridge's review of "The Deep Sleep" by Wright Morris. The review is a perfect exemplar of the current attitude that a book cannot be "important" unless it is negative.

IT will come as a surprise to many gardeners to learn that the fabulous night-blooming cereus of the tropics can be grown as a pot plant here in the North. What is more, there are several hybrids of this showy and unusual member of the otherwise well-known cacti clan.

NOW that gardens are no longer prodigal with bloom, and shops must be relied on to supply blossoms and greens for the home, it would seem sensible to try to keep arrangements of cut flowers as long as possible.

ALTHOUGH the film buyers are not frenzied these days, trading has been brisk in some sectors and authors may still look to Hollywood for a reasonable return on their efforts. Last week, for example, Twentieth Century-Fox parted with a reported $35,000 for movie rights to "Tigrero!" the autobiography by Sasha Siemel published just the other day by Prentice-Hall.
KISSIMMEE, Fla. -- Cattle have become a tourist attraction in Florida. This cow town, eighteen miles south of Orlando on US 17-92, has the authentic atmosphere of the cattle range.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 31 -- Detectives armed with "John Doe" warrants raided a Tenth Ward Democratic club early today, seized 10,000 copies of a political circular entitled "Pin-point," and arrested five men on charges of circulating libelous and inflammatory literature.
Television receiver distributors and stores have one thing in common with automobile dealers. All three groups are badly oversupplied and must sell their products quickly to avoid heavy losses.

TELEVISION is the wonder of our century to some -- and a symbol of its paranoia to others; whether it is a blessing or a torture, it is certainly here to stay. Alfred Bester, an active worker in the TV foundries on the allegedly creative side, faces up squarely to that dilemma in this corrosive, frequently strident but almost always engrossing novel.

Trans-Atlantic passenger steamship lists from Jan. 1 to the present are running about 23,500 more passengers than for the same period of 1952. Nevertheless, barring a tremendous and unexpected spurt in bookings, they will fall far short of the 1,000,000-person volume predicted for 1953.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Officials here are discussing the question of rearming West Germany within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as one way out of the dilemma in which British defense planners find themselves.

A NOVEL about school teachers, "The End of the Week" has a ring of authority that will not be questioned by anyone whose contact with the scholastic world extends beyond attendance at a P. T. A. dance. Virginia Chase presents thirteen heroines -- thirteen teachers struggling through the nightmare of politics, red tape, misused authority, overcrowding and low salaries that characterize so many public schools.

Turning to New Orleans, the country's second most active winter cruise port, the traveler will find that sailings there have been augmented this year by the French Line's Antilles, a sister ship of the Flandre, normally in the West Indies service.
The little man who isn't there is still one of the biggest problems facing American industry.

FKIH-BENSALAH, French Morocco, Oct. 23 -- The Tadla Plain is for the most part a scorched and desolate stretch of territory known locally as the Crematory of Morocco. But a fever of expectancy has come over this place because in the Atlas Mountains to the southeast an artificial lake fifteen miles long is rising behind the great new Bin el Ouidane Dam.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization today approved Federal tax benefits to assist American Pipe Line Corporation construct a $144,000,000 project.

Some time between now and, say, 2053 the boys at General Electric and General Motors had darned well better solve the remaining problems of space flight. Even before that time, the way things are going, this world will have to get rid of quite a few hundreds of millions of its inhabitants and deportation to the planets -- if any -- about Alpha Centauri is probably more humane than war.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- How to negotiate seventy-five yards within twenty-one ticks of the clock -- that was the problem that confronted the Giants in the closing seconds of the National Football League game against the Cardinals at Comiskey Park today.

Celebrating Reformation Sunday yesterday, New York's Protestant ministers called for an awakening of the protesting spirit of Martin Luther that challenges authority without fear. They also reaffirmed the doctrine that there is no separation between the individual and God.

Three New York representatives urged the United States Government last night to exercise its influence in the United Nations to bring about a permanent peace settlement between Israel and the Arab States.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams spotted the Detroit Lions a 10-point lead, caught and passed them in the third period and went on to whip them, 37 -- 24, today in a game marked by spectacular long-scoring plays. A crowd of 93,751 watched.

NISHINOMIYA, Japan, Nov. 1 (UP) -- Bob Lemon's pitching and a salvo of four home runs gave Ed Lopat's major league all-stars an 8-2 victory over a Pacific League pickup team today before a crowd of 55,000.
A song recital of rare distinction was sung by Jussi Bjoerling, tenor, at Hunter College Saturday evening. The concert was the first event of the subscription series being presented by the college.

BONN, Germany, Monday, Nov. 2 -- An unofficial count of the returns in Hamburg's municipal elections yesterday showed early this morning that a bloc composed of the four parties of the Bonn Government coalition had won 62 of the 120 seats in the City Assembly.

A few weeks ago this correspondent listened to a German expatiate on his experience as a prisoner of war in the United States. Though he now has a good job in Germany he looked back nostalgically on the years he spent in a POW camp in this country, describing them with fervor as "the best years of my life."
The lightest vote in a contest for Mayor of New York since 1933 is in prospect for tomorrow's election.

Downtown Boston, whose streets were, it is said, laid out by the meandering of the cows from the Common, is far from dead as a retail center. The Boston woman, who seldom lives in Boston but all the way from Lynn to Brookline, "the world's richest village," goes to Washington and Milk and Boylston Streets for her luxury and style shopping.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 1 -- It was worth the trip to see two fine teams in action -- meaning Notre Dame's first and second teams. The Navy varsity might have been able to hold its own against the second platoon but it couldn't begin to contain the green-shirted behemoths on the Irish varsity. They move with the speed and the fierce, irresistible drive of enraged water buffaloes.
LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The stock markets have demonstrated their inherent strength in the last week.

Putting the goalie out of the nets worked for the Toronto Maple Leafs last night. With time running out on them and faced by a one-goal deficit, the Northerners' resort to the strategy of mass attact enabled them to score the goal that gave them a 2-to-2 tie with the New York Rangers.
The three principal candidates for Mayor struggled yesterday over the problem of "Mr. X." in their political equation, but they did not reach a solution.
CAIRO, Nov. 1 -- The Sudan will step onto the threshhold of self-government tomorrow.

PARIS, Nov. 1 -- Thanks to United States supplementary aid, French outlays for defense in 1954 will be cut, while the effort for equipping new divisions in Indo-China will be increased by 68,000,000,000 francs ($197,200,000).

New Yorkers will pay a penny a quart more for milk beginning tomorrow. The increase will add more than $14,000,000 a year to milk bills in the metropolitan area. The price rise was announced as milk deliveries spurted back to normal after the six-day strike that ended Saturday morning.
We summarize here our recommendations regarding questions and candidates to be voted upon tomorrow.

The American Labor party, which has Clifford T. McAvoy as its candidate for Mayor, urged yesterday a negative vote on proposed Amendment 8 to the State Constitution. This amendment would raise the limit of the tax on real estate in New York City from 2 per cent to 2 1/2 per cent of assessed valuation.
AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 1 -- King Hussein, 18-year-old ruler of Jordan, declared today that his country would continue to champion the policy of no compromise between Israel and the Arab States.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1 -- When all the figures are in they will show that steel tonnage turned out in October was about 9,500,000 tons, compared with 8,913,000 in September. That was a better showing than most observers expected. The predicted decline for the early part of the third quarter was less than had been forecast.

ILOILO, the Philippines, Nov. 1 -- Impartial observers of the pre-election scene in this Visayan city of 100,000 persons describe the situation as gray. Traditionally Iloilo and its hinterland have had peaceful elections which were considered relatively honest, but this year the rivalries are the bitterest ever known and there may be violence and attempts at fraud in the voting on Nov. 10.

Controller Lazarus Joseph made public yesterday his eighth and final annual report on the city's financial operations. Covering the fiscal year 1952-53, the 416-page document presented a statistical picture of a city financially sound as of last June 30.

The Rev. Dr. Harold C. DeWindt, for the last eleven years pastor of the West-Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, has accepted a call to the pastorate of the Kirk-in-the-Hills at Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

Prices of cotton futures in the domestic market moved over a fairly wide range last week, but closed Friday with relatively moderate changes. Final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to $1.05 a bale higher. Gains mostly were limited to the near-by options.

The former Ward baking plant, a new building containing more than 200,000 square feet of space at 800 Pacific Street, in Brooklyn, has been sold to the Pechter Baking Company for service on Long Island and in Brooklyn and Manhattan.

In the communication from Alexander Kerensky which you printed in your issue of Oct. 9 he discusses the position taken by the American Committee for Liberation From Bolshevism in the conflict between the two groupings within the Coordinating Center of the anti-Bolshevik emigres.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- A total of $101,500,000,000 was spent at all levels of government in the United States during the fiscal year that ended June 30, 1952.

Wilbur and Orville Wright never wrote the story of their invention of the airplane, but they left thirty-three diaries and many letters which Marvin McFarland has now edited into two volumes for McGraw-Hill publication on Nov. 24.

Man's vocation to become a saint and man's function as a member of the "communion of saints" were discussed in sermons commemorating the Feast of All Saints yesterday in the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).
Arthur E. Johnson has been appointed credit manager of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The head of the Commission on Intergovernmental Relations said today that any shift in governmental and tax functions it might recommend contemplated no reduction in present services.

Robert F. Wagner Jr. and his running mates made public yesterday the principles by which they propose to guide the city government. The Democratic candidate for Mayor issued his platform jointly with Lawrence E. Gerosa, candidate for Controller, and Abe Stark, nominee for President of the City Council.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- President Eisenhower's political prestige is on the line in four major electoral contests in three states this week.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 -- Mental and emotional disturbances affect 20 to 25 per cent of workers, Dr. George S. Stevenson, medical director of the National Association for Mental Health, said here today.
Under a grant of $150,000 announced yesterday by the Carnegie Corporation of New York, basic factors in the economic development of Africa will be studied.

Fundamental changes in the method of paying for future sewers in the city were proposed yesterday by Borough President James A. Lundy of Queens. He charged that the existing assessment procedure was designed in "horse and buggy days." More than one-fifth of Queens and more than half of Richmond do not yet have public sewers.
The National City Bank in its letter for November finds that business generally has held up better than expected.

Almost every civilization, every nation and every institution, however unimportant or ephemeral, can be seen in historical retrospect to have enjoyed its own Golden Age, using that phrase in a purely relative sense.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 1 -- Israel's natural wealth will begin to pay off to the country next year, according to the Government's plan for the development of mineral resources.

There is rich irony in Moscow's current attempt to use Field Marshal Friedrich Paulus, the loser at Stalingrad, in the campaign to win Germany. Last week the Communist East German radio announced that Paulus had finally been allowed to return and would live in East Germany.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 1 -- Oswaldo Aranha, Minister of Finance, is the target of strong criticism over the new foreign exchange plan instituted last month with a sliding scale of rates.

I have before me your editorial with reference to the Coliseum that appeared in THE TIMES of Oct. 26. I am the nominal plaintiff in the lawsuit, and represent many property owners and tenants in the area. Your attention is respectfully called to the fact that time, which was not of the essence for approximately ten years, has apparently suddenly become very important.

CHATHAM, N. J., Nov. 1 -- A 17-year-old high school student who was turned away today when he called to take a girl classmate to the movies reappeared later at the house with a pistol and killed her father and wounded her mother and her brother.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor declared today that women's efforts in the 1952 Presidential campaign had won for them an "increased respect as participants in party politics."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- President Eisenhower is running into trouble again on the tariff problem.

The Vermont twang mingled with the accents of Harlem yesterday in a worship service and dinner here. It marked the tenta anniversary of the Vermont Inter-Racial Project, and was conducted jointly by the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street, and the United Church of Colchester, Vt.

HYDE PARK, N. Y., Nov. 1--The King and Queen of the Hellenes broke the bonds of a split-second schedule today and roamed for nearly an hour over the grounds of the Roosevelt estate. Their presence gave vast delight to hundreds of tourists who had had no idea the royal visitors were coming.
The chaotic conferences that preceded the settlement of the milk strike were an object lesson in the folly of round-the-clock negotiations to end industrial disputes.

In Brooklyn anything can happen, and this made Leroy Wooten, 35, a long-time Brooklynite of 25 MacDougal Street, very sad early yesterday. Wearing handcuffs while drinking coffee -- it could happen suddenly to anybody . . .
A. Rogers Maynard, Charles A. Siegfried, and John J. Sutter have been appointed second vice presidents of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

The electric news sign in Times Square will be twenty-five years old this week. Making its debut on Nov. 6, 1928, the night of the Hoover-Smith election, the sign has been a Broadway hit ever since as it rotates in five-foot golden letters around The Times Tower All the News That's Fit to Print.

The Concert Society of New York, which presented Elizabeth Schwarzkopf, soprano, at its first concert at Town Hall last Sunday, gave its subscribers a second concert of musical distinction yesterday, when it presented the Pro Musica Antiqua of Brussels, under the direction of its American-born founder, Safford Cape.

It was family week for the Casadesus' with the New York Philharmonic. On Thursday and yesterday, Robert Casadesus was soloist in Saint-Saens' Fourth Piano Concerto. On Saturday evening his son, Jean, was heard as piano soloist in Mozart's Concerto in C (K. 467). Too bad that Jean's mother, Gaby, did not join the proceedings somewhere along the line.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The color line in jobs has not changed much in the upper South in fifteen years, a survey reported today.

MADRID, Nov. 1 -- Spain's Primate gave assurances today that the Roman Catholic Church in this country would not oppose a policy of military and economic collaboration between this Catholic state and the United States.

PETER FREUCHEN has called his autobiography "Vagrant Viking"* and the title is apt. No real viking in the days of Harold Bluetooth could have had a more passionate love of adventure than this mighty modern Dane. For forty-seven years, ever since he was 20, Mr. Freuchen has been rushing off to fabulous adventures north of the Arctic Circle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Veterans of Foreign Wars today accused the president of the American Medical Association of misrepresentation in saying that 85 per cent of veterans in V. A. hospitals are non-service-connected cases.

In these our troubled times grim dramas hold the stage, and while the curtain is up the actors come to the footlights, their voices hoarse with destiny, their faces threatening doom. But between the acts there are lighter moments, played out in the aisles and in the crowded lobby.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 1 -- Formal discussions between the United States and Pakistan looking to a military alliance are expected to follow the visit of the Governor General with President Eisenhower in Washington Nov. 12.

Steps are being acceIerated by the League of New York Theatres in its fight to have the 20 per cent Federal admission tax repealed. This was confirmed yesterday by James F. Reilly, executive director of the league, who said that Ralph E. Becker, a lawyer with Washington experience, had been engaged to formulate plans before Congress convenes in January.

Rudolph Halley renewed his barrage against Robert F. Wagner Jr. yesterday, charging him with desiring to keep the books closed on his running-mate, Lawrence E. Gerosa, "in a matter concerning bribery of public officials and falsification of records."

A room full of historians, writers and publishers listened fascinated yesterday afternoon while a mild-mannered, elderly textile executive discussed the hobby that has made him an expert on what Abraham Lincoln looked like.
Constant adult urging to compete with others is one of the biggest school problems some teen-agers face, according to Charles Cook, head worker at the University Settlement Society.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 1 -- Mrs. Peter Frelinghuysen's toy poodle, Ch. Smilestone's Fancy Fee, became best-in-show at the fifteenth annual event of the Union County Kennel Club today. The Morristown, N, J., candidate was put up by Mrs. Geraldine R. Dodge of Madison, N. J., to end the 650-dog show at the Elizabeth Armory.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today that a security official of the Army's top loyalty board would be called before his committee for questioning about alleged Communist affiliations. The Senator "spoke of the official as suspended."

THE arrangements which I had made with the President in the summer [of 1944] to divide our responsibilities for looking after particular countries affected by the movements of the armies had tided us over the three months for which our agreement ran. But as the autumn drew on everything in Eastern Europe became more intense.
Harold Riegelman, Republican nominee for Mayor, recapitulated yesterday in an election eve statement the program of his "good government forces" for the city.
Throughout the garment center, Maurice Rentner is known as the "Little Napoleon" -- little because he is small of stature, Napoleon because he is a fearless man of vision who believes in himself.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 1--Yugoslavia made known today her readiness to participate in a conference on Trieste, even if the decision to turn Zone A of Trieste over to Italy is not revoked.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 1 (AP)--Rudolf Roessler, one of Russia's master spies of World War II, goes on trial here tomorrow charged with organizing a far-flung espionage system against the Western powers on behalf of the Czechoslovak secret service.

The United Hospital Fund this year is seeking $3,500,000 in contributions from persons who live and work in New York City. As in former years, gifts to the fund will be distributed among eightyone member voluntary, nonprofit hospitals to help them continue services essential to individual and community health.

A syndicate of investors headed by Karl Klein, attorney, has purchased the apartment house for 210 families at 144-02 Seventy-eighth Road, Kew Gardens, Queens, from Leo Bercow and Walter Berger, operators. Charles H. Kelman was the attorney for the sellers of the development, which covers one and one-half square blocks and is assessed at $1,320,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 -- A "blood bank treatment" in the form of increased cargo handling performance and reduced costs in every category was prescribed today for the intercoastal steamship trade. This segment of shipping was described as "slowly bleeding to death as a result of excessive operating costs."
BERLIN, Nov. 1 -- Friedrich Paulus, former field marshal general in command of German troops at Stalingrad, appeared today to be about to enter the stage of East German politics.

DETROIT, Nov. 1 (UP) -- Ted Lindsay scored a pair of second-period goals tonight to lead the Detroit Red Wings to a 5-to-1 victory over the front-running Montreal Canadiens before 12,305 fans at the Olympia.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 1 -- An increase in the consumption of tea in the United States has had tremendously beneficial effect on Ceylon's economy.

TEHERAN, Nov. 1 -- The Iranian Government, with the assistance of United States technicians, will build a 500-unit low-cost housing development in Teheran as part of a $2,000,000 program of public works financed by United States emergency aid.

THE NEW YORK TIMES will furnish complete radio coverage of the election on Tuesday night through the facilities of WQXR and WQXR-FM. Other FM affiliates of the WQXR network, including all those in New York State, also will carry the returns.

Extremists of all hues dislike the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), perhaps because extremism has no use for the search for truth or the appeal to reason. The Soviet Union, for instance, has never belonged to UNESCO and the three satellite countries that did belong have resigned.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 1 -- The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization reported today it had made steady progress in 1952-53 in fifty-two countries toward producing more food for the world.
TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 2 -- The Indian command in custody of Korean war prisoners canceled talks scheduled today between the Communists and North Korean captives.

The carefully devised program Victoria de los Angeles sang last night in Carnegie Hall to a near-capacity audience was for the most part beautifully suited to her capabilities. Miss de los Angeles is not the most convincing exponent of lieder, and these were kept to a minimum.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 1 -- Bette Davis is expected to return to Hollywood in February to star in "The Big Casino," to be produced independently by Robert Lord in association with Jacques Braunstein, New York tax attorney.
The many group and one-man exhibitions opening this week indicate that the art season is well under way.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Quarterback Bobby Thomason hit his receivers with ease today to lead the Philadelphia Eagles to a 35-7 victory over Pittsburgh. The result dropped the Steelers to third place and moved the Eagles to second in the Eastern Confernece of the National Football League.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 1 -- Several Southern Governors agreed today that President Eisenhower's popularity as a "party leader" and that of the Republican party were waning.

Shipowners and cargo shippers ended last week's charter tug-of-war in a stand-off. The shippers were paying about the same rates as a week earlier to send their goods and the shipowners were getting a bit more business.

The appointment of Joseph Lilly as public relations counsel to the Real Estate Board of New York was announced yesterday by Clinton W. Blume, president. Mr. Lilly has served, in a similar post with the State Rent Control Commission since it was formed three and one-half years ago.
PARIS, Nov. 1 -- As the laborious process of constructing new United States base facilities in Spain gets under way, many administrative problems are posed.

PARIS, Nov. 1 -- Signs of a real recovery have been noticed in French textiles, one of the industries most seriously affected by the sales decline since 1952. Textile exports, which were only 12.1 per cent of French exports in 1952, have risen to 15.5 per cent for the first nine months of 1953.

ZURICH, Nov. 1 -- For the first time since World War II the price of gold on the free markets of Europe fell last week to below $36 an ounce. The price in Zurich yesterday was $35.80. Dealers always have declared that trading in gold on the free market would not pay unless the price was at least $36.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UP) -- The League of Women Voters urged the Administration today to continue United States technical aid to under-developed nations with "substantial" funds and a non-political emphasis.

Frank L. Boyden, headmaster at Deerfield Academy, certainly gets around. One of New England's leading educators, Boyden keeps his hand in numerous fields that range from athletics to politics although he is approaching his seventy-fifth birthday.
In his sermon yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral the Rev. Charles J. McManus told the congregation that the Holy Spirit shaped their spiritual decisions in the direction of salvation.

The Soviet Government has decided to expand substantially the activities of free peasant markets, one of the few major areas of the Soviet economy not under direct Government control, recent issues of the Moscow press reveal. The aim is to encourage collective farms and collective farmers to supply much more food for Soviet consumers through direct sale than ever before.

TRENTON, Nov. 1 -- When 2,000,000 registered voters in New Jersey go to the polls Tuesday to elect a Governor and other candidates, one of the most bitterly contested political campaigns in this state in recent years will be ended.
FIRST reception of colored television in one's own home, which became a reality with Saturday evening's telecast of "Carmen," produces a host of varying impressions on the viewer.
Five new films, including an import from Italy, are slated to ar rive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
It is hard to say upon whom--parent, teacher or pupil--American Education Week is the greatest strain.
New accessories for the home and for the people in it have recently arrived from Mexico and may be found at two shops here.

NEW DELHI, India Nov. 1 -- Prime Minister Jawaharal Nehru declared in Patna today that India would not withdraw her custodian force from Korea although the troops were facing considerable difficulty in persuading the North Korean and Chinese prisoners to listen to Communist "explanation" teams.
All voting tomorrow in the city's 4,217 polling places and in the 6,141 election districts outside of the five boroughs will be done by machine.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Grain futures showed a strong undertone last week. But on the extreme upturns offerings increased, while demand from shorts appeared to have been satisfied.
AMSTERDAM, Nov. 1 -- Non-interest bearing bankers' balances with the Netherlands Bank last week rose a further 106,000,000 to 506,000,000 guilders.

WAILUKU, Hawaii, Nov. 1 (UP) -- Former Police Lt. Louis Shoulders, who solved the Greenlease kidnap slaying, flew to the Hawaiian island of Maui today, hoping to "settle down" with his St. Louis landlady.

VIENNA, Nov. 1 -- From a book by Foreign Minister Karl Gruber, to be published here soon, the Vienna newspaper Die Presse gave today purported details of the 1947 Moscow conference of Foreign Ministers. This parley discussed peace treaties for Austria and Germany.

The apartment house for twenty families at 4357 Vireo Avenue, the Bronx, has been resold by Phillip P. Zipes, operator, to an investor in a deal negotiated by Allan S. Feldman Co., brokers. The tax valuation is $91,000.
The Detroit Steel Corporation reported a rise in its profit to $4,695,045 in the first nine months this year from $3,010,975 in the 1952 period.

GENEVA, Nov. 1 -- Switzerland has offered to provide a haven for ninety tubercular refugees now in Trieste. In one stroke this would solve the most pressing problem faced by the Allied authorities concerned about the future of 4,500 refugees in that troubled city.

In his statement reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 26 David Ben-Gurion assigns the recent diplomatic failures of his Israeli Government to "something that happened 2,000 years ago in this very country" (Palestine).
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 (UP) -- The San Francisco Forty-Niners scored 21 points in the first half and then hung on to whip the Chicago Bears, 24 -- 14, today in a game marked by numerous penalties.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Five top foreign thoroughbreds bound for Laurel race track and Saturday's second running of the $65,000 Washington, D. C. International, were delayed today when bad weather kept their plane on the ground in England.

The battle between Protestant and Roman Catholic forces in New Jersey over legalizing bingo, raffles and other games of chance to support public causes reached its climax yesterday in a barrage of pulpit politics.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 1 (AP) -- -- Billy Maxwell of Odessa, Tex., today won the Mexican amateur golf championship by defeating Frank Stranahan of Toledo, 8 and 6.
LANGLEY, Va., Nov. 1 (UP) -- Randolph Leigh, author, explorer and former newspaper publisher, shot and killed his wife today and hanged himself after a family quarrel, the police said.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, Nov. 2 -- The Communist attitude in the preliminary Korean peace talks here, Arthur H. Dean, United States envoy, told the Reds today "leaves doubt in our minds that you really want a political conference."
The Royal Canadian Mounted Police, who will present their intricate maneuvers at the sixty-fifth National Horse Show opening tomorrow at Madison Square Garden, will arrive here this morning.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 1 -- Iran is preparing to resume talks with the Soviet Union on frontier and financial disputes. These were interrupted in mid-August by the overthrow of former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh and his replacement by Premier Fazlollah Zahedi.
The campaign for the election of a Mayor of New York will end today, with supporters of Robert F. Wagner Jr., Democratic candidate, confident of his election tomorrow.

A steady tone for the British pound sterling and continued strength in the Canadian dollar marked the trading in foreign exchanges last week. Volume of business in the pound was moderate while that for the dollar was fairly heavy.
LANGLEY, Va., Nov. 1 (UP) -- Randolph Leigh, author, explorer and former newspaper publisher, shot and killed his wife today and hanged himself after a family quarrel, the police said.
