At her local debut last year Alyne Dumas Lee, soprano, revealed her gifts as an interpreter, but her second New York recital last night at Town Hall showed that the first had not given any adequaet idea of the capacity of her voice.

Hayato Ikeda, who represented Japanese Premier Yoshida, is on the way back to Tokyo after a series of conferences with officials in Washington. His mission, as might be expected, is being attacked as a failure by extremist parties of both left and right in Japan but it is being defended both by the Government's party and by the more conservative splinter groups.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (UP)--Chicago's Black Hawks and the Boston Bruins battled to a scoreless tie tonight in a game marked by a fight between the rival coaches.
A proposal to modernize the war-built Liberty ships as a defense bulwark and to create shipyard employment was criticized by shipping men here over the week-end.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Army refused to comment tonight on reports that a member of a loyalty-security review board had been suspended.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Three times in the second half, the unbeaten Cleveland Browns turned breaks into touchdowns and whipped the Washington Redskins, 27 -- 3, today. It was the Browns' sixth straight National Football League victory.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- A charge that an organized effort was afoot to "discredit and destroy" Ezra Taft Benson introduced a new element tonight into the farm situation.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Pakistan's decision to become a republic was greeted with equanimity tonight in London. It was pointed out here that the change had been fore-shadowed a year ago in a report by the Pakistan Basic Principles Committee.

In one of the heaviest passenger movements of the waning trans-Atlantic travel season, 5,924 tourists debarked here yesterday from six liners bound in from Continental European and Mediterranean ports. Their numbers were swelled by 294 on four vessels from South America.

Pioneer studies on the prevalence of hardening of the arteries in a random sample of a large population have revealed "an unusually high frequency of the condition in both men and women above the age of 40."

JERUSALEM, Nov. 2 (UP) -- Anexplosion today wrecked the main pipeline serving the Arab section of this divided city and cut off its water supply. It was the latest act in a chain of violence that has threatened the truce between Arabs and Israelis.
Frank Costello sought permission yesterday in Federal Court to leave the jurisdiction to prepare for his Dec. 7 income tax evasion trial. Judge Edward A. Conger set tomorrow for argument.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 2 -- A high official announced tonight the discovery of a plot of Iranian Communists and extreme nationalist supporters of former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh to paralyze Teheran with a five-day general strike beginning Friday.
Notre Dame topped the United Press college football ratings yesterday for the sixth straight week. The Irish point-total was just 6 short of a perfect score.
Helicopters hovered and turned dizzily in a clear sky over the Battery in downtown Manhattan yesterday as New York opened its week-long celebration of the Fiftieth Anniversary of Powered Flight.

No man to avoid a fight, Secretary of Agriculture Benson has plunged headlong into another major battle with the drastic reorganization of the Soil Conservation Service, which he ordered into effect yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Eisenhower Administration shouldered aside mounting criticism on the operation of the Department of Agriculture today and made "effective immediately" a departmental plan of reorganization.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- "The administration of our criminal law, from one cause or another, is a humiliation and a discredit to our profession and our country," Robert H. Jackson, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, declared here today.
Evidence of thriftiness among children in this city is shown by a survey on their attitude toward money matters.
A free testing clinic for motorists was opened yesterday in the Port Authority Bus Terminal at Eighth Avenue and Fortieth Street. It is being conducted by the Greater New York Safety Council.

At least 1,119,000 residents of this city can disregard any appeal that they go to the polls today. If they did go they couldn't vote, for though they registered last year they did not register this year. An indefinite additional number can't vote, either, for they didn't register in 1953, just as they didn't in 1952.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Tuesday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The neutral camp where twenty-two United States prisoners of war wait restlessly was pictured today as a valley of fear. And only fear keeps possibly nineteen of them from asking to go home.
LONDON, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- Trade Minister Peter Thorneycroft told bankers here tonight that Great Britain had reached a period of great peril in the export field.
Thirty-eight local housing authorities have invited bids on Nov. 10 for $130,149,000 in temporary loan notes, its has been announced by the Public Housing Authority.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 2 -- Eugene Monahan, 44 years old, an ex-convict, was found guilty of first-degree murder tonight by a jury that deliberated an hour and thirty-five minutes. The verdict was given although Dr. Lawrence M. Collins, clinical director of the State Hospital at Greystone Park, had testified that Monahan was insane.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion tonight announced his intention of resigning the premiership at a meeting of the political committee of his Mapai party.
The North Atlantic Treaty Organization is entering the winter of its discontent.

When I read the news item in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 16, and thereafter the editorial "Children's Court" of the 17th, I felt, though I was not at all well, that I should express myself not only with regard to the editorial, with the purpose of which I am in agreement, but particularly the basis of both the article and the editorial.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- A cloak of secrecy surrounds reported heavy gold purchases from the Soviet Union by Britain. The gold traffic here is strictly controlled by the Bank of England and a bank spokesman said tonight that operations in this field "are a secret matter."

Mary Bothwell, Canadian-born soprano, who has given frequent recitals here since her debut fifteen years ago, was heard last night at Town Hall. Accompanied by Paul Meyers she sang the Immolation Scene front Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung," two groups of lieder by Schubert and a group by Hugo Wolf.
The city began yesterday a new investigation into milk prices. The inquiry got under way as New Yorkers started paying a cent a quart more for the 4,000,000 quarts of milk they drink each day.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit appealed today to women of all nations to build toward peace through willingness to hear both sides of international points of view. American women particularly have much to contribute to such a policy, the president of the United nations General Assembly said, through American pride in the diverse elements that make it a nation.

Rocky Casillo, Chicago welterweight, registered a technical knockout over the favored Danny Giovanelli of Brooklyn in 2:37 of the last round of the main bout scheduled for ten sessions at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. Casillo weighed 147 pounds, Giovanelli 147 1/2.

" The Joe Louis Story," which arrives at the Holiday Theatre, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The independently made biographical drama, which was filmed here in its entirely, stars Coley Wallace, a contender for the heavyweight championship, in his first screen role, as Joe Louis.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- An advance in most soybean futures to new highs for the season stimulated buying of wheat and rye. The exception was the November delivery. But corn was draggy, traders ignoring the strength in other grains because of increased hedge pressure. Buying of oats broadened as the demand for corn slackened and March and July oats registered new highs for the season.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Leslie J. Carver, acting director of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees, declared today that the welfare agency hoped this year to find jobs for 12,000 Arab refugees on new rehabilitation projects.

A striking demonstration of Germany's dedication to Chancellor Adenauer's European policy has been provided by the election in Hamburg, which ousted the Socialists from one of their few remaining strongholds and removed the last technical obstacles to final German ratification of the European Defense Community.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Government announced today the cancellation of its contract with the Westmoreland Manganese Corporation, Batesville, Ark., and the foreclosure of its mortgage on the company's uncompleted facilities.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 2 (AP) -- The foreign field for Saturday's $65,000 Washington, D. C., International race was completed tonight with the arrival by plane of four horses from England and the Continent and one from Argentina.
The General Council of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. warned yesterday against what it described as a growing tendency in this country to combat communism with "fanatical negativism."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- The United Nations Security Council posponed today for a second time consideration of a Soviet proposal to elect a governor of Trieste and establish the Free Territory on a permanent basis.

HUDSON, N. Y., Nov. 2 (AP) -- A county judge declared unconstitutional today a section of the state motor vehicle law holding a truck driver responsible for the weight of his load, even though he might not have known the vehicle was overloaded.

City College opened practice for the 1953-54 basketball season yesterday with a squad of thirty players. Eight are lettermen, two are returning servicemen and one a transfer student, Jack McGuire of Queens College. Jerry Domershick is starting his third season as C. C. N. Y. court captain.

The elections that began in the Sudan yesterday represent what might be called a calculated risk. The voters will be largely illiterate, scattered over 1,000,000 square miles of territory with bad communications, and personally separated by religious, racial and social differences.

George C. Sherman Jr., of New York was re-elected president of the Indoor Polo Association of America at the annual meeting held at the Racquet and Tennis Club. Sherman was named for the eighth time. He is also vice chairman of the United States Polo Association, outdoor governing body.

Two nations women's magazines are jubilant over the report by the Department of Labor that more than half the country's 19,000,000 working women were married and that 27 per cent of all married women hold jobs.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 3 -- Arthur H. Dean, United Nations representative to a meeting with the Communists at Panmunjom, Korea, urged the Reds today to share their views with him on essential arrangements for a Korean peace conference.

Impasse of the Valley Farm Stable made a "one-horse" event of the Borrow Handicap, the classified race that served as the feature on the card of the Empire City Racing Association at Jamaica yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- A mild outbreak of triskaidekaphobia momentarily swept a sixty-member United Nations committee here today. Triskaidekaphobia is a word coined from the Greek by anti-superstition experts and means fear of the number thirteen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today there was "a definite possibility" of unity with the Congress of Industrial Organizations but not with John L. Lewis' United Mine Workers because, "good Lord, he's the fellow who split the A. F. L."
Confident of victory, Robert F. Wagner Jr. pleaded last night with New York voters to give him and his running mates overwhelming pluralities in today's election.
The text of the letter issued yesterday by the General Council of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. to members of 8,000 congregations throughout the country follows:

AS our armies moved eastwards and southwards it became increasingly urgent to set up a unified and broadly representative Administration in France. We were anxious not to impose a ready-made Committee from abroad, and we tried first to gauge the feelings of the people themselves as the liberation progressed.

ALBANY, Nov. 2 -- The state government moved one step closer today to its long-sought goal of building the $600,000,000 St. Lawrence power project as a public development. This will be done jointly with Canada's Province of Ontario.

A Federal judge signed a permanent injunction last night prohibiting the old International Longshoremen's Association from interfering with the organizing activities of its American Federation of Labor rival.

TORONTO, Ont., Nov. 2 -- Representatives of 12,000 Ontario pulp and paper workers formally rejected today the majority report of a conciliation board, which had recommended against any wage increases.

The East will get a look at football's wonder team this week. The coming of Notre Dame to Franklin Field, Philadelphia, to play Pennsylvania inevitably brings to mind the appearance there of Khute Rockne's Fighting Irish of 1930.
Harold Riegelman declared last night that the election of Robert F. Wagner Jr. would bring a rise in subway fares to 20 or 25 cents in the next four years.

The contemporary urban architect strives desperately to convince the public that he is both "utilitarian" and "functional" in his design efforts. These catch-all words represent the criteria for successful public relations. By definition alone they are commendable achievements.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 2 (AP) -- A national business leader told some of his colleagues today that "the psychological reaction of consumers" would largely determine whether business would keep on booming or slip into recession.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The Labor party will continue to urge a high level Big Four meeting as a means of preventing a reversion to German barbarism by what it considers a revival of German arrogance.

Pinched between week-end and the Election Day holiday, stock market movements were limited yesterday. There was a small advance as some of the oils, chemicals, motors and aircrafts rose and managed to hold most of their gains, but the market as a whole was sluggish. Steels, rails and tobaccos were on the weak side.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Nov. 2 -- Joe Segel and Steve Legakis of Glen Head took the top honors in the Long Island Professional Golfers Association amateur-pro tournament today at the North Hempstead Country Club. They carded a best-ball 68 to lead the field of forty-five teams by a stroke.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- A good illustration of the revised concepts of what the United States Information Agency should do and avoid is provided in a statement recently made by its new director, Theodore C. Streibert, to the press. Answering a question about changed policies in broadcasts within the Iron Curtain he said:

In these days when billions of dollars are required for defense and hundreds of millions for almost any kind of economic aid, the sum of $6,700,000, which the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization is now spending in fifty-two countries, seems hardly worth mentioning.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 3 -- North Korean war prisoners filed peacefully into "explanation tents" in the Korean demilitarized zone this morning to hear Communist persuaders try to win back their loyalty.

The first rehearsal of the Metropolitan Opera. Orchestra, which hung in jeopardy during eight days of dispute between the opera and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, took place yesterday. The threat of a strike passed when an agreement was reached on Saturday.
A picture postcard mailed Sunday, Nov. 5, 1911, in Brooklyn reached the end of a six-mile journey to the Manhattan District Attorney's Office on Saturday, Oct. 31, 1953.

Many tickets have been purchased for the preopening performance tonight of "Kind Sir," with Mary Martin and Charles Boyer in the leading roles, at the Alvin Theatre, which is a benefit for the New York City Mission Society.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Nov. 2 -- Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay served notice on critics of the Administration's public land policy tonight that the Government's main objective would continue to be the gradual transfer of the public domain to private ownership.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- Voters in Cook County will cast about 1,000,000 ballots tomorrow in the county's first sharply contested judicial elections in thirty-two years.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Selwyn Lloyd, British Minister of State, declared tonight that the question of Communist China's admission to the United Nations should be reconsidered when "satisfactory progress" had been made at the Korean political conference.

EDITH, Sir Osbert and Sacheverell Sitwell, the three graces of aristocratic English letters, are often merged in the public mind into a collective personality. All three have worn an air of precocious brightness for something like thirty-five years. All three are versatile, erudite, haughty and eccentric. All three delight in smiting artistic Philistines, in arrang ingwords into patterns of Byzantine formality and oriental opulence, in defying the mandates of popular taste and current critical fashions.

THE NEW YORK TIMES will furnish tonight complete radio coverage of the election through the facilities of WQXR and WQXR-FM. Other FM affiliates of the WQXR network, including all those in New York State, also will, carry the returns.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- An apparent marked increase in homosexual offenses in Britain, coupled with recent court cases of such offenses involving men of high position, has troubled magistrates here and has alarmed the serious and responsible sections of the press.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 2 -- Herbert Hoover Jr., State Department oil consultant, said today that he had been "deeply impressed by the sincere desire of everyone I have talked with to find a dignified and constructive approach to the problem of Iranian oil."
Sales in October in twelve major New York department stores were 4 per cent below the level of the same month of 1952. This was ascertained by a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

YONKERS, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Volo Chief, 8-year-old Chief Abbedale pacer owned by Stanley Dancer of New Egypt, N. J., was driven to victory by his owner in the $3,500 Bear Mountain Pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway in 2:04 3/5 for the mile.

Victims of concentration camps will picket the offices of the Soviet delegation to the United Nations, Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street, next Saturday to mark the first observance of the Day of the Unknown Political Prisoner. They will carry signs with the names of the camps in which they suffered.

The November goal of the New York regional Red Cross blood program is 15,000 pints. In announcing this goal, T. Morgan Williams, program chairman, said yesterday that 18,057 pints had been collected in October. Half of this went to laboratories for national defense purposes and for processing into gamma globulin and half was used locally.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- A liberalized lending policy is likely at the Small Business Administration according to official sources.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- A working group was appointed today to seek a solution to the three-week deadlock over the proposal for a special United Nations economic development fund of $250,000,000.

" Those Perplexing Argentines," a portrait of a people by James Bruce, will be published Nov. 16 by Longmans, Green. The author, an American industrialist, was our Ambassador to the Argentine from 1947 to 1949. He has combined anecdote and characterization, fact and foible to present a story of the people and things that influence Argentine life.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- More than 600 movie-house owners and theatre-equipment men viewed, today new wonders of the cinema business, including machines that butter popcorn on delivery or serve it dry.
Declaration of a 3 per cent year-end stock dividend and record sales and earnings for the first nine months of 1953 were reported yesterday by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company:
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 (AP) -President Eisenhower has saved Tomoya (Meatball) Kawakita from death in the San Quentin Prison gas chamber.
The text of King Paul's remarks at the academic convocation at Columbia University yesterday follows:

Two phases of modern manufacture were displayed at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday. The Magnesium Associaion heard from G. F. Hodgson of the National Lead Company about the recent wide applications of magnesium die castings in all fields of manufacture, often replacing zinc and aluminum on a price and efficiency basis.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 2 -Why are movie stars important people? How does an actor become a star?

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Orioles disclosed today that their purchase of the Browns included a provision that makes the first half million dollars of net income tax free and every cent will go toward rebuilding the American League team.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 2 -- Ceylon's coconut oil industry, an important part of this country's economy, faces a precarious future as a result of developments in the United States and the United Kingdom.

LUCERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Rudolf Roessler, the Soviet Union's master spy of World War II, told the Swiss Federal Court today that United States secret agents tried to enlist his services after the end of the war.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Bank of Brazil announced today it is establishing minimum prices for dollars to be sold at auction under the nation new import exchange control plan.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Looking for something to celebrate? Take your pick from the calendar of the Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives.

Plans are being formulated at frequent meetings for the benefit performance of "The Teahouse of the August Moon" on the night of Dec. 2 at the Martin Beck Theatre in behalf of Brantwood Camp in Petersborough, N. H. The event has been arranged under the auspices of the New York Committee of Brantwood Camp.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The United States moved today to tighten its economic relations with West Germany.

NOTRE DAME did a commendable job in keeping the score down on Navy fast Saturday. The varsity played only some twenty-six minutes and the second team even less as the Irish won, 38 to 7. It isn't always an easy assignment and no one should know better than Rip Miller.

MADRID, Nov. 2 -- Units of the United States Air Force operating from Spanish bases will be supplied with "atomic weapons," Harold E. Talbott, United States Secretary of the Air Force, declared here today.

Horton Foote's latest play, "The Trip to Bountiful," starring Lillian Gish, makes its Broadway debut this evening at the Henry Miller Theatre at 8 o'clock. The Theatre Guild and Fred Coe. who is described as one of NBC's foremost producer-directors, are the sponsors of the attraction.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 2 -- Pakistan's Constituent Assembly decided today that the country should be made an Islamic Republic. It acted despite a walkout of Hindu members who said minority rights would be endangered.

Since the Union of South Africa passed the Suppression of Communism Act in 1950, prohibiting Communists from holding positions in trade unions or in the public service, there have been charges that the Nationalist Government of Prime Minister Malan plans to destroy the free trade unions.

For the last six weeks the steel industry has maintained production at a steady rate averaging slightly above 95 per cent of theoretical capacity. Mills operated last week at 94.6 per cent of their potential and turned out 2,132,000 net tons of raw steel.

Curfew will not ring tonight at the Election Frauds Bureau until the last votes in the city have been counted. Telephones, however, are expected to ring early and often at the bureau's number, COrtlandt 7-9800, and from 6 A. M. workers will answer questions and investigate complaints.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 2 -- President Getulio Vargas has approved a plan to spend $4,000,000 on improvement of river shipping in an effort to relieve Brazil's chronic transport crisis. This particular projects covers renovation and expansion of what is known as the River Plate fleet, plying through the River Plate up the Paraguay and Parana Rivers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Treasury Department said tonight its offering last week of about $2,000,000,000 of fully marketable bonds was oversubscribed more than five-fold.
City Hall, focal point of the political campaign, devoted itself on election eve mainly to routine business and ceremonials.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Queen Elizabeth II will formally open Parliament tomorrow with a speech outlining a legislative program expected to keep both houses busy and turbulent through the 1953-1954 session.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 2 -- Both the winners and losers in the Hamburg city election, which was held yesterday, were pondering today the formation of a coalition to govern the city.
A guidebook to cooperative housing ownership has been published by the United Housing Foundation to supply impartial and reliable information on tenant-ownership of apartments.
John H. Wishnick has been appointed vice president in charge of production of the Witco Chemical Company.
TRENTON, Nov. 2 -- Upward of 2,000,000 New Jersey voters -- 2,668,695 have registered -- will flock to the polls tomorrow from Cape May to High Point.
HAMPTON, Va., Nov. 2 (UP) -- The tactical Air Command's 465th Troop Carrier Wing will leave the United States shortly for Europe, Gen. John K. Cannon announced today at Langley Air Force Base.
TOKYO, Nov. 2 (UP) -- The visiting New York Giants have played before 346,000 spectators in eleven games -- an average of 31,400 per game -- Bill Goodrich, Giants public relations man, said today.

The forty-seven-family apartment house at 717-19 Coster Street in the Bronx has been purchased by Morris M. Greenstein, operator, from clients of Moses Kooperstein and Sidney Leichter, lawyers. It was sold for cash above mortgages of $102,500.
A plan to merge with the Hinde Dauch Paper Company and a four-for-one split of the common stock were approved here yesterday by stockholders of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 2 -- The general reaction at the Southern Governors Conference here today was unfavorable on the Secretary of Agriculture's decision to pursue his plan to reorganize the Soil Conservation Service.

A business machine operator for the National City Bank, Madison Avenue and Forty-second Street, was seized at 7:30 P. M. yesterday by the woman manager of the Loft candy store at 11 East Forty-second Street, as he left the store after robbing it of $73, according to the police.

The steel framework is scheduled to rise within a few weeks for the twenty-two-story office building at 460 Park Avenue, northwest corner of Fifty-seventh Street, where the foundation work is now nearly completed. Known as the Davies Building, the air-conditioned structure is being built by the Tishman Realty Construction Company.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 2 -- The Foreign Ministry in Jerusalem announced tonight it had been officially informed by the Government of Czechoslovakia that two Israeli citizens were convicted for espionage and treason.

Consolidated net income of the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation in the first nine months this year fell to $5,377,716, or 98 cents a share, from $5,978,945, or $1.09 a share in the like period of last year. The company operates a gas pipeline system.
KHARTUM, Sudan, Nov. 2 -- The Sudanese parliamentary elections, which are to result in self-government for the country, got under way today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Ezra Taft Benson may not be doing so well with the farmers, but he sure is popular at the Department of State.

The fifth annual card party under the auspices of the Committee for the Rehabilitation of Crippled Children will take place on the afternoon of Nov. 17 in the ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the Cerebral Palsy Recreation Center.

CHERRYFIELD, Me., Nov. 2 -- This is the happy hunting county for hundreds of out-of-state sportsmen. Although the woodcock and grouse shooting has been something of a disappointment, the deer season which opens today promises to hold bright prospects, for the woods are quiet following the rains of last week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 2 -- A group of Federal court witnesses described today what happened to a series of checks from the Milton H. Biow Advertising Agency in New York on which Arthur, H. Samish, a California lobbyist, is accused of having evaded payment of income taxes.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -Nationalist China's promise to arrange for the removal of some Chinese operating under its flag in Northeast Burma was welcomed here today.

NAGOYA, Nov. 2 (UP) -- A seven-run second-inning rally gave Ed Lopat's major league All-Stars a 9 -- 6 victory over the Japanese Central League All-Stars before 20,000 fans today. Hank Sauer of the Chicago Cubs and Harvey Kuenn of the Detroit Tigers belted home runs in the big frame.
A big mobile emergency feeding unit for the metropolitan area in case of a bombing attack will be built under the direction of the Salvation Army.
Water in the city's reservoirs was at an even 50 per cent of capacity, or 126,587,000,000 gallons, at 8 A. M. yesterday, as it continued its drought-induced descent.

Interest in knitwear has grown rapidly in the last few seasons. The reason for this resurgent popularity lies in the enthusiasm for higher styling and new ideas that designers in this field have injected into their merchandise.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 2 (AP) -- James Dolsen, Communist party writer, was sentenced to twenty years in the Allegheny County workhouse and fined $10,000 today for violating the Pennsylvania sedition law.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Speaker of Lebanon's Parliament said today that a Jordan Valley water development program suggested by the United States was unacceptable to the Arab peoples and refugees.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Officials today disparaged reports the United States was trying to sign water power pacts with Jordan River countries, individually or collectively.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today that personal income declined slightly in September to an annual rate of $286,000,000,000, compared with $287,000,000,000 in August.
MANILA, Tuesday, Nov. 3 -Mounting reports of pre-election violence and terrorism are reaching the Commission of Elections.

City Hall, Madison Square Garden and the railroad yards on the West Side shared in reminding those who happened to be around yesterday that a large horse event would begin today. Each of the scattered places held components of the National Horse Show, which will run in the Garden for eight days.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Harry L. Lourie, executive vice president of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers of the United States, warned here today that "any radical change" in the present price structure of Scotch whisky "might be disastrous."

Medicine for ailing houses that the homeowner himself can administer is the concern of a "Do-It-Yourself Clinic" being conducted at Bamberger's in Newark this week. The program, which will include continuous demonstrations of household first aid, will also introduce several new products.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 2 -- Secretary Benson's reorganization order will cause 110 of 171 employes of the regional office here to be dismissed or transferred, according to C. E. Swain, the acting director. The annual payroll is about $900,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Buying of automobiles for all offices of the Government except the Defense Department was reported today to have been sharply reduced.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Soil Conservation Service is regarded as one of the Government's most valuable contributions to the farmers and the country.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Prices of some of the "blue chip" industrials, which advanced steadily all last week, slipped back slightly today. They reacted to profit-taking sales on a day when buying was lighter than at the end of last week.

BOSTON, Nov. 2 -- A searing explosion raked a cargo hold of the Norwegian freighter Black Falcon today, killing seven men who were trapped below by the flames and injuring thirteen others. The victims all were longshoremen.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 2 -- Ezra Taft Benson said tonight that the farm price and income situation had "now become fairly stabilized" and "offers encouragement."
PANAMA, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- Panama celebrated today the fiftieth anniversary of her independence and, in anticipation, the conclusion of a new Canal Zone treaty with the United States.

Jack Brause, real estate investor and developer, has contracted to purchase the five-story building at 24 West Fifty-eighth Street. He plans to modernize the structure and convert the apartments into office space. Farber-Wittman, Inc., was the broker and the attorneys were Breed, Abbott Morgan for the seller and Irving Lester Levitt for the buyer.
The city's investigation into autopsies was extended yesterday into a full inquiry into all practices of the Medical Examiner's office in every one of the five boroughs.

An imaginative use of color, rather than an impressive array of dining accessories, seems to be the key to arranging an inviting table setting, judging from a collection of twelve tables on view at McCutcheon's. According to Mrs. Mary L. Brandt, the color stylist who arranged the tables, the settings were designed much as a color scheme for a room interior might be.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- The steering committee of the United Nations General Assembly recommended today that the Assembly take up United States charges that the North Korean and Chinese Communists had massacred or tortured nearly 30,000 prisoners of the Korean war, including 6,113 Americans. The vote was 12 to 2.

BERLIN, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The East German Communist Government announced today discovery of old Nazi Wehrmacht files listing the execution of 25,000 men who opposed the war. It said many Germans mistakenly believed these men were still held as prisoners by the Russians.

Strong London cables pushed the price of the near-by December cocoa option up the limit for the day on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday. There was heavy short covering and trade and manufacturer buying. Volume was the largest since Aug. 21.
Manufacturers other than the old-line producers of skirts and separates have made a substantial contribution to the output of women's skirts in the last year.
Cotton futures turned easier yesterday in rather slow trading and closed barely steady, off 19 to 43 points. The distant months were weaker than the near on the New York Cotton Exchange.
ALBANY, Nov. 2 -- On the eve of the day when the voters will decide on the controversial Ostrander amendment, Governor Dewey remained quietly opposed to the measure.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Nov. 2 -- Francis T. Nichols Jr., 22-year-old heir to a chemical fortune, was killed by a shotgun blast late this afternoon while hunting crows on his father's sixty-acre estate in Muttontown.
Rudolph Halley said yesterday that a poll conducted over the week-end by his supporters indicated that he would win today's election by a plurality of 71,000 over Robert F. Wagner Jr.

Of the many urgent decisions that the Administration and Congress will have to make during the coming year, a decision on tariff and trade policy will be among the most significant. To help arrive at a sensible solution of the problem before the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act expires in June the President's Commission on Foreign Economic Policy, headed by Clarence B. Randall, has just concluded the first of its public hearings in Washington.
Establishment of more branch factories in Scotland by American industries is in prospect as a result of cost-saving inducements offered by that thrifty land, according to Lord Bilsland of Kinrara.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 2 -- A program of prevention against schizophrenia, the most prevalent of the severe mental diseases, is now possible the National Association for Mental Health was told here today.

DETROIT, Nov. 3 -- The Chrysler Corporation will lay off about 1,000 employes this month when it finishes its Army contract for M-47 medium tanks at Center Line, Mich. The plant is just north of Detroit.
A warning was sounded yesterday that outlets that have been selling fair-traded merchandise at lower than fixed prices would be subjected to a careful scrutiny.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, said today that military and naval officers, not civilians, should direct the financial management of the armed services.

The voluntary hospitals of New York range widely in size. The smaller hospitals have fewer than 100 beds; larger hospitals have more than 600 beds. Regardless of size, member voluntary hospitals of the United Hospital Fund have this in common: they use a substantial proportion of their beds for the care of persons who cannot afford the full cost of treatment.

A young American who found himself seated next to a pretty girl his own age on a Cairo-Capetown plane eleven years ago had a chance to renew the acquaintance last night. The girl is now Queen Frederica of Greece.

Endorsing a state commission's proposals for basic organizational changes in the city government, the committee on city affairs of the New York Chamber of Commerce recommended yesteray that charter amendments to accomplish the changes be submitted to the voters next year.
The cozy atmosphere of a church bazaar pervaded the vast Seventy-first Regiment Armory yesterday when the thirtieth annual Women's International Exposition opened.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- The Administrative and Budgetary Committee of the United National General Assembly went beyond the advice of its own Advisory Committee today.
Three coaches whose teams fared differently last Saturday were among the speakers yesterday as the football writers met for their weekly luncheon at Toots Shor's.

The Coast Guard has under study a newly developed Danish Diesel marine engine for lifeboats. It has been designed not only to propel the craft but to pump them free of water that might enter through faulty launching.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Republican National Committee is contributing to privately financed distribution of "Interlocking Subversion in Government Departments," a Senate document published late in August.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 2 -- The young Indo-Chinese state of Vietnam received a double warning today against attempting to force the departure of the French Expeditionary Corps or to leave the French Union.

Queen Frederika of the Hellenes got confetti in her hair yesterday. King Paul got an honorary degree from Columbia University. Mayor Impellitteri got a Greek decoration. And 750,000 New Yorkers, it was estimated, got a glimpse of the royal couple in the course of their official welcome by the city.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Sixty residents of Rye City and Port Chester asked today to have part of a proposed six-lane state thruway shifted into neighboring Connecticut because of hardship it would cause in Westchester. The county Board of Supervisors ordered a survey.

O. John Rogge, counsel for David Greenglass, denied yesterday the contention of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's subcommittee that the confessed atom-spy had supplied "important information on espionage in the radar field."

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 2 -- The Indian Army's opinion on the defenses of Nepal, independent Himalayan kingdom between India and Tibet, stresses the feasibility of Chinese and Tibetan Communist infiltration from the north.
You think you can beat the horses? A man who has been selling race selections for thirty years was arrested yesterday. His bank account showed a balance of 49 cents.

Nat Holman, suspended basketball coach of City College, yesterday defended his inaction regarding a letter written by his assistant several years ago. The aim was to induce a student to participate in a South American basketball tour in 1950 on a "pay for play" basis.

A quiet, orderly election is in prospect for today, when New York's voters go to the polls to select a new Mayor, a new Board of Estimate and a new City Council. The voting follows a campaign in which apathy was more conspicuous than at any time in the last twenty-five years.

Kenneth F. Sutherland, who backed Mayor Impellitteri unsuccessfully in the recent Democratic primary, confided to friends yesterday that he would resign this afternoon as Democratic leader of Brooklyn. He has held the post since last December.
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Mickey Mantle, the New York Yankees' center fielder, was operated on today for the removal of a cartilage from the right knee.
Fresh artichokes, off the market during the summer, return at this season, when availability hits a peak that is not reached again till spring.

All tables have been reserved for the annual luncheon in behalf of the Friends of the Philharmonic, to be held Thursday in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mrs. Philip L. B. Iglehart is chairman of the committee for the event, and Mrs. James J. Lee is vice chairman.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Two more groups today asked the United States Court of Appeals to halt participation by New York State in the building of the St. Lawrence power project.

ROTTENDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 2 (Reuters) -- A post-war shipbuilding boom in the last two years has lifted the Netherlands from sixth to fourth place among the world's shipbuilding nations and has made her the world's leading exporter of ships. Only the United States, Britain and West Germany now send more ships down the ways.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 3 -- A Department of Experimental Biology that will specialize in cancer research was dedicated today at the Weizmann Institute of Science in Rehovot. A few minutes later the cornerstone was laid for a new Institute of Physics.

As professional meteorologists we were disturbed to learn of the decision of the United States Government to withdraw from the North Atlantic weather ship network of the International Civil Aviation Organization (I. C. A. O.).

Charles Rosen, pianist, played his third recital in Town Hall last evening. A native of this city, Mr. Rosen made his debut in 1951 and subsequently studied in France on a Fulbright scholarship. He is perhaps the only concert pianist now before the public who has earned his Ph. D. in French literature.

RICHMOND, Va., Wednesday, Nov. 4 -- Thomas B. Stanley, backed by the powerful state Democratic organization of Senator Harry F. Byrd, was elected Governor of Virginia yesterday over his Republican opponent, Theodore Roosevelt Dalton.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 3 -- The eight-year Republican Administration of Mayor William Celentano ended here today when, Richard C. Lee, twice defeated for the office, was elected Mayor by an official plurality of 3,738 votes. The Democratic victor carried his party's slate with him.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 3 -- Slight but definite Democratic gains, without upset victories in traditional Republican strongholds, characterized local elections today in seven cities and towns in Fairfield County.
YONKERS, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Ernest Duke, a 4-year-old owned by Mr. and Mrs. Howard Smith of Salisbury, Md., scored his third straight victory tonight at Yonkers Raceway in the $3,500 Sleepy Hollow Pace.

The intellectually gifted child, no less than the retarded one, should be helped to accept the inequality of his abilities, to understand his relationship to others and to accept his responsibility to society, it is indicated by findings of a study on education of the gifted.
Any doubt whether Ted Williams and Stan Musial are major league baseball's most consistent hitters may be dispelled by a glance at the lifetime battling records.
Hulan E. Jack will become the first Negro Borough President of Manhattan next Jan. 1.

Plans are being formulated at frequent meetings for a benefit performance of "The Trip to Bountiful" on the night of Dec. 1 at the Henry Miller Theatre in behalf of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York. Mrs. Clifford D. Mallory Jr. and Miss Augusta de Peyster are co-chairmen of the patroness committee for the benefit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The elderly lady in blue asked if she might see President Eisenhower. She was not asking to be in his presence, for she already was there. She was, in fact, in the President's office. She was standing in front of him and could have touched him.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The legislative program presented to Parliament by the Government today was studded with domestic items bound to produce bitter controversy.

THE broadest funnel for election returns last night was the city's broadcasting station, WNYC, on the twenty-fifth floor in the Municipal Building. Grover Whalen, who helped start the station when he was in Mayor John F. Hylan's Cabinet twenty-nine years ago, showed up with a group of friends to catch the returns while they were hot, a practice he began the night Jimmy Walker was elected in 1925.
" NEVER in me life," said the gnarled old Irishman, sagely nodding his head, "did I see a horse jump so high. 'Twas at least nine feet, it was."

Miss Hoey, who was chosen president of the National Conference of Social Work for 1940-41 because of her distinguished achievement, was born in Nebraska, the daughter of Irish immigrants. She was brought up in New York.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- A shortage of pictures and exorbitant film rentals, not television, are the factors that may lead to the destruction of the motion picture industry, Leonard H. Goldenson, president of American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc., warned today.
Queen Frederika slipped away from New York late yesterday and paid an unannounced call on Gen. George C. Marshall in Washington to thank him for his part in providing economic aid to her country.
Inspired by the National Horse Show now in progress at Madison Square Garden, B. Altman Co. has arranged a miniature equestrian display in the form of five table settings.

MINEOLA, L. I., Wednesday, Nov. 4 -- County Judge Norman F. Lent, who was under attack in the investigation of harness racing, was elected to a. full six-year term on the bench yesterday, but he ran significantly behind his mates on the Republican ticket in Nassau County.

Thomas Denny of Archbishop Stepinac, White Plains, and Cardinal Hayes of the Bronx were the individual and team winners, respectively yesterday in the annual Bronx - Manhattan - Westchester cross - country championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association.

Well-known women headed by Mrs. Alfred Corning Clark and including Mrs. Henry Ford 2d and Mrs. Charles Minot Amory will participate in an elaborate pageant entitled, "A Fantasy of Flame and Frost," which will be an entertainment feature at the Fan Ball.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Queen Elizabeth II rode today through the roar of cannon and the cheers of massed thousands of her subjects to reaffirm the ancient alliance between a monarchy that has lasted 1,000 years and its Parliament.

Proclamation by Mayor Impellitteri of the week of Nov. 9 through Nov. 15 as Lighthouse Week has served to focus fresh attention both upon the work done by this important unit of the New York Association of the Blind and upon the fact that the Lighthouse is currently engaged in a $2,500,000 development fund drive which deserves the support of all New Yorkers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- President Eisenhower summoned the Secretaries of State and Defense to the White House today and appealed to them to get their departments together on public statements affecting the delicate international situation.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Industrial shares overcame profit-taking and showed a long list of gains when the stock markets closed today. British government securities and foreign bonds also made further progress.
The Democrats captured twenty-three of the twenty-five seats in the new City Council, which takes office next Jan. 1.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The city of Philadelphia proclaimed to the world today that it still was the nation's third Largest city.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- A call for a reappraisal of all foreign trade restrictions of the United States was issued today by Charles P. Taft, president of the new Committee for a National Trade Policy. Mr. Taft, brother of the late Senator Robert A. Taft, addressed a conference on world trade policy held by the League of Women Voters of Illinois.

City Court Justice Owen McGivern and Jacob Markowitz, chairman of Tammany Hall's law committee, were easy winners yesterday for two vacancies on the Supreme Court bench in the First Judicial District (Manhattan and the Bronx).

Several readers have written us concerning our column on sauerbraten that appeared in a recent issue of the Sunday Magazine of this paper. Sauerbraten is a particularly delicious German way of pot-roasting tougher beef.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 3 -- Harrison A. Williams Jr., a 33-year-old Democrat, squeezed through to a 1,997-vote victory in the Congressional contest in New Jersey's Sixth District.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- President Eisenhower received today the first copy of "The Columbia Historical Portrait of New York."
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Midwest Stock Exchange had a quiet session today, with most prices unchanged to lower.

Canada ruled the opening of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday. Dominion riders won international contests both afternoon and evening. What was most striking in a show that blended sport and the world of society and fashion was that one of the winners was a young woman, after a jump-off against another young woman.
Robert B. Meyner possesses many of the attributes long considered essential to a successful career in politics.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Central Bank disclosed today that the Chilean Government has asked it not to sell strategic copper to Communist countries while Chile is negotiating with Washington for the sale of 100,000 tons of the metal.
The Pabst Brewing Company will become the first of the major national brewers to produce beer on the West Coast when bottling operations in its $15,000,000 Los Angeles plant begin on Nov. 16.
BERLIN, Nov. 3 -- The story of three of five Czechoslovaks who survived a twenty-eight day trek and a gunfight with the East German People's Police was revealed here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, said today he preferred to have civilian managers watching over the armed services' financial accounts.

With more and more men shopping in food stores it is time to reexamine many merchandising, advertising and distribution ideas for products they use. This is the conclusion drawn by Dale Anderson, director of research for Erwin, Wasey Co., from a recent study by that agency.

Jim Byrne and Don Townsend staged a one-two finish for St. John's but the Redmen yielded the team title to a better balanced Manhattan squad in the twenty-seventh annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

The Coast Guard helped New York continue yesterday its weeklong celebration of the Fiftieth Anniversary of Powered Flight by demonstrating spectacular sea-air rescue operations by helicopter at the Battery.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Grain futures were weak here today in a continuation of the reactionary trend that had begun yesterday.

Queen Elizabeth's Speech from the Throne yesterday had nothing new or even mildly surprising in it. The Conservative party program for the new session of Parliament, of which the Speech was the traditional opening, will do nothing to change anything fundamental about British affairs.

United Air Lines, Inc., set new records for traffic volume and operating revenues in the first nine months of this year. Because of higher operating expenses, however, net income for the period declined slightly from the year before, the company's report showed yesterday.
Many of the conveniences and a few of the cliches of modern architectural planning are included in a model home in mid-Manhattan going on view to the public at noon tomorrow.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- The United Nations General Assembly today urged the nations of the world to speed ratification of the convention on genocide -- mass murder on political, racial or cultural grounds. It also asked the widest possible dissemination of information on the subject.

The American Federation of Labor announced yesterday that it would ask the National Labor Relations Board to bar the old International Longshoremen's Association from the ballot in an election to pick a bargaining agent for New York dock workers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles delivered a brief but hopeful report today on the dispute between Britain and Iran.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- The appearance of advertising on British television within the next year was indicated today by an announcement in the speech of Queen Elizabeth II that the Government would submit its "policy for television development" to Parliament during the current session.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- King Paul of the Hellenes told diplomats from sixty countries today that Greece stood ready to answer the call of the United Nations if the time came again to fight the "powers of destruction."

AFTER several false starts, the institution of soap opera now seems firmly established in television. By the latest count there are eight daytime serials on the air, and the N. B. C. and C. B. S. networks have thoughtfully arranged their schedules so that there is no need to miss a single one.

ON nearly any bookshop counter you will find several dozen of them, the clumsy melodramas disguised as historical fiction that are the staple product of our contemporary literary hacks. Wrapped in gaudy jackets, packed with brutal violence and sexual sensationalism, they are the delight of many thousands of uncritical readers and the comfort of publishers who need the support of a few certainties in an uncertain business.

Steven Pankow, a 45-year-old automobile dealer, last night ended eight years of Republican rule of Buffalo. He won the mayoralty of the nation's fifteenth largest city as the Democratic candidate over Fire Commissioner Harold C. Becker, Republican.

In your Oct. 28 issue you published a letter written by Edward S. Greenbaum in which he discussed the necessity of expediting accident trials. In it he pointed out that our courts are becoming more and more congested and that an injured person must wait longer to get his case tried in New York City than anywhere else in the country.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 3 -- The Mississippi Legislature was convened in special session today to consider expenditure of an estimated $100,000,000 to equalize the state's white and Negro public schools.

All nine amendments to the State Constitution that were submitted to the voters at referenda yesterday appeared to have been adopted early this morning by substantial margins. None had been the subject of wide public discussion during the campaign.
Robert B. Meyner, youthful Democratic lawyer, was elected Governor of New Jersey yesterday by a surprising landslide plurality.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 3 -- French and West German representatives took another tentative step today along the rough and rocky road that leads to agreement on the Saar.

A plan under which the city of New York would be able to acquire immediately the seven privately owned ferry boats running between St. George, S. I., and Sixty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, and to pay for them later will be discussed soon by Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, and Ogden B. Hewitt, president of Electric Ferries, Inc.

MADRID, Nov. 3 -- James C. Dunn, United States Ambassador, said today Spain could easily absorb United States economic aid without the risk of inflation by applying appropriate and efficient measures.

BOSTON, Nov. 3 -- The captain and the cargo officer of the Norwegian freighter Black Falcon said today that the chemicals blamed for yesterday's explosion had been shifted, on orders, during a stopover from Europe.

Unless a settlement is forthcoming, the controversy between Walter Fried, who contends he owns Liam O'Brien's comedy, "The Family Man," and Mr. O'Brien will be submitted to arbitration. This development was initiated by the author, who insisted yesterday that the script no longer was the property of Mr. Fried because he had failed to put on the attraction by the stipulated date of Oct. 15.

Studies indicating that the polluted air over large cities may be the major factor in the alarming increase in deaths from lung cancer in the last twenty years were reported yesterday to the American Cancer Society.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles expressed doubt today as to whether the Communists really wished to hold a Korean peace conference.
BACOLOD, the Philippines, Nov. 3 -- On all lists, the Province of Negros Occidental on the Visayan Island of Negros is near the top as a potential danger spot in the Philippines elections.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 3 -- The Bank of America has received permission from Federal Judge William C. Mathes in Los Angeles to foreclose mortgages it holds on ten independently produced motion pictures made between 1946 and 1948 and distributed by Universal-International Pictures.

Robert F. Wagner Jr., in winning one of the nation's most onerous and important public offices, brings to the Mayoralty a name long honored by liberal Democrats, and a record marked by success at the polls.
Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, switched plans yesterday to question David Greenglass, confessed atomic spy, in a closed session on Friday.
NOVARA, Italy, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A jammed courtroom clamored today for acquittal of three Italians on trial in the wartime murder of Maj. William Holohan of New York.

It appears unlikely that any team will displace Notre Dame from the No. 1 spot in The Associated Press poll unless the season of upsets should reach a climax on Saturday and all the favorites are beaten.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Nov. 3 -- Iceland's long dispute with Britain on fishing rights off this island's shores, the country's major foreign controversy, appears to have been indefinitely prolonged.

Mr. Wagner's victory in the race for Mayor carried along his city-wide candidates, Abe Stark for President of the City Council and Lawrence E. Gerosa for Controller. The Democrats will also control the Board of Estimate.
HARTFORD, Nov. 3 -- The Democratic party won an upset victory over the nonpartisan Citizens Charter Committee in today's municipal election, capturing the City Council by a 5-to-4 margin.

If honesty of purpose and anxious sincerity were the prime requisites for a successful stage presentation, the Artists Theatre, which put on two short plays last night at the Amato Opera Theatre on Bleecker Street, could be credited this morning with having achieved its aim. DETROIT, Nov. 3 -- George W. Mason, president of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation, said today that it was "ridiculous" to suppose the smaller automobile companies could not survive without a merger in the face of increasingly stiff Big Three competition.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Department of the Army said today that construction of the proposed air defense base at Sandy Hook, N. J., had been stopped "temporarily."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Soviet Union replied today to the Western Big Three's proposal for a four-power foreign ministers' conference on Germany and Austria. One authority said the reply was "unresponsive" while another found it "evasive."

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 4 -- Arthur H. Dean, United Nations delegate at the Korean preliminary conference, suggested today that subcommittees of Allied and Communist representatives discuss the time and place and the composition of the Korean peace conference concurrently.

A pair of fourth choices, Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Home-Made and Marian W. O'Connor's La Corredora, captured the two divisions of the $25,000 added Comely Handicap before 41,194 fans at Jamaica yesterday.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Tennesseans voted by large majorities today to lengthen the Governor's term to four years, raise the pay of legislators and make other changes in the state's eighty-three-year-old unamended Constitution.

A plot of about one and one-half acres fronting on Northern and Port Washington Boulevards in Roslyn, L. I., has been sold by Albert Bartholemy and Elizabeth Randy to Morton and Lawrence Lane of Great Neck. The sale was made through the Ernest G. Blaich Company as broker and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 3 -- Voters of this city rejected a proposal for fluoridation of drinking water here today. The decision was on a referendum that had been submitted by the City Council upon petition of 36,000 voters.

When children seem to have difficulty settling down to their homework, the rearrangement of a room to provide a special study area may prove of assistance. The Bordo Corporation a subsidiary of Bing Bing, Inc., has conveyed title to the nine-story apartment house on plot 102 by 165 feet at 45 East Eighty-fifth Street to an investing client of Emil Rogers, attorney. There are fifty apartments in the property, which is assessed at $610,000.

BURBANK, Calif., Nov. 3 -- The Radio Corporation of America today demonstrated coast-to-coast color television. It also announced the development of recording color and black-and-white television on magnetic tape.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 3 -- For ten years Ceylon and India have tried to solve the problem of citizenship rights for Indians resident in Ceylon without arriving at an acceptable solution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The National Labor Relations Board reversed another of its rules today.
The Times Square election night crowd tradition, which had thrashed feebly for survival in recent years, finally gave up the ghost last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- The United Nations General Assembly rejected today a resolution adopted by one of its committees that called on France to grant "free democratic institutions" to Morocco.

Led by Captain Irwin (Buster) Wolosky, DeWitt Clinton brought Stuyvesant's winning streak to an end yesterday at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island. Turning back their old football rivals, who had been unscored upon previously during the season, Clinton triumphed, 19 to 6, before a crowd of 6,000.

The sacrifice fly, twice discarded in the past, was restored yesterday to baseball. With the start of the 1954 campaign, a batter who flies out to score a run will not be charged with a time at bat. This rule was last in effect in 1939, but was dropped after one season.

Ships lost as a result of the hazards of the sea numbered 181 of 219,429 gross tons in 1952, the lowest in point of tonnage in a peacetime year since 1928 and the second lowest in the number of vessels.
A 24-year-old City College student has built a machine to test the validity of syllogisms -- a form of logical argument that dates back to Aristotle.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- A delegation from the National Retail Dry Goods Association told top Treasury officials today that the association opposed a sales tax at any level of trade.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 3 -- The Yugoslav Government revealed today that Italy had prohibited all Yugoslav imports from Italy. Belgrade formally protested the measure and denounced it as discriminatory.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- Newburgh voters elected a Republican and a Democrat to four-year terms on the City Council in today's municipal elections. Both were endorsed by the Republican City Committee and nominated by the Republican party in the September primaries.
Appeals by domestic concerns to the Tariff Commission for restriction of competing imports are again on the upturn after a decline through the early part of this year.

A charge that new definitions for certain types of smoke, proposed in changes of the rules of the Department of Air Pollution Control, would "pull the teeth" from enforcement was made and denied yesterday.
DETROIT, Nov. 3 -- Albert E. Cobo, Mayor of Detroit for the last four years, won re-election tonight, overcoming the challenge of James H. Lincoln, a lawyer, making his first bid for public office.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 4 -- Communist "explainers" trying to win back the loyalty of their former personnel turned their attention to Chinese prisoners again today. There was every likelihood the Reds would suffer their fifth propaganda setback in as many meetings with the captives refusing repatriation.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- In a broadcast over the Moscow radio today Academician S. I. Voitskovish said that "Soviet scientists can make several types of atomic and hydrogen bombs."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- An examiner for the Federal Trade Commission has dismissed a complaint against Doubleday Co., Inc., of New York, and its subsidiaries. The complaint had charged the publishers with deceptive use of the word "free."
PATCHOGUE, L. I., Nov. 3 -- Republican candidates retained substantial control of the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors today, but their membership on the ten-man body was cut from eight to seven.
MANILA, Wednesday, Nov. 4 -- Heads of the two opposing political parties have signed a formal agreement intended to insure honest and orderly voting in next Tuesday's Presidential elections.

Bishop Loughlin swept the varsity honors yesterday in the annual cross-country championships of the Brooklyn-Long Island section of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association at Van Cortlandt Park. The meet drew entries from nine schools.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 3 -- Anthony J. Celebrezze, Democratic State Senator, who campaigned without the support of the regular Democratic organization, swept to a decisive victory over William J. McDermott, Republican, in today's Mayoralty election.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Nov. 3 The annual Western Governors Conference urged today the passage of legislation that would hasten the exit of the Federal Government from the fields of gasoline tax collection and Indian affairs.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Nov. 4 -- Democrats scored major upset victories in New Jersey and held their own in New York and Virginia yesterday in balloting that was interpreted generally as a significant test of the popularity of the Eisenhower Administration.
Contests for eight Assembly seats were split evenly last night between Democrats and Republicans. A Republican was the winner in the only Senatorial contest in the state. There were no upsets.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- The United States announced today that it had signed a contract to fly to Formosa 2,000 Chinese soldiers now in Burma, and that the airlift would begin within a week.

Down in Wall Street yesterday some brokers were overheard saying: "There's not much doubt now which Board makes the stock market.'' What they were referring to was the fact that although most business places remained opened Tuesday, the New York Stock Exchange closed for the elections.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 4 -- The United Nations Command will be adamant on holding to a ninety-day limit for completing the explanations to non-repatriate prisoners in Korea, George V. Allen, United States Ambassador to India, declared today.

Harold Riegelman received 661,410 votes. Rudolph Halley received 468,392 votes. Together they had 1,129,802 votes, or 108,314 more than Robert F. Wagner Jr., the Democratic candidate, who was elected Mayor. Perhaps it isn't so simple as two plus two equals four, but it must be plain once more, as it has everlastingly been plain, that if you want to beat Tammany Hall in this town you have to do it with fusion.

MIDDLESBOROUGH, England, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- A 25-year-old soldier whose conviction for cowardice in battle set all England arguing, got a hero's welcome on his belated return home from Korea tonight.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 4 -- President Juan D. Peron has assured Argentina's General Confederation of Labor that no matter what happens to La Prensa, the paper will never be restored to its former owners from whom it was confiscated.

Covering a wine tasting, always a pleasant assignment, was even more so the other afternoon when Macy's gathered food writers in its executive dining room to sample a collection of German white wines, which go on sale today.

White Skies once again demonstrated his liking for the Jamaica race track yesterday. The 4-year-old son of Sun Again won the $22,725 Sport Page Handicap with plenty of room, for his third victory in three attempts on the local course in the last month.

The results of Tuesday's elections have been awaited with unusual off-year interest because of the light they might throw on the national fortunes of the two major parties just twelve months after the upheaval of last November.
WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 4 -- The women of Westport were in lottery trouble for a while again today.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 5 -- The United Nations delegate, Arthur H. Dean, suggested today that the Panmunjom meeting trying to arrange the Korean political conference be recessed until the two sides can agree on the Panmunjom agenda.
A prediction that the reconstructed Eastern Boulevard Bridge, which carries Bruckner Boulevard over the Bronx River, would create one of the worst bottlenecks in the city, has come true.

Fordham's triple-pronged pitching fork, comprising passers Roger Franz, George Murphy and Vinnie Drake, yesterday gave indication that the Rams would attempt to match the tosses of Penn State's Tony Rados, the East's leading passer, when the football teams meet Saturday at State College.

A former police lieutenant, who is expected to be an important witness in a trial of twenty-two former policemen and bookmakers in Staten Island, pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of perjury and conspiracy.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 4 -- Dr. Urho K. Kekkonen, Agrarian premier, tendered the resignation of his minority coalition cabinet tonight to President Juho K. Paasikivi after having lost a vote of confidence in the Diet (Parliament) last night. The vote concerned a state grant for housing.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Low pluralities for Republicans in the Westchester County election yesterday were attributed by party leaders today to public disapproval of the ties of some Republican leaders to raceways, labor extortionists and objectionable Thruway routes.
The city's first "television bank" will begin operations today when The New York Savings Bank opens its new Rockefeller Center office.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Bernard A. Gray, president of the Black River Regulating District, indicated today that the district might test the constitutionality of Amendment Nine, which was approved yesterday by the state's voters.

HANOI, Vietnam, Nov. 4 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon declared here tonight that the United States would vigorously disapprove any negotiation for peace in Indo-China whose effect would be to end the freedom of the Indo-Chinese people.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- The Pandora's box of Trieste, opened by Anglo-American diplomacy Oct. 8 when it was in effect proposed that the Free Territory should be partitioned, is continuing to produce nothing but trouble for everyone concerned.

The premiere of "The Search," an educational television series that the C. B. S. network had hoped to get on the air this fall, has been delayed until early next year. The program, being prepared in cooperation with twenty-six universities and colleges, is being produced by Irving Gitlin.
The 1954 line of De Soto cars will go on display here today. Ten body styles are offered.
JUAREZ, Mexico, Nov. 4 -- The United States will waive passport requirements for certain classes of immigrants from Mexico beginning today, Robert Y. Brown, Consul General, said.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- The United States warned the Arab States and Israel today it would not continue indefinitely to be the financial mainstay of the United Nations program for helping Arab refugees.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Three men identified by the Justice Department as Communist party leaders were arrested here today on charges of conspiring to advocate the overthrow of the Government by force and violence. The men were identified as Martin Chancey, 45 years old; George Watt, 39, and Anthony Krchmarek, 55.

A Colonial dwelling and nearly two acres on High Point Lane in Scarsdale, N. Y., have been sold by George M. Morrison to Jerome Adler. Robert E. Hill, Inc., broker, represented the buyer, and the Robert E. Farley organization was the seller's broker.

BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Justice Leo Hagerty ordered stricken from the State Supreme Court records today statements by two Saratoga National Bank officers who said they thought James A. Leary was the bank's principal stockholder.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Canadian Government has informally rejected a State Department request that it help the Senate Internal Security subcommittee interview Igor Guzenko, former code clerk in the Soviet Union's Embassy at Ottawa.

Don't look now, but that stranger you will see in the City Council come Jan. 1 is another Republican. Stanley Isaacs, heretofore a one-man Republican minority carrying the title of Leader with only himself (and public opinion) to lead, will have as a colleague Robert E. Barnes from the Fourth District in Queens, a lawyer, who won -- with some fortuitous assistance -- by a vote of 81,326 to 59,210.
The quality of British horsemanship was tested and found up to its reputation in the international jumping competition at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A prevalent view on Capitol Hill today was that Republican setbacks in yesterday's election stemmed from the party's failure nationally to back up 1952 campaign promises with performance.
Pan American World Airways has no intention of abandoning its campaign to effect a sharp reduction in trans-Atlantic air cargo rates.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 5 (UP) -- Japan may lose world skating and wrestling championships scheduled for next year because the Foreign Office refuses to admit athletes from Russia and her satellite nations, it was disclosed today.
Trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closing prices were 11 points higher to 4 points lower than on Monday.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Nov. 4 -- The Republicans' chances of avoiding a "strike-out" in this Fall's special congressional elections admittedly looked slim today. A prospective split party vote overshadowed issues in the California Twenty-fourth District campaign.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- More incentives were offered to business today to build or expand defense plants in chronic labor surplus areas.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 4 (UP) -- Head Coach Frank Leahy of Notre Dame decided today to rest another day before he returns to the campus to direct football practice.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- After prolonged discussions last night and today, the French Cabinet authorized Finance Minister Edgar Faure to submit to the National Assembly a budget for 1954 showing a reduction of about 60,000,000,000 francs (about $174,000,000) from present year's outlays and an undetermined deficit.
BAYONNE, N. J., Nov. 4 -- Surplus, over-age and obsolete Navy material went on the auction block here today, sales totaling $186,308, after six and one-half hours of spirited bidding.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- President Eisenhower said today he would take the lead in presenting the Administration's farm program to Congress.
The city's new First Lady takes a strictly housewifely view of her prospective home.
CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
DETROIT, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Blair Moody, former United States Senator, said today that he would publish a weekly newspaper in Livonia and another in Plymouth. Both are in Detroit's industrial suburbs.

i There is nothing more disconcerting to a driver than the feeling that the {car behind him is practically crawling ,up'his back. That feeling is too'often felt oh our highways, where drivers 'neglect to consider the accident possii bilities of following too closely tile car ahe .t:forty. mil per hour

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers had accuracy at the free throw line and a closing rush for the finish tonight to trip the Milwaukee Hawks, 73 -- 67, in the first game of a National Basketball Association double-header.

Ordering has been light at the Spring Market Week sponsored by the Boys Apparel and Accessories Manufacturers Association. Exhibitors blamed the unseasonably warm weather for the poor business at the showing which opened on Sunday.

Governor Dewey's fight against Senator Arthur H. Wicks of Kingston appeared yesterday to have placed passage of a legislative reapportionment act in jeopardy. Mr. Dewey has demanded the Senator's replacement as majority leader and President pro tem of the State Senate.
OTTAWA, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Canada's imports again outpaced exports during July, resulting in a $7,200,000 trade deficit -- the sixth monthly deficit for 1953.

Promising new marketing research methods should be encouraged but they should be adopted and used with caution, A. C. Nielsen, president of the research company bearing his name, warned clients yesterday. The safety of an entire business often is at stake when important decisions are made on the basis of research, he said.
Senator Joseph R. McCarthy yesterday laid the Republicans' election defeats to failure of their candidates to make an issue of Communist infiltration of government.

Voters approved on Tuesday the issuance of more than $800,000,000 of new bond issues by state and municipal governments, and turned down proposals calling for the issuance of more than $50,000,000 of new bonds. In the bond referendums of Election Day last year, approvals totaled $1,028,670 and disapprovals, $88,146,000.

Much discussion and debate have transpired since the Korean armistice on the question of so-called "cooperative" American prisoners of war. The Defense Department officially and unofficially has indicated that it is in a quandary as to what position to take on this touchy issue. Secretary of Defense Wilson, commenting on this subject, has to date issued somewhat confusing and ambiguous statements.

Democratic leaders throughout New Jersey were jubilant yesterday, but admittedly surprised, over the decisive majority given to Governor-elect Robert B. Meyner in Tuesday's election. The final unofficial tally gave him a plurality of just under 154,000.
ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 4 -- The rate war on cargoes from the Continent to American ports is slated to end soon.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- The management of the Frank Seder Department Store, a twelve-story establishment in the center of the Philadelphia shopping district, announced today it is going out of business.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Wage and work negotiations between the country's railroads and the fifteen brotherhoods of non-operating employes ended abruptly today in a deadlock on three of the brotherhoods' demands.
