Today's new film is Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Kiss Me Kate," at the Radio City Music Hall. The Technicolor musical stars Kathryn Grayson, Howard Keel, Ann Miller and Keenan Wynn, with Bobby Van, Tommy Rall, James Whitmore and Kurt Kasznar in featured roles.

As significant as may have been the political news of Tuesday, it had relatively little effect on stock prices yesterday. Investors and traders appeared to be more interested in corporate news developments than election results.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- An unofficial count of Kingston's vote today gave Senator Arthur H. Wicks' candidate for Mayor, Frederick H. Stang, a victory by forty-seven votes over Gerald E. FitzGerald, Democrat-Liberal.

ENRICO CARUSO sang "Carmen" in the Mexico City bull ring early in 1920 for a fee of $15,000. Historians might well date the beginning of the golden age of the Nineteen Twenties from that spectacular event, so characteristic of so much that was to follow. He died not long after he had given a perfect prelude to an era.

Harris County, Tex., borrowed $15,500,000 in the public market yesterday on issues of serial bonds, some of which are backed by the county's full taxing powers and others by only limited taxes. The bonds, which will come due serially from 1954 to 1973, were sold to finance various improvements, including road and court house construction and flood-control installations.

TORONTO, Nov. 4 (UP) -- Ramming in two second-period goals, the Toronto Maple Leafs tripped the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 -- 1, tonight. The Hawks suffered their first defeat in four starts as the Leafs moved to within a point of second place in the National Hockey League.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Democratic successes in key elections enveloped the political paths of pro-Eisenhower Southern Governors in uncertainty today.

ALBANY, Nov. 4 -- Republican and Democratic leaders took a second look at the upstate election returns today. Both parties concluded that they had received a promising send off toward the race for the governorship next fall.

Milk distributors, recovering from last week's strike, were assured last night that drivers of huge tank trucks bringing milk from upstate areas to bottling plants in the city had no immediate plans to call a walk-out for higher wages and other benefits.

Abraham Brothman, who served two years in prison for conspiracy to obstruct justice during an espionage investigation, has free run of a Port Jervis, N. Y., plant that manufactures defense material, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said yesterday.
NEW CITY, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Rockland County Democrats gained their greatest county-wide victory in fifty-two years yesterday when four of the five County Supervisor candidates were elected.

BONN, Gemany, Nov. 4 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, indicated today that plans had been made for West German forces to join Western defense even if the European army treaty were not ratified by all signatories.
KHARTUM, The Sudan, Nov. 3 -- The Suakinese, displaced citizens of the ghost port of Suakin on the Red Sea, received the right to vote in the present parliamentary eleced down in the last few days.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 4 -- Rabbi Mordecai Kirshblum of Brooklyn, president of the Mizrachi Organization of America, urged the United States tonight to propose a United Nations peace conference between Israel and the Arab States.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UP) -- President Eisenhower wishes the women could make up their minds so he could give a party for them.

VIENNA, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The official newspaper of the Polish Communist party admitted today it had wrongly announced the installation of a Roman Catholic bishop in Wroclaw, the former German city of Breslau.

There was slight shading of prices in longer-term Treasury securities yesterday, the first trading session following announcement of the allotment of the oversubscribed new issue of 2 3/4 per cent bonds.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 4 -- Some 14,000 motion picture studio workers are due to receive a 5 per cent wage increase, it was learned today, following a joint announcement by the Association of Motion Picture Producers and the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes that agreement had been reached on terms for a new contract.

BOSTON, Nov. 4 -- After the Democratic victories in the Commonwealth's city elections, Massachusetts Republican leaders maintained today that their basic strength lay in the towns, where elections would be held next spring.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- President Eisenhower said today that all the Universities of the free world would be rallied next year behind Columbia University's 200th anniversary theme: "Man's right to knowledge and the free use thereof."
Fashion accessories just flown from Paris made their appearance yesterday at Saks Fifth Avenue main floor boutique, at the opening of an exhibit under the sponsorship of the French Government.
Frederic G. Melcher's excellent letter to the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES regarding the increase of the international surface mail rates does not stress one point which I would like to add:

BOSTON, Nov. 4 -- Investigation of the fiery blast that took seven lives aboard the Norwegian freighter Black Falcon continued today as suits totaling $500,000 were filed against the ship's operators in Federal Court in behalf of eight longshoremen and their families.

Operations of the B. F. Goodrich Company for the first nine months of 1953 resulted in an estimated net income of $25,201,898. The report, released yesterday by John L. Collyer, chairman and president, showed earnings for this year's period were equal to $6.01 each on 4,191,979 common shares.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 4 -- Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion announced tonight his decision to retire from the Government for two years at least because of "mental strain." His decision was made public when the governing Mapai party made public the text of a letter from him.
Former Representative Vito Marcantonio announced yesterday his resignation as state chairman of the American Labor party. He said he would continue to be active politically as an independent.
BOSTON, Nov. 4 -- Confetti tossing throngs estimated by the police at 50,000 gave King Paul I and Queen Frederika of the Hellenes a royal send-off in downtown Boston today.
MONTREAL, Nov. 4 -- The face of Montreal has been undergoing broad changes through street-widening programs in the downtown area. Now it is Montreal's skyline that is to be changed.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 4 -- Revitalizing the long-dormant Nassau County Democratic party was assured today as analyses of yesterday's vote showed that Republicans suffered an over-all 11 per cent reduction in pluralities.

Acrilan, one of the newer synthetic textile fibers, has been improved to overcome a degree of brittleness. This weakness, revealed after many millions of pounds had been produced, caused the Chemstrand Company to reduce Acrilan production last summer in its new $50,000,000 plant in Decatur, Ala.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UP) -- Only about 24 cents out of every dollar's worth of beef sold in Eastern supermarkets goes to the rancher who raised the cattle, Senator Lester C. Hunt, Democrat of Wyoming, said today.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Emphasis in the stock markets here shifted today from industrial shares to British Government securities. The optimistic tone of Prime Minister Churchill's speech yesterday was among the factors that encouraged buying of gilt edge issues and led to price rises of as much as thirteen-sixteenths per cent.
A military science building, under construction on the Bronx campus of New York University, was dedicated yesterday to the memory of the late Robert P. Patterson.

CHERRYFIELD, Me., Nov. 4 -- For exercise in its more strenuous form we can recommend what is known locally as "hunting the barrens and the burns," but as a means or providing venison for the table it falls somewhat short of perfection.

An assistant medical examiner has resigned, on request of Dr. Thomas A. Gonzales, Chief Medical Examiner, and the latter said yesterday that the case was an "example" to staff members to comply with all requirements of the Administrative Code.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The Associated Press Managing Editors Association cited forty-eight newspapers in twenty-five states today for outstanding examples of Associated Press membership cooperation in news and newsphoto coverage.

NOT since the Athletics scored ten runs in one inning to defeat the Cubs, 10 to 8, during the 1929 world series has there been a more unexpected denouement in Philadelphia than the latest bit of fantasy. Jimmie Dykes has been abruptly ousted as manager of the A's and Eddie Joost brought up from the ranks to take his place. It makes no sense whatsoever.

TUSCALOOGA, Ala., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Dr. A. B. Moore, president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, issued a statement today clarifying his position on college football. He said his talk at Talladega, Ala., Monday night had been misinterpreted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- President Eisenhower, otherwise serene in his news conference today, showed anger in denouncing the charge that General of the Army George C. Marshall had been a tool of traitors.

Suspended Patrolman John Brullman, said to be the first policeman in this area to be indicted and tried as an alleged civil rights violator, was found guilty last night in Federal Court, Brooklyn. The jury of seven men and five women recommended clemency.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 4 (AP) -- A German chemist who did essential spadework in plastics and a Dutch physicist who invented a microscope that opens new vistas of living matter were awarded 1953 Nobel prizes today.
Record sales and earnings were recorded by the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., in the nine months ended on Sept. 30.

At the White House on Oct. 14 President Eisenhower personally greeted a delegation of thirty-five "aviation pioneers'' assembled from some half-dozen countries in celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of powered flight. The largest single delegation came from Germany and included among its numbers Gerhard Fieseler, Willy Messerschmitt and Helmuth Sachse.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 4 (AP) -- The second running of the $65,000 Washington D. C. International at Laurel Park Saturday will be the final race for three of the eleven horses entered.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- President Eisenhower said today that the Soviet Union seemed determined to prevent a four-power conference on Germany and Austria.

The first specific step toward the elimination of the shape-up system of pier hiring will be taken next week when the New York New Jersey Waterfront Commission opens its first Government-operated employment center.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- A forty-mile stretch of the south coast of England is being invaded by swarms of black flies, called coelopids, that have defied efforts to repel them. The flies are breeding in huge masses of a variety of seaweed, new to the British coasts, that was cast up by gales last summer.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 4 -- Virginia's electorate, which last year reversed its Democratic voting tradition and supported President Eisenhower, rejected in yesterday's general election a Republican bid at the state level.

CHITTAGONG, Pakistan, Nov. 4 -- With 20,000,000 persons, almost half the population of the East Bengal Province, going to the polls for the first time in February, the East Pakistan Communist party is campaigning in support of the growing Opposition parties.

The second evening performance of the sixty-fifth National Horse Show last night at Madison Square Garden attracted a large gathering of prominent persons. Many dinner parties were give in private homes and hotels before the performance.

DETROIT, Nov. 4 (AP) -- A continuing drop in the retail sales volume of the smaller manufacturers of automobiles was reported today by R. L. Polk, auto industry statisticians, in a monthly new-car registration analysis.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Nov. 4 -- Democrats retained their control of local offices in Louisville in yesterday's elections, but were ousted by Republicans from their twenty-year control in Lexington.

The first English translation of the journals of Matthew Ricci, the missionary who in 1583 was the first to get into China, will be published by Random House on Nov. 20. Ricci spent twenty-seven years there and died in Peking in 1610.
A new 10 per cent increase in commutation fares will be sought by the Long Island Rail Road to help pay for a $24,828,562 passenger car improvement program.
Acquisition by the Sayre Fisher Brick Company of three properties has been approved by the board of directors, according to William A. Shea, chairman.
Thomas I. Parkinson lost a last-ditch fight late last night to retain his control over the nation's third largest life insurance company.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Nov., 4 -- Robert P. Aex, city manager here since January, 1952, submitted his resignation to the City Council today in the face of adverse election results. Mayor Herbert A. Warren, one of his supporters, called him a "quitter."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, said today persons and institutions wanting to make "real savings" should be given the first chance to invest in United States Treasury bonds.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- President Eisenhower will take refuge tomorrow in the White House air raid shelter in a test of the capital's civil defense system.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of today's White House news conference, with President Eisenhower's remarks in indirect discourse as required by conference rules:

Isabel Mourao, a pianist from Brazil, gave her third Town Hall recital last night. She picked a difficult, dangerous program that posed the question of where courage should leave off and discretion begin. It is not that Miss Mourao lacks ability.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- An official of the American Council on Education said today he regarded the N. C. A. A. president's blast at "skullduggery" in football as a major stride toward "sweeping the rascals out of college football."

Two hold-up men led a seventy-five-mile-an-hour chase last night through Brooklyn with two police prowl cars in gun-fire pursuit for more than a mile a long busy streets. Two policemen were wounded and one of the robbers was captured after a cross-volley of sixteen shots.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- A representative of the pro-French Government of Sultan Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa of Morocco gave assurances here today that there would be no future acts of violence against the French or United States bases or personnel in Morocco.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 18, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

A new and musing collection of gloves is being shown at B. Altman's. Six styles, designed by Merry Hull, will add glamour and the proper finishing touch to any costume. These gloves offer unusual and functional construction, giving added comfort as well unrestricted action to the wearer.

DETROIT, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Tireless Al Andrews landed just enough right hands to score a narrow split 10-round decision over Chuck Davey, the 3-1 favorite tonight. Davey weighed 149 1/2 and Andrews 151 pounds.
YONKERS, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The favored Hal Tryax was driven to victory by his owner, Sanders Russell of Stevenson, Ala., in the Oscawanna Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Cook County Republican candidates scored an upset victory yesterday to break a twenty-year Democratic grip here.

Kale is a leafy green that arrives with the frost and continues in good supply through the winter. It is distinguished for its low cost and high nutritional value -- virtues apparently unappreciated by Americans who eat less than a pound of kale a year.

Ohrbach's, a cash-and-carry specialty store situated on Fourteenth Street for thirty years, is moving a mile uptown to Thirty-fourth Street, taking with it the prospect of keen price competition for Herald Square stores.
TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 5 -- The Indian chairman of the neutral repatriation commission in Korea personally broke off today long "explanations" by the Communists to Chinese prisoners of war.

BAY SHORE, L. I., Nov. 4 -- The election of Justice of the Peace James F. Willis of Sayville as Supervisor of the Town of Islip "probably will be protested," according to the Islip Town Democratic leader, William G. Carroll of Bayport.

LONDON, Nov. 4 (UP) -- A 19-year-old Grenadier Guardsman who jolted British military tradition by falling asleep by his sentry box at the Tower of London was sentenced today to serve eighty-four days in the guardhouse.

DETROIT, Nov. 4 (AP) -- General Motors Corporation announced today the first production of hydramatic transmissions at its leased space in the Willow Run, Mich., plant of the Kaiser Motor Corporation.

PARIS, Nov. 4 (UP) -- Avery Brundage of Chicago, president of the International Olympic Committee, today criticized "special benefits" United States college football players received. He was replying to charges by the French leading sports newspaper L'Equipe that he was a "symbol of intolerance."

The four-story house on lot 20 by 100 feet at 34 West Eighty-seventh Street has been sold by Isadore Epstein to the Marson Realty Corporation in a deal negotiated by Rubin Solove, broker. It is assessed at $30,000.

Many parties will be given at the Versailles Ball, to be held tomorrow night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the fund for the restoration of the historic Royal Chateau at Versailles. Mrs. William C. T. Gaynor heads the benefit committee and among those assisting her are Mrs. Basil Goulandris and Mrs. Clark Williams.

Since every one is devoted to Mary Martin and Charles Boyer, it would be a pleasure to report that their play is equal to their quality. The play is Norman Krasna's "Kind Sir," which was put on at the Alvin last evening with all the luxury that Broadway can afford.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- President Eisenhower met Republican electoral reverses today with a smiling comment that he had "lost skirmishes" before but never major wars.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 4 -- West German Government quarters expressed "great disappointment" tonight over the latest Soviet note. Reports reaching here indicated that the note made no mention of a four - power conference on Germany and Austria as proposed by the Western powers.
We appreciate very much the fine editorial which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 27 commending our efforts to raise the sum of $3,500,000 on behalf of our eighty-one member hospitals.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 4 -- Yugoslav authorities are raising with increasing persistence the question whether member nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization have the right to move on their own initiative the troops they have assigned to the Western military organization.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- The Republican organization, through an upset election victory of unexpected proportion, today had broken the Democrats' solid, two-year hold on City Hall offices.

A teacher and a clerk, who are among fifteen members of the city school system charged with insubordination, went on trial yesterday at the Board of Education headquarters, 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.
Baseball yesterday changed the balk rule to give the offensive team the option of accepting or declining a balk by the opposing pitcher.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Shortstop Eddie Joost today was named the third field manager in the history of the Philadelphia Athletics in a move so surprising that the deposed manager, Jimmie Dykes, knew nothing about it.

MANILA, Nov. 4 -- President Elpidio Quirino found fresh ammunition today for his campaign keynote of American intervention in the Philippine election in the presence in Manila Bay of the aircraft carrier Wasp and four destroyers on a casual visit.

Cocoa prices continued to rise sharply on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday. Most options were up the daily limit. Trading was influenced by sharp advances in London. Accra cocoa was about 1 cent above Monday's offerings for near-by delivery and Bahias rose about 1 1/2 cents to reach a new high for the year of 39.55 cents.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- Pennsylvania's football team will be in its best physical shape of the season when it plays Notre Dame here Saturday before a sell-out crowd of 74,711 at Franklin Field. So says Coach George Munger, and he says, too, that the spirit of his team is "terrific."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, said today he still thought a military man made a better money manager for the Army than would a civilian.
TOKYO, Nov. 4 (UP) -- Ed Lopat's All-Stars blasted nine home runs in the last five innings to swamp an all-Japan team, 16 to 2, before 30,000 fans today.

A diverse party of sixty, including a consumer representative and several of President Eisenhower's expert advisers, will gather today atop a mountain for four days of talk about the problems of economic security.
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- British officials are discussing ending with a curt "no sale" the present exchange of notes dealing with a four power conference between the Western allies and the Soviet Union.

PARIS, Nov. 4 -- Addressing the Cabinet today Georges Bidault, Foreign Minister, interpreted the Soviet note received yesterday as showing there was no chance of negotiating with Moscow at present. Other officials described the note as being as negative as possible and as merely repeating its predecessor of Sept. 28.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 4 -- A nation-wide drive to raise $5,000,000 to fight muscular dystrophy was launched in the White House today by Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower. She accepted a contribution envelope from 7-year-old Richard Fowler of Apollo, Penn., a victim of the disease.

A fashion design contest for students of universities, colleges and professional schools teaching fashion and textile design will be sponsored by Allen Knitting Mills of New York, it was announced yesterday. Two categories of designs will be judged, according to Harry F. Goldman, president.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Atomic Energy Commission is drafting a series of important amendments to the Atomic Energy Act to increase the participation of private industry in the program at home and to liberalize the exchange of atomic information among the Allies.
MELBOURNE, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Australia today made public its program for the 1956 Olympic Games in Melbourne.
A helicopter landing area on barges tied up at piers along the North River has been proposed by the city.

BACOLOD, the Philippines, Nov. 4 -- Behind boss rule and the bitter political passions in Negros Occidental Province lies a long-standing feud between clashing groups in the Philippines multimillion-dollar sugar industry.

In commenting on the refusal of the Supreme Court to review lower court decisions upholding price fixing John W. Anderson, president of the American Fair Trade Council, was quoted as saying the decision represented a "victory for the consumer."

The surface to be dealt with by the vacuum cleaner, rather than that appliance itself, was the subject of the third annual home vacuum cleaning conference yesterday at the Commodore Hotel. Held under the auspices of the Vacuum Cleaner Manufacturers Association, the meeting was attended by home economists in industry, the utility field and education.

MADRID, Nov. 4 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco pledged today that Spain would give the West "efficient help" against Soviet aggression through her new pact with the United States, but ruled out direct military cooperation now with Britain and France.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Department of the Treasury announced plans tonight to sell $1,500,000,000 more in discount bills. Thus it will extend for ninety-one days a bill borrowing of like amount coming due on Nov. 12.
Prospects for apparel and soft lines in the spring and the balance of next year are excellent for retailers and manufacturers who will take the opportunities that are open to them.

Val Peterson, Federal Civil Defense Administrator, predicted yesterday that "eventually" America might have to go underground to protect itself from surprise atom or hydrogen bomb attacks by guided missiles.
DETROIT, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Briggs Manufacturing Company employes had assurances from Chrysler Corporation today that the transfer of Briggs to Chrysler ownership would have little effect on their jobs.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Wheat reversed its early downtrend here today following reports of large flour sales. Mill buying of hedges turned active and futures prices closed sharply higher on the day after being 1 cent or more lower near the opening.
Lung cancer in the advanced stages has responded favorably in a number of cases to a large dosage of X-rays from a 2,000,000-volt machine, it was reported yesterday to the American Cancer Society.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, expressed today "surprise and considerable shock" at the statement yesterday by Henry Cabot Lodge, permanent United States delegate to the United Nations. yesterday on the Genocide Convention.

NEWARK, Nov. 4 -- This city, the largest in New Jersey, will have a Mayor and nine Councilmen to govern it instead of five City Commissioners, beginning next summer. The change was voted yesterday in a local referendum, after a bitterly fought campaign.

Events today: Herbert Burtis, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 12 noon; City College of New York String Orchestra and Chorus, Townsend Harris Hall Auditorium, 12:15 P. M.; "Rigoletto," City Center, 8:15; Philharmonic-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Eleanor Steber, Nell Tangeman, Harvey Smith-Spencer and Jerome Hines soloists, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.
CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 4 (UP) -- Sam Boulmetis completed a riding triple at Garden State Park today when he booted home Post Card, the 3-5 favorite, in the feature before a crowd of 17,334.

Next week Pakistan's Governor General will be in Washington for a visit to President Eisenhower and talks with Government officials. It is believed that a major part of these talks will center about exploring the possibilities of a military alliance between Pakistan and the United States.

Josephine Hull, veteran performers, opens on Broadway tonight as the star of "The Solid Gold Cadillac," a comedy by Howard Teichman and George S. Kaufman, at the Belasco Theatre. The curtain will rise at 8 o'clock.

INDIAN VILLAGE, Korea, Thursday, Nov. 5 -- After thirty minutes in the "explanation" tent, a prisoner is desperate, hoarse and gasping for breath like a drowning man. Though the day is cold, beads of perspiration stand out on his face. His rage is such that, were he turned loose for the moment, he would savagely assault the Communist lecturers.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 4 -- The City Charter Committee, a fusion of Democrats and independent Republicans, seemed certain tonight to capture five of the nine seats in the City Council in a contest with the regular Republican organization.

The Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation announced yesterday an extra dividend of 50 cents a share and a 25 per cent stock dividend, in addition to the regular quarterly disbursement of 50 cents a share.

Those searching for the exciting and luxurious in furs might find their requirements at Ritter Bros. Their collection shown yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel was impressive in its richness, with such designs as an almost floor-length theatre coat of lutetia mink.
Aviation notables will be honored today as the city's week-long celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of powered flight moves into its fourth day with the observance of New York Police Day.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Queen Elizabeth II sent word to Parliament to day that she would like her husband, the Duke of Edinburgh, to be regent -- that is acting head of the state -- should she become incompetent or die before her son is old enough to reign.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (UP) -- A former Air Force sergeant who once spilled a cup of coffee over the then General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower presented a painting today to the President.

ON the eve of the impending Triple Conference the political situation, at any rate in Eastern Europe, was by no means satisfactory. A precarious tranquillity had indeed been achieved in Greece, and it seemed that a free democratic Government, founded on universal suffrage and secret ballot, might be established there within a reasonable time.
Ticket agents and office clerks in thirty-five United States and Hawaii offices of the Northwest Airlines were slated to go on strike early today in a walk-out described by the company as "illegal."
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 5 -- Martiniano Passo, the managing editor of La Prensa, has been dismissed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller reassured state and territorial health officers today that Federal grants to state health programs would not be eliminated.

A group of specialists in parent education, financed by the Ford Foundation, has just completed the first step in developing a "packaged course" for parents' groups. The specialists hope ultimately to make the course available to any group that would like to use it.

Alicia Markova, one of the world's leading ballerinas, has been engaged by the fetropolitan Opera as guest artist for the cornLug season. She will make the first of several appearances on New Year's Eve in "Fledermaus," in the ballet choreographed by the 1etropolitan's ballet director, Zachary Solov. This is a light and gay role that departs widely from those i with which her name is usually associated, such as "Giselle" and "Swan Lake."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- During the week ended Nov. 4, member bank reserves increased $445,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

THE Soviet headquarters at Yalta were in the Yusupov Palace, and from this centre Stalin and Molotov and their generals carried on the government of Russia and the control of their immense front, now in violent action. President Roosevelt was given the even more splendid Livadia Palace, close at hand, and it was here, in order to spare him physical inconvenience, that all our plenary meetings were held.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 5 -- Vladimir Bakaleinikoff, conductor of special concerts for the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, died today after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

ALBANY, Nov. 5 -- The puzzling legal question of Senator Arthur H. Wicks' status as "Acting Lieutenant Governor" has prompted the State Controller's office to hold up the salaries of two aides he appointed to vacant posts in the Lieutenant Governor's office.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 5 -- Establishment of a pension program for studio craft-workers is a feature of the new contract terms agreed to yesterday by the major film companies and the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes. Confirmation of the pension plan, to which employes will make a contribution, was obtained today from labor and management sources.
The machines the home laundress uses and the substances she puts in them were discussed by speakers at the first day's meeting of the Seventh National Home Laundry Conference yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Members of the Industrial Management Society, including executives and production engineers, were told today that the "most critical" question confronting them is, "Where can industrial engineering training be obtained?"

VATICAN CITY, Nov. 5 (AP) -- A memorial library bearing the name of Pope Pius XII, to be built at St. Louis, Mo., will make available to scholars in the Western Hemisphere microfilm reproductions of the Vatican's priceless, ancient manuscripts.

OTTAWA, Nov. 5 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian General Electric Company, Ltd., is resigning as operator-manager of the Government's big jet engine repair and overhaul plant at Toronto and the Government is negotiating with de Haviland Aircraft of Canada, Ltd., to take over the plant on Jan. 1.
DETROIT, Nov. 5 -- Sales and net earnings of the Packard Motor Car Company for the first nine months of 1953 were about double those for the same period in 1952.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- United States officials gloomily put aside today any immediate hope they might have had for negotiating an end to the "cold war."
PARIS, Nov. 6 -- The Government announced today that it had closed twenty butcher shops in the Paris region for selling meat at prices above those officially set.

It was unfortunate that anyone could have placed the construction of American "intervention" in the Philippine election upon a routine call to Manila of a few of our naval vessels. It is a good thing, however that the misunderstanding has been rapidly cleared up.

MONTREAL, Nov. 5 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens surged from behind with three goals in the final period tonight to beat the New York Rangers, 4 -- 3, before a crowd of 14,013 and maintain their home ice unbeaten streak this season.

ALBANY, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation today arrested twenty-seven civilian employes who it said took part in "share-the-wealth" thefts of $7,803 worth of Government property from Army depots at Schenectady and Voorheesville, N. Y. It said a twenty-eighth would be arrested when released from a hospital.

Sol A. Rosenblatt, a lawyer who was shot twice as he started to enter his residence at 525 Park Avenue on the evening of March 6, 1952, asserted yesterday he knew no reason why anyone would want to shoot him.
Prices of cotton futures declined yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, with active months off 10 to 26 points.

OTTAWA, Nov. 5 -- A proposed pre-Christmas shopping spree by Canadian Government employes in Watertown in northern New York, where prices are lower than in this capital, has aroused the indignation of the Ottawa Board of Trade and many merchants here.
A Federal Court judge made it clear yesterday that defiance of the fair-trade laws of this state could be an expensive matter.
described yesterday as "particularly deficient" in facilities for routine X-raying of hospital admissions.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- British Government securities increasingly dominated the stock markets here today. A further increase, announced last night, in Britain's gold and dollar reserves stimulated buying of gilt edge issues and prices advanced as much as three-eighths per cent.

BERLIN, Nov. 5 -- The first shipment of a United States Christmas food gift to the German people is due to arrive in Bremen tomorrow. The program is designed to aid needy residents of West Berlin and West Germany.

In the event of a Supreme Court decision declaring racial segregation in education unconstitutional Negro private colleges will survive only if they are of the highest caliber, according to Dr. Rufus E. Clement, president of Atlanta University.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 5 -- Dr. Mordecai Nurock of Jerusalem, a member of the Israeli Parliament and a leader of the Mizrachi party in Israel, urged Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion tonight to reconsider his announced intention of retiring from Government service.

Intermediate and long term ] tTreasury bonds came into the market for sale in excess of demand yesterday, and with dealers cagy about extending positions, prices were forced down slightly. Offerhqgs were ascribed to the! need of certain investors to raise cash with which to pay for sub.scriptions to the new 2$ per cent issue.

The program that Ida Krehm assembled for her Town Hall piano recital last night was of more than usual interest. The "big" number was Schumann's Intermezzi, Op. 4, a work that for some reason pianists choose to avoid. And yet, here is a piece with the poetry of the "David" Dances, the romanticism of the "Kreisleriana" and the whimsy of the "Carnaval."

Many dinner parties were given in advance of the evening performance of the National Horse Show last night at the Madison Square Garden, which attracted a representative gathering of members of society, the armed services and members of the diplomatic and financial worlds.
SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Nov. 5 -- The Saarlanders, who can never be sure from one generation to the next whether they will be French or German, like the idea of becoming "European."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- President Eisenhower designated the New York State Power Authority today to act as United States agent in developing the huge hydroelectric power potential of the St. Lawrence River.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- If reorganized according to a pending plan, the Long Island Rail Road could use 12 to 14 per cent of estimated $60,000,000 annual gross earnings to pay fixed charges and income tax.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Misgivings over the Administration's attitude toward the Point Four program, providing technical assistance to underdeveloped countries, were expressed today by five Democratic Senators.

This is the time that apples come to market, and so it is a good time to sing the praises of the praiseworthy apple. It is a good time to renew acquaintances with the deep red Baldwin, the bright red Jonathan, the dark red Winesap and the green, green Greening.
YONKERS, Nov. 5 (AP) -- For the first time in Yonkers Raceway's four-year history only three horses finished in an eight-entry field tonight as a result of a six-horse mix-up.

Though points in dispute are now being referred to staff advisers, the preliminary meeting at Panmunjom, called to make final arrangements for the political conference on Korea, has run into a deadlock which ten days of talking and a most conciliatory attitude on the part of the American delegate have been unable to break.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, has told the United Packinghouse Workers of America, C. I. O., that although it is free of Communist domination at the top, there are Communist influences below and they should be removed.

CHERRYFIELD, Me., Nov. 5 -- For the first time, we are leaving Maine without a deer, but despite this lack of venison, the trip was a successful one. We had three days of fine hunting in an area where deer apparently were present. No hunter could ask for more.

New York will conduct its last scheduled air-raid siren test of the year on Tuesday at 11 A. M. Herbert R. O'Brien, Civil Defense Director, said yesterday that additional sirens had been added to cover "blind spots" revealed in previous tests.

Cadets and other military and civilian personnel at the United States Military Academy at West Point completed yesterday a three-day contribution of 810 pints of blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.
LONDON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Government tonight submitted to Parliament an order creating an interim administration for British Guiana under close London supervision.

Exotic blooms from greenhouses and homely flowers and vegetables from suburban backyards joined forces for the forty-sixth annual autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York, which opened yesterday at the Essex House, 160 Central Park South. This three-day show is being held for the benefit of the Goodwill Industries of New York, Inc.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- The United Nations political and security committee voted today to postpone until Nov. 23 further discussion of Burma's charges that Nationalist China was guilty of aggression by maintaining Chinese troops on Burmese soil. The United States, Thailand and China are paying the cost of an airlift that will move 2,000 troops from Burma to Formosa.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- It seems reasonable to assume that Henry Cabot Lodge's explanation of the vote cast recently by the United States in favor of the United Nations resolution to hasten ratification of the projected genocide treaty was part of the effort of the Eisenhower Administration to defeat the Bricker Amendment to the Constitution.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 5 (UP) -- Unbeaten West Virginia moved a step closer today to a possible Sugar Bowl invitation as a special committee of the Southern Conference recommended that the loop approve participation in bowl games recognized by the National Collegiate A. A.

William Shakespeare, Sam and Bella Spewack, Cole Porter and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, not to mention Howard Keel, Kathryn Grayson and two or three dozen other folks, may share the honors among them for one of the year's more magnificent musical films, "Kiss Me Kate," which came dancing and tumbling into the Music Hall yesterday.

" THE strength of any political system will, in the long run, depend upon its capacity to protect people against conditions of want that are now becoming increasingly intolerable," says Fairfield Osborn in his new book, "The Limits of the Earth."* Hungry people will resort to violence, like the Mau Mau, or succumb to the false blandishments of communism, like the Chinese.

While we do not wish to detract from the work being done by the United States Department of Justice and the lawyers representing the several states, we believe mention should have been made in Arthur Krock's column of Oct. 27 of work being done by others in connection with the school segregation cases.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 5 -- The Western powers are considering the lifting of interzonal travel restrictions in Germany, it is understood here. United States officials hope that an announcement to that effect can be made within the next twenty-four hours.
Unless there is a radical change in his thinking, Peewee Reese will not manage the Brooklyn Dodgers next year.

The City of Philadelphia has decided against offering an issue of $20,000,000 of bonds this fall to finance construction. The city is reviewing the spending program and present plans do not call for the issuance of bonds until after the first of the year.

An investor has purchased the ten-story and penthouse apartment building on lot 50 by 120 feet at 952 Fifth Avenue, near East Seventy-sixth Street, from Allan Stillman and others for cash over a mortgage of $525,000. Assessed at $525,000, the property contains thirty-five apartments and was sold through Henry Rice of James Felt Co., brokers.

National Horse Show international jumping glory went to Great Britain again in Madison Square Garden last night when Patricia Smythe rode two horses to victory for the President of Mexico Trophy. There was distinction for America, too, because the United States equestrian team was a winner at the matinee.
Permit me to correct an error of fact which appears in your editorial of Oct. 31 entitled "Palestine in the U. N."

Aviation is "a potent force in our economy and a primary agency in deterring aggression in the world today and in our national security," Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle said here yesterday. General Doolittle and four other aviators were honored by Mayor Impelliterri in ceremonies on the steps of City Hall as part of the city's week-long observance of the fiftieth anniversary of powered flight. The Mayor presented five scrolls.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 5 -- Officials of a building union were indicted tonight on charges of extortion in an alleged shakedown of $360,000 from 250 builders over a five-year period.

The one-story taxpayer building at 38-76 Tenth Street in Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the Rebarb Realty Company to a client of Spooner Spooner, attorneys. The property occupies a plot about 25 by 100 feet, Sydney M. Sievel Co. were the brokers in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

An article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 12 reported that the Special Regents Commission appointed to review subversive textbooks had never held a meeting. The article stated: "When the commission was appointed by the Regents on Feb. 6, 1952, it was charged with investigating a textbook only on receipt of a complaint from an individual or a group.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- Lebanon declared in the United Nations today that the problem of 850,000 homeless Arab refugees could be settled only by their repatriation to Israel Economic schemes to improve conditions in the Arab states are not sufficient, her spokesman added

A strike of ticket agents, baggage checkers and clerical employes failed to halt operations of the Northwest Orient Airlines yesterday. The walkout involved 1,500 members of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks, A. F. L., employed at the company's headquarters in St. Paul and at airports from New York to Honolulu.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 (AP) -- There aren't four better managers in the major leagues than Jimmie Dykes.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Everett D. Reese, president of the American Bankers Association, urged the bankers today to combine promotion of public understanding of "sound money" with increased effort to sell United States saving bonds.
SAN JOSE, Calif., Nov. 5 -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, said tonight the Republicans "have not been too sharp in our sales talk this year."
TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 6 -- New Communist delaying tactics prevented the "explanations" to anti-Red war prisoners in Korea today.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The Archbishop of York, traditional political spokesman for the Church of England, said today that "the Jewish vote in New York has had a paralyzing effect on the United Nations'' in the Israeli-Arab problem.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Cargill, Inc., one of the world's largest grain companies, was named defendant today in a triple damage anti-trust suit filed in Federal District Court by two Chicago grain dealers. The suit charged that Cargill depressed the oats market illegally in 1951 and 1952 by importing large quantities of Canadian oats.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Enthusiastic appreciation greeted Madeleine de Rauch's midseason showing in which she combined with chic restraint tweed and satin for cocktail ensembles consisting of reefer and slim princess frock.

TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 6 -- Allied and Communist delegates agreed at Panmunjom, Korea, today to let their advisers try to break the deadlock that has been delaying arrangements for a Korean peace conference.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- United States officials discounted today the likelihood of any war of restrictions on civil aviation between the United States and Canada.

Robert Moses said yesterday that he had accepted the invitation of Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. to serve the city as Park Commissioner and City Construction Coordinator after Mr. Wagner takes office Jan. 1.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 5 (UP) -- Coach Frank Leahy returned to his Notre Dame football duties after a twelve-day absence due to illness today, "very pleased" with the way his club performed without him.

Two little countries that are not garrisoned by foreign troops and are not anybody's satellites stand out on today's map of Europe. One is Switzerland, secure down to now in its age-old neutrality and its stubborn mountains. The other is Finland, which came out of the Second World War with 13 per cent of its territory gone and a heavy indemnity payable to Russia.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- By a margin of only four votes, a United Nations committee officially endorsed today the status of Puerto Rico as a self-governing commonwealth.

THE nearest thing in this city to the old New England general store with cracker-barrel forum is the Quong Yuen Shing at 72 Mott Street in Chinatown. Neither its sober front nor dark interior has changed in seventy years.

Penelope the platypus was exposed at the Bronx Zoo yesterday as a faker who posed as an expectant mother just to lead a life of leisure. Thus came to a disappointing end -- at least temporarily -- one of the longest zoological guessing games in history.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- A new plan for distribution to the public of tickets to United Nations sessions goes into effect tomorrow. The plan is expected to stop individual phone reservations for tickets and give a greater percentage of the available tickets to organizations at the expense of individuals.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- The big Social Security issue confronting the next session of Congress will be how far the Government should go to supplement the savings of the individual, in the opinion of Edward T. Gibson, executive director of the American Assembly.

Broadway will get "The Confidential Clerk," T. S. Eliot's reigning London hit in the dramatic field, on Feb. 3. Discussions were said to have been concluded yesterday by Henry Sherek, West End producer of the comedy in blank verse and the recently formed New York combine of Robert Whitehead, Roger L. Stevens and Robert V. Dowling.
Senator Joseph R. McCarthy declared yesterday that at Harvard University students were exposed to "Communist professors" and party philosophy.

CEBU, the Philippines, Nov. 5 -- Sergio Osmena Jr., son of the wartime President of the Philippines, is handling a canny election campaign for President Elpidio Quirino and the Liberal party in this second largest Philippines city.

One speaks with mixed feelings of the performance of the Beethoven "Missa Solemnis" by the Philharmonic - Symphony Society, Dimitri Mitropoulos conductor, the Westminster choir and solo quartet, last night in Carnegie Hall.

Some real progress is being made on the troublesome question of anti-Communist Chinese irregulars in Burma. The core of the Chinese group, some 2,000 former regulars who are and can be controlled by Gen. Li Mi, will shortly be taken out and air-lifted to Formosa. As for those who refuse this and remain, the Chinese Government in Formosa has specifically repudiated them.

Women headed by Mrs. Richard C. Bondy Jr. and including Mrs. John P. Lins and Mrs. Leonard Locke are aiding the sale of tickets for the performance of "The Solid Gold Cadillac" on the night of Nov. 18 at the Belasco Theatre for the benefit of the Washington Square Home for Friendless Girls. They have been holding meetings recently at the Pierre for advance plans for the benefit.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., announced late yesterday a reduction averaging slightly more than one-fourth cent a gallon in the wholesale price of regular grade gasoline throughout the Eastern marketing territory.

The voluntary hospitals of New York City receive their income from a number of sources. A major portion is in fees paid by and for patients. Some hospitals obtain income from endowments and from private contributions.

NOVARA, Italy, Nov. 5 (AP) -- A defense attorney, appointed by the court for Ildo Icardi, said today in a final plea that the former American Army lieutenant had to eliminate Maj. William Holohan "as an obstacle in the fight for victory."

The median percentage of advertising expenditures to net sales for all industries shows a slight {drop this year compared with last --2.6 per cent and 2.75 per cent, respectively. This is reported in the 1953 annual survey by the As-' sociation of National Advertisers covering data from 170 companies.

THE day before Notre Dame squared off against Navy, the Irish varsity followed the midshipmen into the stadium for a final workout. The green-jerseyed horde kicked and passed and ran through signals. It may interest George Halas to know that one lad outkicked, outpassed and outsprinted all the others. He was the trim and superbly conditioned Johnny Lujack.

Volume increased yesterday on many items on the New York commodity exchanges. Cocoa had the largest sales since Aug. 21, the world sugar contract since Sept. 24 and cottonseed oil, potatoes and coffee since Oct. 15.

DETROIT, Nov. 5 -- Circuit Judge Miles N. Culehan, sitting as a one-man grand jury, took the first step today toward the ouster of Orville L. Hubbard, Mayor of suburban Dearborn. Both are Republicans.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Commerce Department has been silenced on the Taft-Hartley law debate, and the Labor Department is reported to be at the bottom of it.

Egg production is at a record high for this time of year the Poultry and Egg National Board reported yesterday. As a result, shoppers this week-end will find all sizes of eggs, large, medium and pullet, down 4 cents a dozen.

Since Josephine Hull can do no wrong, there are some charming moments in "The Solid Gold Cadillac," which opened at the Belasco last evening. Howard Teichmann and George S. Kaufman, collaborators, present her as a motherly stockholder who destroys the serenity of a corporation annual meeting by asking the officers some leading questions.

GUATEMALA, Nov. 5 -- The emergence of the Communists to a position of dominance in Guatemala has continued during the past six months. It is evident that from the United States point of view the situation here will go on getting worse.
Wall Street took another look yesterday at Tuesday's election results and interpreted them as bullish.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Following is the unofficial English translation of the Soviet note of Nov. 3 replying to a Western proposal for a meeting on Germany and Austria, as issued by the State Department.
The new Committee for a National Trade Policy has started a research project to illustrate the extent to which industry and labor are dependent on a high level of exports.

In the matter of enlisting the aid of private companies in the development of nuclear power the chief difficulty that confronts the Atomic Energy Commission is the interrelationship of nuclear power and nuclear weapons. Because of this interrelationship the Government cannot afford to imperil national defense or to undermine its foreign policy.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., NOV. 5 -- The great outdoors became a classroom today as twenty-four wide-eyed sixth-graders from the Edgemont School, in the adjoining Town of Greenburgh, took to the woods for an on-the-spot lesson -- and adventure -- in outdoor education.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 5 (AP) -- A suit was filed in Superior Court, Trenton, yesterday to force Leschen Sons Rope Company of St. Louis, Mo., to pay $199.22 a share to stockholders.
Business borrowings from New York banks were marked by cross currents last week, holding the expansion of such credits to $3,000,000.

KHARTUM, the Sudan, Nov. 5 -- The voting for a Parliament in the Sudan, which is a step toward democracy, was delayed in a jungle constitutency in south Sudan yesterday by 1,000 Dinka tribesmen who thought they needed spears to exercise their franchise.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- Dr. G. J. van Heuven Goedhart, recently re-elected as United Nations Commissioner for Refugees, warned today that regardless of any political decision on Trieste, 4,300 refugees in the disputed territory must be removed from this "contentious area where new dangers may arise."
GENEVA, Nov. 5 -- The Soviet Union has asked to join the International Labor Organization.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 5 -- Unofficial returns disclosed today that 301 candidates had been named for the 282 seats in Yugoslavia's new Federal Council. They are all members of the Socialist-Alliance of Working Peoples party.

A dispute over higher wages for tank-truck drivers threatened yesterday to put new pressure on milk prices. This possibility developed as city and Federal agencies began separate investigations into the penny-a-quart price rise that went into effect here Tuesday.

President Harry D. Gideonse of Brooklyn College said yesterday that a decision on the retention of intercollegiate football at Brooklyn College would be rendered within ten days. Gideonse's statement came in the face of reports that the Kingsmen, without a victory in three years, would drop the gridiron sport after their season finale against Upsala tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Government moved today to discourage veterans from seeking free hospital treatment for non-service-connected ailments when they could afford to pay.

A model of a French ship of the line, believed to have been built in 1790 and probably one of the few in existence in this country, has been acquired by the Marine Historical Association in Mystic, Conn.
The backlog of defense orders of the Electric Auto-Lite Company has "shown a declining tendency," according to Royce G. Martin, president and chairman.
Mayor Impellitteri asked Governor Dewey yesterday to include consideration of Federal Social Security benefits for city employes on the agenda of the Nov. 17 special session of the State Legislature.
The first annual Xavier award was received last night by Cardinal Spellman at a Jesuit Mission Benefit dinner. The event, at the Commodore Hotel, was attended by 1,300 guests.

WASHINGTON Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Government reported today that deliveries under its purchase programs for domestic tungsten, manganese, chrome, mica, beryl, asbestos and columbium-tantalum all are running far below the amounts authorized to be purchased.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5 -- Plans for modernizing Snellenburgs Department store, opposite the Reading terminal, at a cost of $4,500,000 were announced today.
At a crowded hearing before the Board of Air Pollution Control yesterday, several women supported stricter regulations for apartment incinerators and other sources of smoke and soot.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 5 -- Reckless motorists pouring over borders from New York and other states have brought death and destruction by causing almost 50 per cent of the highway accident fatalities in Delaware.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- An official of the American Metal Company expressed the conviction today that higher tariffs will not benefit the domestic lead and zinc industry.

TRIESTE, Nov. 5 -- Pro-Italian demonstrations got out of hand in this disputed city today and the police killed two persons and wounded fifteen. Scores of other demonstrators and policemen were injured and about three dozen persons were taken to hospitals.

Republican state leaders have agreed to support an attempt by the Brooklyn party organization to carve out two Republican Senate districts in Kings County as part of a general legislative reapportionment.
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- A noisy demonstration by 3,000 members of engineering unions was broken up by mounted police here today as employers rejected their demands for a 15 per cent wage increase.
Columbia's speedy halfback, Bob Mercier, is not likely to be available for the game with Dartmouth tomorrow at Baker Field because of an injury.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, ruled today that Congressional committees might interview prisoners in Federal jails but only under procedures he established to protect the prisoners from unfair treatment.

Louise T. Weber has sold the three-story building at 109 Graham Avenue in Brooklyn containing a store and four apartments. The property was purchased by Mike Petrovsky, Edwin E. Roberts and Emilia Gorofsky, who were represented by Sulsky Selawsky, attorneys.

THE actors in "Outlaw's Reckoning," a Western drama seen on the A. B. C. network on Tuesday night, finished last to the carpenters, plasters, painters and horses. The production simply ran away with the play.
The Clifford B. Harmon International Aviation Trophy, which had been missing since May, 1940, has been returned to this country.
A Senate subcommittee this week started cutting into the heart of the problem of more defense for fewer dollars.

The fate of the Saar is one of the most delicate and complex problems in Europe today -- which is saying a great deal. That is why, when any new development arises, a sense of anxiety and tension is bound to accompany whatever happens. Today the French Parliament is due to start a debate on the ratification of the seven revised conventions between the Saar Government and France.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 5 -- Several United Nations delegates who are stanch friends of the United States rejoiced today over President Eisenhower's instructions to the Secretaries of State and Defense to get together on their public statements.

I read your admirable editorial "The Nature of the Enemy" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 30, and I was horrified by the reports on Communist brutality in the concentration camps and the hunger marches in Korea. I may even say that I was more horrified than millions of Americans who fortunately, have never had to suffer foreign occupation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UP) -- The State Department announced today that 306 American employes had been dropped for security reasons since President Eisenhower assumed control of the Government. The department also discharged 178 foreign employes from stations abroad.
The National Dairy Products Corporation and its domestic and Canadian subsidiaries had a net profit of $24,655,471 in the nine months through September.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- If the cheers of a more than ordinarily excited first night audience are anything to go by, Terence Rattigan's new play, "The Sleeping Prince," will add one more long run to the writer's almost unbroken list of successes.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 5 -- There will be no coalition of West German Chancellor Adenauer's government parties and the Socialists in the city of Hamburg.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Nov. 5 -Ernest C. Gould, executive secretary of the Watertown Chamber of Commerce, said today that advertisements had been placed in the R. A. News because newspapers in Ottawa had refused to take advertising from Watertown merchants, presumably to protect their own.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 5 -- A junior-size atom smasher that is looked upon as a possible tool for bringing nuclear research within reach of smaller colleges was unveiled today at the University of California.
VERNAL, Utah, Nov. 5 (AP) -- An unexplained explosion left eight miners missing and hurled and burned timbers in a deep, itrench-like gilsonite mine at BoInanza early today.
Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester Country Club was reelected president of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the group's annual meeting in the Hotel Shelton yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The Government announced plans today to end all food rationing by next summer and to restore free trading in all agricultural products while continuing price guarantees to farmers.

Millions of Americans from coast to coast viewed on television last night a demonstration at the University of Chicago of a new type of atomic weapon. It was designed for a more effective fight on cancer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Two imaginary atomic bombs struck downtown Washington and the vicinity of the Pentagon this morning. If the attack had been real, officials said, this would be the situation tonight:
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden accused the Egyptian Government today of intervening by propaganda "and a variety of other means" in the elections now going on in the Sudan.
The New York City Opera Company presented "Rigoletto" at the City Center last evening, with a young tenor named Gianni Iaia making his debut as the Duke of Mantua.

One would-be rescuer was killed and two others were overcome at noon yesterday in an unsuccessful attempt to remove an unconscious ship's officer from the gas-filled hold of the Norwegian motor vessel Granville.

The Transit Authority had a busy day yesterday. It welcomed a new fifth member, authorized the spending of $27,388,225 for improvements, including 200 new cars, a painting program and better lighting in trains, and was told that the 15-cent fare had failed to yield the expected revenues in October.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said today that Soviet rejection of talks on German unity had left the Allies with no choice but completion of their military defenses and association of West Germany with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (UP) -- The National Education Association said yesterday it was more than ten times cheaper to pay for a child's education than to let him run wild and become a juvenile delinquent.
Two leading spokesmen for the western democracies called last night for concentration on improving the economic position of the free world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Reduced railroad rates on heavy shipments of manufactured iron and steel articles were put into effect throughout the South today with the sanction of the Interstate Commerce Commission.
ROME, Nov. 5 -- Three French cardinals defended before Pope Pius XII today the activities of French worker-priests.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5 -- A battle over alleged pro-Communist ties marked the campaigns today of the principal contenders in California's special Congressional election next Tuesday.

For about a decade, the Equity Library Theatre, dedicated to the principle that performers need be active to remain in good fettle, has usefully served as a showcase for actors "at rest." But, besides being utilitarian minded, the E. L. T. also is civic spirited enough to have conjured recently the noteworthy scheme unflatteringly labeled "Scrapbook Productions."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Fees will be increased next year for Federal licenses, permits, certificates and the like under new policies laid down by Joseph M. Dodge, Director of the Bureau of the Budget.

Representative Jacob K. Javits called yesterday for a drastic revision in procedures of Congressional investigative committees to safeguard the "rights and reputations of witnesses and those named" by the committees.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Net profit of Zenith Radio Corporation in the first nine months of 1953 was $4,098,074. or $8.32 a share, an increase of 59 per cent from $2,576,212, or $5.23 a share in the 1952 period. E. F. McDonald Jr., president, reported today. He also disclosed that Zenith was planning to produce a limited quantity of color TV receivers.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 5 (UP) -Chamier, the hero of this year's Irish Derby, arrived by plane today from Ireland for his "pinch runner" assignment in Saturday's second edition of the Washington D. C. International race at Laurel.
C. T. Chenery's Fly-Lo scored his second straight victory in the Empire-at-Jamaica meeting yesterday. Not more than a length separated the first five finishers.

One of the minor triumphs of Election Day was approval by the voters of Tennessee of eight amendments to their State Constitution. What is so remarkable about that? a New Yorker might well ask, mindful of the ease and frequency with which we amend our own Constitution.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 5 -- Charlie Caldwell confesses that he doesn't know how to figure Harvard's football team. But he has definite convictions that Princeton is going to find itself in a dogfight at Cambridge on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday numbered 780,863 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
DETROIT, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The manufacturing division of the auto industry has cut back its production schedules for this month.

YONKERS, Nov. 5 -- Decisions on its suspensions of the trainer-driver, Wayne (Curly) Smart, and his assistant, Carl Larsen, were reserved by the New York State Harness Racing Commission after a hearing today.
TRENTON, Nov. 5 -- Governor-elect Robert B. Meyner declared today that he believed his victory in Tuesday's election was no particular reflection on the Administration of President Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 2 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year.

" Three Forbidden Stories," an Italian-made drama in three episodes, has been scheduled to have its local premiere on Saturday, Nov. 14, at the Baronet Theatre, it was announced yesterday by the distributors, Ellis Films. Gino Cervi, Frank Lattimore, Elenora Rossi Drago, Antonella Lualdi and Lia Amanda have the principal roles.
BERLIN, Nov. 5 -- The riots of June 17 and the subsequent slow-downs in factories have curbed East German production, but the effect has been less than that expected by Western experts.

The bi-state Waterfront Commission signed its first leases yesterday for offices to control dock hiring. One lease covered space at 64 Union Street, Brooklyn, and a second at 22 Wave Street, Stapleton, S. I.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- All grain and soybean futures were strong at the start of trading today, extending the late recoveries of yesterday. The demand was quickly filled however and a reactionary trend developed. Buyers were cautious, and there was considerable profit-taking by yesterday's buyers.

The grass-fed beef now in plentiful supply make juicy, flavorful meat loaves at reasonable cost. This beef has been fed none of the grain that gives fat and tenderness (bread, cereal, potato, etc.), meat, too low in tissue fat for successful broiling and roasting, is tenderized by grinding and kept moist by the addition of fat.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Compensatory benefit plans for business executives were suggested today as a means of offsetting inflation and income tax rises.

HANOI, Vietnam, Nov. 6 -- Bao Dai, Chief of State of Vietnam, is experiencing difficulties in his talks with Vietnamese leaders who, he finds, are insistent upon changes in the text of the French Constitution in defining the French Union.

Moscow's celebration yesterday of the thirty-sixth anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution was the first such event since Joseph Stalin's death, but the late dictator's impress was evident. For the first time since last March there was a formal mourning ceremony in his honor, a sharp contrast to the implied attacks on him during the recent campaign against the "cult of personality."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended on Tuesday.

Columbia opens a three-game home stand today when a rapidly improving Dartmouth eleven, fresh from a 32-0 upset of Yale, invades Baker Field. The kick-off is scheduled for 1:30 P. M. Navy will be met next Saturday and Rutgers a week later.
ALBANY, Nov. 6 -- James R. Macduff, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, has urged the state's 5,600,000 drivers to use chains in preference to "snow tires" to reduce the hazards of winter driving.
Canadian riders dominated the West Point Challenge Trophy competition at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night by placing first and second before a crowd of 10,000.
ROME. Nov. 6 -- Demonstrations in protest against the killing of two Italians in Trieste yesterday were held in major Italian cities today and in some places degenerated into rioting.
CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. urged again tonight that some reluctant witnesses should be forced to testify by granting them immunity to subsequent Federal prosecution.
The State Department of Insurance got a special counsel yesterday to head its inquiry into union welfare funds.

Representing a new approach to merchandising, a program designed to "insure" its distributors and dealers against cold weather has been established by the Mitchell Manufacturing Company, maker of air-conditioning equipment, Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Following are the texts of the White House statement and President Eisenhower's Executive Order, which it accompanied, on "Safeguarding Official Information in the Interests of the Defense of the United States":
WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 6 -- Warnings of traffic violations instead of arrests are flouted by the average motorist "as a slap on the wrist," a group of traffic experts believes.

The mixture of finely ground liver with seasonings that we call pate is largely available in this country in canned form. Canning connoisseurs say, may not change flavor in a way that can be detected by the average palate. But it does impair taste to some degree for the gourmet. He usually prefers a fresh pate.

Jewish organizations and individuals, joined by at least one non-Jewish group, replied sharply yesterday to the charge made Thursday in London by the Archbishop of York that "the Jewish vote in New York" exercised undue influence on the United Nations.

Your article of Oct. 28 about the improvement of the Eastern Boulevard Bridge on Bruckner Boulevard in the Bronx, which cost over two million dollars and which still did not eliminate the bottleneck of the railroad bridge over Whitlock Avenue, just one block south, justifies the opinion that thousands of motorists must have had while driving past the area during the many months of construction.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- President Eisenhower issued today his heralded Executive Order prescribing how defense information should be safeguarded. It voided former President Truman's controversial order on the same subject.
Fifty visitors braved the season's first snow yesterday to take a look at a new type of Navy ship after she had tied up here ending her maiden shakedown voyage.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- The United Nations plans to cut its staff by about 15 per cent within the next two years.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Nov. 6 -- The Penn State football squad, which meets Fordham here tomorrow, left the campus tonight during a snowstorm for a secret hideaway.

The college-trained woman who regards her job as a stopgap before marriage shouldn't be surprised if no interesting job awaits her when her children are grown. Mrs. Millicent Carey McIntosh said yesterday.

" Gratitude," said Aesop some 2,500 years ago, "is the sign of noble souls." This being the case -- and since gratitude is a rare virtue among nations -- the American people will duly appreciate the visit of the present-day. Greeks, King Paul and Queen Frederika, to convey their thanks for the help extended by the United States to their country.

TRENTON, Nov. 6 -- The New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission has set midnight tomorrow as a deadline for the filing of applications by all persons subject to the licensing provisions of the bi-state waterfront act.

NEW DELHI, India. Nov. 6 -- This is a day of traditional goodwill in India. It is a happy coincidence, from the United States point of view, that it comes when its stock is going up and that of the Communists is falling.
Charges of anti-Jewish discrimination in the admission policies of a New York State medical school were withdrawn yesterday by the American Jewish Congress.
President Eisenhower's Administration is keeping all its campaign promises, Representative Charles A. Halleck, Republican of Indiana, asserted yesterday.

Operations of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 resulted in a net profit of $2,795,911. This compares with $1,773,875 for the same period in 1952. The report was issued yesterday by Captain E. V. Rickenbacker, chairman.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Newspaper editors applauded the new Government information order issued by the White House today, as a gain in their fight for a free flow of news. They served notice, however, that they would keep a close watch on the new system.

The Beekman-Downtown Hospital, which recently occupied its new quarters in the block on William Street from Beekman to Spruce Streets, has sold the old seven-story Beekman Hospital building at Beekman and Water Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky returned today to the old tough Stalin line. He charged that the "aggressive North Atlantic bloc" was trying to place a ring of military bases around the Soviet Union and the "people's democracies."

William C. De Koning Sr., Nassau County labor boss, his son and five other unionists were revealed yesterday to have been named in the two building shakedown indictments that were returned Thursday. night by the holdover Nassau grand jury.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov., 6 -- Israel complained to the United Nations truce supervision organization in Jerusalem today that armed Jordanians murdered a guard last night in an attack upon a post along the railway track north of Hadera in the coastal plain.
The City Commissioner of Investigation yesterday ordered ten big metropolitan milk distributors to produce records of their pricing practices for the last three years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Two doctors on the staff of the National Cancer Institute of the Public Health Service at Bethesda, Md., received a patent this week for a method of growing human tissue in a special laboratory flask, starting with a single living cell taken from the body.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- An echo of the struggle between the Southern states and the railroads over the level of rates on manufactured goods from points in the South to the North, which led to a general investigation by the Interstate Commerce Commission, was heard today in that agency.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Defense Department called today for the draft of 23,000 men in January.

EL OBEID, the Sudan, Nov. 5 -- A survey in Khartum and Omdurman and at whistlestops along the railroad to Kordofan, once a stronghold of the Dervish empire, suggests that the political successors of the Dervishes will lose the urban constituencies in the Sudan's first contested election.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 6 -- Harvard, which lost a strong link in its offense and defense when Quarterback Bob Hardy was sidelined with a fractured elbow, may be without Capt. Dick Clasby in the forty-sixth annual meeting with favored Princeton at the Stadium tomorrow.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- In a speech broadcast from Moscow tonight the President of the Soviet Union stressed the importance to world communism of the Chinese alliance, the opportunities for Communist policy throughout Asia and a multiplicity of economic problems on the home front.
The annual meeting of the American Cancer Society at the Commodore Hotel ended yesterday with the election of officers and directors for the coming year.

Michael Danna, an 11-year-old victim of muscular dystrophy, braved yesterday's snow to greet a token force of nearly 100 letter carriers, who will be among the 100,000 postmen seeking $5,000,000 to finance research into the crippling and often fatal disease.

The Trieste affair is too serious to be minimized -- and much too serious to be exaggerated. Late dispatches indicate that Anglo-American troops have restored order in Trieste and that Italian police have dispersed the rioters outside the American and British Embassies in Rome. But this was not accomplished without shooting.
George Cable Wright is a fine person and a good newspaper man. But an inaccuracy crept into his story on the New Jersey political campaign which appeared on Page 1 of THE TIMES of Nov. 3.

Net sales of Chrysler Corporation and wholly-owned domestic subsidiaries for the first nine months of 1953 were 49.5 per cent above those of a year ago. Earnings however showed a 6.7 per cent decline.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 6 -- Yale will meet Temple in the Bowl tomorrow in quest of its fourth victory of the season after two ties and an upset defeat by Dartmouth in its last three games.

There may be disappointment but there can be no particular surprise in the Soviet Union's reply on the question of the proposed Four-Power meeting. If the Soviet Union really wanted any early solution of problems such as those of Germany, Austria and even Korea, action would have been taken long before this.
LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told a member of the House of Commons today that the British Government was eager to encourage an expansion of legitimate trade with the Soviet Union.

Attorney General Herbert Brownell and Paul A. Walker, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, have been asked by Alfred M. Lilienthal, author and lecturer and critic of American policy on Israel, to investigate what Mr. Lilienthal terms an "information blackout" on radio and television with respect to Zionism and anti-Zionism.
