LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 6 -- For the first time in more than a quarter of a century the totalitarian regime of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar will face opposition candidates in the national elections Sunday.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Miami Typographical Union, A. F. L., has ended a disagreement with Greater Miami newspapers that lasted nearly five years.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- The Administration may ask Congress to provide additional Social Security beyond the extension of coverage already requested by President Eisenhower, a Cabinet member said tonight.

The perils lurking in the unsolved problem of Trieste have been demonstrated again by the two riots which have engulfed and paralyzed that city and have now spread to other Italian centers, including Rome and Milan. These riots have already cost at least six lives and have brought injuries to more than threescore.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 6 -- Marlon Brando will be the star of "Waterfront," the Budd Schulberg story of racketeer domination of dock workers on the New York-New Jersey piers. The deal with Mr. Brando was set this week in New York by Sam Spiegel, who is producing the picture in association with Mr. Schulberg, and Elia Kazan, the director.
Yesterday's stock trading showed divergence. While more stocks advanced than declined, the list as a whole, as measured by THE NEW YORK TIMES composite average of fifty issues, ended lower.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- South Africa said here today that she would be glad to discuss the status of South-West Africa with the United States, Britain and France, but not with the United Nations. The area concerned, a former German colony, was turned over to South Africa as a mandate in 1920.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 6 -- Yugoslavia made another proposal tonight to solve the Trieste dispute. The terms were not disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- An allotment of $11,000,000 for economic assistance to Spain has been made by the Foreign Operations Administration. The allotment, announced today, will be used for the purchase of raw materials and equipment upon Spain's request.

Old wives' remedies for the ills flesh is heir and to have ingredients that sometimes suggest the brew served by the witches in Macbeth for their incantations. But modern medical science has found sometimes in the contents of these homely empirical concoctions an unsuspected relation to the latest inventions applied to the healing arts.

Yesterday was hardly a day to be running around Van Cortlandt Park in shorts and T-shirts. Cross-country runners are made of stern stuff, however. It takes more than just a blinding snowstorm to keep the harriers from making their appointed rounds.

TRIESTE, Nov. 6 -- Trieste policemen killed four more persons today in combating savage rioting. The riots eased only after British and United States occupation troops with bayonets marched into the city's waterfront square.

The sixth semi-annual campaign of fine Maritime Association of the Port of New York on behalf of the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program yielded 526 pints. The three-day collection ended yesterday afternoon at the Downtown Athletic Club, 18 West Street.

Homer's Penelope justly carries the adjective faithful. While her husband was spending close to twenty years at war in a foreign land and having fine adventures on the way home, including some adventures with ladies to whom the word siren could justly be applied, Penelope resisted all invitations to invoke the Enoch Arden taw and marry somebody else.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 6 -- Three representatives of the Citrus Marketing Board went to Moscow by plane today to discuss a Kremlin offer to barter Soviet crude oil or wheat for Israeli oranges. The Israeli mission carried samples of textiles and soft goods, and will attempt to broaden the scope of the barter deal.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Nov. 6 (AP) -- All but one of the 100 industrialists polled at the National Association of Manufacturers industrial relations institute today were optimistic about business in their areas in the months ahead.
Norwegian ship operators are concerned over heavy taxes and trade restrictions at home and abroad that are severely hampering their ability to compete for cargoes in a sagging world market.
Paddy Young of Greenwich Village knocked out Sammy Giuliani of Stamford, Conn., in the second round at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The bout was scheduled for ten rounds.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 6 -- Yale University's new Art Gallery and Design Center was described today as an affirmation of "faith in humanity and in man's noblest aspirations."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UP) -- The United States Tariff Commission took under advisement today the question of increasing duties on lead and zinc imports to protect domestic producers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- There was evidence tonight that the Eisenhower Administration hoped to let go a series of attacks on what it calls the "corruption and Communist infiltration" of the five preceding Democratic Administrations.
CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of that portion of an address to the Executives Club by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr., discussing Communist infiltration of the Government:

With due respect to the Archbishop of York, we should like to express disagreement with his reported opinion that "the Jewish vote in New York has had a paralyzing effect on the United Nations" in the Israeli-Arab problem. The Archbishop, Dr. Cyril F. Garbett, offers no evidence to support this sweeping statement.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Saturday, Nov. 7 -- Switzerland threatened today to withdraw from the neutral nations group handling the Korean war prisoners unless the controversial "explanation" proceedings were modified.

ALBANY, Nov. 6 -- The irate village of Suffern went into court here today in an effort to keep the State Thruway Authority from a river diversion project that the community charges would pollute its water supply.

The release of Federal Reserve System statistics yesterday reflecting the return of the central bank to the buying side of the Government bond market, gave some assurance to a nervous trading session yesterday morning, halting a price retreat which had set in the night before.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Representatives of the Western Big Three will meet in Paris tomorrow to consider the Soviet note rejecting the Western proposal for a four-power conference on Germany and Austria.

PITTSBURG, N. H., Nov. 6 -- A long rifle shot to the east or west would put a bullet in Maine or Quebec, for we are perched on the rim of First Connecticut Lake, where the deer are wild and the hunters wilder.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- United Nations diplomats called attention today to the fact that the Soviet note rejecting a four- power conference on Germany announced also that the Soviet Union would not attend a Korean peace conference unless "neutrals" were allowed to participate.

ALBANY, Nov. 6 -- The Public Service Commission closed the door today on the possibility of revising downward the commercial rates for electricity authorized for the Consolidated Edison Company of New York a little more than a year ago.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Representative Timothy P. Sheehan, Republican of Illinois, assailed the loan policy board of the Small Business Administration today. He asserted it had established a policy that was contrary to the intent of Congress in enacting legislation setting up the agency.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower promoted twelve brigidier generals today to the temporary rank of major general. The promotions, which are subject to Senate approval when Congress reconvenes, went to the following:

Women headed by Mrs. Charles W. Lewis, as general chairman, and including Mrs. Albert L. Morse, are aiding in the arrangements for the Christmas fair under the auspices of the Women's Association of the Brick Presbyterian Church.

Police boat and Coast Guard vessels were searching last night for five duck hunters in two groups who disappeared off the south coast of Long Island during yesterday's storm. One of the police boats later sent in a call for help to the Coast Guard.

UTICA, N. Y., Nov. 6 (AP) -- A seriously wounded 265-pound man was carried from a remote hunting camp in the Adirondack Mountain wilds over four miles of rocky trails to an ambulance today and was hurried here for surgery.
Four New England textile mills with sales of close to $30,000,000 a year have set up their own sales agency, it was announced yesterday.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 6 -- Plans for a new city of 30,000 population on the outskirts of Houston were revealed here today as a development of the Jersey Village Development Company.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UP) -- President Eisenhower held another of his celebrated "stag" dinners tonight for prominent men of the nation.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 6 -- The worst storm since the 1944 hurricane hit the south and central New Jersey coast tonight. Winds whipped high seas into the boulevards and streets of seashore communities, causing floods and disrupting power and telephone services in a wide area.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Bud Dudley, athletic director at Villanova Colloge disclosed today that he was attempting to organize a new football conference, the "Northeastern Conference."

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers combined a fast-breaking offense with smooth ball handling and shooting to whip the Milwaukee Hawks, 80-68, tonight in a National Basketball Association game before 2,909 fans.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The White House asked and got today a postponement of a special meeting of a House of Representatives subcommittee on the reorganization of the Soil Conservation Service.

MONTREAL, Nov., 6 (UP) -- Frank Shaughnessy, president of the International League, said today there was a chance that both Havana and Richmond, Va., would be admitted as member cities next year in a sweeping reorganization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, called the Government's top labor experts to a meeting today to arrange a continuing, informal exchange of information on labor aspects of the defense program.
Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were barely steady yesterday and declined 1 to 11 points.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Senator George A. Smathers, Democrat of Florida, protested bitterly to the Pentagon today against what he termed "intolerable interference" by the Army with newsmen's efforts to report the news from Korea.
Six firemen were overcome by smoke last night while fighting a two-alarm fire in a five-story tenement at 1421 Prospect Avenue, the Bronx. No occupant of the twelve-family building was hurt.

ROME, Nov. 6 -- The Italian Ambassador to London was summoned to Rome by Premier Giuseppe Pella tonight on receipt of news about additional clashes between police and pro-Italian demonstrators in Trieste today.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Nov. 6 -- More than two months have passed since the United Fruit Company appealed to Guatemala's President against the expropriation of company lands. There is still no sign that President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman is ready to give a decision.
One of the nation's largest zinc smelters has cut its production about 17 per cent to avoid further accumulation of unsold metal.

BOSTON, Nov. 6 -- Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, head of Harvard University, took informal cognizance today of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's remark that the institution was "a mess." Dr. Pusey told a cheering audience that new facilities for education "give the lie to that kind of remark."

Sparks fly when women artists work together of an afternoon at the Sculpture Center at the top of the building at 167 East Sixty-ninth Street. But the studio is fireproof, and welder's goggles take care of other hazards as torch-bearing sculptors pursue what is to them the most fascinating developments in their affair with art.

Now it's possible to give what appears to be an almost exact count on the number of horse players who form the hard, nutty core of the try-to-pick-a-winner business in the metropolitan area. The total, it seems, is 10,752.
Harry Dexter White, accused by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of being a Russian spy, was regarded as one of the world's foremost authorities on international monetary matters.
The appearance of football's No. 1 team, Notre Dame, on Franklin Field and the opening of the Big Three series command the main interest on today's intercollegiate program in the East.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today a "top Communist undercover agent" had been "in telephone contact" with the Army radar center at Fort Monmouth, N. J., as recently as a week ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Canadian Metal Mining Association expressed its opposition today to the increased tariffs on lead and zinc sought by American producers.
SAARBRUECKEN, the Saar, Nov. 6 -- Some leaders of the prohibited pro-German parties in the Saar have proposed a United States trusteeship here.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- French political parties today began a four-sided struggle for Cabinet control. The new phase was started by the distribution among members of Parliament of a letter from former Premier Antoine Pinay and his friends, asking a regrouping of the parties to take command after the Presidential election at the end of the year.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 6 (UP) -- Garden State Park officials announced tonight that tomorrow's scheduled program of racing had been called off because of the heavy snowstorm which also forced the cancellation of today's program.

Harrison G. Reynolds of Manchester, Mass., owner of the 43-foot auxiliary sloop Sachuest, was elected commodore of the Cruising Club of America at the annual dinner meeting at the New York Yacht Club last night. He succeeded G. W. Blunt White of Mystic, Conn., who was elected to the board of governors.

The annual Horse Show Ball, the most colorful event of the week's festivities in connection with the sixty-fifth National Horse Show, was held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, after the evening performance at the Madison Square Garden.
Commodity price changes were irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Volume was light in the usual pre-week-end lull, characterized by evening of positions.
World Fellowship Week will be marked by Young Women's Christian Associations in the United States starting at 4 P. M. tomorrow with a vesper service in Washington.
Directors of the Bell Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday a dividend of $1.25 a share on the common stock. payable on Dec. 22. The company distributed a dividend of 75 cents a share in June.
The following is a round-up of recently published booklets that may interest homemakers:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The State Department said today that it took a "most serious view" of the rioting in Trieste and it appealed to the people of the territory to cooperate with Allied authorities.

LONDON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Following is the text of a speech by Kliment E. Voroshilov, President of the Supreme Soviet of the U. S. S. R., at the Moscow celebration of the anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution, as broadcast from Moscow:
Nearly 300,000,000 miles of thread is used each year in clothing the people of the United States. Forty-six million pounds of it -- 11,000 yards to the pound--were produced in 1952.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (UP) -- Representative Edith Nourse Rogers, chairman of the House Veterans Committee, admonished today that the prosecution of some veterans for filling false medical care financial statements might result in the "persecution" of all former servicemen.

WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 6 -- A sorely tried New York advertising executive won a four-year fight against a prominent native of this community last night when the Zoning Board of Appeals assured him of the relief he sought. The board was composed entirely of native dwellers.
CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Grain futures rallied sharply from early weak spots here today and closed irregularly higher than on Thursday.

The first equity financing undertaken by General Precision Equipment Corporation since its formation in 1936 will get under way today. The company's common stockholders will be offered 108,167 shares of $2.90 dividend convertible preferred stock at $50 a share.

ATHENS, Nov. 6 (AP) -- From bauxite mines developed near Eleusis, famed in antiquity for the Eleusinian Mysteries, ore is flowing out of Greece at the rate of 1,000 tons a day to become, in Germany, aluminum for defense purposes.

A new edition of "The Autobiography of Colonel John Trumbull," patriot-artist of the American Revolution, has been scheduled for Nov. 18 publication by Yale University Press. Trumbull, who had been an aide-de-camp to George Washington, wrote of the great men of the early days of the nation, but with some distortions and omissions.
Protestant church women over the nation observed World Community Day yesterday with special programs and worship services dedicated to the achievement of a lasting world peace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Attorney General, Herbert Brownell, today asked for expedited court action on litigation opposing construction of the proposed hydroelectric development in the International Rapids section of the St. Lawrence River.

WAYNESBORO, Va., Nov. 6 (AP) -- The General Electric Company announced plans today to construct a factory near here for the manufacture of electronic controls. The plant will serve as headquarters for the company's new specialty control department.

The laundry equipment of tomorrow and some of the washing problems today were discussed yesterday at the closing session of the Seventh National Home Laundry Conference at the Commodore. It was held by the American Home Laundry Manufacturers and attended by home economists and representatives of publications.

" The job of managing the Dodgers is wide open," Buzzie Bavasi, vice president of the Brooklyn club, said yesterday, after Pee Wee Reese suddenly made it definite that he would not take the post as player-pilot.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Mao Tse-tung, Communist China's leader, has sent a message to Premier Georgi M. Malenkov in Moscow, declaring "The Chinese and Soviet peoples have forged an unbreakable, brotherly friendship." The Peiping radio announced this today in a broadcast heard here.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- Eight underdeveloped countries introduced a resolution today aimed at encouraging both private and public investments abroad.

Let us face the truth. The sweeping Democratic victories in our elections were not a repudiation of President Eisenhower but rather of the people who tried to ride into office on his coattails. The majority of the people wanted General Eisenhower to become President, so they voted for him, and in 1952, it is true, others who would not otherwise have been elected were swept in with him, but obviously this could not last forever.
Sol A. Rosenblatt, the attorney who was shot outside his home, 525 Park Avenue, on March 6, 1952, testified yesterday he believed the shooting was motivated by his participation in a contested will.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6 -- The National Citizens-for-Eisenhower Congressional Committee launched an eleventh-hour drive today in behalf of Glenard P. Lipscomb, the Republicans' principal candidate in the special Congressional election here.

David Aldrich and Anna Wiman finally have settled who is to stage their forthcoming production of "Sodom, Tennessee." It will be Peter Cotes, the English director, who staged the recent "A Pin to See the Peepshow." With that matter attended to, the producers will place the William Berney-Howard Richardson play into rehearsal late in December.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Saturday, Nov. 7 -- Four United Nations and Communist staff advisers met today for the first time to try to agree on the agenda for the current Panmunjom sessions that seek to arrange for a Korean peace conference.

The nation's youth was urged yesterday to take an active interest in civic activities and not sit back and wait until reaching voting age. The advice was given by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein at the Conference on Education for Public Service at the McAlpin Hotel.
VIENNA, Nov. 6 -- Hungarian leaders have charged that old guard Communist leaders have been sabotaging Hungary's new economic policy of more food and consumer goods.

Dairy animals worth an estimated $12,000 -- fifty-eight heifers and one bull -- will leave here today on the United States Lines cargo vessel American Importer, consigned to needy farmers in Western Germany. The shipment is part of a project of the Interfaith Rehabilitation Agency which since 1944 has shipped thousands of farm animals to twenty-nine countries and also supplied food to needy persons abroad.

NOVARA, Italy, Nov. 6 -- Two wartime United States agents were convicted by the Novara Court today of the cloak-and-dagger murder of their commanding officer in 1944. They were sentenced to prison terms they could not be forced to serve.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Laurel race officials tonight called off tomorrow's scheduled running of the track's dream race, the $65,000 Washington D. C. International, because of a snowstorm that swept through Maryland today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said today that former President Truman had promoted an official to a high Government post in 1946 despite a report by the Federal Bureau of Investigation that the man was spying for Russia.
The members of the Kings County Democratic Executive Committee are scheduled to meet at noon Monday to vote for a successor to Kenneth F. Sutherland as Brooklyn Democratic leader.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6 -- Icardi said today he was not surprised at his conviction.
The elections in New York and New Jersey carry several lessons of great political and civil significance.

A home colony is planned for the Great Neck Estates section of Great Neck, L. I., where twenty-two half-acre plots have been sold by the First Great Neck Corporation to Milton Epstein, builder. The property, which formerly was the site of the Soundview Golf Club, will be improved with dwellings in the $45,000 and $50,000 price class.
One of the nation's largest food cooperatives has bought control of American Fruit Growers, Inc., packers and commission merchants who market their products under the Blue Goose trademark.

Boys High and Brooklyn Tech, a pair of early season title contenders who were turned back by Lafayette, are matched at Boys High Field, Brooklyn, in the local feature of today's heavy school football schedule.

That artistic arrangements are a popular part of flower shows has been proved again by the forty-sixth annual autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of News York at Essex House, 160 Central Park South. The arrangements, as well as other floral and fruit displays, may be seen today from 10 A. M. to 3 P. M.

Columbus, Ohio, borrowed $1,975,100 in the public market yesterday on an issue of airport bonds due serially on Nov. 1 from 1955 to 1974. The bonds were sold to a syndicate headed by Northern Trust Company at a bid of 100.54 for obligations bearing 2 per cent interest.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- Army will conclude its home football season before a sellout crowd of 27,000 at Michie Stadium tomorrow against North Carolina State. The game marks the first meeting between the two institutions.

The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service yesterday invited operators of privately owned ships to offer vessels for charter. The service wants ships that are Liberty type quality or better, available at a West Coast port between Dec. 5 and Dec. 15.
" Carmen" was presented at the City Center last evening with Rosemary Kuhlmann making her first appearance in the title role.

EAST AURORA, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- Parenthood can be very much like Pandora's box, filled with troubles, or like Christmas morning, full of wonderful surprises. A parent's attitudes have much to do with which it turns out to be. At least that is the opinion of Dr. Alfred Baldwin, head of the Department of Child Development and Parent Relationships, College of Home Economics, Cornell University.

Events today: "Die Fledermaus," City Center, 2:30 P. M.; Claudio Arrau, pianist, Town Hall, 3; "Tosca," City Center, 8:15; Richard Dyer-Bennet, tenor-guitarist. Town Hall, 8:40; Kroll String Quartet, Washington Irving High School, 8:30.

The Executive order issued yesterday on the safeguarding of official information represents a commendable effort to deal with this ticklish question. The order has obvious pitfalls and only time can tell whether it will succeed in establishing that delicate balance between national security and the right of the public to know what's going on.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- The stock markets here were upset today by the engineering workers' militant reaction to rejection of a wage claim and by rioting in Trieste. These factors combined with the usual Friday restraint before the week-end to eliminate an early improvement fostered by Wall Street's strength yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -- Notre Dame, the nation's top football team, puts its undefeated and untied record on the line against Pennsylvania tomorrow.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- The National Assembly refused today to remove Parliamentary immunity from Communist Deputies whom the Government had accused of having instigated subversive propaganda in the French Army and of having sabotaged French efforts in the Indo-China war.

TRENTON, Nov. 6 -- The high command of the Republican party in New Jersey, still admittedly stunned by the decisive defeat in Tuesday's election, is considering a purge of party leaders. This has become increasingly evident in the last seventy-two hours.
KEFLAVIK, Iceland, Nov. 4 -- The move to confine Americans stationed here to their base has touched off harsh comment among them.

Clear and forthright performances of standard segments of the piano repertory were played last night in Town Hall by Piero Weiss. Mr. Weiss, a pianist with a sincere and devoted view, programmed Bach's "Capriccio on the departure of his most beloved brother,"

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Nov. 6 -- Dr. Benjamin F. Wright, president of Smith College, believes that four years of preparatory school and four years of college constitute a minimum amount of time to develop maturity and judgment.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Chilean Government broke off negotiations with the United States today for the sale of 120,000 tons of Chilean copper.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Japan's Katsuji Yameshita defeated Wayne Moore of the United States in the 400-meter free-style race of an international swimming meet at the Agua Branca Club tonight. The finish was so close that each was given the same time -- 4 minutes 44.2 seconds.

LONDON, Nov. 6 (UP) -- Great Britain, envisioning the day of atomic-powered aircraft, has decided to rejuvenate its giant flying boat project and expects to have ten-engine seaplanes carrying passengers to the United States and other countries within four or five years.

JAMES T. FARRELL'S new novel, "The Face of Time,"* is a family chronicle of the Chicago South Side Irish around the first decade of this century. If you want to date the time any more precisely than that, you can do so by making a scholarly deduction from the young hero's conversation with a friendly priest who is asking him to identify pictures of baseball players.

DIAMONDS may a be girl's best friend, as Carol Channing chirped a couple of seasons back in "Gentlemen Prefer Blondes" and there probably is no thrill equal to that of motherhood, as she found out eight months ago. But the fact remains, nevertheless, that there is nothing like a show to keep a girl in show business.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 7 -- In the comparative privacy of the yawning Yale Bowl, the Bulldogs romped to a 32-6 victory today over Temple in the first football game ever played between the universities. The Elis scored three times in the final period.

AS a Spaniard and as a poet, I was greatly surprised to read in Gerald Brenan's "Literary Letter from Spain" the assertion that he considers Leopoldo Panero's "Canto personal" "the most important book of poetry to have appeared in Spain since Lorca's 'Romancero Gitano'."
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Johnny Bratton, the sharp-punching welterweight, will get his long-awaited chance to take the 147-pound title from Kid Gavilan Friday night.

ONTOGENY repeats phylogeny Which is to say that the growth of a single germ cell into a complete individual repeats the evolutionary pattern by which it reached its present state of complexity. Nowhere is this more true than in the evolution of a physician from the raw material of the student, through the various stages by which medical science has evolved.

A DISTINGUISHED professor, observing a small procession of apes, remarked: "There but for the passage of time go I!" In the present volume Ruth Moore, who is a reporter on The Chicago Sun-Times, has endeavored to report the latest developments, particularly with respect to the passage of time during which pre-modern and modern man developed.

One of the largest of the country's ad agencies specializing in financial advertising celebrated its fiftieth anniversary last week. The agency is Doremus Co., founded in 1903 at 44 Broad Street by the late Clarence W. Barron, pioneer in collecting and distributing business and financial news.

ON the fifteenth anniversary, Tuesday, of the death of Kemal Ataturk (1881-1938), Turkey's "modernizer" and its first President, Turkey will remove his body from Ankara's Ethnographic Museum to the Ataturk Memorial Mausoleum, also in Ankara.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 7 -- Rick Bethune scored two touchdowns as Williams College defeated Wesleyan University, 13 -- 0, today before 3,000 fans at Andrus Field. The fleet halfback galloped eighty yards to score on the opening kick-off and tallied again late in the final period.
MANY a baseball manager has angrily pounded the desk in his office after losing a close game and disgustedly exclaimed, "Just one fly ball. That's all we needed to win. Just one lousy fly ball."

Never shoot an albatross is an adage of the sea. Don't kick one either, or any other bird for that matter, is the latest amendment by a Waterman Steamship Corporation mate fresh from a scuffle with a feathered "friend."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UP) -- Representative Dewey Short, chairman of the House of Representatives Armed Services Committee, said today Congress had gone too far in cutting benefits of service men.

VIEWERS who stay up beyond midnight to watch color television tests over Channel 4 have discovered a new quiz game -- trying to guess the hair and eye coloring of the female model who smiles into the camera. They also try to read her lip movements as she chats with unseen engineers, technicians and stage hands.

THE obvious importance and immense usefulness of the present volume of reproductions is that it gathers between its two covers 300 illustrations, in photogravure and full color, of the whole of the master's work apart from the drawings.

A JURY with a point of view, a rare occurrence, has picked the winners in Photography Magazine's $25,000 (face value United States Savings Bonds) contest. The 280 winning prints, of which 119 were by photographers in the metropolitan area, will be shown at the presentation ceremony tomorrow evening in the Kodak Information Center in Grand Central Terminal.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 7 -- Princeton struck through the air in the fading minutes today to defeat Harvard, 6 -- 0, before 24,000 chilled spectators in sodden Harvard Stadium. The victory put the Tigers in position to take their seventh straight Big Three title. A triumph over Yale next Saturday would give it to them.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 7 -- A United States agency is working on plans for restoration of the Ruhr iron and steel combines, according to reports to the West German iron and steel industry.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 7 (UP) -Jim Miller, a sophomore quarterback, demoralized the Northwestern pass defense today, while Harlan Carl and Alan Ameche moved on the ground to give Wisconsin a 34-to-13 victory before 47,000 Wildcat homecoming fans.

AS readers who enjoyed "Shane" will testify. Jack Schaefer is a born writer. In the opening pages of his new novel. "The Canyon," he makes the placement of his story in geography and time into a passage exciting in itself and promissory of an equally exciting tale.

The little red schoolhouse is more than just a memory for about 1,500,000 boys and girls across the nation who trudge off each morning to the one-room buildings in which they receive their primary education.

Last Thursday I saw "Gilbert and Sullivan" at the Bijou, so it was with more than usual interest that I read your review of this film on Sunday. I, too, was impressed by the colorful samples of Gilbert and Sullivan and the entertainment afforded by certain pieces, but I left the theatre feeling dissatisfied.

" THE pleasures and problems of historical research need no explanation to its addicts, and very little to people with a taste for detective stories." Thus Kathleen Romoli begins her book, and thus she writes it.

CLEARLY there is a surprised, awed glance due this morning in the direction of Manifest Destiny. As suggested up front. "The Columbia Historical Portrait of New York" may well be the picture book to end all picture books, of New York, that is.

LILIES that are hardy, dependable and easily grown are available for gardens, and their bulbs are now being delivered for planting this fall and bloom next summer. In addition to the new hybrids and varieties found on the market, old well-known species (wild lilies) have been newly raised from seed so that these, toa, are available.

Dr. Solon Bernstein of Mount Sinai Hospital, New York City, is an internist who takes an interest in the history of medicine. Delving into the history of epidemics he finds that smallpox played a decisive part in the American Revolution.

AT the recent International Rally for Motor Coaches in Montreux, Switzerland, the grand prize and a special citation for design were awarded to a motor coach of the German Touring Company, an affiliate of Europabus, the tourist busline of the European Railways.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- President Eisenhower appeared to have made clear this week that he is prepared, as of now, to go down the line with all his influence in backing the new farm program that his Secretary of Agriculture and other farm advisers are now putting together.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The statement by the Archbishop of York that the New York "Jewish vote" had paralyzed the United Nations in dealing with the Israeli-Arab conflict was a comment on a purely political question, the Archbishop's chaplain said today. He added that no religious issue was involved.
Men's clothing may cost more in the near future. The increased cost will not be due to a rise in price but to charges for alterations.

Leon H. Keyserling, economic adviser in the administrations of Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman, predicted yesterday that the United States would not have "any more big depressions."

FOR gardeners or would-be gardeners with extremely limited space, miniature plots planted with hardy material can be both practical and charming. Very dwarf trees, shrubs, alpines and bulbs may be permanently placed on outer window sills, on low pedestals in a small garden or patio, on a terrace or penthouse roof.

BACH: Chaconne, and shorter pieces transcribed for the guitar; Andres Segovia; BACH: Prelude and Fugue in A, C and A minor; Carl Weinrich, organist (M-G-M). This is a strange coupling -- the tinkling of the guitar on one side, the massiveness of the organ on the reverse.

AARON COPLAND is more than a famous composer. He is a man with a profound interest in every aspect of America's growing stature as a country which produces first-rate music. For many years now, Mr. Copland has lavished his considerable intellectual powers and sympathetic nature on behalf of young composers.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Nov. 7 -- Long Island garden clubs have evolved an unusual way of supporting the campaign to save Sunken Forest, a sixty-acre woodland on Fire Island.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 7 -- Eight amendments to the State Constitution, including one that provides a four-year term for Governor, are scheduled to go into effect next week.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Three children were burned fatally today despite the efforts of their crippled father to rescue them from their flaming home. The father, Earl Baldwin, 57 years old, suffered numerous burns. A fourth child, Dianna, 7, was unharmed.

THE plight of the lone middle-aged woman, widowed or maiden, has seldom been made into an attractive, serious novel. Authors have fared best when they treated the subject melodramatically or comically, usually in a play.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 7 -- A study by the Stanford Research Institute has concluded that the average American worker produces three times as much as his Western European counterpart and receives three times as much in real wages.

TORONTO, Nov. 7 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings staved off a strong bid by the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game tonight, coming from behind for a 2-2 deadlock on Al Delvecchio's goal late in the third period.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 -- Senator William F. Knowland of California late yesterday announced his support of Glenard P. Lipscomb in the special Congressional election here next Tuesday. The action by the Senate majority leader disregarded the "hands-off" policy pursued by the National Administration.

IN "The World Beneath the Sea" Otis Barton, adventurer, explorer and inventor, tells his personal story. He is the creator of the "benthoscope," in which he made a record breaking descent off California in 1949 in 4,500 feet. The diving record is now 10,330 feet, set by Prof. Auguste Piccard in late September.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today proclaimed Thursday, Nov. 26, as Thanksgiving Day and asked Americans to pray for "wisdom in our striving for a better world."

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 7 -- Minnesota Republicans, led by a new state chairman, are out to hold the farm vote in 1954. A meeting of the State Central Committee was told this is the major party objective. A close second is the discovery of a candidate with a chance to defeat Democratic Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, who is up for re-election next year.
PARIS, Nov. 7 -- A commission that is expected to play a vital role in the economic relations between the United States and Europe arrived here tonight.

AS all who laugh know, Osbert Lancaster is one of Britain's wittiest penmen. He draws, he writes, he dissects in drawing and writing the British scene past and present. His work is born of a long, informed, amused (self-amused would be more accurate), nostalgic sigh.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Sluggish and overconfident Maryland ran into a souped-up George Washington team today and needed two third quarter breaks for a 27-6 victory that preserved the Terrapins' undefeated record.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 28 -- The Dutch Reformed Church, which three years ago pronounced in favor of total apartheid -- the territorial division of South Africa between Negro and white -- has called a preliminary conference of church leaders for Nov. 17 to pave the way for a national, inter-church convention to be held next year on race relations in South Africa.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, struck out at Mr. Brownell's charge today.

YONKERS, Nov. 7 -- Chuck Volo a 5-year-old Volomite pacer own by S. A. Wathen and Son of Fo Fairfield, Me., and driven by Wendell Wathen, scored a length victory over Scotch Spencer at $17.5 for $2 in the Greenwich free-for-a pace before 15,113 fans at Yonke Raceway tonight. Volto Man wins third.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 (UP) -- Sam Tsagalakis' 28-yard field goal in the final thirteen seconds today nullified one of the greatest passing exhibitions even seen here and gave Southern California a 23-to-20 victory over Stanford. A crowd of 79,015 witnessed the wild game at Memorial Coliseum.
PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 7 -- About 1,500 native families in Alaska are destitute as the result of salmon run failures this year, Gov. B. Frank Heintzleman of Alaska said here this week.

Hopes for a potash industry in Canada's Saskatchewan Province were encouraged last week by the signing of an exploration agreement between the Potash Company of America and the provincial Department of Mineral Resources.

IF Andre Dugo had written "Tom's Magic TV" for adults, to illustrate how some of the current television programs build up nightmares among the small fry, his book would be worth the asking price. As a juvenile, however, it deserves little of the praise that Mr. Dugo's past efforts have justly received.

A better "merchandising" job by the Democrats last week gave them an edge over their Republican opponents in the regional elections. The election results are likely to slow up plans for changing Governmental policy in relation to industry and commerce, at least until the Administration can get its bearings.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Eisenhower Administration probably will move again early in the next session of Congress for an increase in the national debt limit.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 7 -- Lehigh University scored a 13-0 victory over Muhlenberg College this afternoon before 2,000 spectators in Taylor Stadium. It was the Engineers' third triumph in seven games played this season and the twenty-ninth triumph over the Mules in the forty-three-game series begun in 1907.
CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (UP) -- The New York Rangers scored twice in the first period and added a goal in the second to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 to 1, tonight.

Michael Hoffman's article in your Oct. 14 issue describes accurately the plight of refugees in Trieste, but it does not give the picture of the strenuous efforts being made by voluntary agencies to resettle them overseas and in other areas of Europe.

EVERY night for more than a year Maurice Evans has been cheerfully plotting the slaughter of a wealthy wife in "Dial M for Murder," and audiences continue to be delighted. There is nothing that settles a good dinner quite so satisfactorily as the spectacle of a well-regulated crime.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 7 (UP) -- Florida's unspectacular but relentless rushing game eclipsed a one-man aerial circus staged by Zeke Bratkowski today as the Gators beat Georgia, 21 to 7, for their first Southeastern Conference victory of the season before 36,000 fans.

In your issue of Oct. 31 I note the news item entitled "People Are Urged to Guard Freedom" and comments on the address given by Turner Catledge at an educational conference at the University of Kentucky.

AS I followed the royal servant in his blue serge battledress with gold flash along the ornate and endless Buckingham Palace corridor, I could not help wondering what sort of a home this must seem to a small boy who will be just 5 on Nov. 14 and who is still much too young to know his destiny.

DES MOINES, Nov. 7 -- Distribution of the nation's beef herds appeared to be changing this week, with the cattle populations of some Western and Southwestern States either slowing down or remaining static while those in most Southern states showed a sharp increase.

FORMS of natural and man-made power are illustrated in photographs of familiar experiences in a new show, "Energy," which opened last week in the Corner Gallery of the American Museum of Natural History. The forty-eight pictures on display were selected from the Photographic Library of the Standard Oil Company (N. J.) and were taken in this country and abroad by some of America's leading photographers.

IT is unfortunate that Francis Taylor in an otherwise innocuous review of Will Durant's "The Renaissance" concludes with the hoary myth that in the Renaissance we see "modern man emerge from a thousand years of medieval slumber."

By a vote of 50 to 0, with eight abstentions, the General Assembly of the United Nations has urged member nations to speed ratification of the genocide treaty -- a convention designed to protect human groups from destruction, wholly or in part, for national, ethnical, racial or religious reasons.

IT was shortly before 10 A. M. in Carnegie Hall one day last season. The justly famous N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra was seated onstage, ready for rehearsal. The din of tuning and last-minute practicing subsided as a loud call of "Stand by, Maestro coming down" came from the control booth.

Along the roadside, twined among the dead and dying weed stems of November, is the brittle stem of the wild clematis. The stem itself may pass unnoticed, unless you essay a short-cut and find it snagging at your legs like persistent strands of coarse twine. But along that stem are plumy gray tangles of whorled filaments, something like rosettes heads of gray elfin hair ruffled by the wind.
LONDON, Nov. 7 (Reuters) -- Results of today's British soccer and rugby games:

C., lost to the West Point cadets by only one point earlier in the campaign.

There will be a transit of Mercury on Nov. 14 at 10:36 A. M. The planet then comes between the earth and the sun. Mercury will be observed as a black dot on the sun's surface. Such a transit may be observed only once or twice in a lifetime and then only through a telescope.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- Large-scale public works are being planned as one of several stand-bys against a possible depression, Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of President Eisenhower's Council of Economic Advisers, said today.

THE first volume of an eight-volume edition of the COMPLETE PROSE WORKS OF JOHN MILTON (Yale University Press, $12.50), edited by Don M. Wolfe, is just out, and prepossessingly too. Inside the rambling, grey building each man was handed a nearly identical copy of a diplomatic note. The note spelled failure to a month-long Western effort to bring the Russians to the conference table on the question of Germany.

The only result of "Operation Candor" to date has been even strieter censorship of atomic information. Now no official may reveal any facts without prior clearance with the chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.

Members of the Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service of Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will hold their annual card party in behalf of their philanthropic work tomorrow afternoon in the ballroom of the Colony Club.

MOSCOW, Nov. 7 -- The Russians cut their military show to twenty-five minutes today in the Red Square celebration of the thirty-sixth anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution. They empha sized the civilian demonstration just as they did on this year's May Day holiday.

FOUR novellas make up Robert Heinlein's fourteenth book. "Gulf" narrates the adventures of a secret agent who allies himself with a colony of mutants to destroy an incipient world dictatorship. In "Else-when" a professor and his pupils travel among alternate probability worlds.

ATLANTA, Nov. 17 (UP) -- The speed of Billy Teas, who gained 195 yards for the day, enabled Georgia Tech to recover from the shock of an early touchdown by Clemson today and go on to a 20- to-7 victory in its quest of a Sugar Bowl bid.

Without the first trait no one can glimpse the meaning of the natural world; and unless one has the seeing eye he misses the revealing details that fill in the outline.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- Moscow removed this week one of the main obstacles to ratification of the pending European army treaty. LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A total of 150 swimmers, boxers, fencers and sharpshooters representing six nations gathered at Uxbridge R. A. F. Station today for final practice before the 1953 Britannia Shield competition.

THE Metropolitan Opera season of 1953-54 opens one week from tomorrow night under auspicious circumstances. The threatened strike of the orchestra players has been averted, under terms of settlement which assure the functioning of the orchestra under terms mutually agreed upon for the next two years.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 7 (UP) -- Paul Larson, California quarterback, shattered a school passing record today and Washington in the process as he led the Golden Bears to a 53-25 victory over the Huskies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The Weather Bureau will begin an inquiry to find out why that snowstorm refused to go to sea and went to the big Eastern cities instead.

BECAUSE spring and summer weather was difficult for shade trees, fertilizing is being urged strongly this fall. The recommendation is based on the proved correlation between loss of tree vigor and the inception of disease such as the wilt that may infect maples.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- Westchester County Airport's sixth and by far its largest aircraft hangar will go into operation on or before the first of the year.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 7 -- Mayor Carl W. Rich, Republican, and Theodore M. Berry and Edward N. Waldvogel, Charterites, have been re-elected to the City Council in the proportional representation count now under way here.

THE effects of age on night vision and resistance to headlight glare have been determined in a series of tests given to 500 men and 800 women by the Alexandria, Va., Department of Health. CHORE FOR THE WEEK: After raking up leaves, the lawn probably needs to be cut once more, for it should not go into winter any higher than one and a half inches. Because crabgrass is still setting seed in southern New England, rake the lawn first to pull blades upright so they can be cut off. Mow a new lawn, seeded this fall, if it is two inches or more high.

ALONG, strong suit opposite an opening bid presents a bidding problem that no system in popular use has solved satisfactorily. The reason is that the hand is of variable and unpredictable value. If it fits with the opening bid, it is a slam-going hand and should be bid strongly.

TOKYO, Nov. 7 -- A pessimistic reporter asked an optimistic negotiator in Panmunjom this week whether he thought the scheduled full-dress political conference on Korean problems really would ever be held.

This map shows a stretch of the St. Lawrence River crucial to the long-debated plan for a St. Lawrence Seaway. As the map indicates, the plan combines two projects. One is to dig, parallel to impassable sections of the river, a chain of deep-water canals which would permit ocean going vessels to pass between the Great Lakes and the Atlantic via the St. Lawrence.

PUCCINI'S Manon Lescaut, already recorded on LP for Columbia under the direction of Lorenzo Molajoli, now makes its appearance in a three-disk set from Cetra. The title role is sung by Clara Petrella, Vasco Campagnano sings: Des Grieux and Federico del Cupolo conducts the chorus and orchestra of Radio Italiana, Turin.
Thousands of families in low-lying waterfront areas were evacuated yesterday morning when a gale-driven tide flooded or destroyed their dwellings.

MOLIERE'S Bourgeois Gentleman was delighted to find that he had been speaking prose all his life. But speech and prose are two distinguishable things. There has long been in print the properly famous "Oxford Book of English Prose."

For the fourth time since 1924, New York Stock Exchange commissions are to be increased. They will go up an average of 18 per cent tomorrow. Although the new rates have been passed by a majority of Stock Exchange members, there is little enthusiasm for them in Wall Street.
UVALDE, Tex., Nov. 7 -- A visitor called this week at a small frame house on the outskirts of this busy little Southwest Texas town.

Department store shoppers throughout the country will soon be able to purchase a greater volume and wider variety of goods imported from Western Europe, according to plans of a large buying organization here.

Young women serving on the junior committee, headed by Miss Joan Levering, chairman, and Barbara Ann Hoggson, vice chairman, have been holding frequent meetings in the Tea Terrace of the Waldorf-Astoria to further the success of the performance of "Il Trovatore".

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 7 -- Army's injured quarterback, Fred Attaya, sat on the sidelines today and cheered as Pete Vann, his replacement, led the cadets to a 27-to-7 victory over North Carolina State.

THE American Federation of Arts, founded "to unite in close fellowship all who are striving for the development of art in America," met last week at the Corning Glass Centre in Corning, New York. The principal theme discussed was "Economic Support of Art in America Today."
ALBANY, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Cities and villages in New York State employ larger police staffs in proportion to population than the national average, a private taxpayer's group reports.

Former President Harry S. Truman will speak Tuesday night at the seventy-third annual dinner of the City College Alumni Association. The affair will be held in the grand ballroom of the Commodore Hotel.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 7 -- Pakistan's decision to become an "Islamic Republic" has newly inflamed the basic animosities between that country and predominantly Hindu India. This is more important internationally than the blow to British sentiment occasioned by the loss of 76,000,000 Asian subjects of the Queen, the largest overseas component of Her Majesty's dominions.

The American Cancer Society held its annual meeting in New York City last week and discussed the rapid increase of lung cancer as well as the latest methods of getting rid of cancer by surgery and treating tumors with X-rays, radium and such agents as hormones, nitrogen mustards and various chemical compounds.

ALBERT McCleery, producer-director of the "Hallmark Hall of Fame" (Sundays, 5 P. M.), is an outspoken, high-voltage zealot who, after falling flat on his face artistically four years ago, is today sitting pretty as one of eight executive producers at N. B. C.

ANTHOLOGIES are nearly as personal as tooth brushes. If they are a sincere expression of their editors' tastes and not just a commercial venture they reflect an individual attitude toward life and special interests. Readers who share those attitudes and interests delight in them. But no serious anthology is intended for the mass of readers who keep one eye glued on the best-seller charts. Mr. Adams' isn't.

O'NEILL is the single instance in American literature of a first-rate talent devoting itself exclusively to the stage. As a consequence, he enjoys an uncomfortable sort of eminence today. His plays are still honored in professional drama criticism but are seldom on view in our commercial theatres.

IF there was anyone who still thought conservation was an esoteric subject fit only for philosophers, the battle that burst forth in Washington last month over the proposed reorganization of the Department of Agriculture must have been an enlightening experience.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- President Eisenhower has started work on his State of the Union Message, and it looks as if the battle within the Republican ranks on tax policy, farm policy, the Taft-Hartley Act, and the tariff is going to center on this document.
An arbitration award that would mean a higher fare on nine privately operated bus lines in the city and new financial problems for the Transit Authority is scheduled to be made this week.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 8 -- Jose Figueres became President of Costa Rica today. He immediately pledged the republic's unqualified support to the United States in the struggle against international communism.

Mr. M. W. S. is a partner in a large brokerage firm. Not long ago he contracted pneumonia, and his doctor sent him to one of our big voluntary hospitals. He stayed in the hospital only a few days, because of a drug called peni cillin. He is almost ready to return to work.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8 -- Alleged attempts by some educational theorists to foist atheism on schools and colleges were attacked here tonight by the Rev. Dr. Luther A. Weigle, Dean Emeritus of the Yale Divinity School.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- The most intensely nonpolitical man at the United Nations is a mild-spoken Danish soldier who for five months has been in the middle of one of the world's touchiest political controversies.
Recommendations for improving procedures in the courts dealing with juveniles were made yesterday by a special committee of the New York County Lawyers Association.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- Rene Pleven, Minister of Defense and a former Premier, withdrew today from the presidency of the Social and Democratic Union after the party had called on the Government to try to get a cease-fire in the Indo-China war.

Underlying the broad purpose of the program of the Young Women's Christian Association is the expressed aim: "To build a fellowship of women and girls devoted to the task of realizing in our common life those ideals of personal and social living to which we are committed by our faith as Christians."

In the mountain of literature on medical care which has piled up ever since the Committee on the Costs of Medical Care published its famous report, nearly a quarter of a century ago, little has been said about the part that life insurance companies have long played in preventive medicine.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- It was quite accidental that President Eisenhower's Commission on Foreign Economic Policy assembled in Paris four days after receipt of the negative Soviet note to the Western powers. But there sometimes is a curious logic in accidents. There is in this one.

The Bureau of the Budget is reported to be working on a program for a privately financed hospital insurance plan for seamen. This would replace the Public Health Service hospital medical care program, according to Hoyt Haddock, executive secretary of the C. I. O. Maritime Committee.

Government -- in the states as well as in Washington -- was accused yesterday of failing to develop a legislative program "to safeguard those rights now denied to millions of American." Dr. David Petegorsky, executive director of the American Jewish Congress, charged that in the last four years there had been a "disturbing lack of progress" in achieving a program of legal action to assure civil rights advances.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 8 -- Moslem League leaders gathered today to map a defense of the party's control of the Legislature in East Bengal. The league is threatened there by a united Opposition of three parties, including the Communists.

Howard Hughes, aircraft and motion-picture industrialist, has sold his 929,020 shares or R. K. O. Theatres Corporation stock, representing effective control, to a group headed by David J. Greene, New York investment counselor.

IT was not what the doctor had ordered. When a convalescent is permitted to return to work, he is directed to observe a few simple rules. He must avoid drafts and excitement. He must take it easy and never try to do too much at once.

RIO DE JANIERO, Nov. 8 -- Opposition circles are alarmed lest Joao (Jango) Goulart, the Labor Minister, is working with the tacit backing of President Getulio Vargas to create a labor organization along the lines of the Argentine General Confederation of Labor.

Textile converters today are calling for the establishment of quality standards for synthetic fabrics. Such standards, they held, would force yarn producers and weavers to accept responsibility for their products.

President Rutherford B. Hayes was fighting for civil service reform in Washington. New York's Tammany machine and Boss John Kelly were about to be beaten in the Mayoralty election. At New Haven's Hamilton Park Yale was downing Amherst in football, 2 goals, 3 touchdowns to nothing.

BOGOTA, N. J., Nov. 8 -- The Rev. Thomas F. Maher, Professor of Political Science at the College of New Rochelle, N. Y., said today that Roman Catholics should work for a single standard of morals for private life and public office.

Next month marks the fiftieth anniversary of the Wright brothers' successful flight. For this occasion two books will be issued later this month. On Nov. 20, David McKay will publish "How We Invented the Airplane," by Orville Wright with an introduction and commentary by Fred C. Kelly.

The Post Office Department has held up mailing of the October issue of the monthly magazine New World Review -- formerly Soviet Russia Today -- for three weeks pending decision on whether it contains "disloyal matter."

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, Nov. 9 (AP) -- United Nations and Communist staff advisers met in a "serious and businesslike" closed session today in an attempt to break the two-week deadlock on plans for a Korean peace conference.

Most of the persons displaced by the snow, wind and floods of the last two days were back in their homes yesterday. A vast clean-up was in progress in New Jersey, Long Island, Westchester and Connecticut. The over-all damage was in the millions.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 8 -- Former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh, at the opening of his trial today on charges of rebellion, challenged the power of the nation's ruler to dismiss him from office and the competence of the military court and prosecutor to try him.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Harold H. Velde, chairman of the House of Representatives Committee on Un-American Activities, said today that Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam was not "an effective fighter against communism and the Communist ideology."
Key contests in the Newark City League and the Northern New Jersey League are the highlights of today's school football schedule.

A happy event for Costa Rica and for the progress of democracy in Latin America has just been celebrated in the charming and beautiful little Central American country. Jose Figueres ("Don Pepe" is what he must be called) was yesterday inaugurated President of a country which is less well known than that other little gem to the south -- Uruguay -- but which ranks with her in the virtues of democracy.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Two small girls and their smaller brother today got the treat of their young lives. They had breakfast with the King and Queen of the Hellenes.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Railroad announced today it will use the "largest single installation of continuous welded rail ever put into service at one location, enough to construct 112 miles of track," in the construction of the new Conway freight classification yard near Pittsburgh.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Babe Parilli hit Bill Howton on a 23-yard scoring pass with less than a minute and a half to play today to pull the Green Bay Packers into a 21-21 tie with the Chicago Bears.

The American Medical Association in letters to all advertisers and agencies has informed them that, beginning on Jan. 1, no tobacco or alcoholic beverage advertising will be accepted for any of the association's publications. Though no public announcement of the decision has been made, Advertising Age in its issue out today quotes the letter as saying:
BACOLOD, West Negros, Monday, Nov. 9 -- Ramon Magsaysay flew to this liberal party stronghold and trouble spot yesterday for the wind-up speech before tomorrow's elections.

HONG KONG, Monday, Nov. 9 (AP) -- A gunboat presumed to be Chinese Nationalist chased and fired on a British freighter yesterday off the coast of Communist China. It was the second such incident in two days.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- A month ago Bobby Thomason was the second-string quarterback for the Eagles. Today at Connie Mack Stadium the V. M. I. man who had failed to make the grade with the Rams and the Packers was hailed by 24,331 fans as the greatest of greats. Principally through Thomason's efforts, the Eagles downed the Giants, 30 -- 7, the heaviest setback handed to Steve Owen's club this season.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8 -- The special Congressional, election in California's Twenty-fourth District Tuesday, paradoxically, may produce a defeat for the Republican party while yielding a moral victory for Eisenhower Administration policies.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Nov. 8 -- Fire last night closed the doors of historic Price's Hotel, where Presidents dined and where James Buchanan (Diamond Jim) Brady ate forty-eight hard-shelled crabs at a sitting.

The New York Americans, leaders in the American Soccer League, defeated the Swedish F. C. eleven, 8 -- 2, in the Eastern division opening round of the National Challenge Cup competition at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, yesterday. The halftime score was 3 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The case of the late Harry Dexter White, who was branded by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. last Friday as a Soviet spy, has hit this city harder than any loyalty charge since the Hiss case.

THE FAR EAST played no part in our formal discussions at Yalta. I was aware that the Americans intended to raise with the Russians the question of Soviet participation in the Pacific war.
