ZURICH, Nov. 8 -- Authorities of Zurich have reached the conclusion that the slump in the price of free gold marks the end of another world economic era. The weekly banking report of Julius Baer Co. for example, says:
Alfred Rainer is a believer in elegant understatement in furs. His new designs, shown at 17 East Fifty-Fifth Street, had the simplicity of subtle taste.
In the manner of Ralph Waldo Emerson, "I awoke this morning with devout thanksgiving" that Stanley M. Isaacs has been returned to our City Council.

Not all the needed "technicians" in various parts of the world are builders of bridges or planners of factories. There are other skills that may be necessary to make a better world. There are times when these less practical factors can become of great importance in the life and happiness of a people.

Members of the Woman's Auxiliary, Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation Branch, have arranged a Christmas sale, which will be held tomorrow and Wednesday at 209 Madison Avenue. The sale will open at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow and will close at 5 P. M., and on Wednesday will be open from 2 P. M. to 9 P. M.
Waterfront employers warned President Eisenhower yesterday that a new coastwide dock strike was likely unless he ordered a quick election to pick a bargaining agent for New York pier workers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- The national debt, as reflected in mere figures, will go above the legal limit of $275,000,000,000 tomorrow. But then, again, it won't; for there are figures and figures.
BOSTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins scored two goals in less than two minutes tonight to beat the Montreal Canadiens, 2 -- 0, before 10,245 fans at the Boston Garden.
NARAYANGANJ, Pakistan, Nov. 8 -- Pakistan's economic strides became steadier today with the completion of the world's largest jute mill on the tropical shores of the Lakshya River here.
PARIS, Nov. 8 -- In the last twenty months the gold bar has declined by 28 per cent and the French gold louis (20-franc piece) has declined 31 per cent.

With regard to your editorial of Oct. 26 entitled "Those Auto Horns" the attention of your readers, and perhaps the Police Department, is referred to a gem found in the Administrative Code of the City of New York.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, today challenged Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, to "tell it to the grand jury."
Vigorous support of a United States foreign policy that builds up the physical and moral strength of the free world was advocated here yesterday in a sermon by the Rev. Albert T. Mollegen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Eddie LeBaron, supposedly sidelined by injuries, came off the bench to ignite a two-touchdown fourth-period explosion today that carried the Washington Redskins to a 28-17 victory over the Chicago Cardinals in their National Football League game before 19,654 fans.
A business plot consisting of 180,000 square feet of land on Bloomingdale Road and Mamaroneck Avenue in White Plains, N. Y., has been purchased by a syndicate headed by Levine-Raynes of White Plains.

TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 9 -- The chairman of the neutral repatriation commission will visit the Communists' armistice headquarters in Korea today to try to break a deadlock in the "explanations" to Korean war prisoners.

Richard Dyer-Bennet gave his annual fall recital Saturday night at Town Hall. As usual, the event attracted a large audience of more than 1,400 persons, most of them in their twenties or early thirties.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- The grain market last week saw irregular trading and net price changes were small. Support on the declines was based upon Washington reports that there will be no drastic change in farm commodity price support levels.

The Metropolitan Opera's first week of its sixty-ninth season will consist of "Faust," on opening night next Monday, and "The Marriage of Figaro," "La Forza del Destino" and "Boheme" in weekend performances. The four productions will introduce eight of the new singers engaged for the season by Rudolf Bing, general manager.
Eight new films, including English, Italian and German importations, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

The Weather Bureau's prediction for this region for last Friday was "fair and continued quite cool." What was described as "a cold mass of Canadian air" had produced snow flurries "in the eastern lake region, the northern Appalachians and northern New England,'' where the inhabitants are used to them and don't mind, but down this way things looked perfectly lovely.

VENISON season's started in town, but probably not one New Yorker in 10,000 is aware of it or has ever tasted deer meat. People in the trade, though, expect to sell 2,500 to 3,000 head of deer in the city this winter. They count, too, on getting rid of 150 head of elk, forty to fifty bears, and pheasants, quail, ptarmigan and Scotch grouse by the thousands.

Sunshiny Mexico was evoked at Orsini's, 43 West 56th Street, Friday as the winter's first snowflakes were falling. The brilliance of our neighbor was expressed in a showing of play clothes designed by Lila Bath, an American who has been living for thirteen years in Mexico and who for the last four has headed a shop in Mexico City.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Nov. 8 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers won their fourth National Basketball Association game out of five starts tonight, defeating the Fort Wayne Pistons, 75 -- 70, behind the scoring of Harry Gallatin and Sweetwater Clifton.

TACHILEK, Burma, Nov. 8 (Reuters) -- Groups of lean, khakiclad fighters converged here from the Burmese jungle today as the evacuation of 2,000 Chinese Nationalist guerrillas to Formosa got under way.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Clement Attlee, leader of the Labor party and former Prime Minister, said today that the slightest recession in the United States could bring disaster to British industry.

LISBON, Portugal, Monday, Nov. 9 -- Final election results from Lisbon, Oporto and Aveiro showed today that candidates opposing Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar's totalitarian regime had polled 16.7 per cent of the vote there.
The third program in the series presented by the Concert Society of New York at Town Hall yesterday afternoon was, like its predecessors, an interesting one and well delivered.

The Cresca Company last week invited food writers to a tasting-luncheon in its offices in the Port of New York Authority Building. There, huge trucks arise on elevators to the eighth floor to deliver to this severity-five-year-old importing concern delicacies from across the seas.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- A report concluding that Dr. Syngman Rhee poses a problem on the economic as well as political front in Korea is being prepared for Congress.

In his post-mortem on the milk strike in the Nov. 2 NEW YORK TIMES, A. H. Raskin quoted an anonymous "key negotiator" as stating that the group of mediators whose services had been made available to the milk companies and the Teamsters Union were "a bunch of prima donnas whose main interest is in being in the middle of the picture when the agreement is signed."
BOSTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Bishop John J. Wright of Worcester said today that resistance to Communist propaganda by our soldiers had reassured him as to the stability of the present generation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Former President Hoover, chairman of the Commission on Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, today announced that fifteen persons had agreed to serve on the commission's task force on the medical services.

VIENNA, Dec. 8 -- Whether the People's party, senior partner in Austria's coalition Government, will be able to resist the wiles of communism seems to be becoming a major issue in Austrian political life.

Signs of a "bumper" crop forced cotton futures prices lower in the domestic market last week. At the close of trading on Friday final quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange were $1.15 to $3.70 a bale lower. Weakness in the market was most pronounced in the distant options.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 8 -- The stock market last week was completely under the influence of a fresh buying wave for Royal Dutch shares, which jumped further from 330 guilders to 346. The general stock average rose from 157.54 to 160.77, a new high for the year, against a low of 138.08.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- Dr. Goodwin Watson, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, will stand "trial" soon before a committee of the Larchmont Community Chest as a result of a new attack upon him by the Americanism Commission of the Westchester County American Legion.
ROME, Nov. 8 -- The Italian Government laid the responsibility for the Trieste shootings squarely at the door of the British commander today.

DETROIT, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Ted Lindsay scored with less than three minutes remaining in the final period tonight to give the Detroit Red Wings a 2-to-2 tie with the New York Rangers before 10,513 fans at Olympia.
The city's alternate-side-of-the street parking program was criticized sharply yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 8 -- Hollywood's estimation of three-dimensional films as a box-office stimulant, decidedly negative a month ago, is again tinged with optimism because of the 40 per cent increase in business reported by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for "Kiss Me Kate" in areas where it was given in 3-D.
Many Americans of Jewish faith must have read the report of the statement of the Archbishop of York in THE TIMES for Nov. 6 with greatly mixed emotions.

European and American artists, past and present, are represented in the wide diversity of art exhibitions on view here this week. These vary from the thirteenth annual of the League of Present Day Artists, at the Riverside Museum, to two shows opening tomorrow -- drawings by Toulouse-Lautrec and his circle, at the Delius Gallery, and paintings by Sir Alfred Munnings, former president of the Royal Academy, at Wilderstein's.
Once she gets into a lovely peignoir, Mary Jane casts aside the worries of the day and relaxes. It is her big opportunity to look pretty in an informal way.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Marty Marion tomorrow can talk himself into or out of the job of managing the Baltimore Orioles.
TRIESTE, Nov. 8 -- Thousands of persons attended the funeral today of six Italian residents of Trieste killed in last week's rioting.
MANILA, Monday, Nov. 9 -- The rival Presidential candidates in tomorrow's elections were in the concluding stage of their campaigns today.

Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, former Assistant Secretary of Defense, said last night that there were alarming signs that this country might allow itself to be lulled into a belief that the Russians meant no harm.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Sir Adrian Ivor Dunbar, the former farmer and handyman in a Maryland village who inherited an old Scottish baronetcy, said today that he might take off his coat and do a little milking when he reached his new estate in Scotland.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 -- Western Republican leaders at a "family meeting" asked Leonard W. Hall, the party's national chairman, today to inform President Eisenhower that the Administration was not moving fast enough.

MANILA, Nov. 8 -- The mechanics of national elections in the Philippines are simple enough but bound with rules and regulations that make it difficult to commit fraud without detection. Past elections, however, have proved there are plenty of chances for fraudulent practice.

Four major statements of Soviet policy appeared last week: the Soviet note on Germany and allied matters, the major policy declaration of Marshal Voroshilov, and the pronouncements of Marshal Bulganin and Andrei Vishinsky. What conclusions can be drawn about Soviet foreign policy and the international situation from this mass of verbiage?

Plans for consolidating the New York offices of the American Machine Foundry Company were announced yesterday in conncetion with a $6,000,000 leasing contract for large space in the building nearing completion at 261 Madison Avenue between Thirty-eighth and Thirty-ninth Streets.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8 -- The steel industry's operating rate was maintained at 93 per cent of capacity last week, down only two points from the week before. Thus there was further evidence that output this year will top 111 million tons for a record.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Two spectacular touchdown runs by Ray Renfro -- one a 79-yard gallop with a blocked place kick -- paced the undefeated Cleveland Browns to their seventh 1953 victory today, a 34 -- 16 triumph over the Pittsburgh Steelers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Some of the nation's dairy men are complaining that the Government is buying the good butter and leaving low quality and under-grade butter for consumers.

Making a splendid showing in the jump-off to decide the first four places, Mrs. Carol Durand of the United States equestrian team captured the $1,000 international stake at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night before a crowd of 11,000.
A 15-year-old high school student was shot in the back and killed last night when a gang of five youths attacked him and his girl companion.
The dramatic chase and capture of a 14-year-old boy driving a stolen automobile disturbed the Sabbath noon of the Hillcrest section of Queens yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- West Point cadets and Annapolis plebes are quitting in increasing numbers before their first year is out.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- The staff of the House of Representatives and Senate Economic Committee has concluded that Western Europe's own economic restrictions are a greater threat to her economic health than United States trade barriers, it was disclosed today.

Anthony Speranza, a 61-year-old insurance agent from Yonkers, took the lead before the three-mile mark and held on to win the tenth annual Joseph Labowsky Memorial ten-mile walk in north Queens yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Five grand old ships, whose names ring with memories of glorious exploits, are weighing on the Navy's conscience.

Jangled nerves, sleeplessness, dizziness are illnesses that cannot always be cured with patented pills, Donald Harrington, minister of the Community Church of New York, declared yesterday. In a sermon on "Your Power of Healing," Mr. Harrington stressed the necessity of viewing health from the medical, psychiatric and spiritual standpoints since man is an "interfusion" of physical, emotional and spiritual forces.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- While the stock markets in the past week have maintained a high state of activity, there has been some shifting of emphasis and direction in price movements.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 8 -- With the arrival today of James W. Riddleberger, the united States was represented here by an Ambassador for the first time in nine months, a period of almost continual crisis over Trieste.
In the chill of a wintry day, as in the 93-degree heat of Oklahoma, Notre Dame maintained its invincible pace-setting, well out in front of the college football pack.

HELEN HAYES was placed in low-voltage surroundings on Saturday at 10 P. M. over the C. B. S. network, and failed to shine with her customary brilliance. The light she struggled to throw off was all but hidden beneath the uneven script of "Battle Hymn," a feature of the "Medallion Theatre," which pressed hard on the accelerator without knowing where it was heading.

The incidence of the Trieste riots with the negative reply of the Russians to the Western Powers' invitation to a conference on Germany and their equally negative attitude on a political conference on Korea has driven home to the Westerners that their immediate problem is to mend their own fences.

Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner said last night that he intended to reorganize the Mayor's office and to appoint a City Administrator. He made this remark on a radio program recorded before he left the city for a vacation in Nassau.
Fewer ships were chartered last week, although brokers said that cargoes were waiting and freight rates were firm after their small rise of recent weeks.

It is a pleasant duty to record that Erna Berger was in far better voice at her recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall than when this reviewer heard her last season in the same auditorium. Especially in the songs of Richard Strauss, forming the second half of the program, the soprano came definitely into her own, vocally and from the interpretive angle.
Federal maritime authorities are making rapid progress in clearing a once-tremendous backlog of ship subsidy payments, but are still $79,000,000 in arrears in payments to subsidized operators.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Y. A. Tittle of San Francisco's 49'ers, threw aerial fireworks at the Los Angeles Rams today, whipping them in the final minutes by a 31-27 score and sending the Western Conference of the National Football League again into a three-way deadlock.
BERLIN, Nov. 8 -- The East German Government has gone all out to try to drown out the American-operated radio station R.I.A.S. The station's initials mean Radio in the American Sector (of Berlin).

A new play is being done at the Cherry Lane Theatre in Greenwich Village. It was written by Paul Leslie, and the program says: "Under the sponsorship of Punch Opera and Trio Productions, the Producers Company, in association with Fred Finkl, presents 'Have You Heard This One.'"

Under pressure from party leaders, Kenneth F. Sutherland has decided to continue as Brooklyn Democratic leader, at least for the present. He has canceled the meeting of the executive committee of the Kings County Democratic Committee, which was to have been held at noon today at headquarters at 4-5 Court Square and at which he was scheduled to submit his formal resignation.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- The American Assembly said today that unemployment insurance had not kept pace with changing times. It called for a revision of the social insurance system to coordinate responsibilities now scattered among different governmental units.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- Iona Prep won its fourth game of the season by beating Xavier of Manhattan, 12 to 6, before more than 3,000 fans at Iona Field today. George La Pera, fullback, went 49 yards after a break through right tackle three minutes before the game ended for the winning touchdown, his second of the game.

SAARBRUCKEN, the Saar, Nov. 7 -- The people of the Saar, one is told here, are afflicted with a split personality: they are torn between a national loyalty to Germany and an economic affinity for France.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 8 (AP) -- A soft track for the Washington, D. C., International is just what Crafty Admiral wants, Owner Charles Cohen of Miami Beach, Fla., said today regarding reports the handicap star might be scratched from the Laurel race classic.

The Metropolitan New York Chapter of the Construction Specifications Institute will meet tomorrow night at the Architectural League, 155 East Fortieth Street. The principal speaker will be Julius Storch, president of the Employers Association of Roofing and Sheet Metal Contractors.

King Norodom of Cambodia has returned to his capital at Pnompenh after six months of self-imposed exile in another Cambodian city, Siemreap. He is acclaimed as a "national hero" for having by his gesture wrung great concessions from the French and set the Cambodians firmly on the road to national independence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UP) -- New officials at the Department of Labor today sharply criticized the operational record of the legal division and said that "better and more efficient" service was now provided with fewer employes and less money.
The Christian church was described in a sermon yesterday as a "changeless source of life" that provides an inspiration to its members to promote improved social conditions around them.

The seven or eight persons who operate the United Nations correspondence unit, on the tenth floor of the U. N. Secretariat Building, and the editors of newspapers everywhere have something in common: they both get a lot of mail.

Last week's scattered election results were not of a kind to encourage the belief in Administration circles that what is usually referred to as an ebbing political tide had reversed its course or that there was any immediate prospect of its doing so.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 8 -- More mortgage funds are becoming available and this trend is expected to continue, executives of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America reported here today.

Three thousand striking cafeteria workers began returning to their jobs last night after a ten-day stoppage. They went back with a wage rise of $2 a week, retroactive to Oct. 1; a further increase of $1, effective Jan. 1, and a third increase of $2, next Oct. 1.

Within the next decade many teen-agers throughout the country will no longer be able to benefit from what has been one of their most dependable and productive sources of employment -- baby-sitting. This prediction was made in a report released last week by the Institute of Life Insurance.

Citations for bravery end exceptional police duty have been awarded to 274 members of the Police Department. Among the award winners were five men who received honorable mention, the department's highest recognition.
The evil that exists in the world today "is often a direct result of man's own wrongdoing," the Rev. Thomas A. Donnellan declared yesterday at solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- A high Eisenhower Administration source said today that it was a reasonably safe assumption that the Department of Justice would oppose in the Supreme Court segregation by color in the public schools.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., Nov. 8 -- Following is the text of the findings of the American Assembly on Economic Security for Americans.
Four burglars who worked four hours with an acetylene torch, drills and crowbars to crack a safe in Brooklyn early yesterday made off with week-end receipts of $6,000 to $10,000.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (UP) -- Tim Horton led the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 2-to-1 National Hockey League victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight. He registered an assist on the first goal and scored the winning tally in the final period.

SHAT DAMMAN, the Sudan, Nov. 8 -- Primitive tribesmen came to this grass-thatched, mud village from twenty miles around today to ballot in a parliamentary primary election that was as bare of political issues as they were of clothes.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 8 -- The Mizrachi Organization of America told Congressional investigating committees today to avoid "wounding or humiliating man made in the image of God" or face condemnation by religious opinion.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 8 -- Twelve raids against Israel by Jordanian regulars and armed infiltrators since Oct. 17 were listed by an Army spokesman here tonight. On that date the United States, Britain and France requested that the United Nations Security Council consider Israeli-Jordanian border tension.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 8 -- Memorial High's football team continued to roll unbeaten in New Jersey schoolboy ranks when it defeated St. Peter's Prep, 20 -- 6, today before about 15,000 fans at Roosevelt Stadium.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Nov. 8 -- Faced with a difficult and thankless task, the Indians as custodians of Korean war prisoners and as the pivotal member of the Neutral Repatriation Commission are doing a well-balanced job, in the view of most of the impartial observers here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- House of Representatives investigators charged today that two "questionable" tax rulings by John W. Snyder, former Secretary of the the Treasury and other officials had cost the Government more than $10,000,000 in revenue.
Food Machinery and Chemical Corporation for the first nine months of this year reported an increase in billings and earnings, it was revealed yesterday.

Your editorial of Nov. 5 entitled "Our New City Council" can certainly serve as no inspiration or encouragement to a newly elected member. Indeed, I must say it is strongly colored by your feelings of disappointment over the Wagner victory, but surely this is no reason for your blanket castigation and abuse of a body of men duly elected to serve the people.
I was one of the several thousand people caught in the traffic tie-up north of Tuxedo Park on Route 17 from early evening on Friday, Nov. 6, until almost noon on Saturday.

ROME, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Italians from Trieste to the toe of the peninsula laid down their tools today in a ten-minute "memorial" work stoppage for the six persons killed by police during Trieste rioting last week.

Cocoa prices were up the 100-point limit for the day when trading opened on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday, and held the gain throughout the day. Bidding was heavy with shorts attempting to cover but few contracts were offered.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9 -- Urban decentralization in both the residential and industrial fields was a major topic of discussion as several thousand real-estate men assembled today for the forty-sixth annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- Col. Rahat S. Chhatari of Pakistan, lashed out at United States policy, in the United Nations today, attacking Washington's position on Palestine, Morocco, Tunisia and "humanitarian problems in general."

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 9 -- The Senate will tackle tomorrow the ticklish problem of what shall be done with more than 100,000 tons of copper, most of it in the United States. This is the metal which Chile failed to sell to the American Government after more than three months of active negotiations in Washington.
GLEN COVE, L. I., Nov. 9 -- The fires in two new furnaces at the world's largest tungsten refinery were started here today by Secretary of the Army Robert T. Stevens.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Federal Government should not be in the transportation business except as an absolute necessity. Robert B. Murray Jr., Under Secretary of Commerce, said today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 9 -- The United States and Britain have informed the Yugoslav Government that they have taken under consideration a Yugoslav proposal for the convocation of a conference on the Trieste dispute as soon as possible.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren delivered his first opinion in the Supreme Court today. The unanimous decision gave a longshoreman a chance to collect damages for injuries received in a ship fire.

TACHILEK, Burma, Nov. 9 (Reuters) -- United States officials sought today to clear up a dispute snagging evacuation of Chinese Nationalist guerrillas from Burma to Formosa in the third day of the scheduled one-week operation here.
ALBANY, Nov. 9 -- Senator Arthur H. Wicks has made an abrupt about-face in his political struggle with Governor Dewey.
For the seventh straight week, Notre Dame led the Associated Press' poll yesterday by collecting seventy-nine of 125 No. 1 votes and 1,159 points.
YONKERS, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Wilmington Day, with Hugh Bell replacing the regular driver, Stanley Dancer, won tonight's feature at Yonkers Raceway, the $3,500 Harrison Pace, in 2:06 for the mile.

BOSTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Federal Judge Francis J. W. Ford took under advisement today a plan to exchange 5 1/2 shares of Gatineau Power Company stock for each share of International Hydro Electric Company preferred. Counsel for the securities and Exchange Commission told the court the plan is fair and equitable and should be approved.
The race for conference championships reaches the show-down stage in all sections of the country this week as the intercollegiate football season approaches a climax.

FOR several years now some of our young and talented novelists have been lost in the darkling wood of symbolism. There they perform secret rituals and chant cryptic invocations to private gods -- to their mutual satisfaction and to the bemused admiration of a small coterie of initiates. They write their novels with considerable verbal skill and with the most com mendable artistic ambitions.

BOSTON, Nov. 9 -- The Most Rev. Richard J. Cushing, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, said tonight that a happy home, even in a trailer, could contribute to the solving of juvenile delinquency problems.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- Britain, the United States, France and Greece said today they held Israel responsible for the raid on a village in Jordan Oct. 14 and 15, in which fifty-three persons were killed.
United States security checks make it virtually impossible for the World Health Organization to employ American health experts, it was charged yesterday.

THE Vermont and Catskills deer seasons open the coming week-end, Vermont on Saturday and the Catskills on Sunday, and we are eager to try a new and very satisfactory hunting system. It was discovered quite by accident in New Hampshire last Saturday.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 9 -- Amendments to the West German Constitution authorizing the raising of German contingents for a European Amy have been prepared by legal experts, government quarters disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, said today that after World War II "we were dumb enough to turn over the whole German submarine fleet to the Russians."

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- One of the few pleasant results of the war and austerity in Britain is the increased attention paid good cooking and eating. Large numbers of Britons regarded these in the past as suspect and even immoral.

Oliver Wendell Holmes the elder was just past his twenty-first birthday when he read that the Navy had decided to break up the frigate Constitution. Capt. Isaac Hull's old command, famous for her victorious action against the British frigate Guerriere in 1812. He wrote the poem that saved her:

The Society of the Silurians presented its citation for editorial achievement last night to Peter Kihss of THE NEW YORK TIMES staff for a series of articles on the property and physical plant of the City of New York. Mr. Kihss received the award at a dinner meeting at the Statler Hotel.

LA PAZ Bolivia, Nov. 9 (UP) -- The Government announced today it had quelled a revolt by members of the Bolivian Socialist Falange. The rising was said to have been timed to coincide with the visit here of a United States Joint House-Senate Banking and Currency Committee.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Baseball is still a sport, not a business, the United States Supreme Court ruled today.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9 -- California Fashion Creaters National Press Week got off to a gala start yesterday with a cocktail party and dinner at the Beverly Hills Hotel honoring the fifty-one newspaper fashion editors assembled from all parts of the country.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Rear Admiral Lamont Pugh, Surgeon General of the Navy, advocated today a system of scholarships to offset the menace of a shortage of doctors in the event of another war.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today that a security investigation was under way of an International Monetary Fund employe whose removal had been sought unsuccessfully by the last two Secretaries of the Treasury.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Hey, Earl Sande, move over a bit!

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 10 -- The Indian chairman of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission said today it was now entirely up to the Communists whether "explanations" to Korean war prisoners would continue.

While on the staff of Yank in Europe during World War II, James Dugan met Capt. J. Y. Cousteau, the undersea explorer, and two projects for American publication were conceived. One was Captain Cousteau's "The Silent World," written in collaboration with Frederick Dumas, which Harper published last February.
The prisoner-of-war "explanations" at Panmunjom have resulted, so far, in a major loss of face for the Communists.

In the beginning there was some apprehension about the attitude and function of an Indian custodial military force in Korea. The anxiety was not allayed when the first instruction to reluctant prisoners was issued by the neutral repatriation commission. This document placed its emphasis upon the right of the prisoners to be repatriated rather than upon their right to make a free choice.

After an absence of almost twenty-seven years, the Hungarian composer, Ernst Von Dohnanyi, returned last night to the New York concert stage at Carnegie Hall. He returned to play the solo part in the first local performance of his Piano Concerto No. 2 in B minor, a work he completed in 1947 while living as a "displaced person" in Austria.
Abdul-Aziz Ibn Abdur-Rahman al-Faisal Al Saud, King of Saudi Arabia, who died yesterday, was a seventh-century feudal conqueror and a twentieth-century absolute monarch at the same time.

A new booklet, "Futurama of New York," concerning future zoning of apartment houses, public buildings, schools, playgrounds, shops and highways in this city, will be offered free to the public on Nov. 23. This has been arranged by the Women's City Club of New York, 277 Park Avenue, it was announced by Miss Charlotte Abbott on Alma Dettinger's "Other People's Business" program on radio station WQXR yesterday.

The Shah of Iran and Premier Zahedi have boldly defied both the nationalist fanatics and the Communist plotters in their country and have put on public trial the man who was only recently the darling and tool of both these elements -- former Premier Mossadegh.

A "Christmas traffic program" to keep cars moving on all lanes of major crosstown streets in peak periods was submitted yesterday to the city's leading merchant groups. The plan was approved unanimously for a trial period of six weeks to start about Dec. 1.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- The French Foreign Ministry said today it had not been informed of any freeze by the United States of aid funds because of what Washington considered to be French discrimination against United States business men in Morocco.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 9 -- Democratic leaders said today they had asked permission to place on a permanent basis their political organization which presented twenty-eight candidates for Parliament in yesterday's election. None of the candidates was elected.

The Internal Revenue Department will crack down on business men who abuse the expense account deduction, T. Coleman Andrews, U. S. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, warned last night. Revenue service examining agents, he said, have been instructed to check carefully for illegitimate entertainment expenses.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 9 -- If anyone wants a nice, sturdy lighthouse with a bright red base and sugar-white tower surmounted by a black cap, this is the place to get it. For today the regional office of the General Services Administration in Boston relegated the old Stamford Light to the category of surplus property.

HANOI, Vietnam, Nov. 9 -- Bao Dai, Chief of State of Vietnam, has agreed to meet with five ultra-nationalist leaders to discuss a program of political reform that would draw the people away from the Communist banner.
Former President Harry S. Truman charged last night that fear of communism was being "manipulated by a few" to cause a nationwide wave of hysteria.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Attorney General's latest account of Soviet espionage warnings to the Truman Administration by the F. B. I. in 1945-46 lends new and great emphasis to the previously established fact that such warnings were systematically disregarded by that regime until Congressional inquiries and court trials aroused the country to the condition and its dangers.
Plans are nearing completion for the Blue Cotillion Ball to be held Nov. 30 in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre for the benefit of Just One Break, Inc., which finds employment for the handicapped.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Nov. 9 (AP) -- A United States Air Force Korean war veteran said today he had won a delay of a scheduled reduction in force release pending a review of his security status.

MUSKOGEE, Okla., Nov. 9 (UP) -- A 17-year-old baby sitter, who is "crazy about babies," said today that she took a 5-month-old boy from his home in Evansville, Ind., because she had lost her own child when he was only fourteen hours old.

St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases is considering use of its cancer pavilion, formerly utilized for advanced cases, to diagnose and treat early stages of the diseases. This will be possible, according to the hospital's eighty-seventh annual report, issued yesterday, because fewer advanced cancer cases now come into the hospital.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles and Marty Marion refused to tell today whether he had struck out or would come to bat next year as manager of the new American League club. The decision has been promised for tomorrow.

You report that the suggestion has been made that the United States should abandon the dual defense system and concentrate on atomic weapons. This may be desirable from a financial standpoint, but there are other considerations.
DETROIT, Nov. 9 -- Unless the Government can readjust its spending in the face of the scheduled corporate and individual tax cuts it will face a deficit of $8,000,000,000 to $9,000,000,000 next year.
New York City's Tercentennial Marine Corps Company, which was founded in honor of the city's 300th anniversary and sworn into service three months ago, returned yesterday to City Hall.

The first major industrial exposition to be held in New York since the Grand Central Palace was closed to such events -- the National Hotel Exposition -- got off yesterday to a seemingly successful start in the armory at Kingsbridge Road and Jerome Avenue in the Bronx.
RUMSON, N. J., Nov. 9 -- Eighteen Monmouth and Ocean County beachfront municipalities estimated today that the storm last week-end had caused damage totaling $5,865,363.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9 -- Greater emphasis on religion in the total education of youth was urged here today by speakers at the golden anniversary convention of the Religious Education Association of the United States and Canada.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Nov. 9 (AP) -- United States and Communist diplomats met secretly today on an agenda for planning a Korean peace conference. The Communists offered a statement that obviously interested the United States negotiators.

KIBYA, Jordan, Nov. 9 -- King Hussein of Jordan paid his first visit to the devastated village of Kibya today since Israeli forces attacked the frontier settlement Oct. 14 and 15. The 18-year-old King told the villagers that "the day will come when we shall avenge your sixty-seven brothers who were killed here and all those other countrymen of ours who have died at the Israelis' hands."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 9 -- The United States asked today for continuance of the Disarmament Commission in the hope that some day the Soviet Union would join "humanity" in efforts to disarm.
A group of song writers filed an anti-trust suit yesterday to the tune of $150,000,000.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 9 -- On the fifteenth anniversary of the day when the Nazis set fire to the synogogues of Germany, a leader of Jews in the United States was received today by the West German President and Chancellor.

There was nothing shopworn about the program presented last night at Town Hall by Thomas Scherman and the Little Orchestra Society. In fact, one of the evening's four soloists was Barclay Hodges, who is all of 11, about as unshopworn an age as one can expect of a performer at a grown-up musical event in this town.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Charting a course for the Western world, Sir Winston Churchill asked France tonight to lead her old enemy, Germany, back into the world family of free nations.
Mr. Braden said last night he recalled having received a report on alleged Communists in Government late in 1945, but that he could remember no mention of Mr. White.

PARIS, Nov. 9 (AP) -- A French Government spokesman said today that France was abiding by a ruling of the International Court of Justice at The Hague and was not discriminating against American business men in Morocco.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Prices receded slightly in all sections of the stock market here today, although many groups finished above the day's lowest levels.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (UP) -- Employment in manufacturing industries continued to decline in September, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said today. The hiring rate dropped to the lowest point since July, 1952, while layoffs climbed to the highest peak of the year, the report showed.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Nov. 9 -- Thirteen Morris County youths accused of the slaying of 32-year-old Ross Midgette in a lover's lane in Denville will not go to trial. Superior Court Judge Donald Waesche allowed some of them to plead guilty to lesser charges this morning in Morris County Court.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 9 -- Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard University, told Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today that he was unaware of any Communists among the university's 3,000 faculty members.

MANHASSET, L. I., Nov. 9 -- Pete Burke of Cold Spring and Gus Popp of Rockville won the pro-pro championship tournament sponsored by the Long Island Professional Golfers Association at the Links Club today. They won with a best ball score of 34, 33 -- 67, five under par.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The fostering of racial hatred and religious prejudice for the sake of political expediency was denounced today by George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor.
BAHREIN, Nov. 9 -- King Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia, who won a desert kingdom with his sword and huge revenues by shrewd oil leases, died today after a long illness.

Investment banking syndicates will place on the market today $50,000,000 of new debt securities of public utility and natural gas distribution companies. Money raised by the sale will be used largely to pay off bank loans. The offerings are as follows:

Although rails, movies and electric equipments made gains, the stock market as a whole wobbled in a narrow range yesterday and closed a little lower. Seventy-eight issues, including a number of leaders, were selling ex - dividend. Changes in either direction were mostly small, with chemicals, rubbers and tobaccos losing most.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Nov. 9 -- The senior Swiss member of the Neutral Nations Repatriation Commission said today that the Communists were trying to mask their failure to convince a substantial number of prisoners to return home by falsely putting the blame on agents planted in the prison camps.
The stars of "Cyrano de Bergerac," which has its City Center preview performance tonight, will be taking the stage in a double feature.

Mounting interest in controlling alcoholism has put a strain on the financial resources of the National Committee on Alcoholism. This voluntary, non-profit agency is devoted to supplying the latest scientific findings to the nation's schools, colleges, professional groups and the public.
College football's big issue -- TV, to be or not to be and, if to be, to what extent -- received an unexpected airing yesterday as writers of the game held their weekly luncheon at Toots Shor's.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 9 -- The House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church began a five-day interim session here this afternoon with 145 prelates attending.
Veterans' organizations will mark the thirty-fifth anniversary of the Armistice Day that ended World War I on Nov. 11, 1918, with a Fifth Avenue parade and other ceremonies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- President Eisenhower will meet with the prime ministers of Britain and France in Bermuda within the next few weeks to discuss the recent deterioration of relations with the Soviet Union.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 13 to 23 points net higher, with a moderate volume of business.
Retailers were warned yesterday against overcaution in placing spring fabric orders.
The Texas International Sulphur company plans to build a plant near San Felipe, Mexico, to extract crude sulphur from ore mined on near-by concessions.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Shipowners, builders and naval architects here have been shown the possibilities of extinguishing oil fires in ships by means of a new type of nozzle, Fognozl, made by Fire Armour. Ltd. It produces a solid cone of water-fog giving, it is asserted, a complete blanketing effect and thus eliminating the volume of water that often capsizes ships on fire.
Questionnaires will be sent this week by the special state commission investigating racing to all harness tracks in the state where ownership and operation are by different companies.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Increased competition in the oil industry, although calling for greater stress on profit making, is not "something to be sad about," A. W. Peake, president of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, said here today.

DESPITE their defeat in the Ardennes,* the Germans decided to give battle west of the Rhine, instead of withdrawing across it to gain a breathing-space. General Eisenhower planned three operations. In the first he would destroy the enemy west of the river and close up to it, then he would form bridgeheads, and finally drive deep into Germany.

Operations in the nation's steel mills were at a slightly slower rate last week for the third consecutive time and were expected to fall back a shade more this week. Mills operated at 93 per cent of their theoretical capacity and produced 2,960,000 net tons of raw steel, the Amelican Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The approaching first public test of a new anti-polio trial vaccine is going to "dwarf" experiments conducted last year with gamma globulin.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 -- Arthur H. Samish, lobbyist reputed to wield substantial power in California politics, went on the witness stand in Federal Court here today to defend himself against charges of evading income taxes.

A second "Cook's Tour" of New York kitchens will be held next Tuesday afternoon for the benefit of the Yorkville Youth Council and the Parents League of New York. The first tour, conducted last fall to assist two educational agencies, was so successful that the idea has been revived.

There is good reason to believe that in the months ahead business can "negotiate the intricate shift to a more normal prosperity without serious trouble." This is the declaration made in the first issue of the publication, "Business in Brief" that will be issued quarterly by the economic research department of the Chase National Bank.

A child's play is serious business for adults, Miss Florence S. Beaumont, associate superintendent in charge of elementary education of the New York City Board of Education, said yesterday at the annual meeting of the Play Schools Association. The meeting was held at the St. Regis Hotel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 9 -- Marjorie Millar, blonde newcomer who will make her debut with Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis in "Money From Home," has been chosen by Hal Wallis to play the romantic lead opposite Alex Nicol in "About Mrs. Leslie."

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9 -- With the "Russian spy" controversy burgeoning as an eleventh-hour talking point, the four candidates in California's special Congressional election wound up their appeals to the 165,000 voters of the Twenty-fourth District tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Treasury Department took emergency action today to keep the mounting public debt within the $275,000,000,000 legal limit.

A three-judge Federal court-upheld yesterday the constitutionality of the pivotal provision of the bi-state compact adopted by New York and New Jersey to drive crime from the waterfront. The statutory court ruled unanimously that it was within the police power of the two states to require that all longshoremen register with the Waterfront Commission in order to work on the docks after Dec. 1.

The recently established Harbison Fund for Faculty Awards at Wellesley College will be the beneficiary of a tour entitled "Private Homes of Public Figures," to be held this afternoon and tomorrow afternoon under the auspices of the New York Wellesley Club.

Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain plans to reduce the alternate-side parking ban to a maximum of three hours a day by the end of the year. He said yesterday that he had arranged to take up the reduction today with Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Prime Minister Churchill advised extremists on both sides in the disputed zones of Trieste tonight to "keep quiet and behave in a law-abiding manner" in the quarrel over the Free Territory's future.

Mrs. Carol Durand and Reno Kirk of the United States won a delightful and it-never-happened-before jump-off for the International Individual Championship Challenge Trophy at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.
