Town Hall. 8:30; Harpsi-i chord Quartet. Carnegie Recital, I-Iall. g:30; Arved Kurtz. violinist, Lexington Avenue "Y." 8:40: Alexander ]3railowsky. pianist. Brookls.-n Academy of L~iusic. 8:30.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 9 -- Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh continued today to attack the legality of the court-martial trying him on a charge of rebellion against Iran's sovereign and Constitution. Between tears and tirades, the 73-year-old former Premier said he would kill himself rather than accept the court's findings.
Pictures of ships old and new that have traded to this port will go on view at the Museum of the City of New York beginning tomorrow.
ALBANY, Nov. 9 -- Delegates from 282 affiliates of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs arrived here today for the fifty-ninth annual convention of the federation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, at his news conference today:

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 9 -- The volume of home building to be undertaken in this country in the period of readjustment just ahead will be determined by the market demand rather than by the ease of financing of availability of mortgage funds, members of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America were told here today.

Three five-story apartment buildings, also containing six stores, at 2465, 2467 and 2469 Eighth Avenue, near 133d Street, have been purchased by Roosevelt Gabriel, real estate investor, from the Bershor Realty Company and 2463 Eighth Avenue, Inc.

Following are the texts of a statement on the Harry Dexter White case issued to THE NEW YORK TIMES by Gov. James F. Byrnes from his home in South Carolina last night, and of a statement issued by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. in Washington, as transmitted by The Associated Press yesterday:
A plea for consideration of the long service record of a teacher was offered yesterday as a counter to charges of insubordination in refusing to answer questions about possible Communist affiliation.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9 -- L. L. Colbert, president of the Chrysler Corporation, predicted today that the automobile industry would "build and sell" more than 5,000,000 passenger cars next year.

Emir Saud, the new King of Saudi Arabia, was Crown Prince from 1933 until the death yesterday of Ibn Saud, his father. The decree fixing his succession was signed by all members of the Royal High Council when he became Crown Prince. He is 52 years old.

TRIESTE, Nov. 9 -- The net result of last week's riots here is that the United States-British occupation of Trieste city and its environs will continue considerably longer than the two Allied Governments originally had intended.

Plans for a $35,000,000 shopping center at Roosevelt Field in the heart of Long Island, with a branch of Macy's New York as the focal store, were announced yesterday. The center is expected to serve almost 1,000,000 persons.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 9 -- Launching the twelfth ocean-going ship built in an Indian shipyard at Visakhapatnam today, K. C. Reddy, the Production Minister, disclosed details of the expansion of the industry under the first five-year plan.
MANILA, Tuesday, Nov. 10 -- Citizens throughout the Philippines began flocking to the polls this morning as booths opened on schedule in the national elections.

Kenneth F. Sutherland left New York yesterday for a post-election vacation of at least three weeks without resigning as Democratic leader of Brooklyn. Before departing he designated John J. Lynch, secretary of the executive committee to serve as party "administrator" in his absence.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 9 (AP) -- Northwest Airlines announced tonight that striking railway and steamship clerks had agreed to submit their wage dispute to arbitration, ending the five-day-old walkout of some 1,500 employes.

The regime of Prime Minister Salazar in Portugal has, of course, again achieved complete victory in the elections for the National Assembly. No other result was possible, although some crumbs of democratic comfort are being taken from the fact that the opposition candidates were permitted to run in Lisbon, Oporto and Aveiro and they collected about one-sixth of the votes in those cities.

Shortly after dinner on one of these dark evenings, when the wind is rehearsing its winter repertoire of huffs and puffs outside the window, a man may be reminded of something he had quite forgotten: the relief with which, fifteen or twenty years ago, he completed the last course in a branch of mathematics as required of him by an educational institution.

The Supreme Court ruling yesterday upholding, in effect, the controversial "reserve clause" was hailed as a tremendous victory by baseball's executives. For one, Commissioner of Baseball Ford Frick declared that the decision removed the game from the "fog of uncertainty."

CINCINNATI, Nov. 9 -- The role of the purchasing executive is crucial "in the important task of eliminating waste and extravagence in the operations of our Government," President Eisenhower said in a message today to the annual conference of the National Institute of Governmental Purchasing.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Labor party spokesmen charged in the House of Commons today that the new agricultural and derationing policies of the Government would increase food prices and thus make it impossible for poorer Britons to buy enough good food.

Teddy Atkinson got himself a little Florida traveling money by scoring a triple at the Jamaica race track yesterday. With a crowd of 21,644 cheering him on the popular jockey capped his afternoon's exhibition by scoring in the feature event.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 629 pints of blood last Friday and 341 on Saturday. The Saturday collection included 195 pints received at the Lawrence, L. I., High School in a community collection from the Five Towns of the area -- Lawrence. Woodmere, Cedarhurst, Inwood and Hewlett -- and 146 from Masons at the Richmond Hill Temple, 114th Street and Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, Queens.

FOR more than three decades baseball folk had been nervously biting their fingernails, much too afraid to look under the bed to see if an intruder actually was there. They feared for their lives but were too paralyzed by terror to holler for the cops or look for themselves. The Supreme Court finally took a peek yesterday. There was no one there.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Professional football claims the same immunity from Federal antitrust laws as baseball, a National Football League attorney said today.

The Soviet Union has asked to rejoin the International Labor Organization after an absence of thirteen years. Indeed, the Soviet Legation in Berne has written to David Morse, Director-General of the I. L. O., advising that the Soviet Union is already "in." Such unilateral acceptance is made possible because any member of the United Nations has a right to join the I. L. O. by declaring that it accepts the obligations of the organization's constitution.
Former President Truman, arriving in New York for a week of speeches and awards, refused to comment yesterday on the case of the late Harry Dexter White.

The stiff Soviet note of Nov. 3, rejecting in vigorous language a Western invitation for a Four-Power conference on Germany and Austria, leaves people wondering about the reasons behind such a peremptory move.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Department of Agriculture estimated the 1953 cotton crop at 16,093,000 bales today, up 497,000 bales from last month's forecast.

A building inspector who had extorted $80 from a landlord was denounced yesterday by Queens County Judge John F. Scileppi as having done "the worst thing a public official can do" but was let off with a suspended sentence because of his war record.

A survey of the health knowledge of the American people in the last twenty years shows that few individuals have sufficient knowledge about health "to be able to act wisely for their own personal needs."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Following are the texts of today's Supreme Court opinion holding that professional baseball is not subject to Federal antitrust laws, and of a dissenting opinion written by Associate Justice Harold H. Burton:

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Grains and soybean futures registered substantial price gains today but then met enough profit taking by longs to cause recession from the top levels. This price movement pattern has been frequent recently

VIENNA, Nov. 9 -- The Yugoslav Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, Col. Gen. Koca Popovich, arrived in Vienna today on an official visit to which the Italian-Yugoslav conflict over Trieste lends special significance.

The Circle in the Square, the downtown theatrical producing group that has gained considerable prestige for successful revivals of former Broadway attractions, such as "Summer and Smoke" and "The Grass Harp," opens its fourth season tonight at 5 Sheridan Square with a new play called "American Gothic," written by Victor Wolfson. The curtain will rise at 8 P. M.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Nov. 9 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon was acclaimed by cheering crowds today after he reaffirmed the United States position that the Formosa Government was the only one truly representative of the Chinese people.

Operations of Schenley Industries, Inc., and subsidiaries for the year ended Aug. 31 "must be considered far from satisfactory." This was the gist of the report issued yesterday by Lewis S. Rosenstiel, chairman, and Ralph T. Heymsfeld, president.

Many tickets have been purchased for the benefit performance of "The Solid Gold Cadillac," with Josephine Hull in the leading role, on the night of Nov. 17 at the Belasco Theatre, in behalf of the Park Association of New York City
Long Island University has received a gift of $500,000 from William Zeckendorf, real estate operator. who is president of the university's board of trustees.

Many dinner parties were given in advance of last night's performance at the sixty-fifth National Horse Show at the Madison Square Garden. After the closing performance tonight, members of the teams, judges and exhibitors will be the guests of honor at a midnight reception and supper given by officers and directors of the Nation Horse Show Association.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 9 -- The proposed Nassau County budget for 1954, filed here today, calls for a tax increase of 11 1/2 cents for each $100 of assessed valuation.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Government mourned today the death of King Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia and wished his successor, the former Crown Prince, "a long and prosperous reign."

The State of California announced yesterday that it would put up for sale on Jan. 13 an issue of $50,000,000 of veterans' aid bonds. The offering represents the final installment of the $150,000,000 borrowing authorized by California voters a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Treasury reported tonight that the cost of its short-term borrowing was going up again.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Gov. James F. Byrnes of South Carolina supported Herbert Brownell Jr. tonight in his charge that President Truman had read a report that Harry Dexter White was a spy for Russia before Mr. White was commissioned as an official of the International Monetary Fund.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Export-Import Bank will begin next Monday to offer insurance of United States exports against risk of loss by war or confiscation by foreign governments.

Registration yesterday for the annual meeting of the principal food processors of the country at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel was almost four times what it had been last year on the first day of the meetings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Tom C. Clark, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, who was Attorney General when Harry Dexter White was under investigation as a spy, was at the White House today.
The officers of the Irish Army received the hearty applause of a crowd of 12,000 in Madison Square Garden last night for their first international jumping triumph of the National Horse Show.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 10 -A wide-open breach in the seven-month regime of Prime Minister Mohammed Ali is threatened by a series of sharp disagreements among Cabinet members over an increasing number of national and provincial issues.
There will be little change in retail sales volume through the first half of 1954, one of the nation's leading retailers predicted yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Eisenhower pledged a breathing spell today to investigation-harried personnel of the United States Information Service.

Independent television stations and the major networks will put up a solid front shortly in demanding a reduction in the scale of fees they pay for the use of music licensed by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers. Current contracts between the society and 100 stations and three networks expire on Dec. 31.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The Labor party failed tonight in its second attempt in two days to force the resignation of the Conservative government.

MANILA, Wednesday, Nov. 11 -A peculiarly vicious battle of psychological warfare at the political level has marked the Philippine Presidential election contest. It can be held to account for the incidence of violence in a few scattered provinces and for the overwhelmingly peaceful character of the Election Day performance in all the rest.
Although Coach Frank Leahy lives in constant fear of a Notre Dame upset, his colleagues on the United Press board of coaches rated the Irish No. 1 yesterday for the seventh week in a row.

A storekeeper who was unwarrantedly shot by a policeman last April asked the Bronx County Court yesterday to give the patrolman every possible consideration in passing judgment. A. startled jurist, Judge Eugene G. Schulz, looked down from his bench and commented that the mercy plea was "almost Biblical in its concept."

An 86-year-old New York lawyer, who was in the audience when the spanking new Metropolitan Opera House opened on Oct. 22, 1883, has been invited by the management to be its guest at the opening next Monday evening.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 10 -- Preferences shown for certain bidders on contracts for Government supplies was deplored by William J. Burke, purchasing agent of Corpus Christi, Tex., in an address here today before the National Institute of Government Purchasing.
ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The body of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, who led feudal Turkey into Western ways, was buried today, fifteen years after his death.

A 16-year-old messenger boy with red hair, freckles and plenty of courage helped two policemen arrest an armed hold-up man late yesterday afternoon after a two- block chase through heavy shopping traffic on Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- William G. Carr, executive secretary of the National Education Association, reported today that one of three children in city elementary schools was being denied a fair amount of the teacher's time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- The American Booksellers Association today gave President Eisenhower 200 books for the White House library -- including a collection of Adlai E. Stevenson's campaign speeches.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- Dr. Farid Zeineddine of Syria today renewed his appeal to the United Nations Security Council to stop Israeli preparations to divert water from the upper Jordan.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 10 -- A world record for light planes was announced here today by the Air Force's Air Research and Development Command.

An American edition of a Briton's challenge to British industry is published today by Macmillan entitled "We Too Can Prosper: The Promise of Productivity." The author is Graham Hutton, economic consultant and a former member of the United Kingdom section of the Anglo-American Council on Productivity.

Senator William F. Knowland said yesterday that President Eisenhower would have the team-like cooperation of Congress in the vital task of coping with the "international arsonists" of communism. The Republican leader of the Senate spoke at a luncheon of the Union League Club, 38 East Thirty-seventh Street.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 10 -- The Democratic Progressive party approved a resolution last night setting forth five conditions before it would consider President Juan Peron's plans for restoring peace to the country.
TOKYO, Nov. 10 (UP) -- The New York Giants completed their baseball tour of Japan today feeling extremely short-changed.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 10 -- Acute water shortages in hundreds of municipalities in the summer months have accelerated a trend toward air-cooled air conditioners, it was disclosed at the refrigeration and air-conditioning exposition here today.

Two thugs were arrested late yesterday afternoon on the campus of Columbia University after an attempt to strangle and rob a woman student in the elevator of an apartment building several blocks away.

ROME, Nov. 10 -- The statement by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles that the United States had full confidence in Gen. Sir John Winterton, the Allied military commander in Trieste, has put Premier Giuseppe Pella in a difficult political situation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Former President Truman, Gov. James F. Byrnes of South Carolina and Associate Justice Tom C. Clark of the Supreme Court were subpoenaed today to appear this week before the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

The Belair Stud's Hyphasis, a 17-to-20 favorite, and the North Downs Farm's Risque Rouge, a 7-to-1 shot, won the $7,500 races that were co-features on the Empire City program at the Jamaica race track yesterday.
In giving children reading fare, the job of parents is to guide, not prescribe, according to Dr. Leland Jacobs.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10 -- Federal and state legislation to assist the construction under private auspices of 1,500,000 new housing units a year was urged today by Charles B. Shattuck, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

Jack Kramer's troupe of professional tennis players will launch its second international tour on Jan. 3 at Madison Square Garden. A matinee program that afternoon and a session the following night will start the net aces on a trip that will carry them to some eighty cities in this country and in Canada.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 10 -- Both West German Government and Opposition leaders welcomed today the announcement that there would be a three-power conference in Bermuda at which Germany would be discussed.
Two Queens firemen, brothers, have resigned abruptly from the Fire Department after being asked whether they were members of subversive organizations.

We would like to take this opportunity to state the cases of two college students who have completed three years of the Air Force Reserve Officers Training Corps and are now enrolled in their final year. We believe that our opinions in this respect and those shared by many in a similar status throughout the country.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 10 -Stephen A. Mitchell, National Democratic Chairman, charged today that the Republicans had "tried a former President of the United States for treason before a luncheon club." He said the trial was instigated by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr., whom he called "a man without a conscience.

THE American Medical Association has lodged a complaint with the television industry against commercial pitchmen posing as professional "men in white." In a number of instances, the association held, it had not been clear to the viewer that the "doctor" shown on the screen was only a hard-working trouper in greasepaint, and not a bona fide subscriber to the Hippocratic oath.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Whittaker Chambers' "pumpkin papers," which contributed materially to the conviction of Alger Hiss, were released by the House of Representatives Un-American Activities Committee today in support of the charge of Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. that "Harry Dexter White was a spy."

THE well-upholstered members of the football fraternity gathered the other day to second guess each other and the conversation speedily got around to various illegalities and officials' blunder that had cropped up over the week-end. Ed (Moose) Krause, the Notre Dame athletic director, started it.
Why do recipes go wrong?

The interest and goodwill won by the Harpsichord Quartet in its first season was demonstrated last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. When the expert and sensitive ensemble returned there for the first concert of its second season the 300-seat hall was jammed to capacity with an audience that included many persons well-known in the musical world.

LOS ANGELES, Wednesday, Nov. 11 -- In an unexpected show of strength in California's Twenty-fourth District, the Republican party reversed the trend of two previous fall special Congressional elections and won another seat in the House of Representatives last night.

Thanks to Victor Wolfson's "American Gothic," Circle in the Square is still an interesting place to visit. For this genre play about New England in the nineteenth century has literary qualities that are congenial to central staging; and the performance, which was put on in Sheridan Square last evening, is sensitive and imaginative theatre work.
Deaconess Amelia Marie Propper, the gentle tracery of 105 years upon her cheeks, celebrated her birthday again yesterday.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 10--Ceylon, which recently substituted her own flag and anthem for those of the British, further sees no reason why her governor general should be a Briton. This assertion of independence within the British Commonwealth was made bluntly by the Ceylonese Prime Minister in a message to the Governor General published today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- Insurance company executives at the eighth annual meeting of the Life Insurance Agency Management Association today told how advertising paid off for them. The executives spoke at a forum sponsored by the association's public information committee.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 10 -- United States prestige in a considerable part of Latin America will be at stake in forthcoming negotiations between the Costa Rican Government and the United Fruit Company for revision of the company's present contracts here.

ROME, Nov. 10 -- The official Italian position on exports to Yugoslavia is that as long as that country keeps her army mobilized and in a threatening posture at the frontier, Italy cannot be expected to supply her with strategic materials.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- The Soviet Union asked today that the United Nations Disarmament Commission be ordered to turn in new atomic-control and disarmament proposals within four months.

More than 1,000 members of the New York Athletic Club filled the tiled gymnasium on the sixth floor of the clubhouse last night to eat a hearty stag dinner and then lean back and indulge in reminiscences on the past, present greatness of their institution, their city and sports at large.

Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey's prediction of some turn-down in business next year and a possible Federal deficit of $8,000,000,000 or more evidently put Wall Street in a cautious mood yesterday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 10 -- Finland is ready to take up to 50,000 tons of copper and 1,000,000 tons of iron ore from Chile. This statement was made by the British commercial agent of Finnish companies who submitted offers today, based principally on the barter exchange system. Immediate shipment is called for.

A special distribution clinic will be held in conjunction with the 1953 Congress of American industry sponsored by the National Association of Manufacturers in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Dec. 2-4. Keynote of the clinic on the afternoon of Dec. 4, will be "Integrating the Marketing Team."

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 -- Concern over present programs of religious education for youth was expressed today at the golden anniversary convention of the Religious Education Association of the United States and Canada.
PARIS, Nov. 10 (UP) -- A special Olympic committee recommended today that about 1,000 athletes and officials be eliminated from the 1956 games at Melbourne.

A wild scramble has developed among Republican State Senators for the combined office of Majority Leader and Temporary President, which would become vacant if Senator Arthur H. Wicks of Kingston should be ousted.

THE waterfowl season will get under way at noon today in Maryland and North Carolina, and reports from both the Chesapeake and such North Carolina hot spots as Currituck and Pamlico Sounds and Lake Mattamuskeet indicate that both ducks and geese are present in large numbers.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- In the sense that the power triumvirate leading the Western democracies is drawing together to discuss divisive issues, Europe on the whole can be expected to welcome the realization of the long-postponed Bermuda conference.

MARGARET IRWIN'S third historical novel about Elizabeth I is now published and it is just as able a combination of scrupulous scholarship and skillful writing as its distinguished predecessors, "Young Bess" and "Elizabeth, Captive Princess." But "Elizabeth and the Prince of Spain"* contains a considerably more controversial interpretation of history than Miss Irwin has indulged in before.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower made tonight's diplomatic reception here an event of significance in White House costume history.

President Eisenhower, Prime Minister Churchill and Premier Laniel plan to meet in Bermuda early next month to concert their policies for dealing with the continuing Soviet menace. Such a meeting had been scheduled for June, when Stalin's death and Malenkov's softer words aroused wistful hopes for a top-level conference with the new Soviet rulers.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 10 -A six-man observation and liaison team from Burma received its final clearance from the Thai Government today to proceed to the scene of evacuation of irregular Chinese Nationalist troops from northern Burma.
Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, came here yesterday from Washington to announce a Department of Justice "clerkship program" for law school students.

Benno Moiseiwitsch, one of the few pianists of today who have as a native attribute the so-called "grand manner," with the opulence of technique and tone, the sense of architecture, and the wide range of poetical tone-coloring that a great artist needs for his task, played a program of a prevailingly conventional, even old - fashioned character last night in Carnegie Hall.

Two penthouse apartment buildings -- one twelve stories high and the other seven -- at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and East Thirtieth Street have Been purchased by Philip P. Zipes, operator, who has obtained a new first mortgage for ten years.

Many prominent persons in the social, civic and financial worlds as well as high-ranking officers of the United States Armed Forces, attended the final performance of the sixty-fifth National Horse Show last night at the Madison Square Garden. As on the opening night all of the boxes and parterre seats were filled.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- Grain trading on the Board of Trade was largely a matter of evening-up before the holiday tomorrow and the Government crop report this afternoon. Price trends were irregular, with pressure on new crop deliveries of wheat. The March and May contracts were steady.
New York leaders of the American Federation of Labor are trying to find a way to call off the federation's war against the expelled International Longshoremen's Association.

YONKERS, Nov. 10 (AP) -- J. M. H., a 4-year-old gelding, owned by Edmund Harrington of Felton, Del., and driven by Tom Walters, took the $3,000 pacing feature tonight at Yonkers Raceway in 2:06 3-5. He paid $13.40 for $2.

With renewed emphasis to be given in our schools to the parts played in history by American heroes, we note with mild alarm that the Planning Commission of Tulare County, Calif., has threatened to remove to remote parts a prominent memorial statue honoring the figure who, more than any other, personifies our national admiration for getting things done.
DETROIT, Nov. 10 -- The General Motors Corporation bought the giant former bomber plant at Willow Run, near Detroit, from the Kaiser Motors Corporation today. The price was $26,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Neither parliamentary experts of the House of Representatives nor the American Law Section of the Library of Congress could come up today with a parallel for the action of the House Un-American Activities Committee in subpoenaeing a former President.

A 16-year-old student at Lafayette High School was taken to the Coney Island Hospital yesterday with a possible brain concussion received in a post-game brawl between members of the football teams of Lafayette and New Utrecht High Schools.

OTTAWA, Nov. 9 -- Pressure is increasing on the Government to adopt a trade policy that would give this country greater independence of the United States economy. Unsold agricultural surpluses and recent attempts by groups in the United States to discriminate against Canadian exports are two of the reasons.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 10 -- The International Court of Justice held a public hearing here today in the case brought by Liechtenstein against Guatemala despite the latter's absence.

Hoping to break the unusual jinx held over them by the Black Hawks, the New York Rangers skate against Chicago in a National Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden tonight. On their last six visits to New York, encompassing last season and this, the last-place Black Hawks have won all their games.

Enough dates to supply every eighth American with at least a pound of the sweet and sticky fruit for Thanksgiving have arrived here by ship from Iraq. They are being unloaded from the Steel Voyager of the Isthmian Steamship Company at Erie Basin, Brooklyn.

AS THE weeks passed after Yalta it became clear that the Soviet Government was doing nothing to carry out our agreements about broadening the Polish Government to include all Polish parties and both sides. Molotov steadily refused to give an opinion about the Poles we mentioned, and not one of them was allowed to come even to a preliminary round-table discussion.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 10 -Leather popped on University Field until long after dark this evening as Princeton's football team spruced up in scrimmage for its Saturday rendezvous with Yale at Palmer Stadium.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Eisenhower rejected today an increase in the tariffs on briar pipes.

APPELTON, Wis., Nov. 10 -- Trustees of Lawrence College named Dr. Douglas M. Knight Assistant Professor of English at Yale University, as the president of the college today. He succeeds Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, who resigned last summer to become president of Harvard University.
Predictions of prosperity were unanimous from experts in diverse fields at yesterday's meetings of the Grocery Manufacturers of America at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

All financial and commodity markets in the United States will be closed today in observance of Armistice Day. Canadian financial and grain markets will also be closed, for Nov. 11 is Remembrance Day in the Dominion. European markets will be open as usual.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee's "task force" ran into a roadblock in its inquiry into sabotage and espionage in district defense plants today when five leaders of the left-wing United Electrical Workers Union, independent, refused to answer whether or not they were or had been Communist party members.

An eight man squad representing New York University's varsity wrestling team will travel to Cuba next month to compete with Cuba's Pan American wrestling team, James V. Gilloon, N. Y. U.'s Director of Athletics, revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson said today that "the misunderstandings that seem to have existed" in the Far East Command regarding censorship "have been, or shortly will be, cleared up."
A move to drive the honky-tonks from Times Square was made yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The greatest problem facing the petroleum industry is one of cooperation, an industry spokesman said tonight.
DILLING, the Sudan, Nov. 8 -The bitter sectarian struggle that dominates the Sudan's first parliamentary election broke out in the open here today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- Supplies of drill pipe, casing and tubing for the oil industry next year are expected to be about in balance with requirements. This prospect is based on drilling operations remaining about the same as this year, Jay W. Owings, field manager of the pipe division of Republic Steel Corporation, said today.

MANILA, Wednesday, Nov. 11--Ramon Magsaysay, Nationalist-Democratic candidate, had piled up a lead of landslide proportions in his race against President Elpidio Quirino for the presidency of the Philippines this morning on the basis of a partial and unofficial count of votes up to 9 o'clock.
Plans have been furthered at recent meetings at the Ambassador for the benefit performance of "Sabrina Fair" on Friday night at the National Theatre in behalf of the Turtle Bay Music School.
Activity picked up on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closing prices were very firm, 7 to 22 points net higher than on Monday.
The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis issued a statement yesterday to reassure the public that the anti-polio vaccine to be tested this winter on thousands of children was absolutely safe.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation cut prices of all six twenty-one-inch television receivers in its line 28 to 40 per cent yesterday.
Customs collections for this area in October were $30,275,712, an increase of $750,000 over the month before, but a drop of $450,000 from October, 1952.

In the appointment of Dr. Courtney C. Brown as dean of its Graduate School of Business Columbia University has obtained the services of an exceptionally fine educator and administrator. Dr. Brown will bring to his new post a wide background of experience in business, economics and education.

Although he had fourteen more years of life than John Keats and ten more than Christopher Marlowe, still Dylan Thomas dies a young man. And there is no saying now what might have been the extent of his literary accomplishment had he had the time our age allows most men.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Laurel Park was set to run the $65,000 Washington, D. C., International turf classic tomorrow with ten thoroughbred stars from six countries eyeing the prize.

Prices on the New York commodity exchanges moved generally higher yesterday in light volume. Cocoa and soybean oil were active. Cocoa, wool, coffee, burlap, potatoes, rubber, tin, lead and copper were stronger; cottonseed oil, hides and zinc closed lower, and soybean oil and sugar ended mixed.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 10 -More than 80 per cent of American communities fail to provide adequate facilities for emotionally disturbed children who need special care, the fifty-second annual conference of the New Jersey Welfare Council was told here today.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Acting Gov. Charley E. Johns suspended tonight for malfeasance in office of five members of the State Racing Commission.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 10 -- The top ranking prelate of the Protestant Episcopal Church in this country took sharp issue here today with individuals and groups who had endeavored to pin the Communist label on certain areas of Protestantism.
TRIESTE, Nov. 10 -- Trieste returned to normal today.

The public, the shipping industry and honest longshoremen should view with satisfaction the decision of a federal court upholding the constitutionality of the bi-state requirement that all longshoremen must register with the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor in order to work on the docks after Dec. 1.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, indicated today that "new strategic plans" might bring an end to the "balanced force concept" under which the three armed services had shared about equally in defense funds.

Red Cross blood donor centers in this city will be open for their regular hours today, Armistice Day. T. Morgan Williams, chairman of the regional program, urged New Yorkers to take advantage of the holiday to make donations.

Two new attractions, "Sabrina Fair" at the National and "Cyrano de Bergerac" at the City Center, which is celebrating its tenth anniversary, will arrive tonight at 8 o'clock. Because of the conflict in openings, "Sabrina" will be reviewed in tomorrow's paper and "Cyrano" the next day.

A stylishly dressed business woman, who allegedly used charity fashion shows to obtain $54,177 worth of furs that she never returned to their owners, was arrested yesterday on a twelve-count grand larceny indictment.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Wednesday, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon told Chinese Nationalist leaders last night that "a great deal more strength exists on this island under the Republic of China than the majority of the free world is aware.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Fred W. Hooper's Olympic came from far back to score a two-length victory in the $50,000 added Trenton Handicap today at Garden State Park. Olympic, a 15-1 shot, was timed in 1:51 3/5 for the mile and an eighth.

I have read with great interest the editorial in your issue of Oct. 24 with reference to Communist infiltration in British Guiana. It has surprised me to find it in such open contradiction with an article and commentaries, published in The New York Times some time ago, with regard to Bolivia.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- The United States asked the United Nations today to look into the possibility of setting up a code of fair treatment to encourage private investment in underdeveloped lands.

The problem of smog facing Staten Island has become worse over the past few years. The pungent, evil-smelling and poisonous gases, including sulphur dioxide, from New Jersey oil refineries creep toward Staten Island on the prevailing westerlies and settle down with the fog, forming the threatening menace known as smog.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -The Department of Commerce estimated today that retail sales in October had bounced up about 6 per cent from the September level. They were about 1 per cent better than in October a year before, the agency said.
Harry S. Truman was vocal yesterday on matters ranging from pigeons to traffic conditions but continued his silence on his advancement of the late Harry Dexter White, accused of spying for Russia.
ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- The New York State Federation of Women's Clubs today adopted a resolution opposing state owned and operated television stations for educational purposes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UP) -The Commodity Credit Corporation, the Government's price support agency, expects to stay within its statutory borrowing authority this fiscal year. But officials are worried about future years.

TEL AVIV, Nov. 9 -- The land redemption work being carried out in Israel is making the country a pilot area for 1,500,000,000 persons living in a subsistence agrarian economy, Prof. Walter C. Lowdermilk said today.
Arnold Galiffa, who suffered a fracture of the transverse process at Philadelphia last Sunday, was resting comfortably at St. Elizabeth's Hospital yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 9 -- Essential civilian production should be given equal emphasis with defense production, Eugene L. Colcord Jr., general sales manager of the Green River Steel Company, Owensboro, Ky., told the Select Committee on Small Business of the United States House of Representatives here today.

MONTREAL, Nov. 10 (UP) -Jimmy Carter, a "chips-down" champion, will defend his lightweight crown at the Forum tomorrow night against Armand Savoie of Montreal, who defeated Carter in a non-title fight nine months ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture reported today that harvest of lategrowing crops was "favorable-toideal" during October and that the expected volume of crop production increased slightly.
LANDER, Wyo., Nov. 10 (UP) -- Prospectors have found new and richer discoveries in the recently located Fremont County uranium ore deposits in Wyoming.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Dr. Frank P. Graham, a mediator for the United Nations, asserted today that the United States, haven of heretics in its infancy, should not in the days of its power become the stronghold of fear and bigotry.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 10 -Production of motion pictures in the United States has reached an "all-time low," according to a report read tonight at the annual membership meeting of the Screen Actors Guild.
Operations of the Household Finance Corporation and consolidated subsidiaries for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 produced a net income of $12,397,227. This compares with $10,959,796 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- President Eisenhower said today that Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson were enduring symbols of his conviction that one could rise to high estate without surrender of principle.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 10 -- Yugoslavia told Italy today that, despite the present state of tension between them, their differences could and should be resolved by peaceful means.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Wednesday, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Diplomatic staff officers met today for the fourth straight day in their efforts to break a deadlock over arrangements for a Korean peace conference.
The nominating committee of the Metropolitan Golf Association will present its list of candidates to the association at its annual meeting on Dec. 10 at the Princeton Club.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, Nov. 10 -- Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner of New York announced today the selection of Dr. Luther H. Gulick as City Administrator, a new office he wants created to improve the administration of city government.
The final air-raid siren test of 1953 in New York City took place yesterday from 11 A. M. to 11:13 A. M.
ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- A plan for redrawing the state's Senate district lines and strengthening Republican chances for maintaining a safe majority in the Legislature's upper house was made public today.

Color gives a rich, sophisticated look to six new Penny Wise room settings at W. J. Sloane. Most of the furniture is traditional, small in scale and, like the fabrics and accessories of the rooms, comparatively inexpensive.

Unbeaten but tied Lafayette High defeated New Utrecht, 20 -- 12, in a closely contested football game at Lincoln Field yesterday. It was the fifth victory of the season for the Frenchies, who had been tied by New Dorp. Utrecht was beaten for the fifth time in six games.
The International Paper Company and subsidiaries cleared a net profit of $42,976,489 in the first nine months of this year.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 10 -Hartley W. Barclay, industrial advertising manager of The New York Times, said here today that the era of America's greatest advances in industrial electrification was just opening. He predicted that progress "in the next five years will exceed the advances in the twenty-six-year period from 1925 to 1950."

CAIRO, Nov. 10 (Reuters) -Saudi Arabia's new sovereign, King Saud Ibn Abdul Aziz, promised today that his reign would bring an era of international cooperation and internal development to the rich but backward desert kingdom.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 10 (UP) -- Members of the International Typographical Union have voted down a proposal that would give its officers unlimited use once more of funds for union defense purposes.

Thirty-five years ago this morning men were climbing out of the trenches all along the old Western Front, from Switzerland to the sea, as what was called an Armistice went into effect. It was one of the longest armistices in history, lasting a little less than twenty-one years.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The White House announced today that the leaders of the United States, Britain and France would meet in Bermuda Dec. 4-8 to discuss "various matters of common concern."

France is the sixteenth nation to put into effect a UNESCO-sponsored international agreement for duty-free importation of books, works of art and other materials of an educational, scientific or cultural character. The treaty itself, drawn up three years ago, is based on the premise that the free exchange of ideas and knowledge is "vitally important both for intellectual progress and international understanding, and consequently for the maintenance of world peace."
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 10 -- The United States faces a critical shortage of scientists and engineers, Dr. Arthur S. Flemming, director of the Office of Defense Mobilization, warned here today.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Wednesday, Nov. 11 -- Explanations for war prisoners, provided for by the Korean armistice agreement, remained hobbled this morning for the sixth straight day. The reason was the Communists' insistence that they be allowed to see as many prisoners as they liked for as long as they liked.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 10 -- West Germany has asked for a chance to appear before United Nations members with charges that the Soviet Union has failed to return or account for many thousands of missing German war prisoners.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 10 -- Senator Edward Martin, Republican of Pennsylvania, proposed today the Federal Government get out of the field of gasoline taxes for highways. He made this proposal at the opening of the thirty-ninth annual meeting of the American Association of State Highway Officials.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -Mme. Jacqueline Auriol, daughterin-law of the President of France, and two Americans received from President Eisenhower today the Harmon international trophies for outstanding achievements in aviation in 1952.

The New York City Housing Authority borrowed $29,000,000 yesterday to further the temporary financing of six Federally aided housing projects. The Authority sold to four major commercial banks issues of notes dated Dec. 1, 1953 and maturing on June 1, 1954 at public bidding at interest rates ranging from 1.2 per cent to 1.27 per cent.

OROVILLE, Calif., Nov. 10 (UP) -- The Western Pacific Railroad's California Zephyr ran into a rockslide in Feather River Canyon late today, tumbling two of the train's three Diesel power units into the river bed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- John William Tramburg, Wisconsin welfare official, was appointed by President Eisenhower today to be Commisioner of Social Security.

A Coast Guard Court of Inquiry has found after a lengthy investigation that a leading official of a ship masters' union in New York obtained his master's license fraudulently. A commander in the Coast Guard, formerly in charge of issuing officer "tickets" in the Port of New York, has been officially reprimanded by the commandant of the Coast Guard as a result.

The stage has remained free from blacklisting incidents because of the efforts of the League of New York Theatres, Arthur Schwartz, outgoing president, reported yesterday at the league's annual meeting.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 10 -- With a display of bad temper and an attempt to walk out, Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh overawed today a court-martial trying him on charges of rebellion. He won the right to talk discursively and without limit on his record.

DETROIT, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Professional Golfers Association refused today to change its 1954 national tournament from match to medal play and appointed President Eisenhower honorary chairman of the P. G. A.
A laconic Soviet announcement of honors to more than 2,300 scientists gives a clue to the magnitude of the successful Soviet effort to manufacture a thermonuclear weapon.
An Italian film director and automobile racer was arrested early yesterday after he allegedly assaulted two patrolmen in the apartment of Mrs. Brenda Frazier Kelly at 563 Park Avenue.
The country has not yet seen the end of disclosures of subversive influence in past Democratic administrations, Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The stock markets here continued active today and prices improved in nearly all markets.

A clown on a poster came alive Sunday afternoon on the stage of the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N. J. Then, after a few blasts on his red whistle, an elephant, a bear, a hippopotamus, a turtle, a rabbit and other circus personalities appeared from all parts of the theatre to the gaping amazement of 700 children.
CONSUELA STEPHENS is one of the dedicated. She thinks that if humans do not live for one another they do not live at all.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 10 -- Despite economic and fiscal readjustments now in progress, prospects are bright for a continued high level of general business activity in this country, members of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America were told today.

Greek Revival shapes and motifs have been combined with contemporary furniture designs in a new group of pieces at the Blackamoor, 17 East Sixty-fourth Street. The furniture and accessories at this showroom are available through decorators.
When a designer possesses a lively sense of color and design as does Tom Brigance, recent winner of the American Fashion Critics Award, it crops up in every fashion that he creates.
Chemical companies were urged yesterday to pool their resources in a cooperative basic research program. The aim is to avoid "duplicating so much of the work we are doing in our laboratories."

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Sir Winston Churchill's belief that the personal approach can settle the outstanding differences of political strategy among the Western Allies is regarded here as the motivation for the three-power conference in Bermuda next month.

Prime Minister Churchill is determined to have a top-level meeting. In default of any response to his suggestion for informal talks with Premier Malenkov and in face of Moscow's negative reply to the invitation to a Four Power conference, he has proposed a reunion of the heads of the Governments of Britain, the United States and France.
Following is the text of the speech by former President Harry S. Truman at the seventy-third annual dinner of the Alumni Association of City College at the Commodore Hotel last night.
Michael J. Quill plans to present to the Transit Authority within ten days a demand for $50,000,000 in wage and working improvements for 44,000 employes on city-owned transit lines.

MANHASSET, L. I., Nov. 10 -- An indefatigable group of women here is managing Manhasset's first antiques show, a fund-raising event that opened today in quarters of the Congregational Church, the affair's beneficiary.

Sixty workers on the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway, in six weeks of their own time, have figured out how that carrier can best convert its vast steam engine repair shop at Huntington, W. Va., into a new diesel-repair facility. It was a planning job that management engineers had told the road's officials would take as much as three years to draw up.
Former President Harry S. Truman lashed out last night at "fake crusaders who dig up and distort records of the past to distract the attention of the people from political failures of the present."
A somewhat disappointing song recital was presented at Town Hall last evening by the mezzo-soprano Janice Moudry.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 10 (AP) -Art Ehlers, general manager of the Baltimore Orioles, balked again today at saying whether Marty Marion would manage the baseball team next season.

The Supreme Court has this week pushed aside at long last a legal cloud that for years has hovered ominously over that uniquely American institution, organized baseball. By a vote of 7 to 2 the court turned thumbs down on three suits, all of which rested fundamentally on the charge that professional baseball is conducted as a monopoly in violation of the federal antitrust laws.

AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 10 -- Ibn Saud's death yesterday has created the possibility of open conflict among Saudi Arabia's nomadic tribes over the question of succession, according to competent Arab sources here.

So much heat and passion have been engendered over Trieste that there is a danger of losing sight of the fundamentals. The Anglo-American declaration of Oct. 8 was the climax of seven years of efforts to find a solution for the knotty problem. The situation had deteriorated to the point where something had to be done.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Britain's intention to stake her industrial future on atomic energy was emphasized today.

WOOSTER, Ohio, Nov. 10 (UP) -- A 'world peace workshop" scheduled for this week-end was postponed indefinitely today after its sponsors received protests that two of the featured speakers belonged to alleged Left-Wing organizations.
An additional major source of supply of natural gas for New York City and surrounding metropolitan areas was proposed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -Dwight D. Eisenhower, an old soldier and a new President, led the nation this morning in observance of Armistice Day, honoring the war dead.

BOTH the deer population and the general hunting conditions offer excellent prospects for the Catskill deer stalker, and the opening of this area to hunting on Sunday should see a record number of hopefuls prowling the farm fringes and deep woods during the sixteen-day season.
The nation's steel mills produced 9,459,000 tons of that metal in October, raising their output for the first ten months of this year to 94,969,617 tons.

Studies of an epidemic of acute respiratory illness at Fort Dix, N. J., in the winter of 1951-52 have shown that two-thirds or more of the cases attributed to influenza were not caused by any known flu virus.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- President Eisenhower announced today that the Navy's policy of non-segregation was now "completely effective."

NASSAU, the Bahamas, Thursday, Nov. 12 -- George P. Monaghan is likely to be replaced as Police Commissioner when Mayor-elect Robert F. Wagner Jr. takes office in January. A report to this effect was confirmed early today by William Peer, Mr. Wagner's press officer.
Two more important links in the city's vast arterial highway system will be opened to traffic tomorrow, They are:...
Former President Truman was quoted by a visitor yesterday as saying he would answer the history-making subpoena he had received from the House of Representatives Commmittee on Un-American Activities.

The Greater New York Safety Council reported yesterday that more New Yorkers were injured and killed last year in accidents in their homes than in traffic, industrial and all other kinds of accidents combined. Today schools throughout the city will distribute to pupils checklists for the tenth annual home safety inspection.
Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, has resigned from his college fraternity as a protest against a racial clause in the fraternity's constitution.

MANILA, Thursday, Nov. 12 -- President Elpidio Quirino conceded victory in the Philippines Presidential election to Ramon Magsaysay, leader of the Nationalist-Democratic coali tion, at noon today. In his statement Mr. Quirino said:

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association council today voted to submit amendments to its national convention next January that would put further limitations on playing and practice seasons for football and basketball.
LONDON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Moscow radio declared tonight that the United States had established a new "record of stupidity and political cynicism" by subpoenaing former President Truman.
Jacob K. Javits last night termed the Bricker Amendment" a new return to isolationism" and urged its defeat as "essential to make the search for international peace possible."

HOBOKEN, N. J., Nov. 11 -- The 15,652-ton Veendam, 30-year-old Holland-America Line ship known affectionately as the "graceful old lady of the Atlantic," completed her last crossing today. Later this week she will head south for Baltimore and conversion into scrap steel.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 11 -The Indian Government has been urged in an official report to undertake an intensive birth control campaign to avert national disaster implicit in the rapidly growing population.

By a virtually unanimous vote (except, of course, for the Soviet bloc) the General Assembly of the United Nations has taken the first step toward citing the Chinese and North Korean Communists before the bar of world opinion to answer to the indictment presented by the United States charging them with wholesale atrocities in Korea.

ALBANY, Nov. 11 -- Senator Arthur H. Wicks and Dean P. Taylor, Republican State Chairman, directed a cross fire of political accusations at each other today on the eve of a special meeting of their party's State Executive Committee.

Debutantes are aiding in the arrangements for the annual tea dance and fashion show for the benefit of the Judson Health Center to be held on Nov. 18 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. They include the Misses Olivia E. Hutchins, Jean Connelly, Averell Turner, Beatrice Wagstaff, Charlotte Roesler, Lorraine Van Dolen, Cassandra Maresi, Nancy Stevenson, Deborah Cobb, Ashley Reber and June Pynchon.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 11 -- The motion picture industry became involved in a new kind of censorship issue today by barring television newsreel coverage of the studio tour and luncheon reception to be held Friday for King Paul and Queen Frederika of Greece under the sponsorship of the Association of Motion Picture Producers.

MANILA, Nov. 11 -- Ramon Magsaysay (pronounced Mog-sigh-sigh) has brought something new to politics in the Philippines with his apparent election to the Presidency. He has broken down old precepts and working rules with a vigorous and direct sincerity that is a reflection of the man himself and his character.

Although it will take a few days to complete the count and to certify the result, the next President of the Philippines will be Ramon Magsaysay. There was sporadic violence on election day, as might have been expected in a country where there is some reputation for hot blood and where political passions have been running high for many months.

MANILA, Nov. 11 -- Senator Carlos P. Garcia, Mr. Magsaysay's running mate, has been the quiet man of the election campaign. The Vice Presidential candidate of the Nationalists, who also appeared to have been elected, has had no political build-up, partly by personal inclination against self-ostentation and partly as a piece of campaign strategy.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- The Laborite and Conservative parties united today in support of a bill naming the Duke of Edinburgh Regent and guardian of the heir to the throne in the event of Queen Elizabeth's death or incapacity.

NEWTON, Mass., Nov. 11 (AP) -Mrs. Bessie Bloom, a sister of the late Harry Dexter White, branded a spy for Russia by Attorney General Herbert Browneli Jr., has made public letters reportedly written by two former Treasury Secretaries -- Henry Morgenthau Jr. and John W. Snyder -- praising Mr. White's Government service.
BOSTON, Nov. 11 (UP) -- Gordie Howe's goal with less than a half-minute remaining enabled the Detroit Red Wings to tie the Boston Bruins, 2 to 2, tonight before 11,036 Boston Garden fans.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 11 -- Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh, who is before a court-martial after a long, troubled term as Iran's Premier, delivered his valedictory today. It was an emotional plea for continuation of the fight against "foreign colonial influence."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- Despite strong opposition by the Soviet bloc, the United Nations General Assembly decided today to place on its agenda a United States complaint on Communist atrocities in the Korean war.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 11 -- A Government White Paper today called for international planning and direction of the resettlement of 600,000 Arab refugees in Arab states.
Formal evening dresses in short and long styles designed by Gothe were shown yesterday at luncheon by Bonwit Teller in the Empire room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Your editorial of Nov. 8 takes the "Let's not be too rash" line with regard to the shocking case of Harry Dexter White, which indicates either that you are not familiar with the facts (which is difficult to believe) or that you are unable to use the same objectivity in a case involving the highest persons in a former Administration that you employ in lesser cases.

LIVINGSTON, N. J., Nov. 11 -- After a five-week maternity leave, Heather has returned to "work" at the Central Elementary School here. Heather, a 5-year-old black and brindle Scottish terrier has been a model for the school's art classes since puppyhood.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- A return to business careers would be best for many women when the "empty nest" stage arrives -- the period of their lives when their children have grown up and left home or they are widowed, according to Dr. Mirra Komarovsky.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Nov. 11 (UP) -- Gov. James F. Byrnes refused today on the ground of States' rights to go before a House committee in Washington but gave the committee a chance to come here and receive his sworn testimony.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 -King Paul and Queen Frederika of Greece were delighted today by giant redwoods, almost as ancient as the early Greek concept of democracy.

" Maharani: The Story of an Indian Princess," by Brinda, Maharani of Kapurthala, previously announced for publication this year, will be issued in January by Holt. The author, who lived in Europe in the Twenties, writes of her problems of adjusting to an independent life after she left her husband, the heir of Kapurthala, to whom she had been betrothed in childhood.

The Grocery Manufacturers of America, representing the leading food processors of the country, heard last night from Walter Williams, Under Secretary of Commerce, that in ten months the Eisenhower Administration had checked the rise in food prices.
The nation's 528 mutual savings banks are getting ready to pay out $195,359,772 in Christmas Club savings to 2,128,194 depositors, an average of $91.80 for each account.

Following closely on the good news that Mayor-elect Wagner intends to retain Robert Moses as Park Commissioner comes the further good news that Mr. Wagner has chosen Dr. Luther H. Gulick to be "City Administrator." This is a new office, requiring amendment of the City Charter, which Mr. Wagner wishes to create.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 11 -- Current proposals supposedly designed to extend social security to persons not now protected would actually lower benefits to the aged, it was charged here today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 11 -The Association of Land Grant Colleges and Universities adopted today a statement of policy that branded Communists or those under Communist discipline as unfit to remain on any college faculty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UP) -- Former President Hoover, chairman of a new commission on Government reorganization, today announced names of twenty-four members of a task force to study Federal activities in the water and power resources field.

Man's -- and woman's -- curiosity being what it is, the working habits of writers rarely are their private affairs. It does not really matter to a reader, as a reader, how a writer gets his work done; good or bad, it is of small consequence that a book was written atop a mountain in a tent, on a raft moored in the middle of a lake or in odd moments on the subway.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 (AP) -- An Atomic Energy Commissioner suggested today the United States should consider inviting foreign observers to a hydrogen bomb test.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11 -- The Republican victory in California's special Congressional election shaped up today as a credit both to the Eisenhower Administration and to some energetic, if belated, party organization work.

Nick Wall, who in his 46 years has learned patience, applied his knowledge profitably to ride the winner of the Daingerfield Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. Mrs. Harry L. Nathenson's Guy was the horse that took the first money of $19,625, scoring by more than two lengths over Emilio Alvarez' Meloso.

The Kaiser Steel Corporation has completed financing arrangements for an expansion program at Fontana, Calif., it was announced yesterday by Henry J. Kaiser, president. Sale of $8,000,000 of first-mortgage bonds to insurance companies was arranged by the First Boston Corporation.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 11 -- J. H. Jewell of Pittsburgh, vice president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, was elected president of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association here today at its twenty-seventh annual convention at the Haddon Hall Hotel.

With a substitute halfback scoring the deciding touchdown in the last two minutes of play, De Witt Clinton defeated Evander Childs yesterday, 19 -- 13, at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island. The game was the second of a schoolboy football twin bill in which Stuyvesant stopped Monroe by 12 -- 0 in the opener.
TRIESTE, Nov. 11 -- The Americans here have been getting a good lesson in how to behave like a great power.

American shipbuilders, gloomy about the lack of business, can take the busy Boucher-Lewis "yard" in downtown Manhattan as a model of what they would like conditions to be. As a matter of fact, many of them do, since the seven-story plant specializes in launching scale models of modern American ships.

The running of two substitute halfbacks highlighted yesterday's Columbia football practice. Ken Priore and Alex Giampetro, both sophomores, are preparing for the possibility that they may have to replace the injured Bob Mercier at left half in Saturday's game with Navy.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 11 -- Yugoslav Government leaders have set themselves a psychological deadline for this Friday. By that time, they feel, the Western powers should have come up with a proposal for solving the present deadlock over Trieste.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Two big American Federation of Labor union came together this Armistice Day to try for peace in their forty years of war. Their all-day meeting ended on an optimistic note.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- The oil market will continue to expand for a long time, John R. Suman, a vice president of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), told the thirty-third annual meeting of the American Petroleum Institute today.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 11 -- The vibrant notes of "La Marseillaise" were heard on Laurel Race Course's loudspeakers after the running of the $65,000 Washington, D. C., International today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, said today that science was "on the threshold of many more discoveries in the atomic age."

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. declared last night that the charge that President Truman had promoted Harry Dexter White after being informed that Mr. White was a "Russian spy" was intended to draw public attention from the split in the Republican party.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 11 -- General Matthew B. Ridgway, Army Chief of Staff, warned today that the Soviet forces threatening our security knew no scruples or restraint except the fear of effective retaliation and defeat.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 11 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union and the Socialist opposition party joined today in protesting against the Saar Government's action in expelling from the Saar the Christian Democratic Bundestag deputy Karl Walz.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 11 -- The proposed legislative re-apportionment bill, apparently faced with strong Democratic opposition throughout the state, was endorsed here today by Lawrence W. McKeon, Nassau County Democratic leader.
LONDON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Pakistani and British informants said today that the United States was negotiating with Pakistan for permission to establish military bases there in exchange for defense aid.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 11 (UP) -- Billy Martin, the Yankees' world series hero, returned to his home here today, content with the world; pleased with his share from the all-stay tour of Japan, and ready to rest up during the winter months to prepare for the 1954 campaign with New York.

The Manhattanville Neighborhood Center, 514 West 126th Street, will be the beneficiary of a concert by Eleanor Steber, soprano, of the Metropolitan Opera, at Town Hall tonight. Miss Steber has donated her services for the occasion. Dr. Russell Potter is general chairman of the benefit committee and serving as honorary co-chairmen are Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Mrs. Grayson Kirk and Mrs. Frank Hogan.
PARIS, Nov. 11 -- The European case against American trade barriers was put before the United States Commission on Foreign Economic Policy here today by several European witnesses.

A courageous and difficult decision has been taken by President Eisenhower in rejecting the appeal of the American smoking-pipe industry for an increase in the tariff on briar pipes. By this action, which is the second of the kind he has taken this year, he has resolutely set his face against the protectionism that is being urged upon him by some leading members of his own party.
YONKERS, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Chestertown Boy, driven by Jack Walters, was a surprise winner in tonight's Yonkers Raceway feature, the $3,000 Armistice Day Pace.

This is the week set aside by proclamation of Mayor Impellitteri for the city to salute and honor fittingly the magnificent Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra of New York as one of the municipality's great cultural institutions. This orchestra is bringing the world's finest music to New Yorkers for the 112th year.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 11 (UP) -- Mi-Marigold, a 34-to-1 shot, led all the way at Garden State Park today to gain a two-and-one-half length victory in the $49,425 Vineland Purse before a crowd of 25,457.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UP) -Following is the text of a statement by Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, on the Harry Dexter White case:

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 11 (UP) -- Louisiana State University canceled the registration of its first Negro undergraduate student today under a court ruling. But as 17-year-old A. P. Tureaud Jr. left the campus his father said that the United States Supreme Court had been asked to review the case.

CARLYLE, Ill., Nov. 11 (UP) -Maj. Gen. William F. Dean told a ,,homecoming" crowd in an Armistice Day celebration in his honor today that the Korean war "is by no means ended" and "we must stand prepared with our eyes open."

AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 11 -- Dr. Fawzi el Mulki, the Premier, said today Jordan would invoke the Anglo-Jordanian treaty and request Britain to send more troops here if Israeli forces launched another attack like the Oct. 14-15 assault on the village of Kibya.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 11 -- Charles Edison, former Governor of New Jersey, blamed the nation's states today for a major share in causing the growth of Federal Government.
Food of one kind or another is a favorite for Christmas gifts. Hence, there should be interest in Schrafft's new holiday packages.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Nov. 11 (AP) -- American agriculture faces a three-sided fight on economic, political and public relations lines in finding a solution to its problems, the National Grange was told today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- The General Assembly of the United Nations voted down today a resolution calling for more independence for Tunisia, but it came surprisingly close to the required two-thirds majority.

A water main break at Twentieth Street near Fifth Avenue yesterday caused the cracking of a steam pipe, which sent up clouds of vapor, the collapse of a section of the roadway and the closing of the street to traffic.
Business, agricultural and industrial flying increased last year, while instructional and pleasure flying dropped, according to a survey recently completed by the Civil Aeronautics Administration.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Stock market prices continued to strengthen today despite yesterday's weakness in Wall Street.

" Sabrina Fair," which opened at the National last evening is a humorous, romantic comedy that is acted with style and taste, and ought to be in the neighborhood indefinitely. It is the work of Samuel Taylor, who adapted "The Happy Time" into an entertaining prank in 1950.
Production and shipments of rayon and acetate yarn in October were in close balance, and for the first time since May, producers' stocks did not show a substantial gain.

The troubles of the Madison Avenue advertising man pale before those of his Canadian brother, according to a study in Advertising Agency magazine's November issue. The Canadian, with a market less than one-tenth that of an American agency, must produce copy in two languages, often from a different approach.
A luxury hotel that will take the place of the famous Shepheard's in Cairo will be constructed with Egyptian funds and operated on a twenty-year lease by the Hilton Hotels Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Room to get away from other people as well as ability to work with others was termed important to brotherhood today at a luncheon meeting of the National Conference of Christians and Jews. The session closed the annual meeting of the conference.

Communist Poland is drastically revising her economic plans for 1954 and 1955 in order to put more stress on providing housing, food and consumer goods for that country's population, recent Warsaw radio broadcasts reveal.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 11 -- Although not in the best physical shape, the Yale football team approaches its eightieth anniversary meeting with Princeton, convinced that it has its best change in recent years to defeat the Tiger. They play Saturday in Palmer Stadium at Princeton before a prospective sell-out crowd of 48,000, and victory for Nassau would give it the Big Three championship for the seventh successive time.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 11 -- To capture a larger share of the tea trade in the steadily expanding United States market, India must advertise far more extensively. Such is the opinion of an official delegation just back from studying American market conditions.
M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., yesterday reported net income of $6,036,880, or $4.48 a share for the nine months ended Sept. 30, compared with $4,861,757, or $3.58 a share in the like 1952 period.
ALBANY, Nov. 11 -- Reduced insurance rates for drivers with accident-free records were recommended here today by the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 -- Kurt Herbert Adler, former assistant to the late Gaetano Merola, general director of the San Francisco Opera Company, has been appointed artistic director of the organization.

Mrs. Mignon Rankin bought the four-story apartment house on lot 20 by 100 feet at 112 West Thirteenth Street, in Greenwich Village, from the 112 West Thirteenth Street Corporation in a deal negotiated by William Alfred White, broker, for cash over a first mortgage of $28,000. She bought the house for investment and plans to occupy one of the apartments.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. -- Ernest A. Gross, former United States representative to the United Nations, said today that a conference on foreign affairs at Wooster, Ohio, entitled "Democracy in Action," would be held this week-end as scheduled. He will make the principal address Friday night.

In Maine it is called dollar-fish; in Connecticut, pumpkin-seed, and in other places, harvestfish, shiner and skipjack. In this market, ask for butterfish which, when in season from April to December, is low-cost as well as delicious.
