WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Mrs. Belmont Dennis of Covington, Ga., today was elected by acclamation president general of the United Daughters of the Confederacy, in sixtieth annual convention here. She succeeds Mrs. Glenn Long of Newton, N. C., and will serve for two years.
Americans and their allies celebrated yesterday the thirty-fifth anniversary of the Armistice Day that ended the fighting in World War I and brought joy and hope to millions.

ALBANY, Nov. 11 -- The State Education Department today urged local school officials to cooperate with citizens' advisory committees to promote educational economy in the face of increasing enrollments.

It has been several seasons since Rosalyn Tureck played Bach in Town Hall. Last night was a welcome reappearance. All-Bach programs are rare these days, and even rarer is the opportunity to hear that composer played with such technical and musical mastery.

The majority leader of the Senate, William F. Knowland of California, demanded here yesterday that the United States delegation to the forthcoming meeting of the Western Big Three "ask a very direct question" as to the support Britain and France would lend in facing up to the Soviet Union.
A recommendation that retailers lay greater stress on higher-priced women's apparel lines in the coming spring season was made here yesterday.

MONTREAL, Nov. 11 (UP) -- Jimmy Carter retained the world lightweight championship by knocking out Armand Savoie of Montreal with a long straight right to the chin at 59 seconds of the fifth round tonight in the Forum.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- The West proposed today that the United Nations Disarmament Commission consider a call for a closed-door meeting of the major powers on disarmament and atomic control.

Bob Chrystal, a rookie up from the Cleveland Barons, helped the Rangers get rid of a jinx last night. His first goal as a New York player gave the Blues a 3-2 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks before 6,765 fans in Madison Square Garden.

The Metropolitan Opera Association will begin its sixty-ninth season Monday night with a new production of Gounod's "Faust," the same opera that was used for the opening of the famous Broadway house in 1883.

ROME, Nov. 11 -- The quarterly magazine Latinitas has, with Pope Pius' approval, established a yearly international competition and prize for Latin poetry and prose open to Latinists of the whole world.
MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 11 -- Sweeping changes in the nation's housing policies were proposed today by Albert M. Cole, Administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency.
Costume jewelry enjoys its greatest popularity at holiday time. It completes the festive costume and adds sparkle and a touch of luxury to the simplest dress.

Lee Cass, bass-baritone, this year's winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation Award, made his recital debut at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Mr. Cass is a graduate of the Juilliard School, where he studied with Mack Harrell.
Noor Mohammed Taraki has quit his position as press attache of Afghanistan's Embassy in Washington in protest against the "dictatorial" Government he has been serving, he announced yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United State representative in the United Nations, defended himself today against complaints by correspondents about the lack of information now being provided by his delegation concerning United States policy.

BALLSTON, Spa., N. Y., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Herbert C Stone's attorney today denied he had coached the missing Gloversville man to protect James A. Leary in testimony before a special grand jury. The jury was investigating Saratoga County gambling.
Joseph P. Ryan's International Longshoremen's Association bowed last night to the registration requirement of the bi-state compact adopted by New York and New Jersey to wipe crime off the docks.

The current controversy over former President Truman's role in the Harry Dexter White affair, now being conducted almost entirely along party lines, underscores the absolute necessity for removing from party politics the issue of Communist infiltration into government. Like war, this is an issue too vital to be left to the politicians.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Five tumultuous days in partisan politics have passed since Attorney General Brownell, in a speech at Chicago, arraigned former President Truman and his Administration as benefactors of persons known to its highest authorities as Communist spies, the late Harry Dexter White in especial.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Israel accused the Arab states today of refusing, for political motives, to help settle the Arab refugee problem, and of even hampering the welfare operations of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- The 1954 steel market will cause plenty of tough competition among producers, but it also will give them a chance to concentrate on efficient and economic operations instead of forced production, Leslie B. Worthington, president of the United States Steel supply division of United States Steel Corporation, asserted today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 11 -The human poliomyelitis virus has been isolated and photographed in pure form for the first time.

The New York Community Trust marked yesterday thirty years of administration of its first fund. It sent to Public School 9, the continuing beneficiary of the original fund, a "special dividend" in the form of the complete furnishing of a faculty room.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The Department of the Treasury will borrow $1,500,000,000 next week.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 (UP) -- The University of Pennsylvania announced an eight-game 1954 football schedule today which added one Ivy League opponent but dropped four of the teams which made its 1953 listing one of the toughest in the nation.

Although for the last week or so the names of Ina Claire and Claude Rains have been associated with the forthcoming production of T. S. Eliot's verse comedy, "The Confidential Clerk," the official announcement that they would be co-starred in it was made yesterday.

President Truman approved transfer of $10,000,000 in Chinese Nationalist funds to China in 1945 to help fight inflation, but the late Harry Dexter White held the shipment down to $1,000,000, Dr. H. H. Kung said here yesterday. Thus the Chinese banker confirmed an account of the transaction appearing in a new book "Formosa Beachhead," by Mrs. Geraldine Fitch.

Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit of India, President of the United Nations General Assembly, said yesterday that the Western countries had no reason for "fear or suspicion of India" just because India did not wish simply to "follow in their footsteps."

From the stirring football clash between Notre Dame and Pennsylvania last Saturday emerged the outstanding lineman and back of the week, in the opinion of sports writers and broadcasters polled by The Associated Press.

Prices of broad woven glass fiber fabrics for industrial use are 27 per cent lower on an average than in 1946, according to Raymond F. Clark, vice president of Hess, Goldsmith Co., Inc., largest weaver of glass cloth.
The city's leading trucking companies threatened yesterday to stop deliveries on major cross-town streets unless the proposed "no standing" rule for Christmas rush-hours was rescinded.
Forty per cent of the 234 students who were graduated in the 1953 class at Barnard College have jobs, while eleven girls, or 5 per cent, are still seeking employment.
LONDON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Middleweight Ken Phillips won a slugging match from Jimmy Palmer of Philadelphia tonight to clinch the third straight Britannia Shield championship for the British Air Force.

The self-styled "Citizens Committee of Scarsdale" in a letter to The New York Times on Nov. 6 charged the Special Regents Commission of New York State with dereliction of duty because it has disregarded the "evidence" supplied by them and failed to institute an investigation of the Scarsdale public schools.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 11 -- The controversy here over Atlantic pact bases in Denmark has been renewed with vigor.

The New York Knickerbockers will meet the Philadelphia Warriors at Madison Square Garden tonight. This National Basketball Association game will be preceded at 7:30 P. M. by an exhibition clash between the famed Harlem Globetrotters and the Philadelphia Sphas.

New York had not quite awakened yesterday morning to greet the Navy transport Gen. M. B. Stewart, carrying 2,214 veterans of Korea home from the Far East, as the ship edged through the Narrows into the Upper Bay.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- More than thirty passengers were injured and scores were shaken up when a Pennsylvania Railroad commuter train was wrecked on the Schuylkill Bridge, just east of the Thirtieth Street Station at 8:28 this morning.

TUSCOLA, Ill., Nov. 11 -- A modern petro-chemical plant that rose in two years from the flat corn fields of Douglas County to a position of prime importance in American industry was dedicated here today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of today's White House news conference, with President Eisenhower's remarks in indirect discourse as required by conference rules:

ORMSKIRK, England, Nov. 11 -- The hearty commonsense of the northern English voter will give a preliminary verdict on the Conservative party's legislative program and on its newly revived leadership tomorrow in two adjacent Parliamentary constituencies.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- President Eisenhower took some of the personal and political rancor out of the Harry Dexter White case today by defending the patriotism of former President Truman.

THERE is nothing much wrong with the vitality of the English novel that a new book by Joyce Cary will not cure. While other gifted British writers are spending energy thriftlessly telling us that the state of existence is too desperate, too grim, for gaiety or any sort of creative work he proceeds to create gay and grim and desperate characters in magnificent variety.

ORMSKIRK, England, Nov. 11 -- The hearty commonsense of the northern English voter will give a preliminary verdict on the Conservative party's legislative program and on its newly revived leadership tomorrow in two adjacent Parliamentary constituencies.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- President Eisenhower took some of the personal and political rancor out of the Harry Dexter White case today by defending the patriotism of former President Truman.

While other gifted British writers are spending energy thriftlessly telling us that the state of existence is too desperate, too grim, for gaiety or any sort of creative work he proceeds to create gay and grim and desperate characters in magnificent variety.

TORONTO, Nov. 11 -- New British investments in Canada probably will total $150,000,000 this year, W. K. Warrender, Minister of Planning and Development for Ontario, said today on his return from Europe.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 11 (UP) -- Jimmie Dykes, veteran of thirty-six years in baseball, was named today to replace Marty Marion as manager of the Baltimore Orioles.

LIVERPOOL, England, Nov. 11 (UP) -- Howard Hassall of the Huddersfield Club scored two goals today as England became the first of the British Isles group to qualify for next year's world cup soccer tournament by defeating Ireland, 3 -- 1, at Goodison Stadium before 40,000 fans.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Nov. 11 -The purity of Suffern's future water supply apparently was assured today as village officials and the State Thruway Authority resolved a dispute over the highway route that had been headed for a long court fight.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Prospects for the early establishment of a United Nations International Finance Corporation to speed the flow of private capital into under-developed quarters of the world faded noticeably today as representatives of several larger countries made known their objections to haste in the matter.

The $500,000,000 Ford Foundation, in keeping with the gradual widening of its endowment operations, has appointed Dr. Thomas H. Carroll, dean of the University of North Carolina's School of Business Administration, as a sixth associate director.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 11 -- The Protestant Episcopal Church was called upon here today by two of its bishops to support the work of Alcoholics Anonymous.

WHILE all the vexations of the Soviet abandonment of the spirit of Yalta were the subject of the prolonged correspondence set forth in the preceding chapter a far more bitter and important interchange was taking place between the British and American Governments and the Soviets.

The maritime industry has been unable to achieve unanimity on Government subsidy for American-flag shipping. This conclusion was made evident by a special panel in reporting to Robert B. Murray Jr., Under Secretary of Commerce for Transportation.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 11 -- Angel Borlenghi, Argentina's Minister of the Interior, disclosed today the texts of two proposed amnesty bills that the Government hopes will restore political tranquility in the country.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 12 -- The Communists' efforts to win back their former personnel now in neutral custody were called off today for the fifth time in a week. The Red Command was turned down again by the Indian guard forces in the Korean demilitarized zone in its demand to see about 350 Chinese captives, who refuse to meet with agents from their Communist homeland.

The three-story commercial building at 93 Elm Street in Yonkers, N. Y., has been sold by Harry Sherman to a client of Green Selzer, lawyers, for cash over mortgages of $50,200. Hyman Leff was the broker in the sale.

BEDFORD HILLS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- The American Jewish Congress should have canceled its award to former President Harry S. Truman when he "became the center of a dispute involving protection of a Soviet spy," Rabbi Benjamin Schultz said here tonight. Mr. Truman had received a civil rights award from the congress in New York Monday night.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 11 -- The National Milk Producers Federation was told here today that emphasis on three points can turn a dairy products surplus into a shortage.

Today's new film is an Italian import, "His Last Twelve Hours," at the Cinema Verdi. The fantasy stars Jean Gabin, with Mariella Lotti and Elena Altieri in featured roles. The screen play was written by Suso Checchi, D'Amico, Vitaliano Brancati, Diego Fabbri and Henry Jeason from a story by Cesare Zavattini.

Central Public Utility Corporation hopes to be able to distribute Central Indiana Gas Company's common stock, share for share, to Central Public Utility stockholders before the end of the year, the company said yesterday. Also likely is payment of a dividend to the new stockholders of Central Indiana early in January, it was said.
PARIS, Nov. 11 -- Soft gathers on drapery over the bosom topping a princess silhouette, slender or gored into bell shape with added backswept fullness highlight Maggy Rouff's Christmas party frocks.

THE lowly state into which the Busted Beak industry has drifted becomes all too obvious this week. Three world championship fights are on the schedule and few folks, outside of close friends and relatives of the participants, give much of a hoot who wins what.

Bishop Loughlin won its third straight meet by capturing the team title in the thirty-first cross-country championships of the Athletic Association of Private Schools yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. The event drew entries from twelve schools.

In the matter of the late Harry Dexter White I should like to express the opinion that Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. has practiced one of the most flagrant misuses of insufficient evidence for political purposes that I have ever encountered in a lifelong study of American political history.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 11 UP) -- Despite a tradition of the people's right to information, secrecy still prevails on local, state and national government levels, the Sigma Delta Chi Committee for the Advancement of Freedom of Information Reports.

VIENNA, Nov. 11 -- Col. Gen. Koca Popovic, Yugoslav Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, declared at a press conference here today that his country would regard a plebiscite in the Trieste Free Territory as an anti-democratic measure that would settle nothing.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Two government appointments, designed to give Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden extra assistance, were announced from 10 Downing Street tonight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- A proposal for the unrestricted draft of first-year professional baseball players was made today by General Manager Frank Lane of the Chicago White Sox. Through the Memphis club of the Southern Association, Lane will submit his proposal to the minor league meeting in Atlanta Nov. 30.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 11 -- The main east-west street of this sedate residential community has been ripped open from one end to the other since last April, as every one here knows. But the fact that the work is coordinated with national defense has thus far escaped the attention of almost everyone in town.
Three young men working in London's Royal College of Art are making ten stained glass windows for the modern-style Coventry Cathedral that will replace the Gothic structure razed by a German blitz.
Pride in personal appearance stirs earlier in the male than in the female, according to a national survey.

We agree thoroughly with the disapproval expressed yesterday by President Eisenhower regarding the issuance of a Congressional subpoena to ex-President Truman in the case of Harry Dexter White. Ours is a government of separate powers -- legislative, executive, judicial.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old, a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Home furnishings business was off somewhat, mainly because the bulk of promotions was in the apparel departments. Men's clothing departments reported a pick-up with interest being shown in topcoats, overcoats and lined sport coats and jackets.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Republican leaders of the House Un-American Activities Committee apparently backed away tonight from an effort to subpoena this week testimony by former President Truman and Associate Justice Tom C. Clark.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 4, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 12 -- President Juan D. Peron gave the green light today to organizers of a new union to raid the once-powerful General Confederation of Workers for members.

An issue of $850,000 of bonds of the Fredonia N. Y. (Pomfret) Union Free School District No. 8 was sold yesterday to Salomon Bros. Hutzler at a bid of 100.07 for interest of 2 1/3 per cent. The bonds will come due serially on Feb. 1 from 1955 to 1983. The bonds were reoffered at yields of 1.4 to 2.65 per cent.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Manlio Brosio, Italian Ambassador, called on Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden today upon returning from consultations in Rome on the Trieste issue. The Foreign Office said it could neither confirm nor deny reports from Rome that Italy was favorably disposed toward the Yugoslav proposal for discussions to ascertain whether there was common ground for calling a conference on a higher level.

Paramount Pictures lost an appeal yesterday against a decision requiring it to make three dialogue deletions in "Cease Fire!", produced by Hal Wallis and filmed in three dimensions in Korea under actual battle conditions with a cast of combat infantrymen.

More than 200 special merchandising days, weeks and months have been scheduled for next year, according to Printers' Ink. There were only 150 such events this year and five years ago only about seventy. Some of the special events include: anniversary of the tea bag, Jan. 15-23; National Kraut and Frankfurter Week, Feb. 4-13, and National Hospital Day, May 2, followed by National Pickle Week, May 13 to 22.

Robert Morley's next London stage appearance is apt to be in his own adaptation of a French script. Although his West End office was mum about details, the impending venture, nevertheless, was confirmed. From other sources, it was learned that the play is "Les Oeufs de L'Autruche" ("The Ostrich's Eggs").

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Foreman M. Lebold, president of the Morrisl Pape Mills, died last night after a heart attack in his honie. ':He! was 58 years old. Mr. Leb01d vas a coUctor of Lincolniana. In 1949 he presented a number of imporE tant Lincol documents to Ihdiana University and Lincoln MemSrial University, Harrogate, Tenn. ; Survivors include his widow; i Peggy, 'and a brother, Samuel N. i Lebold. lOtker .obituaries on'receding page.
MANILA Friday, Nov. 13 -- Ramon Magsaysay, President-elect of the Philippines, received yesterday new assurance of full control of Congress by his party.

Cocoa prices fell the 100 point limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The 599 lots traded comprised the heaviest day's volume of the year. Trading followed London prices, which broke sharply on Wednesday when the Exchange was closed here and continued downward yesterday.

SYDNEY, Friday, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The champion, Jimmy Carruthers of Australia, and Pappy Gault of Spartanburg, S. C., weighed slightly below the bantamweight limit of 118 pounds for their fifteen-round title fight tonight. Gault weighed 117 3/4 pounds and Carruthers at 117 1/2.
The Democratic legislative leaders decided yesterday to press for an investigation of the circumstances that resulted in the parole of Charles (Lucky) Luciano.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Without opposition, member states voted today to keep up United Nations assistance for 850,000 Arab refugees and to spend $24,800,000 for relief next year, mainly for foodstuffs, additional shelter and medical care.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- The technical assistance program of the United Nations received limited Soviet bloc support today as delegates met to make voluntary national pledges for the 1954 budget.
Perhaps you know a family into which a premature child was recently born. A lifetime ment of this world are hardly suitable to someone who weighs less than five pounds at birth.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 12 -- "The Communists must have congratulated themselves, inasmuch as the subpoena had the tendency to discredit the highest political office in the world," Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam, head of the Washington (D. C.) area of the Methodist Church, said here today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned somewhat irregular at the close yesterday and final prices were 3 points off to 10 points up, near months showing the most weakness.

Navy assistance in vessel construction has brightened the shipbuilding industry's outlook, but there remains much that an improved Government policy can accomplish, W. E. Blewett Jr., president of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, asserted yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Abba S. Eban, Israeli representative in the United Nations, proposed today that Israel and Jordan meet here "without delay" to discuss their differences.

Having spurned all Western efforts to enter upon serious negotiations for the settlement of international problems, the Soviets now appear to concentrate their propaganda fire on the related questions of armament and disarmament, with the unchanging aim of disarming the free world to their own advantage.
